title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, NEIL TURNER JR.
description: ALLEN-Neil Turner Jr. Age 70, of NYC, passed away on October 26, 2000. Mr. Allen was born on June 28, 1930, in Brownsville, TX. He was preceded in death by his friend of over 30 years, Harold Mattsson. He is survived by his nephew Jack M. Allen Jr., of Albuquerque, NM, and his niece Julie Ann Remboldt of Lake Oswego, OR. A celebration of Mr. Allen's life will be held at the home of Helen Berry, 252 West 30th, on Thursday, November 2, 6-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose for a fourth consecutive session against the dollar on evidence the United States economy is cooling. In New York, the euro settled at 84.91 cents, up from 84.14 cents on Monday.

title: CZECH CENTRAL BANKER RESIGNS
description: Josef Tosovsky, the governor of the Czech National Bank, said he would resign at the end of November to join the Bank for International Settlements. Mr. Tosovsky, 50, widely praised for keeping the country's currency stable through the 1993 breakup of Czechoslovakia, has recently been criticized over the collapse of more than a dozen banks because of mismanagement and fraud. His resignation comes as lawmakers are threatening to limit the central bank's independence. Mr. Tosovsky has held the office for 10 years. His announcement came just a week after Hanna Gornkiewicz-Waltz, another longtime central banker, stepped down as head of the National Bank of Poland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELSINGER, MORTIMER NATHANIEL
description: FELSINGER-Mortimer Nathaniel. October 30, 2000. Life will never be the same without our dear, wonderful, one-of-a-kind Morty. He was THE BEST!-a devoted son, a loving, caring husband, a dear father and father-in-law, an adoring grandfather, the best brother and brother-in-law; an asset to his profession, and a joy to all who knew him and dealt with him. Sylvia and Howard Novitt

title: Grieving Relatives Seek Kin Among Taiwan Crash Victims
description: LOS ANGELES -- David Ralph's family got the telephone call they feared most.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Napster to Change Service With Aid From Bertelsmann

title: PRODUCER PRICES HIGHER
description: Prices charged by factories in France, Italy, Spain and the Netherlands soared in September, government reports showed, adding to expectations that the European Central Bank will raise interest rates to ward off inflation. The four nations account for about half of the euro zone's economy. Analysts said high oil prices and the weak euro, which together made imported equipment and materials more expensive, were responsible.

title: Arabs, Israelis and Days of Fury
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Memo; Strategy for Senate Race: Get Out the Vote, Selectively
description: Never mind ethics or issues, Newt Gingrich or the Lincoln Bedroom, or where Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton spent the first years of their lives. With one week left in the campaign for Senate, aides to Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Lazio have reached the same conclusion: the single most important force that will determine the outcome of this contest now is who comes out to vote.

title: RUSSIAN OIL COMPANY IN DEBT DEAL
description: Russia's fifth-largest oil company, Tatneft, said it agreed with foreign creditors to restructure $354 million in debt. Tatneft failed to meet loan payments in 1998 after the Russian currency was devalued, driving up the price of its foreign debt, then about $700 million. After two years of negotiations with foreign banks, including Chase Manhattan, West Merchant Bank, Dresdner Bank and Societe Generale, the company announced it would spread monthly debt payments of up to $22 million over the next two years. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIGGINS, RONALD E.
description: WIGGINS-Ronald E. The partners, associates and staff of Fross Zelnick Lehrman & Zissu record with profound sorrow the sudden loss of our associate and friend, Ronald E. Wiggins, on October 28, 2000. Ron joined our firm in 1998, and immediately became an active and highly-valued member of our litigation department. He was a 1996 graudate of the New York University School of Law, where he was an editor of the Review of Law and Social Change. He received a Master of Arts degree in Sociology in 1993, and a Bachelor's degree, with Honors in Sociology and Communications in 1991, from the University of Missouri. We extend our deepest sympathy to Ron's parents, Robert and Susan Wiggins, of Grain Valley, MO, and to the rest of the Wiggins family.

title: In a Return To Campaign, Mayor Praises Lazio on Israel
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday dipped briefly back into the Senate race he abandoned last spring, presiding over a news conference in which he unveiled an advertisement that starred himself praising Representative Rick A. Lazio as a strong supporter of Israel.

title: Night of the Living Pitchman at Halloween Parade
description: Back in 1973 -- or was it 1974? -- at the very first Halloween parade in Greenwich Village, participants who wandered from Westbeth to Washington Square might have crossed paths with a man in a lobster suit, a zombie cocktail party on a balcony or a scarecrow going up and down a flagpole.

title: Air Time Is at Premium As Election Draws Near
description: Thomas R. Carper, the Delaware governor who is running for the United States Senate, is finding what many other politicians across the country already know: that the closer it gets to Election Day, the more expensive it is to get campaign commercials on the air.

title: AMBEV REVERSES LOSS
description: A year after Brazil's two largest beverage companies merged to become the world's fourth-biggest brewer, the company, Cia. de Bebidas das Americas, or AmBev, posted a profit in the third quarter on increased sales and lower overhead. The company posted net income of $203 million in the third quarter in contrast to a net loss of $91 million in the period a year earlier. Sales increased 6.1 percent while production and distribution costs fell 12.4 percent.

title: Liberties; Rats In The Barn
description: In the ''Oedipus Wrecks'' segment of the 1989 movie ''New York Stories,'' Woody Allen plays a lawyer named Sheldon Mills who has a suffocating mother he desperately wishes would disappear.

title: 3 Pioneers Hailed for Breaking Color Line
description: Earl Lloyd was as dedicated to his teammates as anyone else. He worked just as hard in practice and in games and wanted victory just as much. But there were some things that Lloyd, as an African-American, could not do.

title: Clinton Raises Stakes in the Battle Over a Bigger Medicare Pot
description: President Clinton escalated the fight over Medicare spending today, demanding that Congress shift money to health programs for poor people, disabled children and legal immigrants.

title: A Tangle of Vines and Lawsuits
description: A ROSE by any other name may smell as sweet. And so may a grapevine. But don't tell that to Chuck Wagner Jr.

title: Sports of The Times; In the N.B.A., Stern's Rules Are the Rules
description: FROM the sublime to the sad, from Selig to Stern, the autumnal glow of October was fading to the grim reality of November for the YankeeNets of George Steinbrenner and partners last night at an outdated playing site that no one is particularly anxious to save.

title: Mets Finish At the Top In Ranking Statistics
description: The Yankees edged the Mets in the World Series last week, but the Mets thumped the Yankees in baseball's ranking statistics yesterday. The Mets, however, should not hold their breath waiting for rings for their achievement.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: San Diego Charter School a Model for Technology Leaders
description: The progress of an industry-initiated high-tech charter school in San Diego is sparking interest from technology leaders seeking to boost the number of students graduating with marketable technology skills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'ECCLESIIS, MARGARET (NEE BARRY)
description: D'ECCLESIIS-Margaret (nee Barry). On October 30, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Vincent. Devoted mother of David and William. Loving mother-in-law of Regina and Mary-Jo. Dear sister of Helen Hill and the late Jack Barry. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Diana and Christina. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial on Friday, 9:30AM at St. Thomas More Church, Breezy Point. Entombment Holy Cross Cemetery. Visiting Wednesday 710PM & Thursday 2-5 and 7-10PM.

title: UNILEVER IS SELLING ELIZABETH ARDEN DIVISION
description: Unilever has agreed to sell its Elizabeth Arden division to French Fragrances for $225 million in cash and stock. French Fragrances, based in Miami Lakes, Fla., will acquire the Elizabeth Arden fragrances, color and skin care brands, the White Shoulders brand and the license to Elizabeth Taylor's White Diamonds and Passion fragrances. Roughly 1,500 employees are expected to transfer to French Fragrances. Shares of Unilever closed down 25 cents at $27.88, while shares of French Fragrances closed up $1.75 at $11.50. Unilever, a British conglomerate, has been selling businesses, including its European bakery supplies unit last month, as part of a restructuring. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: The Way It Is: End the Dumbing Down of TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Datek Is Said to Be Near Agreement to Sell Majority Stake to Group
description: Datek Online, one of the nation's largest online brokerage firms, is close to announcing an agreement to sell a majority stake in the company to a group of private equity firms for about $700 million, according to executives close to the talks.

title: Vanbiesbrouck Helps Isles Turn Back Bruins
description: Butch Goring announced late tonight that he had hollered himself hoarse. He said he had yelled at his Islander players to shoot, shoot, shoot the puck, and that only the Boston Bruins seemed to be listening to him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, THOMAS E.
description: WEINSTOCK-Thomas E. Of South Orange, NJ and Long Beach Island, NJ on Tuesday, October 31, 2000. Beloved husband of Sharon. Devoted father of Michael and Rick. Dear stepfather of Shelley, David & Richard. Loving brother of Frank and Mrs. Joan Manning. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Memorial service on Thursday, November 2 at 3:00 PM in Temple B'Nai Jeshurun, Short Hills, New Jersey.

title: Metro Business Briefing; WATERFRONT PROPOSALS SOUGHT
description: After several years of planning, Glen Cove, N.Y., yesterday issued a request for proposals to develop 50 acres of waterfront property into a tourist location. The city said it was seeking $150 million in private investment to build a 250-room hotel and conference center, a marketplace with restaurants and boutiques and a separate area with bookstores, galleries or sports and health centers. Glen Cove was also seeking an operator for a high-speed ferry to Manhattan. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Will a Fund by Another Name Do Better?
description: Last year the word Internet was a golden apple for starved investors, but this year it has become a taboo.

title: Mexico's Border Industries Facing Some Import Taxes
description: Mexico's maquiladoras, the thriving assembly-plant industries, have received the news they have been dreading for years -- they will now have to pay taxes on some of the imports used to assemble finished goods for export.

title: The Second Time Around: Tweaking 'Gatsby'
description: John Harbison, who wrote the music and libretto to ''The Great Gatsby,'' which had its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera last season, is enjoying an opportunity rare for living opera composers that in a healthier musical climate would be commonplace: the chance to change things.

title: Lieberman's the No. 1 Domino in Connecticut Politics
description: Since Al Gore offered him a job as his running mate in August, Joseph I. Lieberman and his decision to run for both vice president and re-election to the United States Senate have generated plenty of talk in Washington.

title: Sotheby's and Christie's Face New Class-Action Suit
description: A class-action lawsuit filed yesterday on behalf of customers of Sotheby's Holdings Inc. and Christie's International contends that several officials of both houses were aware of a conspiracy by their superiors to fix prices, but did nothing to stop it.

title: Politicizing the Bombing of the Cole
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the Clinton campaign plans to begin broadcasting today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, KEVIN
description: QUINN-Kevin. It is with deepest sadness that we share the news of the passing of Kevin Quinn, Lower Eastside Center's Senior Vice President. Kevin died at Calvary Hospital on October 30, from kidney cancer. Kevin will long be remembered for his 27 years of utmost dedication to LESC. Kevin first joined LESC in 1973, as a vocational supervisor. In 1974, he was promoted to Administrator of Residential and Day Treatment at Su Casa. In 1978, he was promoted to Administrator of LESC and subsequently Senior Vice President. In his final years, Kevin oversaw the Su Casa renovations and while his involvement was increasingly peripheral, he considered his limited participation a welcome distraction from his illness. He often expressed a wish to see the renovation through to completion, but, in time, recognized that his dream would not be realized. In loving memory of Kevin and his deeplyfelt commitment to this project, at Su Casa's grand reopening ceremony, LESC plans to name the newly renovated facility ''The Kevin Quinn Building'' In this way, he will remain an integral part of Su Casa's history and future. His love and devotion to his family and the joy and light he brought to all who knew and worked with him will be deeply missed and remembered always. Visitation: Thursday,, November 2 from 7-9PM and Friday, November 3 from 2-4PM at Higgins Funeral Home. Funeral Services Saturday, November 4 at St. Gregory's Church at 9:A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Stony Point Volunteer Ambulance at 6 Lee Avenue, Stony Point, New York 10980.

title: Article 2000110191449184385 -- No Title
description: The debate over health care in New York's race for the United States Senate has often seemed like a confusing swirl of attacks and counterattacks, with Hillary Rodham Clinton and her Republican opponent, Rick A. Lazio, accusing each other of distorting the facts.

title: Korean Construction Concerns in Trouble
description: Dong Ah Construction Industrial, South Korea's No. 1 construction company, said today that it would file for bankruptcy protection. And the top construction company narrowly avoided the same fate.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARTIG, HERBERT
description: HARTIG-Herbert. November 1, 1991. OK, OK, so you didn't disappear. Got it. Miss you like crazy. Naomi

title: Americans Find Their Beachfront Dreams Washed Out in Mexico
description: The federal police continued today to evict more than 200 retirees, most of them Americans, from their homes in a Baja California resort, under orders from Mexico's highest court, which has ruled that the Americans have no right to live there.

title: For the New York State Legislature
description: New York's state legislators have always enjoyed job security that rivals university tenure. But those elected this year will have an added bonus. They will draw up new election districts next year for all New York candidates, including themselves.

title: Metro Business Briefing; WEB SITE FOR RESIDENTIAL LISTINGS
description: CityRealty.com, an online company for residential real estate in New York City, began operating a new Web site last week. The site is designed to connect buyers and renters with brokers. The company, which changed its name from nyrealty.com several months ago, collects listings from various sources, including property owners and brokers. Brokers and buyers can search the information, officials said. The Web site includes listings for more than 1,000 apartment buildings in the city, and applications that allow many transactions traditionally conducted on paper to be done online. These include mortgage- and loan-related forms. Buyers and renters can have the company notify them by e-mail as properties become available.

title: P.& G. Predicts Weakness Will Spread to Next Quarter
description: Procter & Gamble posted first-quarter earnings today that were in line with estimates but said its second-quarter profit might be below forecasts because of a weaker euro.

title: A Survivors Relative: We Pray for all the Other Families
description: LOS ANGELES -- David Ralph's family got the telephone call they feared most.

title: NEUBERGER BERMAN ACQUIRES UNIT FROM DELTA CAPITAL
description: Neuberger Berman, a mutual fund company based in New York, has agreed to acquire the private asset management business of Delta Capital Management, the company said. The Delta unit Neuberger will acquire has $550 million in assets, Neuberger said. Delta's institutional business was excluded from the deal, which is expected to close before the end of the year.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The left wing seemed to hit something, and then it was just a big roller-coaster ride. Flames were everywhere.''

title: Focusing on Gore Hyperbole
description: There is an air of mischief in the Bush campaign advertisement that began running on Halloween night in highly contested states in the East, Midwest and Pacific Northwest. The 30-second spot replies to a recent attack advertisement by the Gore campaign by needling Vice President Al Gore on his reputation for exaggeration.

title: Israel Agrees With Palestinians to Halt Violence
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 1  In a chaotic and contradictory day, Israelis and Palestinians renewed high-level diplomatic contacts despite deadly gun battles and Israeli helicopter attacks on sites in the West Bank.

title: Lead Paint Fears
description: To the Editor:

title: When Top Jobs Go Begging
description: About 18 months ago, Harvey M. Greenberg, the Polaroid Corporation's vice president for human resources, looked around and hated what he saw -- or, more accurately, what he did not see. Many of the best and brightest of Polaroid's top people were no longer there. Some had retired early, many more had defected to Internet start-ups.

title: Overhaul of R-Rated Movies Gets a C Rating: Confusing
description: In the month since they assured a Senate committee that they would do more to ensure that R-rated films were not marketed to children, Hollywood's major studios have taken some small, initial steps. But some uncertainty remains about how to keep all the promises they made, meaning major changes are still months away.

title: Weak Euro Causes Honda to Shift Strategy
description: Because of the continuing weakness of the euro, Honda Motor said yesterday that it would export most of the sport utility vehicles built at its Swindon plant in southern England to the United States and would postpone plans to build a new small car in Europe.

title: Contest in Nebraska Defies A State's Republican Trend
description: Nebraska is Republican territory, getting more Republican all the time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, HAROLD D., JR.
description: GREENWALD-Harold D., Jr., 80, of Fair Haven, NJ., on October 29, 2000. Husband of Patricia Tracy Greenwald; father of Susan E. and Joan M. Greenwald, Kate Hughes and her husband, Robert, and the late Harold D. Greenwald, III; brother of John H. Greenwald, and his wife, Lila; and grandfather of Elizabeth A. Hughes. Memorial service will be 11:00 A.M. Saturday, Nov. 4, at the First Presbyterian Church of Atlantic Highlands, Third and East Highland Avenue, Atlantic Highlands, N.J. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the charity of your choice. Woolley Funeral Home, 10 Morrell Street at Broadway, Long Branch, New Jersey.

title: Election Day Spending Cap At Issue in Tight Senate Race
description: With the race between the two Senate candidates tightening just a week before the election, Representative Bob Franks called on his opponent, Jon S. Corzine, to agree to a voluntary Election Day spending limit of $1.5 million. And his campaign, as it has done repeatedly in recent weeks, accused Mr. Corzine of trying to buy the Senate seat.

title: Nutritionist on Board
description: A large truck painted lavender and green should be a tipoff that something unusual is going on inside. How about selling street food that runs to tofu and organic juices?

title: Napster Users Mourn End of Free Music
description: A Napster fan who posted an anonymous note on an Internet message board yesterday afternoon may have best articulated the reaction of the music-swapping service's users to the news that they may no longer be able to use Napster to copy as much music as they want, free:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times yesterday about a brain disease in some deer and elk misstated the surname of a veterinarian at the Colorado Department of Wildlife who doubted the need to close affected areas to hunters. He is Dr. Mike Miller, not Williams.

title: Redskins Open the Door for Giants
description: It is a good thing for the Redskins and the Giants that the Tennessee Titans do not play in the National Football Conference East. A few weeks ago, the Giants played at Tennessee and were thrashed in the most convincing 28-14 defeat you will ever see. On Monday night, Tennessee took its act on the road, right here, and kicked the Redskins, 27-21.

title: Past Champions, Changing Times
description: Bill Rodgers and Miki Gorman, winners of the 1976 New York City Marathon, the first to be staged through five boroughs, were asked repeatedly yesterday to compare the 26.2-mile race then and now.

description: SCHER-Rose. On October 31. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Devoted mother of Gerald, Marlene, Marcia (Bernstein) and the late Myron. Cherished grandmother of seven and great-grandmother of seven, who all adored her. Service Thursday, 1PM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY (near Avenue V).

title: More Acquisitions Narrow the Field
description: Several agencies and specialty companies are being acquired.

title: City To Chickens: You've Got Mail
description: Cross a chicken with a computer and you get eggs to order. Sort of. Knoll Krest Farms of Dutchess County, which has some of the longest lines at the Union Square Greenmarket on Wednesdays and Saturdays, has moved into cyberspace. It now books orders for its excellent eggs (and chickens) by e-mail, at knollkrestfarms@aol.com. The phone works as well (914-266-3720); either way, the line moves faster. REGINA SCHRAMBLING

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about the acquisition of Basin Exploration by the Stone Energy Corporation misstated the value of the deal. Based on Monday's closing stock prices, the value in stock and assumed debt is $428 million, not $458 million.

title: I.B.M. PLANS ASIA VENTURE
description: Adding to its Asia business, I.B.M. agreed with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, Japan's largest phone company, to market computer support services in Asia in an alliance I.B.M. said could generate up to 1.5 trillion yen ($13.78 billion) in revenue over the next 10 years. I.B.M. also signed a consulting contract with N.T.T. as part of the deal, which it called its largest outsourcing contract yet in Asia. Since many of the operating details remain to be worked out, however, the computer giant declined to say how much revenue it would create for itself. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMERSCHLAG, JAMES JOSEPH
description: HAMERSCHLAG-James Joseph. Peacefully on October 30, 2000. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Bennett). Father to James, father in law of Beth, brother to Kay Beaudine. Reposing Fairchild and Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave, Garden City, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10 AM, St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church, Garden City. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Parkinson Disease Association. Family will receive friends Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARSON, JOAN TAVIS
description: CARSON-Joan Tavis. Of Newport Beach, California, widow of John Reese Carson, passed away on October 27, 2000. A native New Yorker, Joan Carol Tavis was born at home in Bayside, New York on December 25, 1933 to Greek and Italian parents. She was their third child, their second daughter. Joan graduated from high school in Hempstead, Long Island where she served as President of the Junior Debs. Joan moved from New York to the Pasadena area in 1955 where she worked for the President of Avon. In 1962, Joan married Jack Carson and in 1964, they founded Carson Industries. The company was sold in 1983 and in 1985, Joan and her husband relocated to Santa Barbara from San Marino. All through her life, Joan was an avid skier and tennis player and enjoyed a love for roses and her gardens. Joan was an accomplished photographer and painter. She described herself as ''a lady who paints''. Her paintings have been shown in galleries in Santa Barbara. In Santa Barbara, Joan enjoyed volunteer work and gave many hours to the Crisis Hot Line and to her work as an ombudsman-one of her favorite activities. Joan also served on the Women's Board of the Art Museum. Joan moved from Santa Barbara to Newport Beach in September 1998, where she was a member of the Balboa Bay Club and the Tennis Club. Joan leaves behind Kim Carson of Newport Beach, Eric and Jayne Carson of Yucaipa, California, and Carey Carson of Scottsdale, Arizona; six beloved grandchildren, Nicole, Matthew, Clayton and Kyle Carson of Yucaipa and Jennifer and Carlin Karr of Scottsdale as well as loving nieces, nephews and their children. She also leaves her brother, Mr. Stacy Tavis of Upland. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends. A memorial service will be held on Friday, November 3 at 1:00 PM at Pacific View Memorial Park at 3500 Pacific View Drive, Newport Beach, California. The family is asking that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made in the name of Joan Tavis Carson to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, 3191 Airport Loop Drive, Costa Mesa, California 92626, phone number (714) 957-9157.

title: Supply, Demand, Wages and Myth
description: THE wage premium for a college degree has soared. In 1979, a college graduate's first job typically paid 35 percent more than a high school graduate's. Twenty years later, in 1999, the premium had grown to 80 percent.

title: Nets' Scott Gets First Loss Out of the Way
description: The Nets bounded into the regular season tonight, their adrenaline pumped up past haywire, energy covering for inexperience and injury on the opening night that was supposed to introduce a new era.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDER, FRANCIS J.
description: SEIDER-Francis J. On October 30, 2000 of Garden City. Loving husband of the late Wanda. Devoted father and friend of Lois & Bruce Till and Susan & John Morrison Jr. Cherished grandfather of James & Robert Till and John Morrison III. Beloved great grandfather of Christina & Elisabeth Till. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. @ 12 St. Garden City, 2-4 & 79pm Wednesday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City, Thurs. 10 AM

title: Doctors Reign, Teachers Gain, Lawyers Wane in Public Esteem
description: Accountants may want to hire Aretha Franklin as their spokeswoman and use the soul singer's classic hit, Respect, as the theme song of a national publicity campaign.

title: Tyson Sneaks a Peek as Lewis Spars for Fans
description: The hulking Lennox Lewis skulked around a boxing ring assembled inside Grand Central Station's Vanderbilt Hall yesterday. In his Spiderman-inspired trunks, he threw tepid punches at his sparring partner for the cameras.

title: Ring Lardner Jr., Member of Blacklisted Hollywood Ten, Dies
description: Ring Lardner Jr., whose satirical screenplays twice won the Academy Award, but who was best known for being jailed and blacklisted after he refused in 1947 to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee if he had ever been a Communist, died Tuesday night at his apartment on Manhattan's West Side. He was 85 years old.

title: ALLIED DOMECQ'S PROFIT RISES
description: Allied Domecq P.L.C. said full-year pretax profit rose 16 percent, to $:404 million ($586 million), buoyed by benefits from a revamping as well as solid performance in wine and spirits and fast food restaurant units. Profits in the restaurant unit, which includes the Baskin-Robbins chain, rose 14 percent after its international division returned to profitability. Allied Domecq, which is bidding for the Seagram drinks business, recently sold its British retail operations, John Bull Pubs and Panrico, as part of a restructuring. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MODELL, JILL
description: MODELL-Jill. Happy Birthday sweetheart. You are always in our thoughts. We miss you so very much. Love Bon and B

title: At Ducasse, Lots of Luxury (But Just 1 Pen)
description: IT's a pity that restaurants, like Broadway musicals, can't open out of town. Protected from the scrutiny of critics, they could work out the kinks before facing Manhattan's harsh spotlight. A detour to New Haven certainly would have saved Alain Ducasse a world of grief.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE CZECH CENTRAL BANKER RESIGNS

title: Experience as a Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Asia Is Down, but Nobody Is Panicking
description: Raphael Tham and his partners at WizOffice .com, an Internet start-up, did something recently that is becoming increasingly rare, some might even say foolhardy, given the state of Asia's financial markets: they offered shares to the public.

title: Clemens Appeals a Fine; Yankees Get Back to Work
description: As expected, Yankees pitcher Roger Clemens has appealed the $50,000 fine levied by Major League Baseball for the bat-throwing incident in Game 2 of the World Series, beginning a process that will probably take weeks to conclude.

title: Three Faces of Porcini: Frozen, Dried, Fresh
description: The Italians call them porcini, the French know them as cepes. In Latin, these rich, meaty mushrooms are called Boletus edulis. In the past, most Americans could buy only dried ones, but now fresh and frozen are available, too, and each has different uses.

title: CALENDAR
description: Restaurant Roundtable

title: People
description: Andy Bateman was named managing director at Interbrand Interactive, New York, and David Weisman was named creative director. Mr. Bateman had been a planning director at J. Walter Thompson, New York, part of the WPP Group, and Mr. Weisman had been creative director at T3Media, New York, part of Tact. Interbrand Interactive is a new unit of Interbrand, owned by the Omnicom Group.

title: In His Own Words
description: AL GORE

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Steve Allen, Comedian Who Pioneered Late-Night TV Talk Shows, Is Dead at 78
description: Steve Allen, the versatile entertainer who created the ''Tonight'' show for NBC in 1953 and was widely regarded as a founding father of the late-night talk show, died on Monday at the home of his son Bill in Los Angeles. He was 78 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Gore Accuses Bush of Waging 'Class Warfare'
description: Turning his opponent's language against him, Vice President Al Gore delivered a stinging rebuke of Gov. George W. Bush's tax-cut plan today, calling it a redistribution of wealth that amounted to ''class warfare on behalf of billionaires.''

title: As New Eras Dawn, Knicks and Nets Fall
description: The Knicks, refashioning their team with the departure of Patrick Ewing, and the Nets, playing under their new coach, Byron Scott, were both beaten last night as the National Basketball Association season got under way.

title: ONLINE ENFORCEMENT EFFORTS OUTLINED
description: The Federal Trade Commission and four other government agencies, in collaboration with consumer groups, have taken action against 251 online scams over the last year. The commission also released a list of the most effective online scams, including pyramid and get-rich-quick schemes, Internet auction fraud and ''Web cramming''-- the billing of customers for Web sites they do not know they have. The scams were culled from a database of more than 285,000 consumer complaints maintained by the F.T.C.

title: Giant Leap, Tiny Footprint
description: A historic era in space exploration dawned yesterday, with an American astronaut and two Russian cosmonauts -- the first permanent crew to inhabit the new International Space Station -- blasting into orbit atop a Soyuz rocket launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Central Asia.

title: College Initiates Program to Give Back to Its Neighbors
description: Carlos Espinosa remembers when the wrought iron fence that envelops the Trinity College campus was extended across Vernon Street to insulate the liberal arts enclave further from its neighbors. That was in 1994, during a time of drive-by shootings and youth-gang turf wars in a community undergoing a long, steady decline.

title: Democrats Set Sights on Arkansas Republican
description: Representative Jay Dickey, a four-term Republican congressman in an overwhelmingly Democratic district, is not an elegant speaker. But as he spoke from atop a flatbed trailer at this town's annual timber festival this weekend, he was a model of oratorical efficiency.

title: Merger fever spreads to the in-store advertisers that entice shoppers at the very last minute.
description: THE buyout fever that has been remaking Madison Avenue is spreading to the large, splintered field known as in-store advertising or display advertising.

title: These Patties Need No Filler Or Buns
description: CALLING something a chicken burger makes it sound like either fast food or a 1950's throwback. But if you make this dish with up-to-the-minute ingredients, the result is far better than any burger alternative I know.

title: Race for the Senate: Candidates Share in Goals, but Point to Different Paths
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } The 2000 Election function displayDate(month) { if (month == "Jan") smon = "January"; else if (month == "Feb") smon = "February"; else if (month == "Mar") smon = "March"; else if (month == "Apr") smon = "April"; else if (month == "May") smon = "May"; else if (month == "Jun") smon = "June"; else if (month == "Jul") smon = "July"; else if (month == "Aug") smon = "August"; else if (month == "Sep") smon = "September"; else if (month == "Oct") smon = "October"; else if (month == "Nov") smon = "November"; else if (month == "Dec") smon = "December"; return (smon ); }

title: In a Tossup State, This Town Turns Inside Out
description: Never has this place meant so much to so many.

title: Article 2000110192258907337 -- No Title
description: November 1, 2000

title: New Violence After Rocket Strikes on Palestinians
description: Israel's helicopter gunship strikes against Palestinian offices -- pre-emptive ''pinpoint'' operations, the army said -- drew only more defiance and clashes today, threatening to intensify a conflict that by day's end added 5 more dead to a total of at least 154 in just over a month.

title: Sports of The Times; Bobby V Homecoming Is Pricey but Joyous
description: MARY BRANCA VALENTINE from Westchester County had a self-image of a Texas cowgirl, with enough acreage for her own horses. She got to live out that fantasy for a few memorable years.

title: Paywatch: A Wall Street Of Bulls, Bears and Hunks
description: There's a brief, exciting sequence toward the end of tonight's opening episode of ''The Street'' that offers a frustrating glimpse of what this Fox series might have been. The high-stakes Wall Street traders of Balmont Stevens Inc. are taking a new stock public. Millions will be made or lost in seconds, as phones are worked and careers are put on the line.

title: Article 2000110191409058723 -- No Title
description: PlayStation 2 as Trojan Horse

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the jazz trumpeter Willie Cook on Oct. 21 misspelled his wife's given name. It is Christl, not Krystal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, JEAN
description: OLSON-Jean. The Board and staff of the Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Jean Olson. A dedicated member of the Board, Jean's commitment and thoughtful leadership enriched us all. She will be missed. Doris C. Halaby, Chairman Barry J. Alperin, President Wanda Wooten, Exec. Director

title: Counting Hits And Misses
description: With the season off to a truncated start because of the Olympics and the presidential campaign, the television calendar remains in disarray.

title: Company Tried to Block Report That Its H.I.V. Vaccine Failed
description: A California company tried to block the publication of a scientific paper that showed its H.I.V. vaccine was not effective, and it has asked for damages of more than $7 million from the universities and researchers who published the findings.

title: Film Ban Ends in Jakarta
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 31  Long banned by the former dictator, Suharto, for its graphic depiction of his tumultuous and murderous rise to power in the 1960's, the "The Year of Living Dangerously" is set to be screened in Indonesia for the first time.

title: Article 2000110190792957350 -- No Title
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Oct. 31  Dick Cheney continued to try today to deflect Democratic criticism that Gov. George W. Bush of Texas is not ready to be president, saying here not only that Vice President Al Gore lacked experience in the private sector but also that his role in government was a "list of serious missteps."

title: Job Contracts With Noncompete Teeth
description: A year ago, Dr. Pamela Mancini was pulling in six figures as a pediatrician at a Fredericksburg, Va., medical center.

title: EARTHLINK SAYS GROWTH IS SLOWING
description: EarthLink will begin a new national advertising campaign during the fourth quarter. The campaign was announced as the Atlanta-based Internet service provider reported better-than-expected third-quarter results, but indicated that fourth-quarter subscriber growth would be soft. Garry Betty, the chief executive, said the company hired the TBWA/Chiat Day advertising agency to try to increase brand awareness. The campaign, aimed at offsetting expected slowing in subscriber growth, will use billboards and print and television ads, he said. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, EarthLink lost 33 cents a share, excluding merger charges. Revenue rose to $249.3 million from $177.8 million a year earlier. EarthLink's shares slipped 22 cents, to $6.53.

title: Cleveland Journal; Delta Chinese Hang On To Vanishing Way of Life
description: Just off the Delta blues road, Highway 61, a small brick church sits in a grove of oaks, next to a boarded-up two-story building. Above the sanctuary's water-stained wooden doors hangs a seemingly improbable sign, in English and Chinese: ''Chinese Baptist Church.''

title: GROWTH PICKS UP IN CANADA
description: Canada's gross domestic product rose 0.4 percent in August from July, or 4.4 percent from August 1999, a more robust growth rate than analysts had forecast. Electrical and electronic goods, including telecommunications equipment, led an overall increase in manufacturing of 0.8 percent, offsetting lower production in forestry and mining. Retail sales rose 0.1 percent.

title: Destroyer May Not Have Fulfilled Security Rules
description: As the destroyer Cole pulled into Aden, its crew was under orders to follow a secret security plan aimed at avoiding exactly the kind of attack that killed 17 sailors on Oct 12.

title: Definition Of Safety Eluding The Jets
description: Chris Hayes could be the next starting free safety, and he knows it.

title: Space to Mission Control: Love You, Honey
description: KOROLYOV, Russia -- The first residents of the International Space Station drew closer to their new home with each lap of Earth on Wednesday and got a surprise call from Russian Mission Control.

title: Zito Seeks Late-Season Lightning in Breeders' Cup
description: Nick Zito stood outside Barn 39 at Churchill Downs this morning and confessed that he was a man with a mission: to win redemption.

title: FMC TO SPLIT IN TWO AND SPIN OFF PART OF UNIT
description: The FMC Corporation, a maker of machinery and chemicals, said yesterday that it would split into two companies and would spin off 20 percent of its machinery business through a public offering in the second quarter of 2001. The company, based in Chicago, said it expected to make a tax-free distribution of the remaining shares of the machinery business by the end of 2001, subject to market conditions, approval from the board and a favorable tax ruling. FMC, which employs about 15,000 people worldwide, said it might reassign some employees but expected no layoffs.

title: Senate Heading Home With Budget Unresolved
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The Senate agreed today to adjourn until after the election, leaving to a rare lame-duck session a number of decisions on highly contentious issues including spending, immigration, and worker safety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SYDNEY
description: KAPLAN-Sydney, Died October 30, 2000 at the age of 85. Beloved husband and fishing buddy of Sylvia. Loving and loved father of Judy (Martin) Milner and Howard (Sharon) Kaplan. Beloved grandfather of Eric and Jeffrey Milner and Jeremy Kaplan. Dear brother of Beatrice Kraus. He will be missed.

title: In a Shift, Internet Service Will Pay for Music Rights
description: Napster, a start-up that has terrified the recording industry by letting its users copy music from each other free over the Internet, agreed yesterday to a plan to change course and charge a fee for its service, distributing part of the fee as royalties to record companies.

title: Where Are the Elysian Fields of Yore?
description: To the Editor:

title: News Organizations Ask White House to Veto Secrecy Measure
description: Chief executives of four of the nation's largest news organizations wrote to President Clinton today urging him to veto legislation that would greatly increase government secrecy by making it a felony for a government official to disclose classified information.

title: Schools' Federal Aid Data Under Investigation
description: A state commission is investigating allegations that some New York City schools falsified data about their eligibility for federal Title I money, which provides aid to schools in poor communities.

title: Petite Sirah's Forward March
description: WHILE some wines are habitually likened to string quartets or symphonies, petite sirah is like a brass band in the mouth, powerful and thumping, full of loud tannins and bold fruit. You wouldn't retire to the library for a spot of petite sirah; it needs to be allowed to shout.

title: Cheney Cites List of Serious Missteps by Gore

description: Dick Cheney continued to try today to deflect Democratic criticism that Gov. George W. Bush of Texas is not ready to be president, saying here not only that Vice President Al Gore lacked experience in the private sector but also that his role in government was a ''list of serious missteps.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JACK
description: MILLER-Jack. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our member Beth Friedmann and family on the loss of her beloved father. May the family be comforted among those who mourn for Tzion and Yerushalayim. Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi Joel Felderman, President

title: Flower District Considers a Repotting; Wholesale Market Feels Pressure As Neighborhood Is Transformed
description: For much of the past century, wholesale flowers have been sold amid the fur fabricators of the West 20's. But in recent years, many wholesalers have closed up shop, and those that remain in the flower market, now concentrated on two blocks of 28th Street, say they may soon be pulling up roots.

title: Hong Kong Mobile Unit Raises $7.2 Billion
description: China Mobile (Hong Kong) Ltd. has raised $7.2 billion selling debt and equity to help pay for new wireless networks, in the biggest sale of shares to overseas investors by a state-owned Chinese company.

title: THAI TARIFFS CUT
description: As part of a stimulus package intended to energize its flagging economy, Thailand cut import tariffs on more than 70 materials used to manufacture electronics and chemicals, in some cases by 90 percent, and said it would provide about $1.18 billion in subsidized loans to manufacturers. Central bank officials said last week that sluggish consumer spending and private investment, rising oil prices and the deteriorating value of the baht endangered the country's recovery from a two-year recession that began in 1997.

title: Competition Is Too Much For Treasuries
description: Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as rising stocks and Fannie Mae's sale of $7 billion in new debt overshadowed earlier reports pointing to a slowing economy.

title: Reticence by Yemen Raises U.S. Concern
description: American officials said that since the attack on the destroyer Cole, Yemen appears to have obscured crucial evidence in the case and that there has been a pattern of resistance and evasion that has caused concern about its willingness to get to the bottom of the attack.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about City University's efforts to hire outstanding scholars misspelled the surnames of two award-winning faculty members. They are Profs. Jill Bargonetti (not Bargontti) and Judith Summerfield (not Sommerfield). The caption also referred imprecisely to them and to Edwin G. Burrows, John Corigliano, Cecilia Macheski and Daniel Akins. CUNY officials cited them as examples of the caliber of professor it sought to recruit; none of the six were recently hired.

title: Bush Returns Fire Over Plan For Social Security Overhaul
description: Gov. George W. Bush swept up the West Coast today, telling audiences to vote for a westerner who could end the ''finger pointing and name calling'' in the nation's capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIN, MURIEL
description: MARGOLIN-Muriel. On October 30, 2000 in Jupiter, FL. Beloved wife of Benjamin. Devoted mother of Eric (Kathleen) and Barbara (Kenneth) Wedeen. Loving grandmother of Emily and sister of Sybelle Levy and the late Irwin Leibowitz. Services at Parkside Funeral Home, 98-60 Queens Blvd. on Thursday at 9:45 AM. Should friends or family desire contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 919 N. Michigan Ave., Suite 1100, Chicago, IL 60611.

title: Fernando Gutierrez, 73, Head Of the Secret Police in Mexico
description: Fernando Gutierrez Barrios, Mexico's longtime spymaster, the feared chief of its secret police and a formidable figure in the once-dominant Institutional Revolutionary Party, died of a heart attack on Monday in a hospital here. He was 73.

title: Arabs, Israelis and Days of Fury
description: To the Editor:

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Little Rock, Ark.; Birmingham, Ala., and Atlanta

title: B.A.T.'S PROFIT IMPROVES
description: Despite costly litigation in the United States, British American Tobacco P.L.C. said its third-quarter profit rose 23 percent, to $344.5 million, helped by the purchase of Rothmans International and increased stakes in Argentine and Canadian tobacco companies. B.A.T., the maker of Lucky Strike, said its share of the United States market fell from 15 to 12 percent after it raised prices by an average of 6 cents a pack to cover the cost of health-related lawsuits. Its shares slipped 2 percent.

title: LOEWEN FUNERAL CHAIN TO FILE A REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: The Loewen Group, a chain of funeral homes and cemeteries based in Canada that has operated under court protection from creditors for 17 months, said it expected to file a reorganization plan with a federal bankruptcy court in the United States by Nov. 15. Common shares will probably become worthless, the company's chairman, John Lacey, said. Loewen's head office is in British Columbia, but 90 percent of its business is in the United States. It owes $2.2 billion to about 9,000 creditors. For the third quarter, the company reported a loss of $3 million, or 7 cents a share, in contrast to a year-earlier profit of $1.9 million. Revenue fell 12 percent, to $206.2 million. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: A Battle for the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Portraits of Lenin and a Little Girl
description: I've been on this street, Arbat Street, for nearly 14 years, drawing people's portraits. I started during perestroika, when the Soviet government was trying to change things. I can only do this work during summer, because in winter, my fingers freeze. The rest of the year, I teach art at a college in the Volga region for about $30 a month. Often, I have to wait about three or four months to get paid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSARIO, SIEVERT, HEATHER, PH.D.
description: ROSARIO - SIEVERT - Heather, Ph.d. Died peacefully at home on October 30, 2000 after a courageous battle against lung cancer. Professor of English at Hostos Community College of CUNY, translator and poet. Loving wife of William Sievert. Devoted mother Liana Rosario and her husband David Aronson & Claudia Rosario Hammond. Cherished grandmother of Hailey London Aronson. Sister of Audrey Novoa. Services today, 3 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions in her name to Save the Children Foundation.

title: PERFORMANCE FOOD MAKES DEAL TO PURCHASE REDI-CUT
description: The Performance Food Group agreed yesterday to buy Redi-Cut Foods, based in Chicago, for $133 million in cash, stock and assumed debt, to expand its fresh produce business in the Midwest. Performance Food, based in Richmond, Va., sells fresh and frozen food to restaurants, hotels, schools, health-care centers and fast-food restaurant chains. Redi-Cut expects to have sales of about $130 million this year. Performance Food's chief financial officer, Roger Boeve, said the acquisition would add about 5 cents a share to earnings next year.

title: Lyn Austin, Theater Producer, Dies at 78
description: Lyn Austin, an innovative theatrical producer who, as the founder and head of the Music-Theater Group, discovered, nurtured and produced the work of Martha Clarke, Julie Taymor, Richard Foreman and other major experimental theater artists, died on Sunday in New York after being struck by a taxi. She was 78.

title: Hate-Crimes Sentences
description: To the Editor:

title: ALCATEL IN DEAL WITH 360NETWORKS
description: The big French communications equipment maker Alcatel announced a deal with 360networks, an upstart Canadian communications carrier, under which Alcatel will invest $1 billion in 360 while 360 will spend more than $1 billion on Alcatel products and services. Alcatel agreed to buy up to $1 billion in 360 convertible stock. The Canadian company awarded Alcatel a contract worth about $1.1 billion to build a new undersea fiber optic communications system linking the United States, Canada and Japan. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: Candidates Share in Goals, But Point to Different Paths
description: The debate over health care in New York's race for the United States Senate has often seemed like a confusing swirl of attacks and counterattacks, with Hillary Rodham Clinton and her Republican opponent, Rick A. Lazio, accusing each other of distorting the facts.

title: A Bush Rally in Florida Becomes a Family Affair

title: Boos Make It Clear Who's Missing
description: The harshest critics of the Knicks' decision to end the Patrick Ewing era could not have foreseen what happened last night at Madison Square Garden. In what looked like a presentation on Why Not to Trade a Future Hall of Fame Center, the Knicks experienced their worst season-opening loss in franchise history, a 101-72 thrashing by the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Now Arriving: Cipriani

title: A Chance to Tackle Satay in Privacy
description: SATAY, the classic Indonesian dish of meat threaded on slender skewers and grilled, always presents a challenging question of restaurant etiquette. Unlike shish kebab, in which the meat is divided into cubes that are easy to remove from the skewers with a fork, satays are usually placed on the skewer in one long piece. When it's time to eat, pushing the meat off the skewer with a fork is virtually impossible. Dragging the meat off with your teeth is equally difficult, while taking small bites directly off the skewer (apparently the preferred method of Indonesians) is awkward if you're not used to it.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BRITISH AMERICAN TOBACCO, Louisville, Ky., said its Brown & Williamson unit, the No. 3 cigarette maker in the United States, would eliminate as many as 300 jobs, or 5 percent of its United States staff, at a plant in Macon, Ga., to cut costs as sales decline.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about plans to divide the proceeds of a $512 million settlement among auction customers in the class action antitrust suit against Sotheby's and Christie's misstated the starting date for calculating overcharges and the timetable for distribution of the money. The starting date is Sept. 1, 1995, not 1997. Within 30 days of preliminary and final approval by the federal court, the money will be deposited in stages in an escrow account, not distributed directly.

title: All This Useful Beauty
description: WHEN my in-law equivalents came to visit this fall, one of their goals was to find a kabocha squash. When I had dinner with a friend soon afterward, she spent much of the meal wondering about Hubbard squash. And when I tried to buy a golden nugget squash at a Food Emporium last week, the cashier who couldn't help fondling it insisted it was a gourd.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Gathering of Clarks For a New Novel

title: An Ineffectual Congress
description: The 106th Congress, with little to show for its two years of existence, has all but vanished from public discourse. In past presidential campaigns, Congress has at least been an issue, if only as an object of revulsion, as Bill Clinton made the Gingrich Congress in 1996. But nobody, least of all the presidential candidates, is talking about this particular Congress, and the reason is plain. On almost every matter of importance -- gun control, patients' bill of rights, energy deregulation, Social Security -- Congress has done little or nothing, failing to produce a record worthy of either celebration or condemnation.

title: Israel Agrees With Palestinians to Halt Violence
description: JERUSALEM, Nov 2 -- Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak said on Thursday that Israel and the Palestinians had agreed on measures to end a wave of violence that has killed at least 163 people in the last five weeks.

title: Playwrights And Heroes, Growing Up In Full View
description: One reason the theater world always seems to be lamenting a dearth of promising young playwrights is that it rarely makes room for the kind of play that young people tend to write. Unlike the publishing industry, which reserves a very long shelf for the coming-of-age autobiographical roman a clef, the theater can be particularly indifferent to the literature of immaturity, unless it comes in the form of a budget-saving monologue. Otherwise it's most often relegated to the classroom.

title: INSIDE
description: Steve Allen Is Dead

title: Rock-Tossing At School Another Issue
description: THE uniformed security guard at Columbia University's main gate looked bewildered. Who could blame him?

title: Clinton Seeks to Help Candidates Where He Can Do No Harm
description: With just six days remaining before Election Day, President Clinton began a six-day, coast-to-coast campaign tour today to carefully chosen sites.

title: Rio Dulce Journal; A Guatemalan Harbor, Away From Life's Storms
description: The hurricanes that wreak havoc in the Caribbean and most of Central America each year are pretty much spent by the time they reach this winding river nestled between lush mountains and craggy cliffs. So, too, are the hundreds of yachtsmen and sailors who journey to this Guatemalan outpost trying to keep ahead of the storm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COULOUCOUNDIS, EMMANUEL J.
description: COULOUCOUNDIS-Emmanuel J. On October 30th, 2000 at age 74. Beloved husband of the late Cleopatra. Loving father of John and Sonya. Cherished grandfather of Emmanuel and Michael. Dear brother of Elias and Mary, Maria and Ulysses, Basil and Claudia, Nicholas and Maria. Devoted son-inlaw of Eleftheria. Friends may call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral services at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 319 East 74 Street, Friday 11 AM. Interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 120 Wall Street, 19th Floor, New York, NY 10005.

title: Rochester Developer in Talks Exploring a Catskill Casino
description: In the latest proposal for gambling in the Catskills, David Flaum, a developer from Rochester, is hoping to put together a deal with the Seneca-Cayuga tribe for a casino at the southern end of Sullivan County.

title: Metro Business Briefing; NEW REAL ESTATE VENTURE ONLINE
description: Two competing groups that were attempting to create separate Web sites for residential real estate listings in Manhattan announced yesterday that they would unite to form one joint service. The Web site is expected to include more than 2,600 sales listings and between 550 and 1,000 rental listings from about 120 companies, according to the brokerage concerns. For the first time, Manhattan brokerage firms have agreed to share all listings. The firms agreed to share the information within 72 hours and appoint an 18-member board of directors that includes the president of the Real Estate Board of New York as a nonvoting member. The officials said they hoped to make technological advances to speed up the sharing of listings. The agreement ends months of bickering between the two groups -- one led by Douglas Elliman and the Corcoran Group, the other made up of smaller brokerage firms. The new service will use the smaller group's Web site address -- nymls.com -- until a permanent name is chosen. Present at the announcement of the new Internet venture were (pictured from left to right): Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York; the Corcoran Group's founder and chairwoman, Barbara Corcoran; Douglas Elliman's chief executive officer, Alan J. Rogers; and Stuart N. Siegel, president of Sotheby's International Realty. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Gay and Crude? Whatever Happened to 'Faaabulous'?
description: It's hard to imagine anyone accusing ''Normal, Ohio'' of presenting a stereotypical gay leading man. The sitcom's main character isn't good-looking and empathetic nor is he a campy queen. John Goodman's Butch Gamble is a fat, crude, pizza-and-beer inhaling fellow who does hum Judy Garland songs but also yells at the television when he watches sports.

title: A New Bakery Shines on West 47th Street
description: Sullivan Street Bakery, known for its crusty breads and focaccia-like pizza bianca, opened a branch in Midtown yesterday with a new whole-grain bread to sell. The sleek place stands out like a gleaming beacon on a dark block of Clinton. And like more and more shops, including Amy's Bread in the Chelsea Market, Mitchel London on Ninth Avenue and the Doughnut Plant on the Lower East Side, it is a mix of industrial and retail. Jim Lahey, the owner of the original Sullivan Street Bakery in SoHo, took over the former William Greenberg Jr. Desserts wholesale bakery space at 533 West 47th Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues. Like the SoHo bakery, this one has a small but polished retail shop in front of a large commercial space, where Mr. Lahey and his crew, including Gerardo Dominguez, above, will be doing most of their baking. The shop carries the big new whole-grain bread for $6 as well as pizza bianca and other varieties of this rich flatbread ($1.75 to $2.25), ciabatta ($1 or $2) and baguettes ($1.75).

title: Comments on AIDS Weaken Mbeki
description: For months, President Thabo Mbeki doggedly endured a relentless shower of censure, refusing to agree that H.I.V. causes AIDS and dismissing his critics as ''blind defenders of the faith.'' The government's announcement two weeks ago that Mr. Mbeki was reducing his role in the debate came too late to lift many South Africans' deepened confusion about AIDS and its origins.

title: Reckonings; Bait and Switch
description: The big lesson of this year's campaign -- a lesson that we can be sure politicians will take to heart -- is that a candidate can get away with saying things that are demonstrably untrue, as long as the untruths involve big numbers.

title: WorldCom to Create 2 Tracking Stocks; Cuts Earnings Forecasts
description: Mr. Armstrong, meet Mr. Ebbers.

title: Holiday Gifts, Par Avion
description: EVERY year, when I test the waters of mail-order gifts, I cast a wide net in the hope of finding some treasures. And every year, there are things I would love to have someone send me. Some years there are things so wonderful that I will be sending them to myself.

title: I.B.M. TO BUY BACK MORE OF ITS STOCK
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back up to $3.5 billion more of its stock. The company has spent more than $14 billion to buy back its shares over the last two years, including a $1.4 billion repurchase authorized earlier that the company has not completed. The repurchases have already reduced the number of shares outstanding to 1.81 billion from 2.21 billion. The new buyback, which will take place over an unspecified period, would reduce the current total by 2 percent. Shares of I.B.M. rose $5.06, or 5 percent, to close at $98.38.

title: SLIDE IN PRIMEDIA SHARES SLOWS
description: Primedia, controlled by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, was downgraded to ''buy'' from ''outperform'' by an analyst at Lazard Freres a day after the magazine company agreed to buy About.com for $690 million in stock. Primedia's shares skidded 25 percent after the deal was announced on Monday. Yesterday, they slipped 1.1 percent.

title: Viacom Is Said to Be Trying to Acquire BET
description: Viacom Inc. is in talks to acquire BET Holdings, a cable television network devoted to reaching black audiences, several executives close to the negotiations said last night.

title: Challenging Graham Board, Director Reveals A Rival Plan
description: Ron Protas, the director of the Martha Graham Trust, which holds the rights to the choreographer's works, says that he presented a plan to the state attorney general's office in early October to reopen the Graham school within a major New York City university. The announcement, on Monday, came in response to reports that the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance is itself planning to reopen the school.

title: A Crucial Election For Medical Research
description: As a Parkinson's disease patient and a new American citizen, I look forward to Election Day as something momentous: It's not just the first presidential race in which I can vote (I was born in Canada). The outcome is likely to have a dramatic bearing on my prognosis -- and that of millions of Americans whose lives have been touched by Parkinson's, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, spinal cord injury, Huntington's disease, Alzheimer's disease and other devastating illnesses. That's because one question that may be decided on Tuesday is whether stem cell research -- which holds the best hope of a cure for such diseases -- will be permitted to go forward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, JOSEPH
description: FUCHS-Joseph. On October 30, 2000. A born & bred New Yorker, residing in Greenwich Village for over 50 years. Proud to be an American, and proud to be Jewish. He joined the Navy at 18, and at 23, The Merchant Marines, serving with courage in the North Atlantic and Pacific in World War II. An elected official in The National Maritime Union, he negotiated for the rights of ordinary seamen. A man of principle, integrity and generosity. He will be surely missed by his friends and always loved by his companion, Miriam Lewis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, LYNDA L.
description: WRIGHT-Lynda L. Age 60. Artist, resident of NYC and East Dummerston, VT, on October 29, 2000. Beloved wife of Eugene Hill Ferrara, dear sister of Joyce Connell of Moorestown, NJ, and Richard W. Wright of Simi Valley, CA. Loving aunt of Jocelyn Graney, Peter Connell, Carin Wright and Michael Wright. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: A Seat at U.N. Recommended for Yugoslavia
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 31  The Security Council recommended to the General Assembly today that it admit Yugoslavia as a member of the United Nations, bringing Belgrade in from the diplomatic cold after eight years.

title: Federalism Debate at Heart of Environment Case Before Justices
description: The Supreme Court's great continuing federalism debate came to rest today in an unlikely place: the site of an abandoned strip mine in northeastern Illinois, dotted with dozens of small ponds where the earth was scooped out more than 50 years ago, that a consortium of suburban Chicago cities and towns proposes to use for a solid-waste landfill.

title: Nader Sees a Bright Side to a Bush Victory
description: Ralph Nader has no campaign plane and arrives for his commercial flight at the last possible moment, along with just one aide. The Green Party's presidential candidate keeps his head down, as if he is not sure he wants to be noticed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICOLL, GRACE T.
description: NICOLL-Grace T. On October 29, 2000. Reposing at Walter B. CookeKennedy F.H., 117 West 72 St, NYC Wednesday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass Corpus Christi RC Church, Thursday, 10 AM. Interment Cedar Grove Cemetery,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESSMAN, RICHARD A.
description: PRESSMAN-Richard A. In Orlando, FL, Oct. 26. Survived by daughters Deborah Harbin & Elizabeth Pressman; son-in-law Ray Harbin; granddaughters Deryn & Kendell Harbin; brother William Pressman. Born in Philadelphia 1/31/16, Dik lived most of his life in Bklyn & Queens. A devoted and generous father, grandfather and uncle. A private service in Montclair, NJ on November 12th, 973-744-1951.

title: Sweep Gently
description: Perhaps distracted by the late season start and all this contingency planning, the networks seem to have backed off on loading up the heavy weaponry for the sweep month, which starts tomorrow night. Only three mini-series are scheduled. Two are on CBS: ''Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy Onassis,'' a biographical drama on Sunday and next Wednesday, and ''American Tragedy'' on Nov. 12 and 15, about the O. J. Simpson defense team. Mr. Simpson sued to try to keep the show off the air. (He failed.)

title: Opening the Space Station
description: There was something anticlimactic about yesterday's launch of an American and two Russians toward the International Space Station, whose first linked modules are now circling 240 miles overhead, ready to be activated and expanded. The huge $60 billion engineering project has been delayed repeatedly, and when the astronauts were finally sent aloft from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, the venture got limited attention in an America absorbed in its closest presidential race in years. Even so, if all goes well in coming years, this could mark the start for Americans of continuous operations in space as opposed to intermittent shuttle trips.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Making Education Compute

title: No One Thought France Would Fall. Only a Gambler.
description: STRANGE VICTORY

title: S.E.C. Faults Auditor at Solucorp Industries
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that an auditor for Solucorp Industries had failed to meet his professional obligations upon discovering possibly illegal conduct at the company.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of All Saints' Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: FALLING PROFIT AT WHITBREAD
description: With Britons drinking less beer, Whitbread, which is trying to sell 3,000 pubs, said first-half profit slid by 16 percent, to $136 million. Whitbread, Britain's dominant operator of restaurants, fitness clubs and budget hotels, wants to sell the pubs to concentrate on its other businesses. The company, which operates Marriott hotels in Britain, is also reorganizing and rebranding parts of its restaurant division. Its shares fell slightly in London. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Commercial Real Estate; Building Adds Third Source of Power for Cooling
description: When executives of the Rockefeller Group decided the time had come to replace the 40-year-old air-conditioning equipment in the 48-story Time & Life Building at 1271 Avenue of the Americas at 50th Street, they had to take the gradually deregulating market for energy into consideration.

title: Accounts
description: Montgomery Ward & Co., Chicago, to the Chicago office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its media planning and buying. Billings were estimated at $75 million. Those duties had been at BKN Media, Chicago, which is closing. Creative duties remain at Laughlin/Constable, Milwaukee.

title: NATO Chief Says Bush Aide Reassured Him on Balkan Stance
description: NATO's secretary general said today that he had received assurances from George W. Bush's campaign team that Mr. Bush would not unilaterally withdraw American peacekeeping troops from the Balkans if he wins the presidential election.

title: A 'Techno-Peasant' Goes Internet
description: Frederick Forsyth, the British author who made his name in the literary ''old economy'' of spies, mercenaries and assassins, hardly seems a likely candidate to blaze a trail through the literary thickets of cyberspace.

title: Discoveries Along the Mekong River
description: THE marriage of travelogue, anthropological text and cookbook is not always a comfortable one, but Jeffrey Alford and Naomi Duguid have made it a success in ''Hot Sour Salty Sweet: A Culinary Journey Through Southeast Asia'' (Artisan, $40).

title: U.S. Aides Say the Yemenis Seem to Hinder Cole Inquiry
description: American officials said today that since the attack on the destroyer Cole, Yemeni officials appear to have obscured crucial evidence in the case, in particular by delivering a version of a videotape from an Aden harbor police surveillance camera that begins only after the actual bombing and appears to have been edited to show only parts of the chaotic aftermath.

title: Countdown - 6: Nader Sees a Bright Side to a Bush Victory

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KISSEL, LESTER
description: KISSEL-Lester. A memorial for Lester Kissel will be held at The Century Association, 7 West 43rd Street, N.Y.C., on Wednesday, November 15, 2000, at 4:30 P.M.

title: Redgrave Retires After 5 Games and 5 Golds
description: Steve Redgrave, the only man to win five consecutive Olympic gold medals in an endurance sport, announced his retirement yesterday from international rowing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, RUTH
description: FRANKEL-Ruth, on October 31, 2000, of Massapequa, LI. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Ronni and Martin Begleiter, Jeffrey and Doreen Frankel. Loving sister of Herbert Kaplan. Dearest sister-in-law of Evelyn Kaplan, Benjamin, Morton and Phyllis Frankel. Cherished grandmother of Wendy, Victoria, Adam and Hilary. She was a Founding Trustee of the Plainedge Public Library from 1963 to 1975 and from 1975 served with distinction until her passing as Chairperson of the Board of Trustees. Services Thursday, 12 Noon, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, LI.

title: Netanyahu Watches and Waits for His Opening
description: In a technology park near the Jerusalem Mall, the door of Citizen Bibi's office boasts but one sign: the seal of the prime minister. Benjamin Netanyahu may be a businessman now, but his preferred identity is clear.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE GREENS

title: Paul Bowles Lives On in His Words and Music
description: Anecdotes to the contrary notwithstanding -- and there are plenty -- Paul Bowles spent much of his adulthood officially scowling at the notion of nostalgia, preferring to keep his feet firmly planted in the here and now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORY, EMILY
description: FLORY-Emily. Beloved wife of Verdon, loving mother of Chris and Brian. Dear sister of Michael Abrams. You will never be forgotten. Services Thursday 12:45 P.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to Meals On Wheels.

title: A Third Bidder for Auction World Heft; Phillips, With a Rich New Parent, Seeks to Join Sotheby's and Christie's Cozy Club
description: As the Justice Department investigation into Sotheby's and Christie's unfolds, the world's largest auction houses are proceeding as if it is business as usual, gathering all the best Impressionist, modern and contemporary art they can for important auctions planned over the next two weeks. But the historical tug-of-war between Sotheby's and Christie's has turned into an expensive three-way fight.

title: Few Voters Credit Democrats for Gains
description: Twice as many American families own mutual funds as in 1992, when Al Gore was first elected vice president. That might seem a plus for Mr. Gore in his race against Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, since the stock market has quadrupled during Mr. Gore's time in office.

title: A Closer Look at the New York Senate Race
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } The 2000 Election function displayDate(month) { if (month == "Jan") smon = "January"; else if (month == "Feb") smon = "February"; else if (month == "Mar") smon = "March"; else if (month == "Apr") smon = "April"; else if (month == "May") smon = "May"; else if (month == "Jun") smon = "June"; else if (month == "Jul") smon = "July"; else if (month == "Aug") smon = "August"; else if (month == "Sep") smon = "September"; else if (month == "Oct") smon = "October"; else if (month == "Nov") smon = "November"; else if (month == "Dec") smon = "December"; return (smon ); }

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Monday about ''A History of Britain,'' a series this week on the History Channel, misidentified the opponent of William, Duke of Normandy, depicted in the Bayeux Tapestry, which shows the Battle of Hastings and is used as a visual aid in the program. His opponent was the English king Harold II, not the Viking Harald Hardrada (an invader whom Harold II had defeated).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEDLOW, SAMUEL L.
description: TEDLOW-Samuel L. The Metropolitan Opera mourns with profound sadness the loss of our very dear friend, Samuel L. Tedlow, a member of the board for more than 24 years, who served as a managing director for 10 years and was an honorary director at the time of his death. A courtly, kind and gentle man, he gave devoted service to The Metropolitan Opera as a member of the finance committee and chairman of the audit and nominating committees during important years of transition for our company. Together with his beloved wife Lillian, Ted set a leadership example for other good friends of the Met through his quiet generosity to our activities for nearly four decades. As patrons of the Met since the company moved to the new Opera House at Lincoln Center in 1966, Ted and Lillian were founding members of the Golden Horseshoe Program and the Encore Society and participated in creating our first endowment campaign and the Pooled Income Fund, the Silver Anniversay Fund, and the new campaign to increase our endowment fund. We recall with deep affection Ted and Lillian's enjoyment of opera at the Met. Together they took special pleasure in underwriting two new productions, ''Les Contes D'Hoffmann'' in 1973 and ''Rigoletto'' in 1977, as well as helping to underwrite nine other productions, even during recent years when ill health prevented them from attending Met performances. We will miss Ted's wise counsel and his abiding support of our company as well as his personal friendships with many of us on the board and in Met management. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Lillian, his sons, Richard and David, his daughter, Roberta Rood, and his family. Mrs. Gilbert W. Humphrey, Chairman Emeritus Bruce Crawford, Honorary Chairman James w. Kinnear, Chairman Paul M. Montrone, President

title: Looking Oddly Like a Loser, Kasparov Trails in Chess Duel
description: In his 15 years as world champion, Garry Kasparov has cultivated a fearsome reputation as the chess-playing equivalent of a trash-talking basketball star. He glares, he swaggers, he makes exaggerated sighs of disdain in the faces of his opponents. And he always wins.

title: Conjuring Up an Inexpensive, Informal Italian Spot
description: SINCE La Grolla opened about a year and a half ago, it has been one of my top choices for Italian food on the Upper West Side. But while I enjoyed its hearty specialties from the Val d'Aosta region in the Italian Alps, I also wished it were less expensive and a little more casual.
