title: THE BOSS; The Arrogance of My Youth
description: In contrast to now, I was a little arrogant as a teenager.

title: Kramnik Fights for a Draw And Now Leads Match, 8-6
description: Some awkward arrangements of his pieces in the early middle game in the 14th encounter of the Brain Games Network World Chess Championship gave Vladimir Kramnik trouble yesterday in London, but he struggled through to an endgame that was salvageable and got the draw that maintained his two-point lead over Garry Kasparov.

title: Wholesome Holiday Tradition Goes On Parade in Brooklyn
description: In her carefree, childless days, Fabiola Gaerlan was a regular in the annual Manhattan debauch known as the Village Halloween Parade.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about newspaper circulation figures issued by the Audit Bureau of Circulations misstated the result for The Daily News of New York on Sundays for the six months ended Sept. 30. Its circulation was basically unchanged in comparison with the period last year. The figure did not decline by 2.8 percent.

title: Technology Briefings
description: E-COMMERCE SCHWAB TO BE A `PREFERRED PROVIDER'

title: $10 Million Fund to Help New York City's Charter Schools Pay for Equipment and Repairs
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city had created a $10 million fund for its fledgling charter schools that would provide annual grants of up to $250,000 per school for new equipment, laboratories, libraries, air-conditioning and construction projects.

title: THE CHEF
description: EGG drop soup was the first thing I learned to cook for myself. I was about 10 years old and had been watching my mother make this Chinese classic as long as I could remember. The basic recipe is so easy -- you just drizzle eggs into a boiling broth -- that even a child can make it for lunch. But I find that it can actually be a very sophisticated dish.

title: OFFICEMAX WILL CLOSE OR RELOCATE AS MANY AS 50 STORES
description: OfficeMax said yesterday that it planned to close or move as many as 50 stores -- but did not say which ones -- and that it would cut back its expansion plans in 2001. About 2,000 workers will be offered transfers, the company said. The company, based in Shaker Heights, Ohio, is the third-largest operator of office-products stores, behind Staples and Office Depot, which has also said it will scale back growth plans. OfficeMax also said it had offered to pay $5.1 million to settle a contract dispute with a unit of Ryder System.

title: ARENA TEAM COMING TO COLISEUM
description: The owners of the Islanders are buying the Iowa Barnstormers of the Arena Football League for $7 million. The team will be brought to Long Island and renamed the Dragons.

title: Market Place; According to the Dow, Gore's worries are just about over.
description: THE verdict of the Dow Jones industrial average is in, and it says Al Gore is headed for the White House.

title: CHARGES DISMISSED IN SHOOTING CASE AGAINST TROOPERS
description: A New Jersey judge dropped all charges today against two state troopers stemming from the 1998 shooting of three unarmed black and Hispanic men during the traffic stop on the New Jersey Turnpike that made racial profiling a national issue.

title: Japan's Mobile Phone Giant Is in Talks on Investing in U.S.
description: NTT DoCoMo Inc., Japan's largest mobile telephone company, is talking with several wireless carriers in the United States about taking a stake in a company as it pursues its aspirations to become a global operator, a company executive said today.

title: Global Warming And the Election
description: To the Editor:

title: McCann Unit Wins 6 Echo Awards
description: McCann Relationship Marketing Worldwide has taken top honors, winning six awards, at the 2000 International Echo Awards competition sponsored by the Direct Marketing Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, TAMAR
description: WEBER-Tamar. July 3, 1910-October 30, 2000. We celebrate the life of a remarkable woman. Mother of Jessica and Mark. Mother-inlaw of Alan Peckolick and Karen. Grandmother of Jordana and Valerie. Widow of Wally Weber. Graduate of Wellesley/'31. Tam traveled the world in her later years with an insatiable curiosity and love of adventure that will be her legacy. She was smart, inquisitive, and loved to share her knowledge and experiences with those who were privileged enough to have known and loved her. Memorial servies will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 65 Street and Fifth Ave. at noon on Thursday, November 2. Contributions in her memory may be made to Temple Emanu-El or the Wellesley College Fund, Wellesley, MA. She was truly an original.

title: Piniella Stays in Seattle
description: Lou Piniella, the third of three potential free-agent managers, followed the other two yesterday, deciding to stay right where he was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, ROBERT W.
description: WALKER-Robert W. July 17, 1923October 30, 2000. Beloved husband of Georgina (Rena), loving father of Gail (Nicholas) Patitucci, Lynn (Michael) Kern, Robert (Nancy) Walker and Coreen (Wayne) Sumple. Devoted grandfather of Krista, Scott, Jennifer, Heather, Kimberly, Robbie, Colin, Tyler, Kyle and Kelsey. Loving greatgrandfather to Drew, Tyler, Daniel, David and Rebecca. Raised in Greenwich Village and graduated from the High School of Commerce. Three years in Naval service in China during WWII. Retired from the textile industry as Executive Vice President and Member of the Board of Directors, Stonecutter Mills. Formerly a member at North Jersey and Ridgewood Country Clubs. Always devoted in his faith, Bob was a former member of Advent Lutheran Church in Wyckoff, New Jersey, where he served as Church Council President. Retired to Palm City, Florida where he was a member of Immanuel Lutheran Church and Harbour Ridge Golf and Country Club. A celebration of his life will be held on November 1 at 11:00 AM, Immanuel Lutheran Church, 2655 Immanuel Drive, Palm City 34990. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be given to the Music Fund at Immanuel Lutheran Church or to the Salvation Army.

title: Article 2000110192200462060 -- No Title
description: GURDON, Ark., Oct. 29  Representative Jay Dickey, a four-term Republican congressman in an overwhelmingly Democratic district, is not an elegant speaker. But as he spoke from atop a flatbed trailer at this town's annual timber festival this weekend, he was a model of oratorical efficiency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURWITZ, JEROME
description: HURWITZ-Jerome. On October 31, 2000. Beloved husband of Esther. Dear father of Joel and the late Barbara Theurer. Loving grandfather of Eve, Michael and Carl. Funeral services today 1PM, Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Cleaning Mushrooms

title: Starwood to Sell European Luxury Hotels
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide reported sharply higher third-quarter earnings today and said that it would put up for sale a chain of European luxury hotels.

title: A Tough Yank Takes On the Underground
description: TRAITOR. Mercenary. Carpetbagger. Capitalist. And, worst of all on this brisk day when the Yankee parade and its attendant toilet tissue swirl past his office window overlooking Battery Park, Red Sox fan.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about Ericsson and MetLife, which are reconsidering their ties to Young & Rubicam Advertising, referred imprecisely to remarks by Kevin Foley, a MetLife spokesman. While he commented on a report in Adweek, that said the company was beginning a review for its account, he did not confirm such a review.

title: Tick Tick Tick Tick
description: Before Regis Philbin and ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' came along, ''60 Minutes'' was regularly the top-rated Sunday night program.

title: Clinton and Lazio Turn Negative On Campaign Use of Cole Attack
description: The New York Senate race, mired in a dispute over Muslim American support for Hillary Rodham Clinton, turned vitriolic yesterday as both Mrs. Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio resorted to invective and abusive attacks that centered on the bombing of the destroyer Cole.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL DROPS. Heating oil fell on signs that regional suppliers have enough fuel to meet demand in November. In New York, heating oil for November delivery fell 2.23 cents, or 2.3 percent, to 94.1 cents a gallon.

title: The Prune Gets Its Day in the Sun
description: The California Prune Board is changing its name. From now on, it will be the California Dried Plum Board, and the product it promotes will be dried plums. Despite a $10 million campaign, though, some people aren't getting the message.

title: Judge Declares Mistrial in Case Of 6 Protesters
description: A judge in District of Columbia Superior Court declared a mistrial today in the case of six people seeking Congressional voting rights for the city.

title: Stop the Flow!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRODE, MURRAY
description: GRODE-Murray. On October 29. Beloved husband of Leah. Devoted father of Inez and Barry Wade, and Karen and Alan Terner, and the late Stanley Grode and Phyllis Grode. Loving grandfather of Jonathan, Gabrielle, Faith, Brett, Adam, Francesca and Benjamin. Services were held. Contributions may be made to the Stanley E. Grode Research Fund, U. of Penn Cancer Center, 3400 Spruce St., 1224 Penn Tower, Phila., PA 19104.

title: Rangers Promote Witehall
description: With Valery Kamensky out with a bruised kidney, the Rangers today recalled Johan Witehall from Hartford, leaving John MacLean closer to the end of his career with the Rangers.

title: Praise and Harsh Criticism Greet Judge's Ruling
description: In the Trenton courtroom, there were a few smiles, tears and quiet hugs. Even afterward, outside, the two New Jersey troopers who had just heard a judge throw out all charges against them from a shooting were subdued.

title: VIACOM ADJUSTS OFFER FOR INFINITY BROADCASTING
description: Viacom said yesterday that it would issue more Class B stock and would increase the number of those shares that it would exchange for the part of the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation that it does not already own, to compensate for a slide of 20 percent in the value of its stock since August. Under the new agreement, Viacom raised by 5 percent its per-share offer for Infinity, a large radio broadcaster. The new offer, 0.592 B shares for each share of Infinity, values the acquisition at $12.5 billion, $3 billion more than the old offer's current value but below the $14.9 billion the deal was worth based on stock prices of Aug. 15, the day it was announced. Viacom is buying 36 percent of Infinity; it acquired the other 64 percent when it bought the CBS Corporation in May.

title: Trade Dispute More Likely as Telmex Sues on Connection Fees
description: A long-simmering telecommunications dispute between the United States and Mexico appeared to be heading more rapidly toward a World Trade Organization arbitration panel today.

title: Investigators Begin to Unravel Taiwan Crash
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Thursday, Nov. 2  Investigators interviewed the jet captain and recovered two crucial data-recording boxes Wednesday from the Los Angeles-bound Singapore Airlines flight that crashed during takeoff late on Tuesday, killing 79 of 179 on board.

title: Political Memo; G.O.P. Gambles, Cautiously, in Budget Face-Off
description: Determined not to lose once again to President Clinton, Republicans in Congress have pursued a new strategy this year and chosen to bide their time in budget negotiations, a move that could result in a rare post-election session.

title: TRADE SURGE FROM OLYMPICS
description: Australia posted its best monthly trade figures in three years, largely because of the Sydney Olympics. The Australian Bureau of Statistics said the country's trade balance, a $680 million deficit in August, became a surplus of $355 million in September, its second-largest surplus ever and the first of any size since November 1997. But the figures had little impact on the country's struggling stock and bond markets. ''Like any pole vault, we'll crash back to earth next month,'' said Michael Blythe, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia's chief research economist.

title: Council Panel Approves Income Tax Cut
description: City personal income tax cuts first proposed nearly a year ago are finally making their way toward reality, with a City Council committee yesterday approving a scaled-back cut that would save city taxpayers only about $190 million a year, about a quarter of the original plan.

title: WorldCom to Announce Overhaul Plan and Lower Forecasts
description: A week after AT&T announced a sweeping reorganization that will break the company up into four parts, WorldCom Inc. is expected to announce a similar, if somewhat less grand, revamping today that will include issuing a stock to track its consumer and wholesale long-distance units.

description: A growing number of Arab entertainers, intellectuals, politicians and business people have been flying off to Baghdad over the last two weeks, thumbing their noses at international sanctions and giving the Iraqi government a shower of publicity after its 10 years of near isolation.

title: Grand Jury Fails to Indict Penn State's Casey
description: Rashard Casey, the Penn State quarterback, was cleared yesterday by a grand jury of charges that he had assaulted an off-duty police officer in Hoboken, N.J., last spring.

title: SCHWAB TO BE A 'PREFERRED PROVIDER'
description: Charles Schwab said yesterday that it would become a preferred provider of brokerage services and investment information on America Online's redesigned financial Web channels. David Pottruck, left, Schwab's co-chief executive, said he expected the three-year arrangement, at a cost he would not disclose, to attract new customers to Schwab. He said he did not know what percentage of AOL's 28 million users already were Schwab customers but, he said, ''more customers come to Schwab.com through AOL than any other source.'' Citigroup, which has announced a similar relationship with AOL, said yesterday that it would provide AOL with a payment system, called AOL Quick Cash, that its members can use to transfer money over the Internet for $2 a transaction. That system will be identical to a money transfer system called c2it that Citigroup introduced yesterday. The new service allows anybody with an e-mail address to send or receive money online. The payment can originate or wind up in a bank account or on a credit card. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELMAN, RENEE
description: ADELMAN-Renee. Of Lawrence, N.Y. and Boca Raton, FL. Passed away tragically and suddenly on Monday, October 30, 2000. Devoted wife of Seymour, beloved mother of Marcia A. Delman and Debra Buckley. Adored grandmother of Ariel and Ross Buckley, who gave Renee so much joy, pride and pleasure during her life. She is also survived by her brother, Leonard Kleiman & his family. She will always be kept in our hearts, always remembered for her joyful spirit, vitality, kindness, music-making and delightful wit. Her loving memory lives in our dreams and our lives. Forever in our hearts, we will miss her more with each passing day.

description: LEVY-Robert I., M.D. The Board, Staff and membership of Research!America honor the life of Dr. Robert I. Levy, Senior VP, American Home Products and former director of the National Institutes of Health's Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. He was a global leader committed to making medical and health research a higher priority. He leaves a legacy of dedication, integrity and vision for a stronger public-private partnership for the treatment, cure and prevention of disease. We extend our condolences to his family. Honorable Paul G. Rogers, Chair Mary Wolley, President

title: A Bitter Race in Connecticut Reflects National Platforms
description: In a subdued debate, the major candidates in the closely fought race for Connecticut's Fifth Congressional District cast their contest today as a microcosm of the presidential campaign. The Democratic incumbent, James H. Maloney, and the Republican challenger, Mark Nielsen, each firmly aligned himself with his party's nominee on the core issues of the economy, taxes, Social Security and education.

description: One of the last stumbling blocks to a final budget deal between Congress and the White House is a set of proposed federal rules intended to protect millions of workers from injuries associated with repetitive-motion activities.

title: Plane Explodes in Angola, Passengers Believed Dead
description: LUANDA, Angola -- A Russian-built plane exploded shortly after takeoff in northern Angola, civil aviation officials said Wednesday. Local media reported that all 42 passengers and six crew members were killed.

description: REDMOND-Dewitt Jr. On October 26, 2000, in his 68th year. Loving husband of Amanda (Jones). Brother of Hertacine Redmond, Jamaica, NY, Cleta Dutton, Benny Redmond and Matthew Redmond of Gulfport, Miss, and Joseph Redmond of Atlanta, GA. He was employed by The New York Times newspaper for over thirty-five years until his retirement in 1994. Visitation on Friday is from 9-10 A.M., followed by religious services at 10 A.M. at Paul Lane Funeral Home, 115-33 Sutphin Boulevard, Jamaica, New York. Interment is to follow at Fairlawn Cemetery in Fairlawn, New Jersey.

title: COMERICA AND IMPERIAL BANCORP IN $1.3 BILLION DEAL
description: Comerica Inc., Michigan's largest bank and the 24th largest nationally, said yesterday that it agreed to buy Imperial Bancorp for $1.3 billion in stock, expanding its business in California. Imperial stockholders will receive 0.46 of a Comerica share for each Imperial share held. The pact values Imperial, based in Inglewood, Calif., at $27.74 a share, a 14 percent premium to the Tuesday closing price. Comerica is paying 2.4 times book value, or assets minus liabilities, to buy Imperial.

title: Kosovo Albanians Cheer the Return of a Doctor Freed in Serbia
description: Flora Brovina, a prominent doctor, poet and activist for Kosovo Albanians, was freed from a Serbian prison today by a special pardon from the new Yugoslav president. Arriving home to a tumultuous welcome, she dropped to her knees to kiss the ground as she crossed into Kosovo, her home province.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, TAMAR
description: WEBER-Tamar. July 13, 1910-October 30, 2000. We celebrate the life of a remarkable woman. Mother of Jessica and Mark. Mother-in-law of Alan Peckolick and Karen. Grandmother of Jordana and Valerie. Widow of Wally Weber. Graduate of Wellesley/'31. Tam traveled the world in her later years with an insatiable curiosity and love of adventure that will be her legacy. She was smart, inquisitive, and loved to share her knowledge and experiences with those who were privileged enough to have known and loved her. Memorial services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 65 Street and Fifth Ave. at noon on Thursday, November 2. Contributions in her memory may be made to Temple Emanu-El or the Wellesley College Fund, Wellesley, MA. She was truly an original.

title: Bill Clinton in the Eye of History
description: It's a time of transition, a time to look to the judgment of history. The case before us is the first Democratic president in six decades to be elected to two terms. Voters understood at the outset that he came before them trailing conspicuous liabilities: His party had been deeply discredited by its questionable role in a divisive war just a generation earlier. He himself had avoided military service in that war. His presidential campaign was marred by salacious rumors of sexual misconduct, to which, in effect, he publicly confessed -- a confession that the public, somewhat surprisingly, appeared to understand and accept. And thanks to a splinter populist movement that siphoned off some of the strength of the incumbent Republican president, he was elected.

title: Metro Business Briefing; NEW YORK CITY ECONOMY GROWING
description: Although the national economy appears to be slowing, business conditions in New York continue to improve, according to several economic reports released yesterday. A periodic survey of economic conditions by the Federal Reserve Bank, informally known as the beige book, reported that inflationary pressures in New York were waning and that the ''economy has shown few, if any, signs of slowing.'' And the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that New York City had added far more new jobs -- 101,000 -- than any other metropolitan area in the country during the last 12 months. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: BRITISH AND IRISH FACTORY REPORTS
description: Manufacturing activity in Britain fell for the first time in 18 months in September, as the pound's rising value slowed factory output, forcing manufacturers to curb price increases as growth in new orders slowed, a survey showed. Manufacturing exporters are struggling to stay profitable in the face of the pound's 13 percent increase against the euro since January 1999. While not contracting, manufacturing output in Ireland, which is within the euro zone, was seen to grow at a pace well below last year's pace, according to a monthly survey of purchasing managers. Shortages of labor were said to be the main constraint.

title: U.S. ALLOWS UNIONS OF POSTGRADUATES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNESA, MICHAEL C.
description: TURNESA-Michael C., 93, of Elmsford, NY. Died October 31, 2000 at Phelps Memorial Hospital, Sleepy Hollow, NY. Michael was born June 9, 1907 to Vitalie and Anna (nee Pascarella) Turnesa. Mr. Turnesa was the Golf Pro at Knollwood Country Club, Elmsford, NY from 1942 thru 1986 & the Director of Golf until present. He is predeceased by five brothers Frank, Phil, Douglas, James, Joseph Turnesa & one sister Rose Ercoli. Michael is survived by his wife Mary (nee Marinucci) Turnesa of Elmsford, NY. Two daughters Jean DeZalia of Austin, TX, Mary Ellen De Felice of Pleasantville, NY, two sons Michael of Rockville Centre, NY, James of Elmsford, NY, one brother Willie Turnesa of Elmsford, NY one sister Mildred Recchia of Elmsford NY. Grandfather of 8 great grandfather of 1. Reposing Hawthorne Funeral Home, Thursday and Friday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10AM Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, Elmsford, NY. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Westchester Golf Associatn Caddie Scholarship Fund, 49 Knollwood Rd., Elmsford, NY 10523 in his memory.

title: Israel and Palestine Set Stage for Truce
description: Israel pulled back tanks from friction points and Palestinian police restrained rock throwers Thursday, in first tentative steps to carry out a truce agreement reached by Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in an overnight meeting. The cease-fire was to take hold Thursday afternoon with announcements by Arafat and Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak. However, in the hours leading up to the deadline, a 17-year-old Palestinian was killed in a rock-throwing clash with Israeli troops in the West Bank village of Hizme, near Jerusalem, and Palestinian gunmen fired on Israeli positions in the West Bank town of Hebron, drawing return fire. Clashes also erupted in the Gaza Strip. But in at least two locations, near the Jewish settlements of Kfar Darom and Netzarim in Gaza, Palestinian police pushed back rock throwers for the first time in several weeks. Near Netzarim, police bundled several dozen stone throwers in trucks and drove them away. Previous cease-fire agreements, including one brokered by President Clinton last month, did not hold, with each side accusing the other of violating commitments. Peres and Arafat met at the Palestinian leader's Gaza City office for two hours late Wednesday in the first high-level meeting since the conflict erupted Sept. 28. At least 162 people have been killed in the fighting, most of them Palestinians. "We hope we shall have two or three days without funerals," Peres told Associated Press Television News. "We shall return to normalize the situation in the territories and return to peace talks." Palestinian peace negotiator Nabil Shaath said that according to the understandings reached, Israel will gradually lift its closure of Palestinian areas, permit Palestinian workers to return to jobs in Israel and open Gaza International Airport, as well as border crossings with Egypt and Jordan. Such restrictions have cost the Palestinian economy about $4 million a day, the U.N. relief agency for Palestinian refugees said Wednesday. Arafat convened his Cabinet ministers around noon. In an apparent call for calm, the Palestinian Information Ministry said in a statement that "the Palestinian leadership asks our Palestinian people and all our national forces to forge a united stand and express ourselves peacefully in all circumstances in our national struggle." But the leader of the Islamic militant group Hamas, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, said the Palestinian uprising against Israel would continue. Yassin said the protests were an expression of popular anger and could not be reined in by an order from Arafat. Barak and Arafat spoke by phone before the 2 p.m. deadline to coordinate the wording of their announcements, which were to be broadcast live by Israeli and Palestinian media, respectively, Barak's office said. Barak also expressed sorrow for the killing of the Palestinian teen-ager Thursday. Israeli security officials, meanwhile, announced that a Palestinian militant has been caught in the Israeli town of Upper Nazareth. The officials said the man had plotted to carry out a suicide attack in northern Israel. On Thursday morning, Israel pulled back tanks from several friction points in the Gaza Strip, including the Karni crossing, where eight Palestinians were killed in two days of fierce gun battles. One of the Karni protesters died Thursday of injuries sustained earlier. Israeli soldiers withdrew from a Palestinian police post at Karni which they had seized earlier this week. Israel also lifted its siege of several West Bank towns, including Nablus, Bethlehem and Hebron. Within a few hours, Palestinians were to be able to move freely in the West Bank, said Brig. Gen. Ron Kitrey, the Israeli army spokesman. Israeli and Palestinian troop commanders and lower-level officers held a series of talks in the West Bank and Gaza to work out the details of the truce. As a result of the agreement, Israel at the last minute froze attacks on Palestinian targets that were to come as retaliation for the killing of three Israeli soldiers in gun battles with Palestinians on Wednesday. The three soldiers were the first to die in combat since Oct. 1. Seven Palestinians were also killed, as armed clashes intensified in the West Bank and Gaza Strip and the conflict appeared to be spiraling out of control. Denouncing what he called "grave escalation initiated by the Palestinian Authority," Barak convened a special session of his Cabinet late Wednesday and "decided on a number of appropriate steps," a statement said. But the Peres-Arafat meeting led to the decision to hold the fire. Each side has blamed the other for the violence. Israel says its forces have responded with restraint to Palestinian attacks. The Palestinians charge that Israel has used excessive force in putting down demonstrations. A pitched battle was fought Wednesday in the village of Al Khader, near Bethlehem, where two Israeli soldiers and three Palestinians were killed Wednesday. Four Israeli soldiers were wounded. Heavy Palestinian gunfire prevented Israeli forces from reaching the soldiers who were hit, so the Israelis sent attack helicopters to rake the village with machine guns while tanks provided covering fire for an armored vehicle to retrieve the soldiers. Israeli attack helicopters and tanks fired at Palestinian intelligence headquarters in Jericho overnight, in retaliation for Palestinian gunfire at an Israeli army outpost where a reserve army officer was killed, the military said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POST, SEYMOUR C., MD.
description: POST-Seymour C., MD. Died October 26 after a prolonged illness. Esteemed colleague at the Columbia Medical Center Consultation Liaison Service for close to 50 years, special Rheumatology consultant, graduate NYU Phi Beta Kappa, MD NYU, associate attending psychiatrist Presbyterian Hospital 25 years, fellow American College of Psychoanalysts, Presidential Fund Chairman, fellow American Academy of Psychoanalysis, fellow-The Medical Strollers, avid tennis player, lover of Cape Cod, devoted father and grandfather, respected clinician, author many scientific papers, outspoken advocate of Medical Savings Accounts. We shall miss your wisdom and feisty luncheon presence.

title: Offer of Free Computers for Schools Is Withdrawn
description: Earlier this year, Plainfield High School in Central Village, Conn., signed up for a free computer lab from the ZapMe Corporation. The highflying company was promising to connect the nation's schools to the Internet, asking only to deliver advertising to the students' computer screens to pay the freight.

title: . . . BUT FACES HOMEGROWN COMPETITION
description: Kinokuniya and Microsoft announced an alliance in which the Japanese bookseller will open an online store that uses Microsoft's technology for the secure distribution of electronic books in Microsoft's Reader format. The site will open in early 2001 for English language titles and in mid-2001 for Japanese language ones. Miki Tanikawa

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Oct. 13 about the dismissal of two wrestling coaches at Trumbull High School in Connecticut, where eight team members were arrested in connection with the violent hazing of a 15-year-old, referred incorrectly in some copies to the resolution of the criminal case against three team members who were charged as adults. They did not plead guilty. The judge granted their request for ''accelerated rehabilitation,'' a form of probation that can lead to dismissal of the pending charges after two years if the terms of probation are met.

title: Computer Controls? Save Your Breath
description: FOR decades, researchers have hoped that speech technology would provide a natural, intuitive link to computers, freeing us from the rigid world of windows, icons, menus and pointers.

title: Corrections
description: The Revisions column in the arts pages on Monday, about the scarcity of minority characters in television series, misidentified a Showtime series focusing on a Latino family. It is ''Resurrection Blvd.,'' not ''Resurrection City.''

title: At the Top, Prices Have Flattened Out
description: PRICES of upper-end properties, the creme de Manhattan's creme, have eased in recent weeks, according to a report to be released next week. The report, by Brown Harris Stevens, known for its white-glove listings, examines a series of sales on the Upper East Side, from Third Avenue to Fifth Avenue, along with Central Park West, Sutton Place, Beekman Place and assorted doorman buildings on East 86th and East 57th Streets, as well as the sales in some of the newest condominium loft buildings in TriBeCa.

title: Ralph Nader's High-Wire Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Depicting Rival as Beholden to Donors
description: This 30-second television advertisement, titled ''Look,'' was released yesterday by Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate from New Jersey, in his campaign against Representative Bob Franks.

title: Internet Skull Sessions Let N.F.L. Players Seek Degrees
description: ON any given Sunday in the fall, Chris Hayes, a special-teams player with the New York Jets, hits the field and tackles the competition. Weekdays are a different story. At home on Long Island each morning, Mr. Hayes settles into his La-Z-Boy recliner with his laptop computer to tackle college course work.

title: Essay; The Secrecy Legacy
description: President Clinton has until Saturday to sign or veto a stealth attack on American freedom. On his desk is a bill to prosecute any government whistle-blower who dares make public any corruption or abuses of power any official stamps ''classified.''

title: EMC ACQUIRES CROSSTOR FOR $300 MILLION
description: The EMC Corporation, a leading maker of data-storage systems for businesses, said it had acquired CrosStor Software Inc. for about $300 million in stock. CrosStor, based in South Plainield, N.J., makes software that allows users to maintain and have access to files on computers. EMC is based in Hopkinton, Mass.

title: Doctors Say Republican Candidates Are in Good Health
description: Gov. George W. Bush is in top physical shape, has never had a serious illness, and there is no medical reason that he could not serve a full term as president, Mr. Bush and the doctor who has performed Mr. Bush's annual checkups since 1989 said in interviews.

title: Dying on Main Street, Diners Are Alive Online
description: MANY years ago in Worcester, Mass., there was a diner called Alice and the Hat. One block off Main Street, the diner was a classic red Worcester Lunch Car Company design, with gothic lettering on the side and a sign showing a fedora. The Hat was the nickname of a former newspaperman and Alice was his wife.

title: Car Bomb in Jerusalem Kills 2 as Call for Truce Is Delayed
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 2  As if defying a pre-dawn truce agreement, a car bomb killed two Israelis when it exploded today near a bustling open-air market that has been a favorite target of militant Islamic groups in the past.

title: STOCK SOARS ON MERGER TALK
description: Shares of United Internet, the largest German online marketer, surged after the German magazine Die Teleborse said the company was talking with T-Online International, Europe's largest Internet access service, about a merger. Efforts by news services to reach officials of the company for comment on the report were said to be unsuccessful because Nov. 1 is a holiday in most of Germany. But the stock market was open, and the rumor drove United Internet shares sharply higher. Both companies have been the subject of extensive media speculation about possible combinations and management changes in recent months.

title: Car Bomb in Jerusalem Kills 2 as Call for Truce Is Delayed
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 2 - Hours after Palestinians and Israelis reached a tentative truce to end more than a month of violence, a car bomb went off today near a popular outdoor market, casting doubt on whether the two sides had achieved any progress.

title: Drawing on the Computer Without Dipping Mouse in Ink
description: Picasso said it took him a lifetime to learn to draw like a child. But then, Picasso never had to create a Web page using a computer mouse.

title: In the Middle of Michigan Politics, a Forecaster Much in Demand
description: If Bill Ballenger were a retail product, this would be his Christmas season.

title: Looking for Comic Relief? Then Consider the Duke
description: In the great American political tradition of Pat Paulsen and Pogo, the character Duke of the Doonesbury strip by Garry Trudeau is running for president.

title: Political Luminaries Hit The Trail for Franks and Corzine
description: Trying to tip the balance in a close race, New Jersey's Senate candidates turned today to out-of-state guest stars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULHEREN, JOHN A.
description: MULHEREN-John A., 87. Of Rumson, NJ on October 31, 2000. Former Director of Advertising Sales with Schnell Publishing, NY, NY. Husband of the late Isabel A. (nee Kane). Father of John A. Jr., Michael W., Maureen Mulheren, Colleen A. Wood, Patricia Skinner, and Katherine M. Cabrera. Grandfather of 18. Visitation will be held Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, NJ. Mass of Christian burial will be Saturday 12PM at Holy Cross Church, Rumson, NJ. The family requests that memorial donations be made in his memory to Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church Building Fund, Ward Avenue, Rumson, NJ 07760.

title: Ring Lardner Jr., Wry Screenwriter and Last of the Hollywood 10, Dies at 85
description: Ring Lardner Jr., whose satirical screenplays twice won the Academy Award but whose career collapsed in 1947 after he refused to tell Congress if he had ever been a Communist, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: Senate Votes to Recess, But House Has Other Ideas
description: Unable to reach agreement with the White House on crucial end-of-the-year issues, House and Senate Republicans were unable even to agree among themselves today over what to do next.

title: A Rising Star's Long Fall From Grace
description: Through much of her tenure at the helm of one of the city's largest school districts, in Southeast Queens, Celestine V. Miller was regarded as an effective leader with a knack for skillful budgeting and raising sluggish reading test scores.

title: Gore and Bush Trade Jabs On Pensions and Spending
description: Vice President Al Gore warned elderly and middle-age voters today in a campaign sweep across central Florida that Gov. George W. Bush's Social Security proposals would threaten their retirement and the country's economic well-being.

title: Tua Says He Sees Lewiss Weaknesses
description: David Tua, preparing to meet Lennox Lewis for the heavyweight championship next Saturday in Las Vegas, has an analysis of the champion and a strategy to beat him.

title: Tracking Book Bargains
description: To the Editor:

title: Loroupe Hoping To Forget Sydney Disappointment
description: Hardly bigger than a pillow mint, Tegla Loroupe finally settled into a plush couch lined with overstuffed cushions that all but gobbled up her indefatigable body. Just an hour after her 10-hour flight arrived Tuesday afternoon, the fresh-pressed Loroupe had been roaming the hotel suite of the New York City Marathon organizers, popping grapes and chatting with whomever she saw.

title: F.B.I. and Yemen Said to Be Near an Agreement on Investigation of the Cole Blast
description: Yemen's prime minister said today that American and Yemeni negotiators were close to working out an agreement under which agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation could attend Yemeni security police questioning of witnesses and suspects in the suicide bombing of the destroyer Cole, with the right to write down ''follow up'' questions that Yemeni investigators could put to those under questioning.

title: Squawking and Swaggering Their Way Through a Ribald Irish Carnival
description: The Irish writer Brendan Behan was one of literature's legendary drunks, and his 1958 play ''The Hostage,'' a fond satire aimed at a society scrambled by decades of confusing political strife, has the shape and spirit of an exuberant binge. It opens with a party, proceeds in hilarity, devolves into disastrous chaos and wakes up at the end with a rueful wink as though it were all a self-indulgent hoot.

title: 60's Design, More or Less
description: ''It's not a museum,'' said David Martin, of Lido, a store he and a partner opened last month in the Flatiron district. So when Mr. Martin finds a piece of midcentury modern furniture, he feels free to change the upholstery. ''I buy it for the look,'' he said. The steel lamp of unknown origin, below left, is one of a pair ($1,800); the 1960's chair, reupholstered in red leather, below right, is from the Philippines and is also being sold with a mate ($1,390); and the four Danish teak chairs, bottom, by J. L. Moller, probably from the 60's, are from a set of eight ($4,000). Lido is at 32 East 22nd Street, (212) 529-8787.

title: Putin in Paris, Where Talk Is Mainly Of Business
description: It is probably unfair to read much into the fact that on the last day of the three-day visit here of Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, President Jacques Chirac changed his schedule to fly to Cherbourg and visit the spot where a chemical tanker had just sunk in the English Channel.

title: For the Frustrated Carpenter
description: EVERYBODY wants to be Norm,'' said Don Lamond, the designer of Oxo's new Good Grips hammer, referring to Norm Abrams of ''This Old House.'' With sheetrock sales soaring and Home Depot parking lots overflowing, it was bound to happen: the designer hammer has arrived.

title: 4 New Polls Show Bush With an Edge, With Nader a Factor

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ARBY'S INC., New York, which operates a chain of fast-food restaurants, expects to open about 156 new Arby's restaurants in the United States and 11 in Canada by September 2001. Arby's is a subsidiary of Triarc Companies Inc., which is based in White Plains.

title: Rangers Squeeze the Lightning Into a Bottle
description: It has to be the sticks.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- St. Charles, Mo.; Glen Ellyn, Ill.; and West Allis, Wis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, LYN
description: AUSTIN-Lyn. The Hale Matthews Foundation mourns with profound saddness the loss of this extraordinary person of the theatre, whose work we were proud to support over many years. Lyn was very special-a loyal and witty friend, an intuitive and brilliant producer, and, above all, a believer in the power and value of the artist. She remained all her life dedicated to the theatre as one of the highest forms of art. In a world in which mediocrity is too often praised, Lyn held to a purer, higher standard and enabled artists to work at their most unfettered creative best. She will be missed by us all, and we send our sympathy to Diane Wondisford and Lyn's family. William Ashbey, President Richard Hewitt Helen Brann Faith Stewart-Gordon Frances Scaife

title: Spigot Is Shut Off for Devils As They Score Only Once
description: After producing 15 goals in two games, the Devils managed only a goal by Sergei Brylin tonight and settled for a 1-1 tie against the depleted Philadelphia Flyers.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: THE MIDDLE EAST

title: Bidding Deadline Set for Suzuki
description: It's open bidding season on Ichiro Suzuki. Actually, the bids will be closed, but major league clubs were notified late yesterday that if they are interested in securing rights to the Japanese star, they have until 5 p.m. Wednesday to submit a bid. @bt:The seldom-used process is expected to generate significant interest in the 27-year-old Japanese outfielder, who won his seventh successive Pacific League batting championship this year by hitting .387. The problem that interested teams face, however, is that they will be bidding blind. They will have no idea what any other teams bid, so one team could submit a figure millions beyond the next highest bid.

title: CANADIAN GAS ACQUISITION
description: Centrica, an energy distribution company that was split away from British Gas in 1997, made its first purchase of natural gas reserves in Canada, buying the privately owned Avalanche Energy of Calgary, Alberta, for 253.5 million Canadian dollars ($167 million). In August, Centrica bought Direct Energy, a gas distribution company in Ontario, for 912 million Canadian dollars ($600 million). Centrica plans to use Avalanche's production to support Direct Energy's deliveries to 850,000 natural gas customers in Ontario. With further deregulation of Canadian energy markets, Direct Energy intends to sell electricity as well as natural gas across Canada. Timothy Pritchard

title: The U.S. tax system is discouraging married women from working.
description: THE single women of ''Sex and the City'' read the New York Times wedding announcements and mock a bride who was ''until recently'' employed as an account executive. Now that she's found an investment banker to marry, they scoff, she doesn't have to pretend to be interested in her career. These independent women are contemptuous of such behavior. They're looking for love, not a meal ticket.

title: Mets Make Offers
description: In the early innings of Game 5 of the World Series, Turk Wendell turned in the dugout to his close friend, Rick Reed, and said, ``This might be the last game we play together.'' Reed told Wendell not to count on it. Both of them, Reed said, might still come back to the Mets.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in Business Day yesterday about two financially troubled South Korean construction companies reversed their industry rankings. Dong Ah Construction Industrial, which said it would seek bankruptcy protection, is the second-largest in South Korea. Hyundai Engineering and Construction, which avoided insolvency, is the largest.

title: QUEBECOR SAYS IT WANTS TO REPLACE ABITIBI CHAIRMAN
description: Quebecor Inc. wants to remove the chief executive of Abitibi-Consolidated Inc., John Weaver, and replace him with Michel Desbiens, who had been chairman of Abitibi before his resignation, a spokesman for Quebecor said. Quebecor is Abitibi's largest shareholder, with an 11 percent stake, and controls 3 seats on Abitibi's 12-seat board. Abitibi is the world's largest newsprint maker; Quebecor is a media holding company. Both are based in Montreal.

title: Progress in Kosovo
description: The United Nations has rarely taken on a mission as complex and challenging as the rebuilding of Kosovo, and for the first year it stumbled. While shelter and food were provided for a flood of returning Albanians and the Kosovo Liberation Army was partially disarmed, little progress was made on rebuilding the economy, courts, police and other institutions. Worst of all, the peacekeepers and police were unable to protect Serbs and Gypsies from Albanian revenge killings.

title: Adjusting Web Colors for the Colorblind
description: LIKE many people with a colorblind spouse, Christine Rigden is occasionally surprised by her husband's reactions. ''He'll look at a software interface and say, 'That's a really lurid yellow.' But I look at it and think, 'It's just a nice shade of copper brown.' ''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Clinton's campaigning for Senate and House candidates referred inaccurately to Eleanor Jordan of Kentucky, who is running for the House. She is the only black woman in the Kentucky Legislature, not the only black member.

title: Hampton Leaves Door Open for Mets
description: Mike Hampton and his agent are aware of what the Mets did immediately after the 1998 season. With two of their premier players eligible for free agency, the Mets signed both to lucrative long-term deals. Mike Piazza and Al Leiter never got onto the open market.

title: Gandhi's Spirit Hovers as India Debates Iodized Salt
description: India has made tremendous progress in eradicating the ancient scourge of iodine deficiency -- the single most preventable cause of mental retardation -- by making cheap, iodized salt available to most of its billion people. But a recent government decision has jeopardized these advances, medical researchers say.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: The Senators Give Holmqvist a Rude Welcome
description: KANATA, Ontario, Nov. 2  Rangers Coach Ron Low could not have asked for more balance. Each of his four lines recorded a goal here tonight. It still was not enough.

title: Charter School Rigidity
description: To the Editor:

title: Van Gundy Says The Bottom Line In Opening Loss Is Lack of Effort
description: Coach Jeff Van Gundy offered little analysis of the Knicks' dreadful performance after their humiliating season-opening loss to the Philadelphia 76ers on Tuesday night. He basically said that the 76ers played hard and well, and that the Knicks did not.

title: DEUTSCHE BANK PROFIT SOARS
description: Deutsche Bank reported a strong increase in profits today, largely the result of rapid growth in securities trading. Net income rose nearly ninefold in the third quarter, compared to the comparable period last year, to 591 million euros ($504 million) from 67 million euros ($56.9 million). Much of the increase reflects the impact last year of huge bonuses that were paid to retain executives at Bankers Trust, which Deutsche Bank had just acquired. Even so, the new results were stronger than analysts had forecast, although Deutsche Bank still trails behind the biggest Wall Street investment banks in the lucrative business of advising on mergers and acquisitions. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Ralph Nader's High-Wire Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Portland Shrugs Off A Turn in the Spotlight
description: For a moment on Monday morning, Sandra Shipley thought she might head over to Portland Community College to see the man she prefers to be the next president of the United States, Vice President Al Gore.

title: Home Decoration: Last Chapter; At Queens Cemetery, Styles Form an Ethnic History
description: For Rose Di Mango, there is no such thing as a quick trip to the cemetery.

title: I.B.M. AND BANKS PLAN CHECK SYSTEM
description: Chase Manhattan Bank, Bank of America and I.B.M. have established a venture called Viewpointe Archive Services to store electronic images of checks using technology developed by I.B.M. and Chase. The companies said that the shared archive would be marketed to all banks as a way to speed check clearing, which now takes up to 12 steps, and that such centralized imaging could cut check processing costs by up to 30 percent. Banks on the system could also use it to give customers access to electronic copies of their checks over the Internet. Viewpointe expects to eventually expand beyond checks to archiving other bank transactions. Barnaby J. Feder

title: A Classroom of Crayons and CD-ROM's
description: To the Editor:

title: Majors Are Scrambling For Japanese Outfielder
description: A good-hitting 27-year-old outfielder is about to become the central figure in a two-pronged test of a basically untried system designed to transfer Japanese players to the United States. If the system works, the outfielder, Ichiro Suzuki, could become the first Japanese position player to play in the major leagues in this country.

title: Laptop Makes Weepers Out of Finders
description: Over the past year there have been some embarrassing incidents where laptops containing sensitive data have vanished. Among those left blushing was Irwin Jacobs, the chief executive and founder of Qualcomm who lost a laptop containing several years' worth of confidential corporate and personal information earlier this fall.

title: Patent Lawsuit Is Settled
description: Baxter International Inc. has settled a patent lawsuit with the Spectranetics Corporation, which says it will take a $4 million charge to resolve the litigation. Baxter sued in federal court in Delaware in August 1999, saying Spectranetics was infringing three patents awarded since 1987 for laser-surgery equipment. Spectranetics will pay back royalties and license the technology from Baxter through 2005.

title: Internet Complaints Are Climbing, Spitzer Says
description: The New York State attorney general's office said yesterday that consumer complaints to the office about Internet shopping and other online matters could be twice as numerous this year as they were two years ago, reflecting a steady rise in Internet use.

title: Emotional Appeal Urges Blacks to Vote
description: The N.A.A.C.P. began a $2 million advertising campaign last week featuring Renee Mullins, the daughter of James Byrd Jr. of Texas, who was chained to a truck and dragged to his death in 1998. This television commercial briefly recounts the story of his killing and urges viewers to vote on Nov. 7. An earlier advertisement asked viewers to call Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and demand that he support hate crimes legislation. The 30-second advertisements are being shown in 10 contested states with large numbers of African-American residents.

title: INTERNATIONAL TRUCK WILL LAY OFF 1,851 WORKERS
description: The International Truck and Engine Corporation, a unit of Navistar International , expects to eliminate 1,851 jobs, or nearly 40 percent of the work force, at its plant in Springfield, Ohio, by the end of 2003, a spokeswoman said. The plant will be retooled to produce the company's next-generation medium-duty truck model and cab assemblies, and fewer workers will be needed to meet the company's sales forecasts for the truck. Union officials said that they had been expecting some cutbacks, but warned that the plant might be understaffed if demand is strong.

title: The Napster Deal
description: The deal between Napster, the 18-month-old upstart music site, and Bertelsmann, the giant media conglomerate, may irritate the 40 million Napster users who have gotten use to grabbing music free online. But the deal deserves praise. It preserves traditional protection for copyrights. If followed by the rest of the industry, the deal would allow Napster to develop its file-sharing technology without facing the threat of being shut down or fined heavily for fomenting copyright infringement. The deal also offers long-term benefits to consumers, although they will lose their free ride.

title: Metro Business Briefing; WNBC-TV NEWS DIRECTOR LEAVING
description: Paula Madison, left, one of the few black female news directors in the country and the woman who helped WNBC-TV become the No. 1 station in the New York market, is leaving to become the president and general manager of KNBC-TV in Los Angeles.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Ultimate G.P.S. Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Fusaichi Pegasus Listed As Favorite in Classic
description: Fusaichi Pegasus, the ''flying horse'' who won the Kentucky Derby and then was syndicated for $60 million, was made the 8-5 favorite for the final performance of his career Saturday in the $4.7 million Breeders' Cup Classic, a race that could leave him with the ultimate honor in racing, Horse of the Year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELMAN, RENEE
description: ADELMAN-Renee. Of Lawrence, N.Y. and Boca Raton, FL. Passed away tragically and suddenly on Monday, October 30, 2000. Devoted wife of Seymour, beloved mother of Marcia A. Delman and Debra Buckley. Adored grandmother of Ariel and Ross Buckley, who gave Renee so much joy, pride and pleasure during her life. She is also survived by her brother, Leonard Kleiman & his family. She will always be kept in our hearts, always remembered for her joyful spirit, vitality, kindness, music-making and delightful wit. Her loving memory lives in our dreams and our lives. Forever in our hearts, we will miss her more with each passing day.

title: A New York Courthouse Is Left Nameless in the Wake of Partisan Fighting in Congress
description: The tit-for-tat started last month when Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat, blocked a bill by Representative Rick A. Lazio, a Long Island Republican, to name a new federal courthouse in Mr. Lazio's district after Theodore Roosevelt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALENTINE, THOMAS
description: VALENTINE-Thomas. Of Blauvelt, New York, on November 1, 2000. Retired driver for The New York Times. Beloved husband of Geraldine (nee McNaughton). Devoted father of James Valentine and Eileen Verde. Dear brother of Sister Katherine Thomas. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, 9:30 AM at St. Catherine's RC Church, Blauvelt, NY. Burial, St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Visiting hours, Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Moritz Funeral Home, 98 Route 303, Tappan, NY.

title: Seagram Runs Into Trouble In Sale of Alcohol Business
description: The Seagram Company is facing potential hurdles as it tries to sell its wine and spirits business, people close to the negotiations said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURSTEIN, JOEL
description: BURSTEIN-Joel. Died on 11/2/90. Beloved husband of Eleanor, father of David, Daniel, Jonathan, Michael, and Joshua. Martyr of the 1990 Daily News strike. We miss you still

title: Yes to Transportation Bonds
description: New Yorkers will be doing more than electing hundreds of officeholders throughout the state on Tuesday. They will also have an opportunity to approve a $3.8 billion bond issue that, if enacted, would speed improvements in New York City's mass transit system and upgrade highways and rail links crucial to the upstate economy. Incurring new borrowing is not something to be done lightly by a state already heavily burdened by $37 billion in debt. But the projects to be financed by this issue are so crucial that a ''yes'' vote is merited.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the possible effect on Connecticut politics if Senator Joseph I. Lieberman was elected vice president misstated the timing of a special election that would be held if a member of Congress were appointed to replace him in the Senate. The election for the vacated House seat would be in March 2001, not 2002. The article also misidentified the House seat that could be sought by State Senator John McKinney in such a special election. It is the one held by Representative Christopher Shays, not Nancy L. Johnson.

title: Concern for the Economy Upstate
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign began broadcasting yesterday.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE SUES FRITO-LAY OVER PATENT
description: The Procter & Gamble Company accused the Frito-Lay unit of PepsiCo Inc.of infringing a 1993 patent for the dough used in Pringles potato chips. In a lawsuit filed in federal court in Delaware, Procter & Gamble said Lay's Stax chips, which have been test-marketed in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, but not yet introduced nationally, are made from ingredients similar to Pringles and are shaped into uniform chips and packaged into canisters just as Pringles are. Lay's is the No. 1 brand of potato chips in the United States, with about 35 percent of the $2.37 billion retail market, according to Information Resources Inc. Pringles is the top brand among other types of salty snacks. Frito-Lay declined to comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARGER, ANN PRICE
description: KARGER-Ann Price. Of Hartsdale, NY on Halloween, her favorite holiday. Loving daughter of John and the late Ellie, and stepmother Mimi. Sister of Tom and Mary Jane, beloved aunt of Mike and Dave. Friend of Irma Cusack and Mae Dawson. Funeral services private. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the charity of your choice or to Little Mount Zion Holy Church, White Plains, NY.

title: 2 Dead, 41 Injured in South Korean Plant Explosion
description: SEOUL, Nov. 2 -- Two people were killed and 41 injured in an explosion at a South Korean plastics plant on Thursday, firefighters said. By early evening rescue workers were still struggling to free one person trapped under the rubble, a firefighter said. The explosion occured at 5:08 P.M. (0808 GMT) at a plant operated by Tanil Chemical Co in the industrial city of Ansan, about 50 km (31 miles) southwest of Seoul, firefighters said. They said the explosion engulfed the plant and a nearby plastics factory in flames. "The fire was extinguished at around 7 o'clock (1000 GMT)," Kim Young-jin, a firefighter at the Ansan Fire Station, told Reuters. "No toxic gases were leaked." The cause of the blast was not immediately known. Local YTN television earlier reported toxic gases were believed to have leaked from the plant after explosion. Kim said rescue workers pulled three people from the rubble who were later taken to a nearby hospital. He said seven were hospitalised with serious injuries, and those with minor injuries were treated and allowed to go home.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Oct. 20 misstated a federal judge's action in the case of a black woman who sued the New York Yankees, contending that she was barred from entering the Stadium Club attired in a tank top while white women similarly dressed were admitted. The judge did not dismiss the lawsuit, by V. Whitney Joseph; it is to be heard later this month. He refused the Yankees' request to dismiss the case summarily, and refused Ms. Joseph's request for injunctive relief, saying she had not claimed ''a likelihood of future harm.''

title: After Another Rocky Quarter, Revlon Announces Cutbacks
description: After posting its eighth consecutive quarterly loss yesterday, Revlon Inc., the cosmetics giant controlled by the billionaire Ronald O. Perelman, announced yet another round of cutbacks.

title: Pirro Sentenced To 29 Months In U.S. Prison
description: Four months after being convicted of conspiracy and tax evasion, Albert J. Pirro Jr., the influential Republican businessman and husband of Westchester County's top prosecutor, was sentenced today to 29 months in a federal prison, concluding a trial that put the Pirros' lavish lifestyle on display.

title: Disputed Order Heard on Tape at Bosnia Trial
description: THE HAGUE, Nov. 1  "Kill each and every one. Do not leave a single one alive."

title: Islanders' Owners Purchase New Franchise for Coliseum
description: For Charles Wang, acquiring an Arena Football League team did not involve the secrecy and political intrigue of buying the Islanders for $187.5 million last April.

title: Search Warrant Case Prompts Lively Debate at Supreme Court
description: The State of Illinois asked the Supreme Court today to let police officers bar people from entering their homes during the time it takes to get a warrant to search for drugs or other illegal items that can readily be destroyed.

title: Ruffles and Flourishes to Hail the New Chief
description: NEWS flash: The White House has been redecorated. You haven't heard? Six of the seven ceremonial rooms on the State Floor have been face-lifted, just in time for this week's fife-and-drum celebration of the building's 200th birthday. But unlike the decorating contretemps that have plagued previous administrations -- Nancy Reagan's pricey china, Jacqueline Kennedy's French decorator, Martin Van Buren's gaudy Parisian carpets -- this time out, hardly anyone has noticed the changes.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Time Warner holders look beyond a drop in share price to happy days after the AOL merger.
description: BACK in January, in the good old days when Internet stocks were hot, America Online agreed to buy Time Warner with AOL stock. The deal, if approved by regulators, would leave AOL shareholders with 55 percent of the merged company, even though Time Warner's revenue and cash flow are far greater.

title: Web Company Will Sell Assets To Settle Suit On Music Files
description: Scour, an Internet start-up company that was sued by media companies for letting users exchange copyrighted music and video files, has agreed to sell its assets to an online company with financial backing from the five major record labels.

title: ING Group Selects Agency for Account
description: The ING Group in Amsterdam, a financial services and insurance company, said yesterday that it had named Jordan McGrath Case & Partners/Euro RSCG in New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, as its agency of record to handle marketing and branding assignments in the United States. Billings were estimated at $50 million.

description: EISEN-Nat. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member, Nat Eisen. May the Almighty console the family, together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

description: Urban Box Office Network, one of the largest Internet companies specializing in hip-hop and Latino entertainment, appears headed for the expanding dot-com graveyard.

title: Brazil's Big Scandal
description: Brazil recently established American-style congressional committees to hold hearings into one of the great scandals of the day, the plight of the national soccer team, the ''scratch du ouro,'' the golden team. In recent World Cup qualifying matches, Brazil lost to Paraguay and Chile, and tied with Colombia and Uruguay, all humiliating results. The team coach, Wanderley Luxemburgo, whose job Brazilians' compare with that of the presidency, was dismissed when a junior-varsity version of the team failed to win a medal at the Sydney Olympics.

title: SINGAPORE EXCHANGE TO GO PUBLIC
description: Shareholders in Singapore's combined stock and futures exchange voted to sell shares in the market to the public in an initial offering. The approval clears the way for the exchange to sell stock to the public and strategic investors by year-end, making it the third exchange in Asia after Australia and Hong Kong to trade its shares.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the Nissan Motor Company's results for the six months ended Sept. 30 misstated the number of cars it sold in the United States. The number was 406,000; 9.2 million was the total in the United States for all automakers.

title: In America; Medieval Justice
description: When President George Bush nominated Clarence Thomas to fill a vacancy on the Supreme Court in 1991, one of the other candidates on the president's very short list was a federal judge from Texas named Edith Jones.

title: History Could Be Green Party's Toughest Opponent
description: For as long as he has been running for president, Ralph Nader has made clear that his quest is not about winning, but about building a viable third party, the Greens, that could reform Washington, elect state and local candidates and provide a home for disenchanted liberals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMERSCHLAG, JAMES JOSEPH
description: HAMERSCHLAG-James Joseph. Peacefully on October 30, 2000. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Bennett). Father to James, father in law of Beth, brother to Kay Beaudine, brother in law of Msgr. Austin P. Bennett and the and the late Gerard E. Bennett. Reposing Fairchild and Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave, Garden City, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10 AM, St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church, Garden City. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Parkinson Disease Association. Family will receive friends Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Costly Plan to Promote Alternative Fuels Jolts Arizona
description: It sounded irresistible: buy a car that burns something other than gasoline and the state pays up to 50 percent of the cost; convert an existing gas-burner to alternative fuels and the state pays 100 percent of the cost of the conversion.

title: German Team Enters Challenge
description: The expanding field of America's Cup challengers gained some fresh players yesterday when the first German challenge was announced at the Hamburg Boat Show. Backed by the German plastics conglomerate Illbruck and representing the Dusseldorf Yacht Club, the Illbruck Challenge will be skippered by the American sailor John Kostecki.

title: Comic Books Not Quite Comic
description: The first, most obvious reaction was to push it aside and ask, who needs a comic book, even one that is adult? It's an absurdity. But after absorbing a few pages of funny book panels, the reader is thinking that this is very pleasant entertainment. Particularly if it can be justified on literary grounds. So what was once fantastical nonsense is now edgy and hip, elegant indulgence that is relevant.

title: Riders Compete for National Titles
description: With the American Horse Shows Association and the American Hunter and Jumper Council arguing over control of the rules and regulations for showing hunters, the National Horse Show will open its 117th run tonight without the scarlet-clad riders and their mounts at Madison Square Garden.

title: Sizing Up a Lively Baton From Pittsburgh
description: Almost every music critic in town who was not covering the opening of the New York City Opera's new production of Handel's ''Rinaldo'' seemed to be across the plaza at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night checking out the conductor Mariss Jansons, who led a special nonsubscription concert with the New York Philharmonic.

title: Rice Directs Bush's Operations; Fuerth Is Gore's Key Player : Foreign Policy Teams Coming of Age
description: WASHINGTON  Leon Fuerth, who has wielded quiet influence on foreign policy by tutoring Vice President Al Gore and working within the bowels of the White House, stood uncomfortably before a Washington audience as he addressed the Council on Foreign Relations in September. Recalling the awkwardness of his bar mitzvah, he felt he should repeat the words he said that day: "Today I am a man."

description: To the Editor:

title: Working at Home Today?
description: TWO days a week, Christine Parupia, an executive at Charles Schwab & Company, drives for five minutes from her house in Walnut Creek, Calif., to a towering office building and starts her workday. Her spacious corner office overlooks one of the San Francisco Bay area's most congested freeways, which Ms. Parupia can gaze out on with all the smugness of someone beating the system.

title: India Accuses Pakistan of Border Terrorism
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 1  India rejected Pakistani accusations on Kashmir today, denying that it had stirred tensions along a military cease-fire line and in turn accusing its rival of stepping up acts of border terrorism.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Revlon to Close 3 Plants As Loss Beats Forecasts

title: EIDOS EXECUTIVE RESIGNS
description: Charles Cornwall quit as chief executive of Eidos P.L.C., Britain's biggest maker of video games like ''Tomb Raider,'' and was replaced by Michael McGarvey, the chief operating officer. Mr. Cornwall, 37, postponed his resignation earlier this year as the company's earnings and stock price fell. Eidos said he quit to devote more time to technology and mining interests, including South African gold mines. Eidos's American depository receipts, which traded at $21 last December, rose 3 percent yesterday, to $4.25, on the Nasdaq stock exchange in New York. Alan Cowell

title: CREDIT WARNING ON ARGENTINA
description: The credit rating agency Standard & Poor's placed Argentina on watch for a possible downgrade after a corruption scandal that led to the resignation of the vice president created uncertainty over the government's ability to service its debts. S.& P. said that the country's BB rating for foreign-currency obligations and BBB- local-debt rating were in jeopardy. The Argentine economy has been in recession for two years, and the government has been struggling to cut its budget by $700 million this month to reduce its 2001 deficit to a projected $4.1 billion. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Space Station Astronauts Board Their Orbiting Home
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Eight years after the United States and Russia agreed to cooperate in a permanent human outpost in space, astronauts from both countries arrived at the International Space Station today and began what they hope will be continuous habitation of an expanding research platform 240 miles above Earth.

title: Weeks Before Europeans' Meeting, the Union Is Showing Strains
description: With more than 12 countries lined up to join the European Union in the next decade or so, no one is disputing the need to overhaul the cumbersome institutions of the entire bloc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRZANOWSKI, DR. GERARD
description: CHRZANOWSKI-Dr. Gerard. Died in his home on the Upper East Side on November 1. Eminent psychoanalyst, founder of the Bleuler Institute for Psychotherapy, and co-founder of the International Federation of Psychoanalytic Societies, past president of the William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Society. He is survived by his children, Romola, Peter, Christopher and Dr. Paul Chrzanowski, Barbara Alexander, Francesca Cohn and six grandchildren. Memorial services Friday, 3:30, Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, 288-3500. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to W.A. White Institute, 20 West 74th, New York City 10023.

title: Car Bomb Explodes in Jerusalem, Killing 2
description: JERUSALEM -- A car bomb exploded Thursday near a crowded outdoor market in the heart of Jerusalem, killing at least two people, police said. Ambulances raced to the Mahane Yehuda market, which sells food, vegetables and clothing in Jewish west Jerusalem. Huge plumes of black smoke rose into the sky. Israel TV said that the two people killed were the bombers, but the report could not immediately be confirmed. The blast came shortly before Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat were scheduled to make separate announcements of steps toward a cease-fire -- an effort to stop more than a month of fighting that has left at least 162 people dead, most of them Palestinian. An Israeli soldier, Oshri Atun, said he saw a white sedan being chased by a police van with sirens wailing. The car turned into a side street, and seconds later the bomb exploded, Atun said. Another witness, who only gave his first name, John, said he heard a powerful blast. "When I looked down the street, there was a big fire and people were hurt," he said. There was no immediately claim of responsibility. However, the Palestinian militant groups Hamas and Islamic Jihad have said they would carry out new terror attacks in Israel. The leader of Hamas, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, has said the Palestinian uprising against Israel would continue. Yassin said the protests are an expression of popular anger and could not be reined in by an order from Arafat. Also, Israeli army spokesman Brig. Gen. Ron Kitrey said Thursday he had detailed warnings about attacks, and Israeli security forces have been on high alert for the past few weeks. For years, the market -- spread over several blocks of a predominantly religious neighborhood -- has been a choice target for those trying to sabotage peace between Israelis and Palestinians. It was the scene of a car bomb in November 1998 that killed two suicide bombers and wounded 21 other people. Hamas claimed responsibility. And in July 1997, two militants blew themselves up in the area, killing themselves and 16 shoppers. Dozens have been killed at the market since the 1960s. Palestinian militants with explosives strapped to their bodies have blown themselves up in the narrow, cobblestone lanes or detonated car bombs on the larger streets. The market is closed off to vehicular traffic during shopping hours.

title: Shinahota Journal; Where the Coca Trade Withers, Tourism Sprouts
description: Drug smuggling planes used to land in the middle of the street in this farming town at the height of the cocaine boom in the mid-1980's. Roberto Suarez, the local kingpin, was so rich he offered to pay off Bolivia's entire national debt.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose after an unexpected decline in United States inventories left supplies close to a 24-year low. In New York, crude oil for December delivery rose 55 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $33.25 a barrel.

description: An online health-care company is unveiling a wireless service today that has all the characteristics of a nagging mother, cell-phone style.

title: Bush Backers Say Their Zeal Gives Him an Edge
description: Supporters of Gov. George W. Bush say he has one intangible advantage in his race against Vice President Al Gore: Republicans are far more enthusiastic about his presidential candidacy than Democrats are about Mr. Gore's.

title: State Audit Finds Poor Bill Collection By Fire Department
description: New York City is failing to collect on millions of dollars worth of ambulance bills each year because of a poorly organized and badly managed collection effort, according to an audit released yesterday by state Comptroller H. Carl McCall.
