title: Second Typhoon Hits Philippines Days After Storm Kills 40
description: MANILA, Philippines -- Typhoon Bebinca battered several eastern Philippine provinces with winds of up 150 kilometers (94 miles) per hour Thursday, several days after another typhoon killed 40 people and left 66 others missing, officials said. At midday Thursday, Bebinca was in the vicinity of Catanduanes province, about 360 kilometers (225 miles) east of Manila, with sustained winds of 120 kph (75 mph). It was moving at 19 kph (12 mph) westward and was expected to pass about 90 kilometers (55 miles) north of metropolitan Manila on Friday, said the weather bureau, which raised high storm alerts over about a dozen provinces on the eastern side of the Philippines. Last week, typhoon Xangsane plowed through the main island of Luzon, knocking down power lines, flooding many provinces north of Manila and stranding thousands of commuters, some for two days, on flooded roads. In its latest report, the office of civil defense said Xangsane left 40 people dead, 249 injured and 54 missing. In addition, the coast guard said 12 crew members of a fishing boat not listed by the civil defense office remained missing after their boat sank Sunday off La Union province northwest of Manila. The civil defense office said 1.3 billion pesos (dlrs 25 million) worth of property and infrastructure had been damaged and more than 118,000 people were forced to flee their homes because of typhoon damage and flooding in provinces north and southeast of Manila. After leaving the Philippines early this week, Xangsane moved north toward Taiwan, where flights were canceled and classes suspended. Officials said at least 53 people died and 10 were missing in the island's worst flooding in three decades. A Singapore Airlines plane crashed while taking off Tuesday night in heavy winds and rain from Taipei's airport, killing at least 81 people.

title: Camacho Jr. Overshadows Mosley
description: Until Hector Camacho Jr. entered the room, the loudest thing at yesterday's news conference at Madison Square Garden was Shane Mosley's championship belt. Gold and green, with a big metal buckle and many national flags, the belt was decorated with picture pins, the kind people wear for candidates during political campaigns.

title: Antitrust Trial Involving 2 Airlines Begins
description: After last-minute efforts to reach a settlement failed, lawyers for Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines traded harsh accusations during opening statements today in the federal antitrust case against the two airlines.

title: Four Finalists Named In T. J. Maxx Review
description: T. J. Maxx in Framingham, Mass., the discount retailer owned by the TJX Companies, said yesterday that it had narrowed a review for its broadcast account to four agencies from seven. Spending for the assignment, handled for 24 years by Holland Mark Edmund Ingalls in Boston, was estimated at $20 million.

title: It's a Sculpture And a Chair, Too
description: In 1997, David Shearer opened Totem Design, a home furnishings shop in TriBeCa featuring the work of Karim Rashid, an industrial designer in Manhattan, and plastic furniture by Inflate, a company in London. On Nov. 15, Mr. Shearer, in collaboration with Tricia Collins Contemporary Art, will open Totem Gallery in SoHo, with six-week exhibitions and sales of new furniture and art -- sometimes created by the same person. ''Lots of designers consider themselves artists and view a chair as a sculpture, a carpet as a painting,'' Mr. Shearer said. Mr. Rashid designed the 1,500-square-foot gallery and stars in its first show, with furniture (including the Soft Lamp, left, $1,560) and digital art. The cutout wall forms a small space that is ''sensual but minimal at the same time,'' Mr. Rashid said. The Totem Gallery is at 83 Grand Street (near Wooster Street).

title: Azingers Hard Journey Leads to Tour Championship
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 1  When Paul Azinger qualified for the Tour Championship in 1993, he never imagined it would take him seven years to get back.

title: NEW BID ROILS DUTCH MERGER
description: Buhrmann, a major office supplies distributor in Europe and, through its Corporate Express unit, the United States, said it might bid about 1 billion euros ($855 million) for two Dutch rivals, Royal Ahrend and the Samas Groep, disrupting their planned merger. Buhrmann said that adding Ahrend and Samas would make it Europe's market leader in office supplies and that it would sell the companies' office furniture businesses, which together would be Europe's largest. Ahrend's chief executive, Hans Koenders, said he opposed Buhrmann's bid and preferred Samas's friendly merger offer. Ahrend and Samas shares rose sharply on the news; Buhrmann's slipped.

title: Remembering Steverino
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: On Deck in Japan

title: Where Age Is No Barrier To High-Level Competition
description: More than any other sport or recreation, bridge offers its disciples the possibility of competing at an advanced age. Not long ago England had Julia Chadwick, who played regularly in tournaments when she was over 100. This year Jessel Rothfield of Australia represented his country in the Bermuda Bowl at 82, a record.

title: Council Finds Old Sales Tax Is Still Assessed
description: An investigation by the New York City Council has found that retailers continued to charge the 8.25 percent state sales tax on baby goods, hats, gloves and other merchandise even though the items were exempted from the tax on March 1.

title: A Beer Garden in Astoria Shelters a Lost Era
description: THE beer garden at Bohemian Hall and Park in Astoria isn't a garden in the usual sense of the word. It's a grove of about 20 old trees -- maples, sycamores and lindens -- enclosed by a high wall. It has the sheltering feel of an ancient European village, where the townspeople gather for beer and gossip.

title: The Name Means Joy, and the Audience Feels It
description: ''Jabula,'' the second new work in American Ballet Theater's season at City Center, is a vague ritual with unmistakable energy. On Saturday night, the audience gave a whooping ovation to this company premiere by the Australian choreographer Natalie Weir.

title: Mixed Media and Mixed Metaphors Recall a Golden Era
description: Say ''Harlem Renaissance'' and the floor is yours: such is the lingering power, both literal and symbolic, of black American art of the 1920's. But you must be specific, for if it's one of those buzz-terms that legitimize any new labor of culture, it also means about a dozen different things. The Carnegie Hall Jazz Band, led by Jon Faddis, opened its season last Thursday night with a mixed-media concert about the Harlem Renaissance. The show included theater music, some newly commissioned jazz, dancing and literature. It was a tough assignment, and though the concert wasn't always exciting, it was energetically programmed.

title: Iona Picked to Win The M.A.A.C. Title
description: Coach Jeff Ruland eased the pressure on his Iona program last season by taking the Gaels to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament for the first time during his tenure.

title: Jets Must Brace for Return of Broncos' Davis
description: The report came early in the week: running back Terrell Davis, who has missed five games with an injured left ankle and has rushed for only 99 yards this season, will return for the Denver Broncos when they face the Jets on Sunday.

title: Free PC's for Schools Are Too Good to Last
description: ZapMe, a company that promised to connect the nation's schools to the Internet through free computers as long as it could deliver advertising to the students, has now said it may have to charge the schools because of tough financial times.

title: An Ad and Several Mailings Create Problems for Lazio

title: U.S. Auto Sales Sag, Another Slowdown Sign
description: Not even aggressive discounting by automakers could lift sales of new cars and light trucks last month, and bloated inventories of unsold models have led to the closing for a week of 8 of the nation's 55 auto assembly plants.

title: Electronic Voting Machines Let Disabled Choose in Private
description: DURING this election season, some blind and visually impaired voters will be able to cast their ballots in private for the first time using an electronic voting system that has been adapted for use by the disabled.

title: Log Off, John Boy, cc: Grandpa Walton
description: ROY SMITH knew that his children -- Robin, 14, Roy, 12, and Tyler, 11 -- needed computer access for schoolwork, but he did not want to share his home office machine. He had homework of his own to do. And while he could envision buying them each a computer, he did not want to have to purchase three printers and three scanners and pay for three Internet connections as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVITUSO, MICHAEL S.
description: RIVITUSO-Michael S. On November 1, 2000. Commander of the American Legion Post 510 in Bayside, NY. Fundraiser of Iris Hill Nursery School, Bellerose, NY. Beloved husband of Eva R. Loving father of Louis, Angelo and JoAnn Smith. Dear brother of Lucy Scalise, Josephine Rivituso, Fannie Pugliese and Frances Rivituso. Cherished grandfather of six and great grandfather of two. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193rd St. Visiting hours 2-5 and 710PM. Funeral Mass Friday, 10:30AM, St. Robert Bellarmine R.C. Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: TWO AT MERRILL LYNCH REGISTER TO SELL SHARES
description: The chairman of the Merrill Lynch & Company brokerage business and his predecessor registered to sell more than $45 million of Merrill stock. E. Stanley O'Neal filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 404,634 shares and John L. Steffens, a vice chairman whom Mr. O'Neal succeeded in February, filed to sell 341,520 shares. A Merrill spokesman cited ''diversification and year-end tax planning'' as reasons for the sales. Earlier this year, Mr. Steffens had registered to sell shares worth about $32 million. Patrick McGeehan

title: Keeper of Village's Folk Tradition Battles Eviction
description: The apartment is on the Greenwich Village side of West Houston Street, a railroad walk-up with naked light bulbs casting a yellow glow over worn furniture, cracked walls and a dusty collection of old books and LP's. The bathtub is in the kitchen, and the toilet down the hall. A luxury apartment it is not.

title: Labor Tailors Its Vote-for-Gore Message, State by State

title: Swiss Charge 8 Sports Workers In Deaths of 21 Canyon Tourists
description: Police officials charged eight employees of a defunct adventure sports company today with manslaughter in the deaths of 21 people who drowned last year on a canyoning trip in the Alps.

title: TURKISH BANK SALES TO OMIT BAD LOANS
description: Turkey's banking supervisory board will probably replace the bad loans from financially troubled banks under its control with special-issue government bonds before it sells the banks in the next few months, according to analysts. The board is expected to announce its plans for eight seized banks this week. The International Monetary Fund and World Bank are pushing Turkey to sell the banks to limit their damage to government finances. The exact amount of the bad loans is not known, but it is thought be similar to the $7 billion the banks have posted as losses since they were taken over, analysts said.

title: Building Art Collections For Artists of Diplomacy
description: How would you like to have a dreamy painting by Milton Avery over your bed, an Edward Hopper in your dining room, a Christo sketch and a Robert Rauschenberg fresco in your living room, with Jasper Johns's twin American flags over the fireplace for good measure?

title: A Classic Flutters Off to Sunnier Climes
description: Firebirds can migrate.

title: Is He or Isn't He a Nazi? His Hairdresser Knows for Sure
description: In the home stretch of rehearsals for the Jewish Repertory Theater's production of ''Big Potato,'' the playwright Arthur Laurents and the director Richard Sabellico publicly expressed their disappointment with the show, flummoxing the artistic director of the Jewish Repertory Theater, Ran Avni, who declined their request not to open the show to critics.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: TV Vehicles Running on Retreads; In New Sitcoms, Stars Often Play Themselves or Throwback Characters
description: While we weren't paying attention, Dan from ''Roseanne'' discovered that he was gay and Kramer from ''Seinfeld'' became a detective. Bette Midler tried to channel Lucille Ball, while Geena Davis moved to the suburbs to try to rescue her career. And somehow Gabriel Byrne morphed into Danny Thomas.

title: School Officials in Westchester Ask State to Suspend 4 New Tests
description: School superintendents from Westchester County -- home to some of the state's best schools -- have asked the State Education Department to suspend four new eighth-grade tests to be given this spring, arguing that the tests will overload students who have not yet adjusted to the existing tests.

title: Officer and Suspect Are Shot As Police Rescue a Woman
description: A police officer and a man suspected of kidnapping his former girlfriend were shot in an exchange of gunfire in Brooklyn yesterday when officers, responding to a frantic telephone call from the woman, arrived to rescue her, the police said.

title: The Go-Getter's Guide to Better Nesting
description: IT'S one of the oldest stories in Manhattan. Philip Galanes and Michael Haverland had outgrown the one-bedroom studio they shared in a 1920's apartment building on University Place, but found themselves priced out of the market for something bigger. Their setback became an opportunity for invention when they decided to stay put and combine two apartments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHMAN, ADELE RONSON NAHM
description: REICHMAN-Adele Ronson Nahm, actress. Died October 31, 2000 in New York City. Her career began in the 1920s in radio and on the stage and continued until her death. Predeceased by her husbands, Horace H. Nahm and Theodore Reichman, DDS. Mother of Dorothy Nahm Friedberg, M.D. and Nancy Nahm Sidhu, mother-in-law of Neal Friedberg, M.D. and Dip Singh Sidhu, M.D. Stepmother of Lee Reichman, M.D., Rose Reichman, David Reichman and Sheila Uniti, grandmother of Abbe and Michael Friedberg and Daniel and Deborah Gar Reichman, aunt of Pat Stewart. Died in her sleep one day after returning from a trip to Venice with her family. An unforgettable woman of great spirit who will live through the memory of all those who knew her. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 5, 3:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Jordanian Struggles to Keep Ties to Israel
description: Omar Salah, the 33-year-old chairman of the Century Investment Group, a diversified Jordanian holding company, was sitting in his office surveying the wreckage of the new Middle East.

title: AMAZON MOVES INTO JAPAN . . .
description: The online retailer Amazon.com introduced a Japanese-language Web site offering more than 1.7 million Japanese and English titles. The new site (Amazon.co.jp) will also include book reviews, recommendation lists and interviews with authors and translators. ''We can now make our customer-centric shopping experience -- great service, selection and convenience -- available to everyone looking for popular or hard-to-find Japanese-language books,'' said Jeff Bezos, above, the company's chief executive. Japan is Amazon's fourth foreign operation, after Germany, Britain and France, and the first one in Asia. Despite Mr. Bezos's enthusiasm, many analysts and industry observers are cool on Amazon's move in Japan. The market has begun to look crowded, with dozens of players including Kinokuniya, a big book retailer; E-Shopping Books, backed by Softbank; and Bertelsmann's BOL.com. Miki Tanikawa

title: TELENOR, NORWEGIAN PHONE COMPANY, TO SELL STOCK
description: The Norwegian government plans to sell about 25 percent of Telenor A.S., the country's largest phone company, in an initial public offering later this month, a government official said. Institutional investors will be able to bid for shares from Nov. 13 to Dec. 1, and private investors from Nov. 17 to Nov. 30, an industry ministry spokesman said. The offering price will be set Dec. 2 or 3, and the shares will start trading Dec. 4. Valued by analysts at $9.7 billion or more, Telenor will be one of the two largest companies on the Oslo Stock Exchange after the sale, the other being Norsk Hydro, an oil and aluminum maker. The shares may also be listed on Nasdaq.

title: U.S. Proposes Changes in Electricity Marketing in California
description: Citing the ''seriously flawed'' nature of the California electricity market, which was plagued with price spikes and brownouts this summer, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission proposed changes yesterday in the sale and pricing of electricity intended to overhaul deregulation in the state.

title: Metro Business Briefing; EX-FINANCIER INDICTED AGAIN
description: Robert E. Brennan, the former financier who was indicted in August on charges that he concealed $500,000 in gambling winnings from a bankruptcy trustee, was indicted again yesterday. He was charged with hiding $4 million in bonds, the United States attorney's office in Newark said.

title: Indian Lawsuits on School Abuse May Bankrupt Canada Churches
description: Lawsuits filed by thousands of former Indian boarding school students in Canada, claiming sexual, physical and ''cultural'' abuse, threaten to swamp the financial resources of four mainstream Christian churches that ran the schools until 1970.

title: LYCOS EUROPE BUYING FRENCH PORTAL
description: Lycos Europe has agreed to purchase the French Internet portal company MultiMania for stock worth 222 million euros ($188 million). Lycos Europe said the deal, which catapults it into the No. 2 spot in France, gave it a leading position among portal companies across the Continent in terms of revenue, monthly page views and visitors. Lycos Europe recently moved into the leading slot in Scandinavia when it bought a Swedish portal company, Spray Network. Suzanne Kapner

title: Gore and Bush Clashing Over Retirement Proposals
description: As the presidential race draws to a close, Vice President Al Gore is asserting that Gov. George W. Bush's plan to create personal investment accounts within Social Security would eat up $1 trillion needed to pay benefits to current retirees.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: NEW STEPS ARE SET ON ENDING VIOLENCE IN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: After a chaotic day of gun battles and helicopter attacks, the Israelis and Palestinians agreed early this morning on steps to try to halt more than a month of violence.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Hewlett-Packard sends Amazon.com a big 'thank you' just in time for the holidays.
description: ADVERTISING run by a supplier on behalf of a customer usually attracts as much attention as a Bush-Cheney rally in Cambridge, Mass., or a Gore-Lieberman rally in Salt Lake City. But a television campaign that the Hewlett-Packard Company is about to start running on behalf of Amazon.com should turn some heads.

title: Observing, Yet Shunning, Political System
description: Outside the Shady Rest tourist cabins, a relic of the 1930's flaking away on old Route 66, Charles W. Murphy and his low-rent neighbors along this margin of the American dream broke the seal on a half pint of Kentucky Deluxe whiskey.

title: The Gore Method
description: To the Editor:

title: Democratic Senate Seat Is Anything but Secure
description: It was never supposed to be this hard for Nevada Democrats to hold onto Senator Richard H. Bryan's seat after Mr. Bryan announced 20 months ago that he would not seek a third term.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORNBURG, JARED PAUL
description: DORNBURG-Jared Paul. On Sunday, October 29, 2000, of Washington D.C. Beloved husband of Kimiko Watanabe Dornburg. Loving father of Jed and Erica Miwa Dornburg. Brother of Ian (Wanda) Dornburg and Roger (Ann) Dornburg. Memorial service will be held at DeVol Funeral Home, 2222 Wisconsin Ave. N.W., Washington D.C., Friday, Nov. 3rd at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: At a Virtual Garage Sale, It Frequently Pays to Wait
description: OVER the years, my friends Ford and Jean have become well known for their garage sales. When they lived in a prime location across from the town park, the heavy traffic they attracted resembled Fifth Avenue on the day after Thanksgiving. And there was some discussion about whether the police should assign a special detail to keep things moving.

title: Amid Widening Losses, Covad Chairman Resigns
description: The chairman and chief executive of the Covad Communications Group, Robert E. Knowling Jr., resigned yesterday in the latest reflection of the turmoil at several small companies providing high-speed Internet access that have failed to meet investors' expectations.

title: POWER PROBLEMS MAY REDUCE KAISER ALUMINUM OUTPUT
description: The Kaiser Aluminum Corporation said yesterday that it would have to pay 20 percent more for power next year in Washington State and would be allocated less power, threatening to further choke the company's aluminum production. The company, the nation's No. 2 producer behind Alcoa, now makes about 138,000 metric tons of aluminum a year in Washington, where its only two United States plants are situated. But its new five-year contract with the Bonneville Power Administration, which takes effect in October 2001, will cut output to about 110,000 metric tons annually.

title: Economics as the Path to Foreign Policy
description: DAVE H. WILLIAMS, the new chairman of the Foreign Policy Association, grins when asked if he can name the political leaders of Taiwan, India, Pakistan or Chechnya.

title: New Circuit Breaker for Planes and Homes Is the Sensitive Type
description: THE humble circuit breaker, an electrical device barely smarter than a toaster, is going digital, as a way to reduce the risk of fires on the ground and in the air.

title: Scott's First Nets' Step Is on Wrong Foot
description: Nets Coach Byron Scott watched the film at 11 this morning with his team and realized that opening night was worse than he thought.

title: 2 in Terror Case Suspected in Stabbing of Guard at Federal Jail
description: A guard at the federal jail in Manhattan was stabbed in the eye and critically injured yesterday by one of the defendants who is awaiting trial in the bombings of two American embassies in Africa, officials and others said. They said a second defendant was also involved in the assault, which left the guard in a coma.

title: Aetna's Net Declined 14% in 3rd Quarter
description: Aetna said today that its third-quarter profit fell 14 percent as medical costs rose.

title: Why West's Billions Failed to Give Russia a Robust Economy
description: Western powers gave tens of billions of dollars in aid to Russia with no comprehensive strategy, and, at least partly as a result, the programs failed to bring about the desired capitalist transition there, a Congressional study has concluded.

title: Patterns by the Yard
description: Since 1984, when K. A. International opened its first home furnishings store in Madrid, the company has expanded to 300 outlets in 35 countries. On Nov. 9, it will arrive in Manhattan. Although the company also sells chairs, sofas and stools, it is known for its inventory of 800 fabrics, mostly cotton, linen and raffia, with some polyester -- generally selling for around $30 a yard. The New York franchise, owned by Regina Oben, 27, a former investment banker, is at 1119-1125 Third Avenue near 65th Street.

title: For Those Who Feel Squeamish in the Dark
description: WHEN I was growing up outside Boston, I thought a monster lived in our attic. Thirty-some years later and 3,000 miles away, that monster has been brought back to life by Blair Witch Volume 1: Rustin Parr. In so doing, it raises a useful question about explicit and implicit threats within games. Namely: How many monsters are too many?

title: This Is the House That Students Built
description: Since the 1960's, first-year graduate students at the Yale School of Architecture have been required to design and build a project -- from bandstands and pavilions to houses -- in or around New Haven. Tomorrow, Pamela Joyce, a social worker in New Haven, will move into the student-built yellow clapboard house, left, which she bought for $95,000. The 1,500-square-foot, two-story house is in the Newhallville section of the city.

title: Ex-Queens School Chief Charged In $6 Million Bid-Rigging Scheme
description: A former school superintendent in Queens was charged yesterday with taking bribes valued at more than $900,000 to rig bids for $6 million in computer equipment for 19 schools.

title: Labor Tailors Its Vote-for-Gore Message, State by State
description: At the giant DaimlerChrysler engine plant here, 75 volunteers from the United Automobile Workers distributed a leaflet today seeking to reassure the factory's employees, many of whom hunt on weekends, that Vice President Al Gore's gun control proposals would in no way hurt sportsmen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, STEVE
description: ALLEN-Steve. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed longtime Member Steve Allen. He put the gold in the golden age of television, not to mention the rhythm. His genius for comedy and for music has given him an esteemed and valued place in the annals of show business. We are honored and proud to have been touched by this pioneer of American Television. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Sally Jessy Raphael, Prior David B. Cornstein, Treasurer Stewie Stone, Scribe Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Deal by Berkshire Hathaway Raises Presence in Lloyd's
description: Reinforcing its presence in the Lloyd's of London $10 billion commercial insurance market, Berkshire Hathaway, the holding company of the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett, agreed to buy the Marlborough Underwriting Agency for an undisclosed sum from CGNU P.L.C., Britain's biggest insurer, CGNU said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Personal Shopper column last Thursday, about a show house called the Traditional Home Built for Women, omitted part of the name of the organization that is to benefit. It is the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, not the Breast Cancer Foundation.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is a lot of denial, people thinking this is a bad dream. I told a priest recently, 'When your rectory gets sold out from underneath you and you are living in the street, maybe you will understand this is for real.'''

title: Concern for Foreign Relations and a Distaste for Politics as Usual : From Students, a Global Perspective
description: The following is an unscientific sampling of the views of students around the world on the U.S. election.

title: Republicans Claim an Edge: A Will to Win
description: Of all the factors driving voters to the polls next week, Republicans say they expect their candidate to benefit most from an intangible advantage: Republicans are far more energized about Gov. George W. Bush than Democrats are about Vice President Al Gore.

title: HEWLETT SAID TO CUT OFFER FOR CONSULTANT
description: While Hewlett-Packard's negotiations to acquire the consulting arm of PricewaterhouseCoopers are continuing, executives close to the talks said that the offering price had been lowered from a range of $17 billion to $18 billion to less than $15 billion. The price has been adjusted, the executives said, because the value of consulting operations had fallen since talks on the deal began. The executives said they hoped to announce the details of a final agreement in the next several weeks. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: PC Help In a Hurry, For a Fee
description: NO matter what sort of computer, new or old, you place in your home or office or even toss in your briefcase, the moment will arrive, as unavoidably as death and taxes, when your computer fails to do what it is supposed to do.

title: CHIQUITA INVESTOR IS PUSHING FOR HIGHER STOCK PRICE
description: The Consolidated Fruit Corporation, a Panamanian company that owns 9.9 percent of Chiquita Brands, is seeking talks about ''a possible transaction'' or other ways to increase Chiquita's stock price. Consolidated disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had written to Carl Lindner, the chairman of Chiquita, to ask for talks, and to request a list of Chiquita shareholders and an opportunity to inspect ''certain material contracts'' of the company. Mr. Lindner and Chiquita's president, Steven Warshaw, were not available for comment. Profits at Chiquita, based in Cincinnati, have been dragged down by a long-running trade dispute between the United States and the European Union that has caused a banana surplus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSCHER, LINDA
description: LIPSCHER-Linda. Loving wife of Allan. Beloved mother of Mali and Kim. Loving sister of Les Silverman and cherished aunt of Brad and Jon. Services today at Garlick Kirschenbaum Chapels, Coney Island Ave. and Ave. H, at 12 PM.

title: Harshest Shot of the Battle
description: This 30-second ad, titled ''Already,'' was released yesterday by Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate from New Jersey, in his campaign against the Republican candidate, Bob Franks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, LYN
description: AUSTIN-Lyn. The Board, staff and artists of Music-Theatre Group are deeply saddened by the sudden death on October 29th of its innovative leader and fearless founder. Her 30 years of productions and creative use of artists are unique in the American theater. A funeral service will be held at St. James Church, 71st and Madison, on Saturday, November 4 at 2PM. A memorial tribute will be announced later. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Music-Theatre Group Fund For New Work, 30 West 26 Street, suite 1001, New York, New York 10010.

title: Some Owners Bet Big At the Breeders' Cup
description: Gander had just run the race of a lifetime, finishing second to Albert the Great in the Grade I Jockey Club Gold Cup. As Tonja Terranova, the assistant trainer, led the horse off the track at Belmont Park 18 days ago, she turned to Gander's owners and blurted, ''We got to go.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHEELER, FRANK R.
description: WHEELER-Frank R. November 3, 1989. Not a day goes by. Miss you always. Love, Sis and The Kid

title: Private Buildings Sought for Public Schools
description: Trying to address a shortage of sites on which to build new schools, Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday that he wanted to ask private real estate developers to construct mixed-use buildings that would put commercial offices or apartments on top of new schools.

title: In Space: The Costs, the Dreams
description: To the Editor:

title: Car Bomb Kills 2 Israelis and Threatens Truce Effort
description: Threatening an early morning truce agreement, a car bomb killed two Israelis this afternoon as it exploded near an open-air market that was a favorite target of Islamic groups during previous waves of terrorism.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Despite Stock Sale Limits, Corzine Pledges Blind Trust

title: Rallying Voters and Relishing a Leading Role
description: The curtains have not quite been drawn around Charlton Heston's holding room backstage at the big National Rifle Association rally here, so thatin the moment before entering, one sees the old actor seated there, alone. He is wearing a gray suit and those cloth slippers the airlines hand out and is looking straight ahead, his expression not sad, exactly, but not anything -- still in a way not often glimpsed in the cell phone century, at least not on the campaign trail in the final days of a close presidential race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, MINNA (ENGELMAN)
description: WALLACH-Minna (Engelman). On October 29, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Harry Wallach. Loving sister of Howard, Isadore and the late Abraham & Max Engelman. Also survived by nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Services private.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a Critic's Notebook article about familiar stars and themes in new television sitcoms misidentified the actor at the center of a scene from an episode of ''The Michael Richards Show.'' He is Ed Begley Jr.; Mr. Richards was pictured at the right.

title: Bipartisan Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, STUART M.
description: HIRSCH-Stuart M. It is with profound sadness that we share the news of the passing of Stuart M. Hirsch, 71, of New Providence, N.J. Born and raised in Plainfied, N.J., he had a long and distinguished career in the real estate and publishing industries, complimented by extensive commitment to numerous community and charitable undertakings that were dear to his heart. Stuart will long be remembered for his love of life, great wit, caring and compassion toward others and deep love of books, but above all family was the centerpiece of his life. A devoted husband to Maxine Kunitz Hirsch for 46 years, he was the loving father of two children, Chuck Hirsch of Seattle, WA. and Robin Friedman of Montgomery Twp, N.J., and daughter-in-law Carol and son-in-law Jeff. He was an adoring grandfather to Hannah and Lily Friedman. Also survived by his brother Simon Hirsch of Allentown, PA. He attended both Muhlenberg College and Rutgers University and served with the U.S. Army in the Korean Conflict. Upon his return to Plainfield, he joined into partnership with J.J. Schwartz and Company, a real estate firm. Later he changed the course of his career by joining the publishing giant Simon and Schuster at 36 years old. He thrived in this environment, immediately assuming responsibility for sales for the greater New York region, rising to the position of National Sales Manager. During his tenure with the company, his sales and marketing expertise helped insure the best selling status of some of the most prominent authors of the past century. In retirement he served as Chairman of the Board of Managers and President of the Volunteer Guild of Runnells Hospital in Berkeley Heights, N.J., devoted ten years as a volunteer at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. and participated actively as a member of the New Providence Rescue Squad, Board of Adjustment, Board of Health and of the Summit Old Guard. He was widely admired for his warm and engaging personality, and his deep knowledge of, and interest in books, politics, sports and family. His intellect, spirit and great courage inspired and uplifted all fortunate enough to know him. He will be deeply missed. Funeral services to be held at the Higgins Home for Funerals, 752 Mountain Blvd, Watchung, N.J. Friday, November 3rd, 11AM. Interment Beth David Orthodox Cemetery, Elmont N.Y. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to be made to the American Cancer Society, Union County Unit, POB 815, 507 Westminster Ave, Elizabeth NJ 07207-0815 or the New Providence Rescue Squad, 360 Elkwood Dr., POB 804, New Providence, N.J. 07974.

title: EATING OUT
description: Children Welcome

title: EARNINGS RISE AT BOOTS
description: Britain's leading drugstore chain, Boots P.L.C., posted small increases in pretax profit (2.3 percent) and sales (1.3 percent) for the first half, results that analysts said were too weak to stem fears that Boots is vulnerable to discounters. Boots shares fell 24.5 pence, to 536.5 pence. Boots has been trying to reposition by focusing on higher end cosmetics and brands like Clearasil, which it bought for $340 million last month. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Women, Faith And Moral Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. BACKTRACKS ON TRANSMETA
description: Microprocessors made by the upstart Transmeta Corporation will not be used in new I.B.M. laptop PC's after all, in part because of questions about the chips' battery life, an analyst said. ''They didn't find enough of a difference in terms of performance between the Transmeta technology and Intel's to justify the extra cost and risk,'' said Rob Enderle of the Giga Information Group, citing conversations with I.B.M. executives.

title: Commercial Attacking Bush Is Gore's Most Hostile Yet
description: Now, the gloves come off. The Gore campaign upped the ante on the air yesterday with the most relentlessly hostile commercial it has yet produced, a 30-second spot that responds to the Bush campaign's attacks on Vice President Al Gore, by questioning whether Gov. George W. Bush has what it takes to be president.

description: ATTRACTIONS

description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Greensboro, N.C.; New York; Hartford, Conn.; and Providence, R.I.

title: 1,500-Year-Old Wooden Ship Is Found Off Coast of Turkey
description: Probing the depths of the Black Sea off the coast of Turkey, oceanographers and archaeologists have found a 1,500-year-old ship resting on the bottom, its wooden hull almost perfectly preserved and its mast still standing tall.

title: DEVELOPERS DIVERSIFIED REALTY IS BUYING REST OF A REIT
description: Developers Diversified Realty, which owns 54 percent of American Industrial Properties, a real estate investment trust specializing in warehouses, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the remainder of the trust's shares for about $156 million, or $13.74 a share. The price represented a 9.9 percent premium to the trust's closing price on Wednesday. To finance the purchase, 32 of the trust's properties will be sold under agreements already concluded; all but one of the properties will be acquired by Lend Lease Real Estate Investments.

title: Els Back in Top Form After Week Off From Competition
description: After a terrible performance at the Presidents Cup last month, where he lost all five of his matches, Ernie Els needed a vacation. So last week, Els went to the Bahamas with his wife and daughter. He did not watch television or read a newspaper. He relaxed on the beach, took a break from competitive golf, and did a little gambling.

title: Pataki Selects Judge for Appeals Court He Sees as Lenient
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he would nominate Victoria A. Graffeo, a Supreme Court justice in upstate New York with strong ties to the Republican Party, to the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals.

title: Mutombo Hinting at Leaving
description: Center Dikembe Mutombo of the Hawks said last night that he had not considered signing a contract extension with Atlanta and sounded as if he was looking forward to becoming a free agent next summer.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Surefire Way To Score Tickets

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHMAN, ADELE RONSON NAHM
description: REICHMAN-Adele Ronson Nahm, actress. Died October 31, 2000 in New York City. Her career began in the 1920s in radio and on the stage and continued until her death. Predeceased by her husbands, Horace H. Nahm and Theodore Reichman, DDS. Mother of Dorothy Nahm Friedberg, M.D. and Nancy Nahm Sidhu, mother-in-law of Neal Friedberg, M.D. and Dip Singh Sidhu, M.D. Stepmother of Lee Reichman, M.D., Rose Reichman, David Reichman and Sheila Uniti, grandmother of Abbe and Michael Friedberg and Daniel and Deborah Gar Reichman, aunt of Pat Stewart. Died in her sleep one day after returning from a trip to Venice with her family. An unforgettable woman of great spirit who will live through the memory of all those who knew her. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 5, 3:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Tuning In Internationally
description: Television has often been described disparagingly, from ''the idiot box'' to ''the plug-in drug.'' But this weekend at the Museum of Television and Radio, it will deserve a more lofty title: the dream machine.

title: A Movable Birthday Party For the Vienna Symphony
description: The Vienna Symphony is celebrating its centennial with a 14-city American tour, but its present is worth celebrating as much as its past. On Monday night at Carnegie Hall the orchestra played under its music director, Vladimir Fedoseyev, and displayed itself in fit and responsive condition.

title: In His Own Words
description: GEORGE W. BUSH

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE GREEN PARTY

title: Priceline Reduces Staff 16% And Reports a Sales Plunge
description: Priceline.com continued its downward slide yesterday, laying off 87 employees, or 16 percent of its work force, as it disclosed that its airline ticket sales plunged in October and its chief financial officer had quit.

title: Metro Business Briefing; LOW UNEMPLOYMENT IN STAMFORD
description: With unemployment rates of just over 1 percent in September, Stamford and Danbury, Conn., are among the cities with the lowest levels of joblessness in the nation, the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday. The Stamford-Norwalk area's unemployment rate was 1.1 percent, a rate matched by Bloomington, Ind. Danbury and Sioux Falls, S.D., had rates of 1.2 percent. Columbia, Mo., had the lowest rate: 1 percent. The average unemployment rate for the nation is 3.9 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: PROFITS LEAP AT CANTV
description: The national phone company, Nacional Telefonos de Venezuela, said third-quarter net income soared fivefold on the strength of its rapidly growing mobile phone and Internet units. Net income rose to $26 million from $4.7 million in the quarter last year, when results were hammered by the country's recession. The company is 40 percent owned by a group led by Verizon Communications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEWSON, DAVID
description: HEWSON-David. Age 67 of NYC October 26, 2000. Beloved husband of Luule, father of David Hewson, Jr. and Rose Elizabeth Hussey. Also survived by 2 grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEVELAND, DONALD L.
description: CLEVELAND-Donald L. Of Greenwich, CT, died October 27. Survived by Caroline, his wife of 61 years, three sons, 2 brothers, 2 nephews. Memorial contributions may be made to Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perryridge Rd., Greenwich CT. 06830.

title: Bill Gates Turns Skeptical On Digital Solution's Scope
description: As the ''Creating Digital Dividends'' conference drew to a close in Seattle recently, the final speaker arrived and started asking skeptical questions. The premise was that ''market drivers'' could be used ''to bring the benefits of connectivity and participation in the e-economy to all of the world's six billion people,'' according to conference materials, but the speaker would have little of it.

title: New List of Ailing Companies May Include Unit of Hyundai
description: For the second time since the onset of the economic crisis two years ago, South Korean banks are set to announce a list of ailing companies that have been selected for closing, hoping this time to demonstrate their resolve to clean up bad loans that continue to undermine the financial industry.

title: All the Worlds a Stage
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Gothic Tale Of a Bedstead Fit for a President
description: Just in time for the election, the Lincoln Bedroom is back in the news. An immense Gothic Revival bedstead reportedly commissioned for the bedroom in 1844 (before Lincoln even slept in it) has just been acquired by the Dallas Museum of Art for $450,000. It will be on view after Thanksgiving.

title: In New Galleries, a Collection of the Unexpected
description: PHOTOGRAPHY is at a peculiar juncture right now. It crowds the walls of museums and commercial galleries with images that pointedly question its powers -- a medium flaunting its disillusionments. Traditional silver-based still images stand by helplessly as digitization and video claim a piece of their territory, a conquest that seems only to heighten interest in both winners and losers.

title: Album of the Week
description: GODSPEED YOU BLACK EMPEROR! ''Lift Your Skinny Fists Like Antennas To Heaven!'' (Kranky Records). ''Pop music is so dumb,'' pessimists say of today's jiggling, jeering mainstream. Perhaps in defiance, the underground is producing some of the most laboriously smart music in years. The Montreal collective Godspeed You Black Emperor! leads the way with its rarefied, hook-free instrumental rock, requiring either a detailed map of antecedents or the willingness to drift on sound forever floating off from its touchstones.

title: Arrests Spur French Fears Over Spread Of Mad Cow
description: The arrest of a father and son who tried to sell a diseased cow for slaughter and succeeded in getting hundreds of pounds of suspect meat onto supermarket shelves has set off a new wave of concern in France about the spread of mad cow disease.

title: Quaker Oats Said to Refuse PepsiCo Bid
description: The Quaker Oats Company informally rejected a $13.7 billion offer to be acquired by PepsiCo yesterday, according to executives close to the negotiations. Executives of the two consumer products giants had been meeting privately to discuss a sale, but could not agree on a price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DONOVAN, RICHARD PALMER, ''POP, O''
description: O'DONOVAN - Richard Palmer, ''Pop-O'', age 86 of Rockville Centre, NY on November 1, 2000. Beloved husband of Adele (Nee Cox). Loving father of Douglas O'Donovan, Patricia O'Donovan Rutledge and Deacon Robert O'Donovan. Dear brother of Thomas Buchann and Joseph O'Donovan. Loving grandfather of 11 adoring grandchildren and 7 great grandchildren. WWII Navy Combat Veteran, Loyal 45 year Employee of the New York Steam Company and Consolidated Edison Co. Past President NYC Council Boy Scouts of America (BSA). Past President of the New York Chapter Sons of the American Revolution (SAR). Member NYU Chapter Beta Gamma Sigma. Funeral Mass Friday 9:45AM St. Frances de Chantal R.C. Church, Wantagh. Interment following Calverton National Cemetery. For more information please call the Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, Wantagh, New York.

title: Clinton Goes on the Attack
description: The campaign of Hillary Rodham Clinton last night began televising this 30-second advertisement, ''Exactly,'' in New York City.

title: METS MAKE OFFERS
description: In the early innings of Game 5 of the World Series, Turk Wendell turned in the dugout to his close friend, Rick Reed, and said, ''This might be the last game we play together.'' Reed told Wendell not to count on it. Both of them, Reed said, might still come back to the Mets.

title: The Senators Give Holmqvist a Rude Welcome
description: Rangers Coach Ron Low could not have asked for more balance. Each of his four lines recorded a goal here tonight. The Rangers scored five times in all. It still was not enough.

title: City to Charge Truck Drivers For Parking
description: Saying that traffic has brought many Midtown streets to a near standstill, the city has decided for the first time to charge delivery trucks for parking when they are loading and unloading around Times Square.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEIDMAN, ABRAHAM
description: ZEIDMAN - Abraham. Devoted husband of Betty, Adored father of Victoria and Michael Eller and Leslie Zeidman. Loving ''Grampy'' to Samantha, Melinda, and Lee. Fond brother of Zelda Kushner. Beloved uncle and friend. Services Sunday, 1:30 PM, at ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Copyright Office Issues Unusual Rule
description: It's not every day that the federal government gives its blessing to hacking. But that's what happened last week when the U.S. Copyright Office issued a special rule clarifying a new federal law that governs copyright in the digital age.

title: Countdown - 4: Rallying Voters and Relishing a Leading Role

title: Clinton Now Running on Husband's Record
description: Moving into the final leg of her campaign for Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton sprinted from Buffalo to Manhattan to Long Island today, trying to do in New York State what Al Gore has studiously avoided doing across the nation: run on the record of the Clinton administration.

title: On the Streets, Palestinians Vow to Keep Fight Going
description: As darkness fell, people paused in a narrow, twisting street of this embattled Palestinian city to study the two big-screen televisions outside an appliance store showing the chaos of the Jerusalem car bombing.

description: AL GORE

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HERRMANN, RICHARD A., M.D.
description: HERRMANN-Richard A., M.D.. Died on 11/3/99. Beloved husband of Marilyn, father of Rachel and Amy. Loving husband and father, caring physician. We miss you so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOLA, RALPH JEAN
description: ZOLA-Ralph Jean. Of Englewood Cliffs, NJ. Beloved husband of Penni (nee Silver), cherished son of Helen and the late Irving Zola, devoted father of Gregory Zola and Stephanie Bailyn, dear brother of Paul Zola and Marion Urcis. A sweet singer of Israel, whose melody has been stilled. Services Friday at noon, ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St., Englewood.

title: SWEDISH COMPANY MAY PLAY PART IN GEORGIA-PACIFIC DEAL
description: Svenska Cellulosa, a tissue maker based in Sweden, may be emerging as the primary bidder for factories that the Georgia-Pacific Group would have to divest to win antitrust approval for its $11.2 billion purchase of the Fort James Corporation, Bloomberg News reported yesterday, citing unidentified sources. When Georgia-Pacific announced the acquisition in July, the company said it would shed 250,000 tons of yearly tissue production to help finance the transaction and pay off debt. Antitrust experts said much more would be needed to allay regulatory concerns. The acquisition would make Georgia-Pacific the world's largest maker of toilet paper, facial tissues and paper towels. Svenska has no manufacturing presence in the United States.

title: Why Be a Prop for Pyongyang?
description: After 50 years of hostilities, one can understand the desire to establish good relations with North Korea. By making Pyongyang more dependent on the outside world, particularly the United States, it is possible to encourage progress on issues like terrorism, missiles and weapons of mass destruction. One may even hope that a less isolated and more engaged North Korea would fundamentally change the way its government behaves and its society is run.

title: How to Go To The Polls Twice
description: I tried to visit Voteswap2000.com, but it was shut down this week after California's secretary of state threatened to prosecute its operators. This site is among many that have sprung up on the Internet to offer this deal: A Democrat in a state like New York or Texas, where the outcome has been known for months and the ballot is unlikely to matter, can ship his or her vote for Al Gore someplace where it will make a difference. The site matches the Gore supporter with a Ralph Nader supporter in, say, Michigan, and the two agree to trade candidates. Mr. Gore gets a vote where he needs it, and Mr. Nader gets one step closer to his goal of 5 percent of the popular vote, which would qualify the Green Party for federal funds in 2004.

title: Estrada Crisis Deepens but He Vows to Fight
description: MANILA, Nov. 3  The crisis surrounding Philippine President Joseph Estrada deepened on Friday as a number of key government allies deserted the embattled leader, leaving him almost certain to be impeached over a gambling pay-offs scandal.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Five Hurt in Hit-and-Run Accident in Harlem
description: A driver who apparently tried to beat a light at a busy Harlem intersection hit five people, including three children on their way to school, before leaving the car a few blocks away and eluding capture, the police and witnesses said.

title: In Space: The Costs, the Dreams
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRASER, LILLIAN
description: FRASER-Lillian. On October 29, 2000 in Italy while on vacation. Beloved wife of the late Willard. Loving mother of Steven and his wife Jill and Jon Fraser. Devoted grandmother of Max and Emma. Dear sister of Arthur Oluwek. Services Monday, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her name to Gay Men's Health Crisis.

title: In Space: The Costs, the Dreams
description: To the Editor:

description: Theater

title: 'Puente/Bridge'
description: Taller Boricua

title: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., Ex-Housing Secretary, Dies at 78
description: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., whose accomplishments as one of the most prominent black lawyers of his generation were overshadowed by corruption and influence-peddling during his tenure as housing secretary in the Reagan administration, died on Tuesday. He was 78.

title: Protege Ends Kasparov's 15-Year Chess Reign
description: The 15-year reign of Garry Kasparov, considered by many people the greatest chess player of all time, ended today when he was overwhelmed by the bravura performance of a lanky young Russian who was once his protege.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: How Winner of the Popular Vote Could Lose After All
description: If the race for the White House is as close as the polls suggest, the candidate who gets the most votes on Tuesday may not become president of the United States.

title: Felony Costs Voting Rights for a Lifetime in 9 States
description: Sunday mornings find Arthur Sabree, a onetime cocaine dealer of considerable influence, standing at the pulpit of the Shining Light for Lost Souls Ministry, a cramped, low-ceilinged sanctuary in the back of a single-chair barber shop here called Willie's House of Style.

title: I.B.M. MAKES A BIG SERVER SALE
description: Japan's second-largest convenience store chain, Lawson Inc., will install more than 15,000 I.B.M. server computers running the Linux operating system in what the computer maker said was the largest commercial use of Linux ever. Financial terms were not disclosed. I.B.M. said Lawson would put two of the computer maker's xSeries servers in each of about 7,600 of its stores throughout Japan. The servers will enhance existing Internet-connected terminals in the shops so customers can copy music, movies and other Web content.

title: 'Tres Complementaires'
description: The Art and Lives of Ethel Mars and Maud Hunt Squire

title: BIG WIRELESS CARRIER HITS NEW YORK
description: In a move that extends the reach of the nation's second-largest wireless carrier to New York City, Cingular Wireless, the company formed by SBC Communications and BellSouth, agreed to swap wireless spectrum with a rival carrier, VoiceStream Wireless. Under the agreement, Cingular will exchange spectrum licenses covering California and Nevada for spectrum in metropolitan New York, St. Louis, Detroit and parts of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Connecticut. The transaction, which does not involve cash and should be tax free, involves spectrum licenses in areas that each cover about 35 million people. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Al Gore in the Home Stretch
description: Marlo Thomas has the right idea. An ardent Democrat, she went on the ''Today'' show Thursday to reprimand her husband, Phil Donahue, for helping Ralph Nader spread the fallacious message that it makes no difference whether Al Gore or George W. Bush wins the presidency. Ms. Thomas set an admirable example when she said the refusal to recognize profound differences between the two candidates had made her ''come out fighting.'' Her action ought to signal Gore supporters everywhere to put on a burst of energy and not be intimidated by the triumphalist theater of the Bush campaign. Borrowing a page from Ronald Reagan's playbook, Governor Bush is trying to act as if he has this contest locked up. But in fact, this presidential election is up for grabs. With four days left to campaign, Vice President Gore is ahead, gaining or highly competitive in the swing states that will decide the outcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGEN, DALE W.
description: HAGEN-Dale W., October 8, 2000. Loving husband of Sharon, brother of Bill, of pancreatic cancer in Sarasota, Florida. A memorial service will be held on Monday November 13th at 6:00 PM at Marble Collegiate Church, 29th and Fifth Avenue, Manhattan. Contributions in his memory may be made to The American Cancer Society or National Kidney Foundation.

title: On a Path to Enlightenment, Nourished by Rice
description: At what seemed the end of ''Songs of the Wanderers,'' a New York premiere by Lin Hwai-min and his Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan, sheets of yellow rice rained down upon dancers onstage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: BIDDING DEADLINE SET
description: It's open bidding season on Ichiro Suzuki. Actually, the bids will be closed, but major league clubs were notified late yesterday that if they are interested in securing rights to the Japanese star, they have until 5 p.m. Wednesday to submit a bid.

title: Foreign Affairs; Diplomacy by Other Means
description: The other day I was interviewing Marwan Barghouti, the leader of the Palestinian Tanzim movement, which has led the street war with Israel, in his office in Ramallah. He had a photocopy of the Israeli paper Maariv on his desk, with a headline about him. With my rusty synagogue Hebrew, I couldn't fully understand the headline, so Mr. Barghouti happily translated it for me. He speaks fluent Hebrew, thanks to long years in Israeli prisons and long negotiations with Israeli leaders. The encounter underscored something you forget when you're not here: how much Israelis and Palestinians are intertwined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELMAN, RENEE
description: ADELMAN-Renee. Of Lawrence, N.Y. and Boca Raton, FL. Passed away tragically and suddenly on Monday, October 30, 2000. Devoted wife of Seymour, beloved mother of Marcia A. Delman and Debra Buckley. Adored grandmother of Ariel and Ross Buckley, who gave Renee so much joy, pride and pleasure during her life. She is also survived by her brother, Leonard Kleiman & his family. She will always be kept in our hearts, always remembered for her joyful spirit, vitality, kindness, music-making and delightful wit. Her loving memory lives in our dreams and our lives. Forever in our hearts, we will miss her more with each passing day.

title: ALCOA SAYS IT IS CLOSING REFINERY IN VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: Alcoa said yesterday that it would close a refinery in the Virgin Islands because of falling demand. The plant, in St. Croix, V.I., produces the main raw material for aluminum. It belongs to a subsidiary 60 percent owned by Alcoa and 40 percent by WMC Ltd. of Australia. The plant will close on Jan. 31, and all but a handful of its 350 employees will be laid off. The plant produces alumina, the oxide extracted from bauxite ore to be refined into pure aluminum. Shares of Alcoa fell $1.31, to $27.75. They have fallen 33 percent this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the crash of a Singapore Airlines jet in Taiwan misstated the name of another airline at the same airport. It was China Airlines, not China Airways.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Hybrid Cars Show Up In M.I.T.'s Crystal Ball
description: THE Massachusetts Institute of Technology and DaimlerChrysler have given their assessments on the future of the automobile, and have both come out in favor of hybrid gasoline-electric cars. But scientists at M.I.T.'s Energy Laboratory, working with computer models, had an easier time predicting costs and benefits of the cars than DaimlerChrysler, working in steel and glass, is likely to have selling them.

title: Half-Open Congress Keeps Money Flowing
description: On one side of the Capitol today, House leaders made sure they showed up at a news conference on a Republican patients' bill of rights bill. Later in the day, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert invited photographers into his office to take pictures of him signing legislation.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO OFF. The euro fell as a bigger-than-expected jump in productivity bolstered expectations that the United States will continue to lure investors. In New York, the euro settled at 86.01 cents, down from 86.10 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARK, JANE E.
description: STARK-Jane E. Died November 1, 2000 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Walter, devoted mother of Jodi Budnick, Kirk Budnick and Lisa Stark, loving grandmother to Mallory, Nicole and Gregory. Daughter of Betty L. Goldberg of Lakewood, NJ. Sister to Nancy Isaacs and Edwin Isaacs of Toms River, NJ. Funeral services will be held at Hellman Memorial Chapels, 15 State St, Spring Valley, NY on November 3, 2000 at 11:30 AM. Interment will follow at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Shiva will be observed at the home of her daughter, 21 Feller Court, Suffern, NY Saturday evening through Wednesday.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 10
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: Hasidim and Iowa Townsfolk: A Test of Diversity
description: POSTVILLE

title: SONUS NETWORKS IS ACQUIRING TELECOM TECHNOLOGIES
description: Sonus Networks said yesterday that it would buy Telecom Technologies for $440.6 million in stock. The companies both make networking products that help phone companies and Internet service providers transmit voice and data. Sonus, based in Westford, Mass., said it wanted to gain access to the customers and engineering staff of Telecom, which is privately held and is based in Richardson, Tex. Sonus shares rose $2, to $40.88.

title: When a Dime Matters: Levitt Goes After Option Markets
description: ARTHUR LEVITT, the longest-serving chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is at it again. He's angry about ways in which individual investors are badly treated, and he wants to do something about it.

title: Gulotta Cuts Tax Increase Included In Fiscal Plan
description: Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County executive, sharply cut the Legislature's four-year fiscal rescue plan tonight. He reduced a proposed 15.4 percent increase in county property taxes to 7.9 percent and slashed millions of dollars in government spending.

title: Shanghai Plans the Biggest 'Aida' Ever and Hopes the Sun God Smiles
description: If it rains here on Friday, this city is in trouble. Stung by the sniggering at an unremarkable American magic act that was the centerpiece of Shanghai's international art festival last year, the city's culture cadres have catapulted to the other extreme: they're planning the biggest performance of Verdi's ''Aida'' the world has ever seen.

title: Less Venture Backing for Start-Ups Is Seen
description: The nation's venture capital firms, while continuing to invest at a steady pace, are bolstering companies in which they already have stakes at the expense of financing new ventures, according to an industrywide report to be released today.

title: United States-North Korea Missile Talks End Unresolved
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Nov. 3  The United States' talks with North Korea on Pyongyang's missile program ended on Friday in Kuala Lumpur with significant issues unresolved.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: M:I-2

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, THERESE, (NEE BLUM)
description: STONE-Therese, (nee Blum). In her 97th year. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Frederick E. Stone. Loving mother of Barbara Coppe and Louise Spring, (Lionel). Adoring grandmother of Michael Spring and Tony Spring, (Grace), and great - grandmother of Tyler Spring and Nathan Spring. Sister of the late Julius Blum, (Esther), and Harold Blum, (Anita). Services private. Friends and relatives will be received at the home of Tony Spring today from 4:00-8:00 PM at 6 Fordham Avenue, Rye, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAVE, PAUL T.
description: CHAVE-Paul T. Age 87, November 2, 2000. Survived by his beloved wife Rita M. Chave (nee Harrington), pre-deceased by daughter Anne Marie in 1944, also survived by several nieces and nephews. He was an executive in the textile industry in Manhattan for 50 years and most recently CEO of Chave & Earley, Inc. Visiting at John Krtil Funeral Home Saturday from 7-9, Sunday 2-4 and 7-9. Funeral Mass 10am on Monday at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church, 55 St at 1st Ave. Interment following at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to Jacob Perlow Hospice of Beth Isreal Medical Center would be appreciated.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Airplanes and food have a long relationship of mutual contempt. Airport cuisine means Sbarro, Pizza Hut, Taco Bell, McDonald's and, with luck, a shopping-mall bistro that can just manage a cheeseburger. Airplane food -- well, better not to dwell on that topic.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil dropped as prospects for an end to violence in the Middle East eased concern about disruption of oil exports. In New York, crude oil for December delivery fell 71 cents, to $32.54 a barrel.

title: Sleek, Tough, Frosted? Must Be Empowerment
description: ''Charlie's Angels'' is dedicated to the proposition that you can have your cheescake and eat it too. Its three heroines -- played with varying degrees of swagger and sultriness by Cameron Diaz, Lucy Liu and Drew Barrymore -- are meant to appeal both to teenage girls, who will admire their professionalism and fighting spirit, and to teenage boys, who will find other things about them to admire. The original television show, which ran from 1976 to 1981, was the leering ancestor of ''Baywatch''; each week it found ingenious new ways to exploit the unlikelihood of its premise, that three luscious babes could be a fearsome crime-fighting force.

title: Skidding as She Chases Profundity
description: ''The Tale of the Allergist's Wife,'' which had a limited run last season at the Manhattan Theater Club, reopened last night at the Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street, Manhattan. Following are excerpts from Ben Brantley's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 1.

title: Where Gore Seemed Safe, There's a Race After All
description: A few weeks ago Illinois's 22 electoral votes were thought to be squarely in Vice President Al Gore's column.

title: Rout by Knicks Doesn't Wipe The Slate Clean
description: Anything less than a double-digit victory over the Atlanta Hawks last night would have exposed the Knicks as a potential lottery team. Hold the Ping-Pong balls.

title: Article 2000110390457277471 -- No Title
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 2  Ross Perot, the estranged founder of the Reform Party whose candidacy in 1992 helped defeat President George Bush, tonight offered a surprise endorsement of the former president's son, Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Cigna Results Top Expectations
description: The Cigna Corporation said yesterday that third-quarter earnings fell slightly, but the results still surpassed Wall Street estimates as its health care business improved.

title: White House Debates Bill Meant to Stop Leaks
description: Senior aides to President Clinton emerged from a White House meeting today deeply divided about whether the president ought to sign or veto legislation on his desk that would make it a felony for a government official to disclose classified information.

title: CENDANT IS BUYING FAIRFIELD FOR $728 MILLION
description: The Cendant Corporation, which franchises everything from Ramada hotels to the Avis car rental brand, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the largest independent time-share operator, Fairfield Communities, for $728.5 million. Cendant is paying $15 a share in cash and stock for each Fairfield share and will assume about $93.5 million of debt, Fairfield said. Cendant, based in New York, owns Resorts Condominiums International, which helps owners of time shares exchange their properties for others. Fairfield operates 33 resorts in the United States and Canada. In August, Cendant offered to buy the part of Avis Group Holdings it does not already own, for $750 million. The Avis Group is the largest franchisee of Cendant's Avis brand. Also in August, Cendant bought the AmeriHost Inn and AmeriHost Inn and Suites brand names and franchising rights. Cendant shares rose 6 cents, to $12.19. Fairfield shares rose 88 cents, to $14.

title: European Central Bank Gives Euro a Boost
description: FRANKFURT, Germany -- The European Central Bank said Friday it intervened in currency markets to buy euros, a move that immediately lifted the region's ailing currency. It is only the second time the central bank has acted on behalf of the euro.

title: Riders Compete For National Titles
description: With the American Horse Shows Association and the American Hunter and Jumper Council arguing over control of the rules and regulations for showing hunters, the National Horse Show will open its 117th run tonight without the scarlet-clad riders and their mounts at Madison Square Garden.

title: An Elusive Mideast Truce
description: A new terror bombing in Jerusalem yesterday quickly deflated hopes for an early cease-fire between Israelis and Palestinians based on the understandings reached between Shimon Peres and Yasir Arafat Wednesday night. But if nothing else, the steps agreed to by the former Israeli prime minister and the Palestinian leader show a recognition on both sides that further escalation of the fighting would serve no one. Despite the latest violence, Israeli and Palestinian leaders were still hoping last night that a truce might yet be established. If the latest agreement can be fully carried out, open warfare can be avoided and many lives saved.

title: FIRE INSURERS CONSOLIDATE
description: Three more Japanese insurance companies have decided to merge. Yasuda Fire and Marine, Nissan Fire and Marine and Taisei Fire and Marine, all members of the same family of companies and financial institutions, will combine to create Japan's second-largest casualty insurer with a market capitalization of 612 billion yen ($5.7 billion). Eight other casualty insurers have recently joined forces in various configurations as the industry deals with deregulation, low interest rates and falling stock prices. No details of the merger, which is meant to be completed by April 2002, were announced. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: A City of Clowns? What Else Is New?
description: Lights strung in the crisp-leaved trees of Damrosch Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIGGANE, MOLLIE S.
description: BIGGANE-Mollie S., age 20, on November 1, 2000, All Saints Day, at home with her family, after a valiant 6 month battle with Melanoma. Beloved daughter of Jack and Maggie. Loving sister of Julie, John and Cara. Cherished granddaughter of Jack and Loretta Biggane and the late Phil and Peggy Glennon. Also survived by many loving aunts, uncles, cousins and friends. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City 2-4 & 7-9PM Friday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City 9:45AM Saturday. Interment Sacred Heart Cemetery, Cutchogue, NY. Donations to the Long Island Community FoundationNew York Community Trust for the benefit of the Mollie Biggane Melanoma Fund, 2 Park Avenue, NY, New York 11016 appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about the sale of the assets of Scour.com, a Web site for trading music and video files, to Listen.com misstated the reason for the sale. The sale was part of bankruptcy proceedings; it was not being conducted to settle a suit on music files.

title: Small Boy as Square Root Of Exponential Bathos
description: Pay It Forward

title: As Publishers Perish, Libraries Feel the Pain; Mergers Keep Pushing Up Journal Costs
description: Sitting in her windowless office deep within the stacks of Bobst Library at New York University, Suzanne Fedunok, a science librarian, is surveying the toll of her latest ''cancellation project,'' a list of 269 serials the library will no longer receive. The casualties range from a $3,595 subscription to Anatomical Record to a $2,195 subscription to the neuroscience favorite Synapse.

title: Martin Kippenberger
description: 'Jacqueline: The Paintings Pablo Couldn't Paint Anymore'

title: Democratic Senator Is in Fight of His Political Life
description: The slugfest between Senator Charles S. Robb, the two-term Democratic incumbent, and his Republican challenger, former Gov. George F. Allen, turned even more bitter this week when Mr. Robb accused his rival of compiling an ''intolerable'' and ''appalling'' record on racial issues.

title: Labor Board Rules for Post Owner on '93 Layoffs
description: The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that Rupert Murdoch, the owner of The New York Post, does not owe millions of dollars to members of the Newspaper Guild of New York who were laid off when he acquired that newspaper in 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RONSON, ADELE
description: RONSON-Adele. See Adele Reichman.

title: Bold Quest: Gas, Food and Lodging; Fact-Finder Plies Roads For Auto Club's Maps
description: In Bob Hawkinson's 11 years crisscrossing the nation's highways, no one has ever asked him what the heck he was doing.

title: Rival hair-product companies devise campaigns that brush aside the 'bad hair day' image.
description: TYPICAL commercials for haircare products usually include the conventional pattern of ''You've got a hair problem? Well, we've got your solution.'' But two rivals are introducing campaigns that ditch that ''Advertising 101'' hair care theme in favor of unusual techniques.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRZANOWSKI, GERARD, MD.
description: CHRZANOWSKI - Gerard, MD. This year marks the fiftieth anniversary of Dr. Gerard Chrzanowski's graduation from The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute. Given that he had a talent for both contributing to and extracting from any given day, twice as much as most mortals, he can with modesty be given credit for one hundred years of extraordinary service to the repair of human hurts and to the needs of the lay and professional communities on the local, national and international levels. Acknowledged as a forceful and brilliant teacher, supervisor, psychoanalyst, and author, his apparently limitless energy and irrepresible creativity made him a formidable and peripatetic presence in countless professional endeavors of exceptional distinction. Gerry founded the Bleuler Clinic over fifty years ago; he co-founded the International Federation of Psychoanalytic Societies in 1962; he served actively and with distinction in the American Academy of Psychoanalysis; and he wrote a seminal book on interpersonal psychoanalysis. Dr. Chrzanowski was the recipient of many awards of which two were the White Institute's Certificate of Appreciation in 1977, and the IFPS ''award for lifelong dedication to psychoanalysis'' in 2000. As a determined agent for growth and a man of fierce loyalties and strong opinions, Gerry willed himself and others to face head-on the challenges of life and to triumph. Unencumbered by reticence, he nonetheless had an infinite capacity for patience, kindness and compassion. Gerry's understanding, love and devotion was returned in full measure by his many colleagues, analysands, supervisees, family, friends and others whose lives were enriched by his unique array of talents. His vision will be carried by a profoundly grateful Institute and Society on which he left his salient, striking and indelible mark. Joerg Bose, MD, Director, White Institute Betsy Hegeman, PhD, President, White Society Charles C. Harrington, PhD, President, Board of Trustees

title: House Votes for Program to Revamp Everglades
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  House leaders injected a touch of politics into an issue of wide bipartisan support today as lawmakers put the finishing touches on an Everglades-restoration project before getting ready to flee the capital.

title: RATES LEFT UNCHANGED
description: As expected, the Euro pean Central Bank left interest rates in the 11 euro nations unchanged, as signs mounted that economic growth was slowing after seven earlier rate increases over the last year. The bank's benchmark rate has increased by 2.25 percentage points, to 4.75 percent, raising borrowing costs. Soaring energy prices have also increased companies' costs.

title: Pataki Calls His Partys Phone Attacks on Clinton Wrong
