title: IN STRATEGY SHIFT, GORE ADS QUESTION BUSH'S CAPABILITY
description: In a late shift in his advertising strategy, Vice President Al Gore sought to heighten anxieties about Gov. George W. Bush today by broadcasting a tough new advertisement that bluntly questions whether Mr. Bush is ''ready to lead America.''

title: Reds and Blue Jays Reject Randolph as Manager
description: Instead of coaching at third base for the Yankees the past seven seasons, maybe Willie Randolph should have been in their broadcast booth. Statistically at least, he would have had a better chance of getting one of the six managers' jobs that opened up after the season. After all, Buck Martinez got one of the jobs yesterday and Randolph learned that he wasn't getting the only one remaining open.

title: Runway Mistake Suspected in Taiwan Jet Crash, Officials Say
description: Early evidence suggests that the Singapore Airlines jet that crashed during takeoff in heavy wind and rain here Tuesday night, killing at least 81, may have been barreling down the wrong runway and hit construction materials, Taiwan's air safety agency said Thursday night.

title: A Smorgasbord of Nifty Ideas
description: Make yourself comfortable. Starting today, Scandinavian culture has a new home-away-from-home: a handsome, welcoming six-story building on Park Avenue, just below 38th Street, designed by James Stewart Polshek, with Robert Young, a design associate, of Polshek Partnership Architects. Scandinavia House, as it is called, conveys some of the different traits and qualities of Scandinavian architecture and design, both modern and traditional, especially when you factor in its densely packed inaugural exhibition of work by the region's young designers.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Ignoring Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Runway Is Focus of Inquiry

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Lawmaker Focuses on Re-election, Not Investigation
description: State Senator Guy Velella, facing a criminal investigation into whether he took money to help steer a state contract to a Bronx company, vowed yesterday to spend the final days of his hard-fought re-election campaign focusing on the issues he deems vital to his district.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. *denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12.

title: A Believer in Peace Buried With Honors
description: In the rolling fields of the kibbutz where he was born, Amir Zohar, an Army Reserve officer who advocated peace with the Palestinians but died in battle with them, was buried today at sunset.

title: Nader's Green Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: Men in the News; The Crew of the International Space Station
description: William McMichael Shepherd

title: Hearing Explores Personal Side Of Push for Suicide Prevention
description: Pat Roberts had talked to her 14-year-old son about AIDS and drugs and smoking; she just had not known she needed to talk to him about suicide.

title: USX-U.S. STEEL SAYS IT IS PLANNING CUTS AT MINNESOTA MINE
description: The USX-U.S. Steel Group, the country's largest steel producer, said yesterday that it would idle some operations at its Minntac mine near Mountain Iron, Minn., eliminating up to 140 jobs, or 10 percent of the mine's hourly workers. The operations process the mine's ore to render it suitable to make steel. The company said the closing was partly attributable to ''staggering volumes'' of steel imports. Shares of USX-U.S. Steel, based in Pittsburgh, fell 56 cents, to $14.75. They have fallen 55 percent this year.

title: Handel's First London Hit: Still an Enchanting World
description: First-rate singers are the messengers who carry ''Rinaldo'' to 21st- century audiences, but it is the translators of that message who bear the key. Handel's world of magic and sudden scenic transformation first played to spectators readier to be won by mechanical stage apparatus than our film- and special effects-drenched eyes. Now it is 290 years later, and it will take new metaphorical bridges to reach across that gap.

title: Singapore Airlines Jet Used Wrong Runway
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan Nov. 3  The Singapore Airlines jet that crashed here Tuesday night during a storm, killing 81, definitely taxied onto the wrong runway and slammed into construction equipment just before takeoff, Taiwan's air safety chief announced today.

title: Aon, Insurance Broker, Plans Broad Reorganization
description: Aon, the world's second-largest insurance broker, had a particularly bad day yesterday.

title: 2 Ex-Salvador Generals Cleared by U.S. Jury in Nuns Deaths
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 3  A federal jury today cleared two retired Salvadoran generals of responsibility in the abduction, rape and murder of four American churchwomen by members of El Salvador's National Guard in 1980. The jury said the two men could not have done anything more to prevent the crime.

title: Article 2000110392379365923 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFIN, JAMES J. SR.
description: GRIFFIN-James J. Sr., 79, died November 1, 2000. He is survived by his wife Helen, two children James J. Griffin Jr. and Meg Griffin and 3 grandchildren Lauren, James J. III and Knoah. A memorial Mass will be held Saturday at 10:00AM at St. Bernards Church in White Plains. McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett funeral home. (914)949-7777

title: Euro Slips Despite European Central Bank Intervention
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 3 Looking more and more like an institution that has been backed into a corner, the European Central Bank again intervened in global currency markets today to prop up the euro, Europe's woebegone common currency.

title: Republicans Step Up Effort In Tight Connecticut Race
description: Now seeking an 11th term, Representative Sam Gejdenson, a Democrat and the most senior member of the state's Congressional delegation, has survived some hard battles for re-election. The closest of all was in 1994 when he won by just 21 votes, a result that was contested by his opponent for more than six months after the election.

title: Shell Posts 80% Jump In Earnings
description: With world oil prices running at sustained highs, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Europe's biggest petroleum company, reported third-quarter operating profits today of $3.25 billion, an increase of about 80 percent over the comparable period a year earlier.

title: Biggest Voter Turnout Effort Corzine's Millions Can Buy
description: Albert Hawkins, who lives in a homeless shelter in Philadelphia, will not be in Pennsylvania to vote for Al Gore on Tuesday. He will be in New Jersey, ''volunteering'' for Jon S. Corzine in return for a fast $75 and all the coffee, doughnuts and sandwiches he can eat.

title: HOME VIDEO
description: First seasons of television shows are growing into their own video genre. This summer HBO released the first season of ''Sex and the City,'' and this winter it will issue the first year of ''The Sopranos.'' On Tuesday Docurama released the first season of Michael Moore's ''Awful Truth,'' which sends the corporation-tweaking gadfly on various missions to make life uncomfortable for the rich and exploitive.

title: 'Ball Four' Makes Another Comeback
description: ''Ball Four'' is back. Actually, Jim Bouton's diary of the 1969 season -- which Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn ordered him to disavow as if Jacqueline Susann had penned a tell-all from inside major league locker rooms -- has never gone away. Bouton issued a 10th anniversary edition, then a 20th. Over 30 years, more than five million copies of the book have been sold.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about President Clinton's veto of a spending bill that finances the Treasury Department and White House and Congressional operations referred imprecisely in some copies to negotiations with Republicans in Congress. Republicans say he promised to sign the bill, but White House aides say he did not. He never publicly promised to sign it.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Campaign Briefing column on Tuesday about travel by the presidential candidates referred incorrectly to one city visited by Vice President Al Gore. It was Green Bay, Wis., not Michigan.

title: An Effort At Tuning The Pianist
description: Melvyn Tan gracefully sprang to fame in the 1990's as a player on the early piano -- the piano as it was two centuries ago -- and his performances of Beethoven's sonatas then could be as breathtaking as they were fresh. Now he prefers modern instruments, perhaps because they provide him with a wider repertory. On Sunday at the Frick Collection he offered the second book of Debussy's Preludes as well as sonatas by Beethoven (Op. 101) and Mozart (K. 570, in B flat). The modern piano also yields greater strength, which he is obviously still enjoying. But his adjustment does not yet seem quite complete.

title: Frank Dituri
description: Rosenberg + Kaufman Fine Art

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINER, BENJAMIN
description: FEINER-Benjamin. Of Malverne, NY and Delray Beach, FL, passed away on Thursday, November 2, 2000. Devoted husband of Jeanne for 69 years, beloved father of Irwin and Fred. Devoted father-inlaw of Elizabeth and JoAnne. Adored grandfather of Steven, Andrea and Andrew, Scott, Robert and Alexandra. Ben is also survived by his sister Eva Ezra. His loving memory lives in our dreams and lives. We will miss him more with each passing day. Services Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, Friday at noon.

title: CYTEC INDUSTRIES IS PLANNING ANOTHER STOCK BUYBACK
description: Cytec Industries, a specialty chemical maker, said yesterday that it planned to buy back as much as $100 million more of its common stock, or about 14 percent of the shares now outstanding, in the open market. The company has bought back about $310 million of its stock since 1996, including a $100 million buyback program announced in January that the company said was 94 percent complete. Cytec stock rose 56 cents, to $35.63.

title: Article 2000110392887040227 -- No Title
description: THE GREEN PARTY

title: ROLLS-ROYCE IS CLOSING AIRCRAFT PARTS PLANT IN ENGLAND
description: Rolls-Royce, the world's second-largest aircraft engine maker, said yesterday that it was planning to close a parts plant in Derby, England, by June 2001, and eliminate up to 180 jobs in a cost-cutting effort. Rolls-Royce said it would buy substitute parts from an Austrian company, Fischer Advanced Composite Components, at a 25 percent savings. The company expects to save $:3 million ($4.3 million) annually for the next five years by closing the plant.

title: Singapore Airlines Jet Used Wrong Runway
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan -- A Singapore Airlines jumbo jet was on the wrong runway when it started to take off for Los Angeles and crashed this week, killing 81 people, the chief investigator said Friday. The pilot realized at the last moment he was on a strip closed for repairs and tried to lift off but plowed into construction equipment.

title: Article 2000110393427766856 -- No Title
description: Home Networking Grows Up, Sort of

title: Sports of The Times; Norwegians And Yanks Join Ranks
description: SARA WHELAN has bumped into Ann-Kristin Aarones before -- quite literally. These things are to be expected when the United States plays Norway in one of the very best sporting rivalries in the world.

title: Mets Make Offers
description: In the early innings of Game 5 of the World Series, Turk Wendell turned in the dugout to his close friend, Rick Reed, and said, ``This might be the last game we play together.'' Reed told Wendell not to count on it. Both of them, Reed said, might still come back to the Mets.

title: Decisions Made On Several Accounts
description: Several advertisers have made decisions on accounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, MAE
description: HALL-Mae. The board, staff, clients and many friends of Seniors Helping Seniors deeply mourn the passing of our President and Guiding Light, Mae Hall. Mrs. Hall, one of our founders, dedicated her retirement years to making the lives of older people easier and more comfortable. A strong woman of deep convictions and long experience, Mae Hall has left a beautiful legacy in Northern Manhattan, where she lived and worked for older people. We who loved her at Seniors Helping Seniors will treasure our memories of this great lady for the rest of our lives.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Hospitals Question Overpriced Flu Vaccine
description: While some hospitals wait anxiously for the flu vaccine that they ordered months ago, some small distributing companies are obtaining the vaccine and offering to sell it for as much as five times the normal price.

title: St. Raymond's Senior Chooses N.C. State
description: Julius Hodge is an outstanding forward for St. Raymond's High School in the Bronx, a player rated by some scouts as the top senior in New York City. He definitely has a flair for the dramatic, and he displayed it yesterday when he announced that he would play college ball at North Carolina State next season.

title: Here's to You, Mrs. Robinson
description: HELLO, darkness, our old friend. We've come to talk with you again.

title: Corrections
description: The Residential Real Estate column last Friday about two market surveys that showed a cooling in average sales prices for Manhattan apartments referred incorrectly to a sample used in one of them. The survey by the Douglas Elliman company omitted condominium sales in calculating average sales in the luxury apartment category only, not for all apartments in the study.

title: Lobbying Left Assemblyman Neutral on Senate
description: The decision by Assemblyman Dov Hikind to remain neutral in the New York Senate race came after weeks of intense lobbying by both campaigns that involved direct appeals by President Clinton on behalf of his wife and by Gov. George E. Pataki on behalf of Representative Rick A. Lazio.

title: 2 Couples Go to the Catskills And Discover The Answer
description: The modest pleasures to be gleaned from John Gallagher's sudsy romantic comedy ''Blue Moon'' come mostly from watching its two veteran stars, Ben Gazzara and Rita Moreno, infuse life into a formulaic story whose plodding, expository dialogue suggests that the movie may originally have been written as a stage play. Mr. Gazzara and Ms. Moreno are Frank and Maggie, an attractive, still-in-love couple whose 40-year marriage has suddenly hit a retirement-age pothole.

title: Camby Lifts Knicks With Energy Boost
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The popular sentiment was that Marcus Camby wanted nothing to do with slamming his straw- thin, 225-pound body against the massive muscles of Jahidi White. Banging with White for half of a preseason game had given Camby lower back pain for two weeks, so the thinking was that the Knicks' post player was a bit frightened of the Washington Wizards' 290-pound center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELENIK, ANTON
description: VELENIK-Anton. On October 29, 2000. Beloved husband of Margaret Regan and son of Emiglia and the late Marco. Devoted father of Gary, Pedro and Christopher. Dear brother of Angelo and brother-in-law of Ina. Survived by his nephew Zeljko and niece Sylvia and other family members. A memorial service will be held Sunday, 2:00 PM at the Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street, New York City.

title: Students Bring Real Passion to a Mock Election
description: The topic under discussion was energy and environmental policy, specifically which of the two major presidential candidates had a better plan for supplementing the nation's oil reserves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, ROBERT DAVID
description: WEISBERG-Robert David. The Clergy, Officers, Board of Trustees, and the members of the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center announce with profound sadness the passing of their beloved President, Robert David Weisberg, Esquire. Robert D. Weisberg served the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center as President for almost twenty years. He was raised in the synagogue and spent his entire life deeply attached to ''his'' synagogue. He was an attorney of great distinction and a gentleman of great compassion. He served his country proudly in World War II, in the US Army Air Corps. He is survived and sorely missed by all, especially by his mother Tillie, wife Roslyn, daughters and sons-in-law Eileen and Dr. Barry Blutig, Phyllis and Neil Greenblum, as well as by his five grandchildren. May the Lord count them among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Typhoon Hits Philippines, at Least 24 Dead
description: MANILA, Nov. 3  At least 24 people were killed and over 100,000 others fled their homes on Friday after a typhoon slammed into the northern Philippines island of Luzon and roared through the capital of Manila, officials said.

title: Weakness of Bench Could Matter Sunday
description: The Giants entered the season confident they had talent to compete but fearful that their lack of depth could be exposed. On Sunday, two players and possibly a third will not play against the Browns.

title: Rule No. 1: Smile. Appear Cool and Detached. Always.
description: ''Why should people care what I do?'' asks the title character late in ''Jackie Bouvier Kennedy Onassis.'' Well, if the real woman had been as lifeless as this mini-series makes her, fewer people would have cared.

title: Article 2000110390022249684 -- No Title
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 2  After throwing barbs at all the other presidential candidates, Scott Dailey, a member of the school board here, introduced Patrick J. Buchanan to a luncheon today by joshing: "Pat says he is a serious candidate. The polls say he is dead serious."

title: Bush Assails Gore Proposals On Health Care
description: Gov. George W. Bush used a trip through the politically pivotal Midwest today to deride Vice President Al Gore's proposals for Medicare and prescription drugs as the nostrums of a man with a dangerously robust appetite for federal regulation.

title: Article 2000110393535401174 -- No Title
description: NEWARK, Nov. 2  Facing new questions about whether his wealth would influence his politics, Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate in New Jersey, today restated his vow to place his investments in a blind trust if he is elected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULHEREN, JOHN A.
description: MULHEREN-John A. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of NY note with sadness the passing of John A. Mulheren Sr., beloved father of John A Jr., a dear friend of the Jewish community who has enhanced our network's legal services to the poor through his exceptional generosity. We extend our sincerest condolences to Mr. Mulheren's sons, John and Michael; to his daughters, Maureen, Colleen Wood, Patricia Skinner, and Katherine Cabrera; to his 18 grandchildren; and to the entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Public Interests; Now, the College Bowl
description: These days, the Gore campaign really cannot say enough good things about the Electoral College.

title: Washington's Official Secrets Act
description: If President Clinton signs a bill that would make it a felony for government officials to disclose any kind of classified information, the American people should no longer expect to hear much about Washington's foreign policy failures and intelligence lapses, or even to learn the details of arms control treaties. These are some of the consequences that could come of the misguided secrecy measure that Congress approved last month with little debate and no open hearings.

title: SPAIN: AIRLINE MERGER TALKS
description: Spain's national carrier, Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana S.A. is engaged in talks about a possible merger with its smaller rival Air Europa S.A. Executives have set a period of 45 days to conclude the negotiations. No financial details were released. Spain's state holding company, SEPI, owns 54 percent of Iberia. Benjamin Jones (NYT)

title: Fitful Spirits Popping Up Everywhere, From the Mountains to McDonald's
description: Restless spirits roam the stage of the New Victory Theater these days and nights, but these ghosts are far from the usual specters that Hollywood sends out to haunt audiences in search of cheap thrills.

title: A New, and Ambitious, Home Away From Home
description: Eight years after the United States and Russia agreed to cooperate in a permanent human outpost in space, astronauts from both countries arrived at the International Space Station today and began what they hope will be continuous habitation of an expanding research platform 240 miles above Earth.

title: Sir Steven Runciman, 97, British Historian and Author
description: Sir Steven Runciman, a British historian who wrote stirring narratives of the crusades and the fall of the fabled Byzantine city of Constantinople to the 15th-century Turks, died on Wednesday in Radway, Warwickshire, England. He was 97 and lived in Dumfriesshire, in Scotland.

title: Mellow, Dazed or Manic, Break On Through to the Other Side
description: Call it a movement, call it a mood, European Romanticism was like adolescence: alternately ecstatic and bummed out; misanthropic and in love with love; self-absorbed and cosmically empathic. Life was approached as a kind of chemical experiment, volatile, risky. Any little thing could blow the mind, and often did.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY GOES ONLINE
description: The Social Security Administration began accepting new applications for benefits through its Web site (www.ssa.gov). Under the new system, applicants can go to the site, fill out an application form, print and sign it, and mail it to an address provided by Social Security. Along with the application, other documents like a birth certificate are required to establish eligibility for benefits, and there may be questions to be answered over the phone. Privacy is a high priority, officials said in a statement, so the administration is using the ''strongest commercially available encryption.'' An administration spokeswoman said the online process took about half an hour.

title: Article 2000110391621367027 -- No Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2  Responding to a radio host's lament that the Constitution barred him from running for a third term, President Clinton said today that Americans should vote for "the next best thing" by electing Vice President Al Gore on Tuesday.

title: Islanders Finding Ways to Win in Early-Season Uprising
description: Butch Goring grew accustomed to watching his Islanders squander leads or fall hopelessly behind with youthful indiscretions last season. The coach is now witnessing a metamorphosis. This long-suffering franchise appears to have embarked on a brighter future, aided by an infusion of veteran players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, HELEN SATZ
description: ROSENBLATT-Helen Satz, 97. On November 2 in Brooklyn, New York. Beloved wife of Harry and mother of Franklin and Arthur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELSINGER, MORTIMER NATHANIEL
description: FELSINGER-Mortimer Nathaniel. The generations of families who have grown and built enduring friendships at Camp Monroe, express their deepest gratitude to our friend whose strength and steadiness behind the scenes supported their summer home. He was a source of wisdom, integrity and guidance, especially for the Camp partners, as he modeled those qualities humbly, yet impeccably, in his own dealings with others. Even in our grief at his sudden departure from us, he is an inspiration of assurance in the Jewish beliefs which guided his life. We extend our deepest sympathy to all of the members of the Felsinger family. Wilson and Patricia Alling Lenny and Sam Amdurer David and Ellen Krieger Bruce and Nancy Rothstein

title: Clinton Says if He Can't Run, Gore Is the 'Next Best Thing'
description: Responding to a radio host's lament that the Constitution barred him from running for a third term, President Clinton said today that Americans should vote for ''the next best thing'' by electing Vice President Al Gore on Tuesday.

title: Pedro Barbeito
description: Lehmann Maupin

title: Qualcomm Profit Edges Up As Korea Wireless Sales Sag
description: Qualcomm said yesterday that its earnings edged higher in the last quarter, despite a decline in revenue resulting from slower sales in South Korea, one of its largest markets.

title: California Power Market
description: To the Editor:

title: I.C.I. PROFITS UP
description: Third-quarter profit at Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. rose 19 percent on the strength of cost-cutting at its fragrances, flavors and paints units. Net income before one-time gains rose to $:76 million ($110 million), or 10.5 pence a share. I.C.I. also said it would sell its remaining 30 percent stake in a joint venture making plastics and titanium oxide to its partner, Huntsman, for $365 million.

title: MUSICIANS OFFER COPYRIGHT WARNING
description: A group of recording artists led by Don Henley and Sheryl Crow warned Judge Jed S. Rakoff that his ruling on a key issue in a trial that will determine how many of the Seagram Universal Music Group sound recordings MP3.com infringed could directly affect hundreds of musicians. MP3.com, which is liable for over $100 million in damages, is contesting the validity of several thousand of Universal's copyrights on the ground that sound recordings are not works made for hire. That designation has long been a source of friction between artists and record labels, because unlike other copyrights that return to the artist after 35 years under the copyright law, the underlying copyright of a work made for hire never reverts back to its original author. But there has been no authoritative legal judgment on the status of sound recordings. In a letter to Judge Rakoff dated Nov. 1, the Recording Artists Coalition asked for permission to file a brief before the trial begins on Nov. 13. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Bilingual Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Protege Beats Grand Master in World Championship Chess
description: LONDON -- Chess has a new world champion after 15 years of domination by Garry Kasparov, who had fought off five previous challengers with his bold, brilliant moves and intimidating stares.

title: Students Bring Real Passion to a Mock Election

title: Ecce Bandwidth
description: Amoney manager once explained to me the attraction of the Gilder Technology Report newsletter. He didn't subscribe for the stock tips: George Gilder is wrong as often as he is right about individual companies. But Gilder tends to be on the money about trends or entire technological sectors. Such acumen, it appears, is in short supply. Thus his popularity with the plutocratic set. That, and his politics. Gilder is the original supply-side evangelist -- his book ''Wealth and Poverty'' (1981) influenced Reagan administration economic policy. And as he writes in ''Telecosm,'' his new book, ''The rich provide the investment and the rest reap the rewards.'' Gilder has married his technological perceptiveness with a libertarian brand of anti-government antagonism so right-wing as to make William Buckley blush. From the robber barons to Michael Milken to Bill Gates, Gilder never met a megacapitalist he didn't like. One can practically hear the Croesus class wishfully thinking: if he's correct about high-tech, then he's probably got the goods on politics, too! Not to mention the proper relationship between men and women. Gilder also happens to be the author of ''Men and Marriage'' (1972), an antifeminist polemic that got him named ''male chauvinist pig of the year'' by Time magazine. Gilder's tune seems not to have changed all that much. He writes in ''Telecosm'' that in the utopian future, while the husband gets stock news as he shaves, his wife will be grocery shopping online. Gilder should stick to technology. He's cute when he throws around words like ''petahertz'' and ''petabit'' and ''add/drop multiplexers'' and ''dispersion compensation modules.'' His enthusiasm is like that of a 2-year-old staring at zoo animals for the first time -- easy to share, hard to disagree with. But when he scorns big government he's not just boring and predictable -- he's whiny, and surprisingly halfhearted. In a chapter on Netscape and the birth of the Web that wearily covers old ground, his critical treatment of Microsoft's ultimate Web browser triumph is limited to putting the word ''monopolistic'' in quotation marks, as if the punctuation alone were enough to undermine any hint that Microsoft didn't play fair. Such rhetorical flourishes work only when you are preaching to the converted. And Gilder does deliver a good sermon. Miracles and transcendence abound in Gilder's telecosm -- his universe of fiber optic light, all glimmery with ''cornucopian radiance.'' God, angels, the Bible -- they all make appearances. It's no accident that the book's last word is ''divine.'' Gilder's got a gospel to spread -- the gospel of unlimited bandwidth. His book's unifying principle is that we are all destined to be brought together into ''networks of light linking cathedrals of mind.'' When Gilder focuses on the engineers who have delivered this ''promethean light'' he is engaging. When he zeroes in on individual companies, however, as he does in this book's latter half, he tends to sound like an annual report. But the book's main weakness is neither Gilder's exuberance nor his distaste for government meddling. The real problem is that his gospel has already been spread, most notably by himself. If the name Gilder and the word ''telecosm'' sound vaguely familiar, that's not surprising. ''Telecosm,'' the book, was first promised to readers as far back as 1993. Meanwhile, Gilder has been pounding out his passions in magazine articles, columns and endless lectures. He's impossible to avoid. It would be petty to blame Gilder for the delays. It's hard to keep up in the 21st century, as Gilder would be the first to acknowledge. No sooner have you hailed the ascendancy of a new paradigm than you're scrambling for cover as your latest metastructure crumbles in the face of yet another. Maybe Gilder is right. Maybe unlimited bandwidth will usher in an era of unlimited prosperity. But reading ''Telecosm'' you may find yourself asking, ''Yeah, and so what else is new?'' Andrew Leonard edits the technology and business sections of Salon.com.

title: Golf Angel to the Rescue
description: If you've ever been stuck on a long airline flight without a good spy novel or the day's newspapers, you may have found yourself flipping through the fat, glossy catalog thoughtfully placed in the seat pocket in front of you. Amid the pages of high-tech toys, power ties and kitchen gadgets, you might have noticed a section devoted to tchotchkes and posters emblazoned with deep thoughts and uplifting slogans. Many of these items have something to do with golf: tee-shaped cuff links, dimpled paperweights, and soft-focus framed photographs of sun-dappled fairways accompanied by proverbs like ''A man's grip on his club is like his grip on life'' or ''Golf is a game that can't be won, only played.''

title: Bush Acknowledges an Arrest for Drunken Driving in 1976
description: Gov. George W. Bush said tonight that he was arrested for driving while intoxicated 24 years ago while visiting his family's vacation home in Kennebunkport, Me.

title: Manuel Ocampo
description: Jack Shainman Gallery

title: Touring Pro Mike Turnesa, 93, Dies
description: Mike Turnesa, a member of a renowned Westchester County golfing family who competed as a top touring pro in the 1930's and 1940's, and was runner-up to Ben Hogan in the 1948 Professional Golfers Association Championship, died Tuesday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. He was 93.

title: Smaller Than Pyramids But Just as Monumental
description: For anyone used to thinking of Egyptian art in its massive, magnificent and even grandiose forms, the show ''Egyptian Art at Eton College: Selections From the Myers Museum'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will come as a minisurprise. Many of the stunning works in it are no bigger than a man's hand, and some are as small as a fingernail. They are almost all from the collection of Maj. William Joseph Myers (1858-99), an alumnus of Eton College in Windsor, England. Myers, who was killed in the Boer War, was an avid acquirer of things Egyptian and bequeathed the objects to his alma mater as a teaching collection.

title: Ugo Mulas
description: 'Sequences'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARDNER, RING, JR.
description: LARDNER-Ring, Jr. The Tisch School of the Arts mourns the passing of the great writer and dramatist, Ring Lardner, Jr. In his time teaching screenwriting in the Department of Dramatic Writing with Ian Hunter and with Waldo Salt, Mr. Lardner had a profound influence on his students. He was a teacher, a mentor, an inspiration, a model of integrity, engagement, and artistry. What he was and what he represented cannot be replaced. We shall miss him deeply.

title: Buchanan Nears the End of a Weak Run
description: After throwing barbs at all the other presidential candidates, Scott Dailey, a member of the school board here, introduced Patrick J. Buchanan to a luncheon today by joshing: ''Pat says he is a serious candidate. The polls say he is dead serious.''

title: Tua Says He Sees Lewis's Weaknesses
description: David Tua, preparing to meet Lennox Lewis for the heavyweight championship next Saturday in Las Vegas, has an analysis of the champion and a strategy to beat him.

title: A Lexus Republican, but No Friend of Lazio
description: YOU'RE practically neighbors, and there was a time when you might have earned his vote. He's a registered Republican, just like you. But beware, Representative Rick A. Lazio, you've gotten under the skin of the wrong guy. And not just because your Senate campaign keeps sending him that junk mail, or because he had a great time with President Clinton at that White House prayer breakfast in September (no, he didn't sleep in the Lincoln Bedroom). It's those things you've been saying about certain Muslim groups.

title: A Draw by Kramnik Makes Kasparov the Ex-Champion
description: Vladimir Kramnik, a 25-year-old Muscovite, is the new world chess champion. By drawing Game 15 of the match in London yesterday, he compiled the 8 1/2 points that determines the winner, and he will be awarded the $1.33 million prize. Garry Kasparov, the defeated former champion, will receive $667,000.

title: Pataki Says G.O.P. Calls Were 'Wrong'
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he believed that the state Republican Party's telephone campaign last week was ''wrong'' for trying to connect some of Hillary Rodham Clinton's donors to the kind of Mideast terrorism that has been blamed for the bombing of the destroyer Cole.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, BERNARD L.
description: GROSS-Bernard L. On October 31 in Stamford, CT. Father of William and adoring Pop-Pop to Katherine. Born Lion Gross in Brooklyn, N.Y. in 1915. He always lived up to that name. A business executive who took on his most cherished roleProfessor-in his later years. His knowledge, strength and unwavering high standards influenced many young minds. We'll miss his hearty laugh and his roar. Goodbye, Old Lion.

title: BRITAIN: CABLE ACQUISITION
description: In a deal valued at up to $407 million, Telewest Communications has agreed to buy Eurobell, which provides cable TV service to 336,600 homes in southern England, from Eurobell's parent, Deutsche Telekom. Telewest will pay up to $:280 million, including a portion of Eurobell's revenue next year.

title: Underwriting Dia's Dreams
description: Gifts totaling $50 million to the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea will underwrite a host of projects, transforming the center into a national institution concentrating on artists of the 1960's and 70's.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CONTAINER PORT LEASE SIGNED
description: A subsidiary of the P&O Group of London has signed a 30-year lease with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for a 158-acre site in Newark where P&O will open its first container port in the United States, the company and the port agency announced. The lease is for $65,000 per acre a year, said Richard Larrabee, director of port commerce for the agency, putting its total value at $308 million. P&O will spend an additional $150 million through 2001 dredging berths and upgrading cranes and other equipment. The site had been occupied by Maersk-Sealand, which signed its own 30-year lease to consolidate its operations at the nearby Elizabeth-Port Authority Marine Terminal. The P&O Group plans to combine two subsidiaries, P&O Nedlloyd and P&O Ports, both of London, to form a new company, Port Newark Container Terminal L.L.C., to run what will be P&O's first container port in the United States, Ray Venturino, a company spokesman, said. The new operation will be able to handle 800,000 shipping containers annually, compared with the 2.5 million containers that moved through Port Newark in 1999, a 7 percent increase, the port agency said. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: 'Print Fair'
description: Seventh Regiment Armory

title: Cole Sailors Return to Home Port
description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 3  More than 200 sailors from the crippled destroyer Cole returned to their home port today and were greeted by cheers from relatives and well-wishers under a cloudless blue sky.

title: Metro Business Briefing; REAL ESTATE LISTINGS GO MOBILE
description: Douglas Elliman, the real estate brokerage firm owned by Insigna/ESG, has made a version of its residential listings that can be downloaded onto a hand-held computer available free on its Web site, www.douglaselliman .com. Officials at Elliman said they hoped potential buyers would use the database and portable computers to get access to listings as they walked through Manhattan neighborhoods. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIS, DONALD J., MD
description: REIS-Donald J., MD of New York City and Stonington, CT, beloved husband of Cornelia Langer Noland and stepfather of Lyn, Cady and William Noland, died at age 69 on November 1, 2000. He was the George C. Cotzias Distinguished Professor of Neurology and Neuroscience at Cornell Medical Center and a renowned international neuroscience pioneer. Doctor Reis trained more than one hundred scientists around the world and received numerous awards for his work throughout a long and illustrious career. A memorial service is scheduled at the Century Association, 7 West 43rd Street on Friday, November 17th at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Department of Neurology and Neuroscience, WeillCornell Medical Center, 1300 York Avenue (Room F613), NY, NY 10021 or to the Citizens Commit tee for New York City, 305 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001.

title: Hacker Defaces Pro-Israel Web Site as the Mideast Conflict Expands Into Cyberspace
description: The Web site for the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, a lobbying group, was defaced Wednesday with anti-Israeli commentary -- an increasingly common occurrence as the escalating conflict between Israelis and Palestinians has spilled over into cyberspace.

title: Perot Supports Bush, Citing Character and Texas Record
description: Ross Perot, the estranged founder of the Reform Party whose candidacy in 1992 helped defeat President George Bush, tonight offered a surprise endorsement of the former president's son, Gov. George W. Bush.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Priceline Cuts Work Force As Financial Officer Quits

title: Destination Unknown in the Swirling Mist
description: Because its stage and sightlines allow choreographic details to be unusually clear, the City Center is a fine place to see quirky ballets. And American Ballet Theater has been presenting some fascinatingly quirky creations in its autumn season there.

title: Despite Stock Sale Limits, Corzine Pledges Blind Trust
description: Facing new questions about whether his wealth would influence his politics, Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate in New Jersey, today restated his vow to place his investments in a blind trust if he is elected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, EVELYNE HARTFIELD
description: LEEDS-Evelyne Hartfield. on Nov. 1, 2000 at her home. Survived by a daughter and son-in-law, Lydia Hartfield-Leeds Hoban and Patrick N. Hoban of Ridgefield, CT. Services will be private. Memorials in her memory may be made to the Robert L. Fine Cancer Research Laboratory Foundation at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, New York, NY.

title: Mary Esch
description: Bronwyn Keenan

title: Working Plenty And Loving It
description: ''I'm a bit of a workhorse,'' said Laura Linney, the versatile Juilliard-schooled actress who has brought her craft to projects as diverse as ''Uncle Vanya'' on Broadway, ''Tales of the City'' on television and ''The Truman Show'' in the movies. ''I made four films last summer. I went from one to another, and I just loved it.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're just starting a long journey.''

title: Turkish Women Who See Death as a Way Out
description: A 22-year-old woman threw herself from the roof of a seven-story building across from her family's apartment after being beaten by her parents for wearing a tight skirt.

title: Canadian Party Wrestles With Its Leader's Record on Gay Issues
description: To Glen Murray, the openly gay mayor of this western prairie city, Stockwell Day is a homophobic, ''dangerous man'' whose ambition to become Canada's prime minister threatens ''this country with some of the most extremist policies ever.''

title: Puerto Asis journal; To Make a Point, the Rebels Are Strangling a Town
description: At the San Francisco de Asis Hospital, doctors say antibiotics are running dangerously low. Gasoline, normally $1.50 a gallon, is being sold out of darkened doorways, for close to $5.

title: Democratic Senator Is in Fight of His Political Life

title: Home Video
description: First seasons of television shows are growing into their own video genre. This summer HBO released the first season of "Sex and the City," and this winter it will issue the first year of "The Sopranos." On Tuesday Docurama released the first season of Michael Moore's "Awful Truth," which sends the corporation-tweaking gadfly on various missions to make life uncomfortable for the rich and exploitive.

title: Alone in the Wilds, Where Nature Makes Waves
description: There are many iconic American landscapes, but perhaps none is more evocative than the mountains and lakes of the Adirondacks. The northern forests, a mix of conifers and hardwoods, are everything we think a forest should be. The peaks are ancient, bare granite; the streams are magical, tumbling past banks blanketed in green moss and ferns. James Fenimore Cooper's Hawkeye could still be lurking in the morning mists, or at least the movie image of Daniel Day Lewis in ''The Last of the Mohicans.''

title: 'Photasm'
description: Hunter College/Times Square Gallery

title: Canada Port Gains as Ice Diminishes
description: Here on the edge of Canada's tree line, where polar bears prowl the tundra under the dancing lights of the northern sky, a Barbadian flag vessel was at port one recent evening, its crew sweeping aside snow to fill its holds with grain for shipment direct to Europe.

title: Residential Real Estate; 'Green' Tower at Battery Park City
description: While it will be the 22nd residential tower in Manhattan's Battery Park City, the 266-unit rental scheduled to rise there next will be the first designed as a so-called green building: one that is energy efficient, environmentally sensitive and healthier for tenants.

title: Officers to Testify Against 5 Charged in Beating of Suspect
description: The chief prosecutor in the civil rights trial of five Orange, N.J., police officers accused of beating a police-shooting suspect who died in custody told jurors today that the case would rely largely on testimony from two other officers.

title: HAMPTON STANDS PAT
description: Mike Hampton has not filed for free agency, which could be a sign that his agent, Mark Rodgers, is waiting for an offer from the Mets. Rodgers said he was keeping his promise to give the Mets an exclusive negotiating window but said he already knew where the Mets stood based on his conversations with them since the World Series.

title: Suavely Taming the High-Kicking Kander and Ebb
description: The singer and pianist Steve Ross deserves points for bravery, if for nothing else, in his newest cabaret show, ''Love and Laughter: The Sequel.'' This ultra-debonair performer who has made his name celebrating Cole Porter, Noel Coward and Fred Astaire has turned his attention to the brassier work of John Kander and Fred Ebb in a show that runs through Dec. 2 at the Firebird Cafe (363 West 46th Street, Clinton). But the chemistry between the performer and the material just isn't here.

title: The Big City; Voucher Issue Casts Light On a Paradox
description: SUE CLEARY has approximately zero chance of unseating Major Owens, the Brooklyn congressman, but she was raising an awkward issue for him and his fellow Democrats on Wednesday afternoon in Flatbush.

title: Bush's Guard Attendance Is Questioned and Defended
description: Two Democratic senators today called on Gov. George W. Bush to release his full military record to resolve doubts raised by a newspaper about whether he reported for required drills when he was in the Air National Guard in 1972 and 1973.

title: At Michigan State, Politics Interrupted by Class
description: Pop quiz: Why did 120 students pack into a dormitory lounge here at Michigan State University the other night?

title: Racial Profiling Case in New Jersey Puts Supreme Court Justice Under More Scrutiny
description: For two decades, he was the ambitious and inexhaustible foot soldier, a record that led Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to name him to be attorney general and then, before he turned 40, to a spot on New Jersey's Supreme Court.

title: Mayor Says He Has Little Use For State Transportation Bond
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was ''not a big proponent'' of the $3.8 billion Transportation Infrastructure Bond Act that is to go before New York State voters on Tuesday, even though his administration has endorsed it.

title: Stamford Janitors Are Seen, Hoping Wage Plea Is Heard
description: For years, this city of gleaming office towers has prided itself on its prosperity. But suddenly, Stamford has been rocked -- and embarrassed -- by a janitors' strike that has forced the city to pay attention to its often-ignored underside.

title: To Aid Poor, Gates Takes On Odd Role
description: For a man thought of as the world's chief evangelist for computer technology, William H. Gates is assuming a surprising role these days, taking his own industry to task for having too much faith in digital solutions to the planet's worst ills.

title: With Finish Line in Sight, An All-Out Race for Money
description: Five days before the most expensive election in American history, top officials of the Republican and Democratic Parties were still scrambling to raise huge sums of money today, asking some top donors for checks as large as $1 million.

title: Senior Philippine Lawmakers Resign
description: MANILA, Philippines -- The heads of both houses of Congress resigned from the ruling party Friday, the most senior lawmakers to abandon the embattled president, amid growing support for his impeachment over a corruption scandal.

title: 'Rhythm' Faces Money Blues
description: With reports of a financial setback circulating, producers of the new musical ''The Rhythm Club'' say they are still raising money for the $7 million show but are confident that they will open on Broadway as scheduled.

title: Jets Lose Abraham, Possibly for the Season
description: The rookie linebacker John Abraham, who has helped make the Jets' defense more aggressive by reviving the team's pass rush, will have surgery Friday to repair a torn abdominal muscle, the Jets announced today.

title: Psinet Suffers Losses, Weighs Independence
description: Psinet Inc., a major commercial Internet service provider, said today that it would consider whether to remain independent after spending one-third of its cash in four months and losing more money than expected in its third quarter. Its shares plunged 56 percent and its bonds slumped.

title: Court Considers if Employer Can Force Pledge Not to Sue
description: Five years ago, St. Clair Adams saw a Help Wanted sign at the Circuit City store in Santa Rosa, Calif., and went in to apply for a job. He remembers feeling only ''minor discomfort'' when told he would not be considered unless he gave up his right to sue the retailer.

title: Sufi Passion That Rises To Ecstasy
description: Poetry is at the core of the Sufi devotional songs called qawwali. The words praise saints, yearn for a beloved (who may be human or divine) and extol spiritual ecstasy. At the same time, the music propels listeners toward that ecstasy with steady handclapping, incantatory refrains, surges of drumming and soaring vocal improvisations.

title: Israel on Full Alert After Jerusalem Bomb
description: JERUSALEM -- Israeli and Palestinian leaders both urged restraint Friday in hopes the latest cease-fire effort would take hold, but clashes erupted in several West Bank towns following Muslim midday prayers.

title: An Environmental Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, MARIE
description: PETERSON-Marie. 80, died October 30, 2000, of Bronx, NY. She is still with us in our hearts. She is survived her daughters Linda Vazquez, Marilyn Friedland and her sons Richard and John Peterson.

title: Maple Leafs Come Back In Third to Defeat Devils
description: The Devils' dressing room was full of gloomy faces after a third-period collapse led to a 5-3 loss to the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight at Air Canada Center. The Devils (6-3-3-0) saw a six-game undefeated streak come to an end and may lose goalie Martin Brodeur for a few days because of a slight groin injury he sustained in the third period.

title: In Space: The Costs, the Dreams
description: To the Editor:

title: Perot Endorses Bush
description: Ross Perot endorsed George W. Bush, eight years after his own White House bid helped to defeat Mr. Bush's father. Page A27.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WORLD WRESTLING FEDERATION ENTERTAINMENT, Stamford, Conn., announced that it would take a $7 million charge after settling a wrongful death lawsuit brought by the family of Owen Hart, a professional wrestler. Mr. Hart fell 78 feet to his death in May 1999 when a mechanism on a harness lowering him to the ring opened prematurely.

title: Distance Runners No Longer Lonely
description: Just after his daily 6 a.m. bargaining session with the snooze button, and before his desk job would begin hours later, Josh Cox would start a 10-mile training run by quickly summoning his matador instincts.

title: Value of Welfare Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBEL, RICHARD K.
description: WEBEL-Richard K. Of Old Brookville, NY, on November 1, 2000, age 100. Loving husband of Pauline D. Father and stepfather of Robert G. Pratt, Arthur D. Pratt, Pauline P. Brown, Richard C. Webel. Grandfather of seven and great grandfather of four. Funeral service to be held at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY, at 11:00 AM on Saturday, November 4. Contributions may be made to the Webel Scholarship Fund, Box 560, Locust Valley, NY 11560.

title: On a Favorite Issue, Gore Finds Himself on a 2-Front Defense
description: Vice President Al Gore has labored long and hard to make environmental protection his signature issue, but in the closing days of the presidential campaign, he is finding himself in an unexpected position.

title: Requiem for a Dot-Com
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets' Martin Is Hoping To Shake Rookie Jitters
description: In only one game, Kenyon Martin has experienced the highs and lows of a rookie. His emotion took him soaring to the catwalks in Continental Arena, where his shots quickly seemed to follow.

title: Retail Sales in October Up a Disappointing 2.9%
description: At the Lord & Taylor flagship store on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, decorators are hard at work on the circus-themed holiday windows to be revealed in two weeks. Sony Play-Station 2, the season's hottest gift item, is already almost impossible to find. But even as the season's rituals unfurl with predictable flourish, many retailers are preparing to deal with a rising tide of consumer malaise.

title: Article 2000110393022706623 -- No Title
description: FAIRFAX, Va., Nov. 2  The slugfest between Senator Charles S. Robb, the two-term Democratic incumbent, and his Republican challenger, former Gov. George F. Allen, turned even more bitter this week when Mr. Robb accused his rival of compiling an "intolerable" and "appalling" record on racial issues.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with a theater review of two plays -- ''Rice Boy'' at the Yale Repertory Theater and ''Nocturne'' at the Hasty Pudding Theater at Harvard -- reversed the identifications of two actors in ''Rice Boy.'' Sean T. Krishnan was at the center and Sanjiv Jhaveri at the left. Wayne Kasserman was correctly identified on the right.

title: Hillary Clinton Now Running on Husbands Record

title: Officials See Escape Bid In Jail Attack On a Guard
description: Officials said yesterday that there were indications that an attack on a jail guard was part of an escape attempt by two prisoners awaiting trial in the African embassies bombing case.

title: Article 2000110391220404074 -- No Title
description: November 3, 2000

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Winston Grennan, 56, Jamaican Drummer
description: Winston Grennan, a Jamaican drummer whose extensive studio work crystallized and disseminated the fundamental reggae rhythm called one drop, died on Oct. 27 in Nantucket, Mass., where he had moved this year. He was 56.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REMETICH, GEORGE J.
description: REMETICH-George J. On November 2, 2000. Retired Baldwin (NY) High School Science teacher and sports coach. Husband of Darcey (Janowsky), Father to Jeannette, Sally Ann, stepfather to Ava Schoneberg, friend of Larry Frishman, Roni Pagano, wife of Vincent, and Ian. Son of Minnie (Zorovich) and the late George R, brother to Diane Feduniec, friend of Kenny Lohr. Grandfather to two. Services Monday with visitations Sunday in Montrose, the Bartron Funeral Home, Montrose, PA.

title: Popularity Is Increasing for Balloting Outside the Box
description: In Denver, requests for absentee ballots have tripled from the 1998 elections. Special early polling stations, allowing people to vote at libraries, shopping malls or supermarkets before Election Day, have attracted long lines in New Mexico, North Carolina and Texas. And, in Oregon, no one is expected to show up at the polls on Nov. 7 -- everyone votes by mail.

title: After 'Next Best' Thing, Clinton Carefully Praises Gore
description: The crowd yelled, ''Four more years! Four more years!'' and their cheers brought a huge smile to President Clinton.

title: The Refrain of a Bitter Town: Where Was Al?
description: It is enough to rattle political ghosts in the empty steel mills rusting away along the Ohio River Valley: Virgil Reynolds, retired mill hand and Democratic precinct committeeman here in Columbiana County, is agonizing that he cannot bring himself to vote for Vice President Al Gore next Tuesday.

title: Plastic Bodies That Defy Extremes
description: ''Trips and Trysts,'' a shimmering new piece with a futuristic chrome finish and music by Wynton Marsalis, has been a highlight of the Garth Fagan dance company's season and will be performed again tonight and at both performances tomorrow. Yet many of Mr. Fagan's earlier works stand up even more impressively.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: So Boson Arrives At the Party . . .
description: Particle physics is outside the realm of ordinary experience, so it's hard to explain. And in particular, the physics of the Higgs boson is so hard to explain that scientists once competed in a contest to see if anyone could do it in less than a page.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Viacom in $2.3 Billion Deal For Black Entertainment TV

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTEIN, SYDELLE
description: GERSTEIN-Sydelle. Died on November 3, 2000 in her 94th year at her home in Hewlett, NY. She was the widow of Irving C. Gerstein, who died in 1969 and is survived by her son, David M. Gerstein, her daughter, Barbara Shore, her grandchildren, Cynthia Sila, Steven Shore, Lisa Gerstein and Clifford Shore, her great-grandchildren, Michael Sila, Elizabeth Sila and Jonathan Sila, her grandsonin-law, Bora Sila, her daughter-inlaw, Susan Gerstein, her son-inlaw, George Shore, and her brother, Herbert Feinberg. Her special qualities will always be remembered. A funeral service will be held on Sunday, November 5th, at 12:30 PM at Boulevard-Riverside Funeral Home, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557.

title: Pierce Leads Celtics To Victory Again
description: Paul Pierce scored 30 points and Antoine Walker added 20 last night as host Boston beat Toronto, 93-91, sending the Raptors to their third consecutive loss despite 33 points from Vince Carter.

title: WIRELESS BIDDERS RAIDED
description: Dutch antitrust regulators said they had raided the offices of Versatel Telecom International and Telfort, two bidders in a July auction of mobile-phone licenses, seeking evidence that the two companies had colluded in their bidding. The auction yielded only one quarter of the proceeds the government had hoped for. Telfort is a unit of British Telecommunications.

title: Kaj Aage Strand, 93, Astronomer At the U.S. Naval Observatory
description: Kaj Aage Strand, an astronomer and former scientific director of the United States Naval Observatory, died on Tuesday in Washington. He was 93.

title: Glyndebourne Finds Itself With No Chief
description: After just over two years in the job, Nicholas Snowman resigned this week as general director of the Glyndebourne opera festival, a spokeswoman for Glyndebourne Productions said today.

title: Corrections
description: An entry on Thursday in the listing of the blacklisted writers, directors and producers known as the Hollywood Ten, with the obituary of Ring Lardner Jr., misstated the year of the writer Samuel Ornitz's death. It was 1957, not 1985.

title: A Final Weekend of Campaign Thrust and Parry
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Fire Chambliss; Rojas Leaves the Mets
description: Success for both the Yankees and the Mets is not translating into stability for their respective coaching staffs. The Yankees fired Chris Chambliss, the hitting coach, during the team's string of four championships in five years, and the Mets will lose at least two coaches and maybe another.

title: The Welfare Safety Net
description: To the Editor:

title: Staid Ivy League Town Suits the Party of Nader
description: When Green Party die-hards want to feel the warm embrace of like-minded progressives, they come to this mannered and manicured college town, even though it is not exactly famous for political radicalism.

title: Second Suspect Is Charged in Attack on Immigrant Laborers
description: After being the target of a 45-day search through three states, the second suspect in the beating of two immigrant day laborers turned himself in to the Suffolk County police and was arraigned today.

title: Dr. Donald Reis, 69, Professor Who Explored the Brain's Effects
description: Dr. Donald Jeffery Reis, a New York neurobiologist who explored the brain's role in human emotions, behavior and disease, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 69 and lived on the Upper East Side and in Stonington, Conn.

title: New Competition Arises to Run Realty Listings Web Site
description: Just a few days after two competing groups of real estate companies announced that they were going to start a joint Web site for Manhattan residential listings, a new level of confusion and competition has emerged, this time between the two companies vying to run the Internet operation.

title: Yes, Even the Rich Deserve a Tax Cut
description: Allow me to introduce myself: I am among the richest of Americans, excess of the 1980's, some people might say. I earned about what a top athlete does over the last 17 years by starting a chip company in Silicon Valley now worth $5 billion.

title: 'Perfect' Apple Pushed Growers Into Debt
description: Nearly a half-century ago, the farmers in these dun-colored valleys east of the Cascade Mountains set out to create the perfect apple. It would be lipstick red; broad-shouldered; uniform in size, color and crispness; a health food that would look as dazzling as an ornament on a Christmas tree.

title: MetroStars Expect Matthaus to Depart
description: The MetroStars' acquisition of Francis Okaroh, the Nigerian international defender, from the San Jose Earthquakes yesterday is a strong indication that Lothar Matthaus will not return to the team.

title: In His Own Words
description: AL GORE

title: Insular Congress Appears to Be Myth
description: The common wisdom about Congress, repeated in news reports and accepted as truth at foreign embassies and in graduate seminars, is that its members are homebound and uninterested in the world. And the statistic most often cited to back up this wisdom is that only half even hold a passport.

title: From High in the Austrian Alps, A Bracing Whiff of Forgotten Glories
description: Among his many gifts, the Austrian composer Ernst Krenek was an engaging and original writer. He wrote the librettos for his own operas, including ''Jonny Spielt Auf,'' the audacious 1927 work that for a while made him the hero of avant-garde European opera.

title: For Mosleys, Fighting Is Reserved for the Ring
description: After growing up in the Watts section of Los Angeles, Jack Mosley got married and moved to suburban Pomona, Calif., to raise three children with his wife, Clemmie. But Mosley wanted his only son, Shane, to get a sense of city life, so he took him on frequent field trips.

title: Returning to Freud for Help With the Riddles of Philosophy
description: ''I say this whole picture of striving toward something needs to be criticized,'' said Jonathan Lear. Mr. Lear is talking about nothing less than death and happiness. That may not seem odd for a philosophy professor. Still, at a time when departments are dominated by Kantian abstractions and the narrow logical constructions of analytic philosophy, Mr. Lear is someone who isn't afraid to ask big questions.

title: Legislators In Nassau Will Try An Override
description: The Democrats who control the Nassau County Legislature hope to override the line-item vetoes that County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta made to their four-year fiscal rescue plan. But they will wait until the last possible day to take that vote, they said today.

title: Is Social Stability Subverted If You Answer 'I Don't'?; Fears for Children's Well-Being Complicate a Debate Over Marriage
description: The statistic has not yet lost its power to shock: about a third of the births in this country each year are to unmarried mothers.

title: Maine Lawyer Delights in Leaking Bush's Arrest
description: Thomas Connolly makes no bones about it: he is delighted to have served as a central conduit for spreading the word that George W. Bush was arrested for drunken driving in Kennebunkport, Me., in 1976.

title: G.O.P. Stalwart in Bronx Now Looks Vulnerable
description: For nearly 14 years, Guy J. Velella has been the most unlikely of kingpins: an influential Republican state senator in the Bronx, New York City's most Democratic borough; an amiable politician to whom even the state's Democrats went for counsel or support.

title: A Final Weekend of Campaign Thrust and Parry; The Nader Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNY, H. JAMES, JR.
description: KENNY-H. James, Jr. Age 78 of Bernardsville, N.J. formerly of Summit, N.J. on Nov. 2, 2000. Beloved husband of 53 years of Mary Jane (Devine), devoted father of Bonnie Cooper, Jandy Hemingway, Christine Frisbee, Susan Long, Linda Kenny, Karen Kenny, James Kenny, Peter Kenny, Meganne Kenny-Cusato, Christopher Kenny, Mark Kenny and Tara McKenna. Brother of Marie Bauer, Robert Kenny, and grandfather of 36, and great grandfather of one. Private Family services on Monday, Nov. 6, 2000. Relatives and Friends may visit at the Family Residence, 5 Pine Hollow, Bernardsville, N.J. on Saturday and Sunday from 2-5 P.M. only. In lieu of flowers, please make donation to the Museum of the 390th Bomb Group, Tuscan, AZ. 85726-9999.

title: An Abrupt Ending Cools Off the Islanders and Their Hot Streak
description: The Islanders' hottest streak in five years came to a sudden end tonight.

title: Out on a Limb, Another Effort To Lift the Euro
description: Looking more and more like an institution that has been backed into a corner, the European Central Bank intervened in global currency markets again today to prop up the woebegone euro.

title: Marbury Comes Alive To Lead Nets Past Bulls
description: Stephon Marbury had promised: wait until Friday. That was when, albeit a game late, he would make his real debut.

title: A Final Weekend of Campaign Thrust and Parry
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Thursday about Brazil's national soccer team misidentified a player allegedly pressured to play while ill. He is Ronaldo, not Romario.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELBIN (ELBOGEN), HERMAN ZVI
description: ELBIN (ELBOGEN)-Herman Zvi, died November 3rd, 2000. He was born December 19th, 1915. The funeral was held in Jerusalem, Israel. The surviving families are Elbin, Ronen and Penchina in New York, Tel-Aviv, Baltimore, and North Egremont.

title: SATELLITE STAKE IN BRAZIL
description: The European satellite operator Societe Europeenne des Satellites, or S.E.S., acquired 20 percent of the satellite unit of Embratel Participacoes, a Brazilian long-distance provider, for $675 million after receiving Brazilian regulatory approval. S.E.S., which runs the European Astra network of broadcast satellites, has the option to raise its stake to 30 percent of Embratel Satellite, which provides broadband Internet services via satellite throughout Latin America. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Journal; George W.'s America
description: It's now official: We have learned far more about George W. Bush and Al Gore than they know about themselves. The press has at last plumbed the shallows of both men, and even the ''November surprise,'' a Fox reporter's revelation of Mr. Bush's police blotter during his blotto years, is not up to Rupert Murdoch's top scandal standards. There may be little choice now but to move on to those nostalgic staples of photo-finish horse races: What if it's a tie? What if the popular-vote victor loses the Electoral College? Most entertaining of all is this year's last-minute human-interest sideshow, ''Dead Man Running'': If Missouri elects a corpse to the Senate, can it still purport to be the ''Show Me'' state?

title: RESUMPTION OF PERSONAL COMPUTER SALES IS PLANNED
description: The Kmart Corporation said it would return to selling personal computers for the first time in 20 years by introducing a low-priced private-label PC called the BlueLight True Blue, to be sold through the company's BlueLight.com Web site and at 1,600 of Kmart's 2,163 stores. The basic computer, with a 633-megahertz Intel processor, will sell for $499, the company said; bundled with a color printer and monitor, it will cost $650 after a $30 rebate. The company said it would introduce other products under the BlueLight label, including jewelry in the next few months.

title: Seoul's Most-Indebted List Leaves Questions
description: Hoping to ease concerns about mounting bad loans at financial institutions, South Korean banks announced today a much-anticipated list of the most-indebted businesses that have been designated for closing.

title: Napster Is Dead. Long Live Napster!
description: To the Editor:

title: A Final Weekend of Campaign Thrust and Parry
description: To the Editor:

title: Cape Town Journal; Bones in Museum Cases May Get Decent Burials
description: For decades the ugly secrets slept in the dusty storerooms of South Africa's museums, hidden with the bones of a forgotten people whose bodies were defiled in the name of science.

title: A Tyrant in the Workplace: Who Will Face Him Down?
description: ''Tabletop'' by Rob Ackerman was presented at the Bessie Schonberg Theater in Chelsea from July 8 through Aug. 13. A new run began on Monday at the American Place Theater, 111 West 46th Street, Manhattan. Here are excerpts from a review by D. J. R. Bruckner on July 25:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ATCHISON CASTING CORP., Atchison, Kan., a maker of iron, steel and nonferrous castings, said it had determined that asset accounts had been overstated and liabilities understated at its Pennsylvania Foundry Group division. Atchison Casting said it was conducting an investigation.

title: Schools Leader Treads Lightly On Instruction
description: Nine months into his tenure as New York City's schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy has earned a reputation as a hard-nosed manager who does not abide the sluggishness of the school bureaucracy. With much fanfare, he has handed more power to superintendents, started overhauling the way teachers are recruited and sought to privatize some failing schools.

title: NIKKO BUYS PORT OPERATOR
description: A unit of Japan's Nikko Securities, agreed to buy Powell Duffryn, which operates the Tees and Hartlepool shipping port in northeastern England, for about $:550 million ($797 million) in cash and assumed debt, or 650 pence ($9.44) a share. Nikko said it would try to sell Powell Duffryn's engineering-related businesses units.

title: Communist School Days
description: To the Editor:

title: Limits of Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Austrian bass-baritone Walter Berry on Tuesday misidentified his wife, who survives him. She is Elisabeth Flechl; Brigitte Hohenecker was his second wife.

title: Lieberman Homes In on Bush's Foreign Policy
description: Continuing to hammer at Gov. George W. Bush's relative inexperience in government, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman dedicated an entire speech today to making the case that, unlike Vice President Al Gore, Mr. Bush is not qualified to handle foreign policy.

title: In a Battle for the Senate, Themes Mirror the National Contest
description: Treated to one of the tightest, nastiest, most expensive races for the United States Senate, voters in Michigan could become dizzy watching the swirl of punches and counterpunches between Spencer Abraham, the Republican incumbent, and Representative Debbie Stabenow, the Democratic challenger.

title: Jets' Hayes Is Elated To Be Starter at Last
description: For Chris Hayes, this is a dream, a chance after years of the anonymity and body-beating of special teams to get significant playing time at his true position, safety.

title: Gore Describes Texan as Not Up to the Job
