title: Corrections
description: A music listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for the New York Philharmonic misstated the schedule for the pianist Emanuel Ax. His schedule included evening concerts Thursday, yesterday and tonight, but not the concert this afternoon.

title: In Blow to True North, Chrysler Shifts Ad Accounts to Omnicom
description: In one of the largest consolidations ever of advertising assignments by a giant marketer, the Chrysler Group said late yesterday that it had decided to use units of the Omnicom Group in New York to handle its worldwide creative and media accounts, with billings estimated at $1.8 billion.

title: MORE CANADIANS UNEMPLOYED
description: Canada's unemployment rate rose to 6.9 percent in October from 6.8 percent in September. Although 20,000 new jobs were created by an economy that remains strong, even more Canadians began looking for work. The manufacturing and service sectors accounted for most job gains; construction employment fell. Wage increases slowed to a 3.7 percent annual rate in October, from 4 percent the month before. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Duval Says He Is Ready For Woods
description: Tiger Woods and David Duval love playing together, but they also love to win.

title: Stakes High For Miami Against Va. Tech
description: For the Miami Hurricanes, Saturday's showdown against Virginia Tech comes down to one fundamental question: how much longer can we let these guys beat us?

title: Fighting Eviction With Song and Brio
description: The San Francisco Mime Troupe has a lot to say about urban real estate development. And it said so at the Theater for the New City last Saturday with wit and high spirits.

title: Minikus and Oh Star Faultless at Garden
description: Oh Star, ridden by Todd Minikus of Loxahatchee, Fla., jumped all 13 fences on the course without a fault in 53.48 seconds last night to win the $30,000 Welcome Stake for open jumpers at the opening session of the 117th National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden. The chestnut stallion and his 38-year-old owner-rider defeated a field of 23 in the invitational event that served as a prelude to tomorrow's $125,000 Grand Prix of New York.

title: Doctors Back Many Palestinian Accusations, but Not All
description: An independent investigation into the past month's violence, reported today, echoed many Palestinian accusations against Israel. Still, Palestinian officials criticized the study for finding that one publicized Palestinian death was a result of a traffic accident, rather than a killing.

title: Panel Urges Remedies to Abuses by Police
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights urged Congress today to make it easier for people to sue abusive police officers and for the government to investigate police misconduct.

title: U.S.-North Korea Missile Talks Stall; Clinton Trip Is in Doubt
description: Three days of talks with North Korea about its missile program ended inconclusively today, throwing into doubt whether President Clinton would visit North Korea.

title: Impeachment Of Estrada Is Certainty, Rival Asserts
description: MANILA  Vice President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo said Friday that her political allies had collected enough votes to impeach President Joseph Estrada and that she had already decided on several posts in the "next administration," including the position of finance secretary.

title: Protecting a Favorable Image; Biotechnology Concerns in Quandary Over Drug Giants
description: When executives and lobbyists from the biotechnology industry visit Capitol Hill these days, they are often given unsolicited advice: distance yourselves, they are told, from big pharmaceutical companies, which have become public villains in the debate over rising drug prices.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY
description: MOYNIHAN'S LEGACY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, ISABEL (NEE OWEN)
description: WRIGHT-Isabel (nee Owen), of Manasquan, NJ, formerly of New York City, NY, on November 3, 2000. Wife of the late John Gilbert Wright. Beloved mother of Virginia Westphal, and Henry Owen Wright. Loving grandmother of Michael, Gil, and Kendra Wright and Lauren Westphal. Greatgrandmother of Zachery Wright. Sister of the late Henry Owen. Funeral from the O'Brien Funeral Home, Hwy 35 at New Bedford Rd., Wall, NJ, Monday, November 6 at 8:30 AM. Mass St. Mark's Church, Sea Girt, NJ at 9:30 AM. Entombment St. Catharine's Cemetery Mausoleum. Visiting hours Sunday, November 5 from 1-5 PM.

title: On a Particle's Trail, Physicists Seek Time
description: Before hundreds of their cheering colleagues, scientists at the leading European particle physics laboratory pleaded with its managers yesterday to be allowed to continue working on experiments they believe may be about to answer one of thorniest questions in physics: what gives matter its weight.

title: Political Scientists Leading a Revolt, Not Studying One
description: The protester used the code name Mr. Perestroika. His e-mail messages preached popular revolt. ''Head for the Parliament folks! (just as they did in Belgrade),'' one read in part. ''When people are pushed to the brink, the leaders go, the regime goes, the country changes!'' read another.

title: INSIDE
description: Mideast Meetings Planned

title: UNILEVER EARNINGS UP
description: Unilever, the BritishDutch consumer products giant, posted a 7.2 percent rise in third-quarter profits, aided by strong dollar earnings from American acquisitions, including Ben & Jerry's ice cream and SlimFast diet foods. The company, which completed its $24.3 billion purchase of Bestfoods on Oct. 4, said net income excluding charges rose to 957 million euros ($824 million) from 893 million euros in the period a year earlier. Unilever stock rose 4.5 percent in Amsterdam and 6.3 percent in London. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: A Final Weekend of Campaign Thrust and Parry
description: To the Editor:

title: A Final Weekend of Campaign Thrust and Parry
description: To the Editor:

title: Jobless Rate Held at 3.9% Last Month
description: The unemployment rate remained at a 30-year low last month, even as evidence mounted that the nation's economic growth is slowing.

title: For Georgia Name-Calling, Nothing Is Lower Than 'Hillary'
description: It is the lowest, meanest, nastiest insult one Georgia politician can hurl at another. It is worse than scalawag or Yankee, liberal or atheist, so incendiary a weapon that it has not been wheeled out until the final weeks of the campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVANEY, MURIEL
description: DEVANEY-Muriel. On November 2, 2000 of Port Washington. Formerly of Manhasset. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Loving mother of Daniel (Patricia), Maureen Melley (Peter) and Brian (Maura). Also survived by 13 adoring grandchildren and one great grandchild. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Sunday, 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral mass Monday, 9:30AM at St. Peter of Alcantara Church, Port Washington. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Port Washington Fire Department, Fire Medic Company #

title: Police Call Drug Gang Hard to Root Out
description: In an era of stabilized crack markets and increasingly intricate drug investigations, the Black-Top gang kept pace with the times to make close to $2 million a year, city prosecutors said yesterday.

title: A Final Weekend of Campaign Thrust and Parry; Swapping Votes
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a request from Microsoft to limit briefs in its antitrust case referred incorrectly to those whose briefs the company opposed. Not all supported the government; two groups -- the Association for Objective Law and the Center for the Moral Defense of Capitalism -- sought to file in support of Microsoft. Later developments are reported today on Page C4.

title: After Sides Are Chosen, Turnout Settles the Game
description: Twelve thousand registered voters live in the Century Village retirement complex in Deerfield Beach, across the state from this bedroom community east of Tampa. Nearly all of them are Democrats from the Northeast, and Amadeo Trinchitella, the condominium president, has them organized like a precision drill team.

title: Police and Parishioners Point Fingers as Church Clash Goes to Jury
description: Five years after a clash between police and parishioners at a Queens church, a federal jury heard closing statements yesterday in a case stemming from a lawsuit brought by church members alleging that police officers had injured them, violated their civil rights and falsely arrested them.

title: China's AIDS Epidemic
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, MARY HUNTER
description: WOLF-Mary Hunter, on November 3, 2000 in Hamden, CT. Survivors include step-children David and Bill, and Louise Chandler, six grandchildren, one great-grandson, and former husband, Herman Wolf. Born Bakersfield, CA., December 4, 1904, Mary's career in the theater and education spanned almost 70 years. She co-founded the American Actors Theater and the American Theater Wing Professional Training Program; founded the Center for Theater Techniques in Education. Among other Broadway plays, she directed ''Carib Song'' starring Katherine Dunham, ''Only the Heart'' (Horton Foote), and ''The Respectful Prostitute'' (Sartre). Associate Director with Jerome Robbins of ''Peter Pan'' starring Mary Martin. Those wishing to honor Mary may make donations to the Mary Hunter Wolf Scholarship Fund, Center for Theater Techniques in Education, Co-op High School, 444 Orange St., New Haven, CT 06511, or the Mary Hunter Wolf Award Endowment at the Long Wharf Theater, 222 Sargent Dr., New Haven, CT 06511. Memorial event Mon., Dec. 4th, 3PM at the Long Wharf Theater.

title: Abroad at Home; The Uses of Secrecy
description: He has been in prison for three and one-half years, not charged with any crime but held because the United States government said he was a danger to national security. He was not allowed to see the evidence that supposedly proved him dangerous.

title: DEVILS' BRODEUR RESTS INJURY
description: Martin Brodeur, who suffered a slight injury in his left groin in Toronto on Thursday night, felt well enough to practice yesterday but decided against it after the Devils' coaches and trainers encouraged him to rest.

title: SOLECTRON WARNS PROFITS WILL NOT MEET ESTIMATE
description: The Solectron Corporation, the maker of electronic components, warned that profits in fiscal 2001 would not meet its estimate because of the effects of recent acquisitions. The company reduced its forecast for earnings per share for the year ending Aug. 31, 2001, by 3 cents, to a range of 99 cents to $1.02 a share. It expects sales to grow about 15 percent, to $23 billion, for the year. Solectron agreed earlier this week to buy a Singapore-based rival, NatSteel Electronics Ltd., for $2.4 billion, and agreed last month to buy two Japanese factories from Sony. Solectron's stock fell 88 cents, to $44.13.

title: RANGERS' INJURIES ARE ADDING UP
description: The Rangers' injury trend continued during their wide-open 6-5 loss to the Ottawa Senators on Thursday night. The Rangers were down to four defensemen for most of the final period.

title: Where Politics and Comedy Intermingle, the Punch Lines Can Draw Blood
description: The line between show business and presidential politics has never been thinner than in this campaign, and the best evidence comes at the start of a prime-time special called ''Saturday Night Live's Presidential Bash 2000'' tomorrow night from 9 to 11 on NBC. In separate appearances taped recently, the candidates themselves appear on a split screen. George W. Bush says he is ''ambilavent'' about the appearance because some of the show's material has been ''offensible.'' Al Gore responds, ''I was one of the very first to be offended by material on 'Saturday Night Live.' ''

title: Destroyer's Sailors Fly Home to a Hero's Welcome
description: Engineerman Third Class John Thompson said he operated on autopilot as he carried injured crew mates from a mangled steel shell that minutes before was a mess hall aboard the destroyer Cole, wading through water that flooded the hold, past exposed live power lines and thick clouds of smoke until he reached the deck and safety.

title: Newspaper Pulls Magazine Because of Democratic Spin
description: The San Jose Mercury News has pulled its Nov. 5 Sunday magazine out of circulation because the cover story, a personal essay, pondered how anyone the author liked or admired could be a Republican.

title: Giants Do Not Intend To Look Past Browns
description: Over and over this week, the Giants' Jessie Armstead heard the same question: how will the Giants avoid looking past the lowly Cleveland Browns on Sunday when next week's opponent is the St. Louis Rams?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILLING, PETER
description: SCHILLING-Peter. On November 3, 2000 of Syosset, NY. Beloved husband of Nancy (nee Cook). Loving father of Peter, Roger and Paul. Dear grandfather of six. Fond brother of Scott, Lydia Cummins and Fredrik. Visiting Sunday at St. Bede's Episcopal Church, 220 Berry Hill Rd., Syosset, NY 3:00pm to 4:00PM followed by a Funeral Mass at 4:00PM with a reception to follow in Parish Hall. Interment Monday leaving St. Bede's Church at 10:00AM for St. John's Cemetery, Riverhead. Funeral entrusted to the Beney Funeral Home, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POKART, BILLIE
description: POKART-Billie. I still miss you and always will. Love, Joe

title: A Judicial Threat to Clean Water
description: The Supreme Court's continuing debate over federal power reached a critical juncture on Tuesday. The justices heard arguments in a closely watched case from Illinois with potentially devastating consequences for environmental protection and, more broadly, Congress's traditional authority under the Constitution's Commerce Clause to address pressing issues of national concern.

title: A Final Weekend of Campaign Thrust and Parry
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Nationwide Settlements Are Close in Smoking Cases
description: Negotiators for two major tobacco companies are close to reaching two nationwide settlements that would cover all individual smokers' claims for punitive damages against them, people familiar with the negotiations said last night. Together, the settlements could be worth $8 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ROBERT RONALD, MD.
description: LEVINE-Robert Ronald, MD. Beloved husband of the late Betty Louise (nee Baer). Devoted father of Linda Levine, Naomi Klotz, Edwin Levine and Keith Levine. Cherished grandfather of Jessica, Samantha, Sarah, Samuel and Eli.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBEL, RICHARD K.
description: WEBEL-Richard K. Of Old Brookville, NY, on November 1, 2000, age 100. Loving husband of Pauline D. Father and stepfather of Robert G. Pratt, Arthur D. Pratt, Pauline P. Brown, Richard C. Webel. Grandfather of seven and great grandfather of four. Funeral service to be held at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY, at 11:00 AM on Saturday, November 4. Contributions may be made to the Webel Scholarship Fund, Box 560, Locust Valley, NY 11560.

title: 2 Salvador Generals Cleared by U.S. Jury in Nuns' Deaths
description: A federal jury today cleared two retired Salvadoran generals of responsibility in the abduction, rape and murder of four American churchwomen by members of El Salvador's National Guard in 1980. The jury said the two men could not have done anything more to prevent the crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOLA, RALPH JEAN
description: ZOLA-Ralph Jean. Of Englewood Cliffs, NJ. Beloved husband of Penni (nee Silver), cherished son of Helen and the late Irving Zola, devoted father of Gregory Zola and Stephanie Bailyn, dear brother of Paul Zola and Marion Urcis. A sweet singer of Israel, whose melody has been stilled. Serviceswere held at ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St., Englewood.

title: 26 Miles To Run Or to Crawl
description: WITH the New York City Marathon upon us, it seemed right to accept the challenge for the first time in a couple of years.

title: Lazio and Clinton Swap Charges on Mideast
description: Roaring into the last weekend of their Senate campaign, Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton battled intensely yesterday over each other's loyalty to Israel, signaling the extraordinary emphasis on Jewish voters in the final days of their race.

title: Struggling Democrats Try to Hold the Line
description: When State Senator Melissa Hart, a Republican Congressional candidate, walked into the florist shop, an elderly worker greeted her with the equivalent of a fraternity password: ''They'll have to pry it from my cold, dead hand.''

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Boston; Portland, Me., and Philadelphia

title: BET Holdings to Be Bought By Viacom for $2.34 Billion
description: As expected, Viacom Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire BET Holdings, the company that owns Black Entertainment Television, the nation's largest black-owned cable channel, for $2.34 billion in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUNDERS, ANNE
description: SAUNDERS-Anne, age 94, on November 2nd, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Stephanie and the late Frederic Roy. She will be missed by her nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. Graveside service on Sunday, 11 AM, at Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, New Jersey.

title: CITIBANK VETERAN TO RUN BANK RESCUE
description: Edwin Gerungan, who spent 25 years as a top Citibank executive in Jakarta and a year at Bank Mandiri, the country's biggest bank, was named to run the Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency, a state agency trying to liquidate $44 billion in assets from failed banks. He will be the third chief in the agency's history; he replaces Cacuk Sudarijanto, who has become a junior economic minister.

title: Campaign's Endgame: Getting Your Voters to Vote
description: In Queens, the Republican Party is giving out stacks of postcards -- one side featuring a photo of Representative Rick A. Lazio, the other a message urging a robust turnout on Election Day -- and asking loyalists to send them to everyone on their holiday mailing lists. Across the state in Erie County, the Young Republicans are hanging thousands of handbills with a similar theme on the front doorknobs of Republican homes.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE SENATE

title: Doomed Slam? Not With an Italian Declarer
description: The International Olympic Committee has a museum at in Lausanne, Switzerland, and some of the world's best players were at work there this week competing for the I.O.C. Cup. Invited teams from China, France, Indonesia, Italy, Poland and the United States played in a round robin, in which China and France were eliminated.

title: Walter Shenson, 81, Producer of Movies Starring the Beatles
description: Walter Shenson, the producer of the Beatles' films ''A Hard Day's Night'' and ''Help!,'' died on Oct. 17 in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 81.

title: The Status of Science
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: GEORGE W. BUSH

title: Playing the Muslim Card
description: The campaign of Rick A. Lazio began yesterday televising this 30-second advertisement, ''Video,'' in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, NICHOLAS R., SR.
description: PHILLIPS-Nicholas R., Sr. Age 64, of Wyckoff, NJ, died Thursday, November 2, 2000 at the Valley Hospital, Ridgewood. Born in NY, NY, a Wyckoff resident for the past 27 years. Nicholas was the owner and president of Wexkill Inc. of Wyckoff and a former money manager at Kalb Voorhis & Company, NY, NY and a former partner at Fahnestock. Member of St. Elizabeth's RC Church, Wyckoff, an Army veteran and former member of the Ridgewood Country Club and NY Athletic Club. Beloved husband of Eileen (nee Weber). Father of Eileen Marie Phillips of Wyckoff; Nicole Ann Phillips of Virginia Beach, VA; Nicholas R. Jr. of Dublin, Ireland; Deirdre Ann and John Paul Phillips of Wyckoff. Brother of Robert E. of NY, NY. Predeceased by his brothers Lawrence E. Jr., William T. and Richard. Visiting at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Ave., Wyckoff on Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass, St. Elizabeth's RC Church, 700 Wyckoff Ave., Wyckoff, Monday 10 am. Interment Christ The King Cemetery, Franklin Lakes. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Wyckoff Volunteer Ambulance Corps, PO Box 214, Wyckoff, NJ 07481.

title: Con Man of the Hamptons, in His Own Words
description: Christopher Rocancourt, the con man who spent this summer in the Hamptons posing as a Rockefeller and bilking the well-to-do out of nearly $1 million, called to set the record straight. He stole. He lied. That was not in question. He admitted as much.

title: A Classic Duel in the Breeders' Cup: Fusaichi Pegasus vs. Lemon Drop Kid
description: Two very good horses will run for greatness in the final race of their careers while 14 2-year-old colts will try to establish themselves as 2001 Kentucky Derby contenders. It isn't exactly out with the old, in with the new, but yesterday will ultimately give way to tomorrow when more than 100 top-flight horses go to the starting gate on Saturday in eight races totaling $15.2 million in purses in the 17th running of the Breeders' Cup championships.

title: City Concedes Leak in Aqueduct But Likens It to Open Hydrants
description: The city and a Hudson River environmental group clashed yesterday over the severity of leaks in a Catskills aqueduct that is part of the city's water supply system.

title: House Approves Plan to Restore Everglades
description: In a rare moment of solidarity, the House voted today for a $7.8 billion plan intended to restore the Florida Everglades, a project supporters call the largest environmental renewal effort ever.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BIOMARIN PHARMACEUTICAL, Novato, Calif., named Fredric D. Price chairman and chief executive, succeeding Grant W. Denison Jr., who continues to serve on the board. Mr. Price had been president and chief executive at AMBI Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Workplace page on Wednesday about ''noncompete'' agreements, in which workers accept restrictions on future employment after leaving a company, misspelled the name of a law firm in Atlanta at which one partner, Michael D. Golden, encourages employers to use the device. It is Arnall Golden & Gregory, not Goden.

title: Turnaround at Sacred Heart Stuns Even Coach
description: When Sacred Heart University won five of its last six games during its inaugural football season to finish at 5-4 in 1991, it was cause for celebration on the campus here. But the subsequent stretch was hardly a good omen.

title: Rutgers's Struggling Coach Steps Down
description: Terry Shea, who compiled an 11-41 record in five years as head football coach at Rutgers, has resigned, the university's athletic director, Robert E. Mulcahy III, announced today.

title: HOUSE ADJOURNS, SHIFTING ITS FOCUS TO ELECTION DAY
description: Its work left undone and with campaigns to finish, the House recessed today until after the election, joining the Senate in an 11-day cooling-off period and hoping that the contentious disputes over spending, immigration, taxes and workplace safety rules can be worked out in a lame duck session.

title: Ad-Weary Tossup City Has a Question: Is It Next Wednesday Yet?
description: Did he stutter?

title: Running Past Reason
description: Today, as runners prepare for Sunday's New York City Marathon, I am filled with the deep longing that I feel twice every year during the days that precede the New York and Boston marathons. I ache to join the hordes of novice runners streaming through the streets in a unique celebration of city and self. Family and friends are perplexed by this powerful desire to run some 26 miles again, because for decades I've had debilitating back pain from an injury I acquired by training for marathons. But those who have run the race hear its siren call and understand firsthand how psychology trumps physiology.

title: With Boost Of Energy, Camby Lifts The Knicks
description: The popular sentiment was that Marcus Camby wanted nothing to do with slamming his straw-thin 225-pound body against the massive muscles of Jahidi White. Being pushed around by White for half of a preseason game had given Camby lower back pain for two weeks.

title: Candidate's Comeback Is Up to Voters and a Jury
description: Judgment Day and Election Day both loom for Pedro Espada Jr., the bad boy of Bronx politics.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The captain, from beginning to end, didn't know he was using the wrong

title: Joseph Greenwald, 82, Delegate To International Trade Groups
description: Joseph A. Greenwald, a diplomat who helped guide international trade policy for the United States over two decades, died on Monday in Washington. He was 82.

title: U.S. to Open Civil Rights Inquiry In New Jersey Turnpike Shooting
description: Three days after a judge dismissed criminal charges against two state troopers who shot and wounded three unarmed black and Hispanic men on the New Jersey Turnpike, the United States Justice Department announced today that it would investigate whether to prosecute the officers on federal civil rights charges.

title: Sports of The Times; For Racing, Splendor And Strife
description: IT is the best of times, and the worst. It is the best in glamour and money, as the racing world will witness again when the eight championship races of the 17th Breeders' Cup are run at Churchill Downs this afternoon, and the stage takes on a glitter rivaled only by the Kentucky Derby. But backstage, where politics fly, it may be the worst of times for the onetime Sport of Kings.

title: Clinton May Meet Next Week With Arafat and Barak
description: Efforts by Palestinians and Israelis to tamp down their clashes were interrupted by new violence today, but they stayed alive with reports that both sides would meet with President Clinton next week.

title: Attacks Grow Sharp as Time Dwindles
description: Seizing a chance to sow doubts about Gov. George W. Bush's ability to be president, Vice President Al Gore today ridiculed him for suggesting on Thursday that Social Security was not a federal program, and the Gore campaign rushed out a television commercial highlighting the gaffe.

title: The Rising Cost Of Luring People To New York; Booming Prices for Housing Make for Creative Job Perks
description: Combine a superheated job market with turbo-charged real estate prices -- and the New York metropolitan region has both -- and you get things like dual housing allowances.

title: Attacks Grow Sharp as Time Dwindles
description: Gov. George W. Bush pushed across two more battleground states today, accusing the Clinton administration of leaving America ''undefended against missile attack,'' and mocking Vice President Al Gore and President Clinton for failing to lock up their home states, Tennessee and Arkansas, for the Democrats.

title: Victory May Prove Hollow To Hair's-Width Majority
description: Both major presidential candidates have been campaigning this fall on their detailed agendas and their ability to get things done. But whoever wins on Tuesday is likely to face the formidable constraint of a narrowly divided Congress, many lawmakers and analysts say.

title: Mike Turnesa, 93, Tour Pro From Golfing Family, Is Dead
description: Mike Turnesa, a member of a renowned Westchester County golfing family who competed as a top touring pro in the 1930's and 1940's and was runner-up to Ben Hogan in the 1948 Professional Golfers Association Championship, died Tuesday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. He was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEVELAND, DONALD L.
description: CLEVELAND-Donald L. Of Greenwich, CT, died October 27. Survived by Caroline, his wife of 61 years, three sons, 2 brothers, 2 grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perryridge Rd., Greenwich CT. 06830.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Romance Does Not Stop Even After the Race Begins
description: Cheryl Riegler fidgeted under the steady drizzle drifting onto the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, fiddling with the layers of gloves, hats, shorts, shirts and plastic, and fretting about everything that could go wrong. It was 1997 and Riegler, then a 36-year-old nurse practitioner, was about to run in her third New York City Marathon, with her boyfriend Boris Leiningen, who had started running six months earlier so he could spend more time with her. She worried that they were going to get wet, contract a rash, feel something pull or burn or break, and that Leiningen, 38, would not be able to finish.

title: Bayer Is Withdrawing Chemicals in Europe
description: Bayer A.G. said this week that it would withdraw about two-thirds of the 60 agricultural chemicals it has on the market to comply with a European Union safety regulation.

title: Taliban and Opposition Forces Are Said to Agree to Peace Talks
description: The Taliban of Afghanistan and an opposition still fighting them along their northern border have agreed to begin talks toward ending the latest phase of a two-decade civil war, the United Nations official who brokered the agreement said today.

title: 3Com Agrees to Pay $259 Million in a Shareholders Dispute
description: The 3Com Corporation agreed yesterday to pay $259 million to people who bought its stock during a five-month period in 1997 when critics said it was concealing important information about the operations of a company it acquired that year. The stock plunged after the information came out but later recovered.

title: WISCONSIN CENTRAL HIRES ADVISER TO EXPLORE MOVES
description: Wisconsin Central Transportation, the regional railroad and ferry operator based in Rosemont, Ill., said it had hired Goldman, Sachs & Co. to evaluate strategic alternatives, including the sale of the company. On Monday, the largest shareholder, Southeastern Asset Management, said it would support a bid by Wisconsin Central's founder and former chief executive, Edward Burkhardt, to regain control of the company. The company's stock price, which had fallen from $20 in July 1999 when Mr. Burkhardt left the company, to less than $10 in September 2000, rebounded sharply during the week and closed at $15.50.

title: The Muddled Profiling Case
description: It is time for federal prosecutors to step in and take control of the New Jersey case in which two state police officers shot at four unarmed black and Hispanic men on the New Jersey Turnpike. The Justice Department announced yesterday that it is beginning an investigation. It should proceed quickly because the New Jersey attorney general's office is simply too politically tainted to provide justice for either the officers or the victims.

title: Napster Is Dead. Long Live Napster!
description: To the Editor:

title: American Composers Names a Music Director
description: Steven Sloane, a 42-year-old American conductor, has been named music director designate of the American Composers Orchestra, the only orchestra today dedicated entirely to the creation, performance and preservation of music by American composers. The appointment was announced yesterday by Carnegie Hall, where the orchestra presents a yearly series of concerts.

title: ABBEY NATIONAL STUDIES POSSIBLE MERGER DEAL
description: Abbey National P.L.C., a British financial services conglomerate, has approached Bank of Scotland about a possible merger, the companies said. Bank of Scotland said the approach was unlikely to lead to a satisfactory transaction for its shareholders. The two banks had discussed a possible combination in July and August, but Bank of Scotland said those talks were ended. Bank of Scotland has been looking for a partner since it lost out to its rival, the Royal Bank of Scotland, in a takeover fight for National Westminster Bank. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Trumpeting vs. Whispering The News About an Arrest
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: PORTAL SOFTWARE IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE SOLUTION 42
description: Portal Software Inc., a maker of programs used to bill customers for Internet-related services, said it had agreed to acquire Solution 42, a German rival, for about $300 million in stock. Portal will issue shares in a German subsidiary that may be exchanged for as many as 7.5 million Portal common shares, or about 4 percent of the combined company. Executives of Solution 42 will be retained for two years, said Portal, which is based in Cupertino, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 24 about a Census Bureau study of women of child-bearing age misstated the prevalence of married couples in which both spouses work. Such couples, with children, have become a majority of all married couples, not just of those with children.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Corzine Pressed Over Homeless In Campaign
description: Jon S. Corzine said today he was unaware that residents of homeless shelters and rehabilitation clinics in Philadelphia were being bused into New Jersey to work on behalf of his campaign for the Senate. But he defended the idea of offering recovering addicts and others $75 a day to put up signs and knock on doors as ''an honest day's pay for an honest day's work.''

title: Religion Journal; For a Historic Church, One More Milestone
description: The Unitarian Church of All Souls, whose elegant building stands at the corner of 80th Street and Lexington Avenue in Manhattan, carries historic associations with such creative figures as Herman Melville, who was a member, and its onetime pastor the Rev. Henry Whitney Bellows, who built the United States Sanitary Commission to care for the sick and wounded of the Civil War.

title: Editorial Notebook; The View From the Voting Booth
description: On Election Day all across America, nearly every candidate for major office will be photographed casting an early morning ballot at the local polling place. Those photographs and film clips have become a ritual over time, a portrait of the politician alone in the one truly transitive moment of the election. It makes you wonder what it means to people so used to seeing their names in print to see them in print in the one place that matters -- on the ballot. Certainly, the candidates stride out of the booths with practiced zeal, the curtains shot back, other voters perhaps startled by the sound, by the brisk ceremony, the sense of a duty discharged. This is the most precisely level moment in the election, the moment when the candidate, no matter who, is just another voter, no different in any respect from the other voters who will drop by during polling hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUPTMAN, ISABEL ''TROTIE'' (ABELSON)
description: HAUPTMAN - Isabel ''Trotie'' (Abelson). New York resident for over 70 years died in her sleep November 3, 2000 at the age of 101. As a graduate of Wellesley College Isabel's loyalty to the school was number 1 on her list. She leaves two daughters, Joannee Marks of New York City and Kit Kuperman of Denver, Colorado, five grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. All of her long time and beloved friends will miss her greatly. Services private.

title: A Bellwether State's Favor Is Pursued by Both Tickets
description: Missourians like to call their state the gateway to the West, but to political scientists it is the nation's electoral heart monitor. Since 1904, it has backed the winner in every presidential election but one, in 1956, when it picked Adlai E. Stevenson from nearby Illinois over President Dwight D. Eisenhower.

title: Large State Utility Wants Market to Set Gas Price
description: The state's largest gas utility, Public Service Electric & Gas, has asked state regulators to approve a plan that by 2003 would let the price of gas be set by the free market.

title: COURT SAYS SUIT WAS MADE A CLASS ACTION IN ERROR
description: A suit against Sears, Roebuck & Company, accusing it of using illegal tactics to collect debts from bankrupt customers, should not have been given class-action status, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled. The court said a federal judge in Houston erred in 1999 in certifying 1.5 million Sears customers as a class in the suit filed by a Texas couple accusing Sears of bullying consumers into agreeing to repay debts wiped out in personal bankruptcies. Sears, based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., has frequently been criticized for its debt-collection practices and pleaded guilty to a criminal bankruptcy fraud charge in February 1999. It was fined $60 million and paid more than $400 million to settle lawsuits, all relating to its handling of consumer bankruptcies.

title: Russian Oil Company Buys U.S. Gas Station Chain
description: Russia's biggest oil producer, Lukoil Holding, purchased a chain of 1,300 gas stations in the United States, most of them in the Northeast, in a move analysts said was aimed more at burnishing its image than bolstering profits.

title: Airline Says Jet Was on Wrong Runway Before Crash in Taiwan
description: The Singapore Airlines jet that crashed here on Tuesday night in a storm, killing 81 people, definitely taxied onto the wrong runway and slammed into construction equipment just before takeoff, Taiwan's air safety chief said today.

title: Strawberry Tells Judge He Lost Will to Live
description: Fighting to avoid a prison term while he is suffering from a recurrence of cancer, Darryl Strawberry told a Florida judge yesterday that he had lost the will to live and had gone on a drug binge two weeks ago hoping it might end his life.

title: Ruling on Procedure in Case Is Partly in Favor of Microsoft
description: In a procedural ruling partly in favor of Microsoft in its appeal of the antitrust decision that could split the company, a federal court ruled yesterday that America Online must join with three industry trade groups if the company wants to file a supporting brief.

title: Acting on Impulse, and Winning a Presidential Role
description: LESS than 14 months ago, William Daniels and his wife, Bonnie Bartlett, sat down for sandwiches at Art's Deli in Studio City with some dissident members of the Screen Actors Guild.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPER, JEROME MILTON
description: ALPER-Jerome Milton. On Friday, November 3, 2000 of Chevy Chase, MD. Husband of the late Janet Alper and the late Muriel Alper. Father of Andrew and Alan Alper. Stepfather of Robin Howe and Jeffrey Teitel. Brother of Dr. Charles Harold Alper. Also survived by six grandchildren. Funeral service will be held on Monday, November 6th, 1:30PM, Temple Sinai, 3100 Military Rd., N.W., Washington, D.C. Interment King David Memorial Garden, Falls Church, VA. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVISON, CHARLES HAMILTON
description: DAVISON-Charles Hamilton, 73, died Thursday, November 2nd, at his home in Vero Beach, FL. Formerly Deputy Chairman of Peat Marwick Mitchell & Co. (precursor to today's KPMG); Vice Chairman of Smith Barney; Chairman and owner of Paramount Cards, Pawtucket, RI. He was a graduate of Dartmouth College and received an MBA from NYU. Mr. Davison was very active on a number of civic and educational boards including a Trustee of Kenyon College, Trustee of Northwestern's Kellogg School of Management, Chairman of United Charities of Chicago, Boards of New York City Ballet and City Center of New York. He is survived by his wife, Lessie, and three sons: Hamilton and Dorothy of Providence, RI; Lang and Mary Jeanne Connors of Mill Valley, CA; and Andrew and Brooke of Boulder, CO, and three grandchildren. Donations in his memory may be made to Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH or Kenyon College, Gambier, OH.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIGG, JOSEPH W.
description: GRIGG-Joseph W. of Peachtree City, GA, passed away on October 29th at the age of 90. Educated at Westminster Boys School in London and at Trinity College, Cambridge, he went on to an illustrious 50-year career with United Press. Serving at various times as Bureau Manager in Berlin, London, Paris, Frankfurt and Bonn, he retired in 1982 as Chief European Correspondent. He is survived by his sister Elizabeth S. Grigg of Ypsilanti, MI, daughter Margaret Griffin of Bluffton, SC, and son Richard A. Grigg of Peachtree City, GA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIS, DONALD J., MD
description: REIS-Donald J., MD of New York City and Stonington, CT, beloved husband of Cornelia Langer Noland and stepfather of Lyn, Cady and William Noland, died at age 69 on November 1, 2000. He was the George C. Cotzias Distinguished Professor of Neurology and Neuroscience at Cornell Medical Center and a renowned international neuroscience pioneer. Doctor Reis trained more than one hundred scientists around the world and received numerous awards for his work throughout a long and illustrious career. A memorial service is scheduled at the Century Association, 7 West 43rd Street on Friday, November 17th at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Department of Neurology and Neuroscience, WeillCornell Medical Center, 1300 York Avenue (Room F613), NY, NY 10021 or to the Citizens Commit tee for New York City, 305 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001.

title: Rosemary Ponzo, Edward Ankudavich
description: Rosemary Ponzo and Edward Anthony Ankudavich were married yesterday evening at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan. Justice Richard F. Braun of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title: A Rush to Put Up Billboards Before a Legal Window Closes
description: Anticipating stricter signage regulations, billboard companies are rushing to erect large, free-standing sign stanchions that would be governed by the more lenient current rules.

title: Jumpers Make Way For Pro Bull Riders
description: Alan Balch sat in the stands at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, shortly after the day events of the 117th National Horse Show had concluded. He was overseeing the reconstruction of the arena floor as the flowers and colorful fence posts were carted away, after the young riders, and horses with silky manes and tails, had left.

title: A Lady Who Never Stopped Being First
description: WE'VE seen so much of it before. Young, pretty Miss Bouvier, hoisting her oversize press camera as The Washington Times Herald's inquiring photographer. Elegant Mrs. Kennedy, taking Paris by storm, then - seconds later, it seems - holding America together in the days after her husband's assassination. Glamorous Mrs. Onassis, beaming at her Greek wedding and relaxing on her second husband's yacht. And finally Jackie - just Jackie, because her own identity transcended those of the men she married - working for a book publisher in Manhattan, standing proud beside her grown children, strolling in Central Park with Maurice Tempelsman, the last man she loved.

title: The World; Currency Of the Realm
description: THE rallies are raucous, the opposition galvanized. Even Corazon C. Aquino, the heroine of the last popular uprising in the Philippines, has emerged from retirement to call for the head of President Joseph Estrada. Everywhere in Manila, people are asking whether ''People Power'' will force out another Philippine leader.

title: Trip to Cuba
description: To the Editor: The Travel Advisory reported that the Boston Museum of Fine Arts and the American Museum of Natural History were conducting Cuba trips (''Two Museums Sponsor Tours to Cuba,'' Oct. 15).

title: World's Fair of 1939-40 Improved the City's Menus
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Says Sexism Is Legion? Not France.
description: COULD it be time for women to serve as soldiers in that longtime bastion of male derring-do, the French Foreign Legion?

title: Robert M. Carroll, Armorer at Metropolitan, Dies at 53
description: Robert M. Carroll, who used tools from medieval times and the space age on his job as armorer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on Oct. 22 at his home in Somers, N.Y. He was 53.

title: Troops for the Balkans
description: To the Editor:

title: A King's Statue
description: To the Editor: The unusual history of the bronze statue of King Kamehameha I in Kapaau on the Big Island of Hawaii, mentioned by Jocelyn Fujii in her article ''The Big Island's Royal Enclave'' (Oct. 8) should not be overlooked. The statue is identical in all but a few details to the much-photographed one in downtown Honolulu, and was in fact made first.

title: Sports of The Times; The Yankee Who Missed The Party
description: HE missed the Champagne and City Hall. As the Yankees' general manager, Brian Cashman had fortified the roster during the season by acquiring eight players, notably David Justice and Luis Sojo, but the night the Yankees won the Subway Series, he wasn't there. And when the Yankees floated up Lower Broadway to City Hall last Monday, he wasn't there, either.

title: Fat People Say an Intolerant World Condemns Them on First Sight
description: Walk in Deidra Everett's shoes a moment: You know that you dress nicely; that you are well-spoken; that you are clean and friendly and funny and smart. Yet when you go for a job interview, your potential employer's eyes tend to sweep your person and fill with horror.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 5, 2000
description: Weeks

title: In Praise of Librarians
description: To the Editor:

title: First Chapter: 'Hooking Up'
description: By the year 2000, the term "working class" had fallen into disuse in the United States, and "proletariat" was so obsolete it was known only to a few bitter old Marxist academics with wire hair sprouting out of their ears. The average electrician, air-conditioning mechanic, or burglar-alarm repairman lived a life that would have made the Sun King blink. He spent his vacations in Puerto Vallarta, Barbados, or St. Kitts. Before dinner he would be out on the terrace of some resort hotel with his third wife, wearing his Ricky Martin cane-cutter shirt open down to the sternum, the better to allow his gold chains to twinkle in his chest hairs. The two of them would have just ordered a round of Quibel sparkling water, from the state of West Virginia, because by 2000 the once-favored European sparkling waters Perrier and San Pellegrino seemed so tacky.

title: Hendrix's Old Boss, a Sax King, Sends Souls Heavenward
description: Lonnie Youngblood has a reputation as one of the sweetest saxophone players in Harlem, so sweet that the living ask him to serenade them at their funerals.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; At Home With the Shakespeares
description: Originally published in England in 1993, Robert Nye's witty novel, MRS. SHAKESPEARE: The Complete Works (Arcade, $23.95), purports to give us an intimate view of the playwright and poet from the perspective of his wife, Anne Hathaway. Anne knows she has a hot property on her hands, but she seems not to understand precisely why; everything about her husband interests her with the exception of his works, which she claims not to have read. ''Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?'' the poet asks his mate. ''No thanks!'' she replies. This manic humor, already familiar from Nye's novel ''The Late Mr. Shakespeare,'' is like a nervous emanation from a too firmly established canon; even so, some of the jokes are very good indeed. Nye is at his best when the material is most bawdy. The question of Will Shakespeare's sexuality -- and its function in the sonnets -- is finally resolved, at least in fiction. Anne's voice is perhaps too various for a single character; at times she sounds like someone from our own century (''She must be some sort of sonnet-freak''), at others a self-congratulatory Elizabethan shrew (''Am I right? I am''). For a person who hasn't read her husband's works, Anne is surprisingly conversant with what they contain (''I know a hawk from a handsaw''). Scholarly topics are not entirely avoided; when Anne wants to comment on a play, she attributes her opinions to her daughter Susanna. Now and then, as if inadvertently, Anne speaks in a more serious tone that nearly reaches critical mass: ''Did Mr. Shakespeare think that his dream of the maypole must always be more perfect than the dance?'' ''Mrs. Shakespeare'' is funny, irreverent and fearless. William Ferguson.

title: Too Many Signs?
description: AS familiar as the changing colors, fall in Connecticut brings with it both politicians campaigning door-to-door and disputes about the signs supporters of those candidates plant all around the state. Connecticut's 169 cities and towns are rife with rules governing the placement, size, and number of campaign signs homeowners can put on private property, and the disagreements over the signs can be more contentious than the races they advertise.

title: Looking at Sachem Group In Farmingville
description: A letter to the editor [Oct. 29] paints the Sachem Quality of Life Organization as a racist, bigoted group. In actuality what this group wants is one thing. They wish the government to enforce the law. Hundreds of thousands of people enter this country illegally every year. Studies have shown that this flood of people keep wages lower then they would be. The people who are harmed most are minority citizens who are displaced from entry-level jobs. The ones who gain are employers, who save money on wages. In addition this illegal immigration is a cause of overcrowding of our schools and increased taxes.

title: Be My Guest
description: Anything Goes!

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUSS, BEN
description: RUSS-Ben. 27th Yahrzeit. In my soul for all eternity. Marion

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOR, PAUL J. JR.
description: Connor-Paul J. Jr. Former executive director of the Church Charity Foundation of Long Island for 23 years passed away on Sunday, October 29, 2000. He is survived by his son Paul and his daughters Claudia and Christine. Mr. Conner lived in Teaneck, NJ.

title: Oct. 29-Nov. 4; Elections in Kosovo Favor the Moderates
description: The results of Kosovo's first post-war elections, for members of local councils, showed that the region's voters had overwhelmingly supported the party of a moderate former leader, Ibrahim Rugova. Under the protection of international peacekeeping troops, ethnic Albanians swamped polling stations in their enthusiasm to vote, saying it was an affirmation of their desire for independence from Serbia. The Serb minority boycotted the election, however, in protest at the continuing harassment and violence they suffer. Carlotta Gall

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIDELSEIT, LILLI (NEE BERNSTEIN)
description: FEIDELSEIT-Lilli (nee Bernstein). Age 93 of Brooklyn, passed away on November 2nd. Daughter of Sarah Ehrenreich (1875-1957) and Harris J. Bernstein (1871-1920). Sister of Michael (1899-1981), Murray (1903-31), and Celia (1909-17). Loving wife of her childhood sweetheart, Harry (d. 1979), proprietor of the former Prospect Pharmacy on Prospect Park SW. Mother of Jay Fields (1930-76). Survived by her loving daughter Marilyn Landau, her grandchildren, Melissa and Brian, and her great-grandchildren, David and Amelia Strauss. She will be sorely missed by her family, and her many friends from the park on East 18th Street.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Philadelphia, Cleveland, Broadview Heights, Ohio

title: Missteps Have Kept Presidential Contest Tight
description: If Gov. George W. Bush wins the presidency, he and his handlers will be hailed for their brilliance in beating an incumbent vice president in an era of sustained peace and prosperity.

title: Article 2000110591366502713 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Because a Beret Is Not Enough
description: Bohemians used to be artists and intellectuals with antiestablishment values. Now, they're former hippies with stock options, S.U.V.'s and summer homes. For this new demographic, Montblanc just came out with the Boheme fountain pen ($350), a writing tool ''for today's bohemians, who work hard and play hard and appreciate the finer things in life,'' said Eric Werner, vice president for marketing. BoHoCo (Bohemian Home Colonial), a home furnishings store at 91 Crosby Street in SoHo, lures shoppers with scattered rose petals and burning incense and sells jean jackets with beaded Buddha faces on the back ($350) and letter-size antique Indian Kama Sutra paintings ($850). And Napa Valley Fragrances offers Boheme perfume ($80 for three ounces at Bergdorf Goodman and Aedes de Venustas), which pays homage to ''the most interesting part of society: the writers and painters,'' said the company's owner, Susan Costner-Kenward. Don't ask how many starving artists actually splurge on $80 perfume.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article about Pauline de Rothschild today on Page 162 of Style & Entertaining, Part 2 of The Times Magazine, misstates the name of an artist whose portrait of her inspired a sketch of the actress Illeana Douglas. The artist is Barnaby Conrad, not Barnaby Conrad III.

title: Using Gas Fireplace For Heat
description: WITH energy prices rising and with real wood as tedious as ever to chop, stack and carry, growing numbers of homeowners are using increasingly efficient gas logs and gas-fueled fireplaces as a supplemental source of heat.

title: From Social Security to Environment, the Candidates' Positions
description: Voters have many questions about issues,and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have many answers. Here aresummaries of the Bush and Gore positions onpolicy issues that have recieved considerable attention in the presidential campaign, with a comparison to show how the candidates differand agree, and assesments of their position fromexperts and political analysts-some partisan, some not.

title: Euro-Wise, Yes, But Dollar-Foolish?
description: One thing that remains predictable about Saddam Hussein is his unpredictability. The latest example was Iraq's demand that the United Nations allow it to get euros for its oil exports, not dollars. Iraq threatened to shut off its oil exports otherwise, so the U.N. capitulated. Will Iraq suffer a bad case of cutting off its nose to spite its face? Even with European Central Bank intervention, the euro remains weak against the dollar, which means Iraq will earn less on its oil sales.

title: 'Hooking Up'
description: Hooking Up:

title: How Kramnik Kept Kasparov Off His Game
description: Vladimir Kramnik won the Brain Games Network World Chess Championship in large part because he outprepared Garry Kasparov, the man who is most feared for his pregame opening preparation, the man who has announced that he has 3,000 innovations on tap to spring on unwary opponents.

title: Erica Dominitz, Yaron Dori
description: Erica Jill Dominitz, a daughter of Renee and Henry Dominitz of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Yaron Dori, a son of Rivka and Reuben Dori of Tarzana, Calif., are to be married today. Rabbi Uri Regev is to officiate at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE REFORM PARTY

title: Wineries That Cut Risk
description: In a city where tidal charts could reflect sommeliers' arrivals and departures, Joseph DeLissio's career as the River Cafe's wine director rests on the same bedrock as the Brooklyn Bridge overhead.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-05-00: The Ethicist; Lights Out
description: While engaging in horseplay in my house, a friend of my 10-year-old son's accidentally broke an antique lamp. I did not ask his parents to pay for it and would decline if they offered, but it irks me that they didn't even make the gesture. May I surreptitiously break something in their house to settle the score? -- Anonymous, Highland Park, N.J.

title: Watching Picasso Through the Canvas
description: IN his 1956 short story ''In a Season of Calm Weather,'' Ray Bradbury writes of an obsessive American Picasso fan, George Smith, who stumbles upon an old man drawing in the sand with a stick on a beach in the south of France. Smith is hypnotized by the sight of the man, who resembles his idol, ''bent down in fever and raining perspiration'' as his hands ''scribbled, ribboned, looped around, over and up'' while sketching a Greek bacchanal. But the American's ecstasy turns to grief when the tide comes in, obliterating the work.

title: Ideas & Trends; Not Voting? How 'Bout if We Have a Big Party?
description: WHEN you leave home on Election Day, chances are pretty good that one of every two adults you see won't be voting. Since 1972, no more than 55 percent of voting-age Americans have cast ballots in a presidential election, and the ratio dipped to 49 percent in 1996. Despite the closeness of the race between Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore, turnout this year could be even lower.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Building Market Still Busy, But Not Hyperactive
description: WHILE the vacancy rate in New Jersey's office market has fallen in the last year, suggesting a healthy climate for real estate investment, there is much less frenzy in the buying and selling of buildings than in recent years, commercial brokers and investors report. Plenty of capital is available for the value-added deals in which properties are quickly improved and rapidly sold, but those kinds of properties are in short supply. And, the brokers say, there is not as much demand for properties with less possibility of quick upside potential.

title: Nader, Abortion And the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetscapes/1040 Park Avenue, at 86th Street; When Conde Nast's Duplex Penthouse Was in Vogue
description: CONDE NAST'S sunny penthouse atop 1040 Park Avenue was a nexus for cafe society when it was built for the publisher of Vogue, Vanity Fair and other smart magazines in the 1920's. Now, more than a half century after Nast died and his apartment was cut up, a 15-story-high scaffold supports repair crews working on Nast's glassy south greenhouse along 86th Street -- but it seems doubtful that anyone will ever put his magnificent apartment together again.

title: Puerto Rico Inn
description: To the Editor: In reference to ''Bargains Under Tropical Skies,'' (Oct. 22) by Frances Frank Marcus, as an experienced traveler in Puerto Rico, I was appalled at your selection of the Gallery Inn. It is hardly an inn -- but rather a guest house with no elevator and very steep stairs.

title: When Parents Don't Know Where to Turn, They Turn to a Lawyer
description: MICHAELENE LOUGHLIN says you only have to look at her car to know that she is not practicing special education law to get rich. Her clients even joke with her about her 1991 Nissan Sentra.

title: Foursome, Woods Included, In Contention for Tour Title
description: Today's third round of the Tour Championship separated the contenders from the rest of the pack.

title: Oct. 29-Nov. 4; The Cole Heads Home
description: More than two weeks after suicide bombers tore a hole in its hull while it lay in the port of Aden, the maimed American destroyer Cole limped out to sea, where it was taken aboard a floating drydock for shipment back to the United States for repairs. The ship left Yemeni waters with its battle ensign flying and the sound system blaring music that ranged from ''The Star Spangled Banner'' to rap. In Washington, defense officials said other Navy vessels had been told to avoid the Suez Canal for fear of another terrorist attack.

title: Eccentrics Who Live Way Beyond The Fringe
description: As part of its current series ''Visions of New York: Films From the 1960's Underground,'' the American Museum of the Moving Image, in Queens, will devote Nov. 25 to avant-garde comedy of the period. In addition to the work of the relatively well-known directors Robert Downey (''Chafed Elbows'') and Paul Bartel (''Eating Raoul''), the museum will present some of the rarely seen comedies made in the Bronx by the brothers George and Mike Kuchar. The filmmaker John Waters, one of their great fans, wrote the introduction to their 1997 memoir ''Reflections From a Cinematic Cesspool.'' Following is an adaptation of that introduction.

title: Reagan, Bush, Clinton . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Colleen Linehan, Patrick Haskell
description: Colleen Elizabeth Linehan, a daughter of Jane and Patrick Linehan Jr. of Amityville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Patrick O'Neill Haskell, a son of Marian and Gerald Haskell of Manchester, Mo. The Rev. Richard E. Hadel performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: BRIEFING: LAW ENFORCEMENT; GUN-BUYING AGE
description: Those who buy a handgun in the state must be at least 21 years old, after legislation signed last week raised the age from 18. The new law prohibits those under 21 from possessing, carrying, firing or otherwise using a handgun. Violators can be fined $10,000 or imprisoned for 18 months, or both. Under the new law, any person who knowingly sells or gives a handgun to a person under 21 can be charged with a crime. The new law would exempt those under 21 who are members of law-enforcement or corrections officer and fire or use a handgun in connection with their duties. Anne Ruderman

title: Clinton and Lazio Differ on School Aid, Social Security and Tax Cuts
description: Education

title: Of Innovation and the Uninsured
description: WHILE 42 million Americans are without health insurance, the plight of those who work for small businesses is among the most vexing.

title: Argentina, A Fiscal Angel That Fell From Grace
description: ONE of Argentina's top money men showed up in New York last week with a confession.

title: Reality Sets In
description: Philanthropy is not just the act of giving away money. It is the hard task of learning what money will do, and how it can work most usefully when applied in the real world. Nearly everyone who hopes to be a successful philanthropist discovers this, and Bill Gates is no exception. Judging by comments Mr. Gates has made recently, the man who created the world's richest foundation may have learned more about the real world by trying to give away his wealth than he did while making it.

title: Reckonings; No Good Deed
description: It started with a good deed. Back in the 1980's Congress decided to act responsibly, making early provision for a crisis that, though predictable, was still 30 years away.

title: Home Alone
description: Sometimes the pleasure of your own company is party enough.

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELS, RICHARD C.
description: DANIELS-Richard C. Of Palm Beach, FL, and formerly of Worcester, MA, died on October 31, 2000. He was a well-loved philanthropist known for his contributions to community arts and education. A veteran of World War II, he received a bachelor's degree from Clark University, studied drama at Columbia University, religion at Union Theological Seminary, and earned a joint master's degree in education at Columbia University. Following careers in theatre and religious education, Mr. Daniels became a distinguished public relations consultant and fundraiser. He was preceded in death by his wife Susan Archdeacon Daniels, who died in 1991. He is survived by his brother, William T. Daniels, Jr. (Julie); two nieces, Donna L. Lewis and Joyce Montenegro; two great-nieces and three great-nephews. A memorial service will be held at 12 noon on November 20, 2000, at the First Baptist Church of Worcester, MA, with private interment to follow at Hope Cemetery. Memorial donations may be made to: Scrogin Memorial Great Issues Fund, c/o First Baptist Church, 111 Park Ave., Worcester, MA 01609. For information, contact Quattlebaum Funeral Home.

title: Taking Aim at the Spiritual in the Material
description: 'The Spiritual in Art'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, PRISCILLA ANN (NEE LABARBERA)
description: BLAKE-Priscilla Ann (nee LaBarbera). Beloved wife of Dr. Robert V., M.D. Devoted daughter of Margaret LaBarbera and the late Casper. Loving sister of Connie Kacer, Margherita Kroop and Ignatius C. Fond aunt of Dawn Lynne, Danielle, Michele, Michael and Ashley. Reposing at the Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC. Funeral mass Wednesday, 9:30 AM, St. Anthony's R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. Visiting Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 PM and 79:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDMOND, DEWITT
description: REDMOND-DeWitt. The York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of DeWitt Redmond, associated with The Times from 1959 until 1995.

title: Lazio-Clinton Race Ends in Squabbling
description: It began as one for the history books -- the wife of a sitting president moving from the White House to New York to run for the Senate.

title: Oct. 29-Nov. 4; U.S.-Indonesia Ties Become Strained
description: Relations between the United States and Indonesia, which has the world's fourth largest population, have been souring, following a series of highly public disputes between the United States ambassador in Jakarta and Indonesian officials who have accused America of meddling in the country's internal affairs. Citing a recent wave of anti-American protests, death threats and regional unrest in Indonesia, the State Department has now advised Americans to exercise extreme caution when traveling to the Southeast Asian country, and the United States Embassy in Jakarta remains closed to the public. Calvin Sims

title: Call for 'Guiding Culture' Rekindles Political Debate in Germany
description: A leading conservative politician has ignited a political storm by saying that the millions of foreigners in Germany must adopt a German ''Leitkultur,'' or guiding culture.

title: Tackling the New York City Marathon Aboard a Hand-Cranked Wheelchair
description: WHEN the New York City Marathon winds toward its conclusion early this afternoon, the first competitor turning into Central Park and heading for the finish line, may well be a 52-year-old man from New Rochelle pumping for all he's worth.

title: Far More Single Mothers Are Taking Jobs
description: For the first time in more than a decade, single mothers are more likely than married mothers to be employed, new government statistics show.

title: Glen Cove Seeks Waterfront Investors
description: THROUGHOUT his six years in office, Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi has pursued a dream to make Glen Cove Creek, the dowdy, dirty stretch of waterfront at the heart of this city, into an attractive place to dine, drink, dock and stroll. Marshaling federal and state grants, the city has already spent $40 million on bulkhead building, dredging the creek and cleaning up the waterfront area.

title: GRAND UNION ON THE BLOCK
description: A federal bankruptcy judge in Newark last week approved an auction of the Grand Union supermarket chain, based in Wayne, which declared Chapter 11 last month. Judge Novalyn Winfield authorized the company to aid any buyer who offers at least $300 million for the chain. C & S Wholesale Grocers, a company in Brattleboro, Vt., has agreed to meet that price, but Adam Rogoff, a lawyer for Grand Union, said there was no binding contract and other offers might be made at the Nov. 16 auction. Angela Starita

title: Soul on Fire
description: W. E. B. DU BOIS

title: Corrections
description: A picture and a house description with the Gazetteer chart last Sunday, about the Ludlow Park section of Yonkers, were published in error. The house at 99 Franklin Avenue is no longer on the market.

title: Winery Hopes Its Blends Will Travel Well Abroad
description: LEWIS E. PLATT spent years on the road cracking foreign markets for Hewlett-Packard, helping the company become a leading technology exporter with more than $20 billion in annual sales abroad. Now Mr. Platt has transplanted his knowledge of selling computer equipment to a far smaller but perhaps trickier challenge: selling more California wine overseas.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZIERING, BLANCHE
description: ZIERING-Blanche. 11/6/20-4/15/94. Self pity wasnt in your vocabulary! You lived and traveled to the fullest. You were so unique and special! On your 80th birthday. Love from your family...Always with us

title: Editor's Notebook; Is There a Designer In the House?
description: The monolithic structure that Tom Ford sketched in a minute and handed off to be built in the Rodin museum garden for the Yves Saint Laurent show was as dark, imposing and sleek as Napoleon's tomb, which is a block away. The Napoleon that this building was designed to shut up was Pierre Berge, the former chief executive of Yves Saint Laurent, who has been stirring French politics and fashion (in that order) for decades. Berge, an infamous little contrarian, was doing his best to spoil Ford's moment; he and Saint Laurent's longtime muse Loulou Klossowski opened a boutique to compete with Ford's vision for the house jsut days before Ford's first show. (Berge retains rights to Saint Laurent's death.) When Klossowski told The Herald Tribune that the boutique was ''a flea on the back of a herd of corporate elephants,'' a member of the new Saint Laurent regime suggested they would show flea collars to close the spring collections on Friday, Oct. 13.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Predicting the future of domestic design has been big business for decades, but few futuristic efforts are as iconic as the Monsanto House of the Future (a), which graced Disneyland's Tomorrowland from 1957 to 1967. Made entirely of synthetic materials, the house featured then-startling inventions like the microwave oven and the picturephone. When the future finally caught up with the house, it proved nearly impossible to demolish; its sturdy plastic walls had to be hacksawed apart. Years later, the utopian imagery of the House of the Future served as the foil in a poignant family memoir in Bernard Cooper's collection of essays, ''Maps to Anywhere'' (b).

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: NEARER THAN THE SKY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, NATHAN
description: SIMON-Nathan. The York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Nathan Simon, associated with The Times from 1967 until 1975.

title: Of Dahlias and Shrubs
description: After frost blackens foliage, cut dahlia stems to 3 inches, carefully dig up, and cure in a dry spot for a day. Tuck tubers into boxes in barely moist peat or vermiculite, and store in a dark frost-free place. The ground is warm enough to plant shrubs. After leaves fall, energies go to root development. Keep watering -- in particular, transplants, container plants and evergreens. PATRICIA JONAS

title: Ideas & Trends: The Color of Love; Removing a Relic of the Old South
description: The Legislature shall never pass any law to authorize or legalize any marriage between any white person and a Negro, or descendant of a Negro.'' -- Constitution of Alabama, Article IV, Section 102

title: Corrections
description: The cover article on Pages 4 and 5 of the Television section today, about the CBS movie ''Jackie Bouvier Kennedy Onassis,'' refers incorrectly to the background of Jill Hennessy, who will play Mrs. Kennedy in a later production, on NBC. Ms. Hennessy joined the NBC series ''Law and Order'' in 1993, not in 1990, when it began.

title: As High-Tech Companies Retrench, Financial Firms Stock Up on Office Space
description: Financial services companies have reasserted their importance to New York City's real estate market and the economy with a vengeance as the dot-com companies have retreated from the stage in recent months.

title: Q & A/Mike Piccoli and Richard L. Zaharek, High Sheriffs; Right to Wear Badge Falls to a Vote
description: ON Tuesday, along with a new president, Connecticut voters will decide the fate of the state's eight high sheriffs. A ballot referendum asks voters to decide whether the state Constitution should be amended to eliminate the sheriffs, who are elected in each of the state's eight counties, and institute a statewide system of appointed marshals instead. The position of high sheriff has been in existence in the state since 1650.

title: Laura Gross, Max Kalehoff
description: Laura Elizabeth Gross and Max Ashley Kalehoff were married last evening by Rabbi Peter Hyman at Brantwyn, a former du Pont home in Wilmington, Del.

title: Endangered by All His Friends
description: Journal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNGER, ROY P.
description: MUNGER-Roy P., 91, of Norwich, VT. Retired Master of Trinity School. Survived by his wife, Judy, four children and six grandchildren. His memory will ever spark a smile to all who knew him.

title: An Evolution Out of Acting Into Dancing
description: IT is curious, but not a surprise, to learn that two fixtures in the downtown dance world originally planned to be actors. The choreographers and dancers Stacy Dawson and David Neumann -- hailed for their work with Annie-B Parson and Paul Lazar, as well as for their own theatrically based pieces -- are striking performers who supply any project with spontaneity, honesty and hilarity. And though their work is wholly contemporary, their presence captures what was so great about Hollywood in the madcap 30's, with Ms. Dawson as a kind of Carole Lombard to Mr. Neumann's William Powell.

title: Putting Your Money Where the Map Is
description: Angela Allen, a New York journalist, has come up with a map that delineates the locations of banks, A.T.M.'s, currency exchanges, check-cashing sources and wire transfer services in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, GLENN
description: ROSENBERG-Glenn. On November 3, 2000. Beloved husband of Valerie. Devoted father of Maggie and Lucy. Loving son of Maxine and Lee. Dear brother of Michael. Services today, 9:30 AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Creating the 'Real,' in Bright Yellow and Blue
description: A NEW season of ''The Simpsons'' begins tonight, arousing the happy anticipation that is one of the pleasures of all ''genre'' works: a certain blend of coziness and anticipated surprise. Genres like the film noir, the 16th-century song and the mystery novel may arouse the expectation not of greatness but of excellence. A penetrating sitcom like ''The Simpsons'' teases its form, and cavorts inventively within that form, the way a poem by Thomas Campion sports through the rhymes and stanzas of English verse.

title: Cure It With Drugs
description: Not every eccentricity can be labeled an illness, and self-control does not come out of a bottle of pills. Only the weak-minded will believe that it does. If shopping to excess is a disorder, then the guilt and blame disappear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINDLINGER, ALBERT E.
description: SINDLINGER-Albert E. On November 1, 2000. Age 93. Chairman of the Board, Sindlinger Company, Inc. Funeral service and interment private.

title: DUMP BECOMES OBJECT OF INQUIRY
description: The county has selected Lockwood, Kessler & Bartlett Inc., an environmental firm, to find out what is in an old, abandoned dump at the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation. The dump, which covers about 2.5 acres, is 200 yards from the Cross River, a main tributary of New York City's Croton Reservoir system. County officials said garbage was routinely disposed of in the dump in the decades before stringent environmental laws were enacted. The garbage was generated by campers and picnickers at the park. But just when the garbage dumping began and when it ended is under investigation. Elsa Brenner

title: Jets Look Past Film To Prepare For Denver
description: The game film landed like a gift in the laps of the Jets last week. As the weather turns colder and winds blow in stadiums, football teams rely more and more on the running game. And for the Jets, there is a special urgency to re-establish the running game with Vinny Testaverde under pressure to reduce his interceptions.

title: Inspiration; How I Learned to Stop Worrying...
description: I think I learned almost everything I know about having people to dinner from Lee Bailey. This was long before he began writing cookbooks and, through them, influencing thousands of readers and a generation of cookbook writers. When I first met him, in the late 60's, he was a designer, and he lived in the East 40's in a duplex that was one of those places you walked into and wanted to live in; everyone felt this way. Every single object in it was simple and beautiful. The glasses were beautiful. The wooden-handled knives and forks were beautiful. The seersucker napkins were beautiful, and what's more, they didn't have to be ironed. Everything was white, or beige, or sometimes gray, and fantastically easy on the eyes. In fact, right around the time I met Lee, Geraldine Stutz walked into Lee's apartment and wanted to live in it so badly that she hired him to open a small shop at Henri Bendel, the department store she was running at the time; as a result, I was able to buy the very glasses and knives and forks and seersucker napkins I had seen at Lee's, and before long almost everything I too owned was white, or beige, or sometimes gray.

title: A Celebration of Aluminum, the Everything Metal
description: A DAZZLING array of today's aluminum scooters brightens a wall near a vintage aluminum-clad Rolls-Royce in the entrance hall of the Carnegie Museum of Art here. These objects are a fitting introduction to ''Aluminum by Design: Jewelry to Jets,'' the first exhibition at an American museum to survey a material that came into use more than a century ago.

title: Here's Looking at You, Kids
description: Pobby and Dingan

title: For a Legendary Jazzman, the Music Has Stopped
description: THE small label above the buzzer Sal Mosca -- hardly draws attention to this three-story building on Fifth Avenue here. Few people notice the name, and even fewer would recognize it as one that appeared on the marquees of the biggest jazz clubs in New York and on landmark jazz records.

title: Potables; Olive or Twist
description: Behind every good cocktail is a story. And sometimes behind a good story is a cocktail. Ernest Hemingway and his characters enjoyed martinis. Margaret Mitchell served hers mint juleps. And F. Scott Fitzgerald had a thing for, well, cocktails. Period. As Daisy mutters in ''The Great Gatsby'' after her indoctrination to alcohol, ''Never had a drink before but oh, how I do enjoy it.''

title: Retreating to Artists' Towns
description: IN Brownsville, Vt., Dick Bullard was just leaving to go home, locking up the old farmhouse he has been using for his real estate office ever since he quit the Boston banking business 24 years ago. Visitors driving down the main road had been attracted by the sign announcing the Bullard Real Estate Company, a blue and white placard with the simple word ''Duck'' hanging right under it.

title: Mosley Defends Title By Stopping Diaz in Six
description: Sugar Shane Mosley defended his World Boxing Council welterweight title and polished his reputation last night with a convincing technical knockout of Antonio Diaz in the sixth round of an entertaining but one-sided bout scheduled for 12 rounds in the Theater at Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUPER, GORDON S.
description: COUPER-Gordon S. Died suddenly and peacefully at home on October 30, 2000. Loving husband of Gail C. Neild, father to Ian and Judith (Childs) of England, brother of Alistair of Florida and Sheila (Buck) of Montana.
