Funeral services will be held on November 11 at 11 AM at The Church of the Good Shepherd, 240 East 31 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to The Church of the Good Shepherd.

title: Spending
description: After reading your issue on spending (Oct. 15), I did not know whether to laugh or cry. Like most of your special issues, this one focused on egregious affluence, with a couple of opposite cases thrown in for balance. I guess my husband and I, who put most of our income toward health care, auto repairs and student loans, just do not fit your demographic profiles -- hence our conspicuous absence from your pages.

title: England May Reclaim the Ocean
description: There are many yacht races which can stake a claim as the world's toughest, but when it comes to long-term hardship, breakneck sailing and an honest chance for disaster, it is difficult to one-up the singlehanded Vendee Globe race.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Volvo V70 and Cross Country; A Connecticut Yankee Or a West Coast Dude?
description: A FRIEND who is a family counselor once attended a seminar on the subject of choosing a vehicle appropriate for her professional image. The recommended car was, of course, a Volvo.

title: Remote Yemen May Be Key to Terrorist's Past and Future
description: By legend, this remote valley nestled between the Arabian Sea and the black, crumpled mountains that form a shield against the vast deserts of Arabia is the land of the Queen of Sheba and the place fabled for the gold and frankincense and myrrh that the Wise Men carried to the manger where Jesus was born.

title: In Marking Slaying Of Rabin in 1995, Israel Seeks Lessons
description: Five years to the day after Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated, Israel's severe crisis with the Palestinians is threatening his legacy as a peacemaker.

title: Palestinians and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Uneasy Pieces in an Era of Mergers; Who's Afraid Now That Big Is No Longer Bad?
description: LAWRENCE A. BOSSIDY had sworn that he would raise annual revenue at AlliedSignal to $20 billion by the time he retired as chairman and chief executive last April. His determination had even become a company slogan: ''20 in 20,'' his people would say, lopping off zeros. But as his retirement approached, revenue was still $5 billion short of the goal. So last year, Mr. Bossidy acquired Honeywell Inc., creating a company with Honeywell's name and $24 billion in revenue.

title: Shelter Island Heights Takes Road of Reason
description: THEY stand proudly alongside the narrow, bumpy road, one of only a few thoroughfares that link the small community of Shelter Island Heights to the rest of the island. One of them, at least, looks to be a good 100 years old. And though it seemed for a time last month that the silver maples on New York Avenue might fall prey to progress, and the cutter's ax, it now looks like they will be preserved, after all.

title: Big Brother
description: FROM THIRD WORLD TO FIRST

title: Nov. 7, Through a Medical Lens
description: To the Editor:

title: Voters to Act on Plan To Replace Penitentiary
description: ON Election Day, Westchester County voters will decide whether to spend $59.5 million to replace the old county penitentiary in Valhalla, which was declared ''unfit for habitation'' by the State Commission of Correction and closed for good in July.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a circulatory problem that can afflict airline passengers and others who remain immobile for extended periods misidentified a blood-thinning drug that is used to treat it. The drug, manufactured by the DuPont Pharmaceuticals Company, is Innohep, not Innopehn.

title: Chateau Babylon
description: 'We're gonna do elegance blase, a lost style, like parents' parties in the 60's.'' David LaChapelle, in Los Angeles for a gallery opening at the Fahey/Klein Gallery, is holding forth on the theme of his after-show party. His allusion immediately brings to mind blocks of cream cheese with tins of salmon caviar, women in sheath dresses, men in sports jackets, party-colored, gold-tipped Nat Sherman cigarettes in little urns on the coffee table, Herb Alpert's ''Tijuana Taxi'' on the record changer.

title: Celluloid Visions Are What Dance In My Head
description: CHRISTMAS EVE was always a production at our house. The towering tree in the central hall, covered with shiny red ornaments, draped in silvery tinsel, lighted with real candles. The staff, in their long black uniforms with starched white aprons and caps, setting out piles of gorgeously wrapped gifts underneath the tree. There were tall white candles on the dining table, where after dinner (which always began at 4:30 p.m.) we sang and toasted everyone's health. Mother wore red brocade and Father, like all the men in the family, wore white tie. Eventually we all held hands and danced through the house, singing until we fell, exhausted, into our chairs and listened to an uncle read the Nativity story from the second chapter of Luke. In lovely, lilting Swedish.

title: Not Deserving
description: To the Editor:

title: Spending
description: I was really disappointed when, toward the end of the interview, Ivana Trump was asked what she would do if she won the lottery and she said, ''I would call Ace Greenberg at Bear Stearns and let him worry about it.'' Wouldn't it be better if she had said she would give the money to charity?

title: Oct. 29-Nov. 4; Moving In and Opening A New Era in Space
description: The long-awaited advent of a new era of space exploration arrived when two Russians and an American took up residence in the international space station. Capt. William M. Shepherd of the United States Navy became the space station's first commander, having traveled there with his crew members, Yuri Gidzenko and Sergei Krikalev, aboard a Soyuz rocket launched from Russia's Baikonur cosmodrome 43 years after Sputnik was put into orbit from there. Jubilant space agency officials expressed the hope that humans had now achieved a permanent presence in space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, ANNA M.
description: FRANK-Anna M. On November 3, 2000, of Manhattan in her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Jerome H. Frank; loving mother of Marjorie and Frank Balaban and H. Stephen Frank. Adoring grandmother of James Schecter, Nancy Starkey, Chrissie Bennett and Jane Frank Pascal, Stacey Frank Kanihan, and Jonathan Frank. Cherished great-grandmother of nine loving great-grandchildren. Always in good humor and with a most generous heart, her indomitable spirit is held in warm memory by her family. Interment at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 5, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Mandi Cohen, A. C. Morgan IV
description: Mandi Sue Cohen, the daughter of Lynda and Robert Cohen of South Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to A. C. Morgan IV, the son of Molly and A. C. Morgan III of Darien, Conn. Spencer Slate, a notary public, officiated at the Ocean Reef Club in Key Largo, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODSON, ABRAHAM
description: GOODSON - Abraham. Beloved husband of Shirley, cherished father of Carole (Roger Yu), Janice (Gordon Taylor) and Barbara (Bruce Gustafson), loving grandfather of Olivia and Andrew, dear brother of Ann Weiner and Rosalie Harris. Our precious Al passed away on November 2. Services will be held Sunday, November 5, at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave., NYC, at 11:30 AM. He will be so deeply missed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HARRIET G.
description: COHEN-Harriet G. Nov 3, 1983. In cherished and loving memory of our dearly beloved mother, grandmother and sister-in-law. Always in our hearts. Sadly missed. Richard Jay & Hope, Lindsey & Ashley & sister-in-law Lucille.

title: Through a Glass of Vodka, Darkly
description: The tintinnabulation of voices had peaked at Jimmy's Corner as its denizens watched the tail end of the Subway Series.

title: Brazil's Soccer Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Phoenicia Journal; Great Views, and a Peek Into the Past
description: Hikers are, by and large, an undemanding bunch. Given a choice between life's goodies and soothing nature, they'll generally go for nature. But when they reach a summit after an often-rugged climb of two hours or so, they want, well, a little payoff. Not much, mind you -- they don't expect a mountaintop Starbucks or a steaming Jacuzzi. But is a stunning view too much to ask?

title: Bridge-Crossers Have Many Great Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Camby Turns Criticism Into Motivational Tool
description: Marcus Camby is paranoid. He thinks the news media hate him, that they perceive every Knicks loss to be his fault. He believes he is the news media's new dartboard now that Patrick Ewing is gone, and that such treatment is the unfortunate birthright of every Knicks center.

title: Nicole Scheps, Michael Kirsh
description: Nicole Beth Scheps, a daughter of Susan and Stephen Scheps of Cherry Hill, N.J., is to be married today to Michael Alan Kirsh, the son of Felice and Robert Kirsh of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Bruce Block will officiate at the Oakeside Mansion in Bloomfield, N.J.

title: Kenyans Seek Marathon Redemption After Olympic Snub
description: A group of masked men approached the home that spread out over a patch of Kenyan countryside and crept up as silently as shadows. Then in one abrupt instant, the band of robbers barged through the door and streamed past John Kagwe's terrified wife.

title: At 79, a Winning Coach Goes Back Into Battle
description: MIKE DELVAL is coming home.

title: Who's a Jew? What's the Joke?
description: MODERN ORTHODOX'' at the Long Wharf Theater ends with a line -- a punch line, to be more precise -- about food after sex.

title: A Black and Orange Ball, a Small Circle
description: THE basketball program here prides itself on one thing besides its winning record -- and that is continuity. And John Thompson III prides himself on being more water in that long stream.

title: Folk Singer Trys to Get Beyond Dylan's Shadow
description: LIKE many contemporary folk musicians, Dan Bern has been saddled with a curse: the singer-songwriter has been deemed the new Bob Dylan. For alternative-folk fans who do not have a historic perspective, the comparisons are well-grounded. For Dylan aficionados, those who have examined his every word, every metaphor, the likening is outrageous. But for Mr. Bern, it is just an annoyance.

title: Caitlin Daniels, David Israel
description: Rebecca Caitlin Daniels, the daughter of Alice Jarman Daniels of New Canaan, Conn., and James E. Daniels of Brooklyn, was married yesterday evening to David Jay Israel, the son of Adele and Howard Israel of Boston. Rabbi Alexander Schindler officiated at the Pratt Mansion in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUPTMAN, ISABEL ''TROTIE'' (ABELSON)
description: HAUPTMAN - Isabel ''Trotie'' (Abelson). New York resident for over 70 years died in her sleep November 3, 2000 at the age of 101. As a graduate of Wellesley College Isabel's loyalty to the school was number 1 on her list. She leaves two daughters, Joannee Marks of New York City and Kit Kuperman of Denver, Colorado, five grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. All of her long time and beloved friends will miss her greatly. Services private.

title: A Bistro With Creative and Affordable Food
description: WHAT a pleasure to discover Metro Bis (for bistro) in Simsbury, a small restaurant with the charm and urbanity of a French bistro, stylish American food, and prices that are surprisingly affordable.

title: Don't Spill It on Me
description: Earlier this fall, I was on a flight to Los Angeles that made a few extra turns after takeoff. Once we reached cruising altitude, the pilot made a long announcement explaining that his computer had been indicating a problem with the hydraulic brake system and that after running some tests, he had decided it was O.K., that the problem was caused by a computer anomaly, not the brakes. So instead of returning to J.F.K., we were cleared to fly on.

title: Tunnel to Join Old Neighbor, Polo Grounds, in Memory
description: A mysterious old train tunnel that annoyed local residents and haunted a Bronx topographic engineer for years will soon have its mouth shut by the city. The tunnel, just west of Jerome Avenue on 162nd Street, had become a home for fires, abandoned cars and dangerous junk. People may have been living there, too.

title: Finding Potential in Computer Security Stocks
description: LIFE for Internet Romeos has become more complicated, now that the old staple, ''I love you,'' has been tainted. Those words, found atop e-mail messages last May, opened the door to the so-called Love Bug computer virus, which cost businesses an estimated $15 billion.

title: A Puppeteer With a Mission and a History Lesson
description: WHEN Schroeder Cherry is not working as a museum educator, he might be found making puppets in the basement workshop of his modest four-bedroom home in Fanwood, N.J. Or a day off might mean, as it often has for the last nine years, that he is traveling around the country with his hand-held creations, performing a play about the Underground Railroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMASINA, ANGELO ANDREW
description: TOMASINA-Angelo Andrew. The York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Angelo Andrew Tomasina, associated with The Times from 1958 until 1993.

title: Mideast Unrest Stalls Israel's Role in Red Cross
description: A solution to the controversy that has threatened to split the Red Cross -- adopting a new emblem to allow Israel's agency into the movement -- has been stalled, perhaps indefinitely, by recent violence in the Middle East.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANBARLIAN, HARRY
description: ANBARLIAN-Harry. On November 4, 2000. Beloved husband of Marina Masi Anbarlian. Dear brother-in-law of Peter and Marisa Johnson. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, November 6, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 650 West 168th St., NY, NY 10032.

title: TROOPERS' CHARGES DISMISSED
description: A judge last week dismissed the most serious charges against two troopers involved in the April 1998 shooting on the New Jersey Turnpike that catapulted racial profiling into a national issue. James Kenna and John Hogan had been charged with aggravated assault and attempted murder for injuring three unarmed minority men during a traffic stop of their van. But Mercer County Superior Court Judge Andrew J. Smithson blasted the conduct of former Attorney General Peter J. Verniero, now a state Supreme Court Justice, saying that prosecutors trampled on the troopers' rights because they overzealously tried to quell the political uproar about racial profiling. Governor Whitman has ordered Attorney General John Farmer Jr. to appeal the ruling. Civil rights advocates and lawyers for the victims say they will press the Justice Department to prosecute the case in federal court. David Kocieniewski

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Cracking The Code, Musically
description: After years of battling computer wizards flashing hit songs around the Internet for no fee, executives from the music and electronics industries announced this fall unveiled a possible technology to turn the tables on their high-tech foes.

title: From Social Security to Environment, the Candidates' Positions
description: Voters have many questions about issues,and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have many answers. Here aresummaries of the Bush and Gore positions onpolicy issues that have recieved considerable attention in the presidential campaign, with a comparison to show how the candidates differand agree, and assesments of their position fromexperts and political analysts-some partisan, some not.

title: Stepping Into Honolulu's Past
description: Hawaii is more famous for its natural environment than for its man-made one, but it's nevertheless home to some remarkable architecture. Honolulu features the only royal palace in the United States, the country's first Chinatown, and a church made of coral, according to David Cheever, the executive director of the American Institute of Architects in Honolulu.

title: Reaching for Perfection
description: WORDS fail me. I have just bitten into the first course of my first meal at the Ryland Inn, a tomato salad from the organic garden on the restaurant's grounds.

title: To Take Part in the Art, You Sleep With the Artist
description: THE buzz began the moment I heard the instructions. I would be sleeping with the artist Mingwei Lee. He was inviting me to spend the night alone with him in the Lombard-Freid Fine Arts gallery: 9 p.m. until 9 a.m. I was to bring nightwear and other things of mine to leave on a table for public display.

title: Sui Generous
description: Anna Sui (arranging flowers in a vase as she gets her Greenwich Village apartment ready for company): I travel so much for work that when I'm in New York, I like to have friends over for dinner at least once a week. Otherwise, I'm in restaurants most nights. It is becoming increasingly impossible to have a conversation in a restaurant because they are too noisy.

title: High Income Welcomes Low Income Into Its Front Yard
description: The bedroom, overlooking a treelined street, is spotless. The bathroom sparkles. The brick building, nestled between the upscale enclaves of Park Slope and Boerum Hill, is a five-minute walk from eight subway lines.

title: Courthouse Project Moving Ahead
description: WHEN bids for the final part of the renovation and expansion of the County Courthouse here were opened in February and found to be $24 million over budget, officials from the county, the court system and the state met in a series of panicked meetings.

title: A True Story of What Now Seems Incredible
description: IT was a fortnight so fraught as to seem surreal, a standoff scholars have come to call the most dangerous moment in recorded history. Thirty-eight years ago this autumn, as the United States and the Soviet Union stood on the brink of nuclear conflict over missiles in Cuba, John F. Kennedy and his men groped for a way to avoid the end of the world as they knew it.

title: Editors' Note
description: A headline yesterday on the continuation of the front-page article about Gov. George W. Bush's presidential campaign said in some copies that he had stressed integrity ''Even as Drunken-Driving Arrest Raises Questions of Character.'' That phrasing exceeded the facts of the article, and its opinionated tone was unintended. A replacement headline went astray in the production process.

title: Q and A
description: American Air Museum

title: Worries About Intruders at Wreck of Edmund Fitzgerald
description: The bodies are 17 miles out and 500 feet below the surface of Lake Superior. But even as family members of the 29 victims prepare to observe the 25th anniversary of the wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald on Friday, they do not consider their loved ones totally at rest.

title: New-World Name And Spicy Flavors
description: Frank J. Prial, wine columnist for The Times, tasted the semillon-chardonnay, cabernet sauvignon-shiraz and zinfandel-shiraz blends that Kendall-Jackson Wine Estates has started exporting.

title: Real Estate, From an Expert
description: INSIDE the CUNY Graduate Center visitors can take a virtual stroll down Fifth Avenue as it appeared in 1911. Photographs from a rare period publication that documented both sides of the street from Washington Square to 93rd Street are displayed in a linear sequence that includes a view of the former B. Altman building, in which the Graduate Center is now located.

title: Not Cluttering His Kitchen Empire
description: Chuck Williams is finding a wider audience for his recipes than he had imagined when he started his kitchenware business almost a half-century ago. A home builder inspired by his travels to France, Mr. Williams opened a shop to sell French cookware in then-sleepy Sonoma, Calif., in 1956, and moved the store to San Francisco two years later. ''We did lots of things to serve our customers,'' Mr. Williams, 85, recalled last week on a visit to New York. ''We answered their questions, gave them recipes. I even got on a bus once to deliver a package to a woman fixing dinner.''

title: Iron-Ons: The Way We Wear
description: Children of the 70's who haven't had their fill of nostalgia with the resurgence of Farrah Fawcett hair and fondue parties have a new style option: high-fashion iron-ons. JET shirts designed by John Eshaya feature vintage iron-ons of Leif Garrett, Shaun Cassidy, Scott Baio and (best seller) Donny Osmond ($58 at Henri Bendel). ''It's fun to wear something that you wore when you were cool, carefree and didn't have to worry about rent,'' said Mr. Eshaya, who pressed the Tiger Beat-era pictures onto snug baseball shirts ''because that's something they would wear on 'Three's Company.' ''

title: After a 40-Year Layoff, a Return to the Pool
description: CHARLES J. URSTADT has lived his life according to the ''sink or swim'' maxim -- but in his case, he's always swum.

title: All the News That Fits
description: The last word in fashion is old news, revived by a new generation. Last January, Dior's designer, John Galliano, showed clothes cut from newspaper-print silk. It caused a scandal because he said he was inspired by homeless people he saw along the Seine, covered in newspapers to keep warm. Today, women in Paris and New York are wearing these newsprint designs. The idea stretches back centuries. In 1860, caricaturists spoofed the follies of fashion in the journal Le Rire, top right. For generations, fathers have folded newspaper pages into play hats for children, while newspaper printers did the same to keep the ink out of their hair. In the late 1930's, inspired by Picasso's collages using newspaper scraps, the Paris designer Elsa Schiaparelli made blouses and accessories in newspaper prints and called them Surrealist.

title: Pepsi, Too, Has a Classic, and It Will Stay On
description: A red neon Pepsi-Cola sign that has beamed toward Manhattan since 1936 and become an urban icon will be part of development plans for the Hunters Point section of Long Island City.

title: Interiors; Plan Ahead
description: What's the most entertaining aesthetic today? It's postindustrial, according to William Sofield, the designer who orchestrated the mod 70's redo of Gucci's Fifth Avenue store, and who has also been hired by the company's creative director, Tom Ford, to redesign the Yves Saint Laurent stores.

title: Encounter With a Legend
description: THE 1998 New York City Marathon was my third. I should have stopped at two.

title: BENEFITS
description: Modernism in Brooklyn

title: Now It's the Art Students' Turn: Sculptors Show Off Their Works
description: BARBARA SEGAL has had plenty of opportunity to show off her own sculpture, most recently in the exhibition ''Women of Stone Part 1'' at the Neuberger Museum of Art that just came down last week.

title: Alison Shanley, Peder Johnson II
description: Alison Parkman Shanley, a daughter of Eleanor and Kevin Shanley of Gladstone, N.J., was married yesterday to Peder Christian Johnson II, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson of North Clarendon, Vt. Msgr. William N. Field performed the ceremony at the Church of the Good Shepherd in Blooming Grove, Pa.

title: A Strange Pleasure
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarah duPont, Edwin Hendriksen
description: Sarah Lewars duPont, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Lewars duPont of Belleair, Fla., was married yesterday to Edwin Hendriksen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bartholomeus Hendriksen of Hengelo, the Netherlands. The Rev. Stephen D. Parker, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Gasparilla Inn in Boca Grande, Fla. Harry Sykes Cline, a friend of the bride's family, took part in the ceremony. The couple graduated from Rollins College, from which the bridegroom also received an M.B.A. degree.

title: Political Memo; Lofty Talk Discarded, Senate Race Ends in Brawl Over Narrow Turf
description: It began as one for the history books -- the wife of a sitting president moving from the White House to New York to run for the Senate, where Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would conduct a high-minded campaign grounded in the Democratic policies and philosophies that she and her husband had embraced over 25 years in public life in Arkansas, Washington and now New York.

title: Maguy by the Sea
description: Maguy Le Coze, a proprietor of Le Bernardin, one of the greatest restaurants in New York -- make that the world -- the woman who, alongside her brother, the late Gilbert Le Coze, revolutionized the way this nation of former fishstick-on-Friday eaters approaches, prepares and savors seafood, the dazzlingly leonine gamine who not only radiates as much Gallic charm as Catherine Deneuve but has done more to rescue French cuisine from the sticky clutches of bearnaise, hollandaise and bordelaise than a million copies of the Gault-Millau, has a secret. And it's a beaut. Maguy Le Coze can't cook. ''It's not as if I never wanted to,'' she says. ''But my parents put us to work in their little hotel in Brittany as soon as we were too tall to crawl between the tables. In France, it is tradition for the man to be in the kitchen and the woman to be out front with the customers. So Gilbert went to cook with my father. And despite my desire, my mother needed me in the dining room. Besides, I was the only one in the family who could speak English.''

title: Popcorn; The Latest Temptations of Uma
description: Food is the hot accessory in the movies this year. It's the new cigarette.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-05-00; The Veep Generation
description: As a less-than-inspiring election campaign has worn on to this week's welcome close, we have heard some rueful talk from Republicans and Democrats alike about the ''kangaroo'' tickets the two parties have put before us -- their strength lies in the vice-presidential hind legs. The feeling has only intensified since the two candidates met a month ago for their only debate.

title: Gloom Over Ad Shares, but Why?
description: THEIR earnings this year have been good -- great, in fact, according to many people who study the industry. Consolidation has increased their global reach, simultaneously reducing their vulnerability to problems in any particular market. And on Wall Street, there is enormous optimism about their earnings and growth.

title: Brownfields And Fairways
description: To the Editor:

title: In Tokyo Station, Enticing Options
description: AT Tokyo Station, municipal subway and rail lines deposit, pick up and transfer hordes of commuters from one local train to the next. A landmark in the Marunouchi business district, the station is also the hub for most long-distance rail service in and out of Japan's capital. Sleek bullet trains transport thousands of travelers daily west and south to Nagoya, Kyoto, Hiroshima and Hakata, or west and north to Nagano, Yamagata, Niigata and Akita prefectures.

title: The New Southern Male
description: MRS. HOLLINGSWORTH'S MEN

title: Joshua Bell in Montclair
description: There was no unanimity of popular opinion on the Academy Award-winning score for the film ''The Red Violin,'' but Joshua Bell's performance of it, which earned a Grammy, elicited only praise. It's not the only time his playing has been judged better than the composer's music. But no one will make that suggestion Saturday, when he plays Beethoven's Violin Concerto at Montclair's Unity Concert, joining Roger Norrington and the Camerata Academica of Salzburg, in an all-Beethoven program to be repeated in Avery Fisher Hall the next afternoon.

title: Nov. 7, Through a Medical Lens
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: How All This Started

title: When Lien From Loan Lives On
description: Q. When I bought a building in Hudson County, N.J., several years ago, the owner provided the financing and took back a first mortgage. The mortgage was due to be repaid in February 1999. At that time, I paid off the balance of the mortgage with a check. The owner's agent advised me that the mortgage had been sent to the Hudson County Register's Office for cancellation. To date, however, I have not received the canceled mortgage although I have written and asked for it several times. I checked with the Register's Office and found out that they never received the mortgage for cancellation and that the mortgage is still listed as a lien against my property. What is my recourse? . . . C. M. Schacht, Haworth, N.J.

title: Word for Word/Court Napping; During a Trial, Should Judges Let Sleeping Lawyers Lie?
description: In death penalty litigation, all cases are hard. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit -- which, because it includes Texas, is probably the No. 1 circuit in death sentences -- recently heard the case of Calvin Jerold Burdine, who was convicted in 1984 of fatally stabbing his lover. The appeal hinged on an issue that is hard to imagine translating into any other profession. The specific question: At a murder trial where the defense lawyer sleeps, how much sleep is too much?

title: Books; Hi, Society!
description: Two dozen or so metabolisms are getting a good workout as Nan Kempner, Mrs. Thomas Lenox Kempner of Manhattan, Purchase, N.Y., and the Bahamas, comes through the front door of Swifty's, that Upper East Side playpen, and spies Gilles Dufour, the French fashion designer late of Balmain, who is having lunch with C.Z. Guest by the open cafe windows as light rain peppers Lexington Avenue.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ONLY THE STRONG SURVIVE

title: Alexander Allport, 78, Green Space Defender
description: Alexander W. Allport, a founder of the Green Guerillas, died on Oct. 15 in a Mount Vernon, N.Y., hospital. He was 78 and lived in Denver, N.Y.

title: INSIDE
description: Battling Obesity's Stigma

title: Pauline On My Mind
description: The scene: Paris, 1917. The characters: a divorced, alcoholic American on the skids, her shy and skinny 8-year-old daughter and a young soldier, a cousin sent to save the child from destitution. The question: Would she come back with him? ''No,'' the little girl remembered having said, years later. ''I want to have a more interesting life.''

title: Doing Business In Small Quarters
description: THERE are small businesses, and then there are really small businesses, those squeezed into spaces no larger than some Westchester master bathrooms. With fewer than 300 square feet of selling space, a tiny retail shop must make every square inch count.

title: Food; Do You Tofu?
description: In a recent, highly scientific and exhaustive poll spread geographically over two or three blocks of the West Village (three women and four men, each representing three-quarters of a billion people), the milk from soybeans, curdled with a coagulant and better known as tofu, wound up just one notch above sea urchin and one notch below okra on the list of Most Despised Foods on the Planet.

title: Robert E. Cormier, 75, Author Of Enduring Books for Teenagers
description: Robert E. Cormier, the author of 18 challenging and critically acclaimed books for young adults, died on Thursday. He was 75 and lived in Leominster, Mass.

title: PRIVATE SECTOR; Smiling Through the Setbacks
description: OCTOBER was tough for Jeffrey T. Arnold, the founder of the WebMD Corporation. Shares of the company, which had made him worth hundreds of millions on paper, fell to a record low. A WebMD merger partner took over the whole business. Then Mr. Arnold's home nearly burned down.

title: DANCE; One-Time-Only Dances, in the Cunningham Style
description: CALL them the Merce Cunningham Variety Hour. Or, to be more exact, hour and a half, since the format the venerable choreographer calls an ''Event'' is 90 minutes without intermission.

title: Canyon of Colorful Surprises
description: WHEN a high-country craving comes over me like a thunderclap, there's nothing to be done except pack up. Last June, struck by my annual hunger for great walls of rock, dry heat, Fremont cottonwoods, darting lizards and a bit of water flashing silver in the sun, I decided to go hiking in southwestern Utah on my own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEATS, WILLIAM PERRY
description: KEATS-William Perry. Of East Hampton, LI, a lawyer, died peacefully at home on Friday, November 3. He was 83. Memorial services will be held at 11 AM, Saturday, November 11, St. Luke's Episcopal Church, East Hampton, NY. He wil be cremated. Perry was born on June 20, 1917, in Brooklyn, NY. Graduate of Harvard University (1939-major: Government and Romance Languages) and Harvard Business School (MBA, 1941). Saw active duty as Lt. Commander of a mine sweeper in the Pacific, retiring as Commander, USNR. Attended Stanford Law School (1949-1951), subsequently New York University (J.D., 1952). Corporate Counsel to Pepsico, Inc., then principal stockholder, director and general counsel, Monsieur Henri Wines, Ltd., White Plains, New York. After retiring in 1981, Perry remained active in the Episcopal Church, The Nature Conservancy and the East Hampton Historical Society. He was a member of the American Bar Association, the Democratic Party and the Harvard Club. Survived by his wife, Ida, his daughter, Catherine L. Roach of Edwards, Colorado, his son, William David of Ljubljana, Slovenia, and two grandchildren, Taylor and Travis Roach. Contributions to Perry's memory may be made to the Unitarian Church, P.O. Box 997, Watermill, NY 11947 or East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978.

title: Outnumbered 11 to 1, The Dollar Ends Up on Top; London: no euros, few bargains
description: Shopping in London, like eating out or finding a hotel room, is not so much a question of bargain-hunting as damage control. Indeed, Britons have taken to calling their land ''rip-off Britain,'' while Americans who live here usually calculate that anything costing one dollar at home costs one pound in London, whatever the exchange rate might be.

title: Landmarks for Common Folk
description: IN Italo Calvino's 1972 novel, ''Invisible Cities,'' a fictional Marco Polo recounts his journeys through imagined lands and their dreamlike capitals. In these mysterious places, people mingle in a caldron of exuberance and suffering, against a backdrop of clashing architecture and sensuous detail.

title: Teaching The Spiritual Art Of Weaving
description: IN the age of the quick purchase, the impulse to weave seems almost perverse. After all, you can walk into a Wal-Mart, plunk down $39.99, and walk out five minutes later with a serviceable bedspread. Better yet, you can order it online and have it delivered in two business days. So who has time to spend countless hours tangled in yarn, adjusting tension and counting warp threads?

title: An Off Year for Gonzalez Sends His Value Down
description: General managers gather here this weekend for their annual meetings knowing that the best-paid team won the World Series again and that the best players available in the free-agent market will cost a lot of money. Nothing new about either of those developments.

title: The Man in White
description: HOOKING UP

title: Victorian Networkers
description: ACROSS AN UNTRIED SEA

title: Opening Up the Voting Booth
description: IF the past is any indication, a lot of people in New Jersey will be making excuses on Tuesday instead of going to the polls. But one group of New Jerseyans won't be voting because they are not allowed: criminal offenders whose rights are being denied by antiquated laws that ought to be revisited.

title: Lives; 'I'd Been Praying That He'd Find Me'
description: On the day I happened to get caller ID, it was July 13, I kept getting phone calls all day long saying unknown name, unknown number. Finally, at 10 o'clock at night, I picked up the phone, and it was this woman, and she said: ''Hi, I have something important that I need to discuss with you. I'm calling for a young man. He's a really nice person. His birthday is July 14. He was born in 1973.'' And then I just knew. It was like being hit by something invisible -- this amazing energy blew through me. And she said, ''You know who I'm talking about?'' And I said, ''Yeah, I know.'' And she said, ''He would very much like to talk to you and meet you.'' She said, ''I'm also a birth mother, so I know, because I found the child I gave up.'' For years I'd been praying that he'd find me, but I never thought he would.

title: A Convincing Plea
description: To the Editor:

title: CASINO SALE
description: Resorts International, Atlantic City's first legal casino, will be under new ownership by the end of this year. The South Africa-based Sun International, which bought the poorly performing casino from Merv Griffin four years ago for $300 million, announced on Monday that it was selling it to Nick Ribis, former chief executive of Trump Hotels and Casinos, for $140 million. Mr. Ribis is buying Resorts in partnership with the Bahamas-based Colony Capital LLC, owner of 11 casinos in Nevada and the Midwest. Bill Kent

title: Home Furnishing Store To Open in Yonkers
description: At its T.J. Maxx and Marshall's clothing stores, the Massachusetts-based TJX Companies has had success supplying high-fashion looks at discount prices. The company is taking a similar approach to home accessories and furnishings with its HomeGoods chain, which will open a store next Sunday at the Cross County Mall in Yonkers. The Yonkers store will be the company's second New York outlet; the other is in Rockville Centre.

title: Black Spartacus
description: MASTER OF

title: Dueling Views of What Rock Stardom Means
description: ROCK STAR 1: ''I'm an idiot, a loser, a microphone abuser. I analyze every second I exist, beating up my mind every second with my fist.''

title: Clinton Veto Blocks Aid For Local Police Agencies
description: In vetoing the 2001 appropriations bill, President Clinton also blocked $300,000 for police forces that help protect the first family when they visit their Chappaqua home.

title: Escape Routes to Mars, Whoville and Elsewhere
description: SO much for the end of the year as the season of serious films for grown-ups. As the holidays approach, escapism is running rampant. Moviegoers can find Terence Stamp rocketing to Mars, Christine Baranski hanging out in Whoville and Jeremy Irons battling evil in a fantasy empire. Actual distant lands are popular, too, with an unusual number of films from Asia. And most of the children's films are set on other continents. Even close to home, the world seems to be awash in vampires, werewolves, seemingly normal humans with supernatural powers and young people close to the Devil. At least most of the documentaries are serious. And in the midst of it all, there are love stories, war dramas and portraits of artists as violently talented men. Opening dates, as always, are subject to change.

title: Media; Full Gallop
description: Before the phenomenal, inexplicable rise of Emeril shtick, and before the Iron Chefs challenged each other to make cr me brlee out of codfish roe, there was an English lad who brought a unique flavor to television cooking shows by combining the haute cuisine of the 60's with the Rat Pack insouciance of ''Playboy After Dark'' and the silliness of ''Laugh-In,'' all pulled together with the suavity of a Burton or O'Toole.

title: Picking Companies by the Book
description: These days, investors looking for stock tips are likely to go online, talk to friends or consult their psychics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESENFELD, SEYMOUR
description: WIESENFELD-Seymour. Beloved husband of Audrey. Devoted father of Caryl and Martin McKellar, and Nancy. Dear grandfather of Paul and Kian. Fond brother of Irene Fine and the late Benjamin, Paul and Harry. Dear brother-inlaw of George Fine, Bess Wiesenfeld and Mildred Wiesenfeld, and Elaine and Herbert Harris. Services Monday, 11:30 AM, at ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. Contributions to your favorite charity will be appreciated.

title: Rebecca Milner, Steven Krein
description: Rebecca Ann Milner and Steven Harris Krein, marketing executives, were married last evening at Oheka, the Otto Kahn house in Cold Spring Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Rita Leonard, a cousin of the bride, officiated.

title: He Did It His Way
description: A Personal Odyssey

title: Oct. 29-Nov. 4; A Message Not Meant for the Kids
description: It was because of the children, Gov. George W. Bush said in his impromptu news conference in Milwaukee, that he never made public his arrest for drunk driving in 1976. ''I made the decision as a dad,'' he declared, with his wife, Laura, looking on. ''I didn't want my girls doing the kinds of things I did.''

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Michael Vollbracht; A Week on the Town
description: I'M Sylvia Miles this week,'' Michael Vollbracht said Thursday night at the Lobster Club. By that, he meant he was attending a party every night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, MILTON
description: ISRAEL-Milton. Age 94, on Friday November 3, 2000. Peacefully after a valiant fight. Loving husband of June, devoted father of Andrew Pullman and Dr. Amy Pullman, beloved grandfather of Milo Pullman, Michael Israel Diamond, Philip Diamond and Julia Diamond. His intellect, spirit and courage inspired all of us. Services will be private.

title: Vendors' Parked Carts and Food Make the Neighborhood Dyspeptic
description: Where do pushcarts go to sleep? One neighborhood knows the answer, but wishes it did not.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Bialy Eaters

title: From Social Security to Environment, the Candidates' Positions
description: Voters have many questions about issues,and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have many answers. Here aresummaries of the Bush and Gore positions onpolicy issues that have recieved considerable attention in the presidential campaign, with a comparison to show how the candidates differand agree, and assesments of their position fromexperts and political analysts-some partisan, some not.

title: A Mere $2.88 per Chapter
description: In a city where tidal charts could reflect sommeliers' arrivals and departures, Joseph DeLissio's career as the River Cafe's wine director rests on the same bedrock as the Brooklyn Bridge overhead. For 22 years, his wine program has illuminated the restaurant's American cuisine as brightly as Lower Manhattan lights that sparkle across the East River.

title: What's a Park With No Cafe? Wonderful, Neighbors Say
description: Depending on whom you ask, a plan to convert a restroom at Stuyvesant Square Park into an outdoor snack bar is either a welcome attraction or a commercial eyesore.

title: All Above Board At Great Neck Library
description: This is to correct the misinformation presented in the opinion essay ''Dead Letters at Great Neck Library'' [Oct. 22].

title: State Justice Rejects Riverhead Mall
description: Astate Supreme Court justice has thrown out the Town of Riverhead's approval for Riverhead Centre, a proposed 395,000-square-foot shopping mall near the Tanger retail center on County Route 58. The ruling said the town had failed to follow its own regulations by approving a conceptual rather than a completed site plan.

title: POSTINGS: At Riverside Drive and 140th Street; Gothic 'Castle' To House Ex-Prisoners
description: Out of prison and facing homelessness, 60 ex-offenders at a time will be able next year to claim an address and a roof over their heads.

title: Outnumbered 11 to 1, The Dollar Ends Up on Top; Frankfurt: Don't take any wooden euros; the real ones are cheap enough
description: Frankfurt is home to the European Central Bank, which sets monetary policy for all 11 countries that have adopted the euro. And in a fit of euro boosterism, the city and its biggest companies have erected dozens of gigantic wooden coins along the streets and plazas, each of them painted with different artistic visions of the euro's significance.

title: Going to Work to Sell Business Casual
description: ONE evening in September, employees at Scient, an Internet business consulting firm in Manhattan, gathered for a party. They sipped green-apple martinis delivered to their desks and snacked on hors d'oeuvres served on fancy platters. A D.J. spun records. People danced and mingled. An hour or so later, they watched a fashion show.

title: From Social Security to Environment, the Candidates' Positions
description: Voters have many questions about issues,and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have many answers. Here aresummaries of the Bush and Gore positions onpolicy issues that have recieved considerable attention in the presidential campaign, with a comparison to show how the candidates differand agree, and assesments of their position fromexperts and political analysts-some partisan, some not.

title: Ophelia Robinson, Gregorio Hunt
description: Ophelia Robinson, a daughter of Sylvia and Willie Robinson of New York, was married on Friday evening to Gregorio Miguel Hunt, a son of Albertina and Cliffton Hunt of Hampton, Va. The Rev. Mariah Britton, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Riverside Church in New York.

title: Writers at Work, Shepherds at Rest
description: YOU see it as a New York sitcom, a little bit of ''Cheers'' and a little bit of ''Seinfeld.'' The setting: a Chelsea coffee shop with brick walls and seven tables. The cast: a couple of writers, who tap on laptops while sipping espresso, and bearded seminarians, who share their tables, steering the conversation to predestination or the metaphysics of the croissant.

title: Still in Blackface
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Stone Field, True Arrow

title: A Man for All Genres Who's Now Sui Generis
description: IN that lively, disparate and increasingly international force that is South Korean cinema, Im Kwon Taek occupies a role roughly comparable to the late Akira Kurosawa's in Japan: he is the emperor, respected by everyone. His films bridge the gap between popular fare for the average Korean and art movies for students and cinephiles.

title: Oct. 29-Nov. 4; Castro and Chavez Form A Havana-Caracas Axis
description: The personal friendship between Fidel Castro and Hugo Chavez, the populist president of Venezuela, was transformed into an alliance of their two nations when the Cuban leader concluded a five-day state visit in Caracas by signing agreements that call for Venezuela to provide one-third of Cuba's oil needs at cut-rate prices over the next five years. The accords also include stepped-up cultural, sports and medical exchanges, in what Mr. Chavez termed an effort to form a new ''axis of power'' separate from the United States. Larry Rohter

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report column on Oct. 8, about a proposed memorial on the Mall in Washington to honor veterans of World War II, referred incorrectly to its design. The memorial's granite plaza would be part of a larger 7.4-acre site with trees, grass and fountains; the plaza itself would not occupy 7.4 acres.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Yiddish Redux, in Concert

title: Cure It With Drugs
description: In 20 years as a therapist, I have discovered that most compulsive spenders have more than one compulsion (Maggie Jones, Oct. 15). One overeater lost weight but ran up her credit cards at the same time. Some stop drinking or smoking and spend instead. I maintain that spending binges are really temper tantrums, not a sign of depression. These people can learn to understand the relationship between their emotions and their behavior without drugs. Learning to live life consciously lasts forever.

title: Monuments
description: Nov. 1: The annual awards dinner of the New York Landmarks Conservancy saluted eight new ''living landmarks.'' The evening at the Plaza raised $400,000 and was attended by 450 guests.

title: Runaway Youths a Thorn in Iran's Chaste Side
description: One afternoon, Fahimeh Eskandari opened the front metal gate of the shelter she runs for runaway girls in central Tehran and was confronted by two men armed with knives and rifles. They had driven from Sanandaj in the northwest corner of Iran, hundreds of miles away, and demanded to see their 16-year-old niece, Ranach. She had shamed the family by leaving home a few days before. They had come to behead her.

title: From Social Security to Environment, the Candidates' Positions
description: Voters have many questions about issues,and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have many answers. Here aresummaries of the Bush and Gore positions onpolicy issues that have recieved considerable attention in the presidential campaign, with a comparison to show how the candidates differand agree, and assesments of their position fromexperts and political analysts-some partisan, some not.

title: Oct. 29-Nov. 4; 77 Die in Jet Crash
description: A Singapore Airlines Boeing 747 jet with 159 passengers and 20 crew members aboard struck an object and crashed during its takeoff for Los Angeles from Taiwan. It burst into flames, and 77 of those aboard died.

title: Deconstruction Sites
description: SEVERAL DECEPTIONS

title: Great Neck Student Survey: Skewed or True?
description: As a senior at Great Neck North High School, I feel that much of what was published in ''High School Confidential: A Great Neck Eye-Opener'' [Oct. 29] was taken out of context. I clearly remember the day in June when we students took the Pride survey. Because there were only a dozen or so class days before final exams and Regents tests, students were given the survey and told to ''hurry up and finish'' so that we could get back to preparing for the upcoming tests. During the survey, I, along with many of my peers, jokingly wrote in false answers, unaware of the consequences of our actions. Also, before writing this letter, I partook in a discussion concerning the survey, where the majority of the students laughingly explained how they had blatantly lied.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-05-00: Economics of Stored-Value Cards; Smells Like Teen Credit
description: Perhaps the first credit card specially designed for teenagers was the Capital One High School Student Card. The pitch was straightforward: ''For all of you out there who didn't think high-school students could get a credit card, we're here to tell you YOU'RE WRONG! . . . Establishing a good credit history starts early. . . . It's kind of like your permanent record they're always talking about in school, except this one is for real!'' The card has a maximum credit limit of $1,000 and a minimum age limit of 16. Parents must agree to be guarantors, which means they must foot the bill if their kids' baby-sitting money falls short.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Though her mother claimed that her daughter looked best in candid poses, Pauline de Rothschild eagerly sat for artists of every persuasion, from the sculptor Laurence Tompkins (his bust of her was exhibited at the Whitney Museum of American Art in 1941) to the photographers George Platt Lynes and Cecil Beaton. John Huston painted a portrait of her, too, but she hated the result and pasted newspaper over the face. This sketch of Illeana Douglas by the Swiss artist Michael Nicklaus recalls one of the baroness by Barnaby Conrad III.

title: POSTINGS: Annual Co-op and Condo Conference; Energy Costs And Dog Tales
description: The 20th annual conference of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums, to be held next Sunday at Hunter College, will offer fresh looks at dealing with rising energy costs, difficult apartment owners, and dogs.

title: When Hollywood Puts Its Spin on the Oval Office
description: WHEN I was in grade school, in the late 50's and early 60's, one of the most popular arguments for the greatness of the United States vis-a-vis the other, stinkier world powers was that in this country any boy could grow up to become the president. (Any girl could by implication be the first lady, if she played her cards right.) You don't hear that bromide much anymore, perhaps because the idea of the presidency as the pinnacle of American aspiration has been discredited by the behavior and/or ''character'' of the White House's post-Camelot occupants, namely: Lyndon Johnson (postsurgical exhibitionism, arrogant prosecution of an unjustified war, cruelty to beagles); Richard Nixon (enough said); Gerald Ford (clumsiness, sporadic confusion about the politics of Eastern Europe); Jimmy Carter (inability to deal with Congress, off-putting air of piety, embarrassing brother); Ronald Reagan (right-wing demagogy, tendency to narcolepsy); George Bush (bad syntax, pandering to the religious right, vomiting on unsuspecting Japanese); and Bill Clinton (slickness, randiness, unflattering jogging outfits). And which of them would you want your son to be when he grows up?

title: Oct. 29-Nov. 4; A Racial Profiling Case Fails in New Jersey
description: New Jersey's fitful efforts to deter racial profiling by its state police suffered another setback when a judge dismissed criminal charges against two troopers involved in a 1998 New Jersey Turnpike shooting. The troopers, James Kenna and John Hogan, had been charged with aggravated assault and attempted murder for shooting three unarmed black and Hispanic men during an April 23, 1998 traffic stop. But in Mercer Country Superior Court, Judge Andrew J. Smithson ruled that the attorney general's office had been so concerned about calming the political furor surrounding the issue that prosecutors made procedural errors and violated the troopers' rights. The state will appeal, but civil rights advocates have asked the federal Department of Justice to take over the case. David Kocieniewski

title: Value Stocks, Wearing The Cape of Superman
description: For years, stock traders who bought shares because they were rising in price -- known as momentum investors -- scoffed at the concept of value investing. Why buy stocks that move glacially, if at all, when you can buy shares that resemble rocket ships?

title: Ideas & Trends: Taking a Stand; Why Newspapers Endorse Candidates
description: IN August 1862, during the Civil War, Horace Greeley, the abolitionist editor of The New York Tribune, published an open letter chastising Abraham Lincoln for insufficient zeal on emancipation. ''A great proportion of those who triumphed in your election, and of all who desire the unqualified suppression of the rebellion now desolating our country,'' he wrote, ''are sorely disappointed and deeply pained by the policy you seem to be pursuing. . . .''

title: Animation That Really Seems Alive
description: O BRAVE new ''CyberWorld''! In the latest attraction from Imax, golden heads fly by in formation on golden wings through clouds of rods and cones that disperse like shimmering liquid. The patriarch of ''The Simpsons'' slips into the universe of ''that wheelchair guy,'' and falls down a black hole. Wondrous moments, and who cares about continuity? This is 3-D, for heaven's sake. Let's not get all linear.

title: How Much Data Access Is Too Much?
description: PICK up an old newspaper or magazine and you may be struck by how much better the advertising captures the spirit of the times than the articles do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, THERESE, (NEE BLUM)
description: STONE-Therese, (nee Blum). In her 97th year. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Frederick E. Stone. Loving mother of Barbara Coppe and Louise Spring, (Lionel). Adoring grandmother of Michael Spring and Tony Spring, (Grace), and great - grandmother of Tyler Spring and Nathan Spring. Sister of the late Julius Blum, (Esther), and Harold Blum, (Anita).

title: Reporter's Notebook; Stabbing May End Debate on Restrictions for Terrorism Suspects
description: With two defendants in the embassy bombings case now accused of stabbing a guard in the Metropolitan Correctional Center, one debate seems over: whether to loosen the restrictive conditions under which all five defendants in the case are being held.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-05-00: Questions for Ray Bradbury; Martian Tourist
description: Q: Next week you'll be receiving a lifetime achievement award at the National Book Awards. Are you still writing science fiction these days?

title: A Writer Fascinated by Pain and Death
description: IT is the cruel lot of some artists to be more celebrated in death than they were in life, although no one can argue that the English dramatist Sarah Kane went unrecognized during her short and controversial career. From the time her first play, ''Blasted,'' leaped onto the stage of the Royal Court's tiny Theater Upstairs in 1995, Ms. Kane was an object of attention, debate and -- among her colleagues and the critics -- growing admiration.

title: Divorce and Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: From Social Security to Environment, the Candidates' Positions
description: Voters have many questions about issues,and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have many answers. Here aresummaries of the Bush and Gore positions onpolicy issues that have recieved considerable attention in the presidential campaign, with a comparison to show how the candidates differand agree, and assesments of their position fromexperts and political analysts-some partisan, some not.

title: In His Own Words
description: GEORGE W. BUSH

title: A World Tour In the West 70's
description: METSOVO

title: RESEARCH TO BEGIN ON LOBSTER DECLINE IN SOUND
description: Responding to a sharp decline in lobsters in Long Island Sound, the State University of New York at Stony Brook plans to spend millions to study the situation. Research will begin this spring at the university's Marine Sciences Research Center on Long Island. The decline in lobsters over the past two years forced many of Westchester's lobstermen, in Port Chester for example, to dry-dock their lobster traps. Glenn Lopez, a professor of marine ecology at the center, said areas of research would include the western regions of the Sound, especially areas off Westchester, where there was ''almost a total die-off'' in the lobster population over the past year. Until last year, the Sound was the third largest lobster supplier in the Northeast, behind Maine and Massachusetts, with an estimated annual haul of 11 million pounds that generated about $15 million in revenue. Corey Kilgannon

title: Debating a Bill on Teaching Abstinence
description: The Legislature had a busy week as members considered legislation before heading off to campaign for this week's elections. Here were some the measures:

title: Neighbors Denounce Plans for Halfway House
description: About 300 parents and children, some holding hands, marched through Washington Heights yesterday to denounce a planned halfway house for federal inmates that would sit amid a cluster of neighborhood schools.

title: A True Definition
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary-Louise Villalba, Philipp Wahl
description: Mary-Louise Villalba, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeronimo Villalba of Paris and Quogue, N.Y., was married in Paris on Friday to Philipp James Wahl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Wahl of Zeiring, Austria. Mayor Pierre C. Taittinger of the 16th Arrondissement performed the civil ceremony in his office. Yesterday, the Rev. Albert Schlick performed a Roman Catholic ceremony at St.-Thomas d'Aquin Church in Paris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERDON, RUTH M.
description: PIERDON-Ruth M. Of Bronx, NY, passed away Saturday, October 28, 2000. Ruth was born August 8, 1904. She leaves no family, but had a lifetime full of friends. Memorial services will be held on Saturday, November 11, 2 P.M. at St. James Church, Bronx, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLOW, SHIRLEY TAXIN
description: POLOW-Shirley Taxin. On November 3. Beloved wife of Herb Polow and the late Harry Taxin. Loving and cherished mother of David, Ira and Paul, mother-in-law of Nancy, Janet and Christine. Adoring grandmother of Amy, Michael, Melissa, Sondra, Liz, Zachary, Julieanne, Jeffrey and Adam. Dear stepmother to Ian and Deirdre Polow. Devoted sister-inlaw, aunt and friend. Funeral services Monday, November 6, at 10 AM at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. The family requests that contributions in her memory be made to Wilmot Group of Hadassah, New Rochelle Chapter.

title: Nursing Homes, Stung By Politics
description: IT'S difficult to believe that an $85 billion industry servicing the fastest-growing age group of the American population could be sick, but sick is what the nursing home industry is. Over the last couple of years, a number of major companies in the sector, including Vencor, the Sun Healthcare Group and Genesis Health Ventures, have filed for bankruptcy.

title: On the Beach, Awash in People's Trash
description: CONSIDER the lowly drinking straw. More specifically, consider banning it.

title: Piano, Times Two, in Darien
description: THE great German 20th-century composer Paul Hindemith once said, ''People who make music together cannot be enemies, at least while the music lasts.'' But there have been moments, say the women of the Duo Piano Group, when they have called themselves the dueling piano group.

title: From the Classroom To the Trenches
description: IN September 1999, Kathleen Rotter -- who had been the special education administrator in the Hillsborough School District for eight trying years -- wanted out.

title: The Arguable Comedy in 'Merchant of Venice'
description: NO kidding, ''The Merchant of Venice'' is a comedy.

title: Ideas & Trends; Who Needs The Next Four Years?
description: THE moment should strike sometime around midday on Wednesday. It will dawn on someone -- perhaps the president-elect himself -- that despite all that rosy campaign-trail optimism about how this is America's moment of glory, the next four years could get really, really nasty.

title: Ann Rakestraw, Steven Farina
description: Ann Helena Rakestraw, a daughter of Sara and Buford H. Rakestraw III of Roanoke, Va., was married yesterday to Steven Michael Farina, the son of Guy J. Farina of Stamford, Conn., and the late Dorothy Farina. The Rev. Thomas Mattingly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Homestead, a resort in Hot Springs, Va.

title: Commercial Property/High Technology; A 500,000-Sq.-Ft. Lease Brings Qwest to Yonkers
description: QWEST COMMUNICATIONS, a supplier of high-capacity telecommunications services, recently agreed to lease a vacant 500,000-square-foot distribution center here and plans to cram it with more than $100 million of computers and other equipment to play host to World Wide Web sites.

title: With Broad Themes, Rivals Seek to Energize Voters
description: Vice President Al Gore kicked off a weekend-long crusade today to inspire a huge turnout among minorities and union members with a series of sermonettes that urged core Democrats to ''take your souls to the polls.''

title: LAND TRUST BUYS PROPERTIES IN DISPUTE
description: The Scenic Hudson Land Trust Inc. has bought 44.5 acres of land across from the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Home and Library in Hyde Park, ending a struggle to raise enough money to buy the properties from a private owner by an Oct. 31 deadline. The properties have been the subject of dispute for years over proposed development projects, including a Wal-Mart retail store proposal in the early 1990's. Major financing for the $3.1 million purchase was provided by the Lila Acheson and DeWitt Wallace Fund for the Hudson Highlands, as well as the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute and several other foundations and individual contributors. Robert Worth

title: A 3-Year-Old Colt Gets His Way by Giving None
description: Last October, Tiznow was an awkward 2-year-old brittle enough to have fractured a bone in his left front leg. By March, the colt had grown into his massive frame and developed a nasty attitude. He would rather drop exercise riders than carry them around the track. It did not bother his trainer, Jay Robbins.

title: The Irish Way of Honoring the Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTING WITH: Richard H. Gould; Rockland Small Cap Growth Fund
description: ON his recent honeymoon in Hawaii, Richard H. Gould, manager of the $72.3 million Rockland Small Cap Growth fund, went swimming and snorkeling. He also checked stock prices on his notebook computer and made about 10 trades a day.

title: A Parking Place for Cash, Turning Into a Fast Lane
description: WITH the stock market gyrating wildly, many investors have begun taking shelter in more stable places like certificates of deposit and higher-yielding savings accounts. They may be surprised to learn that they can sometimes get nearly 7 percent interest.

title: Style & Entertaining; You're Invited
description: ''Eat, eat,'' my uncle Izzy always said when it was time for second helpings.

title: Architectural Firm Named One of the Fastest Growing
description: The Mount Kisco-based architectural firm of Kaeyer, Garment & Davidson Architects, which specializes in school construction projects, has been named one of the country's 50 fastest-growing architectural firms, according to The Zweig Letter, an industry newsletter. It ranked 27th. The Albany-based firm of Einhorn Yaffee Prescott Architecture & Engineering, which has an office in White Plains, was ranked 19th. Rankings were based on a composite of revenue growth and percentage growth. In 1997, K.G.&D.'s revenues were $1.5 million; in 1999, they were $4.9 million.

title: Music to Watch 'Dracula' By
description: ''Where did you get those two little marks?'' Remembering this line probably makes you shiver, but in case you forgot it, or are not up to your lovely neck in post- Halloween chills, you can still stalk some in Englewood on Saturday, when Bela Lugosi and the ghoulish gang bare their famed Transylvanian fangs in a concert called ''Dracula: The Music and Film.''

title: Princeton Will Keep an Eye Out for a Cosmic Greeting
description: In a month or so a telescope at the FitzRandolph Observatory at Princeton University will start looking for laser communications sent by extraterrestrial life. The SETI (Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence) project will be a community effort with professors, undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, local residents, high school students and amateur astronomers taking part. Dave Wilkinson, a Princeton physics professor who is leading Princeton Oseti (Optical Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence), spoke about the project.

title: Recipes for Living; Miss Congealiality
description: Several years ago my mother had a four-day house party, during which she served an almost exclusively gelatin-based menu. I don't think it was on purpose; she just wanted to make everything in advance so that she could spend as much time as possible with her friends. But by the end of the second day, when the guests had already consumed a crab-meat mousse, a strawberry mousse, two kinds of tomato aspic and a charlotte russe, one complained that he could not get up from the table. ''I think,'' he said, ''my blood has coagulated.''

title: For Corzine and Franks, Different Paths to Often-Similar Destinations
description: Education

title: The Polyglot Task of Writing the Global Film
description: HOLLYWOOD storytelling is a volume business, and not just at the retail level. This was brought home to me by a recent summer blockbuster on which I happened to be one of 14 uncredited writers. My own contribution to the blockbuster was minor, and I assume the other 13 nameless fellows (like most Hollywood scripts, this was purely a man's job) made similarly modest adjustments. The film's final form was the cumulative result of all this worker-bee storytelling, a hoarding of narrative productive power.

title: Spending
description: Congratulations on the insightful views on the role of money in our lives. But as I reflected on the issue several days later, I was surprised to find that the ramblings of Ivana Trump, a modern-day Marie Antoinette, were what stuck most in my mind. When Trump steps into a cab without money or with only $100 bills, she shows a contemptuous disregard: why does she think it's appropriate (on a regular basis, no less) to instruct the cabdriver to return another day to ask her assistant for the fare? Does she have so little understanding of working people, who need, expect and are entitled to their money when they provide a service?

title: From Social Security to Environment, the Candidates' Positions
description: Voters have many questions about issues,and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have many answers. Here aresummaries of the Bush and Gore positions onpolicy issues that have recieved considerable attention in the presidential campaign, with a comparison to show how the candidates differand agree, and assesments of their position fromexperts and political analysts-some partisan, some not.

title: Corrections
description: The Wine Under $20 column on Oct. 22 misspelled the surname of a vice president of Chateau Benoit. He is Peter Posert, not Poster.

title: The Cinderella Complex
description: Why would anyone who has ever spent 15 minutes unsuccessfully trying to get a cowlick to lie flat on her head fall for the notion that she could be turned into a raving beauty in nanoseconds? And yet promises abound: just pat this cream on your face or toss this protein shake down your throat. Poof! You're ready for the ball. The prince is going to love you.

title: Crowds Shower President With the Star Treatment
description: President Clinton acted as a stand-in yesterday as he stumped across the Bronx, Harlem and Brooklyn urging New York Democrats to turn out en masse for his vice president and his wife. But at times, this retiring politician whose name will appear on no ballot on Election Day sure seemed like the main attraction.

title: The Know It Alls
description: Some people have a passion for gardening, others love classical music or cooking. The Jipters love answers -- answers in the form of questions, sequential answers, multiple choice answers. So to kick off its first annual convention, this group of game-show fanatics decided it was only logical that they meet here, outside the Manhattan studios of ABC's ''Who Wants To Be a Millionaire.''

title: Haunting the 80's and Loving Every Minute of It
description: PIA GETTY zipped past, dressed up like Bo Derek in her post-cornrow days. Alexandra von Furstenberg arrived late as a blonder version of Farah Fawcett. Rachel Peters, 28, the granddaughter of the composer Irving Berlin, was poised in a banquette between a young man dressed as Hunter S. Thompson with mirrored aviator sunglasses and another who was channeling the band Devo with a plastic red flower pot on top of his head.

title: Uneasy Pieces in an Era of Mergers; The Chaos At the Core Of Prosperity
description: THIS is not what a victory party is supposed to look like.

title: Factory Is Reborn in a Once Busy Valley
description: IN 1983, when the Seth Thomas clock factory closed for good in the Naugatuck Valley town of Thomaston, the workers from the plant carried a bier bearing an elegant mantel clock through the streets in a mock funeral. Then they burned it -- a measure of their contempt for a company that was no longer owned by the family that gave Thomaston its name, but had been bought by a multinational conglomerate and then shut down.

title: A Nontraditional Choice to Head Masters School
description: AT first glance, Maureen Fonseca wouldn't seem to be the obvious choice to head the Masters School here.

title: At Dale Carnegie, Looking to a New Generation
description: ON the wall in the library off the elegant rotunda of the stately brick Garden City home of Dale Carnegie & Associates hangs a formal black-and-white portrait of the founder. The rooms around the portrait house an international business that continues to run according to Carnegie's principles: call people by their names, be enthusiastic and don't leave without asking for the sale. Carnegie began teaching public speaking in 1912, and since then over five million people around the world have signed up for the course and related programs. Most want one thing: to graduate with better selling skills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVIN, KENNETH M.
description: LAVIN-Kenneth M. The York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Kenneth M. Lavin, associated with The Times from 1977 until 1997.

title: China 'Aida': Cast of 2,000, Plus Elephant
description: Giuseppe Verdi could never have imagined the music in his famous opera ''Aida'' upstaged by 1,650 People's Liberation Army soldiers and a trained elephant. But that's what happened Friday when 50,000 Chinese gathered here to watch the world's biggest production ever of an opera.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: A Vote Raider Long Before Nader

title: Fleury's 400th Career Goal Sparks Rangers to Victory
description: Ignited tonight by another goal by Theo Fleury, the 400th of his National Hockey League career, the Rangers' resurgent offense took another leap forward. Fleury, Adam Graves, Mike York, Mark Messier and Petr Nedved scored for the Rangers, Mike Richter stopped 36 of 38 shots for his third consecutive victory, and the Rangers cruised to a 5-2 victory, their third in the last four games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGHOSSIAN, BERG A.
description: BOGHOSSIAN-Berg A. 81. Died at Sloan Kettering on August 4. This special man leaves behind his beloved wife of 51 years Melinee, three daughters and five grandchildren. Up until his death he was a Manhattan attorney for more than 55 yrs. A Brooklyn native he attained the ranks of Eagle Scout and U.S. Army Sergeant in WW II.

title: Dinner That All Cooks at Once and Makes It Easy on the Cook
description: CONVENIENCE food on a Sunday night doesn't have to be Chinese takeout or something in the microwave. It can be a meal that's baking in the oven while you watch a movie or a ballgame.

title: It's a Night to Party, Whatever Your Party
description: UNCLE SAM wants you -- to party!

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: DISGRACE, by J. M. Coetzee. (Penguin, $13.) This South African novel, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 1999, tells of a literature professor whose life is upended twice: when a reckless affair with a student ruins his career, and later, after he takes refuge on his daughter's small farm, when intruders gang-rape his daughter. The result is a ''brief but oddly expansive novel'' whose action unfolds entirely in the present tense, Michael Gorra wrote here. ''Its grammar allows for the sublime exhilaration of accident and surprise, and so the fate of its characters . . . seems not determined but improvised.''

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS; Executive Director Leaving Harms
description: The executive director of the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood, David D. Rodriguez, will depart next month for the Apollo Theater in Harlem.

title: Bush on Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Groups That Defend the Hudson: A Primer
description: RIVERKEEPER is one of three major environmental groups dedicated to protecting the Hudson River and its valley. The others are Scenic Hudson Inc. and Hudson River Sloop Clearwater, both based in Poughkeepsie.

title: MY FIRST JOB; From Milk Crates To High Altitudes
description: David Neeleman, 41, is the founder and chief executive of JetBlue Airways, a low-priced carrier that started operations in February from Kennedy International Airport. Mr. Neeleman was also founder and president of Morris Air, which was acquired by Southwest Airlines in 1993, and was a co-founder of WestJet, a Canadian airline.

title: Stepping Out of Dylan's Shadow
description: LIKE many contemporary folk musicians, Dan Bern has been saddled with a curse: the singer-songwriter has been deemed the new Bob Dylan. For alternative-folk fans who do not have a historic perspective, the comparisons are well-grounded. For Dylan aficionados, those who have examined his every word, every metaphor, the likening is outrageous. But for Mr. Bern, it is just an annoyance.

title: Sparkling Span
description: Seventy-three years ago in Fort Lee, ground was broken for the George Washington Bridge. Since then, the bridge got a second level and the New Jersey tower got the world's largest free-flying flag to display on holidays. After sundown on Saturday, Veteran's Day, drivers can check out the bridge's flashiest new feature. Each tower will shimmer with 355,400 total watts' glow from 386 new halide light fixtures. The lights are pointed upward in crevices along the arched interior of the latticed towers, illluminating their grand design, in the manner of the lighting of the Eiffel Tower. The project took Port Authority electricians 18 months of work. They showed off the finished product to their families at a picnic in Fort Lee on July 4, and they were turn on again on Labor Day and Columbus Day. Stephen Napolitano, general manager of the Bridge, who grew up in Fort Lee, used to ride over the bridge on his bike to see the span. These days, he says, he marvels at the luminosity: ''They look like two crystal towers'' Margo Nash

title: Church, State And Tuesday Converge
description: WHEN Long Island Catholics enter into the sanctuary of the voting booth on Tuesday and draw the curtain behind them, the spiritual head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre will be there.

title: Kat Allen, Robert Olin
description: Kathleen Mary Allen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Allen Jr. of Grand Rapids, Mich., was married at the Kent Country Club there yesterday to Robert Brian Olin, a son of Sheila Olin of Rockville Centre, N.Y., and the late Elliott C. Olin. The Rev. Mark Przybysz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with Rabbi Lewis Weiss taking part.

title: FUJIFILM CONTRIBUTES TO NEW CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL
description: Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. of Elmsford has given $500,000 to the ''Reach for the Stars Campaign'' -- the largest corporate gift to the drive -- to build the new Maria Fareri Children's Hospital at Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla. Stanley E. Freimuth, Fuji's executive vice president and chief operating officer, is joining the board of the Children's Hospital Foundation, and Thomas A. Curley, trade association development director, is becoming a founding member of the Art Committee of the Children's Hospital Foundation. Elsa Brenner

title: After a Long Absence, Bush Is Back to Visit
description: The last time he set foot on New Jersey soil, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas promoted after-school programs, using the slogan ''No child left behind.'' Then he left this state behind.

title: Backyard Scientists Track Diseased Birds
description: THEY are the most unobtrusive of scientists, sitting politely behind their storm windows, not prodding or testing or vivisecting, just observing. They range from elementary schoolers to the elderly, they live in the suburbs and cities and they have contributed to an important discovery about wild animal diseases.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: SOMETIMES Hollywood makes a movie that works in every way. AMERICAN BEAUTY (1999) - which won five Oscars, including best picture - is one of those.
