The British stage director Sam Mendes and a television writer, Alan Ball, teamed up to tell the story of garden but comatose relationships. Kevin Spacey is heaven as Lester Burnham, a hero who makes his midlife crisis count, complete with red convertible, new job in fast-food service and new workout routine inspried by a blond cheerleader his daughter's age. Annette Bening may have lost the best actress award to Hilary Swank for ''Boys Don't Cry,'' but she gives an Oscar-worthy performance as Lester's wife, a real estate agent who recites New Age affirmations before every attempted sale. Some moviegoers consider this a dark comedy, but Lester's final words as narrator could have been written by Thornton Wilder - Saturday at 9 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:35 a.m. on HBO.

title: Habitats/Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village; One-Bedroom Plus a Studio Equals Apartment K-9
description: IT is true that Armanda Squadrilli bought the studio apartment next to her one-bedroom on Bleecker Street in the Village last June just so her two dogs would have their own room. It is true that they have their own couch, often covered with a floral-patterned sheet. But still, at night, like little children looking for their mother, they go into her room to sleep in her bed, along with the two cats.

title: When New Art Was All Called Art Nouveau
description: THERE'S a lot of talk about how art, design and architecture are merging these days, which is true, but it's also old news. The mix has always been there. It's a basic condition of visual culture. It just feels more unitary and dramatic at certain times than at others.

title: Anna B. Mayer, 91, Social Policy Planner
description: Anna Berenson Mayer, a social work policy planner and retired professor of social policy at Rutgers University, died on Wednesday at a New Brunswick, N.J., hospital. She was 91 and lived in East Brunswick, N.J.

title: A Tall Piece of Ukraine Docks in Norwich
description: DESPITE recent hard times, the city of Norwich spent $200,000 to build a 186-foot pier in the hopes that its ship would come in. And finally, after a deal with the Mashantucket Pequots fell through, the new structure will serve as home for the Bat'kivshchyna, a Ukrainian ship. The concrete-hulled vessel, which was originally a Soviet fishing trawler, will dock on the Thames River in Norwich until June.

title: Many Boos, Few Cheers For 'La Scala on the Hudson'
description: A floating ''La Scala on the Hudson'' is how its creator envisions his plan for a floating theater barge. But neighborhoods up and down the West Side are treating it more like a scow headed for Fresh Kills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKENZIE, ALEXANDER INNES
description: MACKENZIE-Alexander Innes. Of Chappaqua, NY. 65. Died October 31, 2000, of colon cancer. Alec's wit, optimism and passion for history, music, art and sports will be greatly missed by his wife, Nora, his daughter Vickie, his brother Archie and his many friends. His daughter Katey predeceased him in 1987. We were thrilled by Alec's first round victory in Jeopardy's 1994 Seniors Tournament. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, November 7, at the Union Church in Pocantico Hills, NY, at 2 PM. Donations may go to the '57 Scholars Fund at Williams College, Williamstown, MA 01267. You're a better man than I am, Gunga Din!

title: In Rye, Where Fare Is Decidedly French
description: THE dark beamed ceiling, lovely wood-trimmed entry and sparkling table appointments remain for us reminders of La Panetiere's once engaging mix of country homeyness and city sophistication. The rich, warm bisque and sienna color scheme, the lighthearted bird and floral motif in the draperies and sconces have been replaced by a far less cozy white and cream decor.

title: Literary Inn in Midtown
description: While Ian Schrager's Hudson and the TriBeCa Grand have marked the arrival of the hotel-cum-nightclub, Henry Kallan has an inn with quieter appeal. A boutique hotelier, he has just opened the Library Hotel, a bookish oasis at 41st Street and Madison Avenue -- steps from the Pierpont Morgan and the New York Public Libraries.

title: In the Coen Brothers' Off-Kilter World, The Only Certainty Is Uncertainty
description: NOTHING comes with a guarantee,'' says a character in the Coen brothers' very first film. ''I don't care if you're pope of Rome, president of the United States, man of the year, something can always go wrong.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-05-00: On Language; Baldfaced
description: As the 2000 campaigners practice their endgamesmanship, each side accuses the other of baldfaced lies. In some instances, the accusers prefer barefaced lies, and in a Virginia race, the mouth-filling modifier has come out sounding like boldfaced lies.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES MEASURE TO PUNISH DISCLOSING SECRETS
description: President Clinton vetoed a bill renewing the authority of the nation's intelligence agencies today because it contained what he called a ''badly flawed provision'' that would make it a crime for a government official to disclose classified information.

title: Nov. 7, Through a Medical Lens
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 22 about energy research gave an incomplete quotation from Dr. John P. Holdren, a professor of environmental science at Harvard. He said that research into nuclear fusion had been impeded by budgetary constraints, not that scientists had pursued the wrong technology.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about the closing of Kiev, a Ukrainian coffee shop in the East Village, misstated the relative locations of the shop and St. George Ukrainian Catholic Church. The coffee shop was on the same block of East Seventh Street, not across the street from the church.

title: Paradise Found, and Thus Threatened
description: CLIMBING on a 1953 tractor by his roadside farmstand piled high with just-picked apples, Tom Wickham, 61, rolled slowly down a country lane through his peach orchard. At a mill beyond the blueberry bushes and his family's 1740's clapboard homestead, his nephews, Stephen Wickham Searl, 22, and Dan Heston, 32, were pressing Mutsus, Cortlands and Jonagolds into fresh cider. In the distance, past an inlet known for more than three centuries as Wickham Creek, was an old Indian camp where Mr. Wickham said he sometimes found arrowheads and potsherds.

title: Letters on Travel
description: AKing's Statue

title: The E-Mail Resume, Addressed for Success
description: When you finally got with the job-hunting program and sent a batch of resumes over the Internet, you might have found the process faster than snail mail, though otherwise little different. You proofread the document 10 times, then hit the ''send'' button instead of licking stamps and addressing envelopes.

title: The Political Era That's Over
description: Seasons come and go, in politics as in life, without always doing us the courtesy of announcing themselves. We know now that an era ended and another one began in 1932, when Franklin Roosevelt swept Herbert Hoover out of office, just as, in a much more dimly remembered time, Abraham Lincoln's election marked a political as well as a societal turning point. But it couldn't have been quite so obvious at the moment the events were taking place.

title: Hampton Decides to Seek Better Offers as Free Agent
description: Mike Hampton's relationship with the Mets grew tenuous today when the pitcher's agent notified the club that Hampton had chosen to become a free agent.

title: Outnumbered 11 to 1, the Dollar Ends Up on Top
description: FRANKFURT

title: THE GUIDE
description: Happenings at Yale

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with an article about the economic future of Mexico under its newly elected president, Vicente Fox Quesada, carried incorrect data for the country's gross domestic product and consumer price index. A corrected version appears today, on Page 6.

title: BACKTALK; Marathons Stay A Source of Fun For Ex-Prodigy
description: Sports for children are supposed to be fun. But the notion of ''child's play'' seems antithetical to organized sports in general and marathon running in particular. How can training for a 26-mile race be fun?

title: After Sharply Different Starts, Cheney and Lieberman Score Points in Campaign
description: Things ran off track as soon as Senator Joseph I. Lieberman reached the Haitian-American Democratic Club in Miami last week. He expected to chat and shake hands for a few minutes, and be on his way. But the organizers had promised the crowd a speech, and they handed the senator a microphone.

title: Hollywood Begins Stoking the Oscar Machinery
description: FOUR months and three weeks from now, on March 25 at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, before an audience of a billion people around the world, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will spare no pomp in dispensing dozens of golden Oscar statuettes.

title: Nov. 7, Through a Medical Lens
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, MRS. JAMES C.
description: OLSON-Mrs. James C. The board of directors of Youth Foundation, Inc. deeply regrets the death of Jean Olson, board member and thoughful friend. She was a dedicated volunteer. The Foundation wishes to extend condolences to her family. A. David Russell, President Mrs. Donald M. Liddell, Vice President Guy N. Robinson, Secretary S. Scott Nicholls, Jr., Treasurer Robert W. Radsch, Assistant Secretary

title: Oct. 29-Nov. 4; Tuning Out Free Music From the Internet
description: Napster, the Internet service that earned the affection of the masses and the wrath of the record industry by enabling users to trade unauthorized copies of music for free, announced plans to go legit. In exchange for a loan from the German media giant Bertelsmann, Napster agreed to develop a fee-based service that would distribute royalties to record companies. Once the new service is in place, Bertelsmann said it would drop its lawsuit against the firm and take an equity stake in it. The news was greeted with on-line howls of dismay by some of Napster's 38 million users, who vowed to continue their Internet trading elsewhere. Others said they would be willing to pay for Napster's services, but only if it provided what they have become accustomed to: unlimited access to virtually all the world's music. Amy Harmon

title: From Social Security to Environment, the Candidates' Positions
description: Voters have many questions about issues,and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have many answers. Here aresummaries of the Bush and Gore positions onpolicy issues that have recieved considerable attention in the presidential campaign, with a comparison to show how the candidates differand agree, and assesments of their position fromexperts and political analysts-some partisan, some not.

title: Cutting Edge Before Her Time
description: ON a recent balmy Wednesday, Jenny Bell Whyte's third-floor brownstone bedroom was filled with a fine bustle, as her late husband, the urbanologist and bustle lover William H. Whyte, might have said. Mrs. Whyte was enfolded in a blue and pink Chinese silk damask jacket; she had cleared a space for herself amid the piles of fabric and museum textile catalogs on a Victorian love seat at the foot of a four-poster bed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPER, JEROME MILTON
description: ALPER-Jerome Milton. On Friday, November 3, 2000 of Chevy Chase, MD. Husband of the late Janet Alper and the late Muriel Alper. Father of Andrew and Alan Alper. Stepfather of Robin Howe and Jeffrey Teitel. Brother of Dr. Charles Harold Alper. Also survived by six grandchildren. Funeral service will be held on Monday, November 6th, 1:30PM, Temple Sinai, 3100 Military Rd., N.W., Washington, D.C. Interment King David Memorial Garden, Falls Church, VA. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMMINGS, THOMAS J.
description: CUMMINGS-Thomas J. On November 3, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Mary Therese. Devoted father of Roberta, Thomas Jr., Mary Austin, Joseph, Therese Graham and Dorothy. Father-in-Law of Diane Cummings and John Graham. Loving grandfather of Thomas, Edward, Jennifer, Chantel, Michael, Samantha and Linda. Great grandfather of 5. Dear brother of Alice Shine. Funeral Monday, 9:30 AM from the Mc Manus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass 10:30 AM. St. Francis of Assisi, RC Church, Interment Calverton National Cemetery. Visiting Saturday and Sunday, 2-5, 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, FERDIE A.
description: FALK-Ferdie A. Passed away November 3, 2000, in Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of New Orleans and Sands Point, LI. Loving husband of Peggy. Adored father of Lori (Marc) Katzman, Chris (Gina) Falk, Mel (Nancy) Jacob and Steven (Ivonne) Jacob. Cherished grandfather of 10. Services Boca Raton, FL. Memorial contributions to the Ursula and Ferdie Falk Endowment Fund at Temple Beth El, 333 Southwest 4th Ave., Boca Raton, FL 33432. For information, contact ''Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel,'' Boca Raton.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, HERMINE K.
description: BERNSTEIN-Hermine K. January 19, 1903-November 5, 1980. Beloved mother and grandmother. Respected artist, musician and teacher. You would have loved your great-grandchildren and they you. You are with us every day.

title: Smashing Drum Display From France
description: THE following concert program is rated PG-13: it contains 17 brawny guys with bare arms, pummeling oil drums in violent rhythms, with pickaxes. Although there is no profanity (unless it's in French) one cannot ignore the yelling, or the smashing oilcans. Earplugs are available to the audience at no charge.

title: Yugoslavia Now Wrestles With Forming A Government
description: More than a month after elections that led to the overthrow of Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav Parliament today confirmed a new federal government dominated by the coalition that backed the new president, Vojislav Kostunica.

title: Moab, Mecca for Mountain Bikers
description: WEIGHT back. Weight back. Weight back.

title: As Alphabet City Grows Richer, The L Train Seems Far, Far Away
description: Plans for a Second Avenue subway line, from South Ferry to 125th Street, have long been a vision, not a reality, and so for people like Elizabeth Avecedo, who lives in Alphabet City, commuting to work can be a lot of trouble.

title: Abigail-Mary Sterling, Harold Olsen
description: Abigail-Mary Ellen Whitney Sterling and Harold August Olsen, associates at New York law firms, were married yesterday at the Unitarian-Universalist Congregation at Shelter Rock in Manhasset, N.Y. The Rev. Heather Lynn Hanson performed the ceremony.

title: Mary Mehagian, Roger Kumble
description: Mary Christine Mehagian, a daughter of Marge and John Mehagian of Phoenix, was married yesterday to Roger Kumble, a son of Barbara Kumble of New York and Steven Kumble of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Carl Carlozzi officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Oct. 29-Nov. 4; Guess What's Almost Health Food
description: At long last, chocolate moves toward its rightful place in the food pyramid, somewhere in the high-tone neighborhood of red wine, fruits and vegetables, and green tea.

title: Bulls, Bears, Donkeys and Elephants
description: After weeks of sloshing higher and lower, the stock market, like the rest of the country, may settle down to watch the finish of the presidential race this week.

title: Devils' Homestand Begins With Listless Loss to Kings
description: In a game of little intensity, passion or coordination, the Devils started a five-game stand at Continental Arena with so many mishaps and giveaways in their zone that they drew jeers in a 2-1 loss to the Los Angeles Kings this afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTEIN, SYDELLE
description: GERSTEIN-Sydelle. Died on November 3, 2000 in her 94th year at her home in Hewlett, NY. She was the widow of Irving C. Gerstein, who died in 1969 and is survived by her son, David M. Gerstein, her daughter, Barbara Shore, her grandchildren, Cynthia Sila, Steven Shore, Lisa Gerstein and Clifford Shore, her great-grandchildren, Michael Sila, Elizabeth Sila and Jonathan Sila, her grandsonin-law, Bora Sila, her daughter-inlaw, Susan Gerstein, her son-inlaw, George Shore, and her brother, Herbert Feinberg. Her special qualities will always be remembered. A funeral service will be held on Sunday, November 5th, at 12:30 PM at Boulevard-Riverside Funeral Home, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557.

title: THEATER; The Job He Found Was Writing a Hit
description: ''The Rocky Horror Show,'' the 1973 musical that served as the template for the 1975 cult film version (''The Rocky Horror Picture Show''), opens Nov. 15 in a new production at Circle in the Square on Broadway. The cast members, under the direction of Christopher Ashley, include Dick Cavett as the Narrator, Tom Hewitt (Frank 'n' Furter), Lea DeLaria (Eddie and Dr. Scott), Joan Jett (Columbia), Daphne Rubin-Vega (Magenta), Raul Esparza (Riff Raff), Alice Ripley (Janet) and Jarrod Emick (Brad).

title: A Quiet Sign of Better Days Ahead
description: THERE were no headlines last week announcing it, so most stock-market bulls are unaware of the good news. But a market timing model with a good long-term record has flashed the all-clear signal to re-enter the market.

title: Drop the Gun
description: The frost is clearly on the pumpkin, and hopes of even one final burst of Indian summer are fading fast. But the people who make the elite toy water gun -- the Super Soaker -- are aiming for next summer. And while they're at it, they're also taking aim at what they claim is an illegal knockoff.

title: Pushing Beyond the Physical Limits for Benefits That Outlast the Pain
description: Toni Baum, a 39-year-old mother of two, runs her first marathon in 10 years today. She has been training even as sciatic pain burns down both legs, upping her dosage of the painkiller Celebrex to keep going. She loves that sense of well-being she feels, the smug righteousness as she hobbles back into the driveway after a long run.

title: Bush Says Integrity Makes Him Right for Job
description: Gov. George W. Bush promoted himself today as the kind of principled, steady leader that he said Americans had been denied for the last eight years, leaning hard on the issue of character as he traced a course through the three most fiercely contested battleground states.

title: Spending
description: I was glad to see your issue. We all spend money -- our common denominator. But it was educational to get a glimpse of other people's habits, intentions, impulses. I have wondered recently, If I were to try to learn how to spend money well, where would I go? I've never seen classes offered on it. Accounting is one thing; financial discipline is another.

title: Shari Roth, Andrew Ross
description: Shari Lynn Roth, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Roth of Scotch Plains, N.J., is to be married this evening to Andrew Marc Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ashley Ross of Chicago. Rabbi George Nudell will officiate at the Crystal Plaza, a catering business in Livingston, N.J.

title: Tradition, Tradition
description: IT is midafternoon, and there is an eerie quiet at Jadwyn Gym. The huge dome that covers the basketball courts and the adjacent indoor track looms like a planetarium ceiling.

title: Style Matters; Turn the Lights Down Low
description: Our inquiring photographer asks, 'What's your secret to a great party?'

title: For Older Authors, a Steeper Hill
description: IN the movie ''Bowfinger,'' a down-on-his-luck filmmaker played by Steve Martin says of Hollywood's obsession with youth, ''They can smell 50.''

title: Oct.29-Nov.4; A Chess Champion Falls
description: Gary Kasparov has been called the greatest chess player of all time, but he may have been too good a teacher. On Thursday, his 15 years as champion ended when he was defeated by Vladimir Kramnik, a 25-year-old fellow Russian who was once Mr. Kasparov's protege. The decisive 15th game of a 16-game match ended in a draw after four hours, giving Mr. Kramnik the half point that he needed to assure himself a winning score for the match.

title: STRIKE-FINE SCHOLARSHIPS
description: A Mercer County judge last week agreed to a proposal in which the unions representing teachers and support staff in Hamilton Township that went on strike in early September will pay a $500,000 sanction for disobeying court orders to return to work during the strike. The money will go into a trust fund that will aid school seniors in Hamilton Township with college tuition. Abhi Raghunathan

title: Air Force Handles Army Once Again
description: Maybe it's time to retire the Commander-in-Chief's Trophy and award it to Air Force outright.

title: Corrections
description: The quarterly mutual fund tables on Oct. 8, in the special Mutual Funds Report, Part 2 of this section, included a fund in error on the list of the laggard municipal bond funds for the third quarter. The fund, J. P. Morgan Institutional Tax Aware Enhanced Income, had a return of 1.19 percent for the quarter, not 0.90 percent. For the 12 months ended Sept. 30, the fund returned 4.48 percent, not 4.17 percent.

title: Why We Split
description: Manny Howard manages a tone of vaguely wounded innocence throughout his tale of cleaning out the bank account he and his wife shared. I think his wife was a saint to give him the benefit of the doubt for as long as she did.

title: A Boomerang Effect
description: Jacques Nasser, chief executive of Ford Motor, has problems that go beyond Firestone tires on the company's sport utility vehicles. His strong Australian accent has emerged as a problem in the company's television advertisements. A Ford official who insisted on anonymity said that many people had called the company to express surprise that an American corporate icon like Ford had a foreign-born chief executive. Some complained that the accent was incomprehensible, others that he sounded like Crocodile Dundee.

title: The Going Rate
description: Thomas Lynch's Endpaper (Oct. 15), about a young widow's choice of a coffin, was a fitting conclusion to your issue. Her decision to purchase a more expensive cherry coffin reflects the anxiety the funeral industry has implanted in the consumer, who must make an emotional decision at a vulnerable time.

title: Korea Troops to Be Tested for Exposure to Herbicide
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  The government is offering to examine American troops who served in Korea three decades ago for possible exposure to the defoliant Agent Orange.

title: The View From/Waterbury on Nov. 6, 1960; The Day the Candidate Stormed Naugatuck Valley
description: PRESIDENTIAL candidates still come to Connecticut, but these days, it seems they come more for money than for votes. For money, the destination of choice is Greenwich or maybe Stamford, not the rusty old cities and towns of the Naugatuck Valley.

title: HOLIDAY FILMS; Trust Me, It's Not Easy Being Cruella De Vil
description: THE biggest, most challenging set built for ''102 Dalmatians'' was that of a three-story derelict bakery, supposedly on the outskirts of Paris. A seemingly precarious ramp led up from the roof of the evil LePelt's wretched sweatshop to a huge industrial fan through which one had to jump in order to get into the bakery. If you managed to dodge the fan's blades and climb through, you stepped onto a steel mesh platform, connected to a series of catwalks. The bakery housed a gargantuan collection of working machinery: pulleys, arms, conveyor belts, a monstrous mixing bowl with an equally monstrous dough hook, rollers, choppers and cake molds -- all leading down to the ancient, rusting, black-encrusted oven below.

title: A Necessary Task: Cleaning the Floors
description: FLOOR cleaning is a necessary part of home maintenance, and it requires vacuuming and dusting all floors regularly. The dust and dirt that accumulate on a floor act as an abrasive that can grind the gloss from the surface, leaving the floor looking dull and drab.

title: Studios Move Slowly With DVD Boxed Sets
description: TO all the things DVD does better than the videocassette, add the boxed set. In looks alone there is no contest. Nothing against Woody Allen, but eight cassettes of his movies in a slipcase is a carton fit for the garage. Sleek little things, DVD's won't sully a bookcase. All of the room on discs for extra features (Allen's DVD's don't have any, but more on that later) doesn't add an inch across the shelf.

title: Venezuela's Leader Is Seeking Decree Powers to Speed Changes
description: Hugo Chavez has a six-year presidential term, a new Constitution drawn up to his specifications and a sweeping majority in the National Assembly. But he says that is not enough to assure the success of the ''peaceful social revolution'' he promises here. He has now asked for, and seems likely to receive, additional authority to govern by decree.

title: N.B.A. to Meet With Sprewell
description: National Basketball Association officials have summoned forward Latrell Sprewell of the Knicks to a meeting tomorrow in Manhattan to discuss possible tampering charges stemming from his recent comments regarding Chris Webber, Sacramento's All-Star forward.

title: Bronx Is in the Name. Drums Are Their Game. P.S. They're French
description: THE following concert program is rated PG-13: it contains 17 brawny guys with bare arms, pummeling oil drums in violent rhythms, with pickaxes. Although there is no profanity (unless it's in French) one cannot ignore the yelling, or the smashing oilcans. Onsite earplugs are available to the audience at no charge.

title: The World; The Strange World of North Korea
description: REPORTERS accompanying Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright on her recent trip to North Korea had no chance to see the rusted steelworks, the flooded mines or factories at a standstill. Nor were they able to see the small livestock markets that have sprung up in some parts of the country, testimony, apparently of farmers' abandoning their collectives and taking matters into their own hands as a matter of sheer survival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RONSON, ADELE
description: RONSON-Adele. See Adele Reichman.

title: The Two-Bucks-a-Minute Democracy
description: Earlier this year, a truly weird and possibly inspired company founded by a pair of Stanford political scientists, Norman Nie and Doug Rivers, finished spending tens of millions of dollars to install Web television sets in 40,000 American homes. The company, called Knowledge Networks, was trying to address the single greatest problem in polling -- getting a random sample of Americans to answer questions -- by paying a random sample of Americans for their time. In the summer of 1999, Rivers sent out 40,000 letters, most of them containing $10 bills. The money was the teaser for the big offer: spend 10 minutes each week answering his questions over the Internet, and Rivers would give you a free Web TV, free Internet access and a raft of prizes doled out in various contests and raffles. If you were uneasy with new gadgets, Rivers promised to give you not only the TV and the Internet access but also to send an engineer to install the stuff. An astonishing 56 percent of the people they set out to contact took the offer -- compared with the roughly 15 percent now willing to answer questions from a stranger over the telephone.

title: F.Y.I.
description: A Tough Parking Lot

title: A Look Ahead to Long-Term Care
description: There is no time like the present -- unless, of course, the topic is unpleasant -- like planning for one's own long-term care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERRIS, ELAINE
description: TERRIS-Elaine. On November 3, 2000 after a short illness. Formerly of New York City, late of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Beloved mother of Marianne Berson and Michaele Keyes. Cherished grandmother of Deborah Berson, Brad Berson, Rachel Keyes, Gabriel Keyes and Caren Teitelbaum.

title: How 'The Grinch' Borrowed Ideas From All Over
description: OFF-KILTER minarets, loopy pediments and far-flung staircases crowd the skyline. A rooftop turns into a Chinese dragon in profile; whole buildings pile up like soft-serve ice cream; and endless strings of Christmas lights and ornaments, evergreen garlands and red bows are iced with loads of snow.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: ONE FOR THE ROAD: Interstate 95 is the great escape road for retirees fleeing Northeast winters. And seven Rodeway Inns and Econo Lodges convenient to I-95 are offering discounts to migrating seniors. Guests 60 or older who book at least 24 hours ahead get discounts of 20 to 30 percent (subject to availability); it's 10 percent for those 50 or older without reservations. The hotels are the Rodeway Inn on O'Donnell Street in Baltimore (ask for property code MD119), with rates starting at $53.10; the Econo Lodge in College Park, Md. (MD092), starting at $63; the Econo Lodge in Doswell, Va. (VA274), from $35.96; the Econo Lodge in Savannah, Ga. (GA218), $37.80 and up; the Rodeway Inn in Florence, S.C. (SC010), $35.96; the Econo Lodge Space Center in Cocoa, Fla. (FL354), from $45; and the Rodeway Inn in St. Augustine, Fla. (FL489), from $89.10. Call (800) 228-2000 for Rodeway Inns and (800) 553-2666 for Econo Lodges. Do not contact the hotels directly.

title: Few Lobsters, and Now, Fewer Lobstermen
description: BOB SPONG, 60, has been a lobsterman on Long Island Sound all his life. But last March, when he thought the lobster population might never recover, he decided to get what he calls ''the first real job'' he has ever held. So now he drives a forklift at the Home Depot store in Commack, N.Y. on the lobster shift -- what else? -- from 10 p.m. to 6:30 a.m.

title: Yael Wyner, Philippe Visser
description: Yael Miriam Wyner and Philippe Barry Visser are to be married today by Rabbi Jehiel Orenstein at the Grand Summit Hotel in Summit, N.J. Dr. Abraham Wyner, a cantor and the bride's brother, will take part in the ceremony, as will Dr. Lisa Malik, a rabbinical student who is the bride's sister-in-law.

title: Waking Up to Some Favorite Bedtime Stories
description: It's hard to overlook Maurice Sendak's ''Seven Little Monsters,'' a family of 10-foot-tall children dealing with life's little problems. On the other hand, the hero of William Joyce's ''George Shrinks,'' standing proud at only three inches, never sweats the big stuff.

title: Men, Women and Coyotes
description: PRODIGAL SUMMER

title: A Complex Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Left Bank Hotel
description: To the Editor: The group of eight with whom we traveled in July had a different experience at the Hotel Pont Royal than Robert K. Brown did (Letters on Travel, Oct. 8). We were greeted warmly by the staff, which promptly and effectively cut through the airline bureaucracy to find our misplaced luggage. They were also helpful in making, and sometimes changing, dinner reservations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARINO, ROMEO V.
description: MARINO-Romeo V. Died November 3, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Philomena, loving father of Robert and Ronald, grandfather of Matthew and father-in-law of Lorraine Pastore and Christine Morrison. Relatives and friends may visit at the Balsamo Funeral Home, 3188 Westchester Ave., Bronx, NY, Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of the Assumption Church, 1634 Mahan Ave., Bronx, NY, Tuesday at 9:30 AM.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-05-00; What They Were Thinking
description: Helen Kaufman, Rose Groman, Sophie Meyer, Boonton, N.J., Sept. 2, 2000

title: Forgettable
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POST, SEYMOUR C., M.D.
description: POST-Seymour C., M.D. The Trustees, Officers and Members of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis would like to express their sorrow for the loss of Dr. Seymour Post, an esteemed member admired for his contribution to psychoanalysis, and to express their condolences to his wife Judy and his family. Sheila H. Gray, M.D., President Joan G. Tolchin, M.D., Secretary

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 22 about Al Jolson misstated the title of a biographical film about him. It was ''The Jolson Story,'' not ''The Al Jolson Story.''

title: Wonder Woman Would Love These
description: It's a long way from peddling your jewelry on the sidewalk in front of Cooper Union in the East Village to a display case in Saks Fifth Avenue, but that is the route Alexis Bittar has followed.

title: DOZEN STATES SEEM TOO CLOSE TO CALL IN THE FINAL DAYS
description: As the 2000 presidential campaign entered its final, frantic 72 hours, with climactic volleys of charge and countercharge delivered in speeches, television commercials and telephone calls, both major-party candidates retained realistic prospects of victory.

title: Macho Uno Has Orseno Dreaming of Next May
description: It took a photo finish and a long nose in front, but it was Macho Uno who held off the determined Point Given in the stretch of the $1,070,000 Breeders' Cup Juvenile today. That had Macho Uno's trainer, Joe Orseno, already thinking about travel plans next spring to the Kentucky Derby.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't understand what people are trying to do by making fun of fat people. It's not going to make them thin; if anything, it's going to make it worse.''

title: Where Is Russia's New Music? Iowa, That's Where
description: RUSSIANS of a certain age are apt to regard the state of Iowa with slightly mordant nostalgia. Nikita S. Khrushchev passed through during his 1959 official visit to America. He took home some Iowa corn, ordered his collective farmers to grow it, produced a historic crop failure and . . . well, you know the rest.

title: An Acre of Outdoor Rooms, Under Glass
description: ANYONE can create beauty, but the wealthy can create beauty on a grand scale. This is as true with gardens as with any other form of art, and if you have ever been to Longwood Gardens in Kennett Square, Pa., you know how well plants can grow when they are mulched and fertilized with cold hard cash. Inspired by the Longwood example, the late tobacco heiress Doris Duke (1913-1993) built a lavish display garden on her estate near Somerville, N.J.

title: A Work on the Edge of Anxiety
description: LET'S stipulate that when the Venetian composer Luigi Nono wrote ''Prometeo,'' the culminating opus of his life, his first concern was not the comfort of the audience. At 2 hours 20 minutes, with no breaks between movements, with vast stretches of music in slow motion devoid of momentum, with the dynamic level often hovering around the threshold of audibility and with many of the ordinary hierarchies of musical values rearranged or simply jettisoned, the work, to a libretto by the philosopher Massimo Cacciari, does not give a listener a lot of familiar ground to cling to.

title: Lazio Rallies His Loyalists To Send Them To the Polls
description: They have made up their minds. They believe from the deepest depths of their hearts that Hillary Rodham Clinton simply must not be senator, ''not here, not now, not ever,'' as the bumper sticker goes.

title: Table Talk; Great Seats
description: The logic of asking prominent interior designers to share their visions of a dream dinner is self-evident. As Jeffrey Bilhuber explains: ''What we do as decorators is establish a dialogue between chairs, tables, lamps, curtains. That's the reason you want to put a Wormley table next to a Louis XVI chair: because the curved lines of one speak to the other's straightness.'' Bilhuber adds: ''It's not about the mix, it's about the match. And the match is being able to put people together like furniture, so they oppose and complement each other.''

title: All Above Board At Great Neck Library
description: The various plans presented to the Great Neck Library ad hoc committee call for only a major expansion of the main facility even though several members of the committee have formally requested that the library director have the architect provide drawings for a renovation plan of the currently existing building, as an alternative to the expansion plan. I feel strongly that there is no need for additional space. The new space would add almost $2 million to the cost of a total renovation of the existing space. As a resident on this committee, which is comprised largely of the library staff and board members, I take my responsibility to my fellow residents very seriously.

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted in The Times Magazine on Oct. 22 for a portrait of Helen Dixon, daughter-in-law of the photographer Dorothea Lange. It should have read, ''Copyright Dorothea Lange Collection, Oakland Museum of California, City of Oakland. Gift of Paul S. Taylor.''

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/New Haven; Capitalizing on an Urbane Atmosphere
description: JOSIAH B. VENTER does not remember exactly what year it was, but he will never forget the moment. Strolling past Sprague Memorial Hall at Yale University one day, Mr. Venter heard a whirl of jazz notes drifting from the auditorium. He poked his head into the doorway only to discover Duke Ellington himself leading a music seminar for some Yale grad students. Mr. Venter stole upstairs to the balcony, took a seat and treated himself to an unexpected afternoon with a jazz giant.

title: THEATER; The Joy of the Stage, Even if Only for a Night
description: MEMORIES of my first job as an actor on a soap opera in 1980: David O'Brien, who played my father, looking into the camera during rehearsal and saying, ''Who do you have to sleep with to get off this show?'' Then he would head out to East Hampton to do ''Light Up the Sky'' at the John Drew Theater.

title: Underwater Walk
description: To the Editor: About ''Walking Under Water, With a Helmet'' (Oct. 22), my family also went helmet diving in Bermuda with Greg Hartley. Mr. Hartley puts out a brochure stressing that your hair stays dry. My husband somehow thought his entire body would.

title: Gore Is Trying to Catch Up In Democrat-Dominated State
description: In politics, West Virginia is synonymous with Democrats.

title: A Colorful Van Is the Bait To Reach Street Youth
description: IT'S 4:30 on a Saturday afternoon, and while others were preparing for a night on the town, Luz Bovell, munching on Cheez Doodles and coordinating a network of outreach workers over her cell phone, was preparing for work.

title: Dream Team Reunites in Glen Head
description: A DREAM team has been reunited at Elmers in Glen Head. Leon Knesel, the savvy restaurateur who changed Barney's in Locust Valley from a corner pub to one of the classiest dining spots on the North Shore in 1984, is back and working his magic at the newly opened Elmers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERBER, ZELDA
description: FERBER-Zelda. A loving mother to all whom she touched, died on Wednesday at the age of 77, leaving a rich legacy of love and family connection. As a teacher and counselor, Zelda was a trailblazer, a woman with exceptional social skills and a burning desire to make families work-both hers and those around her. Zelda shared her love with Arnold, her husband of nearly 57 years, her children Ilene & Bruce, and Roe & Steve, her grandchildren Dorothy, Olivia, Natalie, Melyssa, Marnie & Jill, her brother Allan, her sister-in-law Yvonne, her niece Cheri and her nephew Stuart. Zelda was born on February 25, 1923 in New York City, the only daughter of Sarah & Isaac Korman, attended Hunter College and embarked on a lifetime of contribution-raising both a vibrant family and the next generation. Her magnetic personality drew people to her in a special way. Her laughter and her spirit will be with us always. Services will be held Sunday, November 5, at 12:45pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 W. 76 St. (Amsterdam).

title: Grain Processing Company Plans Public Offering
description: Bunge International, a grain processing company that sells cooking oil to Kentucky Fried Chicken and supplies flavorings to Starbucks for coffee and to Kellogg for corn flakes, plans an initial public offering by 2002.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 23 about the venture capitalist Walter Anderson and his attempts to lease the Mir space station for private use misstated his personal wealth. It is about $4 million, according to Anderson, not almost $1 billion, a figure that confused Anderson's personal wealth and the value of Gold & Appel, a fund he manages. Anderson says the fund is actually worth about $400 million. The article also misattributed the ownership of a jet Anderson uses. It is partly owned by Gold & Appel, and not by him. The article referred erroneously to an aspect of his passion for privacy: his company Entree International is indeed named on the marquee of a Washington office building. The article misstated the date of the Russian launching of living quarters for the International Space Station. It was July 12, not July 11. Anderson approached The Times about the errors late in August. This correction was delayed by the need for new reporting and interviews with Anderson.

title: Hiking to the Kitchens Of Chianti
description: MY watch said 3, and my daughters and I were supposed to be at cooking school no later than 3:30. We had set out on foot from Castellina in Chianti more than an hour earlier, and according to our directions, the school, in the home of Mimma Ferrando, was only two miles from town by the main road. But to avoid traffic, my husband had suggested a shortcut, and here we were in the woods, winding around a fenced garbage dump that was nowhere on our map.

title: A Place of Death, a Place of Play
description: MORE than 50 years since the Allies clawed their way ashore on D-Day, the beaches of Normandy still loom large in the American imagination. They hold particular fascination for my 9-year-old son, whose prized possessions include a poster of ''Saving Private Ryan'' (a movie he is most definitely not yet allowed to see). His 6-year-old brother has also caught the bug, and together they often spread their toy soldiers around the family room, recreating the landings at ''Utah'' or ''Omaha.''

title: High-Technology Revival for Historic City
description: The opening of a semiconductor memory plant and the sudden proliferation of Internet facilities have contributed to a spectacular change in fortune for the Old Town district in this small city 30 miles southwest of Washington, D.C., best known for its key role in two Civil War battles fought nearby.

title: Bookend; Travels With R.L.S.
description: ONE evening in the spring of 1880, Robert Louis Stevenson dropped into the bar of the Magnolia Hotel in Calistoga, at the head of the Napa Valley. There was little more to the town than the springs, the railway station and the enticement of a fortune to be made from mining gold or silver. The West was still pretty wild. Inside, someone asked Stevenson if he would like to speak to Mr. Foss, a stagecoach driver; Stevenson, always alert to the suggestion of travel, said yes: ''Next moment, I had one instrument at my ear, another at my mouth, and found myself, with nothing in the world to say, conversing with a man several miles off among desolate hills.''

title: For The Sake Of Argument
description: On a steamy Wednesday in August, Pat Moynihan rode with his family up Pennsylvania Avenue, a street he helped to resurrect, to the White House, a building where he once worked, to receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom, an award that 37 years ago he assisted in creating. Hillary Clinton, the Democrat who hopes to inherit his seat in the Senate, began the ceremony in the East Room. Bill Clinton, whose departure from office will conclude eight years of strife with Moynihan, presented the award. On most of the 15 recipients, the president bestowed kisses and bear-hugs. But as Moynihan bowed his head to receive his medal, Clinton simply clasped his hand and whispered something in his ear.

title: SOAPBOX; A Frightening Brush With Rabies
description: RABIES warnings have been frequent enough throughout Westchester so that a dead skunk in my horse's stall raised instant fear. Skunks don't usually wander into barns or other dwellings unless they're sick. And rabies has been on the increase among skunks and raccoons in our charming, historic, still-rural town of Pound Ridge.

title: Republican Senator Treads Softly in Run Against Well-Tended Grave of a Governor
description: Senator John Ashcroft is campaigning doggedly these days, crisscrossing Missouri by bus as he rails against big government and autographs blue and gold ''Missouri Values'' posters in five towns each day.

title: No More Stage Fright As Cheney Finds Footing With Crowds
description: The big, boisterous crowd laughed at Dick Cheney's jokes and shouted his lines back at him. Mr. Cheney even pounded the lectern once or twice. Behind him, on the banks of the Illinois River, more supporters watched from a paddle-wheel riverboat. As the rally ended last week, he made for the rope lines as the theme music from ''Rocky'' blared and a shower of fireworks exploded overhead.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-25

title: Elizabeth Martin, Marshall Curry
description: Elizabeth Werness Martin, the daughter of Joan Werness Martin and Joseph B. Martin of Charlotte, N.C., was married there yesterday to Marshall Anderson Curry, a son of Elizabeth Rivers Curry and Ravenel B. Curry III of New York. The Rev. John Rogers officiated at Covenant Presbyterian Church.

title: Melbourne
description: Compared with Sydney's Los Angeles-style brashness, Melbourne has the gentility and correctness of an Old World metropolis. Settled originally by hard-working Scottish Protestants, English and Irish in the 1830's, Melbourne does not share Sydney's convict past. The city's grand late 19th-century buildings, boulevards lined with plane trees, and mature parks speak of its gilding with gold-rush money at the height of the Victorian era.

title: Raising Lady Lazarus
description: THE UNABRIDGED JOURNALS OF SYLVIA PLATH, 1950-1962

title: Outnumbered 11 to 1, The Dollar Ends Up on Top; Paris: Whether Ritz is a hotel or a cracker, there are bargains
description: There is no question that Paris is cheaper these days. For Americans who have always wanted a night of luxury at one of the city's best hotels -- say, the Ritz or the Crillon -- there may never be a better time.

title: Teaching Children The Value of Work
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/Connecticut; In Windsor and Bloomfield, an Office Park Grows
description: IN the mid-1980's, when bulldozers first moved onto land in Windsor that was to become part of the Griffin Center office park, the park's 600 acres were largely tobacco fields, stands of hardwood and a few dirt roads. Today, Griffin Center is nearing 2 million square feet of office space, including one of its most ambitious projects ever, a 165,000-square-foot building for a high-technology tenant, JDS Uniphase.

title: Aristide in Waiting
description: Jean-bertrand aristide is giving a tour. he's talking animatedly about the weather and old friends and landscaping as he makes his way quickly around to the front of his imposing white house in the Tabarre suburb of Port-au-Prince. We've just left the air-conditioning of his office, and it's hot outside, as usual. We're walking through the broad gardens, where palms and banana trees grow and where guards lounge on the periphery. And then we come to the pool. It's a particularly nice pool, with brick trim.

title: Ecce Bandwidth
description: Telecosm

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CADY, NANCY FARR
description: CADY-Nancy Farr. Native New Yorker, resident of Orlando, FL. Passed on October 8, 2000. She will be sorely missed by her children, Gordon Marsh, Lise Pilande, Adrienne Naessil, Marion Skinner; her siblings, F. Shelton Farr, Thomas A. Farr, Diana Farr Louis and Priscilla Farr McCord and other family members who were close to her. Her sense of beauty, her delight in the comic side of life and her unconditional love for her family will remain forever in our hearts.

title: Town Clerk Takes Stand On Land Deal
description: IN 23 years working in Carmel Town Hall, Connie Munday has seen her share of contentious local issues.

title: Vick or No, Hurricanes Manhandle The Hokies
description: Miami safety Al Blades wears the same uniform number as Michael Vick, but he could not believe the audacity of Virginia Tech's star quarterback. Blades said that Vick, despite being limited by a sprained right ankle, told him before the game, ''I'm the real No. 7.''

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about legends surrounding a statue of a woman in the Sleepy Hollow Cemetery misattributed an anecdote about a little girl's visit to the cemetery on a Halloween dare in 1916. It was a fictional ''ghost story,'' not one involving Emily Storms Arminio's grandmother or told by her.

title: A Born-Again Auditorium With a Chapel's Grace
description: Two officials of Bronx Community College stood in the campus auditorium remarking on the light last week. They had come inside to see results of a major renovation that is bringing the room, built as a chapel 100 years ago by Stanford White, back to its original self.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Third Woman

title: West Coast; Let's Twist Again
description: Open almost any magazine, any month, any week, any day, and you see that ''the socialite'' is back. With this young-socialite thing in the air, we decided to meet with a classic, the queen bee of West Coast socialites, Betsy Bloomingdale. She's been a hostess to royalty (the European and Hollywood kinds), to artists and to world leaders. Betsy Bloomingdale is an ber hostess, thoroughly organized and very together. She has kept diaries of every dinner party she's given since 1959 and photographs of every table setting she has designed so that she doesn't do the same thing twice. She creates the most divine flower arrangements from her own garden. Never roses, only dahlias and zinnias. Something of an endangered species, she's from the world of ''Jean Howard's Hollywood,'' where socialites looked like movie stars and lived a very glamorous life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, DONALD C.
description: ROTHMAN-Donald C. of Forest Hills, New York. Passed away Friday, November 3, 2000. Devoted husband of Hazel; loving father of Richard; cherished grandfather of Alex and Jonathan. Services: Sunday, November 5th, 1pm at Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, New York.

title: Mutual Funds Add Loads as a Sales Tool
description: SCUDDER mutual funds lost about 5 percent of their $45 billion this year as investors pulled out their money.

title: Bossa Nova For a New Generation
description: THE biggest-selling album by a Brazilian artist in North America right now -- and possibly since recordings by Sergio Mendes in the 1960's, though it's difficult to know for sure -- isn't by one of the usual suspects, a Caetano Veloso or a Gilberto Gil. It is Bebel Gilberto's ''Tanto Tempo.'' Released in the United States last spring by Six Degrees Records, ''Tanto Tempo'' is one of those slow-but-steady successes that executives at other labels of worldly, adult-oriented music -- even Nonesuch, the king of the genre -- are trying to figure out.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Eminent Hollywoodians
description: Don Bachardy encountered many Hollywood legends in the company of his longtime companion, the writer Christopher Isherwood. Instead of acting starstruck and polite, Bachardy asked many of them to sit for a portrait. And sit they did -- Bachardy wangled a remarkable number of eminent and often reluctant people, among them Henry Fonda, Alec Guinness, Ingrid Bergman and Ginger Rogers. Fifty-five images from the 1970's and early 80's appear in STARS IN MY EYES (University of Wisconsin, $34.95). Bachardy captured likenesses quite quickly, doing all his drawings in front of the models and never reworking them later. However, the sharpest feature of the book is the writing. Bachardy's journal entries about each session accompany the drawings, and they are full of oddly acute observations. Laurence Olivier looked like a ''frostbitten yam,'' and Mia Farrow's ''vagueness is only an affectation.'' Despite his childhood reverence toward movie stars, Bachardy manages to see them quite unsentimentally. He notices things other artists would not, like the way Ginger Rogers's cluttered house reflected her state of mind. Even though a certain level of deference was required to get him in the door, Bachardy wrote that ''the confrontation between my sitter and me is the subject of my pictures.'' Nowhere is this more evident than in an eight-hour encounter with Bette Davis. Bachardy records that she veered from hospitality to brittle resistance to self-pity, and his recollection is richer than most celebrity profiles you'll read this year. Ted Loos

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALLET, FRANCES
description: KALLET-Frances. On November 3, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Loving mother of Stephen and Harriet, Richard and Joan. Adoring grandmother of Jill and Andrew, Beth and Lesley. Greatgrandmother of Emma. Service Monday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Traveling to Cuba Is as Tricky as Ever
description: AMERICANS who hoped that visiting Cuba as tourists might become less complicated saw those hopes evaporate last weekend when President Clinton signed a bill that, among other things, codifies the existing restrictions on United States tourists. The bill also prevents the president or his successors from changing the prohibitions without the approval of Congress.

title: Then & Now; Who Killed Entertaining?
description: Beware of nostalgia. Understand that you are officially old the first time you hear yourself say, ''Things were so much better in the old days.'' People who spend too much time in resorts like Palm Beach, where almost any amount of time is too much time, are always saying, with a pained sigh, ''Things used to be so much more glamorous back then.'' Fashion also has been invaded by the nostalgia beast. Someone, please, punch the monster in the nose. Reviving the 1980's before the silhouette was even cold was ghoulish, regardless of how much the cut was tweaked by the newest designer talents.

title: Outnumbered 11 to 1, The Dollar Ends Up on Top; Brussels: At restaurants, the deals (and waiters) go begging
description: It was nearly 10 o'clock on a recent Tuesday night, but the light from dozens of small sidewalk restaurants kept the Rue de Boucher bathed in an incandescent glow. Next to the Grand-Place in the heart of Brussels' old city, the street's headwaiters were competing fiercely to snare passers-by with offerings of mussels, snails, smoked salmon, Flemish beef stew and rack of lamb. Anyone who looked at all undecided was immediately beseeched to peruse the daily specials and select a table either inside or curbside, where heated canopies shield patrons from the autumn chill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIS, DONALD J., MD
description: REIS-Donald J., MD of New York City and Stonington, CT, beloved husband of Cornelia Langer Noland and stepfather of Lyn, Cady and William Noland, died at age 69 on November 1, 2000. He was the George C. Cotzias Distinguished Professor of Neurology and Neuroscience at Cornell Medical Center and a renowned international neuroscience pioneer. Doctor Reis trained more than one hundred scientists around the world and received numerous awards for his work throughout a long and illustrious career. A memorial service is scheduled at the Century Association, 7 West 43rd Street on Friday, November 17th at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Department of Neurology and Neuroscience, WeillCornell Medical Center, 1300 York Avenue (Room F613), NY, NY 10021 or to the Citizens Commit tee for New York City, 305 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 8 of the Travel section today about the strength of the dollar against the euro misstates the street name for the moderately priced Brussels restaurant La Moule Provencale. It is the Rue des Bouchers, not Rue de Boucher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOLA, RALPH JEAN
description: ZOLA-Ralph Jean. Of Englewood Cliffs, NJ. Beloved husband of Penni (nee Silver), cherished son of Helen and the late Irving Zola, devoted father of Gregory Zola and Stephanie Bailyn, dear brother of Paul Zola and Marion Urcis. A sweet singer of Israel, whose melody has been stilled. Serviceswere held at ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St., Englewood.

title: Italian Cuisine With Earthy Flavors
description: THE tables are too close, the din too loud and at times the service is reminiscent of a comic opera at the new Piccolo Mondo Ristorante Italiano in Inwood. Yet, everybody seems quite happy to be there, no doubt because everything tastes so good and costs so little. Outstanding value and robust jump-off-the-plate flavors have overcome all annoyances for the obviously satisfied customers who t have been crowding into this new hot spot at 233 Doughty Boulevard (516-371-0200). Many of them have, over the years, eaten at Piccolo Mondo in Manhattan, where it has held forth for nearly three decades.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday listing facts and figures about the New York Life Building, completed in 1928, misstated the historical importance of its elevators. They were not the first in an office tower; the Equitable Building had elevators when it opened in 1870 at 120 Broadway.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Stepping Into Honolulu's Past Hawaii is more famous for its natural environment than for its man-made one, but it's nevertheless home to some remarkable architecture. Honolulu features the only royal palace in the United States, the country's first Chinatown, and a church made of coral, according to David Cheever, the executive director of the American Institute of Architects in Honolulu.

title: Alison Vicidomini, Craig Stevens
description: Alison Ann Vicidomini, the daughter of JoAnne and Vincent Vicidomini of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married yesterday to Craig Stevens, a son of Sally and Thomas Stevens of Syracuse. Msgr. John Kauta performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Remember the Olden Days Of Candidates, and Crowds
description: The Somerset County Republican Committee was supposed to turn out a crowd the other day for the kickoff of Representative Bob Franks's down-the-stretch bus tour.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT

title: Ideas & Trends: Kaleidoscope; Trying Hard to Bring The Future Into Focus
description: BY Tuesday night, America will know if it's President George W. Bush or President Al Gore. But just which President Gore or President Bush will it be?

title: Two Groups Drop Plans For a Merger
description: WESTCHESTER County's two major business advocacy groups have broken off talks on consolidation that began five months ago, offering conflicting reasons for the decision.

title: Homes Whose Days, but Not Doors, Were Numbered
description: MIZAN, a 58-year-old former long-distance truck driver, lived from 1991 to 1994 in a series of small shacks on the East River between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges.

title: Secular Passions in the Cloistered Life
description: AMBITION, envy, unholy alli ances and betrayal those words could describe the hit television show ''Survivor.'' But in Montclair, where Luna Stage is producing the new play ''Rapture,'' they have everything to do with life on a different sort of island -- a cloistered convent in Bologna, Italy.

title: Wiping Leaflets, and Perhaps Free Speech, From Windshields
description: In an effort to clamp down on litter, the City Council is weighing a bill to ban leaflets advertising everything from auto painting to firewood that are slipped onto car windshields throughout New York. But critics say the measure would violate the constitutional right to free speech.

title: Offbeat Art In Northern England
description: Kielder Forest Park, on the English border near Scotland, is the site of a new installation by the American artist James Turrell, who specializes in the use of light. ''Cat Cairn Kielder Skyspace,'' situated at a rocky outcrop commanding spectacular views, two miles from Kielder village, is Mr. Turrell's most recent in a series of large installations around the world. Others are in Israel, France, Ireland and the Netherlands, as well as in Arizona, where, in the spirit of Stonehenge, he is transforming a crater two miles wide into an astronomical sculpture.

title: Making the Bands: Hard Days and Nights
description: ON the assembly line that is Lou Pearlman's factory of platinum-selling boy bands, Phillip and Eileen Rosado are a significant stop. Vocal coaching, media training, wardrobe, choreography -- all have their importance. But the Rosados are indispensable. They do hair.

title: Great Neck Student Survey: Skewed or True?
description: The article regarding Great Neck's high schools was refreshing. Too often school districts are reluctant to share the information they have gathered using student surveys. If you want to know what's happening with teens, ask the teens.

title: America's Role Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELMAN, MILTON
description: GELMAN-Milton. Age 90, of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died Thursday after a brief illness. He leaves his loving family, his wife Sylvia (Garfield) of West Palm Beach, two daughters, Arlene Brod and her companion Barry Kay of Great Neck, NY, and Nancy Blecher Davis and her husband Franklin Davis of Brookline, MA, three grandchildren, Mark Blecher and wife Robin Skirboll of San Francisco, Mari Blecher and husband Rick Tetzeli of Brooklyn and Craig Blecher and wife Angela of Richmond, VA, and three great-grandchildren, Robert and Kerry Blecher and Jonah Tetzeli. Milton Gelman practiced law in New York for 40 years and was a significant leader in the Jewish community of Brooklyn. A former President of Progressive Synagogue, Mr. Gelman received numerous honors and awards and was recognized by the State of Israel for his work on behalf of Israel Bonds. He was looked to for advice by several generations of friends and relatives who were fortunate enough to know this truly giving man. A graveside service will take place 1 PM, Sunday, November 5 at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, NY. Donations may be sent to the Alzheimers Association or charity of choice. For information, contact ''Gutterman's,'' Brooklyn, NY.

title: Rights in Guatemala: At Risk Still
description: Celso Balan travels to remote villages armed with nothing more than legal papers and reams of testimony to help people unearth the remains of relatives and friends who were among the 200,000 killed during this country's 36-year war.

title: Not a Candidate, but Still a Campaign Star
description: Senator John McCain was not supposed to be spending the final days before Tuesday's election this way, puddle-jumping across the country for little-known Republican Congressional candidates whose names he sometimes botches.

title: A Biographer of Presidents Tackles an Emperor
description: THE documentary filmmaker David Grubin, who has won eight Emmy awards, usually sticks to American subjects, like the four presidents he has profiled for PBS.

title: In Opera House or Casino, The Song Is the Same
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI has known since the age of 4 that he wanted to make music his life and he has spent the nearly 40 years of his career bringing the joy of that music to others, whether critics in the world of opera approved or not.

title: The German Question
description: TOO FAR AFIELD

title: Moss's Emotions Draw Scrutiny
description: One play last week in the second quarter against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers typified the brilliance of Minnesota Vikings wide receiver Randy Moss. Quarterback Daunte Culpepper threw a tight spiral toward the rear of the left end zone, and Moss leaped, his right hand sticking straight up, his fingers outstretched.

title: Oct. 29-Nov. 4; More Teaching Assistants Can Unionize
description: Union organizers are turning their eyes toward private colleges and universities like Columbia University, following a National Labor Relations Board ruling last week that graduate students who work as research and teaching assistants at private colleges and universities have the right to form unions. Graduate assistants at public universities, who are covered by state labor laws, began to unionize in the late 1960's. Karen W. Arenson

title: Corrections
description: A sports article last Sunday about high school football on Long Island misspelled the name of the school that played Garden City. It is Wantagh, not Wantaugh.

title: I'm Dreaming of a Noir Christmas. You, Too?
description: FOR those of us who grew up in the 40's and 50's, in what we might call B.T.E. -- that is, not entirely Before Television, but Before the Television Era -- movies were the only game in town. And their authority as dispenser of a certain kind of information was absolute. Radio might still cast its spells, but it was the movies, with their larger-than-life blend of reality and fantasy, that provided the instructive images of grown-up life not generally available in our provincial, parentally repressed corner of the planet.

title: Thaler Pekar and Thomas Bergin
description: WHEN Thaler Pekar moved to Hoboken, N.J., 13 years ago, her father, Walter Pekar, took one look at her tiny apartment above a produce store and declared her love life doomed.

title: The Pleasures of Living in a Village
description: I must have missed the high school civics class when we learned the difference between cities, towns and villages, and the dictionary does not shed much light, except to rank them in size order without saying how big is big and how small is small.

title: A Painter's Latest Cinematic Collage
description: REINALDO ARENAS, the gay Cuban writer who was educated, persecuted, imprisoned and exiled by Castro's Communist regime, spent the last nine years of his life in New York City. Before he died in 1990 at the age of 47, he had written ''some of the most beautiful poems by a Latin American author in the 20th century,'' according to the novelist and poet Jaime Manrique. ''And it was here,'' Mr. Manrique continues, ''that he dictated, in a rage, an autobiography that is one of the most liberating works ever written -- and a document that serves as an indictment of what Latin American Stalinist forces, and Fidel Castro, did, not just to homosexuals but to all those who dared to be different.''

title: Ideas & Trends; Pow! Slam! Thank You, Ma'am.
description: LADIES, get out your boxing gloves and bustiers. If popular culture is any guide at all, some very tough women are taking over, and someone is going to get hurt.

title: After the Pig Flew
description: Last month, when The Philadelphia Daily News broke a story about a 300-pound pig that was given a first-class seat on a US Airways flight, the Federal Aviation Administration took notice. The agency is investigating the pig's Oct. 17 flight to see whether the pig fell under the ''service animal'' category that allows trained animals like guide dogs into passenger cabins. ''We have requested statements from the members of that particular flight crew,'' said James Peters, an F.A.A. spokesman. ''We have also requested a list of the passengers.''

title: THEATER; A Massacre, Still Fresh, Remembered
description: AT a critical moment in Olivier Py's ''Requiem for Srebrenica,'' a metal wheelbarrow flies into the air and dangles grotesquely, wheel uppermost, the handles swaying below like legs locked in rigor mortis. Weirdly disturbing, the gesture is one of many that give the lie to those European commentators who have called this response to the 1995 massacre in Bosnia ''simple.''

title: BRIEFING: LAW ENFORCEMENT; PROSTITUTION PROGRAM
description: As part of a civil-rights lawsuit settlement in a case of a prostitute shot to death by a police officer, officials in New Brunswick have agreed to start a program aimed at helping prostitutes with health and child care, counseling and employment advice. The program, called Change A Life, stems from the shooting of Carolyn Adams, 39, a prostitute killed in a struggle with a police officer in 1996. David L. Harris, an attorney for Ms. Adams's estate, said the family asked that in addition to an undisclosed sum of money that was awarded, the city also start a program to help other women on the street. John Holl

title: Searching for the Relevant; For Many, Races Reflect the Worst of Political Times
description: For nearly two years, residents of New York and New Jersey have been exposed to United States Senate campaigns that will not be remembered for their crystallizing moments of political distinction. No William Jennings Bryan speech, no Lincoln-Douglas debate, no photograph of Adlai Stevenson, his feet up to reveal well-worn soles and therefore a piece of his soul.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Put Up Your Mitts
description: The day before the Pillsbury Bake-Off this past February in San Francisco, the 99 finalists were herded into a rules session in the bake-off ballroom, a vast cavern divided by four long rows of ranges and counters, each about the size of the average New York City apartment kitchen. In all, there were 100 ranges, 28 refrigerator-freezers, 2 free-standing freezers and 8 microwave ovens.

title: Ani DiFranco in Atlantic City
description: In what has got to be one of the most bizarre rock 'n' roll moments, Ani DiFranco has decided to perform at an Atlantic City casino. Ms. DiFranco, the poster girl for everything noncommercial and independent, has given those who have criticized her fiery brand of folk-rock as overrated, cause to say the same for her idealism. The times they are a changin', again. Ms. DiFranco will perform at the Sands tonight at 8. Robbie Woliver

title: Nets Take a Step Back, Fall to Hornets at Home
description: Byron Scott took the game ball home from Chicago on Friday night to have it engraved, a souvenir from his first victory as a professional coach and the Nets' first this season.

title: A 'Welcome' in 16 Languages
description: New Immigrant Community Empowerment

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHMAN, ADELE RONSON NAHM
description: REICHMAN-Adele Ronson Nahm, actress. Died October 31, 2000 in New York City. Her career began in the 1920s in radio and on the stage and continued until her death. Predeceased by her husbands, Horace H. Nahm and Theodore Reichman, DDS. Mother of Dorothy Nahm Friedberg, M.D. and Nancy Nahm Sidhu, mother-in-law of Neal Friedberg, M.D. and Dip Singh Sidhu, M.D. Stepmother of Lee Reichman, M.D., Rose Reichman, David Reichman and Sheila Uniti, grandmother of Abbe and Michael Friedberg and Daniel and Deborah Gar Reichman, aunt of Pat Stewart. Died in her sleep one day after returning from a trip to Venice with her family. An unforgettable woman of great spirit who will live through the memory of all those who knew her. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 5, 3:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Outnumbered 11 to 1, The Dollar Ends Up on Top; Rome: Scrimmage for Prada and Gucci, or splurge on a grand hotel
description: Even a year ago, many Americans treated the boutiques around Piazza di Spagna as interactive museums, for looking and touching alone. ''Now our American clients keep telling us what a bargain we are,'' says Walter Pellacci, manager of Loro Piana, a luxury cashmere store.

title: Paper-Products Store Adds Uptown Location
description: Paper Access brought its line of paper and paper products to a second New York site by opening a 3,000-square-foot store last month at 2030 Broadway, near 69th Streets, after 10 years at 23 West 18th Street, off Fifth Avenue.

title: Up or Down, Rules for Both
description: CANDIDATES eagerly put signs up, but sometimes they don't come down with the same haste. So many towns have passed statutes that stipulate the number of days past the election signs can remain.

title: Crime
description: Nobody says it's easy to quit your job, settle your business and personal affairs, and move to another state. But it doesn't have to be as traumatic as Sherlock Holmes going over Reichenbach Falls -- unless you happen to be Kay Scarpetta, the self-obsessed protagonist of Patricia Cornwell's mordant thrillers. The forensic pathologist and chief medical examiner for the State of Virginia starts cracking up in THE LAST PRECINCT (Putnam, $26.95) when a high-powered prosecutor comes down from New York and appropriates the pending case of Jean-Baptiste Chandonne, the grotesquely disfigured ''werewolf'' who nearly killed Scarpetta in ''Black Notice.'' Faced with this setback, she rants, she raves, she crawls onto the couch for some embarrassing psychotherapy sessions. (''You feel lonely,'' her shrink observes, ''and misunderstood.'')

title: A Kennedy and His Mentor Part Ways Over River Group
description: A year and a half ago, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the chief prosecuting attorney for the Hudson Riverkeeper, spoke at a ceremony in Garrison honoring the environmental group's founder and president, Robert H. Boyle.

title: Democrats Given a Shot At Regaining a Majority
description: With Senate races tightening before Tuesday's elections, Democrats seem more likely than they were three weeks ago to pick up at least two seats, and possibly the five they need to reclaim the chamber.

title: Bidding Farewell to the Names That Evoke Apartheid
description: Pretoria's days are numbered. Send your fond farewells, too, to Port Elizabeth, Bloemfontein and East London.

title: The Diva and the Tycoon
description: GREEK FIRE

title: Dinner Recipes for All-at-Once Roasting
description: CONVENIENCE food on a Sunday night doesn't have to be Chinese takeout or something in the microwave. It can be a meal that's baking in the oven while you watch a movie or a ballgame.

title: What's This About Cultural Pollution?
description: WHILE Hollywood executives were professing before a Senate committee not long ago to be shocked, shocked, that somehow R-rated slasher movies like ''I Know What You Did Last Summer'' were being test-marketed to 9-year-olds, the news arrived from London that Tracy Emin, the popular British artist, had unveiled ''I've Got It All.''

title: Police Make Arrest in Accident That Hurt 5 People in Harlem
description: A woman was arrested and questioned by the police yesterday in a hit-and-run accident on Thursday that injured five people in Harlem, including three children, the police said.

title: The Power of the Undecideds
description: The final hours of the presidential campaign are playing out before an almost evenly divided electorate. Most voters may feel settled in their choice of Vice President Al Gore or Gov. George W. Bush. But the small proportion of the electorate that remains wary, uncertain, alienated and even confused will determine the outcome. These swing voters break into three groups, starting with the truly undecided who are still studying the candidates and the issues. Then there are the persuadable leaners, who are inclined toward a particular candidate but not firmly resolved to vote for him. Finally -- and most important for Mr. Gore's chance of being president -- there are the supporters of Ralph Nader who must decide whether their cause is truly advanced by throwing the election to Mr. Bush.

title: Welcome To the White House
description: One cause of voter apathy in recent years must be a vague feeling on the part of many Americans that the White House has about as much in common with their house as, well, Bauhaus. To be sure, it is a rare species of residence: a house designed to withstand any calamity that could befall its occupants, and to stand ready to hold affairs of state with adequate calm. But the Executive Mansion is still a house: home to a family, site of festive meals, with a high-traffic kitchen, a spare room for guests and a well-kept lawn. As such, it's not radically different from an average middle-class American home, like the one owned by the Singh family of Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Will Nasdaq's Fall Haunt the Democrats?
description: MAYBE it's time to replace the famed campaign slogan ''It's the economy, stupid'' with ''It's the Nasdaq, numskulls.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RHEA, ALEXANDER DODSON, III.
description: RHEA-Alexander Dodson, III. Late of NYC, Ft. Worth, TX and White Sulphur Springs, WV, on Friday, September 1, 2000, in his 82nd year. A native of Whitney, TX, a graduate of Princeton University, he served as a Lieutenant Commander, US Navy, during World War II. Mr. Rhea was Vice President of Government Employees Insurance Corp., Washington, DC and Vice President of General Motors Overseas Operations. His career included association as Chairman and Managing Director-General Motors, Melbourne, Chairman and Managing Director-Vauxhall Motors Ltd., Executive Vice President and DirectorGeneral Motors Overseas Corp., Chairman of General Motors Corp. European Advisory Council, and enjoyed memberships in Knickerbocker Club, Princeton Club, the Fort Worth Club, Rivercrest Country Club, Ft. Worth, TX, the Melbourne Club, and Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club, White Sulphur Springs, WV and Boodles, London. The son of the late Alexander Dodson Rhea and Annie Boesch Rhea, husband of Suzanne Menocal Rhea, father of the late Mark Alexander Rhea, he is also survived by extended family in Texas. Friends are invited to a service of remembrance and committal in the churchyard of St. Thomas Episcopal Church, White Sulphur Springs, WV, at 2 PM, Thursday, November 9, 2000. Deeply appreciative of your prayers, messages of comfort, and the gift of your presence, the family will receive friends and associates of the Greenbrier in the Chesapeake Bay Room immediately following this tribute in his honor. Thompson's Harveson & Co Funeral Home 702 8th Avenue Ft. Worth, Texas 76104.
