title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICK, FREDERICK PHILIP
description: GLICK-Frederick Philip. was born in Philadelphia, PA, on December 7, 1910, and died on October 3, 2000. His family and friends loved Fred dearly, and we greatly miss sharing time and conversations with him. We miss his warm smile, his enthusiasm for life and learning, and his kindness, support and devotion. Fred was admitted to Philadelphia's Central High School and he graduated in 1928 with literary, athletic, and academic distinctions. He received scholarships to attend the University of Pennsylvania, where he obtained a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1932 and his law degree in 1935. He was elected to both Phi Beta Kappa and law honor societies, and he was managing editor of the Law Review. At Penn Law School Fred met Helen Lipschitz, and they married in 1936. Fred began his legal career assisting Professor Francis Bolen in authoritative work on tort law. He moved to New York City to work with Irving Lehman, then Chief Judge of the highest court in New York State. In 1943 Fred left positions in public utility law to be commissioned in the U.S. Navy. He received citation for ''his skilled judgement, superb professional ability and conscientious devotion...'' and he reached the rank of Lieutenant Commander by the end of World War II. Fred was in private law practice from the late 1940s, eventually founding Glick & Glick with Helen. In 1969 Fred moved to the firm that became Rogers & Wells, now merged in Clifford Chance Rogers & Wells, the world's largest law firm. As a partner at Rogers & Wells Fred created that firm's real estate department, which he chaired until retirement. Fred also received numerous awards lecturing for the Practising Law Institute. Additional community and philanthropic work included 47 years as an active trustee of Louise Wise Services, in New York City, and membership on the Planning Board for the Borough of Hillsdale, NJ. Fred and Helen had their home in Hillsdale from 1950 to 1998, when they moved to Dunwoody Village, in Newtown Square, PA. Fred remained active, playing tennis and serving as treasurer of the Dunwoody residents association until he suffered a stroke in July. Fred is survived by his wife, Helen; his son, Ned, of Vancouver, BC, and his daughter, Mary Gelbart, of Rehovot, Israel; their spouses and four grandchildren; and his sister, Rose Klein, of Elkins Park, PA. Donations can be made in memory of Fred Glick to the Dunwoody Memorial Garden, 3500 West Chester Pike, Newtown Square, Pennsylvania 19073.

On his plate, there wasn't much left of his mesclun greens and goat cheese salad. But judging from how much he was laughing, Mr. Hanks was enjoying more than just his meal.

title: QUICK BITE/Highland Park; Mozzarella? Mazel Tov.
description: I'm Jewish and I love pizza. So perhaps it was foregone conclusion that I'd wind up at Jerusalem Pizza. The restaurant is a favorite among Highland Park's vibrant Jewish community. As a kosher dairy establishment, it is under the strict supervision of the Vaad Harabanim (Rabbinical Council) of Raritan Valley. As a pizza place, though, it had to meet my own stringent set of standards. I judge all pizzerias by their plain slice; toppings merely cloud the issue. It all boils down to crust, sauce and cheese. Jerusalem Pizza's slice (a reasonable $1.35) passed the test. The traditional New York thin crust was crispy without being too thin. The sauce was rich and tangy. As for the cheese: Pizza cheese draws attention to itself only when there is too much of it or it is just plain bad. Neither was the case, I am glad to report. A whole pizza is $9.95, while a Sicilian pie costs $15.40, and toppings are extra. Remember, it's kosher here, so meat and dairy do not mingle, and pork products -- well, don't even ask. So instead of pepperoni and sausage, you'll find broccoli, eggplant, olives, spinach and more. Pizza-joint perennials ziti and lasagna are joined on the menu by such items as falafel, baklava and a chumus platter ($3.95) that my Gentile friends Sean and Alex greatly enjoyed. Entrees are served from a cafeteria-style line; pizza is ordered at a separate counter. Wash it all down with a Mitzli. That's the name of a ''kosher fruit nectar beverage,'' as well as the Aztec word for cougar. I do not recommend drinking a cougar. The color scheme, just like Israel's flag, is blue and white. Posters and artwork from the Holy Land replace the requisite pizzeria decorations of gondolas and a team photo of Italy's 1982 World Cup champions. What can I tell you? It's a nice nosh. JACK SILBERT

Arthur is in favor of cleaner school grounds, field trips and a ''fun raiser'' to buy more books for the school library. But with Muffy's inexhaustible campaign funding and Binky's promise of no more homework, snacks in the classroom and a day off once a week, does Arthur stand a chance? (Cinar Corp/WGBH)

Mr. Zaslaw, 55, a software engineer who lives in Cream Ridge, N.J., near Trenton, expected some volatility. After all, high-yield -- a k a junk -- bonds pay higher yields for a reason. In the case of high-yield munis, they represent loans to finance municipalities or municipal projects that have low credit ratings or no credit ratings at all.

The cars, named Rotair, carry 80 passengers and were built by a Swiss company, Von Roll Tramways/CWA. The floor of each car rotates slowly twice each trip.

title: Pesticide Found to Produce Parkinson's Symptoms in Rats

title: The Way We Spend Now
description: I take exception to the subtext of David Brooks's article (Oct. 15) that the generation that survived the Depression ''are America's most conspicuous consumers.'' Our generation listened to our parents' cautionary tales. We knew better than not to save for a rainy day. Those of us who could afford it sent our kids to college. Now that we have finished paying off those bills, we might have a little discretionary income, but Brooks calls us ''gray-haired hedonists.'' Enough of this gray bashing. Less than 10 years ago we were told that our children would not be able to live as well as we have. Nonsense. We're not the generation building McMansions. We paid our dues.

For example, he mentions more than once that he has not paid his wife back for the money he took from their joint account, but he doesn't offer any justification for this failure, nor any plans to make the repayment. Does he imagine that admitting to the failure -- getting it off his chest -- is the same thing as making amends?

title: Style; Couture Voyeur
description: If someone asks you to go to the couture shows in Paris, you don't say, ''I have to stay home and darn my socks.'' You go. Who cares what I thought of the clothes? Who cares if you can buy them or not? What matters is the all-consuming obsession of this dazzling club. I saw hundreds of impeccably chic people. Women navigating cobblestones in impossible stilettos. Men kissing the hands of duchesses and debutantes. Weary fashion editors. Movie stars seducing the press. Mannequins of inconceivable beauty. Hype, romance, envy, splendor. It was Paris and the fall couture was unfolding.

Coppola, a Thornwood plumbing company; 400 Benedict Corporation, the property owners; and Marco Martelli, a general contractor. The settlement was reached one day before the case was to go before a jury in State Supreme Court in White Plains. The accident occurred when Mr. Paolicelli was dismantling the 6,000-pound cooling tower on the roof of the Castle Restaurant in Tarrytown. His lawyer, William H. Groner of Worby, Groner & Edelman of White Plains, said the steamfitter will not be able to work again because of his injuries. Elsa Brenner

Another trip, to Harley Street, also cost a great deal more than the return.

Cup was captured by Indonesia, a country that had come close to world titles on several occasions but had never had a victory.

title: C.I.A. Links Cited on Peru Arms Deal That Backfired

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
When Tainted Funds Are Banked
description: Reputable global banks have proved depressingly willing to facilitate the looting of poor nations' treasuries by corrupt leaders, counting among their clients such dictators as Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines and Sani Abacha of Nigeria. Their deposits often came in cash-stuffed suitcases, but raised few eyebrows at institutions that pride themselves on their discretion. The heartening news is that banks are facing increasing pressure to cease being so solicitous to corrupt leaders.

title: A Route With a View Adds to the Adventure
description: In 1984, in what she called ''a fun run,'' Gordon Bakoulis ran her first New York City Marathon and finished in 3 hours 40 minutes. Yesterday, at age 39, she finished 16th in 2:45:17, the leading American woman. It only gets better, she said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDHEIM, ESTHER G.
description: LINDHEIM-Esther G. On November 3, 2000. Retired principal of PS 6 in the Bronx. Beloved wife of the late Burton, mother of Julie and Charles Cantor, devoted grandmother of Deborah C. and Lowell Kirschner and Margalit Cantor. Contributions in her memory may be made to World Jewish Congress or Hadassah. Services were held.

description: Mark Taylor and Nina Zoe Parks-Taylor finished the New York City Marathon in 4 hours 18 minutes yesterday. That, they said, is much slower than they usually run a marathon. They had a good excuse. They stopped along the way to get married.

title: Down to the Wire
description: The last day of the long presidential campaign brings an end to a remarkable journey for Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush. It also concludes, for the public, a compelling competition of ideas and personalities. A year ago, both men were aware of the tough challenge that awaited them in capturing the nomination, uniting their parties and slugging their way state by state through the fall. But few predicted that their fight would bring out so many ambivalent feelings among the voters, with so many states in contention at the end. A great deal depends now on the last-minute decisions of swing voters, the effectiveness of major drives to get out the vote, and the final barrage of slashing attack ads paid for by this election's record fund-raising.

title: Lucia Evangelista, 83, Arts Figure
description: Lucia Evangelista, a former soprano, a notable figure in New Jersey cultural circles and the wife of the renowned American bass Jerome Hines, died on Oct. 26 in North Plainfield, N.J. She was 83 and had been suffering from Lou Gehrig's disease.

title: Women and Men In the Work Force

Pataki strolled along the Hudson River, preparing for a canoe trip with his daughter and urging voters to support a $1.75 billion environmental bond act that he was championing.

Services will be held Tuesday, 10 AM, at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd.

description: It will be greatly weakened leaders who will try to revive the nearly moribund Israeli-Palestinian peace efforts in a series of meetings in Washington in the coming days.

title: End Is Swift and Sudden For an Internet Company
description: In the last weeks of September, the employees at Productopia.com were optimistically gearing up for the holiday season, writing and publishing product reviews -- the site's stock in trade -- at a rapid clip. The company was continuing to hire to fill its large fourth-floor suite and was doling out raises to several employees, suggesting things were going smoothly and good times lay ahead.

title: Donald F. Lach, 83, Historian and Author
description: Donald F. Lach, a historian who was an authority on Asia's influence on Europe from 1500 to 1800, died on Oct. 26 at a Chicago hospital. He was 83 and lived in Chicago.

title: A Big British Stake In America's Election
description: It's our election, too. Americans may be the ones casting the actual votes tomorrow, but the world will be watching -- nowhere more closely than Britain. The TV sets in Downing Street and around Westminster will be flickering through the night and deep into Wednesday morning as members of the London political class wait for a result they believe will affect them all.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the former Metropolitan Opera conductor Martin Rich on Oct. 26 misstated his tenure at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia. He taught from 1947 to 1950, not until two years ago.

title: Entering Last Act, Senate Rivals Stick to the Script; Mrs. Clinton Preaches to the Party Faithful
description: In a day of gospel and politics, Hillary Rodham Clinton preached and prayed her way through seven churches in seven hours yesterday, moving to close out her campaign by urging black parishioners in New York City to turn out to support her tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, FERDIE A.
description: FALK-Ferdie A. Beloved husband, father and grandfather, passed away on Friday, November 3, on his 72nd birthday. Mr. Falk, a well-known liquor executive worldwide, spanning over forty years in the liquor industry. He was founder, Chairman, and principal shareholder of the Ancient Age Distilling Company, which is a major producer of bourbon whiskey. He also served in an executive capacity with Seagrams International, Schenley Distillers and the Fleischmann Distilling Corp, Nabisco Products, Inc., and past Chairman, Chief Executive Officer, Julius Wile Son & Co. He was a member of the Chevalier De Tastevin, Sommelier Society and the Lucullus Circle. He was listed in the prestigious ''Who's Who in America'' and ''Who's Who in the World.'' Mr. Falk was also very active in the community of Boca Raton, Florida, where he lived. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the Boca Raton Resort and Club. He also served as both past President and Board Director of the Boca Raton Resort and Club. He also served as both past President and Board Director of the Mizner Tower Condominium Association. Mr. Falk also founded Falk Properties, Inc., a development and management company with vast real estate holdings in New York and Louisiana. Throughout his lifetime Mr. Falk was very active as both a participant and fund-raiser for numerous charitable organizations worldwide, earning him awards and honors such as ''Man of the Year'' for the Association of Retarded Children, ''Sword of Haganah'' from the State of Israel, ''Cavaleri De Lavaro'' from the Italian Government, ''Federated British Industry'' from the English Government, ''Flame of Truth'' from the Fund for Higher Education and ''Dr. Louis Berger Memorial'' from The American Cancer Society, past President Sky Ranch for Boys, past Chairman of the Liquor Division of The United Negro College Fund. Mr. Falk is survived by his loving wife Peggy, his beloved daughter and son-inlaw Lori Falk Katzman and Marc Katzman of Harrington Park, New Jersey, his beloved son Chris and daughter-in-law Gina Falk of New Orleans, Louisiana, beloved son Mel and daughter-in-law Nancy Jacob of Roslyn, New York, beloved son Steven and daughter-inlaw Ivonne Jacob of Atlanta, Georgia. Adored and loved by his ten grandchildren, Amanda, Eric, Bryan, Austin, Tyler, Jessica, Michelle, Lauren, Elyssa, and Giselle. A devoted husband, supportive father, and the most wonderful grandfather, will be missed sorely by all. Memorial contributions to The Ursula and Ferdie Falk Endowment Fund at Temple Beth El, 333 SW 4th Ave., Boca Raton, FL 33432. For further information, contact Guttermam Warheit, Boca Raton.

title: E-Mail Part of the Effort To Turn Out the Voters
description: As Election Day nears, so do the sounds of get-out-the-vote efforts: the ringing of phone banks, the roar of the crowds, the hammering of signs in front yards and, increasingly, the click of the mouse.

description: To the Editor:

description: Two marketers in the intensely competitive brokerage field are beginning big campaigns, both coincidentally by units of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Although It's a Show, This Game Is For Real
description: So, who doesn't want to be a millionaire? The folks behind the cameras, including the one with the question cards, are just as greedy as the rest of us, and the real question asked in ''Game Show,'' a spunky spoof of America's perennially popular television fare by Jeffrey Finn and Bob Walton, is just how far they are willing to go to claw their way to the top of the network pyramid.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing with the Advertising column last Monday about two executives who were named to posts at CCG.XM, the global e-business unit of the Cordiant Communications Group, misstated the former post of Thurston Yates, director for creative services. He had been associate creative director, not creative director, at the New York office of Zentropy Partners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, ANNA M.
description: FRANK-Anna M. On November 3, 2000, of Manhattan in her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Jerome H. Frank; loving mother of Marjorie Frank Balaban and H. Stephen Frank. Son-in-law of Victor Balaban. Adoring grandmother of James Schecter, Nancy Starkey, Chrissie Bennett and Jane Frank Pascal, Stacey Frank Kanihan, and Jonathan Frank. Cherished great-grandmother of nine loving great-grandchildren. Always in good humor and with a most generous heart, her indomitable spirit is held in warm memory by her family. Interment at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: THIS WEEK
description: THIS WEEK

title: Lieberman Races to Energize Democrats in Swing States
description: Making a last frenetic dash through Western swing states, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman worked today to motivate core Democratic voters to turn out on Tuesday, saying that every vote matters in a presidential race that is closer than any in a generation or more.

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
Nets Are Looking for Ways to Overcome Inexperience
description: For three games, the Nets have sprinted to double-digit leads in the first half, making a splashy first impression. But for three games, their leads have had little substance. Right now the Nets seem young and unsteady, and rather two-dimensional without the injured Keith Van Horn.

title: Candidates Woo Latinos With Ads, but Not Policy
description: Here in Little Village, a world away from the presidential campaign trail, Mexican music spilled from storefronts and passing cars. Young men up and down West 26th Street hawked sliced melon, pineapple and corn from stands in this working-class West Side neighborhood.

description: The fight for control of the House of Representatives, heated by last-minute phone calls and mailings, and sermons in some churches and fliers at others, neared an end today with both parties predicting victory with at least as much bravado as certainty.

title: Piquant Flavors and Colors Along the Silk Road
description: New York Philharmonic

description: The most impressive year of Phil Mickelson's career was capped by his most impressive victory.

title: 2 Linemen Are Injured
description: The Giants have been fairly injury free this season, but their 24-3 romp over the Cleveland Browns yesterday may yet be costly since offensive linemen Dusty Zeigler and Luke Petitgout were injured. Also, running back Tiki Barber has a broken right thumb, though Barber played Sunday and insisted it would not affect his performance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANBARLIAN, HARRY
description: ANBARLIAN-Harry. On November 4, 2000. Beloved husband of Marina Masi Anbarlian. Dear brother-in-law of Peter and Marisa Johnson. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, November 6, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 650 West 168th St., NY, NY 10032.

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
Teacher, 31, Fatally Stabbed in Bushwick
description: Walani Stephens's best friend knew something was wrong yesterday morning when she saw the open windows. Ms. Stephens, an avid art collector who had an apartment full of plants, never left her windows open more than a crack so as not to risk damaging her collection or greenery, her friend Missy Jael Bannister said.

title: Islanders Have Trouble Dealing With Success

A victory at home today not only would have eradicated the frustration of the overtime loss that snapped a six-game unbeaten streak, but would also have put the Islanders into the position of being tied with the Devils for first place in the Atlantic Division.

title: Just Scratched by 1976 Arrest, Bush Keeps Lead in Polls
description: WASHINGTON  Governor George W. Bush on Sunday appeared to have survived, with only minor political scratches, the revelation last week of a past drunken driving conviction as he and Vice President Al Gore kept up vigorous last-minute efforts to energize party bases and assure crucial voter turnouts.

title: E-Commerce Report; Content sites find a way to keep e-tailer marketing booths on their page -- without having lured their visitors away.
description: OVER the last year, affiliate marketing has looked like the perfect choice for e-commerce sites that were searching for ways to find customers on the cheap. Electronic retailers signed up thousands of so-called content sites, which in turn advertised the e-tailers' goods in exchange for sales commissions.

title: Essay; The Clothespin Vote
description: The magic moment of maturity in every voter's life comes when he or she accepts the fact that no candidate is right on every issue. At that moment, one either becomes a chooser or a loser.

title: PullingThePlug.com; More and More Venture Capitalists Give Up on the Internet
description: To look at Internet companies today, said Ron Erickson, a veteran technology executive and investor, is like watching dinosaurs after the proverbial meteor hit the earth: ''Instead of natural evolution you had cataclysmic change.''

title: Kosgei and Countrymen Seem to Be Running in Place
description: Just ahead of Japhet Kosgei were more than a few hills and more than a glimmer of promise. Kosgei thought Abdelkhader el-Mouaziz might slow down on one of those hills and break his pace. Then Kosgei would catch him. Then the New York City Marathon would become a real race.

title: Selectively Mining the 'Nutcracker' Tradition
description: The unicorns, summer meadow flowers and other pastel anomalies are hard to get used to in Kevin McKenzie's second act of ''The Nutcracker,'' performed by American Ballet Theater on Saturday at City Center. Forget about ''The Nutcracker'' and think ''The NeverEnding Story,'' that New Age children's fantasy film that has saved the sanity of many a baby sitter.

title: Fissures in Sunday Papers' Pot of Gold
description: During the first years of the long, slow slide in daily newspaper circulation, Sunday newspapers were the industry's hope and consolation. Weighing as much as a small stack of two-by-fours, filled with enough discount coupons to wallpaper a room and enough sections to keep a reader curled up for hours, they kept on selling.

title: A Close Race Raises the Status of the Vote Coordinator
description: MICHAEL WHITE does not have the sort of job that usually lends itself to engaging cocktail party chatter. As director of legal affairs and policy for the Office of the Federal Register, he spends most days on regulatory analysis and information-dissemination policy -- the kind of topics that prompt Washington party guests to excuse themselves for another canape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARINO, ROMEO V.
description: MARINO-Romeo V. Died November 3, 2000. Relatives and friends may visit at the Balsamo Funeral Home, 3188 Westchester Ave., Bronx, NY, Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of the Assumption Church, 1634 Mahan Ave., Bronx, NY, Tuesday at 9:30 AM.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE SENATE

title: 2 Religions Clashing in Ivory Coast
description: Up a winding street here in a sprawling, working-class neighborhood, a mosque, a Roman Catholic church and a Protestant church have long stood close to one another -- symbols of the religious and ethnic tolerance that made this country the envy of other Africans.

title: Kin of Nun Slain in '80 Keep Faith In a Cause
description: While Bill Ford worried about building his civil law practice on Wall Street in the early 1970's, his sister Ita was preparing to leave New York for Chile as a Maryknoll missionary. Their family asked why she had to go so far away. Ita, whom Mr. Ford described as the conscience of the family, turned the tables on him.

title: Swaggering Bush Camp Chases the Momentum
description: It is not at all clear what a campaign's chief strategist should be doing with a mere 48 hours until Election Day and most aspects of the candidate's schedule, advertising plan and get-out-the-vote effort set in stone.

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
Creditors Offer Hyundai Unit Another Option to Raise Cash
description: The Hyundai Engineering and Construction Company, South Korea's leading contractor, could escape court receivership if it accepts its creditors' offer of a debt-for-equity swap, the Financial Supervisory Commission said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENNINGS, FRED M.
description: JENNINGS-Fred M. Of Hobe Sound, FL, and Sandwich, NH, formerly of New Canaan, CT, on November 4, 2000, in Augusta, ME. He received his BA degree at San Diego State College and law degree at the University of Chicago. Fred served in the Pacific during WWII as an officer on the USS Guardfish, the only submarine to be awarded the Presidential Unit Citation for Valor twice. He worked in New York City in the legal profession at Milbank Tweed law firm and as House Counsel at Riegel Paper Corp. and VP at Great Lakes Paper Company in White Plains, NY. He started an American style feedlot in Australia in 1974. He is survived by his beloved wife, Peggy, his son, Douglas of Hallowell, ME, daughter, Nanci Ouellette of Lansing, MI, and two grandchildren, Amy and Douglas Jennings. Services will be for the family in Hallowell, ME. Memorial contributions to the Alzheimers Association, Chicago, IL.

title: What Did the 106th Congress Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jimmie Davis, Louisiana's Singing Governor, Is Dead
description: Jimmie H. Davis, the troubador and composer of one of America's best-loved songs, ''You Are My Sunshine,'' who yodeled and smiled his way into the hearts of Louisiana voters to serve two terms as their Singing Governor, died yesterday at his home in Baton Rouge, La.

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the history and procedures of the Electoral College misattributed a quotation about the possibility of a tie electoral vote for president. It was Michael Lind, a senior fellow at the New America Foundation, not Thomas Mann of the Brookings Institution, who jokingly said, ''Let the Pentagon decide!'' The article also omitted mention of one election in which the college played an important role. In 1800, after Thomas Jefferson and Aaron Burr received an equal number of electoral votes, the contest was thrown into the House of Representatives, which decided for Jefferson.

title: One Cold Night of Broken Neon and Shady Dives
description: THE ICE HARVEST

title: Romaniuk Wins for 3rd Time
description: Justin Romaniuk of Suffern High School won the marathon's 2.2-mile high school race for the third straight year, finishing in 12 minutes 32.1 seconds. Rob Murray of Ossining (12:54) was second and Ryan Harmon of Xavier (12:56) was third.

title: A Literary Diaspora Toasts One of Its Own
description: Considering the stature of the two literary lions sitting onstage for a historic dialogue, the question seemed so pedestrian that the host and interrogator was apologetic. If you were stuck on a desert island, Leon Botstein, president of Bard College, asked his guests, Chinua Achebe and Toni Morrison, what book would you take with you?

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with a Critic's Notebook article about John Harbison's ''Great Gatsby,'' at Lyric Opera of Chicago, misspelled the surname of the soprano in a scene with Clifton Forbes and Jerry Hadley. She is Alicia Berneche, not Herneche.

title: Milosevic's Old Foe Riding High Again in Kosovo
description: Ibrahim Rugova, long the political leader of the Albanians in Kosovo, is once more in the ascendant after his party, the Democratic League of Kosovo, emerged the winner in local elections.

title: Top Two Executives of Bertelsmann Music Will Resign
description: The two top executives of Bertelsmann's BMG Entertainment music division announced their resignations yesterday, days after their parent company startled the industry by investing in Napster, the music-sharing Web site that BMG and other record companies are suing on charges of abetting copyright infringement.

title: Locution, Locution, Locution!
description: He is as hyperbolic as he is hyperactive as he is hypercritical. He is as alliterative as he is allusional as he is allegorical. He is Chris Lehane, Vice President Al Gore's campaign press secretary, and he has been speaking this way for the better part of a year now.

title: MORE ON THE ELECTIONS
description: STILL WITHIN REACH -- Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush remain ensnarled in one of the closest presidential races of the last 100 years, according to the final New York Times / CBS News Poll. The poll suggested that the candidates were still struggling to lure a tiny pool of undecided voters, with Mr. Bush taking a slight, but statistically insignificant lead. Still, the outcome hinges on state-by-state contests. And the map shows that either candidate is within reach of amassing the 270 electoral votes needed to win. PAGE A23

title: A Journalist, So Unlovable: NBC Cancels 'Deadline'
description: ''Deadline'' should have been a winner. The NBC dramatic series, about a New York tabloid columnist who dabbles in crime-solving, was created by Dick Wolf, one of most successful writer-producers on television. Its high-profile cast was headed by Oliver Platt, a top character actor who has been sought for years by television producers. NBC lavishly promoted the Monday night show and sought to tap into the same audience as Mr. Wolf's most enduring series, ''Law and Order.''

title: Taking Bach Classics Beyond the Living Room
description: With the modern piano the unofficial instrument of choice at this year's Bach celebration, the debate shifted on Saturday night from new instruments versus old to public places versus private ones.

title: Taiwan's Leader Under Fire, With Some Out to Unseat Him
description: Less than six months after Chen Shui-bian's inauguration as president, an event widely hailed as a milestone because it was Taiwan's first democratic transfer of power from the long-ruling Nationalists, Mr. Chen and opposing parties are mired in an ugly and divisive stalemate with no end in sight.

title: Critic's Notebook: Hail to the Chief, Just Another Guy In a Blue Suit; From TV to Hollywood, The Demystification Of the President
description: The sorting out of the much-worried-over Clinton legacy will shortly become a matter for historians, but there can be no doubt that for at least one segment of the population, white male movie stars over 40, the last eight years have been flush times indeed. It's an article of democratic faith that any child can grow up to be president. Whether that has ever been true, in recent times it has seemed that just about any middle-aged guy with a SAG card who looked reasonably good in a blue suit could at least have a shot at playing the president in a movie.

title: A Few Bad Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: Vote-Swapping Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTOTSKY, REBECCA
description: POTOTSKY-Rebecca. On November 4, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Herman Pototsky. Loving mother of Gilbert and Kenneth Parker. Cherished grandmother of four. Services 12 noon, Wednesday, November 8, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Focus Is on Crucial States in Campaign's Final Hours
description: On another 19-hour campaign day that included a swing through four states where the race is nip and tuck, Vice President Al Gore resurrected the name of Bill Clinton today as he declared to blacks in Philadelphia and union members here that Tuesday's election was about not only material prosperity, but also ''prosperity of the spirit.''

title: Just Before Election, Politics and Religion Mix Easily at a Michigan Church
description: The Rev. Michael C. Murphy preached this morning about David, the renowned king of Israel, calling him ''a shrewd politician'' and ''a great organizer.''

title: 10,000 Turn Out to Hear Nader Urge 'Shift in Power'
description: In the final major rally of his campaign, Ralph Nader issued a populist call for a sweeping ''shift of power'' from big business to the downtrodden and disenfranchised, and he urged the country to vote its conscience, not its fears.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
Writers on Writing; Comforting Lessons In Arranging Life's Details
description: The other night I saw a television program about Asperger's syndrome, a disorder characterized by, among other things, the inability to read human emotions and a compensatory passion for objects and rituals. One of the little boys profiled on the program was obsessed with washers and dryers, another with trains, a third with game shows.

title: Giants Winning, but Not Winning Over the Skeptics
description: When the Cleveland Browns pop up on a team's schedule, they do not exactly inspire fear. So Giants defensive end Michael Strahan understood why everyone around the team's complex was a little giddy heading into the weekend. Players cracked jokes in meetings and coaches yucked it up occasionally during practice. The atmosphere was relaxed. It's the Browns, for goodness' sake.

title: Silence Ending About Abuse in Gay Relationships
description: When Benjamin DeLanty's partner started hitting him, Mr. DeLanty did not think of the attacks as domestic abuse. After all, said Mr. DeLanty, 32, he was not a battered woman, but a fit man, slightly larger than his partner.

title: Comforts of Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLENOFF, MATILDA
description: ELLENOFF-Matilda. Formerly of NY, died October 31, 2000, in Los Angeles, CA. Loving wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Lori Ulanova and June O'Neill. Grandmother of Amy, Ora, Adina and Peter. Great-grandmother of five.

title: New Economy; As Internet stocks fell, other emerging technology issues suffered with them.
description: THEY began going public several years ago, promising to use exciting new technology to revolutionize the way people around the world live and work. Though they were rarely profitable and many barely had sales, their potential captivated investors. As their stocks soared, analysts and commentators offered ever more grandiose predictions of the companies' impact, and investment bankers rushed to take more and more of them public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRONG, JULIE DEVIRY
description: STRONG-Julie deViry. 81, of Highland Park, NJ, and Lenox, MA, on November 3, 2000 in Piscataway, NJ. Wife of the late Woodbridge Strong, former attorney in New Brunswick, NJ. Mother of Alan, Timothy, Harmon, and Benjamin Strong; sister of Roselyne Frelinghuysen and Pernet Siemons. Also survived by five grandchildren. Memorial service 11 AM, Monday, November 6, 2000 at the Second Reformed Church, 100 College Ave., New Brunswick

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
Wanted: One President For Famous University
description: Could there possibly be a more delicious nugget to drop into conversation at the faculty club than this? ''Oh, by the way, I'm told I've been nominated for the presidency of Harvard.''

title: Entering Last Act, Senate Rivals Stick to the Script; Lazio Stresses Integrity and Fiscal Restraint
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio today pressed many of the themes from the beginning of his Senate candidacy five months ago, emphasizing his New York roots, fiscal restraint and the character and integrity he suggests his opponent lacks.

title: Goal Achieved in Middle of Pack
description: David Pantos of Edison, N.J., was making his first attempt at 26 miles 385 yards in yesterday's New York City Marathon, but he knew he couldn't match his mother's best time.

title: MediaTalk; Magazine Pitch Fails to Sway Philip Morris
description: It was Britney Spears on the front cover of Rolling Stone -- and a Marlboro ad on the back cover -- that helped lead Philip Morris to stop advertising in 41 magazines earlier this year. Now some magazine publishers, after seeing a market research study released last week, are hoping to recoup some of that lost money -- but Philip Morris is not budging.

title: Lazio and Gianella Rouse Top-Seeded St. Anthony's
description: In the first round of the Catholic High School Football League AAA playoffs yesterday, St. Anthony's, the top-seeded team, defeated Chaminade, the eighth-seeded team, 24-6.

title: National News Briefs; Drug Company Chief Resigns Unexpectedly
description: Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., the United States subsidiary of the Swiss pharmaceutical giant, confirmed yesterday that its chief executive had unexpectedly resigned.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Sports of The Times; Director Sees the Race Up Close and Personal
description: THE runners know the marathon only as a blur because they are busy putting one foot after another.

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
After Day Full of Showdowns, a Few Questions Remain
description: So, who is the Horse of the Year now?

title: Omnicom wins advertising's big race by gaining the consolidated account of the Chrysler Group.
description: THE Madison Avenue version of Election Day came four days before the real thing when the Chrysler Group ended a closely fought, two-month battle for its massive consolidated account by choosing the Omnicom Group in New York over True North Communications in Chicago.

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled for Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
Sprewell Tampering? Coach Doubts It
description: Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy took issue with the National Basketball Association today, calling the notion that Latrell Sprewell could be guilty of breaking the league's tampering rules far-fetched.

title: Cheney Spends a Precious Full Day Courting Californians
description: Dick Cheney campaigned exclusively in California today, a lavish commitment of time and resources on a state that many pollsters believe is securely in the Democratic camp. Democrats called the move a sophisticated feint, but Republicans said it stemmed from their conviction that they could win the state and its 54 electoral votes.

title: Article 2000110692815118022 -- No Title
description: TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 5  Urging the elderly to reject "the old-style politics of scaring folks," Gov. George W. Bush today devoted function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } The 2000 Election function displayDate(month) { if (month == "Jan") smon = "January"; else if (month == "Feb") smon = "February"; else if (month == "Mar") smon = "March"; else if (month == "Apr") smon = "April"; else if (month == "May") smon = "May"; else if (month == "Jun") smon = "June"; else if (month == "Jul") smon = "July"; else if (month == "Aug") smon = "August"; else if (month == "Sep") smon = "September"; else if (month == "Oct") smon = "October"; else if (month == "Nov") smon = "November"; else if (month == "Dec") smon = "December"; return (smon ); }

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Dr. Thomas King, a biologist who conducted early experiments in cloning, misstated the result of work reported in 1952. Dr. King and a colleague told of having produced tadpoles from the nuclei of frog embryos inserted into frog eggs -- not a frog from a tadpole nucleus and a frog's egg.

title: SuperSonics Fans Happy to Have Ewing
description: Wait and see. A roll of the dice. A curiosity.

title: The Ambitions of Hugo Chavez
description: President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela clearly means to be an influential symbol of resistance to American influence, not just in Latin America but around the world. Whether he can succeed remains to be seen, though he is backed by one of the world's largest petroleum reserves at a time of high oil prices. Washington will have to watch him warily, though it should avoid unnecessary confrontations.

title: Week's Schedule Of Bond Offerings
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and 10-year notes on Wednesday. The notes were offered at a price-to-yield of 5.83.

title: Focus Is on Crucial States in Campaign's Final Hours
description: Urging the elderly to reject ''the old-style politics of scaring folks,'' Gov. George W. Bush today devoted his next-to-last campaign day entirely to Florida in a high-stakes drive to bring home the state that could prove decisive in Tuesday's election.

title: Mosley Seeks De La Hoya, Who Prefers to Sing
description: If Sugar Shane Mosley wants another confrontation with Oscar De La Hoya, he may have to take voice lessons and challenge him to a duet in a recording studio.

title: What Did the 106th Congress Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Healthy Performance
description: The marathon was by far the healthiest in nearly two decades, the marathon's medical director said yesterday.

title: Mideast Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
T-Shirt-and-Shorts Crowd Turns Its Wait for Bush into a Bash-Gore Rally
description: The look and mood of the early crowd waiting for the candidate to arrive was worthy of Alexis de Tocqueville's fascination 165 years ago with America's ''strange unrest of so many happy men, restless in the midst of abundance.''

title: Cornered Afghan Foes Hope Winter Will Slow the Taliban
description: The soldiers atop the steep mountain were grumbling. They had a tank perched at cliff side, and they had been firing away. Five days ago they blew apart one of the Taliban's tanks, nested on a facing mountaintop across the broad valley. Usually, such success merits a cash bonus, but they had gotten nothing.

title: Fringe Candidates Plug Along On Efforts of a Faithful Few
description: Most of the attention given to third-party candidates in this year's presidential election has gone to Ralph Nader and Patrick J. Buchanan, each nationally known and each with some potential to be a spoiler in a handful of closely contested states, especially Mr. Nader.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Pittsburgh; Detroit; and Rochester and Buffalo, N.Y.

title: First Lady Re-emerges in Clinton Campaign
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, some in the audience suspected, had shed a tear or two on Friday night when she delivered a speech to the Anti-Defamation League about her experiences as first lady with victims of terrorism.

title: Hayes Starts At Safety
description: The revolving door that is the Jets' free safety position swung around today to Chris Hayes, who had his first career start at his true position. In three previous years with the Jets, Hayes had become a special teams specialist. But he entered the picture at free safety in recent weeks as Kevin Williams, who won the job after a three-way competition in training camp, struggled and lost the job.

title: Humbled Sony Seeks Box-Office Magic
description: In 1997, on the strength of ''Jerry Maguire,'' ''Air Force One'' and other hits, Sony Pictures earned nearly $1.3 billion at the domestic box office, a record that still stands as the most ever brought in by a studio in a single year. Put another way, more than $1 of every $5 spent on movie tickets that year went for films released by Sony's Columbia Pictures or one of the conglomerate's other, smaller production companies.

title: Article 2000110690072121163 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
MediaTalk; Paper Delays Publication of Critic's Column
description: Walter Mossberg, The Wall Street Journal's protean critic of the new economy's tools and toys, did not like the device that a Dallas concern, DigitalConvergence, rolled out this fall. Called CueCat, it plugs into an armchair shopper's computer. When the shopper moves the ''cat's'' nose across bar codes in a catalog or an advertisement, relevant Web pages pop up on the screen.

title: Jets Have Lost Their Winning Touch in the Fourth Quarter
description: Vinny Testaverde knew as soon as he released the ball, off balance and still under pressure, that the Jets' final offensive play in a 30-23 loss to Denver would fail.

title: The Eleventh Hour
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYDEN, BERNICE. ''NICIE''
description: HAYDEN-Bernice. ''Nicie'' died Thursday, November 2, 2000, at Cabrini Hospital after a 30 year struggle with cancer. After good years it finally got her. She is survived by her loving sisters, Frances and Terry and so many friends.

title: Coverage Can't Keep Pace With The News
description: One day, the television production of the New York City Marathon will match the excitement and majesty of the event. Yesterday was not that day.

title: Sports of The Times; The Jets Need Some Loud Alarm Clocks
description: AS if their sudden two-game losing streak wasn't enough to deflate the Jets, they now go to Indianapolis, where the Colts will be steaming after losing to the Bears, and then to Miami, where the Dolphins are leading the American Football Conference East.

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
This Year, Trades May Not Be A Big Deal
description: By this time last year Juan Gonzalez had already been traded. It was during this corresponding week, during the general managers' meetings, that Shawn Green was traded. It was during those same meetings that the Seattle Mariners initiated efforts to trade Ken Griffey Jr.

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
In Montana, Watching to See If Independent Streak Is Fading
description: When Democrats dream of regaining control of the House and the Senate, their thoughts turn to Montana, a rugged, rural outpost of gun rights, individualism and a sizable disdain for government.

title: What Did the 106th Congress Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: The Many, The Proud, The Finishers
Another Contestant Wades Into E-Book Format Wars
description: Consumer demand for books to be read on screens remains largely theoretical. A trio of software companies -- Microsoft, Adobe Systems and Gemstar-TV Guide International -- have been racing ahead to push formats for publishing electronic books, designed to make them more difficult to copy and easier to read. But their competing formats are incompatible.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 28 about Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy's decision to reject a candidate for principal of the Bronx High School of Science misstated the year that Milton Kopelman, who criticized the decision, took the job. It was 1977, not 1970; he left in 1990.

title: Public Interests; The Last Interview
description: After the Revolutionary War, our Founding Fathers made quick work of disenfranchising our founding mothers. Except in New Jersey, which for some reason decided to throw open the doors and give every free citizen a ballot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLOSHIN, SIDNEY E.
description: WOLOSHIN-Sidney E. On November 5, 2000 at the age of 72. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Ellen and Mark, and Jonathan and Debra. Adoring grandfather of Jake and Julia. Cherished brother of Norma Basch. Pioneer in the jingle and advertising business. Award-winning music producer. Admired by all who knew him. Service Wednesday, 10:00 AM, at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to either Ronald McDonald House or to the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Front Row
description: Ralph Lauren Polo Going Online

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANIGSBERG, ISABELLE
description: HANIGSBERG-Isabelle. The partners and staff of Stern Keiser Panken & Wohl, LLP mourn the passing of Isabelle, our dear friend and wife of Oscar. Our heartfelt grief goes out to Oscar and his family.

title: ITALY DEMANDS BLU'S $1.8 BILLION BOND
description: Italy formally requested payment of the guarantee Blu S.p.A. posted to take part in an auction of five wireless phone licenses. Blu's abrupt withdrawal from the auction left the sale in chaos, yielding half what the government had expected. Blu is controlled by Autostrade S.p.A. of Italy and British Telecommunications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, SUE CARROLL
description: KLEIN-Sue Carroll. Beloved wife of Murray; dearly loved mother of Katharine Lord Klein & Constance Anne Klein, grandmother of Jackson Charles Klein Lomis. Memorial service 11 a.m. November 8, 2000 St. Paul's Church, Stockbridge. Contributions in Mrs. Klein's memory may be made to the Music-Theatre Group, the Berkshire Theatre Festival or the New York Times Neediest Cases c/o the Finnerty & Stevens Funeral Home, 426 Main Street, Great Barrington, MA 01230.

title: On Election Day, a Search for Some Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: On Election Day, a Search for Some Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Harlem Troupe Leads Way to China
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem is to tour China from Nov. 15 to 27, performing in Beijing and in the Shanghai International Arts Festival. It will be the first arts group from the United States to visit China since legislation establishing normal trade relations was signed into law on Oct. 10.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Michigan State University students' viewsof the presidential campaign referred incorrectly in some copies to the networks that broadcast the news program ''Hardball,'' which some students watched being taped on Oct. 12. (A similar error occurred on Thursday in an article about Bill Ballenger, an authority on Michigan politics.) The program is on CNBC and MSNBC but not on CNN.

title: Beyond Bean Counting
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNBLATT, SHAYNEE IDY
description: KORNBLATT - Shaynee Idy. March 29, 1950. Beloved daughter of Esther and the late Dave. Beloved sister of Michael his wife Trish, and their children Kerry, Tracy and Myles. Also survived by many loving relatives and friends. She was one in a million and we shall not see the likes of her in our lifetime. Services today, 2PM, Schwartz Bros., Queens Blvd off Union Tpk, Kew Gardens, N.Y., 718-263-7600 followed by interment Elmont Cemetery.

title: Updike Takes Another Shot at Rabbit
description: LICKS OF LOVE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPER, JEROME MILTON
description: ALPER-Jerome Milton. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Jerome Milton Alper, beloved father of Andrew M. Alper, a long-time contributor and advocate of the work of UJA-Federation. To Andrew and his brother, Alan Alper; to his stepchildren, Robin Howe and Jeffrey Teitel; to his six grandchildren; and to the entire family, we extend our sincerest condolences. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO Paul M. Kane, Senior VP Joy Prevor, Mgr, Wall Street Div

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special E-Commerce section on Oct. 25 about Web sites that let consumers invest small amounts of money in mutual funds referred incorrectly to the status of Stockback.com. It began investing for members in August. It is not under development.

title: 3 Held in Botched Robbery; Store Workers Were Hostages
description: Two men and a teenager were arrested today after the police said they took as many as 60 employees hostage at a discount store during a botched robbery attempt in Culver City, next to Los Angeles.

title: The Big City; Making a Case For 'None Of the Above'
description: EVEN before the polls opened, political scientists were sadly wondering why so many New Yorkers were not going to vote today. But that apathy may be easier to understand than another mystery: Why are the rest bothering at all this year?

title: Popular Cold Medicines Are Pulled From Market
description: Some of the nation's largest pharmacy chains and drug manufacturers today began withdrawing cold remedies and appetite suppressants, including some that have been staples in American medicine cabinets for decades, after federal regulators announced they would take steps to ban all use of the active ingredient in the products.

title: Amerada Hess to Buy Lasmo, British Exploration Concern
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation, known for its green Hess trucks and gas stations, agreed today to buy Lasmo P.L.C., a British oil exploration and production company, for $3.5 billion in cash and stock in a move that shifts the balance of its business outside the United States and away from its roots as a refiner and marketer.

title: To Taste an Apple: That Was Paradise!
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford to Include Payload Data In Vehicles
description: The Ford Motor Company will warn buyers of its sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks about limits on how much weight they can carry safely in their vehicles. But the company says that it has not linked overloading to crashes involving Ford Explorer sport utilities equipped with Firestone tires.

title: 2 Teenagers Attacked During Voter Drive
description: Two black teenagers distributing fliers in Queens as part of an effort to get out the vote for today's election were injured Sunday when they were attacked by a group of white and Hispanic teenagers yelling racial slurs, the police said.

title: In His Own Words
description: GEORGE W. BUSH

title: The Head Priest in a Gallic Culinary Temple
description: THERE is a stack of clean spoons on a white napkin on the warming table of the kitchen of Le Bernardin. An entree does not leave the room before the chef, Eric Ripert, sticks a skewer in the fish to make sure it is properly cooked, takes a fresh spoon and tastes the sauce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SOPHIE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Sophie. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Sophie Goldstein. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Kenneth Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, SYLVIA (NEE STAMLER)
description: BRODY-Sylvia (nee Stamler). 88 years, on November 5, 2000. Daughter of the late Bessie and Meyer Stamler, beloved wife of the late William Brody, mother of Barbara Richmon and Ronald Brody, grandmother of Naomi, Jeremy, Andrew, Jason and Joshua, sister of Samuel Stamler, sister-in-law of Evelyn Stamler, aunt of Leslie Stamler and the late Carole Alkon, cousin of Mickey Stein, and the late Lily Linkin, mother-inlaw of Joel Richmon and Susannah Brody. Graveside services 3 P.M. Wednesday November 8, at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: Bill Gates, Skeptic
description: To the Editor:

title: Teaching the Body To Heal Itself; Work on Cells' Signals Fosters Talk of a New Medicine
description: In the Star Trek movie ''The Voyage Home,'' about a visit to present-day Earth from the future, Dr. McCoy sneaks into a hospital to rescue the injured Chekov and views with horror the barbarous implements of 20th-century medicine, the gross knives and saws so unsuited for the delicate soft machinery they are intended to repair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, VOJTECH
description: BLAU-Vojtech. November 6 2000. Prominent dealer of fine antique rugs and tapestries. Beloved husband of Jolana, loving father of Simona and Andrea, cherished grandfather to Stefan and Sasha Krawitz, dear brother of Alex Blau. Services Wednedsay 11am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSON, BERNICE (BUNNY)
description: BENSON-Bernice (Bunny). On November 4, 2000. Beloved mother, sister and aunt. Donations may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice in her memory. Graveside services were held Monday, November 6th at Knollwood Park Cemetery.

title: On Election Day, a Search for Some Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES MAY SELL ELECTRONICS UNIT
description: Litton Industries hired Merrill Lynch & Company to advise it on the sale of its military electronics business, which makes systems for electronic warfare and to navigate warships and aircraft. The unit accounted for $1.6 billion of the $5.6 billion in fiscal 2000 sales posted by Litton; the company's largest business is military shipbuilding. The company is seeking ways to reduce debt after missing profit forecasts twice this year, in part because of cost overruns at the unit, which employs 9,500 people in the United States, Canada, Italy and Germany. Many large military contractors, including Northrop Grumman and General Dynamics, are seen as potential buyers of the Litton unit, analysts said. Litton's shares rose $1.06, to $54.06, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Ancient Artisans and Their 'Rain of the Moon'
description: In the world of the Inca, the moon was a female deity, and silver was her metal; in ancient chants, it was ''rain of the moon.''

title: Other Ways to Fight Flu While U.S. Waits for Vaccine
description: Could the current delay in production of flu vaccine be a blessing in disguise? While some may get sick before getting a flu shot, the publicity given to the temporary shortage and to other methods of combating the flu may greatly increase public awareness and ultimately cause far more people to seek protection than did in years past.

title: Lazio and Clinton, Both Upbeat, Rally Troops on Last Day; Giuliani and Pataki Join Candidate at His Rallies
description: Rick A. Lazio recruited Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for a final, frenzied pre-election blitz in the Hudson River Valley and New York City's suburbs today, saying he still feels like the underdog but is confident he will come out on top.

title: The View From the Top Looks Good To Fassel
description: Jim Fassel stood beneath the grandstand at Giants Stadium today with the buoyant smile of a man who knows only good news. For the previous 24 hours, that was all he had heard.

title: Brooklyn Gunfight Kills One and Injures 2
description: A gunfight in the Red Hook housing projects in Brooklyn last night left one man dead, one critically injured and one wounded, the police said. The shootings appeared to be drug-related, they said.

title: Getting a Lock on Michigan Voters, List by List
description: Blame it on Mark Grebner.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article yesterday about television shows and films that have depicted the presidency misstated a story element from ''Seven Days in May.'' In that 1964 film, a plot to take over the White House is ultimately thwarted; the president is not overthrown.

title: TURNSTONE SHARES TAKE SHARP DROP
description: Shares of Turnstone Systems plummeted Monday, after the telecommunications company lowered its fourth-quarter revenue guidance, citing intensified weakness in the competitive local exchange carrier sector and reduced capital spending. The stock closed at $10.38 on the Nasdaq Stock Market, down $19.13, or 64.8 percent. The previous low of $16 was hit last month. Turnstone, based in Mountain View, Calif, reported $27.5 million of earnings on $132.9 million of revenue for the last 12 months. The company sliced its revenue guidance for the fourth quarter to about $38 million.

title: A New You!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FABIAN, DOROTHY R., ED.D.
description: FABIAN-Dorothy R., Ed.D., 77, November 3. Gerontologist, author, & consultant. She is survived by her sister Ruth Finkel, two sons Timothy Fabian and Jonathan Fabian, & three grandchildren. Contributions Hospital for Joint Diseases in lieu of flowers.

title: Tax Breaks for the Rich? Sure, for Philanthropy
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn School Mourns Teacher Who Was Fatally Stabbed
description: A Brooklyn junior high school was in mourning yesterday, shocked by the news that a dedicated and beloved teacher had been killed over the weekend in her apartment.

title: New Clashes In West Bank And Gaza Put Israel on Edge
description: Clashes between Palestinian protesters and Israeli forces continued today with a 14-year-old Palestinian boy shot dead in the northern West Bank town of Tulkarm and a 17-year-old Palestinian shot dead by troops in the Gaza Strip.

title: Single Mothers, Working
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Thursday, about the acquisition of Time Warner by America Online, misstated the middle initial of the chairman of Time Warner. He is Gerald M. Levin, not R.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNT, REV. MICHAEL J.
description: HUNT-Rev. Michael J. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the Pastor Emeritus of Saint Frances de Chantal Church at 1273 58th Street, Brooklyn, on November 4, 2000. Reposing in Aievoli Funeral Home, 1275 65th Street, Brooklyn, on Tuesday November 7, 2000 from 2-4:30 P.M. Mass of Transferral in Saint Frances de Chantal Church at 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass on Wednesday November 8, 2000 at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of The Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily, Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Flu Shot Delays Reported for Many Who Are at Risk
description: Most years by this time, doctors would be almost finished inoculating the elderly and other vulnerable patients against the flu. This year the vaccine was delayed by manufacturing problems, and many doctors and hospitals, even those serving AIDS patients and others particularly vulnerable to flu, have only just begun.

title: EXFO TO ACQUIRE A RIVAL, BURLEIGH INSTRUMENTS
description: Exfo Electro-Optical Engineering, a Canadian maker of fiber optic testing equipment, agreed to buy Burleigh Instruments, a rival, for $40 million in cash and $235 million in stock. Burleigh, based in Fishers, N.Y., supplies optical wavelength meters and other instruments and is closely held. Exfo, based in Quebec, said it would continue to buy rivals as part of a strategy to consolidate the optical test equipment industry and double manufacturing capacity in the next 18 months. The acquisition is subject to renegotiation if Exfo stock drops 10 percent from the closing price of $38.13 on Oct. 31, and it requires regulatory approval.

title: ASHANTI'S HEDGE BOOK PROFITABLE
description: Ashanti Goldfields said it could now reduce its reliance on forward sales because transactions in its hedge book, which reflects such sales, could now be canceled at a profit. At one point last year, the Ashanti Goldfields' wrong-way bets on price movements, reflected in its hedge book, threatened to cost it about $550 million. Ashanti Goldfields also said its production costs had declined 13 percent, to $254 an ounce, and output rose 18 percent in the latest quarter.

title: CIVIL JUDGMENT AGAINST MICROSOFT
description: A federal judge in Connecticut issued a final judgment yesterday in a private antitrust suit against Microsoft brought by Bristol Technologies, ruling that Microsoft must pay $3.7 million of Bristol's legal expenses. The case centered on a ''software bridge'' that Bristol had developed to ease the creation of programs that could run on both the Unix operating system and Microsoft's industrial-strength counterpart, Windows NT. Bristol accused Microsoft of unfair business dealings. Microsoft is considering an appeal, and Bristol says it plans to ask for a new trial. John Markoff (NYT)

title: ROHM & HAAS DISCUSSING AN ALLIANCE FOR ITS SALT UNIT
description: Rohm & Haas, a specialty chemicals maker, and US Salt Holdings are discussing an alliance of their North American salt units, talks that analysts said could lead to Rohm & Haas's selling its Morton Salt business. A spokeswoman for Rohm & Haas said US Salt, which is closely held and based in Jacksonville, Fla., approached Rohm & Haas, whose Chicago-based salt unit is expected to have sales of $650 million this year. Rohm & Haas bought the salt and chemicals maker Morton International in June 1999 for $5.5 billion, and sold its European salt operations for $270 million in July.

title: Publisher Set to Split E-Book Revenue
description: Hoping to settle a publishing industry dispute, Random House, the largest English language publisher, is expected to announce today that it will evenly split its electronic book sales revenue with writers.

title: A Century Sweeps By, Pulsating
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has started a series in which it puts one of its players in the spotlight, and on Sunday the honoree was the violinist Cho-Liang Lin. Mr. Lin invited four colleagues to join him, with only one -- Gary Hoffman, the cellist -- from the society. The program was rooted in the 20th century: the earliest work was the Ravel Sonata for Violin and Cello from the early 1920's, and the latest was Bright Sheng's Four Movements for Piano Trio from 1990.

title: What Voters Know Early Won't Hurt
description: It will begin sometime during lunch today. At tony restaurants in New York and Washington, cell phones will begin to trill.

title: Republicans in Texas Count Chickens in Glee
description: Bill Miller is a lobbyist and political strategist who manages to keep a finger in just about every pie in this capital city. So in the last days of the presidential race, he has done some informal polling, whether chatting up his barber or his dentist, or gauging the buzz of the political and lobbying class.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Debating Reach of Arbitration Law in Workplace
description: The question of whether employers can require workers to give up their right to a day in court was before the Supreme Court today, but the justices were not debating whether mandatory arbitration of workplace disputes was efficient or fair.

title: The Capital Case Against Carruth
description: It has been two weeks since the murder trial of Rae Carruth, the former Panthers wide receiver, began in Charlotte, N.C., and the prosecution and the defense have not finished choosing a jury. Even though the two sides have yet to make their opening arguments, the outlines of their cases have begun to emerge.

title: In the Hawkins Mode, Serious but Unforced
description: Wellspring Project

title: Classicists Contrasted With Modern Spaniards
description: Alicia de Larrocha

title: State by State: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS

title: BRUNSWICK AND K2 TERMINATE TALKS ON SALE OF UNITS
description: The Brunswick Corporation and K2 Inc. said they terminated talks for K2 to buy Brunswick's outdoor-products businesses for $200 million. The two companies made separate announcements that discussions and letters of intent had been terminated. Neither gave an explanation. A spokeswoman for Brunswick, based in Lake Forest, Ill., still wants to sell its outdoor-products units, including Zebco fishing gear, Igloo coolers, MotorGuide fishing-boat motors, Hoppe's gun-cleaning solvents and other hunting accessories. K2, based in Los Angeles, makes skis under the K2 and Olin brands and other sporting equipment.

title: Kumchon Journal; Railroad Trip to Europe? Koreans Savor the Idea
description: More than a half century after the the rail line stopped operating, Kim Yeon Wha still has strong memories of the train that used to run through this modest trading town on its way north, to Pyongyang and to China beyond -- but the recollections don't come from riding on it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOR, PAUL J. JR.
description: CONNOR-Paul J. Jr. Former executive director of the Church Charity Foundation of Long Island for 23 years passed away on Sunday, October 29, 2000. He is survived by his son Paul and his daughters Claudia and Christine. Mr. Connor lived in Teaneck, NJ. Services November 9 at The Cathedral Of The Incarnation in Garden City, NY at 1:30pm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAULKINS, DIXIE
description: CAULKINS-Dixie. The Women's Board of The Boys' Club of New York mourns the death of our colleague and friend Mrs. Dixie Platt Caulkins of Hobe Sound. A former president and one of the founders of The Women's Board, Mrs. Caulkins a woman of vision and generosity, worked tirelessly to help improve the lives of inner city boys. She will long be remembered with great affection.

title: Another Option on Deafness
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurer Says Results Rose Almost 14%
description: The St. Paul Companies said today that its third-quarter earnings rose nearly 14 percent, driven by rising insurance rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARINO, ROMEO V.
description: MARINO-Romeo V. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of Romeo V. Marino, beloved father of our Trustee Ronald J. Marino. We extend our deepest sympathies to his entire family. Herman Badillo, Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

title: Sea of Merriment, With Audience in Tow
description: A high-powered performance by Hubbard Street Dance Chicago inspired enthusiastic applause tonight at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. It even prompted some theatergoers to get up and dance on stage along with the cast.

title: Who Is Fat? It Depends on Culture
description: Back in the bad, sad days when he weighed nearly 350 pounds, Cedric Williams refused to let people take his picture, so he won't show up in one of those grainy, before-and-after diet ads any time soon.

title: Voters Asked To Decipher And Weigh 2 Questions
description: Kevin Asadi, a law student here, admitted he knew little about the referendum on Tuesday's ballot calling for a state constitutional amendment to allow the names, addresses and photographs of sex offenders to be posted on the Internet.

title: Faulk Is Out: Opponents Grin and the Rams Bear It
description: His knee is the most watched in the National Football League. It is the knee of a most valuable player, the most dangerous weapon in the sport. The knee bone may be connected to the thighbone, but the knee of St. Louis running back Marshall Faulk is connected to much more.

title: Envoy to Acquire Leagas Delaney
description: The Envoy Communications Group in Toronto said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Leagas Delaney in London. The stock-and-cash deal was valued at up to $86 million.

title: Cell Phone or Pheromone? New Props for the Mating Game
description: ''Is that a cell phone you're taking out of your pocket? Well, then, I'm glad to see you!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WANGER, ROBERT C.
description: WANGER-Robert C., died in Nashua, NH on October 30, 2000. Husband of Diane (nee Mueller) Hoisel Wanger. There are no visiting hours. A Service of Remembrance will be held in Davis Funeral Home, One Lock St, Nashua, NH on Saturday afternoon at 2:00. Friends are invited. Those planning an expression of sympathy are asked to consider First Church of Christ, Scientist, 115 Concord St, Nashua, NH 03064. For further information, please call Davis Funeral Home, (603) 883-3401

title: Final Appeal in Senate Races
description: United States Senate campaigns that have besieged New York and New Jersey voters for almost two years with partisan rhetoric, record spending and enough twists for two soap operas roared through their closing hours yesterday with a barrage of TV commercials and a last hurrah by candidates on the stump.

title: Philippine House Panel Clears Impeachment of Estrada
description: MANILA  The impeachment complaint against President Joseph Estrada cleared the House Justice Committee in less than four hours Monday, and the stock market and Philippine currency soared in anticipation that he would resign or be removed.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS TO SELL GO
description: British Airways said it planned to sell Go, its discount airline subsidiary, and announced sharply higher profits. Net income for its fiscal second quarter, which ended Sept. 30, rose more than sixfold to $:192 million ($278 million), or 17.9 pence (25 cents) a share, from $:30 million ($43.5 million) for the period a year earlier, when the company was on its way to its first annual loss. Revenue rose 5.8 percent, to $:2.6 billion ($3.8 billion). Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-A14

title: Amalia Hernandez, 83; Led Ballet Folklorico de Mexico
description: Amalia Hernandez, the founder of the internationally successful Ballet Folklorico de Mexico, died on Saturday in Mexico City. She was 83.

title: Election Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBER, HARRY
description: LORBER-Harry of Lake Worth, Florida and W Hempstead, NY died November 5. Beloved husband of Beatrice, he will also be deeply missed by his children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, brother, sister and many other relatives and friends. An honors graduate of St John's Law School, Harry inspired his family with ideals of social justice and used his talents to benefit the community as Secretary Treasurer of Cake Bakers Union Local 51 and President of combined Locals 3 and 51. Recognized by Histadrut and AMPAL for his assistance to Israel, he also served as President of Old Westbury Country Club, and as Grand Master of the Tuscan Masonic Lodge. Funeral service 2pm, November 7 at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Del Ray Beach, Fl. Contributions may be sent to National Parkinson's Foundation.

title: Jackson Heights Journal; At Hub in Indian Area, Gold Is Always in Demand
description: The Goddess of Wealth hovered over 74th Street in Queens the other evening. It was, after all, her week to be worshiped, and everything -- spices, saris, scarves and milk sweets -- was selling like mad on a commercial strip that looks and smells like a bustling bazaar in downtown New Dehli.

title: Why They Avoid Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Covet Mussina But Have Backup Plan
description: It has been almost a decade since the Yankees snagged a big-time free agent away from another team in the middle of his career. They signed Danny Tartabull after the 1991 season, Jimmy Key after 1992, but had failed dalliances with Randy Johnson and Albert Belle two years ago.

title: VA LINUX WARNS OF BAD NEWS
description: Saying it failed to predict venture capitalists' distaste for Internet companies and a resulting decline in sales, VA Linux warned yesterday that it would post a bigger-than-expected loss and that its revenue would fall short of forecasts. Investors wasted no time in unloading the stock of the open-source software and server maker. Its shares finished down $12.63, or 42 percent, at $17.38, way, way off its all-time high of $320, set on its first day of trading in December.

title: A Latter-Day Angel Fragmenting His Motion
description: Cortez and Company

title: Becoming a Nurse: Two Views, 1900 and 2000
description: In May 1900, Mary Cadwalader Jones addressed the Associated Alumnae of Trained Nurses, a group representing graduates of the nation's fledgling schools of nursing. Though not a nurse herself, Ms. Jones was one of the early organizers of nursing education in the United States, and particularly in New York City. Though her recollections were grim, she could look with some satisfaction at the improvements she and other advocates of nurse training had accomplished and at the stereotypes about nurses that had been overcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINISCH, JEROME
description: REINISCH-Jerome, of Manalapan, NJ on October 26 at the age of 62. Jerry was one of the original members of the Peace Corps, serving from '62-'64 in Puerto Cabello, Venezuela, where he met his wife of 35 years, Gladys. Jerry was a graduate of Evander Childs High School and City College and studied Social Work at Columbia University. Jerry found his greatest joy, and took great pride, in his family, friends, and exploration. Jerry is survived by his wife, Gladys, son, David, daughters Nancy O'Toole and Courtney Reinisch, sister, Lee, nephew, Mark, three grandchildren, and many, many more who will miss him dearly.

title: Nurse in Malawi Wages War on AIDS and Apathy
description: A personal tragedy taught Catherine Phiri that people have more to lose under dictatorship than their civil and political rights.

title: Experts, Once Certain, Now Say Gore Is a Maybe
description: Political scientists who two months ago predicted victory for Vice President Al Gore acknowledged today that they were much less sure now. And they said it was not their thinking but the candidate's campaigning that had been wrong.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Microbe Invasion Route

title: Leonardo Benvenuti, 77, Writer Of Classic Italian Screenplays
description: Leonardo Benvenuti, who wrote some 200 film scripts, including classics like Sergio Leone's ''Once Upon a Time in America'' and Vittorio De Sica's ''Marriage, Italian Style,'' died on Friday in San Giacomo Hospital. He was 77.

title: Microprocessor Maker's Public Offering Raises $273 Million
description: The Transmeta Corporation will make its debut on the Nasdaq Tuesday with an initial public offering that raised $273 million today, in what some analysts are calling the tepid I.P.O. market's first sign of life in more than a month.

title: After Abortion Victory, Doctor's Troubles Persist
description: LeRoy Carhart seems to be an unlikely lightning rod.

title: Drug Shares Advance While Major Indexes End Mixed
description: Drug stocks rose yesterday as investors bet that George W. Bush would win the presidential election and pharmaceutical companies would escape new price restrictions.

title: Ikea Asks 6 Agencies To Vie for Account
description: Ikea in Plymouth Meeting, Pa., the home furnishings retailer, said yesterday that it had invited six agencies to participate in a review for its marketing communications account. Billings were estimated at $50 million to $60 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, TOBIAS (TOBY)
description: MOSS-Tobias (Toby). Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: Choices For the Election
