description: As they vote in schools, libraries and community halls across the country, Americans will be doing more than electing a new president and Congress. In some mysterious but highly ritualized way, Election Day also marks a familiar transition in our political process. With the selection of new officials, we move from a highly charged period of partisan debate toward a new season of unity, cooperation and accomplishment. At its most idealized, Election Day brings the voters a sense of unity with the presidential candidates. The candidates fresh from the trail and the voters entering their millions of voting booths are joined in the quadrennial enterprise by which the shining Republic renews its strength.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: CONNECTICUT

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUSSO, VITO A.
description: RUSSO-Vito A. 1946-1990. With love and gratitude for your exemplary life. Bill Johnso

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, JACK
description: STEIN-Jack. The principals and staff of Jacoby Associates mourn the loss of Jack Stein who has been affiliated with our agency since 1956. Our sympathies to his wife Joyce, his son Ron, his daughter Linda and their families. His memory will long endure.

title: In His Own Words
description: AL GORE

title: Tax Breaks for the Rich? Sure, for Philanthropy
description: To the Editor:

title: With Time Running Out, Rutgers Coach Carries On
description: Coach Terry Shea resumed a job yesterday that he knows will last only three more weeks, but he tried to sound as gung-ho as ever.

title: New Job Pipeline: Booth to the Dugout
description: Jim Kaat has rarely considered trading in his life as a baseball announcer for a job as a major league manager. He might have done it as a younger man, but he would have preferred to apprentice in the minor leagues. But now, at age 62? Turn in a life of relative leisure where he doesn't have to call every Yankee game for the MSG Network for one of full-time worries?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMERSON, MARY E. (BETTE)
description: EMERSON-Mary E. (Bette) of McKinney, Texas passed away on November 5, 2000 in McKinnney. She was born February 2, 1910 in Binghamton, New York, to W. and Mamie (Neal) Ives. She married Tom Emerson. She was an opera singer for the New York Metropolitan Opera and a member of the St. Peters Episcopal Church in McKinney, Texas. She was preceded in death by her husband, Colonel Thomas Emerson who at the time of his retirement was vice-president and general sales manager of Eversharp Pen Company. Funeral services will be held at 2:00 PM, Wednesday, November 8 at the St. Peters Episcopal Church in McKinney, Texas with Father Chuck Treadwell officiating. Interment will follow at Ridgeview Memorial Park. Visitation will be from 6:30 to 8:30 PM Tuesday at Turrentine - Jackson - Morrow Funeral Home. For information, call 972-542-2601. Donations may be made to St. Peters Episcopal Church Memorial Fund, 608 West Lamar St, McKinney, TX 75069.

title: Some Big-Band Variations And an Outburst of Faith
description: Sam Rivers and Eric Reed both made joyful noise on Saturday at Alice Tully Hall in a concert featuring music commissioned by Jazz at Lincoln Center. Mr. Rivers, playing saxophones and flute, led the Studio RivBea Orchestra, making dissonance sound like overflowing euphoria. Mr. Reed, a pianist who grew up playing gospel in his father's Baptist church, brought a new suite that merged intricate jazz with straightforward gospel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIS, DONALD J. GEORGE COTZIAS
description: REIS-Donald J. George Cotzias, Distinguished Professor of Neurology & Neuroscience, Cornell Medical Center, Laboratory of Neurobiology. A terrific boss with an odd sense of humor, a huge imagination for what might be possible, a kindness for deviant talents, and a love for Cole Porter. Thank you, Don. Dr. R. D. Landres Plastic Surgery Albert Enstein College of Medicine/Montefiore Medical Center

title: MANUAL FOR FOOLING INSPECTORS
description: Nissan Motor of Japan gave its employees a manual telling workers to ''put away secret materials'' when government officials held surprise inspections, and ''to switch the computer screen to the one designed for inspection,'' an article in Yomiuri Shimbun reported. Nissan said the instructions were meant to apply only to materials that had not been completed and approved by a supervisor. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Group Reports Genetic Corn in European Food
description: A variety of genetically modified corn not approved in Europe for any use has been found in food in two European countries, an environmental group said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINSLEY, GERTRUDE
description: PINSLEY-Gertrude. Mother of the late Robert Pinsley, November 5, 2000. A teacher in the New York school system for 40 years; survived by brother Dr. Jacob Melnick, nephews Arthur Melnick and Laurence Melnick and niece Judith Brickman.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Little to Cheer About For Public Shareholders
description: Northwest Airlines is getting its cash and keeping the power to prevent a competitor from taking over Continental Airlines. The vast majority of Continental shareholders are seeing their ownership of the company seriously diluted -- and are being given no say about what is happening to them.

title: On and Off The 'Best' Patient List
description: The first thing my patient Debra did when she got out of prison was change her name. She then went on systematically to change every single other thing about herself that she could. Now, six years later, there is not a trace of the old drug-using, prostituting, generally messed-up Debra in the whirlwind of achievement she has become.

title: Sprewell Has Chat With League Over Webber
description: Latrell Sprewell was more than willing to awaken early this morning and maneuver through rush-hour traffic for a 9 o'clock meeting at the National Basketball Association's office in Manhattan. In fact, the get-together was Sprewell's idea.

title: Maligned Hunters
description: To the Editor:

title: Cisco Sales Rise 66%, as Profits Exceed Expectations
description: Cisco Systems reported a 66 percent gain in sales for its fiscal first quarter today, as the company continued its torrid growth as the leading supplier of equipment for the architecture of the Internet. It was the company's 11th consecutive quarter of accelerating year-over-year revenue growth, despite some analysts' concerns that overall growth in the telecommunications hardware business may be starting to slow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYEN, PAUL
description: MAYEN-Paul. Died on November 3, 2000. Noted Architect and Industrial designer, founder of Habitat, Intrex and Architectural Supplements, Inc. Designer of the Visitor's Center at Frank Lloyd Wright's Fallingwater. Many of his works are in the permanent collection at the Museum of Modern Art. A passionate gardener, he was as witty in his designs as he was in conversation, and as an art collector, he was both avid and adroit. At ease in all situations, social and intellectual, he was as widely loved for his humor and rousing spirit, as for his compasssion and humanity. No funeral is planned, but a celebration of his life will be held in his New York gardens in the spring. Contributions in Paul's memory may be made to Western Pennsylvania Conservancy for Fallingwater, Box R, Route 381 South, Mill Run, PA 15464

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Central Bank Intervention Fails to End Slide in Euro

title: Finding a Message in 'Gobbledygook'
description: There has been a movement among young ensembles, particularly contemporary music groups, to escape the sit-down-and-play nature of conventional concerts.

title: Different Viewpoints, in Counterpoint
description: The string quartet recital is one of the most fixed of musical forms: programs virtually have to consist of three works, or possibly two, with Viennese classics predominating before intermission and later works after. On Wednesday at the 92nd Street Y, though, the Tokyo Quartet broke the mold and then turned the pieces upside down. In the first half of their program the musicians played the four movements by Mendelssohn that were published as his Op. 81, and, so as not to pretend that these movements belong together, they interspersed them with items by Schubert, Webern and Gyorgy Kurtag. Then in the second half came the classics: Mozart and Beethoven, both represented by fugues -- the Adagio and Fugue in C minor and the ''Grosse Fuge.''

title: Reed High On Mets, Even After Low Offer
description: Rick Reed is confident he will come back to the Mets. The 35-year-old right-hander wants to stay, and he is the only Mets player eligible for free agency who has not filed.

title: Markings Failed to Distinguish Fatal Runway : Pilots Have Long Faulted Taipei Airport's Hazard
description: SINGAPORE  For years pilots flying into Taiwan had complained about lighting and markings on the airstrip at Chaing Kai Shek Airport where a Singapore Airways jumbo jet crashed a week ago, killing or injuring all but 40 of the 179 people on board, according to two pilots familiar with the airport.

title: Busy Day for the Winners, While the Rest Simply Rest
description: By most accounts, Sunday's 31st edition of the New York City Marathon was a success:

title: Death at a Nursing Home Leads to Indictment of 5
description: Five registered nurses have been indicted on charges including falsifying documents in connection with the death of a 97-year-old patient and other incidents at a Nassau County nursing home, it was disclosed today.

title: True North weighs options, including layoffs, sale or merger, after losing Chrysler account.
description: TOP executives of True North Communications in Chicago are outlining a series of aggressive steps to counter the impending departure of their largest client, the Chrysler Group.

title: Neighboring Officials Quiz Ikea on a New Rochelle Store
description: They had invited Ikea to their meeting, after all, but grim town and village officials for Mamaroneck and Larchmont hardly seemed happy to see the company, or its proposal to build a superstore in neighboring New Rochelle.

title: What Becomes a Legend Most? Three Plays?
description: It must have seemed like a good idea. Why else would would theatergoers be faced this season with three plays about Tallulah Bankhead (1903-1968), the actress who comes attached to the adjective legendary?

title: Lazio and Clinton, Both Upbeat, Rally Troops on Last Day; First Lady Stresses Issues, From Upstate to Midtown
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton closed out her 16-month quest for elective office last night at a boisterous rally in a union hall in Midtown Manhattan, saying the outcome of her bid for the United States Senate should be determined by the issues, not the name-calling that dominated the final weeks of the campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NORWICK, DOUGLAS J.
description: NORWICK-Douglas J. Your star shines brightly and your spirit dances on in the hearts of those you touched. Always love. Herbert J. Baker

title: 25 Years Later, Vietnamese Still Flock to the U.S.
description: ''This present emergency should not last,'' said the top refugee official at the United Nations as desperate people jammed onto helicopters and small boats to flee the Communist victory in Vietnam 25 years ago.

title: Armoring Vietnam's Road Warriors
description: For more than a decade, Greig Craft has lived the rare joys and frequent sorrows of an American doing business in Vietnam. After toiling since 1996 to build an iron mill -- a project that still exists only in blueprints -- Mr. Craft might have been entitled to throw up his hands.

title: Taming the Chinese Hinterland; Beijing Tries to Lift Economic Standards in Its West
description: It was an eerily colonial moment: over the tinkling of wine glasses and the melodic hum of violins in a chandeliered hall here in mountain-ringed Sichuan Province, 300 Western business executives and nearly as many Chinese officials drank not long ago to China's great western development.

title: Critics Say New Highway Safety Law Is Seriously Flawed
description: President Clinton signed a bill last week that he says will remedy ''some of the key shortcomings in identifying the recent Firestone tire problem.'' Although the legislation is expected to increase highway safety, auto safety experts see severe limitations in it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMKIN, IDA MARDER
description: SOMKIN-Ida Marder. On November 5, 2000, nine days shy of her 94th birthday. Resident of East Hampton and formerly of New York City. An artist, wife and mother with the rare gift of causing people to fall in love with her on first meeting. She is survived by her husband, Eugene, her twin sons, Anthony and Steven, and by hundreds of paintings, some of them considered masterpieces. A private memorial will be held.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the growing wave of shutdowns of Internet companies misspelled the name of a Web site whose chief executive is Marleen McDaniel, a board member of one failed company, Eve.com. The site is Women.com, not Woman.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRYMAN, DORIS L.
description: BERRYMAN-Doris L. 74. Educator and leader in the field of recreation and leisure services. Died at her home in NYC on November 3, 2000, of pancreatic cancer. As a Professor at New York University from 1973 to 1997 and as a Professor Emertius until her death, she taught hundreds of students, mentored an international cadre of doctoral candidates, conducted numerous research and training projects, and served as a consultant to leisure recreation and health related service delivery institutions at home and abroad. She was an elected member of the Academy of Leisure Sciences and was the recipient of numerous recognition, research and service awards from professional organizations, honorary societies and service organizations. She received a bachelor's degree from Denver University, a master's from Teachers College, Columbia University and a doctorate from the School of Education, New York University. Before joining the faculty of NYU, she served as Director of Recreation for children and adults at Memorial Sloan Kettering, as a member of the field staff of the National Recreation Association and as Associate Director of Comeback, Inc. She was a pioneer in the establishment and enhancement of recreation services for persons with special needs in hospitals, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, vocational rehabilitation centers, sheltered workshops, and public recreation departments, and in the elimination of architectural and social barriers to recreation services for all. She was an active member of World Leisure & Recreation Assn, the National Recreation and Park Assn, the National Therapeutic Recreation Society, the Society of Park & Recreation Educators, the American Educational Research Assn, the American Assn for Higher Education, the NYS Recreation and Park Society, the NYS Therapeutic Recreation Assn, Metropolitan Recreation & Park Society, Pi Lambda Theta Phi Delta Kappa. She was a regular workshop leader and presented at professional conferences and training workshops in the United States, Canada, Bermuda, Brazil, Spain, France, the Netherlands, Israel, Korea, Taiwan, as well as locally and regionally. She will be remembered by her many friends, colleagues and former students as a model professional, educator, and nurturer, and for her intellectual curiosity, indomitable spirit, elegance, generosity, playfulness, concern for the environment, and love of theater and the arts.She is survived by her longtime companion, Claudette B. Lefebvre

title: David Brower, an Aggressive Champion Of U.S. Environmentalism, Is Dead at 88
description: David Brower, an uncompromising environmentalist who spent more than half a century fighting to protect America's wilderness areas against speculators, developers, state agencies and the federal government, died on Sunday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RIEBER
description: RIEBER-On this, Martin Rieber's birthday, our family wishes to express our sincere thanks to each and every one who has touched his life-especially to our friends who have stood by us during the most difficult of times. Ruth B. Rieber and Family

title: A Collection Illuminates an Arbiter of Modernism
description: When it comes to American art-world myths, there's nothing quite like that of Clement Greenberg, the critic who ruled the New York roost in the 1940's and early 50's. During these years his imperious writing style, sharp eye, streamlined vision of history and belligerent personality created an aura of infallibility that made him feared and resented as well as admired.

title: Drugs Pulled From Shelves
description: The Consumer Healthcare Products Association says these products contain phenylpropanolamine, or PPA, the chemical that the F.D.A. is planning to ban because it can increase the risk of stroke among young women. The chemical is also in similar products marketed by many drug store and supermarket chains as house brands.

title: Campaign Ends; Now the Voters Will Have Their Say
description: Focused to the end on his message, Vice President Al Gore persevered Monday through a 30-hour, seven-city assault on the closely contested states that will determine whether his 13-year pursuit of the presidency culminates in a ''cold driving rain'' or a ''shaft of golden sunlight.''

title: Gore Reminder to Voters: Every Voice Does Matter
description: So he's not swaggering, like some. Rather, Al Gore is determined. He is focused. He doesn't care whether his coffee is caffeinated -- ''decaf or real coffee, either one,'' he told an aide on Monday in Dearborn as he prepared for yet another round of satellite interviews with TV stations in Florida, West Virginia, Tennessee, Iowa and Maine, down-to-the-wire battlegrounds all.

title: 2 Airlines Make Deal in Attempt to End Their Antitrust Trial
description: Days into what was shaping up as a nasty antitrust trial, Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines announced a tentative settlement yesterday in which Continental will buy back the controlling stake held by Northwest for $450 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNTER, TOM
description: HUNTER-Tom. 67 years old. Entered into eternal rest on Monday November 6th. Beloved husband of the late Pat Hunter (nee McGowan). Loving father of Joanne Currey, Kathleen M. Hunter-Steck, Alison Hunter, and the late SusanHunter-Tocci. Dear father-in-law of Jim Currey, Drew Steck, Scott Lief, and Mark Tocci. Adored grandfather of Jamie, Ashley, Matthew Currey, and Jason Hunter-Lief. Dearest brother of Bob, and the late Joseph and Jeanne Hunter. The family will receive their relatives and friends this evening from 7-9 PM and Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave Ridgewood, NJ (201) 444-7650) A Funeral Mass will be celebrated Thursday 11:00 AM at The Church of the Presentation, 271 W. Saddle River Rd, Upper Saddle River, NJ. Interment to follow at Ascension Cemetery, Monsey, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Renew International, 1232 George Street, Plainfield, NJ 07062.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTELLA, GREGORY
description: ROTELLA-Gregory. Died on November 3, 2000 at his home in Short Hills NJ following a lengthy illness. He was 51. Mr. Rotella was an executive at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York City for more than thirty years, where he rose from a management trainee position to become a senior vice president with responsibility for branch banking, small business, middle market and investments. A lifelong resident of New Jersey, Mr. Rotella was born and spent his childhood years in Jersey City. He earned a Bachelors degree from St Peter's College in Jersey City, and later taught there as an adjunct professor. He also held an MBA degree from Fordham University. Mr. Rotella's affiliations included board appointments to several professional and community organizations, including the Robert Morris Associates, New York Sports Commission, New York Inner City Games, and the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital. Mr. Rotella was an active member of the Canoe Brook County Club in Summit, NJ. He is survived by his wife, Kathie, their two children, Jennifer and Matthew, and father Albert. Viewing will be from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm on Tuesday, November 7 at Smith and Smith Funeral Home in Springfield, NJ. A funeral Mass will be at 10am Wednesday, November 8th. at St.Rose of Lima in Short Hills. Interment will be in St. Theresa's Mausoleum Chapel in Summit.

title: On Election Day, a Search for Some Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Baroness Ryder, 77, Charity Organizer, Dies
description: Baroness Ryder of Warsaw, whose deep sense of obligation to others and passion for charity work led her to build an international network of homes and treatment centers for the sick and disabled, died on Thursday at West Suffolk Hospital in Bury St. Edmunds, England. She was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ROSE
description: COHEN-Rose. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of our beloved matriarch who will long be remembered by our congregation. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family. Israel Wohlgelernter, Rabbi

title: Studying Makeup of Miniplanets Beyond Pluto
description: At the mysterious and poorly understood outer reaches of the solar system, what is not seen is telling astronomers almost as much as what is seen.

title: LEAP WIRELESS TO BUY 30 LICENSES FROM CENTURYTEL
description: Leap Wireless International agreed to acquire 30 operating licenses covering seven million potential customers in five states from CenturyTel for $205 million. Covered markets include Fort Wayne, Ind.; Duluth, Minn., and several metropolitan areas in Michigan. Leap, based in San Diego, said it had also reached agreements with various parties to acquire licenses covering an additional population of up to four million in small Northeastern and Midwestern cities like Utica, N.Y., and Peoria, Ill., but did not disclose terms. Altogether, the acquisitions will increase Leap's covered population by about 20 percent.

title: Marathon of Childbirth
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Androids Dream? M.I.T. Working on It
description: Dr. Anne Foerst, 34, a researcher at the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the director of M.I.T.'s God and Computers project, apologized on a recent afternoon that a certain robot named Kismet wouldn't be joining our interview.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Standing Up To Be Counted

title: Jets Take First Step Down As Going Could Get Steep
description: After the ball had dribbled about four inches in front of Richie Anderson on Sunday, and the game was lost, Jets quarterback Vinny Testaverde walked off the field, grabbing his head with both hands, as if trying to grab his reeling mind and steady it.

title: Nature of Job Changes For the Next Speaker
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democrat who would be speaker, has relentlessly skewered Republicans, and at a caucus meeting last month even painted his face blue, like Mel Gibson in ''Braveheart,'' to gird his colleagues for battle.

title: EUROPEANS SUING BIG TOBACCO IN U.S.
description: The European Commission said today that it had filed a civil lawsuit in the United States against the Philip Morris Company and the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company seeking damages for what it called their involvement with organized crime in smuggling cigarettes into Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABARBERA, PRISCILLA
description: LaBARBERA-Priscilla. We deeply mourn the loss of Priscilla LaBarbera, Professor of Marketing and Teaching Excellence Professor at New York University Stern School of Business who passed away Novemeber 3, 2000 following a long and valiant struggle with cancer. Born and raised in Queens, N.Y., Professor LaBarbera graduated from the City University of New York in 1972, serving as valedictorian of her class. She earned her MBA and PhD degrees from Michigan State University, graduating with honors. Priscilla joined the Stern School as Assistant Professor of Marketing in 1976. During her academic career she also held positions at the White House Office of Consumer Affairs and in the private sector. She was the recipient of many honors and awards for scholarship and service, including the Distinguished Teaching Medal from New York University. Her scholarly work on advertising response measurement and industry self-regulation has had a great impact on the way advertising agencies operate today. She has left the lives of those who knew her richer for her presence. Her energy, enthusiasm and boundless optimism served as a source of inspiration for all of her colleagues and students. Her commitment to community service and to those in need formed an integral part of her life. The memory of the nobility of her spirit will long give strength to all of those whose lives she touched, especially the generations of Stern students she taught, mentored and cherished. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family, especially her mother and her loving husband and devoted friend Dr. Robert Blake. Visitation for Professor LaBarbera will continue on Tuesday at the Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleeker St., from 2pm-5pm and 79:30pm. Funeral Mass is Wednesday, 9:30am at St. Anthony's Church, Sullivan and Houston. A Memorial Service will be held at the Stern School later this year.

title: Columnist Critical of Beijing Quits Hong Kong Newspaper
description: Willy Wo-Lap Lam works in a newsroom in Hong Kong, but his column delves into the inner sanctum of the Chinese Communist Party. That combination, ticklish in the best of times, proved combustible today as Mr. Lam and his newspaper parted company.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COTTON RISES. Cotton rose on speculation that snow forecast for the Texas panhandle might further damage a crop already hurt by drought. In New York, cotton for December delivery rose 1.61 cents, to 65.36 cents a pound.

title: CHINA STEEL I.P.O.
description: After months of delays, Baoshan Iron and Steel of China set the share price range for its initial offering at 3.50 to 4.18 yuan (42 to 50 cents). The offering, which could raise up to $1.9 billion, would be the largest yet on Chinese stock exchanges. Baoshan shares will be listed in Shanghai. Craig Smith (NYT)

title: DIAMOND MINE TAKEOVER
description: Rio Tinto won its takeover battle for Ashton Mining, giving it full control of the Argyle diamond mine, the world's largest. When Rio Tinto's sweetened bid of $375 million won approval from Malaysia Mining, which owns 49.7 percent of Ashton, the rival bidder, De Beers Consolidated Mines, acknowledged defeat. Regulatory delays in Australia and Belgium had hampered De Beers's $392 million bid.

title: HACKING SUSPECT CASE ADVANCES
description: A Montreal judge yesterday scheduled a December court hearing for a 16-year-old boy accused of sabotaging prominent Web sites like Yahoo, Amazon, eBay and Dell. The suspect, who cannot be publicly identified because of his age, is accused of hijacking computers at leading universities in the United States and then using them to attack popular Web sites. Robert Frank (NYT)

title: U.S. Picks Barbados Players
description: United States Coach Bruce Arena announced the selection of 19 players yesterday for the World Cup qualifying game Nov. 15 in Barbados. Fourteen of the 19 players are from Major League Soccer teams and five play in Europe. D.C. United leads the M.L.S. teams with four players, followed by three each from the MetroStars and the Chicago Fire.

title: On Election Day, a Search for Some Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: The Court's Clean Air Case
description: Having failed to persuade Congress on the issue, a coalition of industry groups will be in the Supreme Court today asking the justices to disrupt enforcement of the health-based pollution standards that have been a cornerstone of a quarter-century of progress under the Clean Air Act. How the court responds could have consequences not only for the air Americans breathe, but also for the balance of power between the federal legislative and judicial branches, as well as the functioning of the modern regulatory apparatus.

title: Metro Business Briefing; A BIG BOX ON THE EAST SIDE
description: The Upper East Side's taboo on big-box shopping has been broken. Bed Bath & Beyond, which specializes in linens and home furnishings, has opened a 90,000-square-foot store in Bridge Tower Place, a new residential building at 61st Street and First Avenue. It is the second outlet in Manhattan for Bed Bath & Beyond, a 29-year-old company, and the first of its 295 stores to occupy three floors, company officials said. The new store will be tailored to the local market and will offer same-day delivery, said Steven H. Temares, the president and chief operating officer. A few years ago, the neighborhood successfully blocked Toys ''R'' Us from opening a superstore on Third Avenue and 80th Street. This time, however, construction of the Bed Bath store had already begun before people realized that nearly all of the retail space at Bridge Tower would be taken up by one store, said M. Barry Schneider, the chairman of Community Board 8. Terry Pristin

title: A Race in Which Candidates Clung to the Center
description: For all their efforts to differentiate their personalities and positions, Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore shared an approach that might become a model for future presidential candidates: they steered their campaigns toward the absolute center of American politics.

title: Tunnel Vision; Some Bookworms Yearn For Longer Commute
description: Other than taking people where they need to be, the subway is generally of little use. There are, of course, those who spend their days and nights on it because it is more pleasant and less dangerous than where they live, others because it is where they live. And there are those who ride it because it comes with a captive audience, making it a highly effective place to sing songs, sell batteries and save souls.

title: HYUNDAI OWNER REJECTS SWAP
description: Chung Mong Hun, chairman of Hyundai Engineering and Construction, rejected a debt-for-equity-swap demand by creditor banks, opting to sell an unspecified amount of his shares in other units of the Hyundai Group to pay part of the South Korean construction concern's debt. Hyundai Engineering twice avoided bankruptcy last week after falling behind on debt payments. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Rangers' Hierarchy Knows Oilers From Both Sides
description: The meeting of Edmonton and Edmonton East will have a new twist when the Oilers visit the Rangers at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, the only time these teams will battle during the regular season.

title: BROADCOM PLANS TO BUY SIBYTE
description: As one of the few technology stocks still way up in triple digits, Broadcom continues to make hay while its sun shines. The company, which makes semiconductors for cable modems and other networks, flexed its buying-power muscles again yesterday, announcing plans to buy SiByte, a microprocessors designer, for about $2 billion in stock. Broadcom has bought 11 companies in the last year. The company's chief executive, Henry T. Nicholas III, said the acquisition would reduce earnings by 3 cents a share in each quarter of 2001, then add to profits in 2002. Wall Street reacted unusually mildly, and the stock closed down 1.5 percent, or $3.38, to $219. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: State Proposals Will Decide The Pace of Construction
description: Across the nation voters will decide today whether to enact anti-sprawl laws in hundreds of referendums that will show how far residents of fast-growing regions are willing to go to slow the pace of construction in the suburbs.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: New Jersey Senate Rivals Push Hard Amid Signs Race Is Narrowing; Franks, in Final Dash, Pins Hopes on an Upset
description: Hop-scotching furiously across the state with a coterie of prominent Republicans at his side, Representative Bob Franks ducked into diners, senior centers and sports bars today, shaking countless hands and selling himself as the little guy who has spent his entire political life fighting for other little guys.

title: On Election Day, a Search for Some Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: All the Dead Horses, Next Door; Bittersweet Memories of the City's Island of Garbage
description: It was a place of the discarded and the dead. There were no roads. There was said to be nothing green that could live. The smell could sicken at a distance of two miles. In the early years of the 20th century, the tiny island off the coast of Brooklyn was a nightmare: a dumping ground for most of the trash and animal carcasses of the teeming city.

title: Why They Avoid Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VARIAN MEDICAL SYSTEMS INC., Palo Alto, Calif., said its planned $135 million purchase of Impac Medical Systems Inc., Mountain View, Calif., drew a challenge from the United States Justice Department, which says the purchase would stifle competition for cancer treatment technology.

title: Polling Information
description: For polling place information, or to report problems at the polls, the New York Public Interest Research Group and Common Cause/NY will run a telephone help line: (212) 349-0352.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE RUNNING MATES

title: FURNITURE.COM CALLS IT QUITS
description: Furniture.com, whose Web site resembled a glossy catalog of its upscale home furnishings, shut down yesterday and laid off 76 of its remaining 88 employees. The company said it could not obtain enough cash to continue operations, despite reporting $22 million in net revenue between January and September this year. In June, Furniture.com, based in Framingham, Mass., received $27 million from investors, including CMGI @Ventures. Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: Nader, in Harlem, Attacks Gore and Bush With Gusto
description: To cheers of ''Tell it like it is!'' Ralph Nader, the Green Party presidential candidate, harshly attacked Vice President Al Gore yesterday in a Harlem speech in which he asserted there were few differences between Mr. Gore and his Republican opponent, Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GETTENBERG, GUSTAVE
description: GETTENBERG-Gustave. November 5, 2000. Beloved husband of Frieda. Dear brother-in-law of Jay Liben. Cherished uncle of Nina Kurzban and Lynn Liben. Services private. He will be deeply missed.

title: $190.8 Million Loss at Waste Management
description: Waste Management Inc., the largest trash hauler in North America, said today that it had a loss of $190.8 million in the third quarter after charges for asset sales and the costs of terminating a pension plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, BARBARA F. (CHIEFY)
description: HESS-Barbara F. (Chiefy). On November 6 after a long and courageous battle at the age of 77. Beloved wife of ''Tommy'', loving mother of John Newburger, Susan Newburger Karchmer and her husband Michael Karchmer and Billy Straus and his wife Lynne Weinstein. Devoted step-mother of Peter Hess and Debra Kenyon, Tom Hess and Georgianna Dwight and Jill Hess and James Wollum. Adored grandmother of Ian and Emma Straus. Step-grandmother of Rachel and Sara Hess, Carly and Camey Hess and Allie and Jamie Wollum. The family will be receiving at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St, Wednesday, November 8, from 4:30-7:30PM. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell on Friday November 10 at 11:30AM followed by a reception at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 E. 66 St. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering, where Barbara served on the Ladies Board for many years or to Women in Need, 115 W. 31 St.

title: Ringing Phones, Chiming Doorbells, Stuffed E-Mailboxes: The Great Voter Roundup
description: The most extensive get-out-the-vote effort in history went into full swing today as the two major parties and their allies bombarded voters with phone calls, e-mail messages, urgent letters and personal visits, spending $100 million to eke out every possible advantage in what could be the closest election in decades.

title: S.E.C. Sets Date to Consider Auditing Rule
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it would meet on Nov. 15 to consider a rule that seeks to ensure the independence of auditors.

title: AVOCENT, NETWORK EQUIPMENT SUPPLIER, TO BUY EQUINOX
description: Avocent, a supplier of equipment for managing multiple computer networks, agreed yesterday to buy Equinox Systems for $57 million in cash. Equinox shareholders will receive $9.75 a share from Avocent, which is based in Huntsville, Ala. Equinox develops products and software for customers including Hewlett-Packard and International Business Machines. Avocent's equipment allows data center managers real-time access to computers over the Internet without adding special hardware or software, the company said. The acquisition needs the approval of Equinox shareholders and regulators. The companies expect to complete the purchase in the first quarter. Avocent was formed in June by the merger of Apex Inc. and the Cybex Computer Products Corporation; its shares fell $6.13, or 9.4 percent, to $58.75 in Nasdaq trading, while Equinox rose $2.31, or 33 percent, to $9.31.

title: In the Embrace Of Fashion, Hype Helps
description: At a cocktail party on the East Side one Wednesday in October, a fashion editor from a major magazine turned to the subject of politics with this inquiry: was the following Friday, she wondered, ''the day for the voting?'' The editor was not tipsy, nor had she just flown home from a two-year trip to Azerbaijan. She was set straight when the man next to her explained that Election Day, as ''the day for the voting'' is usually called, would occur this year as it had since the mid-19th century: on the Tuesday after the first Monday in November.

title: Easing Midtown Traffic
description: To the Editor:

title: Galileos Portrait of a Snowy Moon
description: Ever since the Voyager missions observed volcanoes popping off on Jupiter's moon Io in the 1970's, its pizza crust face has been a favorite target of wandering spacecraft. Last February the Galileo spacecraft zoomed to within 124 miles of Io and returned high-resolution images showing the moon's surface blanketed by a "snow" of sulfur dioxide and other chemicals from volcanic plumes. Scientists said they were puzzled at how the volatile material continued to be distributed across the moon rather than being lost to outer space.

title: Foreign Affairs; I Love D.C.
description: I realize this is a bit late, but I just have one last question for George W. Bush. Throughout this campaign the Texas governor has repeated the mantra that the government surplus is ''your money, it's not the government's money.'' Fine. But then whose money is the national debt?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I want you to understand that I can't win without you.''

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Robert M. Carroll, armorer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, gave a misspelled name in some copies for the curatorship held by Stuart W. Pyhrr, who heads the department where Mr. Carroll worked. He is the Arthur Ochs Sulzberger curator, not Sulzburger.

title: Q & A
description: Frogs' Tongues

title: CORNING SAYS EQUITY OFFERING WILL BE INCREASED
description: Corning said that because its underwriters had exercised an over-allotment option, its recent equity offering would grow from 30 million to 34.5 million shares, yielding $2.4 billion in net proceeds to the company. Underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs priced the offering at $71.25 a share on Friday. Proceeds from the offering are expected to be used to pay for Corning's acquisition of a 90 percent interest in Optical Technologies USA from Pirelli S.p.A., and for general corporate purposes.

title: Vatican Denies Pope Will Retire; Announces June Visit to Ukraine
description: The Vatican today denied a newspaper report asserting that John Paul II would retire this Christmas, and as if to prove its denial, announced that the 80-year-old pope would visit Ukraine in June.

title: INSIDE
description: Speaker Faces a Tough Task

title: Bush's Finishing Day Includes Tennessee and Arkansas
description: Nearly 17 months after he first issued his call for a ''fresh start after a season of cynicism,'' Gov. George W. Bush ended his quest for the presidency today on a nearly identical note, pledging to purge Washington of what he characterized as a crippling discord.

title: Yes, Candidates, There Is a Fuzzy Math
description: They've been at it for weeks: the presidential candidates accusing each other of using ''fuzzy math.'' George W. Bush first threw this dirty snowball in the debates, attacking Al Gore's analysis of the Bush budget plans. Mr. Gore threw it right back and kept throwing it. He even got audiences at campaign stops to shout ''fuzzy math!'' when he asked them to describe Mr. Bush's budget projections. Both candidates plainly use the term as the ultimate logical putdown.

title: Home-Bred Executives
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Risks But Letting It All Be Fun
description: The Academy of Ancient Music dates to the Jurassic times of period-style performance -- 1973 -- but lately has been discovering a new youth in concerts and recordings with the violinist Andrew Manze. On Thursday he and the group visited Alice Tully Hall for an evening of dashing music in which the players responded eagerly to Mr. Manze, their soloist-director, and to one another.

title: In Moscow, Lines of Unhappy Accountants Find Reform Elusive
description: In Russia, there is nothing that brings back bad memories like a line. Though most lines -- for shoes, bread and women's sweaters, for instance -- disappeared with the fall of Communism, they can still form in a flash when tax time comes.

title: Europeans Intervene, but Markets Don't Listen
description: Is Wim Duisenberg, leader of the European Central Bank, tilting at windmills? That was the question batted about yesterday after the European Central Bank bought euros for the second consecutive trading session in an effort to support the common currency.

title: From Curios And Chaos To London Street Cries
description: It takes a large measure of self-confidence for a performing group to assert its virtuosity in its name. But the New York Virtuoso Singers practice truth in advertising. The singers in this 16-voice chamber chorus, now in its 12th season under their founding conductor, Harold Rosenbaum, really are virtuosos. They would have to be, since they specialize in challenging contemporary music.

title: New Jersey Senate Rivals Push Hard Amid Signs Race Is Narrowing; Corzine Calls Campaign a 'Joyful Experience'
description: Jon S. Corzine wound down his multimillion-dollar quest for a United States Senate seat today with a frenetic 15-hour scramble for votes among workers, shoppers, commuters, students and churchgoers.

title: A Glimpse at the Alliances of Terror
description: As the destroyer Cole was being hauled around the Cape of Good Hope to its home port of Norfolk, Va., and amid the ruckus of the elections, a remarkable piece of intelligence dropped into the public's knowledge about international terrorism. It has drawn little notice yet, but it will likely cause the new administration to reassess American policy and search for a better formula for combating terrorism than launching a few cruise missiles at camps in Afghanistan or pharmaceutical plants in Sudan.

title: Car Slams Into Crowd at Bus Stop, Injuring at Least 27 People
description: After a man suffering from chest pains lost control of his car yesterday afternoon, the vehicle jumped a curb and sped wildly down a sidewalk before slamming into a crowd at a Queens bus stop, the police and witnesses said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSHENBAUM, HELEN
description: KIRSHENBAUM-Helen. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to Lester and David Kirshenbaum and families on the loss of their beloved mother. May they be comforted among those who mourn for Tzion and Yerushalayim. Joel Felderman, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: For 4 Women Of the Stage, Life Is Indeed A Cabaret
description: ''Fame Takes a Holiday,'' a cabaret act wrapped in a gossamer plot about a cabaret act, doesn't add much to the theatrical tradition of backstage comedy. But the show, which is about a four-woman comedy troupe called the High Heeled Women, actually happens to feature a reconstituted version of the 1980's comedy troupe known as the High Heeled Women. And their savvy femininity, with its celebration of both girlishness and womanliness and its affection for the female iconography of the mid-20th century, is difficult to resist.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, RUTH
description: MITCHELL-Ruth. We sadly join the theatre community in mourning the loss of a talented colleague and dear friend, and extend our condolences to Juliette, Jody and David Fleischer, Jessica Mitchell and Florence Klotz. Martin Richards, Sam Crothers and The Producer Circle Co.

title: Calling the Winners: How the Results Are Collected and Projected
description: Tonight, as on every election night, users of the Internet and viewers of television will see all sorts of projections and predictions, with various news organizations "calling" the winners of races at different times and in different ways. You may wonder why this happens and where the information comes from.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, WALTER
description: ROBINSON-Walter. On November 6, 2000. Beloved husband of Sondra. Adoring father of Amy Press and father-in-law of Lyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley and Emily. Brother of Sue. Dearest uncle of Alan, Edward, Ronald, and Kenneth. Funeral serivce at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. today at 10:00 AM. Donations in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Challenging Homework Stumps Parents, Too
description: Lysa Vanible is confident when she faces down tough criminals as a New York City police officer. But her confidence is shaken when she tries to help her fourth grader, Randi, with her math homework.

title: Jury Rejects Church Claims Over '95 Melee With Police
description: Five years after police officers and parishioners battled at an outdoor tent revival in Jamaica, Queens, a jury yesterday rejected claims for damages by church members who contended in a federal lawsuit that the officers had injured them, violated their civil rights and wrongly arrested them.

title: Philippine Panel Sends Impeachment Case to Full House
description: A Congressional committee in the Philippines sent an impeachment complaint today to the full House of Representatives, where more than enough members have said they will vote to remove President Joseph Estrada on charges of corruption.

title: Trial Reopens Pain of 1995 Bosnian Massacre
description: The Bosnian Serb general who is standing trial for Europe's worst mass killing since World War II looked pale and diminished in the courtroom, all the more so as he bent down, again and again, to rub the stump that was once his right leg.

title: Automaker On the Brink Of Failure
description: The Daewoo Motor Company, the ailing South Korean automaker, failed to pay 44 billion won ($39 million) of debt today, leaving the company just one day to avoid final bankruptcy and raising doubts about its possible sale to General Motors.

title: The Man Who Dared Make Religion the Villain; In British Author's Trilogy, Great Adventures Aren't Pegged to the Great Beyond
description: Six months ago, the British author Philip Pullman got a letter from a reader, along with a picture of a winsome little squirrel. ''I want you to admire this squirrel,'' the letter said. ''Now that you've admired the squirrel, please think about your book which the world has spent so long waiting for. Now, put those two things together. Finish your book, or the squirrel will die.''

title: FUND MANAGEMENT CONSOLIDATION
description: C. I. Fund Management offered 3.9 billion Canadian dollars ($2.5 billion), or 28.25 Canadian dollars ($18.44) a share, for Mackenzie Financial. The deal is the third and largest major merger of Canadian fund companies this year. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Sprewell Just Keeps Running
description: THE Fugitive turned himself in yesterday at 9 a.m., which is earlier than he prefers to be interrogated or get out of bed. The National Basketball Association did not have anything concrete on Dr. Richard Sprewell, but league officials brought him in for questioning at the Olympic Tower, ostensibly as part of their annual shakedown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEPPER, JEANETTE
description: PEPPER-Jeanette. Devoted wife of Julius for sixty-one years. Beloved mother of Allan and Barbara; Bill and Lori; Judi and Marty. Devoted grandmother of Leslie and Ben; Joshua; Adam and Tara; Robert, Daniel and the late David. Great-grandmother of Madeline and Jack. Sister of Irving and the late Herman. Services Wednesday, November 8, 1:00 PM, Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows.

title: In Early Experiments, Cells Repair Damaged Brains
description: Researchers meeting here this week are reporting startling results from experiments to repair damaged brains. They are telling of plucking immature cells out of recently fertilized eggs, fetuses, the skin on a human scalp or -- perhaps even more amazingly -- from the brains of people who had recently died, and growing those cells in a dish. Then they have transplanted the cells back into damaged animal brains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIAN, JACK
description: O'BRIAN-Jack. A long-time newspaper columnist, and radio talk show host in New York, died November 5, 2000 in Manhattan. He was 86 years old. In his nearly 60 years in journalism, Mr. O'Brian covered theatre, movies, radio, popular music and television at The Associated Press, The New York Journal American, and later on, WOR-AM. His humor and spirit and his love of music and the theatre will be missed by daughters, Bridget and Kate, and his beloved grandchildren, Emma and Lilly Haberl, and Jake and Sam Brimberg. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street, on Wednesday from 6 to 9 P.M. Funeral Mass will be held at Saint Agnes Church, 143 E. 43rd St. on Thursday at 10 A.M.

title: Thomas Campion, 84, Educator And Former Times Executive
description: Thomas Baird Campion, a former New York Times director of operations, campus administrator at the University of Massachusetts and innovative fund-raiser for Dartmouth College, died on Friday at his retirement home in Lebanon, N.H. He was 84 and formerly lived in Hanover, N.H., and Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Why They Avoid Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: ICN Is Looking Into Offer From a Suitor
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., a drug maker planning to split into three companies, told analysts on a conference call today that it had been contacted by unidentified companies interested in buying it. The company said it had hired an investment banker to weigh options.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIDMAN, HERMAN
description: WIDMAN-Herman. We mourn the passing of the father of our esteemed member Beverly Hochheimer and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck Yaacov Lerner, Rabbi Michael Frank, President

title: Florida Judge Upholds Jury's $145 Billion Punitive Award in Tobacco Trial
description: A Miami-Dade County circuit judge today upheld a jury's landmark award of $145 billion in punitive damages in a class action lawsuit brought by sick Florida smokers against the nation's largest cigarette makers.

title: More Than One Way to Seduce Male Innocents
description: Irina Dvorovenko, as a relentless and predatory Siren ensnaring a bewildered Jose Manuel Carreno in George Balanchine's ''Prodigal Son''; Robert Hill, as another seduced innocent, sweeping Amanda McKerrow into his arms and then being swept away another day by Julie Kent in the sexy bedroom duet from Kenneth MacMillan's ''Manon.''

title: Costly Sale Falls Below Phillips's Expectations
description: ''It's cheaper than buying Sotheby's,'' an art dealer said as she was leaving the American Craft Museum last night. ''I guess that's the price of entry.''

title: Rodriguez Market Close to Opening. Bring Money.
description: Unless Major League Baseball quickly changes the rules and allows 10 defensive players on the field at the same time, two of them shortstops, the Yankees do not figure to sign Alex Rodriguez, perhaps the most attractive free agent in 25 years of free agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MC DUFFEE, WILLIAM M.
description: Mc DUFFEE-William M. On November 4, 2000 at age ninety, formerly of Merrick, LI. Loving husband of the late Agnes and dear father of the late Joan. Devoted father of Donald, Mark, Gerald, Regis and Neal. Adoring grandfather of Donald, William, Helen K., Suzanne, Erin, Amy, Kevin, Kerry, Megan, Morgan, Dylan, Brendan, Elizabeth, Margaret, and great grandfather of Regan, Caitlyn and Kara. Visitation at N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 2039 Merrick Ave, Merrick, N.Y. on Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:45 am at Cure of Ars R.C. Church, Merrick, N.Y. An unforgettable guy of great spirit who will live through the memory of all who knew him.

title: Higher Energy Prices Raised 3rd-Quarter Results at BP
description: BP Amoco said today that third-quarter earnings doubled thanks to sharply higher oil and natural gas prices and cost savings.

title: Brandy With a Spanish Accent
description: SAY the word ''brandy,'' and chances are most people think of France, home of Cognac and Armagnac, the blazing stars of the brandy galaxy. Yet the brandies of Spain are almost as important, especially the constellation produced in the town of Jerez, best known as the home of sherry.

description: It started in 1994, when Tennessee Republicans elected a governor, two United States senators and a majority of the Congressional delegation. Last night, an inexorable trend reached its crest when Tennessee rejected its native son, Vice President Al Gore, giving its crucial 11 electoral votes to the Republican governor of Texas.

title: Buttermilk That Doesn't Go Plop-Plop
description: AS the recipe tester for the Dining section, I am always looking for new products because they can affect the results of what I cook. Recently, I found Saco Cultured Buttermilk Blend, a powder. I always have to run to the store for fresh buttermilk, but the label on the canister said the powdered version needed no refrigeration until opened; once opened, it has a shelf life of perhaps years under refrigeration.

title: Musta Been the Tabasco
description: At the end of the last television season it seemed as if ''Roswell,'' the WB dramatic series about alien teenagers on the run from the government, was set to crash like the U.F.O. that allegedly stranded its protagonists on Earth.

title: Lazio Voices Regrets Over Some Campaign Tactics and Concedes After Decisive Defeat
description: To the strains of ''New York, New York,'' Rick A. Lazio took the stage at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York last night, and, clutching his wife's hand, soaked up the last roars from supporters before acknowledging what everyone already knew.

title: Jack O'Brian, 86, Columnist Of the Entertainment World
description: Jack O'Brian, a longtime New York newspaper columnist who brought a breezy, peppery style to writing about television and Broadway gossip, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 86 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Salvadoran Cooking Celebrates Corn in All Its Guises
description: FOR centuries, corn stood at the center of the Central American universe, providing not only food but a symbol with a wealth of religious meanings. Today, corn may no longer serve the spiritual role it once did, but it is still the keystone of the Central American culinary universe, as is clear if you visit a Salvadoran restaurant like Bahia in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: A Star in Autumn: Potent, Magic Sage
description: SAGE is a typecast herb. Because it plays its supporting role with turkey so well, its big appearances are usually limited to the holidays.

title: From Grease to Gloss
description: MARTIN PARR has been photographing food for more than 20 years, and in a Midtown greasy spoon recently, he discussed the secrets of the trade. ''You have various sprays to put on it,'' Mr. Parr said. ''You photograph it half out of focus to be moody. Surround it with pastel colors.'' Beyond this, however, the details simply stopped. Mr. Parr, 48, is a lanky Englishman with pale green eyes and an aspect of amused detachment. ''I actually don't know how to do it,'' he said.

title: 'Sopranos' Makes Offer Several Schools Refuse
description: As with most gangster stories, this one is simple and dramatic, and the most interesting stuff happens backstage.

Gejdenson Upset as 5 Incumbents Prevail

title: Iraq Seeks Talks With U.N. Chief on Arms-Inspection Impasse
description: Iraq has asked for a meeting with Secretary General Kofi Annan to try to break the impasse over arms inspections in the country, United Nations officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Oct. 19 about new digital signal processor chips from Texas Instruments misstated the thickness of silicon wafers used in the chips. The wafers are 720 microns thick, not 0.15 microns thick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, ISAAC ''BILL''
description: RATNER-Isaac ''Bill''. Of Brooklyn. Died November 2, in his 94th year. His wife of over 60 years, Ida, died last year. He is survived by his brother, Arthur, & his sister, Gertrude, a nephew and three nieces. His humor and style made him one of a kind. He will be missed by family and friends.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Oct. 31 about the discovery of boats built for the earliest pharaohs omitted the identity of a director of the conservation work. Dr. Deborah Schorsch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art shares the role with Dr. Lawrence Becker of the Worcester Art Museum in Massachusetts.

title: Hacker Enters Guilty Plea
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7  A 20-year-old man has pleaded guilty to federal charges of infiltrating sensitive computer systems, including those at Stanford University and NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

title: Ex-Banker, Accountant Indicted in Insider Case
description: A former NationsBank executive and an accountant who was his friend were charged yesterday with insider trading in what prosecutors said was a three-year scheme that produced more than $1.2 million in illegal gains.

title: British Telecom Expected to Outline Revamping Plan
description: British Telecommunications is expected to separate its wholesale operations from its other business units as part of a long-awaited revamping plan, executives close to the company said today.

title: Graduate Students Disagree on a Union at N.Y.U.
description: Jonna Perrillo is one of the army of about 100 New York University graduate students who teach the writing workshop -- or the ''writing sweatshop,'' as it is sometimes called -- that is required of all freshmen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN RIPER, HART E.
description: VAN RIPER-Hart E. 95, formerly of New York. On November 4, 2000 at his residence in Indianapolis. During his medical career, Dr. Van Riper was Medical Director of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis and oversaw the research program under which the Salk vaccine was developed. He is survived by his children, MaryHart Bartley of NY, David Smith Van Riper of Berthoud, CO and Christina Van Riper of Indianapolis. Memorial contributions may be made to the March of Dimes, 233 Park Avenue So., NYC 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNNELLY, PATRICK JOSEPH
description: MUNNELLY-Patrick Joseph. Age 68, of Coram. Formerly of Valley Stream, on Nov. 6, 2000. Beloved husband of Jean M. (nee Haubold). Devoted father of Patrice (and Roy) Klein, Brian, and Maureen. Cherished grandfather of Jaclyn and Matthew. Also survived by his loving brothers John, Kevin, and Terrance. Memorial Mass, Saturday, at 9 AM, St. Margaret of Scotland RC Church. For information Marinello Funeral Home, Inc., Coram. Memorials may be made to The Calvary Fund, Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNAUGH, THOMAS J.
description: LYNAUGH-Thomas J., 61, of Ridgewood formerly of Norristown, PA on November 6, 2000. Beloved husband of Susan nee Dickey, loving father of Brendan and Sean, and loving son-in-law of Frank and Amy Dickey of Dewitt, NY. Dedicated teacher and psychoanalyst in Manhattan and Boston. He was a member of the American Psychological Association, The Society of Modern Analysts and the William Alanson White Society. A memorial service will be held on Friday November 10 at 12:00 noon at the Unitarian Society of Ridgewood, 13 Cottage Pl., Ridgewood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Valley Hospice 15 Essex Rd. Paramus, NJ 07652 or to the Boston Graduate School of Psychoanalysis, 1581 Beacon St., Brookline, MA 02446 would be appreciated. Services entrusted to the C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, 306 East Ridgewood Ave., Ridgewood, NJ 07450.

description: Hillary Rodham Clinton was elected senator from New York last night, ending a 16-month spectacle of a campaign and ensuring that a Clinton will remain in Washington after her husband, the president, leaves the White House on Jan. 20.

title: Sports of The Times; Rangers Are Mirror Image Of the Oilers
description: THE Rangers and the Edmonton Oilers, who met last night at Madison Square Garden, reflect each other like distorted images in a fun-house mirror. The obvious comparisons involve the general managers, the coaching staffs and the captains. All have worked for both teams. The brotherhood was obvious at the morning skate when battle-scarred men smiled and shook hands in the corridors linking the two dressing rooms. Mark Messier, the Ranger captain, hugged a man on the Oilers' training staff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRICK, RHODA (NEE BELDEGREEN)
description: HERRICK-Rhoda (nee Beldegreen). Of Rockville Centre and Amagansett. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving mother of Sanford and Jane Herrick, and Jane and Ed Wollman. Devoted and cherished grandmother of Eden, Alex and Hannah. Services today, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's'' Inc., 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre.

title: Sleep Waits as Gore Makes His Final Appeals
description: Vice President Al Gore, flying into Nashville after nearly 33 hours of straight campaigning, wanted to sleep this afternoon, but with the election down to the wire state by state, his campaign staff said no.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENNETT, CHARLOTTE WOODALL
description: DENNETT - Charlotte Woodall. Died Tuesday morning in Haverford, Pennsylvania. Born on November 20, 1913 in Middletown, Delaware to James E. Woodall and Justine Peverly Woodall, Mrs. Dennett graduated from St. Mary's Hall in Burlington, NJ, Wilson College in Chambersburg, PA and Drexel School of Library Science in Philadelphia. Her marriage to Raymond Dennett ended in divorce. Mrs. Dennett worked for many years as a librarian in Greenwich, Connecticut at the Old Greenwich Library, the Greenwich Library, and was the Middle School Librarian at Greenwich Academy. She was preceded in death by her sister, Justine P. (Toppy) Woodall, and her daughter, Peverly Dennett Kinsey. She is survived by her daughter, Charlotte Dennett Staelin of Georgetown, Maryland, three grandchildren, Justine Peverly Staelin-Lefsky, P. Tyler Staelin, H. Rosemary Staelin and by five great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Saint Anne's Episcopal Church, E. Green Street, Middletown, on Saturday, November 11, 2000 at 11:00 AM. Burial will be at Old St. Anne's cemetery, immediately following the services. In lieu of flowers, her family requests that donations be made in her name to the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy in Queenstown, Maryland or to Saint Anne's Church in Middletown.

description: Whenever players get together, they are bound to talk shop. The Mets' Jay Payton is among the major leaguers playing a goodwill series in Japan this week, and he hears the off-season buzz.

title: Roger Peyrefitte, French Writer, Dies at 93
description: Roger Peyrefitte, a prolific French writer who seemed to delight in shocking French literary and social circles by detailing his homosexual adventures in print and by ''outing'' prominent figures in French public life in his romans a clef, died on Sunday at his home in Paris. He was 93.

description: The most potent legal attack on the Clean Air Act in the statute's 30-year history, startlingly successful in a federal appeals court here 18 months ago, floundered visibly at the Supreme Court today.

title: A Flawed Call Adds to High Drama
description: Dan Rather offered viewers of CBS last night the equivalent of a money-back guarantee. ''If we say somebody's carried the state, you can take that to the bank. Book it!'' he asserted.

title: CONSECO SHARES RALLY AFTER CREDIT UPGRADE
description: Conseco Inc.'s credit rating was restored to investment grade by the A. M. Best Company, the insurance industry rating firm, permitting Conseco to complete a $2.3 billion debt extension it signed with bank lenders in September and also causing its stock to soar. Since Gary Wendt became chairman and chief executive of Conseco in June, the company has sold $1.1 billion in assets, generating enough cash to meet its obligations, A. M. Best said as it raised its rating of Conseco to A- from B++. Conseco shares traded as high as $8.56 before closing at $8.19, a gain of $1.25, or 18 percent, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Williams's Comeback Is Cut Short by the Jets
description: The Jets' vexation with the free safety position took another turn yesterday when they waived Kevin Williams, who was the starter only three games ago.

description: Pets.com Plans to Close And Sell Most of Its Assets

title: Metro Business Briefing; UNITEDHEALTH TO EXPAND
description: The UnitedHealth Group, a large managed care organization, plans to invest more than $22 million in a New York State expansion in which it expects to add more than 1,300 jobs at three operations, according to officials of the state and the Minneapolis-based company. They said the company's Uniprise division would add a new building near its existing site in Colonie, an Albany suburb, and also expand at a site in the Town of Ulster. Another division, UnitedHealthcare of New York, will renovate its offices at 2 Penn Plaza in Manhattan to accommodate its planned enlargement there. The UnitedHealth Group currently has a total of nearly 1,200 employees in the three operations. The company is eligible to apply for nearly $1.4 million in state grants from the Empire State Development Corporation. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Schools Chancellor to Expand Program to Certify Novice Teachers
description: In his latest attempt to meet a court order barring the hiring of uncertified teachers at New York City's lowest-performing schools, Chancellor Harold O. Levy will immediately expand a fledgling program that offers novices a crash course in teaching and grants them an alternative form of certification.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Scramble To Fill a Fund At Hicks, Muse
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, one of the nation's largest leveraged buyout firms, is going to unusual lengths to attract investors to a buyout fund of up to $4 billion for which it is raising money.

title: SINGAPORE IS LOOKING INTO MOBILEONE ASIA'S MARKETING
description: Singapore officials said they were investigating MobileOne Asia over its marketing tactics. At issue are advertising messages the company inserted into calls made by its wireless phone customers over its rivals' long-distance networks, promoting its own long-distance offerings before completing the call. Singapore Telecom, or SingTel, the island's dominant phone company, which had a monopoly on overseas calls before April, complained to regulators that the ads were disrupting its services on Monday. MobileOne removed the ads yesterday. More Singaporeans use cell phones than traditional land lines.

title: Common Joy In Isolation Of Voting
description: IT took more than half an hour just to reach the voting booth yesterday. They were about the best 35 minutes anyone could spend standing in line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNING, JAMES DORR
description: DUNNING-James Dorr. On November 7, 2000, at his home in New York City, after a long illness. He was 89. Mr. Dunning was an executive of New York Life Insurance Company for 45 years. For 25 years he served as a consultant to the Episcopal Church Pension Fund. His extensive lay leadership in the Episcopal Church included service as a senior warden of three parishes, St. Andrew's Church, Wellesley, MA, All Saints' Church and St. Bartholomew's Church, Manhattan. He served as a member of the national standing liturgical commission during the revision of the Book of Common Prayer. In 1996, he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters by the Berkeley Divinity School at Yale. He is survived by Mary, his wife of 66 years, and his son James D. Dunning, Jr. of New York, and his grandsons James D. Dunning III and David F. Dunning. Vigil and visitation Sunday, November 12, 4-6:30PM, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street. Funeral service at St. Bartholomew's, Monday, November 13, 5 PM. Memorial donations to St. Bartholomew's Church, New York, or Berkeley Divinity School at Yale, New Haven.

title: Chief U.S. Mediator in Mideast Plans to Leave in January
description: On the eve of what may be the last attempt by the Clinton White House to revive peace talks between the Israelis and Palestinians, Dennis B. Ross, the leading American mediator for more than a decade, announced that he would leave at the end of this administration.

title: Metro Business Briefing; WPIX EXECUTIVE QUITS
description: Paul A. Bissonette, general manager of WPIX-TV, Channel 11, the New York City station owned by The Tribune Company, resigned Friday in a hastily called meeting with his staff members. Mr. Bissonette, 51, who was named vice president and station manager in 1993, said he was leaving because of ''family considerations,'' citing his wife's illness. Michael Eigner, president of Tribune Television, will take over until a successor can be named. Ratings have risen at WPIX, a WB affiliate, in key demographics, particularly young adults. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: The Pain Israel Must Accept
description: I am opposed to our violent demonstrations,'' a Palestinian friend told me last week. ''We must switch to quiet demonstrations and peaceful methods, not only because of the terrible loss of life, but because our behavior threatens you, and then you respond with even greater violence and are not prepared to listen to us.''

title: Deep Into Lonely Night, A Yawn and Yawn Race For Michigan House Seat
description: It was last call at Bubba's Roadside Inn, the Green Bay Packers had just beaten the Minnesota Vikings 26-20 in overtime and Dianne Byrum had no particular place to go.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RABBI HERSCHEL
description: COHEN-Rabbi Herschel. Lincoln Square Synagogue mourns with sorrow the untimely passing of its esteemed and beloved Associate Rabbi, Herschel Cohen, beloved husband of Shulie, son of Froomie and father of Yehuda and Lisa, Devorah and Menachem. Our anchor of Torah and kindness has been taken. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Shlomo Riskin, Founding Rabbi Ken Cappell, President

title: Scandals Sully Indonesian Leader's Reform Image
description: To some Indonesians, one sign that not enough has changed under President Abdurrahman Wahid came when the police arrested his masseur on charges of bilking the government of $4 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, LILA (NEE GOLDMAN)
description: LIEBERMAN-Lila (nee Goldman), of Northampton, MA on November 6, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Sanford Lieberman. Sister of George Goldman. Mother of Bruce, Daniel, Lawrence and Paul. Grandmother of nine and great grandmother of one. Former president, Sisterhood of Temple Beth El and the Council of Jewish Women, Elizabeth, NJ. Co-founder of Lieberman's Gallery, a national distributor of art posters. Docent at the National Yiddish Book Center in Amherst, MA. The family will receive friends and relatives on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 54 Platinum Circle, Northampton, MA from 11AM. Memorial donations to Hospice of Hampshire County, The National Yiddish Book Center, or the Dana Farber Cancer Institute.

title: The Troubles Are All in the Family
description: The Doyles of Dublin are not the kind of Irish family New York theater audiences are used to meeting in recent years. That is not to say the widowed mother and three grown children in Joseph O'Connor's ''Red Roses and Petrol'' are not at one another's throats most of the time. But the deceased father had a steady job as a college librarian, they used to vacation on Majorca, a huge television sits in one corner of the family sitting room, and if any of them has ever heard about a spot of trouble in the Six Counties it is never mentioned.

title: Once Upon a Time, in San Francisco . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Point of Agreement: We're Glad It's Over
description: Was this any way to choose a president? Americans didn't think so. Most of those surveyed by Harvard's Vanishing Voter Project said in November 1999 that they thought presidential campaigns ''start too early'' and ''last too long,'' and in regular surveys until this week, they never wavered in that belief.

title: Bilingual Ed: Debunking Double Talk
description: TO follow conversation in a foreign language, it helps to know something about what is being discussed. Even if you barely know the language, you can then infer meaning from fragments you comprehend, guessing at unknown words from context.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLOSHIN, SIDNEY E.
description: WOLOSHIN-Sidney E. On November 5, 2000 at the age of 72. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Ellen and Mark, and Jonathan and Debra. Adoring grandfather of Jake and Julia. Cherished brother of Norma Basch. Pioneer in the jingle and advertising business. Award-winning music producer. Admired by all who knew him. Service on Wednesday, 10:00 AM, at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle, New York. Contributions in his memory may be made to either Ronald McDonald House or to the National Endowment for the Arts.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Just Beyond Paris, a Bountiful Wilderness
description: IT is in the central market at Orleans that you get the first, tantalizing whiff of the Sologne. Amid the stalls selling marble-white pyramids of goat cheese, enormous pumpkin slices and fresh vegetables from all over the Loire Valley, the more primitive foods of the hunter-gatherer can be seen. There are robust pheasants, looking asleep rather than dead, their rust-colored feathers fluttering when a passing shopper stirs up a breeze. Up and down the market, butchers slice fat slabs of boar terrine and throw furry hares and rabbits on their scales. Wicker baskets overflow with mushrooms: preposterously large cepes, ocher girolles, chubby pieds de mouton (hedgehog mushrooms) and jet-black trompettes de la mort, or black chanterelles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAIGE, WILLIAM C.
description: PAIGE-William C. Born January 3, 1922-died November 7, 2000 of emphysema at his home in Florida. Mr. Paige was Director of Advertising and Public Relations for the French House of Revillon Freres, in charge of fur parfums and wholesale divisions throughout the United States in the 1950s and 60s. He later became the Executive Vice President of the Ritter Fur Company. Mr. William B. Hoover, a friend, said memorial services will be held later.
