title: Metro Business Briefing; HOMESEEKERS SIGNS DEAL
description: DeCo L.L.C., a company formed this year by Douglas Elliman and the Corcoran Group, signed an agreement yesterday with HomeSeekers.com to provide real estate listing management technology to the two companies. HomeSeekers, based in Reno, Nev., will provide customized software and consulting services to the two companies. Last week, after months of fighting with each other, a group lead by Elliman and Corcoran began working with a group of more than 115 smaller New York real estate firms that were already operating a joint Web site at www.nymls .com. Leaders of that newly formed coalition want to create a multiple listing service that would allow brokers to easily share listing information. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Can Healthier Foods Help the Bottom Line?; Companies Find Gains in Your Loss
description: Andy and Rachel Berliner founded Amy's Kitchen, named for their newborn daughter, in 1988. Shocked by how much work caring for a baby could be, they decided there must be other people like them craving quick, convenient meals made from natural ingredients.

title: Democrat Captures Lazio's Long Island Seat
description: The Congressional seat Representative Rick A. Lazio gave up to wage his unsuccessful Senate race against Hillary Rodham Clinton was won yesterday by a Democrat, Steven Israel, 42, who defeated Joan B. Johnson, 66, the Islip town clerk.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: MIDWEST
description: WISCONSIN

title: Cisco Considers Building Office Tower in Times Square Redevelopment Zone
description: Cisco Systems, one of 11 bidders for the last vacant parcel within the Times Square redevelopment district, is exploring plans to build a major office tower at the southeast corner of 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue.

title: Consumer Credit Slowed in September
description: Consumer credit increased in September at the slowest pace in five months, a sign consumer spending could start to cool, Federal Reserve statistics showed today.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: WEST
description: MONTANA

title: People
description: * Vincent Tulley was named to the new position of partner and creative director at CMG Communications, New York. He had been vice president and creative director at the New York office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group.

title: Found the Crown of France In the Gutter. Picked It Up.
description: At Malmaison, the country estate of Napoleon and Josephine outside Paris, decisions of state were made in a room decorated to resemble the inside of a military tent: an opulent military tent, made of rich striped fabric, but a military tent nonetheless, the place Napoleon felt most at home. That bizarre detail is not included in David Grubin's finely wrought, beautifully photographed ''Napoleon,'' but it suits the series's vision of the man who would be emperor. This Napoleon was first and always a soldier.

title: UConn Makes an Addition By Subtracting a Freshman
description: Indicating the depth of his defending national championship University of Connecticut women's basketball team, Geno Auriemma has decided to redshirt a player for other than medical reasons for the first time in his 16-year tenure as the Huskies' coach.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If this had been carried out in accordance with their wishes, this would have been the largest robbery in the world.''

title: PROFITS UP? TIME TO STRIKE
description: Immediately after Ryanair P.L.C. reported sharply higher after-tax profits, the airline's pilots voted to authorize a strike over working hours. Profits for the six months ended Sept. 30 rose 49.4 percent to 63.4 million euros ($54.4 million), on revenue that rose 37 percent, to 265.9 million euros ($228.2 million); passenger volume was up by one third. Ryanair said its online reservation system held its costs down despite the addition of 10 new routes. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITSIOS, THEKLA
description: LITSIOS-Thekla. 76. Passed away on Monday, November 6, 2000 in Bridgeport Hospital after a brief illness. She is survived by her beloved husband, John Litsios and their three children, Gregory and his wife Maeve, Theodora and Andrew and her two grandchildren, Zoe and Evan. Friends may call Thursday, November 9, 4:00-8:00 PM at the Commerce Hill Funeral Home, 4798 Main Street, Bridgeport, CT. Funeral services will held on Friday 11:00 AM at St. Nicholas Antiochian Orthodox Church, 5458 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, CT. Interment will be Friday 3:30 PM at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ. The family requests in lieu of flowers donations may be made to The American Cancer Society, 800-227-2345 or The American Diabetes Association, 1701 North Beauregard Street, Alexandria, VA. 22311.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: SOUTH
description: VIRGINIA

title: Travails of a Philippine President
description: The Philippine House of Representatives now seems likely to impeach President Joseph Estrada and send him to trial in the Senate on corruption charges. If the accusations that he took nearly $11 million in bribes to protect illegal gambling can be proved, he should be removed from office. Impeaching a popularly elected president is a grave step. But if he is shown to have so blatantly violated his public trust, it would be warranted.

title: Broadway's Revered Flop, Resurrected With Love
description: For more than 25 years ''Mack and Mabel'' has been Jerry Herman's favorite problem child, the bittersweet Broadway flop that refuses to die. Mr. Herman, the composer and lyricist of mega-hits from ''Hello, Dolly!'' to ''Mame'' to ''La Cage aux Folles'' (which each ran for more than 1,500 performances), has had no shortage of successful offspring. But as he put it gently the other day, ''Maybe you're always fonder of the underdog.''

title: Siamese Twin Is Separated; 'Sadly Dies' To Save Sister
description: British doctors separated 3-month-old twin girls today in a court-approved operation that knowingly sacrificed the life of one to save the other.

title: Daewoo Gets Brief Reprieve In Effort to Avert Collapse
description: After last-minute negotiations to avert the collapse of South Korea's second-largest carmaker, creditors postponed until this afternoon a decision to declare the ailing Daewoo Motor Company bankrupt.

title: Aisles of Confusion as Medicines Are Pulled
description: When her coughing and congestion got to be too much yesterday morning, Cindy Moona dragged herself to the Rite-Aid pharmacy on Amsterdam Avenue near West 69th Street in Manhattan. She squinted her watery eyes to read labels, looking for just the right medicine for her many annoying symptoms.

title: From the Historical To the Literary
description: JUST about the time the last wine grapes are crushed and fermented, the first wine books begin to appear for the holiday season. It looks like a bumper crop this year, so for you early shoppers, here are two attractive ones for your consideration.

title: Umpires to Call Strikes by the Book
description: Pitchers and hitters alike will believe it when they see it, but the shrunken strike zone is out and the rule-book strike zone in.

title: A Tax Cut Is Approved; Other Issues Seem Close
description: Here in Massachusetts, voters gave themselves a giant tax cut. In Maine, they split down the middle over assisted suicide and gay rights. And in several states, they leaned toward changes in drug policy, from legalizing the medical use of marijuana to giving some drug offenders treatment instead of jail time.

title: Naming Sex Offenders on the Internet Passes in New Jersey
description: Voters in New Jersey yesterday approved a measure to amend the State Constitution to allow the names, addresses and photographs of sex offenders to be posted on the Internet.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: MIDWEST
description: INDIANA

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: NORTHEAST
description: NEW HAMPSHIRE

title: First Lady's Race for the Ages: 62 Counties and 6 Pantsuits
description: It was the Senate campaign of the century, but it sounded at first like a joke. Back in October 1998, in the middle of impeachment -- and before the last New York Senate race even ended -- Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem teasingly told Hillary Rodham Clinton in Chicago that she should be the next candidate from New York. ''She said, 'Who would want me to run there?' '' Mr. Rangel recalled this week. ''But she had a twinkle in her eye. And I knew then this was more than a joke with her.''

title: ABBEY PREFERS A FRIENDLY TAKEOVER OF BANK OF SCOTLAND
description: Abbey National P.L.C. refused to rule out a hostile bid for Bank of Scotland but reiterated that it preferred a friendly takeover deal. The remarks follow a report in The Financial Times that Abbey National's chairman, Lord Tugendhat, had ruled out a hostile bid. Abbey National's takeover overtures, which could create a bank larger by assets than Lloyds TSB Group with a market value of more than $:23 billion, or $32.9 billion, have been coolly received at the Bank of Scotland's headquarters in Edinburgh. (Bloomberg News)

title: Yankees' Stottlemyre Appears Set to Return
description: Mel Stottlemyre, treated for bone-marrow cancer during the past season, is leaning toward returning to the Yankees next season, according to friends of the pitching coach.

title: NEW YORK VOTES
description: FOR PRESIDENT

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Donald F. Lach, a historian and author, omitted the name of the university at which he was the Bernadotte E. Schmitt professor in history. It was the University of Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, J. SINCLAIR
description: ARMSTRONG-J. Sinclair. Of New York City. At age 85. Died on November 5, 2000. Survived by his wife, Charlotte, and his children, Katherine C.A. Young, James S. Armstrong, Jr., Stephen H. and Jeanne H. Armstrong, Robert S. & Phoebe H. Armstrong & Elisabeth Armstrong-Bushey; also, his niece, Leslie Armstrong, eight grandchildren, a great-nephew and two great nieces, among many other loving family members. Services private. A memorial gathering will be scheduled at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Harvard Library in New York, 27 West 44th Street, New York, New York 10036, or to Harvard Law School, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02138 for the J. Sinclair Armstrong Revolving Student Loan Fund.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: CONNECTICUT VOTES
West Meets East and Willingly Caters to Its Rhythms and Melodies
description: Most of the Western musicians who try East-West musical fusions add some exotic scales and inflections to Western structures. The guitarist John McLaughlin, who brought his group Remember Shakti to the Beacon Theater on Sunday night, takes a more difficult path.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROYAL AHOLD N.V., Zaandam, the Netherlands, an international supermarket retailer, said its Tops Markets and Giant-Carlisle supermarket chains, which are based in New York and Pennsylvania, respectively, would combine support services to cut costs.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: WEST
description: OREGON

title: Margaret Atwood Is the Winner of Britain's Top Fiction Award
description: The Canadian writer Margaret Atwood won the 2000 Booker Prize tonight for ''The Blind Assassin,'' a novel in which the reminiscences of an elderly woman serve as the starting point for an intricate series of stories within stories. Ms. Atwood had been nominated three times before for the Booker, Britain's best-known fiction award.

title: BRAZILIAN BEER BRAND SOLD
description: Molson Inc. agreed to pay at least $98 million to buy the Bavaria beer brand from Cia. de Bebidas das Americas, which was selling to satisfy regulators after a big merger last year. Molson, Canada's largest brewer, gets five plants in the deal, its first manufacturing presence in the fast-growing Brazilian beer market. Molson will pay more if the brand's market share rises after the sale.

title: Tihany Dresses a Dowager
description: IF you wanted to hide a contemporary restaurant in Manhattan, the Plaza Hotel would be an excellent place to put it. In a city famous for tearing headlong into the future, the Plaza sits immobile, a squat dowager at the corner of Central Park who has has seen it all come and go. The Oak Room remains a dark, heavily timbered relic, haunted by ghosts. The Palm Court looks as though it is waiting for Martin Scorsese to drop by to shoot one more scene for ''The Age of Innocence.'' In decor and atmosphere, the hotel makes a perfect match for the horse-drawn carriages that ply the street, and is therefore an astounding location for Alan Stillman, the chairman of the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, to create a snappy, up-to-the-minute American restaurant.

title: Hillary Clinton's Victory
description: Completing an extraordinary metamorphosis from political neophyte to polished candidate, Hillary Rodham Clinton -- the first first lady ever to run for office -- defeated Representative Rick Lazio yesterday in a closely fought race for Daniel Patrick Moynihan's Senate seat from New York. If Mrs. Clinton brings to the Senate the intelligence and energy that she brought to her campaign, she should make a worthy successor to the estimable Mr. Moynihan, who is retiring after 24 honorable years of service.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENMAN, PHILIP
description: GREENMAN-Philip. 11/8/10-10/19/96. Happy 90th birthday, Daddy. I think about you and miss you every day. Always and forever in my heart. Linda.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: MIDWEST
description: KANSAS

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: MIDWEST
description: MINNESOTA

title: Philadelphia Voters Give Gore the Edge
description: With the strong backing of Democratic voters in Philadelphia and its suburbs, Vice President Al Gore captured Pennsylvania's 23 electoral votes tonight.

title: THE CHEF; Juicy? Flavorful? These Are Pork Chops?
description: HAM is all the things that modern pork isn't: flavorful, moist and appealing. Pork is bred to be lean, but fat gives pork moisture and juiciness. Ham is meat from the pig's leg, usually cured in a mixture of water, salt, sugar and spices, a process that adds tons of flavor and keeps the meat juicy.

title: RETAILER'S PROFIT FALLS
description: The struggling British retailer Marks & Spencer said its profit in the six months that ended Sept. 30 fell 6 percent and its sales decline accelerated in the last five weeks. Excluding one-time charges, the company reported net income of $:126.5 million ($181 million), or 4.4 pence a share, on sales that were flat at $:3.2 billion ($4.6 billion). Clothing sales in the five weeks to Nov. 4 fell 14.6 percent from the period a year earlier because new styles were performing disappointingly, the company said. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: NORTHEAST
description: RHODE ISLAND

title: Test Results Hint of Barrier To Graduation
description: Just over half of all New York City students who entered high school four years ago passed the new, tougher Regents exam in math, suggesting that thousands of students could fail to graduate this spring when the math test becomes a requirement for a high school diploma.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIAN, JACK
description: O'BRIAN-Jack. A long-time newspaper columnist, and radio talk show host in New York, died November 5, 2000 in Manhattan. He was 86 years old. In his nearly 60 years in journalism, Mr. O'Brian covered theatre, movies, radio, popular music and television at The Associated Press, The New York Journal American, and later on, WOR-AM. His humor and spirit and his love of music and the theatre will be missed by daughters, Bridget and Kate, and his beloved grandchildren, Emma and Lilly Haberl, and Jake and Sam Brimberg. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street, on Wednesday from 6 to 9 P.M. Funeral Mass will be held at Saint Agnes Church, 143 E. 43rd St. on Thursday at 10 A.M.

title: THE BOSS; No Hiccups in Risk Taking
description: I learned about life's inequalities early on when I saw my little brother get beaten up after school because we were Protestant in Catholic France. If there is a strategy for dealing with inequality, it is the game of out-thinking the competition and taking chances.

title: Fly That Winner To the Moon
description: Having turned ''Survivor'' into the biggest television draw this side of the Super Bowl, Mark Burnett, the show's executive producer, has no reason to suffer any crises of confidence.

title: Long Lines And Problems At the Polls
description: Jonathan Springer, a lawyer, was among those who did not mind the half-hour wait at the polls at 102nd Street and Amsterdam Avenue yesterday. ''It's really exciting to have all these people here,'' he said before voting in an election that many city poll workers said had drawn the largest turnout -- and the longest lines -- that they had seen in years.

title: Preseason Tournaments Could Be Endangered
description: Preseason tournaments usher in the college basketball season with the pageantry of an alumni reunion and the force of traditional powers colliding. But if proposed legislation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association becomes law, such annual festivities could become history.

title: Giants, Tied for Best N.F.C. Mark at 7-2, Have Even Gaudier Possibilities
description: It's a snowy, mid-January day at Giants Stadium, where a dull sky seems shaded gray to match the blunted, ashen outer walls of the big oval stadium set in the Meadowlands parking lots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBACK, ELAINE
description: TOBACK-Elaine. On November 7, 2000, after a courageous battle. Beloved wife and best friend of Myron. Loved mother of Michael and his fiancee Karen and Joy and her husband Eli. Devoted grandmother of Zachary, Sarah and Harrison. Dear sister of Leon Ganeless and his wife Claudette. Sister-in-law of twins Iris and Frances. Daughter-in-law of Judy Toback. Aunt of many nieces and nephews. Services Thursday, 10AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: NORTHEAST
description: MAINE

title: Jon S. Corzine: Making the Move From Wall Street to Senate Seat
description: Jon S. Corzine gleefully declared victory in his race for New Jersey's United States Senate seat tonight, calling his tumultuous passage from Wall Street to Washington a ''joyous journey.''

title: Election Day Suspense
description: After a vote count that stretched into this morning, Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore were locked in one of the most closely contested presidential contests in decades. Mr. Bush's highly provisional lead arose in dramatic fashion, when Florida tilted back toward Mr. Bush's column after the networks had predicted that it would go to Mr. Gore. Then, after 3 a.m., Mr. Gore closed within a few hundred votes in Florida.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: MIDWEST
description: SOUTH DAKOTA

title: The Tax That Gave Birth to a Small Industry
description: High taxes help destroy jobs, right?

title: Laptop Chip Maker Doubles Share Price on Opening Day
description: Shares of Transmeta, the upstart designer of microprocessors fighting for a piece of the laptop computer market with Intel, more than doubled today on their first day of public trading on Nasdaq.

title: VIRGIN ATLANTIC DECIDES AGAINST TAKING STAKE IN AIR INDIA
description: Virgin Atlantic Airways, which is 49 percent owned by Singapore Airlines Ltd., said that after reviewing the possibility, it would not bid for a stake in Air India. Foreign and domestic companies have until Friday to file a bid for the 40 percent stake in Air India that the Indian government wants to sell. Foreigners may bid for up to 26 percent, with an Indian partner bidding on the remainder. Last month, Singapore Airlines said it was in talks with the Tata Group of India to make a bid. Virgin has a code-sharing agreement with Air India and flies twice a week between London and New Delhi, filling Air India's unused slots.

title: Santa Claus, Dancing Bears And the Elves, All Kicking
description: Exit the boys of summer, trailing pennants. Exit the ghosts and goblins of autumn, trailing candy corn. No sooner do the World Series and Halloween step off the exhilarating, never-ending whirligig that is New York, than the Christmas season arrives.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: MIDWEST
description: NEBRASKA

title: Investment Company Faces Suits Over 2 Funds' Collapse
description: The founder of Heartland Advisors staked his personal wealth on the sale of a portfolio of troubled bonds to the State of Wisconsin, a last-ditch attempt that failed to support two of the company's bond mutual funds whose value was later cut in half in a single day last month.

title: In This Spinoff of 'Bacchae,' Dionysus Is a Thermos Bottle
description: For viewers of a certain age, ''Highway to Tomorrow,'' the latest assault by Elevator Repair Service on logic and plot in theater, may bring on a fit of nostalgia. It reminds one of nothing so much as the Happenings of 35 or 40 years ago, except that most Happenings I can recall had tighter structure and more energy. ''Highway'' operates on a seriously rundown battery. All this is quite strange, since no one in this hermetic troupe is old enough to have had personal experience of Happenings.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: NORTHEAST
description: CONNECTICUT

title: Bush and Gore in Tight Race; Florida Will Prove Decisive
description: The outcome of the presidential race between Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore balanced today on no more than a few hundred votes in the closely contested state of Florida.

title: Loyal Electors Expect to Toe the Party Line
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Candidates for the Electoral College, suddenly in the spotlight because of the uncertain outcome of the presidential election, said today that they would never dream of betraying their pledges to support George W. Bush or Al Gore.

title: For Clinton Faithful, Vindication Comes With a Groundbreaking Victory
description: With Hillary Rodham Clinton winning the New York Senate race last night, the Democratic faithful were reveling in the big ''V'' at Mrs. Clinton's election night bash in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINLAYSON, LOUISE S. (NEE SWANSON)
description: FINLAYSON-Louise S. (nee Swanson), age 76, formerly of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, died Saturday, November 4, 2000 at Pine Rest Health Care Center, Ridgewood, NJ. A gentle soul, Louise was the beloved wife of the late Robert M. Adored mother of Elinor Ann Finlayson of NY, NY, Robert M. Jr. of Huntington, NY, Sarah J. Finlayson-DeGarmo of Brooklyn, NY, Mary FinlaysonMatsakis of Wyckoff, NJ and Roderick J. of NY, NY. Sister of Charles O. Swanson, of Lakewood, NY and Mary A. Carlson of Tequesta, FL. Cherished grandmother of 7. A Syracuse graduate Louise was an accomplished athlete and a tennis and golf champion. A memorial service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church, 5th Avenue and 12th Street NY, NY on Saturday, November 11, at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Louise S. & Robert M. Finlayson Family Scholarship Fund, University of Michigan Business School, 701 Tappan St. Ann Arbor, MI 48109. For information Vander Plaat Funeral Home, Wyckoff, NJ.

title: PE CREATING NEW UNIT
description: The PE Corporation said it was creating a molecular diagnostics business that could become the third leg of the company, alongside Applied Biosystems and Celera Genomics. Molecular diagnostics refers to the use of genetic analysis to diagnose disease or patient susceptibility to disease, or to determine what drugs would work best on a particular pathogen or particular patient. PE said the new business would be a way to increase sales of both the genetic analysis equipment made by Applied Biosystems and the genetic information being generated by Celera, which determined the human genome sequence. Eventually, the molecular diagnostics business might have its own publicly traded stock, as do Applied Bio and Celera. The new unit will be headed by Kathy Ordonez, who for the last nine years has been president of Roche Molecular Systems, a unit of Hoffmann-La Roche. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column yesterday about a decision by the city of Florence to call off the reburial of bones said by a local journalist to be those of the Renaissance painter Giotto misspelled the surname of an American archaeologist who disputed the identification. He is Franklin Toker, not Tokler.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: NORTHEAST
description: NEW JERSEY

title: Pets.com, Sock Puppet's Home, Will Close
description: Not even its popular Sock Puppet, the toy dog that starred in its television commercials, could save Pets .com.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: FRANCE TELECOM REVENUE UP
description: Aided by growth in wireless-phone and Internet service, France Telecom posted a 21.6 percent increase in revenue for the first three quarters, to 23.9 billion euros, or $20.7 billion, from 19.7 billion euros a year earlier. Internet revenue more than doubled; wireless revenue rose by half. But the company's market share in the French domestic long-distance calling eroded to less than 70 percent from more than 80 percent a year earlier.

title: Yugoslavs Bicker Over Army and Secret Police
description: A bitter conflict has broken out between the new Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, and his political allies over the fate of the director of the Serbian secret police and the commander of the Yugoslav Army, both of whom were major pillars of the government of Slobodan Milosevic.

title: New Jersey Voters Return Incumbents to Congress in Several Closely Watched Races
description: After a night of shifting leads, one of the most closely watched House races in New Jersey was too close to call, as former Representative Dick Zimmer was in a virtual tie with Representative Rush Holt, a first-term incumbent in the 12th District. Michael Ferguson, a political newcomer, won the open seat in the 7th.

title: Judge Delays Closing of Polls in St. Louis Amid Unexpectedly Heavy Turnout
description: A state judge delayed the closing of polls here, ruling that a huge turnout of voters had overwhelmed polling places and that many voters were being denied their rights to cast ballots.

title: Czech Line Beats Oilers At Their Own Game
description: No line in the Eastern Conference is more suited to the wide-open style of play that the Edmonton Oilers perfected in the 1980's than the Rangers' Czech line. The Oilers still play that style, but the Czechs beat the Oilers at their own game last night.

title: A School Pediatrician With a Lot of Clout
description: FIRST, a disclosure: Dr. Terry Marx, New York City's first chief physician for school health, was more than a little reluctant to report for duty this week.

title: G.O.P. IN POSITION TO RETAIN SENATE
description: Republicans scored an important victory yesterday when former Gov. George F. Allen defeated Senator Charles S. Robb in Virginia, a turnover that led Democratic leaders to say they would not regain control of the United States Senate.

title: Running Question Still Haunts The Jets
description: When the Jets approached a first down and goal from the 2-yard line in the final minute of Sunday's loss to the Denver Broncos, it seemed like simple math. The Broncos had surrendered an astounding 407 yards on the ground in their previous game, the most any team had given up in 50 years in the National Football League. In the backfield, the Jets had Curtis Martin, one of the most proficient backs in National Football League history.

title: Skepticism for U.N. Peacekeeping Force
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that he does not see how a United Nations force could be inserted between Palestinians and Israelis unless both sides agreed to it. The Palestinians are asking for an international ''protection force'' for the West Bank and Gaza. Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, has ruled out such a mission.

title: Strike? What Strike?
description: ABC concluded an unusual deal yesterday with Warner Brothers' television studio that extended the run of the improvisational comedy show ''Whose Line Is It Anyway?'' through the 2003-4 season. In what ABC says is a first for a network, it acquired the syndication rights to the old episodes of the show for use on the network.

title: Mideast Violence Simmers, Though Bombing at Sea Fails
description: A fishing boat laden with explosives blew up near an Israeli patrol ship off Gaza late Monday night, and Israeli soldiers killed a Palestinian protester in Bethlehem today as violence continued to test the latest truce agreement.

title: The Race for President
description: Results as of 4:02 a.m.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: SOUTH
description: KENTUCKY

title: Bush Remains Upbeat as the Tension Mounts
description: One minute, the crowd of Bush supporters outside the State Capitol here would be euphoric; the next, hushed. As the minutes and hours crept by and huge television screens flashed good news, then bad news, then caveats about that bad news, it was impossible to know what to expect.

title: A Request to Link Two Power Grids
description: American Transmission, a venture that will run electricity transmission for six Midwest utilities, has asked federal regulators to promote the combining of two regional power grids to cut costs and improve service.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: NORTHEAST
description: WEST VIRGINIA

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: WEST
description: HAWAII

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: NORTHEAST
description: DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAGDOL, CELIA (EHILSICK
description: MAGDOL-Celia (Ehilsickiltzik)/d, 88, of Beachwood, OH died Oct. 31. Wife of the late Harry Graynum Magdol, mother of Mervin Magdol and Joan (Ron) Arnson, grandmother of Gabriel and Hannah Arnson, sister of the late Lena, Nat, Harry, Lou & Abe. Graduated from MTTS and NYU in 1932, taught w/WPA and then PS 75 in Bklyn. Services were in Ohio.

title: Un-Presidented Election
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: SOUTH
description: ALABAMA

title: The Remnants of a Mideast Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, RUTH
description: MITCHELL-Ruth. We sadly join the theatre community in mourning the loss of a talented colleague and dear friend, and extend our condolences to Juliette, Jody and David Fleischer, Jessica Mitchell and Florence Klotz. Martin Richards, Sam Crothers and The Producer Circle Co.

title: Signs of Investor Worry in Sale of Argentine Debt
description: Argentina sold $1.1 billion in treasury bills today at rates that reflected investors' worries about the government's ability to finance its growing debt.

title: Nader Falls Short of the 5% Needed for the Green Party to Get Federal Campaign Funds
description: Ralph Nader failed in his intention to shake the two-party system at its very roots, and apparently missed his goal of 5 percent of the votes, which would have brought his Green Party federal campaign money in 2004. But he might have played a larger role by doing relatively well in a few swing states -- particularly Oregon -- that had been crucial to Vice President Al Gore.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: There's Observing, Then There's Not

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, JACK J.
description: STEIN-Jack J. Of Melville, L.I., on November 6, 2000. A kind, wise and joyful man loved by all. Devoted husband of Joyce Stein. Loving father of Linda Stein and Ron Feldman-Stein. Cherished grandfather of Mikah and Jesse Feldman-Stein. Caring brother of Evelyn Cooper. Beloved son of the late Jenny and Charles Stein. A dear friend of many, many more who will miss him terribly. Funeral services to be held today on Wednesday, 12:30 PM, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: NORTHEAST
description: DELAWARE

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: SOUTH
description: FLORIDA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACHTENBERG, IRVING M.
description: TRACHTENBERG-Irving M. On Saturday, November 4, 2000, of Mantoloking (formerly of Basking Ridge and Short Hills). Beloved husband of Mary and the late Sarah. Graveside services were held at Mt. Ararat Cemetery Pinelawn, NY on Monday, November 6, 2000. Conducted by Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Changing Places

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Move to Recall Taiwan's President Advances
description: Taiwan's opposition alliance took an important legal step today in its threatened campaign to oust President Chen Shui-bian, passing procedures for a recall motion in Parliament.

title: Nets Getting Harris Back
description: Lucious Harris, the Nets' backup shooting guard, will be on the bench in uniform Wednesday night against the Wizards in Washington. Although he will most likely not play until Saturday against Seattle, his early return from hernia surgery is a welcome sight for a team shooting 39.4 percent in its first three games.

title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: SOUTH
description: NORTH CAROLINA

title: Bill Clinton's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, RON
description: MARSHALL-Ron. Veteran announcer/singer, passed away on October 14. Celebration November 12, 12 noon at Downtime 251 W 30 St. NYC. www.ronmarshall.com

title: Anxiety Seen In Teenagers Who Smoke
description: Contrary to the popular belief that teenagers who smoke are nervous children who use tobacco to calm down, a new study suggests that heavy smoking may have the opposite effect, and actually increase their risk of developing certain anxiety disorders in late adolescence or early adulthood.

title: Blending Comic and Serious in a Magic Potion
description: There is an appealing storybook simplicity in John Cox's production of Mozart's ''Zauberflote,'' which rejoined the Metropolitan Opera repertory on Monday evening. In a house where cinematic realism rules, David Hockney's spare sets and his use of stylized painted flats has a certain old-fashioned charm. So do his bright-hued, traditional costumes, to say nothing of the small menagerie of furry animals that are briefly charmed by Papageno's flute.

title: Men in Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEWETT, CHARLES WOOD
description: JEWETT-Charles Wood, 87, of Mt. Archer Rd., Lyme, CT died Friday, November 3, 2000 at his home. Mr. Jewett was a prominent attorney, banker and former lieutenant governor of Connecticut. Mr. Jewett is survived by his wife of 62 years, Mary ''Molly'' Sheafe Jewett, two sons, Jonathan Jewett of Lyme and New York City, Charles Wood Jewett Jr. of Las Vegas, NV; a daughter, Jennifer Jewett Smith of Silver Spring, Md., nine grandchildren and a greatgrandson. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 am on Saturday, November 11, 2000 at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme. Burial will be private. There are no calling hours. Donations may be made in his memory to the Visiting Nurse Association of Southeastern Connecticut, PO Box 264, Waterford, CT 06385 or the Lyme Public Library, Route 156, Lyme, CT 06371. The FultonTheroux Funeral Home, Beckwith Lane, Old Lyme is in charge.

title: Lowe Lintas Loses Burger King Account
description: The Burger King Corporation, part of Diageo P.L.C., has ended its six-year relationship with Lowe Lintas & Partners in New York by eliminating the agency from a review for the creative part of its account. Total annual spending for Burger King is estimated at $400 million; the national consumer part handled by Lowe Lintas, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is estimated at $100 million to $125 million.

title: Roll Over, Moses: It's a Centrum Lincolnensis
description: What if Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts could be redesigned from the ground up by Michelangelo? Or Jefferson? Or Pericles? Or Nero?

title: Dead Man Wins Race in Missouri
description: Republicans in Missouri conceded late last night that Gov. Mel Carnahan, the Democrat who was killed in a plane crash on Oct. 16, had defeated Senator John Ashcroft, the Republican incumbent, at the polls.

title: KATY, MAKER OF MAINTENANCE SUPPLIES, EXPLORES OPTIONS
description: Katy Industries, a maker of maintenance and electrical supplies, said it was exploring strategic options and was in discussions with a possible buyer, which it did not identify. Katy, based in Englewood, Colo., also said it had a third-quarter loss of $2.55 million, or 30 cents a share, because of increased plastic resin costs, poor performance from its mop and broom operations and lower sales, a trend it said would continue next quarter. Katy's stock, which rose $2.88, to $9, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, has fallen around 40 percent in the last year.

title: BANK BUYS STAKE IN SOCCER TEAM
description: Deutsche Bank, which has said it wants to untangle its web of industrial cross-holdings, is moving toward greater entanglements. Deutsche Bank bought 10 percent of the shares in Borussia Dortmund, the German soccer team that went public last Tuesday, but whose stock has slipped since then. Deutsche Bank, which helped underwrite the offering, said it was moving to stabilize the shares. On Monday, Deutsche Bank made a friendly offer worth about $200 million to take over Varta, a battery maker that is under heavy pressure from foreign competitors. Ed Andrews (NYT)

title: Corrections

title: OUTSIDER TO MANAGE MSN SITES
description: In an effort to attract people to its MSN Internet portal, Microsoft has turned for the first time to an outside company to manage two MSN online communities. Participate.com., a Chicago company that manages online communities for Cisco Systems, and Hewlett-Packard, has been chosen to manage MSN's People and Chat and Zone.com communities. Terms of the deal were not released, but a spokesman said the contract was Participate .com's largest so far.

title: Business Travel; Get as much information as possible before heading to potential trouble spots.
description: LONDON, Paris, Tokyo, Frankfurt, Milan. These are the sorts of places you think of instinctively when considering international business travel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, BARBARA F. (CHIEFY)
description: HESS-Barbara F. (Chiefy). On November 6th after a long and courageous battle at the age of 77. Beloved wife of ''Tommy'', loving mother of John Newburger, Susan Newburger Karchmer and her husband Michael Karchmer and Billy Straus and his wife Lynne Weinstein. Devoted stepmother of Peter Hess and Debra Kenyon, Tom Hess and Georgianna Dwight and Jill Hess and James Wollum. Adored grandmother of Ian and Emma Straus. Step-grandmother of Rachel and Sara Hess, Carly & Camey Hess and Allie and Jamie Wollum. The family will be receiving at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue. at 81st St, Wednesday, November 8, from 4:30-7:30PM. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell on Friday November 10 at 11:30AM followed by a reception at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 E. 66 St. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering, where Barbara served on the Ladies Board for many years or to Women in Need, 115 W. 31 Street.

title: ENDESA IN CHILEAN BUYOUTS
description: Spain's biggest energy company, Endesa S.A., said it would buy out its minority partners and take full control of two Chilean power distributors. It will buy the remaining 27 percent of Chilectra, the country's largest energy distributor, for 2,200 pesos a share, and the remaining 16.25 percent of Cia. Electrica Rio Maipo for 250 pesos a share, spending a total of $480 million. Each offer represents a small premium to the Monday closing prices.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas rose on expectations that cold weather in the Midwest will increase demand for the fuel. In New York, natural gas for December delivery rose 23.2 cents, to $5.081 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a front-page article yesterday about a suit by the European Union that accuses two American tobacco companies of cigarette smuggling included a scrambled passage in some copies. The passage should have read, ''In announcing the suit in Brussels today, the executive body of the European Union accused the two tobacco companies of using money laundering, wire fraud and other activities in 'pursuit of a massive, ongoing smuggling scheme.' ''

title: A Maestro of Many Gifts Returns, on and Off the Podium
description: Lorin Maazel, one of the world's best-known maestros and the music director of the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra, is also more, as he has made clear in recent years. He is a composer of no little imagination, as he showed in 1996 at Carnegie Hall, in a performance of his Music for Cello and Orchestra, with Mstislav Rostropovich as soloist. And he is a violinist of no mean gifts, as he proved more recently in a televised New Year's concert of the Vienna Philharmonic.

title: Cairo Journal; American Headstones Tugging at Egypt's Memory
description: Behind a high stone wall, in twin graveyards shaded by the heavy branches of gnarled ficus and eucalyptus trees, lie the missionaries and mercenaries who were the first Americans in Egypt.

title: State Faults HIP on Spending And Questions Political Links
description: Insurance regulators have concluded that the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York improperly provided luxury cars and apartments to senior executives and may have violated state law in helping its doctors distribute political donations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, PHYLLIS (NEE LIFTON)
description: WEINER-Phyllis (nee Lifton). On November 3, 2000, while traveling in China with her devoted husband of 39 years, Howard. She will be remembered and missed by her children, Jeffrey, Cynthia, Michael and Jeanne Gerstley Weiner, for her spirit, humor, and warmth. She is the cherished sister of Martin and Ellie Lifton of Old Westbury, N.Y., & Dr. & Mrs. Robert Weiner of Denver, CO. She is the beloved grandmother of Zach, Jake, Emmy and Allie. She will be sadly missed by her many nieces, nephews, cousins and close friends, whom she adored. The family will receive visitors Saturday, November 11, from 7-9PM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St. A funeral service will be held Sunday, November 12, at 11:45AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to Smith College, Northampton, MA. 01063, The New York Philharmonic, Avery Fisher Hall, 10 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023, or Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77 Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: SALE OF B. F. GOODRICH CHEMICALS UNIT IS DELAYED TO 2001
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said it would not sell its chemicals business until next year, several months later than expected, because it has been unable to reach an agreement with a potential buyer. The company's chief executive, Dave Burner, speaking to analysts in a conference call, declined to name the potential buyer and did not specify the reason for the delay. Goodrich said in April that it would sell the chemicals unit, which had $1.2 billion in sales last year, because it did not fit with its aerospace and industrial products.

The Martin Agency, Richmond, Va., which had handled the media account, continues handling creative duties. MindShare is the media services joint venture of two units of the WPP Group, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and J. Walter Thompson. Martin is part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

description: DZUBAY-Elizabeth H. Age 61. Died November 6, 2000 of lung cancer. She is survived by her son Richard, daughter Liz, and brother Frank Wahl.

title: With 11 Governorships Being Contested, Democrats Win 7, Some in States Bush Won
description: Voters in 11 states cast ballots for governor yesterday, and early results showed Democrats prevailing even in some states where Gov. George W. Bush of Texas was defeating Vice President Al Gore in the presidential race.

title: Conflict in Bolivia
description: To the Editor:

title: A Husband and Wife's Daydream: To Meet Occasionally for Lunch
description: MEET Brandon and Jill Lowich, two giddy Manhattan newlyweds, immersed in their work, wanting to spend more time with each other. She is in marketing for a fashion designer; he is in business development for an Internet start-up. ''We get out of work, then I go to the gym, she goes to yoga,'' Mr. Lowich says. ''By the time we get home it's 8:30, 8:45 and you're so tired that lively conversation isn't even possible.''

title: Mayor Wants Restoration In Bus Subsidy
description: The longtime mayor of Hempstead today called for the restoration of county aid to Long Island Bus, which serves more than 100,000 riders a day.

title: The Ratings Don't Tell The Story On Monday
description: ''What are they going to rule -- that he caught it?'' ABC's Al Michaels asked incredulously Monday night, as what looked like an incomplete pass was deflected to Green Bay receiver Antonio Freeman, who juggled it from his left shoulder across his chest and into his right hand, then rose from the slick Lambeau Field turf to run it into the end zone. ''Touchdown! He did what?!''

title: A World Of Water, All Murky And Deep
description: Though its human protagonists are intriguing enough, the most complex and arresting presence in ''Suzhou River'' may be the title character, a grimy man-made waterway that snakes through the industrial districts of Shanghai. The narrator of Lou Ye's moody exercise in modernist film noir is a videographer -- unseen except for an occasional hand reaching in front of the camera -- who trawls the river for images and stories. As he makes his way through the shadowy criminal demimonde at the river's edge, he is drawn, like a character in a Borges story or a Paul Auster novel, into a looking-glass world of crossed destinies, urban legends and mistaken identities.

title: Reckonings; To Boldly Go
description: So enough already about the election. Let's talk about William Shatner.

title: An Electorate Largely Split Reflects a Race So Very Tight
description: In the end, the portrait of the voters showed what a brutally competitive race it had been.

title: Isbister Lifts Islanders Into a Tie for First Place
description: First place for the New York Islanders? Believe it.

title: The Delicious Look of Stained Glass
description: IT was the epic banana-battle episode of ''Iron Chef.'' I watched, fascinated, as the reigning chef, Masahiko Kobe, concocted a pasta dish with garlic and banana. Then the challenger, Hirotaka Tsujiguchi, a pastry chef, created something truly amazing: a banana dessert garnished with what looked like shards of stained glass. The judges squealed with delight and awarded Mr. Tsujiguchi the victory.

title: Three-Way Pasta
description: AS popular as spaghetti alla carbonara may be, most American cooks don't realize that its essential element is meat. The crispy bits of cured pork that elevate the eggy sauce are actually the building blocks for three of the great classic pastas made in and around Rome.

title: Another Williams Has Home on Nets
description: Aaron Williams shook his head and scrunched his nose. He's not in favor of his new nickname, ''the Beast.''

title: PERSTORP BUYOUT OFF
description: The Swedish specialty chemicals maker that manufactures Pergo flooring, Perstorp A.B., said it terminated talks with Industri Kapital, a leveraged buyout firm, because Industri Kapital was no longer interested in acquiring the entire company. Industri Kapital withdrew a $1.1 billion offer for all of Perstorp in September but still wanted its chemicals business. Perstorp said it would revive a plan to spin off the flooring unit to shareholders next year.

title: Drug Makers Have New Versions of Cold Remedies
description: A day after the Food and Drug Administration announced its intention to ban a common ingredient in cold remedies and appetite suppressants, many pharmaceutical companies said yesterday that they had already reformulated their products and were ready to place safer versions on the shelves.

Friends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street on Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street on Thursday at 9:30 AM. Interment, Baldwinsville, NY.

title: Canadian Newsprint Producer Faces Attacks on Management
description: Executives of the world's largest newsprint producer, Abitibi-Consolidated of Canada, are fighting for their jobs in presentations to institutional investors across North America this week, after an attempt by its largest minority shareholder, Quebecor Inc., to have them removed.

title: NRG ENERGY PAYS $658 MILLION TO BUY INTO POWER PLANTS
description: NRG Energy Inc., a power-plant operator that first sold shares to the public last May, said it agreed to pay $658 million for stakes in 10 power plants in Illinois, Mississippi, Florida and Texas, some under construction, from LS Power L.L.C. The deal includes projects that together will generate a total of about 5,961 megawatts of power, increasing NRG's portfolio to more than 20,000 megawatts, the company said in a statement. LS Power is a closely held company based in East Brunswick, N.J.

title: Carter and Raptors Smother the Celtics
description: Vince Carter scored 23 points and the Toronto Raptors scored a franchise-record 41 points in the third quarter last night in beating the visiting Boston Celtics, 105-75.

title: Republicans Keep Senate; Goodman Is in Dead Heat
description: Republicans held onto their decades-long control of the New York State Senate last night, as most of the party's incumbents in competitive races beat back their Democratic challengers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYEN, PAUL
description: MAYEN-Paul. Died on November 3, 2000. Noted Architect and Industrial designer, founder of Habitat, Intrex and Architectural Supplements, Inc. Designer of the Visitor's Center at Frank Lloyd Wright's Fallingwater. Many of his works are in the permanent collection at the Museum of Modern Art. A passionate gardener, he was as witty in his designs as he was in conversation, and as an art collector, he was both avid and adroit. At ease in all situations, social and intellectual, he was as widely loved for his humor and rousing spirit, as for his compasssion and humanity. No funeral is planned, but a celebration of his life will be held in his New York gardens in the spring. Contributions in Paul's memory may be made to Western Pennsylvania Conservancy for Fallingwater, Box R, Route 381 South, Mill Run, PA. 15464.

title: Goodman in Tight Battle on the East Side
description: Roy M. Goodman, a Republican state senator who has represented Manhattan's East Side for 32 years, was locked in a tight re-election battle last night, with both the senator and his Democratic challenger suggesting that it might take days before a winner is ultimately decided.

title: Genies for Hire Cash In on Worker Stress
description: Peter London has the biggest to-do list in all of New York. Bigger than Rosie O'Donell's. Bigger then Mayor Giuliani's. Possibly even bigger than Hillary Clinton's.

title: In Detroit, a Coach Is Undone in Full View
description: Bobby Ross quit as the Detroit Lions coach on Monday, but things began unraveling for him after the 1998 season, a 5-11 run. First, the Lions courted Matt Millen, a former pro linebacker and current television broadcaster, as a new personnel chief, a move that would have usurped some of Ross's power.

title: Ruth Mitchell, 81, Producer Who Energized Broadway
description: Ruth Mitchell, one of Broadway's best-known backstage bosses who parlayed her professional prowess and personal flair into a successful producing career, died on Friday in Manhattan. She was 81.

title: The French Idea of Diet Food
description: FROMAGE blanc is a fresh cheese that is nothing more than cultured skim milk with some enzymes and salt. But, oh, what a brilliant culture it must be to turn much-reviled skim milk into a creamy cheese that provides as much pleasure as a schmear on a bagel. Maybe more, because the flavor of fromage blanc has a tangy pizazz, an element lacking in cream cheese.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column yesterday, about Latrell Sprewell of the Knicks, referred incorrectly to his status as a team leader. He is not a tri-captain; the team has co-captains, Allan Houston and Larry Johnson.

title: Corzine Wins Costly Bid for Senate in New Jersey
description: Jon S. Corzine, a liberal Democrat who made a fortune as a Wall Street executive and spent about $60 million of it on his first campaign for public office, won election to New Jersey's open seat in the United States Senate yesterday after shattering the national spending record for a statewide race.

title: RIVAL BUYS EVE.COM ASSETS
description: Sephora.com, the online arm of the cosmetics retailer Sephora, said it had acquired the remnants of Eve.com, an online beauty retailer that recently announced it planned to liquidate. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Eve.com's main financial backer had been Idealab. As part of the agreement, Sephora, a unit of the fashion giant LVMH-Moet Hennessey Louis Vuitton, will get the Eve.com domain name as well as part of its customer database.

title: Illinois Drivers Face Retesting After U.S. Inquiry Finds Licenses Had Been Sold
description: One driver stopped at green lights instead of red. Another did not know how to start his car. Both were among 470 licensed drivers ordered to retake their road tests this fall after the owner of a suburban Chicago driving school was convicted of bribing state examiners to pass his students.

title: T.W.A. SHARES RISE ON TAKEOVER BID FROM GLOBAL AIRLINES
description: Shares of Trans World Airlines Inc. jumped 26 percent yesterday after the Global Airlines Corporation offered to buy T.W.A. for $298 million. Under the offer, T.W.A. shareholders would receive $1.50 a share in cash and $2.25 a share in nonvoting Class B Global Airlines stock, which does not currently trade. Global, which has no operations, said it would assume all T.W.A.'s debt if its offer is successful. Global offered to acquire T.W.A. in June for $381 million, but T.W.A. never publicly responded to that offer. T.W.A. stock closed at $2.52, up 52 cents, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, HARRISON E.
description: TUCKER-Harrison E. The Baruch College community records with sorrow the death of Associate Professor, Harrison E. Tucker, the founder and long-time chairman of the Department of Black and Hispanic Studies. Born in Africa, Professor Tucker had a distinguished career as a magistrate and member of the diplomatic corps in his native Sierra Leone before joining Baruch in 1970. He remained an eloquent and dedicated teacher until his retirement in 1999. Our deepest sympathy goes to his wife Harriett, his children Arvette and Kanei, his grandchildren, and all his large, extended family. President Edward V. Regan, and The Faculty and Students of Baruch College

title: Art Collides With Life in a Cybercafe Made From an Old Public Lavatory
description: Virtual reality has met a kind of ultimate reality in a cybercafe, Public Life, left, which opened in September in recently fashionable Spitalfields. The subterranean space -- concrete-trussed with a glass-block ceiling -- was a men's public lavatory. The checkerboard marble floor and ceramic tile walls are original. A fake-concrete bar, neon baseboard strip lighting and steel entrance staircase are not. In the shadow of Christ Church, which was designed in 1715 by Nicholas Hawksmoor, the derelict lavatory was redeveloped as a commercial cafe with roughly $290,000 in public and private money. Internet connectivity, plus a lively mix of neighborhood types, including bankers and prostitutes, are part of the space's urban design, said the proprietor, Siraj Izhar, 39, an artist (inset). Mr. Izhar, the organizer of Strike, a collective of English Situationists, who have been staging events in the lavatory since 1992, called Public Life's interactions ''cultural jamming.'' Last month during a drag cabaret act, a fight broke out between two young East End toughs and band members in black stockings.

title: Preparations for Smooth Day at Polls Run Afoul of Murphy's Law

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRISANT, MILLARD
description: PRISANT-Millard. On November 8, 2000, at his home in Roslyn Harbor, N.Y. after a brief illness. Adored husband of Carol Lincoff Prisant and father of Barden. Born in Albany, GA. on May 27, 1935 to Myron and Lillian Prisant, Millard Prisant graduated from Shady Side Academy in Pittsburgh, and Magna Cum Laude from Yale with a degree in Physics. He subsequently attended Harvard Business School, and in 1959 he was made part of the MIT team sent to Cape Canaveral to design and troubleshoot the Polaris missile guidance system. These were among the happiest years of his life, for he was truly one of the original rocket scientists. Mr. Prisant then went on to found Mod-A-Can, Inc., a firm which manufacturers aircraft indicator cases, with branches in New York, Arizona and New Jersey. But, he was not a just theoretician. His great pleasure was in restoring-with his own hands-historic houses. There was no plumbing, electrical or landscape challenge that was beyond his talents. He was President of the Roslyn Preseveation Corp., Chairman of the Roslyn Harbor Planning Board, and Past President of the Roslyn Landmark Society. His was Sabatini's line from Scaramouche, ''He was born with a gift of laughter, and a sense that the world was mad.'' It described him perfectly, but he had, as well, a gentle, sweet, and eternally boyish soul. He was loved greatly. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave and 75 St, in New York City at 1:15PM Friday, November 10th. Burial will be at the Roslyn Cemetery, Northern Blvd in Roslyn, following the service. Flowers may be sent to Riverside Memorial Chapel, or donations may be made in his name to a charity of one's choice.

title: KOREAN BANKS FORCED TO MERGE
description: Hanvit Bank, one of South Korea's largest lenders, and three others will be forcibly merged because the government sees no way they can survive independently. Hanvit, Peace Bank of Korea, Kwangju Bank and Cheju Bank, which among them had $9.8 billion in bad loans at the end of June, will be combined under a single holding company. Two other troubled banks, Korea Exchange Bank and Chohung Bank, won approval for restructuring plans and will be allowed to try to remain independent.

So many of them must have been pleased that there was at least some concrete news this morning: Republicans had gained one Congressional seat, Joseph I. title: Video Bumper Cars, Minus the Inhibitions

But when I took one over a hill at 80 miles an hour, flew up into the air, crashed down, rolled over twice as my bumper and rear door flew off, righted myself and delivered my cargo to the gangsters who had contracted for it, I thought, wow, this car can really take a beating. I'm just glad I was wearing my seat belt.

But in the case of one modernist house on Long Island, two architects found two ideal clients. They came along after the fact -- 22 years after, to be precise -- but not too late to begin a close collaboration.

title: WHAT'S NEXT; Seeking Computers That Can Feel
description: DOCTORS have always relied on their sense of touch, for everything from palpating a lump to tightening a suture. But in recent years, technology has been dividing doctors from their patients. Minimally invasive (or ''keyhole'') surgery, in which cameras and surgical instruments are threaded through tiny openings, may drastically reduce patient trauma and recovery time, but it also eliminates the direct contact with organs, bones and muscles that doctors have enjoyed in open surgery.

title: COMDISCO OPERATING PROFIT TOPS FORECAST
description: The technology services and equipment-leasing company Comdisco said its fourth-quarter operating profits more than doubled. Benefiting from strong gains in its Ventures equipment leasing and finance division, Comdisco reported earnings from continuing operations of $70 million, or 44 cents a share, for the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with $44 million, or 27 cents, a year earlier and above analysts' consensus estimate of 38 cents a share. The operating results excluded a $238 million loss from the discontinued high-speed Internet connection business Prism Communication Services. Including that loss, the net loss for the quarter was $168 million, or $1.05 a share, compared with a profit of $30 million, or 19 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter.

title: J. Sinclair Armstrong, S.E.C. Chief, Dies at 85
description: J. Sinclair Armstrong, a Manhattan banker, lawyer and high government official whose 60-year career in the quiet corridors of power had its most public battle in the fight to stop St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church from building a skyscraper on its Manhattan property in the 1980's, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: INTERNET CAPITAL TO CUT STAFF
description: The Internet Capital Group, an investor in online industrial commerce companies, said it would cut 50 jobs, or 35 percent of its work force, and write off some assets as it battles investor distaste for Internet investing. The company said it would take a charge of $25 million to $30 million to pay for the cuts. Internet Capital dropped $3.38, or 21 percent, to $12.88 in after-hours trading. The shares fell $2.06, to $16.25, during normal trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLCOTT, SAMUEL HUNTINGTON, JR.
description: WOLCOTT-Samuel Huntington, Jr. On November 7, 2000 in Westwood, MA. He was a graduate of Saint Paul's School and Harvard College 1933, where he lettered in three varsity sports. Mary, his beloved wife of 56 years, pre-deceased him in 1990. He is survived by three children, Samuel Huntington Wolcott, III of Locust Valley, N.Y., Philip Weld Wolcott of Dana Point, CA. and Pamela Wolcott Fingleton of New York City. His youngest son, William Prescott Wolcott died in 1989. He is also survived by six grandchildren and four great grandchildren. He was a founding member of Loring, Wolcott & Coolidge of Boston, a fiduciary services firm. He served for many years on the Board of the State Street Bank and the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company. He was President of The Country Club in Brookline, MA. from 1957 to 1963, during which time The Club hosted the 1963 U.S. Open Golf Championship. Private services for immediate family are planned at a later date.

title: China Sentences 11 Officials to Death in Smuggling Scandal
description: Chinese courts today convicted 84 people of corruption, smuggling and other charges, handing out 11 death sentences to government officials. These were the first punishments meted out in connection with an embarrassing multibillion-dollar smuggling scandal in the port city of Xiamen.

title: Wedgwood Catches A Case of the Giggles
description: Wedgwood, the 250-year-old British company, approached the designer Nick Munro to create modern ceramics using the jasper clay for which the company has long been known. Mr. Munro used it in its natural cream-color state and dyed it black for the simple cups, saucers and teapots in the collection. ''Wedgwood is perceived as a stuffy company,'' Mr. Munro said. ''I wanted to do something that's fun.'' Thus, he also made the dog and cat bowls, lower left, which are part of the collection. Available at Felissimo, 10 West 56th Street, (212) 247-5656. The teapot is $190; the cup and saucer, $100; and a cat or dog bowl is $142.

title: Metro Business Briefing; HOME PRICES RISE IN HARLEM

Corcoran, a brokerage firm, identified 117 Harlem brownstones sold in the first six months of 2000, up 76 percent from the first six months of 1999. Scott Durkin, chief operating officer of the Corcoran Group, said the information was compiled from Corcoran's data and that of Mitchell, Maxwell & Jackson, its appraisal company. Allison Fass (NYT)
