title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAULKINS, DIXIE THOMPSON
description: CAULKINS-Dixie Thompson, who played a prominent role in women's volunteerism in New York for three decades, died November 4 at her home on Jupiter Island, Florida. She was 84, and the cause was complications from ovarian cancer. Born in Honolulu, of a leading kaamaina family, she attended Punahou School there, then the Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, CT and the Sorbonne in Paris. She was a member of The Daughters of Hawaii and was also inducted into the Most Venerable Order of the Hospital of St. John of Jerusalem. After her first husband Samuel Carnes Collier died in 1950, she moved her family from Florida to New York City and began her long association with a number of its prominent volunteer organizations. After her marriage to H. Whitfield Carhart in 1952, she became most closely identified with The Boys Club of New York, where she served for many years as President of the Women's Board, directing their volunteer activities. She also held a leading volunteer role at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital, chairing the annual Ball of the Roses benefit, and after her husband died in 1977, succeeding as a Trustee until her resignation several years ago. In 1979, she married Dan Platt Caulkins, who died in 1995. Loved by her family and many friends for her great style and wit, and admired for her refined taste and lively dinner parties that often benefited her charities, Dixie also possessed great resilience and an infectious ''joie de vivre'' that created an atmosphere of fun and happiness for those around her. She is survived by her sister Barbara Thompson of Honolulu, her three sons, Richard Collier and Thomas Carhart of New York and Terry Collier of Palm Beach, as well as ten grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. One son Samuel Carnes Collier Jr., and her stepdaughter Elizabeth Morris Carhart, predeceased her. In lieu of flowers, her family requests donations please be sent to either of the above organizations. Memorial services will be held at 5PM, on December 11, at Christ Memorial Chapel on Jupiter Island, Florida.

title: Browser
description: A selection of events and sites on the Web.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTTON, ROBERT L.
description: COTTON-Robert L. Beloved husband of Hannah. Devoted father of William (Eve) & Susan Berkson (Stanley). Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Services Friday, 10AM, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: HONDA'S PROFIT FALLS
description: Hurt by the strengthening yen, Honda Motor, which gets 73 percent of its revenue outside Japan, said its net group profit for the six months ended Sept. 30 fell 10.6 percent from the period a year earlier, to 122 billion yen ($1.1 billion), on slightly higher sales of 3.05 trillion yen ($28.4 billion). Honda reported selling 1.24 million cars, up 4.1 percent from the period a year earlier, and 2.55 million motorcycles, up 18.6 percent. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZELDIN, BENJAMIN
description: ZELDIN-Benjamin. Your incredible spirit, love and devotion are with us everyday. Life isn't the same without you. Love, Beverly, Michael, Randy, Andrew, Amy, Zehava, Robin, and seven grandchidlre

title: The Balance of Power in the States: West
description: States with a change in control of a legislative chamber or the governor's office in bold. States that did not have elections in 2000 are in italics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARROW, SAUL
description: CHARROW-Saul. Long standing member of the Board of Directors of the Workmen's Circle Multicare Center. He was dedicated to working on behalf of the residents and providing the best quality of care and quality of life to all residents. He will be missed by all who knew him. Samuel Byer, President David Londin, Exec. Dir. Judy Fenster, Asst. Exec. Dir.

title: Absentee Ballots Will Be Decisive
description: Across the continent from the vote-counting imbroglio in Florida that will determine the winner of the presidency, Washington state officials were confronted today with another remarkably close contest whose outcome may well determine whether Democrats can lay claim to exactly half the seats in the United States Senate.

title: Turning the Computer Into a Big Clock-Radio
description: As computer makers keep adding more ports to personal computers, other manufacturers keep dreaming up more gizmos to plug into those ports. Now comes the D-Link DSB-R100 U.S.B. FM Radio, and yes, it is exactly what its name suggests: an FM radio that plugs into a computer's U.S.B. port.

title: Florida, Amid Recount, Learns the Power of One
description: Every vote counts. It is something children learn in civics class.

title: First Lady Emerges From Shadow And Begins to Cast Her Own
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton began the remarkable transition yesterday from a quarter-century of derivative power as a political spouse to a potent force in her own right. The world's most famous first lady and senator-elect held a love-fest of a news conference, said that her first bill would be to improve the upstate economy and fended off the inevitable question about whether she would seek the White House in 2004.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Page B12 today showing the political breakdown of the new Senate misstates the affiliations of the members from Idaho and Indiana. Idaho will have two Republicans, not a Democrat and a Republican. Indiana will have a Democrat and a Republican, not two Republicans.

title: Gore Expresses Gratitude
description: Following is an excerpt from a statement yesterday by Vice President Al Gore about the undecided results of the presidential election, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: How Gore Stopped Short On His Way to Concede
description: When his limousine arrived at the War Memorial Plaza in Nashville, where a few thousand despondent, rain-soaked supporters awaited the concession, Vice President Al Gore assumed he had lost the election.

title: Fresh Looks Turn Heads In Notting Hill
description: Westbourne Grove, in the Notting Hill section of London, is home to a happy abundance of stores offering fresh design. Vessel, at 114 Kensington Park Road, has the exhibition ''Salviati Meets London,'' a pairing of Salviati, a venerable Murano glass company, with the home team. ''We wanted the best British designers, and to marry their work with the best Italian glass blowers,'' said Nadia Demetriou Ladas, who owns Vessel with Angel Monzon. The collection includes work by Nigel Coates and Simon Moore. (And the bottlelike sculpture below by Tom Dixon is called ''Sophisticate Set.'') Christopher Farr, at 212 Westbourne Grove, has a new line of upholstery fabrics, above, called Cloth, available in the United States at the de Sousa Hughes showroom in San Francisco, (415) 626-6883, from $57 to $113 for a yard. Even public conveniences in the area are carefully thought out. The Toilets, left, are by Piers Gough and include a flower shop. And there is a new 20-room hotel called Westbourne, at 163-165 Westbourne Grove, with interior design and furniture from CA1, which last month introduced a line of furniture inspired by the 1940's and 50's. The hotel's bed, above, $4,650 from CA1, (011) 44-207-611-5200). Or take it for a test drive at the Westbourne, where rooms start at $215 a night, (011) 44-207-229-7791.

title: Group Roams Chat Rooms to Talk to Gay Men About AIDS
description: WHERE men meet men for sex, health agencies are sure to follow. In San Francisco, the bars in predominantly gay neighborhoods teem with safe-sex posters, baskets of free condoms and fliers for counseling services. Health officials hope that their message sticks in the mind of a patron as he leaves with a willing partner.

title: G.O.P. Retains Control, but Democrats Gain in Both Chambers
description: Democratic gains in the House and Senate on Tuesday fell short of control but produced the most narrowly divided Congress in almost half a century. Democrats gained at least three Senate seats and one or two in the House.

title: SOUTH
description: KENTUCKY BUSH

title: The Races for Governor
description: John Burris, R

title: NORTHEAST
description: MASSACHUSETTS GORE

title: Despite Recount, G.O.P. Senator and Rival Each Sound Victorious
description: The political fate of State Senator Roy M. Goodman, one of New York City's most enduring and prominent Republicans, remained uncertain yesterday, with his race for re-election too close to call a full day after the polls closed.

title: CANCER DRUG TRIALS ARE SUSPENDED
description: Shares of NeoRx, a Seattle biotechnology company, lost nearly half their value yesterday after the Food and Drug Administration suspended clinical trials of a cancer drug because four patients experienced potentially fatal side effects. NeoRx is counting on the radioactive drug, which it calls skeletal targeted radiotherapy, to be its first product. It recently began late-stage trials to treat multiple myeloma, a blood cancer. NeoRx said the four patients developed a syndrome that involves abnormal blood clotting. Dr. Paul G. Abrams, chief executive, said he thought the company would be able to address the F.D.A. concerns. The syndrome appeared only in some patients who got the highest dose and did not have irrigation to flush excess radiation out of their bladders, he said, adding that the irrigation is now being used on all patients. NeoRx shares fell $8.06, to $9.38. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas rose on expectations that wintry weather will move into the Midwest, bolstering demand. In New York, natural gas for December delivery rose 25.7 cents, to $5.338 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Mass Transit Advocates Hope Expansion Plans Can Survive
description: Time for Plan B.

title: Wonderful as a Batter, Not So Wonderful as a Man
description: ''Cobb,'' which had a limited run in a production by the Melting Pot Theater last spring, reopened yesterday off Broadway at the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, Greenwich Village. Following are excerpts of a review by Bruce Weber that appeared on April 21.

title: NORTHEAST
description: RHODE ISLAND GORE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, AYELET HASCHACHAR
description: LEVY - Ayelet Haschachar. EMUNAH of America and Religious Zionists of America mourn the tragic murder of Ayelet Haschachar Levy, graduate of the EMUNAH College in Jerusalem. We mourn the loss of lives. Innocent victims of Palestinian barbarism. This time, it was family! Ayelet Haschachar Levy, a 28-year-old mother and talented artist was killed when a terrorist car bomb detonated Thursday afternoon in downtown Jerusalem. ''Ayelet HaSchachar'' means the 'first sparks of dawn' in Hebrew, but the young woman, whose future was just about to unfold, will never know another dawn. Our heartfelt condolences to her father, Rabbi Yitzhak Levy, Member of Knesset and Head of the National Religious Party, her mother, Chana, and her three-year-old daughter. The human toll, exacted by countless acts of brutality and cold-blooded terrorism, is escalating. We decry the callous disregard for human life, and the violence unleashed against Israel. May the Almighty console the Levy Family together with all mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Sylvia Schonfeld Chairman of the Board Marcia Genuth National President Rabbi Simcha Krauss National President, Religous Zionists of America

title: MIDWEST
description: ILLINOIS GORE

title: For a Divided America, a Momentous Night; A Delicate Fabric
description: To the Editor:

title: Golf; Players Talk Only of Money
description: As the official golf season reaches its conclusion, money has become the most popular topic among the players.

title: Japanese Police Arrest Founder Of Violent 70's Radical Group
description: The Japanese police today arrested the founder of the Japanese Red Army, a radical group that carried out several international terrorist attacks in the 1970's.

title: COURT BLOCKS HEINZ PURCHASE OF BEECH-NUT
description: The H. J. Heinz Company was barred by a federal appeals court from buying the owner of a rival maker of baby food, Beech-Nut, while antitrust authorities press their case to stop the merger. The decision could kill the transaction. Heinz and Beech-Nut together would have roughly 30 percent of the United States baby food market; Gerber Products, a unit of Novartis A.G., has nearly all the rest. The merger agreement between Heinz and the Milnot Holdings Company, the privately held owner of Beech-Nut, expires at the end of the month.

title: In Decade, Queens School District Slips From Desirable to Troubled
description: Just a decade ago, Community School District 29 in southeastern Queens was one of the city's most desirable, in a largely middle-class black neighborhood of stout brick homes and tree-lined streets whose schools had high reading scores and calm classrooms.

title: A Neo-Punk Library And the Edifice Vote
description: The winner of this year's Stirling Prize from the Royal Institute of British Architects is the Peckham Library Center, right, by Will Alsop, of Alsop & Stormer. The library, Mr. Alsop said, ''gets away from the British disease of making high-tech architecture, with all the cables, glass and steel.'' He termed its style neo-punk. On Sunday night, Channel 4 in England televised the announcement of the prize, worth not quite $30,000. The station also let viewers vote for their favorite new building. A Sainsbury grocery store won, by one vote, over Norman Foster's Canary Wharf. Who says architecture isn't democratic?

title: Wedding Wishes Fulfilled Over the Web
description: A PACKAGE arrived in the mail a few years ago. Inside was a curious object: a fat ceramic cat with what appeared to be a cranial tumor. Because the mysterious package had no return address, I wondered who might have sent it. Closer inspection revealed that the tumor was really a knob that enabled you to lift off the top of the cat's head. I ruled out the Unabomber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLOUGH, GRACE
description: CARLOUGH-Grace. 79 of Germantown, TN died November 7. Graveside services will be 11:00 am Monday at Holy Rood Cemetery in Westbury, NY. She leaves two daughters Joan C. Matthews of Germantown and Barbara A. Lindquist of Sandy Hook, CT and one son Stephen P. Carlough Jr. of Fort Myers, FL.

title: For a Divided America, a Momentous Night; The Tightest Races
description: To the Editor:

title: Voting Made Difficult
description: While national attention focused on the vote in Florida, New Yorkers encountered familiar frustrations in the exercise of their civic obligations on Tuesday. Some fidgeted and fumed in long lines that ended at broken voting machines. Some were given the wrong instructions, even the wrong ballots. Others found their names missing from the rolls, including those who had registered when they got their driver's licenses -- proof that the much-touted ''motor voter'' system has serious flaws.

title: At the Altar of Nijinsky, Elusive Firebird and Faun
description: Why such abiding interest in a dancer whose legendary stage presence was witnessed by no one alive today, whose athletic leaps were never caught on film, whose seductive poses and exotic costumes survive only in drawings and photographs? Indeed, how measure the talent of this same dancer as choreographer when he created but four works performed only a few dozen times during his lifetime?

title: Metro Business Briefing; UNIONIZED WORK FORCE
description: New York has surpassed Hawaii as the state with the highest percentage of unionized voters, according to new data from the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Union members made up 25.3 percent of New York's employees in 1999, down very slightly from 25.4 percent in 1998, when Hawaii led the category at 26.5 percent. Nationally, organized labor accounted for about 13.9 percent of all working people, unchanged from 1998. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: St. John's Has New Look and Outlook
description: Eight months later, the memories are still painful for the St. John's men's basketball team. There was anger directed at the National Collegiate Athletic Association for twice suspending its point guard. Uncertainty lingered over who would be playing each night. Players had to miss practice to speak with N.C.A.A. investigators.

title: Holt Has Slim Lead as Most Incumbents Win
description: In the closest of several tight Congressional races in the New York region, Representative Rush Holt, a freshman Democrat in New Jersey's 12th District, led by a whisker, 56 votes, yesterday over former Representative Dick Zimmer, a Republican who had hoped to reclaim the seat he held from 1991 to 1997.

title: Electors Pledge Allegiance to Candidates of Their Respective Political Parties
description: Candidates for the Electoral College, suddenly in the spotlight because of the uncertain outcome of the presidential election, said today that they would never dream of betraying their pledges to support George W. Bush or Al Gore.

title: Hart Edgar Van Riper, 95; Shepherded Polio Research
description: Dr. Hart Edgar Van Riper, a pediatrician who as a foundation official shepherded the development of the vaccines that virtually wiped out polio in the United States, died Saturday in Indianapolis. A former resident of the Upper East Side of Manhattan, he was 95.

title: Recipe for a Stalemate
description: ''Now we learn,'' said the political scientist Thomas Mann, one of the leading authorities on Congress, ''who the grown-ups are around here.'' Like the rest of the nation, Mr. Mann, who is based at the Brookings Institution, a Washington research group, awoke to a situation unprecedented in modern American history, shaped by a once-in-a-lifetime series of electoral events that holds the potential for stalemate and instability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, ROSE, NEE ENGEL V. JANOSI
description: STEIN-Rose, nee Engel v. Janosi, Saturday, November 4. Survived by loving husband, Marcel Stein, daughter and son-in-law Anna Stein-Abdi and Nourredine Abdi, son and daughter-in-law, Gabor and Anna Szikla, grandson and his wife Stephane and Isabelle Szendy and great grandchildren, Olivia and Mathias Szendy. - Born in Pecs, Hungary, immigrated to the United States in 1958, finished her career as a librarian at Columbia University. Developed oral history for the Austro-Hungarian section at Columbia University Library. Memorial donations may be made: Hungarian Oral History Project at Columbia University.

title: WEST
description: MONTANA BUSH

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: REED ELSEVIER , Amsterdam, the British-Dutch publisher, said it had formally begun its $4.45 billion tender offer for Harcourt General Inc., Newtown, Mass., a multiple-media publisher. Under the deal, Reed Elsevier would sell Harcourt's higher education and professional publishing services to the Thomson Corp., a Canadian publisher, for $2.06 billion.

title: SOUTH
description: NORTH CAROLINA BUSH

title: Rock's Past and Thrills of Old Rowdiness
description: Cavestomp, the annual festival of current garage-rock bands and resurrected one-hit wonders that took over the Westbeth Theater Center for three nights ending on Sunday, is all about fuzz-toned guitars and walloping drums, with undercurrents of heartbreak and mortality.

title: If Senate Loss Was a Crime, the G.O.P. Left Many Fingerprints
description: Nearly two hours after the polls closed on election night, some of New York's most prominent Republicans filed onstage at a Midtown Manhattan hotel, turned and faced forward. And for all the forced hand-clapping and tight smiles that followed, they still looked as though they were posing in a lineup for a crime of politics.

title: New in the House
description: WEST VIRGINIA

title: In Hindsight, Fair Showing For Foresight
description: So how did the pollsters come out in the end with their presidential race surveys?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREAKSTONE, MYRON
description: BREAKSTONE-Myron. On November 8, 2000. Beloved husband of Gladys, loving father of Ronald and Steven, dear brother of Joseph, Jane and the late Seymour Breakstone and Natalie Klein. Cherished grandfather to Nina and Dean. Services Thursday 11:15 am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TELEPHONE BACKLOG CLEARED UP
description: Verizon Communications says it has cleared up a backlog of nearly 60,000 orders for telephone service that piled up in New York State during a 15-day strike by its workers in August. The company has told the state's Public Service Commission that the backlog of requests for new lines and added features like call waiting was whittled down to 6,000 by the end of September and eliminated altogether by Oct. 23. A backlog of thousands of repair orders in the state ''was pretty much overcome by the end of September,'' William Allan, vice president for regulatory affairs for Verizon in New York, said yesterday. The 4,034 customer complaints lodged against Verizon with the New York Public Service Commission during the first nine months of this year are one-third more than during the comparable period last year. Mr. Allan attributed this to the strike and to the ''wet spring and early summer this year,'' saying damage to cables and other equipment is more frequent with extended rain and flooding. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: GENERAL MOTORS TO IDLE 2,200 WORKERS AT VAN PLANT
description: The General Motors Corporation, which is cutting back vehicle production for the fourth quarter because of swelling inventories of unsold cars and trucks, said it would idle about 2,200 workers at its Wentzville, Miss., commercial van plant for two weeks beginning Monday. The plant makes the Chevrolet Express and Savana full-size vans. G.M. idled two Michigan car assembly plants for a week last month, affecting about 9,500 workers, as it sought to ease oversupplies of unsold Oldsmobile Auroras and other vehicles.

title: New Faces in Congress
description: ROBERT R. SIMMONS

title: ONLINE GROCER LIFTS FEES
description: Webvan, the online grocery service available in 10 metropolitan areas around the country, took another step toward bolstering its financial position by raising the minimum order for free delivery. The company, based in Foster City, Calif., said it would charge customers in the San Francisco region a $4.95 delivery free for orders under $75, instead of offering free delivery for all orders over $50. The move follows the company's $1.2 billion acquisition of a rival, HomeGrocer.com, in June, after which Webvan announced it would lay off 50 employees. Webvan recently announced a third-quarter loss of $148 million, or 40 cents a share, on $54 million in sales. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: For a Divided America, a Momentous Night; Other Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: A Crowd Around the Televisions
description: Tuesday's down-to-the-wire presidential election was probably the most watched event of the past year other than the Super Bowl.

title: Pepsi Assignments Are Consolidated
description: Pepsi-Cola International said yesterday that it had consolidated its account at offices of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, by naming the agency to handle the Mirinda and 7Up brands in overseas markets.

title: WEST
description: ALASKA BUSH

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, J. SINCLAIR
description: ARMSTRONG-J. Sinclair. Of New York City. At age 85. Died on November 5, 2000. Survived by his wife, Charlotte, and his children, Katherine C.A. Young, James S. Armstrong, Jr., Stephen H. and Jeanne H. Armstrong, Robert S. & Phoebe H. Armstrong & Elisabeth Armstrong-Bushey; also, his niece, Leslie Armstrong, eight grandchildren, a great-nephew and two great nieces, among many other loving family members. Services private. A memorial gathering will be scheduled at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Harvard Library in New York, 27 West 44th Street, New York, New York 10036, or to Harvard Law School, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02138 for the J. Sinclair Armstrong Revolving Student Loan Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENDROFF, BERNARD E.
description: WENDROFF-Bernard E. on November 7, 2000 at age 72. Beloved husband of Rosanna. Loving father of Barry and his wife Andrea and Jill and her husband Bill. Treasured brother of Paula and Alan Barnett, son of the late Rose and Louis. Adoring grandfather of Ali, dear uncle. A most cherised friend to their children's mother Phyllis. Lifelong and devoted friend to Howard and many more who will dearly miss him. His love for life and his big heart made him one in a million. His fantastic sense of humor and quick wit always left us waiting for his next phone call. We will always be talking to you. Services today 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St & Amsterdam Av

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: On NBC, Echoes Of Comedy Central

title: For a Divided America, a Momentous Night; Educate the Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Patients To Get Web At Bedside
description: WHEN the new Montefiore children's hospital opens in the Bronx next fall, it will have Internet computer terminals at each of its 105 beds to help educate, entertain and heal its young patients.

title: Still Growing, Brewing Giant To Sell Shares
description: To bolster its position as Europe's biggest brewing company, Interbrew of Belgium said today that it would seek to raise as much as $2.8 billion by selling an initial public offering in December of roughly 21 percent of its shares.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day yesterday about the third-quarter earnings of MetLife Inc. misstated its share price on Tuesday. The stock rose by 94 cents, to $27 (not $3.81, to $87.38). Yesterday MetLife's shares rose by 88 cents, to $27.88.

title: Getting It Right in Florida
description: First let us pause and survey an extraordinary scene that confronts a nation that is making history moment by moment. On a day when the identity of our next president is usually clear, the political process is frozen. Two former secretaries of state have answered their parties' calls and are headed to Florida to help oversee the recount likely to decide whether Vice President Al Gore or Gov. George W. Bush is the 43rd president of the United States. The candidates themselves emerged briefly from seclusion to issue cautious endorsements of the constitutional process, but neither side seemed to rule out an extended legal or political struggle. Meanwhile, the brother of one of the potential presidents, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, has recused himself from one of the most fateful vote counts ever conducted in an American election.

title: MIDWEST
description: NEBRASKA BUSH

title: Sports of The Times; Ted Williams Still Living On His Terms
description: THE old gray-haired man in the wheelchair was rolled into the private room in the restaurant for a dinner party and immediately created a stir. He always has. He was once known as the Kid, and when he was greeted, and when he spoke, in that deep, emphatic voice mixed with humor and delight, there was still that unmistakable ebullience and charm. It was obvious that, at age 81, Ted Williams still loved life almost as much as he loved to hit a baseball.

title: G.O.P. Gains A Future Edge In Districting
description: Despite Democratic gains that narrowed the Republican majority in the House of Representatives, election results in state legislatures on Tuesday have put Republicans in position to overcome those losses in 2002 by the creation of safe Republican seats as districts are reshaped through reapportionment.

title: Ewing Scores 15 as Sonics Lose to Heat
description: When he was introduced tonight, Patrick Ewing drew only a smattering of boos. Nobody was waving any signs to show love or hate. It was almost as if he had become just another player.

title: Senator Refuses To Challenge Loss
description: It was a strange and unusual Senate race: A dead man and his widow running against an incumbent. And the outcome was just as unusual, if not unlikely: They won.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYEN, PAUL
description: MAYEN-Paul. A beloved and cherished friend. Paul, you will be missed, I will think of you often: your charm, your humor, your kindness-you're truly one of life's rare gentlemen. See you on the other side! Caroline Sharp Jamie Curtis

title: SOUTH
description: LOUISIANA BUSH

title: Introducing Hillary Clinton, Senator-Elect
description: To the Editor:

title: From Japan to New York?
description: The Mets did, but the Yankees did not submit a bid to the commissioner's office yesterday in an attempt to secure negotiating rights to a seven-time Japanese batting champion.

title: NORTHEAST
description: NEW YORK GORE

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the results of New York Regents examinations referred incorrectly to The Daily News's publication of preliminary math and English scores on Tuesday. The News said its reporters had obtained the results from sources outside the State Education Department and were thus unaffected by the department's official release date, set for today.

title: For a Divided America, a Momentous Night; An Electoral Suggestion
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Flags Are Raised in Florida, but No Accusations
description: No one is charging fraud in the confusion and uncertainty surrounding Florida's presidential vote, but the possibility that the final results may hinge either on absentee ballots or recounting the allegedly misleading ballots in one county raises red flags for some people here.

title: Kenyon Martin Shows Why He Was Top Pick
description: Kenyon Martin began his scoring tonight with a backboard-shaking dunk, and as he hung on the rim to enjoy the view, he knew, at last, that he was levitating at the level of expectation.

title: New in the Senate
description: DELAWARE

title: Lazio Silent, But Allies See Bright Future
description: The day after his defeat in the United States Senate race, Rick A. Lazio retreated to his home in the Suffolk County hamlet of Brightwaters, spending time with his family and offering thanks to supporters by telephone.

title: The Balance of Power in the States: Northeast
description: States with a change in control of a legislative chamber or the governor(TM)s office in bold. States that did not have elections in 2000 are in italics.

title: Indian-Graves Fight Forces Change in Missouri River Power
description: A federal court has forced a major shift in hydroelectric power operations along the Missouri River, in a ruling intended to provide at least temporary safeguards for Indian graves that are being exposed by record-low water levels.

title: A Cell Phone With MP3: It's Like Being on Hold
description: Just when it seems that the youth market is growing bored with plain old cell phones, along comes a phone with a built-in MP3 player.

title: DUELING SWISS WIRELESS STAKES
description: The Vodafone Group has agreed to take a minority stake in Switzerland's leading mobile phone company, while France Telecom said it would increase its stake in the second biggest. Vodafone gets 25 percent of Swisscom Mobile, the wireless unit of Swisscom, for $:1.8 billion ($2.56 billion). France Telecom, which already owns 42.5 percent of Orange Communications, will acquire another 42.5 percent from E.on, the German utilities group, for 1.1 billion euros ($940 million). Switzerland will auction new mobile phone licenses later this month. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Back From an Injury, Brodeur Loses
description: Martin Brodeur gave clear testimony on the ice, with splits and flips and flops, that his groin injury has healed. Brodeur played well enough to earn his 250th career victory tonight, but his teammates had their troubles as the Devils sustained their third consecutive loss, falling by 4-3 to the Nashville Predators.

title: A new measure for Internet sponsorships in the search for a viable online business model.
description: A SYSTEM to measure the effectiveness of Internet sponsorships as a brand-building tool for advertisers is being introduced this week.

title: Brown U. Breaks Ground In Picking Black as Chief
description: Ruth J. Simmons, the president of Smith College and the youngest of 12 children of a Texas sharecropper, is expected to be appointed the new president of Brown University today.

title: From the Ballot Box to the Blackboard
description: As Ansley Erickson arrived at her Harlem high school yesterday, her mind was churning. Like social studies teachers around the country, Ms. Erickson knew that she would have to abandon her regular lesson, on the positive and negative consequences of the Industrial Revolution, to talk about the cliffhanger of a presidential election.

title: Prosecutors Air Lockerbie Theories, Trying to Undercut Them
description: After a month's delay for lawyers to investigate unexplained new evidence, testimony resumed in the Lockerbie trial today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, PHYLLIS (NEE LIFTON)
description: WEINER-Phyllis (nee Lifton). On November 3, 2000, while traveling in China with her devoted husband of 39 years, Howard. She will be remembered and missed by her children, Jeffrey, Cynthia, Michael and Jeanne Gerstley Weiner, for her spirit, humor, and warmth. She is the cherished sister of Martin and Ellie Lifton of Old Westbury, N.Y., & Dr. & Mrs. Robert Weiner of Denver, CO. She is the beloved grandmother of Zach, Jake, Emmy and Allie. She will be sadly missed by her many nieces, nephews, cousins and close friends, whom she adored. The family will receive visitors Saturday, November 11, from 7-9PM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St. A funeral service will be held Sunday, November 12, at 11:45AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to Smith College, Northampton, MA. 01063, The New York Philharmonic, Avery Fisher Hall, 10 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023, or Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77 Street, New York, New York 10021.

The award usually goes to one of the great figures in the game, although it once went to Deng Xiaoping, whose enthusiasm allowed bridge to flourish in China. Rarely, it goes to someone who works behind the scenes, as it did in September when Anna Gudge of England was honored in Maastricht, the Netherlands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISER, HARRY
description: WEISER-Harry. At 95, of Rego Park, NY, died peacefully at home November 8. Beloved husband of Rose (deceased); loving father of Alan and his wife, Ruth, and Eleanor (deceased); devoted and cherished grandfather of David, Debra and Diane, and beloved uncle. He will be missed by all who knew him. He was a gentle man who held family above all else. Services will be held at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, Friday, November 10, at Noon.

title: HEAVY DEMAND FOR A NEW COMPUTER
description: I.B.M.'s president, Samuel J. Palmisano, said yesterday that wide availability of its newest mainframe computer, the Z900, would be delayed until next year. The computer maker had been expected to ship the machines in mid-December, but Mr. Palmisano said it would not be able to meet demand by then. ''We're not going to have the supply to satisfy all the customers that want the Z900 in the fourth quarter,'' he said at a meeting with analysts. ''So we've had to go out to our customers, which we did on Friday, and give them the dates.'' He did not specify when the computers would be shipped to all customers who wanted them. I.B.M.'s shares dropped $2.13, or 2.1 percent, to $100.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY TO BUY BENJAMIN MOORE PAINTS
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, has agreed to buy the paint maker Benjamin Moore & Company for about $1 billion in cash. Berkshire Hathaway will pay $37.82 a share in a deal announced in a news release. The price is a 51 percent premium to Benjamin Moore's closing price yesterday. Berkshire Hathaway primarily owns insurance companies. The offer is subject to certain conditions, including the tender of at least two-thirds of the shares outstanding as well as regulatory approval. Shares of Benjamin Moore fell 50 cents, to $25. Berkshire Hathaway Class A shares fell $800, to $64,800.

Web Is a New Stage for Vaudeville
description: SOME say vaudeville originated from drinking songs in France in the Valley of the Vire (Vau de Vire) and later became ''street voices'' (voix de ville). It was marinated in American barrooms and British music halls, and at its height in the 1920's, an estimated two million people a day watched it in perhaps 2,000 American theaters (topped, of course, by the Palace in New York). Even today, one can spot its remnants when Jay or Dave or Conan add variety to their talk, with a funny animal act followed by a popular singer's performance followed by a film clip or a comedy routine.

title: Fresh Prints in Classic Toile
description: IT'S baaaaacck. Toile de Jouy, the classic 18th-century French fabric printed primarily with drawings of bucolic scenes, is turning up on sheets, pillow cases, duvet covers -- even babies' bedding. But this is toile with a difference. Some manufacturers artfully incorporate parts of classic patterns -- horses, chickens, even butterflies -- into looser designs. And the standard colors (red, blue or black on white) are often replaced with more contemporary combinations. All the bedding here is 100 percent cotton. Fans of classic toile, note: An exhibition called ''Heroes, Legends and Martyrs: Images on European and American Toiles'' opens at the Baltimore Museum of Art the day before Thanksgiving.

ARVINMERITOR, MAKER OF TRUCK AXLES, TO TRIM 1,500 JOBS
description: ArvinMeritor Inc., the largest maker of heavy-truck axles, said it would cut about 1,500 jobs, or 4 percent of its work force, as North American heavy-truck and automobile production slows. ArvinMeritor announced the move yesterday along with a 56 percent decline in earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter, which ended Sept. 30. The company, which now has about 36,500 employees, did not say where or when the cuts will occur, but did say it expects to take a charge of $39 million, or 57 cents a share, in the current quarter and sees pretax savings of about $25 million in fiscal 2001 and $50 million the next year.

title: Metro Business Briefing; SNAPPLE OFFICES STAYING
description: Cadbury Schweppes, which acquired Snapple Beverage Group last month, said yesterday that Snapple's headquarters would stay in White Plains. However, the headquarters of Royal Crown Cola, which Snapple makes, will move from White Plains to Plano, Tex., to become part of Cadbury's Dr Pepper/7Up unit. Stewart's, another soft-drink company owned by Snapple, will move to White Plains from Denver early next year.

title: A Home Born In the Hanoi Hilton
description: IN his redwood-lined study outside Washington, Bob Shumaker keeps a scale model of an F-8 Crusader jet fighter plane, maybe nine inches long. The study, like the rest of the house, is modest, with clean, simple lines and crisp right angles. The F-8 model has a broken wheel, and one of its Sidewinder missiles is loose.

title: BP AMOCO IN TALKS TO BUY STAKE IN CHINA NATIONAL
description: BP Amoco is in talks to invest about $200 million in the China National Offshore Oil Corporation, an official at the Chinese company said. A stake in China National would give BP Amoco a share in oil production off the Chinese coast, where China National now has a monopoly. Most of the increase in China's oil output in the next few years is expected to come from offshore, industry analysts say. BP Amoco, one of the largest foreign investors in China, has spent more than $2.5 billion developing oil fields and building chemical plants there and has invested about $1 billion in shares of the two largest oil companies, the China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation and the PetroChina Company. China National is the third largest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNING, JAMES DORR
description: DUNNING-James Dorr. On November 7, 2000, at his home in New York City, after a long illness. He was 89. Mr. Dunning was an executive of New York Life Insurance Company for 45 years. For 25 years he served as a consultant to the Episcopal Church Pension Fund. His extensive lay leadership in the Episcopal Church included service as a senior warden of three parishes, St. Andrew's Church, Wellesley, MA, All Saints' Church and St. Bartholomew's Church, Manhattan. He served as a member of the national standing liturgical commission during the revision of the Book of Common Prayer. In 1996, he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters by the Berkeley Divinity School at Yale. He is survived by Mary, his wife of 66 years, and his son James D. Dunning, Jr. of New York, and his grandsons James D. Dunning III and David F. Dunning. Vigil and visitation Sunday, November 12, 4-6:30PM, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street. Funeral service at St. Bartholomew's, Monday, November 13, 5 PM. Memorial donations to St. Bartholomew's Church, New York, or Berkeley Divinity School at Yale, New Haven.

Bartlet, a former economics professor and Nobel prize winner, rarely needs advice on economics from his staff. Nonfictional presidents, however, must rely on their advisers to make decisions. The way economic advice is organized can determine the success of a president's program. The National Economic Council provides a good model for future White Houses.

description: Starry ensembles convening to play chamber music are hardly rare these days, and if critics tend to take a jaundiced view of them it is because too often the performances have a frustratingly ad hoc quality. Sometimes, though, rehearsal and performance conditions come together in just the right way, and the performances are commensurate with the reputations of the players. When that happens, as it did on Tuesday evening at the 92nd Street Y, the results can be deeply satisfying, even in a program devoted entirely to warhorses.

description: Volkswagen's luxury unit, Audi, said that because its plant in Ingolstadt, Germany, is running close to capacity, it will begin building its A3 sedans at a subsidiary's plant in Gyor, Hungary. Audi's Hungarian subsidiary is Hungary's largest exporter.

title: Tolerance and German Nationalism
description: Friedrich Merz, a parliamentary leader of Germany's conservative opposition party, the Christian Democratic Union, created a stir recently when he said that immigrants must adopt German ''Leitkultur,'' or ''guiding culture.'' The statement harked back to the dangerous German tendency to equate nationality with ethnicity, and is rightly considered menacing to outsiders. Prime Minister Gerhard Schroder, a Social Democrat, decried the use of the term, saying his opponents were ''playing with fire.'' Jewish leaders in Berlin also expressed concern about the remark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, MILTON S.
description: GROSS-Milton S., December 11, 1918-November 5, 2000. Long-time New York City high school teacher, dedicated teacher's union member, and Oberlin College graduate, Milton S. Gross, died peacefully at home in Berkeley, California, following a short illness. He was committed to civil rights, social and economic justice, and world peace. He was a faithful reader of the New York Times and always read the obituary page. His mother, Kathinka, was a great strudel maker. His father, Ernest, was a furrier and as a youth, a traveler and a pool shark. Milton loved books, good food, travel, the women in his life, his family, and friends. He could tell a story with the best of them, always delivered with zest and enthusiasm. He charmed us with his full-throated renditions of Hungarian songs. He is survived by his four children, Toni Gross of Oakland, California; Joe Gross of Berkeley, California; Billy Gross of Copenhagen, Denmark; and Judy Weisman of Plattsburg, New York; eight grandchildren, Jeanette, Kate, Lucia, Mickey, Gabe, Jazbo, Spencer, and Dana; one greatgrandchild, Damani, and two nephews and one niece, Ken, Larry, and Katherine Gross. He was a man well loved by all that knew him. Graveside services will be held at the Beth El Memorial Gardens in Portland, Maine, on November 10, 2000, at 11:00 AM. Milton requested that donations be directed to an organization that he supported: RESIST, 259 Elm Street, Somerville, MA 02144, Phone (617) 623-5110.

title: As Washington Talks Near, More Deaths in Middle East
description: On the eve of a meeting between President Clinton and Yasir Arafat to try to salvage the shattered peace effort, new bloodletting broke out today in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. title: NISSAN WILL BUILD A TRUCK PLANT IN MISSISSIPPI
description: The Nissan Motor Company will build a $900 million factory near Canton, Miss., to make pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles. The cost and location of the factory were released yesterday in advance of a formal announcement planned for today in Jackson, Miss. North America is Nissan's largest market, accounting for about 30 percent of its sales; 25 percent of the company's sales come from Japan. The new plant is seen as a sign of Nissan's confidence that it has recovered from the financial problems that led it to seek help from Renault S.A., which took a 37 percent controlling stake in Nissan last year. The Mississippi factory will employ 3,000 to 4,000 people.

title: For Poe Enthusiasts, Dueling Ravens

Also on the site are a biography, links and a collection of audio excerpts featuring dramatic readings of several poems -- including ''Annabel Lee,'' ''For Annie,'' ''Dreamland'' and ''Lenore'' -- by Joel Grey, Christopher Cazenove and Michael York.

title: Power Station Reincarnated As Museum and Restaurant
description: With the buzz generated by the opening of the Tate Modern in the spring, it is no surprise that another power plant has been converted into the Wapping Project arts center, once more along the Thames. The 1890's Wapping hydraulic power station has just been refurbished by the architectural firm Shed 54 to hold art installations. A Keith Haring retrospective will open on Jan. 4. A new restaurant, Wapping Food, is in the original turbine house. Vitra chairs by Charles and Ray Eames and by Ron Arad, his Tom Vac series (all seen hanging from the ceiling, left), are exhibited in the restaurant, where they are not only part of the design, but also for sale, at a discount, because they are slightly used. Reserve one now and take it home when the show ends in March and new chairs move in. Prices are around $140; (011) 44-207-680-2096.

description: The Cincinnati Reds began their effort to shed payroll yesterday, trading pitcher Ron Villone to the Colorado Rockies for two minor league prospects to be named or cash. Jim Bowden, the Reds' general manager, indicated that more deals would follow.

title: Hand-Printed Screening In the Bag, Up the Walls
description: For any woman who wants to match a handbag to her walls, Neisha Crosland, a new Chelsea store, is worth a look. The sliver of a shop, at 137 Fulham Road, above, the first from Neisha Crosland, the textile designer, has scarves, handbags, cushions and wallpaper, all with the distinctive hand-printed screening techniques that she was known for at Osborne & Little in the late 1980's. Her painterly aesthetic is reflected in the lush mix of fabrics, as well as in the store's wallpaper. Neisha Crosland scarves and bags are available in New York at Bergdorf Goodman. The wallpaper is at Fonthill Ltd. Showroom, 979 Third Avenue, (212) 755-6700 (to the trade only).

title: CALIFORNIA UTILITY SEEKS TO CHARGE CUSTOMERS $3 BILLION
description: Pacific Gas and Electric, California's largest electric utility, sued the state in federal court, seeking freedom to charge customers more than $3 billion for the company's losses in open-market power purchases earlier this year. The company argued in its filing that the state made it sell its power plants and capped the rates it could charge, leaving it no way to avoid losses when wholesale power prices surge. The company, a unit of the PG & E Corporation, and its largest rival, Southern California Edison, a unit of Edison International, have asked the state utility commission to let it pass along the costs, so far without result. The uncertainty of when the issue will be resolved led Fitch Inc., a debt-rating agency, to downgrade PG & E and Edison's credit ratings.

title: U.S. Remains at Impasse With Yemenis Over Cole Investigation
description: Yemen and the United States are discussing arrangements to let F.B.I. agents watch interviews of suspects in the bombing of the destroyer Cole through a one-way mirror or on live television relay, officials said today.

title: Groh and Jets View Running Game From Different Angles
description: If Vinny Testaverde's garish interception total seems to be the most obvious barometer of the Jets' offensive woes, then there is a subtler indicator buried deeper in the statistics.

title: Race to Find Basis of Mass Still On as Lab Retires Device
description: The director of the leading European particle physics laboratory has decided to shut down a particle accelerator here just as scientists using it believed they were on the verge of capturing one of the most glittering prizes in physics: the discovery of the particle that theorists believe is the origin of all mass in the universe.

title: A Mercury-Filled Grab Bag Called a Cunningham Event
description: Merce Cunningham is the wizard of our age: young bespectacled ones should take lessons from him.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the campaign for the Senate in Missouri, where the governor said he would appoint Jean Carnahan to fill the seat if the voters chose her late husband, referred erroneously to a comment from Shane Wilson of Kansas City. He said he wondered whether Mrs. Carnahan's decision would weigh on her if she took the seat. But he did not use the words ''I'm bothered somewhat about the idea of voting for a dead person's wife, simply because she is a widow.'' That was a paraphrase of Mr. Wilson's views and should not have appeared in quotation marks.

title: MIDWEST
description: KANSAS BUSH

title: The Buoyant Spirits Of a Modern Vaudevillian
description: The comic pop-jazz singer Jim Caruso doesn't do any soft-shoe dancing in his engaging cabaret act, which plays Monday evenings at Arci's Place. But this impish, twinkling-eyed performer still exudes the buoyant spirits of a contemporary vaudevillian whom you might expect to start gliding around the stage at any second.

title: For a Divided America, a Momentous Night; Two Rounds of Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: But for the Urban Core, It Could Have Been Senator Franks
description: For years, the future of New Jersey politics was assumed to lie in the growing and politically moderate suburbs. But Jon S. Corzine's path to the United States Senate ran straight back to the cities and their money-heavy Democratic machine politics.

title: In America; Could Bush Govern?
description: What has George W. Bush won?

title: Eternal Spotlight Yields to Infernal Wait
description: For so long, the people of this tossup city in this swing district in this battleground state had waited for it all to be over. Instead, they awoke to the election that refused to end.

title: A Baffling Outcome in America, of All Places
description: ''I would like to be the first from this dispatch box to congratulate the president-elect,'' said Peter Mandelson, Britain's Northern Ireland secretary, addressing the House of Commons from the parliamentary debating lectern. He paused, and the legislators chuckled. ''Whoever he may be,'' he added.

title: Loss In Home State Leaves Gore Depending on Florida
description: The cliffhanger in Florida could have been irrelevant had it not been for the disappointment in Tennessee.

title: For a Divided America, a Momentous Night; A Wider Recount?
description: To the Editor:

title: LOSSES LOOM AT MITSUBISHI
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said it might lose money the next two years as it awaits the benefits of building fewer basic models and other cost-cutting. The company, Japan's No. 4 automaker, said losses in the current fiscal year might triple to at least 70 billion yen ($652 million). DaimlerChrysler paid $1.9 billion in October for a one-third stake in the company. Since then, Mitsubishi has been rocked by a scandal over cover-ups of customer complaints about defects.

title: Beyond Manhattan: Help the Rest of New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney Shares Drop on Word Of Static Profit
description: Shares in the Walt Disney Company fell nearly 15 percent today after the company said that first-quarter earnings would be stagnant and that advertising rates at ABC television were slipping.

title: Democrats Widen Attack -- Recount Seems to Erode Bush's Edge
description: With the recount of Florida's votes still under way and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas clinging to a hairbreadth lead, Vice President Al Gore's campaign vowed today to back a court fight over questionable ballots in Palm Beach County even after the tabulation was complete.

title: Clearing the Runway
description: Congestion at La Guardia Airport is more than an inconvenience to local travelers. It has become an unacceptable bottleneck in the nation's air traffic system, accounting for a quarter of all flight delays in September. Before it gets worse, the Federal Aviation Administration has rightly stepped in to alleviate the situation. In what it views as a short-term measure to ease congestion, the F.A.A. will reduce the number of flights at La Guardia, set a cap on the number of new flights through next September and hold a lottery for these slots.

title: Funeral Business's New Look; As Career Prospects Expand, Work Force Becomes Diverse
description: Annette York's first body was heavier than she had ever imagined. She and a co-worker had just taken it, zipped up in white plastic, from the refrigerator of a Trenton hospital morgue. It was cold and felt like a sack of rocks.

title: Israelis Track Down and Kill a Fatah Commander
description: Israeli helicopter gunships fired missiles at a vehicle carrying a Palestinian paramilitary commander here today, killing him and two middle-aged women who happened to be nearby.

title: Election Is Seen As Vote Motivator
description: Cate Cleary was one of those voters the Bush and Gore campaigns chased down to the final days of the presidential race. She was ''an undecided.'' So on the final weekend, she collected everything she could find on the two men and curled up in her downtown condominium to compare their positions and consider their strengths.

title: Another Free Safety Swirls Through Jets' Revolving Door
description: The latest contestant in the Jets' game of ''Find a Free Safety'' came by way of a cram session by some low-level staffers. They are charged with reviewing preseason tapes of other teams, scouring for any passed-over players who might possess even a glimmer of a future.

title: A Rendezvous With 2 Giants
description: When we heard that the New York City Department of Parks had published ''Great Trees of New York City,'' a guide to the city's most impressive trees, we were intrigued. Although New York has no hulking redwoods, we had heard for years about a monster tree in Queens that was said to be the biggest in all five boroughs. According to the tree grapevine, this behemoth is a tulip tree (Liriodendron tulipifera) growing in an obscure corner of Alley Pond Park, a 635-acre swath of green in northeast Queens that stretches from Union Turnpike to Little Neck Bay.

title: A Rare Consensus On Balloting Woes
description: New Yorkers may be an opinionated lot who don't agree on much of anything, but yesterday in some of the city's busier corners, residents and workers consistently expressed a single sentiment about the nation's presidential quagmire: it, in a word, stinks.

title: AMES TO CLOSE 32 DISCOUNT STORES EARLY NEXT YEAR
description: Ames Department Stores plans to shut 32 of its discount stores in February, mainly locations acquired when Ames bought Hills Stores in 1998. About 2,000 employees will be affected in Ohio, Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Indiana, New York and Massachusetts. Employees will be relocated, the company said. Ames also announced a loss of $37.2 million, or $1.27 a share, in the quarter ended Oct. 28; analysts had forecast 41 cents a share. Shares of Ames fell $1.81, to $2.78, a 52-week low.

title: AUTONATION SELLS ADVERTISING BUSINESS TO INFINITY UNIT
description: AutoNation Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its outdoor-advertising business to a unit of Infinity Broadcasting for $104 million in cash. The sale will result in a pretax gain of about $50 million this quarter, AutoNation said. As part of the transaction, AutoNation agreed to a three-year, $15 million advertising contract with Infinity Outdoor. Republic Media, the business being sold, has about 1,300 billboards, all in Florida. Infinity is the largest outdoor advertising company in the country.

title: Advertising: Red Lobster Revamped
description: After a major three-year effort to rejuvenate its restaurants, Red Lobster has kicked off a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign to show off its new look and attract old and new customers.

title: Democrats Send Troops To Florida For Battle
description: Using scores of imported volunteers and a corps of lawyers, the campaign of Vice President Al Gore set in motion an aggressive legal and moral challenge today to the electoral process in Florida in the hopes of gaining the state's pivotal 25 electoral votes.

title: Airlines Say La Guardia Flight Cuts Will Be Selected in December
description: Airline officials said yesterday that until a plan by the Federal Aviation Administration to reduce the number of flights at La Guardia Airport was finished, it would not be known which flights would be affected, although none would be canceled before the end of the holiday season.

title: AT&T SETTLES PATENT DISPUTE
description: AT&T settled a patent lawsuit with Ronald A. Katz Technology Licensing L.P. for patent licenses for interactive voice technology. AT&T, which admitted no wrongdoing, said it had agreed to pay an undisclosed sum to the closely held Ronald A. Katz, whose patented technology is used in AT&T's calling card, collect calling, messaging and other services.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: In Palm Beach County, Crucible of an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Aides, Casting Gore Camp as Sore Losers, Plot Next Steps
description: As they endured yet another day in political limbo, Gov. George W. Bush and his advisers channeled their energies in two directions today, waging an aggressive public relations war over the legitimacy of the election and tentatively plotting Mr. Bush's transition to the presidency.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Along the Hudson, Vigils Supporting a River Cleanup
description: Cupping candles in the gusty night wind, several hundred people attended vigils last night at dozens of sites along the Hudson River from Manhattan to upstate Hudson Falls to show their support for a cleanup of toxic PCB's in the river.

title: How Criticism Began And Grew in America
description: Hard as it is to swallow, there was a time in this country's cultural life when art criticism was unknown, when the bayings and lowings of reviewers had not yet been heard in the land.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Lesley Dill
description: George Adams Gallery

title: No Headline
In Palm Beach County, Crucible of an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald Judd
description: PaceWildenstein

title: Putin Cuts Forces by 600,000, Promising Military Overhaul
description: The Kremlin said tonight that it plans to shrink its three-million-strong armed forces by 600,000 people, led by deep cuts in the main Defense Ministry forces, to rein in what President Vladimir V. Putin called an unwieldy and extravagant military machine.

title: INSIDE
description: 2nd Bombing Plot Reported

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Brown University's selection of Ruth J. Simmons as its president misstated the day of the decision. The governing body voted yesterday, not on Wednesday. The article also misstated Dr. Simmons's age. She is 55, not 54.

title: Metro Business Briefing; KOZMO FEE FOR CHRISTMAS
description: The online delivery service Kozmo.com, which operates in parts of New York City and 10 other markets, will for the first time charge customers a delivery fee on top of its regular prices for some holiday gift orders. Most online companies will stop guaranteeing Christmas deliveries on Dec. 17, according to Gomez Research, a company that monitors e-commerce trends. Last-minute shoppers will be able to use Kozmo, which relies on its own distribution network of couriers, until Christmas Day. Kozmo will charge a $3.99 gift processing fee, and $2.99 if consumers want the gift wrapped, said Matthew Higgins, a spokesman for the company. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Back Spasms Will Keep Sprewell Out of Action
description: The Knicks will play their second consecutive game without Latrell Sprewell tonight when they face the Boston Celtics at the Fleet Center. While the Knicks flew to Boston yesterday, Sprewell, who is suffering from back spasms, remained in New York to receive treatment. His status for tomorrow's home game against the Charlotte Hornets is questionable.

title: George Tice
description: Ariel Meyerowitz Gallery

title: Chidambaram Subramaniam, India's 'Green' Rebel, 90, Dies
description: Chidambaram Subramaniam, the political architect of the ''green revolution'' in India, which made the nation self-sufficient in wheat production, died Tuesday in Madras. He was 90.

title: F.T.C. Agrees To Extension On AOL Deal
description: With federal officials threatening to block the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner over antitrust concerns, the two companies received three more weeks today to iron out their differences with regulators.

title: British Telecommunications to Split Into 2 Companies
description: Amid fierce competition and mounting debt, British Telecommunications today became the latest stumbling telecom giant to say it would split itself into two smaller companies.

title: Gore Withdraws From the Field as Aides Prepare for Battle
description: Vice President Al Gore decamped from his election night base here tonight and headed home to Washington, while his campaign shifted its apparatus to Florida to contest the election results vigorously.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: BATTLE OVER AUSTRIAN CARRIER
description: Austrian Airlines said it wanted to buy a majority stake in an affiliated company, Lauda Air Luftfahrt, by the end of the year, and may buy the whole company. Austrian Airlines, which now owns 35.9 percent of Lauda Air, wants to reorganize Lauda, which has been struggling financially, and opposes its plan to sell and lease back five airplanes. The German airline Lufthansa owns 20 percent of Lauda; Niki Lauda, the founder, has 30 percent, and the rest is publicly traded.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The Dream Team for an American Nightmare
description: ''A mini-series O. J. doesn't want you to see!'' the promos for ''American Tragedy'' scream. Well, he can't be wrong about everything, though he may have the wrong reasons.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Craig and Alitalia Select Agencies
description: Jenny Craig, the weight-loss center operator, selected the Newport Beach, Calif., and Southfield, Mich., offices of Doner to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: A Triumph Of Orchids
description: ''Nature sells,'' exclaimed John Loring, Tiffany & Company's longtime design director, describing the success of flower jewelry that Tiffany's showed at the 1889 Exposition Universelle in Paris. The orchid pins in particular caused a sensation. Tiffany's had 24 jeweled, enameled orchid brooches, each precisely modeled on a different exotic variety, at the fair. They were numbered and embellished with diamonds, emeralds, aquamarines, pearls and rubies.

title: In Research, Recounts Are Norm
description: First George W. Bush led Al Gore by 1,784 votes in Florida. Then, an unofficial count by The Associated Press suggested his lead was slashed to less than half that. So, which number is right mathematically?

title: FOUNDERS OUT AT LERNOUT
description: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products said its two founders and co-chairmen would step down, sending its already battered stock price plummeting by nearly half. Accounting irregularities at the Belgian company have forced it to restate two and a half years of earnings; the company said third-quarter revenue would be at least 24 percent lower than it had earlier forecast. Roel Pieper, former chief executive of Tandem Computers, will take over as sole chairman. One founder, Jo Lernout, will remain on the board as vice chairman, while the other, Pol Hauspie, will take an indefinite medical leave. The chief financial officer has been reassigned.

title: 'Big Momma' Out Twice
description: On Tuesday the second biggest release of the week, after ''The Perfect Storm,'' will be ''Big Momma's House,'' the Martin Lawrence vehicle about a small F.B.I. agent who disguises himself as a very large woman. Pound for pound, the film stacks up as a strong rental title, but if you want it on DVD, don't go to the store just yet.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about J. Sinclair Armstrong, a lawyer and investment banker involved in a preservation dispute with St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan, misspelled the name of a mutual fund group with which he was associated. It is Bramwell Capital Management Inc., not the Barnwell Funds.

title: Fleury Is Still Scoring Goals, and Now He's Dancing, Too
description: Theo Fleury called his spontaneous piece of performance art -- a jig of sorts -- ''The Dance of Happiness.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PEGASUS COMMUNICATIONS, Bala Cynwyd, Pa., a media company with operations in direct broadcast satellite television and broadcast television, said it would split the company's satellite Internet and satellite-television businesses into two units to attract more customers to the high-speed Web service. The subsidiaries would be known as Pegasus Satellite Communications and Pegasus Broadband Communications.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about the indictment of five nurses in the death of a patient at a Long Island nursing home was truncated. The last sentence, a quotation from John Signor, a spokesman for the State Health Department, should have read, ''We want to be able to respond to complaints more quickly and conduct follow-up inspections more quickly.''

title: Sidney E. Woloshin, 72, Writer of Ad Jingles
description: Sidney E. Woloshin, co-composer of ''You Deserve a Break Today,'' the jingle that set the chipper tone for the national introduction of McDonald's restaurants in 1971, died on Sunday at White Plains Hospital. He was 72.

title: In Palm Beach County, Crucible of an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Negotiations Are Stalled in New York Smoking Suit, Lawyers Say
description: Negotiations between smokers' lawyers and two major tobacco companies to resolve a federal case in New York have stalled and may fall apart, lawyers representing both sides said yesterday.

title: $10 Golf Prize Turns Into $65 Million Payoff
description: James A. Hall thought his weekend was going fairly well when he won a golf tournament late last month, leaving the course with a cash prize of $10.

title: Metro Business Briefing; HIGHEST RETAIL RENTS
description: East 57th Street, which once seemed to be losing its cachet with the arrival of mass retailers like Niketown, is now commanding the world's highest rents, the real estate firm of Cushman & Wakefield reported yesterday. The annual rent for boutique space on 57th Street near Fifth Avenue is now as much as $700 a square foot, compared with $500 a year ago, company officials said. Asking rents on Fifth Avenue between Rockefeller Center and the Plaza Hotel range from $600 to $675 a square foot, while on Madison Avenue from 48th Street to 72nd Street they are $500 to $600. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: NISSAN SAYS ITS PLANT IN MISSISSIPPI WILL OPEN IN 2003
description: Nissan Motor said yesterday that a $930 million plant in Mississippi would start production in 2003, making pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and minivans. Construction of the plant, near Canton, Miss., is scheduled to start in April. The plant will be able to produce 250,000 vehicles a year, employing 3,300 workers when it starts and 4,000 employees at full capacity, the company said. The Mississippi project is Nissan's first major new factory since it announced a three-year revival plan in October 1999. That plan came after Renault of France bought a 37 percent controlling stake in Nissan and installed Carlos Ghosn as Nissan's chief operating officer.

title: Homework for the Parent, or the Child?
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidates Should Be on the Same Page, Experts Say
description: The ballot design at the heart of the Democrats' challenge to the election results in Florida is seldom used because it can easily confuse voters, industry officials and experts said today.

title: Hit Me With Your Best Shot
description: Coney Island is an eclectic oasis on the edge of an eclectic city. It is home to the Polar Bears, those hearty souls who swim in the Atlantic in February, and the Russian women who stroll the boardwalk in mink coats in July. And, of course, the Cyclone, the rickety-looking roller coaster that roars over an amusement park with a fabled past and a faded present. I've been going there for 18 years and still marvel at the delightful weirdness of it all.

title: Veteran Jail Officer Named Correction Commissioner
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani named William J. Fraser, the top-ranking uniformed officer in the city's Department of Correction, as commissioner of the department yesterday. He succeeds Bernard B. Kerik, who left the post to become police commissioner on Aug. 19.

title: Bush Holds Slim Lead Over Gore as Florida Recounts
description: With the official county-by-county recount of Tuesday's vote still under way, Gov. George W. Bush maintained a razor-thin lead today in Florida over Vice President Al Gore.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Red Lobster has successfully revamped its operations. Now it's overhauling its marketing.
description: AFTER a major three-year effort to rejuvenate its restaurants, Red Lobster has kicked off a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign to show off its new look and attract old and new customers.

title: Gay Protest Planned at Bishops' Gathering
description: A gay rights organization that advocates nonviolent civil disobedience and has been staging demonstrations at meetings of major Christian churches around the country, plans one outside a Roman Catholic shrine in Washington next week, to coincide with a gathering of the nation's Catholic bishops.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about motion-capture technology and computer animation was truncated. The last sentence, about interactive computer comics, including one called Virtual Bill, should have read, ''Because the software that mobilizes these characters is sent to the recipient's hard drive, even Web viewers with slow connections can see Bill explicating with nary a stutter.''

title: Paddles and Prices Stay Low at Auction
description: Are cracks beginning to show in the Impressionist and modern art market? Or have the auction houses miscalculated the prices buyers are prepared to pay?

title: Gore Campaign Vows Court Fight Over Vote, With Floridas Outcome Still Up in the Air
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  With the recount of Florida's votes still under way and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas clinging to a hairbreadth lead, Vice President Al Gore's campaign vowed today to back a court fight over questionable ballots in Palm Beach County even after the tabulation was complete.

title: I.B.M. MAKES THINGS EVEN CLEARER
description: I.B.M. has delivered a widescreen computer display to the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory that produces images it says are 10 times the sharpness of the standard computer display and four times that of high-definition television. The liquid crystal units, now roughly $20,000, will be shipped in small volumes next year, but I.B.M. expects the technology to be widely used with supercomputers by 2005. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Democrats Tell of Problems At the Polls Across Florida
description: All over Florida today, Democratic officials and angry voters complained about Election Day irregularities, from confusing ballots, computer glitches and misplaced ballot boxes to accusations by some black voters that they were turned away from polling places.

title: Boy, 7, Dies From Gunshot By Brother, 8
description: An 8-year-old boy accidentally shot his 7-year-old brother in the head on Tuesday, the police here said, and the boy died this morning. The police have arrested the owner of the gun, the boys' stepbrother and legal guardian, who they said was a drug dealer.

title: Yalding Journal; England Is Half-Drowned and Wholly Fed Up
description: True, hordes of voracious locusts have not yet emerged from nowhere in a demonstration of divine wrath. But after the rains, the floods, the windstorms and the torrents of raw sewage, the residents of this little country village would not be particularly surprised if they did.

title: Brace Yourself: XFL and the Hitmen Are Coming
description: One of the tapes the New York/New Jersey Hitmen received before the first XFL draft last month was of a nose tackle who played at a small college. ''His resume said he had three sacks and so many tackles,'' said Drew Pearson, the former Dallas Cowboys wide receiver who is the Hitmen's general manager.

title: Dell Earnings and Revenue Reported Higher in Quarter
description: Dell Computer, the most tightly run ship in the computer industry, relieved some of Wall Street's fears about softening consumer and business demand by reporting earnings yesterday that matched expectations and revenues that slightly beat them.

title: Mariners Gain Rights to Sign Suzuki
description: With a hefty offer of $13,125,000, the Seattle Mariners beat out the Mets and two other teams for the rights to the latest foreign phenomenon, Ichiro Suzuki, an outfielder who has won seven successive batting championships in Japan's Pacific League.

title: DAEWOO PLANT IDLE
description: Production stopped at the main Daewoo Motor Company plant outside Seoul after auto parts suppliers stopped delivering parts not paid for in advance. Creditors forced Daewoo Motor into bankruptcy on Wednesday by cutting off the cash keeping the company afloat, after its labor unions rejected demands for job cuts. The assets of Daewoo Motor were frozen in the bankruptcy. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: A Stirring Beginning For Storm And Cook
description: St. John's opened the Omar Cook era at Madison Square Garden last night, and the freshman point guard showed how valuable he could be.

title: Some Nader Supporters Seem Shaken, Not Stirred, by Result
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: A Freed Albanian Visits Restive Serbian Prisons
description: A Kosovo Albanian human rights worker freed from a Serbian jail only a week ago visited four of Serbia's rioting prisons today, trying to calm the situation and ensure that ethnic Albanians were not being mistreated.

title: In Palm Beach County, Crucible of an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: A Black First In the Navy, Very Manly And Tough
description: ''Men of Honor'' is decidedly manly and for the most part honorable. Like ''Remember the Titans,'' whose box-office success it will probably duplicate, this film tells a story of racial reconciliation against a backdrop of square-jawed masculine striving. It suggests, not implausibly, that an institution devoted to humiliating discipline and self-sacrificing duty -- in this case the United States Navy -- can be a crucible of tolerance and even friendship.

title: T. J. Wilcox
description: Gavin Brown's Enterprise

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Theres Always the Option of Giving In
description: WASHINGTON -- President John F. Kennedy would sometimes write the number 118,574 on a slip of paper and put it in his pocket. That was his margin of victory in the popular vote over Vice President Richard M. Nixon in the 1960 election. The vote was close, the mandate thin, the president cautious.

title: President Could Be Picked Without Florida
description: Dec. 18, the day that presidential electors are to meet in 50 state capitals and the District of Columbia, may produce a political crisis if Florida's 25 votes are still in dispute. But the crisis will not be constitutional, scholars say, for the Constitution enables a president to be chosen even if a big state like Florida does not vote.

title: FORMER CHAIRMAN OFFERS CASH INFUSION TO PRIME RETAIL
description: The former chairman of Prime Retail Inc., Michael W. Reschke, has offered to bail the company out of a cash squeeze by lending it $100 million and buying $30 million of its securities. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Reschke said a group of investors he leads might also acquire a majority of the company's common and preferred stock. The company, which is based in Baltimore and owns 51 outlet malls in 26 states, has been negotiating with Lehman Brothers for a $110 million loan, according to the filing.

title: House Seat In New Jersey Remains Undecided
description: In an election drama echoing the uncertainty of the presidential contest, the outcome of the 12th Congressional District race in New Jersey remained unresolved last night as election workers continued to tabulate paper ballots amid allegations by Republican Party officials of vote tampering.

title: Digital Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: THOMSON'S PROFIT FALLS
