description: Third-quarter profit at the Thomson Corporation fell 6 percent, to $168 million, or 27 cents a share, from the period a year earlier. The results exclude Thomson's newspapers, most of which have been sold, yielding $2.5 billion; the company is now primarily an information vendor. Revenue from continuing operations rose 19 percent, to $1.68 billion for the quarter. Thomson is based in Toronto. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Failed Plan To Bomb A U.S. Ship Is Reported
description: A suspect in the bombing of the destroyer Cole has told Yemeni authorities that the Islamic militants behind the attack tried to bomb another warship in January, but aborted the assault after their explosives-packed skiff foundered near the beach, government officials said tonight.

title: If U.N. Is to Police the World, It Finds It Must Also Police Itself
description: With a steady increase in peacekeeping operations and relief missions around the world, the United Nations inspector general recommended today that the organization needs to review how to police itself better. Corruption and mismanagement have been persistent problems in the isolated, quickly organized missions thousands of miles from New York that now characterize much more of the organization's work.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: You Think Hell Is Wild? Welcome to New York
description: I'll say this much for Adam Sandler: the man is not vain. In ''Little Nicky'' he proves himself willing to go to extraordinary lengths to cement his claim to being the most popular portrayer of lame-brained doofuses in American movies. Decked out in a series of puffy, ill-fitting nylon coats, hunched over and lisping like Peter Lorre, with a lock of lank hair falling over his brow, he makes Jim Carrey in ''Ace Ventura'' or ''Dumb and Dumber'' seem as debonair as Cary Grant.

title: Reformer Says Iran Regime Tortured Him
description: TEHRAN  A prominent journalist who is one of Iran's leading radicals appeared before a Revolutionary Court on Thursday and accused the regime of torturing him.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL RISES. Heating oil surged as cold weather increased demand on stretched supplies. Heating oil for December delivery rose 5.66 cents, or 5.9 percent, to $1.0159 a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Foreign Affairs; Original Sin
description: While no one still knows who won the election, I can tell you what the next cabinet should look like.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: A One-Hit Wonder and All Washed Up? That'll Be the Day
description: ''Looking for an Echo'' suffers from such an acute case of nostalgic tunnel vision that while watching it, you would never guess that hip-hop, not doo-wop, is the sound of urban America. This corny, suds-drenched movie, set mostly in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, would like to imagine that the dreamy, harmonized, rock 'n' roll vocal style refined on city streetcorners, in echoing hallways and under bridges in the late-1950's and early 60's is as vital today as it was 40 years ago. Even when the film's characters venture into a Manhattan music club, the sound (along with a softened version of the 50's greaser look) that drives young audiences wild is doo-wop-oriented but with contemporary pop trimmings and amplification.

title: SUNOCO AGREES TO BUY MITSUBISHI'S ARISTECH CHEMICAL
description: Sunoco agreed yesterday to buy the Aristech Chemical Corporation, a unit of the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan, for $695 million. Aristech, based in Pittsburgh, makes polypropylene and phenol, two compounds widely used in plastics, at two plants in Texas and one each in West Virginia, Ohio and Pennsylvania. Sunoco will pay $167 million more for Aristech if the company's profit margins exceed a certain level, the company said. Sunoco, which owns five refineries in the United States and sells gasoline through 3,500 stations in 17 states, had $8.3 billion in sales last year.

title: Lion Bioscience Seeking U.S. Acquisitions
description: Lion Bioscience A.G., the German biotechnology company, said it was looking for acquisitions and partnership opportunities in the United States to add to a partnership it announced yesterday with Celera Genomics.

title: Microsoft Hears Little Criticism at Its Annual Meeting
description: Despite a bumpy year in the stock market, an uncertain future in the courts and shareholder dissent over some of its political contributions, the Microsoft Corporation presented a relatively upbeat picture of the company at its annual meeting here today.

title: DNA Study Traces European Ancestors
description: WASHINGTON -- About 80 percent of Europeans arose from primitive hunters who arrived about 40,000 years ago, endured the long ice age and then expanded rapidly to dominate the continent, a new study shows.

title: Close Vote Illuminates Hodgepodge of Ballots
description: The controversy swirling over Florida ballots in the still-unresolved presidential election has drawn back the curtain on what election experts have long been saying: that the American voting system is no system at all.

title: Free After Serving 4 Years, a Bronx Man Is Linked to Slaying
description: A former Bronx gang member was released from prison yesterday after serving four years for extortion, prompting criticism from a former federal prosecutor who said the gang member was implicated in a 1990 murder but never charged.

title: Top Gore Aide Is a Man To the Ballot Box Born
description: Until the day he left the commerce secretary's office this summer, William M. Daley kept a grainy, black-and-white photograph of his father, Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago, on the wall by his desk -- a reminder of the fiery political boss he adored but whose shadow he has spent a lifetime stepping beyond.

title: 'We Are Confident': Statements by Officials of the Bush Campaign
description: Following are excerpts of statements yesterday by Karen P. Hughes, the Bush campaign's communications director; Donald L. Evans, the campaign chairman; and Karl Rove, the campaign's chief strategist, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: NEC of Japan Joins Start-Up In Offering Fast Net Service
description: The NEC Corporation, Japan's leading computer and semiconductor manufacturer, has teamed up with eAccess Ltd., a new telecommunications company, to provide subscribers to its Internet service with high-speed connections.

title: Vernel Fournier, 72, Jazz Drummer Revered for Precision and Understatement
description: Vernel Fournier, a drummer who took part in some of the most modern and far-reaching permutations of small-group jazz as a member of the Ahmad Jamal Trio in the late 1950's and early 60's, died on Saturday in Jackson, Miss. He was 72.

title: Disliking Uncertainty, Traders Opt for Treasuries Over Shares
description: Treasury bond prices rose yesterday as stocks fell and the presidential election's outcome remained unsettled. ''The markets want resolution, not fighting,'' said Peter Cordrey, who bought Treasuries yesterday for the $125 billion he helps manage at Prudential Asset Management in Newark. ''People don't want this to drag out and be made into a constitutional crisis.''

title: Residential Real Estate; Manhattan Rents Go Ever Upward
description: The average rent for apartments in Manhattan below 96th Street jumped 10.7 percent to nearly $3,000 during the first six months of this year, according to one survey of the market, topping off a six-year period during which rents increased by nearly 46 percent.

title: Innovators Burst Onstage One (Ka-pow!) at a Time
description: ONE of the great things about New York City is that it really is new, all the time. Fresh ideas keep popping up; so do new faces. And some of those faces belong to artists. Not a month goes by without dozens of solo debuts among the city's hundreds of galleries. This month is no exception.

title: Con Ed Selling Nuclear Plant In Westchester
description: Nine months after the worst accident in the history of the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant, Consolidated Edison announced today that it had reached an agreement to sell the plant to a Mississippi company, signaling the end of the utility's historic role in the business of making electricity.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Lessons column on Wednesday, about bilingual education, misstated the writer's view of when that system is most useful in the teaching of English. The column was intended to say that bilingual teaching of English is warranted when it intellectually challenges pupils in a language they understand. He did not say it should be promoted because most often it teaches English more effectively.

title: In Palm Beach County, Crucible of an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Homework for the Parent, or the Child?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fritz Kredel
description: 'Centennial Exhibition'

title: Tua Is Looking to Make A Name for Himself, at Last
description: In Samoa, a group of volcanic islands in the southern Pacific, he was born Mafaufau Tavita Lio Mafaufau Sanerivi Talimatasi and, as he has said, ''Now you know why I changed my name'' to David Tua.

title: Guess What's Table Talk at the White House Dinner?
description: The 42nd president of the United States dined at the White House tonight with the 38th, the 39th and the 41st. The topic of conversation all night long was, Who is going to be the 43rd?

title: Forests May Help Counteract Greenhouse Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Nov 9 - Letting forests grow on abandoned farmland and logging grounds may do more than beautify the countryside -- they may be soaking up greenhouse gases blamed for global warming, scientists said on Thursday.

title: Recounting Becomes Issue, Not Just in Florida
description: As the nation awaited Florida's recount of votes in the presidential race, there were four other states yesterday where recounts either were under way or had become a prospect.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; Memorabilia of a Full-Service Era
description: IT is not just vintage roadsters and muscle cars that stir the acquisitive juices of car-minded collectors. Some of the hot collectibles these days had passed unnoticed, and unremarked upon, during roadside pit stops in the 1950's and 60's: Restroom and no-smoking signs at gasoline stations, salt-and-pepper shakers, speakers from drive-in theaters.

title: The Big City; Undressed, Proudly, For Success
description: IF you believe that human beings of all ages and body types have a fundamental right to take off their clothes without embarrassment, you will be gladdened by a historic encounter Wednesday evening. The Ladies of Rylstone met ''The Full Monty.''

title: It's Mars Again: Can't Stay Away
description: Antony Hoffman, a first-time movie director with a background in commercials, will at long last see his first feature -- ''Red Planet,'' a big-budget adventure involving beleaguered astronauts on Mars -- arrive in theaters all over the country today (review on page 13). It has been a long, difficult road, Mr. Hoffman said.

title: In China, Ancient History Kindles Modern Doubts
description: Everyone here knows that Chinese civilization has 5,000 years of uninterrupted history, a truism proudly repeated by schoolchildren and President Jiang Zemin alike. But as serious scholars have long conceded, hard proof of the first 2,000 years is missing.

title: TRANSMETA WINS MILITARY CONTRACT
description: A microprocessor designed by Transmeta, whose stock doubled after its initial public offering this week, powers a new wearable computer being tested by the United States Army, said the computer's maker, ViA Inc. The ViA computer that uses the Transmeta Crusoe chip weighs three pounds, is worn around the waist and runs programs as quickly as many desktop computers, according to company executives, who said they had chosen the 600-megahertz Crusoe for its low energy consumption. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Commissioner Says Payroll Is Top Concern
description: Major League Baseball does not plan to follow the old axiom that says if it ain't broke, don't fix it. That is because officials think it is broke despite a period of perhaps unparalleled popularity.

title: Nightmare for PGA: Woods Is at Odds With Tour
description: The dispute between Tiger Woods and the PGA Tour is not over, but Woods contended today that the main issue is not money.

title: There's Always The Option of Giving In
description: President John F. Kennedy would sometimes write the number 118,574 on a slip of paper and put it in his pocket. That was his margin of victory in the popular vote over Vice President Richard M. Nixon in the 1960 election. The vote was close, the mandate thin, the president cautious.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Maytag Chief Steps Down, Citing Board Differences

title: After His Defeat, Franks Looks to the Future
description: In the entryway of Representative Bob Franks's campaign headquarters here, visitors are greeted with a poster of his favorite movie, ''Mr. Smith Goes to Washington.''

title: Public Interests; Call It a Tie
description: Oh no, every vote does count.

title: Russia Orders Gas Company To Let Rivals Use Its Pipelines
description: Russia's government today ordered Gazprom, the country's largest company and its leading supplier of natural gas, to give other companies access to its pipelines in a move toward opening the country's heavily regulated gas market.

title: Another Star Withdraws From Chase
description: The names in the 16-player field for the Chase Championships had been placed on a bulletin board at yesterday's draw at Madison Square Garden, and the card for Venus Williams was still tucked under the arm of a tour official.

title: Falling Short of Sublime, But Tuneful and Clever
description: Theater folk love to celebrate their own, and sometimes you'd like to blame them for it, but you can't. The peculiar and insular world they inhabit, so rich in frustrations and pot-of-gold dreams, tends to turn out personal stories that are, well, dramatic -- or at least self-dramatizing. The line between stories of limited and broad appeal is not necessarily apparent to those who would tell them, which doesn't mean a small-bore story shouldn't be told. But whether it holds up as a two-hour musical is another question entirely.

title: Statements by Daley and Christopher on Their Findings on the Florida Vote
description: Following is a transcript of statements yesterday by William M. Daley, Vice President Al Gore's campaign manager, and former Secretary of State Warren Christopher regarding the vote in Florida, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Bill Viola
description: James Cohan

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Rocky Tenure Ends for Los Angeles Prosecutor
description: On Wednesday, Gil Garcetti conceded defeat in his race for a third term as Los Angeles County district attorney. The same day, a jury here began deliberating the fate of the first four officers to be tried in Los Angeles's worst police corruption scandal in decades.

title: In Palm Beach County, Crucible of an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Maytag's Chief Executive Resigns, Citing Differences
description: After just 15 months at the helm of the Maytag Corporation, Lloyd D. Ward, the chairman and chief executive, resigned today, citing differences with the company's board.

title: STEP TOWARD SPECTRUM MARKET
description: The Federal Communications Commission took the first steps to improve access to airwaves and create a market where wireless frequencies can be swapped or sold. The F.C.C. adopted a policy statement outlining objectives for such a market and began considering rules to foster an exchange. The goal is to encourage mobile services and head off a shortage of available airwaves.

title: A Dysfunctional Family With Wounds Exposed
description: For all the bullying inspirational slogans hurled at us about never giving up on your dream, following your bliss and today being the first day of the rest of your life, the fact remains that most people's lives run on fairly narrow tracks. And in the real world, as opposed to self-help fantasyland, once you find yourself on a track, it's awfully hard to get off, even if it's headed nowhere in particular.

title: Delay Is Urged On Auditor Rule
description: Three of the five major accounting firms told the Securities and Exchange Commission it should put off voting on an auditor independence rule.

title: 'Jekyll and Hyde' Among Closings
description: And then there were none.

title: Finding the Terra Not So Firma on Mars
description: Pity the poor planet Mars. With the arrival of ''Red Planet,'' the most formidable frontier of traditional science fiction has now been dumped on by Hollywood three times in a row. First came Tim Burton's puerile comic misfire ''Mars Attacks!'' Then there was Brian De Palma's sappy ''Mission to Mars.'' And now here's ''Red Planet,'' a leaden, skimpily plotted space-age Outward Bound adventure with vague allegorical aspirations that remain entirely unrealized. If this sort of thing keeps up, nobody's going to want to go there anymore.

title: Messages on Drugs, Vouchers, Guns
description: Voters confronted more than 200 state ballot initiatives on Tuesday. On at least three controversial issues -- drug laws, school vouchers and gun control -- they sent interesting and important messages to the rest of the country.

title: Marks Only in Montenegro
description: Montenegro will stop using the Yugoslav dinar next week, ending a dual-currency system in which both the dinar and the German mark were used. The republic, Serbia's often reluctant junior partner in the remnants of the old Yugoslavia, decided last week to set up its own central bank but chose not to issue currency. Accounts and cash will be converted at a rate of 36 dinars to the mark, officials said.

title: Anger and Chagrin After an Oops on a Ballot
description: In a precinct made up largely of Jewish Democrats from New York and New Jersey, Patrick J. Buchanan, who has never been able to shed a perception among some Jews that he is anti-Semitic, somehow took 47 votes for president.

title: Top Hits Going Back 500 Years
description: To find the office where Frederick Renz oversees the affairs of the Ensemble for Early Music, the period instrument and vocal group he founded in 1974, a visitor must first find the most nondescript of the many doors on the south wall of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and then descend a staircase into the cathedral's crypt and turn right to find yet another virtually featureless door.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Ian Schrager, the hotelier who can do no wrong, has once again thrown down a challenge to cultural criticism. Why would throngs of fashionably dressed young people wait in line on the sidewalk to eat at a restaurant whose modest ambitions and spartan surroundings can be inferred from its name: Hudson Cafeteria?

title: New Jersey Hands Off Baton for Governor's Race
description: The undercard otherwise known as the race for the United States Senate -- is out of the way. Now, on to the main event.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Ruling Upheld, The Race Is On To Land Smith
description: The arbitrator Kenneth Dam yesterday upheld the National Basketball Association's decision to void Joe Smith's previous contracts with the Minnesota Timberwolves, setting in motion the type of recruiting battle that is usually reserved for the off-season.

title: Homework for the Parent, or the Child?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jesse Jackson Demands Inquiry on Florida Vote
description: Saying that Florida voters were denied the chance to cast a true vote -- either through polling place glitches or a confusing ballot in one county -- the Rev. Jesse Jackson called tonight for a Justice Department investigation into irregularities in the state's presidential election, which was still being recounted this evening.

title: A Fateful Step Toward Court
description: Vice President Al Gore has escalated the atmosphere of combat surrounding the presidential election results with his decision to go to court in Florida. What began on Wednesday as a complaint that the ballot in Palm Beach County was confusing was transformed yesterday into a claim that it was illegal. Of course Mr. Gore has a right as a private citizen to take his grievances to court. But he and Gov. George W. Bush are also political figures seeking the world's most important leadership position. Part of the test of presidential leadership, it seems to us, is finding a way to resolve electoral matters in the political arena.

title: Sports of The Times; Rice Hoping To Come Full Circle
description: SOMEONE handed Glen Rice a box with a treasure inside, but Rice tucked it away and sat quietly at his locker contemplating the previous two hours. The Knicks had lost to the Cleveland Cavaliers at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night in a game where their offense danced but their defense tripped. Rice, a new Knick, was absorbing just what that meant to a team that for the last few seasons had functioned in opposite fashion.

title: Unsparing Case Studies Of Humanity's Vileness
description: THE ELEMENTARY PARTICLES

title: 'Modernism'
description: 'A Century of Art and Design, 1880-1980'

title: U.S. ACQUISITION PLANNED
description: Dimension Data Holdings P.L.C., South Africa's biggest computer services company, plans to spend as much as $1 billion to acquire an American ''interactive commerce'' company, extending a growth-by-acquisition strategy that has increased the company's earnings per share by more than a third in the last year. The American acquisition, which the company's chairman said would most likely be ''a pure-play Web company,'' would be paid for out of proceeds from the company's equity offering in July, when it moved its main listing to London.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Perfect Storm

title: Job Loss Under George Bush Almost Cost His Son a Job
description: IT'S still the economy, stupid. Specifically, it's jobs.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Another Danger Of Smoking

title: Playing 'The Price Is Right'
description: EDMUNDS.COM took another step this week toward establishing itself as the dominant provider of online information for individuals buying or selling cars. The Web site added a research tool, the Used Vehicle Appraiser, that provides, it says, the Internet's most reliable guide to the market prices of used vehicles.

title: The Betrayal of the Dead Weighs Upon the Living
description: Early in Olivier Py's play ''Requiem for Srebrenica,'' an actress clad all in black climbs a crude metal staircase. With no warning and little fanfare, she places a megaphone to her lips and thunderously utters the words that will reverberate throughout the performance: ''You are now under the protection of the United Nations.''

title: Anger Over Fate Of Resting Place For Poor Blacks; Church Is Fighting Town For Ownership of Cemetery
description: The historic cemetery still occupies a remote and hilly corner of this town, though the rocky terrain has been pummeled by trespassers and years of neglect. The headstones for men who fought in the Union's colored regiments during the Civil War still stand, too, though many of the names have faded and vandals have not been shy about disturbing the dead.

title: In Palm Beach County, Crucible of an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Seesaw on Election News; Major Indexes Down Slightly
description: Investors went into shock but quickly recovered yesterday as they faced the possibility that the still-undecided presidential election might remain in limbo for days or weeks.

title: PC SALES JUMP IN JAPAN
description: Japanese consumers bought 5.6 million personal computers in the six months from April through September, an increase of 28 percent over the period last year, according to the Japan Electronics and Information Technology Industry Association, which represents 17 major high-technology manufacturers. The association anticipates a 21 percent rise in computer sales in the fiscal year that ends March 31, 2001. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: Lab Invents a Jackhammer That New Yorkers May Be Able to Sleep Through
description: Imagine a city of inordinate peace, where construction snarls traffic only after dark and the jackhammers are quiet enough to come out at night.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Rumbling in City Of Stormy Votes
description: The television blared yesterday afternoon at Edna's Soul Food Restaurant in this largely working-class community on the West Side where poverty runs deep and old men solve world problems over a cup of hot coffee.

title: Japan's Top Party Finds the (Younger) Party Within
description: Taro Kono, a young member of Parliament who represents this town an hour's train ride southwest of Tokyo, was attending a meeting of the governing Liberal Democratic Party this summer when he did the unthinkable: he stood up and shook his fist at the party elders in the front of the room.

title: A Brothel As a Dream Come True, For Owners
description: Anyone who thinks sex is fun ought to meet Mack and Angel Moore.

title: Among a Divided Electorate, Doubt and Anger Tempered by Faith
description: Some wanted re-votes, big or small. Others hoped George W. Bush could claim the presidency without fighting a protracted legal battle. Some saw this as one of the American political system's finer hours. Others saw proof that the Electoral College must be abolished, that election technology around the country should be updated, and that even in a well-worn democracy, elections could smell fishy.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 11
description: Game of the Week

title: Ruling Says Parents Have Right to See List of Sites Students Visit
description: In an opinion sure to heighten the tension between some parents and school systems over the Internet's role in publicly financed education, a New Hampshire judge has decided that a parent is entitled to see a list of the Internet sites or addresses visited by computer users at local schools.

title: Devils, Minus Two Unsigned Stars, Are Divided and Easy to Conquer
description: The absence of the unsigned free agents Jason Arnott and Scott Niedermayer seems more pronounced these days. The Devils have lost their last three games and are 0-3-1 in their last four.

title: Philippine Paralysis
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS IN CASH DEAL FOR PRIMEX
description: General Dynamics agreed yesterday to buy Primex Technologies for $334 million in cash, or $32.10 a share, and to assume $170 million in Primex debt. The addition of Primex's munitions and rocket engine business would make General Dynamics the largest supplier of large-caliber and self-propelled munitions to the Army, the company said; Alliant Techsystems leads the market for small-caliber munitions. Primex, which also makes rocket motors for satellites, was spun off from the Olin Corporation in 1996. Shares of General Dynamics rose 81 cents, to $70. They had gained 29 percent over the last year. Primex, which had risen by almost 50 percent in the last year, rose 44 cents, to $31.44.

title: Sabres Prolong Islanders' Quest to Be Alone at the Top
description: The Islanders have been waiting more than 10 years to take sole possession of first place. They will have to wait some more.

title: Artifacts of Pop Past: Toys for That Inner Child Who Dotes on Buck Rogers
description: Connoisseurs of kitsch, semioticians and youngsters of all ages should get a kick out of the Brooklyn Museum of Art's ''Robots and Space Toys: The Robert Lesser Collection.'' Entertaining and unexpectedly thought-provoking, the exhibition presents more than 200 toy robots, rocket ships, flying saucers, astronauts and space stations produced mostly by Japanese manufacturers for the American market after World War II. Devoted mainly to robots, the collection is said to be one of the largest of its kind in the world. It was assembled by Robert Lesser, a Manhattan resident, over the last two decades.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Italian screenwriter Leonardo Benvenuti on Tuesday included one film erroneously among his credits. The executive producer of Peter Brook's 1963 film ''Lord of the Flies'' was Al Hine -- not Mr. Benvenuti working under a pseudonym. Mr. Benvenuti was not involved in the film.

title: Uncertainty Over the Presidential Outcome Could Complicate the Work of Congress
description: The uncertainty surrounding the presidential election could complicate Congress's return on Monday for an unusual lame-duck session to wrap up their work on next year's budget.

title: Honey, I Shrunk The Theater
description: In an age when stage shows are ever grander, flashier and more mechanized, it's refreshing to find producers who value the intimate and small. The very, very small.

title: In Palm Beach County, Crucible of an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Former Diplomats, Both Steely Corporate Lawyers, Are Ready for Battle
description: Warren Christopher drinks a chardonnay from his favorite Sonoma Valley winery, wears suits custom-stitched by his Beverly Hills tailor, jogs judiciously and prides himself on his verbal politesse. James A. Baker III drinks Dr Pepper, wears finely stitched cowboy boots (sometimes), hunts wild game and engages audiences with his salty one-liners.

title: Allan McCollum
description: 'The Event: Petrified Lightning From Central Florida (With Supplemental Didactics)'

title: Most Seniors Pass Regents Exam With a Lower Cutoff Score
description: The first group of high school seniors required to master the New York State English Regents exam for graduation passed in remarkably high numbers, according to scores released yesterday, with 97 percent of students statewide and 95 percent in New York City passing.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I was so troubled. But, I thought, 'One vote. How much could that count?'''

title: Arafat-Clinton Talks in Washington Yield No Progress
description: President Clinton and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat met here today for the first time since the Camp David summit talks in July, but the White House was markedly muted afterward in its assessment of prospects for tamping down the violence in Israel and the Palestinian lands or for moving back to the negotiating table.

title: Truth Is Fine, Wit Is Divine
description: MORE than a century ago, an eccentrically dressed young Irishman on a lecture tour cast his image across that vast reflective surface known as the United States. And the United States, being an obliging young nation in such matters, threw his image back to him in a form even larger and more colorful than the original.

title: The Helen Keller Role Passes to the Pepsi Generation
description: ''I'm afraid your love for Helen is a greater handicap for her than her blindness or her deafness,'' Annie Sullivan, Helen Keller's teacher, tells the child's parents, who had treated their child as a helpless puppy until Annie appeared on the scene.

title: Florida Courts Tread Warily In Ballot Fights
description: While Florida courts have the power to overturn elections and order new ones, they rarely do so, legal experts said yesterday, because of their reluctance to interfere in politics and a presumption that no election is ever without flaws.

title: Slovene Wins The Boss Prize
description: Marjetica Potrc, a 47-year-old Slovene known for her architectural installations, has won this year's Hugo Boss Prize. While the work of Ms. Potrc (pronounced mahr-ee-yuh-TEETS-uh POT-urch) is little known in the United States, her name is widely recognized in Europe, where her work has been in many exhibitions.

title: Fighting the War at Home, Students for a Just Society
description: In 1962, a few dozen people, most of them college students, gathered at a Michigan campground to draft a manifesto that would nowadays be called a mission statement for their organization. The result, the Port Huron Statement, became one of the defining documents of the era of student radicalism. ''We are people of this generation,'' it began, ''bred in modest comfort, housed now in universities, looking uncomfortably at the world we inherit.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Jabs by Orioles' Owner Irk Yankees' Cashman
description: The Yankees will challenge the Baltimore Orioles for the services of the free-agent pitcher Mike Mussina. The Orioles' owner, Peter Angelos, continues to challenge the notion of the Yankees as a dynasty.

title: In Palm Beach County, Crucible of an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Host With a Sizable Confidence Factor
description: BILL O'REILLY describes himself as a poor prognosticator, a pundit more likely to pick the correct spread in a Jets game than to guess who might win a presidential race. So why is he boasting that he flat-out called Tuesday's (and Wednesday's and yesterday's) vote?

title: In a Split Senate, Corzine Sees Hope for Bipartisanship
description: Jon S. Corzine spent yesterday solidifying his plans as New Jersey's United States senator-elect, saying that a split among Democrats and Republicans in the Senate was as likely to produce an era of cooperation as the four years of rancorous stalemate that others are predicting.

title: Hope for a Copper-Mining Renaissance in Zambia
description: Anglo American, the international mining giant based in South Africa, would be only too happy to see the world ignore its interests here in the northern tip of Zambia's Copper Belt. At least for now.

title: Fred Holland
description: 'Eyes Over Harlem'

title: 2 Accused of Trying to Sell Sculptures Stolen in Paris
description: Two men were in police custody yesterday after they tried to sell bronze sculptures stolen in Paris in 1998 to an Upper East Side art gallery, the authorities said.

title: WESTERN RESOURCES IS SELLING KANSAS UTILITY BUSINESS
description: The Public Service Company of New Mexico agreed yesterday to buy two utilities in Kansas from Western Resources Inc. for $1.5 billion in stock and the assumption of $2.94 billion in debt. After the deal, Public Service will have more than one million electricity customers, 400,000 natural-gas customers and 7,000 megawatts in generating capacity, the company said. Western Resources, based in Topeka, Kan., said in May that it would split into two companies and seek a buyer for its utilities. Its other businesses include natural gas production, and alarm and security services. The utility business includes Kansas Gas and Electric, Kansas Power and Light, and a 47 percent stake in the Wolf Creek nuclear power plant near Burlington, Kan.

title: YAHOO BUYS TAIWAN PORTAL COMPANY
description: The big Internet portal Yahoo said it had agreed to acquire Kimo.com, a Taiwan Web site, from the Systex Corporation for $132.3 million in stock. The acquisition is part of Yahoo's strategy to bolster its offerings in Taiwan and China as it tries to gain market share there. Jerry Yang, Yahoo's co-founder, said the deal reflected the company's commitment to pursuing growth abroad. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: ALLIANCE DELAYS PIPELINE OPENING UNTIL LATE NOVEMBER
description: Alliance Pipeline said yesterday that its $3 billion natural gas line from Western Canada to the Midwestern United States would not be completed until late November, the third time completion has been delayed. Debris in the pipeline was responsible for the holdup, the company said. Producers with contracts to begin shipping gas on Monday were notified that they must wait until the end of the month. Opening of the Aux Sable Liquids processing plant near Chicago, which depends on gas from the pipeline, has also been postponed.

title: Article 2000111093122757510 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: In Palm Beach County, Crucible of an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Various Agencies Make Changes
description: The Grey Global Group in New York is opening Grey Desire in London, a consulting company specializing in what is known as customer relationship management, focused on helping marketers strengthen ties with consumers who already buy their products. Grey Desire opens with 17 employees and clients like Mars and Procter & Gamble.

title: Rite Aid to Pay $200 Million to Settle Shareholder Lawsuits
description: Rite Aid, the large drugstore chain that was forced to restate its earnings last year, settled shareholder class-action lawsuits yesterday by agreeing to pay $200 million in cash and securities and by agreeing to help shareholders in their lawsuits against the company's former top management and auditors.

title: Sehorn Back in Secondary Just in Time for St. Louis
description: While it was just the scout team's rendition of the St. Louis Rams' potent offense that was lined up against him, Jason Sehorn took his regular place among the Giants' secondary today.

title: Heroes of Science Through a Rose-Colored Lens
description: A warm and cuddly sage or a wild-eyed egomaniac demonically tinkering with the balance of nature? The image of the scientist in the popular imagination usually tilts toward one of these extremes. And in ''Me and Isaac Newton,'' a glossy group portrait of seven noted scientists, the documentary filmmaker Michael Apted places his chips on the warm, cuddly side of the table.

title: Lyme Doctors Rally Behind A Colleague Under Inquiry
description: A group of doctors who treat Lyme disease and about 400 patients with the disease accused medical boards in several states yesterday of violating doctors' rights to treat the illness in ways they believe are necessary and scientifically valid. They singled out a current unprofessional-conduct hearing against a New York doctor as the latest example.

title: Cultivating Legends
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Regents Exam Scores Offer Mixed Picture
description: Nearly all of the first group of high school seniors required to master the New York State English Regents exam for graduation met the challenge, according to scores released yesterday, with 97 percent of students statewide and 95 percent in New York City passing.

title: At the Epicenter of a Voting Dispute, a Chasm in the Streets
description: As lawyers and election workers hovered gravely over disputed ballots inside Palm Beach County's government center, the scene outside dissolved into a debate over intelligence: one side ridiculed a candidate, the other side, the voters.

title: COCA-COLA SAYS IT WILL INVEST $1 BILLION IN BRAZIL
description: Coca-Cola will invest $1.01 billion in Brazil through 2002 to step up production there, including expanding a plant at Manaus, the company said yesterday. Brazil is the No. 3 market for Coca-Cola, which gets more than half its sales outside the United States. Last year, Coca-Cola exported $100 million of soft drink concentrate from its Brazil plant, which is in a free-trade zone where companies receive tax incentives to set up exporting and importing businesses.

title: California Gets Set to Shift On Sentencing Drug Users
description: California's enormous prison system, the largest in the Western Hemisphere with more than 162,000 inmates, may be radically altered since voters on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a measure that will sentence nonviolent drug offenders to treatment instead of prison.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Management Shifts At West Wayne
description: Jeffrey L. Johnson was named president of West Wayne in Atlanta after a year as president of its offices in Coral Gables and Tampa, Fla.

title: Eating Out
description: The Season for Game

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Norfolk, Va., homecoming of the crew of the destroyer Cole, which was attacked last month in Yemen, misstated the title of John Thompson, a sailor who discussed the attack. He is an engineman third class, not ''engineerman.''

title: Run, Hapless Men, Run: An Exercise in Haste
description: ''Nonstop,'' a kinetic exercise in hipster cinema by the Japanese director Sabu, is about three men chasing one another through the streets of Tokyo.

title: In Palm Beach County, Crucible of an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Rise in Producer Price Index Slowed to 0.4% Last Month
description: Prices paid to manufacturers, farmers and other producers moderated in October, indicating that inflation remained in check.

title: Lockerbie Defense Traps a Witness Into Telling Seeming Lies
description: Defense lawyers trying to shift blame for the Lockerbie bombing away from their Libyan clients suggested today that one of the passengers who died in the crash had been duped into carrying a bomb aboard in Germany.

title: In Palm Beach County, Crucible of an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: The Race Won, the Senator-Elect Resumes Her First Lady Duties at the White House
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, the senator-elect from New York, returned to Washington today and slipped easily back into the role that made her famous in the first place: first lady of the United States.

title: Nassau Democrats Fail to Override Vetoes to Their Budget
description: In a raucous, sometimes angry session, the Democrats who control the Nassau County Legislature failed today to override the vetoes made to their 2001 budget by County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta.

title: Politics, Old and New, At Independence Hall
description: Sure, Rob Schroeder was saying today, it would be good to know soon who is going to be the next president. And he was hoping it would be Gov. George W. Bush.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: AOL TO OFFER AN APPLIANCE
description: America Online will introduce a device to be sold by Gateway beginning in December, as part of an emerging category called Internet appliances, according to executives close to the situation. It will have a touch-sensitive screen and will use a version of the Linux operating system. Meant to fit into busy and crowded corners of homes, the device will start immediately, rather than requiring a minute to boot like most personal computers. It is expected to cost about $600 and an additional monthly fee that has not been determined. Compaq has introduced a similar device, in conjunction with Microsoft's MSN service. AOL has been extending its services to a range of devices including wireless telephones and television sets.

title: Judge Orders Trial Documents Returned
description: The federal judge presiding over the government's antitrust suit against Visa and MasterCard disclosed yesterday that the Justice Department had inadvertently posted confidential trial documents on its Web site, and she ordered that anyone who obtained the information return or destroy it.

title: Minus Gill, Nets Look Listless In Defeat
description: The Nets returned home tonight with their star player soaring and their prized rookie emerging, poised to convert the momentum from Wednesday's triumph in Washington into their first victory in three tries at Continental Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAVSKY, JOYCE
description: WARSHAVSKY-Joyce. Beloved wife of Murray for 55 years. Devoted mother of Letty and Michael Tanchum and Calvin and Andrea Roberts. Dear sister of Arline Reiss. Adoring grandmother of Meredith, David, Lindsay, Robert and Joanna. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM, ''Plaza Memorial Chapel'', 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Ophthalmology Research Fund at Cornell University Medical College, 1300 York Ave., NYC 10021 would be appreciated.

title: GUESS, CLOTHING DESIGNER, WARNS OF EARNINGS DROP
description: Guess Inc., the clothing design and retail company, warned yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter and in 2001 would decline, and that third-quarter profits were well below forecasts, sending the company's already battered stock down by nearly a third in heavy trading. The company, based in Los Angeles, said it earned $5.64 million, or 13 cents a share, in the third quarter, depressed by heavy discounting to clear inventory, and expected to earn only 8 to 10 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Guess shares closed at $5, off $2.25 for the day and down $16.75, or more than 77 percent, for the year.

title: Manhattan Has Its Own Ballot Dispute
description: As if they contained a trove of top-secret data, nearly 300 voting machines used in a close State Senate race in New York were under police guard yesterday, and the two major candidates were girding for a fight over possible ballot irregularities.

title: Which Way Out of Our National Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Considers Trying for Injunction to Halt Manual Recounts
description: Gov. George W. Bush and his advisers said today that they were moving forward with preparations for a new administration and beseeched Vice President Al Gore not to stand in their way, cautioning that legal challenges to the election could yield wrangling without end.

title: Fleury Flourishes After Stepping From Spotlight
description: Theo Fleury has said he would rather be the second star of the game than the first star on any given night. For most of his career, Fleury has been more suited to a complementary role than to being the player who straps the team to his back and carries it somewhere it would otherwise not have reached.

title: Paterno Stays Optimistic Despite a Tarnished Season
description: Joe Paterno has begun sweeping up a shattered football season, but he sees luster in some of the shards in the dustpan.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Which Way Out of Our National Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bayer to Stop Requiring Applications for Blood Drug

title: Pedestrian Safety First
description: To the Editor:

title: Protection for Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: APERIAN INC., Austin, Tex., named Robert Gibbs, chief executive, to the additional post of chairman. Mr. Gibbs had also been president. In addition, Wayne Irwin, executive vice president for sales and operations, was named president and chief operating officer.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHUAN HUP HOLDINGS LTD., Singapore, the third-biggest marine transport company in Singapore by market value, said it appointed ING Barings South East Asia Ltd. as financial adviser to conduct ''a strategic review'' of its 32.7-percent stake in PCI Ltd., a Singapore maker of printed circuits. Chuan Hup said it was not in talks with any companies and had not set a timeframe for a sale.

title: Price May Still Lead, but Woods Is in His Rearview Mirror
description: Nick Price's lead got smaller, and Tiger Woods gained ground in his quest to win 10 tournaments and $10 million this year.

title: UEFA Drawings Are Announced
description: Real Madrid, the defending champion, wound up in the same UEFA Champions League soccer group as Lazio, Leeds United and Anderlecht during yesterday's draw for the second group phase of Europe's top club competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERSTEIN, MARK FILER
description: SILBERSTEIN-Mark Filer, 51, beloved son of Janet F. and the late Leon M. Silberstein, treasured brother of Judy Rosemarin and Jo Ellen Silberstein, adored uncle of Donna Stevens, Julie Rosemarin and David Weinstein and greatuncle of Jonathan and Emily Stevens, died unexpectedly on November 9 2000 in Sarasota, Florida. As a certified geriatric social worker and President of Supportive Senior Services, Tampa, Florida, he was dedicated to helping families cope with the challenges of aging relatives. Mark was a man of extraordinary compassion, gentleness, love, intelligence, insight with a good-hearted sense of humor. His big heart and love of his family made him one in a million. He will be deeply and forever missed by his family, friends, his animals he so dearly loved and the ducks he fed each and every day. Funeral services will be held at ''The Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 76th and Amsterdam Ave, NYC, on November 13 2000 at 12:45pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to ASPCA, Big Brothers of America Association, or the charity of one's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRINSKY, GERTRUDE. (NEE COHEN)
description: KRINSKY-Gertrude. (nee Cohen) Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Eugene & Joel (Marsha). Also survived by cherished nephew Dr. Robert Crain (Harriet). Reposing Midwood Funeral Chapel, Coney Island Ave. (between L & M). Shiva at Eugene Krinsky Sunday-Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOATE, THOMAS HYDE
description: CHOATE-Thomas Hyde. The Friends of Hyde Hall, Cooperstown, NY express their sorrow at the death of Thomas Hyde Choate. Founding Board member in 1964, former President and active supporter. The Board extends sympathy to his widow Jane and his family. Anne C. Logan, Chairman

title: Victor Grinich, 75, Co-Founder Of Upstart Electronics Company
description: Victor Grinich, an electronics industry pioneer who helped start Fairchild Semiconductor in 1957 with seven other defectors from a small start-up founded by the Nobel Prize winner William Shockley, died last Sunday in Mountain View, Calif. He was 75.

title: Bayer Revises Blood-Drug Policy
description: Under pressure from people with hemophilia, the Bayer Corporation said yesterday that it would stop requiring patients to apply to a special corporate program for its new drug, Kogenate FS, which is in short supply, and would instead begin distributing it through normal channels.

title: Etienne Aigner, 95; Designer of Shoes With a Preppy Look
description: Etienne Aigner, a Hungarian-born belt maker and designer whose line of cordovan accessories with a distinctive omega-shaped logo helped define the preppy look of the 1960's and 70's, died in New York on Sunday, three days before what would have been his 96th birthday. He had homes in New York, Paris and Cannes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, ESTHER
description: LERNER-Esther. On Thursday, November 9, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Philip Hamburger and the late Herman Lerner. Loving mother of Shirley R. Finkelstein and David Hamburger. Cherished grandmother of Susan, Ellen and Brian. Great-grandmother of Sam, Miriam, Rachel, Rebecca and Jacob.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with a review of Cortez and Company Contemporary/Ballet at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church on Nov. 2 included an erroneous identification from the company for the dancer at the right. He was Nicholas Villeneuve, not Izell Blunt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONNELL, JOYCE
description: McDONNELL-Joyce on November 9, 2000. A pioneer in service to the travel and tourism industry by major public relations firms, died at Sloan-Kettering Hospital of complications following a brief illness. Mrs. McDonnell was known professionally as Joyce M. Martin. Beloved wife of the late Peter J. McDonnell. Loving mother of Charles Bowden, step mother to Regina Hayes, Christine Shaneyfelt, Mary McDonnell, William McDonnell and step grandmother of five. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St Sunday 7-9pm and Monday 2-5 & 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, 110-06 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, Tuesday 11am.

title: Nasdaq Takes Plunge of 5% on Dell News
description: Stock prices tumbled again yesterday, falling for the third consecutive day amid questions about the outcome of the presidential election. But it appears that normal investor concerns, including the fear of sharply slowing earnings growth, are still fueling most of the selling.

title: Costs of Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: PACIFICARE RAISES ESTIMATE FOR EARNINGS
description: PacifiCare Health Systems raised its estimate for fourth-quarter earnings to a range of 20 to 30 cents a share, far above the 7 cents analysts had forecast. The news sent PacifiCare's stock soaring, even though the company also reported that earnings in the third quarter had all but evaporated, falling 98 percent, to $1.4 million, or 4 cents a share, from $71 million in the period a year earlier. PacifiCare shares rose $3.31, to $14, but remain down for the year.

title: Democrats' Eyes on Recounts and Courts
description: For all their threats of court action and dire warnings about illegal ballots, Democratic strategists said today that the last place they wanted the presidential election to wind up was before a judge.

title: G.O.P. Warns That It, Too, May Seek Some Recounts
description: The Republicans sent clear signals today that if the Democrats prolonged the fight over Tuesday's election results in Florida, they would ask for vote recounts in several closely contested states where Vice President Al Gore was the apparent winner.

title: Which Way Out of Our National Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentina Says Lenders Pledge to Help Lift Economy
description: Argentina said today that it expects to receive support from international lenders to help revive its stagnant economy.

title: Judge Says Town Went Too Far In Creation of Gun-Free Zones
description: A New Jersey judge has overturned an unusual local law that bans guns within 1,000 feet of schools, parks, playgrounds or libraries in the borough of Roseland, ruling that only the state legislature can regulate firearms.

title: Jersey City's Council President Announces a Run for Mayor
description: With Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City planning a run for governor next year, the city's longtime Council president today became the first candidate to announce officially that he will run for mayor.

title: In This Bible Story, Who Has Time to Rest?
description: There is unlikely to be an outbreak of goose bumps when ''In the Beginning . . .,'' NBC's four-hour dramatization of the early Bible, makes its debut. Nor will the nation's tear ducts be overtaxed. Yet in a backhanded sort of way, the film suggests how it is that these few dozen chapters of an old book have been able to register so powerfully with so many for so long.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article last Saturday about the Justice Department's decision to consider civil rights charges against two New Jersey state troopers misstated the party affiliation of John J. Farmer, the state attorney general, who requested the inquiry. A Democrat until last year, he is now an independent, not a Republican.

title: Disappearance Under Scrutiny After 18 Years
description: Eighteen years after the trail grew cold, police investigators have begun to track new leads in the baffling disappearance of Kathleen A. Durst, the wife of a scion of one of New York's wealthiest real estate families.

title: Sports of The Times; Knockouts Will Bring Lewis Fame
description: LENNOX LEWIS feels unappreciated. As the heavyweight champion in two-thirds of boxing's world and the conqueror of the ruler (Evander Holyfield) of the other third, he believes he should be rated ''up there with'' Joe Louis and Muhammad Ali. He feels he doesn't get enough respect for his 35-1-1 record with 27 knockouts. He resents that he's not yet considered to be a heavyweight of history.

title: Young Red Storm Can't Replicate Rally
description: Comebacks are not designed as much as they are willed. St. John's showed the ability to rally for a late victory in its opening game on Thursday, a skill it hopes not to have to use often this season. It tried to maneuver out of a late deficit again last night, but the Red Storm's youth could not produce a second straight stunner in an 82-74 loss to seventh-ranked Kansas at Madison Square Garden.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial yesterday on the Florida election controversy said incorrectly that in the 1996 presidential election almost 15,000 ballots were disqualified in Palm Beach County because voters had punched in votes for two candidates. The county's supervisor of elections office says that number represents all ballots that were disqualified, not just those disqualified for double-punching.

title: Police Official Quits Under Pressure Over Precinct Conditions
description: The police official in charge of the department's budget and buildings resigned on Thursday after pressure from Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik, who has signaled that improving conditions at police precincts is a priority.

title: Strolling in the Labyrinth Of Bach's Counterpoint
description: There is nothing more reliable in the world of classical music today than the pianist Andras Schiff playing Bach. On Wednesday at Carnegie Hall, for the second of three recitals Mr. Schiff is giving in this Bach year, he played Book II of 'The Well-Tempered Clavier,'' having played Book I on Saturday. It was a privilege to be in the audience.

title: Which Way Out of Our National Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: 2nd Man Is Arrested in Fatal Subway Shooting
description: The police arrested a second man yesterday in connection with the fatal shooting on a Manhattan subway train of a United Parcel Service employee on his way to work, the authorities said.

title: Bosnia Holds Broad Elections Today, and Western Officials Fret
description: General elections in Bosnia on Saturday will tell whether the country's Muslims, Croats and Serbs reject the nationalist parties that have dominated their three communities since the war here in the 1990's. The Muslims seem the most likely to do so.

title: Florida, of Course
description: The intense focus on Florida as the epicenter of the unending presidential election has the same effect as flipping on the kitchen light at 4 a.m. and surprising the palmetto bugs.

title: Bridge; 5 Players, Alabama Bound, Hope for Repeat of Anaheim
description: A throng of New York players will be headed for the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships in Birmingham next Thursday. That is Alabama, not England, although the two cities are almost equally difficult to reach, usually requiring a change of planes from New York City.

title: A Trial Lap for Eschenbach In the Philharmonic's Race
description: The names of the conductors Mariss Jansons and Christoph Eschenbach have long been circulating as possible successors to Kurt Masur as the music director of the New York Philharmonic. Last week the orchestra presented what was, essentially, a hugely expensive public audition for Mr. Jansons, who conducted a hastily arranged nonsubscription concert, nominally a memorial event for Leonard Bernstein.

title: A New President for Brown University
description: Ruth J. Simmons will become the first African-American woman to head an Ivy League university next July when she takes over as the 18th president of Brown University. In addition to making history, Brown has gained a visionary leader who should help consolidate its position as one of the nation's most esteemed schools.

title: Vote Spices Up Bubbling Ethnic Stew
description: At a coffee shop in Little Havana, at a cab company in Liberty City and in between games of canasta at a retirement community in Delray Beach, black, Jewish and Hispanic voters who rarely agree on much agreed on at least one thing today: the racial and ethnic undertones of the election chaos show just how fractured this highly diverse part of the country can be.

title: The Public Duties of Broadcasters
description: A federal appeals court has ordered the Federal Communications Commission to repeal two longstanding rules that apply to the nation's broadcasters. The rules required stations to give candidates free air time to respond either to political endorsements of their opponents made by the stations or to personal attacks. The court's decision last month was not based on the merits of the rules, but on procedural grounds. Even so, the ruling leaves federal regulation of how stations serve the public trust weaker than ever.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's in our country's best interest that we plan in a responsible way for a possible administration.''

title: BASF CONSIDERING SALE OF PHARMACEUTICAL UNIT
description: The German chemicals giant BASF A.G. is considering selling its pharmaceutical unit, according to executives close to the company. BASF has hired the investment bank Wasserstein Perella Securities to advise it on a possible sale, the executives said. The unit, called Knoll, is expected to fetch more than $6 billion. The pharmaceutical unit's main attraction is its rheumatoid arthritis drug, D2E7, which analysts expect to be among the next wave of blockbuster drugs, bringing in $1 billion in annual sales. Likely potential buyers include Bristol-Myers Squibb, Novartis, Roche Holding and Eli Lilly & Company, analysts said. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Clinton Encourages Gore
description: President Clinton called Vice President Al Gore, urging him to ''hang in there'' in his battle to win the presidency through a recount of the balloting in Florida. Page A15.

title: Japan Slightly Downgrades Official Economic Outlook
description: A budding recovery in Japan's economy is faltering, according to the latest government report, raising concern about whether the economy can generate enough steam to recover without more help from the government.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MIESMER, CHARLES W.
description: MIESMER-Charles W. December 13, 1917 to November 11, 1999. My Love, If Tears Could Build a Stairway, And Memories a Lane, I'd Walk Right Up to Heaven and Bring You Home Again You're everywhere I turn. Love, Ginny

title: Clinton Offers Gore His Support but Keeps His Activity Low Key
description: President Clinton called Vice President Al Gore this morning, urging him to ''hang in there'' in his battle to win the presidency through a recount of Tuesday's balloting in Florida, where the latest unofficial tally places Mr. Gore 327 votes behind Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Democrats' Phone Blitz Warned Voters About Confusing Ballot Late on Election Day
description: The Democratic Party unleashed a barrage of telephone calls to voters in Palm Beach County on the evening of Election Day to warn them that a confusing ballot might have led them to vote for the wrong candidate, party officials said tonight.

title: Democrats Split Over Possibility Of Court Battle
description: The Gore campaign's threat of a court fight over the presidential balloting in Florida set off a backstage debate in the Democratic Party today between party leaders who are rallying behind the vice president and others, including longtime Gore loyalists, who warn that such a fight could damage the party and the democratic process.

title: Blacks, Citing Flaws, Seek Inquiry Into Florida Vote
description: African-American voters and community leaders here are calling not just for a recount, but also a re-vote, saying that irregularities at polling places and what they insisted was an illegal ballot layout in Palm Beach County thwarted the true intent of their vote.

title: Contenders Must Win, By a Lot
description: The good, the bad and the ugly of college football's attempt to crown a national champion will most likely create a frothy mix today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATZER, DAVID
description: PLATZER-David. Beloved husband of Frances. Adored father of Steven and Nancy Platzer, Robin Platzer Judson and Robert Judson. Proud grandfather of David Lawrence Platzer, Adam Platzer and Melanie Rose Judson. Services will be held on Sunday, November 12 at 10 AM at the ''Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Family will be receiving at ''Riverside'' on Saturday night from 7-9 PM. Contributions may be made in his memory to N.Y.U. Medical Center, Palliative Care Program, C/O James C. Wernz, M.D., 160 E. 32 St., NY, NY 10016.

title: Yankees Near Deal For O'Neill To Return
description: On the day they withdrew their three-year offer to reliever Jeff Nelson, the Yankees all but concluded a one-year deal with right fielder Paul O'Neill. If O'Neill passes a physical examination, he will return for his ninth season with the team.

title: Works by Anna Sokolow, For Real Adults Only
description: Anna Sokolow's long and successful career as a modern-dance choreographer and teacher was driven in large part by her belief in the importance of craft and theater. And a program by her Players' Project troupe on Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church suggested that the choreographer, who died this year, knew exactly whom to entrust her vision with.

title: For Western Music, the Center Holds
description: Why did the songs of Tin Pan Alley contain so many allusions to Japan? How did Eddie Van Halen modify his electric guitar? What happened to the southern Philippine gong tradition known as kulintang? What makes the finale to Beethoven's Op. 131 String Quartet so unexpectedly piquant? I didn't go to Toronto last week seeking answers to these questions, but they were there to be found, among hundreds of papers offered at a five-day meeting attended by nearly 4,000 scholars from 15 academic music societies.

title: A Playwright Foretelling Her Doom
description: The lilt of a lullaby runs through ''Crave,'' the English dramatist Sarah Kane's chamber piece for four haunted voices. Close your eyes during the play, which is receiving its New York premiere at the Axis Company, and the effect is of thoughts moving restlessly through a mind on the threshold of sleep.

title: In Upstate Victory Tour, Mrs. Clinton Says Electoral College Should Go
description: Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton, who arrived here this morning from the White House for a victory tour of upstate New York, called for the abolition of the Electoral College. She pledged to be a co-sponsor of legislation that would provide for the direct election of the president and vice president.

title: A Prizewinner From Britain With Some American Tastes
description: Badly Drawn Boy, a songwriter otherwise known as Damon Gough, didn't have to remind the sold-out crowd at the Knitting Factory on Monday night that his debut album had won the Mercury Music Prize; everyone already knew. The prize was set up in 1992 to be roughly analogous to the Booker Prize for fiction, honoring a deserving album for artistic quality regardless of popularity.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Sidney E. Woloshin, an advertising executive and writer of commercial jingles, referred incorrectly in some copies to the company that performed a ballet piece called ''PAMTGG,'' named with the initials of ''Pan Am Makes the Going Great.'' It was the New York City Ballet, not American Ballet Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, CAROLYN
description: KING-Carolyn. November 9, 2000. Retired New York City School Teacher for many years. Friends may call at Williams Funeral Home Inc, 5628 Broadway at 232 ST, Bronx, Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Elizabeth Church, Monday at 11 am.

title: OIL STRIKE IN BRAZIL
description: Brazil's union of oil workers plans a strike of at least four days starting Monday, after wage negotiations deadlocked with Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras. The strike threatens crude oil production in the Campos Basin, which accounts for 80 percent of Brazil's output, and operations at the country's two largest refineries. Jennifer Rich (NYT)

title: BID FOR EXCHANGE FAILS
description: Shareholders of the London Stock Exchange rejected a hostile bid from the OM Group, which sells trading systems and owns the Stockholm stock exchange. When the $1.3 billion offer expired yesterday, only 6.7 percent of shares had been tendered. Other exchanges have explored alliances with the London Stock Exchange, but its chief executive, Don Cruickshank, has said it will remain independent for now. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Which Way Out of Our National Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Silicon Alley's Revenues Fall, And More Layoffs Are Planned
description: The dot-com shakeout continued to reverberate through New York's Silicon Alley this week as several companies announced sharp revenue losses, and one said it would soon lay off more than 200 employees.

title: IRISH INFLATION RISES
description: Consumer prices in Ireland rose 6.8 percent in the year to October, faster than the 6.2 percent rate posted in the two prior months. Oil prices were largely responsible, analysts said, though housing and tobacco were also soaring. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: An Endangered Species: Liberal in Canada's West
description: As Canada's justice minister, Anne McLellan has fought for the kind of liberal society many Americans associate with Canada: a national gun control registry, common-law marriage rights for gay couples and defense of the government monopoly in health care.

title: No Headline
Lockerbie Prosecutors Work to Head Off Move to Shift Blame
description: The prosecution in the Lockerbie trial today tried to establish an alibi for a Palestinian bomber whom the defense plans to blame for the destruction of Pan Am Flight 103.

title: Musicians Can Organize At Apollo, Board Decides
description: The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that musicians at the Apollo Theater in Harlem have the right to organize, federal officials and labor organizers said yesterday, after a nearly eight-month battle between management and workers.

title: Days After Its Historic Vote, Oregon Still Trying to Pick a Winner
description: There were no exit poll results coming out of Oregon just minutes after the voting ended on Tuesday, no complaints about long lines or hard-to-read ballots. Voters in Oregon did not even go the polls, in the usual sense of the word. This is the only state that casts ballots entirely by mail.

title: Mets Crunch Numbers And Free-Agent Needs
description: Steve Phillips is like any other businessman working with a budget. Phillips, the Mets' general manager, could go all out to pay millions of dollars to sign shortstop Alex Rodriguez, but he would then have to make other adjustments to stay within the financial parameters set by the team's owners. Phillips would have perhaps the greatest offensive shortstop in history in the early stage of his career, and, presumably, Phillips would not have as much money to spend on pitching.

title: Which Way Out of Our National Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMAN, ETHEL
description: BERGMAN-Ethel of Jamesburg, NJ. Formerly of Bayonne, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Abe Bergman. Devoted mother of Edward Bergman and the late Robert Bergman. Dear sister of Esther Edwards. Loving grandmother of Peter Bergman, Amy Bonomi and Maggie Bergman. Graveside service Sunday 11am, United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAKTMAN, PEGGY
description: TRAKTMAN-Peggy. Goodbye old friend. I miss you already. Sue Freedman.

title: Recalling Nixon and Ford, Baker Urges Gore to Quit
description: Former Secretary of State James A. Baker III today implored Vice President Al Gore to follow the lead of two former Republican presidential candidates who swiftly conceded defeat after narrow contests marred by charges of fraud.

title: Eric Morley, 82, 'Miss World' Promoter, Dies
description: Eric Morley, who made a parade of pretty girls in swimsuits into a televised international sport with millions of fans, died Thursday in London. He was 82.

title: Local Officials Say System Failed on Election Day
description: Bush campaign officials have tried to undercut criticisms of the fairness of the Palm Beach County ballot by saying there were plenty of safeguards and that the problems on Tuesday were not unusual.

title: The Mideast Landscape
description: To the Editor:

title: Affymetrix Found to Have Infringed Patent
description: In a decision concerning one of the most important inventions in biotechnology, a federal jury ruled yesterday that Affymetrix Inc. had infringed a patent held by a British company covering so-called gene chips, which are used for the rapid analysis of genes.

title: After Funeral for a Slain Palestinian Paramilitary Leader, More Death for Both Sides
description: In Manger Square, spiffed up just last Christmas for what was supposed to be a banner year for the now-dead Palestinian tourism industry, thousands of Muslims bowed in prayer today to mourn a paramilitary leader assassinated by the Israelis.

title: L. S. de Camp, 92, Author Of Over 100 Fantasy Novels
description: L. Sprague de Camp, who wrote over 100 science-fiction and fantasy novels and numerous short stories, died on Monday in Plano, Tex., where he lived. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUSSEM, MAX (MOTLE)
description: JUSSEM-Max (Motle). On November 9th., 92 years old, born in Poland. Beloved husband of the late Sonia. Survived by sister-inlaw, Lola Jusem of Israel; loving nieces, Sandy Levy of Israel and Pearl Jusem of Cambridge, Mass., and their families. Also survived by beloved companion, Molly Nussbaum, and her children and grandchildren. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Service Sunday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Thinkers on the Left Get A Hearing Everywhere but at Home; Europeans, Wary of Globalization, Embrace American Economists Who Heed Social Needs
description: James Tobin, a Nobel Prize winner who served as an economic adviser to the Kennedy administration in 1961 and '62, has lived in quiet retirement for more than a decade in New Haven. Yet thousands of French demonstrators are likely to invoke him as their intellectual champion next month during protests at the coming summit meeting of the European Union. They are members of a new organization formed expressly to promote the so-called ''Tobin tax,'' a tax on foreign currency and international financial transactions that came within six votes of being adopted by the European Parliament this year.

title: EMI Talking To Bertelsmann On Music Deal
description: Bertelsmann A.G., the German media giant, and the EMI Group, the British music company, said today that they were in talks about combining their operations in what would become one of the music industry's largest companies.

title: INSIDE
description: Mourning in Bethlehem

title: Which Way Out of Our National Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLINKER, SELMA
description: GOLINKER-Selma. Beloved wife of the late Joseph, devoted mother of Michele and Mitchell Miller, and Lewis Golinker and Joy Blumkin. Dear sister of Miriam Charnick and Cynthia and Alex Rothenberg. Loving grandmother of Rachel, Andrew, Joseph, and Amy. Services Sunday 12:00 noon at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARSON, BROOKE J.
description: CARSON-Brooke J. Born November 11, 1946. Lookie Brookie it's your Bird-Day. We remember every day and miss you and love you. Mother, Ian, Devereaux

title: Truck Manufacturer Offer
description: Scania A.B., the Swedish truck manufacturer, said today that it offered to buy the portion of Beers N.V., its Dutch sales and service company, that it does not already own for $247 million, of $40.30 a share. The bid represents a 33 percent premium over Beers' average stock closing price over the last month, Scania said. Scania already holds a 49.9 percent stake in Beers, which it acquired in 1985. Beers, with annual sales of $502 million, imports and distributes new trucks and parts and has a national sales and service network in the Netherlands with 34 outlets. Under the agreement Scania's bid must be backed by at least 70 percent of Beers' shareholders.

title: Greenwich Cites Fear of 'Jerseyfication' in Beach Dispute
description: Pressing the fight to keep nonresidents off its cherished public beach, this affluent town seems to have summed up its worst fears in two words: New Jersey.

title: Bush Team Questions Results Of the Recounts in 2 Counties
description: With Democrats focusing attention on the voting in Palm Beach County, Florida Republicans and the Bush campaign yesterday questioned the recounts in two counties where Vice President Al Gore saw his tallies increase by several hundred votes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARREN, JOHN
description: DARREN-John. On Novemnber 8, 2000 at home after a long illness. Survived by his loving wife Eileen, his darling daughter Nicole, three brothers, three sisters and his beloved mother Helen. John grew up in Rhode Island and served in the US Navy. He then moved to NYC where he pursued a career as an actor and filmmaker. For many years John taught technical theater and was the Technical Director of the Queens College theater where he was beloved by his students. ''Captain'' John Darren built houses, boats and a Starduster Too biplane. Every day of his life was an adventure and we will all miss the rollercoaster ride. A celebration of his life will be held on December 9th at 873 Broadway, NYC, 4-6PM. Donations may be made to The John Darren Scholarship Fund, Queens College Drama Department, 65-30 Kissena Blvd., Queens, NY 11367.

title: Clinton Seen Issuing Work Rules That Stalled Spending Agreement
description: The Clinton administration is expected to issue workplace safety regulations next week that are vehemently opposed by business groups and that defy Congressional Republicans, whose concern about the rules was a stumbling block to an agreement on a final federal budget.

title: Democratic 'War Room' Tries to Oversee the Battle for Florida, to Mixed Results
description: At a strip mall just off Interstate 95, the Democrats have transformed a modest campaign headquarters into a bustling law office, where a battalion of lawyers, flown in from all across the country, have met with thousands of voters challenging the fairness of Tuesday's election.

title: Larry Rhine, 90, 'All in the Family' Writer
description: Larry Rhine, a writer whose 50-year career embraced radio, television and films, died on Oct. 27 in Los Angeles. He was 90.

title: DEAL FOR ELLIS & EVERARD
description: Europe's No. 1 distributor of chemicals, Royal Vopak of the Netherlands, said it would buy the No. 4 distributor, Ellis & Everard P.L.C., for $:310 million ($444 million), or $:3.10 a share, to expand in Britain and Ireland. Vopak is based in Rotterdam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, J. SINCLAIR
description: ARMSTRONG-J. Sinclair. The members of The Saint Nicholas Society of the City of New York are saddened by the death of their distinguished member, and express their deepest sympathy to his family. John Milnes Baker, President John Shannon, Secretary

title: BIG SCREEN, SMALL MOMENTS
description: Much of the photography about movies today is glamorous, meant to enlarge the myth of Hollywood.
