A special issue of The Times Magazine takes a different view, capturing with still pictures the real life that occurs in the artificial universe of the moving ones, from the construction of a blockbuster like ''Pearl Harbor'' to the food that Hollywood eats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARISI, THOMAS E.
description: PARISI-Thomas E., 45, of Mamaroneck, New York on November 9, 2000. Beloved husband of Teresa (Scimia). Loving father of Talia. Son of Edmee and the late Anthony Parisi. Brother of Michael, Julia, Clelia, James and Camille. Visitation Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at McElroy-Flynn Funeral Home Inc. Elmsford, NY. Mass 11AM Monday at St. Vito's Roman Catholic Church, Mamaroneck, New York.

title: Coach and Canarsie Have Only One Thing Left to Do
description: Mike Camardese has chased a Public Schools Athletic League title ever since he became coach of the Canarsie High School football team nearly 17 years ago.

title: With Vote Count on Hold, House Candidates Step Up Attacks
description: With the final tally incomplete and most election workers off for Veterans Day, the two men competing for New Jersey's 12th Congressional District seat stepped up their war of words yesterday, each proclaiming himself the victor while accusing the other of undemocratic behavior.

title: Penguins Deliver Knockout to Devils
description: Martin Brodeur, the franchise goaltender for the Devils, gave his team and the fans a scare late in the second period of the Devils' 4-2 loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight.

title: War Grips an Eden That Indonesia Won't Set Free
description: It was almost dawn, and the men of this remote jungle village were sitting down to coffee after morning prayers when heavily armed troops descended on the local cafe searching for pro-independence guerrillas. The troops herded the men into a truck and sped away.

title: Supervisor Retains Power Despite Town's Troubles
description: Despite months of gripes about a town board better known for its acrimony than its accomplishments, voters here rejected a proposal this week that would have significantly altered their form of government.

title: U.C.L.A. Tops Kentucky (0-2)
description: Kentucky entered the Coaches vs. Cancer Ikon Classic as the highest ranked of the four teams. The Wildcats left New York without a victory.

title: Lessons in Democracy: Never-Ending Election
description: If visions of misread ballots, never-ending recounts and a thicket of legal challenges make your temples throb, then just imagine the headaches for a group of observers who came all the way from the former Soviet Union for a lesson in American electoral democracy -- at this of all times.

title: TELENOR OFFERING PRICED LOW
description: The price range for the initial public offering of Telenor A.S., Norway's former phone monopoly, values the company at 70 billion to 95 billion kroner ($7.6 billion to $10.3 billion), about two-thirds of what analysts had forecast last month. Rivals like Telia and Tele Danmark have slumped in recent months.

title: Efforts to Save Right Whales Turning From Looking to Listening
description: Every year, endangered right whales migrate along the Eastern Seaboard, from their feeding grounds in the Gulf of Maine to their breeding grounds off Georgia and Florida. And every year, researchers take to the air to photograph them, look for those entangled in fishing gear and report on calving mothers.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Remarks About Election
description: Following are excerpts from remarks yesterday by Gov. George W. Bush in Austin, Tex., and a Bush representative, James A. Baker III in Tallahassee, Fla., as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Illegal Drug's Manufacture Puts Rural Areas at Risk
description: Illegal methamphetamine laboratories by the hundreds have moved into rural areas of Missouri and Illinois, turning commonly used farm chemicals into grave hazards and making quiet neighborhoods and towns dangerous places to live.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Arafat Asks U.N. Council to Send Force to Protect Palestinians
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, implored the Security Council today to send a roving 2,000-member multinational force that could insert itself into the conflict between Israelis and the Palestinians anywhere in the West Bank, Gaza or Jerusalem itself.

title: Op-Art
COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSCH, ROBERT
description: BUSCH-Robert. On November 9th, 2000 at age 86. Died peacefully at his home surrounded by his beloved wife, Norma (Ponoroff), and devoted family, Carole Rako and Bonnie and John Stephens. He practiced dentistry in Freeport for over 40 years. A kind and generous man, Bob touched all who knew him. His memory and gentle spirit will always be with us. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKE, GERALD D., DDS.
description: FINKE-Gerald D., DDS. Died peacefuly on November 9, 2000. Beloved husband of Leslie. Devoted father of Victoria and Michael Shernicoff, David and Junko Finke. Proud grandfather of Harrison, Matthew and Emily. Loving brother of Brian. Funeral on Sunday, November 12, 1:00 PM at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre. In lieu of flowers donations to Family & Children's Association, 100 Old Country Rd., Mineola, NY 11501, would be appreciated.

title: Which Way Out of Our National Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping in Palm of the Hand Is Making Its Holiday Debut
description: E-commerce is already ho-hum this Christmas, and shopping malls are still perceived by many as parking traps. But there is something new as the retailing season comes to its peak: the era of mobile shopping, or m-commerce, is making its debut.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: South Florida Immersed In Another Media Circus
description: Florida has not had a show like this since the last Dumpster fire went cold after the fight for Elian Gonzalez.

title: South Africa's Economic Lament; With Things Looking Up, Foreign Investors Remain Aloof
description: Earlier this year, when Standard & Poor's finally ratcheted South Africa's credit rating up to investment grade, it was supposed to be icing on the economic cake. Disciplined management and difficult decisions had put the country's fiscal house in order, and the other big ratings agency, Moody's Investor Service, had already given the thumbs up.

title: Utility Wins Rate Increase As Workers Stage a Strike
description: The South Jersey Gas Company has received some mixed news: the state has approved a 20.5 percent rate increase for the company, but its workers have gone on strike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGEL, FLORENCE
description: ENGEL-Florence. Devoted sister of Selma Siegel and Helen Meltzer. Beloved aunt. For information call Weinstein West End Chapel, 1800-452-9597.

title: Which Way Out of Our National Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: As Visions of E-Toys Danced In Their Heads
description: Heaven Acevedo was grinning as she clutched a Poo-chi electronic dog to her chest at a Toys ''R'' Us in Manhattan last week. While her mother, Janet, browsed the aisles holding a large stuffed horse, 2-year-old Heaven sat in her stroller and gazed at her electronic toy.

title: Democracy's Rusty Machinery
description: What has become embarrassingly clear over the last few anxious days is that the world's most powerful democracy needs to figure out a better way to vote for president. The stories coming out of Florida this week are bad enough -- ballots missing or stuck together, holes punched for the wrong candidate, questionable absentee ballots. But as Florida's election officials squirm under the international spotlight, voting supervisors in other states are wincing sympathetically, many fearing that their own systems might look just as flawed under such relentless public inspection.

title: It's Business for Ewing, But Not Quite as Usual
description: Patrick Ewing ambled through the practice facility's doors about 2 p.m today. He had gotten permission to arrive here on his own, rather than catch the team charter bus from the hotel. There were people to see, 20 or so tickets to procure for the game and a few moments to let it all sink in.

title: Shoestring Budget and Shoe Leather Pay Off
description: Within roughly two hours on Election Day, Robert W. Megna, a quiet man who adjusts insurance claims for a living and rehabilitates injured squirrels and birds as a hobby, went from being an unknown Democratic legislative candidate to an unlikely political star.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, ILSE
description: DEUTSCH-Ilse of Nutley, NJ, wife of Rudolph A. Funeral service Sunday 8 p.m. at S.W. Brown & Son Funeral Home, 267 Centre St. Nutley. Visiting Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. She was the Bookkeeper for the Federal Law Enforcement Office Assn. and Proof Reader for Eighteen Eleven, retired 1 yr ago.

title: Proud Daughter of a Janitor Reaches an Academic Peak
description: THE two sisters moved speechlessly through the Georgian revival house on Power Street, the official residence of the president of Brown University.

title: After Heroics by Houston, Ward Provides the Reward
description: It was the perfect night for Allan Houston to be at his best. Latrell Sprewell was in New York resting his aching back. Chris Childs was sidelined by a bruised right hamstring. Glen Rice, plagued by foul trouble, did not score a point until the final minute of the third quarter. And the youthful, energetic Boston Celtics, trapping and driving aggressively, were turning the game into the type of mad scramble that has so often doomed the Knicks.

title: She Was Blond and Married. He, a Cabana Boy in Love.
description: For various financing and distribution reasons, many feature films don't find their way into theaters but end up making their debuts on cable television. Sometimes this seems a pity, and sometimes the small screen seems exactly the right size.

title: TELMEX TO INVEST $4 BILLION
description: Mexico's largest phone company, Telefonos de Mexico S.A., said it planned to invest $2 billion in Mexico and another $2 billion elsewhere in Latin America to expand its network of fixed and cellular phone services.

title: Making Economic Lifeline of a Wartime Trail
description: Sometimes when the road builders set off their blasting caps here along the old Ho Chi Minh Trail, one of the bulldozer operators gives an involuntary, comical little duck of the head, as if someone were dropping bombs nearby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRECHER, RONALD
description: BRECHER-Ronald. Of Great Neck, NY. Died on November 9, 2000 of lung cancer. Services Sunday at 1:30pm at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels''.

title: Fighting in Mideast Blocks Wave of Christian Tourism
description: Tahir Kannan squatted despondently in the empty courtyard outside the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, his supply of wooden crosses stacked unused against the pitted limestone walls.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday described regrets expressed by some supporters of Ralph Nader's presidential campaign in interviews and in the chat room of a Web site. The article quoted a chat room entry ''from someone identified as 'Noni Bookbinder Bell' '' saying she regretted having supported Mr. Nader.

title: Hoping Web Success Strikes Twice
description: Denis Dutton, a cherubic 56-year-old philosophy professor, has spent most of his professional career writing books on the theory of aesthetics and teaching Plato in New Zealand. But recently he has turned into a minor media celebrity, a cyberpublishing prophet who is invited to speak at e-book conferences from Los Angeles to New York.

title: For Viewers, Rare Sense Of History In Progress
description: Just as it shaped this election, television may have shaped the messy, enthralling aftermath even more. From the botched, back-and-forth forecasts on Tuesday night (with viewers gleefully discovering that politics can be suspenseful and anchors human) through yesterday's dueling news conferences and photo opportunities (not the most confidence-inspiring images of George W. Bush or Al Gore's careers), it is possible to chart television's influence in several directions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIG, SOPHIE
description: VIG-Sophie. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of John Vig and Ann Bor. Loving grandmother of Alastair and Michael Bor. Services 12:30, Sunday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNING, JAMES DORR
description: DUNNING-James Dorr. On November 7, 2000, at his home in New York City, after a long illness. He was 89. Mr. Dunning was an executive of New York Life Insurance Company for 45 years. For 25 years he served as a consultant to the Episcopal Church Pension Fund. His extensive lay leadership in the Episcopal Church included service as a senior warden of three parishes, St. Andrew's Church, Wellesley, MA, All Saints' Church and St. Bartholomew's Church, Manhattan. He served as a member of the national standing liturgical commission during the revision of the Book of Common Prayer. In 1996, he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters by the Berkeley Divinity School at Yale. He is survived by Mary, his wife of 66 years, and his son James D. Dunning, Jr. of New York, and his grandsons James D. Dunning III and David F. Dunning. Vigil and visitation Sunday, November 12, 4-6:30PM, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street. Funeral service at St. Bartholomew's, Monday, November 13, 5 PM. Memorial donations to St. Bartholomew's Church, New York, or Berkeley Divinity School at Yale, New Haven.

title: Newspaper Editorials Warn About Partisan Battle Over Vote
description: As the nation's political and electoral systems flailed their way through unknown territory, editorials in most of the nation's major newspapers yesterday urged the rival campaigns to tone down their rhetoric, sometimes asking directly whether the candidate they favored cared more about his own victory than the national good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, PHYLLIS (NEE LIFTON)
description: WEINER-Phyllis (nee Lifton). On November 3, 2000, while traveling in China with her devoted husband of 39 years, Howard. She will be remembered and missed by her children, Jeffrey, Cynthia, Michael and Jeanne Gerstley Weiner, for her spirit, humor, and warmth. She is the cherished sister of Martin and Ellie Lifton of Old Westbury, N.Y., & Dr. & Mrs. Robert Weiner of Denver, CO. She is the beloved grandmother of Zach, Jake, Emmy and Allie. She will be sadly missed by her many nieces, nephews, cousins and close friends, whom she adored. The family will receive visitors Saturday, November 11, from 7-9PM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St. A funeral service will be held Sunday, November 12, at 11:45AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to Smith College, Northampton, MA. 01063, The New York Philharmonic, Avery Fisher Hall, 10 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023, or Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77 Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: Which Way Out of Our National Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: CISCO SYSTEMS MAKES DEAL TO BUY ACTIVE VOICE
description: Cisco Systems Inc., agreed to buy the Active Voice Corporation, a maker of call-processing systems, for about $296 million in stock, the companies said. Cisco Systems will retain Active Voice's business that delivers electronic mail, voice and fax messages to a single Internet mailbox, and resell its voice-mail unit to former Active Voice employees for $30 million. Cisco Systems said it expected the transaction, to be completed in January, to result in a charge of as much as 2 cents a share for research and development in progress.

title: How to Make the President Talk to the Local Pol
description: With Al Gore leading in the popular vote, but the presidential election still up in the air, many constitutional scholars have called for abolishing the Electoral College.

title: Giants Have Defensive Test in Store
description: The Giants knew they had a slim chance to defeat the Rams when they met in St. Louis last December. They had been reasonably pleased, in fact, that midway through the third quarter the Rams led by only a touchdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERIDAN, ROBERT A.
description: SHERIDAN-Robert A. Founder, Windham Mountain Ski Area, Windham Mountain Club, on November 9th. Survived by his wife Hope, son Bob, and daughters, Mimi and Margot. Visiting Follett Funeral Home, Sunday, November 12, 2-4, 7-9pm, WHB. Funeral Mass Monday, 10AM, Immaculate Conception Church. Luncheon immediately following, Westhampton Country Club. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Rose's Home for Incurable Cancer, NYC.

title: Uncomfortable Truths in Indonesia
description: Indonesian officials are angry with the American ambassador, Robert Gelbard, for his outspoken criticism of economic corruption and military abuses of human rights in Indonesia. Mr. Gelbard, a State Department veteran, has a reputation for bluntness but has also been an effective diplomat. His advice to Indonesia's fledgling democratic government is appropriate and should be heeded.

title: Martin and Nets Pay a Price For Their Sluggish Effort
description: Nets Coach Byron Scott does not accept excuses from his players, and today he put them through a series of exhausting sprints. Scott was unhappy with their performance during Thursday's 108-94 loss to Detroit, particularly Kenyon Martin's.

title: Seeking Remembrance for Wartime Service; Women Who Filled Stateside Nursing Gap in the 40's Want Veteran Status
description: Strong hands closed around Marjorie Patak's neck, choking off her screams until a male nurse wrestled away the psychiatric patient at Bellevue Hospital. It was a harrowing welcome for a young cadet nurse who had pledged to serve her country in 1944.

title: Which Way Out of Our National Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Surgery for Baxter; Progress for Becht
description: Tight end Fred Baxter had surgery today in which a pin was inserted into his left hand, and he will miss the Jets' game Sunday in Indianapolis against the Colts. Baxter, who broke a bone in his hand during practice this week, is expected to be out for at least one more game. The broken bone was discovered during a CT scan after practice Thursday.

title: Abroad at Home; Where Do We Go?
description: First we have to clear our heads of the notion that the noble precedent of Richard Nixon's 1960 decision not to challenge the vote count in Cook County, Ill., should lead Al Gore to give up now. Pundits of all sorts have been floating that proposition, but it makes a hash of history.

title: Which Way Out of Our National Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the writer and editor Rosalind Baker Wilson on Thursday misstated her relationship to two survivors. Reuel Wilson of London, Ontario, was her half brother and Helen Miranda Wilson of Wellfleet, Mass., her half sister -- not stepbrother and stepsister.

title: Europe Said to Be Set to Seek Sanctions on U.S.
description: The European Union is set to ask the World Trade Organization to apply sanctions against the United States in retaliation for what the union says is an unfair tax break for United States exporters, a European Commission trade spokesman said today.

title: In Austin, the Jockeying, Along With the Partying, Is on Hold
description: Win or lose, Sally Canfield expected to be in Italy right now.

title: James Dunning, 89; Central in Church Fight
description: James Dorr Dunning, an insurance executive who was senior warden of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan during a rancorous dispute over high-rise development on its land, died on Tuesday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 89.

title: American Voices: Divided on Nov. 7, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Eventually, somebody is going to be a hero, and somebody's going to be president. Not necessarily the same person.''

title: Power and Poise Put Ford on Top
description: THREE years ago, when I had a chance to directly compare small sport utilities, they were easy to rank: Subaru Forester first, Honda CR-V second and Toyota RAV4 third. There are more players now, and they are better -- but harder to choose among.

title: Searching for a Respite
description: Beleaguered citizens trapped in the war zone of an endless presidential election may find it hard to believe, but come Jan. 20 either George W. Bush or Al Gore will take office. We thought it might be useful to leap ahead and take a look at what awaits a new president and Congress. Any speculation must start with the reality that two candidates with very different personalities and visions produced an evenly divided electorate. Similarly, Democratic and Republican legislative candidates offering very different approaches to domestic issues led to a House and Senate with only a slight edge for the G.O.P. One question that hovers over all this is what kind of Washington the public really wants. Another is whether all this conflict and division will set the stage for ceaseless partisan conflict or inspire a new search from moderates on both sides for a bipartisan balance point.

title: Dr. Gerard Chrzanowski, Innovative Psychoanalyst, Dies at 87
description: Dr. Gerard Chrzanowski, a psychoanalyst who colleagues say was the model for the caring psychiatrist in the best-selling 1946 novel ''The Snake Pit'' and the famous 1948 film based on it, died Nov. 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Learning How to Learn
description: As they begin their first year of college, many students do not know how to study -- in no small part because they have not been challenged in secondary school, where their transcripts are embellished by grade point inflation.

title: Randi Dorman, Michael Raizner
description: Randi Elise Dorman, a daughter of Barbara J. Dorman and Dr. Robert I. Dorman of West Nyack, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Evan Raizner, a son of Andrea G. Raizner and Dr. Albert E. Raizner of Houston. Rabbi Roy A. Walter officiated at the Omni Hotel in Houston.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Ex-Judge's New Life Still Tainted by Past

title: American Voices: Divided on Nov. 7, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, SEYMOUR
description: WEINSTEIN-Seymour. On November 10th at 81. Retired Major. Beloved husband of Molly. Loving father of Gloria and Lewis. Brother of Norman. Cherished grandfather of Adria, Nicole, Myasha, Marc and Jacob. Services will be today, 1 PM, at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris.

title: A Retirement Plan That Wall Street Likes
description: JUST as companies made the shift away from the fixed monthly pension to the more mercurial 401(k) plan, some politicians want to move Social Security in the same direction. During his campaign, George W. Bush offered just such a proposal, becoming the first presidential candidate to suggest so radical an alteration of the national pension system. If he takes office as president, he will surely ask Congress to act. But transforming Social Security into individual retirement accounts would condemn some older people -- perhaps tens of millions -- to smaller pensions.

title: The Election; Now What? This Time, Cries For 'Blood' Seem Unthinkable
description: UNTIL last week, when people said presidential campaigns lasted too long, they meant before Election Day. So how can the longest campaign be brought to an end?

title: The Pictures; The Home Movie
description: The idea for ''The Anniversary Party'' was born, as many great ideas are, over a kitchen table in Los Angeles. Alan Cumming, having finished his Broadway run in ''Cabaret,'' was staying with his friend Jennifer Jason Leigh when it occurred to them that it would be an awful lot of fun to make a movie with their friends. So they wrote a script, tailoring the characters to 13 actors they know (including, conveniently, themselves, Gwyneth Paltrow, Kevin Kline, John C. Reilly, Jennifer Beals, Jane Adams and Phoebe Cates), and shot it in digital video over 19 days. ''Imagine writing a movie for all your friends and then having them around for a month,'' Leigh says. ''Selfishly, it was just the grandest, greatest time.''

title: Elizabeth Swingle, Joseph Hobelmann
description: Elizabeth Bennett Swingle, a daughter of Anne and Richard Swingle of Baltimore, was married there yesterday at the Church of the Redeemer to Joseph Gregory Hobelmann, a son of JoAnne Hobelmann and Dr. Charles Hobelmann Jr., also of Baltimore. The Rev. James C. Blackburn, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in which the Rev. John Dennis, a Roman Catholic priest, took part.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: SECRETS OF THE FLESH: A Life of Colette, by Judith Thurman. (Ballantine, $18.95.) The prolific French writer is portrayed as a shrewd, imaginative woman who spent her long, eventful life in open defiance of convention and social morality as she created multiple careers for herself and carried on prodigiously with members of both sexes. In 1999 our reviewer, Mavis Gallant, called this ''a fine and intelligent biography,'' and it was chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of the year. In The Pure and the Impure (New York Review, $12.95), which has been reissued with an introduction by Thurman, Colette recounts the passions and affairs of friends, acquaintances and other worshipers of Eros. ''Some of the generalizations Colette is tempted to draw'' from her encounters ''are provocative in the highest degree,'' Margaret Wallace wrote here in 1933.

title: Art on the Road, and Closer to Home
description: THE two exhibitions currently at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven complement each other in an interesting way. One from the Victorian era is about voyaging out, while a contemporary show stays close to home, the center's spiritual home, London. Oddly, the first show seems very modern at times while the second extols traditional ideas.

title: Can Black Gold Ever Flow Green?
description: AS ridged as crocodile skin, the marshy coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge stretches 110 miles from the Canning River in the west to Alaska's border with Canada in the east. Over a few weeks in the early Arctic autumn, the mottled green length of the plain deepens to the color of coffee grounds and rust, a dark vein between the slate Beaufort Sea and the frayed northern edge of the Brooks mountain range.

title: The Pictures; The Food
description: During a painful incarnation as a screenwriter, I once found myself seated in first class right behind Michael Jackson at the height of his reign, and right next to his chef, who told me that she nearly always flew with him. Flying first class is one of the great joys -- some say the only joy -- of writing for the screen. On this particular trip, however, the chef regaled me for 2,800 miles across the country with descriptions of her recipes for the Gloved One -- leaves and acorns, foreign radishes and space sauces, granola fasts and all-grape regimens -- none of which would I have then considered putting in my mouth either singly or in combination. At the time, I thought, Oh, great, another L.A. freak and her freakish L.A. food.

title: Corrections
description: The Bending Elbows column in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about Jimmy's Corner, a bar on West 44th Street, referred incorrectly to ''Under the Boardwalk,'' a song sung by a patron. It was a hit for the Drifters, not Otis Redding.

title: St. John's Jarvis Remains Upbeat
description: Mike Jarvis wore a mischievous smile on Friday as midnight approached. Jarvis, the St. John's coach, appeared to have some inside information he had yet to share with his players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COXEN, FRED H.
description: COXEN-Fred H. On November 8, 2000 at Saint Vincent's Hospital. Retired from Exhibition Productions at the Museum of Modern Art. Alumnus of Cranbrook Academy of Art. Korean War Veteran. Born in Topeka, Kansas, he is survived by sister Norma Risley of Kansas, a brother Francis Coxen of Oregon and many nieces and nephews.

title: Expect the Unexpected Early in the Season
description: As Vin Baker left the court during Seattle's game against Orlando last Monday night, SuperSonics Coach Paul Westphal went to grab his frustrated power forward. Baker slapped Westphal's hand away and the two exchanged words.

title: Merrill Spiegel, Charles Konigsberg
description: Merrill Sue Spiegel, a daughter of Lila Spiegel and Dr. Allen Spiegel of Sayreville, N.Y., is to be married today to Charles Steven Konigsberg, a son of Elsa and Irving Konigsberg of Lyndhurst, Ohio. Rabbi Fred Dobb will officiate at the Willard Hotel in Washington.

title: November 5-11; Luck, Be an Airplane
description: In the last year, as regional jet service has expanded, La Guardia Airport has experienced what many fear could be the future of air travel in the country -- jets stuck on runways for hours, others circling endlessly, connections missed and other airports' schedules ruined. The Federal Aviation Administration says it will begin a lottery to assign take-off and landing spots, to buy time until it can find a more fundamental way to relieve gridlock at overcrowded airports, like making airlines pay more for rush-hour spots. Randy Kennedy

title: Rapper Is Reborn to Sounds of the Spirit
description: HE answered the door of his new home dressed in the requisite rapper outfit of loose Phat Farm blue jeans, a blue jeans jacket and a white T-shirt billowing on his chunky frame. But his greeting, ''Hi, I'm Reverend Run,'' said more about the man also known as Run from Run-D.M.C. and Joseph Simmons of Queens.

title: Using the Right Breathing Protection
description: MANY building or remodeling projects and household maintenance chores release dust, harmful vapors and mists that can contaminate the air. Breathing this air can introduce dangerous substances into the lungs. Once there, they are carried to other parts of the body through the bloodstream.

title: Inquiry Begins Into TV Predictions
description: Every presidential election year seems to bring forth angry complaints about television projections of winners before the polls close, particularly polls in the Mountain West and West Coast. The concern is that such predictions depress turnout and could affect not only the outcome of the presidential contest but also other races on the ballot. Any number of seminars and conferences have been held over the years on the issue, with news executives, political scientists and state and federal election officials thoroughly exploring the accuracy of projections and the competitive pressures to release them.

title: Limited Alternatives For Grocery Shoppers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, HARRY C.
description: LEVIN-Harry C. Died of cancer on November 8, 2000 at age 91. Retired journalist and corporate public relations executive. Beloved husband of Felice and father of Peter, of Manhattan; brother of Golda Solomon of Cleveland. Past Commodore, Overseas Yacht Club, member, Society of the Silurians, Overseas Press Club. Involved Hunter College student. A remarkable intellect and spirit. Services & interment in Cleveland.

title: Disrupter of Families? A Book Questions Homework
description: SHOULD violin lessons, soccer practice, Hebrew school or perhaps chores take priority over homework? How about giving kids more time to develop hobbies for, say, collecting Digimon cards or Barbie outfits?

title: Mama's Girl
description: To the Editor:

title: Famous Faces, All in Wax
description: THE elevator opens onto a dazzling, celebrity-filled New York party. Wolfgang Puck pours Champagne. Liz Smith gossips with Larry King. The mayor and the governor stand around looking affable. Woody Allen, seated alone in a corner, looks wistful; Barbra Streisand, sitting alone on the edge of a fountain, is winsome. In the midst of a fashionable crowd, the designer Jean-Paul Gaultier stands out with bleached hair, five earrings (four in one ear) and a sequined plaid skirt. Movie stars and media figures and tycoons are everywhere you look, but no one is signing autographs, and there is no cocktail-party chatter. And no wonder -- except for guards and tourists, everyone is wax.

title: Jennifer Keates, Carlos Baleeiro
description: Dr. Jennifer Ann Keates, the daughter of Martha and H. Paxson Keates of Ventnor City, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Carlos Eduardo Oliveira Baleeiro, the son of Ana Lucia Lages de Oliveira Baleeiro and Dr. Carlos Oliveira Baleeiro of Salvador, Brazil. The Rev. Park McD. Bodie, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Church in New York.

title: Full Plates And Empty Bottles
description: NEW JERSEY might be the butt of many jokes, but it is the envy of the wine world. While our neighbors in New York and other states have to beg or bribe restaurants to allow them to bring in their own wine, we pick and choose from a plethora of B.Y.O.B. restaurants. And to tweak our neighbors' wine noses a bit more, some of our B.Y.O.B. restaurants are among the most highly rated in the state.

title: As a Patriotic Parade Passes by, Buzz Over a Recount
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 11  To the music of a slightly off-key high school band, a current of old-fashioned patriotism ran through downtown West Palm Beach today in a small Veterans Day parade.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-12-00: Gallery; Big in Japan
description: These stars would never deign to pitch everyday products to American consumers. Japanese consumers, however, are another matter.

description: First and Last Seasons

title: Celluloid Dreams In Hong Kong
description: I STOOD in a Hong Kong police station with my heart pounding. Yes, I was guilty -- guilty of being thrilled. I tried to hide it because I felt bad for my friend Leslie, an American violinist with the Hong Kong Philharmonic, whose wallet had just been stolen.

title: Who Voted: A Portrait of American Politics, 1976-2000
description: Amajority of women, older voters, Democrats, liberals and black, Hispanic and Asian voters cast their ballots for Al Gore. George W. Bush captured the votes of most men, whites, conservatives, Republicans, Southerners and white Protestants. Ralph Nader, who received 2 percent of the vote, did best among independents, particularly liberal ones, and among young men.

description: FOR nearly two decades, the Whitney Museum of American Art, Fairfield County, has been in the business of openings. Now the Stamford branch of the New York museum is in jeopardy of closing its doors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATZER, DAVID
description: PLATZER-David. Beloved husband of Frances. Adored father of Steven and Nancy Platzer, Robin Platzer Judson and Robert Judson. Proud grandfather of David Lawrence Platzer, Adam Platzer and Melanie Rose Judson. Services will be held on Sunday, November 12 at 10 AM at the ''Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Family will be receiving at ''Riverside'' on Saturday night from 7-9 PM. Contributions may be made in his memory to N.Y.U. Medical Center, Palliative Care Program, C/O James C. Wernz, M.D., 160 E. 32 St., NY, NY 10016.

title: Less Austerity, More Diversity at PREP SCHOOL Today
description: Fifty years after Holden Caulfield despaired of life at Pencey, prep schools are far less forbidding. They welcome a variety of students, from Park Avenue to the inner city. And with e-mail contact, friends and family are not so far away.

title: Calling All History Buffs: Identify the Vice Presidents
description: Some vice presidents served their terms and faded into the mists of history, but others became presidents or held other positions of national importance. Even so, most classes in American history pay relatively scant attention to those who held the nation's second highest office. Try testing your knowledge of those who have been only a heartbeat away from the presidency.

title: The Pictures; The Battle
description: For writers and directors in Hollywood, no event in human history has provided a deeper, wider vein of material than World War II. In fact, Hollywood got involved in the war almost as soon as the United States military did. Humphrey Bogart appeared in three World War II films during 1942 alone: ''Across the Pacific,'' ''All Through the Night'' and, of course, ''Casablanca.'' This was the beginning of a long roll call of films that now, more than a half-century later, continues to keep pace.

title: 'Little Victories' at Belmont Playhouse
description: IT was just casual intermission talk, awaking wistful memories of Saturday-night dates when a fellow took a girl to a real live play.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 29 about a trip to southern Morocco referred incorrectly to the nation's imperial cities. There are four, not three -- Fez, Marrakesh, Meknes and Rabat. Tangier is not among them.

title: Only the Best for Man's Best Friend. And Woman's Too.
description: WHEN the Wozar family of Whitestone leaves town, they rarely bring 9-year-old Sherlock along. Instead, they rent a hotel room for him and his two siblings, with color cable television, air-conditioning, a telephone, room service and round-the-clock supervision.

title: Christopher Comments On Recount In Florida
description: Following is a transcript of remarks yesterday in Washington by former Secretary of State Warren Christopher, an adviser to Vice President Al Gore, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: 2 Major Projects for a Once-Seedy Chicago Area
description: Two multibuilding projects that each include apartments, commercial space and hotels are rising on the once-seedy commercial area where Chicago was born, consolidating the Streeterville neighborhood's position both as a premier residential area and the heart of the city's burgeoning tourist industry.

title: Ireland's New Troubles
description: ALICE FALLING

title: Signs and Lamentations Have an Effect on Errant Trucks
description: Broome Street residents may finally be getting a good night's sleep.

title: Where the Curtain Goes Up on Paintings and Sculpture
description: WHEN East Hampton's Guild Hall was opened in 1931, its stated purpose was ''to promote and encourage a finer type of citizenship'' by cultivating a taste for the arts. Those words are chiseled over the doors that lead to the 385-seat John Drew Theater and the Moran, Woodhouse, Spiga and Leidy Galleries that flank it. From its inception, then, Guild Hall has been devoted to both visual and performing arts, a combination that coexists in only four other Long Island institutions.

title: John S. Morrison, Scholar, 87; Rebuilt a Lost Greek Warship
description: Prof. John S. Morrison, a scholar whose boyhood vision of ancient Greek boats known as triremes inspired a modern re-creation of that juggernaut, died on Oct. 25 in London. He was 87.

title: Hitchcock Meets Dali, Rodin and Munch
description: Alfred Hitchcock's name is synonymous with cinema and suspense. But the man behind ''Psycho'' and ''The Birds'' was also an art lover and collector who infused his films with symbolism and surrealist imagery.

title: Pit Bulls Are Really Nice Pooches, An A.S.P.C.A. Conference Asserts
description: ''I told you to get that dog out of here!'' yelled one woman to another. ''You really stink, and so does your dog!''

title: The Sounds of Creativity: Artists' Studios Are Not So Still
description: THEIR art is visual, but that doesn't mean their ears are uninvolved.

title: Lois Mazer, Martin Zelman
description: Lois Mae Mazer and Martin Zelman were married on Thursday by Rabbi Mordechai Waxman at Bouterin, a restaurant in New York.

title: Angry Young Man
description: MAINLY ABOUT

title: Bookend; Book Party
description: Sebastian Schmidt and Raphael Sagalyn do essentially the same thing: sell books. Schmidt is a sculptor. His weightiest tome, at 265 pounds, is of greenish marble; the lightest, weighing about a pound, of ruddy sandstone. Sagalyn is an American agent who sells foreign rights to the books he represents. Both were doing what they do every year at the Frankfurt Book Fair, the international publishing world's weeklong marathon of deals, near deals and partying. Schmidt stood under a tent selling hefty volumes carved into sandstone, granite and travertine. Sagalyn was looking cramped at Table 257 in a riotously noisy hall with hundreds of other agents and editors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORACI, JESS
description: SORACI-Jess, surrounded by love, passed away on November 1, All Saints Day.

title: Affairs of State
description: The Years

title: November 5-11; Hoping for Peace
description: President Clinton met with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, at the White House, the first time the two had met in Washington since the Camp David summit in July. The circumstances were far less optimistic -- Israel had just assassinated a Palestinian militia leader. Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, is scheduled to see Mr. Clinton today. Jane Perlez

title: November 5-11; Marry at Will
description: Alabama voters quietly removed one piece of arcana from their Jim Crow-era constitution: a 1901 state law banning marriage between a Negro and Caucasian. The Supreme Court struck down such laws in 1967, but until last week, when voters passed a ballot initiative to purge that law from the books, it held on as the last such state law in the nation. The margin by which the measure passed was itself a statement. A clear majority, 60 percent, voted to remove the miscegenation statute from the state constitution, but 40 percent of Alabamans -- nearly 526,000 people -- voted to keep it. Somini Sengupta

title: Hesitantly, Students in South Africa Reach Across the Racial Divide
description: While the sun sleeps and the white world slumbers, thousands of black students squeeze into the ramshackle jitneys that wheeze and rattle on the long journey across the color line.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; 165 Rm Ocean Vu
description: In ''Citizen Kane,'' San Simeon was caricatured as Xanadu, Victoria Kastner writes, ''a forbidding, deserted pile, filled with meaningless junk.'' But it was a house (actually four buildings with 165 rooms, two swimming pools on 250,000 acres of land 1,600 feet above sea level) enlivened by William Randolph Hearst's love of the place and by the many colorful guests (not to mention objects) that he and his mistress, Marion Davies, imported to their remote outpost. Construction of San Simeon, now a historical monument run by the California State Parks system, took 28 years (1919-47); the house evolved from Hearst's initial vision of a one-story bungalow into one of the largest private residences in the United States, the repository of Hearst's vast collections of art and furniture. HEARST CASTLE: The Biography of a Country House (Abrams, $49.50) offers a lively narrative documenting the unusually collaborative relationship between Hearst and Julia Morgan, the ''first woman architect of prominence in America,'' according to Kastner, a member of the San Simeon staff. She makes the case that San Simeon, or ''La Cuesta Encantada'' (''The Enchanted Hill,'' as Hearst named it in 1924), was not a ''West Coast anomaly'' but rather a ''representative example of the American country-house tradition.'' The architectural plans, drawings and contemporary photographs that document both the growth of the house and life with Hearst and Davies are accompanied by unusually informative captions that offer an entertaining supplement to the main text. Bill Goldstein

title: Zimbabwe's Troubles Include Drop in Tourism
description: THE ceiling fans still revolve slowly at the elegant Victoria Falls Hotel, and courtly waiters in tuxedos still serve tea and scones on sunny afternoons. But here, on a shady terrace overlooking the roaring Zambezi River, more than half the tables are empty.

title: The Timetable of Age Overtakes Stations
description: SIXTY-THREE years after the last trains slowed for their platforms, after the last late commuters hurried through their handsome doorways, under their elegant roofs and colorful tiled archways, a few abandoned stations of the long-defunct Harlem branch of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad still cling to life in the Bronx. But they endure in a condition that barely hints at their original architectural beauty.

title: Praise Them
description: Nov. 6: The New-York Historical Society held an opening reception for its exhibition ''Elder Grace: The Nobility of Aging,'' 70 photographs by the New York Times photographer Chester Higgins Jr. Many of the subjects stood in front of their portraits, autographing their photographs in a book of the same title, published this year by Bullfinch Press. It includes all the portraits in the show and has a foreword by Maya Angelou.

title: Ideas & Trends: Web War; When Point and Shoot Becomes Point and Click
description: THE online world has entered a new phase. At first it was a combination playground, library and meeting house for scientists and soldiers, an inviolate virtual world. Companies later tried to turn it into a mall. Now, it's becoming a borderless battlefield.

title: Return of the Natives: Playing God in the Fields; Planting the Past Anew in New York City
description: The mugwort sounds like a villain from a Harry Potter novel, or the name of some plug-ugly in a bad 1930's prison movie. It's not a pretty plant, nor, by plant standards, is it very nice. To reproduce, it's quite capable of giving less aggressive flora an elbow in the eye and a shove toward extinction. The mugwort's a survivor.

title: Canoeists Find That Raw Sewage Puts Them Up the Creek With Dirty Paddles
description: Main Creek dissects tufted meadows and darkly forested wetlands as it the winds through the William T. Davis Wildlife Refuge on the west shore of Staten Island.

title: The Lure of Experience, Real and Virtual
description: To the Editor:

title: Lewis Toys With Tua And Wins In Decision
description: As if holding a clinic in how to use a left jab, Lennox Lewis retained his World Boxing Council and International Boxing Federation heavyweight titles tonight with a unanimous 12-round decision over David Tua, the Samoan challenger who is now based in New Zealand.

title: In Senator Clinton's Hometown, Many Are Asking, What Now?
description: IT was the morning after Election Day and my children were moving more slowly than usual, still bleary-eyed from staying up too late watching the results.

title: National Psyche Hates A Game No One Wins
description: Americans do not like ties. Virtually none of the sports that dominate national life allow them. If it takes overtime, a penalty kick, a sudden death playoff or extra innings, everyone expects a winner and everyone knows that the Mets and the Yankees cannot both be World Series champs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FABIAN, DR. DOROTHY
description: FABIAN-Dr. Dorothy. The NYUHospital for Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery mourn the passing of Dr. Dorothy Fabian, dear wife of Dr. Tibor Fabian, who served as our distinguished Honorary President and Chairman of the Board. Dr. Dorothy Fabian's commitment to the hospital through her undaunting efforts toward enhancing patient care innovative programs will long be remembered. With great foresight, together with her devoted husband, Tibor, they established the Drs. Dorothy and Tibor Fabian Award in 1983. This award, presented annually to an academic member of the hospital for the most outstanding and innovative research publication, continues to stimulate the excellent research work accomplished at HJD. Dr. Fabian's encouragement and philanthropic support will live on in perpetuity through the advancement of our major initiatives. She will be sadly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her sons Timothy and Jonathan and to the entire family. Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D. Chairman Victor H. Frankel, M.D. President Emeritus

title: FOR YOUNG VIEWERS
description: Clare Thomas, left, Jack Blumenau and Jemina Rooper portray three children who adopt a tiny trunk railway after their family is cast into dire straits by the mysterious disappearence of their father on ''The Railway Children,'' a ''Masterpiece Theater'' presentation of E. Nesbit's Novel, tonight at 9 on Channel 13.

title: The Arch in Brewster Blooms in Autumn
description: WHEN last at the Arch, we were convinced that summer is its high season: the patio for an aperitif and then the solarium for dinner showed off the gardens -- and we love the incongruity of a formal meal in a georgic setting. But autumnal visits disclose this restaurant's other self, and we like it as well.

title: For UConn Women, Unending Effort
description: Geno Auriemma spent his first eight years living in Italy, which explains why he views basketball through the prism of soccer, yearning for the fluidity and improvisation of a game where the ball must be dribbled with the feet instead of the hands.

title: Modern Science Meets Ancient Mariner
description: FOR years, oceanographers studied Long Island Sound without knowing up-to-the-minute water conditions. To record the temperature or oxygen levels, or the ratio of salt water to fresh, they went out in a boat every few weeks and took readings.

title: FIRST PERSON; Voter's Block
description: ALL I wanted to do was vote.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 16 of the Long Island section today about liturgical artists misspells the given name of an associate pastor at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan, Conn. He is the Rev. Dariusz Zielonka, not Darius.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Playwright With a New Job Title: Auteur
description: EVEN after throwing his back out, the playwright-turned-film-director Kenneth Lonergan can come up with more snappy rejoinders than most people can on a good day. Sitting gingerly several weeks ago in the Greenwich Village apartment he shares with his wife, the actress J. Smith-Cameron, Mr. Lonergan brightened when asked why, after writing two successful off-Broadway plays and several Hollywood scripts (including the 1999 hit ''Analyze This''), he had decided to write and direct his own independent film, ''You Can Count on Me.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WITZLING, MORTON
description: WITZLING-Morton. A memorial service in celebration of Morton Witzling's life will be held on Friday, November 17, 2000, at Sol Goldman Y of the Educational Alliance, 344 East 14 St. (between 1st & 2nd Aves.), NYC, at 2:30 PM.

title: In Praise of a Different Market
description: Abby Joseph Cohen, the Goldman Sachs strategist, rose last Monday night to praise the wiser fiscal policies, lowered inflation, increased openness to trade and better financial disclosure that have improved the business climate. But she was speaking of a Mediterranean climate, namely Israel's. The occasion was a fund-raising dinner in New York for Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, where a cousin of hers is a senior research scientist.

title: 50 Years Later, Remembering Korea and Its Veterans
description: Richard Coate arrived in Korea on his 25th birthday, in early February 1951, as a rifleman for the United States Army. Later he worked as the company clerk, in charge of tasks that still haunt him: identifying the bodies of soldiers who fought alongside him in the war, writing the casualty reports that tallied the wounded and the dead and sending out letters of condolence to the families of those killed in combat.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday exploring the reasons newspapers make political endorsements misstated the year that a Pulitzer Prize was awarded to Michael Gartner of The Daily Tribune in Ames, Iowa, for his editorial commentaries. It was 1997, not 1977.

description: BAILY-Ethel Nettie. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its affiliates mourn the passing of the beloved sister of their devoted member, Florence Chasin and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYEN, PAUL
description: MAYEN-Paul. Died on November 3, 2000. Noted Architect and Industrial designer, founder of Habitat, Intrex and Architectural Supplements, Inc. Designer of the Visitor's Center at Frank Lloyd Wright's Fallingwater. Many of his works are in the permanent collection at the Museum of Modern Art. A passionate gardener, he was as witty in his designs as he was in conversation, and as an art collector, he was both avid and adroit. At ease in all situations, social and intellectual, he was as widely loved for his humor and rousing spirit, as for his compasssion and humanity. No funeral is planned, but a celebration of his life will be held in his New York gardens in the spring. Contributions in Paul's memory may be made to Western Pennsylvania Conservancy for Fallingwater, Box R, Route 381 South, Mill Run, PA. 15464.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Paul Cavaco; Yes, 49 but Fabulous
description: PAUL CAVACO had hoped for a Hummer to take him to Harlem. He had to settle for a 40-foot stretch sport-utility. ''Isn't it beyond?'' he said to his friend the designer Anna Sui, who stopped by his Chelsea apartment for a lift uptown. ''It's totally beyond,'' she marveled. ''It's like the Hamptons Jitney.''

title: The World; Vietnam's Youth Stage A Gentler Revolution
description: CAREFREE, war-free, with multicolored sparkles in their hair, Vietnam's young people are leading a revolution in Vietnam today, and it's not a Communist one.

title: Homeowners' Revenge: Selling Power to the Utility
description: WHILE some of his neighbors are concerned about rising energy prices, Thomas Hood sits comfortably in his 1820 home in Westhampton on Long Island, watching his utility meter move backward even as colder weather sets in.

description: Maybe it says something about how things might go in the future. Maybe it doesn't.

title: Elizabeth Brickman, Jeffrey Greilsheimer
description: Elizabeth Anne Brickman, a daughter of Dr. Jane Pacht Brickman and John M. Brickman of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeffrey Mark Greilsheimer, the son of Carol L. Greilsheimer and William H. Greilsheimer of Manhattan. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson officiated at the Yale Club in Manhattan.

title: November 5-11; Over the Counter And Off the Shelf
description: Dozens of over-the-counter cold remedies and weight loss drugs were swept off pharmacy shelves after the Food and Drug Administration announced it would ban the products' active ingredient. The ingredient, phenylpropanolamine, or PPA, has been a staple in American medicine cabinets for decades, but was recently linked to a slight risk of stroke in young women. Manufacturers insisted it was safe, even as they withdrew their drugs, which include certain Alka-Seltzer, Dimetapp and Triaminic cold remedies, as well as Dexatrim and Acutrim, the appetite suppressants. Some will be reformulated; others may be gone for good. Sheryl Gay Stolberg

title: The Artistry of Getting Into Costume
description: PARTYING in costume is a way for artists to be creative and sociable at the same time.

title: Ideas & Trends: Vacancy; Stunning Estate, 130-plus Rms., 18 Acres, Rose Garden. Available.
description: THE nation crossed a new threshold last week: the permanent campaign became the endless election. The nightly tracking polls that showed a race too close to call turned into an election too close to call, and platoons of Democratic and Republican lawyers descended on Florida to continue the fight.

title: The Pictures; The Location
description: In ''Heaven,'' Cate Blanchett plays an English teacher living in Italy who plants a bomb in the office of a man who has completely destroyed her life. Giovanni Ribisi is the young policeman who understands her deed, falls in love with her and helps her escape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNING, JAMES DORR
description: DUNNING-James Dorr. On November 7, 2000, at his home in New York City, after a long illness. He was 89. Mr. Dunning was an executive of New York Life Insurance Company for 45 years. For 25 years he served as a consultant to the Episcopal Church Pension Fund. His extensive lay leadership in the Episcopal Church included service as a senior warden of three parishes, St. Andrew's Church, Wellesley, MA, All Saints' Church and St. Bartholomew's Church, Manhattan. He served as a member of the national standing liturgical commission during the revision of the Book of Common Prayer. In 1996, he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters by the Berkeley Divinity School at Yale. He is survived by Mary, his wife of 66 years, and his son James D. Dunning, Jr. of New York, and his grandsons James D. Dunning III and David F. Dunning. Vigil and visitation Sunday, November 12, 4-6:30PM, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street. Funeral service at St. Bartholomew's, Monday, November 13, 5 PM. Memorial donations to St. Bartholomew's Church, New York, or Berkeley Divinity School at Yale, New Haven.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KONIAK, DR. MICHAEL RICHARD
description: KONIAK-Dr. Michael Richard. 1/14/46-11/10/99. So greatly missed. He gave of himself to others. He will live forever in the hearts of his loving and devoted family.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; A Career Not According to Plan
description: MY niece is in the process of applying to colleges. She is interested in art and appears to have enough talent to apply to art school. The problem, however, is that she isn't entirely sure that she wants to pursue art professionally, perhaps meaning that such an academic choice would not be the wisest move.

title: It's All the Rage at Work, Too
description: First there was road rage, when stressed drivers lashed out at fellow motorists. Then came air rage, when irate passengers lost their cool at 30,000 feet. Now, perhaps as an unintended side effect of the booming economy, there is desk rage.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Shave, Haircut and the News From Home
description: FLATBUSH AVENUE, lined as it is with small shops and stores serving immigrants from all over the world, has long been a kind of metaphor for the polyglot pastiche of Brooklyn as a whole.

title: Ignoring Their Own
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pictures; The Face
description: The movies feed us all kinds of dreams and illusions, but the most democratic, and also the cruelest, may be the fantasy that those vivid projected shadows we see on the screen are people just like us. There are, of course, movie stars whose charisma amounts to a kind of distilled ordinariness -- the nice guy, the girl next door, Jimmy Stewart, Meg Ryan, Kevin Costner, Doris Day. But there is another, rarer breed whose beauty is almost too unearthly to be sexual, and who we could never in our wildest dreams hope to be.

title: A Reluctant Coach Bids Farewell, 24 Years Later
description: When the principal asked, all those years ago, if anyone knew anything about volleyball, the room full of teachers turned silent. The high school needed a girls' varsity volleyball coach, the principal explained.

title: In This Gilded Age, Gilded Model T's
description: AUTOMAKERS have long portrayed themselves as building cars for everyday American families. Henry Ford took pride in the spartan features of the Model T, available only in black. Alfred Sloan offered a ''ladder'' of models, from simple Chevrolets to elegant Cadillacs, with the slogan, ''a car for every purse and purpose.''

title: College in Canada; Tuition North of the Border Can Be a Steal
description: Though happily ensconced in California, when in earshot of my 17-year-old son, I invariably tout the advantages of college in Canada, generally with the jingoistic fervor that the sportscaster Don Cherry brings to ''Hockey Night in Canada.''

title: Wendy Kopp, Leader of Teach for America
description: Wendy Kopp has never taught. Hasn't had the time. Or maybe she doesn't know how.

title: A FIFTH YEAR FOR TRANSIT GRANTS
description: Local transit agencies will receive $628,000 in state grants to help pay for new buses and improvements to garages. It is the fifth year of the state Transit Dedicated Fund, which has made $54 million in state aid available to transit agencies. The county had hoped for more aid this year, said Wasi Talib, a spokeswoman for the County Executive's office. Elsa Brenner

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: OTHER TRADITIONS

title: Kelly Once Again Claims Regional
description: Keith Kelly, a Providence senior from Ireland, won the National Collegiate Athletic Association Northeast regional cross-country title yesterday for the third straight year at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. He covered the 6.4 miles in 30 minutes 33.2 seconds to lead Providence, with 27 points, to the team title.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRINSKY, GERTRUDE. (NEE COHEN)
description: KRINSKY-Gertrude. (nee Cohen) Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Eugene & Joel (Marsha). Also survived by cherished nephew Dr. Robert Crain (Harriet). Reposing Midwood Funeral Chapel, Coney Island Ave. (between L & M). Shiva at Eugene Krinsky Sunday-Tuesday.

title: Jana Weintraub, David Levin
description: Jana Suzanne Weintraub, the director of marketing and merchandising in New York for the Bertelsmann Music Group, and David Michael Levin, the director of Internet marketing for the company, were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Joshua Caruso officiated at the Puck Building.

title: Heal Thyself
description: To the Editor:

title: Nazi Ferocity
description: To the Editor:

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for MARTIN EAKES; An Advocate For the Poor And a Thorn For Citigroup
description: WHEN Citigroup, the nation's largest banker, announced in September its plans to acquire the Associates First Capital Corporation, consumer advocates were hopeful. The Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department are looking into allegations that Associates has used deceptive lending terms and high fees that strip away the equity in the homes of unsophisticated borrowers. But when Citigroup announced its proposed changes for Associates last week, community groups were distressed to see that the company planned to keep practices like lump-sum credit insurance and penalties for early repayment of loans.

title: Cole Inquiry Provokes Bitter U.S. Dispute
description: A month after the bombing of the destroyer Cole, a bitter dispute has erupted within the Clinton Administration over whether to accept Yemeni limits on the American investigation here or press for a wider ranging inquiry that F.B.I. officials believe could potentially lead to powerful people linked to the Yemeni government itself, American officials on both sides of the dispute say.

title: Hey, Look Me Over
description: Fashion is commerce. It's also about dressing each morning with a freedom of choice. And for a small group of men and women, dressing is the art of self-expression. For those shown here, dressing is all about wearing one's personality on the outside, as they combine different pieces. This year, authentic ethnic clothes are back in the spotlight as part of the mix of designer apparel and secondhand treasures, along with unexpected mixing of colors and patterns. Few have the guts to really let loose, but those here dress themselves every day as if they were works of art. The result is total individuality that often causes heads to turn and smile.

title: Pace University Offering Seminars on E-Business
description: A new series of breakfast seminars on e-business will be offered at Pace University's Graduate Center in White Plains on Thursday and Nov. 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARRA, ELEANOR
description: MARRA-Eleanor. The officers, sales associates and employees of The William B. May Company offer our deepest sympathy to our president and friend Peter R.Marra on the loss of his mother. We extend our sincere and heartfelt condolences to the entire Marra family. May her precious memory bring you comfort.

title: DOBBS FERRY: LONG-STANDING DISPUTE SETTLED
description: After more than a decade of opposing a Dobbs Ferry housing development on a former Indian gathering site, Friends of Wickers Creek Archaeological Site, a community group, said it had reached a settlement with the developer, Summit Landing, a real estate company owned by Louis Cappelli. Summit has agreed to make eight lots available for purchase and preservation as open space. The lots include areas believed to have been used by the Lenape people. Elsa Brenner

title: New Opportunities For Gay Students
description: Like many high school seniors, Galen Newton of Des Moines knew that paying for college this fall was going to be a challenge. But as it turned out, a significant portion of his tuition was paid by a scholarship awarded because of his sexual orientation and involvement in the gay and lesbian community.

title: Young Tennis Champ Prevails In Spite of a Sprained Ankle
description: SWEEPING her regular-season tennis matches without losing a game was not the most impressive thing Jenna Loeb did this fall.

title: Planting To Frustrate Peter Rabbit
description: LAST November, I planted over 350 bulbs, with dreams of spring glory. I made sure all had excellent drainage and some sun for their anticipated flowering. Alas, my floral extravaganza became a dining spread for my neighborhood's booming rabbit and squirrel population.

title: November 5-11; Russian Military Cuts
description: President Vladimir V. Putin took the knife to what he called Russia's ''extravagant'' military, approving a plan to cut 600,000 soldiers and bureaucrats from a military establishment that officially numbers three million -- and, unofficially, may number a couple million more. Outside analysts generally said Russia has little choice but to streamline its unwieldy force, spreading its limited budget over fewer troops. Michael Wines

title: Getting Personal About Yale's Drama School
description: THE stage is set for an unusual triple birthday party tomorrow night: the renowned Yale School of Drama is marking its 75th year, the Yale University Dramatic Association (the Dramat) its 100th, and Yale University its 300th anniversary. The bi-coastal celebration, ''Stage Blue,'' will be held in New York at the New Amsterdam Theater and at Chelsea Piers, and in Los Angeles at the Beverly Hilton Hotel.

title: Savoring the Best of the Island Anew
description: ALTHOUGH I recently retired as a reporter for The New York Times, I still can't resist checking the news wires on my desktop and glancing through the press releases that come in overnight on my fax. Somehow these old habits are comforting.

title: When Top-of-the-Line Is the Minimum
description: DOES it make a difference in selling an apartment for a million dollars and up -- and up and up -- if the faucets are made of sterling silver, if the kitchen has a special refrigerator solely for salad, if there is a screening room on the premises and a four star restaurant to deliver room service orders day or night?

title: When 'Just a Minute' Could Be Grounds for Dismissal
description: GO slow and steady, Aesop preached, and you will win the race.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Quandary in Terror Case: Can Counsel Be Witness?
description: The stabbing of a guard in the federal jail in Manhattan is having a ripple effect on the embassy-bombing terrorism trial scheduled to begin in January.

title: 718 Plus 347 Minus 1 Equals 6,711 Wrong Numbers
description: Frank Chironno has received almost 7,000 telephone calls since April. But he is hardly a popular guy. Most of the calls have been for someone else.

title: The Pictures; The Casting Call
description: On these pages are Polaroids taken between the mid-80's and mid-90's for Mali Finn, a casting agent who has worked on films like ''Titanic'' and ''L.A. Confidential.'' The actors and actresses sometimes were reading for specific roles -- Billy Bob Thornton, say, for the bug exterminator in ''Pacific Heights'' or Christina Ricci for Dana in ''True Lies.''

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Janis Mink, a New London gallery owner, misstated the name of her gallery at one point. As noted elsewhere in the article, it is the Burnished Chariot, not the Unburnished Chariot.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about the legacy of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan misidentified a former senator who was an expert on military affairs. He was Richard Russell, not Russell Long. The article also referred imprecisely to Mr. Moynihan's actions on the 1993 Clinton health-care bill. While chairman of the Finance Committee, he at first declined to hold hearings on the bill, but he held them in 1994.

title: Reckonings; Downhill From Here?
description: So the election is still in doubt. As of Friday evening Mr. Bush led in Florida by a margin smaller than the enrollment in my Econ 102 class; I'm no constitutional scholar, but I think we should suspend judgment until those absentee ballots have come in and some of the votes have been triple-checked.

title: Honor Killings
description: Two years ago in Jordan, a 17-year-old girl became pregnant after being raped by a family friend. Instead of reporting the rapist, the girl's father and brother shot her eight times and left her for dead. Like many other women in Jordan who are threatened by their families, she was sent to jail for her own protection after receiving medical care.

title: Kimberly Corrigan, Bryan Delancey
description: Kimberly Tara Corrigan, the daughter of Lori and Harold Corrigan of Palm Beach, Fla., was married there yesterday to Bryan Lawrence Delancey, a son of Kathleen and Lawrence Delancey of Escondido, Calif. The Rev. Thomas Twomey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Edward's Church.

title: Off the Beaten Piste
description: THERE is, I'm sure, a precise meteorological explanation for what goes on atop Wolf Creek Pass, in the San Juan Mountains of southwestern Colorado. But I will put it in skiers' terms: it dumps. It dumps deep, it dumps light, and it dumps often. This is much to the benefit of the little ski area that straddles the summit of the pass, a place called Wolf Creek. Wolf Creek receives an average of 38 feet of snow each winter, not a flake of it artificial. This is more snow than any other ski hill in Colorado, 32 percent more than Vail, and 52 percent more than Aspen and Breckenridge.

title: American Voices: Divided on Nov. 7, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dinner To Honor Authors
description: THE featured speaker at the Westchester Library System's millennium celebration of Westchester authors on Thursday will be Joyce Carol Oates, the Roger S. Berlind Distinguished Professor of the Humanities at Princeton University.

title: The Pictures; The Inspiration
description: Sam Shepard and I go back quite a long time. In fact, to 1978, when I was casting ''Hammett.'' I was looking for an actor to play the title part, a semifictional version of the American writer Dashiell Hammett, and I found the perfect fit in Sam. Not only was Sam tall and slender with a face remarkably like that of the legendary novelist, he was also a great writer himself. And he had just proven that he could act, in Terrence Malick's ''Days of Heaven.'' Plus: he could actually type. I had seen a lot of other actors struggle hopelessly with the typewriter, and this turned out to be an important asset, in my book.

title: Now on Campus: Untethered Internet Access
description: The next must-have technology for colleges that want to be at the forefront of information dispersal is wireless Internet access on campus, according to John Meerts, director of information technology services at Wesleyan University, Middletown, Conn.

title: The New New Woman
description: FLUX

title: Worth a Detour In the Bronx
description: AMICI'S RESTAURANT

title: WHITE PLAINS: CITY SUES OVER TOWN CENTER
description: White Plains is suing Ian Behar and his company, I.W.L. Associates, for $150 million, blaming the Long Island retail clothing merchant who had planned to move to the city for the unraveling of a $125 million White Plains Town Center movie and retail project. The suit claims that Mr. Behar's filing of a lawsuit had halted progress on the project, which was touted as the linchpin to the revitalization of the downtown area. Mr. Behar and I.W.L. sued the Common Council, arguing that its support for razing a public garage to make way for the Town Center would hurt the proposed men's clothing store. Elsa Brenner

title: Carol Wheeler, Josef Weissberg
description: Carol Einhorn Wheeler and Dr. Josef Herbert Weissberg are to be married today in their Manhattan apartment by Michael B. Mukasey, chief judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: Two $10,000 Questions For Small Businesses
description: One could argue that the Willard & Shullman Group, a marketing research organization in Greenwich, Conn., was toying with small-business owners in its annual survey.

title: Creating Dramas for the Concert Stage
description: AN expectant audience has come to the concert hall to hear a new work by a major composer. The stage is set for a large chorus and symphony orchestra to perform. But only about half the performers are in place when the conductor arrives, and he is evidently in distress. He looks as if he is about to say something to the audience, offer some word of explanation. He gapes. No words will come. All he can do is motion to his scattered musicians to draw nearer, and begin.

title: Bitten by, and Enjoying, the Gardening Bug
description: THE gardening bug is an insidious disease. Once stricken, some victims feel a compulsion to spend all their free time digging in the dirt and all their money buying plants and seeds. Others go even further and transform their working lives by entering the horticultural field.

title: Whistler
description: Over the last decade, Whistler has joined St. Moritz, Aspen and Chamonix among ski resorts whose names evoke much more than going up and down a mountain in winter.

title: Anand Shows His Finesse With an Old French Line
description: The International Chess Federation World Cup Tournament in Shengyang, China, Sept. 1-13, made its debut with a rococo format.

title: Bush and Cheney Join 7 Voters as Plaintiffs
description: The plaintiffs are seven Florida voters and ''Gov. George W. Bush and Dick Cheney, as candidates for president and vice president of the United States of America.'' The defendants are 11 Florida elections officials. The suit seeks to block the officials from recounting presidential ballots in Florida by hand.

title: Corrections
description: A brief review of ''The Starr Report Disrobed'' on Oct. 22 misspelled the author's first name. She is Fedwa Malti-Douglas, not Fetwa.

title: Loan-Fund Yields Come With Risks
description: MUTUAL funds that invest in bank loans to corporations have been marketed as higher-yielding alternatives to money market funds, with average returns of 5.9 percent over the last three years.

title: The Election; Drafting the Perfect Ballot
description: IN the confusion over election results, one sure thing is the poor design of the Palm Beach County ballot. But what would a well-designed ballot look like?

title: Mets Don't Lose Sight Of Their Free Agents
description: While they were able to focus financially on Alex Rodriguez for the first time yesterday, the Mets have not lost sight of their own free agents whom they want to sign.

title: November 5-11; Chinese History Gets Longer
description: Behind China's proud claim to be the oldest continuous civilization, stretching some 5,000 years, has been an embarrassing fact: no reliable chronology of kings went back earlier than 841 B.C. Five years ago, Beijing decided to marshal more than 200 archaeologists, historians and others to rectify the problem. Researchers now say they have proved the existence of a fabled dynasty that began around 2070 B.C. But the report was attacked by some Chinese and foreign scholars, who charge that science was tainted by nationalism. Erik Eckholm

title: Changing Fields (and Lawns and Gardens)
description: THE gardening bug is an insidious disease. Once stricken, some victims feel a compulsion to spend all their free time digging in the dirt and all their money buying plants and seeds. Others go even further and transform their working lives by entering the horticultural field.

title: November 5-11; Europe v. Cigarette Makers
description: America's cigarette makers are in trouble again. The European Commission, frustrated with the rising volume of American cigarettes being smuggled over its borders, filed a civil lawsuit in Eastern District Court in Brooklyn seeking damages from Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds, accusing them of using money laundering and wire fraud in ''pursuit of a massive, ongoing smuggling scheme.'' The companies deny the charges. Suzanne Daley

title: Brighten the Indoors
description: Now is the time to decide exactly how you are going to keep darkness at bay between now and the moment in late winter when those first crocuses emerge from the earth. Start with botanical items that are easily obtainable. During fall cleanup, gather things that dry well, such as lavender, blackberry lily seed heads, dusty miller leaves, rose hips and those last few rosebuds that are doomed never to open. Arrange them in small vases or other container and set them in prominent places.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIVE, LENA GURIN
description: FIVE-Lena Gurin. On November 9th at her home in Great Neck, NY. Educator and sculptress. Beloved wife of the late Helge and devoted loving mother of Cora Lee Five and Ellen F. Wilson. Donations may be made to the Alzheimers Foundation.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: All We Know of Love By Katie Schneider. Broadway, $22.95.

title: POSTINGS: Work Begins on Battery Landing for Staten Island Service; Coming Up: One Ferry Terminal, Hold the Clock
description: Remember that Staten Island ferry terminal design with the giant clock? This isn't it.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-12-00: The Ethicist; That's Rubbish
description: Say I see something in my neighbor's trash that catches my eye. Say it turns out to be an antique worth a lot of money. Do I have to tell my neighbor? Or did it cease to be his property when it hit the curb? -- Anonymous, New Jersey

title: The Propagation of Port
description: Adrian William Michael Bridge was doing quite well at NatWest Securities. As head of United States equity sales, he marketed real estate investment trusts and properties from wrecked savings and loan associations to British investors.
