But in 1994, he joined Taylor Fladgate & Yeatman/Fonseca Guimaraens of Portugal, a mouthful of a company that, according to critics, makes the best mouthful of port.

title: The Pictures; The Parallel Universe
description: The cast and crew of a porn film have gathered in the front yard of a ranch house, a few blocks from where I went to high school in the San Fernando Valley. Women in six-inch heels sink into the lawn; men push around lights and cameras, anxious about losing the light. They are preparing to film a scene in which four blond housewives in a convertible are pursued and overtaken by two men in an appliance-repair van. The neighbors have all come out to water their lawns and witness the scene, and in the late evening light it feels as if Fellini has come to make an updated version of ''Amarcord.''

title: O'Rourke Elected Judge, Gaining a Longtime Goal
description: IN an election that held few surprises for Westchester County, voters returned nearly all incumbent candidates to office, passed a measure to replace the decaying Westchester County penitentiary and approved a variety of local ballot propositions, including seven initiatives to buy open space for land preservation.

title: Puppets That Entertain and Educate About Black History
description: WHEN Schroeder Cherry is not working as a museum educator, he might be found making puppets in the basement workshop of his modest four-bedroom home in Fanwood. Or a day off might mean, as it often has for the last nine years, that he is traveling around the country with his hand-held creations, performing a play about the Underground Railroad.

title: Dayne, the Giants' Big Rookie Runner, Grows in Stature
description: Sometimes football, despite all the scheming, the formations and the endless rearranging at the line of scrimmage, is very simple.

title: Some Thoughts on How The News Is Presented
description: To the Editor:

title: In Senate Race, Clinton Drew on Party Faithful
description: In defeating Rick A. Lazio by 12 percentage points in Tuesday's election for United States Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton received the support of many traditional Democratic demographic groups, most of whom backed Charles E. Schumer two years ago in his successful effort to unseat Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Sleepovers Provoke A Battle For Coach
description: AS a soccer coach, my one blowout argument this fall was not with a referee over his awarding a penalty kick to our opponents. It was with my 11-year-old son, Jeremy, over whether he could sleep at a friend's house the night before a big game.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALINA, FRED
description: MALINA-Fred. Remembering my darling Freddie, who made me laugh and made me feel loved. We were blessed with wonderful children, grandchildren and great grandchildren and a happy funfilled life. Evy

title: Born to Be Wildish
description: Piaggio U.S.A. is reintroducing its Vespa scooter in the United States this month with a flagship Vespa store in Los Angeles and two ''lifestyle boutiques'' (selling logoed togs) vrooming into Manhattan and East Hampton this spring. Owners of the Vespa 2000 model include Leonardo DiCaprio, Sting, Jerry Seinfeld and Steven Spielberg. But not every scooter enthusiast is dying to get on it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGAN, EDWARD JOSEPH
description: EGAN-Edward Joseph. On Wednesday, November 8, 2000, in San Francisco, CA. Beloved husband of Jacqueline Nardi Egan of Darien, CT, and Sag Harbor, NY. Loving father of Mark E. Egan, Regina A. Tobin and Elizabeth R. Egan. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Catherine of Siena R.C. Church, 4 Riverside Avenue, Riverside, CT, on November 13, 2000, at 11:30 AM. Calling hours will be at the Leo P. Gallagher Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, on Saturday, November 11, from 7 to 9 PM and Sunday, November 12, from 3 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Burial will be held Tuesday at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY, at 11 AM. Contributions can be made to New Hope Communities, P.O. Box 289, Lochsheldrake, NY 12579.

title: Columbia Revisited: A NEW GENERATION
description: A member of the class of 1964 attends freshman orientation for the class of 2004. What has changed? Just about everything, starting with the students.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARSON, EUGENE
description: GARSON-Eugene. May 8, 1926November 12, 1998. An everlasting bond of love and devotion can never be broken. Gloria.

title: In Class, Gadgets for Interacting, and No One Need Nod Off
description: Teachers since Soc-rates have known that students learn best when they are engaged. But most undergraduates endure more than one course in which a professor holds forth for 80 minutes at a stretch. Some students just cannot help nodding off.

title: Gary Bonasorte, 45, Prolific Playwright
description: Gary Bonasorte, a playwright and a founder of an AIDS research clinic, died on Thursday. He was 45 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, GUS
description: HALL-Gus. Celebration of the life of Gus Hall, lifelong leader of Communist Party U.S.A., November 19, 2 PM, the Great Hall, Cooper Union, 7 East Seventh Street. For information, 212-989-4994.

title: Delectable Puzzlements
description: THE Katonah Museum of Art sees to it that viewers spend much more time with its current show than they usually spend in a museum. The show is ''Puzzles!'' and that means not only contemplating a range of puzzles and solving them in one's head but also solving many of them the interactive, hands-on way.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: DICTIONARY OF MODERN ANGUISH

title: Palm Beach Tally Starts as G.O.P. Cites Risk of Flaws in Process
description: The disputed presidential election in Florida moved into the federal courts today, when Gov. George W. Bush's campaign filed suit to block the manual recount of ballots sought by Vice President Al Gore. The campaign cited the ''potential for mischief'' and said the process was inherently less fair and more subjective than counting by machine.

title: Signs That Speak a Universal Language
description: Waves of backlighted, two-dimensional green pedestrians are coming to intersections in Queens and Staten Island, and they are not characters in a new ''Terminator'' movie.

title: Four Arrested in Election Protest
description: A protest against the handling of the presidential election drew about 300 people to Times Square yesterday afternoon, and four people were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct.

title: Traffic Accidents Mar Image Of a Tidy, Peaceful Section
description: With its tidy brick-and-timber homes and the children tumbling onto its tree-lined streets, Queens Village offers the stereotypical image of a quiet American suburb.

title: The Pictures; The Debut
description: Kate Hudson is a few hours away from her big moment. At 21, she's had a lot of big moments already: her face appeared on billboards for Cameron Crowe's ''Almost Famous,'' then on the cover of Vanity Fair; she attended the movie's Los Angeles premiere, then its screening at the Toronto Film Festival. Even today was crammed with big moments, from her early-morning television appearance through countless scheduled media events. In coordination with television and magazine journalists, the whole process has been carefully orchestrated, a steady crescendo of publicity meant to maximize public interest without overinflating expectations. Tonight's event, the film's New York premiere, will be the biggest moment of them all, the instant -- if all goes as planned -- that she crosses the threshold from promising young actress to bona fide star.

title: The Election; Electoral College 201: Vote Values
description: Many of us became aware of it as students, though it remained clouded in mystery. As adults, we nodded knowingly when the topic came up at dinner parties, but steered the conversation toward more concrete fare like transcendentalism or particle physics. But as the waltz of American power transition became something more of a procedural striptease last week, even the most timid among us was left staring at that dark secret: the Electoral College.

title: Not 'Natural'
description: To the Editor:

title: November 5-11; An Earlier Plot Against a U.S. Warship
description: Islamic militants who bombed the destroyer Cole on Oct. 12 apparently tried to strike another American warship 10 months earlier. A suspect in the Cole attack told Yemeni agents that a January attack failed when an explosives-packed skiff foundered. The Yemenis have not let Americans question suspects but are sharing information that suggests those involved in the Cole attack are linked to Osama bin Laden, the fugitive Saudi militant. Steven Lee Myers

title: YONKERS: HYATT GIVES $1.5 MILLION FOR SCHOLARSHIPS
description: In exchange for tax abatements, Classic Residence by Hyatt, a senior and assisted living center that opened in August, is giving $1.5 million in scholarship funds to the Yonkers public schools. The gift was negotiated with the Yonkers Industrial Development Agency. The money will provide ten $10,000 college scholarships a year over 15 years. Classic Residence is also giving $300,000 to the Southwest Yonkers Planning Association. ''We believe this is an excellent starting point, and we would like to see other companies follow suit,'' said Edward Sheeran, executive director of Yonkers I.D.A. Classic Residence, which is owned by the Hyatt hotel chain, owns 17 other senior centers around the country. This is its first in the New York area. Robert Worth

title: The Critical Piece of the Puzzle
description: THE kitchen was all clean, and so was the children's bathroom. The dog had been walked, the dry cleaning dropped off, the stamps purchased. Now Karina Estrada, a soft-spoken young woman from Guatemala, was ready to go into chauffeur mode.

title: Using Tall Yellow Globes To Find Elusive Yellow Cabs
description: Right now, there are 30 taxi stands in or near Times Square. Name one. There are also eight different kinds of signs marking those stands. Describe one.

title: Finding a Voice And a Community Through Dance
description: WHEN Adesola Akinleye glides across the dance studio, her lean, fluid arms curling like ribbon, she is not only conducting her students through a sequence of ballet steps, but perhaps more important, she is also leading them to the brink of self-expression.

title: Longing for Ideals
description: To the Editor:

title: Hello Up There
description: CITY kids are known for being tough and jaded, overstimulated and overscheduled. For good reason. While so many of their ancestors came here to give them a better life, it requires as much grit and courage to grow up in New York as it does to immigrate.

title: American Voices: Divided on Nov. 7, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Takes 4-Vote Lead in New Mexico
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas late Friday night took the lead from Vice President Al Gore in the race to claim New Mexico's five electoral votes with what now stands as the slimmest statewide margin in the country and one of the narrowest in American history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNOW, NORMAN L., JR.
description: SNOW-Norman L., Jr. of Naples, FL and Greenwich, CT died October 31, 2000 after a long battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Carolyn, loving father of Wendy O'Keeffe, Norman L. Snow III and Laura C. Snow; dear grandfather of Caitlin, Megan, Devin, Madison, Mary and Mackenzie; brother Paul and sister Carolyn Redington. Funeral and burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to Colgate University, Hamilton, NY 13346 or favorite charity.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Verizon's request for a telephone rate increase misspelled the surname of a spokeswoman for the company in some references. She is Soraya Rodriguez, not Rodriquez.

title: Nassau Republicans Make a Comeback From Voter Revolt of 1999
description: For New York Republicans, Tuesday, in many ways, was a dark day that could be summed up in two words: Senator Clinton. There was no net gain in the House of Representatives, no chance to send Joan Johnson, the Islip town clerk, to Washington to be the first black Republican woman in Congress, and no president to inaugurate, at least not yet.

title: The Election; Talk About Slim Margins . . .
description: AT the 1972 Olympics, swimming officials awarded a gold medal to a Swede named Gunnar Larsson after the clock showed that he had beaten Tim McKee, an American, by a few thousandths of a second in a 400-meter race. Afterward, officials decided that such a tiny margin was an unfair and potentially dangerous way to separate the two performances. From then on, they decided, races would be timed only to the hundredth of a second.

title: 2 Camps Clash Vote by Vote, Scrap by Scrap
description: A Palm Beach County elections board decided this morning to hold a manual recount of all ballots cast in the presidential election on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, RICHARD M.
description: MARSHALL-Richard M. Died on November 10, 2000 in Greenwich, CT, at the age of 75. He was a decorated Ranger in the 86th Infantry Division of the Blackhawks in World War II. A Harvard Law School graduate, class of '50, a partner in the New York law firm of Marshall & Tucker, and a partner in Marsam Realty, a family business that owns and operates real estate in NYC. He is survived by his sons Peter and James, their wives Meltem and Lorri, his stepson Anthony Averett, his granddaughter Lindsey Sage, and his wife Elinor. A memorial service will be held in December.

title: The Proof Is in the Disproof
description: KARL POPPER -- The Formative Years, 1902-1945

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, SYLVIA D.
description: LEVY-Sylvia D. On November 11, 2000. J.D., NY University, and artist. Beloved wife of the late Eli B. Levy. Daughter of the late David and Minnie Goldstein. Niece of the late Judge Jonah J. Goldstein. Devoted mother of Lynn and Leland S. Zaubler, and the late John H. Levy. Loving grandmother of Dr. Thomas S. Zaubler and his wife Katharine Sonnenberg and John N. Zaubler. Great-grandmother of William and Elizabeth Sonnenberg Zaubler. Service Sunday, 2 PM, Beth Moses Cemetery. For information call Plaza, 212-769-4400.

title: On a Losing Team, Glimpses of Maturity
description: IT has not been a storybook season for the Lakeland High School football team. When they kicked the ball on the very first play of the season, the other team ran it back for a touchdown. The rest of the season has been just as inglorious, with losses in all but one of their games.

title: Incremental Progress For Women in Politics
description: After women won 4 seats in the United States Senate and 24 in the House of Representatives in the 1992 elections, the year became known in political circles as the Year of the Woman. The year 2000 will probably not go down as Year of the Woman Redux on the basis of Tuesday's election results, but Tuesday was nevertheless a very good day for women who were running for office.

title: Williamses Missing From Season Finale
description: Beneath the famous pie-sliced ceiling of Madison Square Garden, inside an arena where Martina Navratilova and Steffi Graf once took their graceful last bows, it would be fitting if the final episode in the 20-year run of the Chase Championships unfolded with a fireworks display this week.

title: General Managers Aim to Please Fans
description: By a two-thirds to one-third ratio, general managers think the game's offense is just fine, for the most part because the fans think it's just fine.

title: Sites for skiers: five of the best
description: The Internet provides an avalanche of information on just about any topic, of course, but sites devoted to skiing and ski resorts are in particularly good supply. Here are some sites worth checking.

title: Where the Ponies Outrun Donkeys and Elephants
description: A small group of men sat attentively at the bar, their eyes trained on the television sets, waiting for the returns from Florida.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Experiments Against Reality

title: The Election: It Took a Woman; How Gender Helped Elect Hillary Clinton
description: A TRUISM of Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign was that the candidate inspired ambivalence, resentment and even loathing among women, the very group that should have been her base. These emotions turned up repeatedly in the campaign's own polls, worrying Mrs. Clinton's staff for more than a year. Advisers were also inundated with what one facetiously called ''dinner party evidence'' -- passionate denunciations of the first lady by professional women at social events in Manhattan.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL; Sooner Magic Returns
description: Linebacker Torrance Marshall helped bring back the Sooner magic of Oklahoma football today, providing a game-winning 41-yard interception return for the No. 1 Sooners that helped key a wild 35-31 comeback victory over Texas A&M.;

title: Food-Lovers, Not Supermodels
description: The classical Thanksgiving dinner, from opening crudities to closing pumpkin pie, acquires an extra flavor sheen when Nancy's Wines for Food provide the bottles.

title: Bosnia Votes With Hope to Break Ethnic Parties' Rule
description: The people of Bosnia were voting today in general elections without excitement, but many expressed a determination to try to bring change to their country almost five years after the peace agreement was reached in Dayton, Ohio.

title: A Hall of Almost Any Kind of Fame
description: WHAT rage for fame attends both great and small,'' John Wolcot wrote two centuries ago, but the phrase seems a better fit for the current age. The already famous celebrate themselves with an ever-growing collection of awards ceremonies, while the not famous queue up to be a face in the crowd outside ''Good Morning America.''

title: Can DoubleClick Stock Start Doubling Back?
description: REVENUE growth and earnings were better than expected. Consolidation has increased its global reach. And many analysts are optimistic about its long-term chances.

title: The Unintended Lesson Of Hiring a Bike Tutor
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Bible Stories Draw Big Audiences
description: WHEN it comes to the recurring themes of human existence - jealously within families, the quest for freedom, the search for a place of one's own - the small screen has always provided ample space for big dramas. It is only natural, then, that some of the Bible's richest narratives - the journey of Abraham and Sarah, the rivalry between Jacob and Esau, the flight of the Israelites to the Promised Land - would provide great raw material for television productions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAVSKY, JOYCE
description: WARSHAVSKY-Joyce. Beloved wife of Murray for 55 years. Devoted mother of Letty and Michael Tanchum and Calvin and Andrea Roberts. Dear sister of Arline Reiss. Adoring grandmother of Meredith, David, Lindsay, Robert and Joanna. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM, ''Plaza Memorial Chapel'', 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Ophthalmology Research Fund at Cornell University Medical College, 1300 York Ave., NYC 10021 would be appreciated.

title: PULSE; The Kangol Cap Hops Again
description: In a previous life they were favored by London cabbies and the argyle-clad golfing set, but now Kangols or peak caps have risen to the top of the fashion fairway. The originals evolved from berets and were invented in England back in 1954. They first achieved hipster status when they were adopted by rappers in the 80's, but then they fell off the style map until Philip Treacy, the British milliner, enlisted designers to reinvent some classic Kangol styles. Katharine Hamnett and Fraser Moss (formerly of Vivienne Westwood) reinterpreted the 504 style (the one worn by Samuel L. Jackson in ''Jackie Brown''). Ms. Hamnett's aqua check version ($40) and Mr. Moss's perforated suede style ($48) are available at Knox Hats, 620 Eighth Avenue, or through Kangol at (800) 431-1802.

title: Jennifer Lockhart, Tyler Kepner
description: Jennifer Lockhart, a daughter of Susan Sarshik of Blue Bell, Pa., and Michael D. Lockhart of Rembert, S.C., was married yesterday to Tyler Kepner, a son of Miriam and John C. S. Kepner of Gwynedd Valley, Pa. The Rev. Marek P. Zabriskie performed the ceremony at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Whitemarsh, Pa.

title: Word for Word/Letters Home; The Myriad Ways in Which War Has Been Hell
description: WARTIME letters and diaries, written by ordinary people living through extraordinary times, have become part of American literature. Transformed by their experiences, these men and women often found within themselves unknown reserves of courage and discovered a common ground of humanity as they shared their hopes and fears with loved ones back home.

title: A View of the Island Through Teenage Eyes
description: LONG ISLAND was my teenage rebellion.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: The Last Lover

title: November 5-11; Atwood Receives Her Booker
description: The Canadian writer Margaret Atwood finally won the Booker Prize, Britain's most prestigious fiction award, after being nominated three times before. Ms. Atwood, 60, beat a shortlist of five other authors, mostly unknowns, to take the $:21,000 prize for her 10th novel, ''The Blind Assassin.'' It is set in a small town in Canada and describes, using a complicated series of stories within stories, the fraught relationship between two sisters, one of whom died young. Sarah Lyall

title: Rams Will Push the Limits of Fox's Defense
description: In football jargon, an offensive coach who designs running plays using the same flair he does when designing passing plays, a coach who creates a ton of multiple formations, tricky motions and even, in games, creates new material on the fly, well, that is a coach who has ''a sharp pencil.''

title: A View From the Stage
description: ECHOES DOWN THE CORRIDOR Collected Essays, 1944-2000. By Arthur Miller. Edited by Steven R. Centola. 332 pp. New York: Viking. $29.95.

title: In an Ocean of Marinara Sauce, 12 Places Where Dining Is More Than Molto Bene
description: ITALY reigns supreme on Long Island, from Montauk to Malverne. Because of that, a list of the top Italian restaurants is in reality the best of the best. Many that we regard as just ordinary would be hailed as outstanding elsewhere. Here are 12 that could be considered an Italian hall of fame.

title: In Sarasota, Art Season Opens With a Big Event
description: A stretch of the bay front in Sarasota, Fla., may now seem more suited to giants than mere mortals. Starting today until March 29, 18 sculptures, none less than 10 feet fall and one as high as 16 feet, will be arrayed along two-thirds of a mile.

title: Who Voted: A Portrait of American Politics, 1976-2000
description: Amajority of women, older voters, Democrats, liberals and black, Hispanic and Asian voters cast their ballots for Al Gore. George W. Bush captured the votes of most men, whites, conservatives, Republicans, Southerners and white Protestants. Ralph Nader, who received 2 percent of the vote, did best among independents, particularly liberal ones, and among young men.

title: Expansion Proposed For Research Space
description: Encouraged by the demand for research and development space, Eastview Holdings, the owner of the Landmark at Eastview office-laboratory campus, is asking Greenburgh officials to approve two new lab buildings and a hotel-conference center on its 270-acre property.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-12-00: Questions for Atom Egoyan; Northern Light
description: Q: Your work seems to be suffused with an almost Nordic bleakness, even in a film as visually and narratively lush as ''Exotica.'' Where does that come from? Do you think that is a particularly Canadian trait?

title: Suit Is Seen as a Way to Speedily Shift the Case From Florida
description: The Republican decision to sue in federal court appeared to be a strategic effort to take the politically volatile case out of Florida -- and possibly the hands of local elected judges -- as quickly as possible, experts on election law said yesterday.

title: A Picture Is Worth A Thousand Bytes
description: SOMETIMES, grandparents can't wait for a letter or a visit to see the latest family photographs. And even if the parents have discovered digital cameras as a way around that problem, the images must still be downloaded into computers, which can be cumbersome.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Much of Shoreline North Fork Tract to Be Preserved
description: AN AGREEMENT concluded three years ago between a landowner and a nonprofit land conservation group has led to a development plan designed to ensure that one of the North Fork's most scenic vistas from a public road will forever be preserved. The subdivision plan is now before the Town of Southold awaiting final approval.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; A Blessing on Nearly Everything
description: The loquacious style of David Kirby's poetry can sometimes resemble the riffs of a brainy stand-up comedian. In the 18 long poems in THE HOUSE OF BLUE LIGHT (Louisiana State University, cloth, $22.50; paper, $14.95), which span anywhere from three to six pages, tragicomical trains of thought run at a frenetic pace. In ''At the Grave of Harold Goldstein,'' for example, the speaker recalls attending a funeral and running across a beloved old friend's gravestone, then jumps to memories of his own would-be juvenile delinquency and the rather hilarious time he and another friend accidentally flipped a Renault upside down in their high school parking lot. All of this finally leads him to ponder his life's purpose amid such chance occurrences, illustrated with a quotation from Woody Allen's ''Stardust Memories.'' Kirby's structure -- stanzas of long, alternatingly indented lines that easily accommodate the cadences of conversation -- contributes to the sense of a casual artistry at work. Yet in relating seemingly autobiographical, spryly digressive sagas about work, marriage, travel and even the joys of mediocre movies, Kirby makes the narrative poem -- a form often proclaimed to be outdated -- amusing, lively and relevant enough for contemporary tastes. While his language is at times gratingly prosaic -- as in the line, ''but it's, like, Milk-Bone time for him'' -- Kirby's strings of lyric vignettes are often inspired. In the title poem, a marvelous meditation on music, fatherhood and death, he writes, ''My son, me, Little Richard, Roy Orbison: / it's a mishmash for sure'' -- but a mishmash wrought of cleverly detailed imagery. Megan Harlan

title: American Voices: Divided on Nov. 7, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: She Shopped Till She Dropped Everything Off at the Museum
description: WHEN Valerie Steele, the acting director of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology, met Evangeline Morphos last week, she grasped her hand eagerly. ''You've become a mythical figure for me,'' she exclaimed.

title: The Pictures; The Fabrication
description: Principal photography has just begun on Martin Scorsese's epic film, ''Gangs of New York.'' (Full disclosure: I'm the movie's historical adviser.) It's being shot in Rome, at Cinecitt. This fact seems to throw nearly everyone. Why Rome? New York City, at last report, was still standing. Yes, but the film is set amid long lost 19th-century slums. Every location had to be built.

title: Flight Paths
description: This time of year, it seems, birds of prey descend on the gym of the Church Street School in White Plains. Some sit on the basketball backboards, while others swoop down to get a closer look at the people in the stands.

title: The Dream Factories For Rock Musicians
description: THE club could be small and dingy with beer stains on the floor. The lighting, the little that exists, probably doesn't do much for the band or the audience. The stage is barely big enough for the band, with a smidgen of a dance floor in front of it. Half the handful of people in the room do not have a good view. The other half are not listening, anyway.

title: Pinning Their Hopes
description: THE streets of this little town along the southern Delaware River are not bursting with prosperity even in these flush times. There are lots of ''For Rent'' signs and boarded-up doors and windows. Mergers in the oil industry have caused layoffs at the riverfront refineries. The town hardly seems a destination for the hopeful.

title: City Culture in Danger
description: To the Editor:

title: A Great View Will Disappear (But Sit Tight. It Will Return.)
description: For 50 years, the Brooklyn Heights Promenade has stood not only as a stately perch from which to view New York Harbor but also as a symbol of the resistance mounted by local residents in the 1940's, when the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway threatened to cut through their neighborhood.

title: Babes in the Woods: Putting 5 'Cute Utes' to the Test
description: SMALL sport utility vehicles are grabbing an ever-bigger chunk of the car market, and the hottest ones are cars at heart. They are designed like cars, with one-piece unit bodies, instead of like trucks, with separate bodies bolted to rugged frames. And they meld some car characteristics -- comfortable cabins, relatively responsive handling, compliant rides, reasonable fuel economy -- with the traits that have had people lining up for S.U.V.'s: good outward visibility, a ''commanding'' driving position, flexible cargo space and the bad-weather security of all-wheel drive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, SHIRLEY MILLER
description: GOLDBERG-Shirley Miller. Of Fort Lee, NJ, formerly of Jericho and Brooklyn, NY, at home, surrounded by family, at peace, on November 10, 2000. For 54 years, much beloved wife of Isadore Elliott. Loving and deeply devoted to her children Sandra, Jeffrey (deceased), Neil and Howard, her son-in-law Paul, and her grandchildren John and Brian. Caring sister to Ann (deceased) and Sarah. She graduated from Thomas Jefferson High School and then worked as a legal secretary for more than 40 years, all while raising her family, keeping home and trying to help others. Services Sunday, November 12, at 11:30 AM at Gutterman-Musicant in Englewood, NJ. Graveside services at Beth Moses Cemetery in Pinelawn, NY. Shiva at home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, PHYLLIS
description: WEINER-Phyllis. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the passing of Phyllis Weiner. Phyllis, a long-time contributor, was a beloved sister of Martin Lifton, a cherished friend, major supporter of our mission, and founder of the Long Island Real Estate & Allied Trades Division. We extend our deepest sympathies to Phyllis' husband, Howard, their children and grandchildren, and to Martin, his wife Ellie, and their family. May her memory be a blessing. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair Arthur M. Katz, LI Cabinet Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO Simon Kaminetsky, LI Director

title: Commercial Property; Signs of Slight Cooling in the Feverish Office Market
description: IS the hot market for office space in Manhattan, which has sent rents soaring, sometimes to record levels, beginning to cool off just a bit? There are hints of it in reports on market activity now being published by major brokerage companies in the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ELIYAHU
description: COHEN-Eliyahu. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its affiliates mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member, Dr. Edmond Cohen and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Out and About With the Once But No Longer So Lonely Guy
description: A SLIGHTLY older writer looked himself up on the Internet recently. What he found was this:

title: POSTINGS: Frank Lloyd Wright To Diego Rivera; The Emergence Of 4 Landmarks
description: A series of four presentations on how architects worked -- sometimes contentiously -- with their clients to design some of New York's most notable buildings is to begin on Tuesday at 6 p.m. in the library of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of the City of New York at 20 West 40th Street.

title: The Pictures; The Trailer
description: This corner, says Keanu Reeves, is his favorite spot. It has all he needs: a surface on which to put things and a window to the outside. ''I spend most of my time right here when I'm in the trailer,'' he says, staring at the blank walls and floral-pattern chairs on the set of ''Hardball.' ' ''These things are really quite pathetic and sad.'' And yet, expensive. According to a representative from Movie Movers, which rents deluxe trailers, a top-of-the-line 40-foot star trailer (triple pop-out, meaning expandable; TV; CD player; VCR; and bathroom with skylight) runs about $1,800 a week. Most productions adhere to strict clauses stating that what one star receives, the others also receive, thereby lessening, but not wholly eradicating, the potential for celebrity trailer envy. Stars can still jockey over trailer placement. As one top producer notes, ''The higher paid the star, the closer to location is their trailer.''

title: The End of the Weekend or the Start of Something Good?
description: SUNDAY night: those last few remaining hours of a weekend often bring with them a mix of a fizzling carefree spirit, and the anticipation of the Monday morning back-to-the-grind.

title: Public Realm On Private Property
description: To the Editor:

title: In Senate Race, Clinton Drew On Party Faithful
description: In defeating Rick A. Lazio by 12 percentage points in Tuesday's election for United States Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton received the support of many traditional Democratic demographic groups, most of whom backed Charles E. Schumer two years ago in his successful effort to unseat Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: A Yachtsman Dreams of a New Boat Class
description: One step backward meant a sudden dip in Chesapeake Bay. Suspended above the water as if on a ledge at the very conclusion of the yacht's elegant aft overhang, the long view ahead resembled a straight, clean boulevard of flawless teak. Except for when your eyes met the expansive cockpit, the low coach roof, and the tall mast.

title: American Voices: Divided on Nov. 7, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Encounter at Gym Leads to New Home
description: A chance encounter in a gym has led to a new home for the Bronx Dance Theater. This nonprofit group dedicated to professional dance instruction, which was in the Norwood section for 13 years, moved last month to the second floor of 585 East 187th Street (between Arthur Avenue and Hoffman Street) in Belmont, known as the Little Italy of the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWEITZER, DR. NANCY J. (RUBENFELD)
description: SCHWEITZER-Dr. Nancy J. (Rubenfeld). November 12, 1986. Cherished, respected, incomparable, unforgettable. Your Mom

title: Conveniences: Caffeine Cocktails
description: STEVEN RETAS, his back against the shiny wooden bar at the Village's hot nightspot Luahn, had one hand on his girlfriend's shoulder and another firmly wrapped around his Red Bull and vodka on ice.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Zombie00

title: Allison Lindner, Darren Latimer
description: Allison Stacey Lindner, a daughter of Cathy and Ira Lindner of Woodmere, N.Y., is to be married today to Darren Matthew Latimer, a son of Carole and Kenneth Latimer of Highland Park, Ill. Dr. Arthur Dobrin, the leader of the Ethical Humanist Society of Long Island, is to officiate at the Inwood Country Club in Inwood, N.Y.

title: Strummed by One Hand, Sculptured by Another
description: ANDRES SEGOVIA once lamented that ''the guitar and the dog, in order not to be separated from man, have submitted themselves with resignation to the worst alterations of size and appearance.''

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE story of Teena Brandon - her decision to live as a man, her attempt to start a new life in a small Nebraska town, and her sub-sequent rape and murder at the age of 21 - might have been remembered as just another set of tabloid headlines. But Kimberley Peirce wrote (with andy Bienen) and directed BOYS DON'T CRY (1999). And, of course, Hilary Swank - whose most notable acting credit until then had been a season on Fox's ''Beverly Hills 90210'' - accepted the role of Brandon Teena (the mail name that Teena Brandon assumed), gave an astonishing performance and won the best actress Oscar. Chloe Sevigny is outstanding, too, as the young woman who loves Brandon and goes on loving him, even when his double life is revealed - Sunday at 10 p.m. and Wednesday at 10 p.m. on Cinemax.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, NANCY D.
description: RICHMAN-Nancy D., 57. Died November 5, 2000. Resided in New York City prior to moving to Lauderhill, FL, in September, 1997. Survived by life companion, Nita Novell, of Lauderhill, FL, immediate family, Lori & Lee Richman, of Tamarac, Florida, Elizabeth, Vikram, Anjali, and Evan Prasad of Amsterdam, Holland, and an extended family of aunts, uncles, cousins, and dear friends. Predeceased by her mother, Evelyn Sherman Richman. Nancy will be deeply missed and will remain in our hearts forever. In her memory, contributions may be made to Vitas Hospice, 5420 NW 33rd Avenue, Suite 100, Ft. Lauderdale, Florida 33309.

title: Getting Into M.I.T. by a Whisker
description: Getting into the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has always been challenging, but for some the admissions requirements are formidable: The recent arrivals on campus had to be registered, photographed, immunized and spayed or neutered.

title: Esther M. Stone, 91, Widow of Journalist
description: Esther M. Stone, the widow of the journalist I. F. Stone, who helped him publish his well-read and iconoclastic weekly newsletter, died Thursday at a nursing home in Potomac, Md. She was 91.

title: Holiday Ski Trip Still a Possibility
description: IF the only thing that will make you happy as a skier this Christmas is staying at the Little Nell in Aspen, Colo., you are in for a rotten holiday. This deluxe lodge has been sold out of all its 92 rooms and suites for the holidays since April or so, and has 200 names on the waiting list. David Ryan, a sales manager, says almost all holiday guests come back year after year, happy to pay rates that the hotel does not publish but that run well above its usual $525 a night for rooms and $700 a night for suites, for quarters at the foot of Aspen Mountain. Fifty percent of them even ski, Mr. Ryan said.

title: From the Symphony, a Copland Portrait
description: THIS week the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra pays tribute to Aaron Copland's centenary by performing -- in more than one hall, as always -- some of his most famous pieces. While it is honoring the nation's greatest composer, the state's leading orchestra does honor to its own rewarding struggle toward musical excellence, fiscal sanity and a performing arts center it can call home.

title: Erin Murphy, Ted Ferrarone
description: Erin Nicole Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Murphy of Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to Edward Joseph Ferrarone III, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferrarone Jr. of Pound Ridge, N.Y. Bishop Paul G. Bootkoski, the vicar general of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, performed the ceremony at St. Justin the Martyr Church in Key Largo, Fla.

title: A Listing Service for Manhattan
description: ''IT would not be an exaggeration to say that what the real estate brokers in Manhattan have just done is nothing short of huge,'' Joanne Kennedy, the president of Coldwell Banker Hunt Kennedy, a Manhattan brokerage company, said last week. Ms. Kennedy was talking about an agreement reached late last month by more than 100 Manhattan real estate brokerage concerns to do what brokers most anywhere else in the country do routinely -- share information about their residential listings.

title: 2 for Thanksgiving
description: Mention Cartlidge & Browne to informed, thrifty wine lovers and they salivate.

title: SOAPBOX; Oh No! It's Picture Day
description: I CONGRATULATED myself for having time this morning to clear the table and put away the breakfast dishes before leaving to drop Brian off at the Bedford Road School in Pleasantville on my way to work.

title: A Hall of Any Kind of Fame
description: WHAT rage for fame attends both great and small,'' John Wolcot wrote two centuries ago, but the phrase seems a better fit for the current age. The already famous celebrate themselves with an ever-growing collection of awards ceremonies, while the not famous queue up to be a face in the crowd outside ''Good Morning America.'' Somewhere between those two extremes lies the hall-of-fame phenomenon.

title: The Many Faces of Jeanine Pirro
description: WHEN Jeanine Pirro was named one of the 50 Most Beautiful People in 1997 by People magazine, she was asked how -- as a wife, mother and hard-working district attorney known for championing the causes of battered wives and abused children -- she managed to look so great.

title: Art, Wildlife and a Bit of Investing
description: FOR 28 years, Michael H. Steinhardt managed an investment portfolio. Today he manages a portfolio of enthusiasms: Philanthropy. Art. Wildlife. Gardening. And a little bit of investing. ''I'm addicted,'' he said in a recent interview.

title: The Duck Quacks And Has a Big Bill
description: ''For trading, press 1. For a new account kit, press 2 . . . If you would like to hear a duck quack, press 7.''

title: Political Talk Infiltrates a City Built on Fantasy and Shapes Vacations
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 10  People plan a whole year ahead to escape to this never-never land for adults. Nothing is real, which is precisely the point. The skies inside the casinos are always baby blue, the promise of instant riches rings in the air and Paris is a few blocks from Venice, which is across the street from Rome, a five-minute ride to the Sahara and about a mile from New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHAN, JEROME I.
description: KAHAN-Jerome I. On November 9, 2000. Beloved husband of Marcia. Adored father of Stuart and Ellen, Andrew and Karen, and Elizabeth and Mark Flyer. Loving grandfather of Kimberly, William, Hayley and Emily. Dearest brother and uncle. We will love you forever.

title: A Broom Too Stiff At Carnegie?
description: EUROPEANS hired to run American musical institutions have a way of running into trouble. Franz Xaver Ohnesorg, brought in from the Cologne Philharmonie in Germany to be executive director at Carnegie Hall, is the latest. The reasons are not always the same, but often they are. Hugh Southern barely made it through one season at the Metropolitan Opera a decade ago. In his case, the job overwhelmed him.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: The Limits Of Patience
description: Another week and no more.

title: Jessica Dennis, Michael Capiraso
description: Jessica Hope Dennis, the director of worldwide advertising and marketing for Gucci in New York, was married yesterday to Michael Paul Capiraso, the vice president for television commercial production at Calvin Klein in New York. The Rev. Emmanuel Jaggernauth, a Baptist minister, officiated at Caneel Bay, a resort on St. John in the Virgin Islands.

title: During the Confusion, a Turn Toward Treasuries
description: IN the midst of all the uncertainty about the identity of the next president, the Treasury market is the place to be.

title: A Foundation Opens Wide Its Umbrella
description: THE Long Island Community Foundation makes giving away money easy. ''The whole idea of a community foundation is that everybody can be a philanthropist,'' said Suzy Sonenberg, the executive director.

title: Planned Complex Would Mar Waterfront
description: To the Editor:

title: Stacey Malacos, Kevin La Follette
description: Anastasia Malacos and Kevin Robert La Follette were married yesterday by the Rev. Elias G. Villis at the Greek Orthodox Church of Our Saviour in Rye, N.Y.

title: They Speak For the Animals, And Through Them
description: YEARS ago Dr. Dolittle boasted that he could talk to the animals. Today scientists clone them. Meanwhile, greeting cards, children's books, cartoons and pet food commercials tend to romanticize subjects that purr, bark, chirp or roar. They draw from -- or impose on -- animals an aura of noble innocence. Even well-meaning eco-activists use cute images of pandas to help sell the causes of protecting the environment and saving endangered species.

title: American Voices: Divided on Nov. 7, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTING WITH: Nicholas D. Gerber; Ameristock Fund
description: NICHOLAS D. GERBER, who runs the $111.4 million Ameristock fund, is a tradition-minded kind of guy. ''I have lots of old-fashioned values, such as 'buy-and-hold investing means more than six months,' and 'dividends and book value matter,' '' Mr. Gerber said, adding, ''I'm sorry I couldn't attend Ben Graham's classes at Columbia.'' Benjamin Graham, who taught finance at Columbia University in the 1930's, is widely regarded as a father of value investing.

title: American Voices: Divided on Nov. 7, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: No Recount: Escape Wins
description: PLAYING musical driver's seats attunes one to a vehicle's personality, strengths and quirks. Solid and substantial, the Santa Fe exceeded my expectations. The much-improved RAV4 is impressive in many ways. But the Escape was the standout, striking a fine balance between fun and utility and capably handling every road, trail or track maneuver.

title: A Peek Inside the House, If Not the Woman
description: AT the very moment Hillary Rodham Clinton has shattered the mold of First Lady by winning a Senate seat, she is also celebrating the traditional side of her life for the last eight years, as chatelaine of the Executive Mansion.

title: The Promised Land
description: ONE PALESTINE, COMPLETE Jews and Arabs Under the British Mandate. By Tom Segev. Translated by Haim Watzman. Illustrated. 612 pp. New York: Metropolitan Books/ Henry Holt & Company. $35.

title: WHITE PLAINS: NEW MEDIA SITE FOR MERCY COLLEGE
description: Hoping it will become an incubator for the emerging digital culture in White Plains, Mercy College plans to use a vacant storefront on South Broadway for its new Center for Media Arts. The space will house the college's programs in computer graphics, digital animation, Web site design and related subjects. It will also include a small theater-film-performance space for lectures and independent films. The center is scheduled to open next fall with an anticipated enrollment of about 50 students. Elsa Brenner

title: Out of Context
description: To the Editor:

title: Projecting a Relaxed Air As Recount Battle Sizzles
description: As Gov. George W. Bush's representatives filed a lawsuit to stop a manual recount of ballots in certain Florida counties, Mr. Bush could not have seemed more distant from the fray.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Carville and Matalin

title: Article on Supermarkets Left Out a Bright Light
description: To the Editor:

title: Park Place After Goldberg
description: It has been less than a month since the death at 58 of Arthur M. Goldberg, the chief executive of the Park Place Entertainment Corporation, the world's largest gambling company, with 28 gambling properties including the Caesars casino chain. But doubts about the company's future without Mr. Goldberg, a strong-willed, well-connected leader, have been percolating ever since.

title: Long Island Vines; Wine Is for Pleasure, Not for Storage. Enjoy Now, Not Later.
description: A COLLEAGUE unwrapped a gift package recently and was surprised to find a bottle of Veuve Clicquot Champagne.

title: Disasters in the Making
description: 6 Nightmares

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, ALICE
description: SCHINDLER-Alice, on November 7, 2000. Former Hospital Administrator at Beth Israel Hospital. Loving aunt of Susan Krauss and Robin Schindler. Devoted great-aunt of Abbe Kellner and Erika Krauss. Adoring great-great-aunt of Nicole and Joshua Kellner. Service Sunday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Chic New Bistro, Excitement Included
description: IF you doubt that dining out has become entertainment, drop by Bleu in Greenwich. This chic new bistro has the excitement of a stage set. Its long skinny interior is designed with a zinc bar and raw bar on one side, a handful of semicircular banquettes along the mirror-lined brick opposite wall, and a narrow 32-foot-long oak table, intended for communal dining, extending down the center. On the table are lighted candelabras, which reminded us of the surreal Jean Cocteau movie, ''Beauty and the Beast.''

title: You Can't Eat the Setting, But You Sure Can Enjoy It
description: AT restaurants and at the theater, each night the show goes on for a new audience. Just as theatergoers have the option of Broadway, Off Broadway and beyond, Long Island diners have a range of choices, including places where the setting is as enticing as the food.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Guilt Dogging the Greatest Generation
description: OVER the last few years, a regular cottage industry has sprung up in publishing and Hollywood to celebrate what Tom Brokaw dubbed ''the greatest generation.'' Mr. Brokaw's 1998 book by the same name is only one of numerous works hailing the generation of Americans who led the nation through the Great Depression and World War II. Others include Mr. Brokaw's sequel, ''The Greatest Generation Speaks,'' Stephen Ambrose's ''D-Day: June 6, 1944,'' James Bradley's ''Flags of Our Fathers'' and the Steven Spielberg movie ''Saving Private Ryan.'' It has even led to the establishment of a D-Day museum in New Orleans.

title: Vote in U.S. Senate Race Followed 12-Year Trend
description: Since 1988, Democratic candidates for United States Senate in New Jersey have received 50 percent to 54 percent of the vote, while support for Republican Senate candidates has ranged from 43 percent to 47 percent. This year was no exception.

title: VIEW; Scholarships Are Playing A New Role
description: Admission to a fine college that offers both great career preparation and good connections is the hope of many students and their parents, but for most, financing that education is a challenge.

title: Tell Me What Street Compares With Mott Street
description: Lower East Side Memories

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, ADELINE P.
description: CANTOR-Adeline P. age 86, of Riverdale, NY, and Delray Beach, FL. Survived by her beloved husband Seymour of sixty years, her son Mark, adored grandchildren Fara, Carrie and Justin Cantor. Services are today, 11:30am, graveside at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, NJ.

title: Ellen O'Brien, John Cassels
description: Ellen Nicole O'Brien, the daughter of Carol and Terence O'Brien of New York, was married yesterday to John Collins Cassels, the son of Sondra and John Cassels of Greensboro, N.C. The Rev. Andrew Foster performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Ascension in New York.

title: The Humble Instrument That Conquered The World
description: THE 1964 Fender Stratocaster on this page is as red as the face of a cartoon devil, with horns to match. It's smooth and solid as a surfboard, concealing its electronics behind a plastic pickguard with its own horns, while its metallic socket and tuning machinery gleam like chrome on a new sportscar. Yet it's not all speed and aggression. The Strat is also curvy, inviting a player's touch with a voluptuous free-form shape and beveled edges that generations of guitarists have found to be balanced and comfortable. Simultaneously angular and sleek, masculine and feminine, whimsical and functional, it's just one of the iconic forms of the instrument that conquered the world.

title: Louise DuArt and Squire Rushnell
description: FOR Squire Rushnell, one of the best things about marrying Louise DuArt is that he knows he can always get a great table in any restaurant in town. Ms. DuArt is a comic actress, who specializes in impersonations of celebrities like Cher, Fran Drescher, Carol Burnett and Katharine Hepburn. She does a pitch-perfect gravelly cigar-smoking George Burns saying, ''I was there when the Dead Sea was only sick.''

title: Information Sources on Solar Power
description: HERE are organizations that can provide information about solar power:

title: La Dolce Vita in the Dolomites
description: THERE are mountains, and then there are the Dolomites. From the margins of the pine forests, at a height of over 6,000 feet, the rock faces thrust upward, rising several thousand feet more. Topped with pinnacles as fine as needles, as jagged as saws or as blunt as hammers, these walls of rock overwhelm in their untamed beauty. Treacherous invitations to the climber, the precipices also offer a stunning backdrop to the skier exploring the pistes of Val Gardena in Italy as they wind around the jagged peaks. In few places can the gentle pleasures of the dolce vita be found in a setting of such invigorating power.

title: Giving It Away
description: THERE are many tales about Bernice Wall Barbour, and one of the favorites involves the winter when she heard that elk were starving to death out West. She left her New Jersey home and headed out to her Wyoming ranch, where she bought a snowmobile and spent the winter hauling hay to the hungry animals.

title: Back Talk; The Gifts Passed From Father to Sons Only Begin With Football
description: In his long, fitful career as a star quarterback in the National Football League, spent primarily with the woebegone New Orleans Saints of the 1970's and 80's, Archie Manning played on teams that never won more than eight games in a season, never finished better than .500. In 1999, when his son Peyton was helping convert the Indianapolis Colts from an afterthought to a division champion and the Colts had won their ninth game en route to a 13-3 emergence, Peyton was asked if it pleased him that he had surpassed Archie's ''best'' in just his second year.

title: Reaching Out to Touch Somebody's Hand
description: The scene has been emblazoned on the American psyche for more than 40 years: a woman holds a struggling girl's hand under running water and, in sign language, spells out ''w-a-t-e-r'' over and over again. Suddenly, senses and reason connect, and Helen Keller, blind and deaf from the age of 19 months, has discovered a way to communicate with the world through the teachings of her devoted companion, Annie Sullivan.

title: The Ties That Don't Quite Bind
description: DON'T TELL ANYONE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMAREK, VIOLA W., PH.D.
description: KOMAREK-Viola W., Ph.D. 92, formerly of NYC, died November 10. She was a retired economics professor at New York University.

title: Adventure Runs in a Singer's Blood
description: FOR all their fabled technomania, the Finns have not lost that mystical connection to nature that Sibelius so vividly translated into sound a century ago. A visitor to the mezzo-soprano Monica Groop's tiny summer cottage here on Lake Saimaa in southeastern Finland suspects that this affinity, as much as a custom-tailored leading role in the premiere of ''Aika ja Uni'' (''The Age of Dreams''), is what drew Ms. Groop back to the Savonlinna Opera Festival this summer.

title: Groundbreaking, of Sorts, for a Contested War Memorial
description: Fifty-five years after the end of the war, and 13 years after Congress first took up the idea of a monument to it, President Clinton and other dignitaries broke ground here today for the National World War II Memorial on the Mall.

title: Vicki Gianakakos, Peter Weiden
description: Vasiliki Gianakakos and Dr. Peter Joseph Weiden were married yesterday by the Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian minister, at the ''21'' Club in Manhattan.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-12-00: On Language; Rollout
description: 'Early in its foreign rollout,'' reported Daily Variety, a movie titled ''X-Men'' hauled in $3.4 million over an opening weekend.

title: Amtrak's Acela Express To Start Service Dec. 11
description: Tickets for Amtrak's new high-speed train, the Acela Express, will go on sale Nov. 29 for service between New York and Boston beginning Dec. 11. The Acela Express is to start running between New York and Washington early next year, Amtrak says, with 20 new trains replacing all long-distance trains between Boston and Washington by summer. Amtrak will still offer reserved and unreserved service using its existing fleet, but will call them Acela Regional and Acela Commuter, depending on the route, said Cecilia Cummings, an Amtrak spokeswoman.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDSTEIN, ALBIE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Albie. In memory of Albie Goldstein an unveiling was held at Maple Grove Cemetery on November 7, 2000. Until we meet again, Joanie.

title: Sunday Night Fever
description: FOR many people, the dread of Monday mornings begins on Sunday night. At 7 p.m. Eastern time, to be exact.

title: Back in the Courtroom for People v. Simpson
description: SUDDENLY I had walked into what is still, five years later, a recurring dream: I was back in Department 103 of the Los Angeles County Superior Court. Judge Lance Ito was once more on the bench, sitting solemnly behind his collection of hourglasses. Marcia Clark, in her pre-chic incarnation, had returned to the table where the prosecutors always congregated. Christopher Darden was once more peering into the jury box -- ''He is a murderer. He was also one hell of a football player. But he is still a murderer,'' he was saying -- as the defense lawyers behind him looked laboriously indifferent. The defendant himself was looking away, toward the wall, as he always did when anything unpleasant was going on -- say, when pictures of his bloodied wife or her equally blood-soaked friend, Ron Goldman, were on display.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAFER, HENRY M.
description: HAFER-Henry M. 83, lawyer, on November 10. Beloved husband of Elsie; loving father of Carol and Sally Hafer; William, Edward and Richard Shain; grandfather of Patrick and Will Reina, Charles, Rebecca, Samantha, and Albertine Shain. Graduate of Horace Mann, NYU and NYU Law School. Retired Captain, U.S. Army WW II veteran. Dear friend to all who knew him. Devoted Mets fan. Donations to Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021 would be appreciated.

title: November 5-11; Where Higgs Won't Be Found
description: Physicists at CERN, the particle physics laboratory in Geneva, thought they had found evidence of the elusive Higgs boson, which theoretically holds the key to why matter in the universe has mass. But CERN's particle accelerator was set to be demolished to make way for a more powerful machine that will not be built before 2005. They pleaded for more time, but CERN's management turned them down, raising the possibility that the discovery will be made at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, near Chicago. James Glanz

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPALDO, LOUIS A.
description: CAPALDO-Louis A. 30 years ago, Nov., 1970, Louis passed away. Memories of love and devotion never die. Always alive in my heart. Susan

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-18

title: Devils' Cup A Distant Memory
description: Supporters of the Devils will argue that the National Hockey League season is just 16 games old, and that there is plenty of time to get things right. But, at this stage of the 2000-2001 campaign, the Devils are miles from the team that captured the Stanley Cup last season.

title: Motorcycles Roar Again, And So Do Bar's Neighbors
description: Some people who live near American Trash, a bar on First Avenue between East 76th and 77th Streets, have complained for years about rowdy crowds that arrive on loud motorcycles. Now, they say, the on-again, off-again noise problem is on again, and they want the police to crack down. But the bar's owner says he can't dictate his customers' mode of transportation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 22 about the opening of a Giorgio Armani retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum referred incorrectly to a dinner party that was held afterward at 9 West 57th Street. Mr. Armani was not ''conspicuously absent''; he attended, but in the large and dark room, some guests were unaware of his presence.

title: The Latest Look: Unforgiving
description: POSTED like a sentry near the door of the Helmut Lang shop in SoHo are three massive wooden eagles. Magisterial and menacing at once, these brooding symbols of imperial might seem less appropriate to a fashion boutique than to the arenas of ''Gladiator.'' Mr. Lang said he had not seen that hymn to Roman-era heroism, with its visual nod to ''Triumph of the Will.'' But given the style world's growing fascination with emblems of force and domination, his decor seems prescient.

title: Grete Waitz Looks Back On a Fan's Embarrassment
description: To the Editor:

title: From a Soviet Era That Dared to Defy The Ruling Dogma
description: SYNONYMOUS with a season of worldwide cinematic upheaval, the era known as the Sixties saw new waves pound the shore from Japan to Brazil to Czechoslovakia. In the Soviet Union, however, the arrival of a Sixties cinema was complicated by an additional climactic shift known as the Thaw. Roughly coinciding with the reign of Nikita Khrushchev, this was the period of de-Stalinization, the Space Race and the Berlin Wall.

title: Waiting For the Other Shoe To Drop
description: AS the nation waits to hear exactly what the American people said when they ''spoke'' last Tuesday, investors' voices are coming in loud and clear. Stocks tumbled at the end of last week as the whiff of a constitutional crisis began wafting out of South Florida. The Nasdaq lost 12.2 percent of its value for the week, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 2 percent. The Nasdaq is down 25.6 percent this year.

title: Science Fiction
description: While scientists debate the existence of even microscopic life on Mars, science fiction writers interested in extraterrestrial intelligence are turning to Jupiter. In their ambitious and entertaining novel WHEELERS (Aspect/Warner, $24.95), Ian Stewart and Jack Cohen imagine an advanced alien civilization on the fifth planet from the sun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITMORE, LINDA
description: WHITMORE-Linda. November 10, 2000, at 52 years of age. Loving wife of Michael. Dear sister of Wendy, Polly, Carl, Wayne and Bill. Special friend to many. For more information contact A.J. Desmond & Sons Funeral Home, 248-362-2500. Memorial tributes to U of M Comprehensive Cancer Center, 101 Simpson Drive, Ann Arbor, MI 48109.

title: New Web Site Offers Discounts on 6 Airlines
description: Hotwire.com, a Web site selling discounted airline tickets, went into full operation late last month. The site is designed for vacation travelers, with the focus on price rather than departure time.

title: More Than a Mountain
description: THE ski season of 1999-2000, marked by scant snowfall, warm temperatures, Y2K jitters and ever-weakening European currencies against the dollar, was one that many North American winter resort operators would prefer to forget. Ski areas in Colorado reported a drop of roughly 5 percent in visits from the previous season (which itself had been down about 5 percent from 1997-98). Vail Resorts collected $13 million on a ''reduced skier day'' insurance policy when it failed to achieve seasonal attendance goals last season. In Utah, Park City Mountain Resort had to cancel an annual early-season World Cup ski race. In the East, where areas had to rely almost entirely on man-made snow well into January, skier-snowboarder visits were down by about 2 percent, according to figures from the National Ski Areas Association. Last season's total of skier and snowboarder visits in the United States of 52.2 million was slightly higher than the previous season, but down from 54 million in the 1997-98 season; snowboarding accounted for 26 percent of those visits last season.

title: The Big Business To Be Found in Toys
description: IN a corporate conference room in Plainview, a pair of middle-age executives demonstrate remote-controlled robots with glee; both acknowledge they're lucky to be playing with toys and calling it work.

title: American Voices: Divided on Nov. 7, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUSSEM, MAX (MOTLE)
description: JUSSEM-Max (Motle). On November 9th., 92 years old, born in Poland. Beloved husband of the late Sonia. Survived by sister-inlaw, Lola Jusem of Israel; loving nieces, Sandy Levy of Israel and Pearl Jusem of Cambridge, Mass., and their families. Also survived by beloved companion, Molly Nussbaum, and her children and grandchildren. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Service Sunday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Hold On a Femtosecond . . .
description: GO slow and steady, Aesop preached, and you will win the race.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Mindless Movies for Overworked Brains
description: A group of New York intellectuals last weekend cheered the crime-fighting babes from the Townsend Detective Agency as they battled evil forces with gravity-defying martial arts and fabulous clothes.

title: The Election; Looking for Democracy And Finding, Uh, Florida
description: THIS week, with the future of the free world up for grabs, it is once again clear that Florida -- America's sunny Margaritaville of drifters, grifters and politically active lap-dancers -- has something of a credibility problem when it comes to the heavy lifting of democracy.

title: Nina Sanders, Michael Henry
description: Nina Ellen Sanders, a psychotherapist, and Dr. Michael Walter Henry, an internist, are to be married today at the Picnic House in Prospect Park in Brooklyn. Lisel Burns, the leader of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, is to officiate.

title: Weddings on the Web
description: Marriages on ship are romantic, but what about friends and family left on shore? The Golden Princess, the 2,600-passenger ship scheduled to make its debut in May, will let anyone with Internet access share the joy -- through images (refreshed every minute) from the wedding chapel. Couples must give their permission; (800) 774-6237.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 15 about amateur astronomers in the city misstated the number of asteroids spotted by Eileen Thomas of Ward Hill, Staten Island. She says she has seen at least a dozen, not hundreds. The article also misstated the time at which Ms. Thomas saw the comet Linear. It was late July, not August.

title: Home, Briefcase and Foie Gras in Hand
description: YOU'RE at the station, not yet aboard your bus or train. You've spent an especially interminable day at the office. You're hungry.

title: Some Say They Were Denied a Chance to Vote
description: A dozen witnesses testified about voting irregularities in this city's Little Haiti neighborhood today before a panel of civil rights and election law experts convened by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: Off to the Races
description: The roar of high-revving engines. The scent of burning rubber. The thrill of checking daily net asset values. The Conseco StockCar Stocks Index fund promises to deliver at least the last of those experiences by holding shares in more than 50 companies that sponsor, broadcast or otherwise profit from Nascar races.

title: Princeton Comeback Ends Yale Hopes for Ivy Repeat
description: Two improbable plays with less than a minute remaining -- the last a desperation pass into the end zone -- enabled Princeton to post a 19-14 upset victory over Yale this afternoon, dashing any hopes the Bulldogs had of repeating as Ivy League co-champions.

title: Corrections
description: A roundup of ideas last Sunday for generating voter turnout misspelled the surname of one contributor, a museum exhibition designer. He is Ralph Appelbaum, not Applebaum.

title: In Some Areas, the G.O.P. Has No Objections to Hand Counts
description: Where you stand on the issue of whether ballots in disputed elections should be recounted by hand, it seems, may depend on where you stand in the vote count.

title: MORE ON THE VOTES
description: IN BUSH COUNTRY -- In Austin, Tex., Gov. George W. Bush avoided the fray, projecting an image of assurance and ease. PAGE 22

title: Aimee Adler, Michael Tobman
description: Aimee Michelle Adler, the daughter of Renee and Roger Adler of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Michael Dana Tobman, a son of Joyce and Harold Tobman, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik will officiate at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Rap With Its 'Props' Under Glass. Why Not?
description: THE novelist Ishmael Reed once wrote about something called the Center for Art Detention. It was a peculiar institution, an unhip and unscrupulous place filled with invaluable relics looted from sacred sites around the world. Its curator was an incorrigible crook (and former police commissioner) named Biff Musclewhite, who harbored a murderous hatred of jazz. And its Manhattan headquarters happened to be at 82nd Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/South Amboy, N.J.; A Blue-Collar Town Making a Comeback
description: WHEN the 5:05 a.m. New Jersey Transit train rumbles through South Amboy, N.J., on its way to Penn Station in New York, it rattles the windows of the five apartments above the Landmark Tavern and Cafe. ''We don't charge our tenants for the wake-up call,'' the tavern owner, Robert Heiser, said. Just five feet from the tracks, the building is a symbol of the 1.8-square-mile city's bustling past and its ongoing revitalization.

title: Nancy Greenwald, David Scher
description: Nancy Beth Greenwald, a daughter of Renee and Stuart M. Greenwald of Middletown, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. David Marx Scher, the son of Nancy and Norman H. Scher of South Orange, N.J. Rabbi Barry H. Greene officiated at the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, N.J.

title: Show and Sell: The Art of the Craft Fair
description: WEEKEND after weekend, the tents spring up at festivals and fairs, covering main streets and town squares like portable malls. Under each stretch of canvas, there's a different open air boutique: funky jewelry, beer bottle wind chimes, asymmetrical pottery, hand-blown glass, carved woods. Available are Santa Clauses whittled by Jim Calkins, a forensic scientist by trade and wood carver by passion and whimsical goblets created when Barry Lafler, a scientific glass blower, lets his imagination soar.

title: Artistic Inspiration, Human or Divine
description: WHAT makes a building feel sacred? With no background in the religion's laws or customs, a Baptist can visit a Buddhist temple and be touched by a sculpture's spiritual smile. A Methodist can grasp the devotion behind each calligraphic stroke on a Muslim mosque. A Roman Catholic can sit in a Jewish sanctuary, gaze at the doors of the ark, and feel surrounded by strength and peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERER, JULES S.
description: SCHERER-Jules S. On November 8, 2000 at the age of 92. Beloved husband of Helen. Cherished father of Susan and Edward and father in law of Cheryl. Proud grandfather of Beth and Peter. Well known trade-paper publisher. Interment private.

title: A Collection That Could Fill In a Museum's Gaps
description: AS new museum buildings proliferate around the world, an embarrassing moment has become an all too predictable rite of passage: the collection that seemed just fine crowded together in the old quarters is suddenly, in the cold light of expansive space, exposed as lamentably thin and riddled with holes. It is happening to the new Tate Modern in London, and it happened to the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art when it opened its new $63 million headquarters five years ago.

title: The Pictures; The Lot
description: Hollywood's great studio lots -- those walled fortresses where the secrets of filmmaking were kept hidden behind stucco walls -- are vanishing. Most of the city's sound stages have been shut down, as studios pack up for outer suburbs like Culver City and Burbank. The one true exception is Paramount Pictures, which has occupied the same space since 1926.

title: The Election: Chaos Theory; How to Stop Worrying and Love the Limbo
description: ELECTION Day has always had an almost toaster-like nature to it: we pull a lever today, and a just-elected official pops up tomorrow to thank us, no matter how we voted. And then we move on, content in knowing that for better or worse, the fate of the country is in somebody else's hands. But instead of seeing a president-elect stride onto the public stage to choke up about this great republic of ours on Tuesday night, we have watched day after day as sleep-deprived people named William Daley and Karl Rove drone on about a campaign that apparently hasn't ended.

title: How High School Students Did on the Regents Exams
description: For the first time since it required tougher English tests for high school graduation, the State Board of Regents has released scores that capture the progress of an entire class.

title: The Transformation of AT&T
description: To the Editor:

title: Academic Tune-Ups For Top Executives
description: These days it seems that nearly every young person wants to be in business. Chief executives are viewed as rock stars, and master's degrees in business administration are badges of honor. Even people with no previous business knowledge are enrolling in business courses to learn about this suddenly ''in'' world.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-12-00; The Dream Factory
description: One of my favorite movies is the James Mason-Judy Garland version of ''A Star Is Born.'' It's three hours long, and detailed, and James Mason is about as dignified and yet delicate in his characterization of Norman Maine as I think you could get. It is a perfect performance, lent a great deal of poignancy, of course, by our knowledge of Judy Garland's own alcoholism and past marriage woes with an industry vet, the director Vincente Minnelli. For a movie made in the 50's, ''A Star is Born'' doesn't pull too many punches. There is even a scene in which Norman Maine tries to bribe a matre d'htel into procuring an innocent starlet for him. Jack Carson, a studio publicist, hates Norman Maine, and you can see why he gives in to the temptation to destroy him. It's a great movie and just about as much as I will ever want to know about Hollywood.

title: Immigrants Work in Parlors Offering More Than Massages
description: On the outside, they look like beauty salons and barbershops staffed by hardworking immigrants. But behind the storefront, young Chinese women, some in their teens, are offering something else entirely.

title: Different Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicling a Street of Diminished Expectations
description: I GROANED when, driving through Hollywood a month ago, I saw billboards for two new attempts to skewer the rich and powerful on Wall Street: ''Bull,'' the TNT melodrama, and ''The Street,'' the sassy offering from Fox.

title: The Ex Files
description: IN 1992, when William Smith and Bonni Nieschawer married in Brooklyn, it seemed like every guest was talking about the same thing: the fact that the bridegroom's ex-wife was in attendance. At the time, her presence seemed groundbreaking, and possibly life threatening. Was she invited? Was she heartbroken? Was she armed?

title: Huge Rock Concert Set For Rio de Janeiro Area
description: The Rock in Rio Festival, to be held in a Rio de Janeiro suburb, Barra da Tijuca, Jan. 12 to 21, is expected to attract an estimated 1.5 million people, which, say the festival's organizers, would make it one of the biggest rock concerts in the world.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: THEATER; A Prolific Wit With A Low Profile
description: SHE is the most intimate and allusive of artists, this distinctly American, Southern-born wit with soul, given to wild imaginings rooted in the everyday.

Flickinger of Buffalo. The Rev. Peter Stimpson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Princeton University Chapel.
