title: Vote in U.S. Senate Race Followed 12-Year Trend
description: Since 1988, Democratic candidates for United States Senate in New Jersey have received 50 percent to 54 percent of the vote, while support for Republican Senate candidates has ranged from 43 percent to 47 percent. This year was no exception.

title: A Higher Pension Ceiling
description: Some high-income taxpayers with retirement plans can soon receive more benefits because of inflation.

title: Let the Courts Decide
description: At a time when the nation is suspended in unprecedented doubt over just whom it has elected as its next president, we find ourselves besieged by competing slogans and maxims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, ESTHER
description: STONE-Esther. Beloved and wise friend, graced with extraordinary dignity, wit and kindness. Brilliant and devoted partner to her late husband, journalist I.F. Stone. We will always miss your luminous countenance and understanding spirit. Tova, Walter, Daniel, David and Rebecca Reich

title: Fugu Menu
description: For those who like to live dangerously, Kozue in the Park Hyatt in Tokyo has an all-fugu menu through March. Fugu, or blowfish, has toxic glands; it can be prepared only by specially licensed chefs, like Kenichiro Ooe of Kozue. The menu ($170, at 110 yen to the dollar) includes blowfish porridge and carpaccio. Aficionados say fugu produces a mellow, tingling feeling -- as may Kozue's 40th-floor views; (81-3) 5322-1234, fax (81-3) 5323-3427. JOSEPH SIANO

title: Fans Are Drawn to See the Wrong No. 33 Play
description: Johnny Newman cannot pinpoint whether it was 1989 or 1990, but he does recall that Hakeem Olajuwon came to New York for a regular-season game during a four- or five-game tear across the National Basketball Association when almost nobody could stop him, Newman said.

title: Unknown From Japan Stands in Woods's Way
description: Earlier this week, Hidemichi Tanaka was asked how it felt to be in the same field with Tiger Woods.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Transforming a Plant From Hydrox to High Tech
description: IN a sense, the plan is to switch from bites to bytes, from cookies (edible) to cookies (electronic).

title: Avant-Garde Cultural Center Isn't Quite Home Free Yet
description: ABC No Rio, the cultural center known for avant-garde art exhibitions and raucous punk-rock shows, has been trying to hang on to its home on the Lower East Side. Now it has met with an unexpected hurdle.

title: Mary Alice Kellogg, David Currier
description: Mary Alice Kellogg and David Owen Currier were married yesterday at the Essex House in New York. Tom Radow, the associate village justice of Atlantic Beach, N.Y., officiated with Dana Valery Catalano, a Universal Life minister.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-12-00; What They Were Thinking
description: Garner (far left): ''A bunch of disparate people -- people in television, writers and people in film like myself -- come together once a month over something we're all really excited about: wine. After six courses of fantastic food and an equal number of glasses of wine, we were feeling pretty good. This is the third time I was invited. I couldn't help thinking, What am I doing here? Because I don't know that much about wine. For those guys, it's their passion and their hobby. For me, it's all about indulgence. The best part is it gives us an opportunity to argue about something other than the movie business.''

title: Short on Time and Yardage, Columbia Falls to Cornell
description: Trailing Cornell by 4 points late in the fourth quarter at Baker Field yesterday, Columbia drove 60 yards in 30 seconds. They needed 62.

title: Claudia Rodriguez, Peter Tirana
description: Claudia Patricia Rodriguez, a daughter of Maria Cecilia Ochoa de Rodriguez and Ernesto Rodriguez-Medina of Bogota, Colombia, was married there on Tuesday to Peter Scatcherd Tirana, the son of Patty M. Auchincloss of Riverside, Conn., and Turhan Tirana of Stamford, Conn.

title: Beating Injury, Fatigue And a Top-Flight Team
description: Through their first six games the Knicks looked like the worst defensive team Coach Jeff Van Gundy had ever put on the floor. Small and not exceptionally tough, they had been crushed by two offenses, one of which is mediocre at best. So what transpired last night was totally unexpected.

title: Endpaper; The Pool
description: ''Hollywood pools are different from pools in the rest of America,'' the photographer Lauren Greenfield says. ''Everyone in L.A. has his own pool, and it's very important to certain kinds of people in L.A. that their pools reflect their personalities.'' Above, Peter Guber, a former chairman of Columbia Pictures, and his wife, Tara Lynda Guber, relax beside the pool behind their sprawling home, which took four years to build. Their sons, Sam and Jackson, play behind them. Of her pool, Tara Lynda Guber says: ''It has a certain energy. It's good for my body and my spirit.'' Peter Guber adds, ''It's the part of our house that makes us all children again.''

title: Lily Tomlin Resumes Her 'Search' on Broadway
description: IT was during the summer of 1999 that Lily Tomlin suddenly found herself time-traveling again. The occasion was a workshop at the University of Southern California, during which she was coaxed by a group of students into performing a snippet of ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe,'' the one-woman show for which Ms. Tomlin won a Tony Award in 1986. ''They responded immediately,'' she said, nibbling on a plate of bacon at Sardi's. ''And I felt so great doing it.''

title: Habitats/Bay Ridge, Brooklyn; A Recipe for Renting: Let 'Em Eat Cake
description: ON impulse one day, Amanda Mendoza called the landlord of her tiny one-bedroom apartment on the Upper East Side and asked what it would take to get out of her lease. The answer was hardly a surprise: not much at all.

title: Carolyn Lese, Steven Goldberg
description: Carolyn Lese, the daughter of Linda Lese and John H. Lese of Rye, N.Y., is to be married this evening to Steven Howard Goldberg, the son of Karen Lasker Goldberg and Dr. Joel S. Goldberg of Highland Park, Ill. Rabbi Daniel Wolk is to officiate at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Where Slaves Once Lived, A Museum Will Rise
description: If two men flying over Brooklyn in 1968 had not noticed four dilapidated frame farmhouses nestled behind housing projects, the hamlet of Weeksville might have sunk into obscurity along with the scores of towns that once dotted the landscape.

title: The Pictures; The Contributors
description: Gueorgui Pinkhassov

title: Narrow Training
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-12-00: ShopTalk; The Art of the Pitch
description: In the space of three months last summer, two unemployed screenwriters, David Garrett and Jason Ward, went from being just about broke to being millionaires and minor Hollywood legends. On the strength of what is now recognized as a single perfectly honed pitch, they managed to sell a screenplay they'd worked on for 10 days -- Corky,'' a comedy about the son of a mob boss who infiltrates the F.B.I. -- to Disney's Touchstone Pictures, and went on to sign film and television deals worth $3 million. (''Corky,'' starring Chris Kattan of ''Saturday Night Live,'' recently wrapped; it is scheduled for release next year.) Herewith, these two young masters of their five-minute art form share their most valuable trade secrets: what to say, how to say it and what never to say under any circumstances when pitching a film to a studio executive.

title: When the Apple Was a Pip
description: NEW York: A City Is Born, 1609-1825'' is a documentary on New York history, beginning with Henry Hudson's exploration of the river that bears his name. Historians and writers like E. L. Doctorow and Mike Wallace are on the video, a 45-minute adaptation of ''New York: A Documentary Film,'' the PBS series.

title: Canada's 'Gentle Giants' Await Vanishing Winter
description: Polar bears, their white coats tinged with yellow after a summer of fasting on the tundra, are gathering here on the western shores of the Hudson Bay, waiting for sea ice that once again will free them from land, allowing them to hunt seals.

title: Laura Eng, Patrick Yeu
description: Laura Victoria Eng and Patrick Han Yeu were married yesterday by the Rev. Wayne Plumstead at the Park United Methodist Church in Bloomfield, N.J.

title: Flexing in Tarrytown: A Sea of Pecs and Delts
description: IT was a typical Saturday morning in Tarrytown: Smart-looking couples pushed baby strollers toward brunch destinations; Starbucks-fueled Manhattanites in Gore-Tex and sunglasses wandered into antique stores.

title: Nice House. Great Neighborhood. But, Honey, It Has Only a 3-Car Garage.
description: WANT a quick way to upset auto executives? Just ask how the latest sport utility behemoth contributes to air pollution and global warming. They have a favorite riposte, though: Look how big the luxury houses are getting these days.

description: Weeks

title: Corrections
description: A Notebook article in the sports pages last Sunday, about the National Football League, misstated the position played by Brian Urlacher of the Chicago Bears. He is a linebacker, not a running back.

title: President Tilden? No, but Almost, in Another Vote That Dragged On
description: The election was expected to be close, as recent elections had tended to be. Still, everyone thought it would be decided on election night, not excruciating months later. No one anticipated that it would go down in history not for who won, but for how he won.

title: Kai Singer, Christopher Falkenberg
description: Kai Beth Singer, the daughter of Varda Singer and Dr. Elliot Roy Singer of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married last evening to Christopher Edward Falkenberg, the son of Patricia and Edward Falkenberg of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein officiated at Cipriani 42nd Street in Manhattan.

title: Financial Aid Free-For-All As Students and Colleges Seek Deals
description: When Simon Kendall was applying to college four years ago, he set his sights on a small liberal arts college in the Middle Atlantic region knowing that cost would be a factor in his decision. Haverford College was his first choice, but, like other elite private colleges, it offers financial aid only on the basis of a family's ''demonstrated need.''

title: Sharks Hand the Islanders A Second Straight Shutout
description: Just a few days ago, the Islanders were on a giddy high, sharing first place in their division for the first time in five years.

title: A Star Is Born
description: HENRY NORRIS RUSSELL

title: League to Fine Policy In Salary-Cap Dispute
description: One of the most contentious chapters in recent National Football League history could come to a close as early as this week. Barring any last-minute changes, Carmen Policy, the former San Francisco 49ers general manager who was accused of violating the league's salary-cap rules, will pay a $400,000 fine, team owners and executives have said. The 49ers will forfeit third- and fifth-round picks in a future draft and pay a fine of $600,000 to $1 million .

title: The Election; Any Votes for Bushberg? Goreville?
description: Talk about strange electoral results.

title: Patient Hands Guide the Youngest Athletes
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom has it that most adults would rather do anything than hang out with a bunch of 8-year-olds on a Saturday afternoon. Then why is it, on a Long Island baseball diamond, on a New Jersey ice rink, in a Connecticut gymnasium or in a Westchester County park, there are countless grown-ups screaming, cheering, goading, encouraging and teaching junior Derek Jeters, Wayne Gretskys and Chamique Holdsclaws?

title: Dad and Baby On the Town Is Not So Easy
description: FOR the relatively immobile first months of human life, no accessory is quite as indispensable as an infant car seat. So whenever I carry my 6-month-old daughter in her car seat, I measure Long Island's entertainment value as if I have eyes on my knees. A simple guideline prevails: life must be as intriguing for her down there as it is for me up here.

title: Pay Ball! Baseball's New Season
description: YOU probably believe that Hank Aaron hit more home runs than any other player in major-league baseball history. You might also be under the impression that Aaron holds the record for runs batted in and that Detroit's Ty Cobb scored more runs than any other player.

title: Marbury Puts on a Show to Overshadow Ewing
description: For 29 minutes today, Stephon Marbury flew with the force of a tornado, cutting a determined path of destruction to the basket, razing two All-Stars and turning sentiment to his side.

title: A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Fly-Fisherman: Mayhem Off Montauk
description: None of us was quite sure what to expect when James Prosek, the precocious artist identified as a ''national treasure'' by Tom Brokaw, and hailed by many as the ''heir to Audubon,'' agreed to come saltwater fly-fishing with us during the annual east end of Long Island Octoberfest of bluefish, striped bass and false albacore.

title: Sick Schools, Sick Students
description: AIR quality problems, caused by mold and fungus and triggered by sources as seemingly innocuous as leaking roofs and high humidity, are threatening many of the state's schools and the health of students and teachers.

title: With Capital In Gridlock, It's Back To the Lab
description: AS the lawyers fulminate and election returns remain in limbo, the one sure winner is President-elect Pyrrhus. In case you forgot, this King of Epirus beat the Romans in 279 B.C., but at a huge cost.

title: Sandra Hodor, Alexander Southwell
description: Sandra Thurston Hodor, the daughter of Zena and Howard Hodor of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., was married there last evening to Alexander Henningsen Southwell, the son of Nancy Henningsen of Bethesda, Md., and Michael Southwell of Bloomingdale, N.J. Rabbi Michael Matuson officiated at the Plantation Beach Club.

title: YONKERS: ARRESTS MADE IN GROCERY HOLDUP
description: Four men have been charged with holding up a Key Foods supermarket in Yonkers on Monday morning as the store was opening, and the police said they had recovered $698 in cash and $700 in food stamps that were taken from the store. The suspects fled the supermarket on Bronx River Road in a black BMW, which was then involved in a hit-and-run accident with another car. No injuries were reported. Elsa Brenner

title: Pinter's Timeless 'Betrayal,' in More Welcoming Times
description: AFTER his first three full-length plays -- comedies of menace that take place in raffish English households -- Harold Pinter wrote ''Old Times,'' ''No Man's Land'' and ''Betrayal.'' Each trio of plays comprises a kind of trilogy, unrelated by characters but sharing common textual ground. In the latter three, all written in the 1970's, events take place in posh environments representing a cultural rise to a world of art and literature. In varying degrees, these are comedies of manners. The principal themes are time, love, betrayal and the unreliability of memory. At various points, memory wavers and seems to contradict the reality of a remembered situation.

title: Groh Wants Jets to Focus on Tough Challenges Ahead
description: Coach Al Groh made it clear quickly last week that he did not want the Jets to dwell on their loss last Sunday to the Denver Broncos. He made unusually brief remarks to the players Monday morning, then sent them home several hours early. There would be no film review of the loss and, more pointedly, no discussion with reporters about it either.

title: After Cards Are Poked, The Confetti Can Count
description: The leadership of the free world may be decided by chads.

title: Alexandra Bonney, Timothy McAuliffe Jr.
description: Alexandra Helm Bonney, a daughter of Margaret Helm Bonney and Dr. James Kemper Bonney of Norwich, Vt., was married yesterday to E. Timothy McAuliffe Jr., the son of Patricia McAuliffe Jackson of Montecito, Calif., and Mr. McAuliffe of New York. The Rev. Kathryn S. White performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Display Examines Synagogue Design
description: WHEN Temple Israel, a Conservative congregation in White Plains, decided to enlarge its sanctuary, it had to raise millions of dollars. When the Jewish community of Offenbach, Germany, wanted a new building, it didn't have to raise a penny. The 80 synagogues built in Germany since World War II have been financed by the government. Prof. Alfred Jacoby, an architect who practices in Frankfurt, said that the congregations''don't pay a cent.''

title: No Headline

description: Shaken or stirred? Olives or onions? Now, a new question to ask when ordering a martini: Do you want that in a Big Gulp?

description: Did Lizzie Borden murder her father and stepmother with an ax in 1892? A jury acquitted her, but for more than a century some historians have questioned her innocence.

title: Minnesota Town Demanded a Rematch
description: Last year, the 3,100 residents of the unincorporated rural town of St. Augusta in south central Minnesota were deeply worried that the nearby city of St. Cloud might try to annex them. So they decided to incorporate, following the usual annexation defense.

title: At a Political Party, A Host May Be a Candidate
description: Talk magazine's editor, Tina Brown, Miramax's co-chairman, Harvey Weinstein, and Bloomberg News's founder, Michael R. Bloomberg, brought together politics, culture and business on election night. They invited hundreds of their closest friends, from Barbara Walters to Barry Diller, to watch the televised returns at Elaine's restaurant on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Patricia Keightley, Daniel Davidson
description: Patricia Call Keightley, a painter, and Daniel Francis Davidson, a multimedia artist, both of New York, were married on Friday in Las Vegas. The Rev. Jim Hamilton performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Little Church of the West.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with a review of the play ''Modern Orthodox,'' at the Long Wharf Theater, misstated the surname of an actor. He is Michael Goldstrom, as noted in the review, not Goldstein.

title: Renovation Charges In a Condo
description: Q. Last November, our condominium's board decided to undertake a common hallway renovation project and imposed an assessment based on each unit owner's interest in the common elements. In reviewing the condo's financial statement, I noticed that the amount earmarked for the renovation ended up being less than what was originally anticipated. When I asked the managing agent for an explanation, he told me that two unit owners -- the only unit owners on one of the floors -- had decided to opt out of the project and not have their hallway renovated. Can they do this? . . . David H. Olin, Manhattan.

title: The World; Guess Who's Gloating
description: NOTHING warms a non-American heart more than seeing the Sole Remaining Superpower, that swaggering, self-absorbed font of bad food and worse taste, get its comeuppance. So it should be no surprise that the events of last week have parboiled most of the world's cardiovascular plumbing.

title: Assassination Of Palestinian Fuels Fighting In Middle East
description: The commander of Israeli troops in the West Bank said there was a simple goal to the assassination of a gun-wielding local Palestinian leader by helicopter gunship on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARLMUTTER, DR. PAUL
description: PEARLMUTTER-Dr. Paul. Of South Orange, NJ. Devoted husband of Rose. Loving father, brother and grandfather. Call (888) 351-4414 for information.

title: Indonesians Finally See Film Banned 17 Years Ago
description: The line outside the downtown Djakarta Theater started forming two hours before the movie began. Sorta Karama, 40, a nurse, bought her ticket three days in advance and left work early to get a good seat. Bomar Muhaimin, a lawyer, brought his two young children to what he called a ''historic event.''

title: Federal Agency Offers Help
description: THE United States Environmental Protection Agency has developed a program called ''Tools for Schools'' to help schools deal with their air quality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERSTEIN, MARK FILER
description: SILBERSTEIN-Mark Filer, 51, beloved son of Janet F. and the late Leon M. Silberstein, treasured brother of Judy Rosemarin and Jo Ellen Silberstein, adored uncle of Donna Stevens, Julie Rosemarin and David Weinstein and greatuncle of Jonathan and Emily Stevens, died unexpectedly on November 9 2000 in Sarasota, Florida. As a certified geriatric social worker and President of Supportive Senior Services, Tampa, Florida, he was dedicated to helping families cope with the challenges of aging relatives. Mark was a man of extraordinary compassion, gentleness, love, intelligence, insight with a good-hearted sense of humor. His big heart and love of his family made him one in a million. He will be deeply and forever missed by his family, friends, his animals he so dearly loved and the ducks he fed each and every day. Funeral services will be held at ''The Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 76th and Amsterdam Ave, NYC, on November 13 2000 at 12:45pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to ASPCA, Big Brothers of America Association, or the charity of one's choice.

title: Theater for Children, and Sometimes by Children
description: WALLIS GRANAT was impatient. It was her seventh birthday party and after a vigorous, sometimes frenetic session of emcee-led games and dancing on the stage of the Cultural Arts Playhouse in Old Bethpage, she was ready for what had brought her and her friends to the theater: a performance of the ''Mad Monster Party.''

title: Jill Goldstein, Donald Miller
description: Jill Neisa Goldstein, a lawyer, and Dr. Donald Scott Miller, a cardiologist, were married last evening by Rabbi Stanley L. Asekoff at the Crestmont Country Club in West Orange, N.J.

title: American Voices: Divided on Nov. 7, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: A Thanksgiving Feast With a Rainbow of Flavors
description: AT a time when most Americans have seemingly given up on this country's e pluribus unum promise, the British filmmaker Gurinder Chadha brings an unjaundiced eye to the tribulations and victories of a multiracial immigrant nation. Her new film ''What's Cooking?'' succeeds by means of a simple ruse: it substitutes a roasting pan for the proverbial melting pot.

title: The Pictures; The Period Piece
description: Albert and Allen Hughes have a gift for violence -- not dispensing it, but depicting it on the screen. In urban melodramas like ''Menace II Society'' and ''Dead Presidents,'' they have given their shootouts and gang fights an import that makes them more than just rousing action sequences satisfying the blood lust of audiences. The Hugheses are interested in portraying how violence takes a social toll on the perpetrators as well as on the victims; their films should come with an advisory that the physical destruction is suited for adults, full of desperation and pain.

title: Has Nike Found the Springs Missing From Its Steps?
description: IT has been a long time since Nike has been at the top of its game. Now, the company hopes that it has found a way to stimulate the lagging sales of its athletic shoes, and part of the answer, surprisingly, comes from inside the guts of a car.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 29 about the 1960's television show ''The Prisoner'' misspelled the name of the village in Wales where it was filmed. The village is Portmeirion, not Portmerion.

title: Sarah Olivier, David Isenberg
description: Sarah Ann Olivier, a daughter of Bonnie Brae Haddad of Cambridge, Mass., and Donald Olivier of Boston, was married yesterday to David Alan Isenberg, the son of Janet Isenberg of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Pat Isenberg. Susan Anderson, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the Lyman Estate in Waltham, Mass.

title: Doing Good Deeds on College Break
description: What did you do on spring break in college? Build bridges in rural Virginia? Work with a halfway house in Harlem? Learn about agricultural issues in Costa Rica?

title: Chicago Girds for Big Battle Over Its Skyline
description: On a crisp October afternoon, a giant crane ripped into an old brick building on Maxwell Street, once a hive of pushcarts and tenements, now hailed by cultural historians as the birthplace of the electric blues. The demolition crew did not stop to take down the old hand-lettered placards in the windows, advertising ''Stereo Players'' and ''Blues Jazz Gospel.''

title: Patricia Paul, Jeffrey Eilender
description: Patricia Gulbis Paul and Jeffrey Morton Eilender are to be married today by Rabbi David Lincoln at the Down Town Association, a private club in New York.

title: The Pictures; The Fantasy
description: At first glance, this looks like a small band of techno-moderns about to be ridden down by an army of ancients. Actually, it's a troop of mounted stuntmen -- costumed as characters from J. R. R. Tolkien's ''Lord of the Rings'' -- thundering down upon the audience with the clang of armor and the muscular reverberation of horses. The fiction embraces the landscape too, as it always does in the movies. These are the mountains of New Zealand's South Island, but they will pass, in darkened, popcorn-scented theaters, as part of the mythic elsewhere that the movies are always making and remaking. This elsewhere is called Middle-earth. Not that long ago, a movie like ''The Lord of the Rings'' would have been filmed on a sound stage or a back lot. There would have been something faintly ludicrous, something hyperbolic about the way perspective marched in recessional across painted flats toward the far horizon, where peaks rose too pointed, too lofty, too softened by distance. The real outdoors gives verisimilitude to what is inherently, doubly and trebly, false. A colossal landscape -- think of Monument Valley in all those rattling old westerns -- does for the movies what it does to us in real life. It establishes scale. It dwarfs and enlarges what is merely human. It contributes an almost peremptory silence to the near-camera heroics of language and gesture. And when the accents waver, the actors falter and the dialogue sounds like soap opera on stilts, the landscape lends a measure of depth and grandeur, mutely imploring us to ignore the fuss in the foreground. -- Verlyn Klinkenborg

description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/Westchester; County's Office Market Is Exceptionally Strong
description: THE amount of available space in Westchester's office market has hit historic lows so far this year, with leasing up more than 40 percent and very few large blocks of space remaining. Yet with all the good news, some brokers see harbingers of trouble for the county in the not-so-distant future.

title: November 5-11; Making Peace With a War Long Ended
description: It was a banner week for grappling with the legacy of a war that ended more than 50 years ago.

title: A Winter Hideaway High In The Cascades
description: ALL we wanted was a little snow. One too many summery winters in Los Angeles had left my wife, Ruth, and me with a desperate craving for thick turtlenecks and clinking icicles. It was time, we realized, for a trip north somewhere. To a frosty spot cut off from the world by impassable roads and 10-foot snowdrifts. To a place well-stocked with Flexible Flyers and perhaps some sort of nog. A place like Mountain Home Lodge.

title: White House Tries Again to Restore Yosemite
description: Trying to set in motion at last an overhaul of Yosemite National Park, the Clinton administration is preparing to unveil a $343 million plan intended to restore a more natural air to a destination known almost as much for crowding as for its stunning physical grandeur.

title: Nostalgia for Mao
description: To the Editor:

title: A Garbage Dump Grows Into a Park For Nature Lovers
description: WHEN Jay Pitti admires the New York City skyline from the eight-acre Merrick plateau 115 feet above sea level, he is surrounded by a landscape that includes walking paths covered with wildflowers and natural vegetation, two artificial ponds and a windmill. There's no evidence of the landfill that once dominated the property.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANAUER, ETHEL R.
description: HANAUER-Ethel R. At home in Ossining, NY. Beloved mother of William (Alan Stahl) and Richard (Marcia Roseman). Grandmother of David (Diana Pons), Craig and Andrew. Wife of the late Milton L. Hanauer. Retired guidance counselor, biology teacher at Julia Richman H.S. Services at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Gill Lane, Iselin, NJ today at 12 noon. title: The Election: Unsentimental Education; The Ripe Smell of Political Maneuvering
description: BY the morning after, the only ingredient that seemed to be missing from the grisly stew of Election 2000 -- yellow crime scene tape -- was being festooned by the Florida police on the election headquarters in Volusia County as they pursued reports of purloined ballot boxes. It was ruled a false alarm, but this provided small comfort as the frenetic vote recount flayed the nerve endings of a nation.

title: November 5-11; Kursk Suspicions Remain
description: Adding to the Russian Navy's insistence that a foreign submarine, not a drifting World War II mine or a torpedo-room explosion, sank the submarine Kursk and its 118 sailors in August, Deputy Prime Minister Ilya Klebanov said divers and mini-subs trying to remove the bodies of the dead had found a deep dent and long scratches on the Kursk's bow ''which could have occurred from a blow and nothing else.'' Final proof, he said, awaits the lifting of the giant sub from the Barents Sea floor next summer.

Desmond of Dallas. The Rev. Keith Fennessy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral in New York. Msgr. Earl Provenza, the bride's great-uncle, took part in it.

A juggler unlike any other, he draws inspiration from environmental elements: herons, tree stumps, even the ferns that grow naturally in circular clumps on his property. ''They spark the ideas and give impetus for my works,'' he said.
