Grandmother of Michael, Elizabeth, Patricia and Daniel Dugan, and Joshua and Rebecca Steffen. Great-grandmother of Meghan and Kathleen Grigoleit, and Erin and Allyson Dugan. Funeral services will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice. For more information contact Demaine Funeral Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEFSBERG, VALERIE
description: JOSEFSBERG-Valerie. Of Ridgewood, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Bernard Josefsberg and Henrietta Goldstein. Loving grandmother of Lily, Alison, Daniel and Nathalie. Graveside service at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ, on Sunday at 2 PM. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to a favorite charity. For information ''Wien & Wien,'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: American Voices: Divided on Nov. 7, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Seeks to Regulate Common Gas to Clean Air
description: President Clinton called today for new federal regulations limiting power plants' emissions of carbon dioxide, a gas thought to cause global climate change, through a system similar to the rules now in place for pollutants that cause smog and acid rain.

title: Creating a Better Sales Force
description: AT the new Container Store in White Plains, Jodi Bleakley runs from aisle to aisle filling an order.

title: The Pictures; A documentary album of Hollywood and beyond.
description: In 1960, the Magnum photographic agency sent nine of the top photographers in the world to shoot, exclusively, the making of ''The Misfits.'' Magnum struck a deal with the filmmakers, unusual even then: every 15 days the agency would send a pair of photographers, Henri Cartier-Bresson and Inge Morath or Dennis Stock and Bruce Davidson, among others, to document the entire shooting of the movie. The film, a modern western written by Arthur Miller and directed by John Huston, was set in and around Reno, Nev., and starred Marilyn Monroe, Clark Gable and Montgomery Clift. It was a troubled set: Monroe and Miller, who wrote the script for Monroe, then his wife, were teetering on the edge of divorce; Gable was severely depleted by the desert heat and died shortly after the movie was completed; and Huston was constantly frustrated by Monroe, who was chronically late and had to be hospitalized during the production.

title: Limbo Wasn't Just a National Condition
description: ONE oddity of Election Night 2000 -- some would call it a relief -- was that the four men who battered our eardrums in their quests for the presidency and vice presidency fell abruptly silent.

title: Europeans Set New Schedule To Join Union
description: For the countries vying to join the European Union, the first week of November has become a time of anticipation and anxiety as they await their annual report cards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, REVEREND LAWRENCE BERNARD, S.J.
description: HILL-Reverend Lawrence Bernard, S.J. Beloved brother of Evelyn Bielfeld of Port Washington, NY. Reposing at Murray Weigel Hall, Jesuit Chapel, 515 East Fordham Road. Visitation Monday, 1011:30 AM. Mass of Christian Burial, Murray Weigel Hall, Jesuit Chapel, Monday, 11:30 AM, and burial Tuesday, 1:30 PM.

title: Food Havens for Commuters Spell Treasures to Take Home
description: YOU'RE at the station, not yet aboard your bus or train. You've spent an especially interminable day at the office. You're hungry.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about savings accounts and other investment alternatives to stocks misspelled the given name of the chief executive of ING Direct, a new Internet bank that offers such an account. He is Arkadi Kuhlmann, not Arcadi.

title: Tired Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable-Car Fire Kills 170 Skiers Trapped In Austrian Tunnel
description: At least 170 people were killed early this morning above the Alpine village of Kaprun, near Salzburg, when the cable car they were taking to a glacier ski run stalled inside a mountain tunnel and burst into flames, the provincial governor said.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE HOUSE OF GUCCI

title: Streetscapes/220 West 57th Street; Civil Engineers' 1897 Clubhouse, in French Gothic
description: ALTHOUGH the American Society of Civil Engineers left 220 West 57th Street more than 80 years ago, the clubhouse's delicate French Gothic facade has survived above a succession of storefronts. Now Lee's Art Shop, the longtime store tenant, is trying both to restore some of the 1897 building's hidden glory and to bring shoppers to the upper levels, which lie largely fallow.

title: Another Tradition: Eating Out on Tuesdays
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COURTNEY, MARY C.
description: COURTNEY-Mary C. On November 10, 2000. Beloved mother of Jim, Peggy, Theresa, and Bill, loved mother-in-law of Jane. Cherished grandmother, and stand-in mother on dear Dorothy's untimely death of Dermott, Clare, Susan, and Mary; treasured grandmother of Jennifer, Stacey and Stephanie. Reposing at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave., NYC, Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, at Our Lady of Good Counsel Church, where she and her dear departed P.J. were married 73 years ago. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: The Clouds of Technology and Politics
description: Against a backdrop of political gridlock welcomed by no one on Wall Street, stocks fell broadly last week as the market absorbed yet another series of unnerving developments in high technology.

title: Design Firm Moves To New Rochelle
description: For Nic and Shannon Neumann, originally from Stuttgart, Germany, moving their interior design business from San Francisco to New York this year brought them closer to home in many ways.

title: Pull Weeds, Start Bulbs
description: Continue to pull cool-season weeds so they can't establish themselves. Be careful not to throw weeds that have gone to seed on a compost pile.

title: November 5-11; Putting Worries in Perspective
description: Investors got a little worried about the presidential election and a lot worried about an apparent slowdown in information technology spending, sending stocks to one of their worst weeks since their April meltdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONNELL, JOYCE
description: McDONNELL-Joyce on November 9, 2000. A pioneer in service to the travel and tourism industry by major public relations firms, died at Sloan-Kettering Hospital of complications following a brief illness. Mrs. McDonnell was known professionally as Joyce M. Martin. Beloved wife of the late Peter J. McDonnell. Loving mother of Charles Bowden, step mother to Regina Hayes, Christine Shaneyfelt, Mary McDonnell, William McDonnell and step grandmother of five. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St Sunday 7-9pm and Monday 2-5 & 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, 110-06 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, Tuesday 11am.

title: Just Say Ah and Spray
description: It's the Binaca school of holistic medicine. Oral sprays by Sprayology, sold at sleek shopping meccas like Ad Hoc and Takashimaya, are advertised as alleviating symptoms of jet lag, stress and P.M.S., among other conditions, with homeopathic and other natural ingredients meant to be spritzed under the tongue three times a day. City Life Detoxer ($24) contains a type of mercury and is advertised as a kidney detoxifier. BrainPower ($32) contains ginkgo biloba and amino acids. And StressLess ($24), which purports to decrease anxiety, contains herbs like Hyoscyamus niger, better known as stinking nightshade. (Interestingly, it tastes like a strong martini.)

title: Beyond Dark Glasses
description: COOL RULES Anatomy of an Attitude. By Dick Pountain and David Robins. Illustrated. 190 pp. St. Paul: Reaktion Books/Consortium Book Sales and Distribution. Paper, $19.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOVILLE, LAURA RICHARDSON
description: SCOVILLE-Laura Richardson, 93, on November 6, 2000, in Bennington. Survived by daughters, Virginia S. Sandy and Sally Scoville and three grandchildren.

title: Not the Bronx, but in Its Spirit
description: THE following concert program is rated PG 13: it contains 17 brawny guys with bare arms, pummeling oil drums in violent rhythms, with pickaxes. Although there is no profanity (unless it's in French) one cannot ignore the yelling, or the smashing oil cans. Earplugs are available to the audience at no charge.

title: Pines, Yes. Barren, Hardly.
description: ENDLESS, eerie stillness, almost thick. It's over a million acres -- no wonder it has its own temperature, air pressure, water table, vegetation, fragility, character. In the nation's most densely populated state, we saw no one, no house, no car, for two hours, and almost no one for two hours after that. The Pine Barrens are a different world, and you don't need a passport.

title: A Gathering of Dancers At a Newtown School
description: FROM Hartford to Greenwich, Connecticut is flush with contra and traditional country dance groups. The Nomad Festival of Traditional Music, Art, and Dance in Newtown, however, is the only annual event in the state where dancers convene en masse.

title: Good as Gold Used to Be
description: THE POWER OF GOLD The History of an Obsession. By Peter L. Bernstein. 432 pp. New York: John Wiley & Sons. $27.95.

title: Sports of The Times; Woods Needs the Tour Just as It Needs Him
description: AT the Andersen Consulting Match-Play tournament, which inaugurated the 1999 World Golf Championships series, Tiger Woods was losing a quarterfinal match on Friday to Jeff Maggert. In the gallery at the La Costa Resort and Spa in the soft sun of Southern California, a voice pleaded for Woods to rally.

title: A Land in Exile From Itself
description: UPSIDE DOWN A Primer for the Looking-Glass World. By Eduardo Galeano. Translated by Mark Fried. Illustrated. 358 pp. New York: Metropolitan Books/ Henry Holt & Company. $24.

title: Tackling Entrenched Corruption in the Turkish Economy
description: A tough-talking former police chief who has become interior minister and a new banking regulator have opened an ambitious battle against corruption in a country long inured to it, even daring to arrest the nephew of a powerful Turkish politician.

title: The Pictures; The Makeover
description: Perfecting the perfect house for 'My Big Fat Greek Wedding.'

title: Law Firm's Expansion Will Add 60 Lawyers
description: Wilson Elser Moskowitz Edelman & Dicker, which was ranked 58th out of the nation's 250 largest law firms last year by the National Law Journal, plans to expand its Westchester office from 40 lawyers to more than 100 by early next year with a move to Gannett Drive in Harrison. The Manhattan-based firm has 15 offices nationwide. Its Westchester office, now in White Plains, specializes in commercial litigation, zoning and municipal law, bankruptcy and real estate.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER EAST SIDE

title: For Those Who Watch as Well as Those Who Dance
description: THE history of modern dance in New York City has been defined in part by the theaters that welcomed that unruly, impoverished art form onto their stages. Talent was nurtured in such homes -- often in universities, schools and churches -- for there choreographers could afford to make mistakes and grow, along with their audiences.

title: A Misguided Pornography Bill
description: A handful of Republican lawmakers led by Senator John McCain of Arizona have been intent on attaching an ill-conceived rider to one of the stalled spending bills that Congress will take up when it returns for its post-election session. The rider would require public schools and libraries receiving federal funds for Internet connections to install computer software that would block access to obscene and other inappropriate Web sites. The White House, which has curiously lost its resolve on this issue, should refuse to approve any bill that contains this rider.

title: The Lure of Experience, Real and Virtual
description: To the Editor:

title: Memoirs: Losing an Accent, Buying a Bar, Judging Graffiti
description: MANY New Yorkers enjoy reading the recollections of others. Here are excerpts from three recent memoirs that recall modern New York history:

title: Tinker? Tailor? Or 'Other'?
description: TAKING a cue from the Internet, I have decided to rewrite my resume. For the years 1990 to 2000, I now list my profession as ''other.''

title: Giving Children a Hall of Fame
description: VICTORIA NESNICK, a schoolteacher for 30 years, could not understand why there was a hall of fame for cockroaches and not one for children. So she quit her job in the Bethpage school district and began working full time on the Kids Hall of Fame.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRYER, RICHARD
description: BRYER-Richard. 35 years ago you went away, my precious Richie. In my heart and thoughts we are always together. Mom.

title: Out of His Skull
description: Head Stories. By William Tester. 197 pp. Louisville, Ky.: Sarabande Books. $19.95.

title: View From Bridge May Be Great, but What's That Noise
description: THIS is the story of how one thing led to another and $50,000 worth of noise-abating plywood nearly blocked a Long Island water view that thousands cherish.

title: Island's Artists Create Art for Wrist or Lapel
description: A POTTER'S work makes its home on a shelf. A painter's work hangs on the wall. But the work of a jewelry maker can turn up anywhere: dangling from the ears of a customer waiting in line at the post office, encircling the wrist of a ticket taker at the local movie theater or adorning the suit jacket of a county district attorney.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAAS, RHODA WILLNER
description: HAAS-Rhoda Willner. It has been ten years. You are in our thoughts with love. Stella, Abbie, Jane and Jay

title: Made for Television
description: To the Editor:

title: Short on Ambience, Long on Skiing
description: OUTSIDE, it was snowing on the French Alps. Inside the King Cafe, a Stetson-wearing singer warmed up on Elvis tunes, then shifted to Don McLean. He sang without an accent about driving his Chevy to the levee, and my sister Marta bet that he was not a native of La Plagne, the resort where we were staying and skiing with some friends.

title: For Martha Stewart, a 152-Acre Estate in Katonah
description: MARTHA STEWART already has homes in Manhattan, Westport, East Hampton and Seal Harbor, Me. Now she has one in Westchester too.

title: With That Autumn Nip in the Air, It's Time to Turn to Pears
description: WITH autumn in full blaze, the suitable fruit choices no longer involve peaches, nectarines, strawberries or cherries. Those demanded summer's warmth. Now is the season for pears, apples, quinces, cranberries and dried fruit.

title: The View From/Mystic; Aquarium's Dolphins Headed for New Waters
description: MISTY and Stormy, the two bottlenose dolphins at Mystic Aquarium, are practically mascots for the attraction. They thrill more than a million visitors each year with their leaps, dives and weird noises. But the dolphins will be leaving within a matter of weeks, and they won't be back for a long time, if ever.

title: Yale Rep Celebrates 75 Years
description: WHEN Benjamin Mordecai says, matter-of-factly, ''You know the major theaters in Connecticut were all founded by graduates of the Yale School of Drama,'' one might pause and ask: Did I know that?

title: BENEFITS
description: Urban League Dinner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRESNOWSKE, JOHN
description: TRESNOWSKE-John. 79, died at his home after a long illness on Tuesday, November 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Valerie, loving father of Charles and Richard. He served in the Armed Forces in Europe from 1942 to 1945. He practiced law for many years and served under three Mayors. He was our guiding light and will be missed by all. Contributions in his memory may be sent to his alma mater Brooklyn Law School.

title: Dreamers of the Golden Dream
description: In the Snow Forest

title: The Election; Who Voted: A Portrait of American Politics, 1976-2000
description: A MAJORITY of women, older voters, Democrats, liberals and black, Hispanic and Asian voters cast their ballots for Al Gore. George W. Bush captured the votes of most men, whites, conservatives, Republicans, Southerners and white Protestants. Ralph Nader, who received 2 percent of the vote, did best among independents, particularly liberal ones, and among young men.

title: What They're Reading
description: John J. Brennan, 46

title: Turn Left at the Shoe Store . . .
description: It's probably safe to say the Internet has saved Americans millions of gallons in fuel, formerly wasted by people driving aimlessly along back roads with directions from someone who never quite figured out the whole left-right thing.

title: Richard K. Webel, a Designer Of Landscapes, Is Dead at 100
description: Richard K. Webel, a landscape architect who designed for museums, colleges, racetracks and corporations, died Nov. 1 at a hospital in Glen Cove, N.Y. He was 100 and lived in Glen Head, N.Y.

title: Allison Mitgang, Edward Silver
description: Allison Heather Mitgang, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Mitgang of Lawrence, N.Y., is to be married today to Edward Lawrence Silver, the son of Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and Mrs. Silver of Manhattan. Rabbi Yeshaya Siff will officiate at the Sands, a beach club and catering business in Atlantic Beach, N.Y.

title: Vote Confusion Mobilizes People to Act
description: Chris Acosta, a Manhattan computer programmer with no particular political experience, was disturbed on Wednesday night when he saw elderly Palm Beach women on television saying they thought they had voted for the wrong presidential candidate.

title: Take One Bus, Add Traffic Cones and Barrels, and It's a Rodeo
description: EVERY May, bus drivers from companies throughout the state hold rodeos: competitions in which they turn, park, back up, stop and maneuver an ordinary passenger bus along an obstacle course, coming within five inches of traffic cones, barrels and tennis balls without touching them.

title: After Construction, Problems in the Air
description: WHEN Ellen Papermaster left a job she loved this summer to assume a similar position as a guidance counselor at Amity Regional High School in Woodbridge, nobody bothered to tell her the building has been plagued with toxigenic mold and fungus after the completion of a major 1995 expansion project.

title: In No Rush, The Irish Grind Way To Victory
description: More than a week ago, Bob Davie handed his Notre Dame players a scouting report with a large color photo on the cover. Chris Hovan, who played for Boston College a year ago, was pictured jubilantly holding aloft a chunk of turf. It was a chunk of Notre Dame's home turf.

title: Rutgers Gives Scare To West Virginia
description: For three quarters, the Rutgers football team, nearing the end of an awful season, played miserably, giving away the ball on three interceptions and two fumbles. Then, in the fourth quarter, the Scarlet Knights, down by 17-0, seemingly took the lead over West Virginia and settled for a 17-17 tie that sent the game into overtime.

title: Article on Teenagers Makes a Complex Look Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurer Runs A Program On Reading
description: FROM the bouncing and hopping going on at the Hudson River Museum on a recent Saturday morning, it seemed as if a particularly energetic nursery school class were in session. A dozen 2-year-olds, accompanied by their parents, sang and danced along with a tape recording of Raffi's ''Shake My Sillies Out,'' listened to Dr. Seuss's ''Foot Book,'' worked with construction paper to make pictures of feet and heard an Eric Carle story called ''From Head to Toe.''

title: Baker Calls for 'No Further Recounts'
description: Excerpts from remarks yesterday by James A. Baker III, the Bush campaign's chief representative in Florida, in Tallahassee, Fla., as recorded by The New York Times.

title: American Voices: Divided on Nov. 7, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Attorney General Investigating The Venerable Players Club
description: The finances of the Players Club, a 112-year-old actors' society on Gramercy Park South, are being investigated by state Attorney General Elliott Spitzer.

title: Liberties; Hail Anhedonia!
description: Sure, we were ambivalent about these guys when we voted. But now we've had a chance to watch them in a state-of-the-art crucible. And I think we've learned something:

title: Jamaica Bay Journal; Despite a Warning, Reeling in the Eels
description: Larry Seaman has called the lawyers, but he doesn't know how he can pay them.

title: Researching, in Style
description: To the Editor:

title: When It Comes to Eating Out, Things Are Looking Up
description: AFTER years of casual experimentation with a controlled substance -- restaurant food -- I became a serious user last spring, when I began reviewing restaurants for The Times's New Jersey section. It wasn't long into this new habit that a suspicion began to sneak up on me: Was it just me, or were New Jersey restaurants a whole lot better than they used to be?

title: After Rough Beginning, Miami Cruises to Victory
description: For most of the first half today, the University of Miami struggled to live up to its lofty status: ranked No. 2 by The Associated Press, No. 3 in the Bowl Championship Series ratings.

title: Mentally Retarded Man Facing Texas Execution Draws Wide Attention
description: Even on death row, Johnny Paul Penry is an outcast, shunned by other inmates because of his mental retardation. Mr. Penry, whose I.Q. has been tested by state authorities at 56, spends his days coloring with crayons and looking at comic books he cannot read, his lawyers say. He says he still believes in Santa Claus. Now, after 20 years on death row, he is scheduled to be executed on Thursday by lethal injection.

title: Gore Gains 33 Votes in Palm Beach County Recount
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla  Vice President Al Gore received a net gain of 33 votes for president in a hand count of one percent of the votes cast in Palm Beach County, a county election official said early Sunday.

title: From Tiny Acorns, Philanthropy's Oak
description: IT doesn't take millions to make a difference. Philanthropists come from all walks of life and all levels of income. Some want to leave a legacy; others want to effect social change. What they share is the spirit of giving.

title: Teachers' Fund Happily Learns a New Math, Plus Tax
description: AT first glance, the genteel pension-fund giant with the monstrously ungainly name seems to have lost ground to upstart rivals.

title: An Artist Inspired By Flowers at Home
description: SOME artists travel far from home in search of the perfect subject.

title: Esther M. Stone, 91, Widow of Journalist
description: Esther M. Stone, the widow of the journalist I. F. Stone, who helped him publish his well-read and iconoclastic weekly newsletter, died on Thursday at a nursing home in Potomac, Md. She was 91.

title: Volusia County Workers Race the Clock to Hand-Count Votes
description: A full day behind schedule, after numerous legal wrangles, serious deliberations over what color pens to use and squabbles over such grave matters as the passing of notes, human hands finally got to work today here in Volusia County.

title: Bulked-up AOL May Not Get Bigger on Time Warner Fare
description: The pending combination of America Online and Time Warner represents by far the most powerful player on the Internet, both in providing online access and in online advertising. But AOL was already dominant before the merger.

title: Suharto Son, Now a Fugitive, Flamboyantly Evades Capture
description: Where in the world is Tommy Suharto? It is a question that embarrassed prosecutors and police officials are struggling to answer after bungling the arrest of Hutomo Mandala Putra, the youngest son of former President Suharto, who has been declared a fugitive.

title: New Dispute Over Florida Applications For Ballots
description: An election official in Seminole County, Florida allowed Republican Party workers to correct errors on thousands of applications for absentee ballots for Republicans, a Democratic lawyer said tonight.

title: Lessons From the Election That Shook America
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Fairness for Whom?
description: Take a deep breath. Whatever happens in this election -- whichever candidate is unfortunate enough to win -- the country will survive.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOGEL, DORA LOWENBRAUN
description: KOGEL-Dora Lowenbraun. 93, on November 11, 2000, after a long illness at Parker Jewish Geriatric Institute. Mrs. Kogel was married to the late Dr. Abraham Lowenbraun, residing in the Bronx and Mt. Vernon, and later to the late Dr. Marcus Kogel, founding dean of Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University and former commissioner of hospitals in NYC. They lived in Wading River and Boca Raton, FL. She was a school teacher in the Bronx and a supporter of the arts. Mrs. Kogel is survived by her daughter Alice Funk of Westbury, two grandchildren, Lisa Ann Green and Andrew Funk, and two great-grandsons whom she adored. A funeral service was held Sunday at Gutterman's in Woodbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Mazon: A Jewish Response to Hunger, (www.mazon.org), 12401 Wilshire Blvd., Los Angeles, CA 90025, or World Hunger Year.

title: Equity Offerings Expected This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: EBay Not Liable for Goods That Are Illegal, Judge Says
description: In a decision that could set the stage for how courts respond to accusations of fraud in online auctions, a state judge in San Francisco ruled last week that eBay could not be held liable for bootlegged music sold using its Web site.

title: Foes, Poised for Impeachment, Plan a Strike : Rally Backing Estrada Attracts Over a Million
description: MANILA  As the Philippines braced for a stormy week of strikes and street protests, lawmakers said Sunday that President Joseph Estrada would very likely be impeached as early as Monday and his case sent to the Senate for trial.

title: Essay; Bush Goes to Court
description: For one shining moment last week, it seemed that we would come to election closure.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about the re-election of President Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania misstated his age. He is 62, not 84.

title: Magazine Rivals Fretting; In Books, a Wary Watch
description: The new version of Time Inc. that will emerge from the chrysalis phase of the Time Warner-America Online merger is igniting a wide range of reactions from the chief executives of America's magazine companies and the analysts who watch them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILENIUS, CLARINNE M.
description: TILENIUS-Clarinne M. On November 7, 2000, in Sacramento, CA. Longtime resident of Huntington, NY. Wife of late William O. Tilenius. Survived by her son Eric Tilenius and daughter-in-law Stephanie Schear Tilenius of San Francisco, CA; stepdaughter Irene Bloom and her husband Barry of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY; granddaughter Inae Bloom; sister-in-law Joan Miller; three nieces/nephews. No services. She is deeply loved. Donations to Heifer Project International, 800-422-0474.

title: Affirmations of Hope From Yoko Ono
description: ''We know that our cells are speaking to each other,'' said Yoko Ono, beginning her Thursday night performance at the Japan Society. She mentioned a scientific study in which a skin sample scraped from the mouth of a subject responded to images he viewed in another room. This proved, Ms. Ono said, that consciousness reaches beyond our brains.

title: Lessons From the Election That Shook America
description: To the Editor:

title: An Ironclad Sense of Purpose Built on Strong Communication
description: Vijay Iyer Quartet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, J. SINCLAIR
description: ARMSTRONG-J. Sinclair. The Bramwell Funds are deeply saddened by the loss of their founding independent Director. We will miss his wise counsel, historical perspective, enthusiasm and vision over the past six years. Elizabeth R. Bramwell, President

title: What Venezuela Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils Talk Things Over After Losing Fifth Straight Game
description: With a remarkable speech last spring, Larry Robinson proved that he knew how to help his players get out of a jam and win a Stanley Cup. His speech inspired the Devils to erase a three-game deficit and eliminate the Philadelphia Flyers in the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 4 about South African museum collections of the bones of blacks gathered in the early 1900's omitted the names of two historians cited in the article who have written a book on the subject, ''Skeletons in the Cupboards: South African Museums and the Trade in Human Remains, 1907-1917.'' They are Martin Legassick and Ciraj Rassool of the University of the Western Cape.

title: A Dark Cloud Over the Sunshine State
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Charles Hockett, 84, Linguist With an Anthropological View
description: Charles F. Hockett, one of the last great champions of structural linguistics, an approach to the study of language upstaged by the ''Chomsky Revolution'' of the 1950's, died Nov. 3 at the Cayuga Medical Center in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 84 and lived in Ithaca.

title: Even Marbury Is Awed By His Scoring Outburst
description: For Stephon Marbury, the rhythm is so automatic now that he does not even think about being in a groove.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, ELEANOR
description: SANGER-Eleanor. Died November 11 at age 100. First program director of WQXR and wife of the late Elliott M. Sanger, co-founder of the station. Beloved mother of Kenneth and the late Elliott Jr., grandmother of Ellin, Elizabeth and David, great-grandmother of Benjamin, Joshua, Andrew and Ned. Services private. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, JERRY
description: DAVIS-Jerry. Passed away November 11. Devoted and beloved son of the late Jack and Irene Deckelbaum. Loving brother and brother-in-law of Linda and Marc Goldstein. Adoring and proud uncle of Julie and Janna Goldstein. ''To live in hearts we leave behind, is not to die.'' Funeral Monday, November 13, at Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. at 9:45 AM.

title: The Coyotes' Burke Stops the Rangers, All 39 Times
description: The Rangers threw everything at Phoenix Coyotes goaltender Sean Burke last night. But they could never knock Burke down.

title: In Palm Beach County, Tumult Grew Hourly
description: Ron Klein, a Democratic state senator here, thought something was amiss minutes after he cast his vote and left his polling place in Boca Raton at 7:05 Election Day morning. He had done a double take when he saw that the second hole in his punch-card ballot did not align with the names of the Democratic candidates, Al Gore and Joseph I. Lieberman. He voted for the Democrats anyway and drove to another precinct to campaign.

title: Exotic Gifts From Far Away:Holiday Shopping on the Road : JAKARTA (folo)
description: For globe-trotting frequent travelers, the holidays can mean taking precious time out to shop in unfamiliar cities  but returning home laden with treasure. Here are suggestions for great gifts to pick up during your travels, compiled by our correspondents.

title: Media Buying Duties For Verizon Are Set
description: Verizon Communications, formed by the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE, has consolidated the media buying duties for Verizon Communications, Verizon Wireless and Verizon Information Services -- with billings estimated at more than $500 million -- at the New York offices of Draft Worldwide and Zenith Media.

title: True Stories of Injustice, Drawing Some Big Names
description: An organic farmer convicted of his parents' murder on the basis of a coerced confession. A radical seminarian accused of a rape and murder in a state he hadn't even been in. A vegetarian yoga instructor whose husband spent 13 minutes dying in a faulty electric chair.

title: Tapping the Internet's Power As an 'Obsession Incubator'
description: It is difficult to find a consensus on what the pending merger of Time Warner and America Online means for the music industry.

title: Online brokers shift focus from low-commission trading to a range of services.
description: WHEN online brokerage firms started jamming the airwaves to promote cheap, electronic stock trading a few years ago, the onslaught was considered a byproduct of an overly exuberant bull market. But the long slump in the stock market this year has not deterred e-brokers from advertising heavily to attract new customers.

title: Lessons From the Election That Shook America
description: To the Editor:

title: Ready or Not, the Future Is Big and Bundled
description: The union of disparate media properties that will take place when America Online and Time Warner combine forces is likely to loom large in the advertising landscape -- perhaps too large, some agency executives worry, because of the concentration in fewer hands of the power to set rates for commercial time and advertising space.

title: Yankee Diary Finds Glory in Dixie; Through Serendipity and Detective Work, Virginia Historians Piece Together an Illustrated Civil War Memoir
description: Robert Knox Sneden was penniless, persnickety and ''peculiar in his ways'' when he died a solitary old man and was buried in obscurity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAHL, ADELE
description: STAHL-Adele. Beloved wife of the late Sam. Devoted mother of Jack, Sheila Oliver and Harriet Wulfstat. Dear sister of Sabina Sultan. She is also survived by eight adoring grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren. She will always be in our hearts. Services will be held 1 PM today at the Dix Hills chapel of I.J Morris, Inc., 21 East Deer Park Rd. Interment to follow at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale.

title: European Nights:Dance the Dark Away : AMSTERDAM (folo)
description: Whether you want a serious night on the town or a quiet drink in a congenial bar, Europe's club scene has it all.

title: Walls Talk, But Their Story Has Changed; A Home to Immigrants Now Draws Trendsetters
description: If the walls of 96 Orchard Street could talk, they would speak at least 10 languages. If they could share their stories, they might tell of 3 people sleeping on a couch, or 16 sharing a single toilet, or of dark rooms shut off from fresh breezes.

title: No. 17 Plays the Bully, But Weir Stares It Down
description: Facing the par-5 17th hole at Valderrama Golf Club is like facing the neighborhood bully who is waiting for you after school.

title: MORE ON THE VOTES
description: NEW DISPUTE -- Republicans were allowed to amend applications for absentee ballots in Seminole County, Fla., Democrats say. PAGE A19

title: Clinton and Barak Meet With Reduced Expectations
description: President Clinton met at the White House tonight with the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, for what promised to be a sober accounting of what the two men could achieve -- or, more accurately, prevent -- in the short time that the president, and perhaps the prime minister, remain in office.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Through Ancient Eyes, a Glimpse of a Lost World
description: TRILOBITE!

title: A Universe Whirls Within That Bedside Reading Pile
description: When did I start to read differently, treating books as if they were colors meant to be arranged on one canvas, or the strings of an instrument constantly being retuned?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I saw Al Gore's name and I punched his name. I saw Joe Lieberman's name with a box next to it and I punched his name. There were two holes next to the Democratic box. I know a lot of my friends did that.''

title: Metro Matters; Cart Before Horse Trading Just Won't Do
description: THERE she goes again!

title: Telemarketers Get an Earful Of Rejection
description: From Brooklyn to Buffalo, New York State residents are flocking to get their names on a newly created registry of people who do not want to receive unsolicited phone calls from telemarketing companies, which starting next spring could face stiff fines if they call a registered home or business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ABRAHAM
description: COHEN-Abraham. Beloved husband of the late Dora. Loving and devoted father to Estelle, Evelyn and Jerry, Arnold and Rita. Cherished grandfather of Sandy, Richard and Sheera, Kenny and Chris, Glenda and Larry, Sam and Evan. Adoring great-grandfather of Zachary, David, Joshua and Eliana. Brother of Esther.

title: Big Game, Bad Effort Is Giants' Trademark
description: The Giants began against the Rams with bad field position, bad turnovers, a bad pass rush, bad pass coverage, bad special teams play and, everywhere you looked, bad breaks. Bad, bad, bad.

title: At a Live Homage, Hip-Hop Is King but 'Rapping' Is Taboo
description: At the Brooklyn Museum of Art, a silver choir robe studded with silver lame horns hangs in a glass case, looking like something that might have been worn by an interplanetary Viking. A small sign identifies it as Afrika Bambaataa's Soul Sonic Force cloak, worn in 1983. It is part of ''Hip-Hop Nation,'' a retrospective of the culture that has become, to paraphrase the museum's wall text, the way young people all over the world communicate.

title: Democrats Now Back Jackson's Role in Voting Concerns
description: As the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson continued a civil rights tour across South Florida today, rallying Jewish, black and Hispanic voters to demand an accurate count of the vote in Palm Beach County, Democratic officials and Vice President Al Gore's advisers appeared to back away from earlier complaints that Mr. Jackson was playing too large a role in demonstrations in the county.

title: Online Sites Offer Last-Minute Deals and Advice : Trolling Web for Right Cruise
description: IN THE GLORY days of ocean cruising, liners such as the Queen Elizabeth II defined a standard of luxury and cruise passengers knew precisely what to expect. Today, with the profusion of new ships, the options for cruising can be dizzying. Though a friend or agent can be helpful, the Internet offers advice unavailable elsewhere: straightforward reviews from thousands of recent cruise passengers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLENDORFF, HENRY ''ULI.''
description: ULLENDORFF-Henry ''Uli.'' Died on November 11 in his 91st year in New York City. Survived by his wife Regina, of 50 years, his four children, Jackie, Doris (Ken), David (Alison) and Danielle (Mark) and many grandchildren. Born in 1910 in Gelsenkirchen, Germany, he remade his life after his family perished in the Holocaust. He taught us to take risks; be courageous, brave and dignified in the face of adversity and never forget to enjoy the journey to its fullest. Services will be held on Monday, November 13, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue at 10 AM. Donations may be made to DOROT, 171 West 85th St., NY, NY 10024.

title: On Her Way to the Senate to Help Close the Gender Gap
description: THE new senator-elect from Michigan, Debbie Stabenow, was talking politics over tea in a restaurant here on Saturday when her cell phone trilled. President Clinton was on the line.

title: Yugoslavia Is Cheered but Faces Cheerless Times
description: The new Yugoslavia has been welcomed back to the world almost uncritically by a United States and a Europe that cannot quite believe their luck. Slobodan Milosevic, the autocrat who stirred such turmoil in the Balkans for so long, is gone.

title: Parker Injury Hurts Giants
description: The Giants' offensive line, which has been perhaps the most consistently effective component of the team, could be without one of its key players for several weeks.

title: A Larger-Than-Life Coach, Embellished for the Small Screen
description: Pudgie Walsh, gruff former firefighter and longtime coach of the Brooklyn Mariners, was hardly surprised when television producers turned up recently and asked to base a series on his life.

title: . . . Of Informal Spontaneity And Savored Memories
description: Merce Cunningham

title: Gridlock at the Airport: Ways Out of the Jam
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami May Move Up, or It May Not
description: When the prospect appeared strong on Saturday that Oklahoma would lose to Texas A&M and Miami would become No. 1 in the Bowl Championship Series ranking, Hurricanes quarterback Ken Dorsey tried to put that heady thought into perspective.

title: No Headline
Partners May Have Underestimated Antitrust Issues
description: When executives of America Online and Time Warner announced plans for the largest merger in history nearly a year ago, most analysts and legal experts predicted there would be few significant regulatory obstacles standing in the way of the deal.

title: As Rams Soar, Giants Turn Into the Team That Fell to Earth
description: The Giants knew what they had squandered, and it was different from what they had lost.

title: Lessons From the Election That Shook America
description: To the Editor:

title: Leah Rabin, Israeli First Lady and Peace Advocate, Dies at 72
description: Leah Rabin, who emerged from the shadow of her husband, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, to become a forceful public advocate of his peace policies after he was assassinated, died today of cancer. She was 72.

title: INSIDE
description: Reducing Global Warming

title: If You're on the Subway, Then Read This
description: To the Editor:

title: Fizzy Cabaret-Style Toast To the Gershwins' Zaniness
description: George Gershwin, like the Beatles, was a musical force of so many brilliant parts that by selectively sifting through his legacy, a musical evening could be built around any of several strands. Woody Allen has made Gershwin's airborne tunes synonymous with the glamour of Manhattan's skyline. Others have celebrated Gershwin as the distillation of Jazz Age ebullience, the inventor of a distinctively American classical music and a sharp political satirist (the operettas).

title: Homework Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Problems Stir Calls to End '19th Century' Voting Process
description: Citing long lines at polling places, trouble with vote counting and other problems, two members of Congress said yesterday that the time had come to standardize and modernize the country's voting system.

title: PentaMark Officials Are Named by BBDO
description: BBDO Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, is naming Mike Vogel as chairman and chief executive at PentaMark Worldwide in Troy, Mich., the new agency being formed to handle the consolidated creative and media account of the Chrysler Group unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G.

title: Routing No. 3 Team, Huskies Make A Very Powerful Opening Argument
description: The best team ever in women's college basketball? Maybe Tennessee's national champion two years ago. Maybe Connecticut's national champion last year. Although this is only the preseason, it may be the Connecticut team that pulverized Georgia today in the eighth annual State Farm Tip-Off Classic.

title: Exotic Gifts From Far Away:Holiday Shopping on the Road : HONG KONG (folo)
description: For globe-trotting frequent travelers, the holidays can mean taking precious time out to shop in unfamiliar cities  but returning home laden with treasure. Here are suggestions for great gifts to pick up during your travels, compiled by our correspondents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGAN, EDWARD JOSEPH
description: EGAN-Edward Joseph. On Wednesday, November 8, 2000, in San Francisco, CA. Beloved husband of Jacqueline Nardi Egan of Darien, CT, and Sag Harbor, NY. Loving father of Mark E. Egan, Regina A. Tobin and Elizabeth R. Egan. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Catherine of Siena R.C. Church, 4 Riverside Avenue, Riverside, CT, on November 13, 2000, at 11:30 AM. Calling hours will be at the Leo P. Gallagher Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, on Saturday, November 11, from 7 to 9 PM and Sunday, November 12, from 3 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Burial will be held Tuesday at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY, at 11 AM. Contributions can be made to New Hope Communities, P.O. Box 289, Lochsheldrake, NY 12579.

title: Eleanor Naumburg Sanger, 100, First Program Director of WQXR
description: Eleanor Naumburg Sanger, the first program director of WQXR, the classical music station that was later purchased by The New York Times Company, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 100.

title: Rams Use Slight to Fuel Victory
description: Even without their two best players, the St. Louis Rams needed little incentive playing the Giants today. They recalled how tough the Giants talked last season, only to be routed in St. Louis. So when the Rams heard more rumblings out of the New York metropolitan area last week, they just smiled.

title: A Start, but Only a Start, Toward an Inevitable Transition
description: There is little doubt that one of the main reasons America Online Inc. wants to acquire Time Warner Inc. is potential access to Time Warner's extensive cable television network, the second biggest in the nation. America Online is the leviathan of the dial-up Internet, with almost 25 million subscribers worldwide, but has almost no presence in the business of providing links to cyberspace over high-speed, or broadband, connections, which can be as much as 30 times faster than standard analog modems.

title: Patents; Building a better search engine for records at the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
description: OVER the last month, the United States Patent and Trademark Office has reached out through the Internet and made it easier for inventors, and the lawyers and agents who help them, to navigate the often long and painstaking process of applying for a patent.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Jets-Colts? It Should Be a Rivalry, but It's Not
description: It's the rivalry that should have been, but never was, and probably never will be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, LLOYD BOARDMAN
description: MARSHALL-Lloyd Boardman. Of Fort Lee, formerly of Flushing, NY, and Stoneham, MA, age 77, on November 11, 2000. Former plant manager of Allen-Stevens Corp. of Woodside, NY. Husband of Patricia (nee Kihn). Father of Valerie Emmelhainz, Laura Portee and the late Robert Marshall. Grandfather of three. Visiting Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, at the Patti and Mikatarian Funeral Home, 327 Main St., Fort Lee. Religious services Wednesday, 1 PM, at All Saints Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Orchard St., Leonia. For further information call 201-944-0100.

title: Lessons From the Election That Shook America
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Out Of Their League Vs. Rams
description: It was early in the game when the Giants discovered that becoming an elite team is easier said than done. On the Giants' first possession yesterday, wide receiver Amani Toomer made a catch in the middle of the field. According to teammates, he was hit simultaneously by two St. Louis players, in the back of the head, and across the jaw. Toomer's helmet was basically smashed in the collision and he sustained a concussion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEACH, HAROLD J.
description: BEACH-Harold J. Age 76, of Freehold Township, NJ, on November 11, 2000. Husband of Barbara Mackey Beach. Father of Gary, Kevin and Gerard Beach. Grandfather of Noelle, Scott, Kevin, Brice, Matthew and Courtney. Brother of Charles Beach and Mary Tyrrell. Funeral services will be at 10 AM, Tuesday, at Freeman Funeral Home, 47 East Main St., Freehold, followed by an 11 AM funeral liturgy at St. Rose of Lima R.C. Church, Freehold. Interment in St. Rose of Lima Cemetery, Freehold Township. Visitation will be Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the funeral home. Letters of condolence may be e-mailed to freemansfh@ aol.com

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEANE, JAMES
description: KEANE-James. On November 11, 2000, of Long Beach, NY. Beloved husband of Joan (nee Regan). Loving brother of Mary Walsh, Eileen Keane and Margie Lavin. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY, Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass at St. Ignatius Martyr R.C. Church, Long Beach, NY, Tuesday, 9:30 AM. Interment at St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY.

title: Accounts
description: * Space.com, New York, a multimedia company focused on topics like space exploration, to the New York office of Mediasmith to handle its media planning and buying account for online and offline media, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million. Online media duties had been handled in-house; offline media duties had been handled by the Wolf Group New York, which continues to handle the creative assignment along with the Creative Resource Company, Toronto.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KISSEL, LESTER
description: KISSEL-Lester. A memorial for Lester Kissel will be held at The Century Association, 7 West 43rd Street, N.Y.C., on Wednesday, November 15, 2000, at 4:30 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COURTNEY, MARY C.
description: COURTNEY-Mary C. On November 10, 2000. Beloved mother of Jim, Peggy, Theresa, and Bill, loved mother-in-law of Jane. Cherished grandmother, and stand-in mother on dear Dorothy's untimely death of Dermott, Clare, Susan, and Mary; treasured grandmother of Jennifer, Stacey and Stephanie. Reposing at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave., NYC, Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, at Our Lady of Good Counsel Church, where she and her dear departed P.J. were married 73 years ago. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Democratic Judge Has a Record of Fairness, Colleagues Say
description: The federal judge selected at random to hear the Bush campaign's lawsuit seeking to block hand-counting of ballots in some counties in Florida is a lifelong Democrat who has long been active in liberal causes, ranging from protecting the rights of children to finding lawyers to represent death row inmates and indigents in civil cases.

title: The Jets Cannot Overcome a Sluggish Start, and Lose Their Third Straight Game
description: Do-overs aren't permitted in football, which is just as well for the Jets. With the troubling turn their season has taken recently, a turn that now threatens to rot playoff hopes that seemed so ripe less than a month ago, they wouldn't have merely lost tonight to the Colts, 23-15. They would somehow have had a previous triumph snatched from the victory column, too. They have lost three games in a row, and four of their last six, and are skidding rapidly down the division slope. They are in third place in the the American Football Conference East, in a tie, at 6-4, with Buffalo. They trail the division-leading Dolphins (8-2), whom they play next Sunday in Miami and who were victorious today, by two games.

title: Is the Web a Vehicle to New Riches for Warner Bros.?
description: After America Online and Time Warner announced their merger in January, AOL representatives approached a number of marketing executives at the Hollywood studios. The company was offering each studio premium positions throughout AOL's online service and Web site to promote new films, according to a studio executive involved in the discussions. The total price was $20 million in cash and guaranteed media exposure for the AOL logo in the studios' own promotions of their films.

title: Illegal Tobacco Traffic
description: For years now European authorities have been trying to combat the growing black-market trade in American cigarettes in Europe. Earlier this month the European Union's executive commission filed a damage suit in federal court in New York against the Philip Morris Company and the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. It charged the cigarette makers with money-laundering and taking other fraudulent actions to pursue a ''massive, ongoing smuggling scheme.'' The European officials estimate that they lose more than $1.5 billion annually in cigarette tax revenues as a result of smuggling operations.

title: To Weary Israelis, a Hijacking Augurs Another Difficult Week
description: The hijacked Russian plane landed in the desolate Negev shortly after sunrise this morning like an abrupt announcement of another bad week.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Rock Musicians Enter Fray on Copyrights
description: As the bitter copyright dispute between MP3.com and the Universal Music Group enters its final phase this week, the Internet music start-up has been joined in a key argument by a group of recording artists led by Don Henley, a onetime Universal artist, and Sheryl Crow, who is currently under contract to Universal, the world's largest record company.

title: Lessons From the Election That Shook America
description: To the Editor:

title: Bobby Labonte Finishes Fourth and Clinches Winston Title
description: When it was over today, Bobby Labonte gleefully jumped on the hood of his lime green Pontiac Grand Prix and accepted the bulky Winston Cup Series championship trophy. Labonte hoisted the trophy above his head, but teetered and almost dropped it onto the concrete.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATERMAN, CAROL J.
description: WATERMAN-Carol J. November 9, 2000. Survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Ingrid-Jennifer and Theodore Wolfley, 57 Liberty St., Brockport, NY 14420; grandchildren, Theodore, Tabitha, Matthew, and Robert; sister and brother-inlaw, Susan and Carl Silverman. Funeral services and interment were held in Rochester, NY. Friends wishing may contribute to the Jewish Family Service of Manhattan in her memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHAN, INGEBORG H.
description: NATHAN-Ingeborg H. Of Jamesburg, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Norbert. Devoted mother of Bruce J. Nathan and Roy A. Nathan. Dear sister of Ralph Blumenthal. Loving grandmother of Jennifer, Jared, Nicole and Jessica. For information call ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 1-800-522-0588.

title: As Bush Camp Looks to Federal Court, Gore Supporters Embrace States' Rights
description: If there is one maxim that sums up the Republican-led legal revolution of the past few years it is: Trust the states.

title: Don Bosco Defeats Bergen Catholic
description: Don Bosco Prep beat Bergen Catholic yesterday for the second time this season, 24-10, in the first round of the Parochial Group 4 playoffs.

title: Buenos Aires Yields Antique Treasures
description: BUENOS AIRES  As any traveler with a penchant for antiques knows, just about every major city has an area with a concentration of antique shops, or better yet, a flea market. Usually off the beaten tourist track, they can be excellent places to spend a free morning, not only for the potential treasures one might find, but for the pleasure of learning about a country's history through the atmosphere, people and objects found in the environs.

title: Giuliani Says Safir Merits Security Team
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik yesterday defended the fact that the city continues to pay for a security detail for the former police commissioner, Howard Safir, three months after Mr. Safir resigned to become a consultant for a company in Atlanta.

title: A 'Rigoletto' Without Fuss Gets Quickly To the Point
description: One of the New York City Opera's unwritten mandates is plausible productions of favorite pieces. Those who can't afford the Metropolitan Opera get to see the standard repertory firsthand. Those who still don't know the standard repertory have a chance to.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, GUS
description: HALL-Gus. Celebration of the life of Gus Hall, lifelong leader of Communist Party U.S.A., November 19, 2 PM, the Great Hall, Cooper Union, 7 East Seventh Street. For information, 212-989-4994.

title: Bush Campaign Creates Fund For Vote Fight
description: The Bush campaign, anticipating a costly and potentially lengthy legal and political contest over disputed vote totals in several states, created a fund to finance the fight today and issued an urgent appeal to donors to contribute as much as $5,000 each.

title: The Tally: Errors, Many; Apathy, 0
description: A funny thing happened at the polls here and in many other sites in Broward County last week. After waiting in long lines caused by heavy turnout, thousands of people stepped into the voting booths and then, if the results are to be believed, did not vote for president.

title: Islander Owners Thrill Bettman
description: The Islanders may have extended their scoreless streak to nearly 140 minutes in Saturday night's 4-0 loss to San Jose, but there was at least one person at Nassau Coliseum who liked what he was seeing.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Wednesday about a Metropolitan Opera performance of Mozart's ''Zauberflote'' misidentified the character whose flute playing charms the animals. He is Tamino, not Papageno.

title: European Nights:Dance the Dark Away : MADRID (folo)
description: Whether you want a serious night on the town or a quiet drink in a congenial bar, Europe's club scene has it all.

title: 2 Weeks Starting Today to Argue Fine and Crucial Details of Cutting Greenhouse Gas
description: After four years of tortuous negotiations, a treaty aimed at curtailing global warming faces its greatest obstacles yet in the next two weeks as officials from around the world meet in the Netherlands to tussle over the fine print.

title: Jacques Chaban-Delmas, 85, a Left-Wing Gaullist, Dies
description: Jacques Chaban-Delmas, a former French prime minister who tried to embrace social change despite the resistance of his conservative colleagues, died on Friday of a heart attack at his home in Paris, his family said. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENE, JULIET KALIKOW
description: LEVENE-Juliet Kalikow. Beloved wife of Stephen M. Levene and widow of the late Harold J. Kalikow. Loving mother of Peter Kalikow and Penny Wallerstein. Cherished grandmother of Nicholas and Kathryn Kalikow, Jill and Jennifer Wallerstein. Dear mother-in-law of Mary Kalikow and John Wallerstein. Devoted sister of Gertrude Blum, Harold Citrin, Renee Weil and Barbara Goldstein. Funeral service Monday, November 13, 1 PM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th St. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Juliet Kalikow Levene Memorial Fund, New York Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Now, Doctor, Just Who Are the Sane Ones Here?
description: Stripped down to black lingerie and garter belts, accessorized with splashes of human blood, Mrs. Prentice retains the bright, jaded air of the hostess of a long-running cocktail party. True, it seems entirely possible that her husband is a transvestite and a murderer; true, there may be a corpse in the shrubbery outside; true, she is being blackmailed for sexual indiscretions by the hotel bellboy with whom she committed them.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Talk Turns Murky as Selection of President Lurches Into Uncharted Areas
description: On ''Meet the Press'' yesterday, Tim Russert tried to ask Warren Christopher, Vice President Al Gore's point man on the Florida recount, a simple question about a complex dispute. The query came in at 51 words.

title: Bodies and Questions in an Austrian Tunnel
description: Evacuation workers struggling through the night in a dark and cold Alpine tunnel began extracting the bodies of about 155 people, including eight Americans, who perished on Saturday when a cable car they were riding to a ski run was destroyed in an inferno of flames.

title: Lessons From the Election That Shook America
description: To the Editor:

title: Present Prices And the Call Of Duty-Free
description: WHEN duty calls this holiday season, consider duty-free. You can't go far wrong with a good watch for your spouse, perfume for the mother-in-law and a bottle of decent Scotch for a brother

title: A Museum's Tales From the Crypt: the Met's New Galleries
description: Most New Yorkers look for extra space under their beds or at the top of their closets. The Metropolitan Museum of Art, similarly afflicted with too many possessions, went rummaging under its Grand Staircase to come up with its latest gallery, nicknamed ''the Crypt.''

title: Sometimes an Error Is a Prelude to Triumph
description: Bridge players, like golfers, sometimes make an error, get into trouble and have to make a brilliant recovery. Consider, for example, the diagramed deal played on Thursday evening in the annual Experts Night of the Harmonie Club at 4 East 60th Street in Manhattan. The expert winners were Tom Smith and Gene Saxe, while the member winners were Joan Cohen and Ronnie Schaler.

title: Gore Lives in the Eye of a Surreal Storm
description: Except for a trip to church, Vice President Al Gore remained secluded here today with his family and top advisers in an increasingly surreal state of suspended animation.

title: DISSECTING THE DEAL
description: 2. Conde Nast

title: I.B.M. to Increase Supply of Key Chip Material
description: I.B.M., whose sales have been hurt by shortages of an increasingly popular material used to package chips, has signed an agreement to increase its supply of the material, the company said today.

title: A Salute to Marlboro's Educational Collaborations
description: The Marlboro Music Festival is such a happy story that even those who know it well don't mind being told again. Every summer for 50 years, musicians -- some students and some with major careers -- have gathered in rural Vermont to play chamber music.

title: Decades After Murders, Families Seek Answers in Boston Strangler Case
description: The victims have been dead for decades. The man who confessed to murdering them is long gone as well. But the most terrifying crime mystery ever to strike this city has never really been laid to rest. For years, some have argued that the Boston Strangler, or stranglers, might still be out there.

title: Florida's Crucial Vote Count
description: Despite mounting public impatience with the delay in determining the outcome of the presidential election, the vote-counting process unhappily edged toward more confusion over the weekend. The potential for new trouble was introduced by Gov. George W. Bush, who moved in federal court to block the manual counting of ballots in Florida. It was a puzzling step from someone who earlier had rightly deplored the tendency toward litigation among Democrats. The obvious way out of the current mess is for the forces of Mr. Bush and Vice President Al Gore to drop their actual and threatened lawsuits challenging the validity of the ballots and the vote-counting in Florida and other states. If counting and recounting proceed unimpeded, we can know who the next president is by the end of the week.

title: G.O.P. QUESTIONING BUSH'S CAMPAIGN
description: As Gov. George W. Bush struggles to win a bare electoral margin, many prominent Republicans and party operatives are now questioning his strategy in the final days before the election. They say the campaign's top advisers were consumed with such confidence that they made crucial mistakes that probably cost Mr. Bush a comfortable victory.

title: Lessons From the Election That Shook America
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasuries Set For Auction This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a 33-day cash management bill being auctioned on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROCKBANK, ROBERT T.
description: BROCKBANK-Robert T. 54, of Garden City, NY, on Friday, November 10. Beloved husband of Janet; loving father of Stacey and Kathryn; devoted son of Margaret Meyers; dear brother of Margaret Perrone and James; friend of many at the former Manufacturers Hanover Trust and Chemical Bank, and at Chase Manhattan Bank, AXA Financial and AXA Group. Viewing Monday, 2-4 and 79 PM, at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave., Garden City. Funeral mass 10 AM, Tuesday, November 14, at St. Joseph's Church, Franklin Ave. at 5th St., Garden City. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to Theodore Roosevelt Association, PO Box 719, Oyster Bay, NY 11771.

description: Three companies are making acquisitions.

description: UNMARKED and virtually untouched after dominating David Tua with his left jab during a 12-round clinic on Saturday night, Lennox Lewis was asked about his next opponent.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Muslim Nations Bitterly Denounce Israel at Summit
description: Leaders of the world's Muslim nations, searching for a way to make their numbers and economic weight count, bitterly condemned Israel today and promised the Palestinians their full political and financial support.

title: Republicans Urge Gore to Back Outcome After Overseas Tally : Recount Proceeds in Florida,Roiling the Political Waters
description: WASHINGTON  With the tense presidential standoff defying resolution, spokesmen for Governor George W. Bush on Sunday pressed Democrats to accept the outcome next Friday once all overseas absentee ballots for Florida were counted, while surrogates for Vice President Al Gore left open a door to legal action but promised that the standoff would be over "in a matter of days."

title: Gridlock at the Airport: Ways Out of the Jam
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JENSEN, JIM
description: JENSEN-Jim. Born November 13, 1926. Not just for an hour, not just for a day, not just for a year, always. Rachel

title: Excerpts From Texas Law on Recounts
description: In 1997 Gov. George W. Bush of Texas signed a measure amending the state's election law. In a couple of places the measure seems to refer approvingly to a manual recount of disputed votes. Democrats have pointed to the amendments in rebutting the Bush campaign's court challenges to a manual recount of votes in Florida. Following are excerpts from those sections.

title: Van Gundy Focuses on Game
description: Sometime tomorrow night, Jeff Van Gundy will stand in front of the Knicks' bench and bark out instructions to his team. When Van Gundy's voice pierces through Key Arena in Seattle, it will probably make SuperSonics center Patrick Ewing think twice before realizing that the words he has heard so many times, for so many years, are not for his ears.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNING, JAMES DORR
description: DUNNING-James Dorr. On November 7, 2000, at his home in New York City, after a long illness. He was 89. Mr. Dunning was an executive of New York Life Insurance Company for 45 years. For 25 years he served as a consultant to the Episcopal Church Pension Fund. His extensive lay leadership in the Episcopal Church included service as a senior warden of three parishes, St. Andrew's Church, Wellesley, MA, All Saints' Church and St. Bartholomew's Church, Manhattan. He served as a member of the national standing liturgical commission during the revision of the Book of Common Prayer. In 1996, he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters by the Berkeley Divinity School at Yale. He is survived by Mary, his wife of 66 years, and his son James D. Dunning, Jr. of New York, and his grandsons James D. Dunning III and David F. Dunning. Vigil and visitation Sunday, November 12, 4-6:30PM, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street. Funeral service at St. Bartholomew's, Monday, November 13, 5 PM. Memorial donations to St. Bartholomew's Church, New York, or Berkeley Divinity School at Yale, New Haven.

title: Mary Hunter Wolf, 95, Director Undaunted by a Broadway Barrier
description: Mary Hunter Wolf, one of the first female directors on Broadway, died Nov. 3 in Hamden, Conn. She was 95.

title: Results Tell All About Davenport's Resilience
description: In the background of the two Grand Slam celebrations by Venus Williams this season, off to the side of the jubilant foot-stomping by the winner's proud father, Lindsay Davenport calmly endured each scene as the runner-up at Wimbledon and the United States Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, MARY MILLER
description: PORTER-Mary Miller. On November 11, 2000. In her 94th year, a Holocaust survivor. Dear aunt of Dr. Albert and Elaine Miller, Rita and Gerard Marini and Michael and Janet Miller. Cherished greataunt. Graveside services Sunday, November 12, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: City and Teachers Remain Far Apart On a New Contract
description: With the contract for New York City's 78,000 public-school teachers expiring on Wednesday, a stalemate in negotiations between the city and the teachers' union has fueled tension as the city seeks major changes that could reshape its schools, including merit-based raises for teachers, a longer school day and faster, easier ways to dismiss incompetent teachers.

title: Scrutiny and Disagreements Accompany Hand Recount
description: The presidency of the United States could be determined here by a margin of votes counted not by machines, but by people.

title: Anti-Bias Talk Noticed In Civil-Union Debate
description: In an atmosphere as highly charged as the summer air before a thunderstorm, Vermont's new commissioner of education has been carrying a message of respect for diversity to the schools of this state.

title: A Sure Hand Can Save the New President
description: For the moment, with Florida under siege as armies of partisans descend to watch the recounts, it seems hard to imagine George W. Bush or Al Gore truly winning the White House -- that is, able to claim the mandate necessary to govern effectively. Yet someone will have to be declared the nation's 43rd president, by the courts if not by the electorate.

title: Lessons From the Election That Shook America
description: To the Editor:

title: OPEC Delays Decision on Raising Output
description: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries chose the Venezuelan oil minister, Ali Rodriguez Araque, as its new secretary general today, paving the way for the producers' group to deal with pressing questions of oil output more expeditiously at a time when prices remain stubbornly high. But OPEC put off until January any decision on changing current production levels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUHIG, RITA T.
description: DUHIG-Rita T. On November 11, 2000. Retired chairman of the history department of Fort Hamilton High School. Loving sister of the late James and Angela. Dear aunt of James, Catherine McEvoy, Marian, Cecilia Frazee and Peter. Also survived by many grandnieces and nephews. Served with the American Red Cross overseas in Hawaii and occupied Germany. Volunteer at Lutheran Medical Center. Active in church and community organizations. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Andrew's or St. Vincent de Paul Society. Visiting Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, St. Andrew's Church.

description: It can seem like a bizarre bazaar, one with its own language and its own laws of supply and demand.

title: A Daring Piano Venture For a Big Bach Milestone
description: Although the Bach year, the 250th anniversary of the composer's death, has weeks to go, some sense of anticlimax may intrude. For the central thread of that year in New York, a monumental series of concerts by the pianist Andras Schiff, ran out on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall, with a predictably splendid performance of the ''Goldberg'' Variations.

title: People
description: * Larry Woodard, managing director at Vigilante, New York, a unit of Leo Burnett USA that specializes in urban marketing, was named chief executive. He succeeds Marc Stephenson Strachan, who is leaving to pursue other interests, the agency said. Burnett USA is part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Bcom3 Group.

description: For globe-trotting frequent travelers, the holidays can mean taking precious time out to shop in unfamiliar cities  but returning home laden with treasure. Here are suggestions for great gifts to pick up during your travels, compiled by our correspondents.

title: Media; TV Talk Shows See Hope in the Never-Ending 2000 Election
description: A week ago, panic was about to set in at the television political talk shows: the most talked-about man in America, Bill Clinton, was ready to make his exit, leaving the stage to two guys who did not seem nearly as capable of stirring the public's pulse.

title: Brazilians Protest Trademark on Sugar
description: Leave it to the Internet to open a can of worms over a can of organic sugar.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the defeat of Gil Garcetti for election to a third term as Los Angeles County district attorney referred incompletely in some copies to a murder accusation against Rafael Perez, in a case that fed criticism of Mr. Garcetti. Mr. Perez, a former police officer given immunity in exchange for testimony against police officers in corruption trials, was accused by a former girlfriend, who told investigators that he had participated in the killing of a drug dealer. Mr. Perez was not charged in the killing.

title: Dissecting the Deal; If AOL and Time Warner Do Merge, Regulators, Competitors and Analysts Wonder How the Pieces Will Add Up
description: THE two companies promise to create a 21st-century bridge between the new Internet economy and the venerable entertainment and publishing industries.

title: E-Commerce Report; Portals are eager to make more attractive advertising deals with e-tailers.
description: WHEN the sky began falling on dot-com companies this year, e-commerce sages predicted good things for businesses strong enough to hold on through the holidays. Not only would there be less competition for customers, the thinking went, but e-tailers would be able to negotiate better business terms from manufacturers and vendors, whose client lists had evaporated.

title: Violence Thwarts C.I.A. Director's Unusual Diplomatic Role in Middle Eastern Peacemaking
description: An unusual four-year experiment in which America's chief spymaster served as a broker between Israeli and Palestinian security forces has been paralyzed by six weeks of deadly street clashes and gun battles, prompting the C.I.A. to pull back.

title: Expanded Count Sought for Palm Beach Vote in Florida Standoff
description: As lawyers prepared to square off in federal court over Gov. George W. Bush's efforts to block hand recounts of Florida's disputed vote tallies, election officials in at least two counties conducted manual recounts on Sunday, and spokesmen for Mr. Bush and Vice President Al Gore again took to the airwaves in sharp disagreement over how to end the deadlock.

title: The American Role in Mideast Peace
description: A new round of White House visits by Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, has ended without any clear schedule for resuming peace talks. The two sides even seem to disagree on how future negotiations should be structured. The Palestinians have expressed a desire for increased international involvement, complaining that Washington has abandoned the neutrality required of a mediator. Israel rightly resists any shift to a more international format. Only the United States has sufficient authority and credibility with both sides to help them bridge their remaining differences.

title: Abidjan Journal; Tailor Takes Scornful Measure of Africa's Leaders
description: On an otherwise quiet road here on a recent Saturday morning, the tailor's workshop was bursting with activity as some 30 people sitting before sewing machines frantically stitched together clothes for a fashion show.

title: Sega Teases Sony on PlayStation 2 Woes
description: The taunting began on the evening of Oct. 26, when the first truck-side billboard rolled past Sony's game division in Foster City, Calif.

description: MANDALA-Salvatore. Devoted husband of the late Caroline (Russo). Beloved father of Dr. Paul, Connie Caputo and Joanne Collora. Loving grandfather and greatgrandfather. Dear brother of Peter, the late Jerry, Joseph, Artie, and Nancy Lamastra. Mass St. Stephen's, 11 AM, on Monday. In repose Raccuglia and Son, 321-323 Court St., Brooklyn, 718-855-7737.

title: COUNTING THE VOTE
Blazers Give Nets a Reality Check
description: Byron Scott moped in the locker room, watching his nightmare unfold on a 25-inch television screen and the Nets' game slip away without him. The loss, he knew, would be his fault.
