description: Kamali, Inspired by Kamali

title: Metro Business Briefing; A FINE WINE EXPOSITION
description: A version of Vinexpo, which the wine industry considers the most prestigious international wine exposition, will take place in New York City in 2002. It will be the first trade exhibition in the Western Hemisphere supported by Vinexpo Inc., the parent organization in Bordeaux, France, which in 1998 held its first show abroad, in Hong Kong. The New York exposition, scheduled for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan on Oct. 22 to 24, 2002, will be called Vinexpo Americas. ''All the wines and spirits from all over the world will be invited to participate as exhibitors, as in Bordeaux,'' Robert Beynat, the general manager of Vinexpo Inc., said yesterday in a telephone interview, ''but the exhibition is open to buyers only from United States, Canada and Latin America.'' Mr. Beynat said the for-profit company, which is 66 percent owned by the Bordeaux Chamber of Commerce, and the rest by wine interests elsewhere, hoped to attract 700 to 800 exhibitors and 10,000 to 12,000 visitors in New York. The event will be closed to the public.

title: Smithfield Offers $2.7 Billion for IBP
description: In another sign that the food industry is rapidly consolidating, Smithfield Foods, the nation's largest hog producer and pork processor, made an unsolicited bid today to buy IBP Inc., the giant meatpacker, for about $2.7 billion in stock.

title: Yes, America, Clean Air Begins at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Stalled Pluto Express
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets' Groh Addresses Blitz of Questions About Testaverde
description: Jets Coach Al Groh threw down the gauntlet for his reeling team today. He told his players that they had to win four of their last six games to assure a spot in the playoffs, even as they continue to grasp for reasons to explain the three-game losing streak that has shaken their confidence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, MIRIAM S.
description: GREENE-Miriam S., on November 12, 2000 in her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Dr. David Greene. Dear mother of Betty Mazur and the late Stanley Greene. Adored grandmother of Peter, Alexandra, Nicole, Danielle and David. Great-grandmother of Ross and Elise. Services Tuesday, November 14, at 11:30 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYMONDS, MARTIN., M.D.
description: SYMONDS-Martin., M.D. The members of the Karen Horney Center note with deep sorrow the passing of Martin Symonds, M.D., esteemed psychoanalyst, supervisor, teacher, faculty member and founder of the Karen Horney Clinic Victim Treatment Center. His spirit, contributions and depth will be sorely missed. Henry A. Paul, M.D., President AIP

title: Walter McConaughy, 92, Envoy in Asia, Dies
description: Walter Patrick McConaughy, a specialist on the Far East for the State Department whose high-profile postings included ambassadorships in Burma, Pakistan and Taiwan, died on Friday at a hospital in Atlanta. He was 92 and had moved to Atlanta after retiring in 1974 as ambassador to the Nationalist Chinese government on Taiwan.

title: Lawsuits Block Path of a Catskills Casino
description: In the seven months since Park Place Entertainment Corporation announced that it would build the largest casino resort in the world in the Catskills, the project has attracted more lawsuits than gamblers.

title: STREAMLINE.COM DELIVERY SERVICE FAILS
description: An Internet company with large operations in Northern New Jersey and Boston, Streamline.com, is calling it quits. The company, which aimed its Web-based grocery and home delivery services at busy suburban families, was founded in 1993 and went public last year. In a last-ditch effort to stay solvent, the company, based in Westwood, Mass., had sold off operations in Chicago and Washington. Judith Berck

title: Merged Consulting Concern Plans Big Job Cut to Bolster Stock
description: When the Internet consulting firm USWeb/CKS merged with Whittman-Hart to become MarchFirst on that very date this year, who knew that a company promoting the future of business would have been better off stuck in the past?

description: EUROPE

description: TRACY-Bernadette. You left us too early. We will miss your courtside croquet attire and pithy appraisals of play. You were a great partner. Ellie and Gene Goldberg

title: Recount Near End, Red Faces Remain
description: Volusia County tonight neared the end of its hand count of 184,339 ballots cast in the presidential election last Tuesday, and gave new details about an initially unrecorded batch of 320 votes.

description: For the first time in three years, Dr. Peter Jenniskens this year will watch the Leonid meteors with his feet on the ground.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page news analysis article on Sunday about the looming court battle over the presidential election misspelled the surname of a biographer of Harry S. Truman who recalled Truman's advice to put the country first. He is David McCullough, not McCulloch.

title: G.O.P. Governors in Key States Failed to Deliver for Bush
description: They were among the most powerful and, in many cases, most popular political figures in their states, proven Republican vote-getters who coalesced remarkably early around one of their own for the presidency: George W. Bush. And so, from Tom Ridge in Pennsylvania to John Engler in Michigan to his own brother Jeb, in Florida, Mr. Bush could count on the company of an important Republican governor when he campaigned in the biggest battleground states.

title: The Origin of the Europeans; Combining Genetics and Archaeology, Scientists Rough Out Continent's 50,000-Year-Old Story
description: From what had seemed like irreversible oblivion, archaeologists and population geneticists believe they are on the verge of retrieving a record of human history stretching back almost 50,000 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANKS, CHARLES A.
description: BANKS-Charles A. On November 6, 2000. Husband of the late Helen. WWII Army veteran, long-time resident of Harlem, entertainer, pianist and composer. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St., Wednesday, 4-9PM. Service 8PM. Interment on Thursday, at Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Victor Grinich, an electronics industry pioneer who helped start Fairchild Semiconductor, misstated the size of the company. Its 1999 sales were $786 million, not $786 billion.

title: Mayor Returns From Lost Senate Campaign to Face Waterbury's Fiscal Crisis
description: Less than a week after the end of his vain campaign for the United States Senate against Joseph I. Lieberman, Mayor Philip A. Giordano has returned to work full time to face a city with no money in the bank, unable to meet next month's payroll for its 3,700 employees and on the edge of a state financial takeover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, ELEANOR
description: SANGER-Eleanor. Died November 11 at age 100. First program director of WQXR and wife of the late Elliott M. Sanger, co-founder of the station. Beloved mother of Kenneth and the late Elliott Jr., grandmother of Ellin, Elizabeth and David, great-grandmother of Benjamin, Joshua, Andrew and Ned. Services private. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: American Bishops to Take Up A Statement on Mideast Peace
description: A committee of the nation's Roman Catholic bishops has written a document urging that the United States work ''tirelessly'' to revive the Middle East peace process and that the effort lead to an ''internationally recognized Palestinian state,'' acceptance of Israel's right ''to exist and flourish within secure borders'' and stability for Lebanon without Syria's domination.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZEICHNER, THEODORE (TED)
description: ZEICHNER-Theodore (Ted). Memorial contributions to help students interested in public interest law to NYU School of Law, Office of Development, 161 6th Ave, 5th floor, New York, NY 10013

title: DYNASTY WANTS BREWERY BACK
description: The Hapsburg family, which ruled empires in Austria and Spain for centuries, won a court ruling allowing it to proceed with its effort to regain control of Zywiec S.A., Poland's largest brewer. Zywiec, founded in 1856 in what was then the Austrian province of Galicia, was seized by the Communists after World War II and later sold to Heineken N.V. Poland has no restitution law for confiscated property, but courts have often ruled in favor of prewar owners, including those of Okocim S.A., a brewer that had been sold to Carlsberg A.S. of Denmark.

title: Richard Williams Raises Issues With WTA
description: A week after Tiger Woods expressed his discontent with the PGA Tour, the father of Venus and Serena Williams said yesterday that his daughters were being taken advantage of by the Women's Tennis Association.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I would not want to win the presidency by a few votes cast in error or misinterpreted or not counted, and I don't think Governor Bush wants that either.''

title: Americans Patiently Awaiting Election Outcome
description: Americans are polarized along party lines over whether Gov. George W. Bush or Vice President Al Gore should rightfully claim the presidency, but they are not panicked over the uncertainty and expect the battling to continue for days if not for the next month, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: RUSSIA'S DEBT RATING RAISED
description: Moody's Investors Service raised Russia's foreign-currency debt rating one notch today, citing the country's rapid economic growth and vastly improved finances. The upgrade is the first since Russia defaulted on its domestic debt two years ago. An upgrade in Russia's Eurobond rating will depend on the success of its talks with its official creditors, called the Paris Club, later this year, Moody's said. Sabrina Tavernise

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALLA, FLORENCE
description: VALLA-Florence. Died November 10, at Roosevelt Hospital. Lifelongfriend of the late Pearl Rubenstein. Graduate of Cooper Union. Advertising agency art director. Co-owner with her friend Ruth Stark of Stark-Valla Emporium in Greenwich Village. Manager of the Mt. Sinai Hospital Gift Shop. Service 12 noon, Monday, November 20, at Buckley Funeral Home, 445 West 43 St. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Behind a ''Noble Toga,'' Find Naked Ambitions
description: The English writer Aldous Huxley would have understood precisely what is taking place in Florida. He could very well have been talking about the struggle there when he wrote, ''Idealism is the noble toga political gentlemen draw over their will to power.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEFFER, ALVIN M.
description: JEFFER-Alvin M. Of Jericho, NY and Boca Raton, FL, at home, lovingly surrounded by family on November 12, 2000. He was 75. For 53 years dearly treasured husband of Irma, loving and devoted to his children Rhonda and Eric Moore, Debra and Sanford Gips and the late Kenneth Robert Jeffer. Adored grandfather of Harris, Gordon, Spencer and Julia. Beloved brother of Medwin B. Jeffer and dear brother-in-law of Sanford and Sandra Smith. He was at one time the owner of Jeffer Funeral Home, with which he remained affiliated, helping peple in their time of need with tremendous compassion and kindness. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral service at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel,'' Queens Boulevard and 76th Rd., Forest Hills, NY, Tuesday, November 14, at 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLTON, ELSIE L.
description: CARLTON-Elsie L. Passed away November 12, 2000. Survived by son Richard and wife Joan, daughter Ronnie and husband David, granddaughters Laurie and Karen, and great granddaughter Kaylie Rose, sisters Irma Jacobs and Eva Lieberman, and many dear friends. Funeral services Tuesday, November 14, 10:30 AM, I. J. Morris, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, SOLOMON ISRAEL
description: SIEGEL-Solomon Israel. November 11, 2000, age 86, of Hartsdale, NY. Survived by wife Sylvia. Loving father of Michael R. Siegel, Esq., Daniel C. Siegel and Joanne R. Aldeborgh and loving grandfather of Mark W. Siegel, Julia B. Siegel, H. Nikki Aldeborgh, Winsor R. Aldeborgh and David J. Siegel. Services were held. We will miss him deeply and he will forever be a part of us.

title: Justices Reject Bid to Regain Damages Over Strip Search
description: The United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to review a case in which a woman sought reinstatement of $5 million in punitive damages awarded because she was illegally strip-searched in a New York City jail in 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELNICK, DR. JACOB
description: MELNICK-Dr. Jacob, age 93, of Monroe Twp., NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, Nov. 12, 2000. Husband of Beatrice (Freed). Father of Judith Barbara Brickman, Arthur and Laurence. Grandfather of 3. Service 12:15 PM Tuesday, Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, Cranbury Rd. at Evergreen Boulevard, East Brunswick. Memorials to Dr. Jacob & Beatrice Melnick Fund of Middlesex County Jewish Federation, 230 Old Bridge Turnpike, South River, New Jersey 08882.

description: Following are Sections 102.111 and 102.112 of Florida law, which apply to the handling of vote counts:

title: Sports of The Times; Recalling The Tragedy At Marshall
description: IT was about 8 o'clock on Saturday night, Nov. 14, 1970 -- 30 years ago today -- when Reggie Oliver, a quarterback on the Marshall University freshman team, heard the news of the airplane crash as it crackled over his car radio.

title: Dot-Coms Intrude in the Land of Needle and Thread
description: Jack Ratusch knew something was amiss when he ran into his friend the button man, prowling Midtown with a real estate agent. Bad news is often no news in the garment business. But Mr. Ratusch, who is president of the Garment Center Congregation, a conservative synagogue on West 40th Street, has been around the rag trade for more than 50 years. That's long enough to know that while coat men come and go and better dresses can be fly-by-night, buttons are forever. Or at least they used to be.

title: Pricing Strategy Pays Off for Phillips at Auction
description: Marketing is everything, especially when it comes to auctions. And Phillips, the struggling No. 3 auction house, purposely placed unusually low estimates on works in its sale of contemporary art last night, often far less than they had paid for them. The strategy worked. In a sale of consistently frenzied bidding, only 2 of the 47 works on offer on offer failed to sell. The sale totaled $10.6 million, just above its high estimate of $10.4 million.

title: Voters' Lawsuits Delayed by Recusal
description: There were so many lawyers jammed into Courtroom 4C here today that they filled every seat in the jury box and the first three rows of the gallery. One lawyer even sat, cross-legged, on the carpeted floor.

title: Black, Elite and Proud; Catering to 'a Certain Class,' With No Apologies
description: They sat in pumpkin-colored leather chairs over low tables sipping apple martinis, pale green with slivers of Granny Smith at the top. They said they did not come to Aubette, a swank bar with auburn lighting, for intimacy. But as they spoke, their eyes discreetly scanned the room.

title: Gee, From Dodging Bullets to Fending Off Wisecracks
description: Just in time for holiday giving, here comes the Sitcom-o-Matic. Now there's no need to bother thinking up a television series. Just turn on your Sitcom-o-Matic and sit back while its microchips randomly choose a familiar premise and throw familiar actors into familiar roles. This digital wonder can churn out enough meaningless dialogue to fill the required minutes and compensate with a cascade of laughter that shamelessly begs for affection.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS MIXED. The dollar was little changed amid the uncertainty of the presidential election. In New York, the euro settled at 86.07 cents, down from 86.25 cents on Friday. The dollar traded at 107.63 yen, down from 107.72.

title: Lung Cancer Cure? Try Prevention Instead
description: In January 1964, when the surgeon general of the Public Health Service issued the first report on smoking and health, linking tobacco to a host of serious diseases, including and especially lung cancer, the most common statement from the many smokers I interviewed was, ''By the time I get lung cancer, they'll know how to cure it.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AXELROD, MARTY
description: AXELROD-Marty. 8/10/20-11/14/90 Beloved husband, adored father, devoted grandfather and great grandfather, loving brother and generous friend. Every day in our thoughts and hearts, and forever missed. Your Loving Family

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, ELAINE
description: FOX-Elaine. On November 13, 2000 at the age of 68. Beloved wife of Israel Teitelbaum and the late Dr. Leonard Fox. Loving mother of Dr. Steven, Douglas, and Joanne. Mother-in-law of Jan and John. Adoring grandmother of Stacey, Lara, Lauren, and Erica. Devoted daughter of Jeanette Landow. Service on Wednesday 1:30 PM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Caesar's Commentaries: Unraveling Source of Genius
description: It has been argued for years: Who gets credit for the inspired comedy of such classics of early television as ''Your Show of Shows''? The newly discovered documents from Max Liebman's closet could help resolve the questions.

title: Clijsters Subdues Sanchez-Vicario
description: The unveiling of Kim Clijsters continued last night as the 17-year-old from Belgium shook off jet lag, stepped forth as a last-second entrant in a tournament for the elite, then played as if she belonged among the stars at Madison Square Garden.

title: CON ED SAID TO THREATEN TO SCRAP DEAL WITH NORTHEAST
description: Consolidated Edison will scrap its proposed $7.5 billion buyout of Northeast Utilities unless Connecticut regulators agree before the end of the month to reconsider proposed restrictions on the merger, or unless Northeast shareholders accept a lower offer, according to analysts. Con Ed has asked the state to reconsider a ruling that called for bigger rate cuts for one of Northeast's utilities, Connecticut Light and Power, and has objected to other restrictions on the deal, which would create a utility with more customers than any other. As it stands, Con Ed's offer for Northeast, made in October 1999, is for $25 a share in stock or cash, plus assumption of $4.2 billion in debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, RITA C.
description: McLAUGHLIN-Rita C. On November 12, in New York City at the age of 87. Daughter of the late Thomas P. and Mary G. of Jersey City. Rita worked in the Personnel Dept of Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. for 43 years and retired in March, 1976. She was a member of the Immaculate Conception Church for over 50 years. She was predeceased by her two brothers, Edmund and his wife Anna and Thomas F. and his wife, Mary, her sister, Helen McGuire and her husband, Edward, and her niece Mary Jane Ciotta. Rita was survived by her nephew, Thomas P. and four nieces, Maureen Gonzalez, Ellen McGuire, Patricia Reihman, and Rita MacIndoe. She was also survived by 16 grand nieces and grand nephews and nine great grand nieces and grand nephews. Visiting at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave at 20th St, NYC, Wednesday, 2-4:30 PM and 79 PM. A Mass of Christian burial Immaculate Conception Church, 11 AM Thursday. Interment Holy Name Cemetery, Jersey City, N.J.

title: W.T.O. Sets Date to Discuss China's Entry
description: The World Trade Organization has set a new date, in early December, to try to complete China's entry into the organization.

title: Vanishing Livestock Breeds Leave Diversity Gap
description: With its bare face, belly and legs, the Gulf Coast native sheep of Florida, Georgia and Louisiana looks perpetually half-shorn, like a parody of a show poodle. But to many animal scientists, this odd creature represents a living piece of early American history that may help improve the sheep industry in the Southeast.

title: Electing a President: Into the Second Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Expanded Logging Ban Is Proposed for National Forests
description: The Forest Service recommended today that President Clinton expand the scope of a planned environmental initiative by banning virtually all commercial logging from the remaining roadless areas of the national forests.

title: Mets Pull Out of the Rodriguez Sweepstakes
description: The All-Star shortstop Alex Rodriguez is among the game's most talented and popular players, even while spending the first seven years of his career in the baseball outpost of Seattle. Free agency was supposed to not only make him the richest player ever, but also allowed him to move to New York, where his star would shine brighter than ever.

title: Electing a President: Into the Second Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Sinclair, 78, Television Actress of the 50's
description: Mary Sinclair, an actress who was a familiar face to television viewers in the 1950's, died on Nov. 5 in Phoenix. She was 78 and lived in Phoenix.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Way We Win
description: For foreigners, the most important aspect of this American election is not who wins, but how he wins.

title: Electing a President: Into the Second Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees To Begin Talks With Mussina
description: The agent for pitcher Mike Mussina will meet with Yankees officials tomorrow in their first face-to-face meetings, and they will presumably discuss a deal that could surpass the seven-year, $105 million contract signed by Kevin Brown with the Los Angeles Dodgers two years ago.

title: For the Most Part, the Republicans Close Ranks Behind Bush After a Defeat in Federal Court
description: With rare exceptions, Republicans backed Gov. George W. Bush's approach to Florida's murky election returns today, even after the Bush campaign's suit to block further recounting by hand was thrown out by a federal judge in Miami.

title: Ecologist Loses Political Race in San Francisco
description: Last Tuesday, Dr. Joan Roughgarden, a Stanford University ecologist, lost her bid to become supervisor of District 6 in San Francisco, receiving just 434 out of more than 17,000 votes cast.

title: A Deadly Link: Smoking and Aneurysms
description: Doctors say they have found a link between cigarette smoking and ruptured aneurysms, the sudden, devastating medical condition that leaves 60 percent of its sufferers dead or disabled.

title: Electing a President: Into the Second Week
description: To the Editor:

title: The Public School Emergency
description: Gov. George Pataki and New York State legislative leaders have understandably been preoccupied with state and national politics. But they now need to focus quickly on a dramatic teacher shortage that is undermining a statewide effort to raise public school standards and graduation requirements. Instead of tinkering at the margins, Albany needs to develop coherent solutions to attract qualified new teachers to areas of the state where they are most needed. One way to do that is to draw on programs that have proved effective elsewhere.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Herbert Kraft, 73, Archaeologist Who Studied Reign of the Lenape
description: Herbert Clemens Kraft, an archaeologist whose research threw light on the long reign of the Lenape, New Jersey's earliest inhabitants, died Oct. 31 at his home in Elizabeth, N.J., his birthplace. He was 73.

title: ORACLE IN PARTNERSHIP WITH COMPAQ
description: Oracle and Compaq yesterday announced a partnership to package Oracle's most recent application server, the 9i, inside a Compaq machine. Oracle said the new Internet appliance, scheduled for release in December, should greatly reduce the time spent installing application servers, to just minutes instead of weeks. Michael S. Rocha, Oracle's senior vice president for platform technologies, said the biggest impediment to Oracle's growth had been the complexity of installing and managing the database servers. The ability to buy a server machine with the software already installed, he said, will make running a server essentially a plug-and-play experience. Industry analysts agreed that the reduced cost of installing an Oracle server should help the company, which already dominates the database server market, and improve its showing in the more wide-open application server market.

title: Putin Critic Yields Control of His Media Empire to the Kremlin
description: The Russian media mogul Vladimir V. Gusinsky, a fierce critic of his government and deeply in debt, tentatively agreed today to give up control of his publishing and broadcasting empire to the country's natural gas monopoly, which is controlled by the Russian government.

title: New Findings on Fallopian Implants
description: A new study has found that, contrary to other reports, two methods of in vitro fertilization have about the same success rate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROYCE, ARTHUR M.
description: ROYCE-Arthur M. On November 9, 2000 at age 85. Devoted husband to Florence. Loving father to Robert. Uncle to Susan and Allen. Dear friend to many. We will always remember him with love.

title: The Day's Death Toll: Four Israelis and Two Palestinians
description: Palestinian snipers today killed two Israeli soldiers and a civilian on a West Bank highway, and Israeli soldiers were accused of shooting two youths dead near their homes in the Gaza Strip.

title: Nazi Labor Case Gains
description: Judge William G. Bassler of Federal District Court here today dismissed 45 of the 49 suits against German companies that used forced labor under the Nazis, moving toward disbursing $5.1 billion in a trust established for victims.

title: A Wizard, Cute Lizards and a Prince With a Feather
description: All that glitters looks like gold in the dazzling new version of ''The Firebird'' that James Kudelka has just choreographed for the National Ballet of Canada.

title: Parker Out at Least 2 Weeks
description: Giants left guard Glenn Parker will be out for at least two weeks with a partly torn left calf muscle, and wide receiver Amani Toomer is questionable for the Giants' game this Sunday against the Detroit Lions because of a concussion.

title: 2 From New York Area In College Tournament
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association announced the 32 bids for the men's tournament yesterday, and St. John's and Connecticut were the only local teams to be invited. Columbia and Seton Hall were the only other teams from the area under consideration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, HENRY G.
description: WALTER-Henry G. The Board, staff and volunteers of Thirteen/ WNET New York express their sorrow at the passing of Henry G. Walter, Jr., husband of longtime Board member and dear friend, Rosalind P. Walter. Together Hank and Roz have made an enormous impact on this City through their support and involvement with so many institutions. We are all the grateful beneficiaries of their commitment and dedication. Our sincere condolences to Roz and the family. Steven Rattner, Chairman Bill Baker, President

title: Corrections
description: A picture of a building on Maxwell Street in Chicago with the continuation of a front-page article on Sunday about the building boom there carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Steve Kagan for The New York Times, not Stephen Carrera.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOOMJY, ALICE S.
description: MOOMJY-Alice S. Of Westfield, N.J. Wife of Albert. Mother of Alexander and Robert. Sister of John Condayan. Died November 12, 2000. Alice is also survived by her daughter-in-law Maureen and three grandchildren. Friends may call at the Higgins & Bonner Echo Wake Funeral Home, 582 Springfield Ave, Westfield, N.J. Wednesday, November 15th, 7-9PM. Funeral servcies will be held 1:30PM Thursday, November 16th at Saint Mary's Armenian Church, 200 West Mount Pleasant Avenue, Livingston, N.J. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Haven Hospice, C/O JFK Medical Center, 65 James St, Edison, N.J. 08818 or Saint Mary's Armenian Church.

title: A VOTE DEADLINE IN FLORIDA IS SET FOR TODAY
description: The disputed presidential election results were thrown into new uncertainty today when Florida's Republican secretary of state declared that she would enforce a legal Tuesday evening deadline for certifying the statewide vote, even as predominantly Democratic counties moved forward with hand recounts of ballots that might not be finished in time and both sides wrangled in court.

title: Silicon Alley Rentals Are Hot As Dot-Coms Suddenly Aren't
description: To Web site designers, programmers and other technology workers, the shakeout that has doomed many a New York City Internet company has been sobering. But landlords in Silicon Alley say they think the dot-com blues may be sweet for them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PURNHAGEN, EVELYN H.
description: PURNHAGEN-Evelyn H. Died peacefully at home in New York City on Nov. 12, 2000. Beloved mother of Barbara Gerbasi and Michael Purnhagen. Cherished grandmother of five and great grandmother of 3. Reposed at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset on Monday. Funeral Mass Tuesday, November 14, 2000, 10 AM at St. Marys RC Church, Manhasset.

title: A drama about the ad world and the people who make it work.
description: THE esoteric process required to prepare food and other products for close-ups in television commercials and print advertisements doesn't seem as if it would offer observers any drama -- much less enough drama for an off-Broadway play.

title: NEWPORT NEWS SHIPBUILDING FACES NAVY PENALTY
description: The profit for Newport News Shipbuilding Inc. from building the aircraft carrier Ronald Reagan may by cut by as much as $18 million because of cost overruns, the Navy said. Higher labor costs after a strike last year and a delay in other shipyard work that lowered productivity have pushed expenses $89 million above the original $2.31 billion cost estimate, and the contract between Newport News, the only shipyard that builds nuclear carriers, and the Navy calls for the company to absorb part of the overruns; if it can get the total cost down below $2.31 billion by the time the ship is scheduled to be delivered in 2003, it can earn a bonus.

title: State Law on Third-Party Ballot Spots Is Overturned
description: A New York State law frequently cited in efforts to disqualify third-party or other lesser-established candidates from state or local election ballots has been ruled unconstitutional by the United States Court of Appeals.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Distracted Congress Pushes to Delay Spending Talks
description: The House approved a three-week stop-gap spending measure today, raising the possibility that Congress's lame duck session will last into next month.

title: In Amazon Basin, an Advanced Society Before Columbus
description: While other archaeologists spend their careers looking for ''lost'' cities, Dr. Clark L. Erickson of the University of Pennsylvania Museum keeps a practiced eye out for ''lost'' landscapes.

title: Mother Lode of TV Comedy Is Found in Forgotten Closet
description: The Egyptians may have King Tut's tomb. But now New Yorkers have Max Liebman's closet.

title: What About the Doctor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Saying He Doesn't Expect to Be Final Arbiter, Judge Won't Stop Hand Recount
description: After hearing two hours of argument about the nexus between democracy and chads, a federal judge paused barely an instant today before handing Vice President Al Gore an important victory in the first courtroom battle of the postelection.

title: No Surprise, Martinez Gets Cy Young Award
description: Pedro Martinez won five fewer games this season than he did in 1999, he had fewer strikeouts, allowed more home runs and the Boston Red Sox did not make the playoffs. But Martinez was so much better than any other American League pitcher that he won the Cy Young award unanimously yesterday -- becoming the first to do so in consecutive years.

title: Far From Florida, a Cliffhanger Recount in Physics
description: Last week, at the leading European particle physics laboratory, CERN, an institution straddling the French-Swiss border far from the superhot center of American politics but well within its sphere of influence, the question arose: is it more important to determine who the next American president will be or to discover why all matter in the universe has mass, rather than weighing nothing?

title: Castro Is No Role Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAY, DANIEL Y.
description: MAY-Daniel Y. Daniel died November 10, 2000. Funeral and interment were on November 12. Treasured husband of Debra and adoring father of Elisheva Chaya and Benjamin Moshe, beloved son of Naomi and Sheldon and devoted brother of Rena, Malka and Joshua, loving grandson of Milton May, the late Mildred May and the late Hadassah Finkelstein, dear son-in-law of Toby and Howard Stahl, cherished grandson-in-law of Edna Stahl and caring brotherin-law of Cindy and Jonathan Sherman, Margaret and Sharon Stahl, and kind friend to many.

title: Troopers' Arrest-Records Trial Is Delayed
description: The trial of two state troopers accused of falsifying arrest records in New Jersey's racial profiling shooting case was postponed today until January. The stay will give the prosecution and defense time to prepare for the state's appeal of the dismissal of attempted murder charges against the two men.

title: Ex-Official Uses City Car Four Years After Leaving
description: Four years after stepping down from his post in the Giuliani administration as a deputy mayor, John S. Dyson still has a city car and driver assigned to carry him to meetings related to city business and private matters in between.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Weyerhaeuser Makes Offer For Willamette Industries

title: INVESTORS SEEK REMAINING SHARES OF CB RICHARD ELLIS
description: A group of investors led by Blum Capital Partners offered to acquire the 62 percent of CB Richard Ellis Services that it did not already own for $15.50 a share, or about $340 million, in cash plus assumption of about $400 million in debt. The investor group includes Ellis's chief executive, Ray Wirta; its chairman for the Americas, Brett White; the Koll Holding Company, run by Don Koll, an Ellis director; and a private investment company, Freeman Spogli & Company. Ellis, based in Los Angeles, is the largest commercial real estate broker, with 10,000 employees and $1.2 billion in 1999 revenue.

title: Who's to Blame for the Middle East Violence?
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: District of Columbia Takes A Campaign to the Streets
description: Hundreds of local vehicles are spreading a revolutionary message, with new license plates denouncing the city's plight: ''Taxation Without Representation.''

title: Pension Fund to Scale Back Hedge Investments
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System has drastically scaled back an ambitious plan to invest in hedge funds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, LOUISE WEISS
description: FOX-Louise Weiss. Beloved as wife of David, mother of Amy, Michal, Heather, Erica and James. Bubbie of Zachariah, Jonah and Sarah. Sister of Myron, Allen and Helene. A loving, generous, warm, compassionate and brilliant woman who enriched the lives of all who knew her. She will be lovingly remembered and missed every day. Services Tuesday, November 14th, at noon at Temple Beth-El, 221 Schraalenburgh Rd., Closter, NJ. Shiva at family home Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, 3-5 and 7-9. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to either the Louise Fox Fund, Project Ezra, 197 E. Broadway, N.Y., N.Y. 10002 or the Yiddish Book Center, 1021 West St., Amherst, MA 01002. For info, ''Wien & Wien,'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, HYMAN
description: WEISS-Hyman. Beloved husband of Annie, adored father of Brian, Beverly and Sheri, devoted fatherin-law of Kenneth Eldi and Ada Weiss, cherished grandfather of Howard and Holly. He will be missed.

title: Burnett to Promote New Hallmark Line
description: Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, the lead agency for Hallmark Cards Inc. will promote a new line of Hallmark cards, gift items and other products featuring the work of the poet Maya Angelou.

title: Public Interests; Finally, Y2K Kicks In
description: One of the best parts of watching all-recount-all-the-time news on cable TV is that between breaking bulletins (''This in from Volusia County . . .'') and press conferences by former secretaries of state (''Grebbegannagrebbadueprocess'') you get commercials for the American Association of Professional Psychics, ''registered with the U.S. government and guaranteed authentic.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Corporate Family Ties That Bind Tight
description: The web of interlocking directorates can produce some odd situations, particularly when one company totally dominates another company's board.

title: LOSS GROWS AT MITSUBISHI MOTORS
description: Group net losses at Mitsubishi Motors widened to 75.6 billion yen ($700 million) for the six months ended Sept. 30, almost double the figure from 1999. The company cited the weak yen and a scandal in Japan over customer complaints about faulty cars that had been covered up for decades. Forecast losses for the full year also doubled, to 140 billion yen ($1.3 billion), on expected revenue of 3.4 trillion yen. But Takashi Sonobe, Mitsubishi's president, said the company's plan to reduce its debt to 1.3 trillion yen by the end of March was on track. Miki Tanikawa

title: CRIMINAL INQUIRY ON I.P.O.
description: World Online Holding N.V., the Amsterdam-based Internet access company whose offices were raided yesterday, said that Dutch prosecutors were investigating possible insider trading related to its March initial public offering and that the company was cooperating. In March, investors learned that Nina Brink, the former chairwoman, had sold shares three months before the offering; World's stock has fallen by 70 percent since then. Goldman, Sachs & Company; ABN AMRO Rothschild; and Ms. Brink are targets of the criminal investigation, but World Online is not, a spokesman for the prosecutors said.

title: Lawyers Give Plan to Split Auction-Case Settlement
description: The lead lawyers representing the more than 100,000 buyers and sellers in a recently settled class-action lawsuit against the Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses have detailed for the first time how they propose to divide the $512 million settlement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSTER, MORRIS
description: KOSTER-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of its member, beloved husband of Sylvia. We express profound condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: New Life For Ewing, If Not For Sonics
description: Patrick Ewing caught the ball in the post and went to work today. He faked left and took a power dribble into the paint while spinning quickly to get himself open for a hook shot in front of the basket. His shot bounced off the rim, but that was immaterial. What was notable was the swiftness with which he moved.

title: ROYAL PHILIPS TO ACQUIRE ADAC LABORATORIES
description: Royal Philips Electronics N. V. agreed yesterday to acquire Adac Laboratories, a maker of medical imaging equipment based in Milpitas, Calif., for $426 million, or $18.50 a share, a slight premium to Adac's Friday closing price of $18.12. Philips will combine Adac, which specializes in nuclear imaging, with its existing medical systems division. Adac has 1,070 employees and had sales of $324 million in 1999.

title: Key Roads Taken From Rebels, Colombia Says
description: A military offensive aimed at breaking a 50-day blockade of a southern province has wrested control of crucial roads, government officials said today. More than 20 guerrillas died in the fighting, the officials added.

title: Go With Fuzzy Logic
description: In the first couple of days after Election Day, as lawyers and reporters swarmed around the unlikely constituency for Pat Buchanan in Palm Beach, Fla., it looked as if the 2000 election would be the first to be decided by bad graphic design. Then the phrase ''hanging chad'' entered the debate, and the question was whose supporters were more likely to succeed at punching a hole through a card. Now, in the fight over recounting ballots by hand, the issue turns out to be whether perceptual and analytic skills of machines are better than those of humans -- a strangely fitting theme for the first election of the 21st century.

title: Gore Urges Calm as the Votes Are Recounted
description: For the first time since the election, Vice President Al Gore commented today about the bizarre goings-on of the last week, calling for patience on the part of the public as ballots are tallied in Florida.

title: Metro Business Briefing; SIGNS OF A SLOWING ECONOMY
description: New York City's torrid economy could be on the verge of a slowdown, according to a report released yesterday by economists working for Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller. Their report found that help-wanted advertising, a traditional indicator used to forecast economic conditions, declined slightly in the third quarter. Another indicator, initial unemployment claims, rose; many temporary government workers lost their jobs in the third quarter as the federal census was completed. On the other hand, private-sector job creation was still strong, the unemployment rate fell and income tax collections rose.

title: In the Course of Human Events, Lady Luck Had a Role
description: FOUNDING BROTHERS

title: Grueling 'Play'
description: To the Editor:

title: First Dozens of Bodies Recovered in Alps Tunnel
description: Recovery workers today painstakingly extracted the charred bodies of 66 victims among at least 159 skiers killed in an Alpine tunnel fire on Saturday, but forensic experts said it could take weeks to identify all the bodies.

title: Gore Spurns Victory by Votes 'in Error'
description: Following are excerpts from remarks yesterday by Vice President Al Gore and Warren Christopher, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: A Melodious Paean to Love With Spirit and Sincerity
description: Patti LuPone's evening of song, ''Matters of the Heart,'' is being performed in the lofty grandeur of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center, but it creates the sedate atmosphere of a salon. The lush green backdrop curtain, the elegant flower bowl perched on the piano, Ms. LuPone's de la Renta gowns and her formally attired accompanists -- a pianist, Dick Gallagher, who is also the arranger and musical director, and a string quartet -- all contribute to an intimate formality that the music never disturbs and never tries to.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, SHELDON
description: ROSS-Sheldon, 75. On November 12, 2000. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Loving father of Robert and Laurie. Dear brother-in-law of Jeff (Mimi) Licht, Vera Rabino and uncle of Erica Licht and Michele Kogon. Resident of Manhattan, formerly of Detroit, he taught those around him to love the arts. He leaves behind many friends and colleagues who will dearly miss his warmth, wit and kindness. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., 212288-3500, Wednesday, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow in Amenia, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Daniel Ferro Vocal Program, Inc., 575 Madison Avenue, Suite 1006, NY NY 10022 or to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIMSTON, BLANCHE K.
description: DIMSTON-Blanche K. With your eyes we saw the beauty, and with your spirit we experienced the joy. It continues, and we think of you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEFSBERG, VALERIE
description: JOSEFSBERG-Valerie. Temple Sinai of Bergen County deeply mourns the death of our longtime member, Valerie Josefsberg, beloved mother of Henny Goldstein and Bernard Josefsberg. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire family. Dr. Bruce S. Block, Rabbi Jane Koch Gellman, President

title: Constant Craving
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: DAIHATSU PROFITS SOAR
description: The Daihatsu Motor Company of Japan said first-half group profit rose 74 percent, to 5.2 billion yen ($48.2 million), or 12.3 yen a share, on record demand for its minicars. It also said it expected to earn 16 billion yen, or 37.5 yen a share, for the year on sales of 1 trillion yen.

title: U.S. Classifies Wild Salmon In Maine Rivers as Threatened
description: Federal officials today placed the wild Atlantic salmon in eight Maine rivers on the endangered species list, saying the fish faced threats from their farm-bred brethren and other factors that put them on the brink of extinction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, MARIAN F.
description: MARTIN-Marian F. On November 12, 2000. Loving wife of the late Merrill Martin, mother, grandmother and friend. Humanitarian, civil rights activist, caregiver, and gardener. She is survived by her daughters, Elizabeth and Susan, her son-in-law, Alan, her grand daughter, Lily, brother Melvyn, sister-in-law, Honey, nieces Melanie and Valerie, grandnephew, Keone. Services on Tuesday 12:30 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONSON, ELLEN
description: ARONSON-Ellen. Loving mother and outstanding Physical Therapist. Ellen Aronson passed away Monday morning November 13. Ellen is and always will be fondly remembered by her daughters, partners, and friends. A funeral service will be held Wednesday, November 16, 11 A.M. at the Beecher Funeral Home, 1 Putnam Ave, Brewster. Shiva will be held at 88 Sodom Rd in Brewster. All who loved Ellen are welcome to attend.

title: Electing a President: Into the Second Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Weyerhaeuser Bids for Willamette
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company disclosed yesterday that it had made a $5.3 billion, $48-a-share cash offer to purchase Willamette Industries, setting the stage for a hostile takeover battle.

title: G.O.P. in Wisconsin Collects Election Complaints and Considers Asking for a Recount
description: Describing Election Day problems ranging from accusations that some people voted more than once to claims that homeless people were bribed with cigarettes to vote for Democrats, Republicans said today that they were considering whether to seek a recount in Wisconsin.

title: Three Main Nationalist Parties Showing Strength in Bosnia Vote
description: Early results from general elections on Saturday show the three main nationalist parties all leading in their respective ethnic communities, according to results released today by international election organizers.

title: A Nascent Internet Takes Root in Vietnam; Gleaning Lessons Of What Is Called The 'People's War'
description: Ask Truong Gia Binh whom he looks to for inspiration in running Vietnam's largest technology company, and he doesn't name William H. Gates, Steve Jobs or any other Silicon Valley warrior.

title: Electing a President: Into the Second Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUNER, ROBERT ALEXANDER
description: BLAUNER-Robert Alexander. On November 12, 2000. Robert died in peace at age 23 after a heroic fight with Hodgkin's disease. He is survived by his parents, Allan S. and Loretta; his siblings, Stephen, Peter and Patsy; and his grandmother, Josephine Steinberg Libman. A memorial service for Robert's friends and family will be held in several weeks. For information, please contact lsb@compucore.net. Memorial donations may be made in Robert's name to Yale Stem Cell Program, c/o Dr. Dennis Cooper, Yale University School of Medicine, Medical Oncology, 333 Cedar Street-WWW220, New Haven, CT. 06510.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIDMAN, ZORA
description: WEIDMAN-Zora. Lilith Magazine mourns the death of Zora Weidman in Winnipeg on November 10th. She is survived by her children, Dr. Martin Weidman and our editor-in-chief, Susan Weidman Schneider, and their families. At the request of the family, donations in Zora Weidman's memory may be made to Lilith Magazine in New York.

title: Electing a President: Into the Second Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, EDWARD J.
description: McGUIRE-Edward J. On November 13, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Carmen. Devoted father of Edward Jr. and Eugene. Dear brother of the late Duncan. Loving grandfather of Matthew, Meloney, Benjamin, Lauren and Christopher. Funeral services are private. Contact Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road, Rye, NY.

title: Atop I.B.M.'s Agenda: Telecommunications
description: Trying to capitalize on the latest technical trends in the telecommunications industry, I.B.M. plans to announce an alliance today intended to help communications carriers expand and revamp their networks, company executives said yesterday.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court to Decide Fine Point On Use of Force by Police
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve an important and longstanding dispute over how to assess police officers' liability in suits for damages over the use of excessive force.

title: CMGI Closing 2 Units as Revenue Falls Short
description: CMGI, a holding company that had been one of the Internet's highest fliers, said yesterday that it would close two of its businesses and that its sales for the quarter would fall short of expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABIN, LEAH
description: RABIN-Leah. The officers and staff of UJA-Federation of New York profoundly mourn the passing of Leah Rabin, widow of former Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin. Like her husband, Leah was a tireless warrior for peace and security not just for Israel's people but for Jews worldwide. She carried on her husband's legacy with devotion and a sense of mission. The New York Jewish community in general and UJAFederation in particular remain eternally grateful for her work and devotion to the cause of peace and Jewish peoplehood. We extend our deepest condolences to her children and family and the people of Israel. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair John Ruskay, Ex. VP & CEO

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Oct. 26 about using quantum physics to reduce chip size mischaracterized a process by which smaller wavelengths of light could be produced to help manufacture smaller chips. In the process, the wavelength of light from a laser could be reduced to 124 nanometers from 248 nanometers, to produce transistors 62 nanometers wide. The wavelength would not actually be reduced to 62 nanometers.

title: The Consulting Gambit: Think Technology and Sell Stock
description: Hewlett-Packard has sent PricewaterhouseCoopers back to the drawing board.

title: Electing a President: Into the Second Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Publicis Groupe Acquires Nelson
description: Publicis Groupe S. A. in Paris said yesterday that, as expected, it had acquired Nelson Communications in New York, a health care marketing and communications company, in a stock and cash deal with undisclosed terms.

title: Rate Commission Clears Way for Penny Rise in Price of Stamp
description: Mailing a letter in the United States will probably become a cent more expensive in January.

title: 42 Players in a Conspiracy To Sound Like Far Fewer
description: Many conductors of full-sized orchestras assert that their goal is to get the players to listen to one another and work together as if they were playing chamber music. Of course, conductors of a more authoritarian bent actually cultivate absolute submission and uniformity of execution among their players, and the result can be like some stiff musical equivalent of synchronized swimming at the Olympics.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ULLMAN, SUSAN BETH
description: ULLMAN-Susan Beth. Bunniest Heart, for your birthday, November 14, we love you forever. Mom, Dad, Bill, Jamie, Uncle Lou, Aunt Dorothy.

title: When Teams Say No, And Then Tell Why
description: It's not enough for Alex Rodriguez to be baseball's highest-paid player, at more than $20 million annually. He also wants the opportunity to step back after a few years and assess his contract and see if he's making enough money. And he wants a public relations staff of at least four, paid by the team, to serve him.

title: Buzzi Unicem Stock Shift
description: Buzzi Unicem S.p.A., a big cement producer, said today that it would do away with a special class of stock called savings stock by converting them into common shares to simplify its capital structure. The company will exchange 16 common shares for each 25 savings shares, a tiny premium over the savings shares' closing price on Friday. The savings shares, which have no voting rights but pay a higher dividend than common shares, were authorized under a 1974 government program.

title: US AIRWAYS SEES A MONTH'S DELAY IN MERGER APPROVAL
description: The US Airways Group Inc. said it anticipated that regulators would approve its proposed acquisition by the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, a month later than initially expected. US Airways ''believes that efforts sufficient to satisfy the regulatory requirements can be concluded during the month of January 2001 and that the merger will be completed promptly following satisfaction of such requirements,'' the company said in a quarterly Securities and Exchange Commission filing. To address anticipated antitrust concerns, UAL and US Airways proposed selling some assets in Washington to Robert Johnson, a US Airways director and the chairman of BET Holdings. He would would use them to create a new airline called DC Air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADLER, JOSEPH B.
description: NADLER-Joseph B. Devoted husband for fifty years to the late Harriet. Loving father of Maxine Karas, Lesly Freed Laliberte and L. Gerod Nadler. Beloved fatherin-law of Phil, Jodi and Don. Cherished grandfather of Rick, Nicolle, Gabriel, Andrew, Brittany and Hayden. Dear brother-in-law of Sydell & Leon Hattem and Melvin and Aura Lev. A graduate of Baruch College of N.Y., successful CPA for over fifty years. A loving family man and he will be remembered with a song in our hearts. Services are today, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, ELIZABETH (BETTY)
description: KING-Elizabeth (Betty). Died November 9, 2000 in Clarksville, Tn. She was a former resident of New York, and Executive Secretary to the New York Yankees. She also worked for the New York Mets and was included in the Who's Who in Professional Baseball. She is survived by one nephew, Russell Hunter. Call Sykes Funeral Home for further information. 931-647-1562.

title: Who's to Blame for the Middle East Violence?
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. PLAYED ROLE IN ABSENTEE VOTE
description: In the weeks before the presidential election, Florida Republicans mailed party voters tens of thousands of requests for absentee ballots that were virtually completed, requiring only the applicant's signature and Social Security number.

title: REINFORCEMENTS FOR ISLES
description: The Islanders recalled defensemen Mathieu Biron and Branislav Mezei from Lowell of the American Hockey League for their three-game West Coast trip starting this week.

title: Finance Company in Deal to Get Help
description: The Finova Group, an independent finance company struggling to overcome a liquidity squeeze, announced yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement for an investment of up to $350 million by the Leucadia National Corporation, a financial holding company considered one of the shrewdest investors in troubled companies.

title: Justice and Lawyers Who May Not Comb Their Hair
description: At a party recently a woman was overheard to say: ''My husband and I love watching 'The Practice.' It always gives us something to talk about we hadn't thought much about before, I don't know, like the Fourth Amendment.''

title: Time for a Bush-Gore Summit
description: As I walked through the local airport last week, a baggage handler recognized me and shouted: ''If these two guys can't get together and solve this mess, neither deserves to be president.''

title: Florida Official Has Dual Roles In a Maelstrom
description: The Democrats fighting over the Florida presidential vote focused part of their attack today on Katherine Harris, the elected official who is making some of the pivotal judgments in the post-election struggle and is a Republican Party stalwart who serves in Gov. Jeb Bush's cabinet.

title: UAL OFFERS CELL PHONE BOOKINGS
description: United Airlines has become the first United States carrier to allow travelers to use Internet-enabled cell phones to reserve and buy e-tickets for flights originating in the United States. Since July, customers registered at the company's Web site, www.united.com, have been able to check flight schedules and mileage accounts using their cell phones. Besides ticket purchasing, the options now include itinerary viewing, seat selection and meal preferences. Still, Dan Black, a United official, said the moves were aimed more at preparing for a continued growth of consumers using hand-held devices. Elizabeth Stanton

title: Artery Cleaning and What Spells Success
description: When it is time to choose a surgeon, given the choice between young and inexperienced and older and seasoned, most patients would probably choose the latter.

title: Electing a President: Into the Second Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Your Normal Run-of-the-Motel Cheaters
description: ''The Single Woman-Marred Man Syndrome,'' by Dr. Richard Tuch, (Jason Aronson Inc., $30).

title: The Big City; Stars Propose A Happy End To the Voting
description: FOR some reason, most Americans have thus far ignored a simple solution to the presidential electoral crisis: let the winner be decided at Elaine's. The choice could be resolved there at one dinner by the Emergency Committee of Concerned Citizens 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZODI, JOSEPH (ZODIKOFF)
description: ZODI-Joseph (Zodikoff). Beloved husband of the late Pearl. Loving father of Susan Goldman and her husband, Stuart. Cherished grandfather of Jessica, Paley and Michael. Services Tuesday 1:00 PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Is There a Dr. In the House For 'Seussical'?; Some Rays of Sunshine Upon a Troubled Production
description: Last fall the show was a red hot property and just about every producer in town wanted a piece of it. But by this fall ''Seussical: The Musical'' had become a hot potato, and the theater industry was left wondering where things had gone off-track.

title: The Rural Life; A View From the Roadside
description: Sometimes it seems as though I grew up in the back seat of the family car, face plastered to the window. Summer after summer we drove from Iowa to the Black Hills, to Wyoming, to Colorado, never eastward. We also lived 100 miles, in opposite directions, from both sets of my grandparents, whom we visited again and again. There was always something to look at along the country highways we took, and there was always a way to look at it. The car hummed along the high asphalt crown between the ditches. We drove through thickets of grove shade and farm scent. Barnyards gaped suddenly as we passed and then they closed again as quickly.

title: Q & A
description: Ear Wax

title: Swiss Auction of Wireless Phone Licenses Collapses
description: In just a few months, the auction of Europe's high-speed wireless licenses, once ballyhooed as heralding a new generation of Internet-linked mobile phones and other devices, has turned from cash cow to fiasco.

title: Hewlett-Packard's Profit Disappoints
description: Hewlett-Packard, the nation's third-largest computer company, shocked Wall Street's already jittery technology investors yesterday morning with the news that its earnings had fallen well short of projections despite stronger-than-expected sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAZIN, MEYER
description: KAZIN-Meyer. Beloved husband of Elsie. Loving father of Adele, Philip and Susan, Robert and Susan. Cherished grandfather of Michelle, Elise, and David Spiro, Andrew, Michael & Jeffrey Kazin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENSON, MILTON
description: LEVENSON-Milton, ninety-six, of Boca Raton Fla. Born in Boston, Mass., formerly of New York City. Loving husband of the late Frances, adored father of Ralph (Ruth) Levenson. Cherished grandfather of Neil, Carole, Jimmy and Ellen. Great grandfather of Jeremy and Freddie. Loving companion of Adele Lederer. Services today, November 14, 2000 at 12 noon at Temple Beth El, Boca Raton. Memorial contributions to Boca Raton Community Hospital General Fund, 800 Meadows Road, Boca Raton, FL 33486; Florida Atlantic University Foundation, 777 Glades Road, Boca Raton, FL. 33431 or Temple Beth El, 333 S.W. 4th Ave, Boca Raton, FL 33432. For further infomation ''Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel'', Boca Raton, FL. Toll free 800-992-9262.

title: From the Green Patriarch, A Plea for Planet Earth
description: With his long white beard, flowing black robes, miter and staff, the Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew, the spiritual leader of 200 million Orthodox Christians worldwide, would seem to be more at home talking about the nature of God than about toxic waste.

title: Genetic Studies Promise a Path to Better Treatment of Addictions
description: In a quiet, dark room at the University of Pennsylvania, Edward Coleman, 30, lies back and watches a videotape of addicts like him smoking crack while a PET scanner records each neurochemical nuance of his brain.

title: Electing a President: Into the Second Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Wary Doctors Spurn New Abortion Pill
description: Dr. Linda Prine, a physician with a family practice in Manhattan, openly supports abortion rights. She has signs and buttons around her office saying so, and she tells her patients that she works one day a week at a Planned Parenthood abortion clinic.

title: New York Has Motivation It Needs Against Sonics
description: While it is still questionable whether Latrell Sprewell will play in Seattle on Tuesday night when the Knicks take on Patrick Ewing and the SuperSonics, he still figures that he has an important role to play in the game. With Marcus Camby preparing to take on Ewing, Sprewell planned to provide the necessary spark to Camby's psyche on the long flight to Seattle.

title: No Broad Recount; Appeal is Planned
description: After a full day of partisan bickering and hand counting of 4,000 ballots, Vice President Al Gore today picked up only four votes in the heavily Democratic Broward County, and officials declined to order a broader recount of all the county's ballot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACY, PAUL W.
description: TRACY-Paul W. Suddenly on November 12, 2000. Son of Marylin Noble Tracy and the late William T. Tracy. Brother of Marianne T. Vandervoorn. Uncle of Nicholas, Rebecca and Christopher. A graduate of Georgetown University and Fordham Law School, he was a member of the New York and New Jersey Bar Associations. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, November 14, 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial on Wednesday, November 15th, 10AM St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue and 66 Street. Interment private.

title: Two Ex-Executives Of Bankers Trust Acquitted of Charges
description: Two former executives of the Bankers Trust Corporation were acquitted yesterday of charges they orchestrated the theft of unclaimed client funds and diverted the money to the bank's own coffers to bolster their department's bottom line, a court official said.

title: Auto Workers Stage Walkout For Higher Wages in Brazil
description: Auto workers in the state of Sao Paulo walked off assembly lines today in an effort to persuade car manufacturers, including Ford and General Motors, to increase wages.

title: Experts Explore Deep Sleep and the Making of Memories
description: By isolating slabs of tissue from the brains of sleeping cats and inspecting millions of cells at a time, scientists have discovered what they think may be a key element in the brain's machinery for making long-term memories.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Count Continues in Goodman-Krueger Race for State Senate
description: Backed by a battery of prominent election lawyers, Roy M. Goodman, the longtime Republican state senator, and his Democratic challenger, Liz Krueger, are gearing up for battle today as city officials continue to count ballots cast in their too-close-to-call Senate race.

title: Rise in Health Care Costs Rests Largely on Drug Prices
description: Prescription drugs accounted for 44 percent of the increase in health costs last year, researchers said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ENTERGY CORP., New Orleans, an energy company, has received approval from federal regulators to take over operating licenses for two nuclear plants of the New York Power Authority. The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission staff approved the transfer for Indian Point 3 in Buchanan, N.Y., and the James A. FitzPatrick plant on Lake Ontario north of Syracuse.

title: Electing a President: Into the Second Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENE, JULIET KALIKOW
description: LEVENE-Juliet Kalikow. Beloved wife of Stephen M. Levene and widow of the late Harold J. Kalikow. Loving mother of Peter Kalikow and Penny Wallerstein. Cherished grandmother of Nicholas and Kathryn Kalikow, Jill and Jennifer Wallerstein. Dear mother-in-law of Mary Kalikow and John Wallerstein. Devoted sister of Gertrude Blum, Harold Citrin, Renee Weil and Barbara Goldstein. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Juliet Kalikow Levene Memorial Fund, New York Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Vietnam Hangs Onto a Relic: The Propaganda Poster
description: ''Forever Remember the Contribution of Uncle Ho!''

title: Giants' Radio Fails in Huddle. Over and Out.
description: Kerry Collins stood in the huddle near the St. Louis Rams' goal line, preparing for what would be the pivotal sequence of Sunday's game. Just 2 yards from a touchdown that could pull the Giants to 7 points behind the Rams, the defending Super Bowl champions, Collins's teammates fell silent around him, awaiting the third-down play.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BABSON-UNITED INC., Watertown, Mass., named Peter Meenan, acting chief executive, to the posts of president and chief executive.

title: As Trial Opens, Victim of Brick Attack Describes Ordeal
description: The victim of a brick attack testified in a barely audible voice yesterday that her life of promise was reduced to one of struggle in a violent instant that left her nearly dead on a Midtown sidewalk. The victim, Nicole Barrett, 28, described debilitating injuries, including hearing and memory loss, while Paris Drake, the man charged with trying to kill her, gazed at her on the first day of his trial.

title: TYCO IS BUYING A LUCENT UNIT
description: Tyco International agreed to acquire Lucent Technologies's power-systems unit for $2.5 billion in cash in a move the company hopes will allow it to leverage its strength in selling a wide range of items like fiber optic components, fire protection systems and disposable medical products. The division employs 4,700 people at plants in Mesquite, Tex., and Matamoros, Mexico. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINZ, ANDREW MELCHIOR
description: LINZ-Andrew Melchior. 76, on November 12, 2000 after a long illness. Son of the late Rudolph and Ida Linz, beloved husband of Brigitte Loewy Linz, devoted father of Peter Erwin Linz and Andrea Linz Wyckoff. Dear father-in-law of Ann Secord Linz and Scott Allen Wyckoff. Proud and adoring grandfather of Andrew David Linz, Thomas Gregory Linz and Erica Louise Wyckoff. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral services will be held on Friday, November 17 at 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Linz Memorial Fund for the Gift of Life Program, New York Rotary Foundation, 28 W. 44th St., Suite 1508, NY, NY 10036

title: The Impeachment of Estrada : Day of Political Tumult in Manila
description: MANILA  President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines was impeached Monday without any debate or vote in a stormy session of Congress that lasted just five minutes.

title: When Diseased Gums Can Cause Strokes
description: Another good reason to floss?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARR, GREGORY
description: ZARR-Gregory. On November 12th, 2000. Beloved husband of Roberta. Devoted son of Marie and the late George S. Zarr, Sr. Dear brother of George, Gary, Gale, Glenn and Giulia. Special brother-in-law of Gail, Denise, Kamal, Laurie and Bill. He devoted all of his life to his family, friends and community. We love you and will always miss you.

title: RAIL GROUP PROFIT FALLS
description: The Railtrack Group, the company that owns Britain's railway track and stations, said its first-half profit fell 31 percent as it spent more on safety after three fatal train crashes in three years. The company posted pretax profit of $:175 million ($250 million), or 35.4 pence a share, down from $:252 million in the period a year earlier. Investment rose 36 percent, to $:1.2 billion, or more than twice the level of three years ago. Railtrack also said it would take a charge of $:250 million to pay for track replacement. Suzanne Kapner

title: Philippine Congress Impeaches President on Graft Charges
description: Without a formal vote, President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines was impeached by his country's House of Representatives today on corruption charges centering on millions of dollars in payoffs from illegal gambling.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS GAINS. Natural gas soared as cold weather increased demand for heating fuel. In New York, natural gas for December delivery rose 24.2 cents, or 4.4 percent, to $5.698 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Op-Art; Still Too Close to Call
description: Tom Greenwald is an advertising copywriter. Ron Barrett is the illustrator of "Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs."

title: GRIM REGIME: A special report.; For Burmese, Repression, AIDS and Denial
description: To inoculate themselves against any outbreak of democracy, the generals who run this hermit dictatorship have undertaken two urgent missions of self-preservation.

title: G.E. to Invest $11 Million in UConn Partnership
description: The University of Connecticut and General Electric are forming a partnership that will allow engineering and business students and faculty members to work with G.E. executives to develop advanced computer and Internet-based products, university and company officials said today.

title: Keep Counting in Florida
description: The question before the nation regarding the counting of votes in Florida is actually simple. It is whether the next president should be determined by the most accurate counting of the ballots in that state. By announcing that all of Florida's 67 counties must certify and report their vote totals no later than 5 p.m. today, whether or not the manual counting of ballots has been completed, Katherine Harris, Florida's secretary of state, has made a hasty and partisan judgment. The Florida courts should extend the deadline, as several counties and the Gore camp requested in state court yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about newcomers in the Senate misstated the tenure of Senator William V. Roth of Delaware, who was defeated last week by Thomas R. Carper. Mr. Roth has served five terms, not six.

title: NETPLIANCE MAKING BIG CHANGES
description: Netpliance, a leading maker of inexpensive Internet terminals for consumers, said it was cutting its work force and changing its business focus to market its Internet technologies to broadband service providers. The company is laying off 93 of it 249 employees. Sales of Netpliance's iOpener, a flat-screen terminal, which cost $299 with a subscription to Netpliance's Internet service, declined significantly from the second quarter to the third, accounting for only $230,000 of Netpliance's total third-quarter revenue of $3.8 million. The company said that $3.4 million of that came from subscriptions to its Internet service. AT&T WorldNet and Earthlink said they would continue to market the iOpener with their own Internet service provider services. Catherine Greenman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELFENBEIN, CATHERINE A.
description: HELFENBEIN-Catherine A. On November 10, 2000. A musician and voice teacher at the Juilliard School of Music and Vassar College. Beloved wife of the late Ladisles. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, on Wednesday at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory to the Juilliard School of Music Scholarship Fund would be appreciated.

title: Drug Maker's Profit Falls
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc., which makes brand-name and generic drugs, said today that excess inventory at a recently purchased unit all but wiped out its third-quarter earnings. The company posted operating profit of $2.7 million, or 3 cents a share, down 93 percent from the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 7.1 percent, to $183.4 million. Watson warned in September that profit growth this year and next would be held back by slow sales and high costs at its Schein Pharmaceutical unit, which it bought in August. The company said demand was reviving and it expected 2001 profit of $2.38 to $2.40 a share, above the $2.37 forecast.

title: M.S./Cancer Combo No. 13 And the Coping Mind Game
description: ''The CT scan shows a spot on your liver.''

title: Meola Leaves Earplugs, but Takes His 'A' Game
description: The last time Tony Meola played goalkeeper in a World Cup qualifier was Nov. 19, 1989, as a callow American team traveled to Trinidad and Tobago for the most important match the United States men had ever played.

title: Barkley Vents, and Smiles
description: Erick Barkley said he left St. John's for the National Basketball Association after two years because he was worn down by the suspensions and investigations from the National Collegiate Athletic Association during his tumultuous sophomore season. He returned to the New York area tonight, happy and stress free, even though he is only playing 3.3 minutes a game.

title: Giants and Jets Bumped From Fast Lane
description: When the St. Louis Rams were putting together their defensive game plan in preparation for the Giants, they were genuinely concerned about the running attack of Ron Dayne and Tiki Barber. The Rams decided that to win they needed to shut down Thunder and Lightning and to force quarterback Kerry Collins to beat them.

title: GRAND UNION AGREES TO SELL MOST ASSETS TO WHOLESALER
description: The Grand Union Company, the supermarket chain based in Lake Success, N.Y. operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy-court protection, said it had entered into a definitive agreement for substantially all of its assets to be acquired by C&S Wholesale Grocers, the chain's principal supplier, for $301.8 million in cash. The deal omits 12 of the chain's 197 stores. C&S has previously said it will probably assign its right to acquire some stores to third parties. Grand Union also said the court had approved its hiring of a consultant, Excess Space Disposition Inc., to help it sell some properties.

title: Celebrities' Parents Testify: It's Easy to Get Fit
description: ''Power Pilates,'' 50 minutes, featuring Stefanie Powers and the parents of celebrity children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOGEL, DORA
description: KOGEL-Dora. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the loss of the widow of our Founding Dean, Dr. Marcus Kogel, and we extend heartfelt condolences to her daughter, Alice Funk, and the entire family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: People
description: * Betsy Lazar, director for media operations at General Motors, Detroit, was promoted to the new post of general director for media operations. She will oversee the company's media planning operations, which are handled by G. M. Planworks, a unit of the Bcom3 Group.

title: 'Philadelphia Sound' Faces a Test of Time
description: Sound is what an orchestra does, its stock in trade, so it is hardly surprising that most orchestras care greatly about the quality of that sound. Yet aside from the fabled Vienna Philharmonic, with its ingrown hiring practices and custom-made instruments, few ensembles have historically identified themselves more with sheer sonic grandeur and voluptuousness than the Philadelphia Orchestra, which is to perform tonight at Carnegie Hall and is to celebrate its 100th anniversary on Thursday with a gala concert at the Academy of Music in Philadelphia.

title: A Courtroom Drama, With Little Law in Evidence
description: Plenty of old court rulings were mentioned this morning in the ornate courtroom of Federal District Court in downtown Miami, where the fate of the presidential election was being fought over by some of the country's best lawyers.

title: Delays at La Guardia
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, PHYLLIS
description: WEINER-Phyllis. On behalf of the attending medical staff and affiliate psychology staff of the Department of Psychiatry and the entire Lenox Hill Hospital community, we extend our deepest condolences to our esteemed and longtime colleague, Dr. Howard Weiner, and his family on the loss of their dearest Phyllis. Phyllis Weiner was a caring and elegant woman whom we had the privilege of knowing for over 25 years. Her incisive intellect, subtle sense of humor and engaging manner were constantly refreshing and energizing. We will miss her greatly and hope we can provide some comfort to our friend Howard who has lost his soul mate. Allen H. Collins, MD, MPH Director, Department of Psychiatry President of the Medical Board Lenox Hill Hospital

title: INSIDE
description: Philippine Chief Impeached

title: Stocks Regain Most Losses On Late Buying
description: The tug of war between bears and bulls intensified yesterday as financial markets plunged early on fears of slowing economic growth before regaining most of their losses on late-day buying from investors seeking value in beaten-down stocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, ISRAEL
description: RUBIN-Israel. On Sunday, Nov. 12, 2000, Israel Rubin of Potomac, MD & Tucson, AZ. Beloved husband of the late Janet Rubin and the late Eileen Gordon Rubin. Devoted father of Ronnie (Nancy) Rubin, David Rubin (Linda Louisi) and Shirah Rubin. Loving brother of Blanche Shapiro and Ruth Brooks. Devoted grandfather of Jeffrey, Amy and Steven Rubin.
