Is also survived by devoted fiancee, Barbara Rosenblum. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, November 14, 10:00 AM at Congregation Beth El of Montgomery County, 8215 Old Georgetown Road, Bethesda, MD. Family will be observing Shiva, Tuesday through Monday at the residence of Ronnie and Nancy. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy may be made in his memory to the Rabbi's Fund at Congregation Beth El.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROCKBANK, ROBERT T.
description: BROCKBANK-Robert T. 54, of Garden City, NY, on Friday, November 10. Beloved husband of Janet; loving father of Stacey and Kathryn; devoted son of Margaret Meyers; dear brother of Margaret Perrone and James; friend of many at the former Manufacturers Hanover Trust and Chemical Bank, and at Chase Manhattan Bank, AXA Financial and AXA Group. Viewing Monday, 2-4 and 79 PM, at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave., Garden City. Funeral mass 10 AM, Tuesday, November 14, at St. Joseph's Church, Franklin Ave. at 5th St., Garden City. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to Theodore Roosevelt Association, PO Box 719, Oyster Bay, NY 11771.

title: Documents Shed Light on Assassination of Chilean in U.S.
description: A month before the assassination of a Chilean diplomat and an American colleague in downtown Washington in 1976, the United States government ordered its envoys in Latin America to try to avert a plot to murder leftist opponents of the region's governments, documents released today show.

title: Decision Denying a Request for an Injunction to Block Hand Counts
description: Following is a decision by Judge Donald M. Middlebrooks of Federal District Court in Miami that denied a request for a preliminary injunction to block the manual recounting of ballots in four Florida counties:

title: The Rangers Waive MacLean Again
description: After he was placed on waivers again yesterday, it looked as if John MacLean's tenure with the Rangers was over. Is MacLean's National Hockey League career over as well?

title: Stopping School Trouble Before It Starts
description: It is fairly well established that students who feel the most connected to school exhibit the fewest behavior problems, like truancy, violence and drug use. But figuring out which students feel alienated and how to reach them is another matter.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Funny Result At a Charity Raffle

title: Remaking Baseball Diamonds in the Rough
description: SHOCKED and outraged!'' shouts Richard A. Kahan, shirt sleeves rolled up above his elbows as if there's manual labor that needs doing, as he competes with the rush hour din emoting upward from Madison Avenue into his donated office space at the Loews Corporation. ''I couldn't have lived without baseball. No kid should have to,'' adds Mr. Kahan, 54, who has appointed himself official restorer of New York City's diamonds -- public school baseball diamonds, that is.

title: LAZARD BID TO BUY ALL OF AZEO
description: Lazard L.L.C. offered to take full control of Azeo, an industrial holding company in Paris, by having Eurafrance, an investment company that Lazard controls, pay 1.3 billion euros ($1.1 billion), or 90 euros a share, for the 43 percent of Azeo that it does not already own. Analysts say the deal is probably the first in a series intended to simplify the Lazard empire, whose complex web of holding companies allows Michel David-Weill, chairman of Lazard, to control dozens of companies with relatively little equity. Minority investors in some of its holdings have been pressing Mr. David-Weill to consolidate. Suzanne Kapner

title: Tunnel Vision; Women Feel Hemmed In By Space-Invading Men
description: Gillian Costello is a lawyer. Proof is important to her. So yesterday, to show a reporter something on the subway, she conducted a simple empirical demonstration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYON, DANIEL
description: LYON-Daniel. The officers, staff and leadership of the Jewish Labor Committee note with deep sadness the death of Daniel Lyon, father of our Executive Director, Avram Lyon. A loving father and grandfather, devoted husband to his wife, Tessie, who passed away two years ago. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. We extend heartfelt condolences to Avram, his sister Barbara Redmond, and the entire family. May his memory be a blessing. Morton Bahr, President Jewish Labor Committee

title: Calling the Presidential Race, and Cousin George W.
description: Senior executives for the Fox News Channel acknowledged last night that John Ellis, an executive who played a central role in the first decision on election night to project that George W. Bush had won the presidency, and who is a first cousin of Mr. Bush, spent much of the night in communication with the candidate.

title: Making Magic Other Worlds
description: As if by magic, Pascal Benichou and his five vibrant performers created encompassing other worlds in a prosaic ballet studio on Saturday night at the New York Conservatory of Dance. Each of the three dances in ''Endless Wonder,'' a program of choreography by Mr. Benichou, filled the narrow mirrored space with vivid color.

title: Electing a President: Into the Second Week
description: To the Editor:

title: OPPONENTS SEEK REFERENDUM ON CISCO COMPLEX
description: A group of environmentalists and advocates for the homeless are seeking a ballot referendum to kill the Cisco Systems plan for a $1.3 billion campus in the Coyote Valley, The San Jose Mercury News reported. If the group can get signatures from 27,732 registered voters, it can force Cisco to halt construction until the election is held, probably in the second quarter of 2001. The City Council voted unanimously to approve Cisco's plan to transform the 688-acre site, among the last stretches of undeveloped farmland in Silicon Valley, into a complex for 20,000 workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORON, PATTIE PORTER
description: THORON-Pattie Porter. Of Savage Farm Drive, Ithaca, NY. Died at age 88, on Saturday, October 28, 2000, at her home after a long illness. Survived by her husband, Gray Thoron; her children: Pattie H. Petrou of Sherborn, MA, John P. Holmes, Jr., of Shelter Island, NY, Russell P. Holmes of Boston and James T. Holmes of Atlanta, GA; her stepchildren: Claire T. Pyle of Washington, D.C., Louisa Thoron, M.D., of Philadelphia, Grenville C. Thoron of Lynn, MA, Molly Thoron of Santa Fe, NM, and Thomas G. Thoron of Dublin, NH; thirteen grandchildren; fourteen great-grandchildren, one step-grandchild, and one step great-grandchild. Graveside service and burial were in Bronxville, NY, at the Bronxville Cemetery on Wednesday, Nov. 1. A memorial service, followed by a reception, will be held in Ithaca, NY, on Saturday, December 2, at 3:00 P.M. at the Kendal at Ithaca Community Center, Savage Farm Drive. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Reformed Church, P.O. Box 397, Bronxville, NY 10708; or to the First Presbyterian Church, 315 North Cayuga Street, Ithace, New York 14850.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONASORTE, GARY
description: BONASORTE-Gary. The board & staff of In the Life television mourn the passing of Gary Bonasorte, partner of our director Terrence McNally & talented friend to our community. He will be missed.

title: Daewoo Lenders Seeking More Restrictions
description: The Daewoo Motor Company, which filed for court receivership Friday, may be asked to make more extensive job cuts and close some assembly plants as creditors try to revive the insolvent company, a leading South Korean automaker.

title: Officer Says Orange Police Beat Prisoner
description: An Orange police officer told a federal jury today that during the chaotic investigation of the 1999 killing of a policewoman he saw fellow officers repeatedly beat a suspect after he was handcuffed, and pepper-spray him even after he was secure in Police Headquarters.

title: Angels and Dreaming Robots
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Bury Hatchet and Back McGreevey
description: Days after New Jersey Republican leaders made a show of their support for Donald T. DiFrancesco in next year's race for governor, state Democrats lined up today behind James E. McGreevey, the mayor of Woodbridge, as their man for the race.

title: Public Hires Director To Oversee Finances
description: Fran Reiter, a former deputy mayor in the Giuliani administration, will become executive director of the Joseph Papp Public Theater today in a move to strengthen the theater's business operations, the Public's chairman said yesterday.

title: Clinton, in Brunei, Warns That Backtracking Could Bring a New Asian Economic Crisis
description: President Clinton today began a five-day farewell tour of Asia, arguing that the summit meeting of Asian leaders he began in 1993 has begun to weave the region together for the first time in history.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Accounting Firms Accept Rule to Limit Conflicts of Interest
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission reached an agreement yesterday with four leading accounting firms on a new rule regarding independence that will substantially reduce the amount of consulting work that the firms can do for their auditing clients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OGILVY, ANNE CABOT,
description: OGILVY-Anne Cabot, 69, died November 13, 2000 after a brief illness. Mrs. Ogilvy's life combined family, professional and international aspects in a nearly classic 20th century style. Mrs. Ogilvy played an active role in Middle Eastern archaeological and academic studies, serving as an officer and trustee of ACOR (American Center of Oriental Research) in Amman, Jordan, and ASOR (American Schools of Oriental Research) headquartered in Boston. The daughter of Yale Professor and Mrs. Richard F. Flint, she was raised in New Haven, CT, and later attended Radcliffe College. While there she met and married Thomas D. Cabot, Jr. In 1957, she married David Ogilvy and moved to New York, where she raised her three children and attended graduate school. One of the pioneers of archaeological faunal analysis, she participated in numerous archaeological field excavations during the 1970's including notable excavations at Cesaraea, the Levant and Upper Egypt. She was one of the first women allowd on a classical site when she was invited to do faunal analysis at Stobi, in Macedonia. Mrs. Ogilvy joined the Board of ASOR in 1970, and has served as its Assistant Treasurer. In 1998, she received its Membership Service Award, in recognition of her exceptional contributions to ASOR's membership and programs. During the 1970's she served on the Board of the Albright Institute in Jerusalem. A trustee of ACOR for the past twenty years, Mrs. Ogilvy has served as Chair of the Library Committee and secretary of the Board. She worked to establish a comprehensive academic and archaeological library at ACOR's headquarters in Amman, Jordan. She traveled regularly to the Middle East to participate in inspection trips organized by ACOR's Committee on Archaeological Policy. In 1999, she visited more tha 60 sites in Jordan, Israel, Syria, Cyprus and the West Bank. Mrs. Ogilvy and her companion of twenty years, Dr. Keith Beebe, Professor emeritus of religion at Occidental College, worked together as archaeologists and had shared interests in Arab refugee and international Middle East issues. As Arabists, they actively supported education and training for young Arab archaeologists and researchers. Mrs. Ogilvy is survived by her children, Thomas D. Cabot, III,of Shelburne, VT, Moors Cabot Myers, of Hamilton, NY, Cecily Cabot Klingman, of Mendocino, CA, and eight grandchildren. Burial will be private. The family requests that contributions in Mrs. Ogilvy's memory be sent to: ACOR Library Fund, Boston University, 656 Beacon Street, 5th floor, Boston, MA 02215-2010.

title: Extra Credit: The Great American Civics Lesson; Fuzzy Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MAHONY, EILEEN (NEE KENNY).
description: O'MAHONY-Eileen (nee Kenny). Suddenly on November 12, 2000. 65 years. Retired employee of City Bank-Municipal Bond Division. Beloved wife of the late Jeremiah, loving daughter of the late Dennis and Anna Kenny. Dear sister of Mary DaRos, Anne Eichele, and the late Denis Kenny. Beloved aunt of Rob DaRos and Christian Eichele. Beloved cousin of Msgr James A. Brassil. Family will receive friends Wednesday, 7-9 PM and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 St, Bronx. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at St Johns Church, Friday, 10:45 AM. Interment Long Island National Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: EMBRAER'S PROFIT DOUBLES
description: Aided by strong international demand for aircraft and rising production rates, the Brazilian jet maker Embraer more than doubled net profit in the third quarter to $96.5 million. The company delivered 44 jets and said it had orders and options for an additional $23.3 billion in aircraft and parts. Embraer plans to step up output to 20 aircraft a month.

title: Hingis Reacts to Williamses
description: One day after Richard Williams, the father of Venus and Serena Williams, said his daughters should share in the revenues they help create for the sport of tennis, the No. 1-ranked Martina Hingis acknowledged the sisters' impact, but believes the tour should benefit all of the players equally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHILL, EMANUEL S.,
description: CHILL-Emanuel S., Professor Emeritus of History, City College, NY, died on November 13 in West Hartford, CT of complications from Parkinson's Disease. He was 76. After graduating from Columbia University, he attended Oxford University and joined the history faculty of City College in 1962. His book ''Power, Property and History, Joseph Barnave's Introduction To The French Revolution,'' as well as other publications, are valuable contributions to American studies of The French Revolution. Professor Chill served with honor in The Armed Forces during World War II. He is survived by his wife Philippa Wehle, his son Paul Chill and wife Brigid Donohue, his daughters, Carol Adinolfi and Nina Chill, and grandchildren, Madeleine, Camille, and Declan.

title: Wal-Mart Earnings Up 5.8%, As J. C. Penney Posts a Loss
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter profit rose 5.8 percent as an expanded variety of groceries helped shield the company, the world's largest retailer, from slower consumer spending.

title: GETTY PETROLEUM CONSIDERS OFFER FROM ANOTHER BIDDER
description: Getty Petroleum Marketing Inc., which on Nov. 2 agreed to be bought by Lukoil Holding of Russia for $5 a share, said yesterday that it was now considering a $5.75-a-share offer from another bidder, the United Refining Company of Warren, Pa. Getty, based in Jericho, N.Y., owns or operates 1,300 gas stations in 12 states. In addition to a refinery in Warren, United operates 303 gas stations in New York and Pennsylvania. If Getty backs out of the Lukoil deal, the first in which a Russian company would acquire a publicly held American one, Getty would be obliged to pay Lukoil $3 million to $5 million in expenses.

title: Most Populous Area Won't Seek Recount
description: Recounting the ballots in three sample voting precincts, election officials in Miami-Dade County, the state's most populous county, found only a minor change in the count today and decided tonight not to proceed with a full recount of the county's ballots.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a meeting of Muslim countries in Qatar at which Israel was denounced misstated the extent of Jordan's control of Jerusalem before the 1967 Middle East war. Jordan controlled only East Jerusalem and the Old City; Israel controlled the rest of Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARMAN, JACK H.
description: LARMAN-Jack H. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Jack H. Larman, & extends sincere sympathy to his family and friends. David S. Mack, President Marshall L. Hess, Secretary

title: Extra Credit: The Great American Civics Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: Cutting Tips
description: Abig problem with these delicate tarts is that -- after you've put in all this work and care -- you can crush the sides or disturb the design with heavy- handed cutting. The final trick in this lesson prevents that.

title: It's Still Indiana Basketball (Tantrums Aside)
description: Indiana University opened its basketball season tonight without any of the furniture from the team bench being uprooted and transported across the basketball court, scattering fans. No player was head-butted or kicked in the shins by the coach, nor was the scorer's table punched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, VITA ORTMAN WEISS.
description: MARX-Vita Ortman Weiss. She died at home on October 27, after a long illness. Devoted wife of the late Ralph Marx. She is survived by her daughter Ellen Ash, her stepdaughters Alice Weafer, and Nancy Bocian & six grandchildren. She devoted her life to insuring affordable housing for low and middle income people working for the N.Y.C. Department of City Planning, The Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, The Legislative Drafting Research Fund at Columbia Law School and HUD.

title: Swiss Raise Sum in Bank Case, to $500 Million
description: An investigation has turned up evidence that $500 million, far more than previously believed, was transferred to Swiss banks from accounts at the Bank of New York as part of a Russian plot to avoid taxes and launder money.

title: The High-Minded Fight Over Florida
description: Another day, another series of unanticipated and bewildering events in the presidential election. Even when something apparently decisive happens, different versions of what it means emerge immediately. A Florida state judge issues an opinion in seeming support of Secretary of State Katherine Harris's ruling that the counties should file their results by 5 p.m. yesterday. But the Democrats read the same opinion as holding open the possibility of adding new tallies after the deadline has passed. Broward County is set for a recount; then Broward County decides that there will be no recount.

title: Accounts
description: Veer.com, Johannesburg, a joint venture between McKinsey & Company and South African Airways, to DiMassimo Brand Advertising, New York, as the first agency for the company, which will introduce a worldwide Web site for travelers and travel agents. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: 10 Records in Contemporary Art Are Set at Sotheby's Auction
description: In the gossipy world of contemporary art, if the price is right and the buzz before a sale is positive, the merchandise will move. And move it did at Sotheby's sale of contemporary art last night, an evening that brought 10 records and solid bidding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, LOUIS
description: GROSSMAN-Louis. Of Remsenberg, N.Y. and Boca Raton, Fl. On November 13, 2000. Beloved husband of Marian. Loving father of Steven and Robert, father-in-law of Lynne and Carole. Cherished grandfather of Alison, Ethan, Cary and Leslie. Great grandfather of Daniela. Chairman of the Board of Southern Container Corp forever. Louis was a man of deep caring for his family and will be sorely missed. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Woodbury, N.Y. 10am Thursday, November 16th.

title: Both Sides See Momentum in Congress for Gun Control
description: Two states' overwhelming approval of ballot initiatives last week to require background checks at weekend gun shows is prompting advocates of gun control to predict that the incoming Congress might pass legislation that creates a similar federal law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACY, BERNADETTE
description: TRACY-Bernadette. You left the party too early! You're Netsmart is a winner. You just won The Osborn Cup Doubles in Central Park, wearing Oscar and Eric Javits. You chaired the most brilliant Croquet Hall of Fame Ball at The Yale Club. You have the best table at Orsay. We expected you in Palm Beach this winter. Who else has the style, IQ, humor and loyalty to be our dearest friend? Lynn and Ralph Olson TRACY-Bernadette. Time may pass, but our friendship and love will always remain. We will miss you. Michael & Christopher Cassin

title: A Man Who Vanquished Microsoft Takes On G.O.P.
description: At his first public appearance today on behalf of the Gore campaign, David Boies, the latest big-name lawyer to join the vice president's legal team, discounted a comparison to his role as the victorious trial attorney retained by the government in the Microsoft antitrust case.

title: Degrees Granted Online May Lack Status
description: Employers have mixed opinions on whether to hire those who possess degrees earned over the Internet, a new survey finds.

title: At the End of the Day . . .
DEMOCRATS WANT SHARE OF SENATE
description: Democrats said today that they would tie up the Senate, if necessary, to make sure they get an equal number of seats on committees and possibly co-chairmanships, if the Senate winds up evenly divided.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, SHELDON
description: ROSS-Sheldon, 75. On November 12, 2000. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Loving father of Robert and Laurie. Dear brother-in-law of Jeff (Mimi) Licht, Vera Rabino and uncle of Erica Licht and Michele Kogon. Resident of Manhattan, formerly of Detroit, he taught those around him to love the arts. He leaves behind many friends and colleagues who will dearly miss his warmth, wit and kindness. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., 212288-3500, Wednesday, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow in Amenia, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Daniel Ferro Vocal Program, Inc., 575 Madison Avenue, Suite 1006, NY NY 10022 or to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAPLAN, GEORGES
description: KAPLAN-Georges Toujours dans nos coeurs. Ta Famill

title: Clinton Asks $750 Million in New Assistance for Middle East
description: President Clinton asked Congress today for an additional $750 million in emergency aid for Israel, Egypt and Jordan, a request that immediately drew a skeptical reaction from some influential Republican lawmakers.

title: Put Away That Spoon and Read This
description: YOU can use a big spoon. Or a brush. But the easiest and most effective way to moisten and glaze the skin of roasting poultry with richly browning pan juices is to use a bulb baster. A simple, highly functional tool, a baster consists of a tube an inch or so in diameter that narrows to a small opening at one end and has a large flexible bulb at the other.

title: WORLDCOM MOVES TO LEVERAGE DIGEX
description: WorldCom, the nation's No. 2 long-distance communications carrier, said that Digex Inc. had agreed to use WorldCom's network and to sell its services through WorldCom's sales force. Digex is a leader in operating Web sites and computer servers for corporate customers. WorldCom has come under some fire recently for failing to integrate its myriad acquisitions into a coherent whole. With the announcement, WorldCom is trying to demonstrate that the Digex deal is already bearing fruit. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A caption yesterday about Black Diamonds Entertainment, which organizes parties for young upwardly mobile black people, misidentified a couple dancing at one of the parties. They were Candace Jackson and Brian Monroe, not Kerri Harper and John Byers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Extra Credit: The Great American Civics Lesson; An Election Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian River Riches
description: THE pinot noir grape can't be grown just anywhere. The French have known this for centuries, and now the Californians have figured it out, too. Unlike the hardy cabernet sauvignon, the pinot noir grape is extremely sensitive to climate and soil. After decades of trial and especially error, California winemakers narrowed down the choicest regions for growing pinot noir. Sonoma County has the most acreage planted, and the grape seems to do best in the cool and foggy regions of the Sonoma Coast and the Russian River Valley.

title: JUDGE UPHOLDS HAND RECOUNTS IN FLORIDA; 2 COUNTIES ARE FACING NEW STATE DEADLINE
description: The Florida secretary of state announced tonight that she would comply with a state judge's order to consider results of further recounts in the disputed presidential election, but she gave the two Democratic counties that are moving ahead with, or considering, a time-consuming hand recount a deadline of 2 p.m. Wednesday to explain their reasons in writing.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If we are going to allow somebody to request a recount, the intent obviously is that you expect a recount to be included.''

title: A Blend of Town and Country
description: IN the living room of Bryan Simmons and Ralph Vetters there is a small wooden coffee table. For the first few years they lived together, it was also their dining table. If it was inadequate, they didn't seem to notice, entertaining ceaselessly with big bowls of pasta, one-pot stews and salad, and friends huddled around on pillows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUNER, ROBERT ALEXANDER.
description: BLAUNER-Robert Alexander. On November 12, 2000. Robert died in peace at age 23 after a heroic fight with Hodgkin's disease. He is survived by his parents, Allan S. and Loretta; his siblings, Stephen, Peter and Patsy; and his grandmother, Josephine Steinberg Libman. A memorial service for Robert's friends and family will be held in several weeks. For information contact lsb@compucore.net. Memorial donations may be made in Robert's name to Yale Stem Cell Program, c/o Dr. Dennis Cooper, Yale University School of Medicine, Medical Oncology, 333 Cedar Street-WWW220, New Haven, CT. 06510.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPER, OSCAR
description: HALPER-Oscar. Beloved husband of Beatrice for 45 years, adored father of Harlan, cherished grandfather of Rachel & Jennifer, and revered brother of Aaron, passed away on November 13 in Yonkers, NY at the age of 88. A graduate of NYU and the Columbia School of Social Work, where he received a MSW degree, he went on to successful careers in Academia and Business. He served for 26 years as a member and past President of the Board of Directors of the 1150 Park Avenue Tenants Association. A proponent of Reformed Judaism, he served on the Board of Temple Israel of the City of New York, and has been a member of the congregation since 1967. For all who knew him, both past and present, he will be dearly missed and always loved. Services will be held on Thursday, November 16 at 12 noon ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I. Donations may be made in his memory to Temple Israel of the City of New York, 112 East 75 Street, NY, NY 10021-3297.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: 'And the Winner Is . . . '
description: The never-ending story of the 2000 election has turned into the best continuing subject for television news since the Monica Lewinsky incident, if not the O. J. Simpson trial, with ratings soaring for network evening newscasts and especially for the all-news cable channels.

title: Should Israel Sacrifice Its Hopes for Peace for Settlers?
description: When hundreds gathered today to bury a Jewish settler who was shot dead by Palestinian gunmen in the West Bank, they declared Sarah Lisha, a 42-year-old gym teacher and mother of five, a martyr for Israel.

title: The Season For Hopping The Fence
description: YOU have to admire the fortitude, if not question the sanity, of a nation that would put its political fate in the hands of two of the more despised groups in the land: lawyers and journalists.

title: To Be or Not to Be Evil, That Is the Question
description: If you missed Intro to Shakespeare back in your junior year, or if you need a brushing up or even if all you're up for is a brisk shot of high culture as entertainment, you might think of looking in on the British actor and director Steven Berkoff, who is serving what amounts to a visiting professorship through Saturday at Joe's Pub, the cafe attached to the Joseph Papp Public Theater. In his one-man show, ''Shakespeare's Villains,'' which is part pedagogy, part snippy stand-up and part tour de force acting dazzle, Mr. Berkoff zips through a lecture on a cache of Shakespearean characters with the kind of elan that can turn indifferent students into drama majors.

title: A County Reconsiders A Hand Count
description: The Broward County canvassing board voted today to reconsider its decision against a complete, manual recount of its presidential ballots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, JOSEPH S.
description: PHILLIPS-Joseph S. Passed away on Sunday, November 12, 2000. He was 73. He was a retired stockbroker, music and photography enthusiast. He is survived by his son, Roger, daughter-in-law, Wendy, and grandson, Samuel. We will miss him terribly.

title: Commercial Property; Former Muffin Bakery Is Turned Into High-Tech Flexible Space
description: At one time, the huge Thomas' English muffins bakery in Totowa, N.J., supplied the entire East Coast with the company's muffins, churning them out along conveyor belts as long as football fields.

title: Great Caesar's Toast; New Attention Burnishes the Reputation of a TV Pioneer
description: Sid Caesar rarely watches comedy shows on television anymore. ''I just can't sit and watch because as soon as I do, I start analyzing,'' he said. ''I say to myself, 'They could have done this scene better,' or 'That was a mistake,' or 'Why didn't they have this character do that?' I can't enjoy it. So I watch the History Channel.''

title: Retail Sales Rose Slightly In October
description: Retail sales rose in October as gains at department stores and building-supply outlets offset a decline at auto dealers, the government said today.

title: Can Memory or Anyone Be Trusted? Nope
description: Thinking is not usually classified as a spectator sport. But when it's Liev Schreiber who is doing the cogitation, you tend to sit up, watch closely and suddenly feel like cheering. Mr. Schreiber is in the stylish but seriously imbalanced new revival of Harold Pinter's ''Betrayal,'' from the Roundabout Theater Company, and this dramatically cerebral actor guarantees that those famous Pinteresque silences are not empty.

title: Extra Credit: The Great American Civics Lesson; Voting Improvements
description: To the Editor:

title: 3-Game Slide Puts Jets In a Precarious Position
description: The Jets are like desperate new parents, trying anything to quiet a caterwauling baby. Do they pick it up or leave it alone? Give it a pacifier or a bottle? The grasping at straws is endless, the sleep deprivation taking its toll. And at least the parents know the baby will eventually grow out of it.

title: Catching a Second Career Wind at Age 61
description: After 33 years as a dentist, Roy Yeager recently sold his Manhattan practice and began a new career as a psychotherapist. The offer came unexpectedly, but in retrospect the change seems almost inevitable.

title: From Partisan Ranks, Electoral Referees
description: As a former official with the Atlanta-based Carter Center, Robert A. Pastor has monitored plenty of elections, mostly in developing countries where democracy is taking its first steps. But Mr. Pastor said he had never seen anything like what unfolded this week right here at home, where both Democratic and Republican partisans in Florida have used their elected positions to influence the counting of presidential ballots.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Rebound Strongly, But Analysts Are Cautious

title: Campaign Finance Reform Is Bipartisan Group's Goal
description: Denouncing ''the evils of political money,'' a bipartisan group of New Jersey political, business and civic officials, including former Gov. Jim Florio, announced yesterday that they had formed an advocacy group to fight for the overhaul of the state's campaign finance laws.

title: SYCAMORE NETWORKS MOVES INTO THE BLACK
description: The optical networking company Sycamore Networks Inc. posted a first-quarter profit, reversing a year-earlier loss while beating Wall Street estimates amid worries of a spending slowdown for high-speed networking equipment. Excluding special charges, the Chelmsford, Mass.-based Sycamore said it earned net income of $6 million, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter, in contrast to a loss of $4.1 million.

title: America Today, Through Vietnamese Eyes
description: Naturally, said Ngo Van Ha, the words ''America'' and ''war'' pop into the mind together. But that belongs to the history books. For him, as for many other Vietnamese, ''talking about America means talking about freedom.''

title: Extra Credit: The Great American Civics Lesson; Understand the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Women at Work: The Home Front and the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Hand Recounts Denied in Florida
description: Florida Secretary of State Katherine Harris announced Wednesday night she would deny attempts by scattered counties to submit hand recounts of ballots to the results of the contested presidential election between George W. Bush and Al Gore. The state's chief elections officer, sharply criticized by Democrats in recent days as a partisan Republican, declared it was ``my duty under Florida law'' to reject requests from several counties to update their totals. Bush holds a 300-vote lead in the state whose 25 electoral votes will settle the presidential election. Harris said the state's vote count would be official when overseas absentee ballots are rolled into the totals by midnight Friday. She noted her decision was subject to an appeal in the courts _ and it seemed likely there would be one. Harris stepped to the microphones to make her announcement seven hours after the 2 p.m. deadline she had set for counties to petition for the right to update their returns. She said four counties had done so _ Democratic-leaning Broward, Palm, Miami-Dade and GOP-leaning Collier _ and she had reviewed their paperwork. ``The reasons given in the requests are insufficient to warrant waiver of the unambiguous filing deadline imposed by the Florida Legislature,'' she said, without further elaboration. The announcement capped a tumultuous day in which the state supreme court refused to stop hand recounts planned or underway in three heavily Democratic counties, but a federal appeals court agreed to consider the Bush campaign's attempt to halt the new canvasses. The federal court's unusually rapid decision to accept the case could launch the controversy firmly on its way to the U.S. Supreme Court. The decision by the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta to intervene came as the major players in the vote count also asked Florida's highest court to settle some of the questions. Secretary of State Katherine Harris led the parade to the Florida Supreme Court with an early-morning lawsuit asking the justices to block the hand recounts at least temporarily, and to consolidate election-related lawsuits. The court turned her down without a hearing. The Bush campaign has fought to stop the recounts on several fronts. Former Secretary of State James A. Baker III argued on Wednesday that the ``process is unfair, gives rise to human error, gives rise to the potential for great mischief.'' Baker lamented the proliferation of lawsuits, saying the situation has ``run amok now.'' Warren Christopher, the former secretary of state chosen to lead Gore's recount, defended the legal strategy. ``We simply must, in order to protect the rights of the vice president in this matter, enable us to take steps that seem warranted,'' Christopher said. In rejecting Harris' suit, the justices, all chosen by Democratic governors, did not address the many other election-related legal challenges making their way through Florida courts. ``Our legal team is reviewing it, but we are certainly pleased the court has ordered that the counts should proceed,'' said Doug Hattaway, a spokesman for Democrat Al Gore. The Bush camp disputed that interpretation and noted that the state high court's one-paragraph rejection slip did not address the substance of Harris' request. The court left open the option that Harris could sue in a lower state court, or make her arguments another way. The state high court agreed to review complaints from two South Florida counties _ Broward and Palm Beach _ that say they are confused about how to proceed with recounts. Harris and state Democratic Attorney General Bob Butterworth have given the counties conflicting guidance. The counties are suing both. The status of recounts in four counties hand-picked by Democrats shifted quickly: _Officials in Palm Beach, where concerns about the ballot design prompted the Florida dispute, left Wednesday without starting their manual recount. They plan to meet Thursday afternoon to decide how to begin. _Election officials in Broward County reversed course and authorized a hand recount they previously had rejected. The county canvassing board approved the recount 2-1, with the pivotal vote cast by chairman Robert W. Lee, a Democrat and county judge who switched his vote. Republicans lost a court battle to block the recount. _Volusia has already completed its recount and reported it to the state; _Miami-Dade, Florida's largest, has declined a countywide hand recount for the time being. All are heavily Democratic areas where Gore supporters hope to find additional votes for the vice president. In Gadsden County, west of Tallahassee, a new dispute arose after county election officials announced a recheck of more than 2,000 ballots that had been rejected by voting machines gave Gore a net gain of 153. The gain helped whittle Bush's statewide lead to 300 in new figures announced Tuesday. Republicans complained that those disputed ballots should not have been counted; Democrats on Wednesday withdrew a request to review the disputed ballots. The legality of the recounts is being challenged on several fronts by Republicans, while Democrats countered that Florida law allows them. ``Under Florida law, any candidate has a right to get a manual recount,'' Gore lawyer David Boies said. ``What we're saying is: Don't change the rules in the middle of the game, don't shut out the manual recount here when that has been a traditional part of Florida law.'' In Atlanta, the federal appeals court said that all 12 of its judges would hear Bush's challenge to the hand recounts in selected Democratic-leaning counties. Bush lost a similar bid in federal court in Miami earlier this week. Constitutional lawyer Theodore Olson, representing Bush, argued the counts were unconstitutionally selective and arbitrary, because some voters will be treated differently under the law, depending on whether they live in a recount county. The federal appeals court also agreed to hear a related case filed by Florida voters who say they voted for Bush. They also argue their rights are being violated because their counties are not recounting votes by hand. The 11th Circuit Court did not say when it will consider the case, nor whether it would hold oral arguments. The judges could rule based only on their reading of legal briefs due Thursday. Typically, federal appeals courts assign cases to a three-judge panel, which can take weeks or months to hear it. From there, the losing side can ask for a hearing by the full 12-judge court, a request that is usually denied. The court skipped that step.

title: Two Days Plus Many Memories
description: THANKSGIVING for many Americans has become as much about discovering new dishes as it is about celebrating those from the past. To Kathy Starr, 46, it is about tradition. For her, much of the pleasure comes before anyone sits down at the table. Her time in the kitchen is spent remembering her mother and her childhood. By cooking the foods she grew up with in Mississippi, she can bring it all back.

title: Comments by the Campaigns
description: Following are excerpts from news conferences last night by Karen P. Hughes, communications director for the Bush campaign, and William M. Daley, chairman of the Gore campaign, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANTZ, HOWARD
description: GRANTZ-Howard. Howie, our cherished and oldest friend, you will be loved forever. We admired both your warmth and your strength, right through your heroic fight against lung cancer. Our heartfelt sympathies to your family. You will be sorely missed and will live on in our memories. Barbara and Marty Sass

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTIN, REV. TIMOTHY AUGUSTINE
description: CURTIN-Rev. Timothy Augustine, S.J. Loving brother of Sister Kathleen Curtin, O.P. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Road. Visitation on Thursday, November 16, 3-5PM. Mass of Christian Burial 7:30PM at Fordham University Chapel. For information, contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors.

title: Some in G.O.P. Unhappy Over Bush Florida Tactics
description: A phalanx of nervous House Republicans today accused the Bush campaign of losing the public relations war over the contested presidential election, as Congress put off its lame-duck session until next month, when it hoped to know who would be the next president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, HENRY G., JR.
description: WALTER-Henry G., Jr. The Trustees and staff of the American Museum of Natural History are deeply saddened by the death of esteemed Honorary Trustee, Henry G. Walter, Jr. Hank joined the Board of Trustees in 1972, serving as Vice President of the Board from 1981-1988. An active Trustee with service on numerous committees, Hank was elected an Honorary Trustee in 1996. We will all remember Hank for his deep love of science, his interest in the natural world, and his unstinting willingness to share his time and wisdom to advance the Museum's mission whenever and wherever possible. On behalf of the entire Museum family, we extend our deepest sympathies and affection to his beloved wife, Rosalind, his son, Henry Glendon Walter III, his stepson, Henry S. Thompson, his sister Grace Waring Walter, his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Anne Sidamon-Eristoff, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President WALTER-Henry G. Jr. The Board and staff of the International Tennis Hall of Fame express their sadness at the passing of Henry G. Walter, Jr. A great friend, Hank was a regular visitor to Newport and will be missed by all who knew him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, longtime Board member Rosalind, and his family. John R. Reese, Chairman of the Exec. Committee Joseph F. Cullman, 3rd Chairman Emeritus Tony Trabert, Vice President WALTER-Henry G., Jr. The Trustees and staff of The Pierpont Morgan Library mourn the death of Henry G. Walter, Jr. He was a Fellow for 27 years and a Trustee for 20 years. Hank was a loyal, generous, and wise Trustee. We will greatly miss his commitment to the Morgan Library and his passionate belief in the achievements of Western civilization. We extend deepest sympathies to his wife, Roz, and his family. Charles E. Pierce, Jr., Director S. Parker Gilbert, President, Board of Trustees WALTER-Henry G., Jr. With deep sadness, the trustees and officers of Long Island University extend their heartfelt condolences and sympathies to their beloved fellow-trustee and colleague, Rosalind P. Walter, on the death of her husband. Hank and Roz have been first citizens and benefactors of this University in every respect. We shall miss him greatly, even as we share in her pain. Roger Tilles, Chair David Steinberg, President

title: Black Girl's Courage in 1960 Inspires Children
description: Forty years ago, a 6-year-old girl named Ruby Bridges marched past an angry mob of segregationists to become the first black child to attend William Frantz Elementary School in New Orleans.

title: Palm Beach Panel Votes to Proceed on Count
description: Palm Beach County election officials decided today to move forward with the mammoth task of manually recounting all 462,657 ballots cast here, a process that Democrats believe could provide them the best chance of putting Al Gore in the White House.

title: A Breakthrough Ruling in Florida
description: ''To determine ahead of time that such returns will be ignored, however, unless caused by some Act of God, is not the exercise of discretion. It is the abdication of discretion.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, HERBERT K.
description: GRAY-Herbert K. Age 72, of Stuart, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY and Old Greenwich, CT, on November 12. Retired as a Vice President after a 42 year career with Pfizer, Inc. Served his country in the Army during the Korean War. Former member of the Union League Club and the Riverside Yacht Club. Survived by his wife of 44 years, Joan T. Gray of Stuart, FL, son, Stuart K. Gray of Stamford, CT, daughter, Nancy G. Vibert of Springfield, VA, four grandchildren, and sister, Mrs. John W. Faison of Brooklyn, NY. Those who wish may make contributions to the Council on Aging of Martin County, 1071 South East 10th Street, Stuart, FL 34996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORRA, VICTORINE
description: GORRA-Victorine. On November 13, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Aziz S. Devoted mother of George, Frieda, Lorraine Mezzotero, Claire Shia, Joan Galbi, Marie Danzi, Renee & Vivienne Koroma. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Wednesday 7-9 PM, and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass St. John the Martyr Church, 250 East 72nd Street, on Friday, at 10 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: For All the Talk of Job-Hopping, Loyalty to the Boss Endures
description: Employers say talent is hard to find -- and keep -- in today's tight labor market, but worker loyalty is not a thing of the past just yet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROUT, ROBERT
description: TROUT-Robert. On November 14, 2000. Distinguished journalist in both radio and television. One of the first correspondents to cover London for CBS during World War II and later for ABC radio and television. Husband and colleague of the late Catherine ''Kit'' Trout and brother-in-law of Elizabeth Crane Prucher, uncle of Elizabeth Crane Boland, Stephen and Jeffrey Prucher. A memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: House Approves Tax Measure to Avert Trade Conflict With Europe
description: The House gave final Congressional approval today to legislation that alters tax breaks to American exports and that averts, at least temporarily, a potentially explosive trade conflict with Europe.

title: DNA Tests Point to Suspect in 3 Unsolved Killings
description: In life, they did not know each other and had little in common. But in death, they shared an awful distinction as the victims in three of the oldest unsolved killings in Westchester County.

title: Japanese Math Program Tallies Success With Discipline
description: A 46-year-old Japanese method for teaching mathematics that demands nothing less than 100 percent scores before students move on to new material has been setting up tutoring outposts in immigrant and middle-class neighborhoods of New York City.

title: King Crimson's Long Rule Over a Realm of Art Rock
description: A fan near the stage of the Supper Club on Sunday night demonstrated the emblematic response to King Crimson's music. His gaze was set on the band's four members, but his hands had a life of their own.

title: Ruling Denying Request for an Injunction to Block the Vote-Count Deadline
description: Following is the ruling yesterday by Judge Terry P. Lewis of Leon County Circuit Court in Florida on a request to extend the deadline to report results in Florida's presidential vote:

title: Pumpkin Cleverly Disguised as Pasta
description: A plate of tender pumpkin tortellini, glossed with a little melted butter, Parmesan cheese and fresh sage, makes an elegant first course -- and it's one of the few store-bought items that can be served without apology on the big day. This plump stuffed pasta has a subtly sweet filling of pumpkin puree and cheese. Grace's Marketplace, 1237 Third Avenue (71st Street) has it for $4.99 a pound. At Agata & Valentina, 1505 First Avenue (79th Street), larger tortelloni are $4.99 a pound. And at Citarella, 1313 Third Avenue and 2135 Broadway (both 75th Street), pumpkin ravioli are $5.99 a pound. A pound feeds six.

title: Diocese of Brooklyn Declares Shortage of Priests Is a Crisis
description: As the vocation director for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn in the late 1980's, the Rev. Fernando Ferrarese spent most of his time preaching about the shortage of young men entering the priesthood and what it might mean for parish life: churches without pastors, neighborhoods without churches, fewer Masses, frustrated priests.

title: The Devils Are Skating in Quicksand
description: The Devils produced two goals in the first period tonight and two shots on goal in the second. The offense produced nothing in the third, and the San Jose Sharks rallied for a 3-2 victory at Continental Arena.

title: Liberties; Mistrust In The Trust
description: Finally, Al Gore got wise.

title: American Accents in Australian Executive Suites
description: Americans might wonder why so many Australians have made it to the top of the corporate heap in the United States. There is Geoffrey C. Bible at Philip Morris, Jacques Nasser at Ford Motor and Douglas N. Daft at Coca-Cola.

title: Conflicting Legal Opinions on a County's Recount
description: Following are excerpts from letters that L. Clayton Roberts, director of the Florida Division of Elections, and Attorney General Robert A. Butterworth, sent to Judge Charles Burton, chairman of the Palm Beach County canvassing board, regarding recount procedures:

title: Growing Opposition To Free Drug Samples; Ultimate Costs and Safety Are Cited
description: Worried about safety and rising drug costs, a small but growing number of hospitals, clinics and other health care organizations across the country are banning free samples of brand name prescription drugs, or limiting what samples their doctors can accept from drug companies.

title: THYSSENKRUPP TO STAY IN STEEL
description: ThyssenKrupp A.G. backtracked on plans to sell its steel business after failing to get the price it wanted. A spokesman for the company said it was no longer in talks to sell the steel business, Germany's largest, to any other company. In August, ThyssenKrupp, based in Dusseldorf, which also makes auto parts and elevators, scrapped a plan to spin the steel unit off in a public offering, because investment banks said the offer would not raise the $1.4 billion the company wanted. Analysts speculated that ThyssenKrupp, which was thwarted in a bid to acquire auto-parts assets from Mannesmann, may now pursue acquisitions related to steel, like Klockner & Company, a steel trading house being sold by E.On, Germany's largest utility.

title: Two Heavyweights Won't Bid For Sao Paulo's State Bank
description: With less than a week left before the scheduled privatization of the Sao Paulo state bank, two major foreign banks, Citibank S.A. and Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria S.A. of Spain, have pulled out of the auction.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TECO ENERGY INC., -- Tampa, Fla., said it would invest $960 million in a joint venture with the closely held Panda Energy International Inc., Dallas, a power-plant developer, to build natural-gas-fired power plants in El Dorado, Ark., and Gila Bend, Ariz.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DECLINES. The yen fell after Japan's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, was asked to step down by a member of his own party. In New York, the dollar settled at 108.15 yen, up from 107.63 yen on Monday.

title: PLAYBOY PULLS SHARE OFFERING
description: Playboy Enterprises withdrew a planned offering of as much as $50 million in common stock for its Playboy.com Web site, citing a weak market. The withdrawal came as Playboy posted a third-quarter loss of $6.5 million, in contrast to a $1.1 million loss a year earlier. Playboy said Playboy.com, the online version of its men's magazine, was expected to become one of the company's most profitable businesses by 2002. Playboy said it would continue with the public offering once markets improve. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Cider From France, With Vavoom
description: Restaurant affectations are normally the last thing you want on Thanksgiving, but here's one idea worth stealing: serve a glass of brut sparkling apple cider as an aperitif. Brasserie 8 1/2 pours a gorgeously crisp cider, made by Etienne Dupont in Normandy, into Champagne flutes. The light apple flavor, suggesting chardonnay, and delicate fizz feel seasonal and festive. You might consider bolstering its modest 5.5 percent alcohol content the way it's done in Normandy, by adding a splash of Calvados. A 750-milliliter bottle is $7.99 at Fairway, 2127 Broadway (74th Street) and 2328 12th Avenue (132nd Street).

title: Azteca America Names a President
description: Peter Chrisanthopoulos, a top executive at a leading media services agency, is leaving to join a television network.

title: East New York Senses Promise In a New Mall
description: After years of false starts, East New York is pinning its hopes for economic resurrection on a 230-acre Brooklyn landfill. For decades, the land and scores of other vacant lots helped earn the battered Brooklyn neighborhood a reputation as a hard-luck ghetto, a place where nothing grew but weeds and the crime rate.

title: Turning Point for Pacific Trade Group's Leaders
description: As leaders of Pacific Rim countries gathered today in this sultanate for their annual summit meeting, many faced uncertainties at home that cast shadows over the conference. At least nine leaders, including President Clinton, are leaving office, facing elections or embroiled in domestic crises that could make this meeting their last.

title: Article 2000111592210336281 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: For Some Haitian-Americans, a Bittersweet Election Day
description: Ben Benoit came to this country 20 years ago on a boat packed with other Haitian immigrants. It was a dangerous weeklong journey, but he felt he had no future in Haiti, where the Duvalier government and its secret police ruled by whim and weapon.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  INDOVINO, PETER K.
description: INDOVINO-Peter K. Nov. 15, 1997. Dearest Peter, loved, cherished and missed. Third Anniversary. It doesn't get easier. Your family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELBIN, HERMAN
description: ELBIN-Herman. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of man Elbin, beloved father of our devoted member Deborah Penchina. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: RADIAN GROUP TO ACQUIRE ENHANCE FINANCIAL SERVICES
description: The Radian Group, a provider of private mortgage insurance, agreed to buy the Enhance Financial Services Group for about $558 million in stock, to expand into insurance and reinsurance for municipal and asset-backed securities. Radian will exchange 0.22 share of its common stock for each share of Enhance, about a 4 percent premium based on yesterday's closing prices. Radian rose $2.19, to $66.38 a share, making its offer worth $14.60 for each Enhance share. Enhance Financial rose 20 cents, to close at $14.02.

title: ICG COMMUNICATIONS FILES FOR PROTECTION
description: ICG Communications Inc. said yesterday that it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy-court protection from its creditors and obtained a $350 million loan from Chase Manhattan Bank to keep operating while it reorganizes. The company, which provides local, long-distance and Internet telephone service, has been in turmoil since September, when it warned of slowing sales and its chief executive resigned, the second to do so in less than a year. Two other directors also resigned. Shares of ICG, which reached $39.25 a share in March, were trading at 31 cents a share when trading was halted because of the filing.

title: Elias, Former Giant, Chases His Dream With the Hitmen
description: Keith Elias, part of a crowd of vaguely familiar faces, had a plastic name tag pinned to his chest this afternoon and a new black baseball cap, its tag still attached, pulled down on his head just like many of his new teammates.

title: Each Side Wins Enough to Cite A Court Victory
description: Like the disputed election that produced it today, the most significant legal opinion so far in this week's recount battle was split directly down the middle, giving both campaigns a claim to a legal victory that may eventually lead to a political one.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column yesterday misstated the name of the organization that is presenting a program by Le Concert des Nations tonight at Alice Tully Hall. It is the Gotham Early Music Foundation, not the Gothic Early Music Foundation.

title: A Feast Free of Giblets and Angst
description: Last week, I picked up Martha Stewart Living and flirted with the idea of making the turkey with wheatberry, Black Mission fig and pumpkin stuffing.

title: One Opinion, Two Interpretations
description: The ruling by Judge Terry P. Lewis of Leon County Circuit Court

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Fear of Diseased Beef Deepens In France's Supermarket Aisles
description: At lunch time in a city-owned slaughterhouse here, employees began spraying hot water and disinfectant across the bloodstained cement floors, putting lids on the containers of identification tags taken from cows as they were killed and sharpening knives so that work could begin again in the afternoon.

title: Judge Leaves Open Amount Of Damages On Auctions
description: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a proposed $512 million settlement of an antitrust lawsuit against the Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses could be submitted for consideration to more than 100,000 auction buyers and sellers who have asserted that the companies colluded to keep their fees high. Either side could urge the judge to accept or reject the settlement at a hearing on its final approval, which the judge set for Jan. 8 .

title: The Origins of Man
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Harry Potter and Inquiry by the S.E.C.
description: The Enesco Group, a collectibles marketer, said today that the Securities and Exchange Commission was looking into the trading of its shares before the company announced on July 5 that it had won the right to develop products based on the popular Harry Potter children's book series.

title: Extra Credit: The Great American Civics Lesson; Ballots Should Count
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Travel; Companies continue to tighten up on expenses, sometimes by enforcing long-dormant policies.
description: THERE are policies on the books, unenforced for years, that are suddenly being pulled out and thrust in our faces,'' a business traveler groused in a recent e-mail message describing the way his company has begun tightening up on travel and entertainment expenses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONAN, NADEGE
description: KONAN-Nadege. Died November 6, 2000 at age 35. She is survived by her children Malik and Sarah. Nadege was the charming voice handling reservations at Jean Georges. A Memorial service on Thurs, November 16, 3-7 PM at John H. Joyce Inc., Funeral Home, 2332 Adam Clayton Powell, Jr. (corner 137th St), NY. All who loved Nadege are welcome to attend. Donations may be made to the order of Francoise Rouge, 62 W. 62nd St, Ste 20D, NY, NY 10023

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, HOWARD A.
description: BERNSTEIN-Howard A. Lovingly remembering you on your birthday. In our hearts forever. Our Family

title: THE CHEF; Sweet and Spicy on Bread, or on Turkey
description: I grew up in England and have always been partial to chutneys. Most Americans think these Indian-inspired condiments are sticky and sweet. But chutneys can have a range of textures and heat, with lots of flavor in every small spoonful.

title: EDUCATION: BULLETIN BOARD
description: An Overhaul for Teacher Recruiting

title: Forbes and Fortune are trying to bolster circulation among business movers and shakers.
description: FORBES and Fortune -- the George W. Bush and Al Gore of business magazines -- are at it again.

title: From a Captive Audience, Clients; Law Firm Goes Mass Market With 1-800 Subway Ads
description: Even before he joined his father's firm, Michael Wilens was planning its expansion into a new area of law. So, he explained, ''I called my subway distributor.''

title: Nanchang Journal; The Bike That Won the East Is Now Heading West
description: From the gloomy, grease-smudged recesses of a small garage in an industrial Shanghai neighborhood, gray-haired Zhan Xiong tends to a small flock of starry-eyed devotees of his stock in trade: 750-cc sidecar motorcycles that were once the workhorse of the Communist world.

title: Brick-Attack Victim Nearly Died From Her Injuries, Surgeon Says
description: A neurosurgeon testified in a Manhattan court yesterday that Nicole Barrett, who was struck with a brick on a Midtown street last year, had no brain function after the attack and would have died if not for emergency surgery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEEGERS, EDITH A.
description: SEEGERS-Edith A. Age 72, of Pleasantville, New York passed away November 12 while at home in Florida. Edith worked as a bookkeeper for the Legend Group for thirty years. She is survived by her beloved companion, Tony Ciulla, sons, Richard, Paul and David, and many cherished grandchildren, nieces, nephews and friends. Her generosity, warmth, humor and loving ways will be missed by all who knew her. In lieu of flowers contributions can be sent to the American Cancer Society or the National Audubon Society. For more information please call 860-350-6622.

title: Man Charged With Murdering His Girlfriend and 2 Children
description: A Brooklyn man has been charged with murder in the deaths of his girlfriend, their infant daughter and the young woman's 2-year-old son, who were bound, repeatedly stabbed and set on fire, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Deal Settles Suit Against MP3.com
description: The online music start-up company MP3.com agreed to pay $53.4 million to the Universal Music Group of Seagram yesterday, in a deal approved by a federal judge minutes before the final phase of their yearlong copyright dispute was scheduled to begin.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL GAINS. Heating oil rose as an early spell of cold weather increased demand for heating fuel. In New York, heating oil for December delivery rose 3.78 cents, or 3.7 percent, to $1.0541 a gallon.

title: Playtex in Talks on Debt
description: Playtex Products Inc. said today that it was in negotiations with its bank lenders to try to ease the terms of its debt payments. Playtex said in a regulatory filing that its earnings might fall short of financial ratios that are called for in its loan agreements after it reports fourth-quarter results, putting it in default. The filing did not give specifics. As of Sept. 30, Playtex had long-term debt of $931.6 million.

title: Using the Magic of Lights, Projections and Fairy Tales
description: Magic dominated the program that Jody Sperling/Time Lapse Dance presented on Sunday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

title: MSG Has to Decide Whether One Year of Yankees Is Enough
description: By tomorrow, the MSG Network will decide how badly it wants to keep televising Yankee games.

title: To State's Chagrin, Eyes of the Nation Turn South Yet Again
description: It is not like Florida had such a sterling image.

title: Computers to Track 'Quality of Life' Crime, Giuliani Says
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sent out a pre-holiday warning yesterday to panhandlers, squeegee crews, prostitutes, noisemakers and others who he said disturb the public peace, announcing his latest crackdown on ''quality of life'' crimes in New York City, this time with a high-tech spin.

title: Attacks On Jews Are Surging In Canada
description: Marvin Abugov does not regret investing in strong double-paned windows for Beth Israel, a six-month-old synagogue. A few hours before dawn on Nov. 1, someone threw a rock and then a gasoline bomb at one window. The bomb bounced off the inner pane, flaming harmlessly against a red brick outside wall.

title: One Nation, One Standard Way to Ballot
description: The Electoral College may be here to stay, even though a majority of people polled about our current cliffhanger election would prefer to abolish it. It has often been proposed that we switch to electing the president and vice president by popular vote; Congress debated such a proposal as recently as 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANKS, CHARLES A.
description: BANKS-Charles A. On November 6, 2000. Husband of the late Helen. WWII Army veteran, long-time resident of Harlem, entertainer, pianist and composer. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St., Wednesday, 4-9PM. Service 8PM. Interment on Thursday, at Calverton National Cemetery.

title: A Turkey in Every Pan, but Not Just Any Pan
description: I've tried them all: speckled blue enamel, disposable aluminum, heavy industrial gray. But my favorite roasting pan is All-Clad's solid stainless steel model called the Roti pan. It does the job better and more beautifully than any of the others. Its proportions are squarer than most, just right for a turkey. It's heavy enough not to warp, but still manageable when fully loaded, and it's the perfect depth -- three and a half inches -- for browning. The handles are well placed, securely riveted and large enough to accommodate oven mitts. Though it does not have a nonstick finish, my two-year-old pan still needs only a brief soaking in warm water and detergent and a rub with a nonabrasive sponge to restore its mirror finish. Roti pans -- 16 1/2 by 14 inches, or 14 1/4 by 11 3/4 inches -- are an investment, $175 to $200 for the large size, $160 for the small. But like any strong supporting player, it can make the show.

title: Apple Compote
description: Golden Delicious apples were chosen for the tart because they are high in pectin, which gives them more body. This makes a thick compote -- a chunky, apple-sauce filling  and it also helps the sliced apples in the tarts decorative layer maintain their shape. (They wont melt so easily.)

title: Pet Beneficiaries and ID Mix-Ups
description: I work in employee benefits, processing transactions. I enter information for new enrollees in our medical, dental and life insurance plans, and I note beneficiary designations and life changes, like a marriage or the birth of a child.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: FRITZ, -- San Francisco, a transportation company, named Lynn C. Fritz, chairman, to the additional post of chief executive, succeeding Raymond L. Smith, who is resigning to pursue other interests, but will stay on as a consultant. In addition, Graham R. F. Napier, chief operating officer, becomes president.

title: C & N TOURISTIC SET TO ACQUIRE THOMAS COOK TRAVEL UNIT
description: C & N Touristic A.G., Germany's second-biggest travel company, plans to buy Thomas Cook Group's tour-operating business for about $:550 million ($790 million) in cash, Bloomberg News reported, citing anonymous sources. Preussag A.G., Europe's largest tourism company, is selling the business to satisfy regulators after agreeing to acquire Thomson Travel Group, a British rival of Thomas Cook, in May. A spokesman for Thomas Cook told Bloomberg that the company was ''confident that our ownership position will be clarified by the end of year,'' but declined further comment. As part of the transaction, the Carlson Companies, which owns 22 percent of Thomas Cook, will exercise an option to buy the rest of the company from Preussag and Westdeutsche Landesbank, and then sell the company to C & N, the report said.

title: Many Feasts, One Thanksgiving
description: ANYONE could write the menu. Roast turkey and stuffing. Cranberry sauce. Baked sweet potatoes. Pumpkin pie.

title: Secretary of State's Statement
description: Following is an excerpt from the statement last night by Katherine Harris, Florida's secretary of state, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Amtrak Is Putting Its Hope On a Successful Acela Express
description: The sleek Acela Express that Amtrak will roll out on Thursday is supposed to move more than just well-heeled passengers between Washington and Boston; it is supposed to carry the railroad a long way toward self-sufficiency, which Congress has insisted it reach by 2002.

title: Polls Only Confuse Education Policy
description: WHEN the cold war raged and crime, inflation and unemployment seemed intractable, education barely registered in politics. But now, no public discussion seems complete without reference to schools.

title: A Cheat Sheet for the Holiday
description: FOR New Yorkers, takeout is not just a convenience but a right -- anyplace, anytime. That includes Thanksgiving, of course, which presents the usual logistical challenge of squeezing a 15-pound turkey into a 10-pound oven. There's no stigma attached to putting together dinner over the phone. It's a sign of street smarts.

title: Print the Recipes
description: The Dough

title: Suit Contends Board Of McKesson Knew Of Problems at HBO
description: The McKesson Corporation's board knew of accounting irregularities at HBO & Company eight months before they were disclosed, according to new contentions in a shareholders' lawsuit.

title: Yale to Expand Aid to Foreign Students in Push for Diversity
description: With competition for top students spilling over into the international arena, Yale University said yesterday that it was expanding its financial aid for foreign students and would accept them regardless of their need.

title: State Seeks Plans for Neglected Brooklyn Area
description: After a quarter of a century in which community opposition, lack of government financing and other obstacles thwarted the development of three prime patches at the edge of downtown Brooklyn, New York State moved yesterday to spur housing and retail projects on the sites.

title: Extra Credit: The Great American Civics Lesson; Winners and Losers
description: To the Editor:

title: Extra Credit: The Great American Civics Lesson; A Country of Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: DE BEERS GIVES UP ON ASHTON
description: The South African diamond giant De Beers Consolidated Mines said it was formally withdrawing its takeover bid for Ashton Mining, leaving Ashton to be acquired by a rival bidder, Rio Tinto P.L.C. De Beers, a unit of Anglo American, had bid more, $388 million compared with $371 million, but regulatory delays persuaded Malaysia Mining to accept Rio Tinto's offer instead. That gives Rio Tinto sure control of at least 51 percent of Ashton and its prize property, the Argyle mine.

title: Trade Deficit Poses Risks To Economy, Panel Finds
description: A prominent Congressional commission appointed to study the giant American trade deficit determined that the imbalance has become unsustainably large and dangerous for the economy, but mostly disagreed on what to do about it.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: All That's Missing Are Sound Effects

title: Reckonings; A Legitimate Concern
description: When Mexico's peso plunged at the end of 1994, it didn't come as all that much of a surprise; quite a few economists, myself included, had more or less seen it coming. But the severity of the economic crisis that followed was unexpected. Confidence collapsed, and with it investment and consumer spending. Only a huge emergency loan saved Mexico from a financial, and probably political, implosion.

title: Oil Giant's Chief 'Understands What Investors Look For' : Soft-Spoken Executive Shakes Up Corporate France
description: PARIS  The most powerful businessman in France runs an old-fashioned oil company, even if a brash media mogul steals the headlines.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: New and Numerical

title: Board Wins Furious Race In Bid to Beat The Clock
description: Reaching the end of a frenetic three-day sprint with barely five minutes to spare, Volusia County election officials this afternoon turned in the results of their manual recount of presidential balloting, awarding Vice President Al Gore a net gain of 98 votes over Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Giuliani Says He Is Pleased, Not Pained, by Developments at City University
description: Besides squeegee men and graffiti, few things have provoked greater disdain from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani than the City University of New York. It was less than two years ago when the mayor, in one of his more colorful comments, said the university's standards were so low that it would be proper to ''blow up'' the system.

title: Charting the Dessert Course
description: New Yorkers can truly give thanks for living in a place with so many wonderful bakeries -- it makes cheating on the last course perfectly respectable. Just decide how much time you have, and know your resources.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGG, MARY BROMLEY (NEE HOLT)
description: BRAGG-Mary Bromley (nee Holt) former resident of Dobbs Ferry, NY. Passed away on November 12, 2000. Mary was the devoted wife for 59 years of the late Dr. Everett C. Bragg. Loving mother of Everett E. (Sherrill), James B. (Dee) of Darien, CT, and Malley (Thomas) Heinlein of Sawkill, NY. A memorial service for Mary will be held at a later date in New York. Memorials appreciated to the Wisconsin Humane Society, 4500 W. Wisconsin Ave., Milwaukee, WI 53208 or to the Columbia University School of Nursing, 617 W. 168th St. New York, NY. Feerick Funeral Home, 414-962-8383.

title: Baking and Assembling the Tart
description: The best rolling board is marble because it manages to stay cool the longest, although other surfaces will serve, too. Other tricks in this process: Start the baking at a high temperature to seal the dough quickly, then lower it (as we describe below); remove the ring from the sides of the tart halfway through baking, to allow complete browning; use a black-surfaced tart pan to aid browning by intensifying the heat.

title: Rodriguez Lingers, but Mets Move On
description: Scott Boras lives on the West Coast but works in his own time zone, so it's not uncommon to get a phone call from him at any hour. Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager, received a call from Boras late Monday night. News reports had filtered their way to California, and Boras realized that his client, the free-agent All-Star shortstop Alex Rodriguez, might have lost his biggest suitor.

title: Officials in 4 States Round Up Stragglers and Await Word on Recounts
description: While the post-election turmoil boiled on in Florida, in other states where the vote was close, officials continued to examine vote totals, and Republicans and Democrats considered whether to seek recounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATSON, GEORGE DONALD.
description: MATSON-George Donald. Of New Vernon, New Jersey, on Monday, November 13, 2000. Former Chief Financial Officer of the National Westminster Bank U.S.A. who was previously the C.F.O. of the National Broadcasting Company and began his career with the Arthur Anderson Co. Served in the Navy in World War II. He is survived by his wife, Margaret (nee Hawkes) Matson and his sons, Thomas of Silicon Valley, CA., and James of Beverly Hills, CA. Funeral services are private.

title: CALENDAR
description: Celebrating Nouveau

title: Leetch's Ice Time Equals His Age (32)
description: Sixteen games into his 14th National Hockey League season, the 32-year-old Brian Leetch is nearly averaging his age in ice time. After logging 32 minutes 33 seconds in Sunday's 2-0 loss to the Phoenix Coyotes, Leetch leads the league with 30:11 per game. St. Louis's Chris Pronger, the reigning Norris Trophy award winner, is second at 28:18 a game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINZ, ANDREW M.,
description: LINZ-Andrew M., DDS. The officers and board of directors of the New York County Dental Society are saddened by the passing of Andrew Linz. His contributions to the profession were numerous and he served the Society as president in 1974 with distinction. His counsel will be missed. Mark A. Mintzer, President Donna Rumberger, Pres Elect Robert Raiber, Vice President Jack Hirsch, Secretary Matthew J. Neary, Treasurer Elliott Moskowitz, Immediate Past President LINZ-Andrew M., DDS. The Fellows of the New York Academy of Dentistry extend their deepest sympathy to the family of Past President Andrew Linz. His leadership made a significant contribution to interprofessional relations. A dear friend of the Academy, whose exceptional talents as an administrator, teacher and mentor will truly be missed.

title: Election Furor Prompts Fox To Review Role Of Bush Cousin
description: Fox News is reviewing the status of John Ellis, an executive who is a cousin of Gov. George W. Bush and who played a central role in the first network call of a Bush victory in the Nov. 7 election.

title: AMF Bowling Is Under Inquiry by S.E.C.
description: AMF Bowling, the debt-burdened bowling alley operator controlled by the Goldman Sachs Group, is under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to an earnings report filed yesterday with the commission.

title: DIAL TALKING WITH LENDERS TO AMEND CREDIT AGREEMENT
description: The Dial Corporation, the maker of Purex detergent and Armour canned meat, said yesterday that it had begun talks with its lenders to ease terms after a third-quarter loss. Dial, which is considering whether to sell some businesses or the whole company, said in a regulatory filing that its earnings this year might fall short of the amount required by its loan agreements and put it in default on Dec. 31. The company wants to amend the agreement.

title: Extra Credit: The Great American Civics Lesson; We're All Students Now
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Leisure on Nov. 5 about the current New York production of ''Crave'' by the British playwright Sarah Kane at the Axis Company, and a review of the play on Saturday, misstated the American performance history of her work. Another of her plays, ''Phaedra's Love,'' has been staged in Chicago and San Francisco; ''Crave'' is not the first to be fully produced in the United States.

title: 'Lubricant' on Tracks Offers Clue to Austrian Fire
description: An Austrian investigator said today that a substance similar to a lubricant had been found on the tracks of the cable car that burst into a fierce fire on Saturday, killing at least 156 people.

title: Michigan a Contender Despite Loss of Scorer
description: Last August, Michigan experienced its toughest loss of the 2000-1 men's hockey season without playing a game. From that point on, the Wolverines have rebounded nicely.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Robert Trout, Known as the 'Iron Man' of Broadcast Journalism, Dies at 91
