description: Robert Trout, a pioneering broadcast journalist who was admired for the ease with which he ad libbed his way through some of the century's most important breaking news reports, died yesterday in Manhattan. He was 91 and had homes in Manhattan and Madrid.

title: KULICKE & SOFFA AGREES TO BUY PROBE TECHNOLOGY
description: Kulicke & Soffa Industries, the world's largest supplier of semiconductor-assembly equipment, agreed to buy the Probe Technology Corporation for $65 million in cash. Probe Technology, which is closely held and is based in Santa Clara, Calif., makes testing products for the microprocessor and telecommunications industries. Kulicke & Soffa, based in Willow Grove, Pa., said the purchase of Probe would fit with its October acquisition of the Ceprobe Corporation, which makes products for semiconductor test integration.

title: Add a Little Vietnam, France and California, and Mix
description: BAO-XUYEN LE was standing in her backyard, surrounded by ginger, sugar cane, banana palms and sweet olive. The air was close. Birds were singing and calling. ''Sometimes when I'm here,'' Ms. Le said, ''I feel like I'm back in Vietnam.''

title: Extra Credit: The Great American Civics Lesson; A View From Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Camby Wins the Battle, But Sonics Win the War
description: If it were about personal accolades, tonight would have belonged to Marcus Camby. Flying through the air as if propelled by a trampoline, Camby soared over and around his aged predecessor to win the battle of the Knicks centers, past and present, going away.

title: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES PILOTS CALL FOR CONTRACT TALKS
description: Pilots at Continental Airlines said they had asked the airline to begin contract negotiations in May, more than a year early, because of recent pay increases won by pilots at other carriers. The current contract terms run through October 2002 and do not call for talks to start until July 2002. Pilots at United Airlines won raises of 21.5 percent to 28.5 percent in a new contract last month, and pilots at Delta Air Lines Inc. have said they are seeking to top those gains in their contract talks. Continental had no comment on the request for early talks.

title: CISCO BUYS WIRELESS CHIP-SET MAKER
description: Continuing on its buying spree, Cisco Systems of San Jose, Calif., announced yesterday that it would buy Radiata Inc., a privately held maker of chip sets for wireless networks. The acquisition gives Cisco access to technology permitting wireless communications at speeds previously possible only with wired connections. Founded in 1997 in Sydney, Australia, Radiata developed technology based on research conducted by an Australian government agency, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, along with Macquarie University. The deal calls for Cisco to exchange common stock worth roughly $295 million for all outstanding shares and options of Radiata, which has 53 employees. Cisco, which already owns 11 percent of Radiata, said it expected to close the deal in the second quarter of fiscal 2001. Separately, the fiber optic equipment maker Corning said it would make optical equipment incorporating Cisco gear based on an Internet protocol that breaks data into packets for transmission. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Forest Legacy, Within Reach
description: President Clinton has already produced a stellar record of environmental achievement, but for sheer scope nothing quite matches the proposal he announced one year ago to ban road-building in millions of acres of national forests. On Monday the Forest Service released its final version of that plan, which Mr. Clinton is expected to approve in 30 days. It is a considerable improvement on the original. But it needs two important adjustments, which Mr. Clinton has the power to make.

title: Clinton Again Advises Patience in the Wait for a Result
description: President Clinton said today that Americans should ''just relax, take a deep breath'' while they wait for election results, and he took his own advice.

title: Pudding, Sweet and Not
description: BREAD pudding is one of the most traditional American dishes; cookbooks from the 18th century have recipes for it that are more or less the same as what we make today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in this section last Wednesday with a grouping of scenes from Sologne, France, where game is hunted, misidentified a shot bird. It was a mallard, not a pheasant.

title: A Judge Comfortable With Shades of Gray
description: Head fakes are common in the courtroom of Terry P. Lewis.

title: Flora of Rome
description: To the Editor:

title: Sprout Is a Sprout Isn't a Sprout
description: The brussels sprout is a stubborn little vegetable: no matter how cleverly you cook it, no matter what inventive flavoring you add, it is still, in the end, a brussels sprout. But there is a way to transform it into a fresher, sweeter side dish: serve just the leaves in a quick saute.

title: Courville Wins Top Award Again
description: For the fourth time in the last six years, Jerry Courville Jr. of the Shorehaven Golf Club in East Norwalk, Conn., will receive the Metropolitan Golf Association player of the year award, which was named for his late father in 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, SUSAN BERES,
description: WOLFF-Susan Beres, November 14 at home. Devoted daughter of Elaine Beres and the late Herman Beres. Beloved wife of the late Michael Wolff. Dedicated mother of Russell Wolff and Joanna Wolff, mother-in-law of Patty Wolff and Scott Schneiferman. Loving companion of Stephen Feinberg. Grandmother of Lillian Schneiderman. She devoted her life to her family and friends. We love you and will miss you everyday of our lives. Funeral service are today 1:30 at Westchester Jewish Center, Palmer and Rockland Avenues, Mamaronek. 914-698-2960. For more information, Zion Memorial Chapel 1-888-381-1809 www.zionmemorialchapel.com WOLFF-Susan. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of a dear friend, the beloved mother of Russell (Patricia) Wolff and Joanna (Scott) Schneiderman. A woman of compassion, she was a staunch supporter of our cancer research programs and among the first members of the advisory board to the Albert Einstein Comprehensive Cancer Center. Her husband, the late Michael Wolff, was a respected member of our Board of Overseers and a past chairman of our Men's Division, in whose honor a wing of the Men's Division Research Floor was named. To her children and the entire family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean WOLFF-Susan. To Russell, Patty, Joanna, Scott and Lily. Your strength is our strength, your loss is ours. Susan, a woman of care, concern, laughter and love, we will miss you so much. Find the old man and enjoy all the good times. Love, Barbara, Philip and all the children WOLFF-Susan. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Susan Wolff, and extend sincere condolences to her family. Paul N. Gardner, President WOLFF-Susan. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Russell (Patty) and Joanna (Scott). She fought a valiant battle and she left you a lifetime of wonderful memories. Love, Susan, Ben, David and Alison WOLFF-Susan. To the family of Susan Wolff. Susan, we will deeply miss your laughter, your friendship, and your guidance. We will never forget you. Leslie and Steve

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PONARAS, ANNA CRABB.
description: PONARAS-Anna Crabb. Died November 11, 2000, at the age of 91 in Washington, D.C. She was born in Ithaca, NY, and grew up in Athens, GA. Excelling in academics, swimming and horseback riding. She earned BS and MS degrees from the University of Georgia and in 1930 started her career of teaching English, speech and physical education. Upon marrying Andrew Ponaras in 1944 she moved to New York City, raised a family and resumed teaching from 1959-1971 at Forest Hills H.S. She is survived by her two children Anthony and Niki.

title: Going in Search Of DiMaggio, Relentlessly
description: To write ''Joe DiMaggio: The Hero's Life,'' Richard Ben Cramer expected no cooperation from his subject, the secretive Yankees legend whose largely untold story was the holy grail of sports biography.

title: Riley, Scott's Old Coach, To Oppose His Pupil
description: Knowing that his mentor, Pat Riley, would be dissecting the video from New Jersey's game on Monday night against the Portland Trail Blazers, Coach Byron Scott of the Nets would have liked to show his best side, the calm and composed exterior he usually displays. But what Riley will see is Scott being ejected with two technical fouls in just his seventh game on the sideline.

title: On the Bowery, an Italian of Few Words
description: THE French have two very useful adjectives at hand when they like a restaurant: honest and correct. The words don't sound like much in English, but in French, honnete and correct have a certain resonance, implying sound technique, respect for ingredients and clearly expressed flavors. The English equivalent might be ''solid.'' A fanciful writer might describe a correct, honest restaurant as having the right stuff.

title: TAG SALE AT DEUTSCHE BANK
description: Tax-law changes due in January 2002 will prompt Deutsche Bank to start selling off its vast industrial holdings much more rapidly than it had previously planned, a bank official said, with all its holdings to be sold by 2007. Elimination of stiff capital-gains taxes on cross-holdings removes the main roadblock to the bank's unwinding its holdings, which includes substantial stakes in DaimlerChrysler, Allianz, Munich Re, Continental, Fiat, Holzmann, Heidelberger Zement and other prominent companies. The whole portfolio was worth about $17 billion at the end of October.

title: Free-Agent Waltzing For Yanks And Nelson
description: Jeff Nelson faced 1,225 batters in five seasons with the Yankees, little more than what Roger Clemens might face in a good year. Nelson's role has been to pitch to a few batters in the seventh and eighth innings, a few times a week.

title: Mr. Rogers Plans to Leave the Neighborhood
description: Fred Rogers, who has entertained, soothed and educated children on public television in his trademark cardigan and tennis sneakers for 33 years, is planning to stop producing new episodes of his classic program, ''Mister Rogers' Neighborhood,'' at the end of this year.

title: Fragrant Fruits of a Southwestern Harvest
description: THANKSGIVING at the Harts' house in Phoenix begins not with dinner but with breakfast. A breakfast for those with a hearty appetite and a bold palate early in the morning.

title: Johnson's Third Cy Young a Surprise
description: Randy Johnson was so skeptical about his chances of winning the National League's Cy Young Award yesterday, he told a public relations official from the Arizona Diamondbacks that he planned to play golf in the afternoon. The official begged Johnson to postpone his outing and wait for a potentially important call.

title: A Mathematical Trip to the Inner Recesses of Infinity
description: THE MYSTERY OF THE ALEPH

title: Vodafone Earnings Surge 24%, Excluding Charges
description: The Vodafone Group, the world's leading mobile phone company, announced today a solid rise in first-half profit, excluding the cost of acquisitions. The report propelled a surge in technology issues on the London stock exchange.

title: Extra Credit: The Great American Civics Lesson; The Dark Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Breaking the Same Old, Same Old Indian Mold
description: ONE of my recurring disappointments has been the dismal state of New York's Indian restaurants. Although it is possible to ferret out food with the spicing, vibrancy and diversity that make Indian one of the world's glorious cuisines, a vast majority of restaurants, especially in Manhattan, settle for a dreary sameness. You would almost believe that the extent of Indian cooking is no more than what fits on a takeout menu.

title: N.C.A.A. SUSPENDS RUTGERS WOMAN
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association suspended Karlita Washington, a returning starter on the Rutgers women's team, for the Scarlet Knights' season opener on Friday against California because she played in one summer league too many, Coach C. Vivian Stringer said yesterday.

title: Daimler Will Soon Replace President of a Struggling Chrysler
description: Amid growing exasperation over mounting losses at the Chrysler Group, DaimlerChrysler A.G. plans to replace Chrysler's president with a top German executive, company executives said today.

title: Ethical Question Of a 'View' Host Having Her Soup And Eating It, Too
description: If you watch ''The View,'' ABC's late-morning talk show, you are likely to hear a lot about Campbell's Soup.

title: QUALCOMM SETS UP VENTURE UNIT
description: Qualcomm yesterday formed Qualcomm Ventures, a division whose aim is to invest $500 million over the next four years in companies that increase the use of mobile Internet services based on code division multiple access, or C.D.M.A., a fast-growing wireless technology. Qualcomm Ventures, in addition to providing companies with investment capital, will seek to leverage its parent company's investment in C.D.M.A. networks. ''Our whole mission in life is to drive usage of C.D.M.A.,'' Jeff Jacobs, the executive who will head Qualcomm Ventures, said in an interview. Mr. Jacobs said the unit would typically acquire minority stakes in small companies for no more than $20 million. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Dispute Arises in Florida Panhandle From Recount of Rejected Ballots That Favor Gore
description: Before the mostly Democratic canvassing board in this bucolic town certified the vote here in Gadsden County last Wednesday, they repaired to a sealed room and examined a load of rejected ballots. When they were done, Vice President Al Gore had 170 more votes.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: U.S. Coach Has Faith In His 18-Year-Old Star
description: Before and during the Olympic soccer tournament, Landon Donovan was treated like porcelain by United States Coach Clive Charles, who seemed to think the teenager's confidence might fissure if he was not handled delicately.

title: MINNESOTA MINING TO BUY MICROTOUCH FOR $160 MILLION
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company agreed to buy MicroTouch Systems Inc. for about $160 million in cash, or $21 a share, to expand its line of touch screens used in automated teller machines and kiosks. The price is a 41 percent premium on MicroTouch's closing price Monday. MicroTouch has no long-term debt, the company said. Minnesota Mining is based in St. Paul. MicroTouch is based in Methuen, Mass.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CHAIN STORE IN HARLEM
description: Wilsons Leather, the nation's largest specialty retailer of leather clothing and accessories, will open a store in Harlem next week with 40 to 50 employees, company officials said yesterday. The store, at 208 West 125th Street, will be one of the few Wilsons stores not situated in a shopping mall. The company's only other Manhattan store is at the Manhattan Mall near Herald Square. The opening of Harlem U.S.A., a shopping center on 125th Street, whetted Wilsons's interest in opening a store in Harlem, said Joel Waller, the chairman and chief executive of Wilsons, which is based in Minneapolis. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: From the Pumpkin to the Leftovers, the Feast Is in the Details
description: From the Ground Up

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, JEANETTE
description: HARRIS-Jeanette. The Grand Street Boys Association and The Grand Street Boys Foundation announced with extreme sorrow the passing of our beloved Executive Secretary, Jeanette Harris. She served our organizations and our charitable endeavors for fifty years. Her charm and wonderful spirit will always be with us. Funeral services at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Castle Hill & Lafayette Ave, The Bronx, Friday, November 17 at 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TELLER, SAMUEL
description: TELLER-Samuel. On November 13, 2000. Age 87. Of Deerfield Beach, FL. Beloved husband of the late Nettie Teller. Loving father of Claudette Blumenson, Martin Teller and Howard Teller. Fatherin-law of Robert Blumenson and Ester Teller. Grandfather of Andrea Goldberg, David Blumenson, Lisa Donofrio, Robert, Ilene and Marjorie Teller and great grandfather of Malka Goldberg, Andrew Blumenson, Mitchell and Jake Donofrio. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral service Friday, November 17th, 10AM at Schwartz Bros., 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Rhythmic Cycles of India Spiced With a Dab of Africa
description: India meets Africa somewhere on American territory in the latest project by Trilok Gurtu, a percussionist from Bombay who likes to work where national and musical boundaries blur. He spent the weekend performing at the Bottom Line with his group African Fantasy, which includes a Belgian-Congolese singer, a Cameroonian bassist and an Indian sitarist and guitarist. The guest musician on Sunday night was the great Malian singer Salif Keita.

title: Kournikova Beats Second-Guesses, Too
description: There was a time when it was more acceptable for Anna Kournikova to use the court as her lucrative catwalk rather than a career path to the top of the ranking, when she could simply seduce the cameras without having to produce under pressure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLENDORF, HENRY
description: ULLENDORF-Henry. The National Jewish Outreach Program (NJOP) mourns the passing of Henry Ullendorf, who, together with his wife Regina and family has played a crucial role in NJOP's efforts to assure a Jewish future for American Jewry. Condolences to the entire family Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: The Leaner Russian Military
description: Russia's decision to shrink its military forces by 600,000 people over the next five years is encouragingly realistic. So is President Vladimir Putin's renewed call for drastic cuts in the number of Russian and American nuclear warheads. Russia can no longer afford to sustain the imperial-size forces it inherited from the Soviet Union. Conversion to a smaller, better-equipped force will allow more effective defense against any foreign threats and would decrease the risk to democracy from restive, underpaid military officers.

title: Profit Up at NTT DoCoMo
description: NTT DoCoMo Inc., Japan's largest cellular phone company, reported a 22.2 percent increase in earnings today for the six months that ended Sept. 30, as demand for its mobile Internet services soared. The company said it earned 217.5 billion yen ($2 billion), up from 178 billion yen a year earlier.

title: Staples Reports Drop in Earnings
description: Staples Inc. said today that its fiscal third-quarter profit fell 8.5 percent and fourth-quarter earnings would be lower than expected, as it cuts prices to compete with rivals and consumer spending slows.

title: Unresolved Race for Congress Echoes the Battle in Florida
description: A week after nearly 250,000 New Jerseyans cast votes in one of the nation's tightest Congressional contests, the two men hoping to represent the 12th District are still wrangling in court amid charges of voter fraud, obstruction and political posturing.

title: In Nod to AOL, Time Promotes Top Executive
description: Signaling Time Warner's effort to integrate its operations with those of America Online, the company's magazine division, Time Inc., named Walter Isaacson, the managing editor of Time magazine, to the position of Time Inc. editorial director yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORAWSKI, JOHN H.
description: BORAWSKI-John H. Of Passaic, on 11/14/00. Father of Mikhail, Tatjana, Eudokia. Son of Tatjana and the late Jan. Brother of Nancy, uncle of Alexander. Reposing Shook Funeral Home, Clifton, NJ.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CLUB BUILDING IS NAMED LANDMARK
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted unanimously yesterday to designate the Downtown Athletic Club building a historic landmark. The designation, which protects the 35-story Art Deco building's exterior from most alterations, is not expected to affect plans to convert the upper 22 floors into about 30 luxury condominiums. The structure, best known as the home of the Heisman Trophy, which the club awards each year to college football's top player, is at 19 West Street near Battery Park in Manhattan. It was completed in 1930 and designed by Starrett & Van Vleck, architects of the 21 West Street Building and Saks Fifth Avenue, which also have landmark status. Last year, in a complex agreement with the bankrupt club's creditors, the high-rise was sold for $16 million to an investment firm, which in turn sold the bottom 13 floors back to the athletic club for $8 million, enabling the club to pay its bills and remain in business. In August, the top floors were sold to Jack Lefkowitz, a Brooklyn developer who specializes in residential conversions. Mitchell Belitz (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about life in Myanmar misstated the length of time since the authorities there have granted a journalist visa requested by The New York Times. Such a visa was granted in the spring of 1998; it has not been nearly five years that the authorities have refused to grant one.

title: More Networks Join Script Initiative
description: The Family Friendly Programming Forum, which is made up of 43 major advertisers, is expanding the number of television networks that will participate in its script development initiative.

title: Suspect Dies After Two Officers Use Pepper Spray During Arrest
description: A 31-year-old New Jersey man died Monday after a confrontation with police officers who used pepper spray to subdue him when, the police said, he resisted arrest and kicked out the window of a patrol car.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, TILLIE
description: ROTHMAN-Tillie. Died November 11, 2000 at home in her 100th year. Loving wife of the late Leo. Devoted mother of son Seymour and daughter Freda Hirsch. Loving grandmother of Louise, Erik, Shoshana and Lee Hirsch. Great grandmother to Nava, Elisheva and Ezra. Tillie was a beacon of strength and inspiration to us all.

title: Russian Gas Company Pulls Out Of Deal With Media Tycoon
description: Russia's state-controlled gas company today unexpectedly backed out of an agreement with Vladimir V. Gusinsky, owner of the country's largest independent television station, while federal prosecutors continued to push for his arrest.

title: For the Thanksgiving Meal, An All-American Choice
description: WE have always been a drinking nation; the rise and fall of Prohibition proved that. Even so, serving wine at the Thanksgiving table 50 years ago would have seemed somehow un-American, almost subversive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORN, LENORE
description: HORN-Lenore, 88. Of Ridgewood entered into eternal rest on November 13th. Beloved wife of the deceased Dr. Frederick E. Horn. Mr. and Mrs. Horn moved to the village in 1959. Together they traveled the world having visited over 150 countries including North and South America, Alaska, Canada, Europe, India, China, Japan, Russia, and many islands. Lenore was a longtime member of the Woman's Club of Ridgewood, The League for Creative Work, The Ridgewood United Methodist Church and sang with the Ridgewood Choral. A memorial service will take place on Thursday November 16th at 3:00 PM at the Ridgewood United Methodist Church in Ridgewood. For information CC Van Emburgh Funeral Home, 306 East Ridgewood Ave., Ridgewood, New Jersey 07450.

title: Poll Shows Palestinians No Longer Back U.S.-Led Talks
description: Only 3 percent of Palestinians surveyed by a leading university here support the continuation of peace talks under American sponsorship, reflecting a widespread belief that the three-way peace effort has reached a dead end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENE, JULIET KALIKOW.
description: LEVENE-Juliet Kalikow. Beloved wife of Stephen M. Levene and widow of the late Harold J. Kalikow. Loving mother of Peter Kalikow and Penny Wallerstein. Cherished grandmother of Nicholas and Kathryn Kalikow, Jill and Jennifer Wallerstein. Dear mother-in-law of Mary Kalikow and John Wallerstein. Devoted sister of Gertrude Blum, Harold Citrin, Renee Weil and Barbara Goldstein. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Juliet Kalikow Levene Memorial Fund, New York Presbyterian Hospital. LEVENE-Juliet Kalikow. The Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York, acknowledges with deep regret the passing of Juliet Kalikow Levene, the mother of ABO Governor, Peter Kalikow. Juliet's death will forever leave a void in this great city which she and her family helped develop. Her warm spirit and generous soul will live within all of us in the real estate industry. Rest in peace. Michael Kerr, Co-Chairman Arnold Sollar, Co-Chairman Jerome Belson, President Nicholas LaPorte, Jr., Executive Director LEVENE-Juliet Kalikow. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Juliet Kalikow Levene, a long time member of ADL's Women's Division and generous supporter. Our heartfelt condolences to Stephen, Peter, Penny and the entire family. Glen A. Tobias National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director Babette Bandler Chair, Women's Division LEVENE-Juliet Kalikow. The Partners, Associates and Staff of Podell Schwartz, Schechter and Banfield extend their deepest sympathy to our dear friend Peter S. Kalikow on the loss of his beloved mother, Juliet Kalikow Levene. We share our sincerest condolences with the entire Kalikow family. Podell, Schwartz, Schechter & Banfield LEVENE-Juliet Kalikow. We are deeply sorrowed at the passing of a most elegant lady who was a devoted wife, mother and grandmother. Our sincerest condolences to the Levene and Wallerstein families, their grandchildren and to our dear friends Peter and Mary Kalikow and their children Nicholas and Kathryn. Sugar and Jerry Schrager LEVENE-Juliet Kalikow. Beloved aunt-our heartfelt condolences to Peter, Mary, Penny, John, Stephen and all of Juliet's cherished grandchildren. She will be missed by all who knew her. Carol and Richard Kalikow and Family LEVENE-Juliet Kalikow. title: City Contractor Says Mayor Of Camden Received Favors
description: A prosecution witness in the bribery and racketeering trial of Milton Milan, Camden's mayor, testified today that in 1992 Mr. Milan, then just a first-time City Council candidate, asked for an introduction to Dominick Monaco, also known as Shorty, who held the city's lucrative towing contract.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Metro Business Briefing; SECOND WEB-BASED GROCER FAILS
description: Shoplink.com, the online grocer serving Westchester County and large parts of Connecticut, announced yesterday afternoon that it had abruptly gone out of business. Shoplink, based in Westwood, Mass., is the second online grocer to announce this week that it was shutting down: Streamline.com, also based in Westwood, said it would close next week. Less than a year ago, online grocery stores were considered to be among the most promising Internet ventures. Earlier this year Shoplink, which opened in 1997, received $37.5 million in investments and, already operating in Rhode Island and Massachusetts as well as in Connecticut and New York, said it hoped to build more than 30 distribution centers across the nation by 2003. But in the last several months, online grocers have increasingly come under attack over their continuing losses. Yesterday, Shoplink said it intended to file for bankruptcy protection. About 30 percent of Shoplink's orders were in the New York region, where the company had about 2,200 of its 5,000 customers. In a letter posted on Shoplink's Web site, the company said orders already placed would neither be billed nor delivered. It also said consumers who sent personal items, like film for processing, should contact either the vendors the company worked with or bankruptcy officials once the company files for protection. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: PRICE RISES EASE IN BRITAIN
description: Excluding mortgage costs, British retail prices rose in October at an annual rate of 2 percent, slightly slower than September and well below the government's target of 2.5 percent, suggesting that the economy is slowing enough to keep inflation at bay and that the Bank of England will be able to reduce benchmark interest rates. A fall of 0.9 percent in the cost of driving a car was the main reason the index, Britain's principal inflation gauge, slowed. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Museum Where Art and Commerce Glow Together
description: On the southern edge of this city's expanding downtown arts district, on the ground floor of modern 10-story apartment building, stands the Museum of Neon Art, an inconspicuous temple to neon felicitously known as MONA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTARA, MICHAEL P., GOLDMAN
description: MORTARA-Michael P., Goldman Sachs Executive. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Wednesday, November 15th, at 11:00am at St. Anthony of Padua Church in Litchfield. Burial will be in St. Anthony Cemetery. There are no calling hours. The Rowe Funeral Home, 283 Torrington Rd., Litchfield has charge of the services. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Michael P. Mortara Scholarship Fund, C/O Christine Smith, Georgetown University, 301 Intercultural Center, 37th and O Street, Washington, DC 20057. MORTARA-Michael. It is with shock and disbelief that we acknowledge the untimely death of our Partner and dear friend. As members of the Executive Committee of Salomon Brothers, we worked side by side with Michael during his highly productive years at our firm. He was a major contributor to our firm in the broadest sense. His keen intellect helped to promote the nationwide development of the mortgage backed securities market-today, a cornerstone for the U.S. capital markets. But, his contribution to Salomon Brothers was most apparent in his concern for his fellow partners and colleagues. He was an integral part of the firm's culture during its years of dynamic growth. He deeply cared for and nurtured the people with whom he worked and demonstrated the highest professional standards in every challenge he undertook. While we mourn our loss, it pales in comparison to the loss incurred by his family. To his wife Virginia, and his sons Michael and Matthew, we extend our deepest sympathy. John Gutfreund Allan Fine Gedale Horowitz Henry Kaufman Jim Massey Lew Ranieri Dick Schmeelk Tom Strauss MORTARA - Michael P. The people of Goldman Sachs Group express their heartfelt condolences and prayers to the family of our dear friend and partner. Mike played an important role in the development of the capital markets, and in the management of our firm. His unique talents and quest for innovation will be greatly missed by all who were fortunate to have known and worked with Mike. MORTARA-Michael P. Heather and Steve Mnuchin offer their deepest sympathy to the family of our friend, Michael Mortara: Gina, his wife, and his sons, Michael, Jr. and Matt. MORTARA-Michael P. You have brightened our lives and your light shines on in Gina, Michael, Jr. and Matt. We will miss you and love you forever. Dick and Susan Ebersol, Sunshine, Harmony, Charlie, Willie and Teddy. MORTARA-Michael. It was an honor and a joy to have been a friend of Mike Mortara. He was an extraordinary man. He deeply loved his family. He cared about others. He was a brilliant professional. His word was his bond. My family and I send our love and sympathy to Jenna, Michael and Matthew. We love you. John S. Corzine MORTARA-Michael, a great friend and partner whose humor, creativity and intelligence will be sorely missed. We were all lucky to have known you. Our deepest sympathy to Jenna, Michael and Matthew. Brooke and Daniel Neidich.

title: The Brash Young Voice in Brokaw's Ear

Is anyone really comfortable doing this for an extended period of time? Or is it a statement: a hotshot I was, a hotshot I continue to be, even after the mortal tap on the shoulder of two bouts of cancer.

description: A portrait of a Palestinian terrorist was slowly drawn today from the terrorist himself, a reluctant witness at the Lockerbie trial. Finally, the day ended with his angry refusal to say what the Soviet military trained him to do 30 years ago.

title: Lexington Properties Deal

The partnerships, Net 1 L.P. and Net 2 L.P., own 25 commercial properties in 15 states, which are leased to tenants like Hewlett-Packard, and Wal-Mart Stores. Lexington said it would issue about $65 million of securities for the deal. The company said its chairman and chief executive, E. Robert Roskind, is the controlling shareholder of the general partnerships of the partnerships.

title: With U.S. Missile Defense, Russia Wants Less Offense
description: Unwilling to wait for a declared winner in the American presidential race, the Kremlin has mounted a diplomatic offensive to advertise its desire to make deep cuts in the nuclear arsenals of Russia and the United States as soon as possible after a new president takes office.

title: Sports of The Times; A Big One For Big Fella And Sonics
description: VIN BAKER embraced his teammate at halfcourt. Patrick Ewing had done nothing more than convert a simple reverse layup with less than six minutes left to put the Seattle SuperSonics comfortably in front, barely leaving his feet to do so.

title: Third Consecutive Property Tax Reduction Is Proposed in Westchester County
description: The Westchester county executive, Andrew J. Spano, proposed today to reduce property taxes by 4.8 percent -- the largest county tax cut in 27 years.

title: Deathly Ill Patients Seek Options
description: WASHINGTON -- A majority of terminally ill patients say the options of euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide should be available to Americans but very few would consider such choices themselves, says one of a series of major new studies on how we die.

title: Bay Ridge Journal; 'Green' Offices for the Chesapeake Bay's Friends

The airy, innovative structure is already being hailed by environmental advocates as the ''greenest'' office building yet devised.

title: Canada's Banks Cross The Border to Grow
description: When Americans trade stocks through TD Waterhouse, the third-largest discount broker in the United States, they are dealing with a Canadian bank. The same is true when they apply for a loan at Harris Bank in Chicago or withdraw cash from a SelectBank A.T.M. in a Safeway supermarket in California.

It won't be surprising to find a neighborhood Chinese hole in the wall delivering turkey by bicycle next Thursday afternoon.

title: CABLE AND WIRELESS TO RAISE CASH
description: Mobile and residential phone businesses in Australia are next on the block for Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain, which is amassing cash for future acquisitions to expand its role as a global Internet service provider. The company has already raised a net $6 billion by shedding consumer-oriented businesses in Hong Kong and Britain to focus on corporate customers; selling the Australian units may add another $2.5 billion. Its stock rose 6.2 percent, to 902 pence, in London after it reported better-than-forecast pretax profit of $769 million before exceptional items for the first half of its fiscal year. Alan Cowell

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about newly declassified United States government documents on the relationship with Chile in the 1970's and beyond misstated the date of a cable sent to Washington by an American ambassador in Chile. The cable, in which Ambassador David Popper rejected an order to convey Washington's displeasure with plans by governments in the region to assassinate opponents overseas, was dated Aug. 24, 1976. It was thus sent before -- not after -- Orlando Letelier, a former Chilean diplomat, was assassinated in Washington on Sept. 21, 1976.

title: A's Giambi Is Winner of M.V.P. in A.L.
description: The Oakland Athletics are baseball's most dynamic young team, and Jason Giambi is their leader. For his production and his leadership he is also the American League's most valuable player, after barely winning the fragmented voting.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS. The yen declined on concern that Japan's prime minister, under pressure to resign, might be distracted from efforts to bolster the economy. In New York, the dollar settled at 108.88 yen, up from 108.15 on Tuesday.

title: HARRAH'S UNIT MAY SEEK BANKRUPTCY TO REDUCE DEBT
description: The JCC Holding Company, which owns a struggling New Orleans casino and is controlled by Harrah's Entertainment Inc., told state regulators that it might seek bankruptcy-court protection. The company presented a plan to the state Casino Tax Advisory Committee that would reduce its debt to $129.6 million from $622.3 million, including a proposal to ''eliminate current equity holders through a bankruptcy proceeding,'' the company said in a federal filing. JCC wants Louisiana to reduce what it calls an onerous $100 million annual tax on it, and said the casino will bring in about $248 million in revenue this year, below the $420 million needed to break even.

It paved the way for a significant offer that will probably come later in the week, and another face-to-face meeting after Thanksgiving.

description: A 41-year-old firefighter died yesterday about an hour after he returned from a fire in the Bronx, where he helped haul a hose up six flights of steps and directed its flow of water, officials said.

description: Herbert Brun, a composer who helped introduce the use of electronics and computers in creating music, died on Nov. 6 in Urbana, Ill. He was 82 and lived in Urbana.

description: Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County executive, released his long-awaited plan tonight to bring the county's troubled finances into balance over the next four years.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES INC., St. Louis, the eighth-largest U.S. airline, and America West Airlines, a unit of Phoenix-based America West Holdings Corp., agreed to sell tickets for each other's flights starting in the first quarter of next year.

title: Metro Business Briefing; ZAGAT PUTS NEW YORK FIRST
description: It will come as no surprise to anyone who has walked through Times Square lately, but New York has become travelers' favorite city to visit, according to a Zagat survey to be released today. The last time Zagat's volunteer critics voted, in 1997, San Francisco was first in their hearts. In general, New York's hotels fared poorly in the Zagat ratings, and were also the most expensive in the nation, with average room rates of $261 a night. But for the first time, the 19,400 Zagat travelers gave the top ranking in the country to a New York hotel, the Four Seasons, on 57th Street. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Three Lost Garden Gems
description: LOCAL plants can be the workhorses of the garden, offering beauty and utility to the landscape, as well as sense of place. Here are recent rediscoveries.

title: G.O.P. Disputes Claims That Both Sides Have Counted by Hand

title: Even for Pros, Going Gets Weird Awaiting the Count in Palm Beach County
description: It is not a circus here, say some people in Palm Beach County, when asked by outsiders about the weirdness of its on-again, off-again vote recount.

title: The Call of the Wild, the Beep of the Gadget
description: TODAY, being away from home means never having to say you are lost. The most widespread development in equipment for outdoor trekking -- by foot, bike, boat, car and skis -- is the use of Global Positioning System receivers. When G.P.S. receivers came onto the commercial market in the late 1980's, people could use them to pinpoint any location on the planet by getting a fix on the longitude and latitude. But to get from Point A to Point B, people still needed to use the receivers as they would a compass, with a map.

title: Chase Move Still Hurts Seles
description: While it is not always easy to speed-read the emotions on Monica Seles's face as her words tumble out in a breathless pace, her disillusionment with tour officials was perfectly clear last night.

title: Willamette Board Turns Down Takeover Bid by Weyerhaeuser
description: Willamette Industries said yesterday that its board had unanimously rejected a $5.3 billion takeover offer from the Weyerhaeuser Company, the nation's third-largest forest products concern.

title: Corrections

It was Hudson Valley Community College in Troy, N.Y., not Hudson County Community College.

title: A Treasure at Yale, Freed of Wallboard

Last month, Yale University announced that $20 million had been donated to restore the epoch-making building, with 37 changes of level in seven stories and distinctive hand-hammered ''corduroy'' concrete walls embedded with classical fragments.

description: WILLIAMS - Marilyn Thornton. Ph.D. 68, of NYC, on November 13, 2000. Dearly beloved mother of Jocelyn & Karen. She is survived by her sister Joan Mazzaia, brother-in-law Don, nephew Chris, nieces Julie and Sherry and many, many wonderful friends. Retired professor of American history at Pace University. A devoted educator, an engaged scholar and a determined feminist in both the historical profession and in life. Author of ''Washing the 'Great Unwashed': Public Baths in Urban America'' and scholarly articles. Memorial service Friday, November 17, 10:30 AM, at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, NYC. Memorial contributions may be made to the Marilyn Thornton Williams Memorial Prize in Women's Studies at Pace University.

title: Murderer May Help Find Body Of Slain Socialite
description: Kenneth Kimes, who was convicted with his mother of killing a missing Upper East Side socialite, has offered to clear up the final mystery of the case by telling detectives where they can find the victim's body, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: More to Gaming Than the PlayStation
description: IN the ever-shifting race for dominance between consoles and PC's, the year 2000 will probably go to the consoles. After all, console gamers received a promising new system in Sony's PlayStation 2 (well, some of them did), which can also play DVD's and run games created for the original PlayStation. This after the original PlayStation had achieved a ubiquity typically reserved for household appliances. Sony reported in May that a PlayStation was in one of every four American households.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLENTUCK, ELMER
description: ELLENTUCK - Elmer. Beloved husband of Tara-Jeanne MarcusEllentuck and the late Beatrice. Devoted father of Dan. Loving grandfather of Benjamin and Toby. Services 10AM Thursday, Plaza Memorial, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Reserving a Place At the Holiday Table
description: CALL it taking inventory or, in light of recent events, a recount. With the holidays approaching, check the china cabinet, and if supplies are low, supplement with transferware -- the highly decorated dinnerware with outdoor scenes or wildlife images, usually in brown or blue on a white background.

title: A Staunch Gore Ally Influences Florida Ballot Fight
description: Whether or not he wins Florida's electoral votes, Vice President Al Gore's performance was far stronger here than first expected, and for that Democrats credit state Attorney General Robert A. Butterworth.

title: Nursing Home Failings
description: To the Editor:

title: For Mideast Mediation
description: To the Editor:

title: Adopted Siberian Boy's Death Is Investigated in New Jersey
description: Prosecutors in New Jersey are investigating the death of a 7-year-old Siberian boy whose adoptive parents have since been charged with endangerment and witness tampering.

title: Taken Aback, Bush Campaign Sticks to Script
description: Only an hour or so after Vice President Al Gore made his televised proposal for a way to end the fracas in Florida, Gov. George W. Bush hit the road tonight, making the 90-minute drive from his ranch near Waco to the Governor's Mansion here.

title: Toyota Reports 20.9% Earnings Drop
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that its half-year profit fell 20.9 percent from the period a year earlier, to 159.6 billion yen ($1.48 billion), as the strong yen offset the effect of growing sales.

title: Key Recount Waits Again For Approval From Court
description: Once again, for the fourth consecutive day, no votes were counted in Palm Beach County today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about former members of the civilian Cadet Nurse Corps misspelled the given name and surname of a girl who was being treated by Goldie Solomon, a school nurse in Port Chester, N.Y., who started her career in the corps. The patient was Maggie Kieran, not Maggi Kierun.

title: Article 2000111692842615507 -- No Title
description: ONLINE SHOPPER

title: Telecommuting's Downside
description: To the Editor:

title: EASYJET SHARES HOT ON DAY 1
description: Shares of EasyJet rose 10.3 percent, to 342 pence, in their first day of trading in London, giving the company, a British no-frills airline, a market capitalization of $:865 million. For the year ended Sept. 30, EasyJet earned $31 million before taxes on sales of $377 million. Brian Lavery

title: Lawyer Fighting for a Level Playing Field
description: THEODORE M. SHAW apologizes for breaking the rules, but he's been listening to himself talk for nearly three hours now.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Strikes at West Bank

title: A Mattel doll modeled after a certain singer does a turn on 'Will & Grace.' Is it product placement?
description: THE popular NBC sitcom ''Will & Grace'' is known for its ensemble cast of four, who were all nominated for Emmy Awards last season. But for tonight's episode, they will be joined by a fifth star: a doll modeled after Cher that the toy giant Mattel plans to begin selling next spring.

title: U.S. Study Points Out Ways to Cut Emissions
description: As critical talks on a treaty to fight global warming entered a third day here, the Department of Energy issued a study that addresses a main point of contention: whether the United States could do more to reduce its addiction to fossil fuels.

title: WIRELESS BOOM DRIVES PROFITS
description: Telefonica S.A. of Spain posted a 26 percent rise in third-quarter profit, helped by recent acquisitions in Brazil, Argentina and Peru and a boom in wireless use. Net income rose to 494.7 million euros ($425 million) from 394 million euros in the period a year earlier. Telefonica Moviles, the company's cell phone unit, had 23 million subscribers as of September, up from 14 million in 1999. Benjamin Jones

title: Knicks Falter Down Stretch And Stumble Vs. Clippers
description: When Latrell Sprewell made a shot while sitting near the foul line, it seemed as if the Knicks were in for some good fortune tonight.

title: Miniature Bronze Artworks As Accents for Floor or Wall
description: Clodagh, a designer known for her experiments with unusual materials, has just introduced a collection of cast-bronze tiles. She says the tiles can be embedded in cement floors, used on kitchen backsplashes, even framed as art or used as coasters. The quarter-inch-thick tiles come in four patterns, three sizes (4 inches square, 3 inches square or 1 1/2 by 6 inches) and four finishes: antique brown, rust, nickel with a satin finish and warm, copper-tone bronze. ''There's something ancient and timeless about bronze,'' Clodagh said. ''You can't kill it.'' Prices range from $35 to $55 each. A list of dealers is available from Clodagh Design Works in New York, (212) 780-5300 or at www.metaphorbronze.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: FORMER CLINTON AIDE TAPPED
description: Michael D. McCurry, a former press secretary for President Clinton, was named chief executive of the start-up company Grassroots.com. Mr. McCurry, who has served on the company's board since July, said, ''I think the Internet is going to have a transforming effect on politics.'' Grassroots.com, of San Francisco, opened as a political portal in February with $33.4 million in venture capital. It is shifting its focus from offering political information online to selling software to help groups lobby online.. Rebecca Fairley Raney

title: Publicis Unit Buys Geltzer & Company
description: Publicis Dialog in New York, part of the Publicis Groupe, said yesterday that it would acquire Geltzer & Company, a public relations agency in New York that specializes in consumer electronics companies. Terms of the cash deal were not disclosed.

title: The Youthful Clippers Are Growing Up in a Hurry
description: The night after their much-heralded rivals, the Lakers, received their championship rings two weeks ago, the other basketball team in Los Angeles, the Clippers, took the floor in the Staples Center -- the downtown building the teams share.

title: Third Witness in Orange Police Trial Contradicts Two Others
description: Prosecutors in the federal trial of five Orange, N.J., police officers accused of beating a suspect who later died in custody brought their third eyewitness to the stand today -- only to have him contradict the other two witnesses on some key points.

title: Webb Aims To Be Right On Money
description: For Karrie Webb, this week is about winning, but it is also about money.

title: City Worker Accused of Spying on Officials' Vehicle Records
description: A longtime city employee was arrested Tuesday night and accused of using his work computer to gain access to the motor vehicle records of top city officials, including those of the mayor, police commissioner and several borough presidents.

title: Michael P. Mortara, 51, a Developer of Mortgage-Backed Securities
description: Michael P. Mortara, a partner at Goldman Sachs who was instrumental in the founding of the market for mortgage-backed securities, died on Sunday at his home in Litchfield, Conn. He was 51.

title: Brazil's Chief, While Languishing, Is Challenged on Two Fronts
description: Already struggling with a bad case of the second-term doldrums, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso is suddenly facing a pair of new challenges: charges of campaign financing irregularities and domestic spying.

title: Gore Lawyers Focus on Ballot in Palm Beach County
description: In the hours before Vice President Al Gore made an offer tonight to Gov. George W. Bush, senior members of Mr. Gore's legal team prepared for what they called ''the nuclear button'' option: contesting the election results in Palm Beach County, strategists and lawyers for the Gore team said.

title: Rabbi Alexander Schindler, Reform Leader and Major Jewish Voice, Dies at 75
description: Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, who led the Reform movement of American Judaism through 23 years of growth in which it opened its congregations to unaffiliated Jews, non-Jews and those born of intermarriage, and made room in its pulpits for women and gays, died early yesterday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEAGER, KATHERINE CROMWELL (NEE CLARK)
description: YEAGER - Katherine Cromwell (nee Clark). 89, in Westport, CT, on November 7, 2000. Mother of Jane C. Bulkley, and grandmother of Pamela Bulkley, both of Westport, CT. Services and interment were private.

title: Awaiting a President, From Sea to Shining Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Lugz Shoes, New York, part of Jack Schwartz Shoes Inc., to Avrett Free & Ginsberg, New York, part of the Bozell Group unit of True North Communications, to handle its account, which had been at Amster Yard, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Teacher With Many Arrests Stayed on Staff, Report Says
description: A Bronx school district continued to employ a tenured teacher even though she had been arrested eight times in the last four years on a variety of misdemeanor charges, according to a report released yesterday by the special commissioner of investigation for the public schools.

title: Come In and Pull Up a Hamster
description: Think Ikea meets Urban Outfitters (plus some higher prices) and you have Room Interior Products, an Australian company that sells young-spirited, colorful homewares. The first Room Interior Products store anywhere opens Monday at 435 Hudson Street, offering the Malber combination washer/dryer ($899); soft cotton jersey queen-size sheet sets ($300 including a duvet cover); a beanbag chair ($90, at rear left) in silver or gold that eerily resembles the 1968 Italian Sacco chair; a 6-by-8-foot rug ($2,200, seen at left) woven of wide strips of gray felt, this year's popular material; colorful folding stools ($20 each); plastic stacking chairs ($90 each); and stark-white china ($9 for four dinner plates). Near right, rolling hamsterlike seats covered in fur; $300 for small and $500 for large. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Still Vigilant, Fed Maintains Steady Rates
description: Citing clear evidence that the economy has shifted into a lower gear, the Federal Reserve voted today to hold interest rates steady, but with unemployment low and energy prices high the central bank said it was not yet ready to proclaim that inflation was no longer a threat.

title: Rock of Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Awaiting a President, From Sea to Shining Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLANDER, MILDRED
description: HOLLANDER-Mildred. On November 14, 2000. Beloved and devoted wife of the late Harold Hollander. Cherished friend of Hans & Judi Leerink. Devoted companion of Kathleen Rhody, Marcia Robinson, Gludy Tai, Pauline Thomas & Miriam Lee. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Services Thursday, Nov. 16th at 2PM at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Westchester, NY.

title: Sather Has Interest in Healthy Lindros
description: On the same day that Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager, banished John MacLean to the Manitoba Moose of the International Hockey League, he expressed interest in Eric Lindros, a restricted free agent who is recovering from a series of concussions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPKIN, ROBERT H.
description: LIPKIN-Robert H., on November 14, 2000, when Robert lost his courageous battle with cancer. Robert is survived by his wife Ellen, his daughter Beth, and his brothers Warren and Perry and their families. Prior to his illness, Robert was involved in corporate business finance and consulting in the New York area for his entire career. He was a Vietnam veteran and took pride in having served his country. He was much loved and will be missed by many. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, November 16, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I. Shiva will be observed at the Lipkin home.

title: Move Made to Control Russian Automaker
description: Sibirsky Alyuminiy, a major Russian aluminum producer, took steps to gain control of the country's second-largest automaker, Gorkovsky Avtomobilny Zavod, known as GAZ, to keep the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development from getting GAZ stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, MORTON
description: GREENE-Morton. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, and friend. Died at home. Services Thursday 2:15 P.M. at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Critic's Notebook: Whirlwind of Humanity in London; West End Crackles With Stage Artists, Film Stars and Silly Bits
description: When Hamlet succumbs to uncertainty these days, something he has famously been doing for nearly 400 years, it is both hard and absurdly easy to read the expression on his face. Sadness, anger, good will, self-disgust and the amused, alarmed wonder of an expanding intellect that sees itself from a distance: all these feelings are conveyed in one improbable instant in Simon Russell Beale's glorious study of the doomed prince at the Royal National Theater.

title: Sontag Is Among Winners Of National Book Awards
description: The writer Susan Sontag won the National Book Award for Fiction last night for ''In America,'' a postmodern novel about a 19th-century Polish actress' attempt to establish a utopian community in California. The book, published this year by Farrar, Straus & Giroux, was partly inspired by the true story of the Polish actress Helena Modjeska, who came to America in the last century.

title: Lifting the Curtain on Web Filter Strategies
description: FOR parents worried about online pornography, buying Internet filtering software requires a leap of faith. The companies that make the software say that they are blocking what they consider to be obscene or pornographic Web sites. But they refuse to disclose lists of exactly which sites they block, saying that the lists might end up in the wrong hands.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I propose that Governor Bush and I meet personally, one on one, as soon as possible, before the vote count is finished, not to negotiate but to improve the tone of our dialogue in America.''

title: TUBE MAKERS MERGE
description: In a deal that would propel it into first place among makers of laminated tubes, used to package toothpaste and other products, Essel Packaging Ltd. of Mumbai, India, said it planned to merge with Propack Holding A.G., a Swiss company with extensive operations in India, in a deal valued at $350 million, the company said. Propack is privately held; its owners will control 22 percent of the combined company, to be called Essel Propack Ltd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, TOTLEE J.
description: BROWN-Totlee J. (53) of New Rochelle, died November 12, 2000. Granby's Funeral Service, Bronx, New York, (718) 519-6047.

title: The Slippery Statistics Of the Popular Vote
description: Before Election Day, numerous pundits, citing the polls, prepared the American people for the possibility that George W. Bush might well win the popular vote but lose the Electoral College. Just the opposite may have occurred: Al Gore appears to have won the popular vote, while Mr. Bush will win the presidency if he holds onto his tiny lead in Florida.

title: Agency to Vote on Web Domain Names
description: With the number of desirable Web addresses growing scarce, the board that administers Internet names prepared to issue the first viable competitor to the .com suffix in more than a decade today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Hey, They Do Write 'Em Like They Used To
description: It doesn't take a revolution to wring originality out of convention; a little skill and a little artful vision -- O.K., maybe a lot -- melded to an established tradition, and bingo, everything old can seem new again. That, above all, is the delightful lesson of ''3hree,'' the anthology of snack-size new musicals being presented through Sunday in a snappily renovated former movie house, the Prince Music Theater here. Organized by the veteran producer and director Harold Prince, who directs the final and most singularly satisfying entry, ''The Flight of the Lawn Chair Man,'' the trio of works that make up the show are all by relative newcomers to musical theater, none of whom attempts to stretch the parameters of the genre in word or music. All three works traffic in familiar song forms, all exhibit a relish for hummable melodies, and all take as their themes the soaring twin sentiments that musicals have celebrated forever: the need to pursue a dream and the transcendent power of love.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Big Companies Lead Effort To Reduce Medical Errors

title: Swiss Bank's Profit Hurt By Expenses of Acquisition
description: The Credit Suisse Group posted a 66 percent year-over-year rise in profit for its third quarter today, but the results were lower than in the first two quarters as the cost of taking over the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. brokerage firm cut back profit.

title: High-Tech Stealth Being Used To Sway Doctor Prescriptions
description: As a busy internist, Dr. Bruce Moskowitz frequently prescribes cholesterol-lowering medicines and osteoporosis drugs for his elderly patients. Like most physicians, he is no stranger to pharmaceutical sales representatives, and he often chats with them about his preference in medication.

title: The Spirits of Toys Past, Present and Future
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Mad Dogs Shuffles Creative Leadership
description: Mad Dogs and Englishmen is making changes in its creative leadership. Guy Seese, 30, was named a new creative director at the New York office. And Dave Cook, 38, a partner, was promoted to executive creative director. Mr. Seese had been an art director at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/ Euro RSCG in New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising.

title: In a Funky Hat, Singing The Blues and Other Things
description: Keb' Mo' was born Kevin Moore in 1951, but adopted the more theatrical nickname when he steered his career toward the blues slot in the 1990's. The gesture could be seen as fulfilling a stereotype, a Los Angeles-raised veteran of jazz-rock and soul bands going country to fit his new down-home style. But on Saturday evening at Town Hall, the Grammy-winning Mr. Moore quickly sidestepped the niche he once dug for himself.

title: CALENDAR
description: Gallery Tours

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the hijacking of a Russian plane to Israel and about Israeli-Palestinian violence over the weekend misstated the date of a defacing incident at a synagogue in the Efrat settlement in the West Bank. It was on the night of Oct. 26-27, not last weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUNER, ROBERT ALEXANDER
description: BLAUNER-Robert Alexander. On November 12, 2000. Robert died in peace at age 23 after a heroic fight with Hodgkin's disease. He is survived by his parents, Allan S. and Loretta; his siblings, Stephen, Peter and Patsy; and his grandmother, Josephine Steinberg Libman. A memorial service for Robert's friends and family will be held in several weeks. For information contact lsb@compucore.net. Memorial donations may be made in Robert's name to Yale Stem Cell Program, c/o Dr. Dennis Cooper, Yale University School of Medicine, Medical Oncology, 333 Cedar Street-WWW220, New Haven, CT. 06510.

title: Seeking the High Ground
description: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush vied tonight for the political and public-relations initiative, as surely as they did in their three debates during the presidential campaign.

title: 3 of 4 Officers Convicted In Police Corruption Case
description: In the first case to go to trial in a major police corruption scandal here, three of four officers charged with framing gang members and planting evidence were convicted today in State Superior Court.

title: Dow Jones Drops Wall Street Journal's Regional Editions
description: Dow Jones & Company abruptly ended a seven-year experiment in regional business journalism yesterday, announcing that it would immediately halt publication of six special weekly editions of The Wall Street Journal.

title: A Field of Native Plants Turned Into an Art Form
description: RICK DARKE and Melinda Zoehrer are creating such a powerful landscape in the foothills of the Piedmont, as it rolls down to meet the coastal plain of Delaware, that, just as a good story can drive a novelist, it tells them when a character is out of place.

title: Microsoft Sets Sights On Tablet PC Market
description: It's apparently not enough that Windows runs about 90 percent of the world's laptop and desktop computers. Microsoft now wants to capture a market that does not yet exist: tablet PC's.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 2 about the recent redecoration of ceremonial rooms at the White House misstated the surname of the 18th-century designer whose work influenced interiors installed there under Theodore Roosevelt. He was Robert Adam, not Adams.

title: Sports of The Times; Will Devils Trade Their 2 Holdouts?
description: DURING a Devils game, there is always a multiple-choice quiz on the scoreboard screen to test the fans' knowledge of the reigning Stanley Cup champions. But two of the Devils' proudest questions have yet to appear this season:

title: LEWIS-TUA ATTRACTS 420,000 BUYERS
description: The Lennox Lewis-David Tua heavyweight bout last Saturday night attracted 420,000 cable and satellite pay-per-view buys. The figure exceeded the 340,000 purchases for Lewis's fight against Michael Grant earlier this year.

title: The Unfazed Freshman
description: A flock of reporters gathered around Matt LoVecchio, then another. He patiently answered questions in a low monotone, but continued to crane his neck, trying to pick out two faces in the crowd on the other side of the tall iron gates at Notre Dame Stadium.

title: Mrs. Clinton Makes Plea for Peace at Rabin Funeral
description: Taking center stage in the country that preoccupied and bedeviled her political campaign, Hillary Rodham Clinton met here today with the president and prime minister of Israel and delivered an emotional eulogy for Leah Rabin, who died of cancer on Saturday.

title: Political Juices
description: To the Editor:

title: TBWA Executive Joins Messner Vetere
description: A top creative executive at the agency handling the Apple Computer account is leaving to join the agency that handles the Intel account.

title: Power Plants to Cut Emissions Faulted In Northeast Smog
description: A Virginia power company, accused of violating clean-air standards and contributing to acid rain and smog in the Northeast, has agreed to a landmark legal settlement requiring that it cut emissions from eight coal-burning plants by 70 percent.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Young, Disillusioned
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Begins Jockeying in House on Fate of Election
description: Representative Tom DeLay, the Republican leader who drove the House forward to impeachment, has sent a staff memorandum to Congressional Republicans pointing out that the House and Senate can reject a state's electoral votes if they decide that the votes are tainted.

title: COVAD SHARES ARE PUMMELED
description: The woes of the Covad Communications Group appeared to worsen yesterday after Covad, a provider of high-speed Internet service, restated third-quarter results. Shares in Covad, of Santa Clara, Calif., skidded $1.22 to $4.16, after the company said its loss before taxes was $125.3 million in the quarter instead of the $120.4 million reported last month. Revenue was $56.3 million instead of $66.7 million. Covad, stung by the recent resignation of its chief executive and several lawsuits asserting that executives misled investors about the company's financial situation, faulted late-paying customers for its difficulties in the quarter. A Merrill Lynch analyst, Ken Hoexter, said, ''We don't believe the company can resolve its difficulties in the intermediate term.'' Simon Romero

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: With Campbell's Profit Down 13%, It May Not Be Soup Just Yet
description: The Campbell Soup Company said today that its fiscal first-quarter profit fell 13 percent because of higher marketing costs aimed at increasing soup sales.

title: Management By Objective
description: The latest threat to the status quo of the music industry unveiled itself this week. And this time the threat didn't come from the Internet. It came from a new company called FXM, run by an entrepreneur who has become familiar in the entertainment industry over the last five years, Robert F. X. Sillerman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOHUE, JAMES PATRICK SR.
description: DONOHUE-James Patrick Sr. Died November 14, of Somers, New York, & Stuart, Fla. Husband of Marie. Father of Peter N. and Mary Stevens of New York City, James P. and Katherine Donohue of Bronxville, NY, Ms. Margaret A. Donohue of New York City, John G. Donohue of Orlando, FL., Robert M. and Eleanor Blanchard of Jacksonville, FL., Peter J. Donohue of Holden, Mass., Paul J. & Sandra Donohue of Jacksonville, FL. Brother of Reverend John W. Donohue, S.J., Mary McCarren of Bronxville, New York, & Cecilia Paulmann of New Rochelle, NY. Also survived by 10 grandchildren and 14 nieces and nephews. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, N.Y., Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Croton Falls, New York, Saturday, 11 AM. Interment private.

title: Computers: Workhorses, Show Horses
description: BACK in the Olden Days, which were the 1970's for me, the holiday season officially began on Thanksgiving afternoon, when we would gather around the hearth, er, television set, and the old commercial of Santa sliding over the snow on a Norelco electric razor would magically appear on the screen.

title: The Ballot Weighed, And Wanting
description: ALL America knows them by now: the clinging chad, the pregnant chad, the trapdoor chad. These tiny defects in the punch card ballot system have focused national attention on the design of voting technology.

title: From Novice To Star, In One Night 50 Years Ago
description: It's a founding myth of opera, the dream of every stage-struck ingenue: hours before curtain, the soprano falls ill. Desperate, the manager turns to a junior member of the company, a shoe salesman's daughter and school dropout who has never before performed onstage.

title: Text of the Fed Decision
description: Following is the text of the statement by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision yesterday to leave short-term interest rates unchanged:

title: Using Dance To Extend Another Art
description: Labels matter little for a one-of-a-kind performer like Michael Moschen. He is as much a juggler as Marcel Marceau is a mime. But like Mr. Marceau, he is a creative artist who takes the viewer into his own poetic world.

title: An Oil Barony Knows How to Entertain Important Visitors
description: After hitting a rough patch for a few years, the sultan of Brunei is feeling pretty good again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENE, JULIET KALIKOW
description: LEVENE-Juliet Kalikow. Beloved wife of Stephen M. Levene and widow of the late Harold J. Kalikow. Loving mother of Peter Kalikow and Penny Wallerstein. Cherished grandmother of Nicholas and Kathryn Kalikow, Jill and Jennifer Wallerstein. Dear mother-in-law of Mary Kalikow and John Wallerstein. Devoted sister of Gertrude Blum, Harold Citrin, Renee Weil and Barbara Goldstein. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Juliet Kalikow Levene Memorial Fund, New York Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Brain Signals Shown To Move a Robot's Arm
description: Scientists have identified the signals generated in monkeys' brains as they prepare to move their arms, and, in a major step toward melding minds and machines, the researchers have now used those signals to move a robotic arm.

title: Challenge To Premier Threatens Japan Party
description: The last time a contest for control of Japan's Liberal Democratic Party broke out in the open, in 1992-93, the party was kicked out of power for the first time in decades, though the exodus proved to be brief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROUT, ROBERT
description: TROUT-Robert. On November 14, 2000. Distinguished journalist in both radio and television. One of the first correspondents to cover London for CBS during World War II and later for ABC radio and television. Husband and colleague of the late Catherine ''Kit'' Trout and brother-in-law of Elizabeth Crane Prucher, uncle of Elizabeth Crane Boland, Stephen and Jeffrey Prucher. A memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Micromanager Gore And Delegator Bush Stay Courses in Crisis
description: In standing before the cameras tonight to propose a deal with Gov. George W. Bush, Vice President Al Gore rebuffed some of his top advisers who argued that it limited his political options, campaign officials said tonight.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Tuesday about a visit by Jiang Zemin of China to Cambodia misstated his title at one point. As noted elsewhere in the article, he is the president, not the prime minister.

title: Nordstrom Posts 41% Drop in Quarterly Profit
description: Nordstrom Inc., under new management led by members of the Nordstrom family, said today that its profit tumbled 41 percent in the quarter ended Oct. 31 because of steep price markdowns on slow-selling women's apparel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, ADRIENNE M.
description: SULLIVAN-Adrienne M. On November 13, 2000, of cancer, at Meadow Lakes, Heightstown, NJ, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. T.F.X. Sullivan, and sister of Isabel S. Sefton. Interment is private. Memorial Mass Monday, November 20, 2000, at 10:30 A.M. at Church of Saint Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street, New York. Memorial donations to Calvary Hospital, The Bronx, New York 10461.

title: Software for the School Zone, but Watch Your Speed
description: EDUCATIONAL software is suffering from what for lack of a better term might be called megahertz creep. That is the tendency for late-model programs to require ever-faster processor speeds to function properly.

title: FACING AUDIT, QUINTUS PLACES ITS CHAIRMAN ON LEAVE
description: The Quintus Corporation, a maker of software that manages company orders and services, said it had placed its chairman and chief executive, Alan Anderson, on administrative leave while PricewaterhouseCoopers L.L.P. audits its financial statements. Paul Bartlett, the chief operating officer, will serve as acting chief executive. The company, based in Fremont, Calif., also said it was delaying reporting its results for the quarter ended Sept. 30 because figures for revenue and accounts receivable were under review.

title: From Abbey Road to the Net
description: They came in through the browser window. The Beatles, whose enduring music has inspired countless Internet tribute sites, are finally online. The Fab Four's first official Web site (thebeatles.com) opened on Monday to promote the release of ''1,'' a compact-disk collection of the group's No. 1 hits.

title: In America; Running From the Vote
description: The situation could hardly be more transparent. The Republican Party is consumed with the fear that somehow a fair count of the votes in Florida will be permitted. It is doing all it can to prevent that from happening.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Eagle Scout Speaks Out

title: STOCK EXCHANGE STOPS TRADING OF AMF BOWLING
description: The New York Stock Exchange halted trading in shares of AMF Bowling before the market opened yesterday as the exchange tried to determine if the stock had any value. An exchange spokeswoman said it did not know if or when the stock would trade again. On Tuesday, AMF, an operator of bowling alleys controlled by the Goldman Sachs Group, disclosed in a quarterly earnings report that the Securities and Exchange Commission had subpoenaed financial statements and other company documents. AMF, which is based in Richmond, Va., also said that it was evaluating options for restructuring its $1.3 billion in debt, including filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy-court protection, and that the restructuring would probably render its stock worthless. Patrick McGeehan

title: ABC Planning to Keep Miller On 'Monday Night Football'
description: There appears to be no doubt that the comedian Dennis Miller will return to the ''ABC Monday Night Football'' booth next season.

title: Tolls May Rise For Rush Hour Across Hudson
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is considering a plan that could double the basic fare on the PATH train to $2 from $1 and increase tolls at several bridges and tunnels to $7 from $4 during rush hours, officials said yesterday.

title: Teacher Contract Ends; Giuliani Plans an Offer Soon
description: As the city's five-year contract with the United Federation of Teachers ran out yesterday, the Giuliani administration told the union that it would soon make its first proposal for a new contract.

title: Effort to Diversify Fire Department Bears Fruit, While Drawing Criticism
description: Next month, the city's Fire Department will begin to reap the benefits of a program intended to address a problem as old as faulty hydrants: imbalance by race and sex.

title: SALES WORRIES HURT NETWORK APPLIANCE
description: Shares of Network Appliance, a maker of computers that store and deliver data on networks, fell 21 percent on concern about slower sales growth and increasing competition. The shares fell $20.13 to $76.13. Sales in the quarter ended Oct. 27 more than doubled, but missed some forecasts. Network Appliance may also be facing stronger competition from EMC.

title: U.S. Catholic Bishops Seek Changes in Criminal Justice System
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops adopted a broad but detailed statement on America's criminal justice system today, calling both for a new commitment to rehabilitate criminals and for greater attention to the rights and well-being of crime victims.

title: 2 Companies In Gay Media Plan to Merge
description: Two companies that provide much of the online content for America's gay population, the Planet Out Corporation and Online Partners, announced yesterday that they would merge.

title: Computers: Workhorses, Show Horses
description: BACK in the Olden Days, which were the 1970's for me, the holiday season officially began on Thanksgiving afternoon, when we would gather around the hearth, er, television set, and the old commercial of Santa sliding over the snow on a Norelco electric razor would magically appear on the screen.

title: Executing Johnny Paul Penry
description: Johnny Paul Penry is scheduled to die by lethal injection in Texas today unless the United States Supreme Court agrees to hear his appeal and grants him a stay of execution. Penry, who was convicted of the rape and murder of a young woman in 1979, would be the third death-row inmate executed in Texas this week if he does not receive a reprieve. His case has generated international outrage because he is mentally retarded and suffers from organic brain damage that may be the result of the horrific abuse he suffered as a child.

title: A Compact Disk Player With a Dual Personality
description: Although the new eXpanium compact disk player by Philips Electronics may not turn heads with its ordinary looks, its capacity to play both standard CD's and home-recorded music disks might perk up more than a few ears.

title: Small Step and Deep Breath for U.S.
description: As the wind blew stiffly, the sky continued to spit and the players appeared tense, the chances that the United States would advance toward the 2002 World Cup seemed bumpier than the soccer field at Barbados National Stadium.

title: Beleaguered Capital City Has One Thing on Its Mind
