description: Every spring, a large group of earsplitting public officials sweeps into town, argues for several weeks and engages in blatantly political activity. There is plenty of back-room deal-making and threats of lawsuits, and then everyone goes home.

title: Shades of 1824
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGAR, PHILIP
description: UNGAR-Philip. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice. Devoted father of David. Esteemed member of East Midwood Jewish Center. Graveside services today 2PM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY.

title: For Children, How Cool Is It?
description: LONG gone are the days when children's toys were principally powered by mainsprings and imagination, when a doll capable of uttering only ''Mama'' would be considered downright chatty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, HENRY G., JR.
description: WALTER-Henry G., Jr. The Columbia University community mourns the loss of alumnus, friend, and benefactor Henry Walter. Hank, as he was affectionately known to Columbians, was a tireless supporter of Columbia's Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory. His recognition of the importance of climate research, decades before current issues emerged demanding that knowledge, speaks to his prescient insights. He is deeply missed, and on behalf of the entire University, I extend sincerest condolences to his family and friends. John Mutter Interim Director Lamont-Doherty

title: Chads Have Their Place In Annals Of the Law
description: Believe it or not, courts across the country have thought long and hard about the issues of chad upon which the presidential election may yet turn in South Florida's punch-card counties. And their answer to the question of whether an imperfectly punched ballot can be considered a vote has usually been a resounding yes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, MARYLU
description: HOPKINS-Marylu. The principals and staff of Strategic Resources Corporation extend their heartfelt condolences to their partner, collegue & dear friend, Jim Hopkins, on the passing of his wife, Marylu. Strong until the end, Marylu was a beacon to all of us, and she will be remembered for her will, fortitude & class. Our warmest sympathies are extended to Jim, his sons and the entire Hopkins family. Contributions in Marylu's memory may be made to The Marylu Hopkins Charitable Fund, C/O Strategic Resources Corporation, Carnegie Hall Tower, 152 West 57 Street, 44 floor, New York, NY 10019, which will support charities endorsed by Marylu and her family. Paul Schack Christian Van Pelt Jacques DeLodder And the staff of Strategic Resources Corporation

title: The Electoral Process Gets Ever Fuzzier
description: The process of choosing the next president seemed to grow exponentially more complicated yesterday. Here is a summary of the day's main developments.

title: For People With Disabilities, Self-Expression in the Wool
description: Call them outsider rugs. At the News Gallery in SoHo, there is an exhibition of 33 hand-hooked, mostly wool rugs made by people who are mentally, physically or emotionally handicapped. The artists are from the Creative Growth Art Center in Oakland, Calif., a day school for adults started in 1973. Some of them paint, some draw and others turn those images into rugs. The show includes Donald Patterson's ''U.S. Greenback,'' top left, and William Tyler's ''The Imposter Chicken Took the Eggs to the Movies.''

title: The Changing Climate: Ideas for The Hague
description: To the Editor:

title: Unusual and Custom-Made Gifts, Far From the Beaten Path
description: DOING your holiday shopping online is not just about dodging the crowds anymore. Yes, the big Internet retailers will send you Pokemon cards and Harry Potter books overnight and save you from setting foot inside the mall.

title: William G. Harrington, 68; Wrote Mysteries and Thrillers
description: William G. Harrington, a mystery novelist with a long career as a collaborator with celebrity authors, died on Nov. 8 at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 68.

title: Aggrieved Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: How Local Personalities and Circumstances Are Shaping the Presidential Outcome
description: The three-member canvassing board that oversaw the vote tally here in this quiet, old-fashioned seat of Volusia County was not supposed to be entirely hostile territory for Gov. George W. Bush and his team of powerful campaign lawyers. Two of the three board members are Republicans. So is the county supervisor of elections.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS GAINS. Natural gas rose after reports of falling inventories led to concern that winter supplies might be tight. In New York, natural gas for December delivery rose 24.9 cents, to $6.265 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: New Portrait, New Image for Gingrich
description: Newt Gingrich, the most divisive figure in the recent history of the House, appealed today to both parties to work together and to listen to the fears of each other's political bases.

title: An Old Chagall Haunt, Repainted
description: MICHAEL JACKSON rented it last, but a previous tenant of the Beaux-Arts town house at 4 East 74th Street was an artist of a different stripe.

title: A Missed Opportunity in Florida
description: Vice President Al Gore offered a sensible way out of the legal and electoral quagmire in Florida yesterday when he pledged to abide by the results and not to sue if a complete hand recount was carried out in three critical Florida counties. Mr. Gore also said he would abide by a statewide hand count if his opponent, Gov. George W. Bush, preferred that approach. Mr. Bush's swift rejection of the proposal was a disappointment on civic grounds, a political mistake and unsound as to his reasoning that a manual recount would be ''arbitrary and chaotic.''

title: S.E.C. Approves New Rules On Brokers and Accountants
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved new rules today, one requiring brokerage firms to release composite statistics on where they send customer trades and how well these orders are filled and another aimed at preventing conflicts of interest by auditors.

title: Credit Suisse Under Inquiry in Japan a Second Time
description: For the second time in a year, the Credit Suisse Group is under investigation by Japanese financial regulators.

title: A Growing Corporate Challenge: the Empty Executive Suite
description: Faced with an unforgiving stock market and a harsh business environment, many companies are experiencing another stark reality: a lack of management depth. As more and more chief executives are being rushed out the door by disappointed investors and impatient boards, companies are finding that there is a shortage of obvious candidates to fill these spots, according to executive recruiters and management experts.

title: Taken Aback, Bush Campaign Sticks to Script
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 15  Only an hour or so after Vice President Al Gore made his televised proposal for a way to end the fracas in Florida, Gov. George W. Bush hit the road tonight, making the 90-minute drive from his ranch near Waco to the Governor's Mansion here.

title: NEW CORPORATION LAWS PLANNED
description: The Federal Securities Commission of Russia plans to compile a code of laws on corporate governance next year and begin holding companies to tougher standards, the commission's chairman said. Investors cite lax and abusive practices by Russian companies as a major deterrent to investing in Russia. Sabrina Tavernise

title: Sotheby's Reports Big Losses Related to Price-Fixing Case
description: Sotheby's Holdings Inc. reported a ''significant loss'' for the first nine months of 2000 yesterday, attributing it largely to the special charges associated with the Justice Department's antitrust investigation into price-fixing and pending settlements of class-action and shareholders' lawsuits.

title: Fisticuffs and Knives, But for the Fun of It
description: 'A Few Good Men . . . Dancin' '

title: The Awakening of a Young Ghost and a Grown Man
description: IN THE COUNTRY OF THE YOUNG

title: Second-Period Scoring Binge Revives Rangers
description: Like someone startled from a long nap, the Rangers came alive for the last four and half minutes of the second period tonight. Then they rolled over and went back to sleep in the third period against the Minnesota Wild's numbing neutral-zone trap.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARADNY, ROBERT, MD.
description: PARADNY-Robert, MD. Dear Bob/Dad, you live on in all of us and in your sweet, sweet granddaughter, Renee Dana, named for you on February 24th. Like you, she is already a shining light in all of our lives. We love you and miss you always. Forever, Adelle, Robin, Andrea, Stew, and Renee

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the first part of a sports article yesterday about the Giants' prospects for the rest of the National Football League season was omitted from some copies yesterday, and only the continuation appeared. The article is available on the Web at www .nytimes.com/sports. It may be requested from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Uncounted Overseas Votes Carrying a Pro-Bush Profile
description: Most of the overseas absentee ballots waiting to be tallied in Florida's disputed presidential election have come from voters registered in counties that supported Gov. George W. Bush in the Nov. 7 vote, an analysis by The New York Times shows.

title: 2 Say Suspect Spoke in Jail Of Brick Attack on Woman
description: Two petty criminals testified yesterday that the man charged with attempted murder in attacking a woman with a brick in Midtown alluded to his involvement in the incident while in jail.

title: Deal Ends Strike by Fairfield County Janitors
description: More than 400 janitors in Fairfield County, Conn., agreed last night to end their six-week walkout by reaching a tentative three-year contract that will raise salaries for most of them by nearly 50 percent.

title: Presidential Journey to Vietnam
description: The last American president to visit Vietnam was Richard Nixon, who traveled to the South Vietnamese capital of Saigon in 1969, at the height of a war that eventually took 58,000 American and three million Vietnamese lives. Today, Bill Clinton begins a three-day trip to Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, as Saigon is now called. Mr. Clinton's visit is striking evidence of how far the two countries have moved beyond the rancor of that conflict. But if a healthy new relationship is to be built, Hanoi must ease bureaucratic restrictions on foreign investment and show greater respect for the civil and religious liberties of its people.

title: Longing for Authenticity; Is the Jazz Really Jazz in Harlem Without the Locals?
description: Around midnight, the jazz was live and straight-up in the Zebra Room of the Lenox Lounge, the legendary Art Deco nightclub in Harlem. Cocktail glasses clinked around tiny candle-lit cafe tables. The jazz vocalist, leaning against the baby grand, hushed the room with a big soprano voice that was like a soft, strong wind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACY, BERNADETTE
description: TRACY-Bernadette. One of a kind. How very true, dear lady. We will miss you as a friend, a brilliant researcher, an always amazing mind, and as ''Auntie Bernadette'' to Thomas and Juliana. Farewell wild rose, thorny and so beautiful. Tom and Dana Fenton

title: Groh Tells Testaverde He Need Not Look Over His Shoulder
description: Jets Coach Al Groh glanced at the morning papers on Tuesday and knew it was time for a talk with Vinny Testaverde.

title: JAPANESE BANKRUPTCIES SURGE
description: More than 1,700 companies went bankrupt in Japan last month, 22.7 percent more than in the period a year earlier, Teikoku Databank said. Companies that collapsed in October owed 8.65 trillion yen ($79.1 billion), the highest monthly total since World War II, weighed down by the failures of two huge life insurers. Japan's bankruptcy rate has been climbing, and is set to eclipse the record set in 1998, adding to pressures on the country's banks. Stephanie Strom

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Republican Hopes for Carrying Oregon Are Growing Dim
description: Republican hopes of carrying Oregon, long a part of the Democratic stronghold of the West Coast, were down to a few threads today as Vice President Al Gore held onto a lead of 4,233 votes with fewer than 10,000 ballots still to be counted out of more than 1.5 million cast.

title: A Ballot Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: An Indoor Pet Playground, With Everything but Squirrels to Chase
description: The Biscuits and Bath Doggy Village, a membership-only club that opens tomorrow, may redefine ''creature comforts.'' Sandy Zuchert, 62, owns and designed the five-story spa, playground and boarding facility for dogs and cats, where dogs will be able to gambol on (fake) grassy fields, swim in a pool 30 feet by 6 feet, above right, and clamber up and down seesaws. Among the offerings will be puppy agility classes. (Think Gymboree for animals.) To Ms. Zuchert, pet owners are parents, dogs are doggies, and cats are kitties. The cats who are overnight ''guests'' (Ms. Zuchert would never call them ''boarders'') will not languish from boredom while they are parked at Biscuits and Bath. ''I wanted the kitties to think they were at the Broadway theater,'' Ms. Zuchert said. The front of the cat room (which she calls ''kitty condos'') will have an aquarium, so they can watch the fish. The style of the spa, which cost $1.3 million to renovate, is Greenwich, Conn., with manicured lawns, fresh flowers, wood fences and a cafe, above left, for dogs and their owners . . . sorry, ''parents.'' Memberships are $1,000 to $1,500; 227 East 44th Street; (212) 692-2323.

title: That Sweet Transvestite Doing the Time Warp Again
description: The toilet paper was cascading at a recent preview of ''The Rocky Horror Show,'' hurled onto the stage by members of the audience, and the musical's cross-dressing star was sounding more like a substitute schoolteacher than the mad scientist he portrays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, LOUIS
description: GROSSMAN-Louis. Of Remsenberg, N.Y. and Boca Raton, Fl. On November 13, 2000. Beloved husband of Marian. Loving father of Steven and Robert, father-in-law of Lynne and Carole. Cherished grandfather of Alison, Ethan, Cary and Leslie. Great grandfather of Daniela. Chairman of the Board of Southern Container Corp forever. Louis was a man of deep caring for his family and will be sorely missed. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Woodbury, N.Y. 10am Thursday, November 16th.

title: 6 Records Set at Christie's First Auction of Postwar Art
description: ''The generation now buying art is the generation that relates to postwar material,'' the Manhattan dealer Abigail Asher said at Christie's last night. ''They're selective, but they'll spend big, big money.''

title: To Great Joy in India, a Bandit Frees Movie Idol He Kidnapped
description: India's most notorious bandit today finally freed India's most famous hostage, the beloved elderly movie idol Rajkumar, whom he had held captive for 109 days in an ever shifting series of jungle encampments.

title: Choose Your Battle: Action, Role-Playing, Puzzles or War
description: PC Games

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAULKINS, DIXIE T.
description: CAULKINS-Dixie T. The Board of Trustees, Medical Board and Administration of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center acknowledge with sadness the passing of our longtime friend and beloved benefactor, Dixie Thompson Caulkins, who succeeded her late husband, H. Whitfield Carhart, as a Trustee from 1978 to 1993, then served as a honorary member of the Board from 1993 until the time of her death. She forever will be remembered for her leadership, energy and elegance as well as her unflagging support of the Hospital Center's mission. To her family, friends and loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington, Chairman, Board of Trustees Sigurd H. Ackerman, M.D. President and CEO J. Thomas Barnard, M.D. President, Medical Board

title: Economic Scene; Online auctions as a laboratory for economists to test their theories.
description: ONLINE auctions offer a wonderful laboratory for experimental economists: the participants are intelligent adults, spending real money, who hope to purchase goods in which they have an intense interest. This is a far cry from the reluctant sophomores whom experimentalists have had to rely on in the past to test economic theories.

title: Big Companies Lead Effort To Reduce Medical Errors
description: A group of 60 of the country's largest companies announced plans yesterday to push hospitals to reduce medical errors that are to blame for the deaths of tens of thousands of patients each year.

title: Staying Wired on the Go And Doing More Work
description: BUSINESS people who travel frequently have picked up the spiffy tag ''mobile professionals'' over the past few years, and the gadgets they tote around the world to work in transit and keep in touch with the home office have attained a similar streamlined construction. Laptops have become thinner and lighter, yet more powerful, and hand-held computers can do more and do it more easily through color screens, increased memory and greater expansibility. Browsing the Web and sending e-mail with a cell phone has become commonplace.

title: An Optimistic Bid Makes, While the 'Safe' One Fails
description: Thousands of bridge players converge on Birmingham, Ala., today for 10 days of play in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals. This is the first time a major championship has been played in Alabama.

title: NEW JOB FOR FORMER MANNESMANN CHIEF
description: Klaus Esser, who served as the chairman of Mannesmann before it was acquired by Vodafone AirTouch, will join General Atlantic Partners, a private investment firm in Greenwich, Conn., as a partner. The company said Mr. Esser will be based in Germany and specialize in telecommunications investments. Suzanne Kapner

title: Israelis Kill 8 Palestinians in a Day of Widespread Uproar
description: Israeli helicopter gunships struck at Palestinian targets in the West Bank after a day of surging violence in which Israeli soldiers shot and killed eight Palestinians and wounded dozens in raging street battles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIRANDA, ANTHONY
description: MIRANDA-Anthony. New York City Opera mourns the passing of Tony Miranda, a member of our orchestra for 17 years and Principal Horn player for 12. He was a valued member of our orchestra, a good friend, and we will miss him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Sharon Moe, his children, and all his many friends. Visitation hours are on Thursday, November 16, from 3-5 PM and 4-9 PM, at Marble Collegiate Church, at 1 West 29 St. A memorial service will be held at the Church on Friday, November 17, at 11 AM. Paul Kellogg, General Director George Manahan, Music Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, RABBI ALEXANDER M.
description: SCHINDLER-Rabbi Alexander M. It is with deep sorrow that the officers and trustees of the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture mourn the sudden passing of our beloved and esteemed President, Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler. One of the most influential figures of American Jewry, he served as President of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, the central body of Reform Judaism in North America, from 1973 to 1996. But his leadership and scope of vision were universal. From 1976 to 1978, he was Chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations. Rabbi Schindler served on the Board of the Memorial Foundation almost from its inception, was elected Vice President in 1988, Chairman of the Executive Committee in 1994, and President in 1996. Throughout his tenure as our President, he served conscientiously to strengthen the Foundation's efforts in reconstructing Jewish life in the aftermath of the Holocaust and in developing innovative programs to address the cultural needs of the Jewish people globally. He was a dedicated and creative leader and raised the Foundation to new levels of harmony, accomplishment, and international recognition. To his wife Rhea and children and grandchildren, we extend our sincerest condolences. May they take comfort from his lifelong dedication to k'lal Yisrael. Prof. Anita Shapira, Chairman, Executive Committee Dr. Jerry Hochbaum Executive Vice President

title: Toomer's Concussion Now a Scary Memory
description: After being sandwiched between two tacklers as he made his first reception during Sunday's loss to the St. Louis Rams, Giants wide receiver Amani Toomer was so dazed he needed help getting back to the team's sideline.

title: Mets Forced To Watch And Wait
description: The waiting and the mating games continued for the Mets yesterday as they continued to wonder whether they have a legitimate chance of signing Mike Mussina or Mike Hampton to strengthen their rotation. The Mets are viewed as long shots to agree to contracts with either of the marquee free-agent pitchers, which is why the Mets are forming many contingency plans.

title: Trying to Save Contractor, Hyundai May Sell Its Home
description: In the latest attempt to save its construction unit from bankruptcy, the Hyundai Group said today that it was ready to do something that is all but taboo in South Korean culture -- sell its home as well as its most-prized piece of real estate.

title: Sonia Gandhi Trounces Rival in Party Election
description: Sonia Gandhi, standard-bearer of the Nehru-Gandhi political dynasty, overwhelmed her opponent for the presidency of the Congress Party today. The victory was so crushing that it unequivocally established her as the leader of India's second largest party.

title: Sides Quietly Weigh A Continuing Fight After Florida Count
description: Approaching the endgame of the presidential campaign like military tacticians, the Democratic and Republican camps have quietly been mulling strategies that could continue the battle even after all the votes are counted in Florida.

title: Flamenco Amid Swigs From a Water Bottle
description: Concha Vargas

title: CONDENET TO CLOSE 2 SITES
description: The passion has left Swoon.com and the prognosis is grave for Phys.com. CondeNet, the online unit of Advance Publications has decided to close two of its smaller sites: Swoon, which dealt with sex and relationships, and Phys, on women's health. Sara Chubb, CondeNet's president, said the company wanted to focus on larger sites including Style.com, which is about fashion, and Epicurious, about food. Swoon and Phys were said to be less lucrative, with fewer opportunities to sell products related to their content. Saul Hansell

title: Fight to the Finish
description: Al Gore is determined to fight to the finish. His strategy is to draw the finish line at a place where he takes the lead.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Peony Puzzler

title: Clinton to Try to Juggle Past Horrors and Future Hopes on Vietnam Visit
description: When President Clinton arrives here on Thursday to open a new chapter in postwar relations with Vietnam, the policies he will emphasize will include agendas of the past and of the future that appear to be at odds.

title: Ouija Boards To Motherboards In Online Bazaar
description: WHEN I was growing up, my family greeted the arrival of the holiday season with a sacred tradition: we shopped. We also cared deeply for the ritual of wrapping, which generally led to bitter accusations that someone was hoarding the expensive silver foil paper and counter-charges of excessive cellophane tape usage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINZ, ANDREW MELCHIOR
description: LINZ-Andrew Melchior. 76, on November 12, 2000 after a long illness. Son of the late Rudolph and Ida Linz, beloved husband of Brigitte Loewy Linz, devoted father of Peter Erwin Linz and Andrea Linz Wyckoff. Dear father-in-law of Ann Secord Linz and Scott Allen Wyckoff. Proud and adoring grandfather of Andrew David Linz, Thomas Gregory Linz and Erica Louise Wyckoff. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral services will be held on Friday, November 17 at 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Linz Memorial Fund for the Gift of Life Program, New York Rotary Foundation, 28 W. 44th St., Suite 1508, NY, NY 10036

title: Philadelphians Serve Chestnuts At Their Birthday Celebration
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra began its centenary commemorations last year with a seasonlong look at works composed during the 20th century, and its party ends tonight -- the actual anniversary -- with a celebratory concert to be broadcast by PBS stations (in Philadelphia tonight, in New York tomorrow night and in other cities on various dates). As a prelude, the orchestra and its music director, Wolfgang Sawallisch, brought a program of familiar favorites to Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, along with a box of ''Happy 100th'' buttons distributed by ushers at the doors.

title: Old Modern Houses With Futurist Ideals
description: ABOUT 50 years ago, the future touched down here in the form of a house and decided to make itself comfortable.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, GERDA
description: ABRAHAM-Gerda. In her 90th year on Nov. 14th, 2000. Deeply treasured mother to Ruth Brause and Henry Abraham and sister of Henry Stanhope. Devoted wife of the late Siegfried Abraham. Adoring grandmother of Michelle, Debbie, David and Raphael. Crazy about her six great grandchildren Allison, Rebecca, Alexander, Nicole, Jared and Samuel. We miss her already. Services will be held at Westchester Jewish Center, Mamaroneck, New York at 11 AM on November 16. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital, 1st Avenue & 16th Street, New York, New York 10003.

title: Faizabad Journal; Afghan TV's Last Stand (Taliban Are at the Gates)
description: And so it carries on, nobly if feebly, within the rocky peaks of the remote Hindu Kush, high atop this city on a steep hill and inside a small yellow building with green trim: the last surviving television station in Afghanistan.

title: Furniture on a Scale To Fit Home Offices
description: ''Red is about size and attitude,'' said Greg Parsons, the president of Herman Miller's new home-office division, Red. ''There is a need for scaled down, inexpensive, well-designed home-office furniture that can be delivered quickly and assembled easily.'' The new collection includes the adjustable Red Spider desk (right, $285) designed by Ecco Design with a white laminate top and steel wire legs. Also available are accessories like a document holder ($55) and a hanging supply bag ($55). The Backpack storage unit on wheels (right, $185) is made of soft nylon with a steel frame for hanging files. The plastic foam Grasshopper screen (not shown, $120) looks like a light-gray boogie board on wire legs; it is a space divider as well as a bulletin board. To order: www.hermanmiller.com. A Manhattan store will open this spring. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Two Leaders, Casting an Eye At U.S. Vote, Meet Clinton
description: President Clinton held what will very likely be his last meetings with the leaders of South Korea and Russia today. But Mr. Clinton appeared to reach no firm conclusion with Kim Dae Jung of South Korea over whether it made sense to visit North Korea before leaving office in January, and he made little progress on arms control with Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who is clearly thinking about Mr. Clinton's successor.

title: Quarterback Was a Real Nowhere Man
description: Undrafted, mostly a clipboard carrier through four National Football League seasons and unwanted for another two seasons, Jay Fiedler is finally stepping out of the shadows.

title: Dash of Dementieva Leaves Davenport Surprised
description: It was early in the third set when Lindsay Davenport gently flicked her wrist with no more might than it takes to flip channels, then watched a perfectly placed drop shot die just over the net.

title: An 'Untouchable' Says Caste Is Truly a Human Rights Issue
description: A leader of India's Dalits, the ''untouchable'' underclass of more than 160 million people whose campaign for an end to discrimination is rarely heard in the West, is being honored this month by two major American human rights organizations seeking to raise awareness of the issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MAHONY, EILEEN (NEE KENNY)
description: O'MAHONY-Eileen (nee Kenny). Suddenly on November 12, 2000. 65 years. Retired employee of City Bank-Municipal Bond Division. Beloved wife of the late Jeremiah, loving daughter of the late Dennis and Anna Kenny. Dear sister of Mary DaRos, Anne Eichele, and the late Denis Kenny. Beloved aunt of Rob DaRos and Christian Eichele. Beloved cousin of Msgr James A. Brassil. Family will receive friends Wednesday, 7-9 PM and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 St, Bronx. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at St Johns Church, Friday, 10:45 AM. Interment Long Island National Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: GOLDMAN TO TAKE $290 MILLION CHARGE AGAINST EARNINGS
description: The Goldman Sachs Group said it would take a $290 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings because of costs related to its purchase of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg L.P., the New York Stock Exchange specialist firm. The charge stems from a $702 million retention pool in restricted stock units for Spear, Leads employees, Goldman said in a regulatory filing.

title: Resolution on the Web; Broken Palm Screens
description: Q. Is there a specific resolution that I should use for graphics and pictures that I want to send in e-mail messages or use on Web pages?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, SUSAN
description: WOLFF-Susan. To Russell, Patty, Joanna, Scott, Lily and Elaine. Your strength is our strength, your loss is ours. Susan, a woman of care, concern, laughter and love, we will miss you so much. Find the old man and enjoy all the good times. Love, Barbara, Philip and all the children

title: Eugene Marino, Black Archbishop, Dies at 66
description: The Rev. Eugene A. Marino, the first black Roman Catholic archbishop in the United States, whose resignation as archbishop of Atlanta in 1990 was linked to his affair with a woman, died on Nov. 12 in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 66.

title: Just Say the Word, And Technology Finds It
description: The best feature of the digital age may be the humble Find command, which can turn up a text-based needle in a haystack of Web sites, e-mail messages, or files on the hard drive. But until now, there has been no easy way to search audio or video recordings for a particular spoken phrase -- a growing problem as sound and video files become commonplace.

title: Dance in Review
description: Fisticuffs and Knives, but for the Fun of It

title: Schumer Backs Petition for a Long Island Wine Label
description: Most wine lovers have never heard of American Viticultural Areas: A.V.A.'s in wine-world shorthand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FABIAN, MARIA
description: FABIAN-Maria. Of Forest Hills, NY. Died on November 15 at age 95 after a long and courageous battle. Beloved mother of Eve and Dan, their spouses Corinne and Ed. Grandmother of Janet, Julie, Nancy and Peter. Great-grandmother of Benjamin, Isabel and Brennan. Funeral services will be held at the Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY on November 19, 3:00pm.

title: 2 Counties Argue for Manual Tallies
description: Following are letters to Secretary of State Katherine Harris of Florida from election officials in Broward and Palm Beach Counties, Fla., asking for consideration of a full hand recount of presidential votes.

title: Yankees Hire Boies In Case of a Suit
description: The Yankees have hired the lawyer David Boies to defend them if the MSG Network sues the team in State Supreme Court over the Yankees' newest offer to sell their television rights.

title: Neighborly Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: RAYTHEON TO SELL OPTICAL SYSTEMS UNIT TO GOODRICH
description: The Raytheon Company agreed to sell its unit that makes optical systems for aircraft and astronomical research to the B. F. Goodrich Company. Terms were not disclosed. The unit, Raytheon Optical Systems, makes systems used in the U-2 reconnaissance aircraft, military helicopters and NASA's Hubble Space Telescope. It had $152 million in sales last year. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., has been selling assets to cut debt after its profit and shares tumbled last year as it struggled to digest several acquisitions.

title: Split the Electoral Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Wedding Registries
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. AND SHARP PLAN JOINT VENTURE
description: The Sharp Corporation and IBM Japan have agreed to form a joint venture to develop and sell software and services for supply-chain and internal business resource management. The new company will be based in Osaka, Japan, with Sharp supplying 300 of the initial 320 employees. Separately, Sharp contracted with I.B.M. for information systems management in a 10-year deal valued at $850 million. Barnaby J. Feder

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about left-of-center American intellectuals who are popular in Europe misstated the title of a book by one of them, Jeremy Rifkin. It is ''The Age of Access,'' not ''The Access Society.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABIN, LEAH
description: RABIN-Leah. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations expresses condolences on the passing of Leah Rabin, who worked closely with her husband, former Prime Minister Yitzchak Rabin, on behalf of the Jewish people and the State of Israel. We pray that the family will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Wrestler's Gold Is Late, But Also Right on Time
description: Olympic medal ceremonies can be emotional and inspirational, but most often, they are cookie-cutter rituals. Not Brandon Slay's.

title: A Robot That Coos, Cries and Knows When It Needs a New Diaper
description: RODNEY BROOKS, the 45-year-old director of the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has spent most of his career engrossed in the question of how to model biological systems. A native of Adelaide, Australia, Dr. Brooks started out as a theoretical mathematician, then switched to artificial intelligence and worked in the artificial intelligence lab at Stanford University before moving to M.I.T.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOFFLER, WILLIAM
description: KOFFLER-William, on November 15, 2000 at age 65, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father to Dawn and Dina. Loving grandfather of Gregory, Holly, Emma, Joseph and Benjamin. Dear brother of Nicholas. He leaves behind many friends and relatives who will dearly miss his warmth, humor and kindness.

title: VERIZON IN $1.5 BILLION DEAL
description: The nation's largest wireless carrier, Verizon Wireless, will increase the size of its Southeast business with an agreement to acquire Price Communications Wireless. Verizon Wireless, a venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone, will exchange stock worth $1.5 billion for Price after a planned offering of shares, in addition to assuming $550 million in debt. Simon Romero

title: Bush's Response to Gore's Proposal
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. George W. Bush's statement last night about the Florida recount, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: A Hotel for the Homeless Designed for Dignity
description: A single-room occupancy hotel does not have to be bleak. Since July, formerly homeless men who now work full-time have been moving into the Peter Jay Sharp Residence in East Harlem. By New Year's Day, 74 men will occupy the six-story, 32,000-square-foot brick building, designed by Herbert L. Mandel. The air-conditioned bedrooms have private baths and kitchenettes. There is also a communal kitchen, dining room and gymnasium. At bottom right, two residents, Eric Torres, in white shirt, and Dorian Butts flank Mahmoud Rashid, the building manager, in the garden.

title: In Japan, a Shift In the Culture By Freelancers; Agencies Aid Some Workers Who Want to Go It Alone
description: Bored with her studies in interior design, Mizuho Hino started dabbling in Web design and eventually made a business of it while still in graduate school. The university and her parents frowned on the venture, afraid it would distract her from her studies and hurt her chances of landing a job after she earned a degree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHHOLZ, CHARLOTTE
description: BUCHHOLZ-Charlotte. On November 15, 2000. Born in Berlin, Germany. Beloved wife of the late Heinrich, devoted mother of Edward, adoring grandmother of Joanna and Lucy. Service Friday, 1 P.M., Sharon Gardens, Valhalla.

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize; Toward Fair Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: DEAL FOR ORDER PROCESSOR
description: Dresdner Bank A.G. said that it had agreed to buy at least 80 percent of Lombardkasse A.G., a 77-year-old Frankfurt company that handles back-office operations for about 200 brokers and that it expected to soon acquire the rest. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUTER, BEN
description: YUTER-Ben. The entire New York Community Hospital Family, Trustees, Physicians, Employees and Volunteers mourn the loss of Ben Yuter. Mr. Yuter was a member of the Board of Trustees for 16 years. He contributed greatly to the Board and his assistance to administration for the successful, turn-around of the hospital these past five years will always be remembered. Our condolences to his wife Claire, his children and his grandchildren. George Weinberger, Chairman, Board of Trustees Lin H. Mo, President and Chief Executive Officer

title: CHIQUITA SAYS BANANA FARMS MEET GROUP'S STANDARDS
description: Chiquita Brands International said yesterday that its Latin American banana farms had met an international watchdog group's standards for environmental conservation, chemical use and the treatment of workers. The company said 127 farms it owns in Colombia, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras and Panama were certified by the watchdog group, the Rainforest Alliance's Better Banana Project, as have 30 percent of the independent farms that supply bananas to the company. Chiquita, based in Cincinnati, said it had been working with the Rainforest group since the early 1990's to improve practices on its farms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRVING, EDWARD C.
description: IRVING-Edward C. Suddenly on November 15, 2000. Beloved son of Augusta and the late Val Irving. Services Sunday 1PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: According to a survey, the Democratic and Republican parties have brand-name problems.
description: THE Republican and Democratic parties are mired in election problems.

title: WorldCom's Bernie Ebbers Scrambles to Raise Cash
description: THE saga of WorldCom and Bernard J. Ebbers is one of the great entrepreneurial success stories of the last decade. Mr. Ebbers built a tiny long-distance telephone company into a communications giant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOHUE, JAMES PATRICK SR.
description: DONOHUE-James Patrick Sr. Died November 14, of Somers, New York, & Stuart, Fla. Husband of Marie. Father of Peter N. and Mary Stevens of New York City, James P. and Katherine Donohue of Bronxville, NY, Ms. Margaret A. Donohue of New York City, John G. Donohue of Orlando, FL., Robert M. and Eleanor Blanchard of Jacksonville, FL., Peter J. Donohue of Holden, Mass., Paul J. & Sandra Donohue of Jacksonville, FL. Brother of Reverend John W. Donohue, S.J., Mary McCarren of Bronxville, New York, & Cecilia Paulmann of New Rochelle, NY. Also survived by 10 grandchildren and 14 nieces and nephews. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, N.Y., Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Croton Falls, New York, Saturday, 11 AM. Interment private.

title: In Radio Chat, Gore Shuns Tough Talk on Opponent
description: In the latest step of his public-relations crusade, Vice President Al Gore went on the radio this morning to signal his willingness to work with his foes, but he also cautioned that they should not try to ''short-circuit'' the counting of votes in Florida.

title: Broward Republicans Try to Stop the Music, but the Band Plays On
description: As 60 teams of vote counters sifted ballots inside the ''war room'' of Broward County's Emergency Operations Center this afternoon, Republican Party officials and their lawyers, trailed by television crews, trooped into an adjoining conference room. There they served on the Broward canvassing board subpoenas that ordered an appearance in county court on Friday to defend the manual recount.

title: Adrian Piper
description: New Museum of Contemporary Art

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODSIDE, WILLIAM STEWART
description: WOODSIDE-William Stewart, of Scottsdale, AZ and Litchfield, CT, formerly of New York City, on November 15, 2000 of chronic pulmonary lung disease, at home in the arms of his loving wife, Migs. A deeply loved and loving husband, companion and closest friend for 30 years to his wife. Beloved father of William S. Woodside III, Anne D. Gruzdowich and Samuel T. Woodside. Generous, caring and loving stepfather of Geoffrey Dann and Deborah Dann, and caring father-in-law to Terri Woodside and Lauri Novick. Proud and delighted grandfather of Benjamin and Jacob Woodside, Rebecca and Emily Dann, and also Emily and Nicholas Gruzdowich. Devoted brother-in-law of Lewis W. Bernard. A man of enormous accomplishment and achievement, extraordinary intellect and talent, whose incredible courage and determination in spite of physical adversity was an inspiration to all. Good night sweet prince, may flights of angels see you to your dreams. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, November 29th at 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Please send contributions to the Children of Alcoholics Foundation, C/O Phoenix House, 164 W. 74th St., New York, New York 10024.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS PLUNGES. Natural gas dropped as new forecasts showed that an early cold spell would end soon. In New York, natural gas for November delivery fell 46.7 cents, or 7.5 percent, to $5.798 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Devils End 6-Game Skid On a Goal By Gomez
description: The Devils mobbed Scott Gomez tonight at Fleet Center the way they mobbed Jason Arnott after he scored the Stanley Cup-clinching goal in Dallas last June. The Devils had every reason to mob Gomez, because he scored a goal with two seconds left in overtime to give the Devils a 3-2 victory over the Bruins and bring an end to a six-game losing streak.

title: An Inspiring Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Sprewell Speaks Up: Three's A Crowd
description: It took just nine games and two consecutive losses for Latrell Sprewell to bring the Knicks' smoldering controversy to the fore.

title: 7 New Domains Are Chosen To Join the Popular .com
description: Seeking to expand the virtual real estate of the Internet, the board that oversees the Internet's addressing system decided today on seven new domains to compete with the popular .com.

title: Teachers and City Hall Battle Over Contract
description: The Giuliani administration and the teachers' union ratcheted up the volume and rancor in their contract dispute yesterday as city officials demanded a longer school day and thousands of teachers outside City Hall demanded large salary increases.

title: A Tiptop, Shipshape Attic Right Out of Edith Wharton
description: There was no way to go but up for the New-York Historical Society, which almost closed its doors in 1993 for lack of money to run it. Now, thanks to Betsy Gotbaum, the society's president, and a group of important other rescuers, this museum-library of art, history and significant New York tchotchkes has come roaring back to life.

title: A French Noel With All the Trimmings (Lovers, Secrets . . .)
description: ''La Buche,'' which opens today at the Paris, is a minor miracle: a Christmas movie that won't leave you with indigestion, a splitting headache or a mouth full of cavities. Even though it takes place over the four busy shopping days leading up to Dec. 25, Daniele Thompson's warmly satisfying new film isn't really a Christmas movie at all. It forswears sentimentality and enforced good cheer for deft insight and complex, understated emotions, including the affliction that several of the film's characters call ''hostile depression,'' the Gallic equivalent of seasonal affective disorder. Even if you hate everything about the holidays -- and especially if you hate the kind of movies that herald them -- you will find much to love in ''La Buche.''

title: Womens Peak Fertility May Be Difficult to Predict
description: Women who are trying to get pregnant can buy a plethora of products to help them determine their most fertile days of the month. But according to new study findings, these 6 days, which are thought to fall between days 10 and 17 of a regular 28-day menstrual cycle, are highly variable.

title: Ventura Joins XFL as Analyst
description: Jesse Ventura is not fully satisfied with being the governor of Minnesota. In his spare time, he has refereed a wrestling match and coached high school football. Starting in February, he will have a Saturday night gig: analyzing XFL football games for his old pals Vince McMahon, the chairman of the World Wrestling Federation, and Dick Ebersol, the chairman of NBC Sports.

title: O'Neill Returns to Yanks for One More Run
description: Tino Martinez will be in the last year of his Yankees contract next season, and so will third baseman Scott Brosius and Manager Joe Torre. The dynasty could continue into 2002 and beyond, but almost the entire core of the team that won the title in 1996 and 125 games in 1998 will be gone, and Paul O'Neill is pleased he will have a chance to end his career with that same group.

title: Sailing Again to Byzantium
description: LIKE Byzantium itself, the new galleries for Byzantine and early medieval art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are centrally located, on the way to everything else. Even the most casual visitor to the museum has passed through them: the long, broad hallways that run on either side of the Grand Staircase on the museum's main floor, just beyond the central ticket booths in the Great Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMANN, SHARON LI
description: NEUMANN-Sharon Li, 51, from Clinton Corners, NY, formerly of New York City, died November 14. Wife of Roland R. Neumann. Mother of J. Alexander L. Neumann. Daughter of Gladys Li and sister of Elliott Li. Calling hours are on November 18, 11 AM-1 PM, at the Allen Funeral Home, Pleasant Valley, N.Y. Burial will be private. Memorial services will be held November 26, at 3 PM, at the Pleasant Valley Presbyterian Church. For further information, call 845-635-2124.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Gore Gains 7 Electoral Votes In All Mail-In Election in Oregon
description: Nine days after this state concluded the nation's first and only all vote-by-mail presidential election, a winner has finally emerged for Oregon's seven electoral votes: Vice President Al Gore.

title: Bryant and Lakers Give Sacramento Fans Plenty to Shout About
description: Phil Jackson walked into Arco Arena last night amid a chorus of boos that resonated well beyond the Los Angeles Lakers' bench.

title: John Bury, Set Designer Who Changed the Look of British Theater, Dies at 75
description: John Bury, the innovative production designer whose bold, stylized sets provided a dramatic alternative to the box sets and realistically painted scenes of traditional British theater, died on Sunday in Gloucestershire, England. He was 75.

title: The Value Of Versatility
description: Though born in Britain, the director Roger Spottiswoode has been able to master the obstacle course of contemporary Hollywood. He moves between small, personal films with strong political themes, often made for television -- for instance, the Showtime feature ''Noriega: God's Favorite'' with Bob Hoskins -- and mainstream star vehicles like the 1997 James Bond film ''Tomorrow Never Dies'' and the Arnold Schwarzenegger action film ''The Sixth Day,'' which opens today (review, Page 20).

title: Verizon Unit Picks Hill, Holliday
description: Verizon Wireless, a joint venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone said yesterday that it had named the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its Northeast retail account. Billings were estimated at $50 million.

title: Residential Real Estate; In East Village, New Condo Project Sells Quickly
description: Encouraged by increasing rents in Manhattan's East Village, a developer is testing the area's appeal to buyers with a 16-unit condominium at 217 East Seventh Street. Since sales began three weeks ago, contracts have been signed for all but three of the apartments, which are priced from $182,500 to $1.3 million.

title: Investigators Want to Check Kimes's Story
description: Two days after Kenneth Kimes confessed to dumping the body of a missing socialite at a New Jersey construction site, claiming not to remember the town, law enforcement officials said the vague admission may have been a ploy to get out of solitary confinement.

title: Hundreds Pack Hearing to Oppose Ikea Plan in New Rochelle
description: After waiting for more than a year, many residents of this struggling city and its wealthier neighbors finally got to tell the City Council exactly how they felt about a proposed Ikea warehouse store: they don't want it.

title: Analyst's Downgrade Spurs Another Decline in Shares
description: After two days of gains, stocks resumed their slide yesterday as another group of technology stocks suffered from an analyst's downgrade and the prolonged electoral stalemate dampened market sentiment.

title: Hosea Williams, 74, Rights Crusader, Dies
description: Hosea Williams, a field general for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in civil rights clashes of the 1960's, and more recently an Atlanta politician with a talent for confounding friends and enemies alike, died yesterday in Atlanta. He was 74 and had been suffering from cancer.

title: Corrections
description: The Q&A column in Science Times on Nov. 7 about the mucus that makes frogs' tongues sticky misstated the feeding process of tongueless aquatic frogs. They move food into their mouths with their limbs, not by using water currents.

title: MP3.COM FACES ANOTHER LAWSUIT
description: Unity Entertainment has filed a class-action copyright infringement complaint against MP3.com. The complaint was filed two days after MP3.com and the Universal Music Group of Seagram settled their copyright lawsuit, ending MP3's legal battles with the Big Five record labels. Shares of MP3.com rose $2.31, or 37.4 percent, to $8.50 after gaining 54.7 percent on Wednesday in the wake of the settlement with Universal Music. A statement from the MP3.com chief executive, Michael Robertson, above, said the company was ''disappointed'' to receive the lawsuit in light of securing licensing agreements from the record labels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTNOY, SARAH
description: PORTNOY-Sarah. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Brian C. Rappaport, President

title: 'Skinema' That's X at Heart (With Lovers Named Y and J)
description: The daring but only partly successful Korean film ''Lies'' is built around voyeurism. It is nominally the story of the sexual entanglement between Y (Kim Tae Yeon), an 18-year-old schoolgirl, and J (Lee Sang Hyun), a timid-looking sculptor in his late 30's. But the plotless movie also slips back and forth between the narrative and the bits of reality that the writer and director, Jang Sun Woo, allows to filter into the film, showing the circumstances behind the scenes. Comparisons will be made between this explicit film, which must have been intended as an assault on Korean sensibilities, and ''Last Tango in Paris.''

title: Yonkers Is Ordered to Restore Bus Service for Some Students
description: A federal judge who is overseeing the desegregation of the Yonkers schools ordered the city yesterday to restore bus service that was cut in September for 2,000 students.

title: Leaf is the Starter In San Diego Again
description: The San Diego Chargers' quarterback carousel has spun right back to where it was on opening day, with embattled Ryan Leaf as the starter.

title: 2 Men With No Incentive to Bargain
description: One central political truth in the capital is that it is very hard to strike a compromise if one side thinks it can win outright.

title: Court Inspires Democrats To Press Case For Recount
description: Bolstered by a Florida Supreme Court decision that allows manual ballot recounts to go on in the state, Democrats planned to press ahead with their efforts to get a hand count in Miami-Dade County. But Democratic Party lawyers conceded, and some county election officials agreed, that it was far from clear how helpful this undertaking would be to Al Gore's chances of winning the state.

title: A Season of Yankee Games Will Cost MSG $52 Million
description: The MSG Network agreed yesterday to televise Yankees games next season for $52 million, temporarily ending months of contentious legal skirmishes and negotiations, four people involved in the talks said.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: A Clone Ranger, Fighting the Future's Repetitive Fight
description: ''The Sixth Day'' deals with a phenomenon even more insidious than the most frightening deployment of modern technology to date (that barrage of automated calls asking if you're happy with your long-distance service): cloning. The film's subject is appropriate because almost everything in the movie seems to be lifted from the DNA of other pictures. Despite some deft touches, this logy thriller seems so familiar that you may find yourself waiting for its star, Arnold Schwarzenegger, to awake and find that he's actually in ''Total Recall,'' which was also about confusion.

title: ANTIBIOTICS LIFT BAYER
description: Third-quarter net income from continuing operations at Bayer A.G.rose 24 percent, to 534 million euros ($459 million), or 0.74 euro a share, helped by rising sales of the antibiotic Ciprobay and other drugs. Higher raw material prices held back gains in the chemicals and polymers businesses, the company said.

title: New York-Presbyterian Begins Work on Hospital for Children
description: New York-Presbyterian Hospital broke ground for its new children's hospital in Washington Heights yesterday, becoming the third medical center in the region to begin construction of a children's hospital in the last few years.

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize
description: To the Editor:

title: Stringer Turns to the Court and Finds Refuge From Misfortune
description: C. Vivian Stringer, the coach of the Rutgers women's basketball team, was sipping her fourth cup of coffee in her office. Some of her words flew across the mahogany desk in direct response to a question; others scattered into prolonged tangents.

title: How Tradition Made 'Modern' More Palatable
description: Romantic nationalism is how museum curators now characterize the idealization of folk culture in certain design movements that sprang up in Britain and Europe in the late 1800's. Architects and designers in countries like the new, unified Germany were trying to forge a new national identity. Others were trying to develop a style to establish a firm footing in a newly mechanized, unfamiliar world.

title: CLINTON IN HANOI, INTENT ON FORGING NEW RELATIONSHIP
description: More than a quarter-century after a war that cost 58,000 American lives and shaped the politics of his generation, President Clinton arrived here late Thursday promising a new relationship with Vietnam, a country that is at once fascinated by its former enemy and deeply ambivalent about opening its society and economy to a world that America dominates.

title: Bumbling And Terror In Munich
description: ''One Day in September'' was broadcast on HBO earlier this year. Following are excerpts from Ron Wertheimer's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 11. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: Couple of Grim Fairy Tales, Lacking Only Little Red
description: Will Gould's film ''The Wolves of Kromer'' has the nutty idea of trying to interweave two stories that have essentially nothing to do with each other into a two-pronged fable.

title: Tom Wesselmann
description: 'Blue Nudes'

title: A Spinner of Fantasies Beset by Deep Indecision
description: British cinema in the early 1960's pulsed with the ambitious energy, on the screen and off, of young men -- not angry, necessarily, but certainly restless. The period's defining screen performances include Laurence Harvey in ''Room at the Top,'' Albert Finney in ''Saturday Night and Sunday Morning'' (and then in ''Tom Jones'') and Tom Courtenay in ''The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner'' and, most memorably, in ''Billy Liar.''

title: Article 2000111790473750805 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, MORRIS
description: BLUM-Morris. Died peacefully at home November 15, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Gladys B. Blum. Loving father of Nancy & Murphy Levin, Bob and Michael Blum. Devoted and cherished grandpa to Kelly, Duncan and Timothy Levin; Amanda, Jamie and Alex Blum. Cherished brother to Jackie, Mimi and Clarence. Uncle, and dear friend. Services Friday, November 17, 11 AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: Soda-Drinking Children End Up Lacking Nutrients
description: Children and adolescents who drink large quantities of soda may be selling themselves short of several important vitamins and minerals, results of a survey suggest.

title: Navajo Birth Is a Surprise For a Jew
description: With more dot-coms dropping into the dustbin every day, it's nice to get an occasional reminder that the Internet isn't completely useless, and ''The Lost Child,'' Sunday's movie on CBS, provides one.

title: SPIRENT IN $1.6 BILLION DEAL
description: Hekimian of Rockville, Md., has agreed to sell itself to Spirent P.L.C. of Britain for $1.6 billion in cash and stock. The deal will add to Spirent's share of the North American telecommunications testing market. In the eight months that ended Aug. 31, Hekimian had pretax profit of $36.3 million, on revenue of $129.4 million. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Helping Teachers Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILLIPS AND ANADARKO BEGIN OIL PRODUCTION IN ALASKA
description: Phillips Petroleum and Anadarko Petroleum said yesterday that they had started production at the Alpine oil field in Alaska, described as the biggest onshore oil discovery in the United States in a decade. The field is expected to produce 80,000 barrels a day by the end of the year from 16 production wells. Phillips owns 78 percent of the field, Anadarko the remainder. Since it acquired Atlantic Richfield's oil fields in the state earlier this year, Phillips, based in Bartlesville, Okla., has been the biggest oil producer in Alaska.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIJESINGHE, CONSTANCE RACHEL
description: WIJESINGHE-Constance Rachel on November 11, 2000 in her 96th year. Beloved wife of the late Walter Edward Peiris Wijesinghe. Dear mother of Chitra, Sarath and Nandi and mother-in-law of Eli, Claudia and Neelakshi. Adored grandmother of Shamil, Aruni, Lakmini, Ashini and Manik. Services Sunday November 19th, 9:45 a.m. at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will be receiving at ''The Riverside'' Saturday 7-9 p.m.

title: At Long Last, Army of Volunteers Gets Its Orders to Begin Recount
description: After getting permission from the Florida Supreme Court to proceed with a countywide hand recount of 462,657 ballots, election officials in Palm Beach County put more than 100 volunteers to work on the long-awaited, fiercely debated recount.

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize; We Won't Fall Apart
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, PHILIP CLEARY
description: SMITH-Philip Cleary, 78, retired Chairman and CEO of the former National Securities and Research Corporation, a New York mutual fund company, died yesterday in Rye, New York from complications following a stroke. A native of Brooklyn, New York, Mr. Smith graduated from Brooklyn Prep, and then attended Williams College before leaving to serve in the US Army during World War II. After the war, he graduated from Fordham University, then Fordham Law School. He joined the New York law firm of Satterlee, Warfield & Stevens and later joined National Securities and Research Corporation from which he retired in 1985. A former resident of Rye, Mr. Smith had moved to Tequesta, Florida where he was a member of Jupiter Hills Country Club. He also maintained a membership in Winged Foot Country Club in Mamaroneck, New York. Mr. Smith was married for 49 years to the former Carol Ann Simonson who died in 1995. He is survived by his five children, Kate McDonnell of Wayne, Pennsylvania, Carol Felch of Sebastopol, California, Cleary Simpson of New Canaan, Connecticut, Lauren Steers of Rye, New York, and Philip C. Smith, Jr. of Charlotte, North Carolina and 11 grandchildren. The family will receive visitors at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, in Rye, New York, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, on Friday November 17th 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye on Saturday, November 18th at 9:45am. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations designated ''for research'' to the Alzheimer's Association, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Suite 1100, Chicago, IL 60611.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARESCO, FELIX
description: MARESCO-Felix. On November 15, 2000. Loving husband of the late Catherine (nee McNicholas) of Bohola County Mayo, Ireland. Beloved father of Philip, Nancy McCartney, and Leonard. Also survived by eight grandchildren and nine great grandchildren. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd Street. Services Saturday, 9:30 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: McCall's Joins With Rosie In a Remake
description: Taking a cue from the success of O: The Oprah Magazine, the talk-show host Rosie O'Donnell announced her own newsstand offering yesterday: Rosie's McCall's.

title: 'Unperturbed'
description: 'The Art of Huang Zhongfang (Harold Wong)'

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: Resolute Commander of Israeli Forces in the West Bank
description: It is Wednesday, and just another day at the office for Brig. Gen. Benjamin Gantz, commander of Israel's forces throughout the West Bank.

title: Television Shows Find Comedy in the Errors
description: Along with talk-show hosts and constitutional lawyers, the comedy business is emerging as a major beneficiary of the presidential election deadlock with a slew of jokes about dotty senior citizens, dimpled chads and Gov. George W. Bush's boil that pour forth daily from late-night television and the Internet.

title: Armstrong Holdings May Seek Bankruptcy
description: Armstrong Holdings Inc., North America's largest maker of vinyl flooring, may seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy-court protection if it cannot find additional funds in the next few months to cover asbestos-related claims.

title: MORE BAD LOANS IN TAIWAN
description: Taiwan's central bank said the amount of bad loans plaguing lenders may be as much as double the official estimates, because lenders have been reluctant to report all their loan defaults. The central bank's deputy governor, Chen Shih-Meng, estimated that up to 10 percent of loans may be nonperforming. The official figure was 5.4 percent at the end of September.

title: Pass the Turkey, Tamales, Kugel and Criticism
description: ''What's Cooking?'' opens with a teasing shot of an ad on the side of a bus, a smiling family promoting the wholesome tradition of Thanksgiving. There are, of course, many traditions associated with this beloved American holiday. One of them, especially cherished by screenwriters and television producers, is that Thanksgiving is a time when all of the repressed bad feelings and ill-guarded secrets that simmer below the placid surface of family life come bubbling out into the open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLATT, ARNOLD I.
description: GREENBLATT-Arnold I. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of NY mourn the passing of Arnold Greenblatt, dear friend and former husband of Lucille Greenblatt, a generous long-time donor, and beloved father of Judith, our devoted staff professional. To Lucille; Judith and her husband, Mickey Lane; Lucille's other daughter and Judith's sister, Sharon Deitch; and to the entire family, we extend our sincerest condolences. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair John Ruskay, Ex. VP & CEO

title: In Florida's State Government, Court Is a Democratic Enclave
description: In a state where the Legislature is controlled by Republicans, the top elections official is a Republican, and the governor is not only a Republican but also the younger brother of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Florida Supreme Court is the one branch of government where Democrats still feel comfortable.

title: Wilde Once Again, With an Emphasis on Sexuality
description: OSCAR WILDE

title: Willem de Kooning
description: C&M Arts

title: SPARE TIMES -- FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATERMAN, NEIL S. JR.
description: WATERMAN-Neil S. Jr. On November 8 in Dallas. Founder of SimuFlite, an aviation training company based in Dallas and The Waterman Group, Inc., a venture capital business. Mr. Waterman (Mike) expanded his investment interests to South America and divided his time between Buenos Aires, a home in Santa Fe, NM and his cattle ranch in Rosebud, Texas. He served as a director of St. Mark's School of Dallas, Episcopal School of Dallas and PBS station KERA-TV. He was Chapter Chairman of the Young Presidents Organizations of Dallas and acted as interim Executive Director of YPO International. A Greenwich, CT resident from 1968 to 1981, he was a member of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, Stanwich Club, Riverside Yacht Club, Westchester Country Club, the New York Yacht Club and the Fairchester Chapter of the YPO. Born in Washington, D.C. in 1943, he graduated from Loomis-Chaffee in 1961, Yale in 1965 and attended Columbia Business School. He is survived by his wife Linda Clark Waterman; two sons, Neil C. Waterman, III of Santiago, Chile and Dallas; Whitney C. Sheppard of Short Hills, NJ; a daughter Brooke C. Stahl and son-in-law Paul R. Stahl of Riverside, CT and one grandson. A memorial service will be held on November 21 at 3:30 PM at St. Paul's Church in Riverside, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorials to Angel Depot, 2442 Cerrillos Rd, Santa Fe, NM 87505.

title: Donor Creates Medical Prize Of $500,000
description: In what is believed to be the richest medical award in the United States, Albany Medical Center will give a $500,000 prize annually to doctors for improving health care or making major research discoveries, center officials said today.

title: Bush Will Not Challenge Gore's Narrow Victory in Iowa
description: With an eye on the clock in Florida, the Bush campaign today officially abandoned any effort to contest Iowa's seven electoral votes, casting the decision as a high-road way to help ensure the ''fairness, accuracy and finality'' of the presidential election. There was particular emphasis, of course, on ''finality.''

title: An Army Contract Signals a Shift From Tanks to Light Armor
description: In a move that represents an important shift in Army strategy, the Defense Department today announced a multibillion-dollar contract for the purchase of light armored vehicles that will increasingly replace tanks on the battlefield.

title: Lining Up to Get a Lecture; A Class With 1,600 Students and One Popular Teacher
description: James B. Maas, a professor at Cornell University, teaches a large class. A really large class. With nearly 1,600 students, it is one of the largest lecture classes in any American university, so big that no classroom is large enough to hold it. Instead, the class, Psychology 101, meets in the university's 88-year-old concert hall, with hard-backed wooden seats, bare floors and no desks.

title: Judge May Rule in Admissions Case Without Trial
description: A federal judge hinted today that he might decide whether the University of Michigan could continue to consider race in admissions decisions without even having a trial to explore the mechanics of the admissions process or the educational benefits of a diverse student body.

title: Local Election Officials Are Split Over Florida
description: Like a race car driver watching someone else's 10-car pileup, the top election officials in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey are watching the Florida recount -- and the performance of Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris -- with particular interest.

title: PSINET RETAINS INVESTMENT BANKER
description: PSINet Inc., an Internet technology services company, said it had hired Goldman, Sachs to advise it on a strategic alliance or a possible sale of the company. The report came on the heels of the Nov. 2 announcement of a third-quarter loss of $1.38 billion. The news helped lift PSINet's shares 10.3 percent, to $2. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Certain Conflict Springs From Ambiguous Opinion
description: Once again, Judge Terry P. Lewis's county courtroom was jammed to overflowing today with well-dressed lawyers and hurriedly dressed reporters, but this time he had no one to blame for the crowd but himself.

title: Russia Sounds Death Knell For Mir, Hardy Orbiter
description: For almost 15 years, it has seemed to Russians and the world that what went up might, happily, never come down. Alas, it appears not to be. Today the Kremlin gave its first blessing to a proposal to crash the Mir space station into the Pacific Ocean in February.

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize; The Money, Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Feuding Brothers Unite To Save a Hyundai Division
description: Two brothers of the family that founded the Hyundai Group conglomerate have agreed to end a feud to help save the Hyundai Engineering and Construction Company from bankruptcy.

title: SHAREHOLDER AGREES TO SELL 24% STAKE IN PBOC HOLDINGS
description: A major shareholder at PBOC Holdings, parent of People's Bank of California, has agreed to sell a 24 percent stake in the company for $47.6 million to the FBOP Corporation, an Illinois holding company associated with the First Bank of Oak Park, according to a regulatory filing. Under an agreement dated Nov. 1, the shareholder, the trustees of the estate of Bernice Pauahi Bishop, will sell 4.759 million PBOC common shares for $10 each, the filing said, a 25 percent premium to PBOC's closing price of $8 yesterday. The Bishop estate is a charitable educational trust with more than $6 billion in assets, including about 8 percent of the land in the state of Hawaii.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 6 about an immigrant from Zaire who won an appeal for asylum after years in detention, referred imprecisely to the Board of Immigration Appeals, which granted it. The board is part of the Executive Office for Immigration Review, not part of the Immigration and Naturalization Service; both agencies are units of the Justice Department.

title: Arafat Differs With Barak On Chances Of Peace Deal
description: As an American envoy tried to prod them back to the negotiating table after seven weeks of violence, the Palestinian and Israeli leaders voiced opposite assessments today about the chances of a peace deal soon.

title: INSIDE
description: Mir to Be Crashed Into Ocean

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize; A Uniter, Not a Divider?
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Holiday Fliers Face The Usual Crowds, Plus Riled Workers
description: The busiest travel week of the year officially begins tomorrow, and millions of airline passengers will face the usual headaches of long lines, crowded airplanes, air traffic control delays and perhaps even foul weather. But this year there is another element that could add stress to the annual visit to grandma's house: angry workers.

title: BellSouth Lowers Earnings Expectations for Next Fiscal Year
description: The BellSouth Corporation lowered its earnings expectations for 2001 yesterday after reassessing the costs of expanding its Latin American and high-speed Internet operations. The move highlights the difficulty large telecommunications companies are having in increasing their profits.

title: COCA-COLA SETTLES RACIAL BIAS CASE
description: In the largest settlement ever in a racial discrimination case, the Coca-Cola Company agreed yesterday to pay more than $156 million to resolve a federal lawsuit brought by black employees.

title: Abraham's Absence Hurts Jets' Pass Rush
description: Linebacker John Abraham walks gingerly through the Jets' locker room, healing from the hernia surgery that short-circuited his rookie season and halted the Jets' nascent pass rush like a left tackle picking up a speed rusher.

title: German Transport Minister Quits Over Fraud Case and a Fine
description: Transport Minister Reinhard Klimmt quit today after a court fine for fraud threatened to undermine the government's quest to make impeccable moral credentials a centerpiece of its appeal.

title: 'A Class Act' Is Moving Up
description: After more than a decade in the works, the ascent of ''A Class Act'' to Broadway appears to be complete.

title: Mallon and Kane Share The Lead at 5-Under
description: The best season of Meg Mallon's career may look even better on Sunday.

title: The C.I.A.'s Chile Files
description: The disclosure this week of 16,000 declassified documents on Washington's relationship with Chile is a victory for openness. While many of the documents are still obscured by heavy editing, the public release of information was the final round of a declassification process that President Clinton ordered last year to expose as much of the truth as possible about political violence in Chile from 1968 through 1991. The Central Intelligence Agency was forced to declassify hundreds of files on its covert operations that it had tried to keep secret.

title: Olafur Eliasson
description: Bonakdar Jancou Gallery

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize; A Voter's Will
description: To the Editor:

title: For Many N.F.L. Coaches, Pressure Is Toughest Opponent
description: During a meeting with a group of veteran Detroit Lions players about three weeks ago, the team's head coach, Bobby Ross, threatened wholesale dismissals if the team did not begin playing to his standards.

title: A Dozen Teams Courting Hampton
description: The agent for Mike Hampton said that he was talking to 12 teams about the free-agent pitcher but said it is too early in the process to guess which team Hampton might sign with. But Mark Rodgers, the agent, bristled when asked about the perception that Hampton's relationship with the Mets is over.

title: She's Not Quite Human, but, Hey, Nobody's Perfect
description: There is no truth to the rumors that half the casts of the musicals now on Broadway are filled by robots. Actors' Equity would surely have let us know if this were the case. Still, it's hard not to lament a trend toward dehumanization in so-called live theater, not knowing if you've wandered into a performance of ''Beauty and the Beast'' or the new Madame Tussaud's.

title: World Trade Talks Revived By Pacific Rim Conference
description: Efforts to restart global trade talks, which failed in Seattle last year amid riots, received a push today when 21 nations of the Asia and Pacific region agreed to set a date of 2001 to form an agenda and begin negotiations for eliminating trade barriers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Enough, enough, enough already!''

title: Joseph Kosuth
description: Sean Kelly

title: Partial Sell-Off of Chrysler Reported Under Discussion
description: DaimlerChrysler's slumping stock price and the increasingly gloomy profit outlook at its Chrysler subsidiary have prompted several board members to begin discussing privately the possibility of selling off at least part of Chrysler, according to executives close to the company.

title: The Big City; A Factor Unspoken: Voter Goofs
description: ARE Democrats more likely than Republicans to botch their ballots? That's not a question that politicians are explicitly addressing in Florida, but it's at the heart of the dispute over the presidential election.

title: Emancipated, Yet Chained To Slavery
description: In the wind that swept away the Old South, they lived -- slaves who survived the Civil War, experienced emancipation and continued with their lives.

title: In Good Hands With Mutants
description: The 60's and 70's flavor three releases this week and next, stirring reflections of those times and these.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Coke to Pay $156 Million To Settle Federal Bias Case

title: Heedless Urban Landscapes That Have Squandered Their Wealth of Trees
description: On the corner of 79th Street and Broadway in Manhattan one day, passers-by gasped at the startlingly painful sight of a tree on the sidewalk with its trunk broken in two. Like people familiar to us, the trees on the street are probably taken for granted, but they are expected to be there forever.

title: Naming Hospitals, Good and Bad
description: The uneven quality of American health care is easy to complain about but hard to fix. This week a group of 60 large corporations, the Leapfrog Group, announced a bold start.
