Members, including General Motors, General Electric and I.B.M., pledged to steer employees to hospitals that did the best job treating patients. That may seem an obvious strategy. But naming names -- in effect labeling some hospitals good and others bad -- is a difficult task that few employers relish. Yet it may be the single most effective weapon against sloppy medical care.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Overtime Gets The Guillotine

title: WORRIES OVER ECONOMIC 'NOISE'
description: The Bank of England lowered growth and inflation forecasts and hinted it might reduce interest rates. Prices will rise by less than 2.5 percent in 2001, and growth will be 2.5 percent, not 3.1 percent, the bank estimated. Mervyn King, the deputy governor, warned that economic data ''might bear some resemblance to old-fashioned disco dancing: sharp movements in unpredictable directions creating much excitement, accompanied by a good deal of noise.'' Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Dayne Responds Head-On To Miscue
description: It looked like any other running play during a no-tackling drill. Ron Dayne took a handoff, hit the hole shoulders squared and burst past the line of scrimmage toward the goal line.

title: Rule of Law in Florida
description: The unanimous ruling by the Florida Supreme Court to allow the hand counting of votes to resume in Palm Beach County brought a note of order and reason to the last act of the presidential election. Today, in a State Circuit Court in Tallahassee, Judge Terry P. Lewis needs to put teeth in the State Supreme Court ruling by directing Katherine Harris, the secretary of state, to accept the hand counts from Palm Beach and other disputed counties before she certifies the statewide vote that will determine the next president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLANGER, CHESTER
description: SCHLANGER-Chester. My beloved husband, it has been delightful tripping the light fantastic with you through the years. We shall be in one another's arms forever, here and in heaven it has been an honor to be your wife. I love and adore you my sweet darling. Fontayne

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, JEROME S.
description: LEVINE-Jerome S. On November 16, 2000. Beloved husband of Hilda. Devoted father of Meyer, Peter and Liz, Charles and Ellen, Andrew and Michelle. Adored grandfather of Jason, Jennifer, Joanna, Chelsea, Ali, Steven and Carly. Dear brother of Frank and Gail, and the late Sanford and Zelda. Dear brother-in-law of Jane, Albert and Soraya. Cherished uncle and friend to many. Funeral services will be held at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, in Paramus, New Jersey on November 17th at 2:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 5 about discrimination against overweight people referred incorrectly to Sondra Solovay, the author of ''Tipping the Scales of Justice: Fighting Weight-Based Discrimination.'' Although a law school graduate, she is not a lawyer.

title: Blood Tests Are Proposed for Allocating Livers for Transplants
description: The nonprofit group that distributes organs for transplants today proposed using blood tests to determine which patients would be first in line for the scarce livers. The action came after months pressure from federal health officials.

title: Accounts
description: * Intelli-Check, Woodbury, N.Y., to Korey Kay & Partners, New York, to handle the first account for ID-Check, an identification verification system. Spending was estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

title: Metro Business Briefing; UPSTATE JOB GROWTH LAGS
description: The number of new jobs in New York State has surged in the last 12 months, but the growth has been concentrated in New York City and its suburbs, according to figures released yesterday by the State Department of Labor. Across the state, the job count rose by more than 169,000, or 2 percent, which is faster than the national average of 1.8 percent. But almost 131,000 of those new jobs were downstate, where the job count soared by 2.4 percent. Upstate, the number of jobs grew by just 1.2 percent. Across the state, however, the unemployment rate continued to drop, and is far lower upstate -- 3.8 percent -- than in New York City, where it is 5.4 percent, adjusted for seasonal factors. The national average is 3.9 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Supreme Court Stops Execution of Texan
description: A death-row inmate whom the state authorities have found to be mentally retarded received a stay of execution today from the United States Supreme Court less than four hours before he was to be put to death by lethal injection.

title: And He Clucked, 'What a Faaabulous Trick'
description: Ugh. The shrill, overstuffed, spiritless cinematic contraption being marketed under the label ''Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas'' is a depressing reminder that when Hollywood decides to lavish more than $100 million on a beloved children's story, that money has to go somewhere. The movie is so clogged with kooky gadgetry and special effects and glitter and goo that watching it feels like being gridlocked at Toys ''R'' Us during the Christmas rush. Both the film and its omnivorous star, Jim Carrey, who seems to change voices every few seconds, come at you from so many directions at once that half the time you don't know where to look or how to react.

title: Teenager and Boyfriend Strangled Disapproving Parents, Police Say
description: A high school senior and her boyfriend were charged yesterday with strangling the girl's mother and father in the parents' apartment in Spanish Harlem two weeks ago and then dumping their bodies, with belts still tight around their necks, in the East River last week, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ROBERT
description: GREENBERG-Robert. It is with deep sorrow that we mourn the passing of Robert Greenberg, President of our Insight Laser Centers and former Chief Executive Officer of Sterling Vision, Inc. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Kim, and the entire Greenberg family. Sterling Optical Dr. Alan Cohen, President

description: In percent

title: THRIVING RANK TO SELL UNITS
description: Earnings from its Grosvenor gambling casinos and Hard Rock cafes pushed the Rank Group's third-quarter earnings ''significantly ahead,'' the company said, without giving figures. Mike Smith, the chief executive, said Rank was interested in selling its Deluxe film-processing business and other units, which analysts said could bring $430 million. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Thanks for the Memories
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: From Picassoid to Inlaid, Old Treasures Abound
description: It is amazing how an exhibition as vast and various as the Fall Antiques Show, which opens today and runs through Sunday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, can be at once so funky and so elegant, and maintain so consistently a high level of quality.

title: New Ballot Count Begins in State Senate Race
description: City Board of Elections officials began counting thousands of paper ballots yesterday in a closely contested State Senate race between Roy M. Goodman, the longtime Republican incumbent, and his Democratic challenger, Liz Krueger.

title: So Where Is Madeline When You Need Her?
description: For the ''Rugrats''-obsessed audience, ''Rugrats in Paris'' is a one-way ticket to infantile heaven. And that audience must be a considerable number, since this is the second movie starring the cartoon infants with the irregularly shaped heads.

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize; The Democrats' Jabs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, RABBI ALEXANDER M.
description: SCHINDLER-Rabbi Alexander M. The officers, Board of Trustees and staff of United Jewish Communities are deeply saddened by the passing of Rabbi Alexander Schindler, a progressive Jewish leader of great intellect and compassion. For more than two decades, Rabbi Schindler served with distinction as President of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, where he was committed to the continuity of the Jewish people through Reform Jewish outreach. He led the effort to attract intermarried and assimilated couples back to Jewish life and embraced the inclusion of women as Reform rabbis. At the same time, Rabbi Schindler served as Chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, where his leadership on behalf of Israel and American Jewry was widely respected. He was an eloquent spokesman for Jewish unity with Israel and issues related to peace in the Middle East. Rabbi Schindler also championed development of a positive partnership between federations and synagogues to create the strongest possible Jewish community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Rhea, his sister, children and grandchildren. Charles R. Bronfman, Chairman of the Board Joel D. Tauber, Chairman, Executive Committee Robert M. Schrayer, National Campaign Chairman Stephen D. Solender, President and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OCKO, STEPHEN JAY
description: OCKO-Stephen Jay of Wayland, Mass. Inventor and innovator, beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend passed away peacefully surrounded by love on November 13, 2000. Born May 30th, 1934 in New York City, the son of Beatrice and Harry Ocko, he attended Brooklyn Polytechnic Prep School and graduated from Yale College in 1956 with Bachelors degree in Architecture. He served as an officer on the USS Cassin Young, peacetime, and married his first wife, Stephanie Goss in 1960. In 1963, he was chosen as one of President Kennedy's five young filmmakers to participate in a program developed with George Stevens, Jr. at the United States Information Agency to make films in developing countries. From 1964 to 1966, the U.S.I.A. assigned him to the Democratic Republic of the Congo. He left the Foreign Service in 1968 and joined the Education Development Center in Cambridge, MA to develop innovative classroom curricula. In 1970, he produced and directed a film on the Congo River for the Walt Disney Company. The following year he formed his own company, Ethnographics, to make ethnological films for classroom use. He went on to start Landmark Models, Inc. to produce and sell model kits of historical Americna Architecture. Following this, he worked for several years as an in-house toy inventor for Milton Bradley and then Parker Bros. In 1985 he received his Masters Degree in Education from Harvard University and joined the MIT Media Lab where he worked to develop a classroom learning system based on the marriage of Lego toys with the Logo computer language. He went on to open Lego Futura's Boston office as the Senior Research Designer where he further developed a Lego system of computerized ''bricks,'' motors and gears that inspired children to strengthen their problem solving skills through creative play. In 1997, he married Susan Sjoberg and spent the last years of his life deeply in love and living in Wayland, MA. He is survived by his wife Susan, son Peter and grandsons Oscar and Jeremy. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to The Children's First Foundation, 197A Centre St., Dorchester, MA 02124. A memorial service will be held at a later date. The George F. Doherty & Sons Funeral Home, Wellesley, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATTIKER, BARBARA GILMAN
description: WATTIKER-Barbara Gilman. Beloved wife of the late Bernard J. Wattiker, M.D. Beloved mother of Katherine Olivetti, Virginia Sheerin, William Wattiker, Paula Majors, Barbara Stellway, and Peter Wattiker. Brother of William Gilman. Grandmother of Cristina Spencer, Peter Olivetti, Geoffrey Wattiker, Virginia Wattiker, Jane Wattiker, Christopher Smiles, Rebecca Bodemuller, Diana Stellway, Nicholas Stellway, Elizabeth Wattiker, Bernard Wattiker, and Catherine Wattiker. Donations to Dr. Robert Cancro, Chairman, Dept. of Psychiatry NYU Med Center, 550 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016.

title: Venator Profit Rises 93%
description: The Venator Group said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter profit increased 93 percent as sales of sneakers and athletic clothing rose at its Foot Locker and Champs chains. Profit from operations rose to $27 million, or 20 cents a share, from $14 million, or 11 cents, a year earlier, on sales of $1.13 billion, up 9.6 percent. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 10 percent in the quarter, which ended Oct. 28. Venator is the former Woolworth Corporation.

title: California Returns to the Edge Of an Emergency on Electricity
description: California got a cold dose of reality this week as temperatures dropped to unseasonably low levels, resulting in warnings about possible electricity blackouts ahead and reminders that steep increases in natural gas prices might be coming.

title: Russia to Seek Easier U.S. Rules for Steel Exports
description: Russia plans to ask Washington next month to change trade rules that have reduced steel exports to the United States by as much as 90 percent since 1998.

title: Bush and Gore Turn to Public As Court Skirmishes Intensify
description: WASHINGTON  A spokesman for Governor George W. Bush said Thursday that "this election will be over" on Saturday, with a Florida official expected to certify a Bush victory. But as pressure mounted, Vice President Al Gore warned that the Florida election, upon which the national outcome depends, risked being "short-circuited" by Republicans.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Israeli-Palestinian violence referred incorrectly to the toll on Monday, when four Israelis were killed. The Israeli deaths were not the most in a single day in the seven weeks since the fighting broke out. The number of Israelis killed by Palestinians was the highest. (On Oct. 2, eight Israelis died, including six Israeli Arabs killed by Israeli gunfire.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENE, JULIET KALIKOW
description: LEVENE-Juliet Kalikow. Beloved wife of Stephen M. Levene and widow of the late Harold J. Kalikow. Loving mother of Peter Kalikow and Penny Wallerstein. Cherished grandmother of Nicholas and Kathryn Kalikow, Jill and Jennifer Wallerstein. Dear mother-in-law of Mary Kalikow and John Wallerstein. Devoted sister of Gertrude Blum, Harold Citrin, Renee Weil and Barbara Goldstein. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Juliet Kalikow Levene Memorial Fund, New York Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Foreign Affairs; Beware Of Arnie's Army
description: And now for a sports column, sort of.

title: With Tallahassee All Astir, Jeb Bush Keeps a Distance
description: This morning, after days of near-seclusion, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida finally ended his disappearing act.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about an increase in temporary and part-time work in Japan misspelled the given name of an illustrator who has signed with a company that assists freelancers. She is Akemi Takada, not Alemi.

title: DELHAIZE RAISES ITS BID FOR UNITED STATES AFFILIATE
description: The Delhaize Group, the giant Belgian food retailer, agreed yesterday to raise its bid to buy out an affiliated United States company, which runs the Food Lion and Hannaford grocery chains. Delhaize said it would offer shareholders of Delhaize America 0.4 of a Delhaize Group share for every share held, or $1.9 billion. Delhaize had bid 0.35 share, then worth $1.7 billion, in September. Delhaize Group owns 56 percent of Delhaize America's Class B voting shares and 37 percent of its Class A nonvoting shares, amounting to 45 percent of all outstanding shares; the rest are publicly traded. Delhaize America's Class B shares were unchanged at $17.31.

title: G.O.P. Lawmakers See Bias By Networks in Calling Races
description: House Republicans accused the national television networks today of being biased against Gov. George W. Bush in their election-night coverage, discouraging Republican turnout in conservative strongholds like the Florida Panhandle and Orange County, Calif.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GUESS INC., Los Angeles, a clothing designer and retailer, announced that Brian Fleming, chief financial officer, had resigned effective immediately. No other details were given.

title: Bangalore Journal; What a Plot! What an Ending! A Star's Kidnapping
description: His walk is creaky, his expression serene. Sparse strands of hair straggle across his pate. Today, unlikely as it seems, this grandfatherly figure stirred rapturous adulation from throngs of rowdy young men, who roared and screamed and chanted by the hour for the chance to catch just a glimpse of him.

title: Mischief That's Made by Hand
description: In this election chaos, the controversy swirls around one central question: Is it fair to recount votes by hand?

title: Zimmer, Expecting Narrow Loss, May Ask for Recount
description: As election workers began tallying the final votes yesterday in New Jersey's tortured race for the 12th Congressional District seat, Dick Zimmer, the Republican candidate, said that he would pursue a recount if he lost to the Democratic incumbent, Representative Rush Holt.

title: I (Love) New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: In Yugoslav Misery, Investors Knock
description: Just over a month has passed since Yugoslavia's emerging democrats sent President Slobodan Milosevic packing and Western countries began lifting sanctions. Already, foreign investors are sifting through the physical and economic wreckage for investments and markets in Yugoslavia, a country they say should be the engine of Balkan recovery.

title: Local Leader In Little Italy Admits Theft Of Permit Fees
description: The former head of the Little Italy Chamber of Commerce, and one of the neighborhood's most prominent community leaders, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday to embezzling more than $70,000 that merchants on Mulberry Street thought they were paying to the city for permits, the authorities said.

title: Japan Asks for an End to Debate on U.N. Security Council's Shape
description: Japan, which is campaigning for a permanent seat on the Security Council, called today for an end to the inconclusive debate on whether the Council should be expanded and asked that major nations, especially the United States, come to concrete agreement on its future shape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, JEAN STEWART
description: OLSON-Jean Stewart. Of NY, NY and New Milford, CT died October 29, after a long illness. A Memorial Service will be held at The Brick Presbyterian Church in New York City, Park Avenue and 91 St., at 4 PM on Monday, November 20. Jean Olson was a graduate of Rockford College, receiving Talcott Cross, highest alumni honor, and held a master's degree in mathematics from the University of Chicago. Married James C. Olson in 1945. Active in The Brick Church, volunteer remedial reading programs in NYC public schools, and Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center. Received Award of Appreciation by the Community Narcotics Prevention Program. Member Board of The Youth Foundation, NYC. Member Candlewood Lake Club, New Milford, The Cosmopolitan Club, NYC. Survived by sister Marjorie R. Stewart, Stamford, CT; children James S. Olson, NYC, Julia O. Luckenbill, Paoli, PA, and David C. Olson, Rye, NY, and six grandchildren. Donations may be made to The Brick Church, 62 E. 92 St., NY, NY 10128, The Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center, 415 E. 93 St., NY, NY 10128, and Rockford College, 5050 E. State St., Rockford, IL 61108.

title: Legal Eyes Are Watching 11th Circuit Once Again
description: A herd of television trucks was massed out front, and court clerks had to trudge to work at 5:30 this morning to process the latest urgently requested documents. Already jolted once this year by the Elian Gonzalez case, the federal appeals court here began today to sort out another clamorous dispute from Florida, the question of whether to allow manual recounts of presidential ballots.

title: Sanctions for Burmese
description: The International Labor Organization cleared the way today for sanctions against Myanmar for using widespread and systematic forced labor.

title: Woods Has Hammer, But Needs Soft Touch
description: Mercedes-Benz will never irritate Tiger Woods again.

title: By Deals With Burmese Junta, Minorities Thrive
description: Freedom's just another word for cutting a deal with the generals.

title: Sontag Is Among Winners Of National Book Awards
description: Susan Sontag won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night for ''In America,'' a postmodern novel about a 19th-century Polish actress's attempt to establish a utopian community in California. The book, published this year by Farrar, Straus & Giroux, was partly inspired by the true story of the Polish actress Helena Modjeska, who came to America in the 19th century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARSKY, RICHARD H.
description: DARSKY-Richard H. of Larchmont, NY died on the morning of Thursday, November 16 of complications of acute endocarditis. He had been ill for one month. Mr. Darsky, age 59, is survived by his wife of 29 years, Judith Hyman Darsky; children, Joel, Jonathan, and Ilana. Mr. Darsky was the son of Julius Darsky of Miami Beach, Florida, and the late Rose Darsky; brother of Carole Giller of Akron, Ohio, and Joan Paige, of Miami, Florida; and the son-in-law of Anita and the late Morris Hyman of Cincinnati, Ohio. Born on January 19, 1941 in Akron, Ohio, Mr. Darsky graduated from Buchtel High School in Akron in 1958; graduated with a BA degree in Finance from the Ohio State University in 1962; and a JD degree with honors from Fordham University in 1969. For 25 years he was associated with Lehman Brothers, Inc, directing their real estate workout and restructuring area, most recently as a Managing Director. Earlier he was associated with the New York law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher, where he practiced corporate and securities law. Among his civic and philanthropic activities, Mr. Darsky served on the Ohio State University Fisher College of Business Advisory Board Council; the Planning Board of the Town of Mamaroneck, NY; was a Board member of the Greater New York United Jewish Appeal-Federation and chaired the United Jewish Appeal-Federation Larchmont/Mamaroneck Campaign; was a soccer coach and member of the Board of Directors of the Westchester Youth Soccer League; and an Advisory Board member of the America Israel Cooperative Enterprise. Funeral services for Mr. Darsky will be held at noon on Sunday, November 19 at the Westchester Jewish Center, Rockland and Palmer Avenues, Mamaroneck, New York, Rabbi Jeffrey Sirkman officiating. Please call Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont, NY at 914-834-0144 for information. The family will be sitting shiva at the Darsky home in Larchmont. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that friends consider contributions either to The Institute for the Advancement of Education in Jaffa, 11 Pahad Yitzchak Street (Post Office Box 8216) Jaffa 61081 Israel, or to the United Way of Larchmont/ Mamaroneck (Richard H. Darsky Memorial Fund) 230 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY 10538 or to any charitable organization.

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize; An Arbitrary Call
description: To the Editor:

title: EATING OUT
description: Thanksgiving Specials

title: Rangers Sideline Malakhov With Knee Trouble
description: Vladimir Malakhov has played only three games for the Rangers and may not play again this season.

title: Panel Rebukes Police Leaders In Los Angeles
description: A panel of experts issued a long-awaited report today on corruption in the Los Angeles Police Department, harshly criticizing what it characterized as the force's dictatorial and detached management and recommending a shift in power from the top officers to the civilian police commission.

title: Florida's High Court Rules Recounts Can Go On
description: The Florida Supreme Court ruled today that at least two largely Democratic counties could continue recounting ballots by hand, but a welter of pending legal challenges left it unclear whether any such votes would officially count in determining the outcome of the presidential race.

title: Public Interests; Last Year's Sci-Fi
description: Dear Joanie,

title: Jackson Has A Mentor In Marbury
description: Stephen Jackson, the good house guest and the good rookie, always makes his bed.

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize; A Science Lesson, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Dancing In the Deep
description: Lilly, a little girl, waits patiently for a rare display of song and dance. The performers don't have elegant voices, slim bodies or long, supple legs. Yet their music and movement are as graceful as the tides.

title: Distributor of Flu Vaccine Comes Under Fire
description: With flu vaccine in short supply nationwide, customers of one big distributor say their longstanding orders are going unfilled while other customers that ordered only recently, but at higher prices, are getting the medication.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the counting of presidential ballots in Gadsden County, Fla., gave an incorrect name in some copies for the union that helped get out the vote there. It is the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees -- not the Association of Federal, State and Municipal Employees.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Design; Italian Couture in an Off-the-Rack Era
description: 'CORROSION LABORATORY'' said the sign on the door at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the only readable legend among the multidigit numbers along the long hall. I had gotten lost there, in M.I.T.'s famed ''infinite corridor,'' searching for the room where Sergio Pininfarina, the dean of Italian automotive design, was to speak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERENBAUM, MERWIN
description: ERENBAUM-Merwin. The Israel Education Fund of United Jewish Communites mourns the death of Merwin Erenbaum, a trustee of the Posnack Family Foundation and a friend of Israel, who helped build numerous projects in Israel for the benefit of children and the elderly. We send our condolences to his wife, Beverly, his family and the trustees of the Posnack Foundation. Jane Sherman, President, IEF Yitzchak Shavit, Vice President Marina de Moses, SE Executive Director

title: Cheers of 'Hillary!' Ring in Hanoi's Crowded Streets
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton acted as a one-woman advance team for her husband today, arriving here several hours before President Clinton and plunging into buoyant crowds for a bit of shopping.

title: Consumer Price Index Rose Only Slightly Last Month
description: Consumers paid only slightly more for goods last month than they had in September, but inflation is still headed for its largest annual increase since 1990, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Shares Fallen, TheStreet.com Will Lay Off 20% of Staff
description: TheStreet.com, an online financial news service whose once-soaring stock helped to symbolize the Internet craze, said yesterday that it would lay off about 20 percent of its work force in a broad-ranging effort to conserve remaining cash as it strives to make its first profit.

title: For Florida Watchers, Thrill Is Fading Fast
description: Barrett Buss likes a juicy political potboiler as much as the next guy. Probably more.

title: Key House Leader Withdraws Support for Colombia Aid Plan
description: Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, chairman of the House International Relations Committee, has abruptly withdrawn his support from the decision to funnel $1.3 billion in mostly military aid to Colombia, arguing that the United States is on the brink of a ''major mistake.''

title: Avedon Decides On a Payback
description: The photographer Richard Avedon has given the Metropolitan Museum of Art 115 of his portraits, including those of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, Marilyn Monroe, the physicist Robert Oppenheimer, the playwright Edward Albee and the artist Willem de Kooning.

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize; Gore's Shrewd Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAKER, JACK
description: BAKER-Jack. November 17, 1994. Dear Dad, oh, how we miss you every day. Love, Paula, Beau and Bobby

title: High-Speed Train Makes Flashy Debut
description: Part airliner and part living room, Amtrak's new Acela Express made its debut yesterday morning on a run from Washington to Boston.

title: Bush Aide Hints Police Are Better Peacekeepers Than Military
description: Condoleezza Rice, the top national security adviser to Gov. George W. Bush, said today that it might be necessary to set up international police forces to carry out peacekeeping functions that are now the responsibility of soldiers.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Stake for Kawasaki Steel
description: Kawasaki Steel, Japan's third-largest steel maker, said yesterday that it would buy a stake in Hyundai Pipe of South Korea, but did not say how large, or how much it would pay. Kawasaki said it would share its technology for steel plate used in cars with Hyundai Pipe and would continue to supply it with hot-rolled steel coil. Hyundai Pipe has said Kawasaki may buy up to a 40 percent stake, an amount that would cost about $118 million. Hyundai Motor, the carmaking member of the financially troubled Hyundai Group, owns 45 percent of Hyundai Pipe.

title: WHX SAYS WHEELING-PITTSBURGH HAS FILED FOR CHAPTER 11
description: The WHX Corporation said yesterday that its Wheeling-Pittsburgh steel-making unit had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Youngstown, Ohio. WHX is not affected by the filing. WHX said falling steel prices caused by competition from cheaper imports led to steep losses at Wheeling-Pittsburgh; prices for some steel products have fallen as much as 30 percent this year. Wheeling-Pittsburgh said that its plants would continue operating, and that Citibank had agreed to give the company a $290 million loan to remain open.

title: Behind the Scenes, It's Old News That Elections Are Not an Exact Science
description: Everybody else may be shocked by the double voting, the confusing ballots and the general all-around glitches of last week's elections, but the people who actually run elections say these things, uh, happen.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 'Eye Candy'
description: 'Revisiting the Museum of Modern Art's 1965 Exhibition ''The Responsive Eye'' '

title: A Goal by Isles Is Something, but Not Everything
description: The first game of the Islanders' West Coast swing was not a total loss. At least they scored.

title: Ruling Favors Tobacco Companies
description: In a ruling that is certain to gladden the hearts of cigarette manufacturers, online tobacco retailers and price-conscious smokers, a federal judge has ruled that a New York law effectively banning the direct sale of cigarettes to New Yorkers via the Internet is likely to be unconstitutional.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 12
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Coach Sets Record; Bethpage Wins Title
description: Bethpage defeated Glen Cove, 16-15, for the Nassau Conference III high school football title last night, and Howie Vogts, the Golden Eagles' coach, set the New York State record for coaching victories with his 288th. The record had been held by Johnny Barnes of Canisius in Buffalo; he retired in 1973. Vogts has been a coach at Bethpage since 1947. He is the only football coach the school has had.

title: Biggest Issue Yet to Come for High Court
description: With its ruling late today that the manual recounting of ballots may continue in Palm Beach County, the Florida Supreme Court has handed the campaign of Vice President Al Gore two victories in two days. But the most important issue has yet to reach the justices, though it is almost certainly on its way.

title: Fed Cited Two Points in Holding Rates Steady in October
description: At their October meeting, Federal Reserve policy makers unanimously approved leaving the overnight bank lending rate unchanged because of slowing economic demand and an easing of inflation pressures.

title: High in the Saddle for a Rousing Ride That's Bumpy, Bruising and Scary
description: In mountain biking lingo, ''a yard sale'' is a crash where a rider leaves gear strewn along the trail. Midway down a winding descent on a dry, rocky trail during a mountain bike race in Maui, I tried to avoid a large rock, jammed on my front brakes and went flying over the handlebars -- a judo-style fall known as an ''endo.'' I picked myself up slowly and walked up the trail to retrieve my water bottles, energy bars and spare inner tube. I wasn't badly hurt, but my already shaky confidence took a Learjet to Tijuana.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEITELBAUM, ELAINE
description: TEITELBAUM-Elaine. We extend condolences to our devoted member Dr. Israel Teitelbaum on the loss of his wife Elaine. May he and his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Scarsdale Jacob S. Rubenstein, Rabbi Harold B. Aspis, Co-President William H. Schrag, Co-President

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Wednesday about Indiana University's basketball program misstated the number of games won by its former coach, Bob Knight, as well as his ranking among coaches. He has won 764 games in his career, not 661, and stands seventh, not second. The article also misstated the dates of the semifinals and finals of the preseason National Invitation Tournament in New York. They are Nov. 22 and Nov. 24.

title: Relaxed and Content at Ranch, Bush Leaves Controversy Elsewhere
description: He has no cable or satellite television and only a few local channels, and he rarely turns to those. While they might bring bulletins about a matter no smaller than his hopes for moving into the White House, Gov. George W. Bush is not inclined to get that consumed.

title: Yep, Still Struggling To Make Art of Soup
description: ''In the future, we will still be using the phrase 'History repeats itself.' '' It's a funny enough quip, characteristic of the playwright Jane Wagner and the free-standing observations of the ironies and paradoxes of life on earth that pepper her play ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe.''

title: Where All Roads Lead to the Past
description: Just east of the Delaware River, in this rural South Jersey hamlet of diners and cornfields, lies the Wall Street of the dust trade.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINSIER, JOAN TUBY
description: WEINSIER-Joan Tuby. On the day that you were born, the angels created a dream come true. Our hearts pour out our endless love to our beautiful Mommy on your birthday and everyday. Love, Wendy and Michael

title: Sports of The Times; Right Player Wins Wrong N.L. Award
description: THE right player presumably won the National League most valuable player award yesterday, but the voting was wrong. The San Francisco Giants, despite their status as the team with the most victories in the major leagues, should not have had the top two players in the voting.

title: Mileage Deduction to Rise
description: Taxpayers can deduct an extra 2 cents a mile when they use their car for business in 2001, the Internal Revenue Service said today. The agency set its optional standard mileage deduction at 34.5 cents a mile for 2001. The mileage deduction is set annually based on the costs of operating a car.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAMARIN, LILLIAN, M.D.
description: TAMARIN-Lillian, M.D. Wife of the late Alfred Tamarin and the late Carlton Barlow. Mother of Susan Eluard (Alain). Grandmother of Nathalie Hurwitz (Jonathan) and Lauren Eluard. A graduate of NYU Medical School, she was a member of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis and a practicing Analyst for 50 years. Contributions in her memory may be sent to Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital. A Memorial Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., on Saturday, November 18 at 3:30 PM.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Top prize for the worst new restaurant name goes immediately to A Salt & Battery, a hole in the wall just large enough to contain a front counter, a few stools and stainless-steel shelves to eat from. A Salt & Battery, next to the equally British Tea and Sympathy, is not exactly a theme restaurant, but it definitely has a subtext: fat.

title: AMF BOWLING SEEKS TO CHANGE MARKET LISTING
description: AMF Bowling, the troubled bowling alley operator controlled by the Goldman Sachs Group, said yesterday that it would seek to transfer its stock to the over-the-counter bulletin board. The New York Stock Exchange stopped trading in the shares before the market opened on Wednesday and moved to delist them yesterday. The over-the-counter bulletin board provides quotes on stocks that are not listed on a major exchange -- often highly risky companies that sell for pennies a share. AMF Bowling, based in Richmond, Va., has been trying to restructure a $1.3 billion debt load. It said it had shaken up management of its bowling equipment division and would cut costs throughout the company, reducing expenses by about $4 million a year. It last traded on Tuesday at 23 cents a share. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

title: This Green Isn't Blue About Nader or Gore
description: LIKE Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, another guy for whom the presidential election was as much about family loyalty as it was about party loyalty, Prof. Bert Garskof is not sure how guilty he should feel right now.

title: Behind the Scenes... and Above
description: TIME seems to stand still on a Friday afternoon in October at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, where, in just about two weeks, the new musical ''Jane Eyre'' is supposed to start previews. This should be a typical technical rehearsal in which stagehands run through the show's scenery and lighting cues. Instead, pieces of the set are still piled high on seats in the orchestra section. On the bare stage, people with headsets stand around looking up helplessly into the flies.

title: Pataki Administration Calls for Dredging of the Hudson River to Clean Up PCB's
description: Entering one of the hottest environmental debates in the state, the administration of Gov. George E. Pataki has for the first time called for the dredging of the Hudson River to remove potentially harmful PCB's.

title: Democrats Rue Ballot Foul-Up In a 2nd County
description: Democrats in Duval County prepared meticulously for Election Day. They registered thousands of voters and ferried enough people to the polls in predominantly African-American precincts to give a solid boost to Vice President Al Gore in a county expected to swing reliably into Gov. George W. Bush's column.

title: Hingis, the Pupil, Overcomes One of Her Teachers
description: There are younger, sleeker players than the frumpy Oscar Madison of the tour, but the 33-year-old Nathalie Tauziat can still cross up the neophytes opposing her with a style that has all but gone the way of the phonograph: the serve and volley.

title: Hardee's Names Cliff Freeman
description: A fast-food marketing executive who recently changed jobs is reaching back to his previous agency to work with him at his new post.

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize; Partisan Kingmaker
description: To the Editor:

title: The Election Takes a Turn in Court
description: Most of the action on Day 10 of the presidential election took place in courtrooms yesterday. Here are the day's highlights.

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize; Let's Vote Again
description: To the Editor:

title: A Deadly Twist of Fate, A Tortured Conscience And Then Love's Dart
description: Don Roos's ultra-sleek romantic drama ''Bounce'' is a perfect illustration of the adage that God is in the details. Although its aspirations aren't much loftier than to meet the specifications of what might be called High Formula Hollywood moviemaking, this touching, finely wrought bowl of suds is a seamless piece of work, comparable in its craft to ''Jerry Maguire'' and ''As Good as It Gets,'' if a bit slighter.

title: Lawyers in Terror Case Say Client Access Was Blocked
description: Lawyers for some defendants in the East Africa embassy bombings case complained yesterday that they were blocked from meeting their clients for two weeks after two other defendants in the case stabbed and critically injured a guard.

title: BAYER TO SELL GENE THERAPY
description: Bayer has obtained exclusive worldwide marketing and distribution rights to a gene therapy treatment for hemophilia B being developed by Avigen Inc., the companies are expected to announce today. The treatment, still in clinical trials, has shown signs of becoming one of the first gene therapies that actually works. In tests reported last year, three patients injected with the gene for Factor IX, the blood clotting agent the patients lack, began producing some clotting factor, reducing the need for injections. Hemophilia B is only a fifth as common as hemophilia A. Bayer will buy $15 million of Avigen stock at a premium to market price, giving it a small stake in the company, and will finance further clinical trials. Avigen, of Alameda, Calif., said total payments from Bayer could reach $60 million. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEVESI, JOSEPH
description: HEVESI-Joseph. Age 89. Died peacefully at his home in Harrison, New York on November 11, 2000. Beloved husband of Eleanor for over 60 years. In his early years he was a reporter for the New York Herald Tribune and had also been employed by Benton & Bowles, NBC & CBS TV, where he was Director of Publicity. Between 1940-44 Mr. Hevesi was the writer and publicist for the Major Bowes Original Amateur Hour. Later he spent more than 20 years with the United States Steel Corporation as the Senior Staff Director of the Television and Public Relations Department. He produced the radio and television institutional documentaries for ''Theatre Guild on the Air'' and then the ''US Steel Hour.'' These documentaries earned numerous awards, including the Peabody and Freedom Foundation Award. Along with his wife, Mr. Hevesi is survived by his loving daughters, Joelle Sander of New York City and Carla Tartaglia of Redding, Connecticut, their husbands, Dr. Fred Sander and Peter Tartaglia, his beloved grandchildren, Stephen Sander and his wife Christine of Westport, Connecticut, Jason Sander of New York City, Matthew Tartaglia of Atlanta, Georgia and Nicole Tartaglia of Redding, Connecticut and his cherished great granddaughter Elizabeth Sander. A memorial service is scheduled for December 9 at 2PM at the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Hospice of Westchester.

title: Genetic Worries Hurt U.S. Corn Sales Abroad
description: Corn sales to Japan, South Korea and other countries have declined in part because of importers' concerns that cargoes may be tainted with StarLink, a genetically modified variety that has not been approved for human consumption, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said today.

title: Car Crashes Were Staged For Fraud, U.S. Charges
description: At first blush, it looked like a typical fender bender: a 1989 Mercury sedan with four people inside ran into the car of a woman driving alone in downtown Brooklyn. But even though a police officer noted in his accident report that there were no injuries, three passengers in the Mercury were taken to a medical clinic, where they were treated for back and neck pains.

title: STRONG RESULTS AT LARGE BANKS
description: A boom quarter for investment banking raised profits sharply at major banks, including the No. 1 and No. 3 banks in France, BNP Paribas and Societe Generale, and the second-biggest in Scandinavia, RealDanmark. Societe Generale, whose third-quarter net income rose 65 percent, also did well in corporate banking. Net income at RealDanmark roughly doubled, to 650 million kroner ($75 million), largely on a huge rise in the value of its investments. BNP Paribas reported robust nine-month profits, though net income for the third quarter was off a bit from the quarter before.

title: Alas, Vote-Count Machines Are Only Human
description: One of the central arguments that Gov. George W. Bush has made against the hand recounts in Florida is that machines are impartial and much more reliable than humans. The people who sell the voting systems that tallied 3.45 million votes in the contested state, as well as election officials across the country, say the machines can be, in ideal conditions, 99.99 percent accurate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYON, DANIEL
description: LYON-Daniel. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations mourns the passing of the father of its dear colleague Avi Lyon. We pray that the family will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENBACK, HEDI
description: LEVENBACK-Hedi. Died Nov. 15, 2000. Wife of Robert. Mother of Elizabeth Shamir and her husband Abraham and Charles Levenback & his wife Virginia. Grandmother of Tamar, Matan, Kerin, Shamir, Samuel and Benjamin. Services today 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her memory to your charity of choice or Blue Card, SHARE, or New York 0-3 Network, New York City.

title: Four Unrelated Killings on One Day in New York
description: A 60-year-old Brooklyn man was fatally shot two blocks from his home as he walked his dog yesterday morning, the police said. The shooting was one of four unrelated killings reported in the city yesterday.

title: New Video Releases
description: Chicken Run

title: Giants' Kent Named M.V.P. in N.L.
description: He is not as powerful as Mike Piazza, he is not as smooth as Barry Bonds and he is not yet a future Hall of Famer, as both of them almost certainly are. But Jeff Kent was chosen more valuable last season than Bonds, Piazza and every other player in the National League by the baseball writers yesterday.

title: Europeans Forgo a Rate Change
description: The European Central Bank left interest rates unchanged today as evidence mounts that an economic expansion is slowing in the 11 nations where the euro is the common currency.

title: MERGER BUOYS TD BANK
description: Fourth-quarter operating profit for Canada's second-largest bank, the TD Bank Financial Group, rose 32 percent to 512 million Canadian dollars ($330 million), or 80 Canadian cents a share, on operating revenue that rose 45 percent to 2.68 billion dollars ($1.73 billion). Much of the growth was attributable to TD's acquisition of Canada Trust, the bank said. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize; A Moral Erosion
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW JERSEY

title: Allied Gains Rights to Sell Stolichnaya
description: Allied Domecq P.L.C. said today that it had secured the right to distribute Stolichnaya vodka in the United States from the brand's Russian owner and supplier Soyuzplodimport.

title: I.R.S. Arrests 6 in White Supremacist Group on Tax Charges
description: Six leaders of a white supremacist group were arrested yesterday by Internal Revenue Service agents in Oregon on charges that they ran an elaborate scheme to help 900 people evade income taxes on $186 million over the last 14 years.

title: Controlling 401(k) Assets; Fight Brewing Over Investment Choices for $1.7 Trillion
description: R. Theodore Benna says he found divine inspiration in the Tax Reform Act of 1978. He is not kidding. In the late 1970's, Mr. Benna was a consultant who helped companies develop retirement plans. He had grown so frustrated helping the rich get richer that he was thinking of retiring and becoming a minister. But Mr. Benna believed a new passage in the tax code -- Section 401, Paragraph K -- could be used as the foundation of a new kind of savings plan that would benefit everyone.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Stars of the Last 30 Years Shock and Sell at Christie's Contemporary Sale
description: New art, often sexually explicit or morbid in content, attracted buyers from all over the world to Christie's sale of contemporary art last night. And they couldn't bid fast enough or high enough for works by artists-of-the-moment.

title: Educator Accused of Viewing Child Pornography
description: An assistant high school principal in Old Tappan, N.J., who is also a councilman in a nearby borough, has been accused of using his school computer to view child pornography and of keeping marijuana in his desk, the authorities said.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TWINLAB FINDS GOODS MISSING
description: The Twinlab Corporation said yesterday that it had asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to file its quarterly reports late because it is investigating the absence of $8 million in goods from a Utah warehouse. Twinlab, based in Hauppauge, N.Y., makes nutritional supplements. The company also said its sales fell 6.7 percent, to $76.4 million, in the third quarter, from $81.9 million in the period a year earlier, because a large customer cut back on the inventory it maintained. Shares of Twinlab fell $1.84, or 37 percent, to $3.16, yesterday.

title: Judgment Exercised By Official in Florida At Core of Court Case
description: As the legal battle over the presidency swept through a series of courts yesterday, a central issue emerged in many of the cases: Did the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris, abuse her power when she said she would not recognize hand recounts?

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro declined as traders said the likelihood was waning that the European Central Bank would buy the currency to prop it up. In New York, the euro settled at 85.22 cents, down from 85.75 cents on Wednesday.

title: Hearing Too Much And Learning Too Little
description: As we watch the Overtime Campaign of the 2000 election, the headache of reporting it continues. Election night, when the networks made erroneous projections about who had won, was probably the worst moment in the 50-year history of television coverage of politics. Newspapers that prematurely miscalled the election were humiliated, too. And now, as the networks scramble to fill time, we watch spin doctors and talk show hosts try to shape public opinion until one side or the other capitulates.

title: Port Authority Outlines Plans for New Revenue
description: Some officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that by the end of the year, they might be ready to recommend financing about $9 billion worth of capital improvements over the next five years by increasing long-unchanged tolls at Hudson River crossings, fares for PATH trains and fees charged to commuter bus lines that use the agency's Midtown bus terminal.

title: Palm Beach County Had Prior Complaints About Counts
description: The Election Day confusion in Palm Beach County came as no surprise to State Representative Curt Levine.

title: A Dark Day Turns Less So for the Democrats, Allowing Them to Forgo Escalation
description: The six hours between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. today were among the darkest that Vice President Al Gore's team had spent in the long post-election period.

title: As Courts Rule, Gore and Bush Ride the Same Roller Coaster, in Opposite Directions
description: The roller coaster of the continuing election dispute took a particularly deep dive for Vice President Al Gore today before soaring back up beyond his expectations.

title: Article 2000111890338665696 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: The Forgotten Debt to Vietnam
description: LOS ANGELES -- As President Clinton talked with officials in Hanoi this week, he undoubtedly hoped to lay groundwork for more progress in what is already a much improved relationship with Vietnam. And chances are his hosts, who have much to gain from stronger ties, did what they could to build a case that a friendly and prosperous Vietnam is very much in America's interest.

title: No. 1 Meets No. 2 for the C.H.S.F.L. Title
description: While talking about the Catholic High School Football League Class AAA title game, Ben Sarullo of Monsignor Farrell sounded more like the coach of a dark-horse team than the architect of the league's defending champions.

title: Sports of The Times; Rodriguez Would Add, Not Subtract
description: IN an attempt to improve their team, the Mets entertained the signing of a high-priced free agent. This free agent's agent was asking for a salary greater -- millions greater, in fact -- than any other player on the team, a team that had some pretty high-priced players to begin with. The free agent's agent also wanted certain special considerations to go along with the millions. Such as throwing in a luxury box in the deal. And his own suite in hotels on the road. This was almost laughable.

title: State Representative-Elect Turns Over a Voting Machine
description: Palm Beach County sheriff's deputies confiscated a polling machine from Irving Slosberg, a man who won a runoff election for state representative in October here by just 88 votes, according to a police report released today by the sheriff's office here.

title: Florida Law on Contesting Elections
description: Following is a provision of Florida law that allows the results of an election to be contested once they have been certified.

title: Nets Have Chance to Go Over .500, but Miller Stands in Way
description: Reggie Miller and the Indiana Pacers face the Nets here on Saturday night, but Nets Coach Byron Scott will have no time for sentimentality in spite of his ties to Miller, a future Hall of Fame guard. Not when a victory would put the Nets above .500 for the first time in three seasons. They then begin a four-game road trip during which they will face three of the top teams in the Western Conference.

title: Alternative Schools in City Lose Appeal on Regents Test
description: A state appeals court has affirmed decisions that said students at charter and alternative high schools in New York City must take the state Regents exams, despite a high-profile campaign by those schools to be exempt from the tests.

title: Mets to Interview Hershiser For Job as Pitching Coach
description: The Mets have contacted Orel Hershiser, who pitched for them in 1999, and will interview him for their vacant pitching coach position, baseball officials said yesterday. The job became available when Dave Wallace, the pitching coach for most of the last two seasons, decided to become a senior adviser in the front office.

title: XEROX COULD BE FORCED TO BUY BACK DERIVATIVES
description: The Xerox Corporation could be forced to repurchase derivatives contracts worth as much as $240 million if its credit ratings fall below investment grade, the company said in a regulatory filing. Xerox is dependent on a $7 billion line of credit because it has been unable to sell commercial paper, and it has used three-quarters of the line, the company, based in Stamford, Conn., said. It is trying to sell up to $4 billion in assets and cut costs to alleviate the cash shortage . Xerox's credit ratings from the major rating agencies are one or two notches above noninvestment grade.

title: Annan Plans Mideast Talks on U.N. Force
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that he would begin talks with Israelis and Palestinians about what kind of an international monitoring mission, if any, should be sent to the West Bank and Gaza.

title: Stephen Borsody, 89, Scholar of Hungary
description: Stephen Borsody, a former Hungarian diplomat and scholar who wrote extensively on European history, died Friday in Wellfleet, Mass. He was 89.

title: A Method to the Logic Of the Court Rulings
description: There was a certain topsy-turvy logic to the frantic rulings of Florida courts this week that allowed the vote recounts, declared that the secretary of state had the discretion to exclude those recounts and then ordered her not to certify the election until the State Supreme Court ruled on the election issues.

title: Fordham Heads Into Season With Attitude Adjustment
description: Bob Hill did not know what to expect when he signed as coach of the Fordham men's basketball team last season, but he did not like what he found: a team lacking in principles, values and discipline.

title: Hearst Names Publisher of Newly Bought San Francisco Chronicle
description: Five days before The San Francisco Chronicle's scheduled reincarnation as a Hearst newspaper, Hearst executives named a publisher, John F. Oppedahl, the former publisher of The Arizona Republic.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the views of top election officials in the New York region about the voting problems in Florida referred inconsistently to the official responsible for overseeing elections in New Jersey. It is the attorney general, not the secretary of state.

title: Senator-Elect Is Acquitted Of Larceny
description: Pedro Espada Jr., the state senator-elect from the 32nd District in the Bronx, was acquitted yesterday afternoon of charges that he had misappropriated money from a health plan for low-income patients to pay off campaign expenses in 1996.

title: A Right Way to Teach?
description: To the Editor:

title: HEXAGON BUYS MEASURING INSTRUMENT BUSINESS
description: Hexagon A.B., a Swedish investment company, has agreed to buy the measuring instrument business of the Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Company of North Kingston, R.I., for at least $160 million. Hexagon said it could pay as much as $180 million, depending on Brown & Sharpe's profit this year. The unit had sales of $321.4 million last year and generates cash flow of $27 million to $30 million a year, the companies said. Brown & Sharpe, which makes instruments that measure everything from candy molds to disk drives, has been struggling to pay debts after spending heavily on acquisitions, and has been in technical default on some loans since July 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KHOURY, MARIE
description: KHOURY-Marie. You've been dead a year but you are not forgotten. Love, Laura

title: Staring Into The Navel Of Ballots
description: Now that the presidential election in Florida has plunged everyone into a crash course on the different kinds of holes made in ballots, it turns out that philosophy may offer some consolation. Long before terms like indented, pregnant and swinging-door chads entered our conversation, two metaphysicians, Roberto Casati and Achille Varzi -- proving the adage that nothing is too small for academic study -- published their book, ''Holes and Other Superficialities'' (M.I.T. Press, 1994).

title: The Milder Mayor Regains His Roar; Giuliani Returns to His Critical Self
description: Everyone at City Hall could tell this week that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was feeling like his old self again.

title: Russian Tycoon Reports a Second Accord to Control Media
description: Vladimir V. Gusinsky, whose publishing and broadcast business has criticized the government, announced a new agreement today intended to reduce debt and prevent the Kremlin from gaining majority control of the leading independent television station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, RABBI ALEXANDER
description: SCHINDLER-Rabbi Alexander. The Officers, Board and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed Board member Rabbi Alexander Schindler, one of the most influential leaders in American Judaism. He served as President of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, President of the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture and Vice President of the World Jewish Congress. He was renowned for his commitment to unite people of all faiths and backgrounds. His moral authority had a great impact on the JDC; his vision and eloquence were a guiding force. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Rhea, his children, grandchildren, and to all the Schindler family. Jonathan W. Kolker, President Michael Schneider, Executive Vice President Ambassador Milton A. Wolf, Chairman of the Board

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about population change in the former tenements of the Lower East Side referred imprecisely to the rental income at 96 Orchard Street. The owner says it totals about $32,000 a month for the entire building, not just for the storefront.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASCIOLI, JOSEPH
description: MASCIOLI-Joseph. On November 17, 2000 of Manhasset. Beloved husband of Rose. Loving father of his late sons Charles and Frank. Grandfather of Margaret, Diane, Charles, Joseph, William, Elizabeth, Paul and the late Stephen. He is also survived by 18 great grandchildren. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Sunday from 3-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass on Monday 11:30am St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset. Entombment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Cooley's Anemia Fund.

title: SPLITTING OF FLETCHER APPROVED
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Apache Corporation won regulatory approval to divide up the assets of Fletcher Challenge Energy between them. Shell will acquire the New Zealand part of the business, giving it control of the country's largest oil and gas reserves, and Apache will get oil and gas fields in Canada and Argentina. The joint offer to acquire Fletcher, made Oct. 10, valued the company at $1.84 billion. Shell will have one year to divest itself of Fletcher's stakes in five gas fields in New Zealand and an exploration permit associated with the Pohokura field.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYMAN, MARGARET S., MD.
description: LYMAN-Margaret S., MD. Formerly of 201 East 21 St, New York City. In Middletown, CT. November 17. Formerly employed by Bellevue Hospital and New York University. Services at Doolittle Funeral Home, 14 Old Church St, Middletown, CT. Monday, November 20, 10:45AM. Interment Middlefield Cemetery. Calling hours funeral home Monday 9:3010:45AM. Memorial contributions National Multiple Sclerosis Society, Greater CT. Chapter, 705 North Mountain. Road, Suite G102, Newington, CT. 06111.

title: Sunbeam Likely to Face U.S. Charges
description: The Sunbeam Corporation said today that Securities and Exchange Commission investigators had completed a two-year investigation into whether the company improperly reported sales under its former chairman, Albert J. Dunlap, and that the investigators would recommend that charges be brought against the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHHOLZ, CHARLOTTE
description: BUCHHOLZ-Charlotte. On November 15, 2000. Born in Berlin, Germany. Beloved wife of the late Heinrich, devoted mother of Edward, mother-in-law of Barbara (Ballinger), adoring grandmother of Joanna and Lucy. Contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: Joseph Taubman, 81, Legal Expert On Business Side of Entertainment
description: Joseph Taubman, a New York tax expert for the entertainment industry and a lawyer for many star performers, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 and had his home and office in Midtown.

title: The Slow Countdown to a New Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOHL, DAVID
description: WOHL-David. June '55-Nov. '94 ''My mind's distracted and diffused, My thoughts are miles away, They lie with you and you're asleep, I have to doubt all I once held as true, I stand alone without beliefs, The only truth I know'' was your unconditional love for me. Thank You, Dear, Sweet Bo

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONESTEEL, LOUISE
description: BONESTEEL-Louise. Born March 22, 1918 in Watervliet, N.Y. Died of cancer November 11, 2000 at her home in Washington, D.C. Faithful helper and friend of the late Esther L. Moscow for fifty years. Miss Bonesteel is mourned by all the members of the Heimann and Holm families. Contributions in her name would be welcomed at The Salvation Army.

title: Relic of a Faded Playgound Meets the Wrecking Ball
description: The Thunderbolt roller coaster, an aging relic of Coney Island's past, was demolished yesterday by the city, angering its owner, coaster aficionados and historic preservationists who made an 11th-hour attempt to save the structure.

title: Rangers Fall Short Against Canucks
description: The boos grew louder every time Mark Messier touched the puck tonight. Messier was booed even when he stood still in the face-off circle.

title: Van Gundy Is Unfazed By a 'Crisis'
description: We are standing around Coach Jeff Van Gundy in a corridor of the America West Arena, asking him inane questions about his team, the Knicks, who have a winning record yet are supposed to be on the verge of combusting in November.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Transcript of Gore Statement
description: Following is a transcript of a statement by Vice President Al Gore yesterday on the Florida vote recount, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Seles Beats Coetzer Easily, But That Really Isn't the Point
description: Equipped with a spirit that has proven elastic during some trying years, 26-year-old Monica Seles stepped under the halo of lights at Madison Square Garden last night, then snapped back shots that might as well have been aimed at the WTA Tour officials.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Briton Is Killed in Car Blast Laid to Terrorists in Riyadh
description: A British engineer was killed and his wife was wounded today when their car blew up on a busy commercial street here.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Today's KEY GAMES

title: Teacher Has Arithmetic to Do: What's Half of $130 Million?
description: Eugenia Sitaras knew she had the winning numbers for half of a $130 million jackpot, but she did not alert New York State Lottery officials right away.

title: Nassau County Gets Ultimatum Over Finances
description: The head of the state board overseeing Nassau County's troubled finances yesterday delivered an ultimatum: the county has until the end of the month to adopt a fiscal rescue plan or face some form of state control of its books.

title: Europeans Seek $4 Billion in Trade Sanctions Against U.S.
description: The European Union asked the World Trade Organization today to approve more than $4 billion in trade sanctions on American products to retaliate for what it says is an illegal tax break granted to exporters in the United States.

title: Holt Lays Claim to Victory, But Zimmer Vows Recount
description: Ten days after residents of New Jersey's most populous Congressional district went to the polls, Representative Rush Holt, the Democratic incumbent, declared himself the victor yesterday with 481 more votes than his Republican challenger, Dick Zimmer.

title: Anversa Degli Abruzzi Journal; Adopt a Sheep, for Friend or Dinner Companion
description: In a new twist on long-distance adoptions, sheep lovers can now select their pick of the flock over the Internet. A $154 contract entitles adoptive ''parents'' to a year's supply of their chosen one's merino wool and fresh cheese, as well as a photograph and adoption papers.

title: No Instant Results Expected From Coke Bias Case
description: A day after disclosing plans for an overhaul of the Coca-Cola Company to make sure minorities and women are promoted and paid fairly, plaintiffs' lawyers and company officials said many of the details were still unclear and cautioned that tangible results could be a long way off.

title: A Cinderella With a Cold Gets to the Ball
description: The Juilliard Opera Center, more than most music schools, has one foot on the professional stage and the other in the classroom. Its new production of ''Cenerentola'' on Wednesday occupied a middle ground. Rossini's music, for all its vocal acrobatics, invites a delicacy of attack that young, half-opened voices can be grateful for. The Juilliard Theater has the intimacy and presence to frame them properly.

title: Chief of American Express To Leave Four Months Early
description: The chief executive of American Express, Harvey Golub, said yesterday that he would step down at the end of the year, four months sooner than planned.

title: When Cloth And the Set Make Images
description: What is one to think of Vicky Shick? Her new ''Still Lives,'' performed on Wednesday night at the Kitchen, is a two-part series of exquisitely beautiful images rooted in the inspired costumes and set design of Barbara Kilpatrick. The stage picture is bathed in lighting by Stan Pressner that manages to look both lush and ascetic. Ms. Shick's gift for stillness sharpens the images.

title: Other States' Officials Agree: It's Not the Way They'd Do It
description: Were the presidential election outcome dependent on disputed tallies in any of most large states, there would be much more time for recounting the votes and haggling over possible irregularities than the Florida secretary of state has allowed.

title: PETS.COM OFFERED TO PAY BONUSES FOR HELP IN CLOSING
description: Two weeks before it announced that it would close, Pets.com Inc told 10 of its executives that it had changed the terms of severance agreements so that they could receive a total of more than $1 million in retention bonuses if they stayed to wind down the company. The company, which sold pet supplies online and was based in San Francisco, announced on Nov. 7 that it was closing. According to a regulatory filing, the executives would be paid $75,000 to $225,000 each in cash, with the largest amounts going to the chairman and chief executive, Julia Wainwright, and two deputies. A spokesman said the executives were crucial to the company's efforts to settle its affairs on the most favorable terms. The bonuses would have been paid if the company had found financing or a buyer, the filing said.

title: Arafat Says He Has Told Gunmen to Stop Shooting
description: Yasir Arafat said today that he had given orders for Palestinian gunmen in Palestinian-controlled territories to stop shooting. That is his first public repudiation of the violence and an indication that the Palestinian leader may be trying to steer the conflict back to the negotiating table.

title: ZIPLINK WILL CLOSE, ENDING JOBS OF 80 WORKERS
description: ZipLink Inc., a provider of wholesale Internet access, said it was shutting down operations immediately and might sell its assets to pay creditors. About 80 of the company's 90 workers have been let go, said William DeKay, the chief executive. The company did not disclose how much it owed or how much it hoped to raise through asset sales, but it did say shareholders would not receive any of the proceeds. ZipLink's shares, which reached $21.13 in February, fell 18 percent, to 41 cents, yesterday before trading was halted.

title: Dimpled Chads Cost Me an Election
description: My family refers to the experience as our ''hideous debacle''; it was that and more. When my 1996 primary race for the 10th Congressional district in Massachusetts ended with a judge's decision to overturn my initial victory, I never wanted to hear the term ''chad'' again.

title: Albert Joseph Guerard, 86, Author and Critical Essayist
description: Albert Joseph Guerard, an author and critical essayist who taught modern literature to fledgling luminaries like Alice Hoffman and John Updike, died on Nov. 9 at his home on the Stanford University campus in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 86.

title: VF TO REVAMP AND STOP MAKING SOME WORK UNIFORMS
description: The VF Corporation, the maker of Lee and Wrangler clothing, said that it would stop making some kinds of work clothes, consolidate its distribution centers and restructure units in Japan and Latin America. The businesses that VF is quitting -- customized work uniforms and napkins and linens for restaurants -- generate about $40 million in sales a year. The changes will result in a charge of $120 million to $140 million, or 68 cents to 79 cents a share, in the fourth quarter. The company, based in Greensboro, N.C., said it expected full-year earnings of $2.95 to $3 a share before the charge.

title: Three Candidates Vie to Lead Splintered Transit Union
description: The transition of power in the city's Transport Workers Union has usually been orderly. The outgoing president selects his successor and the membership falls in line.

title: Free Drug Samples
description: To the Editor:

title: Writers Going Hollywood? Dream Factory Nightmares
description: On last weekend's episode of ''The Larry David'' show on HBO, the cranky comedy writer played by Mr. David is infuriated when his lawyer presents him with a $1,500 bill for reading his script and then tells him she's charging him extra for her unsolicited suggestions for revision.

title: RAILTRACK'S CHIEF RESIGNS
description: Gerald Corbett, the chief executive of Railtrack, the company that owns Britain's railway track and stations, tendered his resignation for the second time in a month, and this time the company's board accepted it. Mr. Corbett, left, first offered to leave after a derailment at Hatfield killed four people, the fourth fatal train wreck in three years. He will be succeeded by Steven Marshall, Railtrack's finance director, the company said; its chairman, Sir Philip Beck, will step down next year. The company said it would take a charge of $:250 million ($356 million) to pay for track replacement. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: More Strategy Than Facts In Teacher Workday Row
description: In one of its first salvos in the contract battle with New York City teachers, the Giuliani administration argued two days ago that the teachers spend too little time actually teaching, and bolstered the argument with statistics showing that teachers in New York work up to an hour and 45 minutes less a day than teachers in other parts of the country.

title: Tale of Two Uprisings: This Time, the Palestinians Have Territory, and Guns
description: When Hussam Shaheen was 14, in the first year of the first Palestinian intifada in 1987, his worried parents forbade him to join the street demonstrations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKERSON, FLORENCE ELLIS
description: DICKERSON-Florence Ellis. Of New Rochelle, NY and NYC, died November 14, 2000. Viewing Sunday, November 19 at Barney McClanahan's Funeral Home, Winthrop Avenue, New Rochelle, NY. Funeral Service Monday, November 20, 10 AM, at The Church of St. Simon the Cyrenian, Remington Place, New Rochelle, NY. Interment at Beechwood Cemetery immediately following the service.

title: Advice to Florida Republicans on Absentee Ballots
description: The following is an excerpt from a 1998 letter from the Florida Division of Elections to Tom Slade, then the state's Republican chairman, setting forth the rules under which an absentee ballot application could be sent out:

title: The Current Tally From Florida
description: Florida vote totals for Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore from The Associated Press as of 11:20 p.m. yesterday. The figures include the ongoing tally of overseas ballots but do not include any adjustments from hand recounts started after Tuesday's certification of the results. The hand recount in Broward County so far has resulted in a net gain of 48 votes for Mr. Gore.

title: Army's Armored Vehicles Are Already Behind Schedule
description: The Army today unveiled a new family of light armored vehicles that a senior officer called a step toward ''a new 21st century Army,'' and then announced that that step was nearly a year and a half behind schedule.

title: Romanians Win on Internet As the Fall Nationals Begin
description: Thousands of enthusiasts began play here today in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, looking forward to 10 days of major championships concluding with the Reisinger Teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPER, OSCAR
description: HALPER-Oscar. Temple Israel mourns the loss of a cherished trustee and friend. Our deepest condolences to his family and loved ones. Oskar Brecher, President Judith S. Lewis, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUTER, BENJAMIN
description: YUTER-Benjamin. Age 83. A World War II veteran, he and his beloved wife of 57 years, Claire, were the first Jewish GI couple united in marriage while serving in uniform. Loving father of Arthur, Mona, Edward. Devoted grandfather of Kate, Tess, Remi. Father-in-law of Roni, Kurt Brokaw, Mary. President of Beth El Jewish Center of Flatbush for 27 years. Funeral Services are at Beth El Jewish Center, Avenue T and Homecrest Avenue, Brooklyn, Sunday at 11:30 A.M.

title: Defeated Kasparov Denies He's Past His Prime
description: His stare as intimidating as ever, Garry Kasparov leaned back and waved dismissively at the notion that he may be past his prime.

title: NEW TELEFONICA STOCKS DELAYED
description: Telefonica S.A., the Spanish telecommunications company that is taking its cellular unit, Telefonica Moviles, public on Wednesday, said plans to take three more units public had been suspended. The company's chairman, Cesar Alierta, said offerings for its Data, Media and Emergia units would not go ahead ''unless it were necessary to unlock value.'' Two others, Terra Lycos, the Internet subsidiary, and TPI, which publishes directories, are already publicly traded. Benjamin Jones (NYT)

title: Warm Welcome in Hanoi
description: There are times when the visit of an American president to a foreign nation produces an extraordinary show of public curiosity about the United States and the freedoms that Americans enjoy. That happened yesterday in Hanoi as tens of thousands of Vietnamese lined the streets to greet Bill Clinton, the first American president to visit Vietnam since the end of the war more than a quarter-century ago. At a moment when many Americans are wondering whether the contested election is diminishing the presidency, Mr. Clinton's appearance in Hanoi seemed to demonstrate the enduring power and symbolism of the office.

title: Sharp Swings In the Battle
description: The pendulum of legal and political advantage swung sharply to Gov. George W. Bush today, then not quite fully back to Vice President Al Gore.

title: Corrections
description: Pictures yesterday with the obituary of Hosea Williams, a top aide to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the civil rights crusade of the 1960's, carried reversed credits. The picture of the march from Selma, Ala., to Montgomery was from UPI/ Corbis; the one of Mr. Williams alone was by The Associated Press.

title: William Woodside, Executive, Dies at 78
