description: William S. Woodside, a prominent business and civic leader who used his positions as a platform to promote social change in the New York area and nationwide, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 and also had homes in Scottsdale, Ariz., and Litchfield, Conn.

title: Abroad at Home; Twists and Turns
description: In terms of political legitimacy, the worst has been avoided for now. George W. Bush is not going to be certified in haste as the winner in Florida, and hence the country, when there is reason to think that Al Gore may have been the choice of more Florida voters.

title: Five Are Hurt in Fire On a Hudson Ferry
description: A fire broke out last night on a ferryboat on the Hudson River, seriously damaging the boat and sending five passengers to a hospital to be treated for smoke inhalation, firefighters said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLASH, ARTHUR G.
description: FLASH-Arthur G. 86, of Hartsdale, New York. Died November 16. Beloved longtime companion of Mary W. Kaufman. Husband of the late Hope K. (Billie) Flash. Brother of the late Malcolm Flash. He is survived by nephews, Michael and Douglas Flash. Arthur graduated from Princeton University and served his country during W.W.II in the China-Burma theatre. A trusted stockbroker, Arthur was formerly a member of Quaker Ridge Country Club in Scarsdale. No services.

title: Turning Private And Public Inside Out
description: Images of public life left behind by earlier societies are usually imposing edifices, grand artworks, idealized inscriptions. But the most suggestive images from public life of the last two decades are more peculiar: pubic hairs on a Coke can, Monica's dress, the Jerry Springer Show, a memoir of incest, the ''Big Brother'' television show. Contemporary public life is constructed out of pieces of exposed private life, and contemporary private life strives with all its might to make itself public.

title: Yankee Welcome Mat Is Put Out for Mussina
description: The Yankees want Mike Mussina. They're calling Mussina, they're courting Mussina, they're about to offer Mussina a huge contract. And, as a rival executive conceded earlier this week, ''If the Yankees want Mussina and he's not morally opposed to playing in New York, they've got him.''

title: Huge Crowd in Hanoi for Clinton, Who Speaks of 'Shared Suffering'
description: Tens of thousands of Vietnamese, many of them former soldiers who once battled the United States, poured into the streets of Hanoi today to welcome President Clinton, waving to his motorcade and watching on television as he told the nation that ''shared suffering has given our countries a relationship unlike any other.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: An Evening of Copland In an Intimate Context
description: Marking the centenary of Aaron Copland's birth to the day, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center gave a program on Tuesday evening entirely devoted to him, and played it with affirmation. Perhaps chamber music was not Copland's forte: his frankness made it hard for him to entertain two or more points of view for any length of time. Still, this concert kept up the energy by virtue of committed and often beautiful playing.

title: Challenges, Big and Small, Slow One Count
description: The hand recount of ballots in Palm Beach County inched onward today as court decisions whirled around it, in what promises to be a bitter, tiresome, partisan process.

title: The Slow Countdown to a New Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, GERDA
description: ABRAHAM-Gerda. With admiration and affection we honor a true woman of valor, a wife, mother, grandmother, great grandmother, sister and friend. Beloved by all. Susan and Ben

title: Giants to Face Lions, And a Persistent Moeller
description: Gary Moeller admits that he sometimes calls the veterans on the Detroit Lions seniors or upperclassmen.

title: Practically Zero Tolerance on Traffic
description: Officer Necktie, as he asked to be called, works the traffic beat in downtown Brooklyn. He has been on the job for more than a year, and by now, he says, he knows it pretty well.

title: ST. JOHN'S FRESHMAN IS ELIGIBLE
description: St. John's will receive a needed boost to its front court in the next few weeks. The freshman Mohamed Diakite, a 6-foot-11 center, was declared eligible, the school announced yesterday.

title: Colorado Skier Is Convicted In Fatal Collision on Slopes
description: A 21-year-old man has been convicted of criminally negligent homicide in what lawyers describe as the first criminal trial of a skier who accidentally caused the death of another on the slopes.

title: Small World, Big Emotions
description: ''The World Is Not a Solo'' is what Kara Tatelbaum called her dance program on Thursday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. But her choreographic world was indeed a small one, for she offered three solos, a duet and a quintet. That world's few inhabitants theatrically accomplished quite a lot in concise character sketches filled with movements suggesting rising and falling emotional temperatures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, NORBERT B.
description: MEYERS-Norbert B. On November 16, 2000. Beloved husband of Lisa, devoted brother of Edwin. Loving father of Connie, Eileen, & Andrew, father-in-law of Harris and Janet. Cherished grandfather of Claude, Alexa, Tamara, Ruth, Alex & Paulene. Astute businessman and traveler extraordinaire. Norbert was an exceptionally sensitive and caring man to all who knew him. He will be dearly missed & always loved. Services will be held on Sunday, November 19 at 12:30PM ''Gutterman's Inc'', 1975 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, L.I. Donations may be made in his memory at Winthrop University Hospital-Heart Institute, 259 1st Street, Mineola, NY 11501 Att: Development Office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZGER, FANCHON K.
description: METZGER-Fanchon K. Beloved wife of the late Alwyn, devoted mother of Dr. Steven A. Metzger and his wife Karen L. Metzger, cherished grandmother of Marcie, Debbie and Leslie and spouses Simon Nadler and Adam Falik, adored great-grandmother of Allison and Emily Nadler. Services Sunday 1 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Excited Welcome for Clinton, Part Celebrity, Part Hero
description: It happened twice: the president of the United States, his face glowing, walked right up to Dang Dinh Hiep, grasped his hand and gave him a brilliant smile. Then he returned and did it again.

title: VIRTUAL CAMPUS
description: A humanities professor and an entrepreneur have devised a multimillion-dollar plan to put college courses online. It's not everybody's idea of progress. A report by James Traub in The Times Magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMPSEY, ARTHUR J.
description: DEMPSEY-Arthur J. of St. Simons Island, age 69, died November 16, 2000. He is survived by his wife of thirty-nine years, Joan-Marie Dempsey of St. Simons; daughter, Ellen M. Dempsey of St. Simons; son, Brian J. Dempsey of Vashon, Washington; one grandson, Forest Dempsey of Vashon. Mr. Dempsey was a member of the Knickerbocker Country Club of Tenafly, New Jersey, the Sea Island Golf Club and the Hampton Club of St. Simons. Mr. Dempsey was a retired attorney. A visitation will be from 2 until 4pm on Monday at the Edo Miller and Sons Funeral Home. The family suggests donations to the American Cancer Society of Glynn County, the American Red Cross or a charity of the donors choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AINSBERG, DAVID M.
description: AINSBERG-David M. Died peacefully in his 96th year on November 17th. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Mourned by his sister Jeannette Ikka, brothers Louis and Bernard, stepson Mel Mandell, sister-in-law Zelda, grandson, greatgrandchildren, nephews, and niece, and many friends. Services at Young Israel of the West Side, 210 West 91st Street at 1 PM, on Sunday, November 19th.

title: Groh in a Rush to Slow Dolphins' Ground Game
description: The word from Miami filtered its way to New York that Dolphins running back Lamar Smith had sustained a hamstring injury and was on the team's injured list. While Smith was listed as probable, the Jets were not about to plan for anything but Smith at his best when the teams meet on Sunday.

title: Putter Lets Sorenstam Down on No. 18
description: Annika Sorenstam left the golf course today a little angry at herself, and very angry about her putting. If you looked at her face, and did not look at the leader board, you would have never suspected that she was tied for the lead.

title: The Slow Countdown to a New Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATTIKER, BARBARA GILMAN
description: WATTIKER-Barbara Gilman. Beloved wife of the late Bernard J. Wattiker, M.D. Beloved mother of Katherine Olivetti, Virginia Sheerin, William Wattiker, Paula Majors, Barbara Stellway, and Peter Wattiker. Brother of William Gilman. Grandmother of Cristina Spencer, Peter Olivetti, Geoffrey Wattiker, Virginia Wattiker, Jane Wattiker, Christopher Smiles, Rebecca Bodemuller, Diana Stellway, Nicholas Stellway, Elizabeth Wattiker, Bernard Wattiker, and Catherine Wattiker. Services Saturday, 11:30 AM, at First Congregational Church, Marietta, OH. Visitation McClure & Schaeffer, Marietta, OH. Donations to Dr. Robert Cancro, Chairman, Dept. of Psychiatry NYU Med Center, 550 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016.

title: Elections Officials Focus of Lobbying From Both Camps
description: Bruce Rogow, a highly regarded lawyer representing the Palm Beach County elections supervisor, has heard unsolicited legal advice this week from almost everyone he knows. But he said he was most surprised by a phone call Thursday morning from a stranger, Warren Christopher, the former secretary of state who is leading Vice President Al Gore's recount effort in Florida.

title: Fingers Blur But Lyricism Wins Out Over Speed
description: To hear the 28-year-old pianist Arcadi Volodos play is to take a time trip to a bygone era of Russian Romantic piano playing. A few thousand people were deliriously excited to take that trip with Mr. Volodos on Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINTEL, SYLVIA R.
description: GINTEL-Sylvia R. Cherished wife of the late Sidney. Loving mother of Carol and Barry. Dear sister of the late Adele Arnstein and sisterin-law of Samuel Arnstein. Adored by her cousins, nieces and nephews. Devoted friend of many. A true lady who will be missed forever. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 10:30AM Sunday. Contributions to Multiple Sclerosis Society appreciated.

title: A Day of Twists and Turns in the Courts
description: As in Day 10, most of the action in Day 11 of the presidential election yesterday focused on the face-off in the courts. Here are the day's highlights.

title: INVESTORS MAKE ANOTHER BID FOR GUEST SUPPLY
description: Guest Supply Inc., Monmouth Junction, N.J., said a group of investors led by Barry W. Florescue had offered to buy the company, which sells housekeeping supplies to hotels, for about $139 million, or $21 a share. Guest Supply said it was reviewing the offer and would make a recommendation to shareholders. It was the second bid for Guest in six months by the group, whose holding company, the BFMA Holding Corporation, owns the Marietta Corporation, a supplier of soaps, shampoos amd similar products to hotels. BFMA, which owns 4.7 percent of Guest Supply, offered to buy the rest for $24 a share in June but was rebuffed. Shares of Guest Supply closed yesterday at $18.31.

title: Rally Fueled by Election Ruling Slips on Investor Worries
description: Stocks ended slightly lower yesterday after rallying briefly on hopes that the presidential election would be decided soon and then falling as investors worried about slowing economic growth and the effect that would have on corporate earnings.

title: New Law Ends Time Limits On Wrongful Death Lawsuits
description: Filling in for Gov. Christie Whitman, the New Jersey Senate president, Donald T. DiFrancesco, yesterday signed into law a measure that eliminates a two-year statute of limitations on wrongful death lawsuits involving victims of murder or manslaughter.

title: Religion Journal; Believer and Skeptic See Spirituality in Medicine
description: The Roman Catholic archbishop of Milan, Cardinal Carlo Maria Martini, is known as an innovator, the creator of a series of public events at his city's cathedral, in which two participants -- one a religious believer, the other a nonbeliever -- discuss the search for meaning and significance in a given subject area.

title: ISLANDERS CONSIDER MAKING CHANGES
description: The Islanders fans clamoring to take a wrecking ball to the roster are not alone. Coach Butch Goring sounds as if he is right there with them.

title: May the Best Man Lose
description: The Gods of Bloviation have spoken. It's the Florida Fiasco. It's thisclose to a Constitutional Crisis. Maybe, declared ABC's Cokie Roberts last Sunday, it's ''the most partisan time that we have seen in our lives.'' Or, as the Dean of D.C., David Broder, sermonized, ''This nation has rarely appeared more divided than it does right now.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKOFF, SAMUEL
description: BECKOFF-Samuel, former chairman of the English Department at Music & Art High School, died Friday at the age of eighty-five. Dr. Beckoff taught at City College and Yeshiva University. He was the author of several textbooks, two novels and a family memoir. He had taught and chaired the English Department at Long Island City High School and taught at Queens Vocational High School. He is survived by two daughters Laurie Wellman and Jill Nagy; four grandchildren and a great-granddaughter. His wife, the former Beatrice Ehrlich, predeceased him. Funeral services will be private. Those who wish to, may make donations to Alumni and Friends of LaGuardia High School of the Arts, PO Box 231485, New York, New York 10023-1479. For further information, contact Bryce Funeral Home Inc., Troy, New York, 518-272-7281.

title: Lieutenant Governor Plays a Waiting Game in Texas
description: When the networks mistakenly called the presidential election for Gov. George W. Bush a seeming lifetime ago, the crowd of friends and family inside the state Capitol office of Lt. Gov. Rick Perry erupted in hugs and cheers. They were happy for Mr. Bush, but mostly for Mr. Perry, who would now become governor of Texas.

title: Staten Island Teenager Is Shot and Killed for $100 in Coins
description: A 15-year-old was shot and killed just steps from the front door of his family's house in Staten Island when he struggled with two men who stole more than $100 in rolled coins from his father's business, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVOY, RICHELLE (NEE COHEN)
description: LEVOY-Richelle (nee Cohen). At the age of 34. Beloved wife of David Levoy. Devoted daughter of Stuart & Elaine Cohen. Loving sister of Jennifer, Rebecca and Steven. Daughter-in-law of Irene Levoy Good & Cal Good. Services Sunday 2 PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLONEY, JOHN J., CPA.
description: MOLONEY-John J., CPA. On November 16, 2000, at his home in his 79th year. Retired CFO and Sr. Vice President of The Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center and formerly of Roosevelt Hospital. Beloved son of the late Edward and Mary Ellen Sheehan Moloney. Dearest husband of Helen (nee Kane). Cherished father of Arthur of Floral Park, Mary Ellen Lohne of Garden City and Bernadette McKinney of Mountain Lakes, New Jersey. Loving grandfather of Megan Eileen and the late John Andrew Lohne and Patrick Arthur McKinney. Fond brother of Anne Vegliante, Maureen Moloney, Patricia Marx and the late Edward Moloney. Respected brother-inlaw of the late Monsignor Arthur J. Kane and the late Dr. Edwin P. Kane. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing Barnes-Sorrentino Funeral Home, 539 Hempstead Ave., West Hempstead (1 mile North Exit 17N SS Pkwy) on Saturday and Sunday, 24:30 and 7-9:30. Mass of Christian burial, St. Thomas the Apostle RC Church, West Hempstead, on Monday at 11 AM. Interment at Calvary Cemetery, Woodside.

title: Landscape Pioneers: A Tribute
description: EVEN though we may walk our dogs or eat a sandwich in the same park every day, or rush across it to take a shortcut to the bus, or gaze in rapture at a national park from a road coursing through the Great Smoky Mountains, how many of us know who created those green pockets of inspiration and sanity.

title: The Slow Countdown to a New Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, BETTY GATOFF
description: HOWARD-Betty Gatoff. Of Rye, NY, on November 16, 2000, in her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Robert L. Howard. Cherished mother of Doris (Robert) Gilbert and Dr. Elliott (Ulla). Adored grandmother of Paige, Jon, Carl, James and Edward. Dearest Gammy of Jason, Randy, Haley, Ari, Marley and Dillan. Fondly remembered as ''Aunt'' Betty to generations of Camp Seneca in the Berkshires children. Services are private.

title: Burmese Need Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Union To Sell Most Of Its Stores To Supplier
description: Grand Union, the bankrupt supermarket chain, said yesterday that it would sell 185 of its 197 stores to the Vermont grocery wholesale company that had been its major supplier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, NORMA
description: SIEGEL-Norma. Graveside services will be held 11AM Sunday, November 19, 2000 at The Crestlawn Memorial Park. Mrs. Siegel was preceded in death by her husband Dr. Irving Siegel. Survivors include sons, Stefan and Dr. Robert Siegel. For further information contact Greenlawn Jewish Funeral Directors at 404-876-4311.

title: ELECTRONIC EXCHANGE OPENS
description: As traditional European stock exchanges pursue inconclusive efforts to create a pan-European bourse, a new electronic network called Jiway began limited trading in 320 British, Swedish and French stocks. Jiway is owned by OM Gruppen of Sweden, whose hostile bid for the London Stock Exchange failed last week, and by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. Initial volume on Jiway was light, traders said. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: The Slow Countdown to a New Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: Charter School Poll
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Rulings By 2 Courts on Recounts
description: Following are excerpts from rulings yesterday in which the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, rejected a request to block manual recounts in Florida and Judge Terry P. Lewis of Leon County Circuit Court denied a motion to force the Florida secretary of state to accept hand-counted votes tallied after the state's Nov. 14 deadline:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, ANNE YOULE
description: STEIN-Anne Youle. Philanthropist and retired lumber executive, widow of the late Everett Stein, died on Friday, November 17, 2000, at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, New York, at age 101. Mrs. Stein's philanthropies were directed primarily to medical research. At the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center she endowed the Anne Youle Stein Center for Clinical Orthopedic Research, the Anne Youle Stein Professorship in Orthopedic Surgery, the Everett Stein and Anne Youle Stein Center for Orthopedic Education and Research and the Everett Stein and Anne Youle Stein Fellowship in Advanced Studies. Also at Dartmouth College, the Youle Family Scholarship in International Affairs. Mrs. Stein was a volunteer with UNICEF from 1971 through 1994, serving on the Board of Directors, Executive Committee and Greeting Card Committee. Mrs. Stein was born in Hartford, CT, and studied at Columbia University and Hunter College. She is survived by two nephews, John J. Youle of Peru and Donald Rappaport of Washington, D.C., six grand-nieces, three grand-nephews, two great-grandnieces and one great-grandnephew. Graveside services will be held on Sunday, November 19, at 3 PM at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ. Information the Higgins Home For Funerals, Plainfield, NJ.

title: CITIGROUP POLISH UNIT TO CUT 22% OF WORK FORCE
description: Bank Handlowy S.A., Poland's largest commercial lender, which is mainly owned by Citigroup , will cut its work force by 22 percent by the end of 2001 to cut costs as it merges with another Citigroup unit, Citibank (Poland) S.A. Handlowy earlier said the total costs connected with the merger would amount to 200 million zloty ($43.8 million). It did not disclose separate spending figures for employment cuts alone. Citigroup bought 88 percent of Handlowy in February.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JELLINGER, JUNE
description: JELLINGER-June. On November 13, 2000. Loving mother of Robert and the late Fern. Dear mother in law of Linda. Adoring grandmother of Alexandra. Service Sunday 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Daimler Warns On Earnings; Ousts Executive
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., acknowledging that problems at Chrysler are even worse than when it reported a $512 million loss three weeks ago, vowed a major shake-up that began today with the ouster of its American president, James P. Holden.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about layoffs at TheStreet.com misstated the current occupation of James J. Cramer, a co-founder. He is president of Cramer, Berkowitz & Company, a hedge fund based in New York. He is not a former fund manager.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VERITAS CAPITAL FUND L.P., -- New York, an investment firm, has announced plans to buy Stellex Electronics, San Jose, Calif., a maker of parts for the military and telecommunications industries, for $87.5 million in cash. Veritas also named a chief executive, Gary Bloom, formerly a senior executive at Oracle Corp., replacing Mark Leslie, who will remain as chairman.

title: Democrats 'Need Miracle' in Crucial Senate Race
description: In the nation's last undecided Senate race, Washington State Democrats believe that the incumbent Republican will win by a slim margin, depriving them of the seat they need for an even split of the chamber.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the selection of new category suffixes for Internet addresses misstated the surname of the president of the National Cooperative Business Association, which will manage one new category, ''.coop.'' He is Paul Hazen, not Harven.

title: Book Leads Anthropologists to Look Inward
description: Rocked by accusations of unethical practices by researchers studying the primitive Yanomami people in Venezuela, anthropologists have taken the first step to re-examine their own culture, the way they delve into the mores of other cultures.

title: In Northern Vietnam Countryside, a Village Takes to Hillary Clinton
description: While her husband drew overflow crowds and delivered a soaring speech to university students, Hillary Rodham Clinton struck a more intimate note today, going to this dusty village outside Hanoi to meet with women helped by a foreign lending program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODSIDE, WILLIAM STEWART
description: WOODSIDE-William Stewart, of Scottsdale, AZ and Litchfield, CT, formerly of New York City, on November 15, 2000 of chronic pulmonary lung disease, at home in the arms of his loving wife, Migs. A deeply loved and loving husband, companion and closest friend for 30 years to his wife. Beloved father of William S. Woodside III, Anne D. Gruzdowich and Samuel T. Woodside. Generous, caring and loving stepfather of Geoffrey Dann and Deborah Dann, and caring father-in-law to Terri Woodside and Lauri Novick. Proud and delighted grandfather of Benjamin and Jacob Woodside, Rebecca and Emily Dann, and also Emily and Nicholas Gruzdowich. Devoted brother-in-law of Lewis W. Bernard. A man of enormous accomplishment and achievement, extraordinary intellect and talent, whose incredible courage and determination in spite of physical adversity was an inspiration to all. Good night sweet prince, may flights of angels see you to your dreams. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, November 29th at 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Please send contributions to the Children of Alcoholics Foundation, C/O Phoenix House, 164 W. 74th St., New York, New York 10024.

title: On College Football; Only Known Cure for B.C.S. Blues: Victory
description: So far, the Oklahoma Sooners have demonstrated how to master the Bowl Championship Series standing: win all your games. It worked for the two undefeated teams in last year's national title game, Florida State and Virginia Tech. Tennessee took the same computer-proof path to the championship game in 1998.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, former president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, included an erroneous date from the organization for the first ordination of a woman as a rabbi in the American Reform movement. The rabbi, Sally J. Priesand, was ordained in 1972, not 1973.

title: G.O.P.'s Help for Absentees In a County Is in Court, Too
description: When the chairman of Florida's Republican Party needed some advice two years ago on how far the party could go to help Republicans obtain absentee ballots, he turned to the secretary of state for some advice.

title: Pinch Hitter Comes to the Rescue at the Met
description: Is the karma just not right between the Bulgarian mezzo-soprano Vesselina Kasarova and the Metropolitan Opera? Two seasons ago, Ms. Kasarova, a major new artist, was scheduled to make her Met debut as Rosina in ''The Barber of Seville.'' She withdrew because of illness. Her long-awaited debut was to have come on Thursday as Octavian in this season's first presentation of Strauss's ''Rosenkavalier'' in the realistic 1969 production by Nathaniel Merrill. But three weeks ago Ms. Kasarova withdrew from all seven of her scheduled Octavians, again citing illness. It's hard not to see other factors at play. These were to be her first performances of this touchstone German role, which is a vocal leap from the bel canto fare with which she has mostly earned her reputation.

title: Arts Center Plan Is Sole Bid to Restore Armory
description: A nonprofit group of civic leaders who propose to turn the dilapidated Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue into an important arts center has submitted the only bid for rehabilitating and operating it, state officials said yesterday.

title: Bishop, From Experience, Smooths Way for Immigrants
description: AS chairman of the Roman Catholic bishops' committee that deals with immigration issues, Bishop Nicholas DiMarzio holds a privileged vantage point from which to survey a profound change occurring within the Catholic church in the United States.

title: Bereft of Hits, Reprising Golden Oldies
description: WHEN all else fails, when you sense the audience starting to drift toward the exits, go with whatever worked for you before. Stand-up comics know this. So do cabaret singers. Also newspaper columnists, while we're at it.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Johnny Paul Penry, a mentally retarded man facing execution for murder in Texas, misspelled the middle name of his victim. She was Pamela Moseley Carpenter, not Mosley.

title: No Excuses Necessary As Knicks Defeat Suns
description: Controversy's child, Latrell Sprewell, had found himself immersed in conflict again. But this time it was because of his play.

title: Memo Outlining Overseas Rules
description: Following is an excerpt from a memorandum regarding absentee ballots sent to county election officials on Nov. 13 by Katherine Harris, Florida's secretary of state. The ''last Tuesday'' to which she was referring was Election Day; the Friday was yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The history we leave behind is painful and hard. We must not forget it but we must not be controlled by it.''

title: DEAL ON RUSSIAN TV STAKE
description: OAO Gazprom, Russia's natural gas monopoly, agreed to sell a minority stake in NTV television, a private station that reaches 110 million people, to overseas buyers as part of an accord to settle unpaid debts owed by Media Most. The agreement to resolve $504.5 million in debt is similar to one signed last week that Media Most executives said was abruptly canceled by the government. It calls for the sale of 25 percent plus one share in NTV to foreign investors for at least $90 million. Deutsche Bank is to handle the sale, which is still subject to appoval by the courts.

title: The Cost of Crossing the Hudson
description: Commuters may soon have to pay more to cross the Hudson River. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is considering a plan to increase tolls at several bridges and tunnels, as well as fares on the PATH train under the river. Such a move is long overdue. Price hikes are inherently painful, but these are worth applauding, if not demanding, as a matter of fairness and a means to fight congestion.

title: The Slow Countdown to a New Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: In Switch, Miami-Dade Orders Hand Recount
description: Spurred by a series of court decisions that favored the Democrats and by arguments from lawyers for the Democratic Party, election officials here reversed themselves tonight and decided to allow a manual recount of ballots in Miami-Dade County, the state's most populous.

title: Nader Sees Greens Building Status as a Major Party
description: Ralph Nader, who drew 2.8 million votes 3 percent of the total -- as the Green Party's presidential candidate, contended today that the Green Party was the fastest growing in the nation and would achieve major-party status within 12 years.

title: Clinton in Vietnam, and America's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERR, KENNETH W., JR.
description: KERR-Kenneth W., Jr. Of Newburgh, NY. A New York City Firefighter, entered into rest on Wednesday, November 15, 2000, at Jacobi Hospital, Bronx, NY. He was 44. He was born in the Bronx January 19, 1956 the son of Kenneth Sr. and Patricia Banks Kerr. He served in the U.S. Air Force 1973-1977. Kenneth was also a member of the Emerald Society, Holy Name Society, an Amateur Model Flyer, and an avid Scuba Diver. Kenneth is survived by his loving wife Lorraine Bruno Kerr at home, two sons; Kenneth W. Kerr III and Kevin Kerr of Newburgh, two daughters; Kelly Kerr and Karalyn Kerr also of Newburgh, one brother, Russell Vance of Florida, two sisters; Mary Ann and her husband Richard Day of Poughquag, NY, Patricia Dillon of Florida; one nephew Richard Day, Jr. of Poughquag, NY and one niece; Lance Corporal Colleen Day of Hawaii; one predeceased brother; Michael Vance. Friends and relatives may call on Saturday, Nov. 18 and Sunday, Nov. 19, 2000 from 2-4 & 7-9 PM at the Coloni Funeral Home, Route 9w, New Windsor. Funeral Mass will be held at 10:30 AM on Monday, Nov. 20, 2000 at St. Patrick's Church, Grand St., Newburgh, NY. Interment will be at Cedar Hill Cemetery, Newburgh, NY.

title: The Slow Countdown to a New Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: In Washington, a Close Race and a Balance of Power Tip Toward the Republican Side
description: In the nation's last undecided Senate race, Democrats now believe that the incumbent Republican will hold on by a narrow margin, depriving them of the seat needed for an even split of the chamber.

title: Young Pirates Catch Up With Lane's Fast Start
description: Darius Lane looked as if he had been at the wrong end of a sucker punch. By halftime his left eyelid was swollen and a purplish bruise had formed above his cheekbone. He retreated to the bench at the end of the game and pressed an ice bag to his face.

title: Florida's High Court Steps In
description: At a time when the nation's political system desperately needed a controlling legal authority, the Florida Supreme Court acted decisively yesterday to assure continuation of the best possible vote count in the state that will decide the election. Acting on its own motion, the court enjoined Florida's partisan secretary of state, Katherine Harris, from prematurely certifying the presidential election results today and thus summarily declaring Gov. George W. Bush the winner. The state's highest court is scheduled to hold a hearing on Monday to consider questions concerning the legality of the ongoing hand counts and Ms. Harris's claim that she has authority to ignore all late returns.

title: Four-Day Week to Become Five For State Troopers in New Jersey
description: With troopers' morale already suffering after an uproar over racial profiling, the superintendent of the New Jersey State Police announced yesterday that he was replacing the force's four-day work week with a five-day schedule.

title: Judge Leaves Chads, Dimpled or Otherwise, to Discretion of Recount Team
description: A Broward County judge here said today that elections officials recounting the county's presidential ballots need not reject ballots on which voters did not perforate the punchcards.

title: Ace Ltd. in Stock Buyback
description: Ace Ltd., a large insurance company, said today that it would buy back up to $250 million worth of its stock over an unspecified period of time. The buyback represents about 2.7 percent of the company's shares. Ace, which is based in Hamilton, has about $30 billion in assets. Its stock closed today at $40, up 19 cents.

title: INSIDE
description: Arafat Orders End to Gunfire

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTTER, CATHERINE T.
description: COTTER-Catherine T. on November 17, 2000 of Breezy Point, NY. Loving wife of the late William. Dear mother of Gerald, Eileen, Donald & Gregory. Also survived by eleven grandchildren. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset on Sunday from 3-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass on Monday 9:30 am, St. Peter of Alcantara R.C. Church, Pt. Washington. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRVING, MALCOLM
description: IRVING-Malcolm. Died at his home in Wilton, Conn. at age 84 on November 14. Survived by his wife Roberta & sons Alan and Anthony and grandchildren, Preston and Elizabeth. In World War II served as 1st Lieutenant in British Navy. He worked in New York and CT.

title: JAPANESE CHEMICAL MERGER
description: The Sumitomo Chemical Company agreed to merge with Mitsui Chemicals to form the biggest chemical company in Asia, in a transaction valued at about $6.9 billion. The merger will take effect in October 2003 when the two form a new holding company that will probably sell shares to the public. Detailed terms will not be announced until March. The two companies said, meanwhile, that they would combine their polyethylene and polypropylene businesses in a 50-50 joint venture next October. The combined chemical companies would have group sales of 1.83 trillion yen ($17 billion). No job cuts are planned.

title: United Gets Order Against Its Mechanics
description: A federal judge issued a temporary restraining order yesterday directing mechanics at United Airlines to stop engaging in what the airline asserted was an orchestrated campaign that had forced it to cancel scores of flights in recent days.

title: Floridians Abroad Are Counted, or Not, as Counties Interpret 'Rules' Differently
description: The tally of overseas absentee ballots by county officials across Florida today yielded rampant confusion, partisan wrangling over which votes to count and which to discard, and widespread uncertainty about the rules on what makes for a valid ballot.

title: Baroque by the Experts
description: To open its third season on Monday evening at the Ethical Culture Society, the New York Collegium offered a program of orchestral works mostly composed for the court at Dresden in the early 18th century. Reinhard Goebel, one of five guest conductors for the five programs this season, was on the podium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, DENNIS
description: SINGER-Dennis. The Board of Trustees of the Have A Heart Foundation extends their sympathies to the family of our past president and loyal board member. He exemplified our credo ''that provision for others is a fundamental responsibility of human life''.

title: Battle Lines Drawn Over Ergonomic Rules; Business Pitted Against Washington
description: Washington wants American business to be ergonomically correct, but it will have a big fight on its hands.

title: The Forgotten Debt to Vietnam
description: As President Clinton talked with officials in Hanoi this week, he undoubtedly hoped to lay groundwork for more progress in what is already a much improved relationship with Vietnam. And chances are his hosts, who have much to gain from stronger ties, did what they could to build a case that a friendly and prosperous Vietnam is very much in America's interest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, ALICE
description: BLOOM-Alice. Wife of Dr. Samuel J. Bloom (deceased), age 91 on November 16th in Los Angeles. Died in peace after a long life filled with joy. Loving Mother to sons Dr. Joseph Bloom and Jake Bloom, cherished daughters-in-law Jackie and Ruth, grandchildren Nancy, Paul, Richard, Jason and Rebecca and great grandchildren Zoey, Rachel, Olivia and Lena. Funeral Service to be held at 12:30 Sunday, November 19 at Wellwood Cemetery, Wellwood Ave, Pinelawn, Long Island, NY.

title: ING CONSIDERS SELLING AMERICAN BANKING BUSINESS
description: ING, the Dutch financial services company, is considering the sale of its United States investment banking business, ING Barings, executives close to the company said yesterday. The company has hired Goldman, Sachs to advise it, and although the discussions are focusing on the American unit, they might also extend to ING's other investment banking operations in Asia, Europe and Latin America. Shedding the investment banking operation would be a turnaround for ING, which has been trying to bolster its investment banking businesses and has been expanding in the United States, mostly in insurance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRVING, EDWARD C.
description: IRVING-Edward C. Suddenly on November 15, 2000. Beloved son of Augusta and the late Val Irving. Services Sunday 1PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, GERALD
description: STEINBERG-Gerald. The members and staff of the Falls Country Club, Lake Worth, Fl. wish to express their sincere condolences to our fellow member, Paula Steinberg, and family, on the passing of her beloved husband, Gerald. The Board of Governors Kenneth Mahler, President

title: Clinton in Vietnam, and America's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: F.S.U. Hex Haunting Florida's Title Hopes
description: Amid the furor in Tallahassee, Fla., this week over the counting of votes to determine this country's next president, several dozen Florida State students used the forum to show their affection for the venerable Seminoles coach Bobby Bowden. Some ''Bowden for President'' placards were visible when the television cameras were turned on.

title: Another Round of Layoffs At U.S. Firestone Factories
description: Stuck with a huge inventory of Firestone tires and slow sales because of the current recall, Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. announced its second round of job cuts in a month today, saying that nearly 1,100 factory workers would be laid off for at least five months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAMARIN, LILLIAN, M.D.
description: TAMARIN-Lillian, M.D. Wife of the late Alfred Tamarin and the late Carlton Barlow. Mother of Susan Eluard (Alain). Grandmother of Nathalie Hurwitz (Jonathan) and Lauren Eluard. A graduate of NYU Medical School, she was a member of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis and a practicing Analyst for 50 years. Contributions in her memory may be sent to Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital. A Memorial Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., on Saturday, November 18 at 3:30 PM.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Second Round of Layoffs Because of Firestone Recall

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, RONALD HAROLD
description: CLARK-Ronald Harold. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Sylvia Clark. Deeply treasured father of Alice Marcia Clark. Cherished father-in-law of Doctor Peter B. Schiff. Adored granddad of Sarah Clark Schiff and Jenny Clark Schiff. Devoted son of the late Bernice Ethel Clark and Harold George Clark. Dear brother of Neville Clark and the late Gerald Clark and dear brother-in-law of Lorraine Clark. Let the memory be green.

title: Confusion in Counting
description: The tallying of overseas absentee ballots in Florida led to uncertainty, confusion and partisan dispute in a process that added to the lead of Gov. George W. Bush. Page A11.

title: Networks and Web Sites Keep Manual Tallies Off Screen
description: Network news executives and Web site operators said yesterday that they had decided for the time being to add only the new numbers from the tabulation of overseas ballots -- and not partial results from the continuing hand recounts -- to their on-screen running tallies of the presidential vote in Florida.

title: Champion of Human Survival Tries to Awaken Academics to a Nuclear Menace
description: Dr. Robert Jay Lifton has spent more than half a century pondering subjects like genocide, terrorism and nuclear extinction, but he says he is not gloomy: ''One's life work can be devoted to dreadful events without becoming deeply pessimistic.''

title: FLORIDA COURT BARS NAMING A WINNER; BUSH LEAD GROWS WITH OVERSEAS TALLY
description: The Florida Supreme Court barred the state today from certifying official results in the presidential election until the court rules on the disputed vote. It allowed a manual recount in three Democratic counties and the continued counting of overseas absentee ballots statewide, which more than doubled the 300-vote lead of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

title: Angel to Some, Bookkeeper Pleads Guilty to Stealing $8.2 Million
description: A bookkeeper for a Manhattan publisher pleaded guilty yesterday to grand larceny charges for stealing millions of dollars from her employer. The bookkeeper, Fidela Caparas, sent a large portion of the stolen funds to charities in her native Philippines.

title: LATIN PHONE VENTURE SET
description: Telefonos de Mexico, Bell Canada International and SBC Communications said they had completed a deal to form a joint venture, Telecom Americas Ltd., to expand into the rapidly growing cellular and Internet services markets of Brazil, Argentina, Venezuela and Colombia. Bell Canada and America Movil, a recent wireless spinoff of Telmex, will each own 44.3 percent, and SBC, 11.4 percent. Carlos Slim Helu, president of Telmex, will be chairman of Telecom Americas; Daniel Hajj, now president of America Movil, will be chief executive.

title: Governors Rise to Defense of Bush and Election Official
description: The nation's Republican governors contended today that the Gore campaign was ''brutally abusing'' the good name of Florida's top election official and seriously threatening the foundations of American democracy by continuing to challenge the results of the state's presidential balloting.

title: The Gandhi Dynasty
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy's Top Insurer to Pay $100 Million on Holocaust-Era Policies
description: Italy's largest insurance company, Assicurazioni Generali, has agreed to pay up to $100 million to Holocaust-era policyholders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILDE, ROSE EILEEN (NEE MCGROARTY)
description: MILDE-Rose Eileen (nee McGroarty). On Thursday, November 16, 2000. Beloved wife of Edward. Loving mother of Michael and his wife Maureen of Succasunna, NJ; Jim and his wife Marybeth of Succasunna, NJ; Joseph and his wife Susan of Mendham, NJ and Mary Homa and her husband Michael of Baltimore, MD. Predeceased by four brothers; Judge J. Courtney McGroarty; William McGroarty; Frank McGroarty; and Rev. Joseph G. McGroarty. A funeral Liturgy will be held at St. Patrick's RC Church, 85 Washington Ave, Chatham, NJ on Monday, November 20th at 11am. Friends may call at the Wm A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main Street (Rt 124), Chatham on Saturday from 7-9pm and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm. For further information go to www.bradleyfuneralhome.com

description: To the Editor:

description: Juried Fine Arts Exhibition

title: Filmmaker Was Obscure, Not Dead
description: Some would consider the Puerto Rican filmmaker Tony Felton an obscure cinematic figure. But his admirers -- Spanish-language movie buffs and historians -- thought he was dead.

title: Texas Approaches A Dubious Record for Death
description: In Huntsville, Tex., Johnny Paul Penry, a mentally retarded man who raped and murdered a woman in 1979, was granted a stay of execution by the United States Supreme Court less than four hours before he was to be killed by lethal injection. The court said the stay would last until it decides whether to hear Mr. Penry's appeal, which could take several weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELGLASS, STEPHEN MARK
description: EDELGLASS-Stephen Mark. Died November 17, age 64. Born Brooklyn, NY. Teacher, author, scientist. Survived by beloved wife Hanna, and children from first marriage William and Alexandra. Funeral services: Threefold Auditorium, Hungry Hollow Rd., Spring Valley, NY, 1 PM, November 21. Memorial donations will further his work: SENSRI, 23 Hutchins St., Saratoga Springs, NY 12866.

title: The Changing Face of Shops
description: THERE'S more to shopping than meets the eye: ''The City Shops: Photographs by Martha Cooper and Fred W. McDarrah'' examines shops as neighborhood focal points and signs of changing economic patterns. Ms. Cooper is a photographer with a degree in ethnology who has devoted many years to documenting New York. Mr. McDarrah has been a consulting picture editor and photographer at The Village Voice since 1959. Fifty of their images of shop fronts are displayed in thematic sections; ''Showing Off'' explores the way neighborhood shopkeepers display (or hide) their merchandise, like the Flat Fixed Tire Shop, shown above, in Bedford Park, the Bronx. ''Changing Stores, Changing Streets'' looks at traditional and new ways of shopping, and ''Places That Matter'' presents the social and political role of neighborhood shops.

title: Special Education Hearings Shouldn't Require Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROW, IRVING
description: TROW-Irving. 82. Of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of Bayside, NY. Passed away November 17, 2000. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Joyce Steinman, cherished grandfather of Kenneth and Jason Steinman. Judge Trow was chief Administrative Law Judge of New York State for many years. Services were held in Florida.

description: OLIVIA Written and illustrated by Ian Falconer. Unpaged. New York: An Anne Schwartz Book/ Atheneum Books for Young Readers. $16. (Ages 3 to 7)

description: Duckpin bowling is to the sinew of this city as H. L. Mencken is to its sass.

description: Best Bet

description: THE TWILIGHT YEARS Paris in the 1930's. By William Wiser. Carroll & Graf, $26.

title: Officials Say Ferry's Wiring Caused Fire
description: A fire on a commuter ferry that travels between Weehawken, N.J., and Manhattan was apparently caused by faulty wiring in the engine room, a ferry company spokesman and fire officials said yesterday.

title: Getting a Pre-Enrollment Report Card
description: HERE are some points to consider when selecting an online advanced-degree program:

title: Without Its Top Running Back, Army Cannot Keep Pace With U.A.B.
description: Army's first-year head coach, Todd Berry, scrapped the Black Knights' wishbone for a multidimensional offense this season. Today, with the team's best running back, Michael Wallace, out because of injury, the attack was missing one dimension completely against Alabama-Birmingham.

title: Japan Rail Passes
description: To the Editor: Re ''What's Doing in Tokyo,'' by Howard W. French (Oct. 8), my husband and I have just returned from celebrating our 50th wedding anniversary in Japan. We traveled with rail passes from Tokyo to Kamakura, Osaka, Kyoto and Hiroshima, as well as in and around Tokyo. The system is so efficient, trains so clean, stations so well marked that it is almost impossible to get lost. When it appeared that we needed help, there was always someone eager to oblige, even with a language barrier, going so far as to escort us to our destination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKERSON, FLORENCE ELLIS
description: DICKERSON-Florence Ellis. Of New Rochelle, NY and NYC, died November 14, 2000. Viewing Sunday, November 19 at Barney McClanahan's Funeral Home, Winthrop Avenue, New Rochelle, NY. Funeral Service Monday, November 20, 10 AM, at The Church of St. Simon the Cyrenian, Remington Place, New Rochelle, NY. Interment at Beechwood Cemetery immediately following the service.

title: Toeing the Line, Together: Giants Party On
description: A good offensive line, the saying goes, works like a clenched fist -- five pieces bonding together.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-32

title: Gore Alters His Plans For Monday
description: Vice President Al Gore tonight canceled plans to attend a conference in Nashville on Monday, his aides said.

title: Ideas & Trends; Ebb and Flow of Opinion: Big Dam Projects
description: IF construction on the mammoth Three Gorges Dam project in central China is completed as scheduled three years from now, a 390-mile reservoir will drive the world's largest hydroelectric plant, providing energy and flood control to a country desperate for both. But the project will also have displaced more than one million people, flooded hundreds of towns and villages and, critics argue, destroyed innumerable cultural heritage sites along the Yangtze River.

title: The City Life; A Field Guide to Public Spaces
description: On my way to work, I usually walk past a dark open slot notched into the side of a tall apartment building on Lexington Avenue. The slot is technically called a variance arcade, though the arch implicit in the word ''arcade'' has been squared off into a kind of savage rectangularity. The size of the arcade is 3,342 square feet, bigger, and also far more dismal, than an average American house. Everything about this arcade suggests only one thing, anxiety. It is brightly, almost hostilely lit at night, and a sign warns against almost every imaginable use, including defecating -- the ultimate indicator of low expectations. You can detect the rationale for the existence of this open space only by looking skyward. By offering an arcade to the public, the builder was allowed to make this building taller than its neighbors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, MURIEL BUSCH
description: GREEN-Muriel Busch. of Stamford, CT, formerly of Jericho, NY, died of pneumonia November 14, 2000 at the age of seventy-seven. Mrs. Green leaves a loving family: two sons and their wives, Peter and Carin, of Port Chester, NY and Roger and Enid, of Newtown, PA, a brother and sister-in-law, Bob and Renee Busch of Fair Lawn, NJ, a sister-in-law, Sylvia Fleischmann of Delray Beach, FL, one nephew, two nieces, four grandchildren and many loving friends and extended family members. We all remember her courage, tenacity, warmth, commitment to family, intellect, grace and generosity, and we all will miss her terribly. A memorial service is being planned for Sunday, November 26 at the home of her son, Peter, in Port Chester, NY. The family requests that any donations be made in her name to the Arthritis Foundation.

title: Children's Books; The Shoe Must Go On
description: SHOE SHOE BABY

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 5 with the Long Island Journal column, about Cutchogue, misidentified a restaurant and the two women shown there. The restaurant was a diner, not an ice cream parlor, and the women were Dottie Reich and an unidentified customer, not Ginger Tomazewski and Virginia Magin. The caption also misstated the name of a farm stand shown in another photo. It was Wickham's Fruit Farm, not Wickham's Farmstand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHRON, RITA SAUL
description: SHRON-Rita Saul. Died Friday, November 17. Beloved wife of William H. Shron. Devoted mother to her daughters, Alissa and Francine and their husbands Bill Rosengarten and Steven Gubb. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer and David Rosengarten and Jesse and Daniel Gubb. Loving daughter of the late Ida and Harry Saul. Loving sister of Ellen Gruber and the late Jerry Saul. Loving sister-in-law to their spouses Arnold and Sandy and loving aunt to many nieces and nephews. Services Monday, 11 AM at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Shiva at her home.

title: POSTINGS: Former Edna St. Vincent Millay House, Narrowest in Greenwich Village, Is Sold; 9 1/2 Feet Wide, $1.6 Million
description: There are few addresses as descriptive as 75 1/2 Bedford Street. That ''half'' tells the story of a house so small -- 9 1/2 feet wide -- that it has long been known as the narrowest in Greenwich Village.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: An elegant woman I knew called me because her husband was about to drag her to SOUTH PARK: BIGGER, LONGER AND UNCUT (1999). ''Is it really funny?'' she asked. ''Or is it just a lot of tasteless adolescent humor?'' ''Yes,'' I said. Trey Parker and Matt Stone, who created the animated Comedy Central series ''South Park,'' have put their foulmouthed little heroes - Stan, Kyle, Cartman and the perennially ill-fated Kenny - on the big screen with hilariously subversive style. The boys sneak into a R-rated Canadian movie and just can't stop using the new words they learn there, which ultimately leads to war with Canada. There's a subplot about Satan's affair with Saddam Hussein. Oh, and it's a musical - Saturday at 8 p.m. on Showtime.

title: It Isn't Easy to Detect Arizona's Weakness
description: Amid the expectations that accompany a No. 1 ranking and comparisons to his 1997 national championship team, the search for perspective has already taken Coach Lute Olson inside his players' heads in Tucson. Real or imagined, even for Olson the weaknesses of the University of Arizona Wildcats are not easily defined.

title: The Glow of the Past Is Restored
description: SOMETIMES when the day's work is done, the master maker of cellos and violins settles down on a seat outside his cottage on the main street of Nagyvazsony, a small town in western Hungary, and begins to play. There are few competing sounds to intrude on his music, except for the barking of dogs. Just beyond the treetops, colorful flags rise and fall on the breeze over the watchtower of a castle commanded by a heroic Hungarian patriot who held off the Turkish invaders centuries ago. Has nothing changed here in several hundred years?

title: Lingering Doubts of Legitimacy, for Whoever Wins
description: Having given only occasional lip service to the need for national unity, each side in the struggle in Florida demonizes the other every single day.

title: LIGHT-RAIL STOPS
description: New Jersey Transit was set to open three new stops yesterday in Jersey City on the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail system, which opened in April: at the Harborside business complex, Harsimus Cove residences and businesses, and at the Newport Newport Center mall. John Holl

title: Yesterday's Technology, Ready for the Future
description: WHAT is more up to the minute than a hybrid-powered car? Or is it, what is more old-fashioned?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 5 about an outreach program for teenagers that uses a colorful mobile home misstated the name of a housing project in Peekskill. It is Bohlmann Towers, not Bolhman Terrace.

title: The Tennis Player
description: Whether she's on the court or off, the Swiss tennis star Martina Hingis keeps up with the pace of fashion. Even if it means having to slam together a comeback wardrobe in record time.

title: Karla Wattman, Sean Juneja
description: Karla Alexandra Wattman and Sean Chander Juneja were married yesterday by Dr. Mahesh Shastri, a Hindu priest, at Diwan, a restaurant in Port Washington, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 5 about Glen Cove's waterfront redevelopment plan misstated the position of the Coalition to Save Hempstead Harbor regarding the high-speed ferry operating between Glen Cove and New London, Conn. The group supported the ferry service if the number of sailings and hours of operation were limited; it did not oppose the service.

title: Ilyse Veron, Myron Marlin
description: Ilyse Jennifer Veron, a reporter, and Myron Laurence Marlin, the chief spokesman for Attorney General Janet Reno, are to be married today in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Shira Milgrom will officiate at Tappan Hill.

title: London Cabbies
description: To the Editor: Last year, while spending a delightful Thanksgiving holiday in London, I had one positive experience after another with cabbies. Here is one example.

title: In Not-So-Green Ireland, the Dispute Over Litter Gets Bitter
description: To hear Dub liners tell it and they do, often -- tourists coming to Ireland these days don't leave with memories of rolling green hills, grazing sheep and craggy coastlines. Instead, thinking back on an Irish vacation conjures up images of squashed soda cans, crumpled newspapers and plastic bags blowing in the wind.

title: Corrections
description: The First Person essay on Nov. 5 about the New York City Marathon misidentified a street on the marathon route in Brooklyn. It is Lafayette Avenue, not Lafayette Street.

title: Season Starts Early For Wimbledon Tickets
description: The annual drama that ends with Center Court's taking center stage at Wimbledon is seven months off, but tennis fans are already ordering tickets, most of which were reserved by putting down deposits as early as May. The matches, at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club, run from June 25 to July 8.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Heidi Smith and Daniel Aronson
description: FRIENDS describe Heidi Medney Smith, 37, as a diehard Brooklynite. She has ridden almost every Brooklyn-bound subway line to the end just to see what was there. She loves ethnic food and cannot stay calm in a traffic jam or in the wilderness. ''Heidi was raised in Flatbush by Dodger fans,'' said Elizabeth Hollander, a friend. ''She's very fast and very bossy. She's full of life and speed and intensity and impatience.''

title: Allies of Bush Attempt to Discredit Recount Procedures
description: As the Bush campaign awaited a hearing by the Florida Supreme Court on Monday, officials with the campaign and its Republican allies yesterday issued some of their harshest charges yet about the conduct of Democrats involved in Florida's hand count of votes in the presidential race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, SOLOMON L.
description: GLUCK-Solomon L. Former teacher, Croton Harmon High School. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Sara Lenes and Paul and Cathy Gluck. Cherished grandfather of Andrew, Elizabeth, Jamie and Jody. Loving brother of Fred and Irene Gluck. Service Sunday, 1 PM, Temple Israel of Northern Westchester.

title: Istanbul
description: To the Editor: I wish to add another day or so to Douglas Frantz's visit to Istanbul (''Two Continents, Three Days,'' Oct. 8).

title: Money, Power and Reading, Writing and 'Rithmetic
description: The union contract for New York City's 78,000 public school teachers expired Wednesday, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is seeking a new contract that will enable him to remake the city's schools. He wants a longer school day, weaker tenure protections and a merit pay system. The union insists these steps would make New York a less attractive place to teach, at a time when it is facing a major teacher shortage. To end the shortage, the union wants Mr. Giuliani to give teachers a 25 percent raise to catch up with the suburbs. Steven Greenhouse

title: A Cookie's Fortunes Turn
description: Many believe that the Year of the Dragon brings new good fortune, and if nothing else, this season it's bringing new fortune cookies. Around town, restaurants and lounges are serving up modernized high-style forms of the traditional prognosticating confection.

For cable networks, finding a common denominator has become less important than divining which arcane enthusiasm will spark the imagination of a generation accustomed to channel-surfing until it hits something unusual.

It is 6 o'clock in the morning and I am being driven west on the M4 motorway past Heathrow Airport, heading for Bray Film Studios near Windsor Castle where, in an hour or so, the first day of filming will begin on ''The Trench'' -- my directorial debut. My mood is, to put it mildly, one of high anxiety.

title: A 'Smooth Operator' Unswayed By Fashion
description: LOVERS ROCK,'' the first collection of new songs in eight years by Sade, is, like all her records, immaculate: slickly played, exquisitely arranged midtempo mood music that leaves nothing to chance.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Americans' dislike of tied scores, as a reflection of the stalemate over the presidential election, referred incorrectly to rules of Japanese baseball, cited as a contrast. The Pacific League in Japan allows up to three extra innings, and the Central League allows up to six. Neither league rules out extra innings.

title: Practical Traveler; Air Tickets Shred a Barrier
description: ELECTRONIC tickets became the majority of sales by United States airlines earlier this year, the lines' financial clearinghouse reports. The figures for September at the clearinghouse, the Airlines Reporting Corporation, showed 57.1 percent of all tickets sold were paperless.

title: Streetscapes /The Donac, at 402 West 20th Street; A Curved 1898 Tribute to a Major Chelsea Developer
description: I JUST love the building, the way it's so gracefully integrated with its neighbors,'' said Marion Buhagiar, who owns the Donac apartment building at 402 West 20th Street and is restoring its curved facade.

Cherished grandfather of Claude, Alexa, Tamara, Ruth, Alex & Paulene. Astute businessman and traveler extraordinaire. Norbert was an exceptionally sensitive and caring man to all who knew him. He will be dearly missed & always loved. Donations may be made in his memory at Winthrop University HospitalHeart Institute, 259 1st St., Mineola, NY 11501 Att: Development Office

title: Cy Young Would Have Approved of These Two
description: One is 5 feet 11 inches tall and right-handed while the other is 6 feet 10 inches tall and left-handed, but Pedro Martinez, 29, of the Boston Red Sox and Randy Johnson, 37, of the Arizona Diamondbacks have some striking similarities. Both are intimidators and both won their second straight Cy Young Award, each one's third overall. Martinez, the shorter one, went 18-6 with a 1.74 earned run average and 284 strikeouts to win the American League honor. Johnson went 19-7 with a 2.64 and a major league-leading 347 strikeouts to win in the National League. Beside Martinez and Johnson, only six other pitchers have won the award at least three times. Jack Curry

title: A President's Custom Seat Still Best in the House
description: PRESIDENT William Howard Taft had to look before he sat: in barbers' or dentists' chairs, in bathtubs, in armchairs. His weight had maxed out at 340 pounds by 1913, according to Frederick C. Hicks in his 1945 book ''William Howard Taft, Yale Professor of Law & New Haven Citizen'' (Yale University Press).

title: Using the Right Breathing Protection
description: MANY building or remodeling projects and household maintenance chores release dust, harmful vapors and mists that can contaminate the air. Breathing this air can introduce dangerous substances into the lungs. Once there, they are carried to other parts of the body through the bloodstream.

title: A Tunnel Turned Deathtrap
description: Austrian soldiers working day and night extracted the bodies of at least 155 skiers from the charred ruins of a cable car that was destroyed by a flash fire in an Alpine tunnel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRISANT, MILLARD
description: PRISANT-Millard. The Officers and Trustees of the Roslyn Preservation Corp. and the Roslyn Landmark Society mourn the loss of their dear friend and dedicated officer. For over two decades, Millard enthusiastically participated in the preservation projects of the unique village of Roslyn, be it the handling of salvaged architectural items, the repair of antique hardware, or the climbing of the scaffold to paint the clock face of the village's Ward Memorial clock tower. A strong supporter of the programs of both organizations, he generously shared his years of experience in preservation and restoration techniques and antique connoisseurship. He and his wife Carol spearheaded many preservation efforts, as well as hosting numerous meetings and events in their historic home. Millard's generosity extended beyond his donation of time and talent. He willingly made many generous contributions to assure the completion and success of the various projects undertaken by the two organizations. His cheerful, enthusiastic and dedicated presence amoung us will be greatly missed, but the restoration of many of Roslyn's historic buildings will serve as a permanent and silent memorial to his esteemed memory.
