title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Toyota Prius; It's Easier to Be Green
description: TOYOTA executives describe their Prius as a ''real car.'' While that might sound like damning a product with faint praise, it is actually a compliment for an alternative vehicle.

title: Riding Her Own Wave
description: When Kate Winslet told her agents that she wanted to follow her Oscar-nominated role in ''Titanic,'' the most successful movie of all time, with a role in ''Hideous Kinky,'' a small movie set in Morocco, they were not happy. ''My agents were miserable,'' says Winslet, laughing at the memory. '' 'O.K.,' they said, 'you're going to ride this enormous wave by making a tiny film in the desert. That's a real good idea.' But they know me. They know I make my own decisions, and I didn't want to get lost or confused by the hugeness of 'Titanic.' I deliberately did not do the whole Hollywood thing. I wanted to go to work every day and know everyone's name on the set. It sounds a little mystical, but I had to look after my soul.''

title: POSTINGS: Rent Guidelines Board Book; Housing Trends In the City
description: For those who want to delve into the intricacies of the city's housing market, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board is about to release its annual compendium of research reports, ''Housing NYC: Rents, Markets and Trends 2000.''

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: PROSPECT HEIGHTS

title: Judge Asked by Democrats To Quash Absentee Ballots
description: The fate of thousands of absentee votes cast in heavily Republican Seminole County remained uncertain this morning as a local judge weighed a Democratic bid to have the ballots thrown out.

title: Reckonings; The Two Larrys
description: Suppose that George W. Bush pulls it off -- that he gets to the White House on the strength of chads and butterflies. Will he make good on his boast of being a ''uniter, not a divider''?

title: Tasty Jazz or a Tuneful Dinner? It's Both
description: FIRST-TIMERS could have been forgiven for thinking that they had stumbled into a casual party rather than a jazz concert. There was chatter from table to table, pockets of laughter and the occasional uncorking of wine bottles before the music started.

title: Weinke, Fighting Flu, Helps Seminoles Lay Claim to Title Game
description: For Florida State, it was a fitting end. Time expired on the Florida Gators tonight as they were at the Seminoles' 1-yard line trying to salvage some respect in an otherwise dismal night. Then the Gators were hit with a rainstorm of oranges as they walked off the field.

title: A Newcomer Whose Chef Is the Draw
description: WHY do some restaurants catch on instantly? Monica Bella in Huntington Station, for instance. Many of the diners who flock here are coming for the food of Angelo Vanegas, the chef and co-owner. They know him from the years he spent in the kitchen of Piccolo, a popular local spot.

title: Newt at Rest
description: In James Traub's profile of Newt Gingrich (Oct. 29), Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster, says that what has happened to Gingrich -- brilliance that is now ignored -- is ''a Shakespearean tragedy.'' Thus, some might decide that Gingrich is ''a man more sinned against than sinning.'' And others might describe him as a ''poor player that struts and frets his hour upon the stage and then is heard no more.''

title: Sports of The Times; Agents' Schemes And Harmful Effects
description: IN sports, the bonanza of multimillion-dollar contracts is like the latest wonder medication. While it eases, if not cures, a particular ailment, it can produce harmful side effects. And just as the free-agent market has turned minions into millionaires, it has had a harmful side effect: the scheming sports agent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, HERMAN A., M.D. (SPIKE)
description: RESNICK - Herman A., M.D. (Spike). of Monteray, CA and Seagate, Brooklyn, NY. Devoted husband of the late Muriel. Beloved father of Amy. Dearest brother of Ralph. Loving grandfather, great grandfather and uncle. Not only will he be remembered by his loving family, but by his many, many patients to whom he devoted so much of himself in his lifetime.

title: The Old Order Changeth
description: Leah Rabin, who died last week of cancer, went out fighting. Even in her last weeks, the wife of the late Prime Minister Yithak Rabin never ceased her acerbic incursions into Israeli public life. She took the outbreak of fighting and the breakdown of peace talks personally. She was, to the end ''keeper of her husband's flame,''' as Hillary Clinton said at the funeral here Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADLER, CHARLES D., ED.D.
description: NADLER-Charles D., Ed.D. Loving husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Suzanne Blum and Bruce. Cherished grandfather of Joy, Sarah, Kerri, Adam and Jason. Funeral services today, 1 PM, at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Click-Click, Clink-Clink
description: Old-school cybercafes attract European backpackers sending e-mail to friends back home. The new Dot.com Lounge, located behind closed doors at the back of the Typhoon Brewery bar in Midtown, caters to crisply dressed investment bankers, brokers and traders whose idea of a good time is swigging imported beer while watching Bloomberg Television.

title: The Election; Of Spinners and Connivers, Puppets and Buffoons
description: As the presidential election devolves into a legal Ping-Pong game and election night turns into a marathon, we thought we would pass along this manuscript, written, it would seem, by a student of a certain 19th-century satirist. Its working title: ''A Novel Without a Hero.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAIN, FRANK MCLELLAN
description: DAIN-Frank McLellan. A retired radiologist and resident of Chapel Hill, North Carolina, died November 11, 2000 at his home. He was 79. Dr. Dain was born December 27, 1920 in Jamaica, N.Y., the son of Marguerite Nason Dain and Frank McLellan Dain, II. He graduated from Dartmouth College in 1943 and received his accelerated medical degree during World War II from Columbia-Presbyterian Medical School in N.Y., N.Y. in 1945. He was an intern and resident at St. Luke's Hospital in New York City. He served in the U.S. Navy from 1942-1948, stationed in Bainbridge, MD. from 1945-1948. On May 27, 1944, he and Blossom Mary Huizer were married in Belleville, N.J. Dr. Dain began practicing at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, New Jersey in 1948, and later opened a radiology practice in Nyack, N.Y., which grew to 8 physicians. Before his retirement in 1982, Dr. Dain was the Chief of ultrasound at St. Luke's Hospital in New York City. He was recognized as one of the early specialists in the nascent field of ultrasound. He and his wife retired to N.C. in 1982 and lived in Tryon and New Bern before moving to Chapel Hill in 1995. Dr. Dain was predeceased by his sister, Grace Mary Stern, in 1998. In addition to his wife of 56 years, survivors include his three children, Joanne Dain Hoag of Dryden, N.Y., Susan Single-Dain of Toronto, Ontario, and Frank Westbrook Dain, of Chapel Hill, N.C., 7 grandchildren, and ten nieces and nephews. Memorials may be made to: Hematology/Oncology Research Gift Fund, Division of Hematology/Oncology, UNC School of Medicine, Campus Box #

title: Children's Books; One Man's Family
description: Jefferson's Children

title: Making Harlem Sweeter, One Pie at a Time
description: AMID the resolutely practical small businesses in western Harlem -- the lace curtain stores, the Koreans selling cheap socks and scooters, the hardware suppliers -- the Sweet Chef Southern Styles Bakery is a bright spot, a fanciful sign of a neighborhood on the way up.

title: Gore Lawyers Argue That Hand Recounts Are Best Way to Gauge Voters' Intent
description: Hand ballot recounts are an essential part of election law in Florida and other states, and the most accurate method of objectively determining voter intent. But they are complicated and take time -- plenty of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNALLY, GRACE ELEANOR (NEE NORTON)
description: McNALLY-Grace Eleanor (nee Norton). On November 17, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Edward P. Loving mother of Dennis S.J., Brian, Kerry Graham and Regina. Cherished grandmother of Karin, Melissa, Jodi and William. Devoted great-grandmother of Mackenzie and Connor. Dear sister of Edward, Geraldine, Gerard and Kevin. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193rd St. Visiting hours Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-5 PM. Mass of the Resurrection Tuesday evening, 7 PM, St. Kevin's R.C. Church. Interment Wednesday, Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, Corpus Christi Scholarship Fund, 610-660-1840.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUTER, BENJAMIN
description: YUTER-Benjamin. We mourn the loss of our dear and devoted friend, Ben. He was an outstanding member of our community and a true son of the Jewish people. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved and lifetime partner Claire, their children and grandchildren. Shalom, dear friend. Rose and Carl Appel

title: Bush and Gore Battle in the Field of Dreams, Too
description: THE woman, a supporter of Ralph Nader, discovered that George W. Bush lived across the street from her. She invited him over and made him soup. He repulsed her, but she also found herself attracted to him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASCIOLI, JOSEPH
description: MASCIOLI-Joseph. On November 17, 2000 of Manhasset. Beloved husband of Rose. Loving father of his late sons Charles and Frank. Grandfather of Margaret, Diane, Charles, Joseph, William, Elizabeth, Paul and the late Stephen. He is also survived by 18 great grandchildren. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Sunday from 3-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass on Monday 11:30am St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset. Entombment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Cooley's Anemia Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, DOROTHY PEARL NEE GOLDBLATT
description: KAPLAN-Dorothy Pearl nee Goldblatt. 86. Formerly of Florida, recently of Lakewood, New Jersey, died on November 14. She worked for the New York State Department of Labor for over 35 years, retiring in 1970. Her husband, Morris Henry Kaplan, died in 1989. He was associated with the New York City Mayor's Office during the Wagner and Lindsay administrations. Her sister and brotherin-law Anne and Jacob Lubitz predeceased her. Surviving are sister and brother-in-law Selma and Emanuel Gershkowitz and nieces and nephews: Lucille and Michael Weiss, Rosalyn Lubitz, Allen and Mary Gershkowitz, and Fran and Rick Goldberg. Services were held on November 16.

title: The Election; Surprise! Elections Have Margins of Error, Too
description: WITH its millions of microscopic switches silently clicking half a billion times a second, the computer chip in a typical laptop could tally the presidential vote for the entire country in less than the blink of an eye. Its verdict would be flawless. All it is doing, after all, is counting. No matter how voluminous and rapid its machinations, the chip must simply distinguish between 1's and 0's, the symbols of binary code. There are no shades of gray.

title: East Hampton Debates Scout Use of Property
description: The Town of East Hampton was moving last week toward a compromise solution in a debate over whether to deny the use of town property to the Boy Scouts of America over the group's ban on homosexuals.

title: Napster Redux
description: MP3.com agreed to pay Universal Music Group $53.4 million to settle a closely watched copyright dispute in a deal that clears the way for MP3.com to offer consumers the ability to listen to their CD's wherever they have an Internet connection. As Universal became the last of the five major record labels to agree to license its catalog to MP3.com, executives at the company said the hefty price they extracted should send a message to other Internet start-ups that online music distribution won't fly without royalty payments to copyright holders. At the same time, Universal claimed warrants to purchase a small stake in MP3.com should its onetime renegade service prove lucrative now that it has been legalized. Amy Harmon

title: Composition in Black and White; Balancing the Need For Parking and Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Books; If the Shoe Fits . . .
description: A MOTHER who dies but whose love lives on. A daughter whose beauty proceeds from virtue. Selfish, lazy stepsisters who are, of course, ugly. A stepmother whose wickedness is by now emblematic. A handsome and persistent prince. An ending whose happiness is incidental to its wallop of poetic justice. Even among the fairy tales we hold most dear, ''Cinderella'' really delivers. Perhaps this is why a half-dozen versions are published in a single season.

title: Children's Books: Books in Brief
description: Fever 1793

title: Orchestras Continue To Ignore The Obvious
description: FOR the last three summers the conductor Kent Nagano has been the unassuming hero of the Salzburg Festival in Austria. In 1998 he took the Halle Orchestra of Manchester, England, of which he was then the music director, to perform in Peter Sellars's production of Messiaen's ecstatic opera ''St. Francois d'Assise.'' To judge from the excellent Deutsche Grammophon recording, Mr. Nagano gave a vibrant performance of this complex, nearly five-hour score.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The PowerBook

title: Safety and Zoning vs. Freedom of Religion
description: THEY have names like The Revelation Church of God in Christ, Ephesus Church and Living Waters Evangelistic. They are scattered about North Amityville like seeds sown by the wind. They range from structures originally built as houses of worship to storefronts to converted houses in residential areas.

title: Three-Concourse Meals At Newark Airport
description: LONG ago, before most of us spent far too much time sitting around airports, people actually went there for entertainment, for the thrill of watching planes take off and land when the jet age was still young. They might even have dinner at places like the Newarker, a white-tablecloth ''destination restaurant'' that opened at Newark Airport in 1953. Known for its large portions, its Absecon oysters and its propensity for serving food theatrically flambe, the Newarker became a cornerstone of the Restaurant Associates empire before it closed in 1973.

title: Turning to Online Schools for Advanced Degrees
description: CARLA WRIGHT-JUKES is an unlikely candidate for an M.B.A. degree. An associate director at SciQuest.com, a start-up scientific equipment company based in Research Triangle Park, N.C., and a single mother of two, Ms. Wright-Jukes has had neither the time nor the money for an advanced degree.

title: Composition in Black and White; Balancing the Need For Parking and Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: An Amazon Chief Paves Captain's Way
description: In a back room in a small apartment along a quiet street, Capt. Clive Kelly lies in repose, a force of nature aground on a rumpled futon. In August, Kelly's seagoing adventures and 30-year environmental crusade came to an abrupt halt when his 55-foot trimaran was shipwrecked on a reef off this lush Caribbean island. Now, it appears Kelly might be becalmed for quite some time.

description: At $5,000 a bottle, , L'Esprit de Courvoisier is not the kind of brandy found at the local liquor store or bar. That is fine with Courvoisier, purveyor of what it calls the world's most expensive cognac.

title: Nassau Reassessment: Why the Delay?
description: In ''Nassau Begins the Process of Tax Reassessment'' [Oct. 22], Charles O'Shea, the chairman of the county's Board of Assessors, is quoted as saying that ''this is a modernization of the Nassau County assessment system, and equity and fairness demand it.''

title: TRANSIT STANDEES
description: New Jersey Transit buses and trains cannot provide seats for 22,500 of its 366,350 daily passengers, according to a report released by the agency last week. Ridership rose 3.4 percent, or 14,500 riders a day, last year. Angela Starita

description: Stalinism as a Way of Life A Narrative in Documents. Edited by Lewis Siegelbaum and Andrei Sokolov. Yale University, $35.

description: A LITTLE PRINCESS

title: The World; Living With Mad Cows: The French and Fear Itself
description: AS a wave of fear of mad cow disease gripped France last week, large numbers of French consumers had the same reflex: they spurned the supermarkets they have begun to frequent and went right back to the small corner butcher shop. There, they argued, the man they had known since childhood would do his best to keep them healthy. And besides, he had direct ties to farmers in the country.

title: Pro Pharma
description: How about publishing a rebuttal written by someone who has to pay $15,600 a year out of pocket for drugs? It's easy to ''love drug companies'' when your insurance company pays for your prescriptions. By the way, your ''special advertising supplement'' in the same issue was a reminder of another reason why drug prices are so high: the cost of marketing drugs.

title: Karin Dando, Nikolas Haenisch
description: Karin Michelle Dando, the daughter of Marilyn Dando and B. Gary Dando of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday to Nikolas David Haenisch, the son of Jutta Bertram-Nothnagel of New York and Friedhelm Haenisch of Grafing, Germany. The Rev. Sonke Schmidt-Lange, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Church in New York.

title: A Hatred Smoldering In the Hills
description: Of all the odd and misguided tenets by which Eddie Vaughn lived his life, perhaps the most troubling was his view of the law. ''There's the law way, and there's my way,'' is a maxim Vaughn frequently repeated. He expressed this doctrine by beating his wife and dealing in narcotics and pulling a gun or a knife on whoever he felt required it. Anyone who believed in the righteousness or sanctity of the legal system was, by definition, Vaughn's enemy. He had a temper both violent and unpredictable, and even those who admired him realized that if Vaughn were to encounter the wrong person, in the wrong situation, he was liable to impose a punishment of his own furious creation.

title: There Was Only One Rimbaud
description: RIMBAUD

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a federal appeals court's consideration of whether to allow manual recounts of presidential ballots referred incorrectly to Bruce S. Rogow, who said he was surprised by the court's decision to convene all 12 members. Mr. Rogow is a lawyer for the Palm Beach County elections supervisor, not a lawyer for the Democrats.

title: Democrats Can Take Heart As State Swings Their Way
description: So the election is over, in most states at least, and the voters wait to see who the winner will be. But for the politicians around New Jersey, the real work is still going on as Republicans and Democrats alike pore over the returns to see what it all means for their parties and for the future.

title: Plea for a Field From Soccer Fans, Some Knee-High to a Goal Post
description: Irate yet cheerful protesters stormed onto a strip of Warren Street Nov. 10 to save a sizable green ball field. The Battery Park City Authority, they say, wants to surround their field with two residential towers that would encase it in perpetual shadow.

description: Louisa By Simone Zelitch. 377 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95.

description: Patience paid off for Annika Sorenstam today, but so did her ability.

The elite Princeton institute claimed Dr. Hut had violated an agreement to leave by next year, but Dr. Hut -- known for writing an algorithm used to measure the movement of stars -- had insisted that the agreement was invalid. John Sullivan

title: 'Green Juice'
description: At first glance, Wolffer Estate's label for its 1999 verjus seems to announce a new Bordeaux-blend white wine with an unfamiliar name. But seasoned cooks know what's up.

title: Cruises to Cuba Postponed Indefinitely
description: Citing what it said were numerous telephone threats, including a bomb threat, Toronto-based Cuba Cruise Corporation recently announced an indefinite postponement of its inaugural cruise between Nassau and Havana on its 400-passenger Habana, scheduled for yesterday.

title: Cure It With Drugs
description: I'm a reformed shopaholic -- don't ask me how, I just reformed myself, the same way I stopped smoking. (Maggie Jones, Oct. 15.) And no pills were involved. David Healy, author of ''The Anti-Depressant Era,'' is on target when he says, ''Once a drug is shown to be effective in treating a disorder, the number of diagnoses for that disorder increases.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTTER, JOSEPH V.
description: COTTER-Joseph V. Of Crestwood, NY, on November 17, 2000. Retired Bronx High School of Science teacher. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 1 to 5 PM, Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial Annunciation Church, Crestwood, on Monday, November 20, at 11 AM.

title: With Foundations, Those Who Did Well Keep Doing Good
description: PHILANTHROPIC foundations are part of the hidden landscape of Connecticut. Few people have heard of most of these organizations, many of them set up by families or wealthy individuals. But the effects of their generosity are felt by everyone from college athletes to residents of homeless shelters. Foundations are generally quite discreet about their operations, and many of the original benefactors have attained almost mythic status as their lives recede into history.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for JAMES E. COPELAND JR.; Can Accounting Firms Live With New Rules?
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission voted last week to adopt rules for accounting firms that will impose restrictions on the consulting services auditors provide to clients. The rules seek to prevent situations in which auditors have an incentive to skew their reports to make the advice they had provided look more impressive.

title: Counting Goes On, and On, With None of the Big Gains Sought by Democrats
description: Amid charges of chaos and chad eating, a recount in two crucial Florida counties has not, so far, produced the results that campaign workers for Vice President Al Gore had hoped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODSIDE, WILLIAM STEWART
description: WOODSIDE-William Stewart, of Scottsdale, AZ and Litchfield, CT, formerly of New York City, on November 15, 2000 of chronic pulmonary lung disease, at home in the arms of his loving wife, Migs. A deeply loved and loving husband, companion and closest friend for 30 years to his wife. Beloved father of William S. Woodside III, Anne D. Gruzdowich and Samuel T. Woodside. Generous, caring and loving stepfather of Geoffrey Dann and Deborah Dann, and caring father-in-law to Terri Woodside and Lauri Novick. Proud and delighted grandfather of Benjamin and Jacob Woodside, Rebecca and Emily Dann, and also Emily and Nicholas Gruzdowich. Devoted brother-in-law of Lewis W. Bernard. A man of enormous accomplishment and achievement, extraordinary intellect and talent, whose incredible courage and determination in spite of physical adversity was an inspiration to all. Good night sweet prince, may flights of angels see you to your dreams. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, November 29th at 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Please send contributions to the Children of Alcoholics Foundation, C/O Phoenix House, 164 W. 74th St., New York, New York 10024.

title: 650 KeySpan Customers Turn Off Gas in Drill
description: KeySpan directed 650 commercial and institutional customers to turn off the gas for eight hours last Wednesday to test their readiness to switch to heating oil this winter in the event gas supplies grow tight.

title: It's Ready, but Is It Wanted?
description: Mifepristone, or RU-486, better known as the abortion pill, will finally become available in the United States this week. During the long battle to get the pill approved for sale, proponents predicted it would move abortions from clinics to doctors' offices, making a decision to end a pregnancy a matter between a woman and her doctor. But, so far, that is not happening. Most orders for the recently approved pill are from Planned Parenthood clinics and independent abortion providers, and even many abortion clinics say they think a surgical abortion is better. Gina Kolata

title: Landscape Pioneers: A Tribute
description: EVEN though we may walk our dogs or eat a sandwich in the same park every day, or rush across it to take a shortcut to the bus, or gaze in rapture at a national park from a road coursing through the Great Smoky Mountains, how many of us know who created those green pockets of inspiration and sanity.

title: Battered, Bruised And Soon Down for the Count
description: The long-lived and, in recent years, much-derided Mir space station will be intentionally crashed into the Pacific Ocean in February. The station, which was launched in 1985, was supposed to have lasted just three years, but over time, as it survived electrical blackouts, computer crashes, fires and a puncture by another spacecraft, the Mir became for many beleaguered Russian citizens a symbol of their nation's technological ingenuity and perseverance.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BECKERMAN, LARRY
description: BECKERMAN-Larry. Very dear son, loving brother; we miss you and your hearty laugh. Remembered with love. Mom and Dan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, BERNICE
description: EVANS-Bernice. On November 15, 2000. Loving mother of Emily Ford of Chagrin Falls, OH, and Thomas Hart Evans of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved grandmother of Rebecca and Nathan Ford. Dear sister of Maurice Rosenblatt of Washington, DC. Friends may call Sunday, 11-1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, NJ, 1:45 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Doctors Without Borders or a charity of your choice.

title: More and More, Coaches Earn Their Keep
description: When it comes to head coaching salaries, the Jets' Al Groh is earning the National Football League equivalent of minimum wage. His $800,000 salary ranks near the bottom in his profession.

title: Yale Expands Aid Plan To Help Foreign Students
description: With competition for top students spilling over into the international arena, Yale University said yesterday that it is expanding its financial aid for foreign students and will accept them regardless of their need.

title: Fossil Fuel
description: Trilobite!

title: Pollution Pullback
description: The Virginia Electric Power Company agreed to what government officials call the largest pollution reductions ever by a utility, settling lawsuits filed by New York State and the federal government accusing it of Clean Air Act violations. The company agreed to cut emissions from eight coal-burning power plants by 70 percent, or 252,000 tons per year, at a cost of $1.2 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISENCO, YASHA
description: LISENCO-Yasha. Father, Artist, Educator on November 17, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Claire Sylvia Lisenco. Dear father of Peter, Nina and the late Jonathan and father-in-law of Kathy. Grandfather of Krista, Joshua and Rachel. Loving brother of Dorothy Sakal. Services today, Sunday, November 19.

title: Italian Sociologist's Goal: Make Opium Farming Fade Into History
description: Like the other former Soviet republics on the drug route dubbed the New Silk Road, Tajikistan lacks the resources to combat the flow of narcotics from neighboring Afghanistan en route to Russia and Western Europe.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Directions In Brooklyn
description: AL DI LA

title: Bookend; Artists and Writers in a New World
description: PAST the abalone-encrusted pianos, embroidered Abolition quilts and silver Torah finials of the Metropolitan Museum's glorious exhibition ''Art and the Empire City: New York, 1825-1861,'' pause for a moment in front of a curious painting by Asher B. Durand. On loan from the New York Public Library and titled ''Kindred Spirits,'' in most ways it's a typical Hudson River School landscape -- jutting cliffs, narrow waterfalls, decomposing conifers. What's unusual is that two urbane figures are recognizable amid nature's sublimity: the painter Thomas Cole and the poet William Cullen Bryant. Durand, Cole and Bryant were all good friends, but more significant, they were part of a close-knit circle of artists and writers -- the first to take root in the new land. And although by today's standards many of the paintings of the period may seem quaint and some of the writing, well, atrocious, broadly speaking the group laid the groundwork for the American Renaissance -- the genius of Whitman, Melville, Thoreau, Hawthorne -- that was to emerge a generation later.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 5 about restaurants under Tokyo Station, a municipal rail and subway depot, misstated the year the brick facade of the station was completed. It was 1914, not 1926.

title: Kournikova No Match for Composure and Savvy of Hingis
description: A couple of hours after Martina Hingis and Anna Kournikova stirred up the crowd in their intense semifinal yesterday, their proud mothers were sitting as tight as matchsticks in the front row at Madison Square Garden.

title: Serendipity In the Retail Sector
description: In an example of how the improvement of one area can help another, Martinique Jewelers, which has stood at 1555 Broadway (near 46th Street) for 37 years, opened a second store at 659 Lexington Avenue, at 55th Street, on Thursday.

title: Other People's Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Lauren Frohlich, Howard Cooper
description: Lauren Jill Frohlich, the daughter of Phyllis and William Frohlich of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Howard Adam Cooper, a son of Ellen Kanner and Dr. Jerome Cooper, both of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Deborah Zecher officiated at Wheatleigh, an inn in Lenox, Mass.

title: Marriage Under Glass: Intimate Exposures
description: AT the conclusion of a slide lecture in May at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts in Richmond, the photographer Sally Mann asked whether the audience would be interested in seeing some images of work in progress. The audience was eager for such a glimpse and seemed genuinely moved by what it saw. But controversy, like fame, is easier to court than to control.

title: The Children, Not the Mayor, Grab Adoption Day Spotlight
description: For Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, it was bound to require a bit of humility. And Mr. Giuliani did not seem to mind much when he was upstaged yesterday at the city's first ''Adoption Saturday,'' a marathon of court hearings at which more than 200 adoptions were completed, thanks to 100 court employees who volunteered their time.

title: School Survey Fails To Reflect Achievement
description: I was very concerned and frustrated to read ''High School Confidential: A Great Neck Eye-Opener'' [Oct. 29], about the results of a survey taken in the Great Neck high schools. I am a graduate of Great Neck North High School and proud of it. I have two children attending North High. I do not have my head in the sand. I am very involved with the kids as well as the school. Do we have drugs in our school? Do we have a problem with teenage drinking? Sure we do and I am very concerned about it. But to say that we have gangs, that we have guns and knives? Sure we don't.

title: Defying the I.R.S., Anti-Tax Businesses Refuse to Withhold
description: Al Thompson squeezed most of his manufacturing company's 28 employees into a conference room here in October to say he had good news: Income taxes must be paid by only a few Americans, mostly those working for foreign-owned companies. So, he told the workers, they would not have to pay income taxes ever again. His business is exempt, too, he said.

title: The Age of The Mediathon
description: For those of us who are sick of these sagas, there remain a few easy solutions: turn them off, turn the page and stop talking about them at cocktail parties. Yes, this may take strength. (Frank Rich mentions that it seems ''snotty'' to others if you're not up on the latest.) But I'd rather seem snotty than a sucker.

title: Scaffolding Darkening Street And Moods
description: The owner of a building at York Avenue and East 83rd Street has been renovating his property for more than five years, and people who live nearby say they are tired of the scaffolding that darkens the sidewalk and makes it a haven for the homeless.

title: The Deer Hunter
description: Looking at the photo of Craig DeBaun in his ''box blind,'' waiting and watching for a defenseless animal to wander into firing range, reminds me of a quote attributed to Samuel Johnson: ''It is very strange, and very melancholy, that the paucity of human pleasures should persuade us ever to call hunting one of them.''

title: A Manager Practices What She Preaches
description: It stands to reason that the prime money manager for the United Nations pension fund would be a booster of global investing. In its $850 million acquisition of Fiduciary Trust International, which runs six mutual funds and manages money for institutions, late last month, Franklin Resources acquired such a booster in Anne M. Tatlock, who will continue as the Fiduciary Trust chief executive.

title: A Triumph
description: To the Editor:

title: The Age of The Mediathon
description: Frank Rich notes that coverage of the Persian Gulf war, O.J., Monica and other incidents produced a new entertainment phenomenon. But the gulf war reportage seems different from the other examples. Fascination with dirt is one thing, a guilty pleasure. But excitement about war (and covering it as if it were a major sports event) is more disturbing. That we no longer have a collective memory of our country as imperiled by an enemy in battle might explain why we viewed the war as pseudo-entertainment. In contrast, it would be hard to imagine the Israelis and the Palestinians or so many African nations or the central European states watching with titillation as their armed forces battled an enemy.

title: Separate Morning Fires Leave One Person Dead and 31 Homeless
description: A Queens woman was killed and 31 people in Washington Heights were left homeless in two unrelated fires yesterday, the authorities said.

title: OPINION; With Jury Duty, No Trial After All
description: IF your summons reads No. 00890 through 00950, you must report at 9 a.m. on Monday, November 6, to Supreme Court Building, Juror Selection Room, Lower Level in Riverhead.'' The automated message brooked no excuses. My number was surely up, especially as I had already postponed my initial call to duty because of the busy summer months.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Republican Lawmakers Think They Have an Ace in the Hole
description: Republican state lawmakers here are homing in on an obscure, never used federal statute that, they contend, could offer them a decisive hand in choosing Florida's precious 25 electors if the normal voting process somehow leaves the outcome unclear.

title: Beyond a List: A Shopping Strategy
description: THERE are those people who love shopping with family and friends, strolling leisurely down mall aisles, popping happily into this shop and that, finding just the right gift for everyone on their list.

title: The Big Business to Be Found in Toys
description: BEING a child in Westchester is hardly a hardship posting.

title: When You Come To Visit Me; Dominican Republic
description: The magic of the island, actually a half-island, is the variety you can encounter in an area the size of New Hampshire and Vermont. If you come to visit the Dominican Republic, I'd want you to see a beach because, of course, you've come to a tropical island. I avoid the obvious ones, packed with tourists, and instead head northeast toward the peninsula of Saman1/3 to the easternmost tip of the island. The farther east you go, the more magical and deserted these white beaches become. And there's a fabulous place to stay, Villa Serena, a six-room hotel in a Victorian house, owned by a couple from Croatia. The restaurant is renowned on the island. A rich acquaintance flies his little airplane up to Saman1/3 to eat lunch at Villa Serena.

title: Vendee; Province of Reflection and Memory
description: A few years ago, my mother rented a small cottage in the marais area of the Vendee, on the Atlantic coast of France, south of Brittany, where she had spent her summers as a child. I visited her there in September, around the time of my birthday.

title: Sherry McClaskey, Brewster Thackeray
description: Sherry Lyn McClaskey, the daughter of Janet McClaskey of Naples, Fla., and Ronald McClaskey of Lehigh Acres, Fla., was married yesterday to William Brewster Thackeray, the son of Selma and William Thackeray of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Cynthia Kane, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Universalist National Memorial Church in Washington.

title: School Summitry
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Believers See Prelude to a Fall
description: WHEN the bond market talks, investors don't always like to listen. After all, bond investors tend to spot bad news on the horizon and then telegraph it to the rest of the world in language as complex as Alan Greenspan's when he testifies before Congress.

title: The Tally From Florida
description: Florida vote totals for Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore from The Associated Press as of yesterday. The figures include the tally of overseas ballots but do not include any adjustments from hand recounts started after the certification on Tuesday of the results. Rejected ballots are those that were thrown out for some reason, such as not having an overseas postmark.

title: Changing Fields (and Lawns and Gardens)
description: THE gardening bug is an insidious disease. Once stricken, some victims feel a compulsion to spend all their free time digging in the dirt and all their money buying plants and seeds. Others go even further and transform their working lives by entering the horticultural field.

title: POLICE SOLICITATION FRAUD
description: The State Division of Consumer Affairs last week announced a fraud suit against a Woodbridge telemarketing firm, Community Affairs Inc., charging that it raised $1.9 million in the name of four corrections officers unions and kept $1.6 million. The unions were also sued after the consumer agency said they spent just $35,000 of their $300,000 share on the bulletproof vests and aid to officers' widows and children cited in the fund-raising pitch. Steve Strunsky

title: Lydia Tracy, Mats Carlston
description: Lydia Tracy, a daughter of Sondra Graham and Robert Tracy, both of Philadelphia, was married Friday evening to Mats Gustaf Carlston, the son of Marianne and Sten Carlston of Stockholm. Judge Carol R. Edmead of New York City Civil Court officiated at the couple's home in New York.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Concert by Candlelight

title: Storytelling Only Works if Tales Are True
description: I WAS desperate,'' said Stephen Denning, program director for knowledge management of the World Bank. He had been trying to convince his colleagues of the importance of sharing knowledge throughout the organization. But the persuasive tools he had used all of his professional life -- analytical charts and graphs, written reports -- weren't working. So he decided to tell them a story.

title: Harlem Journal; Gay White Pioneers, on New Ground
description: ''Harlem is on everybody's lips,'' said Willie Kathryn Suggs, a tough-as-wrought-iron real estate broker whose main turf is Harlem. ''It's no longer a no man's land.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-19-00: The Ethicist; The Art of Faking It
description: I am an artist, and I support my family by painting reproductions of the work of more famous artists, a common practice in the tradition of painting. However, some say this is akin to stealing the famous artists' work. Is it right for a wealthy client to commission a copy of a work available in the original? Is it wrong for an artist to accept the job? -- Ray Abeyta, Brooklyn

title: Corrections
description: An annotated listing of holiday films on Nov. 5 referred incorrectly to the career of the director E. Elias Merhige. (The error also appeared in the film listing of the New Season issue on Sept. 10.) ''Shadow of the Vampire,'' which is to be released on Dec. 29, is his second film, not his first. The first, ''Begotten,'' was released in 1991.

title: Leigh Montgomery, Christopher Hartman
description: Sharon Leigh Montgomery and Christopher Gerald Hartman were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Stephen T. Melius at the Lexington United Methodist Church in Lexington, Mass.

title: Florida Sun Puts Ford in the Shade
description: For a corporate leader who has endured the glare of bad publicity, it would seem that the last place Jacques A. Nasser, the Ford Motor Company president and chief executive, would want to appear is at a dinner honoring business journalists. After all, Mr. Nasser recently faced grilling over faulty Firestone tires on Ford Explorers. Yet Mr. Nasser came to Columbia University's annual Knight-Bagehot Fellowship dinner for the business press with a message: ''I want to thank the residents of Florida for taking us out of the news.'' He added that he had heard from 500 angry Florida residents ''who thought they were to get Ferraris when they went to get their Buicks.'' As for his Firestone fame, Mr. Nasser told a story about a child in a California shopping mall who turned to him and said, ''I know you.'' Mr. Nasser, pleased, took it as a sign of the growing popularity of business until the child asked, ''Aren't you the actor in the Ford commercials?''

title: Don't Listen to Reason
description: ROMANTICISM AND

title: Corrections
description: The main front-page article in this section on Nov. 5, about efforts to provide landmark protection for notable buildings of modest architecture, mispelled the name of a singing group whose music was played in the 1970's at the Empire Roller Disco in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. It was the Chi-Lites, not the Shi-Lites.

title: Roosevelt's Tug of War Over Its Charter School; The New Academy Moves Into Its Permanent Quarters, But the Public School District Drags Its Heels Over Payments
description: ALL but lost in the adult wrangling over the Roosevelt Children's Academy, the Island's first charter school, are its 147 students, who arrive for class each day in crisp blue-and-white uniforms.

title: An Acre of Outdoor Rooms, Under Glass
description: ANYONE can create beauty, but the wealthy can create beauty on a grand scale. This is as true with gardens as with any other form of art, and if you have ever been to Longwood Gardens in Kennett Square, Pa., you know how well plants can grow when they are mulched and fertilized with cold hard cash. Inspired by the Longwood example, the late tobacco heiress Doris Duke (1913-1993) built a lavish display garden on her estate near Somerville.

title: How Do You Cure A Sex Addict?
description: Once, sex addicts were treated with pillories and guillotines and gleaming clamps, but what used to be a moral problem is now a medical one, and this is no surprise. Our understanding of sexual compulsion has followed the same trajectory as our understanding of melancholy and moodiness. It's all in the brain. Goodbye heart, goodbye groin, and voil rumpled, slick organ crammed in its sheath of skull. New scientific theories are shedding an interesting light on the biochemistry of perversion and maybe, by extension, on the chemistry of ordinary kinkiness -- what you and I do, volitionally and consensually, behind bedroom doors.

title: Global Warming Moves From Impassioned Words to Modest Deeds
description: Forget the diplomats dithering over protocols and the scientists agonizing over equations. The next wave of the global warming debate is about nuts and bolts. In the New York metropolitan area and in other cities and states, ordinary people in corporations and government -- engineers, teachers and bureaucrats -- are quietly beginning to plan for a future in which climate and geography may be decidedly different.

title: Mideast Lull Interrupted By Attack By Palestinian
description: The day began before dawn with a Palestinian security officer's deadly attack on an Israeli Army post in the Gaza Strip today, auguring ill for the supposed crackdown on shooting that Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, had ordered on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUDOIN, SUZANNE
description: BAUDOIN-Suzanne. November 17, 2000. Loving and caring mother of Patsy, Jean-Yves, Marina and Bettina. Grandmother of Christina, Patrick, Alexander, Daniel and Paul. Mother-in-law of Madge, Ellen, Harry and Henri. She shall ever be remembered by family and friends for her loving warmth and affection, and always ''being there'' for her recently departed husband, Charles, and her family. Her memory shall ever be for a blessing. Richard Netter, Hector G. Dowd and Edward M. Berman

title: Children's Books; Off With Her Head
description: QUEEN'S OWN FOOL

title: Environmentalists Applaud Votes in Nassau
description: JOINING a regional and national trend toward increased local spending for open space and environmental programs, Nassau voters in the Towns of North Hempstead and Oyster Bay have approved $45 million in new borrowing for environmental purposes.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Nisei Knick

title: Maryellen Evans, Kristopher King
description: Maryellen Erica Evans and Kristopher Albert Augustine King were married yesterday in New Canaan, Conn. Msgr. J. Peter Cullen performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church.

title: Olympians Glory in the Beauty of Their Sport
description: THE Summer Olympics are over, but the gymnasts who gathered in Sydney to compete for the top honors in their graceful and high-energy sport are still in the limelight -- only now they are traveling to their audiences.

title: Untrendy Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: When Hillbilly and Jazz Found Common Cause
description: HILLBILLY and jazz go together in the popular mind about as well as honest and politician. Yet such a beast existed, and in its heyday it could have taught less-unlikely genres of jazz a thing or two, had they cared to listen. Now, with a spate of new reissues finally pinning hillbilly jazz down so we can get to listen to it, it's possible that we, feeling our way through the waning of the rock era, might be able to pick up a couple of pointers as well about making music that can be pop and art, rootsy and new, fun and challenging.

title: The Right Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: By the B.Q.E., an Artists' Salon Casts an Avant-Garde Glow
description: THE night air vibrates as a steady stream of trucks grunt and groan on the elevated lanes of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. Below, street lights cast lonely glows on a barren block lined with rusting warehouses and a Roman Catholic convent, hard by the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: Sunday Night Fever
description: IT starts in grade school, and some people never get over it. Call it blah, bleak, bland or the blues, that Sunday-night back-to-class, back-to-work sensation can be overwhelming at any age.

title: Leon J. Epstein, 83, a Pioneer In Treating Mentally Ill Elderly
description: Dr. Leon J. Epstein, a pioneer in the treatment of mental illness in the elderly, died Nov. 6 at his home in San Francisco. He was 83.

title: Corrections
description: The main front-page article in this section last Sunday, about children's poetry, misstated the grade of one poet, Anissa Lashley of P.S. 156 in Brownsville, Brooklyn. She is in the fifth grade, not the first.

title: At Rockefeller Park Preserve, a Magic Still Beckons
description: ALTHOUGH I have roamed from India to Patagonia, from the Galapagos to Bali, from the fells of Lapland to the dunes of Tunisia, my favorite destination is right in our own backyard. It reminds me of other gently beautiful places: London's Hampstead Heath, near where I once lived; pastures in Ireland; ranchland in Uruguay; the lake area of Vermont; Danish dairy farms.

title: Nixon Descending
description: To the Editor:

title: A Brief Middle East Sideshow
description: A Russian airplane hijacked to Israel raised concerns that Muslim Chechen rebels had engineered the stunt to show solidarity with rioting Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Children's Books; The Roads Are Alive
description: BIG TRUCK

title: Children's Books; Things That Go Squish in the Night
description: Some Things

title: It's Just a Game but the Coaches Are Often the Heroes
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom has it that most adults would rather do anything than hang out with a bunch of 8-year-olds on a Saturday afternoon. Then why is it, on a Long Island baseball diamond, on a New Jersey ice rink, in a Connecticut gymnasium or in a Westchester County park, there are countless grown-ups screaming, cheering, goading, encouraging and teaching junior Derek Jeters, Wayne Gretskys and Chamique Holdsclaws?

title: When You Come To Visit Me; Leeds, England
description: The place near Leeds I consider a must for visitors is the Bront Parsonage Museum in Haworth. It is one of the world's great small museums. Like most such it has a small and precise focus: A family of writers who seldom left home, and who wrote together as naturally as they ate, slept and played together. Once you get past the (rather jolly) touristiness of Main Street, you enter the gate by the church and are into Bront territory. The lane winds past the Sunday school where Charlotte and Branwell (but not Emily) taught, with to your left the churchyard, stuffed with bodies that succumbed, usually young, in one of Britain's most unhealthy locations. Overlooking that (''I see around me tombstones grey/ Stretching their shadow far away,'' wrote Emily) is the Parsonage, and beyond that the moors.

title: Children's Books; Snow Day
description: BLIZZARD!

title: Not Quite Creatures From Outer Space
description: Victor Almanzar, 13, who was walking through Theodore Roosevelt Park on his school lunch break, stopped to gawk at a pair of brown and mossy green blobs. They were a fungus, he thought -- a fungus 12 feet tall and bubbling up from park pavement. No, they were creatures from Mars. Possibly they were plastic, he decided, and maybe they were art.

title: Where Troops Fear to Tread, Aid Workers Are at Risk
description: When refugees uprooted by war or other disasters stream out of countries in crisis, the expectation has long been that the United Nations relief agencies will plunge in.

title: The High Cost of Unity
description: One more example of the power of financial markets: The decline of the euro and the currencies linked to it is eroding support in some quarters for the rapid expansion of the European Community to Eastern Europe. In Germany, the costs of European unity come on top of the huge costs of absorbing the former East Germany. While some officials there want to bring nations like Hungary, Poland, Slovenia and the Czech Republic into the European union as soon as possible, those calling for caution are becoming more vocal.

title: The Making of an Icon
description: To the Editor:

title: Man/Woman on Stage/Screen
description: THE Paper Mill Playhouse's choice of ''Victor/Victoria,'' nowhere near a musical of choice, is unfathomable. Although the dearth of doable new musicals coming off Broadway's assembly line, does not signal the death of musicals, desperate times need not require desperate measures.

title: Truly Un-American
description: To the Editor:

title: Introduction
description: Readers gave the usual suspects (particularly O.J.) a thorough going over, as they did Frank Rich for recycling them in his article on ''The Age of the Mediathon.'' And Andrew Sullivan's defense of drug companies, played against his own generous insurance plan, also drew heavy, often envious, mail.

title: Innovative? For Sure. But What Is It?
description: EVEN at a time when the working definition of opera is extremely loose, the growing body of works that the composer John Moran calls operas -- the latest of which, ''Book of the Dead (Second Avenue),'' opens tomorrow at the Joseph Papp Public Theater -- is likely to strain an opera fan's notions of the form.

title: If You Have a Horse, Happy B.Y.O.H. Trails
description: IF you want to go horseback riding in Westchester or Putnam, it helps -- a lot -- to have your own horse. And a lot of people do.

title: Coca-Cola Considering Quaker Oats Acquisition
description: The Coca-Cola Company is in serious talks to acquire the Quaker Oats Company, the maker of Gatorade, in an effort to expand its position in the lucrative noncarbonated drink business, executives close to the negotiations said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about an exhibit of synagogue architecture misstated the location of a synagogue in Germany where the ark is made of glass and the torah scrolls inside can be viewed from the street. It is in Kassel, not Aachen.

title: Morocco
description: To the Editor: While I enjoyed the articles about Morocco, I do not believe they prepared the readers well enough for the aggressive touts and unofficial guides who will besiege them at every turn. Though usually harmless, they are a constant intrusion, at times intimidating.

title: Let's Rebuild The Sound, Too, Please
description: I PERIODICALLY submit to my editors a story idea entitled, ''Let's Blow Up Lincoln Center.'' It is regularly rejected, and perhaps wisely so. Incitements to violence, or at least property damage, have no place at this newspaper. Cooler heads and temperate thoughts have so far prevailed, perhaps saving me from my own worst instincts.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Sag Harbor; A Wave of Wealth for a Whaling Port
description: THE village of Sag Harbor, too well known to have ever been a secret, has been rediscovered with a vengeance by a new wave of admiring buyers who are bidding up home prices.

title: The Scarlet Letters
description: DISOBEDIENCE

title: Art for Pleasure's Sake
description: WRITING IN THE DARK, DANCING IN

title: At Long Last, Ravi Shankar
description: The sitar player and composer Ravi Shankar was dubbed ''The Godfather of World Music'' by George Harrison at the same time the Beatles brought the Indian virtuoso and his form of music to the attention of the western world.

title: Meet Janie Dee (It Rhymes With Three)
description: IT is rare for any one performer in Britain to make a clean sweep of the London theater's three separate prize-giving ceremonies -- unless you happen to be Judi Dench, who managed exactly that for her performance in ''Antony and Cleopatra'' in 1987. Last season, the feat was accomplished again, this time by a young actress, Janie Dee, for her first starring role on the West End.

title: Nets, Mall or Sprawl?
description: At a time when politicians are lining up to condemn sprawl and taxpayers are voting to spend millions of dollars to buy open land just ahead of developers with their front-end loaders, the last measure expected to pass through State Legislature was a bill easing the way for commercial development.

title: Even His Souffles Can't Relax
description: In the summer of 1999, George David and his 50-foot sailboat, Idler, led a United States team in competition for the Admiral's Cup. He expected to win. He came in third in his class.

title: Children's Books; Compass, Knife and Spyglass
description: THE AMBER SPYGLASS

title: The Teacher Drain
description: To the Editor:

title: A Homey Haven for the Oddball Imagination
description: IT takes a vivid imagination to see a traditional salon in the little white-box Construction Company theater on a humdrum block of 18th Street just west of Union Square. There are no little gilt chairs and tables. Instead, there is an uncompromisingly small and simple performance space that measures 35 by 21 feet, with bleacher seating and a piano in one corner. But there, tonight and tomorrow night, a typical gathering of composers, choreographers and musicians will perform new and old pieces together in a setting that has all the intimacy of an old-time salon.

title: Pro Pharma
description: Sullivan made the argument for the pharmaceutical industry in a succinct and powerful way. As one who worked in that industry for 10 years in the 1980's, I learned that prescription drugs represented approximately 15 percent of the total cost of disease treatment. Obviously, if they permit a patient to leave the hospital even one day sooner, this is a significant saving.

title: Morocco; A Vision of Green Oases and Golden Sands
description: On the shimmering journey from city to desert, everything gets less. Less building, less landscape, less humanity, less weather: at the skirts of the Sahara, only sand remains.

title: Humble Italian That's More Than That
description: SOLE, with its gifted chef, inspired food, modest surroundings and down-to-earth prices is just the kind of restaurant that this column searches the Island for: great food and great value. Joseph Bonacore and Robert Carmasino, its chef-owners, made a name for themselves at Tuscany, a distinguished destination restaurant in Rockville Centre where exotic game dishes and Chateau Rothschild wine tastings were the norm. Now Mr. Bonacore, Tuscany's owner, and Mr. Carmasino, who was his sous chef, are partners at Sole, 2752 Oceanside Road, Oceanside (516-764-3218), an everyman spot where Italian finger foods cost $3, an entree can be ordered for $8.95 (none are higher than $14.95) and all the wine costs $20 a bottle.

title: INSIDE
description: Uncertainty in Serbia

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIER, LIBBY
description: SCHEIER-Libby. May 31, 1946 to November 14, 2000. AmericanCanadian, writer/feminist. Survived by son Jacob Scheier, mother Celia Scheier, brother Michael Scheier and family. Contributions may be sent to Women's Centers and Shelters and Woodcock Trust, Writers Union, 24 Ryerson, Toronto. in the name of Libby Scheier. A memorial service December 2, at 2 PM, The Friends House, 60 Lowther, Toronto, On, Can. M5R1C7, 416-921-0368.

title: On the Run With Wolf B36
description: I am sick of reading about wolf-reintroduction programs in our Western states (Sara Corbett, Oct. 29). The cattle ranchers will never accept the wolves and will blame them for every mysterious death of a cow. The West is getting more and more populated -- more people, more towns, more ranches, more resorts -- with less room for the wolves. It's sad but true. Stop trying to ''save'' the wolves and leave those majestic, beautiful creatures where they are, in northern British Columbia. We don't deserve them.

title: Composition in Black and White; Landmarking Is Only Part Of Preservation Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: For TV, a Story With Everything
description: No sooner had Lester Holt, an anchor for MSNBC, begun to study the script that had been slapped into his palm than a voice in his ear from the control room told him to chuck it.

title: Bad Weather? Good!
description: Some vacationers seek sunny weather. For others, Tempest Tours offers storm-chasing expeditions. Experienced storm chasers (who take a cautious approach) lead 10-day tours from Oklahoma City and Denver in May and June. The price, $2,250 a person, double, includes 11 nights' lodging, transportation in 15-passenger vans (limit of six to a van) and instruction on the science of storm tracking. A one-week tour is available. Tempest Tours, Post Office Box 121084, Arlington, Tex. 76012; www.tempesttours.com.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 29 about a survey of student behavior at Great Neck's high schools misstated the occupation of Ronald Savarese, who commented on the pressures that may lead teen-agers to drug and alcohol abuse. He is a certified social worker, not a clinical psychologist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, ROSALYN
description: DEUTSCH-Rosalyn. Forever in our hearts. We love you. Dani, Millie and Barbara

title: Host Harvard Loses 'The Game' to Yale
description: Yale, which could not score in the second half of an upset loss to Princeton last week, scored 17 consecutive points in the final eight and a half minutes of play this afternoon to overcome Harvard, 34-24, in what the universities' adherents call The Game.

title: Tip of the Hat to a Marathoner
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Children's Books; Brazenly Ever After
description: LITTLE LIT

title: Notre Dame Awakens To Overpower Rutgers
description: Trailing by only 7 points midway through the third quarter today, Rutgers still had a chance to upset Notre Dame in a sloppy but entertaining game before the biggest home crowd of the season and a network television audience. Had the Scarlet Knights held on to that near interception or held off that Fighting Irish punt-blocker, they might have pulled it off.

title: The Question of Liberty, And the Lure of America
description: After President Clinton's motorcade swept out of the gates of Vietnam National University here on Friday, an impromptu teach-in began on the steps of the lecture hall, as American reporters quizzed Vietnamese students about their reaction to Mr. Clinton's speech.

title: Canada's New Territory Beckons Tourists North
description: LOOKING for an upside to global warming, Canadian tourism authorities recently calculated that for every degree a North American summer rises above the norm, tourism spending in Canada climbs by about $250 million. Increasingly, an advance guard of travelers is venturing into the far north, to Nunavut, Canada's new Arctic territory, carved out of the eastern half of the Northwest Territories last year.

title: Black Ties, Bearing Gifts
Children's Books; Truth and Reconciliation
description: MANY STONES

title: The Surprise of an Ugly Duckling Geranium
description: THIS is about a geranium. My geranium. My plant has been around for several years and its porper name has long since been forgotten. So it shall just be called The Geranium.

title: Professor Scarry Has a Theory
description: Elaine Scarry is in her garden fretting over her dahlias. ''They were completely wiped out by the freezing temperatures last night,'' she says, her voice edged with concern. She bends over to inspect the limp pink blooms. Perhaps the damage will not prove fatal. The day is warm, after all. Though it is late September, Scarry's narrow patch of green on a quiet side street in Cambridge, Mass., is still thick with summer blossoms -- pansies, morning glories, flowering maples, hollyhocks and hydrangeas. ''Maybe, given some sun, the dahlias will recover,'' she says, visibly reassured. Her voice is high and breathy, almost childlike in its wonder and, given her reputation, startling to hear.

title: In the Region /Connecticut; $320 Million Gives State Universities a New Look
description: ALMOST $320 million of construction is completed, under way or ready to begin at the four campuses of the Connecticut State University system as part of a five-year capital improvement program that is changing the look of the schools.

title: Every Man a King
description: One Market Under God

title: The Real Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Mural Offers Psychic Relief To Recovering War Veterans
description: A new mural on a shard of wall next to a walkway under the Long Island Expressway uses eight-foot capital letters to shout the word ''freedom.'' Since September, the mural has covered a rampart of sprayed obscenity at the bottom of a slope that was thigh-high in debris. Now the artists who painted it are planning to spread the mural to other neighborhood structures.

title: Proximity to a Bus Fuel Leak Dismays the Neighbors
description: Six years ago, when Ronnie Collins bought a two-story frame house on 165th Street, he thought he had made a good investment. But now he is not so sure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINTEL, SYLVIA R.
description: GINTEL-Sylvia R. Cherished wife of the late Sidney. Loving mother of Carol and Barry. Dear sister of the late Adele Arnstein and sisterin-law of Samuel Arnstein. Adored by her cousins, nieces and nephews. Devoted friend of many. A true lady who will be missed forever. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 10:30AM Sunday. Contributions to Multiple Sclerosis Society appreciated.

title: Toward an Orderly End
description: The nation has passed through a political week unlike any other in its long history of presidential elections. Although much of the public may be impatient or even disenchanted, we would argue that the overall picture has been a positive one in which a sense of order seems to be emerging from chaos. American courts have been vindicated as a place of shelter and protection for fairness and democratic values. The decisive rulings came on Friday when the Florida Supreme Court enjoined Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, from certifying Gov. George W. Bush the victor on an incomplete count. Then the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit properly refused the Bush campaign's attempt to end the hand recounts in several Florida counties. This weekend provides a chance to reflect on what looks like the end of the process of selecting the next president.

title: TOLL AND FARE INCREASES
description: PATH fares would double and bridge and tunnel tolls could rise $3 during rush hours under a plan the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is considering, officials said last week. PATH fares have been $1 since 1987, and bridge and tunnel tolls have been $4 since 1991. New York State officials contend that the Port Authority oversubsidizes PATH, which is mainly used by New Jersey residents.

title: It's Hopping in the Lobby As Hotels Party All Night; Innkeepers are turning lounges, bars and everything between, not excluding the elevators, into a club scene.
description: IT'S Saturday night, and amid a swirl of Fendi baguettes, lip-gloss reapplication and leather pants, two polite, middle-aged women from rural Kentucky are standing in the lobby of the Hudson hotel, beaming like julep-happy Derby winners.

title: Lynne Jurgielewicz, Robert Leavitt
description: Dr. Lynne Marie Jurgielewicz, a daughter of Stefne and Joseph Jurgielewicz Sr. of Tilden Township, Pa., was married yesterday to William Robert Leavitt, a son of Patricia and William Leavitt of Dover, N.H. The Rev. Francis Gignac performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Sacred Heart Convent of the Bernadine Franciscan Sisters at Mount Alvernia in Reading, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRVING, EDWARD C.
description: IRVING-Edward C. Suddenly on November 15, 2000. Beloved son of Augusta and the late Val Irving. Services Sunday 1PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Wisconsin Board Wants Training Camp
description: The State of Wisconsin Investment Board has decided to try a little persuasion to improve the quality of corporate directors. The board, which manages $70 billion in assets and is well-known as a shareholder activist, is concerned that directors may not be up to the demands of the job and may need a better understanding of their duties to shareholders. Within the next month, the board expects to mail letters to about 140 companies in which it has a significant stake. It will encourage them to send directors to training programs and will ask what kind of education their directors have already received. A course in cocktails with the chief executive may not count. Reed Abelson

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Ghosts and a Bird Remain
description: Bernard Cooper's funny, compassionate, wistful but uneven collection of stories, GUESS AGAIN (Simon & Schuster, $21), traces private moments in the lives of gay men. Several of the 11 narratives are as whispery and circuitous as a faint pulse: in ''Hunters and Gatherers,'' a man's trip to the supermarket to get food for a Mormon couple's potluck dinner leads to a failed relationship with a guy handing out chili samples. Other tales depict moments of shame that bruise forever: a son of a rigid Christian family falls down his house's basement steps while trying to avoid being found molding a penis onto a G.I. Joe doll, or a boy rashly kisses his sister's boyfriend on the lips in what is ostensibly an attempt to mend a wound there. Cooper, who is also the author of ''Truth Serum,'' a memoir, and ''Maps to Anywhere,'' a collection of essays, has a voice that is fluid and engaging. His concern is less with sex than with how people's lives unfold -- often humorously -- in ways they couldn't have anticipated. In the collection's darker moments, the ghosts of dead and absent lovers and alienated family members crowd around the characters' lives, as thick as sand. It's somehow a characteristic moment when in ''Old Birds,'' the final story, the narrator hears the parrot of his lover, Leon, acting out an exchange between Leon and a former partner who is now dead: ''Honey!'' ''What?'' ''Honey!'' ''What?'' This plaintive little fragment of dialogue, preserved in the ether of the bird's voice, reminds the narrator that a deep emotional attachment is like a ''long and urgent conversation,'' and that loving again after loss can be difficult when ''grief and desire have come to seem the same.'' Charles Wilson

title: A New Assistant Conductor
description: For the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, finding a new assistant conductor did not involve a world search. The man for the job was in Princeton, where he conducts the Princeton Symphony Orchestra.

title: Gore Camp's Argument to Florida Supreme Court
description: Following is the ''Summary of Argument'' from a brief filed yesterday by Vice President Al Gore's lawyers with the Florida Supreme Court. Abbreviations used in the filing are spelled out:

title: Giving It Away
description: BORN three months early and almost blind, tiny Juan Torres did not appear destined for a life of promise. At 8, he was removed from his mother's house and placed in foster care. Between 10 and 14 he lived in 13 homes. But now, at 19, he is on his way to earning a college degree paid for by Don Cecil, an investment banker, and his wife, Jane, a quiet couple in Westchester who had never heard of him until last year.

title: Julia Silverstone, Matthew DeLoca
description: Julia Karen Silverstone, a daughter of Ellen and Edwin Silverstone of New York, was married last evening at the TriBeCa Rooftop in New York, to Matthew Brian DeLoca, a son of Ann and Cornelius E. DeLoca Jr. of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The Rev. Jason E. Leo, an Episcopal priest, officiated at a ceremony that incorporated Christian and Jewish traditions.

title: A Hall of Almost Any Kind of Fame
description: WHAT rage for fame attends both great and small,'' John Wolcot wrote two centuries ago, but the phrase seems a better fit for the current age. The already famous celebrate themselves with an ever-growing collection of awards ceremonies, while the not famous queue up to be a face in the crowd outside ''Good Morning America.''

O'Connor, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, NY. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Francis DeSales Church, Monday at 9:45 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting Sunday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: Sex Charges At the Center Of a Standoff In Taiwan
description: Taiwan's bitter political stalemate veered into soap opera this week, with the news dominated first by unproven charges that President Chen Shui-bian had what the news media dubbed his own ''Monica Lewinsky scandal,'' then by an allegation -- also denied -- that his own disenchanted vice president had spread the story of a presidential affair.

title: Amy Frishman, Jacob Amir
description: Amy Helene Frishman, a daughter of Esther Frishman and Dr. William H. Frishman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Jacob Eytan Amir, a son of Lea and Yair Amir of New Milford, N.J. Rabbi Melvin Sirner officiated at the Doral Arrowwood Resort in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: British Columbia; By Helicopter to a Deep-Powder Heaven
description: If I have to die, I thought, this would be a good way to go: flying through the mountain air for a long, slow-motion moment, then crashing into bottomless snow and tumbling over and over as if I had been caught in heavy surf. No splat, no thud. At some point, the fall ended. My hat, my goggles, my big, fat skis -- all of them were gone. I had managed to pack an astounding amount of snow up my nose. But nothing was broken or even bruised. I was fine.

title: The Election; The New Political Lexicon
description: FROM every political melodrama flows a language unto itself. Witness Richard M. Nixon's ''I am not a crook'' and President Clinton's ''I did not have sex with that woman.'' The vocabulary is reinvigorated, crisis by crisis, evoking a signal moment in the nation's understanding of itself.

title: OCTOBER UNEMPLOYMENT
description: The state's employment rate last month was 3.8 percent, the same as September, according to the State Department of Labor. The state's unemployment rate was 4.5 percent a year ago, and has has matched or been lower than the national level since January 2000. In September the state added 7,500 jobs, mostly in service industries, the department said, reaching a total of 3,943,900. Manufacturing, wholesale trade, and public-sector employment in local government all saw increases, while employment went down in the area of construction, transportation and communications. Anne Ruderman

title: Janet Billig, David Rich
description: Janet Sue Billig and David A. Rich are to be married today by Rabbi Andrew N. Bachman at Bridgewaters, a catering business in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAIMAN, BRUCE P.
description: RAIMAN-Bruce P. Beloved husband of Marcia, devoted father of Stacey & Jay Simens, & Ilyssa Raiman, adored grandfather of Emily Jane, cherished son of Laura Diamond, dear brother of Karen Gnat, loving son-in-law of Mildred Golden. Services ''BoulevardRiverside Chapel'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, at 9:30 on Sunday.

title: The Inner Lives of Purses
description: You can't judge a pocketbook by its cover. So say Kate and Andy Spade, the handbag designers, who just published their first book, ''Contents,'' a collection of ''photographic personality portraits'' featuring the contents of women's purses. ''It occurred to us that the items in your handbag essentially define who you are and what is important to you,'' Ms. Spade said. ''We wondered, 'Would women from all walks of life be willing to show us their personal possessions, their keepsakes, their car keys?' ''

title: Pro Pharma
description: Despite his compelling and understandable personal perspective, Andrew Sullivan uses facts and figures selectively in his defense of pharmaceutical companies. I do not begrudge the manufacturers their profits; I acknowledge that the substantial investment and risk that accompany research and development justify a higher rate of return. However, Sullivan does not mention that the United States government underwrites much of the research and development through cooperative research agreements and other work undertaken by the National Institutes of Health.

title: Something Special For the Toy Chest
description: TOYS can make grown-ups do crazy things. Parents, grandparents and others who have ever loved a child probably know the illogical impulse that can conquer them when little Susie looks up at them with those innocent eyes and says she simply has to have that latest greatest thingamajig, driving otherwise rational people to line up outside a store at 4 a.m. to get it.

title: Justice Is Not the Issue
description: I t's the law, stupid.'' If Michel de Montaigne, 16th-century father of the essay and bedside companion to millions of readers through the ages, were translated into modern times and words, that would doubtless be the lead of his op-ed article on the current fight over the presidential recount.

The acronym Potus (in newspaper style, capitalized and lowercase because it is longer than four letters) stands for the office to be occupied by the man we elected a couple of weeks ago.

title: McEnroe May Step Down
description: Disillusioned with the lack of interest of American stars like Pete Sampras, and discontent with the scheduling of Davis Cup matches, John McEnroe is considering stepping down as captain of the American team, two tennis officials who requested anonymity said yesterday. Yesterday, McEnroe was playing in a senior tournament in Germany and was unavailable for comment. A year ago, the United States Tennis Association handed McEnroe the opportunity to captain the 2000 team in an effort to return the Davis Cup to the United States for the first time since 1995.

title: Yuletide Memories Gathered on the Job
description: While corporate America essentially shuts down on the holidays, the nation's work force hardly comes to a standstill. Many people - from law enforcement personnel, to hotel workers, to telephone operators - are still required to report for duty. What have been some of your most memorable experiences working on Thanksgiving, Christmas or New Year's Day? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959. E-mail: onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.
