title: Where a Beetle Is Still a Beetle, and a Man Keeps Them That Way
description: There is an army of Volkswagen Beetles -- the old ones -- parked outside Clarence Newtown's garage in Riverside: the classic, diminutive bugs that, until the company stopped selling them in the United States in 1979, symbolized thrift, youth, consistency, practicality and much more that the new Beetles do not. Since he began fixing cars -- ''anything Volkswagen'' -- at a Delran Volkswagen dealership in 1973, Mr. Newtown, 57, has been repairing, restoring and hoarding old Beetles. Mr. Newtown. who commutes from his Willingboro home in a 1987 Volkswagen van, is renowned among enthusiasts of old Beetles as the East Coast's preminent Bug doctor (''There's a guy in New Mexico who's also in Beetles, and there are also people in California making parts''). Cars arrive as rusting corpses on the back of flat bed trucks, or sputter in on their own power, from as far away as Rhode Island and Florida. Mr. Newton employs three mechanics, including his daughter, Wanda Faion, who rebuilds engines. Another daughter, Nancy Newton, answers the phones and does the paperwork. Mr. Newton recently spoke of his dedication to Beetles.

title: Rangers Win Despite Late Fleury Penalty
description: Theo Fleury made his first trip back to Calgary as a member of the Rangers memorable tonight, but not for all the right reasons.

title: Call It Silicon Parkway
description: THERE is the Silicon Valley, the Silicon Alley, the Silicon Beltway. None of them are in New Jersey.

title: TROOPERS' TRIAL POSTPONED
description: A Superior Court Judge has postponed until January the trial on lesser charges of two state troopers whose attempted murder counts in the shooting of three minority men on the New Jersey Turnpike in 1998 were dismissed last month. Judge Andrew J. Smithson of Superior Court said last week that both the prosecution and the defense wanted to prepare for the state's appeal of his dismissal of murder charges against John Hogan and James Kenna before going to trial on charges that they falsified their arrest records to conceal evidence they had singled out minorities in traffic stops. Abhi Raghunathan

Herman was a sweet, devoted, highly principled man, who endowed his family with everlasting love and values, ever enduring. Founder, Past President: Kew Gardens Anshe Shalom; and FDR Lodge, B'nai Brith; Wise Counselor. We will never forget him. Service: Sunday, 1 PM, Schwartz Bros., 76th Rd. and Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: New Focus on Punch-Card System

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday comparing the relative value of an individual's vote in the presidential election with the state's electoral vote inverted the numbers for Alaska and Alabama. The value of an Alabamian's vote was 0.96, an Alaskan's 2.20.

title: Attendance Up at NJPAC
description: ''A learning process'' is the phrase that Jeffrey Norman most frequently uses to describe the third year of operation of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, and who can blame him? When Mr. Norman, the center's vice president for public affairs, looks at the center's newly completed annual report, he sees some numbers that are up, some that are down, some that might even seem contradictory on the surface.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-19-00; Something New
description: The first sound on the Beatles' dozenth hit single in America, ''A Hard Day's Night,'' was that of a G7 chord with an added ninth and a suspended fourth strummed by George Harrison on a Rickenbacker electric 12-string guitar. But that's not what you heard. What you heard in July 1964, when the song was released and quickly rose to No.1, was essentially what you'd been hearing for half a year or so from the Beatles: the sound of Something New. The jolting, ringing distention of that unusual but not unpleasing chord, and the wisp of silence between its evaporation and the band crashing in with the first verse (''It's-been-a haaaaard daaaay's niiight''), was nothing so much as a sonic articulation of pleasure in the new-wrought and of promise in what would come next. If you were young enough (and white enough and middle-class enough) when you first heard ''A Hard Day's Night,'' it probably did things to you that are hard to talk about. No, not that. I mean, together with all those other Beatles songs, it essentially shaped your outlook on life.

title: Victory Lapse: Theater Review; But Where's the Leading Man?
description: SO here we are again, glued to the tube at odd hours, sharing helplessly amazed one-liners with strangers in elevators, debating over the dinner table. We're used to this. The O. J. Simpson trial, the Anita Hill-Clarence Thomas hearings, the Oklahoma City bombing, the shootings at Columbine High, the Monica Lewinsky dalliance: more than any creative entertainment, news has the power to focus the national attention. The story of the Florida recount has raised interest to the level that accrued to these dramatic and melodramatic events, gathering us together before a coast-to-coast proscenium, once more an audience communally obsessed, privately agape. American theater.

title: Not Your Father's Chinatown At Hip New Bars and Clubs
description: Chinatown is a neighborhood of dim sum houses, cramped tenements and garment factories, at least according to some nonresidents. But these days, many visitors there are just as likely to spend the night bar-hopping as eating a Chinese meal.

title: Baja; Finding Solitude and Big Fish in Baja California
description: I always thought there were only two Mexicos. One is the Mexico of the package vacation, where all Mexicanness has been neatly eradicated. Yes, you can drink the water, eat the hamburgers and sleep well in the high-rise hotels of Cabo San Lucas or Acapulco, where Spring Break and St. Patrick's Day are highlighted on the calendars. Only the weather is local and natural.

title: Prep School Seeks Slice Of the Dot-Com Era Pie
description: FOR Menlo School, in leafy Atherton, Calif., in the heart of Silicon Valley, the region's lucrative venture capital industry has created something of a problem. Now it may contribute a solution.

title: MILLBURN DEER HUNT
description: The Millburn Township Committee received a permit from the State Fish and Wildlife Council last week that would allow the first controlled deer hunt in a New Jersey municipality. Other such hunts have been allowed in county parks. The township committee will vote Tuesday to hold a hunt sometime in December. Sharpshooters with shotguns will kill about 200 deer in blocked-off areas in Old Short Hills Park and in the town leaf recycling area. Abhi Raghunathan

title: All Aboard; Now Departing Boston for Flagstaff. All Aboard.
description: Shortly after my husband, justin, and I were shown to our dining car table by the hostess on Amtrak's Lake Shore Limited, Ken and Marie, a couple even older than we are, sat down opposite us. Soon we were exchanging obligatory chitchat. Then Marie said, ''Every time we travel something funny happens.'' I asked her what happened the last time.

title: Fast Times Inspiring Topical Songs
description: THESE are both heady and frustrating times for topical songwriters like Sonny Meadows of Huntington. The news is filled with ripe subject matter, but as soon as Mr. Meadows tackles a theme, a new one is demanding to be dissected.

title: This Campus Is Being Simulated
description: Two years ago, a few days before Thanksgiving, Mark Taylor, a faculty member at Williams College, in northwestern Massachusetts, received a phone call from Herbert Allen Jr. Taylor is a professor of humanities, a designation Williams invented for him; his sphere of expertise encompasses religion, philosophy, architecture theory and a couple of other disciplines. Allen is the investment banker and plutocrat famous for the retreat of bankers and plutocrats he hosts each summer in Sun Valley, Idaho. Both men had been members of the Williams community for a quarter-century or so -- Allen is a prominent alumnus and donor -- and they have houses about a mile apart in the thickly forested Berkshire hills in which the college is nestled, but they had never met; nor was it easy to imagine that they would have anything to say to each other. Taylor was one of those protean figures who vex campus life -- a perverse and provocative thinker, a guru and a troublemaker. He was flirting with an attractive offer from the University of North Carolina, and a former Williams administrator had recruited Allen to see if he could do something about it. Allen invited Taylor over for coffee.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about the annual auction and dinner-dance for the French Institute Alliance Francaise misidentified a woman pictured with Michel Legrand, who was honored. She was Lucile Peyre longue, the chairwoman of the gala; Florence Peyrelongue is her daughter.

description: EVERYBODY'S talking about the state of chad in American democracy, but inquiring minds wanna know: What about the state of democracy in Chad?

title: GREYSTONE HOSPITAL
description: The fate of the 545 patients at the Greystone Psychiatric Hospital in Parsippany-Troy Hills Township should be determined in January when a panel will make recommendations to Governor Whitman, it was announced last week. The hospital -- plagued by sexual assaults of patients and failed inspections -- is to be closed, but a decision has yet to be made about how the size and location of a replacement. Karen DeMasters

title: Cyclists Say They're the Missing Element at a Transit Hub
description: It is one of the most famous transportation hubs in the nation, but if you want to ride your bicycle to Grand Central Terminal, good luck. There is no safe place to park a bike at the 42nd Street landmark.

title: Views From the Pulpit Are Legitimate Right
description: I suppose ''Church, State and Tuesday Converge'' [Nov. 5], about Bishop James McHugh's effort to make abortion the No. 1 factor for Catholic voters, was predictable.

description: President Clinton arrived early today in this city, the former Saigon, 25 years after America's final evacuation in the face of victorious Communist forces.

title: The Age of The Mediathon
description: Sympathetic figure? Survivor of a siege? Are we talking about Monica Lewinsky here? Some advice to Miss Lewinsky, who is so reluctant to be thrust into the spotlight or, as she puts it, to be ''introduced to the world.'' Avoid engaging in a sexual relationship with the president of the United States. O.K., if you absolutely can't resist, find something other than a semen-soiled dress to stow away as a memento. And you might want to skip the Barbara Walters interview.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENSON, MILTON
description: LEVENSON-Milton. 96, passed away November 12, 2000. Of Boca Raton, FL, born in Boston, Mass, formerly of New York City. Loving husband of the late Frances, and loving companion of Adele Lederer. Adored father of Ralph (Ruth) Levenson. Cherished grandfather of Neil, Carole, Jimmy and Ellen. Great-grandfather of Jeremy and Freddie. Memorial contributions to Boca Raton Community Hospital, Florida Atlantic Univerisity, Temple Beth-El (333 Southwest 4th Ave, Boca Raton, FL, 33432). For further information ''Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel'' Boca Raton, 800-992-9262.

title: New Financial Disclosure Rule May Not Aid Trading Tactic
description: REGULATION F.D. has been in effect for less than a month.

title: SOAPBOX; Jackie O.'s N.J.
description: WHEN I graduated from Rutgers in 1972, I fled to California, where I've lived the last 28 years. I had hated New Jersey; when I was in high school, I called it ''stunted and stunting.''

title: Children's Books; Wired
description: Joey Pigza

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, DENNIS
description: SINGER-Dennis. The Board of Trustees of the Have A Heart Foundation extends their sympathies to the family of our past president and loyal board member. He exemplified our credo ''that provision for others is a fundamental responsibility of human life''.

title: Anatomy of a Wreck: Racers Strive for a Safe Profile in a Crash
description: True story: The Nascar Winston Cup driver Kenny Schrader is driving his race car, screaming around the track at 180 miles an hour. He is also on his radio with his crew -- discussing handling, gas mileage, maybe something else.

title: Books in Flavors That Say Connecticut
description: FOOD experts can be found throughout Connecticut's hills and valleys, and some epicures even share their wisdom, as the cookbooks of Jacques Pepin and Martha Stewart so amply -- and frequently -- testify. Some authors even write cookbooks specifically about the Nutmeg State, though they are far outnumbered by those covering all six New England states.

title: Help for Mothers in Jail, From Prosecutors
description: It is not exactly unheard of to let incarcerated mothers spend time with their children. There are prison nurseries where women are allowed to stay with their infants, and there is at least one behind-bars program, in California, where mothers can live with no more than two of their children age 6 or under.

title: Lori Chajet, Benjamin Wides
description: Lori Menschel Chajet and Benjamin Andrew Wides, high school English and history teachers in New York, are to be married today by Rabbi Jodie Siff at the Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Fixing in Language A Ceaseless Flow
description: AS the American dance pioneer Isadora Duncan stated in her autobiography, ''My Life,'' shaping an idea into a gesture or into words is a formidable task. ''It has taken me years of struggle, hard work and research to learn how to make one simple gesture,'' she wrote, ''and I know enough about the art of writing to realize it would take me again just so many years to write one simple, beautiful sentence.''

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Andre De Shields; So Hot, He Needs 2 Stages to Do His Misbehavin'
description: YOU representin', baby,'' a friend encountered in the lobby said to Andre De Shields as he left his apartment building, Manhattan Plaza, on West 43rd Street. And indeed he was, dressed in a black tailcoat with a pale blue diamond pattern and a plaid topcoat, on his way to two fund-raising galas Monday night.

title: Absentee Ballots Increase Bush's Lead
description: Day 12 of the presidential election began in the usual way, with wrangling in the counties and in the courts. Here are the highlights.

title: Playwrights Face Armchair Critics
description: WITH a play reading, actors read the words aloud, the audience reacts. One playwright will stand onstage, cloaked by the curtain, watching intently as the audience laughs. Was there a laugh there? he asks himself nervously, checking the script. Another may walk over to the Chinese restaurant across the street. For him, the reaction, any reaction, is just too much to bear. He'll wait for the exit poll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAMARIN, LILLIAN, M.D.
description: TAMARIN-Lillian, M.D. Wife of the late Alfred Tamarin and the late Carlton Barlow. Mother of Susan Eluard (Alain). Grandmother of Nathalie Hurwitz (Jonathan) and Lauren Eluard. A graduate of NYU Medical School, she was a member of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis and a practicing Analyst for 50 years. Contributions in her memory may be sent to Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital. A Memorial Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., on Saturday, November 18 at 3:30 PM.

title: Children's Books; In the Blink of an Eye
description: SILENT TO THE BONE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPION, THOMAS B.
description: CAMPION-Thomas B. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas B. Campion, associated with The Times from 1948 until 1971.

title: Everybody Sing! 'Do, a Deer . . . '
description: The audience dresses up like the popular film's characters. They respond to the dialogue. They sing along with the catchy songs. They boo the bad guys and cheer on the heroes. Campy items are thrown in the air, clever retorts are tossed back to the screen. Midnight at the ''Rocky Horror Picture Show''? No. It's the ''Sound of Music.''

title: The Wall Street Bonanza That Won't Be
description: EVEN if the nasty partisan battle for the White House of recent weeks goes on to infect all of Congress next year, both parties agree on at least one thing: investing in stocks should be a part of any solution to the problem of funding Social Security in coming years. Naturally, all of Wall Street is agog over what such a shift to stocks might mean to the mood of the overall market. Bear markets, be gone!

title: Webber Rules as a King on the Court, for Now, but With Many Options
description: Latrell Sprewell's telephone solicitation of Chris Webber was good for gossip -- not to mention a slap on the wrist from league headquarters. But it had little impact.

title: Back in Minnesota, a Fruitful but Bittersweet Deer Hunt
description: Rain, mud and a swollen Roseau River greeted us at David Tilton's deer camp in northern Minnesota, but slogging about in flooded thickets and woods and huddling in our stands under gray skies, we succeeded in our quest during the few days in which any serious hunting was possible.

title: Macho Mammas Strut Their Stuffing
description: WHEN I think, ''Let's do Thanksgiving,'' I picture a cozy morning, tucking a turkey in the oven with the strains of Macy's parade on TV in the background. I have repressed my memories of those agonizing moments at 4 p.m., when 12 guests appear at once -- all bearing dishes that need heating or refrigeration.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-19-00: Questions for Gene Sperling; Last One Out
description: Q: When did you report to the White House? Was it Inauguration Day, 1993?

title: Election's Lessons Become Focus for G.O.P. Governors
description: The Republican Governors Association ended its annual meeting here today with its new chairman, Gov. James S. Gilmore 3rd of Virginia, declaring that ''against this background'' the meeting had been the best ever for the group.

title: Views From the Pulpit Are Legitimate Right
description: It is no surprise that Planned Parenthood would get bent out of shape when a Catholic bishop encourages his congregation to bring their conscience into the voting booth. After all, abortion is a multimillion-dollar industry for Planned Parenthood.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ZEITGEIST

title: Children's Books; In the Universe, on a Planet, on a Block
description: Madlenka

title: The Brandenburg Gate: Undercover Again
description: The Brandenburg Gate in Berlin, a symbol of a unified Germany, disappeared under scaffolding early this month for a 16-month face lift. The project is aimed at shoring up the monument's unstable 18th-century foundations and using laser technology to strip years of grime from its neo-Classical stonework.

title: Florida Vote Evokes Texas Squeaker
description: With his political career on the line and his cliffhanger Senate election transformed into a titanic legal struggle over how to count the votes, the young Texas congressman looked around a roomful of bright lawyers and asked a question: ''Where's Abe?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLONEY, JOHN J., CPA.
description: MOLONEY-John J., CPA. On November 16, 2000, at his home in his 79th year. Retired CFO and Sr. Vice President of The Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center and formerly of Roosevelt Hospital. Beloved son of the late Edward and Mary Ellen Sheehan Moloney. Dearest husband of Helen (nee Kane). Cherished father of Arthur of Floral Park, Mary Ellen Lohne of Garden City and Bernadette McKinney of Mountain Lakes, New Jersey. Loving grandfather of Megan Eileen and the late John Andrew Lohne and Patrick Arthur McKinney. Fond brother of Anne Vegliante, Maureen Moloney, Patricia Marx and the late Edward Moloney. Respected brother-inlaw of the late Monsignor Arthur J. Kane and the late Dr. Edwin P. Kane. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing Barnes-Sorrentino Funeral Home, 539 Hempstead Ave., West Hempstead (1 mile North Exit 17N SS Pkwy) on Saturday and Sunday, 24:30 and 7-9:30. Mass of Christian burial, St. Thomas the Apostle RC Church, West Hempstead, on Monday at 11 AM. Interment at Calvary Cemetery, Woodside.

title: The Election: The Arbiter; How to Spoil the Spoils
description: PITY Katherine Harris. Just weeks ago it seemed that Florida's secretary of state could expect great things from a George W. Bush presidency. A co-chairman of Mr. Bush's Florida campaign, she was in the cabinet of his brother, Gov. Jeb Bush. She even publicly entertained the notion of a nice job in a Bush administration.

title: Children's Books; Everything You Always Wanted to Know*
description: THE EVERYTHING BOOK

title: Reading a Civilization Through Its Ancient Shards
description: ENTERING the Worcester Art Museum, the first thing a visitor sees is a sixth-century late Roman mosaic, more than 20 feet square, set into the floor of the entrance hall. In it hunters pursue lions, tigers, bear, antelope. A youth on horseback snatches a tiger cub from its snarling mother. Fruit trees, flowers and vignettes of landscapes relieve the carnage, and in the center, a hunter, weary and victorious, crosses his legs and leans against his spear, which pierces the throat of a wild boar.

title: When You Come To Visit Me; Sicily
description: I have to show visitors to my Sicilian farmhouse the Greek temples and the Arab-Norman mosaics, but I enjoy surprising them with an unexpected landscape as well, that of the saline, the checkered swath of salt pans, originally constructed by the Phoenicians about 800 B.C., which hem the island's western shoreline from Trapani to Marsala.

title: Tallahassee Journal; Time Out for the Other Big Game
description: When titans clash in this town, football trumps politics any day.

title: Victory Lapse; One Way to Break a Tie: Start the Next Race
description: WILL Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic fund-raising king, get his wish and become ambassador to the Court of St. James's? Or will Andy Card, the deputy White House chief of staff in Bush I, be promoted to chief of staff in Bush II?

title: Curt Siodmak Dies at 98; Created Modern 'Wolf Man'
description: Curt Siodmak, the novelist, screenwriter and film director who wrote the 1941 film ''The Wolf Man,'' which gave new form to the ancient myth of a man turning into a wolf, adding riveting details like silver bullets, died Sept. 2 at his ranch in Three Rivers, Calif. He was 98.

title: 4 Apply to State for Charter Schools
description: THE Charter School Institute of the State University of New York announced in September that of the 37 applications for new charter schools it had received, 4 were from Long Island. A fifth application from Long Island, for a resource center for home-schooled children, has been withdrawn, at least temporarily.

title: A Study Guide for 'South Park'
description: I TRIED to go database-shopping for some scholarly articles on Comedy Central's ''South Park.'' After all, in a time when academics will solemnly analyze any contemporary ''text'' -- even cigarette advertisements -- ''South Park'' offers enough cultural allusions, and fancy feints of irony, to keep legions of critical theorists busy. I was hoping for titles like ''Big Gay Al, Homoeroticism, and the Semiotics of Masculine Desire'' or '' 'Oh My God, They Killed Kenny': Repetition and the Ideology of Closure in 'South Park.' ''

title: The Age of The Mediathon
description: Frank Rich's article (Oct. 29) on Mediathon journalism is, in fact, a textbook example of how a skillful writer, in the guise of thoughtful analyst taking the high road of historic detachment, can exploit the opportunity to drag our eager noses through the mud one more time. This while avoiding the unseemly pantings found in less dignified venues.

title: Tara Feldman, Jeffrey Skolnik
description: Tara Michelle Feldman, a daughter of Audrey and Barry Feldman of New York, is to be married today to Dr. Jeffrey Marc Skolnik, the son of Sherry and Richard Skolnik of Bellmore, N.Y. Rabbi J. Leonard Romm will perform the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Strip! You're on Constant Camera.
description: A YOUNG woman stares up at me from my computer screen. She has auburn hair and freckles and is strumming the guitar. In a few minutes, she will flop on her futon and play with her dogs.

title: Subway Invaders, From Venus and Mars
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Early Music in Italy, Britain

title: Viewing the County With Teenage Eyes
description: FAMILIES move to the suburbs for their children. But once these children hit their teenage years, many parents regret having left Manhattan, where they wouldn't face issues like . . . teenage driving.

title: Lives; 'I Knew I Was Going to Die'
description: Sally Walker, a paleoecologist at the University of Georgia, was aboard Singapore Airlines Flight SQ006 when it crashed on Oct. 31 in Taipei during takeoff, killing more than 80.Even before takeoff I had a sense of foreboding. On the flight into Taipei from Bali, where I had been at a conference, I knew there was a really bad storm, a really turbulent one. It got so bad that I went into a crouch position with a pillow on my stomach. As we flew in, the plane was wrenching and tilting, and as we landed the pilot gunned the plane and we hit. There were torrential sheets of rain, and I was watching it, incredulous. I had never seen anything like it. The pilot had talked about a storm, and this looked more like a typhoon. I turned to the two Taiwanese ladies next to me and asked, ''Typhoon?'' and they said, ''Typhoon!'' And we just had to laugh.

title: The Endgame in Peru
description: Pressure mounted on Alberto Fujimori, president of Peru, to leave office before his announced July resignation date.

title: FILM; Of the Angry Young Men, One Has the Last Laugh
description: UPON its release in 1963, ''Billy Liar,'' the second feature by the director John Schlesinger, appeared to conform exactly to expectations of the English New Wave, which was even by then beginning to show signs of descending into cliche. It had been shot in black and white (albeit in Cinemascope); it was set in the grim industrial north of England; its protagonist -- an undertaker's clerk with a hyperactive imagination -- is male and frustrated sexually and professionally, and the camerawork and dialogue are self-consciously naturalistic.

title: Rediscovering Old Bratislava
description: I ADMIT, my husband, G. J., and I at first considered our June visit to Bratislava a mere detour from our Vienna-to-Budapest itinerary, a convenient add-on to satisfy our curiosity about what may be one of Europe's least known capitals.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: U.S. v. MICROSOFT

title: Children's Books; Art Without Freedom
description: GATHERING BLUE

title: Automating Your Church Offerings
description: THOSE polished wooden offering plates and wicker collection baskets still make their way across church pews on Sunday mornings. But a growing number of churchgoers are ignoring them, preferring instead to have their offerings automatically deducted from their bank accounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MURIEL
description: STEIN-Muriel. 76, of Florida died November 14, 2000. Formerly on the board of Peninsula General Hospital and was also Chair Lady of the Womens Auxiliary for Peninsula General. She moved to Florida where she became active in starting the Keys Jewish Center and was a board member. She was a great fisherman and a member of the International Womens Game Fishing Association. Muriel was the loving wife of Irving for 54 years. Survived by a brother Mortimer (Florence) Karten of New York and numerous nieces and nephews. Muriel was preceded in death by their daughter, Debra and son Ira. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to the Keys Jewish Center at P.O. Box 1332, Tavernier, FL 33070 or to Mariners Hospital at 91500 Overseas Highway, Tavernier, FL 33070. The Beyer Funeral Home.

title: Retail Shares That Sell Like Teen Spirit
description: MONITORING the fortunes of specialty clothing stores that target young shoppers is like tracking adolescent mood swings. Youngsters are better than ever at following the latest must-have fashions and responding in ways that cause sales, and stocks, to soar or crash.

title: Rambo, First Bubba
description: Two powerful men, both haunted by 'Nam. Then came the final reckoning. A comparison below.

title: High-Tech but Low Grades
description: WHAT does the rest of the country think of New Jersey as a high-tech state? Not much.

title: When Foliage Blazes in the Trees And Big Letters Float in the Sky
description: With the arrival of fall and a succession of warm weekends bathed in honeyed light, the skies over Manhattan were stippled with advertisements written in cloudlike puffs of white. It seemed . . . sudden.

title: It's My Party and You'll Pay for It
description: A GOOD friend just invited me to a formal holiday affair, to be held in a swanky loft in Manhattan's SoHo section. Terrific, I thought -- I love to play dress up -- and then I noticed the $80 fee.

title: Children's Books: Books in Brief
description: HOPE WAS HERE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNORTON, JOHN
description: CONNORTON-John. Formerly of 181 Clark Road, Brookline, MA, November 10, 2000. Loving father of Alice Connorton of New York, Matthew Connorton of San Francisco and Ellen Connorton of Boston. Grandfather of Jake Connorton. Brother of Francis Connorton of Weymouth, William Connorton of Springfield, Alice Rich of Springfield, and the late Rosemary Doocey of Roslindale. Uncle of Roberta Doocey and Frances Doocey of Roslindale. Memorial service and reception on Sunday, December 10, 1-4 PM, at Brookline High School, Brookline, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of John may be made to Alzheimers Association of Eastern Ma., 36 Cameron Ave., Cambridge, MA 02140. Late WWII veteran. For information, Commonwealth Cremation Service, Boston.

title: Artistic Inspiration, Human or Divine
description: WHAT makes a building feel sacred? With no background in the religion's laws or customs, a Baptist can visit a Buddhist temple and be touched by a sculpture's spiritual smile. A Methodist can grasp the devotion behind each calligraphic stroke on a Muslim mosque. A Roman Catholic can sit in a Jewish sanctuary, gaze at the doors of the ark, and feel surrounded by strength and peace.

title: The Plutocracy of the Road
description: At least since World War II, middle-class American families have taken pride in buying new cars. But these days, a shiny new set of wheels in the driveway is increasingly the prerogative of the affluent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, RICHARD M.
description: MARSHALL-Richard M. Died on November 10, 2000 in Greenwich, CT, at the age of 75. He was a decorated Ranger in the 86th Infantry Division of the Blackhawks in World War II. A Harvard Law School graduate, class of '50, a partner in the New York law firm of Marshall & Tucker, and a partner in Marfam Realty, a family business that owns and operates real estate in NYC. He is survived by his sons Peter and James, their wives Meltem and Lorri, his stepson Anthony Averett, his granddaughter Lindsey Sage, and his wife Elinor. A memorial service will be held in December.

title: Palm Island
description: To the Editor: Reading Lisa Fugard's article about Palm Island, ''Doing Nothing Is a Fine Art'' (Oct. 22), I recalled that my husband and I spent our honeymoon there almost 27 years ago.

title: Can March Be Far Behind?
description: The Times's Rafael Hermoso takes an early look at which teams could be on their way to a run at a national championship.

title: Sierra Leone Endures In the Grip of Civil War
description: The Jordanian colonel himself, here as part of a United Nations peacekeeping force, had gotten behind the wheel of his sport-utility vehicle to drive on the lawless road his soldiers had reclaimed. The West Side Boys, one of several militias that rose up as this West African country sank into anarchy, had been coming down from the surrounding hills to terrorize travelers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAHMER, JACK
description: PAHMER-Jack. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of its beloved member, Shelli Pahmer. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: All Wrapped Up
description: Guess what landmarks are under wraps. Answers on Page 82.

title: Adrienne Chandler, Howard Rogatnick
description: Adrienne Anne Chandler and Howard Moss Rogatnick were married last evening at the Yale Club in New York. Rabbi Michael Ehrlich performed the ceremony.

title: Spin the Battle: Fierce Contest To Woo Public
description: Forget, for a moment, the court wrangling and the disputed vote counts. Behind the tedious struggle for legal advantage in Florida is an extraordinarily intense contest for public opinion.

title: The Search for the Meaning of Nov. 7, 2000
description: To the Editor:

title: Holly Atkinson, Galen Guengerich
description: Dr. Holly Gail Atkinson and the Rev. Galen Jay Guengerich were married yesterday at All Souls Unitarian Church in New York, where the bridegroom is a minister. The Rev. Owen Guengerich, the bridegroom's father and a retired Mennonite minister, officiated, and the Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church, the senior minister at All Souls, took part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, LOUIS
description: TAYLOR-Louis. Died November 2, 2000. WWII conscientious objector; hunger striker at Springfield, MO. U.S. Prison; long-time proprietor of Taylor's House of Paperback Books near Columbia University. For word about memorial meeting, call 212-253-5607.

title: When You Come To Visit Me; Tokyo
description: Many tourists to Japan hope to catch a glimpse of majestic Mount Fuji as the morning mists lift. But I take those who visit me here in Tokyo to see a different Fuji -- Fuji Super, my local grocery and sundries store, across from the Yoga train station. Its selection of merchandise, packed into three floors totaling 5,000 square feet, says a lot about contemporary Japanese urban life. Fuji's ground floor includes a pharmacy (six-ounce tube of toothpaste, $1.50), a florist (a bunch of chrysanthemums for family altars, $2.75) and a bakery (a fresh loaf, $2.35), in addition to stationery items (caps to cover sharpened pencils, 85 cents for a pack of five) and toys (''Mama's Helper'' mini-shopping-cart filled with plastic food, $9.10). An array of household cleaning products shares shelf space with pet food ($5.50 for a six-pound bag of dry dog or cat meal).

title: Going Home Again
description: Q. You killed Rabbit off at the end of ''Rabbit at Rest'' -- killed him off prematurely, many of us thought. And it seemed at that point as if you were done with these characters and this material. What made you come back?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, GEORGE
description: WEINSTEIN-George. Loving husband and best friend of Shirley (Greenberg), of 55 years. Father of Stanley, Lenore, Jerrald, Judy, Sarah. Grandfather of Rachael, Moshe, Ronnie and Yinon Libson, Ari, Jay, Dov and Bonnie. Brother of Ira, Janice and Lewis Sachs. Loved by many nieces and nephews. Resided in Israel, formerly of Milwaukee, WI, Great Neck, NY, and Florida. Retired partner of Morris J. Weinstein and Co., CPA's, businessman and philanthropist. Funder of many religious, medical and educational facilities. He will be missed by all who knew him. Let us celebrate his life and emmulate what he belived in. Interment in Israel.

title: Where Stuntman, 'Elvis' and 'Old Blue Eyes' Jostle
description: It was a good crowd at Brunelli's that night.

title: Ideas & Trends: Die Like an Eagle; Indian Rights vs. a National Sanctuary
description: LONG after their military defeat in the 19th century, American Indian tribes remain a world apart. Considered separate governments, Indian reservations are exempt from most state laws, like taxes on cigarettes, and can allow gambling, even if the surrounding state bans it. Practitioners of one Indian religion can legally use peyote, a cactus containing an illegal hallucinogen. Indian burial sites are protected by a 1990 special act of Congress. Devils Tower National Monument, where ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind'' was filmed, is closed to climbers in June so some tribes can perform rites.

title: Publicly Paid Elections Put to the Test in 3 States
description: In Arizona, a long-shot candidate beat the speaker of the State House of Representatives for a pivotal seat in the State Senate. In Vermont, a Progressive Party candidate for governor got a respectable 10 percent of the vote. And in Maine, a third of incoming legislators won their races without having to beg for big contributions.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-19-00: ShopTalk; Making It Count
description: In the days immediately following the presidential election, the eyes of the country turned to an otherwise low-profile group of workers: the people who count ballots in Florida's 67 counties. And there the eyes of the nation stayed. Under intense scrutiny from both parties, and aware of the consequences of their work, they recounted every one of the state's six million ballots. Two people on the front lines were Ron Feingold and Joan Salem- Karoui, from the Miami-Dade County Information Technology Department. Since 1984, they have been part of Miami-Dade's vote-counting team, helping to feed the punch-card ballots into computers. Herewith, they recall what it was like in their office during those first few pressure-cooker days.

title: Housing for People, And for Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REHM, DONALD H., LTC
description: REHM-Donald H., LTC, USA (Ret.), 79, on November 13, 2000, former resident of Northern Virginia and recently of Northport, NY and Melbourne, FL. A 1945 graduate of the U.S. Military Academy, he was a decorated military veteran of the Korean War, duty served at the Pentagon and with the 82nd Airborne Division. Survivors include his wife, Jeanne McSherry Rehm of Northport; his children, Joanne Rehm Johnson of Herndon, VA, Mary Jane Pearcy of San Diego, CA, William Marshall Rehm of Reynoldsburg, OH, and David Marshall Rehm of Williamsburg, VA; sister, Marjorie Rehm Wasilewski of Bethesda, MD; and six grandchildren. Services Wednesday, November 29, 1 P.M., at Ft. Myer Old Post Chapel. Interment at Arlington National Cemetery with full military honors. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in his name to the USMA, West Point Fund-Class of '45, Association of Graduates, 698 Mills Road, West Point, New York 10996, Attention: Bob Lenz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, ELEANOR
description: SANGER-Eleanor. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Eleanor Sanger, associated with The Times from 1936 until 1963.

title: Shaker Gift Drawings Exhibited in Berkshires
description: Shaker religious belief captured on paper is the focus of an exhibition at the Hancock Shaker Village in Pittsfield, Mass. ''Seen and Received: the Shakers' Private Art,'' on display through April 2, features the museum's collection of gift drawings -- 25 pen-and-ink, watercolor and ink-and-watercolor works. The show is being held in the museum's $2.5 million Center for Shaker Studies, which opened in June and encompasses two galleries, a research library and reading room, and a visitors center.

title: The Search for the Meaning of Nov. 7, 2000
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Books; Stay Thy Hand, Popinjay!
description: 24 HOURS

title: Stefanie Olshan, David Shaw
description: Stefanie Paula Olshan, a daughter of Jeanette and Melvin Olshan of Marlboro, N.J., was married last evening to David Lawrence Shaw, the son of Joyce Segal and the stepson of Eric Segal of Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Don Weber officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, RABBI ALEXANDER M.
description: SCHINDLER-Rabbi Alexander M. NATE, the National Association of Temple Educators deeply mourns the death of our member and friend, Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler. He was a staunch advocate of the importance of education and learning in Jewish life, and he worked to serve the Reform movement and Jews everywhere with great vision, understanding and dedication. His presence will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Rhea, children and grandchildren. Sharon S. Morton, President Rabbi Stanley T. Schickler Executive Director

title: A Disputed Election's End Was Only the Beginning
description: THOSE searching for a precedent for Indecision 2000 have repeatedly turned to the tortured election of 1876, which pitted Samuel J. Tilden, a Democrat, against Rutherford B. Hayes, a Republican.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-19-00: Point Of Purchase; How Sweet It Is
description: What do you get when you take C12H22O11, knock off three hydroxyl groups and, in a special patented process, replace them with three chlorine atoms?

title: Sunday: a Day of Rest, or Is It?
description: NEW YORK may be the city that never sleeps, but Connecticut, on Sunday nights, doesn't have that problem -- perhaps because it's part of New England, which traditionally treats Sunday as a day of rest.

title: Frommer's It's Not; Guidebook Burnishes a Rugged Image
description: Almost a decade ago, a newcomer riding the elevated F train over the Gowanus Canal was told to look out the window. ''That's Red Hook, where the gangsters throw dead bodies,'' said her friend, pointing to the murky water below. ''Even the subway doesn't stop there.''

title: Morocco
description: To the Editor: Steven A. Holmes, in ''Into Berber Country'' (Oct. 29), does not mention the tented camp in Merzouga. He lost a great opportunity to experience the desert dunes in all the glory of twilight, starlight and sunrise. Sleeping under the elaborately carpeted tent amid the dunes offered, with a little imagination, a sense of a Berber encampment in days gone by. For dining and socializing, a large sandy area was generously covered with carpets. We also rode camels into the dunes, but from our camp. Facilities, it must be noted, were primitive.

title: He's a Party Animal
description: LeVar Burton surprises his furry frined Roy with a birthday party at Three Dogs Bakery in ''Pet Stories: You Don't Have to Walk,'' the season-premier episode of ''Reading Rainbow,'' on Monday at 2:30 p.m. on Channel 13. The Emmy Award-winning series, now in its 18th year, focuses on children's literature -- in this case, Seymour Reit's ''Dog's Tale'' and Syd Hoff's ''Dinosaur'' -- through readings and re-enactments.

title: An Injury Factor to Consider
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: OUT THERE/Stockholm; The Swedes, Too, Know About Cool
description: THE other evening, two Englishmen who had just arrived in Stockholm were wandering around the lobby restaurant, named the Lobby Restaurant, of the Lydmar Hotel. A favorite hangout of the city's music and media crowd, the Lydmar is the sort of place where the waiters moonlight as D.J.'s and the tiny telephone-boothlike elevator offers 10 different kinds of music. Guests can press buttons to choose soul, jazz, Latin or dance-club genres like ambient as they whoosh up to their rooms. Often, people ride the elevator up and down just for its built-in jukebox.

title: Corrections
description: An art review last Sunday about a show called ''Puzzles'' at the Katonah Museum of Art misstated the given name of the curator of mechanical puzzles and mistakenly referred to him as ''Ms.'' He is Jerry, not Amy, Slocum.

title: G.O.P. and Democrats Trading Accusations on Military Votes
description: The two sides traded accusations of misconduct and manipulation today in the overnight counting of absentee ballots cast by Floridians abroad, a tally marred by confusion over rules and vastly differing standards from one county to the next.

title: HOUSING PRICES
description: The median price of houses in the Middlesex-Somerset-Hunterdon area increased 17.9 percent in the third quarter of 2000 compared with the third quarter in 1999, the largest increase in New Jersey and one of the largest in the Northeast, according to the National Association of Realtors. The median price of existing houses for the three counties was $234,700. The median price in the Bergen-Passaic area was higher at $245,900, but it was a smaller increase at 10.8 percent. The median price nationally rose 5.1 percent, two points more than inflation, to $142,800. Karen DeMasters

title: Been Up So Long It Looks Like Down
description: Two empty stores loom like bookends at either end of town. Sandwiched between the two properties -- where a Saks and a Marsh jewelers once sold costly clothing and trinkets -- are eight vacant storefronts along a one-block stretch of downtown.

title: U.S. to Preserve More of Pine Barrens
description: Secretary of Energy Bill Richardson announced that 530 acres of pine barrens on the Brookhaven National Laboratory campus would be permanently preserved under an agreement with the federal Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: College Endowments Learn to Live With Risk
description: SOME years it is the football coach. Others, the Nobel Prize-winning physicist. This year, however, the biggest celebrities among college faculty members and administrators sit not in the field houses or the science labs but in the investment offices, where they have guided endowments to record gains.

title: Only the Best for Man's Best Friend (Woman's Too)
description: YOU'VE tiled your kitchen and refinished your counters in a matching hue. You've redecorated your living room in elegant tones, and you've carpeted and papered your upstairs, each bedroom in its own color scheme.

title: Children's Books; 10 Best Illustrated Books
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from the Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 2000. Every year since 1952, the Book Review has asked a panel of judges to make a selection from among the several thousand children's books published that year. The judges this year were Lisa Von Drasek, children's librarian at the Bank Street College of Education in New York; Martha Davis Beck, the editor of The Riverbank Review of Books for Young Readers; and Mordicai Gerstein, an artist whose most recent illustrations appear in ''The Jar of Fools: Eight Hanukkah Stories From Chelm.'' As a matter of note, Gabrielle Vincent won this award once before, and Anita Lobel has won it twice.

title: Stacy Singerman, Matthew Brudner
description: Stacy Michelle Singerman, the daughter of Margaret Singerman and Dr. Laurence Singerman of Moreland Hills, Ohio, was married yesterday evening to Matthew Scott Brudner, a son of Roberta and Richard Brudner of New York. Rabbi Yaakov Neurenberg officiated at the Four Seasons Resort in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: When You Come To Visit Me; Sarasota, Fla.
description: When I was in Prague this summer and my hostess asked me what I wanted to see, I told her, ''I want to see the fancy neighborhoods where the rich people live. Show me the Beverly Hills of Prague.''

title: Miami Makes Its Case With Shutout
description: Laughter and chatter filled the stuffy room. Not a single Miami football player seemed worried or puzzled or disappointed about what had happened tonight. The Hurricanes, who came here to beat Syracuse, whipped the Orangemen, 26-0. What could possibly be worrisome or puzzling or disappointing about that?

description: Eugenia Rawls, a theater actress who portrayed Tallulah Bankhead and others in one-woman shows, died on Nov. 8 in Denver. She was 87.

title: Labyrinth Is Razed; Minotaur Among the Homeless Now
description: Every morning over the summer, residents of tall apartment buildings could peer down from their windows and watch a labyrinth unfolding on a lot at 136th Street and Willis Avenue. The lot had once been called the Devil's Playground because of the drug use there, so these meditative circles of tree stumps and wood chips meant a lot to the community.

title: Neighbors Mourn a Lover Of Dogs and Their People
description: In the 45 years that Kurt Kjellin sold antiques in the East Village, he was known for his intense work ethic, generous spirit and strong, gnarled hands, which seemed always to be busy. Neighbors remember his willingness to listen and offer counsel and his love of animals, particularly dogs, many of which he rescued from the streets.

title: First Woman to Lead Ivy League College Is the Highest-Paid University President
description: The president of the University of Pennsylvania, Judith Rodin, the first woman to run an Ivy League institution, had the highest annual salary and benefits of any college president in the country in 1998-99, receiving $655,557, a survey by The Chronicle of Higher Education shows.

title: The Age of The Mediathon
description: Your article made me realize how the media circus has dominated my life. In 1949, when television was new, I remember Kathy Fiscus, a little girl who was stuck in a well. Her story was covered around the clock. I could never resist human drama. I think these stories serve as our Greek tragedies in a way.

title: A Presidential Scholar Not Seen on Geraldo
description: THE country was in an uproar: A closely contested election had left the nation uncertain about who was to be the new president of the United States.

description: MANDELL-Irving. Beloved husband of Louise. Devoted father of Norman and Susan. Cherished grandfather of Geoffrey and Zachary and a very special uncle of Anne, Doris and Eilene. Services today at 11:30 at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels,'' 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY (corner Avenue V). Interment Beth Moses Cemetery.

description: EVEN if you don't have a diploma from any of Connecticut's colleges or universities, it is easy to get swept up in school spirit by stepping into a campus bookstore and immersing yourself in that school's culture.

title: With No Regrets, Williams Is at Ease at Duke
description: It came down to Rutgers or Duke for Jason Williams. But whatever pangs the celebrated point guard had in bypassing his home state school for Duke are long gone. A trip to Madison Square Garden last season as a Blue Devils freshman reinforced Williams's decision.

title: The Age of The Mediathon
description: I was disappointed that Frank Rich, whose work I have admired, elected to include an interview with O.J. Simpson. And I was further disappointed that you chose to feature Simpson on your cover. To present this man's inauthentic alarm at the news media he paid others to manipulate to secure his freedom -- and to do so without irony -- is part of the problem.

title: A Walkway Filled With Words and Images of Connecticut's Past
description: THE crew of a whaling ship in New London harbor, circa 1907; a smiling young Algonquian man, portrayed in 1645; munitions workers during World War II; a Yankee peddler in his horse-drawn wagon; the legendary Charter Oak -- these are some of the images, well known or unfamiliar, chosen to tell the story of Connecticut in an exhibition mounted along the walkway between the Capitol and the Legislative Office Building in Hartford.

title: Defiant Chinese Muslims Keep Their Own Time
description: In this far western outpost, where a Muslim majority lives restively under Chinese rule, you can tell a lot about a man's politics by how he sets his clock.

title: How Easy Cash Became Hard Debts
description: IN a Nov. 2 report, ''The Other Side of Leverage,'' Ravi Suria, a convertible bond analyst at Lehman Brothers, examined the consequences of the recent surge in debt at telecommunications companies at a time when intense competition for customers had reduced revenue growth. It is a sobering piece of research.

title: When a Franchise Holder Says 'So Long'
description: CUSTOMERS usually pick a brand name over an unknown label, which is often why franchisees decide to own and operate a business on someone else's terms, rather than setting out on their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENTHAL, HELEN O.
description: LOWENTHAL-Helen O. 87. November 17. Peacefully at home. Beloved wife of Jesse for 64 years. Cherished mother of Judy L. LaSorsa and Connie Lowenthal. Adoring and prized grandmother of Anna and Nicholas LaSorsa. Sister of Natalie Langner and Henriette Wallach. A loving, generous and beautiful lady, with a lifelong talent for friendship. Rest in peace

title: Rare New Housing for Historic New Castle, Del.
description: WITH more than a third of the homes in this city's beguiling historic area dating to before 1860, real estate agents have been known to call the few Victorian houses here new construction.

title: PLUS: TRACK AND FIELD; DeGennaro Finishes On a High Note
description: Mike DeGennaro, a fifth-year senior at University of Delaware, made his final college race a triumphant one, taking the 92nd annual Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America men's cross-country championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Children's Books: Books in Brief; Wild Pig-Rats and Carrot-Headed Dogs
description: To children, dreams seem without rhyme or reason. In NIGHT GARDEN: Poems From the World of Dreams (Margaret McElderry, $16; ages 7 to 10), Janet S. Wong's poems slide in and out of rhyme and capture the wacky reasoning of dreams. Nothing heavy here. Fifteen wispy verses -- insubstantial as their subjects -- trail down these pages, leaving the reader with a fleeting image or insight: how the dead return to visit the ones they love most, why a dreamer finds herself speaking fluent French, how sickbed dreams are most vivid. Or, ominously for parents, how the seeds of terror are planted by television and ''in the quiet of the night / those things will spring into your dreams, / giving you a frightful scare -- / a news-at-seven true nightmare.''

title: Secrets of The Paris Metro
description: PARIS'S Metro system, that baby of the belle epoque, is celebrating its 100th anniversary this year. With its 50 miles of corridors, its 131 miles of tracks and its 297 stations -- including the cavernous Chatelet-les-Halles, considered the world's largest public transit station -- the Metro is a parallel, underground city, one that is as deeply embedded in the French psyche as it is in the limestone and gypsum of Paris itself.

title: How Florida Got Close Enough to Fight Over
description: A half-moon hung low over Miami at 1 a.m. on Election Day, and the air was thick with possibility. Vice President Al Gore had drawn a large crowd, most of it in tight jeans, to the sands of South Beach for the final rally of his two-year campaign. Embraced by celebrities like Stevie Wonder and Robert De Niro, he was clearly moved, and encouraged. ''We're going to carry Florida!'' he vowed in an arm-pumping speech. ''We're going to win the White House!''

The city continues to enjoy a trendy image, and there's an infectious buzz in the air, especially in the streets of Soho, some of which are now closed to cars after dark.

Arthur and his friends are no exception as they make plans for Christmas, Hanukkah and Kwanzaa, only to watch their preparations unravel as the festivities fast approach, leaving them to face perhaps the ultimate holiday question: do the wrappings and the trappings really matter?

title: A Master Of Laughter In Motion
description: IN a career in animation that spans 69 years, Chuck Jones has directed more than 300 films whose characters -- Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, Porky Pig, Pepe le Pew, Roadrunner and Coyote -- have saturated the American consciousness and become a joyous staple of the culture. And unlike Walt Disney -- the other person whose name is synomymous with the so-called Golden Age of Hollywood studio cartoons -- Mr. Jones, who turned 88 on Sept. 21, is still with us. His long career will be celebrated Wednesday night on Channel 13 in ''Chuck Jones: Extremes and In-Betweens, a Life in Animation,'' part of the ''Great Performances'' series on PBS.

The measure of my hospitality therefore depends on two things: an extremely close relationship to the invitees and their willingness to see Washington on their own.

He was in Herrlingen, near Ulm, not in Berlin. The article also misstated the year that a commander of Army Rangers, Lt. Col. James Earl Rudder, died. It was 1970, not 1976.

title: Plenty of Movement to Get Nowhere
description: The stock market bounced around last week but thanks to a hefty gain on Tuesday, when the Nasdaq composite posted its 10th-biggest advance on record, the major indexes wound up about where they started. The stalemated presidential election dampened spirits, as did several corporate earning warnings. Federal Reserve policy makers did little to encourage investors looking for an interest-rate cut.

title: On the Run With Wolf B36
description: I would like to see the wolf, grizzly, jaguar, etc. reintroduced to their former habitats. You can be sure there will be a lot of complaining from ranchers who may lose livestock. So when it happens, why not just throw money at them. If the government can't afford it, Ted Turner (and other alpha males) must have pockets deep enough to shut everybody up. Pay enough, and we will be up to our ears in fat, happy cows, sheep, wolves and ranchers.

title: Sprewell Plays On, Despite Aching Back

He had just helped lift the Knicks to a surprising and invigorating victory over the Phoenix Suns, but he looked like anything but a conquering hero.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; What He Did in the War
description: June Feldman and Tracy Sugarman were Glenn-Miller-and-saddle-shoes college sweethearts who married just before he went off to World War II as a junior naval officer. His war was a slogging time of loading and unloading, plodding the same saltwater trails to deliver men and materiel from England to the threshold of war at the French beaches and channel ports -- a time of never-dry clothing and repetitive work, always redolent of fuel oil, stale sweat and tobacco smoke, and punctuated by occasional combat from D-Day on, as well as by savagely bad weather at sea. At home, June wrote him letters and saved his replies, together with his sketchbooks, stored ''in the cellar of every house we've had'' until the 50th anniversary of D-Day was approaching and they decided to look at them for the first time since Sugarman came home from the Navy in 1945. ''I found my own Baedeker to a time when June and I were both 21, and the war was the only world we knew,'' he writes in MY WAR: A Love Story in Letters and Drawings (Random House, $30). Sugarman's art (he later became a professional illustrator) underscores the affecting and evocative qualities of the book. One sketch leaps off the page, showing an almost fierce-faced teenage swabbie in dungarees, white hat perched resolutely on the back of his head, his waist girdled with a web belt from which hangs a holstered .45 seemingly half as big as he is. David Murray

title: Children's Books: Books in Brief; It Was a Hot and Stormy Day . . .
description: Out of the starting gate with a bang, Belgrade-born Manya Stojic makes an assured debut with RAIN (Crown, $15.95, ages 2 to 5), a vibrant picture book. ''It was hot,'' she begins, whisking readers to the African savanna and setting the stage with smoldering shades of high-noon yellow and glowing-ember orange. ''The red soil was hot and dry and cracked.'' As a cast of animals anticipates an impending storm, Stojic neatly introduces the twin concepts of the five senses and the cyclical nature of weather. ''The rain is coming! I can smell it,'' says a porcupine, who hastens to tell the zebras the news.

title: Tales of Resistance
description: In ''Resistance: Untold Stories of Jewish Partisans,'' a documentary by Kenneth M. Mandel, the forest is the telegenic star, but the most compelling performers are the aging Jews who recount tales of striking back at the Nazis from beneath the kind of canopy few were accustomed to. Mr. Mandel, 53, of West Orange, filmed the forest in gauzy black and white, with sunlit, gently swaying branches that suggest more a haven than a hideout. The Emmy Award-winning documentarian and Newark native filmed the old partisans in color, letting their stories speak for themselves: a doomed mother tells her son to flee the ghetto and avenge her death; a father is forced to hang his own son because another son fled their work camp. Mr. Mandel, who will speak at the debut of ''Resistance'' tonight at 7 p.m. at Temple Tefilo-Israel, 432 Scotland Road in South Orange (admission $18), said the interviews were not cathartic. ''Nobody feels better,'' he said. ''They feel it's their duty to tell the story.'' Steve Strunsky

title: The Deer Hunter

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENERSTEIN, RITA
description: DENERSTEIN-Rita, 82, of Valley Cottage, November 14, 2000 after a long illness. Daughter of the late Samuel Asbel and Minnie Zevin. She is survived by her husband, Hyman; their son, Dan; their two grandsons, Matthew and Evan; her sister, Sarah Jacobson and her brother, Bernard Asbell. Her immediate and extended family, particularly the members of her family organization, the Zevin descendants, mourn her loss. Rita had a long career as a bookkeeper and office manager for Sam Goody, and the Cambridge Book Company, which was an affiliate of The New York Times. Memorial service at Hellman's Funeral Chapel, 15 State Street, Spring Valley, New York, 3PM, Monday, November 20. Donations in her name can be made to United Hospice of Rockland and/or Meals On Wheels of Rockland County.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JAMES J., M.D.
description: SMITH-James J., M.D. 88. Former director of the Nuclear Medicine Service for the Veterans Administration, pioneer in the fields of Endocrinology and nuclear medicine, and devoted husband of the late Beatrix Goldzieher Smith, M.D., died on September 9 in Washington, D.C. He was the first person to describe the uses of ultrasound in medical diagnosis, and the first to describe and demonstrate that alcoholism is a genetic inborn error of metabolism. Dr. Smith showed, also for the first time, the phenomenon of mixed cerebral dominance and metabolic disturbances in patients with dyslexia. He developed innovative and important new approaches to treatment in all these fields. Before moving to Washington D.C., he had an active practice in New York City as well as prominent hospital and university appointments. James Smith was a keenly original thinker and brilliant diagnostician, a compassionate healer who combined analytical and intuitive skills to resolve seemingly intractable puzzles of illness. Forward thinking and visionary, he had a gift for seeing things not only as they were but as they could be. During World War II, Dr. Smith was Chief of Medical Intelligence for the OSS (Office of Strategic Services) in Europe. James J. Smith is survived by two sisters, his children Briged Smith, Jennifer Smith, Andrew Smith, son-in-law Samuel Rubin, and two grandchildren, Clara and Julia Rubin-Smith. His funeral was at Arlington National Cemetery. Contributions may be made to the Hospice of Washington and Doctors Without Borders. Condolences may be sent to the family , c/o Jennifer F. Smith, Box 589, Belmont MA 02478.

title: Multiple Motives
description: To the Editor:

title: Pro Pharma
description: Sullivan gets it right when he chides those who complain about the high cost of prescription drugs. A sense of entitlement about the ''right'' to affordable health care certainly contaminates the debate about the cost of drugs in particular and health care more generally.

title: Pro Pharma
description: Sullivan implies that high drug prices are a transient phenomenon, related to the temporary monopoly granted to drug companies. Once the patents expire, generics solve the problem, right? Wrong. When this happens, the big drug companies can pay off the little guys in return for not marketing a generic product. In one case, a drug used for high blood pressure and prostate disease was prevented from going generic by using this kind of bribery. Or they can repackage old wine in new bottles, as when Eli Lilly recently gave Prozac, which had to go generic, a new name and marketed it as a patented name-brand remedy for mild PMS.

title: Children's Books; Can You Spare a Rhyme?
description: The Remarkable Farkle McBride

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Dining Out column on Nov. 5 about Elmer's, a new restaurant in Glen Head, described the interior decor incorrectly. The charcoal gray accent color is on the walls, not on the natural wood floor.

title: Police Road Checks to Focus On Sobriety and Child Seats
description: More than 10,000 police departments around the country will begin a campaign on Monday to enforce laws on drunken driving and child car seat safety, prompted by a federal study that found a tight link between the two.

title: BUSH'S LEAD STANDS AT 930 AFTER OVERSEAS COUNT
description: Gov. George W. Bush's lead in Florida more than tripled today as all absentee ballots from overseas were opened and tallied. But his campaign was unable to claim the victory it had expected, as both sides awaited a hearing on Monday in the Florida Supreme Court.

title: A Parkway With Roots in Pollution Fight
description: WHEN the Bronx River Parkway opened on Nov. 5, 1925, it became the first limited-access parkway in the United States and part of Westchester's first county park.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on Oct. 22, about Los Cabos, Mexico, at the tip of Baja California, referred incorrectly to the area's size ranking among peninsulas. While reference works give length figures for some peninsulas, geographers say there is no uniform standard to determine exactly where a land mass ends and a peninsula begins. Thus Baja cannot be ranked fourth.

title: Pro Pharma
description: Andrew Sullivan (The Way We Live Now, Oct. 29) totes up his own annual drug bill, paid ''mercifully'' by his insurance company, and cheerfully informs us that the amount is ''easily more than I pay separately for housing, food, travel or clothes.'' There's hope for those left out, however, if they will only be patient until ''patents run out and generics compete.'' Meanwhile, they can console themselves with the thought of better drugs, free, for Sullivan. ''Mercy,'' sad to say, has nothing to do with it.

title: City Survives a Flood, But Faces an Exodus
description: KEN TOWERS had planned to be retired by now, but nearly four years after a flood devastated his two restaurants and much of this city of 47,000, the 62-year-old restaurateur is still struggling to stay ahead.

title: With That Autumn Nip in the Air, It's Time to Turn to Pears
description: WITH autumn in full blaze, the suitable fruit choices no longer involve peaches, nectarines, strawberries or cherries. Those demanded summer's warmth. Now is the season for pears, apples, quinces, cranberries and dried fruit.

He died on Nov. 1 at his home in Santa Monica, CA. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Pacific Palisades, CA, on November 20 at 4 P.M.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The Cost Of Repairs At a Condo
description: Q. For the last four years, our condominium board has levied special assessments for repairs. The assessments were allocated on a per-unit basis, even though the bylaws require that they be prorated according to each owner's percentage of the common interests. As a result, each owner was assessed the same amount; some owners paid more than they should have, and others paid less. The allocation was properly calculated this year, but no provision has been made for repaying the owners who were overcharged in previous years. Is the board responsible for repaying those losses? Also, can it recover undercharges in past years from current unit owners, even though those owners have only recently purchased those units? . . . John R. Sachs, Manhattan.

title: Lasers and Laptops Join Hard Hats At Construction Sites
description: CONSTRUCTION company officials are among the first to admit that their industry had been slow to embrace technology. ''It's been a dinosaur,'' according to Joseph Maguire, a vice president of Bovis Lend Lease in New York. But as if making up for lost time, the industry, which the Commerce Department estimates at more than $400 billion, has bestirred itself in recent years to embrace technology with an alacrity that, if it does not yet approach warp speed, at least takes construction out of the Mesozoic Era.

title: Critics Say an Arch, From a Painter's Blue Period, Isn't Art
description: A few months from now, a new bright blue steel structure that frames the entrance to Downtown Brooklyn may be torn down. Or it may be joined by two others at nearby intersections. It all depends on the outcome of a battle between the organization that erected the arch and the local community board, which says neither it nor the city's Art Commission ever approved it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LODICO, CARMINE
description: LoDICO-Carmine. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Carmine LoDico, associated with The Times from 1960 until 1985.

title: Parents Quiz Council: Why Not a School in the Armory?
description: Flustered after a ride down from the Bronx, Myra Goggins arrived in a committee room in City Hall last week and sat on a hardwood chair in the back.

title: Homage to a Theatrical Comet of the 80's
description: LAST Wednesday, an enterprising Off Broadway company called Rattlestick Productions began a three-week festival devoted to Harry Kondoleon's work. Some might ask, who is Harry Kondoleon? Others will recall that for a decade beginning in 1983 he was practically ubiquitous in the New York theater. He had plays produced at the Manhattan Theater Club, Second Stage, Playwrights Horizons, Theater for the New City, the Public Theater and at Circle Repertory. He won the George Oppenheimer/Newsday Play writing Award for ''Christmas on Mars'' in 1983, the same year that he won his first Obie Award as ''most promising young playwright.'' He won another Obie in 1993 for ''The House Guests.'' In that same span of time, he published a volume of poetry, mounted an exhibition of his paintings, directed several shows and wrote a number of novels as well as screenplays that were never produced. This torrent of activity came to a halt in March 1994, when he died of complications from AIDS. He had just turned 39.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, HENRY J.
description: MEYER-Henry J., Professor Emeritus Social Work and Sociology (1957-1978), University of Michigan, died October 29. Scholar of sociological and social work theory, labor disputes, mental health and family service program evaluation, community organization, and population policy. Founded University of Michigan's Joint Doctoral Program in Social Work and Social Science, the first of its kind. Survived by his wife Suzanne, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE WALKING TOUR, by Kathryn Davis. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $13.) Set in both the present and an environmentally blighted future, this complex whodunit is narrated by a woman whose parents died in a mysterious accident during a walking tour in Wales. The result is a ''brilliant and sometimes unbearable'' novel packed ''with nests of stories and symbolic digressions,'' Lorna Sage said here last year. The same publisher has reissued the author's first novel, Labrador ($13), a coming-of-age tale about a girl who tries to escape her obsession with her dangerous older sister by retreating into a fantasy world and following her grandfather to Labrador. ''Davis has taken the sad and binding stuff of many a first novel . . . and fashioned genuinely new embodiments for it,'' John Crowley wrote in these pages in 1988.

description: HAS a sip of a soft drink ever inspired thoughts of how they put the pop into soda? Do you ever wonder, ''How was this made?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, ANNE YOULE
description: STEIN-Anne Youle. Columbia University Health Sciences has lost a great friend. Anne Youle Stein, age 101, died at New YorkPresbyterian Hospital on November 17, 2000. Mrs. Stein, a philanthropist had an avid interest in helping to advance health care which perpetuated a close relationship with many members of the Columbia medical faculty. She became a major benefactress for the Department of Orthopedic Surgery where she named a floor which houses administrative, research and library space and funded the establishment of an endowed professorship. She also provided the Department of Medicine with an endowed teaching fund. Her kindness and support will keep her memory fresh in our hearts for many years to come. Dr. David Hirsh Interim Dean for Research College of Physicians & Surgeons Columbia University Dr. Thomas Q. Morris Interim Dean for Clinical & Educational Affairs College of Physicians & Surgeons Columbia University

title: Style; The Hills Were Alive. . .
description: What New Hollywood envies most about Old Hollywood isn't that there was a Cary Grant or a Katharine Hepburn who could star in a ''Philadelphia Story,'' or a George Cukor who could discover both stars and eventually make such a film, or even that there was a Philip Barry who could write the play with such effortless wit. What is most enviable about Old Hollywood is that it was such a tiny little colony that it was easy for talents like these to find one another. It was, after all, a Hollywood so minute that, as Shelley Winters (also discovered by Cukor) tells it, she could be hitchhiking to her screen test for Cukor's ''Double Life'' and be given a ride by Lou Costello. Or she could be heading off to her first interview with Hedda Hopper to publicize the film and run into Fred MacMurray at a Chinese restaurant and be offered a few words of advice. (The advice? Bring up Hopper's secret tryst with a drunken John Barrymore.)

title: Hiking Theories: Going Back and Forth
description: I FIRST discovered a serious flaw in the Loop Theory late one afternoon in Dartmoor. Since my husband, James, and I had arrived at our country-house hotel two hours before dinner, we decided to take a short reviving hike on the nearby moor. Studying my British Ordnance Survey map, I noticed the tantalizing notation of a stone circle not far from a parking area. Off we went.

title: A Rational Vision That Lets You Know Who's Boss
description: THE new United States Courthouse and Federal Building in Central Islip, N.Y., designed by Richard Meier & Partners, brings to mind those guided visualizations in which we are instructed to imagine our parents growing infinitesimally small. The objective of this mental exercise is not to bump off the parents but to render them within the emotional scale of the child's empathic power. Richard Meier's courthouse has a similar effect. Topping off at 12 stories, the building is not small; in recent summers, Fire Island vacationers have watched it nearing completion across the water. But compared with Meier's Olympian Getty Center, the courthouse is a bagatelle. We have to readjust the scale of our mental landscape to take it in. In doing so, we restore Meier to the human scale of his contemporaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONALD, LARRY

The entire ConHealth Partners family acknowledges with sadness the passing of Larry Donald, beloved brother of our dear friend and colleague, Linda Donald, Executive Director of Renal Research Institute. To Linda, her sister-in-law Nancy, nephew David and all of Larry's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Robert G. Newman, M.D. President & CEO Peter A. Kelly Executive V.P. & COO Thomas J. Hayes Executive V.P., Corporate Affairs

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Windfalls In Tax and Water Bills
description: FEW people would idly sit by if their banks failed to credit the interest due on savings accounts. And few people would hesitate to protest if items rung up by supermarket cashiers exceeded the correct sales prices.

title: Michele Browne, Michael Culver
description: Michele Anne Browne, the daughter of Rose Browne of New York and Stanley Browne of Bloomfield, N.J., was married on Friday to Michael Christian Culver, a son of Mary and David Culver of Westmount, Quebec. The Rev. Chris Ney, a Disciples of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church in New York.

title: Grand Old Coats
description: ''Pat doesn't have a mink coat,'' Richard M. Nixon said of his wife in his Checkers speech, struggling to remain Dwight D. Eisenhower's running mate in 1952. ''But she does have a respectable Republican cloth coat.'' For the next two decades, plain cloth coats were referred to as Republican slipcovers, even the ones Democrats wore. This year's coats, seen here, echo the period looks: princess style, slim and fitted, or boxy, all with hemlines that cover the knee and stop around the top of the calf. And now, after decades of struggle to gain acceptance in trousers, many women have voted for the silk-stocking leg of the early 50's.

title: An Accidental Utopia
description: WHEN I was a child, growing up in Stuyvesant Town, I did not know any women who live as I do now, in a house in the woods, miles from any city. I am a stranger even to my imagination then. Now, the trees dwarf my house, fight for sky space. They've provided fuel for the wood stove, shelves for my study. There's a pond in my distant view, beyond the clearing we call a lawn. Dark as well-brewed tea, it teems with life.

title: Views From the Pulpit Are Legitimate Right
description: Bishop McHugh saved few souls and did a disservice to Catholics and the Catholic Church by making ours a one-issue religion, focused strictly on opposition to abortion in electoral decision-making.

title: Freeing Up A Logjam In Prison
description: The state came a step closer to naming a new chief for the embattled parole board last week when the Senate Judiciary Committee unanimously approved the nomination of a professor and former parole officer to head the board.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: KIND OF BLUE

title: Elizabeth Smith, Paul Dougherty
description: Elizabeth DeVere Smith and Paul Christian Dougherty were married yesterday at Christ Church, Georgetown, in Washington. The Rev. Stuart Kenworthy performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Habitats /Upper East Side; Turning an Apartment Into a 2-Night Art Gallery
description: JENNIFER SHURDUT graduated from Harvard and the Columbia University School of Law, but as far as she is concerned, her older brother, Jeffrey, 32, is the one with the talent in the family. He's a painter of wildly colorful abstract works who has had some success in Sweden and Norway but not nearly as much in New York.

title: Nina Moadel, Max Karpel
