title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONHEIM, SUE
description: CONHEIM-Sue. November 19, 1950, In ever loving memory. Daughter, Marilyn

title: Liberties; What He's Thinking
description: The President-elect is surrounded by manic-depressive aides who are pumped and then slumped, doing high fives one moment and singing the blues the next.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-19-00: The New Economy; Dot Dot Dot?
description: It has been a bumpy few months for many Internet companies: their profits have fallen short of projections; their stocks have tanked; their venture capital has dried up. Some have restructured; others have closed up shop entirely. While investors sort out what this means for their portfolios, a large number of former employees -- used to working long hours in high-stress, high-reward jobs -- are left to figure out what it means for their careers. For some of these workers, their dot-com job was the first they ever had; for others, it's the last in a long series of tech-industry postings. So where will they go next? Will they return to the volatile economic sector from which they were just bounced? Or will they go in search of something less cutting edge but more stable? Herewith, a survey of how California's dot-com job seekers are mapping out their future. -- Cate T. Corcoran

title: When Fate Takes a Hand And an Attack Goes Astray
description: There is often a feeling of outrage on the part of a player who has performed brilliantly but then wasted his wonderful work by strewing errors right and left to lose the game.

title: UConn Names a Flower After State's First Lady
description: LIKE many political spouses, Patricia Rowland, the wife of Gov. John G. Rowland, heads committees, plays host at public events and promotes her home state. Unlike most political spouses, Patricia Rowland has a flower named after her, a pink alstroemeria christened Patricia Lynn.

title: The Ruin of Myanmar
description: The Southeast Asian nation of Myanmar is a case study in repression and misgovernment. For 12 years a secretive military junta has ground down the liberties and living standards of 50 million people. By banning most contact with the outside world and buying off the leadership of restive ethnic minorities, the junta has deflected serious challenges to its rule, despite the dismal failure of its economic policies and spreading social ills.

title: INVESTING; New Cancer Therapies Become Market Niche
description: A doctor by trade, academic by inclination and chief executive by fate, Jeffrey Jonas is trying to warm Wall Street analysts and money managers to the idea of the novel cancer treatments offered by companies like Avax Technologies, which he founded.

title: Shaper of Foreign Policy In Yugoslavia Is a Joiner
description: Goran Svilanovic, slight and 37, has been the foreign minister of the new Yugoslavia for just over a week, capping a dizzying time, after the fall of President Slobodan Milosevic, when the country has resumed its ties with the world and been readmitted to the United Nations and important bodies in Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HATCH, WILLIAM B.
description: HATCH-William B. Of Washington, DC, Vancouver, BC and Portland, OR. Died November 15, 2000 after a four month struggle with lung disease. Bill spent many years at the Republican Policy Committee of the Senate in the days of Senators Dirkson and Hickenlooper, but his most important work was as a 24 year member of AA. His words of wisdom, encouragement and acceptance helped countless other members, as they also helped him with his sobriety. Lovingly remembered by his daughter Sybil and son-inlaw David Hopkins (Fargo) and grandchildren, Rose, (Washington, DC), Alayne, (St. Paul) and Connor (Fargo). Friends are encouraged to remember Bill in their own way. In lieu of flowers, memorials can be sent to Silent Unity, 1901 N.W. Blue Parkway, Unity Village, MO 64065-0001.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Normally, we're the Maytag repairman around this time. No one needs us or pays much attention to us.''

title: Front Lines in the Cocktail War
description: The rivalry between Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange has spread to a whole new domain, with a volatile mix of liquor, food and the press. On Dec. 1, beginning at 6 p.m. with cocktails on the trading floor, then moving upstairs to dinner, the New York Stock Exchange hosts its annual holiday reception for the press. But at 5:30 p.m. comes a Nasdaq party, at its 43rd and Broadway site, marked by its huge electronic billboard and ticker.

It included a first-half humiliation; a halftime detonation by the coach; a 23-point fourth-quarter comeback; a tackle-eligible touchdown reception; two interceptions on the same drive by the same player; and overtime.

description: ONE in 10,000 people hear Connecticut the way I do.

description: The girl is pale-skinned and green-eyed with blond hair cut to frame her face. Now 12, she arrived in Germany from Kosovo almost two years ago; her German is now near perfect. At home in her adoptive land, she seems a model immigrant, bright and integrated.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Economy; A novelist dissects the information age and finds a Socratic tragedy.
description: IT'S a long stretch from Socrates drinking the hemlock to Pets.com pulling the plug. Some 2,400 years in fact. But Alan Lightman, a runner-up in the National Book Award for fiction that was awarded last week, has produced a novel connecting what the author sees as the central tragedy of each epoch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDIAKOV, MICHAEL
description: RUDIAKOV-Michael. The Board of Directors and Advisory Council of the Manchester Music Festival mourn the passing of our dear director. His passion for the music, dedication to the education of audiences of all ages and enthusiasm for the growth of young artists will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Judy, Ariel and Lisa.

description: HAS it come to this?

title: This Time, Jets Don't Need a Comeback
description: The Jets have talked incessantly and desperately in recent weeks about starting faster to avoid the bottomless holes in which they seem to sink week after week. But fast starts -- like good victories -- are relative for the struggling Jets. So, when the Jets took a 3-0 lead against the Dolphins today in a rematch of a game in which the teams combined to score 77 points four weeks ago, it qualified as a fast start. And when the Jets beat the Dolphins, 20-3, despite only 228 yards of offense, and despite losing two of their most potent offensive players to injury, the victory was significant, if not artistic.

title: Keep the Cans, Just Send Cash
description: RELIEF organizations like CARE and the International Red Cross conjure images of frantic relief workers distributing food, clothing and medicine to victims of flood, fire or famine around the world. But though they engage in disaster relief, these organizations say that the bulk of their services cannot be distributed in signature packages.

title: From Wildlife to Tireless Crusader, See Jane Run
description: JANE GOODALL arrived at the Gombe Preserve on the shores of Lake Tanganyika 40 years ago to study chimpanzee behavior. Her first important observation -- that the chimpanzees picked and stripped small twigs to dig up termites -- challenged the established wisdom that humans were distinguished from all other animals by the ability to make and use tools.

title: Teenagers Share Their Vision in a Film Festival
description: Many of the stories are like pages from a diary. In a video titled ''Communication Gap,'' a young woman tries to interview her father about their tense relationship, but ends up with the camera on herself, crying in the bathroom mirror.

title: Kawasaki City Journal; Forever Korean: Once Scorned, Always Scorned
description: Like tens of thousands of other Koreans, Okwan Riyuj's grandfather was forcibly brought to Japan as a young man and sent to the frigid mines of Hokkaido, where he worked in near-slavelike conditions to feed Japan's war machine during World War II.

title: As Dot-Com Windfalls Shrink, Gifts Don't
description: A YEAR ago, philanthropy was threatening to overtake the Palm V as a Silicon Valley fashion statement. Everyone was giving, it seemed. In 10 years, the valley's leading charitable foundation saw its assets multiply 55-fold, to more than $625 million.

title: Saints, Already Minus Williams, Lose Blake
description: The New Orleans Saints entered the game against the Oakland Raiders missing a golden left foot, the broken one of running back Ricky Williams. In less than a quarter of football here today, the Saints were also missing a prized right foot, the broken one of quarterback Jeff Blake. It left them with too little to stand on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, BLANCHE SEMBROFF
description: GOLDEN-Blanche Sembroff. On Friday, November 17. Beloved wife of Henry. Devoted mother of Daniel (Arline), Edward (Barbara) and Ellen (Joel) Dressner. Cherished grandmother of Madeline and David Dressner. Shiva Monday through Wednesday at her home, 3-7 PM.

title: In Stress Of Recount, Complaints Get Bizarre
description: Perhaps it was inevitable that bizarre charges would emerge from the biospherelike counting room where hundreds of workaday people have been hunched over tables counting votes in Broward County under the glare of the nation.

title: Shop, E-Mail and Web Surf on the Telly
description: Calvin Butler does not own a computer, nor does he have access to the Internet at the Birds Eye frozen food plant where he works as a machinist near his home in Suffolk, England.

title: A Meal at Boxcar Bertha's Supports One for the Road
description: NAME -- Boxcar Bertha's Cafe.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Coca-Cola Seen in Talks To Bid for Quaker Oats

title: For UConn, No Modesty in Words or Goals
description: The rules of the coaching fraternity are strict: No matter how good your team is, you must always find fault. The news media and the public will tell your players they are great, even if they are not, and the players may start to believe it, so you try to curb their egos before fatal overconfidence sets in.

title: To See Your Story Clearly, Start by Pulling the Wool Over Your Own Eyes
description: The habits and methods of writers are sometimes peculiar enough to be interesting.

title: Gordon Rich Is Dead at 43; Built Vast Corporate Mergers
description: Gordon Rich, an investment banker at Credit Suisse First Boston who constructed some of the largest mergers in corporate history and was known on Wall Street for his irreverent personality, died yesterday. He was 43.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: John Hamilton Reynolds, 77; Improved Study of Cosmic Ages
description: Dr. John Hamilton Reynolds, a physicist who helped refine the techniques for dating meteorites and primordial rock formations, died on Nov. 4 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 77.

title: Knicks Stay Grounded To Win Without Camby
description: They did not fly through the lane with their limbs outstretched. Nor did the Knicks emphatically swat opponents' layups or make the Madison Square Garden crowd roar in response to artistic dunks.

title: Leon Epstein, 83, Pioneer In Treatment of the Elderly
description: Dr. Leon J. Epstein, a pioneer in the treatment of mental illness in the elderly, died Nov. 6 at his home in San Francisco. He was 83.

title: Peru's President To Resign Soon, Top Aides Say
description: Signaling the demise of one of Latin America's most authoritarian rulers, two top officials announced today that President Alberto K. Fujimori would resign by Tuesday, ending a tumultuous decade in power that saw him do battle with terrorists, drug traffickers and hyperinflation before succumbing to a series of scandals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMICK, PATRICK J.
description: AMICK-Patrick J. Age 55, of Upper Makefield Township, PA. Died on November 17, 2000. Retired from Citi Corp. Survived by his wife Wynne, a son and daughterin-law, William and Cheryl, and granddaughter Madelyn. Contact Fitzgerald - Sommer Funeral Home, Yardley, PA.

title: Panel Set to Change Newspaper Circulation Accounting
description: After years of argument, the board of the Audit Bureau of Circulations has given preliminary approval to a major restructuring of procedures newspapers use to account for their circulation to each other, to the public and to advertisers, four board members said yesterday.

title: Morgan Anderson Consulting forms a unit for marketers in the new economy.
description: A WELL-KNOWN consulting company that helps advertisers find and keep agencies is forming an operating unit dedicated to working with marketers in the so-called new economy.

title: A Victory for Cleaner Air
description: A novel legal strategy aimed at reducing smog and acid rain in the Northeast yielded a huge victory on Wednesday when the Virginia Electric Power Company agreed to spend $1.2 billion to cut harmful pollutants from eight coal-burning plants by 70 percent. This is the biggest settlement -- in dollar terms, as well as promised reduction in pollutants -- in the 30-year history of the 1970 Clean Air Act. It sets the stage for further such settlements that, over time, could lead to substantial reductions in two pollutants that are blown eastward from power plants in the border states and the Midwest -- sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain, and nitrogen oxides, which contribute to smog.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: The Legal Arguments of Bush and Secretary Harris
description: Following are the ''summary of argument'' from a brief filed yesterday with the Florida Supreme Court by lawyers for Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and excerpts of the ''summary of argument'' from a brief by Katherine Harris, Florida's secretary of state. Abbreviations used in the briefs are spelled out.

title: A Jubilant Evening, in Spite of a Cold
description: When it was announced that the cherished American soprano Roberta Peters would mark the 50th anniversary of her Metropolitan Opera debut, to the day, by giving a recital at Alice Tully Hall, even some of her most loyal admirers must have thought she had lost all reason. In her day Ms. Peters set an admirably high standard for vocal health and personal conditioning. Her technique was solid, and she wisely avoided roles outside the light, lyric coloratura repertory for which she was ideally suited.

title: Gordon W. Gilkey, 88, a Curator Known for His Collection of Prints
description: Gordon W. Gilkey, an artist, teacher, collector and for 22 years the curator of prints and drawings at the Portland Art Museum in Oregon, died Oct. 28. He was 88.

title: 13 States to Unite to Cut Truck Emissions
description: Thirteen states from all regions of the country will try to impose new national controls on pollution from truck and bus engines on Monday, when they announce a plan to jointly adopt emission limits that would be far stricter than the federal rules.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLANY, KEVIN C., SR.
description: MULLANY-Kevin C., Sr. 79, on Thursday, November 16, 2000, at his residence in Great Falls, VA. Beloved husband of Margaret T. Mullany. Loving father of Kevin Jr., John, Thomas, Robert, Maribeth Mullany. Grandfather of Connor, Michelle and Jessica. The family will receive friends from 5-8 PM today at the Adams-Green Funeral Home, 721 Elden St., Herndon, VA. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at 10:30 AM on Tuesday, November 21, 2000 at St. Catherine of Siena Catholic Church, 1020 Springvale Rd., Great Falls, VA. Private interment at Quantico National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorials to World War II Memorial Fund.

title: The Weekend That America Held Its Breath; This Election Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Back Injury Halts Martin
description: Curtis Martin, having sustained a sprained back, left today's game after he made a 6-yard run early in the third quarter and did not return. Martin believes the injury occurred on a 4-yard run just before that, although he was not sure how it happened. He might have taken a helmet to the back.

title: Florida Ordered to Count Votes Without Postmarks
description: Attorney General Robert A. Butterworth of Florida, the chairman of Vice President Al Gore's campaign in the state, told local election officials today that they should count overseas ballots that arrived without postmarks.

title: From Beginning, Giants Seem Utterly Lost Against the Lions
description: In victory today, it was all going to be laid before the Giants: a virtual lock on a playoff berth, the memory of last week's collapse to St. Louis pleasantly purged and enough feel-good momentum to carry them through a holiday week of travel to the next game in Arizona.

title: Whose Rite Is It?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Changing the White Male World at the Top of the Foundations
description: EMMETT D. CARSON had a confession to make: Minnesota has one of the largest concentrations of Somalian immigrants in the United States, but as of mid-October, there were none on the board of the Minneapolis Foundation, which he directs. Nor did he have any Hmong board members, even though there is a sizable local Hmong community. For several years, he had two Hmong trustees, but with the recent departure of one, he had none.

title: How Urban Green Spaces Got Greener
description: MOST of America's urban parks grew up in the 19th and early-20th centuries, a time of blooming budgets and steady growth for the cities that built them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLATT, PESSIE
description: GREENBLATT-Pessie. 97. Devoted wife of the late Julius; beloved mother of David and Bernice Weiss; Lily and Morty Veron, Kathy and Herman Klein and Robert Greenblatt. She leaves behind many loving grandchildren, great-grandchildren and a greatgreat-grandchild. A Holocaust survivor, she came to America to reestablish her family, a goal that with God's help she readily attained. She will be sorely missed.

title: Hillary Clinton Sings Praises of Vietnam Women, and Vice Versa
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, not yet a senator and not quite a former first lady, brought her trademark mixture of feminism and family values to Vietnam today, telling an audience made up largely of women that ''anything we do to help women helps children and families and society.''

title: India to Halt Military Acts in Kashmir for Muslim Holy Month
description: In a rare, hopeful step toward ending more than a decade of violence in Kashmir, the Indian government announced Sunday night that it would unilaterally stop military operations in the troubled region of Kashmir during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, which begins later this month.

title: Sports of The Times; The Giants Are Not So Special, After All
description: IT'S one of pro football's oldest tenets: dependable special teams make teams dependable. Just as vulnerable special teams make teams vulnerable.

title: The Weekend That America Held Its Breath
description: To the Editor:

title: Struggling to Make Recount Deadlines
description: More ballots were counted by hand on Day 13 but without a resulting surge in votes for Vice President Al Gore. He and his lawyers would like such evidence when they argue before the Florida Supreme Court today that the recount ballots should be added to the vote total. Here are the day's highlights.

title: Tallahassee Journal; Churchgoers Seek Certification From a Higher Authority
description: As Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush tussled for votes across the state, God and man were fighting each other today for the souls of the First Baptist Church.

title: In Myanmar, Ancient Temples and Slave Labor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Adopt a Swagger As They Travel West
description: When the last letter of H-O-R-S-E was called today and Nets Coach Byron Scott had finished another in a series of victories over Stephon Marbury, Marbury stalked to the far side of the court. Marbury, who has been nearly unstoppable against just about everyone else this season, was oblivious to his coach's taunts.

title: Florida Ordered to Count Votes Without Postmarks
description: Attorney General Robert A. Butterworth of Florida, the chairman of Vice President Al Gore's campaign in the state, told local election officials today that they should count overseas ballots that arrived without postmarks.

title: N.C.A.A. Graduation News Mixed
description: The graduation rate for Division I-A football players who entered school in 1993-94 sunk to its lowest percentage since the entering class of 1985, but over all the graduation rates of student-athletes surpassed those of the general student population, according to a report released yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Two Rivals Each Win a Title In Play at the Fall Nationals
description: Two major titles were won here on Saturday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals by two female stars who have been dueling for the top spot in world rankings. Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif., who until recently was the world's top female player, won the Life Master Open Pairs with Steve Garner of Northfield, Ill. Some famous names were close behind: Zia Mahmood and Chuck Burger were second; Jeff Meckstroth and Perry Johnson were third.

title: A Human Lightning Rod In a Vote-Counting Storm
description: They just can't stop talking about her. Her integrity, her ignorance. Her lashes, her lipstick.

title: Recounts Drag On; Court Battle Lines Are Drawn
description: With the Florida Supreme Court set to hear arguments on the fate of hand recounts of the presidential vote, election workers in two Florida counties today resumed the laborious manual process that in recent days has been slowed by fatigue, partisan disputes and -- in one county -- another change in the definition of a vote.

title: Vietnam's New Struggle: How Global to Become?
description: Bill Clinton took extra trouble 30 years ago to avoid showing up here for America's first conflict with Vietnam.

title: Wiggles, Leaps and Squeals In a High-Spirited Frolic
description: Kinetic humor is David Parsons's strong suit as a choreographer, and squeals of delight from a young audience punctuated the Parsons Dance Company's performance at the New Victory Theater on Thursday night.

title: Fassel Lets Anger Out
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel was terse, irritated and critical in his conference after today's 31-21 loss to the Detroit Lions.

title: Meet Me in St. Louis
description: The Times's Frank Litsky picks the teams he thinks will make it to the Round of 16, and the team that will be eventual national champion. The Final Four is March 30 and April 1 in St. Louis.

title: Sports of The Times; From a Job at U.P.S. To Delivering for Jets
description: THE United States was a much simpler place on Oct. 23, when the Jets and the Miami Dolphins faced each other at Giants Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, BERNICE
description: EVANS-Bernice. On November 15, 2000. Loving mother of Emily Ford of Chagrin Falls, OH, and Thomas Hart Evans of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved grandmother of Rebecca and Nathan Ford. Dear sister of Maurice Rosenblatt of Washington, DC. Services were held Sunday at ''The Riverside.'' Contributions to Doctors Without Borders or a charity of your choice.

title: A Newspaper Experiment in San Francisco
description: Ted Fang is out to prove something. On Wednesday, The San Francisco Examiner, after more than a century as a Hearst newspaper, will be published under his name. Also on Wednesday, a new Hearst-owned San Francisco Chronicle will make its first appearance. But it is Ted Fang's Examiner that, people here expect, will be unlike anything published here before.

title: The Weekend That America Held Its Breath; Where's the Unity?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire at Ski Resort Forces Guests to Flee
description: VAIL, Colo., Nov. 19  A fire burned for nearly six hours on Saturday night, forcing the evacuation of scores of guests at a 350-room ski resort hotel before being contained early today, the authorities said.

title: If One Family Gathering Is Too Many, Try Three
description: Eli Wallach and Anne Jackson are old hands at being a couple, onstage and off, so it's not surprising that as they cavort together as a long-married pair of retired comedians in Anne Meara's new play, ''Down the Garden Paths,'' their chemistry feels as established as the periodic table. The play, which opened at the Minetta Lane Theater yesterday, is a dubiously contrived family drama that makes an unrevelatory point: events of a moment can greatly alter whole lives. But it is buoyed by the bristly and fond couplehood of the two stars, whose characters, Sid and Stella Garden, are asked to cope with three different versions of their family that could have resulted from a single turning point.

title: Cal Turner, 85; Founded Dollar General
description: Cal Turner Sr., who began a retailing empire based on the philosophy that no item should cost more than a dollar, died at his home in Scottsville, Ky., on Tuesday. He was 85.

title: Nine Moments and a Legal Decision
description: In the compilation of the greatest athletes and athletic events of the 20th century, women appeared to get short shrift.

title: Will the Laughs Last?
description: To the Editor:

title: Source of Classic Images Now Struggles to Be Seen
description: CAN the marketing approaches of advertising be applied to social issues? Should slogans and jingles be used to draw attention to serious problems and needy causes?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUDOIN, SUZANNE (NEE DEVILLIEZ)
description: BAUDOIN-Suzanne (nee Devilliez). November 17, 2000. Beloved widow of Charles. Cherished mother, mother-in-law and grandmother of Patsy and Madge; Jean-Yves, Ellen, Alexander and Daniel; Marina, Harry, Christina and Patrick; Bettina, Henri and Paul. She will be remembered by all for her kindness and compassion, her love of the arts, and her playful spirit. Private gathering. Donations can be made to the Ovarian Cancer National Alliance, 910 17th St. NW, Washington, DC 20006.

title: Pepper's Season of Pain Ends in Triumph
description: For Dottie Pepper, the year's final Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament was clearly the most satisfying.

title: For Checking Out a Charity, Remember the Number 990
description: WITH more than one million charities registered with the Internal Revenue Service, how is a donor to tell which charity for terminally ill children does good works and which allows its managers to live luxuriously? Despite the best efforts of charity watchdogs, their evaluations cover only a few hundred organizations at a time, leaving donors with little more than their gut and personal experience to distinguish between stewards and shady operators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, GEORGE
description: WEINSTEIN-George. Loving husband and best friend of Shirley (Greenberg), of 55 years. Father of Stanley, Lenore, Jerrald, Judy, Sarah. Grandfather of Rachael, Moshe, Ronnie and Yinon Libson, Ari, Jay, Dov and Bonnie. Brother of Ira, Janice and Lewis Sachs. Loved by many nieces and nephews. Resided in Israel, formerly of Milwaukee, WI, Great Neck, NY, and Florida. Retired partner of Morris J. Weinstein and Co., CPA's, businessman and philanthropist. Funder of many religious, medical and educational facilities. He will be missed by all who knew him. Let us celebrate his life and emmulate what he belived in. Interment in Israel.

title: South Carolinians Nurture a Little Cause That Could
description: THE coastal landscape around Charleston, S.C., has long been known as the Low Country -- wetlands filled with waterfowl, beaches on barrier islands where waders can walk far out to sea and still be knee-deep, forests growing at an altitude of approximately zero and waterways shallow and deep interlaced throughout.

title: Essay; Arafat's 'War Process'
description: When the leader of the Hezbollah in Syrian-occupied Lebanon came up with a plan to kidnap three Israeli soldiers six weeks ago, his Iranian sponsors cautioned him to first get the approval of Bashar al-Assad, the new president of Syria.

title: Time Gets A New Style At the Helm
description: Walter Isaacson is a pretty tough act to follow.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They told me nothing ever happens on the canvassing board.''

title: E-Commerce Report; Web and catalog businesses are crossing into storefront territory, creating parallel avenues of retailing.
description: SLEEP is coming more easily these days to traditional retail executives, who by now barely become excited over the dot-com body count, or the latest e-tailing stock to drop below a buck. Gone are the days when they agonized about being ''Amazoned,'' or blind-sided by a dot-com, and when the phrase ''first-mover advantage'' conjured images of 20-year-old Stanford drop-outs destroying their lives.

title: And the Award for Most Gifted Performance Goes to . . .
description: IT'S a wonder anyone gives to charity, considering the reputation it has in movies and novels and on television. If page and screen teach us anything about

title: The 'Accidental Techies' of the Nonprofit World Need Help
description: THE Sharehouse has three full-time employees, one truck, 8,000 feet of warehouse space and an old-fashioned mission -- collecting used furniture and appliances for homeless people in Seattle who have found a place to live.

title: Voting Battle Threatens Florida's Uneasy Truce Between Political Parties
description: To understand the pragmatic culture of Florida politics -- and how it is being threatened as never before by this extra-innings presidential election -- it is useful to consider the example of Dempsey Barron, a man of humble Panhandle roots who emerged as one of the state's most powerful politicians in the 1970's and 80's.

title: A Watchdog Leaves the Scene
description: DONORS who have relied on two watchdog organizations for years to evaluate national charities will soon have just one watchdog on duty. The National Charities Information Bureau in New York, the nation's largest and oldest charity watchdog organization with 15 staff members, is shutting down because financial support fell last year. Founded in 1918, the bureau operated on a $1 million annual budget.

title: Attention, Shoppers: Gallows Humor
description: MALL

title: The Weekend That America Held Its Breath; A Shining Moment
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex Attacks on Disabled Girl Stun a Berkeley Community
description: As the police count it, the first time the 12-year-old mentally disabled girl was sexually assaulted occurred on Oct. 24, by a 13-year-old fellow student at Willard Middle School.

title: Which Direction Now For Digital Music?; Recording Labels Are Ready to Move, But the Path Is Uncertain
description: You would think that the recent peace offerings in the war between online music upstarts and the recording industry would have music lovers breaking into song. Not only did the Universal Music Group settle its copyright infringement lawsuit against MP3.com last week for a cool $53.4 million, but the German media giant Bertelsmann brokered a truce with Napster the week before, presumably opening the door for the other four major recording companies to do the same.

title: The Indians Sign Burks For His Bat
description: With Manny Ramirez seemingly going elsewhere, the Cleveland Indians took the first step yesterday toward fortifying their offense, reaching agreement with Ellis Burks on a three-year, $20 million contract.

title: Where Poor Table Manners Can Quickly Cost a Fortune
description: To a professional gambler with a handful of cards, $100 bills become mere rectangular slips of green paper, and the smallest of details -- a once-twitched pinkie finger, a throbbing neck vein -- can make the difference between separating $50,000 in casino chips from a table of losers and becoming a loser yourself.

title: British Concern Set to Spin Off Power Division
description: Invensys P.L.C., a British automation and controls company, is expected to disclose plans to spin off its fast-growing power systems division when it announces its half-year financial results on Wednesday, people close to the company said today.

title: A Vegas-Like Ambience in Palm Beach
description: Palm Beach County's manual recount is occurring in its Emergency Operations Center, the headquarters for public officials during hurricanes and other natural disasters. It is a cream-colored warehouse that stands at the corner of Military Trail and Southern Boulevard, surrounded by a Dairy Queen, a cowboy boot shop, a used-boat yard, a liquor store, a pet supermarket and a topless dancer establishment with a sign that says, ''Go-Go Girls.''

title: Doctors' Drug Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Pictures of a South Baltimore bowling alley yesterday, with an article about the loss of a blue-collar institution to luxury loft apartments, carried a misspelled credit. They were by Marty Katz, not Rutz, for The New York Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERTHEIMER, JEANNE D.
description: WERTHEIMER-Jeanne D. 86, formerly of Asheville, NC, died Saturday, in RI. Widow of Philip M. Wertheimer. Born in NYC. Survived by Alan P. and Eric D. Wertheimer and Susan Deutsch. For information contact AveryStorti Funeral Home, 401-783-7271.

title: Clinton to Issue New Rules On Medical Data Privacy
description: The Clinton administration will soon issue sweeping new rules to protect the privacy of medical records. But under pressure from the health care industry, officials say, they are backing off a proposal to give patients a broad new right to sue and recover damages for the improper disclosure of confidential information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITCHCOCK, ETHAN ALLEN
description: HITCHCOCK-Ethan Allen. Died November 18, at home in Oldwick, NJ. Husband of Mari Watts Hitchcock, brother of Betty Gaillard, father of Connie Hitchcock and Polly Bigham, grandfather of Matthew Bigham, Nelson Hitchcock and Liz Bigham Hotson and greatgrandfather of Ethan Hotson. Donations may be made to Channel Thirteen. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, November 21, at 11 AM, at the Lamington Presbyterian Church in Lamington, NJ.

title: Romantic Takes Colonial Cup
description: Romantic took the lead approaching the last jump and then withstood homestretch challenges from Campanile and All Gong to win the 31st running of the $100,000-guaranteed Colonial Cup Steeplechase at Springdale Race Course in Camden, S.C.

title: Breathless Coverage Blurs Divide of Fact and Farce
description: Flipping channels yesterday morning, you might have caught this moment of political drama on C-Span: Will Ferrell of ''Saturday Night Live'' as Gov. George W. Bush, striding up to the television cameras and trying to seize the election by declaring in Bush-speak, ''Tonight I am victoriant.''

title: How 2 Families and the Phillies Made a Little Charity Grow
description: IN 1982, a Philadelphia lawyer named Alan Philips was given a death sentence: a diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S., the inexorable disease of the central nervous system that killed Lou Gehrig. The same year, another Philadelphian, a prominent real estate developer named Howard Abrams, got the same diagnosis.

title: No One Spared as the Justices Look for an End
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 20  About two minutes into the Florida Supreme Court's bracing session today, Chief Justice Charles T. Wells began arching his long eyebrows, squinting skeptically, and leaning forward restlessly in his chair as if he could not quite believe that the lawyer in front of him was delivering a civics lesson on the nation's cherished right to vote.

title: Hingis Pulls Out Victory Over an Emotional Seles
description: It was easier for Monica Seles to keep moving, to go about the busy work of untying her shoes, stuffing her tennis bag and refolding the towels by her chair. It was simpler not to stop, not to take in the crowd's sympathetic sigh on match point, not to think about how close she came to tucking this last Chase Championship into her hope chest yesterday.
