description: To the Editor:

title: The Weekend That America Held Its Breath; Voting Anachronism
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODSIDE, WILLIAM STEWART
description: WOODSIDE-William Stewart, of Scottsdale, AZ and Litchfield, CT, formerly of New York City, on November 15, 2000 of chronic pulmonary lung disease, at home in the arms of his loving wife, Migs. A deeply loved and loving husband, companion and closest friend for 30 years to his wife. Beloved father of William S. Woodside III, Anne D. Gruzdowich and Samuel T. Woodside. Generous, caring and loving stepfather of Geoffrey Dann and Deborah Dann, and caring father-in-law to Terri Woodside and Lauri Novick. Proud and delighted grandfather of Benjamin and Jacob Woodside, Rebecca and Emily Dann, and also Emily and Nicholas Gruzdowich. Devoted brother-in-law of Lewis W. Bernard. A man of enormous accomplishment and achievement, extraordinary intellect and talent, whose incredible courage and determination in spite of physical adversity was an inspiration to all. Good night sweet prince, may flights of angels see you to your dreams. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, November 29th at 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Please send contributions to the Children of Alcoholics Foundation, C/O Phoenix House, 164 W. 74th St., New York, New York 10024.

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AKE, KENNETH WHITTIER JR.
description: AKE-Kenneth Whittier Jr. Age 66. Born in Hartford, CT, died November 17, 2000, of a massive stroke. A son of the late Kenneth and Corinne Ake. Loved husband of Alice Bradley Ake. Beloved father of Allison Ake Fulton and Alexander Ake and wife Mary. Brother of Nancy Ake Cecil. Happy grandfather of Nicholas, Charles, Marcy Corinne and Thomas. Interesting uncle to Russell, Sarah, Andrew Cecil and Bradley children and their children. A longtime resident of Rye. He graduated from the Hill School in 1951 and Trinity College in 1956. He was a Vice President of Marine Midland Bank, Burns Brothers and Denton, and Gulf Bank International. He was a retired Captain in the United States Air Force. He was formerly a member of the American Yacht Club, India House and Saint Anthony Hall. His vitality and wit will be sorely missed. Funeral services will be private.

title: Knoxville Stores Offer More Than Meat and Potatoes: Bus Rides
description: NAME -- Knoxville Area Transit (KAT) Shop and Ride.

title: The Wait Is Making Seminoles Nervous
description: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, the secretary of state, Katherine Harris, and about 60 state legislators took in a football game Saturday night a few miles away from the State Capitol in Tallahassee. They saw a good one at Doak Campbell Stadium as Florida State defeated Florida, 30-7, which may or may not have been a welcome respite from the presidential vote counting.

title: When 'Rosie' Asks, New York's Elite Can't Say No
description: HE swears that in the half-century since his mother pressed a single, tiny mustard seed into his hand, not a day has gone by that he has not touched that ancient symbol of faith and good fortune.

title: Credit Offerings Planned This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a 33-day cash management bill being auctioned on Tuesday.

title: An Evolving Legal Maze
description: For a brief interval late Friday afternoon, it appeared that the electoral stalemate in Florida might finally be headed toward something approaching a definitive judicial resolution in the State Supreme Court.

title: INSIDE
description: Coke With Your Oatmeal?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLSTEIN, GEORGE S.
description: MILLSTEIN-George S. 10/7/2511/20/95. My sweet darling twin brother. Always loving and always thinking of you. Your loving twin sister Annie

title: Cable TV Shatters Another Taboo; A New Showtime Series Will Focus on Gay Sexuality
description: Less than 30 years ago, Home Box Office created the pay-television business by showing uninterrupted and uncut feature films. On network television, feature films were cut up by commercials, any foul language was bleeped, and any sex scenes edited.

title: As a Tragedy Is Revisited, A Sisterhood Is Forged; Survivors of Pan Am Flight 103 Victims Wait And View From Afar a Trial on the Bombing
description: Since May, a handful of women have been meeting regularly over cafeteria lunches at the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building downtown, like relatives brought together with a sad purpose at a hospital. Lunch is the break in each day of watching the trial of the two men accused of killing their husbands and children.

title: Bill to Curb Gang Loitering Raises Civil Liberties Concerns
description: New York City police officers would have the power to arrest suspected gang members found loitering on street corners under a bill introduced by two City Council members, but the proposal drew harsh criticism from a prominent civil libertarian yesterday.

title: It Pays to Win the Small States
description: As the protracted election of 2000 plays out, the nation's attention has narrowed again and again: to a few ''battleground'' states out of 50; then to just one state, Florida; to just a few counties; and even to one county's confusing ballot. But when the lens is broadened again, a deeper reality emerges in the battle of George W. Bush and Al Gore: the bias in the Electoral College toward small states.

title: Patents; Researchers figure out to how to tell male and female turkeys apart (it's harder than you think).
description: WHEN the nation celebrates Thanksgiving later this week, 92 percent of Americans will sit down to a meal featuring turkey. The National Turkey Federation (the trade group that presents the president with a turkey every year) says 45 million turkeys are eaten on Thanksgiving -- meals that make up part of the 18 pounds of turkey eaten annually by the average American.

title: Sound and Fury, but Not Where It's Needed
description: It has been a long while since the halftime locker room scene of a Giants game has been this emotional. And it was not what an angry Coach Jim Fassel said that raised the temperature, but the words of some of his players, namely defensive lineman Keith Hamilton.

title: Mission Possible: Inclusive Idea Is Reviving Baseball in the Inner City
description: NAME -- Reviving Baseball in Inner Cities (R.B.I.)

title: Now Appearing in Your Favorite Cause
description: CELEBRITIES hold enormous sway in our culture. They entertain us and fascinate us. We want to hear about the intimate details of their lives, and for better or worse, we listen to what they have to say about issues. It is hardly surprising, then, that celebrities are in huge demand in the intensely competitive world of philanthropy, where a popular face and voice serve as irresistible lures to donors and lawmakers alike.

title: Fiedler Injury Leaves Miami Hurting
description: The game was not yet over, but with a Jets victory assured, Dolphins defensive tackle Daryl Gardener sat on the bench tonight with a towel covering his head. Nearby, defensive end Jason Taylor was slumped over, his hands cupped over his face.

title: Democrats Weigh Options In 'Endgame Discussions'
description: Democratic allies of Vice President Al Gore, including his running mate, left open the possibility today of further litigation in Florida if the state Supreme Court disallows hand-counted ballots, but other Democrats are suggesting that if the court rules against Mr. Gore, he should not prolong the challenge and instead concede the election.

title: Tangled in Life's Daisy Chain, Yet Holding Fast to Sunlight
description: Every so often even the most major of modern artists needs to step back and lighten up. ''Dandelion Wine,'' Paul Taylor's newest dance piece, is as heady as its title, a brew of old and new exploding with the joyous energy of springtime.

title: The Weekend That America Held Its Breath; A Conflict of Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Law Collides With Immigration and Welfare Rules
description: It was 2 a.m. in a hospital emergency room in Brooklyn one night in August 1999. To the doctor on duty it was unimportant that the sick woman was an undocumented alien, and that her American-born child, the frightened 9-year-old boy clinging to her side, was healthy. The doctor admitted them both, because the mother urgently needed hospital treatment, and the child had no one else.

title: Changes at the Top For a BBDO Unit
description: @tmosphere in New York, the digital branding unit of BBDO New York, is losing Susan Pinkwater, who has been president and chief executive since the agency opened in August 1999. Ms. Pinkwater is returning to consulting, the agency said. Drew Ianni will succeed her as chief executive. Mr. Ianni, 31, had been an equity research analyst for Lazard Freres & Company, covering internet technology service providers.

title: Election in Canada Is Shorter, but Just as Brutal
description: Quickly and cheaply, Canada may choose a prime minister in less time than it takes the United States to settle an election for president.

title: The Old Order Changeth, Or Does It Become New?
description: Americans who rely on outsiders to tell us who we are must have been thoroughly confused after Friday afternoon's fascinating program by the Chicago Symphony at Orchestra Hall here. Did the spirit of this country change so drastically in the 20-odd years that separate ''The New World'' Symphony from ''Amerique''?

title: Encouraging the Audience To Stand Up and Have a Cry
description: ''No! No! No! No!'' shouted Skye Edwards at a hapless usher telling a Morcheeba fan in the front row to sit down Wednesday night. ''Everybody stand up!'' Ms. Edwards, the singer for this English band wanted this to be a party, and a reclining audience wouldn't aid her goal. The audience, naturally, went with her request, and soon the ushers at Town Hall had no hope of putting the swaying crowd in its place.

title: Coca-Cola Reported in Talks To Acquire Quaker Oats
description: The Coca-Cola Company is in serious talks to acquire Quaker Oats, the maker of Gatorade, in an effort to expand its position in the lucrative noncarbonated-drink business, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: His Play Has Been Breathless, But Leetch Can Use a Breather
description: If the Rangers want Brian Leetch to still be able to walk come springtime, they are going to have to find a way to stop taking so many undisciplined penalties.

title: Bush vs. Florida
description: The lawsuit by George W. Bush challenging Florida's manual recount has had a rough reception. A federal appellate court declined on Friday to issue an injunction while the matter is in state court. And most legal scholars panned Mr. Bush's federal lawsuit, arguing that federal courts hate interfering in state-run elections, especially when the challenge is to a rule that seems neutral and has a long history of use.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Luring Colombian Farmers From Coca Cash Crop
description: On a verdant farm carved from thick jungle, Leonardo Arevalo raises 7,000 fish, a small herd of cattle and plenty of yucca and corn. Yet, in eight years of farming in this corner of southern Colombia, Mr. Arevalo says with a tired look, none of it has brought him much of a living.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, J. SINCLAIR
description: ARMSTRONG-J. Sinclair. We are saddened by the loss, but exhilarated by the life. As Senior Warden, Sinc led St. Mark's Church inthe-Bowery through a tumult of community and cultural change. As our first president, he championed the rebuilding of the fire devastated landmark church by a cadre of neighborhood youth. In all of this, he acted with unmatched courage, courtesy and good cheer. Sinc knew always how to assure that others were safe at sea. Peace and love to Charlotte, his family and friends. Trustees, St. Mark's Historic Landmark Fund

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMICHELLA, MARIO J.
description: FORMICHELLA-Mario J. 81 years old. Entered into eternal rest on Friday, November 17. Mario was a CPA and worked his entire career for the firm Ernst & Young (formerly Arthur Young & Co.). In 1946 Mario started as a staff auditor with the firm's NYC office. He advanced quickly to higher positions. During his long career he held a number of senior management positions in the firm. He was a member of the firm's Management Committee for many years. Mario was highly respected within his profession. He was a well known problem solver/ troubleshooter. He worked as a consultant to the firm for numerous years after official retirement. Mario also served on various corporate and charitable boards. Mario is survived by his beloved wife Anne (Nan), nee Connolly; his loving children Susan Corsi, of Silver Spring, MD, Janet McElroy of Potomac, MD, and Paul Formichella of Hackensack, NJ; his dear sons-in-law Tom Corsi and Greg McElroy. Mario is also survived by seven grandchildren, all living in Maryland, and one brother James Formichella of Syracuse, and two sisters, Constance Reed of Fort Lauderdale, FL, and Katherine Seidel of Kissimmee St. Cloud, FL. The family will receive their relatives and friends today, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave., Ridgewood; 201-444-7650. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at St. Luke's Church with interment at St. Luke's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, 20 Mercer St., Hackensack, NJ 07601-5600.

title: ACCOUNTABILITY; Putting a Cold, Hard Number on the Value of Good Works
description: IN the feel-good world of philanthropy, the executives at nonprofit organizations routinely offer up anecdotes about people whose lives were turned around because of their agencies.

title: Metro Matters; Better Curbs Meant to Make Better Streets
description: WITH the advent of the Christmas tourist season, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has begun another quality-of-life campaign. Fine. The innate qualities of this city, after all, do not lean toward the most gracious.

title: Moving Beyond the Four Horsemen of the Philanthropy Beat
description: THE good-news headlines are familiar. ''Gates Will Donate $1 Billion Toward Scholarship Fund,'' declared The Houston Chronicle a year ago. ''Even Elvis's TV Antenna Gets Sold at Charity Auction,'' reported The Plain Dealer in Cleveland, around the same time. ''High-Tech in High Spirits/Silicon Valley Charity Ball raises $1.2 million at speakeasy in San Jose,'' The San Francisco Chronicle declared last spring.

title: New Pro Bono Ads On AIDS Are Set
description: The White House Office of National AIDS Policy is working with Madison Avenue on pro bono public service campaigns.

title: Arnott and Niedermayer Ending Holdouts
description: The struggling Devils have come to terms with their restricted free agents, Jason Arnott and Scott Niedermayer.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the World Business section on Nov. 8 about businesses that help companies and individuals reclaim the value-added tax levied on some products and services in Europe referred imprecisely to remarks made by Barry O'Sullivan, marketing manager at Fexco Tax Reclaim. Mr. O'Sullivan, who said that the level of computerization for processing such claims was ''a lot less than we'd like it to be,'' was referring to the industry as a whole, not to his company in particular.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEDERS, ELLIOT R.
description: RIEDERS-Elliot R. 79, of Bronx, NY, on November 19, 2000. Beloved husband of Rosalind. Adored father of Eileen and Robert Resnik and Patricia and Larry Kolber. Cherished grandfather of Jon and Jed Resnik and Jaime Kolber. Loving brother of Gloria Griffenberg. Dearest friend of Rita and Lawrence Tepper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAM, SIMON
description: PAM-Simon. 90, of Deerfield Beach, FL. Husband of the late Berta Pam; father of Alvin, Eleanor (Juceam), Jeffrey, and Robert and their spouses, 13 grandchildren, two great-grandchildren. Survived also by brothers Rabbi Abraham Pam and Charles Pam. A disciplined intellectual man of quality, generosity, modesty, dignity, and conscience, he was adored, admired, and will be missed by his large family. He was a chess champion and philosophy student with working class roots. Until the end of his life he remained engaged in the world, the life of the mind, and political discourse, exercising daily and diligently at the gym, reading voraciously, and being fully independent, functional, and self-sustaining. Forever, and passionately, he remained the champion of the underdog. He was a great and special man.

title: Israeli Diplomat Wounded in Jordan, but Fighting Tapers Off
description: An Israeli diplomat was shot and slightly wounded outside his home in Jordan today, raising fresh concerns that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is affecting neighboring countries that have already made peace with Israel.

title: Concern in Minneapolis as Target Remakes an Icon
description: ON Jan. 30, 2000, the Dayton Hudson Foundation one of the nation's oldest and most respected corporate foundations -- officially became known as the Target Foundation, mirroring the name change of its corporate parent to the Target Corporation.

title: WRITERS ON WRITING; To See Your Story Clearly, Start by Pulling the Wool Over Your Own Eyes
description: The habits and methods of writers are sometimes peculiar enough to be interesting.

title: The Weekend That America Held Its Breath; Some Victory!
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; Viacom Units Bridging the Generations
description: When CBS and Viacom merged, executives at the new company bragged about its broad reach -- how its news and entertainment programming could hold the attention of Americans from the cradle (with Nickelodeon) almost to the grave (with CBS shows like ''Diagnosis Murder'').

title: The Weekend That America Held Its Breath; Hurt by Gamesmanship
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloodied Safin Wins Paris Masters
description: Bloodied and bandaged, Marat Safin emphatically showed why he is the world's No. 1 player by winning the Paris Masters in five sets against Mark Philippoussis in a final featuring one screaming serve after another. Safin, the top-seeded Russian, won his sixth title of the year, 3-6, 7-6 (7), 6-4, 3-6, 7-6 (8).

title: In Milwaukee, a Chance for Free Job Training to Escape the Low-Wage Life
description: NAME -- Esperanza Unida (''United Hope'')

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIG, SIDNEY H.
description: WILLIG-Sidney H. Professor Sidney H. Willig, noted jurist and community leader, died November 17, 2000. A pioneer in the field of food and drug law, he was a professor of law at Temple University in Philadelphia for over 30 years and a Chair was established in his honor upon his retirement. His path to scholarship started as a student at Townsend Harris High School in Manhattan and his entry at 14 to Brooklyn College where he received his BA. Subsequently, he attended St. John's University and Brooklyn Law School where he received degrees in pharmacy and law. In addition to teaching and publishing several legal texts, he was counsel at the Sterling Drug Company for over 45 years. A WWII hero who evaded capture in occupied Holland for 148 days after his B-17 crash landed, he was the Commander of the Jewish War Veterans of Foreign Wars on Staten Island and active nationally in veteran's affairs. He was the President of Temple B'nai Jeshurun on Staten Island, where his funeral will take place at 12 noon, today. Professor Willig is survived by his childhood sweetheart and wife of over 57 years, Eleanor Huss Willig, his son Kenneth, his daughter Randi Willig Cane, three grandchildren Lauren, Spencer and Brooke, and his sisters, Myra Baron and Adele Traurig. His son, Steven, died in 1975. The family will sit shiva at the Willig home on Staten Island. Contributions may be made to the S. Willig Scholarship Fund at Brooklyn College or the Willig Chair at Temple University.

title: Behind the Prosperity, Working People in Trouble
description: IT has become an unspoken cultural axiom: anything less than financial well-being is a person's own fault. After all, this nation has been on a prosperity bender for the better part of a decade, intoxicated by the economy's seemingly boundless potential to generate fortunes or, at least, jobs.

title: Britons Love a Cause With Legs, Preferably Four of Them
description: IT begins with a solitary yap, then builds to a crescendo of barks, howls, whimpers and growls. In the distance, a plaintive mewing joins the chorus. Moving between the cages, humans murmur to one another and appraise the animals clamoring for attention. Charitable Britain is doing one of the things it most likes to do -- finding new homes for lost dogs and cats.

title: People
description: * Gus Weill was named president and chief executive at PR 21, New York, part of Daniel J. Edelman, succeeding Will Sullivan, now president at Wamnet, Eagan, Minn. Mr. Weill had been chairman of the United States corporate and financial practice at Burson-Marsteller, New York, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group.

title: Military Ballots Merit a Review, Lieberman Says
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Democratic candidate for vice president, said today that Florida election officials should reconsider their rejection of hundreds of military ballots from overseas, even if they might not comply with the law.

title: Body Found in River Is Thought To Be That of Strangling Victim
description: A decomposed body found in the East River yesterday is believed to be that of a woman who was strangled with her husband early this month in their East Harlem apartment. The couple's daughter and her boyfriend have been charged in the deaths of the two, who were said to have disapproved of the relationship.

title: Compressed Data; Discount Recommended for Internet Postage
description: Sending a letter with an old-fashioned stamp might become a cent more expensive in January. But for those willing to use postage generated by a home computer, the cost might drop by a few cents.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day last Monday showing the increase in visitors to television news organizations' Web sites before and after the presidential election omitted figures for CBSNews.com. According to Media Metrix, an Internet research firm, CBSNews.com drew 47,000 visitors on Oct. 30; 234,000 on Oct. 31; 124,000 on Nov. 1; 76,000 on Nov. 2; 103,000 on Nov. 5; 158,000 on Nov. 6; 341,000 on Nov. 7; 408,000 on Nov. 8; and 407,000 on Nov. 9. Media Metrix was unable to measure the number of visitors fully on Oct. 29. No figures were available for any site for Nov. 3-4.

title: James Russell Wiggins, 96; Editor and U.N. Ambassador
description: James Russell Wiggins, a longtime editor of The Washington Post who served as United States Ambassador to the United Nations and spent his last 30 years running a weekly newspaper in Maine, died yesterday at his home in Brooklin, Me. He was 96.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACNAUGHTEN, JOAN H. (NEE HEVERIN)
description: MacNAUGHTEN-Joan H. (nee Heverin). Of West Caldwell, formerly of Verona, NJ, and Queens, NY, on November 16, 2000. Wife of Alan MacNaughten. A funeral mass will be offered in Our Lady of the Lake Church, Verona, on Monday, November 20, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Memorial Fund of Our Lady of the Lake Church, 32 Lakeside Ave., Verona, NJ 07044 appreciated.

title: Accounts
description: * Vindigo, New York, which offers shopping, dining and entertainment information for mobile and hand-held devices, to FUEL North America, New York, as its first agency of record. Billings were not disclosed. FUEL is part of Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/ Euro RSCG, a unit of Euro RSCG Worldwide, owned by Havas Advertising.

title: Italy's Mistreatment of Gypsies
description: A year ago, a town in the Czech Republic made international news when it erected a wall separating its Gypsies from the rest of its citizens. While Gypsies face discrimination in most of Eastern and Central Europe, their lot is not that much better in the west. One example is Italy, a country that has historically embraced minorities. Yet the Italian government has institutionalized the prejudices many Italians feel toward Gypsies. They face police abuse and hostile speech from public officials, and many live in segregated housing or camps.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Supercomputing Takes Yet Another Turn
description: The world of supercomputing, which revolves around modeling complex phenomena like how weather changes, drugs work and accidents unfold, is rarefied by any standard. It has long been the domain of folks who call themselves the nerdiest of nerds and who regard Deep Blue, the I.B.M. computer that defeated the chess champion Garry Kasparov, as no big deal.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRITZMAN, ARTHUR LAWRENCE
description: KRITZMAN - Arthur Lawrence. November 20, 1917 - February 4, 2000. May you rest in peace. Helaine, David, Lesley and Carey

title: The Weekend That America Held Its Breath; Lose-Lose, Continued
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUGMAN, ABRAHAM ARTHUR, D.D.S.
description: KRUGMAN - Abraham Arthur, D.D.S. Orthodontist and retired colonel in the U.S. Army Reserves, of Closter, NJ, on November 18. Beloved husband of Estelle. Devoted father of Carole (Marc) Shale and Michelle (Mitchell) Leibson. Dear brother of Anne Eisenstadt. Loving grandfather of Adam, Allison, Lauren, Alex and Max. Services at ''Wien & Wien,'' 129 Engle St., Englewood, NJ, today, November 20, at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, STELLA L.
description: WERNER-Stella L. Devoted wife of the late Herbert L. Werner, died peacefully on November 18 at her home in Mamaroneck, NY, after a long and full life. Beloved mother of Laurel Bauer, Beryl Elon and Jeff Werner. She is survived by her brother Jack C. Werner, sonsin-law William G. Bauer, Gadi Elon, daughter - in - law Elyce Wakerman-Werner and four cherished grandchildren, Danielle, Ari, Juliet and Bob. Services will be held at Larchmont Temple, November 20, 1PM. Interment Beechwood Cemetery, New Rochelle, immediately following services.

title: Media Talk; Rats, Psychological Warfare, Now Combat
description: Mark Burnett is raising the stakes in reality television: he is bringing in the Green Berets to square off with the Navy Seals to see who is best at rescuing hostages and eliminating street snipers.

title: New ABC Unit Signs Major Deal
description: A new unit of the ABC Television Network that sells commercial time and advertising space in packages that include sibling media properties has signed its first major national deal since being formed in September.

title: Giving
description: In the competitive world of philanthropy, a star name like Michael J. Fox or Mary Tyler Moore can make a big difference. Reed Abelson reports on celebrities who, for better or worse, have taken up a cause. SECTION F

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; AT&T Faces Hard Choices Over Its Debt
description: Talk about tough jobs. For AT&T's chairman, C. Michael Armstrong, reducing AT&T's debt could prove as complex as explaining the company's plans to separate itself into four parts.

title: Colombia Aid Misgivings
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Serving In the Military Run Obstacles To Balloting
description: The complexities of absentee voting appear to have confounded many members of the armed forces who were stationed abroad and tried to send ballots to Florida to participate in the presidential election, experts on military voting said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROUT, ROBERT
description: TROUT-Robert. On November 14, 2000. Distinguished journalist in both radio and television. One of the first correspondents to cover London for CBS during World War II and later for ABC radio and television. Husband and colleague of the late Catherine ''Kit'' Trout and brother-in-law of Elizabeth Crane Prucher, uncle of Elizabeth Crane Boland, Stephen and Jeffrey Crane. A Mass in memory of Robert Trout will be celebrated at his parish church, St. Joseph's in Greenwich Village (371 Sixth Avenue), on Saturday, December 2, 2000, at 3:30 PM.

title: Top Execs Seek Job w/Fulfillment, Pay Cut Optnl
description: THE 92ND STREET Y -- formally the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, but New Yorkers use the short name -- has no shortage of talent in its work force. Some 300 full-time and 900 part-time employees run its concerts and lectures, fitness programs and Bronfman Center for Jewish Studies; they mastermind its new push for international and Web-based programs.

title: Heretic, Homosexual, Playwright, Spy, a k a Kit
description: Christopher Marlowe, the profligate genius who was Shakespeare's short-lived contemporary, wrote his plays -- among them ''Tamburlaine,'' which established blank verse as a medium of dramatic writing, ''Dr. Faustus'' and ''The Jew of Malta'' -- about men of defiance and desire, and he lived, evidently, with the unmitigated passions of such a man himself.

title: Give Money Away Now Or Later? A Rundown Of Options
description: HAD the charitable remainder trust been around in biblical times, the saying might be, ''Give and ye shall receive, especially if ye have a good tax lawyer.''

title: Cost of TV Ads Increases Sharply
description: The average cost of producing a 30-second national television commercial increased 16 percent in 1999 from 1998, according to an annual survey by the American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York. That was the largest one-year increase in the 13 years the survey has been conducted.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Bosnian Election Returns Point to Little Change, Analysts Say
description: Five years after the Dayton peace accords ended the war in Bosnia, its neighbors have turned decisively toward democracy. But Bosnia has failed to make the leap, says Wolfgang Petritsch, the Austrian diplomat who effectively runs this deeply scarred Balkan land for the foreigners who bankroll it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHRON, RITA
description: SHRON-Rita. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck George N. Abrahams, President

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: ING Group to Trim Investment Banking Units
description: The ING Group, the Dutch financial services company, confirmed today that it was considering the sale of its United States investment banking business and also disclosed that it would fold its London arm into its European commercial banking division.

title: Charities Award Grants, Then Pay to Evaluate How the Money Is Spent
description: IT stands to reason. Those who give away millions ought to have a way of knowing how their money is being spent -- whether their grants are actually feeding the hungry, housing the homeless or protecting the planet.

title: In America; This Is The Easy Part
description: Incredibly, the year 2000 is almost over. It flew by in an instant. And yet the biggest story of the year, the presidential campaign that ended in a virtual deadlock, is moving so agonizingly slowly it seems to have stopped time altogether.

title: Media Talk; From Ad to Arrest, Fox Has Busy Week
description: The Fox News Channel seems to enjoy making news as much as it does covering it.

title: More Than a Name Change: A Foundation Goes Digital
description: IF you want a grant from the Verizon Foundation, there is only one way to go about it -- online. From application through processing and financing, the Web is the route to this multimillion-dollar foundation's heart.

title: Mentally Ill Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Says Deadline Is Strict as Gore Seeks Tallying Standard
description: Lawyers for Gov. George W. Bush contended today that Florida law set a clear deadline of last Tuesday for counties to submit all vote tallies except those for overseas absentee ballots, and they asked the Florida Supreme Court to let the state reject any manual recounts conducted after that date.

title: More Students Are Saying That a Big Paycheck Can Wait
description: LEE DAVENPORT, a recent graduate of the University of Texas, was headed for a business career. But Mr. Davenport thought he would first do a stint in the National Civilian Community Corps, a unit of AmeriCorps, a government-sponsored program based in Washington that focuses on community service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUTHERS, HARVEY J.
description: STRUTHERS-Harvey J. In Brunswick, ME. November 13, 2000, age 83, born in Minneapolis, MN, died from Parkinson's Disease. Formerly of Darien, CT, and Naples, FL, an executive of 40 years with CBS. He is survived by his wife, Helen Gould Struthers of Brunswick, sons Harvey J. Struthers, Jr., of Chicago and Thomas G, Struthers of Freeport, a sister, Martha S. Farley of Evanston, IL. Also survived by three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Services will be private in Yarmouth, Maine with interment in Minneapolis, Minn. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to Struthers Parkinson Center, 6701 Country Club Dr., Golden Valley, MN 55427 or Courage Center, 3915 Golden Valley Rd., Minneapolis, MN 55422. Services by Lindquist Funeral Home, One Mayberry Lane, Yarmouth, ME.

title: The Count and the Map
description: Anyone who listened to the talk shows over the weekend could see that the representatives of Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush have turned at this point to repetition as the weapon of choice. Nothing has been left unsaid -- and said again -- about the familiar points of contention. One new development was the unusually high rejection rate for absentee ballots from Floridians living abroad, including many in the military. The Bush campaign was right to complain that almost 40 percent of these late-arriving ballots were disallowed in the final round of counting, and Senator Joseph Lieberman correctly asserted on NBC's ''Meet the Press'' that the ''benefit of the doubt'' should be given to military ballots from abroad. Common sense and the best available information indicate that many in the armed services were unable to get their ballots properly postmarked. The ballots ought to be analyzed according to the same principle that should govern recounts in Palm Beach, Broward and Dade Counties. That means every effort should be made to allow as many votes as possible under flawed circumstances.

title: West Coast Trip Ends Up As Total Loss For Islanders
description: The free fall continued for the last-place Islanders tonight as they finished their West Coast trip with a 2-1 loss to the Anaheim Mighty Ducks.

title: Spirits, but Not Heavenly, In a Wordless Song of Love
description: Lincoln Center, in its Great Performers presentations, has come to rejoice in breaking down boundaries, artistic as well as geographic (venturing in this case, for example, to the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, a frequent refuge on the Upper East Side). It even applies its own categories loosely.

title: U.S. Move Improves Chance For Global Warming Treaty
description: In a shift that is likely to brighten prospects for a global warming treaty, American negotiators at talks here have said the United States would be willing to limit its use of forest projects to reach its target for reducing heat-trapping greenhouse gases.

title: Jockey Parts Ways With Grey Agency
description: Two advertisers are making changes on accounts.

title: Clinton Basks in the Adulation Of a City Once Called Saigon
description: President Clinton ended an emotional three-day visit to Vietnam today as he began it, pressing America's former foe -- gently but insistently -- to set aside its fears and join the global marketplace of trade and ideas.

title: They Came, They Saw and They Made a Difference
description: DOZENS of Americans, drifting through a sea of smiles and tiny, outstretched arms, handed out fuzzy Beanie Babies to the youngsters at the Colonia Infantil San Juan Sacatepequez, a charitable clinic that slowly nourishes starving children back to health. The weakest infants were still in cribs, their eyes twinkling from the unexpected nuzzles and cooing. For some of them -- toddlers whose parents are away all week working at backbreaking jobs -- it was a welcome gift of that most precious nourishment, affection.

title: Medtronic Posts 21% Rise in Earnings
description: Medtronic Inc., a maker of several medical devices including pacemakers, said its profit rose 21 percent in the fiscal quarter ended Oct. 27 on very strong sales of products that treat heart and neurological diseases.

title: Tunnel Vision; For Londoners, Greenwich Mean Time
description: Almost reflexively, New York subway riders are a querulous lot. ''Excuse me'' is never a request; it is a command. The morning commuting may be reliable 20 times in a row, but let the 21st run be a little late and the whole system is falling apart.

title: Franco Moves Closer to a Decision
description: If John Franco keeps to his desired timetable, he should know by the time he sits down to Thanksgiving dinner if he will be back next season as the Mets' setup relief pitcher or if he will be the closer for the Philadelphia Phillies, the Pittsburgh Pirates or the Chicago Cubs.

title: What Is It With Mona Lisa's Smile? It's You!
description: For nearly 500 years, people have been gazing at Leonardo da Vinci's portrait of the Mona Lisa with a sense of bafflement.

title: In Eye of Recount Hurricane, There's Nary a Hint of a Storm
description: The political spin has become a whirling storm here, with Republicans saying that the recount is in chaos and that chads are flying through the air like palm fronds in a hurricane.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas increased on forecasts for colder-than-normal weather at a time of low supplies. In New York, natural gas for December delivery rose 14.9 cents, to $6.249 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: For Most Local Phone Users, Choice Is Not Yet an Option
description: AT&T's plan to break itself into four pieces has many experts worried that nationwide competition in local telephone service is at risk.

title: J. Russell Wiggins, 96, Editor, Statesman, Then Editor Again
description: J. Russell Wiggins, the editor who was widely credited with transforming The Washington Post from a small and struggling enterprise into a nationally respected newspaper after World War II and who then became the United States ambassador to the United Nations in the waning months of the Johnson administration, died on Sunday at his home in Brooklin, Me. He was 96.

title: Dance in Review; Taking Their Inspiration From Yoga and Meditation
description: 'Bones of the Earth'

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHIFFER, ROBERT L.
description: SCHIFFER-Robert L. We celebrate the life of Bob Schiffer. Selma, Suzi and Franklin, Michael and Wend

title: The Week in Science: Human History Through Genetics
description: People entered Europe for the first time in the early Paleolithic era some 45,000 years ago, again in the late Paleolithic up until the peak of the last ice age 20,000 years ago, and also in the Neolithic period some 10,000 years ago, when agriculture was first invented.

title: A Newsworthy Moment
description: To the Editor:

title: Theatrical Composers' Generational Challenge
description: Any concert dedicated to showcasing little-known work by younger theater composers deserves points simply for challenging an audience with the unfamiliar. And on Friday evening, the Carnegie Hall program ''New Faces on Broadway'' by the New York Pops offered songs by Michael John LaChiusa, Ricky Ian Gordon, Adam Guettel and Jason Robert Brown, four heralded Young Turks of American musical theater.

title: Dying to be Thin
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Legal Fees Set in Auction Settlement
description: Lawyers representing more than 100,000 customers who sued Sotheby's and Christie's for fixing auction prices would be paid $26.75 million in legal fees for reaching a $512 million settlement that had received preliminary approval from a federal judge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWE, BARBARA BEALE
description: LOWE-Barbara Beale. On November 19, at home in Greenwich, CT. Dearest sister of William L. Beale, Jr. & Betty Beale Graeber of Washington. D.C., beloved mother of Barbara, William and Peter and extraordinary grandmother of six. Memorial service Nov. 25 at 11:30 AM at Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: SUEZ LYONNAISE BUYS EUROPATWEB STAKE
description: Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux agreed to buy about a third of Groupe Arnault's Internet holding company, Europatweb, for 300 million euros ($255 million) in stock to gain Web services and increase its chances of winning a license to provide fast wireless Internet access.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MICHAEL L.
description: KLEIN-Michael L. The President, Chancellor Emeritus, Chairs of the Board of Governors and Boards of Overseers, administration, faculty, staff and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion record with profound sorrow the death of Dr. Michael L. Klein, Dean of the Jerusalem School, 1981-1998, and Effie Wise Ochs Professor of Biblical literature on Saturday, November 18th in Israel. Dr. Klein was a distinguished scholar, teacher and friend who touched the lives of countless students. He contributed to the growth and development of the Jerusalem Campus through his tenacity and determination. That same tenacity helped him through these last few years of his serious illness. Funeral services were held at Kibbutz Givat HaShlosha in Israel on Monday, November 20th. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Shoshie, their children Mattan, Elad, Rachel and Ruth and the entire family. May they find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, Pres. Dr. Alfred Gottschalk, Chancellor Emeritus Mr. Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLIN, LILLIAN
description: PERLIN-Lillian, age 96. Loving mother of Marcia (Leonard), grandmother of Jonathan and Elizabeth Weiss, Frederica & Harvey Kadden. Great-grandmother of Zachary, Joshua, Daniel, Jared and Aaron. Services Wednesday 1:00PM at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: TELEKOM OFFER SCALED BACK
description: Austria reduced the number of shares on sale in Telekom Austria by 20 percent and priced them at 9 euros each, at the low end of the expected range. The issue wound up raising only 1.16 billion euros ($980 million), about half of what analysts had forecast. The shares will trade in Vienna and New York beginning today.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Cal Turner Sr., founder of the Dollar General Corporation, gave an incorrect spelling at one point for the name of the Nashville newspaper in which he was interviewed. It is The Tennessean, not Tennesseean.

title: Florida's Justices Zero In on Recount Deadlines
description: The Florida Supreme Court sharply challenged lawyers for Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush on parallel tracks today, asking the Republicans to justify a state deadline that ignored hand recounts in big, largely Democratic counties, and pressing the Democrats to explain how the court could set a new deadline without jeopardizing Florida's voice in the Electoral College.

title: VITAL SIGNS: AT RISK; New Link: Bone Damage and Anorexia
description: Anorexia causes a serious loss of bone density in young women that not even extra estrogen can counteract, according to a study to be published today in The Annals of Internal Medicine.

title: The New Burmese Leisure Class: Army Capitalists
description: Every morning and every evening in this city with the sweet-sounding name, thousands of poor people take a long, sullen look at how the other half lives.

title: The Court Should Boldly Take Charge
description: With its aggressive and broad-ranging questions yesterday, the Florida Supreme Court assumed its place in the eye of a political hurricane as tumultuous in its way as the other type that traditionally hits the state. The Supreme Court is now the only state institution able to quell the political paranoia of all but the fiercest partisans and bring this presidential election to a credible close. To do that, it must do more than address the immediate issue before it -- whether hand-counted votes must be tallied -- and take command of the entire dispute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARES, SARAH
description: CARES-Sarah. On Tuesday, Nov. 14, 2000. Beloved mother of Carol V. Berman and mother-in-law of Harvey B. Berman. Also survived by three grandchildren, Adam C. Berman and his wife Allison Goldberg, Robin F. Berman and Lisa B. Olswing, & a great-granddaughter, Emma Sophie Olswing. Memorial service Friday, November 24, 2000, 2:15PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. The family requests no flowers. Memorial contributions may be made at the discretion of the givers to the Skin Cancer Foundation, 245 5th Ave., Ste. 1403, NY, NY, 10016, National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD), PO Box 8923, New Fairfield, CT 06812-8923, or the University of Pennsylvania, OncoLink, C/O Office of Medical Center Development, 400 Penn Tower, 399 South 34 Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19104.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Redskins Bury the Rams in a Pile of Points
description: Riding a blitz of big plays from the end of the third quarter through most of the fourth, the Washington Redskins sank the St. Louis Rams, 33-20, at the Trans World Dome tonight in the kind of performance the Rams must have recognized. Often, it is the Rams who bewilder teams with a barrage of momentum-swinging action.

title: The Florida Thicket, From Courts to Chads; The Experiment
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big City; Voting Variety: Sticks Nix Affluent Slicks
description: WHATEVER becomes of Florida's dimpled chads, there is already a clear result from the presidential election. Suburbanites across America have sent Washington a message: Take my money, please.

title: The Florida Thicket, From Courts to Chads
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of a performance by the Parsons Dance Company at the New Victory Theater misidentified a dancer. The woman with Henry Jackson was Katarzyna Skarpetowska, not Ruth-Ellen Kroll.

title: Avnet Earnings Will Fall Short
description: Avnet, the second-largest American distributor of computer parts and semiconductors behind Arrow Electronics, said its fiscal second-quarter earnings would fall short of analysts' estimates because of excess inventory in the semiconductor industry.

title: Sports of The Times; Fassel's Desperate Decision
description: JIM FASSEL is concerned. You can see that concern in his clenched teeth. You can hear it in his clenched voice. He's concerned not just about the Giants, he's concerned about his job, about whether he'll be back next season to fulfill his one-year contract extension. And he's known all along what his future will depend on.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ASCHER, GERARD
description: ASCHER-Gerard. 7/31/17-11/21/99 Remembered by your loving family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITCHCOCK, ETHAN ALLEN
description: HITCHCOCK-Ethan Allen. The Board, staff and volunteers of Thirteen/WNET New York express their sorrow at the passing of our former Chairman of the Board, Ethan Allen Hitchcock. Serving on the board since 1967 and serving as Chairman from 1968-1980, Ethan Allen Hitchcock presided over the station during an evolutionary period. During his tenure as Chairman, Thirteen created some of the legendary series that have become the hallmark of public television, including Great Performances, The Newshour and Bill Moyers' Journal. We are all the grateful beneficiaries of his dedication and committment to public television. Our sincere condolences to his wife, Mari, their children and family. Steven Rattner, Chairman William F. Baker, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTLEY, FREDA
description: HARTLEY-Freda. On November 20, peacefully at home at age 88. Beloved mother of Leslie Gise M.D, and Sara Hartley M.D. Adoring grandmother of Robin Gise, J.D. Services Wednesday, November 22, 11:30 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St.

title: The ocean roars. Their eyes meet. A kiss is imminent. Forget the phone.
description: PHOTOGRAPHED last August in Malibu, the 30-second spot is in black and white and entitled ''Couple,'' and it leaves little to the imagination, to say the least.

title: SAS TO UNIFY STOCKS
description: Scandinavian Airlines System will combine its three shares into one in the first half of 2001, according to a Swedish newspaper report that quotes the airline's chief executive, Jan Stenberg. SAS is now controlled by three national holding companies, one each in Denmark, Sweden and Norway, with their own local-currency stocks. Approval will be needed from the three nations' governments, which hold stakes in the airline.

title: The Florida Thicket, From Courts to Chads; A Good-Faith Effort
description: To the Editor:

title: Divergent Views Are Argued On the Function of the Court
description: Lawyers offered the Florida Supreme Court two starkly different views yesterday, not just of the historic case before it but of the role of the courts in American life.

title: A Hearing in the Florida Supreme Court
description: While manual recounts continued in three Florida counties, all eyes were on the State Supreme Court yesterday. Here is a summary of the day's events.

title: Charles Ruff, White House Counsel Who Defended Clinton in Impeachment, Dies at 61
description: Charles F. C. Ruff, a former White House counsel to President Clinton who was known as one of Washington's most influential if least self-important lawyers and who played an important role in events from Watergate to Mr. Clinton's impeachment, died on Sunday at 61.

title: Database of Doctors Serves a Medical Need
description: To the Editor:

title: 15,000 Absentee Ballots At Stake as Lawsuit Gains
description: A local judge agreed yesterday to hear a lawsuit seeking to throw out the 15,000 absentee ballots cast in heavily Republican Seminole County, Fla.

title: Read My Clothes: Dressing Presidential
description: Like characters in a comic opera, the presidents-almost-elect have passed much of the last two weeks making cameo appearances in the theater of public opinion. As lawyers skirmished and handlers cranked scenery in the background, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush skittered from stage left to stage right, finally stalling in the mediagenic, vaguely neutral center.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BASF A.G., Ludwigshafen, Germany, the biggest chemical maker in Europe, said it would buy a 14.2 percent stake in Hanwha Chemical Corp. of South Korea, the No. 2 petrochemical firm by sales in Korea, for about $106 million, to secure chlorine for making polyurethane plastic used in car parts and appliances.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen slumped on concern that an attempt to oust Japan's prime minister will delay extra government spending to spur the economy. In New York, the dollar settled at 109.92 yen, up from 108.84 on Friday.

title: Into the Orchestral 'Ring,' Where Sound Stands Alone
description: Wagner wanted his orchestra subterranean, his music an invisible atmosphere supporting the life of his characters and their world. But there are advantages, too, in putting the music and the orchestra on display, as the New York Philharmonic did on Thursday night when it invited Lorin Maazel to conduct his compilation ''The Ring Without Words,'' a 70-minute Rhine journey from the birth-of-nature music at the start of ''Das Rheingold'' to the ecstatic cataclysm that closes ''Gotterdammerung.''

title: City Center's Leader, and Other Rare Finds
description: HERE we are again in the writers' room -- well, actually, in the closet, a few paces down the corridor from the spot where the likes of Neil Simon and Mel Brooks once polished jokes for Sid Caesar -- with Judith E. Daykin, current landlady of the writers' room. How many landlords would have a eureka moment when they saw the words ''Your Show of Shows'' on scripts that had been left undisturbed in the closet for decades?

title: OLD MUTUAL MOVES TO RETAIN PILGRIM BAXTER FOUNDERS
description: Old Mutual P.L.C., the South African insurer, said that as part of a plan to retain the co-founders of Pilgrim Baxter & Associates Inc., an American mutual fund company that it bought last month, Old Mutual would buy from the executives the rights to 35 percent of Pilgrim Baxter's revenue for $220 million. As part of the agreement, Gary Pilgrim and Harold Baxter promised to manage the company through 2008. Old Mutual, whose claim to Pilgrim Baxter revenue rises to 70 percent in the deal, also has an option to pay an additional $420 million for the remaining 30 percent, an option it may exercise starting in January 2002. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Drama in Tallahassee
description: The two-and-a-half-hour hearing conducted yesterday by the Florida Supreme Court had a seriousness suitable to the task of setting vote-counting rules that may well determine the outcome of the presidential election and public confidence in that election. With careful questioning, the seven justices illuminated the key issue of whether the hand recounts now under way in Palm Beach, Broward and Miami-Dade counties should be included in the official returns. They also pressed attorneys for Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush on how the process can be completed in time for Florida's representatives in the Electoral College to be certified by the Dec. 12 deadline.

title: Israel Charges Palestinians With Flouting Commitments
description: The Israeli government today published a detailed catalog of what it contends is a systematic Palestinian flouting of commitments under successive peace pacts and cease-fire accords.

title: RICHEMONT PROFIT SURGES
description: Companie Financiere Richemont, maker of Cartier, Piaget and Baume & Mercier watches and other luxury goods, said its group profit before extraordinary items rose 51 percent in the first half of its fiscal year, to $265 million, on strong demand in Asia and the United States. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Sudden Fame on a Quest for Freedom; A Nobel Prize, Not Politics, Shakes Up the World of a Storyteller in Exile
description: Until Gao Xingjian exhibited his ink paintings at a local cultural center this spring, his working-class neighbors in the Paris suburb of Bagnolet had no idea they had an artist in their midst. He was simply the polite Chinese immigrant who lived on the 18th floor of their run-down housing project. Only after the show did he become something of a celebrity, at least to those riding the elevator with him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, LEONARD
description: GREENE-Leonard. Temple Beth Torah, Westbury, New York mourns the loss of our beloved member. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Fran, children Charles, Ruth and Steven and to his mother, sister and grandchildren. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Michael Katz Leonard B. Austin, President

title: Northwest Gets Order to Avert Holiday Slowdown
description: Northwest Airlines Corp., the No. 4 U.S. carrier, won a temporary restraining order to keep its mechanics from disrupting flights during the busy Thanksgiving travel season, the company said.

title: Review Military Votes, Florida Attorney General Says
description: Retreating under fire from Republicans, Florida's attorney general, a top ally of Vice President Al Gore, said today that local officials should count absentee ballots from overseas military voters that were thrown out because they lacked postmarks.

title: Dance in Review; A Long Trip Around Greece And a Short Poem by Sappho
description: Cosmos Dance Company

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNN, LILLIAN L.
description: LYNN-Lillian L., eighty-five, died Sunday, November 19th in New York City; wife of Leo N. Lynn (deceased), mother of Stephan Lynn, Bruce (wife Ruth) Lynn, and Myrna (husband, Mark) Cortez; grandchildren, Rachel, Sarah, Joshua, and Noah Lynn. Services in Munster, Indiana at 11 AM on Tuesday, November 21st. The family will be gathered at Stephan Lynn's home in New York City on Sunday, November 26 starting at 6PM. Donations to the charity of your choice in lieu of flowers.

title: Average Family Just Getting By, No Safety Net; They Fly Through the Air, Usually With Greatest of Ease
description: It was spaghetti sauce from a jar and canned corn for dinner. Mom had to go back to work in a few hours and there wasn't time for anything fresh.

title: A Startling Bank Privatization in Brazil
description: With branches of Banco do Estado de Sao Paulo closed throughout Brazil in protest, Banco Santander Central Hispano won the auction for the bank, a state-run enterprise, with a bid of $3.57 billion today. It was the largest amount ever paid for a government bank in South America.

title: Coping With a 'Cold' That Stays Too Long
description: Many people are all too familiar with this condition: It starts with a cold that lingers well beyond the 7 to 10 days colds usually last, leaving a person feeling stuffed up, dragged out, headachy and irritable. Or perhaps it begins with a spring or fall allergy, but long after the person is no longer exposed to pollen or mold spores, discomforting respiratory symptoms persist.

title: Quaker Oats Battle Comes Down to Getting Gatorade
description: The war for Quaker Oats can be summed up in one word: Gatorade.

title: Arguments Before Florida's Supreme Court on the Presidential Recount
description: Following are excerpts from a hearing before the Florida Supreme Court on hand recounts, as recorded by The New York Times. The lawyers questioned by the seven justices included David Boies, for the Gore campaign; Joseph P. Klock Jr., for Secretary of State Katherine Harris; and Michael Carvin, for the Bush campaign.

title: Giants Begin Makeover for Ugly Special Teams
description: With five games to go in the regular season, a playoff berth far from assured and his team on a two-game losing streak, Giants Coach Jim Fassel returned to a vexing problem of preseason basics. Since training camp, Fassel has dedicated extra attention to the improvement of his special teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUERTOLLANO, MARILU M.D.
description: PUERTOLLANO - Marilu M.D. The Department of Psychiatry at the Long Island College Hospital mourns the untimely loss of our colleague Marilu Puertollano M.D. She was an excellent clinician and a teacher to many young physicians. We will miss her. We extend our sympathy to her entire family. Arnold Licht, M.D. Chairman Ravindra Amin, M.D. Assoc. Chairman Loraine Fleming, Sr. Administrator

title: Israel Strikes Back After a School Bus Is Bombed
description: A powerful roadside bomb ripped apart an armored school bus used by settlers' children this morning, instantly killing a teacher and a maintenance man and dismembering several young children.

title: FIRST-TIME ONLINE ADVERTISERS RISE
description: The number of companies advertising online for the first time has more than doubled since January, according to AdRelevance, a Jupiter Media Metrix company, growing by 157 percent the last 10 months. In the third quarter of 2000, 5,489 advertisers came online for the first time, far surpassing the first and second quarters, in which there were 2,935 and 3,879 new advertisers, respectively. Also, while traditional advertisers accounted for about 41 percent of the top 100 new online advertisers in January, they made up close to 50 percent in October. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, MIRIAM S.
description: ROSENBERG-Miriam S. Of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Mitzi died peacefully on the morning of November 17, 2000 after a lifetime of tremendous strength of spirit. Her generosity to family, friends and colleagues is unsurpassed and for all of us, never ending. Greatly devoted wife of over 50 years to Louis. Mother of Steve R. of Oakland, CA, Eve M. of Chester, England and Carrie C. of Peapack-Gladstone, NJ. Nurturing grandmother of Louise, Laura, Jesse, Clarissa and Lucas. Mentor and friend to all of her colleagues and students at Mt. Sinai Hospital, the New Rochelle Hospital School of Nursing, the Maternity Center Association, the Visiting Nurse Service of New York City and the Lehman College Department of Nursing. We all shall miss her brave and determined love of life. Her spirit lives on in all those whose lives she has touched. A memorial service to be announced at a later date. Donations in Mitzi's memory may be sent to WNYC Foundation, One Centre Street, New York, NY 10007, Attn: Kim Hudson.

title: The Florida Thicket, From Courts to Chads; Voter, Inform Thyself
description: To the Editor:

Grandmother to 29, great grandmother to 35 and great, great grandmother to one.
