description: LEVY-Vivian. On November 19, 2000. Volunteer at NYU for many years. Beloved wife of the late Harold, devoted mother of David, second mother to Suzanne Weissman, cherished grandmother of Dana and Andrew and lifelong friend of Rose Ullman. Warm and caring mother, grandmother and friend to many. Services Tuesday, 1:30 PM, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. at 76th Rd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOTT, SISTER CATHERINE REGINA
description: BOTT-Sister Catherine Regina. of Sisters of St. Dominic in Amityville, NY on November 19, 2000. A friend and educator to many over her years of dedicated service to her Order. Loving sister of Margaret and William. Visitation will be held Tuesday 2-5 and 7-10 PM at the R. Stutzmann & Son Funeral Home, 224-39 Jamaica Avenue, Queens Village, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Wednesday 11 AM at St. Albert's Chapel, Amityville. Interment in Sister's Cemetery, Amityville.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWBIN, JESS N.
description: TOWBIN-Jess N. On November 20, 2000. Beloved husband of Doris E. Towbin. Father & father-in-law of Lisa & Leonard Olim, Barry, & Laura Towbin, brother, A. Robert Towbin. Also surviving are his grandchildren, Michael & Zachary Olim. Funeral Services will be held on Wednesday at 12 Noon in the McCriskin Home for Funerals, 2425 Plainfield Ave. So., Plainfield. Entombment will follow in the Temple of Israel Mausoleum, Woodbridge. Family members will be receiving family & friends on Wednesday from 10 AM to 12 Noon in the funeral home. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to the Towbin Foundation C/O Muhlenberg Regional Medical Center, Park Ave & Randolph Ave. Plainfield, N.J. 07060. Shiva will be observed on Wednesday, 7-9 PM, Saturday from 6-9 PM & Sunday, 2-5 PM @ 141 Smith St., South Plainfield, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERNER, NATHAN
description: KERNER-Nathan. The Merrick Jewish Centre Congregation Ohr Torah mourns the passing of our beloved member and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Jean Kerner and the entire family. We pray the family will be consoled with all the mourners of our people. Barry M. Lasky, President Rabbi Charles A. Klein

title: AOL DEAL WITH AUDIOBASKET
description: AudioBasket, a company in San Francisco that offers computer users a customized audio news and information service, has reached agreement with America Online to become a feature on Spinner, the AOL music player. Terms were not disclosed. AudioBasket will also be made available on other AOL properties like AOL.com, Netscape and ICQ. AudioBasket users can choose to receive content from media outlets like ABCNews.com, CNN Radio, Entertainment Weekly magazine and National Public Radio. Stuart Elliott (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHIZNER, JUDITH
description: CHIZNER-Judith. Temple Israel, Lawrence, NY, mourns her loss and extends deepest sympathy to the bereaved family. Allen Kaplan, Rabbi Alan Hartstein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STORCH, GERTRUDE
description: STORCH-Gertrude. On November 19, 2000. Beloved wife of Sidney. Cherished cousin. Services ''The Riverside'', NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAWRON, MICHAEL A.
description: GAWRON-Michael A. Age 57, of Brooklyn. Died on October 12. Burial was in Chicopee, MA. He was an Associate at William B. Tabler Architect and was most recently Project Architect on Brooklyn Renaissance Plaza which includes the Marriott Hotel and Office Tower. A memorial celebration will be held at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, Manhattan on December 2, at 4:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTKIN, RUTH
description: GOTKIN-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Muni, devoted mother of Paul and Janet Gotkin, cherished grandmother of Miranda Gotkin Obo and Bethany Gotkin, great grandmother of Mima and Salim, loving sister of Pearl Goldfarb. Services 10:30 Tuesday, Waterbury Kelly Funeral Home, 45 South Highland Ave., Ossining.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Nov. 5 discussed growing cultural and economic conflicts in the Mission District of San Francisco between the working poor who inhabit the neighborhood by day and the Silicon Valley rich who return to its bistros and loft apartments by night. The article included statistics on income level in the district.

title: After Gaza Rocket Attack, State Dept. Gives Israel Stern Warning
description: The murderous new cycle of violence in Gaza today drew the most severe warning to Israel by the Clinton administration since the fighting broke out seven weeks ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CABELL, WILLIAM D.
description: CABELL-William D., 92. On Nov. 14 at home, Rock Castle, VA. He is survived by his wife Ellen Rolston Cabell, children Kathleen Cabell Hildreth and William D. Cabell Jr. and their families. He graduated from the University of Virginia College and Law School and practiced law in NYC from 1932 to 1991. After serving as a Lieutenant in the Navy in W.W. II, he resided in Chappaqua, NY. A member of Delta Psi Fraternity, Squadron A and the Knickerbocker Club in NYC. In the 1950's he published ''Voters Voice'', an innovative Congressional watchdog newsletter. A great gentleman.

title: City Revises Plan to Create Jobs for Poor
description: The Giuliani administration, after winning a nine-month legal battle with the city comptroller over $104 million in city contracts to place welfare recipients into private-sector jobs, is now backing away from that plan, according to the top executive of the company at the center of that conflict.

title: Camby Is Day to Day With an Ankle Sprain
description: A magnetic resonance imaging exam confirmed yesterday that Marcus Camby had incurred only a sprain of his left ankle. He traveled with the Knicks when they flew to Orlando, Fla., for tonight's game with the Magic.

title: The Florida Thicket, From Courts to Chads; The Politics of Ego
description: To the Editor:

title: Front Row; Writing about Russian emigres in Paris and their contribution to an era of glamour Modeled on herself Sundays at Tiffany's.
description: When the Russians Took Paris

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRENSTEIN, ADELE
description: EHRENSTEIN-Adele, On November 19, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Irving, loving mother of Dr. Gerald and Debbie Ehrenstein and Dr. Lila and Dr. Richard Nachtigall. Cherished grandmother of Margaret and Anthony, Lisa and Rob, Ellen and Matthew, Ruth and Larry, David and Judy and Steven and Elissa. Adoring great grandmother of Julia, Greg, Andrew, Justin, Jenny, Sam, Jacob and Sam. Dear aunt and great-aunt. Services Wednesday 11:15AM at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to Foundation for Women's Wellness, 251 East 33rd Street, New York 10016.

title: Pupils Molested On 2 Stairways Inside School
description: A man lingered yesterday morning in two stairwells at a Queens elementary school, where he sexually assaulted a child who was running an errand for her teacher and groped three other pupils before getting away, the police said.

title: China Signs U.N. Pact on Rights and Rule of Law
description: Calling it a milestone for China, the top human-rights official of the United Nations signed an agreement here today for cooperation and training on individual rights and the rule of law.

title: BEAR STEARNS IN ACCORD TO BUY HELIOS GROUP
description: The Bear Stearns Companies agreed to buy Helios Group, a privately held company that creates electronic trading systems for securities markets. Terms of the purchase, which requires regulatory approval, were undisclosed. The companies said in a statement that Bear Stearns, based in New York, would acquire substantially all of Helios, which is based in Chicago and has offices in London and Amsterdam. The deal will allow trading in futures and options on stocks, indexes and bonds on 11 exchanges.

title: Four Accused in New Case Tied to Stock Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Federal authorities accused four Massachusetts residents of making over $7.5 million as beneficiaries of "a massive fraud" involving the promotion and sale of unregistered Internet stock.

title: Corrections
description: In my previous column I misspelled the name of a golf club maker. The company is Callaway Golf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIN, STANLEY H.
description: MULLIN-Stanley H. Age 84, on November 2, 2000. The Pace University community records with sorrow the passing of Stanley H. Mullin, former professor and chair of the Marketing Department. Dr. Mullin worked at Pace for 35 years until his retirement in 1984. He served in a variety of administrative roles including Director of Student Activities, Director of Development and Vice President for College and Community Relations. After his retirement he helped form the Pace Retirement Organization and served as the editor of its newsletter until August 1999. Sincere condolences are extended to his wife, Kathleen, his daughter Joan Myers, and her husband Steven, and their daughters Kathleen, Carolyn and Mary.

title: Staff Cuts Expected At BBDO Worldwide
description: The BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group in New York said yesterday that it would soon make an unspecified number of staff reductions among employees in North America to help achieve the cost savings the agency had promised when it was awarded the consolidated account of the Chrysler Group unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G.

title: No One Spared As the Justices Look for an End
description: About two minutes into the Florida Supreme Court's bracing session today, Chief Justice Charles T. Wells began arching his long eyebrows, squinting skeptically, and leaning forward restlessly in his chair as if he could not quite believe that the lawyer in front of him was delivering a civics lesson on the nation's cherished right to vote.

title: All Channels Tuned to Courtroom Drama in Florida
description: It was a big day for courtroom drama on television. So big, in fact, that one network was even compelled to pre-empt that ratings queen of justice in the afternoon, Judge Judy.

title: INSIDE
description: Fujimori Resigns

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEVIN, ELSIE
description: SEVIN-Elsie. Of Hollywood, FL, on November 20th, 2000. Wife of the late Benjamin Sevin, M.D. Mother of Betsy Sevin Eisenberg & Richard M. Sevin. Grandmother of David, Laurie & Andrew Sevin and Douglas, James and Joshua Eisenberg. Mother-in-law of Philip M. Eisenberg and Ellen Sevin. Graveside service will be held on Wednesday, 1 PM, at Mount Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Torre Tells the World That He Wants Mussina
description: Experience can build and toughen like scar tissue, and what Joe Torre has seen, from a distance, is an evolution within Mike Mussina. Torre watches Mussina and sees an angry and tested competitor, rather than a pitcher who seemed overcome by frustration, as Torre thought in his first year as Yankees manager in 1996.

title: The Victims of Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: New Insurance Rules for Patients Ease Way for Faster Decisions and Appeals
description: President Clinton today issued new rules that define the rights of more than 130 million Americans to obtain prompt, fair decisions on health insurance claims and to appeal if the claims are denied or delayed.

title: Supervisor Of Elections Quits Job Of Recounting
description: The lone Republican member of Broward County's canvassing board resigned today, saying that she could no longer work 15-hour days and that she wanted to go to California on vacation with her family.

title: Ant Talk
description: Q.: Watching ants traveling in a line, I noticed they meet head-on for a moment, then continue on their way. Is this some type of communication?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUER, PHILLIP H.
description: FEUER-Phillip H. On November 19, 2000. Beloved husband and soulmate of Sarene P. Shanus. Cherished and loving father of Rose R.S. Feuer and Abigail E.S. Feuer. Dear brother of Marvin Feuer and Susan Feuerwerger and brother-in-law of Debra Feuer, Peter Young and Corey and Amy Shanus. Adored son of the late Gita and Henry Feuerwerger and son-in-law of Harriet and Sol Shanus. Loving uncle, nephew, cousin and friend. Funeral services 12:30 PM, November 21 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Martin Set for Tests as Jets' Coach Insists Injury Is Unclear
description: If the Jets' defense was the cornerstone of their 20-3 victory over the Miami Dolphins on Sunday, then their medical team may be the critical unit for the Jets this week.

title: Israelis Living In Gaza Strip
description: THE POPULATION -- More than 7,000 Israelis in 17 settlements live among one million Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.

title: His Eyes on Tallahassee, Gore Talks to Nashville
description: Vice President Al Gore spent this afternoon secluded at his residence here as the Florida Supreme Court weighed arguments that could determine the outcome of the presidential election.

title: E-mail Shows Action by an Aide to Jeb Bush
description: Among the thousands of complaints that poured in to Gov. Jeb Bush's e-mail in-box in the tumultuous days since the election, one prompted an unusually passionate response. And today, when the governor's office released a pile of e-mails, it turned out to be somewhat embarrassing.

title: First Arrest in Case of the Purloined Code-Breaker
description: A British antiques dealer has been charged in connection with the theft of a rare German Enigma encryption machine from its Buckinghamshire museum case. The arrest came after months of complex secret correspondence that required the police to develop their own code-breaking skills.

title: Two Familiar Faces Raise Devils' Optimism
description: Two overtime victories this weekend made the Devils feel pretty good. The return of Jason Arnott and Scott Niedermayer today made the team feel even better.

title: U.S. Agency Issues Con Ed a Code Red Violation for Indian Point 2 Radioactive Leak
description: In the latest blemish to Consolidated Edison's stewardship of the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission issued the harshest citation possible today under a new color-coded ranking of risk, saying the company neglected a host of problems that led to a radioactive leak earlier this year.

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL TO BE BOUGHT BY OHIO BANK
description: Fifth Third Bancorp, an Ohio bank that has been expanding in the Midwest, agreed to buy the Old Kent Financial Corporation of Grand Rapids, Mich., for $4.92 billion in stock. The deal would create the country's 15th-largest bank, with $69.1 billion in assets and 980 branches in five states. Fifth Third will pay 0.74 share for each share of Old Kent, equivalent to $34.32 a share based on Fifth Third's closing price of $46.38. Old Kent's stock rose $8.56, to close at $33.56, eating up most of the 42 percent premium the deal represented over Old Kent's closing price Friday. Fifth Third, whose unusual name reflects the merger of the Third National and Fifth National Banks of Cincinnati after the Panic of 1907, has made or announced 46 acquisitions since 1980, all of them in the Midwest. Fifth Third said it expected to take a $235 million charge from buying Old Kent.

title: The Florida Thicket, From Courts to Chads; Whose Rule of Law?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Divine Gift in Sickness Vanishes Painfully in Health
description: LYING AWAKE

title: McEnroe, Davis Cup Captain, Resigns
description: In just 14 months, John McEnroe discovered he could not force America's top players to share his passion for Davis Cup, magically alter a problematic event schedule or instantly restore the United States to its champion status.

title: Memorial for Canby
description: A public memorial service for Vincent Canby, the former chief film critic and Sunday theater critic for The New York Times, will be held on Nov. 29 at noon in the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street. Mr. Canby, who worked for The Times for more than 35 years and gained an international reputation as a critic, died on Oct. 15 at 76.

title: Auto Sales Have Slowed This Month
description: Auto sales, often a leading indicator of the economy's health, have slowed since the beginning of the month, prompting carmakers to increase their already deep discounts and to consider additional temporary closings of factories, industry officials said today.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Ingo Potrykus; Golden Rice in a Grenade-Proof Greenhouse
description: In a quiet village on the outskirts of Zurich, a genetically engineered strain of rice that its creator says could save millions of children's lives is locked up in a grenade-proof greenhouse as if it were the Frankenstein monster that some critics contend it is. Unlike any other rice on earth, this so-called golden rice produces beta carotene in its seeds, thanks to genetic instructions that scientists added to the rice from a daffodil, pea, bacterium and virus.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the broadcast news correspondent Robert Trout on Wednesday misspelled the surname of a colleague at CBS News. He was Winston Burdett, not Burdette.

title: ORACLE SHARES DECLINE
description: Shares of the Oracle Corporation closed down 14 percent yesterday in very heavy trading as Wall Street reacted sourly to the weekend news that Gary L. Bloom, 40, an executive vice president, was leaving to become president and chief executive of Veritas Software. In July, Ray Lane quit as president of Oracle. Oracle shares closed at $24.75 yesterday, down $4.06. ''Dozens of companies in the Valley are now headed by Oracle alumni,'' said Jeff Henley, Oracle's chief financial officer. ''There is no better proof of the quality of our people.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a proposal to turn the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan into an arts center gave a misspelled surname in some copies for the spokesman for the New York Philharmonic, which would perform there. He is Eric Latzky, not Latsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REILLY, JAMES V.
description: REILLY-James V. On November 19, 2000, born November 27, 1927. Beloved husband of the late Grace. Loving Father of Kevin Reilly and wife Barbara, Cathleen Dennehy and husband Geoff and Colleen O'Toole and husband Sean. Cherished grandfather of Kevin, Geoffrey, Meghan, Daniel, Jack and Julia. Dear brother of Edward Reilly. Friends may call Tuesday 2-5 & 7-9:30 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, Inc. 29 Atlantic Avenue. Floral Park, New York (at RR Plaza). Mass of Christian burial is on Wednesday 9:30 A.M., at Our Lady of Victory RC Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Article 2000112192231190114 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Particle Physics Braces for the Next Big Thing
description: Gerard Bachy, an engineer, stands 250 feet underground in an immense, bottle-shaped cavern that scientists around the world might regard as a kind of magic lantern. Thousands of those scientists hope, in effect, to rub this lantern and conjure a mysterious subatomic particle called the Higgs boson that their most trusted theories say is the source of all mass in the universe, the reason matter has weight.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: TIME WARNER JOINT VENTURE IN JAPAN TO CLOSE
description: Weak consumer spending in Japan will force the dissolution of the joint venture that operates Time Warner's licensed-character retail stores there. The five stores, stocked with Bugs Bunny and Tasmanian Devil plush toys and other goods, will remain open until summer and then be liquidated, according to Daiei, Time Warner's Japanese partner, which owns two-thirds of the venture. Daiei will pay Time Warner subsidiaries 1.55 billion yen, or $14 million to cancel the contract. Daiei also said it would liquidate a casual clothing company and a real estate leasing company it controls and take a charge of 24.9 billion yen, or $226 million, as part of a plan to reduce debt.

title: Forestalling Death Penalty In Wendy's Massacre Case
description: The lawyer for one of the defendants in a massacre that left five people dead at a Wendy's restaurant in Queens last spring said yesterday that her client is mentally retarded and therefore cannot be put to death if convicted in the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLEY, HERMAN
description: KINGSLEY-Herman. The officers and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Herman Kingsley, whose family has embraced his legacy of righteous deeds and Jewish community leadership. His son, Alfred, a former member of our board of directors, serves in a leadership capacity on our Wall Street and Metropolitan campaigns and on the boards of several of our affiliated agencies. Alfred's wife, Temma, a guiding light in our Women's Campaign, is a vice president of the Board of Jewish Education and sits on numeous commissions and cabinets. Our deepest sympathies go to them; his other children, Stephen and Robert; his wife, Betty; his grandchildren; and the entire family. May all who benefited from Herman's kindness and wisdom be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Florida Justices Declare Recounts Should Be Allowed
description: In at least a partial victory for Vice President Al Gore, the Florida Supreme Court ruled tonight that state election officials must include hand recounts in the official results of the state's presidential election.

title: VITAL SIGNS: REACTIONS; Getting a Handle on Asthma and Aspirin
description: Patients whose asthma is caused by an allergic reaction to aspirin can manage the condition by increasing their intake in carefully controlled steps, according to an article published last week in the journal Chest.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: ING GROEP PLANNING MAJOR LAYOFFS IN LONDON
description: ING Groep's decision to abandon its plan to build a global investment bank may result in layoffs of as many as 1,000 people in London, executive recruiters and analysts said. ING, based in Amsterdam, has already announced that it expects to sell or close its American investment banking unit, affecting another 1,800 jobs. As part of the reorganization, the company will fold ING Barings in Europe into its other banking businesses, a move that analysts said would eliminate more than half the company's 1,700 London-based jobs. ING bought Barings for $:1 in 1995, Furman Selz in 1997 for $600 million and Charterhouse Securities four months ago for $190 million.

title: Astros' Offer Gets Vizcaino
description: Jose Vizcaino, the infielder who had the decisive run-scoring hit for the Yankees in Game 1 of the Subway Series, signed a one-year, $1.5 million contract, plus incentives, with the Houston Astros yesterday.

title: Study Links Rises in School Financing and Test Scores
description: Failing schools that received extra resources for smaller classes, longer school days and more teacher training had higher scores on standardized tests than similar schools that did not get the same kind of help, according to a study released yesterday by the New York City schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy.

title: Reality, Virtually: Computers Put Seminoles in the No. 2 Spot
description: Florida State leapfrogged over Miami into the No. 2 spot in the Bowl Championship Series ranking yesterday as college football moved closer to the nation's first championship matchup that was computer generated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, GEOFFREY
description: MARSHALL-Geoffrey. The faculty, staff and students of The Graduate Center of The City University of New York are profoundly saddened by the loss of Geoffrey Marshall, our former Provost and Senior Vice President. For his 13 years at The Graduate Center, first as Associate Provost and then as Provost, he will be remembered as a gentle and wise person, a champion of academic excellence, ever graceful and gracious. A man of unquestionable integrity, Geoffrey Marshall's many contributions to The Graduate Center, including the role he played in the planning of our new home, will be everlasting. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Mary, and family. Frances Degen Horowitz President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, GORDON
description: RICH-Gordon. With great sorrow, we learned of the passing of our new friend, colleague and group co-head. Obvious to us even in the short time we knew him was that his role as a manager and mentor was invaluable; he easily won the admiration of clients and colleagues alike; his enthusiasm was infectious. We were unfairly robbed of the opportunity to achieve great things together. We will miss you, friend. The DLJ Media & Communications Group

title: Former Prosecutor Is Charged With Insider Trading Attempt
description: A former prosecutor now in private practice in Westchester was charged yesterday with trying to buy confidential information about pending mergers from a paralegal at the Manhattan law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUDOIN, SUZANNE
description: BAUDOIN-Suzanne. Thanks to Scandinavia notes with sadness the passing of Suzanne Baudoin, beloved wife of our late board member and vigorous champion of Thanks to Scandinavia's scholarship fund dedicated to the nations of Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden in appreciation of the historic heroism of their people, governments and churches in rescuing thousands of their Jewish neighbors during WW II. Our heartfelt sympathy to her children Patsy, Jean-Yves, Marina and Bettina and their families. Victor Borge, National Chairman Richard Netter, President

title: French Uphold Ruling Against Yahoo on Nazi Sites
description: Upholding a verdict that has unsettled the Internet industry in France for the last seven months, a court here ruled today that Yahoo must prevent World Wide Web users in France from visiting its auction sites that sell Nazi memorabilia, or face heavy fines for each day that it did not comply.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACY, BERNADETTE
description: TRACY-Bernadette. The Board of Directors and members of the New York Croquet Club are deeply saddened by the passing of one of their own, Bernadette Tracy. Her wonderful sense of fun, her loyalty to the sport, her unmatched style and spirit will be sorely missed. The New York Croquet Club

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Why isn't it correct that we are jeopardizing with each passing day Florida being able to have its votes counted in the Electoral College?''

title: The Florida Thicket, From Courts to Chads; Electoral Inequity?
description: To the Editor:

title: Whatever the Disguise, You Can Name That Tune
description: One way to interpret jazz is to see it is as a history of subversions, and one of those subversions has been the practice of disguising an old song with harmony and arrangement. It's a form of play and surprise that can work beautifully when the originals are tough and modest things, like some of the rhythm tunes by Monk or Ellington, or songs in which the harmony is already rich enough to encourage alternate readings. But when an arranger builds over really strong old melodies, the original article can still blaze so brightly underneath the layers of disguise that you start to wonder why it wasn't allowed to show more of itself.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: COMMERZBANK, named Klaus-Peter Muller chief executive. He succeeds Martin Kohlhaussen, the current chairman.

title: The Palestinians' Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: CARDBOARD UNIT ON THE BLOCK
description: AssiDoman of Sweden said it was in talks to sell its corrugated and containerboard division ''to several parties,'' scrapping an earlier plan to split its industrial and forest-products units into separate businesses. The company gave no further details. Its cardboard box business, including the units to be sold, had revenue of 9.155 billion kronor ($898 million) in the first nine months, about half AssiDoman's total.

title: 2nd Officer Describes Beating of Man Who Died in Custody
description: An Orange police officer, echoing his partner's testimony a week ago, said in Federal District Court today that he saw another officer spray pepper gas directly into the face of a handcuffed man who was lying on the floor of police headquarters and who later died in police custody.

title: National Gallery to Return a Family's Painting Looted by the Nazis
description: The National Gallery of Art said yesterday that it would return a 17th-century Flemish painting to the heirs of Marguerite Stern, the widow of a Jewish banker from France whose art collection was seized by the Nazis when they occupied Paris. Members of the Stern family, now living in Europe, moved to reclaim the painting, by Frans Snyders, after reading about it on the gallery's Web site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, JAMES G.
description: TOBIN-James G. Retired Con Ed employee of 25 years. Beloved husband of Eileen (nee Higbee). Loving father of Jane, Brendan, the late James, Kyra, Michael, and John. Grandfather of Jillaine, James, and Olivia. Brother of the late John J. and Eileen. Reposing at Ralph Giordano Funeral Home, 1727 Crosby Ave., Bronx, Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass Wednesday 9:30 AM, Our Lady of the Assumption RC Church.

title: The 'Patch' That Saved a Pregnancy
description: A year ago, Laurie Melzak-Klein, a 29-year-old social worker in Manalapan, N.J., was pregnant with her first child. She was carrying a boy, tests had shown, and he seemed perfectly healthy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADDISS, LUISE KRAUS
description: ADDISS-Luise Kraus. November 19, 2000 of cardiac arrest at the age of 101. Loving mother of James and Stephen Addiss and Penelope Yungblut. Grandmother of Wendy Dellar, Edward Addiss III, Justus Addiss, Susan Hemingway and Yosa Addiss and three great grandchildren, mother-inlaw of Lee Addiss and Gail Addiss. Wake at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28 St, Tuesday, November 21, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral mass at Epiphany Church, 22nd St and 2nd Ave, Wednesday, November 22, 11AM. Burial private. Memorial gifts in her name in lieu of flowers: The Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: AMRO ON THE PROWL
description: ABN Amro Holding, the largest Dutch bank, said it was seeking acquisitions in consumer banking in Europe and fund management in Britain and Japan. It also plans to expand its private-banking business in Germany, Italy, Brazil and the United States, according to Rijkman Groenink, chief executive of ABN Amro. ''We are not setting ourselves a deadline,'' he told reporters.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, WILLIAM H.
description: PECK-William H. Suddenly on November 17, 2000, at age 76. Services will be private. Please omit flowers. For further information contact John Krtil Funeral Home, 212-744-3084.

title: Europe Acts to Build Own Military Force
description: The European Union today took its first major step to turn itself into a military power, as its defense ministers pledged troops and equipment to create a 60,000-member force by 2003.

title: The Math Problem
description: In the labor negotiations for New York City's 78,000 public-school teachers, a forceful mayor is facing off with a mighty union, but there is a third powerful force hovering over the bargaining table: the huge problem the city faces in attracting enough certified teachers.

title: Let Priests Marry
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Team Begins At Familiar Site
description: The United States finds itself in a familiar position in its attempt to qualify for the 2002 World Cup in Japan and South Korea. The Americans' last qualifying game will be held at Trinidad and Tobago at the same stadium where, in 1989, they qualified for the World Cup for the first time in 40 years.

title: AUSTRALIAN WINE COMPANY TO SELL PACKAGING UNIT
description: Southcorp Ltd., Australia's biggest wine company, agreed to sell its Asia-Pacific packaging unit to the Visy Group. Precise terms were not disclosed, but Southcorp said the sale price was greater than the unit's book value of 700 million Australian dollars, or $360 million. Southcorp said it also expected to sell its United States packaging assets, which have a book value of about $105 million, by July 2001 and to make acquisitions in its remaining business lines, wine and water heaters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIMAN, HARRY
description: LEIMAN - Harry. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our past President and esteemed member, Harry Leiman. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Kenneth Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President

title: Mori Has a Hairbreadth Victory In No-Confidence Vote in Japan
description: After a week of parliamentary hardball, Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori today narrowly escaped a no-confidence vote hatched from his own party.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEAVY, EDWARD T.
description: LEAVY-Edward T. On November 21, 1979. In loving memory. Remembered always. Your children and grandchildren.

title: Aggressive Approaches Can Bolster Heart Health
description: Eat some food before flying, but not too much on Thanksgiving. Take vitamin B3 with cholesterol-reducing drugs. Sporadic exercise may be hazardous to your health. Aggressive treatment of mild heart attacks saves lives.

title: Tokyo's Flagship Stores Are Architectural Statements : White Noise and Color Shock
description: TOKYO  It is only a vast hole in the ground and a bunch of hard-hat construction workers, but already Prada's new Aoyama store here is being hailed as a future architectural monument.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, CARL
description: BRODY-Carl. On November 12, 2000. Husband and partner of Dorothy S. Brody. Highly respected tax attorney and business associate of T. L. C. Beatrice. Interment private.

title: An Overall Net Gain
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLASER, MORRIS
description: BLASER-Morris. October 16, 1966. Loving father. Sorry for being late. We will never forget you.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Fall on Concern About Profits and Election

title: Time Warner Makes Access Deal With Earthlink
description: In the face of government pressure, Time Warner agreed yesterday to allow Earthlink to offer high-speed Internet access over Time Warner cable television systems if the government approves Time Warner's proposed merger with America Online.

title: Charging Yankee Skulduggery, MSG to Get Its Day in Court
description: A sham.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEICHNER, THEODORE
description: ZEICHNER-Theodore. Community Board 6, Manhattan, expresses its deep sorrow at the passing of its former treasurer, friend and 20year colleague, Theodore (Ted) Zeichner.

title: The Florida Thicket, From Courts to Chads; Wanted: A Statesman
description: To the Editor:

title: Distractions Can't Keep The Nets From Winning
description: The day was surreal for the Nets, as five police helicopters circled above their blockaded team bus.

title: The Florida Thicket, From Courts to Chads; Our Real Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Garbage Plan Hearing Is Unusually Tidy
description: New Yorkers have seldom had much trouble summoning up a decent fit of rage on the subject of their garbage and what to do with it. In the early 1990's, when a trash-burning factory was proposed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, screaming tussles on the steps of City Hall were often the news du jour.

title: CHINA WEB RULE LIMITS FOREIGNERS
description: China has barred foreign companies from assigning Chinese-language Internet addresses to Web sites based in China, shutting companies like VeriSign of Mountain View, Calif., out of the lucrative market. China's Information Industry Ministry posted a notice on its Web site on Friday that said only the semiofficial China Internet Network Information Center had the authority to register Chinese-character Web addresses, or domain names. The information center, in turn, has named nine domestic companies to act as its agent in the registrations. VeriSign and the information center began competing Chinese-character domain name registration services earlier this month. Craig Smith (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ELAINE
description: STERN-Elaine. On November 19, 2000. Loving wife, mother, motherin-law, grandmother, sister and aunt. Survived by her children Kenneth and Judith, daughter-inlaw Sharon, grandchildren Evan, Rachel and Rebecca, sister Ruth and niece Mia. She will be remembered for her integrity, honesty and abiding intellectual curiosity. The family expresses deepest gratitude to Comprehensive Community Hospice in Lake Success, NY and Wayne County Hospice of Ohio. Donations may be made to your local hospice organization. Funeral services at Noon on November 22, 2000 at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Rockville Centre.

title: Fujimori Resignation Sets Off Succession Scramble in Peru
description: The Peruvian Congress received President Alberto K. Fujimori's formal resignation today, setting off a flurry of maneuvering by congressional leaders to decide who will succeed him and oversee the transition to new elections.

title: Malakhov's Ranger Season Could End After 3 Games
description: Vladimir Malakhov's first season with the Rangers could be summed up in three games. After a medical examination yesterday confirmed that Malakhov's torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee went from partial to complete in Minnesota last week, the defenseman appears to be lost for the season.

title: Metro Business Briefing; WATERFRONT PLANS REQUESTED
description: The New York City Economic Development Corporation is issuing a request for proposals to redevelop the South Brooklyn Marine Terminal in the Sunset Park section. The corporation is seeking a developer to improve and operate the 95-acre terminal. The site, which consists of three piers with seven berths and an upland area with six buildings and sheds ranging from 3,000 to 350,000 square feet, is between 29th and 39th Streets, and between the Bay Ridge Channel and Second Avenue. The terminal is the busiest center in the United States for importing and distributing cocoa beans.

title: Where Republicans See a 'Mess,' Democrats See 'Smooth'
description: The battle for Florida was distilled today to its essence: a sharpening contest between dueling images of chaos and order.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUHL, BERNARD, D.D.S.
description: STRUHL-Bernard, D.D.S. On November 18, 2000. Devoted father of Pamela, Meridith, and Samuel. Father-in-law of Larry. Grandpa of Jayson and Jonathan. He served his last ace!

title: Analyze This: A Physicist on Applied Politics
description: Who would have guessed that the election of the president of the United States would come down to a question of measurement error?

title: CASES; Of Pretzels and Fruitcake: The Tales of a Rural Doctor
description: It is a peculiar privilege of a rural doctor to walk among one's dead. When I was training in San Francisco, I never considered the cemeteries. I was too busy analyzing test results and treatment options to wonder what happened when my patients went home, or when they died.

title: Turning Athletes Into Students
description: Some coaches protested when the National Collegiate Athletic Association stiffened eligibility requirements for freshmen athletes, many of whom had entered college so poorly prepared they stood no chance of graduating. Graduation data published this week by the National Collegiate Athletic Association confirm yet again that raising entry standards was a good idea. Trouble spots remain in basketball and football. But on the whole, the data show that athletes who entered college under the new standards are more likely to graduate than those who entered under the old system, as well as their contemporaries in the general student body.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: Public Interests; Thanksgiving 2000
description: This is going to be a Thanksgiving to remember. Never have Americans had more to be grateful for. No matter what other burdens afflict us, at least we are not counting votes in Broward County.

title: Questions of Access in a Land of Ancient Volcanoes
description: At sunrise here, thin layers of mist blanket vast expanses of grass as hundreds of elk emerge from the mountainside evergreens to graze, the valley echoing with their bugling calls. Bright yellow aspen light up the landscape, as pristine as it has ever been.

title: New Jersey Senate Asks Whitman's Staff to Turn Over Documents on Racial Profiling
description: The State Senate's inquiry into racial profiling by state troopers took a politically provocative turn today when investigators asked Gov. Christie Whitman and her staff to turn over any documents regarding discrimination by troopers.

title: Shunyi Journal; Blinded by Poverty: The Dark Side of Capitalism
description: In 15 minutes, Dr. Jiang Lijuan broke up the dense cataract that had long covered Liang Xingwang's eye, removed the debris and slipped a new tiny plastic lens under his cornea. She squirted in a few drops of antibiotic and prepared a heavy gauze bandage.

title: Doctor Plans Off-Shore Clinic for Abortions
description: As a child in the Netherlands, Rebecca Gomperts often sailed with her family in the chilly waters of the North Sea, a pastime that left her with a seemingly fearless attraction to things nautical. Today, as a 34-year-old gynecologist and public health advocate, Dr. Gomperts hopes to brave the elements again, this time to offer abortions and other reproductive services 12 miles offshore to women who cannot obtain them legally at home.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRANDER, THELMA (TILLY)
description: BRANDER-Thelma (Tilly). My Mom, you are always in my thoughts. I miss you. Roberta

title: U.N. Peacekeepers in the World According to Brecht
description: Few theatrical works in Germany have been more reviled than ''Die Massnahme'' (''The Measures Taken''), written by Bertolt Brecht and first performed in 1930. The play centers on a Communist in a country very like China who supports a peasant revolution but who is executed by his comrades because his efforts interfere with ideological goals.

title: French Court Affirms Auction Sites Ruling : Yahoo Faces Deadline To Block Nazi Items
description: PARIS  In a ruling certain to reverberate through the uncharted world of the Internet, a civil judge in Paris on Monday ordered Yahoo Inc., a leading U.S. Web company, to keep French citizens from seeing its American-based sites that auction Nazi-related items.

title: Ex-Enemies On Insurance Offer a Plan
description: Insurance companies, hospitals and a consumer group joined forces today and offered a proposal to provide health insurance to about half of the 42.6 million Americans who have no coverage.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Mutual Fund Rewards May Be a Gimmick and a Godsend
description: WOULD you like a mutual fund with those honey-roasted nuts?

title: Democrats Seek Wider Standard for Tallies in Two Counties
description: Disappointed by the results so far of the hand recounts, Democrats have set aside hundreds of ballots with no holes punched for a presidential candidate in the hope that they can persuade the canvassing boards or the courts that an indentation next to Vice President Al Gore's name should be counted as a vote for him.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TREATMENTS; A New Regimen for Lyme-Like Disease
description: A study published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine suggests a change in the standard treatment for babesiosis, a tick-borne infection that has similarities to Lyme disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, GEORGE
description: WEINSTEIN-George. Lake Park Synagogue, Milwaukee, WI notes with deep sorrow the passing of our founding Chairman. There are many accomplishments in life which measure our success. Few however, have as much far reaching significance and lasting impact as the foundation of a Synagogue. George Weinstein exemplified outstanding devotion and extraordinary commitment and gave so much of himself to make our dream a reality. His impact and legacy will be felt in our community for years to come. Our thoughts are with dear Shirley and children. David Fine, Rabbi Eliot Bernstein, President

title: Blue Moods And White Lightning
description: Old cars pop up often in Mississippi blues songs, and the genre itself is like one of those beautiful clunkers: its great engine has been driven into the ground, and fetishists love it more for its form than its function. But nobody knows a vehicle the way an owner does, and the players dedicated to this rusty, still powerful form understand its problems as well as its propelling force.

title: Assembly Moves to Restore Parental Notification of Abortion
description: The New Jersey Assembly took the first step today to bypass the State Supreme Court's overturning of a state law that would require parental notification before an unmarried girl under 18 could get an abortion.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SIDE EFFECTS; Pregnancy, Calcium and Levels of Lead
description: For pregnant women, low calcium levels can let more lead find its way into their blood, according to a new study that also found that the problem increased with age.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Alive, Kicking And Pinching, Too

title: Holiday Fare: Grumbling Takes Wing, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Fraud Charge Filed Against Dean Witter
description: Legal troubles continued to mount yesterday for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company when securities regulators accused the investment bank's brokerage unit of misleading thousands of investors into buying mutual funds that resulted in losses of $65 million.

title: Foreign Affairs; Can Gore Ever Win?
description: While it all may sound like just partisan noise coming out of Florida these days, there's actually a big difference between how Al Gore and George W. Bush have been behaving.

title: 76ers Go To 10-0 On Season
description: Allen Iverson scored 26 points and Theo Ratliff added 21 last night as Philadelphia beat host Boston, 114-90, to improve to 10-0.

title: How Making Smarter Mice May Pay Off for People
description: Here's one of the things you can learn tonight from ''Scientific American Frontiers'': ''Mice living an active and interesting life had more neurons than mice sitting around being bored.'' If you can summon a few neurons of your own, you won't be bored during ''Changing Your Mind,'' the season-opening installment in this earnest series on PBS. As host, Alan Alda again slips effortlessly into the role of curious layman, asking the right questions and nodding affably at the experts' answers.

title: A Mad Cow Is Just the Half of It
description: The rage and dismay seizing France since tons of beef potentially infected with mad cow disease were found to have been sold in some supermarkets seems both warranted and excessive, like most public and political matters that involve national beliefs and betrayals of good faith.

title: Lockerbie Prosecution Calls Pierre Salinger and Rests Its Case
description: The prosecution rested in the Lockerbie trial today, calling as its last witness Pierre Salinger, the former ABC News correspondent and press spokesman in the Kennedy White House.

title: Broad Drop Leaves Nasdaq at Its Lowest Level in a Year
description: Stock prices fell yesterday, pulled down by worries about fourth-quarter earnings, ratings downgrades by research analysts and the unresolved race for the presidency.

title: U.S. Nears Decision on Investigation of Goodyear Tire Safety
description: Federal officials are in the final stages of studying whether to open a formal investigation into the safety of Goodyear tires on large pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and vans, a person close to the study said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODSIDE, WILLIAM S.
description: WOODSIDE-William S. A generous and compassionate man of great vision, William S. Woodside is mourned by the Children of Alcoholics Foundation. He was an extraordinary business leader and thoughtful philanthropist, whose deep devotion to children and passion for our cause he shared with his wife Migs, our founder.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about President Clinton's visit to a site in Vietnam where an American pilot was shot down in 1967 referred incorrectly to his plane. The F-105D is a Thunderchief, not a Thunderbird.

title: Cases: Of Pretzels and Fruitcake: The Tales of a Rural Doctor
description: It is a peculiar privilege of a rural doctor to walk among one's dead. When I was training in San Francisco, I never considered the cemeteries. I was too busy analyzing test results and treatment options to wonder what happened when my patients went home, or when they died.

title: Cries of Victim Open Carruth's Trial
description: The murder trial of Rae Carruth, the former wide receiver, got off to a dramatic start yesterday, as the prosecution and defense painted starkly different versions of the crime and the jury listened to the victim's own anguished words to a 911 dispatcher as she lay bleeding in her car.

title: Youngstown Reformers Seek Mob-Fighting Tips in Sicily
description: After years of struggle with organized crime, and dozens of indictments of officials in this proud city, sadly dubbed Crimetown U.S.A., weary leaders of the reform movement are journeying to the ultimate Old World role model for help.

title: Hyundai Moves to Rescue Construction Unit
description: The Hyundai Group said today that it would raise $1.1 billion by selling real estate and securities to keep its construction unit out of bankruptcy.

title: Europeans In Big Deal To Create Data Group
description: France Telecom agreed today to take control of Equant N.V., the Dutch operator of a huge data communications network, in a deal worth almost $4 billion. Equant will be combined with France Telecom's Global One division to create a new force in corporate telecommunications services.

title: Testing the Retailing Net; This Holiday Season Is Critical for Many Online Merchants
description: The online retailing business is looking like the last episodes of ''Survivor.''

title: VITAL SIGNS: REMEDIES; Fix the Wrinkles, Ease the Headaches
description: The substance injected by plastic surgeons to smooth wrinkles may also help to ease chronic headaches, although experts say more research is needed.

title: AGCO MAKES DEAL TO ACQUIRE AG-CHEM EQUIPMENT
description: The Agco Corporation agreed to buy the Ag-Chem Equipment Company for $247.1 million, or $25.80 a share, in a mixture of cash and stock, a premium of more tham 100 percent over Ag-Chem's closing price of $11.50 on Friday. The deal would make Agco, the third-largest farm equipment maker, the leading manufacturer of self-propelled sprayers for farm fields. Ag-Chem, based in Minnetonka, Minn., had estimated sales of $299 million in the year ended Sept. 30; Agco, of Duluth, Ga., had $2.41 billion in sales last year.

title: Ancient Egypt Segues Into the Lower East Side
description: We find ourselves surrounded by late modern versions of all those ritual dramas and religious pageants that thrived in ancient and medieval times. We have had Indian epics like Peter Brooks's ''Mahabharata,'' Greek epics like the John Barton's ''Tantalus'' cycle and the merging of spirituality and science found in Philip Glass's opera ''Einstein on the Beach.''

title: Clinton Is Urged to Declare Moratorium on Federal Executions
description: An array of religious, civil rights and political leaders are appealing to President Clinton to declare a moratorium on federal executions in the closing days of his presidency.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 28 about Canada's arrest of two men charged in the deaths of 329 people on an Air-India plane that blew up in 1985 referred incorrectly to the place where the plane went down. (Similar errors appeared in four articles in 1996 and an editorial in 1985.) The plane fell into the Atlantic, about 150 miles southwest of Cork, Ireland, not into the Irish Sea between England and Ireland.

title: The Victims of Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Cheats Who Brag About It
description: Dozens of small-business owners have embraced a bizarre theory that only foreign-owned companies owe federal income taxes, and that American employers and their employees do not. Indeed, some of these owners have stopped withholding taxes and have told their employees they do not have to pay income taxes.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TWINLAB REPORTS LOSSES
description: The Twinlab Corporation of Hauppauge, N.Y., which makes and sells vitamins and herbal remedies, said yesterday that it lost more than $11 million in the three months that ended Sept. 30. The company attributed the third-quarter loss to slow sales of herbal products, and said it was going to stop making some of them. The company had previously announced that it also had shortages in its inventory totaling about $8 million. The company's serious financial problems prompted Moody's Investors Service to downgrade Twinlab's debt on Friday, cautioning about a danger of default.

title: Sony Plans a Tracking Stock For Its Internet Service Unit
description: The Sony Corporation said today that it was preparing to offer a tracking stock to investors to highlight the corporate value of its wholly owned Internet service provider, the Sony Communication Network Corporation.

title: Keeping a Worried Eye on the Calendar
description: The resolution of a momentous political question who will be the next president of the United States -- passed today, at least for now, into the hands of the justices of the Florida Supreme Court, seven men and women little known in their state, let alone the nation as a whole.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, DENNIS
description: SINGER-Dennis. The Galin families and the associates of G+G Retail, Inc. mourn the passing of our dear friend and supplier Dennis Singer of Dennis Industries/A Time For Us. Our deepest sympathy to his loving family. Sharon, Jonathan and Robin.

title: Victims Fight Over Splitting Reparations For Holocaust
description: They came from all over.

title: HONG KONG BANK DEAL
description: Bank of East Asia Ltd. will acquire control of FPB Bank Holdings Ltd. for 4.37 billion Hong Kong dollars ($560 million) after outbidding four rivals, including United Overseas Bank Ltd. of Singapore. The deal, equivalent to 3.50 Hong Kong dollars (45 cents) a share, is for the 75 percent of FPB Bank held by its two main shareholders, Mimet Fotic and First Pacific Group; the Bank of East Asia is expected to follow with an offer for the remaining 25 percent, which is publicly traded. Mimet Fotic is a joint venture of two Chinese state-owned industrial companies; First Pacific is a Hong Kong-based conglomerate.

title: To Help Bush, Racicot Steps From Shadow Into Spotlight
description: They met for the first time almost five years ago, walking to a men's room at a hotel in Washington. Over the years, they became such good friends, discussing issues like the environment, taxes and the death penalty, that when Gov. George W. Bush of Texas decided to run for president, Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana was near the front of the line to offer support.

title: Florida Judge Says He Can't Order Revote
description: A state judge here concluded today that he lacked the legal authority to order a second presidential election in Palm Beach County, even if he were to determine that the county's ''butterfly'' ballot design had confused enough voters to make a difference in the election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEPS, HANNAH
description: SCHNEPS-Hannah. November 20, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Sam. Loving mother of Millie Werfel Krefsky and Sidney, Murray and Teri, and the late Herbert. Devoted grandmother of Michael Mauerstein, Lynn Blocker, Lisa Friedman, Lori, Lara, Elizabeth, Samantha and Joshua. Cherished great-grandmother of five. Dear sister of Sylvia Brochin, Murray Kandel and Ethel Falbel. A proud and beautiful lady. Services today, 1:00 PM, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: The Victims of Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Concerns Grow Over Reactions To Lyme Shots
description: Federal health authorities are investigating whether some people who received the vaccine against Lyme disease later developed severe cases of arthritis and even Lyme disease itself as a result.

title: Blankets Used Aboard Planes Are Not Cleaned, Union Says
description: With countless holiday air travelers about to curl up for in-flight naps or movies, a union today accused a widely used Long Island-based airline laundry service of failing to wash blankets or sanitize headsets before sending them back for reuse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COVERDALE, MILES
description: COVERDALE-Miles. Age 77. Born in New York City, died November 19, 2000 at his home in Brookville, L.I. Son of the late William H. and Harriet H. Coverdale, beloved husband of Enid S. Coverdale, beloved brother of Mary C. Winnett and Harriet C. Marsh. Also survived by his children from his first marriage, Linda, Miles Jr., and Susan Coverdale; his stepchildren Jane P. Bryan and Elsie Paalzow; and his grandchildren, Katherine Coverdale, Andrea Coverdale, and Carrie Bryan. A graduate of Pomfret School and M.I.T., he served in the United States Navy. He worked for Colonial Airlines as an aeronautical engineer until his retirement. He belonged to the Creek Club in Locust Valley, N.Y. He was an active member of the L.I. Soaring Association and past president of the Soaring Society of America. A much respected collector of antique and classic cars, he belonged to the Mercer Club, the Stutz Bearcat Club, the L.I. Old Car Club, & the American, British, French, and Australian Bugatti Clubs. He was a direct descendant of Bishop Miles Coverdale, who translated the first printed English Bible in 1535. A memorial service is planned for a later date.

title: POGO, AN OIL DEVELOPER, AGREES TO PURCHASE NORIC
description: The Pogo Producing Company, a Houston-based oil developer and producer, agreed to buy the Noric Corporation, the closely held parent company of the North Central Oil Corporation, for $630 million, half in cash and half in stock. Pogo will also assume $120 million in Noric's debt. The acquisition will increase Pogo's oil and gas reserves by 63 percent to the equivalent of 1.38 trillion cubic feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, SELMA R.
description: GINSBERG-Selma R. On Nov. 20, 2000 at age 94. Beloved wife of the late Ralph, cherished mother of Helene Friedman and the late Jimmy. Mother-in-law of Hal Friedman and grandmother of Cathryn, Jill & Michael Friedman. Great-grandmother of Emily Carroll-Friedman and Leana Friedman. Sister of the late Gladys Kanrich and Mildred Dreier. Aunt to many loving nieces and nephews. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday at 11:30 AM. Interment to follow Beth Olem Fields Cemetery.

title: Mideast Terrorist Provocation
description: Yesterday's Palestinian terrorism and Israeli retaliation were all the more disheartening because they came after a weekend of some hope that seven weeks of bloodshed in the West Bank and Gaza Strip might be winding down. It is typical of terrorist tactics to try to thwart any perceived movement by more responsible leaders toward a truce. The unspeakable remote-control bombing of a school bus full of children predictably drew a strong Israeli response. With the horror of the bus blast, which left two adults dead and several children mutilated, and the Israeli missile attacks against Palestinian targets in Gaza, there is strong potential for the spiral of violence to resume.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; A Group Hit Hard by Hypertension
description: A survey of Korean-Americans in Maryland has found that more of them have high blood pressure than their typical American or Korean counterparts.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Tracing Cocaine

title: Words and Music, Not as Partners but as One
description: Saturday night's Lyric Opera production of ''Jenufa'' had a studied plainness. Walls, towers and descending roofs are like a lesson in geometry. As scenes shift, facades are made to shine in washes of burnt orange, lilac and shades in between.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEJONG, THE REVEREND DOCTOR PIETER
description: deJONG-The Reverend Doctor Pieter. 77, formerly of Madison, NJ, NYC, and Canada. Died on November 18, 2000 at Fellowship Village Retirement Community, Basking Ridge, NJ. Born in Gouda, The Netherlands. He is survived by his wife Anne, daughter Alida, sons Pieter, Paul and Tim; four grandchildren; brother Willem and sister Mieke Gerrits. He was in the Dutch underground during World War II. He met his wife at International House, NYC, while studying at Union Theological Seminary. He served as Dean and was the John Fletcher Hurst Professor of Systematic Theology at Drew Univerisity Theological School. He was formerly a professor at New York Theological Seminary, St. Andrew's College in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, and Queens Theological college in Kingston, Ontario. His career included 2 sabbaticals in the Far East and Hawaii as Theologian in residence. He was deeply loved and respected as a father, husband, teacher and minister and will be dearly missed. Services Tuesday, November 21, 10:30 AM at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, South Street and Miller Road, Morristown, New Jersey.

title: NRG ENERGY AND DYNEGY AGREE TO BUY POWER RESOURCES
description: NRG Energy Inc. and Dynegy Inc. agreed to buy the 740-megawatt Clark power plant and most of the output of another, the 605-megawatt Reid Gardner plant, from the Nevada Power unit of cobiSierra Pacific Resources for $634 million. The two plants provide power to Las Vegas. Clark burns natural gas and Reid uses coal. Sierra was obliged by antitrust regulators to sell the plants as a condition of approval for its acquisition of Nevada Power in July 1999. Nevada Power will buy electricity from the Clark and Reid plants until March 1, 2003.

title: SECOND OPINION/A special report.; With Death, Lessons About Policing Doctors
description: After a young, healthy woman named Lisa Smart died in a Manhattan hospital following a routine gynecological operation, the State Department of Health issued a damning litany of charges.

title: Bruised Lungs Sideline Hilliard
description: Giants wide receiver Ike Hilliard will not play in Sunday's game against the Arizona Cardinals, and could be sidelined indefinitely, because of a bruise to his lungs and sternum, which he sustained in the Giants' loss to Detroit Sunday. Hilliard was hurt when he collided with Detroit safety Kurt Schulz while trying to catch a pass over the middle. Schulz, who hit Hilliard in the chest and head with his shoulders and helmet, was penalized for unnecessary roughness.

title: Milbury Convinced Islanders Can Solve Own Problems
description: Mike Milbury waved his hand around the empty Islanders locker room, indicating the tags that bore the names of Roman Hamrlik, Kenny Jonsson, John Vanbiesbrouck, Garry Galley, Mariusz Czerkawski and Claude Lapointe.

title: Joyful Holiday Travel
description: Thanksgiving, like any self-respecting holiday, is all about tradition. You have your family, your turkey, the annual argument about how long it should be cooked, the Lions game on TV, the pumpkin pie and the day-after sales. Oh, and don't forget being trapped for hours at an airport so mobbed it brings to mind the hellish ''Gone With the Wind'' scene of the Confederate wounded at the rail yard.

title: British Retailer Thrives the U.S. Way
description: When making out their holiday shopping lists, few investors would place shares of British retailers at the top. They have been among the worst-performing stocks this year as the industry undergoes a profound shift that promises to alter permanently the way many of these companies do business.

title: Ruling Is Seen as Affirming Primacy of Will of Voters
description: Last night's decision by the Florida Supreme Court was a broad reaffirmation that the purpose of election law is to try to record the will of voters, election law specialists said.

title: More Technology Training for Teachers
description: Schools are spending more to train teachers how to use technology, but the amount still lags behind that invested in new computers and software, according to a recent analysis of technology spending in education.

title: A Prosecutor Even the Mobsters Respect
description: HERE'S what some members of the loyal opposition are saying about James Walden, an up-and-coming mob prosecutor who works for the United States attorney's office in Brooklyn.

title: Despite Gains, Rangers Still Show a Loss
description: The Rangers accomplished two rarities at Madison Square Garden last night. They not only scored at home for the first time in nearly six periods, they also scored a power-play goal against the National Hockey League's stingiest penalty-killing unit.

title: BAYER WILL FOCUS ON 13 MEDICAL AREAS, INCLUDING AIDS
description: Bayer A.G., Germany's biggest drug maker, said yesterday that it planned to concentrate on 13 fields of medicine, including a new area, AIDS research, to increase sales and profits. Research in other areas, including development of medicines for osteoporosis, fibrosis of the liver, and stroke, will be dropped. Bayer has business activities ranging from farm chemicals to polymers, but company officials have said they intend to focus more on health care.

title: Announcer Set For XFL Action
description: Matt Vasgersian has called one football game in his career, but yesterday he became the play-by-play partner of Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota for NBC's XFL Saturday night games starting in February.

title: Hundreds of Workers Strike At 2 Newspapers in Seattle
description: Newspaper Guild workers at Seattle's two daily newspapers, The Seattle Times and The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, went on strike yesterday over issues including wages, pensions and health benefits.

title: Punter's Sudden Boldness Leaves the Giants Rattled
description: Brad Maynard is from central Indiana, where in his big backyard he just happened to start punting a football one day and discovered he was good at it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLEY, HERMAN
description: KINGSLEY-Herman. We are saddened to learn of the death of Herman, loving father of esteemed Board Member Alfred Kingsley. Alfred is a valued Board Member and supporter of The American Friends of David Yellin College of Education. Elias Strum, President Marjorie G. Price, Executive Director The American Friends of David Yellin College of Education

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about reasons the eye sometimes perceives the Mona Lisa to be smiling misspelled the name of the art historian who wrote about the painting in ''The Story of Art.'' He is E. H. Gombrich, not Gombich.

title: Knicks' Reserves Come to the Rescue, Just in Time
description: There were 18 seconds to play tonight and the Knicks appeared to be doomed, destined for a gut-wrenching loss to the energetic Orlando Magic. But on what became the play of the game, three Knicks reserves foiled the Magic's two best players to deliver a thrilling comeback victory that sent Coach Jeff Van Gundy bounding off the floor as if his team had just won a playoff round.

title: Ice and a Victory Soothe Marbury and Martin
description: If ice halts the swelling of a rolled ankle, then a victory can dull the throbbing pain.

title: Metro Business Briefing; NO G.M. BUILDING SALE
description: Conseco Inc. will not move forward with a sale of its stake in the General Motors Building as a way to raise cash, a spokesman said yesterday. Conseco, an insurance company based in Carmel, Ind., is selling assets to pay down debt and bolster its stock price. In 1998, Conseco and its partner, Donald J. Trump, paid $800 million for the 50-story building, since renamed the General Motors Building at Trump International Place. The acquisition was financed with $20 million in cash from Mr. Trump, $80 million from Conseco and a $700 million mortgage. Last year Mr. Trump filed state documents valuing the building at $2.25 billion. The building, at the southeast corner of Central Park, is home to the flagship F. A. O. Schwarz toy store.

title: Giving Thanks
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Granola
description: Adapted from Heartbeat

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIMAN, HARRY
description: LEIMAN-Harry. To our dear friend Harry, he knew the true meaning of humility. Marlyn and Martin Persky

title: Ford to Offer Social Services For Workers and Retirees
description: The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers announced one of the most ambitious social efforts ever undertaken by an American corporation yesterday, a program that will provide child care, recreation programs for teenagers and book clubs for retirees.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Theater Club Has Plans for Broadway House
description: The Manhattan Theater Club, one of New York City's most prominent nonprofit theaters, has agreed to renovate and take over operation of the Biltmore Theater, a deteriorating Broadway landmark that has been dormant for more than a decade.

title: Democracy in America, With Its Ups and Downs; See You in Court
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LOEWEN GROUP INC., Burnaby, British Columbia, the second-largest funeral home operator in North America, had its common and preferred shares suspended by the Toronto Stock Exchange for failure to meet the continued listing requirements. The company, which is reorganizing under bankruptcy-court protection, has said it expects all its assets to wind up in the hands of creditors, leaving none to distribute to shareholders.

title: The Days Are Grim, but a Shared Dream Binds Arab and Israeli
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hefty Chamber Program in a Vast Chamber
description: The Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall has proved to be one of the most interesting ideas that Judith Arron mapped out for Carnegie Hall before her death in 1998. It recognizes that among the performers who spend their lives jet-setting from concert to concert, there are some singularly gifted musicians whose ideas about the repertory are so overarching that the traditional presentation format cannot do them justice.

title: Wake Up and Smell the Truffles
description: WHEN I think of the great New York breakfasts, I think of a wiry old Cuban man in a brown pinstripe suit and a fedora.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHIZNER, JUDITH
description: CHIZNER-Judith. The Board of Governors and Members of Inwood Country Club record with sorrow the passing of Judith Chizner, beloved wife of the late Richard Chizner and we extend deepest sympathy to the family. Edwin R. Stein, President Allan Sexter, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLZ, MONICA ANNIE FLORENCE
description: STOLZ-Monica Annie Florence. Deceased at Yonkers, New York on November 21, 2000. Loving and devoted wife of the late Bernard Stolz, MD, of Troy, NY. Loving mother of Daniel of St Louis, Alan of Houston and the late Robert. Cherished grandmother of Tracy, Brian, Barry (Patricia) & Tammy Stolz. Dear mother-in-law of Phyllis Stolz, Roberta Stolz and Matt Price. A woman of valor who gave of herself lovingly and unselfishly to all. Service Friday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Ronald McDonald House or the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRENSTEIN, ADELE
description: EHRENSTEIN-Adele, On November 19, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Irving, loving mother of Dr. Gerald and Debbie Ehrenstein and Dr. Lila and Dr. Richard Nachtigall. Cherished grandmother of Margaret and Anthony, Lisa and Rob, Ellen and Matthew, Ruth and Larry, David and Judy and Steven and Elissa. Adoring great grandmother of Julia, Greg, Andrew, Justin, Jenny, Sam, Jacob and Sam. Dear aunt and great-aunt. Services Wednesday 11:15AM at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to Foundation for Women's Wellness, 251 East 33rd Street, New York 10016.

title: Deal Proposed For Defendant In Net Sex Case
description: Manhattan prosecutors have proposed a plea bargain with no further jail time for a Columbia University graduate student facing a new trial on charges that he kidnapped and sexually abused a woman he had met on the Internet, say the student's mother and others familiar with the negotiations.

title: John Manship, 73, Artist and Sculptor's Son
description: John Paul Manship, an American artist who was the son of the sculptor Paul Manship (1885-1966), died on Friday in Gloucester, Mass. He was 73.

title: Scientific Finger to the Wind Holds the Big Balloons' Fate
description: Henry Perahia is nervous. The wind whipping down 81st Street near Central Park West is giving him a bit too much assistance as he flips through his dictionary-size Report of Wind Effects on Parade Balloons manual.

title: MODERATE INFLATION IN CANADA
description: Driven mainly by higher prices for natural gas and fuel oil, Canada's annual inflation rate rose to 2.8 percent in October from 2.7 percent in September, less than analysts had forecast. Excluding energy, consumer prices rose 0.1 percent in each of the last two months, a 1.5 percent annual rate. Gasoline prices fell but natural gas jumped. Timothy Pritchard

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Courts must not lose sight of the fundamental purpose of election laws: The laws are intended to facilitate and safeguard the right of each voter to express his or her will in the context of our representative democracy.''

title: Opponents of Planned Trump Tower Lose Battle
description: The legal battle waged by Walter Cronkite and other neighbors of Donald J. Trump's planned 72-story condominium tower on the East Side of Manhattan came to an end yesterday.

title: Jets Remain One of Four A.F.C. East Contenders
description: Consider this scenario for Sunday's National Football League games:

title: Israeli Reprisals Leave Gaza Military Sites in Ruins
description: Glancing warily overhead, Gazans ventured out today to inspect the bombed-out police stations, the crippled television studios, the wrecked office suites and the other physical evidence of an unnerving night of missile barrages from Israeli helicopters.

title: Woof! A Cruella De Vil Who Changes Her Spots
description: Disney is not a company known for leaving well enough alone. In its zeal to convert every successful movie into a franchise, the studio often crosses the line between giving audiences what they want and mindless overkill.

title: Lucent Lowers Revenue Stated In Last Quarter
description: Lucent Technologies warned shareholders yesterday that it would revise financial results already reported for the last quarter by cutting revenue by about $125 million. The unexpected move by the company, a maker of communications equipment, sent shudders across Wall Street.

title: Liberties; The PBJ President
description: We will have a president.

title: The Florida Court Decision
description: The Florida Supreme Court acted in the best interests of the nation last night by ruling that manually counted votes must be included in Florida's final ballot tabulation. The unanimous decision of the seven justices, which said that the right of citizens to have their votes counted was the overriding issue, properly and eloquently affirmed the broad principle that should govern the counting of Florida's presidential votes. As many votes as possible that were cast in good faith and marked in a fashion that can fairly be discerned should be tabulated and included in the final count, regardless of which candidate benefits. With the application of that standard, the presidential election can be brought to as equitable a conclusion as possible under conditions that can never be made perfect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMBERG, STUART
description: ZIMBERG-Stuart. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed Member Friar Stuart Zimberg on November 19th. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Services will be held on Thursday, November 23, at 10AM, Boulevard Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York, 516-295-3101. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Minnesota Stripped Of Big Ten Title
description: The Big Ten stripped Minnesota of its 1997 men's championship because of the academic fraud scandal under the former coach Clem Haskins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINS, ROSE
description: LEVINS-Rose. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our dedicated member and benefactor Rose Levins. Deepest sympathy to her sister Hilda Semel, niece and nephew Maxine and Dr. Joel Hirsch, great-nephew Jeremy and the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Reckonings; The Shadow Of Debt
description: If Argentina were a first-world country, its debt wouldn't be a problem. Both its budget deficit and its national debt are about the same fraction of G.D.P. as those of the U.S. eight years ago, and compared with Japan the country is a paragon of fiscal prudence. But global bond markets aren't equal-opportunity lenders, and third-world countries don't get the benefit of the doubt. In a recent debt refinancing Argentina had to pay an interest rate of 16 percent -- 10 percentage points more than the U.S. Treasury pays.

title: NISSAN TO AID RENAULT'S PROFITS MORE THAN EXPECTED
description: Renault S.A. said yesterday that profit from its Japanese partner, the Nissan Motor Company, would increase its second-half earnings by 453 million euros ($387 million), more than had previously been forecast, after Renault revised downward its expected tax bill and increased the amount it expects to earn from asset sales. Nissan is on course to earn a full-year profit for only the second time in the last nine years, after cutting its work force by 6 percent and trimming 10 percent from its component costs. Over all, analysts expect Renault to earn 1.07 billion euros this year, and Nissan's contribution would represent almost half of that. Renault owns 37 percent of Nissan.

title: ABC Is Down In the Sweeps
description: Michael Davies, the executive producer of ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' has noted several times in recent months that his hit game show, after huge exposure by ABC, can no longer be considered event programming.

title: Op-Art
Democracy in America, With Its Ups and Downs; Equality of Error
description: To the Editor:

title: For Teaching's Real Pros, Coaches on the Sidelines
