description: TEACHERS sometimes complain that they are not ''treated like professionals,'' pointing to things like lack of personal office space or access to telephones. But the most unprofessional aspect of their job is excessive autonomy. Behind classroom doors, teachers are mostly on their own.

title: GENER SHAREHOLDERS TO VOTE ON ISSUE KEY TO AES BID
description: Shareholders of Gener S.A., Chile's second-largest power generator, will meet on Dec. 12 to decide whether to lift a rule limiting any one shareholder's ownership to 20 percent, Gener said in a regulatory filing in Chile. Approval would clear the way for the AES Corporation to acquire 80 percent of Gener for $1.06 billion. AES has been competing with TotalFinaElf S.A., the French oil company, which offered to pay $810 million to buy 20 percent of Gener plus control of its Argentine power plants, a bid that requires no change in the Gener bylaws. TotalFina suspended its offer until after the vote. Copec S.A., which owns nearly 20 percent of Gener, supports the AES bid.

title: A Heartbreaker's Posthumous Power
description: Brian Skeet's film ''The Weekend'' has the dubious distinction of being perhaps the first movie in which the characters argue about a pair of grape scissors. What exactly are grape scissors, you might ask? Apparently they are used for cutting grapes at the dinner table. Who knew?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANET, SARAH (COHEN)
description: BANET-Sarah (Cohen). Of Ann Arbor, Michigan, on November 20, 2000. Biology teacher at Julia Richman High School in Manhattan, 1930-1966 and a resident of Sunnyside, Queens for fifty years. Beloved wife of the late Leo, devoted mother of Bernard (Barbara), cherished grandmother of Jeff (Shelly), loving great grandmother of Lee Callender, Jay and Heather Banet.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BADER, NATHAN
description: BADER-Nathan. ''Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine That all the world will be in love with night And pay no worship to the garish sun.'' Happy Birthday, Daddy. I miss you. Love Ann

title: Congress Puts Baseball Economics in Play
description: Senator Mike DeWine, an Ohioan whose state embraces a baseball team of ''haves,'' the Cleveland Indians, and ''have-nots,'' the Cincinnati Reds, convened a Congressional hearing today to ask what baseball was doing to make teams in small markets competitive.

title: INTEL AND BROADCOM SETTLE LAWSUITS
description: The rival chip makers Intel and Broadcom said yesterday that they had settled some heatedly fought litigation. The settlement ended a trade-secret dispute that began in March when Intel sued Broadcom for hiring several former Intel employees. It also settled a cross-complaint filed by Broadcom in an attempt to block Intel from releasing some of its latest networking chips. The settlement did not include another suit that Intel filed against Broadcom in August asserting that Broadcom violated five Intel patents. Both sides said they were satisfied with the settlement but declined to give any details. The news lifted Intel shares 3.7 percent, to $42.63, but sent Broadcom's down 3 percent, to $126.25. Laurie J. Flynn

title: Democracy in America, With Its Ups and Downs; Where's the Civility?
description: To the Editor

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: With a Little Bit of Luck

title: Yanks Get Oliver to Back Up Posada
description: Leery of signing someone who might be perceived as a threat by catcher Jorge Posada, the Yankees thought about acquiring Joe Oliver last year but didn't. So all season, club executives and staff members cringed every time a foul ball cracked off Posada's bare hand or shoulder, because the Yankees didn't have a backup catcher they trusted.

title: Egypt Recalls Envoy, Protesting Israeli Attack on Gaza
description: Following Israel's most intense bombardment of the Gaza Strip to date, Egypt recalled its ambassador from Tel Aviv today to protest what the Arab world condemned as a disproportionate response to a Palestinian terrorist attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, PAULINE B.
description: FALK-Pauline B. On Tuesday, November 21, 2000 at 90 years of age. Loving wife of the late Myron S. Falk, Jr. (Johnny). Mother of Patricia, Michael and Nancy. Grandmother of Christopher, Brooke, Melanie, Amerin, Gregory and Logan. Great grandmother of Ruby, Zoe, Jasper and Leon. Sister of the late Herman Baerwald, Jane Aron and Florence Doubilet. Also survived by devoted family and friends. Funeral service Tuesday, November 28th, 12 Noon, Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, 120 West 57 St, NY, NY 10019.

title: Phillies See Franco As Remedy In Bullpen
description: The way Larry Bowa sees it, the Philadelphia Phillies are very talented and have no business being in last place. Bowa is the Phillies' new manager, and although he coached for Seattle last season, he is aware of just how rudderless the Phillies' bullpen was.

title: Fasten Your Seat Belts, It's Going to Be a Bumpy Ride in the N.F.C.
description: When the Detroit Lions came to the New York area last Saturday for their game against the Giants, their flight was anything but routine. Well into the trip, the crew made an announcement: because of severe turbulence that blanketed the skies ahead, the plane would be forced to turn back to Detroit. But several minutes later the pilots changed their minds and the flight continued through rough air.

title: Mubarak's Move
description: Egypt's decision today to recall its ambassador from Tel Aviv marks the end of a long period of relative restraint in Arab-Israeli relations.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Pepsi in Buyback Worth $4 Billion
description: PepsiCo Inc. said today that it would buy back $4 billion of its shares over three years, starting early in 2001.

title: Ranger Spirit Rising, And Maybe the Team
description: After three seasons of irrelevance, the Rangers are again fun to watch.

title: Patricia Yeo
description: I LOVE potato gnocchi, but they are too Italian for my menu. To give them an Asian spin I turned to taro, a root vegetable used in Asia and Latin America. What I came up with has all the merits of gnocchi -- starchy but light, chewy but delicate -- but goes better with my Asian-influenced main courses.

title: U.S. Safety Panel Begins Inquiry on Goodyear Tires
description: Federal regulators opened a safety investigation today into Goodyear tires installed on very large pickup trucks, vans and sport utility vehicles, the latest sign of spreading concerns about tire safety after Firestone's sweeping recall on Aug. 9.

title: PROFIT HIT AT HYUNDAI
description: The latest rescue plan, the sixth of the year, for Hyundai Engineering and Construction includes heavy interest payments that will all but wipe out profits, analysts said, leading investors to bid its stock down sharply. Hyundai Group announced details of a $1.1 billion fund-raising package for its flagship company on Monday after brushes with bankruptcy led creditors to demand that the construction company raise capital. But Hyundai Engineering's own figures indicated that interest payments this year would reduce projected operating profit by 88 percent of the amount initially forecast.

title: INTEC WILL BUY COMPUTER GENERATION FOR $245 MILLION
description: Intec Telecom Systems P.L.C., the largest vendor of software that telephone companies use to bill each other, agreed yesterday to buy Computer Generation Inc., a closely held maker of software for large-scale network operation, for $245 million in cash. Computer Generation's software enables network operators to collect information about the use of both data and phone networks and bill clients. Intec, based in Woking, England, said it planned to shut down the Computer Generation unit that sells equipment and contributes 18 percent of its revenue, but all current employees will be retained.

title: Fresh Cranberry Vinaigrette
description: Adapted from "An American Place" by Larry Forgione (William Morrow, 1996)

title: DIAL'S LENDERS EASE THE TERMS OF $450 MILLION LOAN
description: The Dial Corporation, maker of Purex detergent and Armour canned meat, said yesterday that its lenders agreed to ease terms on a $450 million loan for the next three quarters to help the company avoid default. Dial had warned that the loss it posted in the third quarter and the results it expected in the fourth quarter could leave it in default of the loan's terms by the end of the year. In a regulatory filing, the company said yesterday that the danger had been averted. The company has also said it is considering whether to sell the company or individual lines in the next year to reduce debt.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a hearing on the distribution of a settlement from Swiss banks to Holocaust survivors and an article on July 27 about the settlement misstated the given name of the lead lawyer for the survivors. He is Burt Neuborne, not Burton.

title: Suspect in Terror Case Is Mistreated, Wife Says
description: The wife of one of the defendants in a government terrorism prosecution says federal jail officials in Manhattan have been retaliating against her husband ever since two other defendants in the case were accused of stabbing and critically injuring a guard.

title: MANAGEMENT: Shape Up to Ship Up; Boot Camps for Executives on the Fast Track
description: Tom Healy had just been promoted to lead a new division of the Best Buy Company, the nation's largest electronics retailer, from his old job as regional vice president in Kansas City, Mo. Obviously, Best Buy had high regard for Mr. Healy's management expertise -- so it sent him to Philadelphia to learn why he was a weak manager.

title: THE BOSS; A Theft, and a New Friend
description: A couple of years ago, I was just back from India and I was feeling sick at an annual industry meeting. I went to the clinic at the resort where the meeting was held, and the doctor told me it was probably walking pneumonia.

title: From Algae, Perhaps a Healthier Egg
description: EGGS, which are generally regarded as nature's most inherently nutritious food, are now being fortified with omega-3 fatty acids to make them even more of a powerhouse. And down the line, chickens and yogurt with the same advantage may come to market as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATEK, STANLEY
description: MATEK-Stanley. The New York State Podiatric Medical Association mourns the passing of Stan Matek on November 19 in Chicago. Mr. Matek served as the Executive Director of the Association from 1983-1993. He left his mark by working with determination on behalf of our Association and our profession. He will be remembered fondly by those who knew him. Donations in his memory may be made to The American Cancer Association.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PRICE, BARRY
description: PRICE-Barry. A beautiful boy away from us 25 years. You are always in our hearts. Love and kisses, Mommy, Daddy, Jodi, Blair and Mar

title: Air Force Awards Contract to GSD&M
description: The United States Air Force said yesterday that it had awarded to GSD&M in Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group, a one-year contract to handle its strategic marketing and advertising account. The contract takes effect Feb. 1, with six one-year renewal options. Billings were estimated at $50 million a year.

title: Guiltless Pleasures of Room Service And a Quiet Night, Blissfully Alone
description: FOR two all-too-fleeting nights next week, Alaka Basu will be happily scattering her belongings around a Manhattan hotel room. As a senior research associate of social demography at Cornell University and a trustee of the Population Council, she will be in town technically for a board meeting. But while her employer may think work is the main reason for this trip, Ms. Basu is most looking forward to something else.

title: Coca-Cola Board Abandons Its Efforts to Acquire Quaker Oats
description: The board of the Coca-Cola Company abandoned its effort to acquire Quaker Oats, the cereal and drink maker, late last night. The deal, for as much as $16 billion in stock, would have been Coke's largest acquisition ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILBERDING, JOSEPH C., JR.
description: WILBERDING-Joseph C., Jr. On Nov. 21, 2000. Beloved husband of Katherine Van Cortlandt Wilberding, dear father of Stephen Van C. Wilberding, Katherine Garcia, Joan Hirte and Augusta Laidlaw. Also survived by 10 grandchildren and six great grandchildren. Funeral service will be held on Friday, November 24, at 11 AM at St. Marks Episcopal Church, Mt. Kisco, N.Y. Interment private. For information call Oelker & Cox Funeral Home, Inc., 914-666-5891.

title: The Days Are Grim, but a Shared Dream Binds Arab and Israeli
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Suisse Is Losing Another of Its Top Bankers
description: Credit Suisse First Boston learned yesterday that it was losing one of the top bankers who came to it from Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, which it recently acquired for $12.2 billion.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: New York State of Mind

title: Campaigns for and against cigarettes share a single space.
description: IT is not every day that ads praising and attacking cigarette smoking are posted opposite each other in the same room, but that unusual juxtaposition is the basis of a current exhibit that is intended to offer a new perspective on tobacco marketing.

title: Report Links Smoking and the Mentally Ill
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (Reuters)  A report from the Harvard Medical School released today estimated that people with diagnosable mental illness accounted for nearly 45 percent of the total cigarette market in the United States.

title: U.P.S. Given Right to Fly Cargo to China
description: Dividing a coveted new slice of the China air market among a gaggle of hungry airlines, the Transportation Department said today that it would add United Parcel Service to the short list of carriers allowed to fly there and give it the right to make six trips a week.

title: Mayor May Face Inquiry in Dorismond Case
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that an obscure 127-year-old provision of the City Charter could provide the legal groundwork for a public inquiry into Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's disclosure of the sealed criminal record of Patrick M. Dorismond last March.

title: INSIDE
description: China to Halt Missile Help

title: A Dream Takes Seagoing Shape; Three-Year Labor of Love Will Steer for the Caribbean
description: When the huge, pristine, navy blue and red sailboat emerged on Monday from a giant warehouse in Harrison, N.J., sunlight hitting its freshly varnished teak railing for the first time, two dozen people applauded and cheered, as if something were coming to life.

title: Checkpoint Sapper Journal; G.I.'s in Kosovo Are Judges, Jailers, and Much More
description: ''What we do here,'' said Lt. Patrick Grow, ''could affect the president of the U.S. in three minutes.''

title: Giuliani in Washington to Block Police Suit
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani traveled to Washington yesterday to meet Attorney General Janet Reno and federal prosecutors from Brooklyn in a last-ditch effort to forestall a civil rights lawsuit accusing the city of failing to discipline brutal police officers effectively.

title: Bush Camp, Outraged, Vows to Seek Recourse to Ruling
description: In a voice of moral outrage, the Bush campaign's representative in Florida, James A. Baker III, denounced the Florida Supreme Court's ruling last night as a gross usurping of its bounds and all but invited the state Legislature to step in and take action against the manual recounts in several Florida counties.

title: Times Columnist Is Given New Role
description: Gail Collins, who has been on special assignment for the Op-Ed page of The New York Times covering the elections in her column ''Public Interests,'' was named yesterday to write a column twice a week for the Op-Ed page on governmental and legislative issues at the state, regional and national levels. The announcement was jointly made by Arthur Sulzberger Jr., publisher of The Times, and Howell Raines, editor of the editorial page.

title: Martin Volunteers To Be Captain
description: If the circumstances were right, Todd Martin would be delighted to succeed John McEnroe as the United States Davis Cup captain. But Martin also said yesterday that he wishes McEnroe's predictably eventful tenure had not been so unpredictably brief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, GEORGE
description: WEINSTEIN-George. The American Friends of Soroka Medical Center of the Negev are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed supporter. We extend heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Shirley and his children Sarah, Stanley and Jerrald and the entire family. Benjamin Belfer, Chairman Mona Abramson, Exec. Director

title: Aventis Says More Genetically Altered Corn Has Been Found
description: The Aventis Corporation said yesterday that a genetically altered protein unapproved for human consumption had been discovered in a variety of corn that could be headed toward the nation's food supply.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRATENSTEIN, HELEN
description: KRATENSTEIN-Helen. On November 20 at Albany, NY. Wife of the late Meyer Kratenstein. Mother of Rhoda Kratenstein of Schenectady, NY and Selig Kratenstein and his wife Robin of North Woodmere, NY. Sister of William Bellinger of Roswell, GA. Grandmother of Matthew and Andrew. Services 1:00 PM, November 22 at the Old Montefiore Cemetery, Queens, NY. Contributions to the United Jewish Appeal. The period of mourning will be held at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Selig Kratenstein. For information call the Levine Memorial Chapel, Albany, New York at 800-427-0280.

title: 'X-Files' Still Flying
description: Last spring, ''The X-Files'' on Fox looked as if it might be headed for troubled times. That is when Fox executives announced that the program's big star, David Duchovny, who plays the F.B.I. agent Fox Mulder, would be in only half of this year's 22 episodes. And in many of those episodes, they said, his appearances would amount to little more than a cameo. The cut followed the settlement of Mr. Duchovny's suit over his share of the show's profits.

title: Democracy in America, With Its Ups and Downs; Patient, and Ambivalent
description: To the Editor:

title: FLORIDA COURT BACKS HAND RECOUNTS AND ORDERS VOTE DEADLINE OF MONDAY
description: The Florida Supreme Court ruled unanimously tonight that the results of manual ballot recounts in three heavily Democratic counties must be included in the state's final tally, as long as they are submitted no later than Monday morning. But it set no firm standards for determining how to count partly punched ballots.

title: Peru Congress Says Fujimori Is 'Unfit' and Picks Successor
description: Congress cleared the way today for its leader, Valentin Paniagua, to succeed Alberto K. Fujimori as president of Peru, vaulting the political opposition to the threshold of power for the first time in more than a decade.

title: Official Tarte Tatin
description: Adapted from the Confrerie des Lichonneux de Tarte Tatin

title: We're Measuring Bacteria With a Yardstick
description: No mountaineer would climb Mount Everest, scratch a quarter inch of ice off its summit and then claim that it was now only 29,027 feet, 11 3/4 inches high. After all, everyone realizes that its height is just an estimate -- and that the margin of error is much greater than a quarter of an inch. Likewise, no one suggests that to lose weight we should go up to the attic, since gravity is minutely weaker up there than it is downstairs.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Through a Labyrinth to a Japanese Cook-It-Yourself
description: EVERY once in a while something on a restaurant menu will jump out. Like the appetizer called ''salted squid guts'' at Yakiniku JuJu, a small and friendly restaurant that specializes in cook-it-yourself shabu-shabu, sukiyaki and Japanese barbecue. Who could resist salted squid guts?

title: The Show Will Go On, In Spite of Kidnappers
description: Mauricio Kagel, the Argentine composer long resident in Germany, has written plays and radio dramas, made 18 films and composed numerous theatrical works for the concert hall. So it was surprising that miscalculated dramatic pacing turned out to be the one shortcoming of ''Kidnapping in the Concert Hall,'' Mr. Kagel's latest musico-dramatic work. Called ''Entfuhrung im Konzertsaal'' in the original German, the piece received its United States premiere on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall by the remarkable Schoenberg Ensemble and Netherlands Chamber Choir, conducted by Reinbert de Leeuw.

title: Tough Task: Uniting Teachers in Learning
description: Eric Plaks and Golda Foxman represent the new and the old, the idealistic, spirited and fresh perspective of the latest generation of teachers, and the seasoned, experienced one of a generation ago.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Birthday Song For a Rabbi

title: The Florida Supreme Court Ruling
description: In its crucial ruling tonight in the case that could decide the presidential election, Florida's Supreme Court decided a number of the legal issues that have been raised here in favor of Vice President Al Gore, but it squarely addressed a number of questions and issues. Among them are these.

title: New Route To City Hall: A Screen Test
description: THE city comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, may be raising the most money. The public advocate, Mark Green, may be ahead in a new poll, inconclusive though it is. The Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer, may have the inside track with the city's increasingly important Hispanic voters.

title: Claude Fouquiaus Tarte Tatin
description: Time: 1 hour

title: M.A.A.C.: New Force In East To Receive Automatic Bid
description: Having paid its dues in its first two seasons, the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference has achieved a measure of respect in Division I.

title: Ikea Cuts Review To 3 Agencies
description: Ikea in Plymouth Meeting, Pa., said yesterday that it had narrowed a review for its marketing communications account to three agencies from six.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Charles F. C. Ruff, the Washington lawyer and former White House counsel to President Clinton, omitted a surname in some editions for his mother, who survives him. She is Margaret Carson. The obituary also omitted another survivor. She is a half sister, Carla Ruff.

title: Corrections
description: A book review yesterday about Mark Salzman's novel ''Lying Awake'' misidentified the setting of his memoir, ''Iron and Silk.'' It recalls a visit to China, not to Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, MARION
description: MANDEL-Marion. On Tuesday, November 21, 2000. She was 75 years old. Beloved wife of Seymour. Loving mother of Barry & Steven. Devoted sister of Milton Greiss. Loving grandmother of Adam, Alyse, Jason and Carrie. Funeral services will be held today, 11:30AM at Hellman Memorial Chapels, Spring Valley, New York, 845-356-8600.

title: A Security Guard. Then Kapow! A Sorrowful Superhero.
description: ''Unbreakable,'' a follow-up to ''The Sixth Sense'' by the writer and director M. Night Shyamalan, is probably the most anticipated film of the season. As such, it is bound to disappoint because there is no way to repeat such a box office sensation.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column last Wednesday about the naming of a chief executive at the parent company of Envirotest, the automobile testing company, referred imprecisely to the company's contract with the State of Connecticut for vehicle safety inspections. The state has notified Envirotest that it believes the company to be in default and is awaiting a formal response before taking further action. The contract has not been voided.

title: Old-Fashioned Modernist Whose Neglect Is Fading
description: The second half of the 20th century produced more music, of all kinds, than any previous era. There is a lot of sand for the winds of time to blow away, but blow they will, to leave scattered rocky monuments, among which will be the small but crucial output of Jean Barraque, celebrated at Miller Theater last Wednesday evening.

title: Lars-Erik Nelson, 59, Writer Of Columns at The Daily News
description: Lars-Erik Nelson, a columnist for The New York Daily News who covered and commented on the collapse of Communism and other events that shaped history, died on Monday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 59.

title: Democrat Now Leads In Tight Senate Race
description: Maria Cantwell, the Democratic challenger to Senator Slade Gorton of Washington, pulled ahead by 2,000 votes with fewer than 12,000 still to count in a contest that could decide the political balance of the Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, MILTON
description: RATNER-Milton. Beloved husband of the late Goldie. Loving father of Sheldon & Joan, Kenneth & Susan. Dear brother of Bernice Levy and Bernard Ratner. Cherished grandfather of Richard, Tracy, Brett and Lisa. Fond uncle. Always in our hearts. Services today, 12:00 PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: S.E.C. Says Brothers Used Tender Offer to Cheat Investors
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil charges yesterday against two brothers accused of masterminding a tender offer in 1999 for shares in Mattel Inc. that brought in stock that they used but never paid for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, EDWARD J., REV.
description: LYONS-Edward J., Rev., CSP. On November 20, 2000 at age 73. Born in New York, NY, he was ordained a Paulist priest on May 1, 1953. Fr. Lyons first served in Lubbock, TX, then as hospital Chaplain in the Back Bay section of Boston, MA. He received numerous converts into the Catholic Church while serving at the Catholic Information Center in Grand Rapids, MI. As Chaplain to the GR Police Department, he mediated during periods of racial tension and was awarded the key to the City. In the Diocese of GR he established the Ecumenical Commission and was a member of the Priests' Senate, working closely with local Catholic clergy. Fr. Lyons also served in Vancouver, BC, Canada; Houston, TX; Portland, OR; Tucson, AZ, and at Saint Paul the Apostle Church, New York City. There will be a wake on Friday, November 24, 2000 from 6-9 P.M. at Saint Paul the Apostle Rectory, 415 West 59th Street, New York, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 9:30 A.M. on Saturday at Saint Paul's. Burial will be at the Mount Paul Cemetery, Oak Ridge, New Jersey.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Texans Win Again in Bridge
description: For six experts from Texas, a remarkable string of successes continued here on Monday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: Favoring a Small and Understated Setting
description: SIGN of the Dove no longer exists, but it continues to exert a quiet influence on the dining scene. The chefs who spent their formative years there have fanned out across the city to restaurants like Little Dove, Five Points and Cibo, bringing a restrained stylishness along with them. The latest in this crop is Steven Zobel, who spent four years at Sign of the Dove before taking over the stove at one of its sister restaurants, Contrapunto. Now he has his own showcase, Triomphe, in the remodeled Iroquois Hotel in Midtown.

title: Metro Business Briefing; NEW CNBC HEADQUARTERS
description: With the help of a $4.6 million New Jersey grant intended to keep businesses from moving out of state, CNBC, the cable financial news network, broke ground in Englewood Cliffs yesterday on an expanded headquarters. It will cost $140 million to build. CNBC opened its studios 11 years ago in Fort Lee, where it rents space. It expects to house 700 employees, up from 600 now. The grant, awarded last year by the State Commerce and Economic Growth Commission, will be spread over 10 years. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Business Travel; Talking to a TV may be a little weird, but it could mean one less journey through the crowded skies.
description: ON those occasions when I indulge the impulse to speak to a television set, what I utter is always too vile for decent company. So let's just say that I was a more than a little weirded out, finding myself in a cordial if skeptical conversation with a television screen sitting on a shelf 10 feet away.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro dropped after German business confidence declined for a fifth consecutive month in October. In New York, the euro settled at 84.34 cents, down from 84.92 cents on Monday.

title: Milosevic, Seeking a Comeback, Makes 2nd TV Speech in 2 Days
description: The fallen leader of Yugoslavia, Slobodan Milosevic, has been making a determined effort at a political comeback this week, with a decisive congress of his Socialist Party of Serbia scheduled for Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANNON, VICTOR, JR.
description: CANNON, VICTOR, JR. LE BEAU NAUFRAGE and DAVID NOVEMBER 24, 1991.

title: GEOLOGICAL PROBLEMS WILL CUT PROFITS AT USX-U.S. STEEL
description: The USX-U.S. Steel Group, the nation's largest steel maker, said geological problems at two coal mines were hindering production and would reduce fourth-quarter profit by $10 million to $20 million before taxes. Production and delivery at 30-year-old mines in Alabama and West Virginia are being hampered by conditions including mine roofs that are sloping inward or falling in chunks. While it determines what to do about the problems, the company said, it will try to reduce the effect on customers by allocating limited supplies.

title: Sports of The Times; Chaney's Old-School Temperament
description: THE way John Chaney tells it, first Eddie Jones of the Miami Heat called him in early September, followed shortly by Aaron McKie of the Philadelphia 76ers and then by Rick Brunson of the Boston Celtics. Each had played for Coach Chaney at Temple, each asked him the same question:

title: Democracy in America, With Its Ups and Downs; If Bush Wins
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush and Gore Steadfast in Belief in Own Victory
description: While the Florida Supreme Court's ruling tonight that the state must accept recounts of votes in the presidential election appeared to be a victory for Vice President Al Gore, Gov. George W. Bush was determined not to back down easily.

title: Angry Parents Demand Answers on Pupil Sexual Abuse
description: About 200 angry parents gathered yesterday outside Public School 89 in Elmhurst, Queens, demanding to know how a man who sexually assaulted one child and groped three others on Monday was able to gain entry to the school and why school officials did not tell the police that a student had reported seeing an intruder in a stairwell last week.

title: Prelate With Gift for Raising Money and Recruiting Priests
description: It is not every day that an archbishop visits a small congregation in the suburbs. For Jim Chern, an earnest 16-year-old contemplating the priesthood, that Sunday more than a decade ago when Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick celebrated Holy Communion at his parish church in Clark was a life-altering event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMONICO, LOUISE WEBB
description: deMONICO-Louise Webb. On November 19, 2000, age 89, after a short illness. She is survived by her son Ernest Brandt, her daughter-in-law Cree Maxson and sister Mary Bruder. She will be fondly remembered by family and friends for her energy, zest for life and service to others. A Memorial Service will be held at the Riverdale Ethical Culture Society at a date, to be announced later.

title: ARTS IN AMERICA: No Place Like Home, Sometimes; Children's Author Illuminates Japanese-American Identity
description: Allen Say never intended to become a children's book author, or any other kind of author for that matter. For years he worked as a commercial photographer in San Francisco, then did some freelance illustrations before deciding to write his own stories for children. These were truly his own stories, an immigrant's musings about a home he never quite seems to find.

title: Frances Mercer, 85, Model-Turned-Actress
description: Frances Mercer, a model who took up acting and went on to appear in films and on Broadway, radio and television, died on Nov. 12 in Los Angeles. She was 85.

title: Vargas Wants Trinidad Right Here, Right Now
description: Fernando Vargas contends that waiting for his next fight has been harder than training for it.

title: No Time for Crust? Who Needs It, Anyway?
description: PUMPKIN pie may be a Thanksgiving classic, but the last thing most people want to do on a day already crammed with cooking is start mixing and rolling out a crust.

title: The Tart That Turned France Upside Down
description: IN the United States, small towns get to brag if they give birth to a vice president or a major league pitcher. In France, a dessert can put you on the map, and what after-dinner classic could be more famous than the tarte Tatin, the beguilingly simple combination of thick caramelized apple slices resting on a bed of flaky pastry?

title: POWER LINES TESTED FOR INTERNET USE
description: The Ambient Corporation, based in Brookline. Mass., said yesterday that it had successfully completed the first test of technology for providing high-speed Internet and video services over standard power transmission lines. The use of lines that currently transmit only electricity could allow electric utilities to compete with telephone and cable companies in the market for Web services. Ambient said it expected to begin selling its product in 18 months. The first test was conducted at a Con Edison plant in Queens.

title: Mindshare Appoints Goldstein President
description: Marc Goldstein, 52, a leading agency media executive, has been named president for national broadcasting and programming at MindShare North America, New York, a joint venture of two WPP Group agencies, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and J. Walter Thompson. He succeeds Peter Chrisanthopoulos, who left last week to become president and chief operating officer at Azteca America Network and Spot Sales and Marketing in New York.

title: News Is the Comedy
description: What an election season it has been for ''The Daily Show'' on Comedy Central

title: Software That Tracks E-Mail Is Raising Privacy Concerns
description: It was during a recent job search that Donald Bell gave in to the temptation to bug his own e-mail. Mr. Bell, 55, had e-mailed dozens of resumes to prospective employers and received scant response. Naturally he wondered: was he being rejected, or had his messages gone unread?

title: September Trade Gap Raises Some Fear on Pace of Slowdown
description: Imports surged, exports slipped and the United States trade deficit widened sharply to a record in September, raising fears that the economy is slowing faster than expected and that the robust dollar may come under pressure.

title: BRITISH TELECOM AND TELENOR MAY END JOINT VENTURE
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. and Telenor A.S., Norway's former phone monopoly, are talking about ending their joint ownership of three European phone companies in the next few weeks. Telenor, which wants to raise cash and reduce its indebtedness, has the right to sell to British Telecom its 49.5 percent stake in Esat Digifone of Ireland by Dec. 7, and a 10 percent holding in Viag Telekom of Germany by Dec. 31, for a total of $2.6 billion. The two companies also jointly own Telenordia A.B. of Sweden; Telenor may want to take full control of Telenordia, an official said.

title: Knight a Presence at Preseason N.I.T.
description: Mike Krzyzewski was never Bobby Knight, even when these polar opposites existed on the same team. And even without Knight at a gathering yesterday for the Preseason National Invitation Tournament, Krzyzewski was no match for the attention the controversial former coach received.

title: Watching Bush Try for the Right Pose
description: A phalanx of network television cameras stood at the ready and a crowd of onlookers gathered, brimming with anticipation for the big event.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing with the Advertising column on Monday about changes at the New York office of FCB Worldwide misstated the plans of Herb Miller, who was succeeded by Deborah Sullivan as executive vice president and director for broadcast production. Mr. Miller is seeking another job in the advertising industry; he is not retiring.

title: Profit Alert by Dean Foods
description: Dean Foods, the dairy processor and distributor, warned today that its fiscal second-quarter earnings would disappoint Wall Street. It expects earnings of 65 cents to 68 cents a share, below the average estimate of 82 cents from nine analysts surveyed by First Call/ Thomson Financial.

title: The Days Are Grim, but a Shared Dream Binds Arab and Israeli
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey Offers Troops for New European Force, With a Proviso
description: Turkey offered today to contribute a substantial number of troops and equipment to a new European Union force in return for an important role in planning the organization's military operations.

title: Europe Rejects Compromising With U.S. Over Tax Benefits
description: The European Union has ruled out any deal to resolve its latest trade dispute with the United States over a system of tax benefits for American exporters, according to the union's trade minister, Pascal Lamy.

title: Giuliani Starts Final Phase of Cancer Treatment
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he had begun daily radiation treatments for his prostate cancer, which he said had left him at times ''very, very fatigued.''

title: Blue-Collar Urgency: Bathroom Rights
description: For three years, Audrey Jo DeClue endured an endless stream of workplace abuses, according to a complaint filed in federal court. Ms. DeClue, the first female line worker for the Central Illinois Light Company, said she had been shoved, hit and propositioned by male co-workers; had plied country roads in trucks fluttering with pornographic magazines; and had been subjected to the sight of men urinating on the ground in front of her.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Trade Deficit Rose To a Record in September

title: MEDTRONIC UNIT INFRINGED PATENT ON STENTS, JURY SAYS
description: Medtronic AVE Inc., a unit of the No. 1 pacemaker manufacturer Medtronic Inc., was found by a federal jury in Delaware to have infringed patents held by the Cordis Corporation unit of Johnson & Johnson for devices known as expandable stents that are used to hold unclogged blood vessels open. Cordis sued AVE, then Arterial Vascular Engineering Inc., in 1997, asserting that the unit had misappropriated technology that Cordis had patented in 1988 and 1993. Johnson & Johnson, acquired Cordis in 1996; Medtronic, based in Natick, Mass., acquired AVE in 1998. A companion suit by Cordis against the Boston Scientific Corporation over stent patents began in the same court after the Cordis-Medtronic verdict was announced. Stent sales last year totaled $2.2 billion.

title: Small Fish on a Big Pond
description: What are the odds that two men who became friends as teenagers in Dauphin, Manitoba, would one day become rival hockey coaches in New York?

title: DoCoMo Reported Near to Buying Stake In AT&T Wireless
description: NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest wireless carrier, is nearing an agreement to acquire a minority stake in AT&T Wireless, a unit of the United States telecommunications giant AT&T that is being spun off as part of AT&T's recent restructuring, according to executives close to the negotiations.

title: China to Stop Selling A-Arms Delivery Systems
description: The Clinton administration and China said today that China had pledged to stop selling missile parts or the equipment needed for missile production to countries developing nuclear weapons.

title: Count Tilts to Democrats for 50th Senate Seat
description: Five days ago, Democrats said it would take a miracle for the challenger, Maria Cantwell, to come from behind and defeat the Republican incumbent, Slade Gorton of Washington, in the nation's last undecided Senate race.

title: Recipes From a Renegade
description: JOHN THORNE is the antidote to trendy food writing, a literate man who produces pleasurable, instructive, even profound prose, along with satisfying recipes. And don't look for glossy food photography in his books: there isn't any.

title: French Toast With Apples
description: Adapted from Nougatine

title: All Aboard! (Better Late Than Never)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENZ, JANET W.
description: RENZ-Janet W. On November 8, 2000. You were an inspiration to so many. Be well now, be safe. We miss you, but are so grateful to you for so much. We love you Mommy/Grandma. Memorial service to be announced. Muffy, Delaney, and Jake

title: Idealism Is a Casualty In War Zone
description: William Boyd's stirring World War I drama ''The Trench'' joins a sizable list of films that evoke the futility of war and the tragic waste of young lives with a potent and simmering anger. Almost the entire movie, which opens today at Film Forum, is set in a British army trench during the 48 hours leading up to the Battle of the Somme in the summer of 1916. During that battle, Britain suffered 60,000 casualties in what is still considered its worst military disaster.

title: Defense Focuses on Conflicts In Officers' Trial Testimony
description: Defense lawyers for the five Orange police officers accused of federal civil rights violations in the beating and abuse of a suspect who died in police custody zeroed in today on a significant conflict between the accounts of two policemen.

title: Europeans to Join 2 Cases Against Microsoft Into One
description: The European Commission is planning to merge its latest investigation into the Microsoft Corporation's practices with an antitrust case that it opened against the company in August, lawyers here said today.

title: Make Mine Mayonesa
description: ANY true American knows that the real sauce for Thanksgiving is not cranberry. Mayonnaise is what makes leftover turkey taste so good you want to have it on bread only hours after eating way too much off a plate.

title: PARIS DEPARTMENT STORE SOLD
description: LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton agreed to take control of the Paris department store La Samaritaine, paying 1.5 billion francs ($190 million) for a 51 percent stake. The store will join a retail network that includes Au Bon Marche and Franck et Fils, and extends the rivalry between Bernard Arnault, chairman of LVMH, and Francois Pinault, who outbid LVMH for control of Gucci Group.

title: CALENDAR
description: Eating at Raoul's

title: Bold Scholar Who Knew Everybody Who Was Anybody
description: A LIFE IN THE 20TH CENTURY

title: Ethan A. Hitchcock, 91, Lawyer and Civic Leader
description: Ethan Allen Hitchcock, a Manhattan lawyer and civic leader who was a former chairman of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, died on Saturday at his home in Oldwick, N.J. He was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, HENRY
description: FELDMAN-Henry. Kislev 19-1994. Beloved. Still missed-still loved. Toujours dans nos coeurs. Your wife Helen and son Leonard

title: Peru After Fujimori
description: Alberto Fujimori, the unpredictable and often erratic president of Peru, resigned from office this week while on a visit to Japan. Peru's Congress, in turn, refused to accept his resignation and instead ousted him, declaring him ''morally unfit'' for office. It was an appropriately bizarre exit. The circumstances surrounding Mr. Fujimori's decision remain somewhat mysterious, but should not obscure the fact that his departure is a positive development. Peru's citizenry and opposition parties, as well as the international community, should capitalize on this opportunity to encourage the start of a new democratic era in Peru.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, GORDON ALEXANDER
description: RICH-Gordon Alexander. We mourn with our cherished friends of more than 45 years, Evie and Marv, his beautiful Swarthmore sweetheart, wife MaryAnn, and his beloved buddies, sons Max and Alex. From his first day of life, he was extraordinary. Cousin Gordie to Lois and Lila, always in our hearts. Ruth and Sam Perelson, Lois and Stewart Perelson Gross, Lila and Keith Adwar.

title: Metro Business Briefing; JOE FRANKLIN, THE RESTAURANT
description: Joe Franklin, the talk-show host who has interviewed more than 350,000 celebrities on radio and television over the last 50 years, is the latest entrant to the dining scene in the ever widening Times Square area. On Dec. 14, Mr. Franklin and his longtime producer Richard Ornstein are opening a 160-seat theme restaurant called Joe Franklin's Memory Lane Restaurant at 713 Eighth Avenue, at 45th Street. Mr. Franklin, 70, will occasionally broadcast from a radio booth at the center of the restaurant, surrounded by Greta Garbo's shoe, Mickey Mantle's Yankee uniform and other memorabilia, as well as big-screen televisions featuring old Franklin interviews. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Governor of Florida Proposes Bipartisan Panel to Overhaul Much Criticized Voting System
description: Gov. Jeb Bush, echoing his brother's criticisms of the hand recount of South Florida election ballots, today proposed the creation of a bipartisan panel to overhaul Florida's much maligned voting procedures, and he warned Democrats against trying to manipulate the outcome of the recounts.

title: Article 2000112290374801741 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS GAINS. Natural gas climbed as an early cold spell increased demand when supplies are low. In New York, natural gas for December delivery rose 15.9 cents, or 2.5 percent, to $6.408 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Orchestra Dressed in Black, Its Leader Without a Jacket
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic has been giving titles to its concerts in recent years, and the name it affixed to its concert on Saturday evening was ''1899.'' But it could just as easily have been 1943. In the first half of the program, Robert Spano led the orchestra in Schoenberg's ''Verklarte Nacht,'' a work that was indeed composed as a string sextet in 1899, expanded for string orchestra in 1917 and revised in 1943.

title: Schools Chief Wants to Shift TV and Radio To Nonprofits
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy wants to turn over the operation of the Board of Education's radio and television stations to WNYC and WNET because he thinks that they could run the stations more effectively and improve their programming, board officials said yesterday.

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE PRESIDENT QUITS AND RESHUFFLE IS PLANNED
description: Liz Claiborne Inc. said its president, Denise V. Seegal, had resigned, effective Dec. 8, and that other management changes would be made. The company's chairman and chief executive, Paul R. Charron, said ''differing views on the structure'' of the company were behind the departure of Ms. Seegal, who had joined the company from Calvin Klein Inc. in 1996. Liz Claiborne makes and sells apparel, fragrances and accessories under a number of labels including Liz Claiborne, Elisabeth, Crazy Horse and Dana Buchman.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a public hearing on New York City's long-term waste management plan referred imprecisely to the status of government actions on a proposal for a waste transfer station in Linden, N.J. The county, state and federal governments have not taken final action, but the Linden City Council has approved the plan. Its decision is not pending.

title: Political Fallout After a Legal Finding
description: The victory that the Florida Supreme Court handed tonight to Vice President Al Gore, while huge, was nonetheless notably incomplete, and that left open the chance that the nation might be heading for political Armageddon.

title: RUSSIAN ELECTRIC DEREGULATION
description: The Russian prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, tentatively approved a broad reorganization of the country's electricity industry proposed by the national power-transmission monopoly, Unified Energy System. The company, which operates Russia's national grid, said it would develop a free market for power that would set prices. Shareholders criticized a similar proposal earlier this year. Sabrina Tavernise

title: The Case of the Vanishing Berries
description: LAST summer there was such an abundance of cranberries that the federal government announced that it was forcing growers to cut production of their crops by 15 percent.

title: Trenton Backs Off Proposal To Take Control of Camden
description: New Jersey backed away today from its ambitious plan to take over the collapsing fiscal and civic management of Camden. Instead, it offered a blueprint for recovery based on cooperation with a city government that state officials were once determined to supplant.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Democracy in America, With Its Ups and Downs
description: To the Editor:

title: The Days Are Grim, but a Shared Dream Binds Arab and Israeli
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark Prelate to Head Washington Archdiocese
description: Pope John Paul II appointed Archbishop Theodore Edgar McCarrick of Newark yesterday to lead the Roman Catholic archdiocese of Washington, handing one of the church's most prominent American posts to a cleric already influential in the capital's corridors of power.

title: Merger Moves Cause EMI To Post Loss
description: The EMI Group played down the possibility of reaching a quick merger agreement with the German media giant Bertelsmann today as it reported that a charge related to its failed Time Warner deal led to a first-half loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNN, LILLIAN L.
description: LYNN-Lillian L., eighty-five, died Sunday, November 19th in New York City; wife of Leo N. Lynn (deceased), mother of Stephan Lynn, Bruce (wife Ruth) Lynn, and Myrna (husband, Mark) Cortez; grandchildren, Rachel, Sarah, Joshua, and Noah Lynn. Services in Munster, Indiana at 11 AM on Tuesday, November 21st. The family will be gathered at Stephan Lynn's home in New York City on Sunday, November 26 starting at 6PM. Donations to the charity of your choice in lieu of flowers.

title: Loyal Contributors Keep Both Candidates in Cash
description: They were by their candidates' sides when the race started, wielding their checkbooks and their Rolodexes to generate the millions of dollars needed to wage a presidential campaign. And, for the most part, they are still there as the campaign without end hurtles on.

title: Blends, Great and Small
description: IN the old days, winemakers produced what were called field blends. A vineyard would be planted with several kinds of grapes that would be made into a single wine. This practice has largely disappeared in today's world of precision planting, but winemakers are still producing the equivalent of field blends: inexpensive, easygoing red wines made from different grapes, intended for short-term gulping.

title: When Salad Is a Cold-Weather Friend
description: ADDING heat to your salad bowl may sound like an unusual idea, but a warm dressing, some steamy potatoes or grilled meat can transform a cold pile of greens into a surprisingly indulgent starter or entree.

title: Deal Announced to Reunite The Ticketmaster Operations
description: Ticketmaster Online-City Search Inc., the company that sells tickets online and manages 77 city Web sites worldwide, announced today that it was buying the Ticketmaster Corporation, a subsidiary of USA Networks, the cable television company run by Barry Diller.

title: Police May Raise Spending 25% for Anticrime Program
description: The Police Department is planning to increase spending on Operation Condor by at least 25 percent, according to figures released yesterday in a City Council hearing at which officials said the department needed such programs to keep the crime rate going down.

title: Real Estate; Slim Building Casts a Modern Image
description: The slender 24-story glass tower rising at 11 East 52nd Street in Manhattan has been described as a thermometer, totem pole, exclamation mark and space needle, while the architect himself has compared the planes of its sloping glass and steel facade to a guillotine blade slicing down.

title: A Final March for Hosea Williams, and Many Tributes
description: Hosea Williams's last march took a familiar route today, down Auburn Avenue and past Atlanta's citadels of power, first the state Capitol and then City Hall. As usual, he wore his protest clothes: denim bib overalls, a long-sleeved red shirt and matching sneakers.

title: Masochists Always Hurt The Ones They Love
description: ''Sasayaki,'' a slow, dark Japanese teenage romance, unspools like a long, kinky episode of ''Dawson's Creek.'' There's a little more sex than you'll see on WB, but mostly there's an atmosphere of brooding psychodrama and erotic cruelty that falls somewhere between ''Cries and Whispers'' and ''Say Anything.''

title: Canada's Premier Tugged to Right by Challenger
description: Riding out of the West on a platform of tax cuts and born-again social conservatism, a smooth-talking college-dropout-turned-politician named Stockwell Day has given Canadian politics its biggest shake-up in years.

title: Winnowing Process Begins for Novice Teachers
description: Judging from the rapturous way he describes his new life, Franklin Headley is among the lucky ones.

title: ONLINE POPULATION RISES IN PORTUGAL
description: The number of Internet users in Portugal rose 181 percent the first six months of this year, to 1.3 million, or 13.4 percent of the population, according to figures released yesterday by Portugal's telecommunications regulator. At the end of 1999, there were 474,000 Internet users in the country. Eighty-three percent of the users had free access to the Web, while those paying for access fell 9 percent in the three months to the end of June. The Portuguese pay among the highest Internet access fees in Europe. Benjamin Jones

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Lingering questions on who knew what in the McKesson-HBO deal.
description: IS it really possible that one company would buy another after learning that the company being bought had fudged its accounting to increase profits in ways that the Securities and Exchange Commission would never approve if it learned of them?

title: Decision Hews to Lines Of Gore Team's Position
description: The members of the Florida Supreme Court held not only the presidential election in their hands tonight but also their own reputations and that of the institution they serve.

title: HOLIDAY TOMORROW -- Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: DOUBLECLICK SHIFTS PERSONNEL
description: DoubleClick in New York is realigning and naming executives to new posts. Barry Salzman, president for international media operations, was named president for global media. Wenda Harris Millard, executive vice president for domestic media business, was named executive vice president for global media. Ms. Millard had previously reported to Kevin Ryan, chief executive at DoubleClick, but will now report to Mr. Salzman. Also, David Rosenblatt, senior vice president of DoubleClick's technology solutions division, becomes president for technology marketing services. And Susan Sachatello was named chief marketing officer; she had been chief marketing officer and general manager at Prodigy Internet. Allison Fass

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADDISS, LUISE KRAUS
description: ADDISS-Luise Kraus. November 19, 2000 of cardiac arrest at the age of 101. Loving mother of James and Stephen Addiss and Penelope Yungblut. Grandmother of Wendy Dellar, Edward Addiss III, Justus Addiss, Susan Hemingway and Yosa Addiss and three great grandchildren, mother-inlaw of Lee Addiss and Gail Addiss. Wake at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28 St, Tuesday, November 21, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral mass at Epiphany Church, 22nd St and 2nd Ave, Wednesday, November 22, 11AM. Burial private. Memorial gifts in her name in lieu of flowers: The Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Baker's Response to Ruling
description: Following are excerpts from a statement last night by former Secretary of State James A. Baker III on the Florida Supreme Court decision, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Gore's Response to Ruling
description: Following is a transcript of the statement by Vice President Al Gore last night regarding the Florida Supreme Court decision allowing hand recounts of ballots in three heavily Democratic counties, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: All Aboard! (Better Late Than Never)
description: To the Editor:

title: EU Rejects France's Call For Ban on Meat in Feed
description: PARIS  France failed Tuesday to persuade fellow members of the European Union to follow its lead in banning meat and bone meal in livestock feed, ingredients considered to be responsible for the spread of "mad cow" disease.

title: Dimpled Votes Are New Hope For Democrats
description: Senior Democratic strategists said tonight that the Florida Supreme Court's unanimous decision set a broad enough standard for hand recounts that they would be able to accumulate the indented ballots that Vice President Al Gore needs to win the presidential election.

title: Excerpts From Ruling by Florida Supreme Court on the Recount of Votes
description: Following is the Florida Supreme Court's unanimous decision yesterday that the results of hand recounts in three counties could be included if they are submitted by Monday. Italicized portions show where emphasis was added in the original.

title: Andy Logan, 80, City Hall Reporter, Dies
description: Andy Logan, the reporter whose witty, elegant and gently sarcastic voice dissected the goings-on at New York's City Hall for The New Yorker magazine for 25 years, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 80 years old and had been ill with pancreatic cancer.

title: Where the Sommeliers Shop
description: IN New York's overheated wine market, restaurant owners and their sommeliers are often forced to go to auctions to find the fine wines they want. Last Saturday, one of the city's best-known restaurateurs did just the opposite: he went to Sotheby's to sell wine, about $343,000 worth, as it turned out.

title: Torturing Everybody, And Loving It
description: One of the funniest and most riveting scenes in ''Quills'' sets the tone for the movie, though it doesn't come early. In the Charenton Asylum, Abbe Coulmier (Joaquin Phoenix) and Dr. Royer-Collard (Michael Caine) are discussing the best way to handle the infuriating Marquis de Sade, and as they walk, these men of reason are surrounded by demonstrations of the most modern medical treatments: bloodletting, phrenology and the like. It's the kind of casual absurdity that the film's director, Philip Kaufman, delights in, and ''Quills'' at its best lets him display a graceful wiliness. This story of the Marquis de Sade, adapted by Doug Wright from his play of the same title, isn't exactly a docudrama. It invents elements to make its rather obvious point about the price exacted by art and the state that liberals trying to do what's right can be whipped into. Fortunately, the elegance of Mr. Kaufman's direction and his handling of the cast make for the kind of euphoric stylishness that has been missing from moviegoing for some time.

title: Democrats Praise Ruling, And the Count Continues
description: Democratic canvassing board members in Broward and Palm Beach counties, still hard at work when the Florida Supreme Court delivered its ruling late tonight, praised the court's decision and expressed optimism that they would complete their counting on time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MARTHA
description: BERNSTEIN-Martha. The American Friends of Bar-Ilan University mourn the passing of Martha Bernstein of Miami Beach after a prolonged illness. She was a generous patron of Bar-Ilan and, in addition to other gifts, dedicated a classroom in one of our buildings in Israel. We extend our sympathy to all members of her family. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor, Bar-Ilan University

title: Democracy in America, With Its Ups and Downs; The Impartial Machine
description: To the Editor:

title: Message Sent by Redskins: Defense Is Formidable
description: Marshall Faulk tried to block Bruce Smith on a pass play late in the battle between the Redskins and the Rams on Monday night. Now, Faulk is a terrific player, but he is a running back who weighs 211 pounds. Smith is a defensive end who weighs 68 pounds more than Faulk. Smith, at 6 feet 4 inches, is also 6 inches taller than Faulk.

title: Wiretapping System Works On Internet, Review Finds
description: A highly anticipated technical review of Carnivore, the Internet wiretap system developed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has found that the system does what law enforcement officials say it does: gathers information from Internet service providers about the online messages sent and received by criminal suspects.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a family of trapeze artists performing with the Big Apple Circus misstated the location. The circus is at Lincoln Center, not in Radio City Music Hall.

title: Power Agency Details Plans For Electric Turbines in City
description: Stepping in to reduce the threat of blackouts next summer, the New York Power Authority is detailing its plans to install a fleet of small electricity generators around Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx and on Long Island and possibly in Staten Island.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: American Aquavit: Delightfully Impure
description: WHEN is aquavit not aquavit? When this caraway-flavored spirit is put in the hands of Michel Roux, the liquor importer who made Absolut vodka a best seller and who modernized such drinks as peach liqueur and absinthe.

title: CHINA STEEL STOCK SOLD
description: The Baoshan Iron and Steel Company completed the largest initial public offering yet in China, raising nearly $1 billion by selling 1.87 billion new shares. Three-quarters of the offering was taken up by Chinese institutions, the rest by individual investors. Baosteel, as the company is known, had wanted to sell shares on the Hong Kong exchange but found insufficient demand. Craig Smith

title: Fox Expected to Start Naming Cabinet Today in Mexico
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Democracy in America, With Its Ups and Downs; Those Hanging Chads
description: To the Editor:

title: Nature Lets Buffalo Know It's Not a Match for Winter
description: It was just last Saturday that Mayor Anthony M. Masiello inspected Buffalo's 16 new snowplows, boasted of a hefty increase in the number of workers trained to clear winter streets, and declared the city armed with ''the will to win against winter.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTLEY, FREDA
description: HARTLEY-Freda. On November 20, peacefully at home at age 88. Beloved mother of Leslie Gise M.D, and Sara Hartley M.D. Adoring grandmother of Robin Gise, J.D. Services Wednesday, November 22, 11:30 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Mount Sinai Alumni Association and/or The 92nd St. Y. The family will be sitting Shiva at 8 E. 96 St, #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, JOHN D.
description: GREGORY-John D. The Rockefeller University mourns the loss of Dr. John D. Gregory, a dear friend and colleague. A beloved member of the University community for over fifty years, he made significant contributions to scientific understanding through his research on the structures and functions of connective tissues. Dr. Gregory will be remembered for his commitment to the University's mission of biomedical research and education. He will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Polly, and their family. Arnold J. Levine, President Richard B. Fisher, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFIN, MARGARET L. DODSON
description: GRIFFIN-Margaret L. Dodson. December 21, 1909-Nov. 20, 2000. Peacefully at home in Bethlehem, PA. Smith College Alumna '33. Margie was the beloved wife of the late Albion M. Griffin. Cherished mother of David, James G., Patrick, Michael and Kevin. Grandmother of Nicholas, Rachel and Catherine; Sarah and Elizabeth; Alexandra and Peter; and Graham. Services and burial November 24 from Herron Funeral Home, Bethlehem, PA. In lieu of flowers donations to a charity of your choice.

title: The Days Are Grim, but a Shared Dream Binds Arab and Israeli
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Meet With Irate Parents At School Where 4 Were Molested
description: Two days after a man lurking in the stairwell of a Queens elementary school molested four children, school and police officials and local politicians met with hundreds of frightened and angry parents yesterday to assure them that additional guards would be assigned to the building on Monday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Stephen Borsody, a former Hungarian diplomat and scholar, misstated the date of his death and referred incompletely to his academic interest. Dr. Borsody died on Oct. 17, not Nov. 17. His principal academic interest was analyzing, and proposing solutions for, the instability of central Europe, not just of Hungary.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY

title: All Used Up With Someplace to Go
description: WHEN the Computer Recycling Center opened 10 years ago in Silicon Valley, Steven Wyatt hoped to collect 200 old and discarded computers a month. The center fell short of that target, ending the first year with about 2,000.

title: G.O.P. Expresses Rancor Over Ruling; Lawmaker Threatens to Challenge Electors
description: The Florida Supreme Court ruling in favor of hand recounts in three heavily Democratic counties provoked bitter denunciations by Republicans in Congress today, with the House majority leader calling for the Florida Legislature to step in. One House Republican threatened to challenge Florida's electoral votes in the House in January.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas gained on expectations that cold weather has depleted supplies of the heating fuel. In New York, natural gas for December delivery rose 16.9 cents, to $6.577 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America; Gore's Good Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: For One Group of Counters, Crucial Hours Are at Hand
description: On Friday morning, the Palm Beach County canvassing board will begin its most difficult task yet. The three members will determine whether thousands of disputed ballots -- some with dimples, others with partially punched holes -- will count as new votes in the presidential election.

title: Net at TotalFinaElf Rises
description: The French oil company TotalFinaElf S.A. said today that its net profit for the third quarter more than doubled, to 2.1 billion euros ($1.8 billion), excluding nonrecurring items. Sales rose 54 percent, to 30.9 billion euros. Its effort to acquire Gener S.A., a Chilean power producer, gained new life when Gener postponed a shareholder vote on bylaw changes needed to accept a competing bid.

title: U.N. Envoy Voices Worry On U.S. Image
description: With barely a month to go until a decision on an American request to pay lower dues to the United Nations, Ambassador Richard C. Holbrooke said he was afraid that his yearlong campaign for the cuts could be stalled by nations that think no one is in charge in the United States.

title: Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America; In the Event of a Tie
description: To the Editor:

title: Coke's Retreat Puts Quaker Back in Play
description: The collapse of Coca-Cola's $16 billion bid to acquire Quaker Oats prompted rival bidders yesterday to re-evaluate their acquisition strategies and raised discussion about the implications for Coke's chairman and chief executive, Douglas N. Daft.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-20

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVACK, MICHAEL
description: NOVACK-Michael, 32, Westport, CT, died Tuesday in Westport. Mr. Novack, an attorney, was Vice President for u-medik, Inc. of Stamford. He is survived by, his wife Michelle Novack, parents, Martin and Linda Novack, brother, Robert Novack, and sister-in-law Nancy Novack, grandmothers, Rosalind Novack and Natalie Schechterman, nephew, Brian Novack and niece, Jennifer Novack. Services Friday 1:00PM Temple Beth El, 109 East Avenue, Norwalk, CT. Interment Beth El Memorial Park Cemetery, Norwalk. The Collins Funeral Home, Norwalk is in charge of services.

title: Cheney Is Likely to Recover Quickly, Hospital Says
description: The mild heart attack that Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, suffered this morning was his fourth, and his cardiologist at George Washington University Hospital here said Mr. Cheney had ''moderate impairment'' of his heart.

title: Excerpts From Doctor's Updates on Cheney Status
description: Following are excerpts from two news conferences yesterday by Dr. Alan Wasserman of George Washington University Medical Center in Washington, who treated Dick Cheney for chest pains early yesterday. The first news conference, which began at 2:32 p.m., was recorded by The New York Times; the second, which began at 4:54 p.m., was recorded by the Federal News Service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, PAULINE
description: FALK-Pauline. With deep regret we note the passing of our esteemed honorary Board member, Pauline Falk. She was a devoted and valuable leader of the JDC for many years, until ill health forced her to curtail her activities. Pauline came to her JDC commitment naturally. Her father was the illustrious Paul Baerwald, President of the JDC 1932-1940 and 1944-1945. May her example be our inspiration. We express our condolences to her children Pat, Michael, and Nancy and to their families. Jonathan W. Kolker-President Michael Schneider Executive Vice President Ambassador Milton A. Wolf Chairman of the Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILBERDING, JOSEPH C., JR.
description: WILBERDING-Joseph C., Jr. On Nov. 21, 2000. Beloved husband of Katherine Van Cortlandt Wilberding, dear father of Stephen Van C. Wilberding, Katherine Garcia, Joan Hirte and Augusta Laidlaw. Also survived by 10 grandchildren and six great grandchildren. Funeral service will be held on Friday, November 24, at 11 AM at St. Marks Episcopal Church, Mt. Kisco, N.Y. Interment private. For information call Oelker & Cox Funeral Home, Inc., 914-666-5891.

title: A Top Officer Leaves I2
description: I2 Technologies Inc., which makes software that links manufacturers and their suppliers, said after the close of regular stock trading yesterday that its chief operating officer, Robert Evans, had resigned. The company's stock declined $9.56, to $106.63.

title: Russia Ending Deal on Arms Negotiated by Gore
description: Russia has notified the Clinton administration that it intends to withdraw from a 1995 agreement negotiated by Vice President Al Gore limiting Russian sales of tanks and other conventional weapons to Iran, officials said today.

title: Former Nurse on Trial in Patients' Deaths
description: ''There was a coldness in Ward C,'' the prosecutor began his wintry tale of white-coated murder this week.

title: Lewis and Clark's Trip to Manifest Destiny
description: THE adventures of Lewis and Clark are not over.

title: Laptop Prices Tumble In Time for Holidays
description: Generous gift givers have been given a break this holiday season. Price cuts announced by Sony and Compaq this week on several, mostly high end, consumer laptops will probably inspire other makers to follow suit, said Stephen Baker, director of hardware analysis for PC Data, a company that tracks electronics sales.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JORGE, ANITA
description: JORGE-Anita, 11/24/99 and Edith Minkoff, 11/20/99. Mom, mother-inlaw, grandma, sister, aunt, role model. Two special women who left us one year ago, now forever with the two great men they loved. We thank the four of you for teaching us how to live and love. We miss you The Jorge/Minkoff Family

title: CALENDAR
description: From the 20th Century

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, CARRIE SKLOOT
description: ROSENBLATT-Carrie Skloot. On November 22, 2000. Age 94. Beloved wife of the late Jacob H. Rosenblatt. Loving mother of Emily Spiegel and her husband Jerry, and the late Eleanor Sondock. Adoring grandmother of Pamela Sanders, Lise Wilks, Clifford, Bradford and Joanne Sondock and great grandmother of Jordan, Remy, Erin, David, Andrew, Jack, Jason, Joshua and Eleanor. Dear sister of Evelyn Tobin. Interior Designer and former National Vice President and Forest Hills Chapter President of the National Women's Division, American Technion Society. Services are Friday, November 24, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Ave & 76 St. Contributions in her memory may be made to National Women's Division, ATS, 810 7th Ave., New York, NY 10019.

title: Student Killed in Fire Started by Candles
description: A 25-year-old film student died early yesterday in a fire ignited by candles burning near her bed in her downtown Brooklyn apartment, officials said.

title: Profit Rises 53% at Barneys New York
description: Barneys New York Inc., which emerged from bankruptcy protection in 1999, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 53 percent on higher sales at its full-price and outlet stores open at least a year.

title: Yemeni Cites Cole Suspects Seen as Linked to bin Laden
description: Yemen's prime minister said today that the investigation into the attack on the American destroyer last month had identified the bombers as two Saudi citizens with Yemeni family roots who fought Soviet forces in Afghanistan.

title: Protests Are Stepped Up at Hague Talks on Greenhouse Gases
description: Protests at climate-treaty talks here reached a high pitch today. Demonstrators climbed into the rafters of a central room, blockaded doorways, passed out Christmas stockings stuffed with coal and splattered the top American negotiator with a cream pie at a news conference tonight.

title: Girlish, Simple, Sultry, And Even a Little Like Ella
description: If Lincoln Center's troubled American Songbook series has yet to find a steady artistic footing in its main concert events at Alice Tully Hall, its cabaret series at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse is flourishing. The penthouse, with its excellent acoustics and sight lines and gorgeous floor-to-ceiling views of the city, is a truly elegant nightclub space that makes you feel special the moment you enter it.

title: Bus in Crash That Killed Eight Had Problems, a Report Finds
description: A bus that crashed on the Garden State Parkway in New Jersey on Christmas Eve 1998, killing eight passengers, had six mechanical problems not caused by the crash, each of them serious enough to have kept the bus off the road, a federal report has found.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with a review of Janacek's ''Jenufa'' at Lyric Opera of Chicago misidentified the cast member at the bottom right. It was Patricia Racette in the title role, not Patrick Denniston, who sang the role of her unsuccessful suitor.

title: Wait, It's a Platter, and a Vase
description: Some people consider the main dish the centerpiece of the holiday table. Others feel a table isn't festive without a floral arrangement. The Hybrid platter combines the two schools. Twenty-two tubes extend from the center, allowing a wreathlike bouquet to surround the roast beef.

title: Vexed Judge Orders Psychological Tests For Ex-Union Chief
description: Annoyed that an indicted former union leader did not show up in court, a state judge in Manhattan yesterday sent police detectives to pick him up and take him to Bellevue Hospital Center's psychological unit, pending a determination of whether he is competent to stand trial.

title: Architecture, Step by Step
description: PATTERNLANGUAGE.COM is intended to help ordinary people unversed in the ways of design to devise a home suitable for them and for its surroundings. It does so by leading them through 19 steps, starting with garden location and ending with ornamentation. The order of the steps is crucial, with the early decisions setting the context for what follows. The steps outlined here have been adapted from the site.

title: Calling All Treetop Lovers
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON was joined in Vietnam last week by an entourage of American business executives. The group included David Greenberg, a Hawaii-based architect who was there to sign a partnership agreement with Vietnamese officials to open a treehouse vacation resort in the province of Hue, 15 miles north of China Beach, where combat-weary G.I.'s once came for R.&R.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASMUSSEN, HAROLD F.
description: RASMUSSEN-Harold F. On Tuesday, November 21, 2000. Beloved husband of Sara J., father of David, of Portchester, Garret, of Washington, D.C., Anne Fraser, of Rye, and six grandchildren. Service Friday, November 24, at 2:00 P.M. at Christ's Church, Rye.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Sony's New Digital Camera: Filmless, Yes. CD-Less, No.
description: DIGITAL cameras offer all kinds of advantages over film cameras. For example, the resulting photos are computer files; you can edit them, send them via e-mail or print only the ones in which your hair doesn't look weird. And the built-in preview screen spares you the humiliation of opening freshly developed prints only to find that in six of them, the primary foreground element is your index finger.

title: G.O.P. Campaign Urges End to 'Capricious' Florida Counting
description: The campaign of Gov. George W. Bush urgently sought the intervention of the United States Supreme Court tonight to stop what his lawyers called a ''selective, capricious and standardless'' vote counting process that ''now borders on anarchy'' and is ''turning the presidential election in Florida into a circus.''

title: ABC Tightens Its Rules On Declaring Winners
description: Seeking to prevent repeats of the erroneous projections that made election night such an embarrassment for the networks, officials of ABC News said yesterday that they would no longer call a contest in any state until all of its polls had closed and would try to ''insulate'' their analysts from competitive pressures to project a winner prematurely.

title: Today's N.F.L. Matchups
description: New England (3-8) at Detroit (7-4) 12:30 p.m., CBS

title: An Efficient Laugh Machine Chews Up Many Targets
description: ''Mother Lolita,'' a new play by Guillermo Reyes -- billed as an ''outrageous comedy'' by Urban Stages, which is giving it its first production -- is actually an extended cartoon strip beyond the reach of parental guidance. And while it is a remarkably efficient laugh machine, Mr. Reyes assumes that if all the characters are sufficiently corrupted in one way or another, the playwright's license is unlimited, so outrage is not a response that would occur to anyone.
