title: Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America; Alabama, 1960
description: To the Editor:

title: As Election Melodrama Lurches On, Some No Longer Care Who Wins
description: As the plot thickened and thinned and thickened some more today in the elongated presidential election serial, residents here were feeling so whipped into exhaustion and exasperation that some were forming imaginative and wholly unexpected opinions.

title: WATSON EXPECTS DELAY IN APPROVAL OF ANTIANXIETY DRUG
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc., the maker of generic and brand-name drugs, said yesterday that a patent awarded to the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company may delay regulatory approval of Watson's generic version of buspirone, an antianxiety medication marketed by Bristol-Myers as Buspar. Watson, based in Corona, Calif., had hoped that approval would be imminent, but it said that the Food and Drug Administration was required to wait 45 days after the patent's approval before giving Watson the go-ahead to market its drug. If Bristol-Myers filed an infringement complaint, the wait could be 30 months. The delay will cost Watson at least $18 million to $20 million in lost fourth-quarter revenue and $38 million to $40 million in 2001, the company said.

title: Rap, Rock and a Surprise Visit From a Fugitive
description: ''I'm like a butterfly on your windowpane,'' said Russell Jones, the rapper known as O. D .B., when he sauntered onstage during the Wu Tang Clan's concert on Tuesday at Hammerstein Ballroom. It's doubtful that O. D. B. knows the minutiae of rock history, but his phrase evoked an earlier incident involving pop stars who challenged the law.

title: Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America; Ballot by Orwell?
description: To the Editor:

title: Framfab to Cut One in Six Jobs
description: Framfab A.B., a Swedish Internet consultant, said today that it would cut more than one in six jobs to try to return to profitability in the second quarter.

title: Searching for Games by Their Ratings
description: PARENTS and other gift givers who are not sure what software titles are suitable for children can turn to the Internet for guidance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKISCH, GERHARD
description: ELKISCH-Gerhard. Beloved husband of Liselotte; father of Michael, and grandfather of Scott and Jamie, passed away on November 17.

title: Heavenly Intervention
description: SOME of Thomas Jayne's society clients would probably describe his decorating as divine, and they'd be right on the money about his last job. Mr. Jayne, a New York decorator who has worked in more than a few of the major apartment buildings in the city, from the Dakota to River House, is completing the refurbishment of the rectory at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, off Times Square. Mr. Jayne is a parishioner.

title: Retaining Distinct Spirits, A Cello and Piano Marry
description: Many of the musicians appearing in Carnegie Hall's Distinctive Debuts series have indeed proved distinctive. Two were the Belgian cellist Marie Hallynck and the French pianist Cedric Tiberghien who performed at Weill Recital Hall on Friday.

title: Looking Back at the Tethers of Fantasyland
description: MANFRED G. BASS, the designer of the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, is retiring after 41 years, so a stroll around the old balloon corral seemed called for.

title: Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America; Voodoo Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH FOOD RETAILER BUYING 12 GRAND UNION STORES
description: J. Sainsbury P.L.C., Britain's second-largest food retailer, announced yesterday that it was moving to buy 18 Grand Union stores in Vermont and Connecticut to add to its Shaw's subsidiary as it continued to expand in New England. No financial details were disclosed. Most of Grand Union's assets are being acquired out of bankruptcy-court protection by C&S Wholesale, Grand Union's main supplier, and many of the stores are being immediately resold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRMAN, EDITH K.
description: EHRMAN-Edith K. Died on November 21 after a long life and a short illness. Predeceased by her parents, Jesse and Edith G. Koshland; by her husband, Frederick L. Ehrman; by her daughters, Edith Ehrman and Anita L. Ehrman; and by her sisters, Ruth K. Hellman and Frances K. Skipsey. Survived by her nephew, F. Warren Hellman; by her niece, Nancy H. Bechtle; by six great nephews and great nieces; and by thirteen great great nephews and great great nieces. Passionately interested in and profoundly generous to a myriad of charitable organizations, including The New York University Medical Center; The Mount Sinai Medical Center; The Lincoln Center Theater; and Playwrights Horizons. There will not be a funeral service. There may be a memorial service at a time and place yet to be determined.

title: It Makes the World Go Round, Among Some Other Things
description: ''Looking at Love . . . ,'' which may sound like a magazine title, was what the New York City Ballet called the benefit opening of its fall-winter season at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night.

title: Grocery Chain Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
description: Big V Supermarkets, which operates 39 ShopRite supermarkets in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, said today that it had filed for bankruptcy-court protection and would close 7 stores in New York and Pennsylvania in the next three months.

title: ANGLO AMERICAN WANTS TO RENEGOTIATE MINE PURCHASE
description: Anglo American P.L.C. is trying to recover as much as $210 million from its $900 million purchase of the Australian coal assets of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group because of problems with a mine in Queensland state, according to The Sydney Morning Herald. Anglo has been discussing its claim with Shell about the Moranbah North mine, the newspaper said. Anglo has complained that Shell did not fully disclose the mine's design problems during the sale earlier in the year; Shell has responded that the problems were widely known and that it did not hide pertinent information.

title: Converting WordPerfect To Microsoft Word
description: Q. Is it possible to convert my WordPerfect 6.0 files to Microsoft Word 97? What might happen to the files when converting them?

title: BOARD PRESSES SWISSAIR TO IMPROVE EARNINGS
description: The board of SAirGroup has ruled out a sale of its Swissair unit and told the airline's chief executive, Philippe Bruggisser, to develop a plan to improve earnings. Analysts said the company was under pressure to win back investors who fled as airline reorganization costs increased, clouding the profitable growth in the group's nonairline businesses, which account for more than half of sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHLMAN, CLEM
description: KOHLMAN-Clem. The Board of Governors and membership of Edgewood Country Club record with deep sorrow the death of Mr. Clem Kohlman, an esteemed member and extend to his beloved wife Eleanor and family its deepest sympathy. Arthur I. Frankel, President Brian Strum, Secretary

title: BUSH TAKES APPEAL TO U.S. SUPREME COURT; CHENEY IN HOSPITAL WITH MILD HEART ATTACK
description: The disputed presidential election was thrown into new turmoil today as Miami-Dade County, the largest Florida Democratic enclave still recounting votes by hand, abruptly decided to stop, and a state court judge in Palm Beach County gave ballot counters there wide discretion about which of hundreds of disputed votes should actually count.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing traffic rules and schedules for Thanksgiving referred imprecisely to parking regulations in New York City. Alternate-side regulations and meter regulations are suspended today, along with the ''No Parking'' rules that are normally suspended on Sundays. Signs that say ''No Stopping,'' ''No Standing'' or ''No Parking Any Time'' remain in effect; those regulations have not been suspended.

title: To Aid the Blind, A.T.M. Maker Gives Its Machines a Voice
description: GETTING cash from an automated teller machine is a convenience that most people now take for granted. But not the blind.

title: Florida Legislators Consider Options to Aid Bush
description: Openly contemptuous of the Florida Supreme Court, senior Republican legislators, led by men with strong political ties to the state's governor, Jeb Bush, searched with a partisan intensity today for a legislative stroke that would deliver Florida and the White House to George W. Bush.

title: Gore Has Decided to Start Engines of His Transition
description: Over the summer, Vice President Al Gore quietly assigned his longtime adviser and former top aide, Roy Neel, to plan the transition from campaigning to governing.

title: Panoramic Maps From the Library of Congress
description: The Library of Congress has several collections of maps online, including panoramic maps made between 1847 and 1929 (lcweb2.loc.gov

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDSBERG, DEBRA
description: LANDSBERG-Debra, suddenly on Tuesday, November 21, 2000. Dear sister of Judith Bralver, beloved aunt of Barbara (Michael), Charles (Belinda), adored great aunt of Matthew, Joshua, Andrew, Robert, Caroline, and Alexandra. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the New YorK Times Fund For The Neediest. Services will be at 11am Friday, November 24, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 Street, NYC.

title: Publishing Declares Open Season on Famous Figures
description: A new season of debunking is upon us. Unflattering revelations, uncharitable surmises, harsh correctives and outright slanders are raining down on the just and the unjust alike. On the receiving end these days are Joe DiMaggio; Susan Sontag; Saul Bellow; Richard M. Nixon; Diana, Princess of Wales; and Barbara Marx Sinatra, Frank Sinatra's widow. And that varied menu does not include recently retired or still active political figures, who are fair game for abuse at any hour and from many sources.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTLEY, FREDA
description: HARTLEY-Freda. The Executive Board and Members of The Mount Sinai Alumni deeply regret the passing of Freda Hartley, beloved wife of the late Dr. Joel Hartley, and cherished mother of our friend and colleague, Leslie Gise, M.D. Our deepest sympathies are extended to the entire family. Avi Barbasch, M.D., President Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria L. Padilla, M.D., Secretary William G. Stein, M.D., Treasurer

title: Politics of the Teachers' Contract
description: Contract negotiations between City Hall and the United Federation of Teachers have yet to begin officially, but they have already descended into shouts and bluster that will make a reasoned settlement more difficult to reach. The two sides need to lower the volume and move quickly to the core problem of how to put a qualified teacher into every New York City public school classroom. That goal will require the city to provide higher teacher salaries, the chief goal sought by the teachers' union. But the city should grant such raises only in exchange for an extended work schedule for teachers and disciplinary procedures that make it easier to dismiss teachers who do not perform on the job. Most crucially, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the U.F.T. president, Randi Weingarten, need to put aside their bitter rivalry and reach accord for the good of the city's schoolchildren.

title: Flurry of Activity in Cheney Case Left Bush Struggling to Keep Up
description: Midway through a tumultuous sequence of events today, Gov. George W. Bush sought to assure people that the hospitalization of his running mate, Dick Cheney, for chest pains was a ''precautionary measure'' and that Mr. Cheney had sounded ''strong and vibrant'' during an early morning telephone conversation.

title: ITALIAN BANK DEAL
description: A large, cooperatively owned bank based in Milan, Banca Popolare Commercio ed Industria, has agreed to buy 75 percent of Banca Carime, a unit of Banca Intesa, Italy's biggest bank, for 2.3 trillion lire ($1 billion). Intesa said Popolare Commercio has the option to buy the remaining 25 percent of Banca Carime, a regional bank based in Cosenza in the toe of Italy, during the next three years. Rather than merge with local rivals, Italy's major cooperative banks have been trying to grow large enough to compete with the country's biggest banks by acquiring banks in distant regions.

title: British Airways Chief Ready to Make Broad Changes
description: When the subject of the Singapore Airlines crash in Taiwan came up during a recent gathering of British Airways executives, the chief executive, Rod Eddington, stunned colleagues by going into a detailed technical analysis of what happened to the plane, right down to its takeoff speed, people who were present said.

title: What the Timpanists Had to Say for Themselves
description: After two hours of music that strove to say a great deal at the American Symphony Orchestra's concert on Sunday afternoon (Ernst Krenek's Second Symphony and Harold Farberman's ''Millennium Concerto''), Philip Glass's ''Concerto Fantasy'' for two timpanists and orchestra was welcome for saying just a little and doing so directly, strongly and with abounding good humor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUSYNOWITZ, IRVING
description: NUSYNOWITZ-Irving. Of Peekskill, NY, formerly of the Bronx. Died November 21, 2000. Husband of Judith. Father of Michelle, Nina and Lisa. Grandfather of Jessica and Zachary. Brother of Martin. Funeral service at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, Friday 11:00 AM. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: The Neediest Cases; Symbol of Family's Hope: Thanksgiving in Their New Home
description: A year ago, Randy Dillard and his five children slept night after night in a public shelter. Full of cockroaches, mice and rats -- and teenagers who intimidated his young children -- it was no place to raise a family, Mr. Dillard said.

title: California Utility's Rate Plan
description: Pacific Gas and Electric, California's largest electric utility, asked state regulators today to end a freeze on customers' power rates and allow it to recover losses from buying power on the wholesale power market this year.

title: Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America; A Partisan Tribunal
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida's Justices Went Too Far
description: In a bold example of judicial activism, the Florida Supreme Court has ruled that the technical requirements of state election law are less important than vindicating the will of the voters. The court allowed manual recounts to continue in Democratic counties, and without saying so explicitly, it strongly hinted that dimpled ballots should be part of the count.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CONNECTICUT WAGES RANKED
description: Workers in Connecticut had the second-highest average pay in the nation again last year, according to data released last week by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The average in Connecticut in 1999 was $42,653, which trails the $50,742 average in for workers in the District of Columbia, but surpasses New York's $42,133, which ranked third. The numbers, based on unemployment-insurance data, are calculated by dividing the total payroll in the state by the average number of people who work there. Connecticut workers matched the average annual wage-growth increase of 4.3 percent. New York workers' gains lagged at 3.6 percent; The state of Washington scored the highest increase, at 8 percent. Leslie Eaton

title: Metro Business Briefing; CABLE RATES RISE 7 PERCENT
description: Cablevision Systems Corporation will raise rates for its 2.9 million customers in the New York region an average of 7 percent early next year. The company said the increase reflects increased programming and operating costs. The increase will appear on January or February bills.

title: 2 Automakers Plan to Idle Some North American Plants
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. and the Ford Motor Company said today that they would idle some North American plants next week as the automakers try to reduce the number of unsold cars and trucks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, KATHERINE E. (EPLER)
description: GREEN-Katherine E. (Epler), in New York City. Formerly of Revere and Brookline Massachussetts on November 21 in her 100th year. Wife of the late J. Walter Green. Sister of the late Oliver, George and Herbert Epler, Alice, Victoria and Louise. Beloved sister-in-law of Mrs. Irene Epler of Revere, MA and Mrs. Beatrice Epler of Westford, MA. Also lovingly survived by several nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. Family and friends are invited to attend a period of visitation in the Vertuccio Home For Funerals, 773 Broadway, Revere, MA, on Saturday beginning at 10:30AM followed by a funeral mass in Saint John Vianney Church, Revere, MA at 12noon. Interment is in Holyhood Cemetery, Brookline, MA. Mrs. Green along with her late husband owned and operated J. Walter Green Fine Glassware and Giftware of New York and Boston.

title: N.T.T. UNIT NEARS AT&T WIRELESS DEAL
description: Investors responded negatively yesterday to news that NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest wireless carrier, is nearing an agreement to acquire a minority stake in AT&T Wireless, a unit of AT&T that is being spun off as part of AT&T's restructuring. NTT DoCoMo's American depository receipts sank $6, or 4.5 percent, to $127, while AT&T executives close to the negotiations said DoCoMo was close to taking as much as a 20 percent stake in AT&T Wireless in a deal with a price tag that could exceed $9 billion. The executives cautioned that the deal could still fall apart, but said the two companies planned to announce the transaction as early as next week.

title: Bach as Bach Never Intended. Or Did He?
description: One of the remarkable things about this Bach year, the 250th anniversary of the composer's death, is how much the climate around his music has changed in the mere 15 years since the last Bach year, the 300th anniversary of his birth.

title: Torre Isn't Looking Past 2001
description: Joe Torre may or may not decide to manage the Yankees in 2002, but one Yankee official insisted yesterday that it was premature to say that Torre had had meaningful discussions with George Steinbrenner about the possibility.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLZ, MONICA ANNIE FLORENCE
description: STOLZ-Monica Annie Florence. Deceased at Yonkers, New York on November 21, 2000. Loving and devoted wife of the late Bernard Stolz, MD, of Troy, NY. Loving mother of Daniel of St Louis, Alan of Houston and the late Robert. Cherished grandmother of Tracy, Brian, Barry (Patricia) & Tammy Stolz. Dear mother-in-law of Phyllis Stolz, Roberta Stolz and Matt Price. A woman of valor who gave of herself lovingly and unselfishly to all. Service Friday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Ronald McDonald House or the charity of your choice.

title: Flat Opening Day for Telefonica Unit
description: Shares of Telefonica Moviles S.A. of Spain ended where they began in their debut today on the Madrid bolsa, closing at 11 euros, the price set for the initial offering.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Make no mistake. The court rewrote the laws. It changed the rules and it did so after the election was over.''

title: David Hermelin, 63, a Diplomat Who Artfully Used the Hot Dog
description: David B. Hermelin, ambassador to Norway until last January, a real estate developer, a philanthropist who gave to Jewish and other causes, and a contributor to the Democratic Party, died yesterday in Detroit. He was 63 and lived in Bingham Farms, Mich.

title: OP-ART
Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America; An Illogical Ruling
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Economic Scene; No matter who's the next president, there will be some hard choices to make.
description: ONE piece of conventional wisdom making the rounds these days is that investors in the financial markets may prefer the Washington gridlock that a close presidential election brings. No new policy is good policy, the argument goes. But circumstances are shifting rapidly, and such a view seems especially naive right now.

title: Hungary May Allow Freer Trade of Forint
description: Hungary may allow its currency to trade more freely and open up its domestic gas market next year if inflation slows, Finance Minister Zsigmond Jarai said today.

title: Unions Pushing to Organize Thousands of Amazon.com Workers
description: Seeking to exploit a major retailer's vulnerability during the holiday season, the labor movement has begun a broad campaign to unionize thousands of workers at Amazon.com in what is labor's most ambitious foray into the new economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEGG, JAMES J. JR.
description: LEGG-James J. Jr. Of Levittown L.I. suddenly on November 20, 2000. Beloved son of Ann De Marino, Mr. and Mrs. James J. Legg. Dear brother of Vincent Legg and Kim Ciano. Loving grandson of Mary De Marino and uncle of Samantha, Dominique & Thomas Ciano Jr. Visiting Friday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Cassidy Funeral Home, 156 Willis Avenue, Mineola, New York. Prayer services 10:30 AM Saturday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Andy Logan, the longtime New York City Hall reporter for The New Yorker, referred imprecisely to her tenure. While her column, About City Hall, appeared from 1969 to 1994 and she was the acknowledged dean of the City Hall press corps for the last 20 years of that time, she wrote about municipal affairs both before and after the life of the column.

title: Unpredictably, Fassel Foretells Playoffs for Giants
description: Jim Fassel, the Mister Rogers of football coaches, tore off his cardigan today, tied it around his head and joined the Hell's Angels.

title: Mutombo Is Considering Knicks
description: Admitting that he was growing more and more frustrated with the Atlanta Hawks' unsuccessful rebuilding efforts, Dikembe Mutombo said today that he had spoken with Patrick Ewing about what it was like to play for the Knicks.

title: No Cable? No D.S.L.? Try Satellite
description: IBRAHIM MARDAM-BEY, an international corporate financier, recently decided he could not live another day without a fast connection to the Internet from his home in Bethesda, Md. After giving up on the wait for a digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., he became a beta tester early last month for a new two-way satellite service from StarBand, a startup company in McLean, Va.

title: The First Boat People
description: To the Editor:

title: GETRONICS FORECASTS LOSS
description: Shares of Getronics fell 42 percent after the company, which is Europe's third-largest computer services provider, said that it would lose money in the first half of next year. Spending by businesses spending on installing and maintaining new computer systems and software is not rising as quickly as anticipated, Getronics said. The company said that it would spend 35 million euros ($29 million) next year to expand its business software offerings to help industries seeking to enter electronic commerce. It forecast lower profit for this year. The share price fell 5.24 euros, to 7.36.

title: Petke to Try Out With Bayern
description: The MetroStars' Mike Petke, a popular defender whose contract with Major League Soccer expires on Dec. 31, will leave on Sunday for Germany and a one-week tryout at Bayern Munich.

title: Keeper of the Flame for a Master of Light; Joanna Steichen, Widow of the Legendary Photographer, Basks in His Legacy
description: From the Whitney Museum of American Art to the Howard Greenberg Gallery in SoHo to the windows and walls of Bergdorf Goodman, New York is an Edward Steichen festival. His pioneering photography is also being celebrated in ''Steichen's Legacy: Photographs, 1895-1973,'' a new book by his widow, Joanna. The book is a large, lavish exhibition within hard covers of the most memorable Steichen pictures across the 20th century.

title: Mobile Robot Spy Can Keep An Eye on a House or a Human
description: It may not bark when the FedEx truck pulls into the driveway, but a new robot can keep an eye on things in the home. Probotics, Inc., a company based in Pittsburgh, has introduced Spy-Cye, a 10-pound, 16-inch by 10-inch by 5-inch personal robot with a built-in video camera that can be controlled to move around a house, take pictures and transmit them to an away-from-home user over the Web.

title: Colonists' Travails in Earliest Virginia
description: BIG CHIEF ELIZABETH

title: TOP EXECUTIVES QUIT NETGRAPHE AFTER STOCK FALLS
description: The top two executives of Netgraphe Inc., a Montreal-based Web site operator controlled by Quebecor, have resigned, the company said. Pierre Simon, the chairman of Netgraphe, and Normand Drolet, the chief executive, left the company after its stock had fallen about 86 percent from its February high. The chief executive will not be replaced, Quebecor said; the parent company named its chief operating officer, Monique Leroux, as Netgraphe chairman.

title: Gore Camp Vows to Contest Miami-Dade Ballot Results
description: Vice President Al Gore's efforts to win the presidency suffered another setback this afternoon when the Supreme Court of Florida denied his campaign's appeal to force Miami-Dade County to resume its manual recount. The campaign responded with a vow to contest the results of the Miami-Dade vote.

title: Chambliss Hired To Manage in AAA
description: The Florida Marlins named Chris Chambliss manager of their Class AAA affiliate Calgary Cannons. Chambliss was fired as the Yankee batting coach earlier this month after five seasons on Joe Torre's staff. He had been considered for managerial positions in Arizona and Los Angeles before leaving the Yankees. (Bloomberg News)

title: Aardvark And Pals Celebrate
description: As the families in a placid-looking suburb prepare for Christmas, children and adults alike feel overwhelmed by anxiety. A divorced mother neurotically wakes up early day after day to prepare presents and a special breakfast for her son, and then wearily falls back in bed when she realizes that she's too early by a few days -- once again. A Christmas party causes a rift among close friends. Disappointment seems to be the prevailing holiday spirit.

title: Health Care for All
description: To the Editor:

title: A Wild Day in Miami, With an End to Recounting, and Democrats' Going to Court
description: After a furious demonstration by Republicans, Miami-Dade County election officials stunned both sides in the bitter contest for Florida's presidential vote and decided unanimously today to end their recount of 654,000 ballots.

title: As Violence Flares in Kosovo, U.N. Aide Says 'Crisis' Persists
description: Yugoslav authorities warned today that the region could be facing the risk of a new war after violence grew with attacks on Serbian targets in Kosovo and southern Serbia.

title: 2 Airlines Seek to Press Court Actions on Unions
description: United Airlines and Northwest Airlines returned to federal court today to seek enforcement of orders they received in the last week barring their mechanics from disrupting flights.

title: The Thanksgiving Call
description: Before dinner begins, whenever it begins, there is always a tally of the present and the absent on Thanksgiving. On this day nearly every family considers for a moment the way it has expanded and dispersed, in directions no one could have predicted when it was still a knot of children around a table. The very idea that they could have grown up and struck out into the world on their own seems exotic, and so the stories of the children who married and settled almost next door feel as strange and involved as the stories of the children who cast themselves to the wind and are living half a globe away, doing jobs that didn't exist when they were born, or five years ago for that matter.

title: Democrats -- Bush's Assumptions Seen as Arrogant
description: Sometimes Ken Miller's mind is working overtime, worrying about the state of democracy, poring over the daily -- no, hourly -- changes in the election in Florida, and as a die-hard Democrat, he is incredulous at what he says is the Republicans' hubris in assuming that their candidate has won the White House.

title: In Week 11, Adelphi Strike Takes Its Toll On University
description: In the classes and the cafeterias, it looks like campus life as usual. But in the offices of Adelphi University, books and supplies are not being ordered, paid for or delivered on time. Since support staff members went on strike in September, students have been having difficulty making appointments with their advisers as the time for choosing next term's classes approaches. And some staff members are worrying that the university may be set back in its effort to recover from a crisis three years ago in which its leaders were fired.

title: Shares Fall on Fears That Technology Growth May Slow
description: Stocks resumed their broad slide yesterday in a session that experienced sudden shifts in response to the legal battle over Florida's presidential vote and felt the weight of concerns about the profits of technology companies.

title: OUT OF WIRELESS AUCTION
description: Because Deutsche Telekom does not already have customers and networks in France, it will not bid for one of the country's four next-generation wireless voice and data licenses after all, the company said.t Deutsche Telekom said earlier this month that it would focus on France after pulling out of Switzerland's license auction because of mounting debt; it also abstained from Italy's auction, which was abruptly broken off.

title: No Excuses As Knicks Just Avoid A Blowout
description: No amount of excuses can absolve the Knicks of the horrible basketball crimes they committed tonight. Not injuries to the starters Marcus Camby and Charlie Ward, not the fact that they were playing less than 24 hours after a draining, come-from-behind victory over the Orlando Magic, not even the presence of Dikembe Mutombo in the opponents' lineup.

title: Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America; Not Theirs to Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets May Lead the League in Questions
description: Mets General Manager Steve Phillips spoke to the news media by telephone yesterday, but the only announcement was a minor league transaction that shrunk the Mets' 40-man roster to 36. The Mets have open spots and offers to pitchers to fill them, but the coming weekend may be tense for the National League champions.

title: Republicans -- Frustration At Court Moves
description: Duplicating some documents at a copying center, Norman Kramer suddenly realized that the machine right under his hand was a good way to take out his frustration over the deepening confusion and inconclusiveness of Florida's struggle to settle the presidential election.

title: Can Be Added as Needed
description: ''Our clients really love this stuff, so we figured we should give them more of it,'' said Jayme Sklar, the proprietor of Foundation, a contemporary furniture store in Brooklyn. She was referring to the stylish yet practical furnishings of Blu Dot, a Minneapolis company that takes the affordable 50's designs of Charles and Ray Eames as its guiding spirit. The Dot Spot, a Blu Dot store-within-a-store, opened recently in Foundation's basement, and Charlie Lazor, a partner in Blu Dot, said he hopes the idea will catch on. Foundation's large selection of Blu Dot goods includes the Modulicious storage units ($550 for two drawers, far left; $850 for four compartments; and $1,200 for two drawers and four compartments, right). The Clip-Top coffee table, foreground, is $400; 329 Atlantic Avenue (at Smith Street); (718) 403-9757, or www.foundationny.com.

title: Emil Zatopek, 78, Ungainly Running Star, Dies
description: Emil Zatopek, perhaps the greatest distance runner ever and surely the most ungainly, died yesterday in Prague. He was 78 years old.

title: Undersea Cable Break Shows Internet Vulnerability
description: The break in a key undersea cable link between Australia and Singapore this week underlines the vulnerability of global telecommunication networks and the need for access to alternatives in case of emergencies, executives said Wednesday.

title: WALKER DIGITAL CUTS STAFF
description: Walker Digital, the technology incubator that created the Priceline .com ''name your price'' concept for buying airline tickets and other items online, has laid off 100 of the 125 employees at its Stamford, Conn., headquarters after failing to raise capital, said Kevin Goldman, a spokesman for Jay Walker, founder of Walker Digital. The company's remaining employees will focus on licensing Walker Digital's existing intellectual properties and the commercialization of several businesses currently in development, including Retail DNA, a dynamic pricing company in New York, Mr. Goldman said. Three early-stage companies started by Walker Digital -- High Circle in Los Angeles, Atlantis in Atlanta and Pulse 123 in San Francisco -- have been closed. Earlier this month, Priceline cut 87 jobs, or about 16 percent of its work force. WebHouse Club, an Internet gasoline and grocery bidding service that licensed the Priceline concept, said it would wind down operations by the end of the year. Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: Company Is Told to Stay and Face New Union
description: The Quadrtech Corporation could have been just another company relocating to Mexico in search of cheaper wages and lower operating costs. But a federal judge, acting on a union complaint, has blocked the company's plans and ordered it to stay in California, a decision that has delighted union officials and worried manufacturers.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Calamondin Calamity

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLOOM, BERNARD D., D.D.S.
description: BLOOM-Bernard D., D.D.S. April 11, 1922-November 23, 1992. Eight years ago today. Alive in our hearts always. Jack

title: Library Trains Dot-Com Pros to Teach Computer Skills
description: ON a recent Saturday afternoon, five dot-com executives gathered at the Harlem Branch Library on 124th Street in Manhattan to perform a bit of public service. They were there to teach local children how to make the best use of the library's computers during a two-hour session called Web Searching for Teens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIT, ALBERT
description: HEIT-Albert. Distinguished entertainment attorney, on November 21, 2000. A 1934 graduate of Cornell Law School and an avid alumni supporter, Mr. Heit handled business affairs for film producer Sam Spiegel for 35 years. He is survived by his beloved wife, Natalie, brother, Murray, his niece, Berit, nephew, Jay. Donations can be sent to The South Salem Library, South Salem, NY. Services Friday, 1 PM November 24 at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave

title: Minimum Sentence Sought For Doctor Who Killed Wife
description: Lawyers for a plastic surgeon who was convicted of murdering his wife and dumping her body from a plane have asked a judge for the minimum sentence of 15 years to life.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR EDGES UP. The dollar was little changed against major currencies. In New York, the euro settled at 84.33 cents, down from 84.34 cents on Tuesday; the dollar traded at 110.25 yen, up from 110.16 yen.

title: INTERNET ACQUISITION TALKS
description: Wanadoo, the Internet subsidiary of France Telecom, said it was in talks to buy Freeserve, Britain's biggest Internet service provider, which has lost money on advertising and on subsidizing the telephone bills of some of its two million customers. Freeserve said it was discussing an all-stock deal but would not confirm that Wanadoo would be the buyer. The deal could be worth up to $2.6 billion. Dixons Group, an electronics dealer, owns 80 percent of Freeserve. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Excerpt From Bush's Comments on Ruling by Top Florida Court
description: Following is an excerpt from comments by Gov. George W. Bush at a news conference yesterday in Austin, Tex., as recorded by eMedia MillWorks Inc., a private transcription service:

title: AMRO PAYING $2.7 BILLION FOR MICHIGAN NATIONAL
description: ABN Amro Holding, the largest bank in the Netherlands, announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Michigan National Corporation, a bank holding company in Farmington Hills, Mich., from National Australia Bank Ltd. for $2.75 billion. Amro owns banks in Troy, Mich., and Chicago as well as the European American Bank in New York. National Australia bought Michigan National in 1995 for $1.56 billion, its first bank in the United States; it has since acquired a Florida mortgage lender, HomeSide Inc.

title: Prowling And Spying With Nancy Drew, The Un-Barbie
description: WHILE it's common for computer games to hold sway over boys all through adolescence and into adulthood, it seems that girls tend to lose interest much earlier, preferring such low-tech activities as playing with their friends or reading. That has produced a male population comfortable with and knowledgeable about computers and a female population that is popularly thought to be a little behind the technological curve.

title: Mystery Ailment Kills Hundreds of Geese in New Jersey
description: Hundreds of small maritime geese called Atlantic brants have been found dead in the last eight days in a coastal wildlife refuge near Atlantic City, prompting officials to shut part of the preserve and urge hunters not to shoot or eat any of the birds.

title: Rap Is Slower Around Houston
description: ''In the city of syrup we like to jam music slow,'' raps Big Moe. The line, from his album ''City of Syrup,'' is as concise a statement of purpose as one is likely to find for one of the most interesting, little known regional genres of popular music today. The city Big Moe is referring to is Houston, and in the last several years music and the drug culture have been colliding to produce what is known as syrup music or Screw music, after the producer who has almost single-handedly popularized the style, D.J. Screw.

title: They Don't Just Hang There
description: In the city's tight living spaces, extra seating that can be easily tucked away is an asset. The clever Seat Storage (above) from Freecell -- a collaborative run by the architects Lauren Crahan, John Hartmann and Troy Ostrander -- does more to earn its keep than the typical folding chair. The 16-inch-square painted enamel stools turn into covers for a nine-cubby wall unit, solving two problems in one cubist design. It was the Shaker tradition of wall-hung chairs, Ms. Crahan said, that inspired the idea of stools that can be removed from the floor. The nine-cube grid, 52 inches square, has birch plywood shelves, and the ultralight fiberboard stools are painted in three glossy shades of blue. Seat Storage was introduced this month at the Chicago Design Show and retails for $3,000 through Freecell, New York: www.freecellcollective.com, or (917) 567-7150.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMELIN, DAVID B.
description: HERMELIN-David B. The officers, Board of Trustees, and staff of United Jewish Communities deeply mourn the passing of Ambassador David B. Hermelin, a beloved friend and colleague, one of the world's great philanthropic leaders, and a devoted supporter of Israel and the Jewish people. A renowned local, national and international leader, David's dedication to many charitable causes was legendary, and his commitment lives on in the work of many institutions in Israel and his own community of Detroit. He was a UJA National Vice Chairman, member of the Board of Trustees and Campaign Cabinet, and served as Chairman of the Israel 50th Anniversary Committee. He served as International Chairman of State of Israel Bonds, President Emeritus of World ORT Union and President of American ORT Federation. David's leadership also included the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, Hebrew University, Weizmann Institute, Bar-Ilan University, HIAS, and United Synagogue for Conservative Judaism. Locally, he played leading roles as Vice President of the Jewish Federation of Metropolitan Detroit, Chairman of the Federation's Annual Campaign, President of the Jewish Home and Aging Services, President of Congregation Shaarey Zedek, Board Member of Children's Hospital of Michigan, National Co-Chair for Major Gifts at the University of Michigan from which he received an Honorary Doctorate, Chairman of the Special Advisory Council of the Karmanos Cancer Institute, and much more. He was nominated by President Clinton in October 1997 to serve as America's Ambassador to Norway, a position he held until January 2000, when he resigned for medical reasons. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Doreen, their five children and five grandchildren. Charles R. Bronfman, Chairman of the Board Joel D. Tauber, Chairman, Executive Committee Stephen D. Solender, President and CEO

title: Gorton Is Defeated
description: Maria Cantwell appears to have defeated Slade Gorton, the Republican incumbent, in the Senate race in Washington. The Senate will be evenly divided unless Joseph I. Lieberman is elected vice president.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARASZTY, ESZTER
description: HARASZTY-Eszter. Born September 28, 1920, died November 24, 1994. You made the world more beautiful for all to see. Rumpole, Slippers, Bruce

title: Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America
description: To the Editor:

title: INVENSYS SPINOFF PLANNED
description: A British automation and controls company, Invensys, said it would spin off its fastest-growing business, power systems. Initial investor enthusiasm for the plan quickly faded because of concerns that the spinoff would do too little to increase profits at the company, formed by the 1998 merger of BTR and Siebe. Slowing construction in the United States, adverse currency movements and the recent $643 million acquisition of Baan, a money-losing Dutch company that makes software, have hurt earnings, the company said. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: New York and Its Jazz
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Alone: Short-Sheeting the Guest Room
description: TWENTY years ago, when David Easton first saw the ramshackle artist's studio on the property he later bought near Tuxedo Park, N.Y., he invented the fantasy he now calls ''Bloomsbury.''

title: Humanoids That Can Do Tricks, Kick a Ball and Climb the Stairs
description: Perhaps envisioning the day when there is a robot in every living room, Sony and Honda are introducing prototypes of humanoid robots at the Robodex 2000 exhibition in Yokohama, Japan, on Friday.

title: Bush Files Suit to Restore Rejected Military Ballots
description: Gov. George W. Bush sued election officials in 13 Florida counties today for rejecting the absentee ballots of members of the military serving abroad, capitalizing on an issue that has been a public relations boon to the Republicans and that could determine the fate of hundreds of votes for the presidency.

title: A Forgotten Monument To Carousing And Clanging
description: It's easy to poke fun at ''verismo'' opera, the slice-of-life approach to operatic storytelling. The aim of the Italian verismo composers at the turn of the 20th century was to write emotionally raw operas with realistic depictions of everyday people. The movement gave us a small repertory of enduring operas by Puccini, Mascagni and others. But what about all the hyper-charged and hammy melodramas that were also churned out?

title: Cantwell Declared Washington Victor
description: Maria Cantwell, a 42-year-old Democrat who made a fortune with a high-tech company and campaigned as champion of the new economy, has been named the winner of what had been the nation's last undecided Senate race, defeating the three-term Republican incumbent, Slade Gorton of Washington, by just under 2,000 votes.

title: Bush Motion Cites Fear of 'Disruption,' Saying 'Presidency Itself Is at Stake'
description: Following are excerpts from two filings in the United States Supreme Court by the Bush campaign and others, the first seeking expedited handing of an appeal of a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, and the second the appeal itself:

title: Finding Strength In Home and Hymn; Pulled From Streets a Year Ago, A Man Rebuilds and Reflects
description: Some things about Raymond Lawrence have changed hardly at all in the last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, SEYMOUR (PHILIP)
description: ROTHMAN-Seymour (Philip). On Wednesday, November 22, 2000. Beloved brother of Frances Rabinowitz and Estelle Sabsels. Loved and respected uncle and great-uncle to many nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. Respected friend of Kendall Shaw. Graveside service Friday, November 24, at 12:30PM at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ..

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday of J. Russell Wiggins, a former editor of The Washington Post and United States ambassador to the United Nations, misstated his birth date. It was Dec. 4, 1903, not 1904.

title: Democrats Face Setback in Miami
description: With only five days left before all vote recounts in Florida must be completed, attention turned yesterday to court appeals and Dick Cheney's heart attack. Here is a summary of the day's events.

title: Istanbul Journal; Ataturk Slept Here: Hallowed Yacht Can Be Rented
description: The spot is scarcely larger than a dime, a coppery blush against the white of a soft cotton coverlet. But the stain is a relic of mythic dimensions, and visitors often drop to their knees in tears at the sight of it.

title: Blacks -- A Seesaw Unsettles Some Black Voters
description: A dash of cynicism peppered the mostly optimistic views of a number of African-American New Yorkers yesterday in the wake of the Florida Supreme Court's ruling upholding hand recounts in three counties.

title: Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America; Not My President
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto-Parts Trade Pact Reached
description: After months of deadlock, Brazil and Argentina reached an agreement over car parts that clears an important hurdle in the path toward a free trade agreement for automobiles within the Mercosur trade bloc by 2006.

title: Talk Radio -- They're on the Air, And Up in Arms
description: The roller coaster of the presidential race gave talk-radio hosts a chance to vent, puzzle and advocate today. But many of their callers sounded simply exasperated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAUL, BOB
description: SAUL-Bob. Happy Birthday. We love you. We miss you. Love, Nancy & Elizabeth

title: Mafia Informer's 2nd Appeal Says His Plea Deal Was Undercut
description: For a Mafia warlord it was a cozy bargain. Facing life imprisonment on murder and racketeering charges, Anthony Salvatore Casso agreed in 1994 to become a turncoat witness for the government in exchange for a lenient sentence.

title: Zimmer Is Granted Recount In House Race Against Holt
description: A judge in New Jersey Superior Court yesterday granted Republicans' request for a recount in the state's 12th Congressional District, where the Democratic incumbent, Representative Rush Holt, has already declared victory.

title: The Sky Garden of the Ornament King
description: AT the beginning of the movie ''The Talented Mr. Ripley,'' audiences glimpse a panorama of Central Park from the kind of rooftop garden God might have created had he wanted a penthouse on the West Side. Christopher Radko, an entrepreneur whose empire is based on molded glass Christmas ornaments, has such a view from his home on Central Park West.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, LARS, ERIK
description: NELSON-Lars-Erik . ''The Wandering Minstrel''. Unique voice. Brilliant journalist. Keen thinker. Warm, witty, caring. We'll miss his song. June Tauber Golden Bronx H.S. of Science, Class of '59

title: Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America; A Dark Chain of Events
description: To the Editor:

title: Reckless Republican Rhetoric
description: George W. Bush has a right to register his unhappiness about the rulings of the Florida Supreme Court, but the increasingly bellicose statements made by the Texas governor and his aides ill serve the nation. By all but declaring that the presidential election will be illegitimate if Mr. Bush does not win, and hinting that the Florida Legislature should somehow neutralize the Supreme Court's decisions, the Bush campaign risks undermining the rule of law and the office he hopes to occupy.

title: Making a List by Scanning Things Twice
description: WHEN I shop, I browse more than I buy for one reason: fear.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Device Helps the Blind Avoid Clothes That Clash
description: For the blind, getting dressed poses a series of logistical problems. Careful organization -- or a limited wardrobe -- is necessary for avoiding fashion faux pas such as clashing colors.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Decline on Concern Over Election and Profits

title: WCM MAKES AN OFFER FOR REST OF KLOCKNER-WERKE
description: WCM Beteiligungs-und Grundbesitz A.G., an investment company in Hamburg, Germany, offered yesterday to acquire the part of Klockner-Werke A.G., a foil and packaging maker, that it did not own. The offer values Klockner at about 1.15 billion euros ($970 million); WCM owns slightly less than half of the company. Shareholders of Klockner would receive one share of WCM and 7 euros for each Klockner share held, equivalent to 23.9 euros at yesterday's closing price; Klockner, of Duisburg, Germany, closed at 23.2 euros.

title: Big Run By Suns Too Much For Nets
description: When Stephon Marbury landed softly from his soaring alley-oop dunk two minutes into the second half, he sent a penetrating glare toward the Phoenix Suns' bench, as if to warn the Suns to believe.

title: Fox Follows Up on Pledge Of Diverse Mexican Cabinet
description: Following on his promise to build a government that is representative of his country's 100 million men and women, President-elect Vicente Fox Quesada began announcing today the names of an eclectic mix of people who will be in his cabinet.

title: Explosion of Generics About to Occur in Brazil
description: Maria de Jesus Viana may have saved only a dollar, but the discovery she made could eventually be worth much, much more.

title: Troops Kill 4 in Gaza; 2 Die in Car Bombing in Israel
description: A powerful car bomb killed two Israelis and wounded scores during rush hour in the coastal city of Hadera this evening. Prime Minister Ehud Barak immediately pledged that Israel would ''get even'' for a ''barbaric'' attack that took the current violence into the country's heartland.

title: A Winner Makes a Boast, and Delivers
description: A most remarkable string of successes has been compiled by Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif., in the last three years. On Saturday at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here, she won the Life Master Open Pairs title with Steve Garner of Chicago, who had himself won a bronze medal in the World Teams in Maastricht, the Netherlands, in September. She added this to a victory a year earlier in the Blue Ribbon Pairs with John Mohan of Christiansted, V.I. Both these titles had been won just once before by a woman.

title: STRIKE THREAT IN ARGENTINA
description: A confederation that includes most of Argentina's labor unions plans a 36-hour strike starting at noon today to protest the government's spending cuts, failure to revive the economy and changes in the health care system. Argentina has been in a two-year recession; the spending cuts planned by the government are meant to meet conditions set by the International Monetary Fund for new credits to help the country pay its $123.5 billion in debt.

title: Sports of The Times; Millennium Thank-You Messages
description: IN a year when the Yankees and the Mets created a Subway Series, the Devils won the Stanley Cup, and both the Giants and the Jets might make the Super Bowl playoffs, Thanksgiving is the time to remember those who make sports' little corner of the world a better place:

title: A.& P. Moves to Halt Grand Union Sale
description: A.&P. Supermarkets is seeking to halt the sale of 185 stores of its bankrupt competitor, Grand Union, charging in bankruptcy court that the auction last week was marked by secret deals and collusion.

title: CBS Cancels 'City of Angels'
description: CBS has canceled ''City of Angels,'' its hourlong Thursday night hospital drama, network executives announced yesterday.

title: Peru's New Chief Sworn In, Vowing to Revive Democracy
description: The veteran legislator Valentin Paniagua was sworn in as interim president of Peru today, ending a decade of authoritarian rule by Alberto K. Fujimori that defeated two terrorist rebellions but failed to repair the country's endemic instability.

title: Article 2000112391591842892 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RHODES, JOHN B., SR.
description: RHODES-John B., Sr. The Board of Trustees of The New York Institute for Special Education (founded in 1831 at The New York Institute for the Education of the Blind) records with deep regret the death of its beloved and distinguished member. Mr. Rhodes was a dedicated friend of the Institute. He ably assisted in its growth as a Trustee and member of numerous committees for 25 years. His guidance in long-range planning and his important contribution to the establishment of our Cornerstone Literary Program was invaluable. His friendship will be sorely missed. Our sympathy is extended to his wife, Joan, and to his family. The Board of Trustees and Staff The New York Institute for Special Education

title: INSIDE
description: Fatal Bombing in Israel

title: Screen Savers as Artists' Medium
description: JAMES BUCKHOUSE wants to brighten your office with a little art. But put away the thumbtacks. You will need an Internet-connected computer to install these works.

title: Essay; As Good as It Gets
description: With a tie vote and that's what we have, no matter what the final count -- who's to decide who won the national election? Not the Florida secretary of state on her own say-so, despite the plain language of the law, because she's a partisan Republican.

title: For Texas and Other States, A Bump Is Sometimes a Vote
description: Last Monday morning, county officials gathered on the second floor of the Smith County Office Building in Tyler, Tex., for a hand recount requested by Bill Hollowell, a Republican who had apparently lost his bid to unseat an incumbent Democratic state representative.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Lars-Erik Nelson, columnist for The Daily News, listed his survivors incompletely. They also include his brothers, Nils-Peter, of Martinsville, N.J.; Randolph, of Point Reyes, Calif.; and Linde, of Stony Point, N.Y.

title: Metro Business Briefing; BUILDING BOOM PREDICTED
description: A New Jersey construction-industry group has predicted that a record $20.4 billion in public and private projects will be built in the state next year and the year after. The trade group, the New Jersey Alliance for Action, said the largest amount, $3.1 billion, would be for school, construction, most of it in the state's poorer districts, followed by $2.6 billion for industrial and office projects, and $2.1 billion for utility construction. The group could not say how accurate its 1998-99 projections turned out to be. Steve Strunsky

title: 2 Allies of Jeb Bush at Helm of Florida Legislature
description: As the Florida Legislature prepares to take a role in the disputed presidential election, the key decision of whether to call a special session will depend on two allies of Gov. Jeb Bush -- John McKay, the president of the State Senate, and Tom Feeney, the House speaker, who was Mr. Bush's running mate in 1994.

title: Davis's 'Soft' Hoosiers Are Pounded by Temple
description: The Mike Davis era was advertised as the quiet epilogue to Bob Knight's stormy tenure as Indiana's basketball coach. That does not mean that Davis lacks a strong personality or is afraid to unleash it on his players.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP. and J. P Morgan & Co. announced that shareholders for the companies will vote on a merger on Dec. 22. The combined company, to be named J. P. Morgan Chase & Co., would have assets of about $660 billion.

title: Unwild But Woolly
description: WHEN the weather turns wintry, there's nothing like the feel of fur. Fortunately, the longing can be indulged without cost to animals.

title: QUINTUS FIRES CHAIRMAN AND PLANS TO RESTATE REVENUE
description: The Quintus Corporation announced yesterday that it had dismissed its chairman and chief executive, Alan Anderson, and would restate its revenue downward by $13.5 million over the last three quarters after an audit showed that the company had relied on falsified documents. Quintus reported revenue of $51.7 million in its 2000 fiscal year, which ended in March; the adjustments affect the last quarter of fiscal 2000 and the first two in fiscal 2001, with more than half the reduction in the most recent quarter. Quintus provides e-mail and Internet systems to corporate customers. It announced last week that it would delay filing a quarterly report while it conducted an audit. Mr. Anderson had been placed on leave during the audit.

title: The $4,800 Handbag Under the Tree; Another Jolly Season for Luxury Goods
description: While most Americans would be content with a Sony Playstation 2 or a sweater twin set under the tree, for an increasing number of people mere cashmere does not say ''I love you'' with quite the same authority as pashmina. Accustomed to luxury, these new-economy swells expect the most expensive version of everything -- and are likely to get it.

title: Strong Opinions From Voters Watching Story Unfold
description: When Miami-Dade County election officials called off their hand count of presidential ballots today, Isabel Cordoves did not quite know how to react. She had voted for Gov. George W. Bush and opposed all recounts, but if Broward and Palm Beach Counties were still going ahead with theirs, she wondered, would it be fair to Miami-Dade voters to give up the recount here?

title: It's Hard to Count Out The Jets' Ailing Martin
description: The Jets got the best possible news about Curtis Martin today, when the running back was listed as questionable -- 50-50 -- to play against the Chicago Bears on Sunday with a muscle strain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMBERG, STUART
description: ZIMBERG-Stuart. Thank you for all the wonderful times we've had together. You were not only a close cousin, but a closer friend. We will all miss you. Barbara & Bernie, Lisa & Stacey

title: In America; Breaking Faith
description: George W. Bush and the Republicans are coming dangerously close to breaking faith with the system.

title: Officer Contradicts Accounts of Others in Death of Suspect at Orange Police Station
description: An Orange, N.J., police officer who said he saw a suspect the night he died in police custody contradicted his fellow officers' written reports today, testifying that the suspect did not collapse after entering a room in Police Headquarters.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Assistant Pastor Is Charged in Theft At Brooklyn Church
description: The assistant pastor of a Brooklyn church was arrested yesterday and charged with burglary and grand larceny in the theft of more than $11,000 in cash and about $17,000 in checks from the church's safe, the police said.

title: Plywood Bends Over For a Stackable Chair
description: As chairman of Vitra Inc., the furniture maker, Rolf Fehlbaum (top) is often asked to judge student designs. He doesn't usually find new talent, but that's what happened when he saw work by Jakob Gebert (below). Mr. Fehlbaum discussed Mr. Gebert's chair, Taino, which Vitra will offer for about $490: 149 Fifth Avenue (22nd Street), (212) 539-1900.

title: We Now Join the 2001 Campaign for Mayor, Which Is Already in Progress
description: On Election Day, Mark Green, New York City's public advocate, sent more than 300 volunteers to polling stations around the city to pass out fliers asking people to vote for his fellow Democrats: Al Gore for president and Hillary Rodham Clinton for the United States Senate.

title: OIL PIPELINE COMPLETE
description: A $2.5 billion pipeline to carry oil from the Tengiz fields of Kazakhstan across Russia to Novorossisk on the Black Sea has been finished, its builders say. Its completion gives Russia an edge over an American-backed alternative route through Georgia in a race to control oil shipments from the Caspian region. The group that built the new pipeline, made up of oil companies and the governments of Russia, Kazakhstan and Oman, said oil would begin flowing through the 560,000-barrel-a-day line in mid-2001. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: JUDGE CLEARS CARGILL IN GRAIN OPTIONS CASE
description: A federal administrative law judge has dismissed government charges that Cargill Inc., the giant food processor, illegally sold options for the future delivery of grain. In August 1999, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission accused Cargill of offering grain contracts, called premium offer contracts, that were neither traded on a regulated commodity exchange nor sold by an options merchant registered with the commission, making them illegal. But the judge, Bruce C. Levine, found that the contracts, developed by Cargill to help it and the farmers who sell it grain guard against the risk of violent price swings, were more akin to forward contracts, which were permitted and outside the agency's jurisdiction.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: On the Run And in Concert

title: Where It Goes; Breaking Down All Those Computers: Glass Over Here, Plastic There
description: COMPUTER components have changed over the years, but a PC today is typically 40 percent steel, 30 percent to 40 percent plastic, 10 percent aluminum and 10 percent other metals, including copper, gold, silver, cadmium and platinum. A monitor adds glass and lead to the components.

title: A Design Controversy Goes Cozy.com.
description: ''I would invite you to know something about me,'' said Christopher Alexander, the creator of ''A Pattern Language,'' the 1977 folk bible for home builders, lay people and professionals alike. ''Design is not really my thing.''

title: African Drumbeats That Shout Out in Celebration
description: The elegant revelers at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Sunday night were not fazed by the fact that Youssou N'Dour and his band, Super Etoile, took the stage at 10:30, despite the workweek looming only hours away. This mostly African crowd considered a visit by Mr. N'Dour, a Senegalese singer, an international holiday, and the energy in the room kept rising until the lights came up two hours after midnight.

title: BUSH TAKES APPEAL TO U.S. SUPREME COURT; CHENEY IN HOSPITAL WITH MILD HEART ATTACK
description: Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, suffered a mild heart attack early this morning, raising anew questions about his health and adding even more uncertainty to an already tense and confused election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISERT, ISRAEL J.
description: EISERT-Israel J. on November 21, beloved husband of the late Bess, loving father of Cheryl Dreyfus, husband Richard, and Edward G. Eisert, cherished grandfather of Jonathan, Deborah, Carolyn and Stephen, dear brother of Otto, Yetta, Pearl and Jack. Mr. Eisert was a Manhattan lawyer, civic leader of the Chelsea-Clinton Community, and former head of the Torts Division of the NYC Transit Authority. He served 5 terms as President of Cong. Emunath Israel over 3 decades beginning in 1951 and served as President of the Chelsea Community Planning Board. Mr. Eisert, a 1936 graduate of NYU School of Law, served as Class President for more than 40 years. Services Friday, November 24, 11:45AM, Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 Street.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America; A Victory for Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Unanimous in Tallahassee, Divided in America; To U.S. Supreme Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Luckiest Holiday Travelers Are Happy Non-Campers
description: On the rapid-transit train to Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport, at 4:15 p.m. yesterday, Michael K. McNeil sat calmly with a large suitcase and a rolling carry-on, thinking maybe he should have packed a little lighter for his 5:35 flight to Rome, where he hoped to spend Thanksgiving with his in-laws in nearby Peruggia -- if he made the flight.

title: After Fujimori, a Quiet Peacemaker
description: Peru's new president, Valentin Paniagua, a soft-spoken man known for his modesty, has been politically active since he was a law student in the 1950's. He is a member of the Popular Action party, which dominated Peruvian politics in the 1960's and early 80's but is now a shadow of its former self.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUER, PHILLIP
description: FEUER-Phillip. The officers and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the untimely passing of Phillip Feuer whose life embodied the world of our values and the compassion of our mission. As a member of our Commission on Jewish Identity and Renewal and our Westchester Business and Professionals Group, he was a beacon of righteous deeds and Jewish community leadership. His dedication to those in need was as passionate as his devotion to his family. Our deepest sympathies go to his loving wife, Sarene Shanus; his two teenage daughters, Rose and Abigail; his brother, Marvin; his sister, Susan; and the extended Feuer & Shanus families. May all who benefited from Phillip's kindness and wisdom be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair Marion Blumenthal, Chair, Commission on Jewish Identity & Renewal John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: CURRENTS: STORAGE SOLUTIONS; To Divide a Room, They Took a Sink. Then They Took a Few More.
description: Most people store dirty dishes in their sinks. The Manhattan architecture firm LOT/EK, known for ingenious adaptations of truck tanks and cargo containers, transformed 16 workaday stainless steel sinks into storage cubbies, below, for Edizioni Press, a publisher of architecture and design books. The publisher asked LOT/EK's principals, Ada Tolla and Giuseppe Lignano, to create room dividers that could double as storage and display units. Ms. Tolla and Mr. Lignano lined up 12-inch-deep industrial sinks in an aluminum frame grid, using amber-colored rubber to hide bolts and seams. The architects painted the bottoms of the sinks with bright orange automotive paint. ''The existing space was very elegant, with gray walls and hardwood floors, but it needed a punch of color,'' Mr. Lignano said. The idea came from the architects' own studio. ''We had a very deep sink and thought it would be great for storing books and files,'' he said.

title: Rangers Own New York, for Time Being
description: The rivalry is not as intense. The Rangers have not qualified for the postseason the last three seasons and the Islanders have not reached the playoffs the last six. But they still bring out the best in each other.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday about the new cabinet taking form in Mexico described the incoming foreign minister, Jorge G. Castaneda, as a ''strident leftist.'' While he has taken leftist positions, his views are not doctrinaire; he should not have been described that way.

title: Validity of Dimpled Ballots Will Be Assessed One by One
description: On the day before Broward County election officials were to begin the hotly contested manual recounting of dimpled ballots, Democratic and Republican lawyers made a last-ditch effort today to win votes for their presidential candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBICHEK, NORMA
description: ROBICHEK-Norma, 74. Of San Clemente, CA., on November 17, 2000. Born in New York City on December 24, 1925. Survived by three children, daughter Jane, son Mark and daughter Sue.

title: Here's an Excuse to Have a Party: E-Mail Invitation Sites
description: SENDING invitations to your annual eggnog party over the Web instead of the old-fashioned way has its advantages. For one thing, you can skip agonizing over whether to wait in line at the post office for the special holiday theme stamps or just buy the usual ''berry'' design from the vending machine.

title: Excerpts From Gore Petition to Florida High Court
description: Following are excerpts from a petition filed yesterday with the Florida Supreme Court by lawyers for Vice President Al Gore and the Democratic Party concerning a recount in Miami-Dade County:

title: Blair Criticizes Thatcher, Relegating Her to History
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair has marked the 10th anniversary of Margaret Thatcher's departure from office by abandoning his usual respectful references to her legacy and attacking her politics as dated and irrelevant to contemporary Britain.

title: A Full Plate For the Holidays
description: The movie industry has much to be thankful for.

title: MORE ON THE RECOUNT
description: OPTIONS NARROWING

title: Albright's Desire to Meet Yugoslav Leader Goes Unrequited
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright would like to meet the new leader of Yugoslavia, Vojislav Kostunica, who fulfilled one of her long-held ambitions: sweeping Yugoslavia's strongman, Slobodan Milosevic, from power. But it is not clear that he wants to meet her.

title: A Plucky New Life Made Of Hearts and Flowers
description: ''The Moving of Sophia Myles,'' a new television movie being offered by CBS on Sunday night, has one of those awkward, unhelpful titles that raise obvious and immediate questions. So to answer them straight away:

title: Dr. Louis Neel, 95, Physicist; Studied Aspects of Magnetism
description: Dr. Louis Neel, one of France's most distinguished physicists and a Nobel laureate for his discoveries about magnetic fields and their uses in everyday life, died last Friday in Brive-Correze, France. He was 95.

title: Correction; Alternative Schools Say Ruling On Tests Does Not Affect Them
description: A group of New York City alternative schools say they are not affected by a recent court decision that required students at two charter schools to take Regents exams.

title: DVD Land, Ever Expanding
description: When DVD was new (1997), distributors predicted that titles would explode in number and variety once 10 million DVD players were sold and the format seemed solid. That is now the case, but in fact a broad range of items have been appearing on disc for some time. A check of this month's releases, for example, finds ''The Nutcracker,'' with Rudolf Nureyev and the Royal Ballet; Fritz Lang's ''Destiny''; ''The Jazz Channel Presents Bobby Womack''; Merian C. Cooper and Ernest Schoedsack's ''Chang''; ''David Hockney at the Tate''; ''Cute Cavalcade of Christmas Cartoons''; and ''Kiss Toledo Goodbye,'' a mob comedy starring Christopher Walken, Michael Rapaport and Robert Forster as a crime boss named Sal Fortuna.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Giving section on Monday about the rise of urban park conservancies misstated the title of a recent report by an advocacy group, the Project for Public Spaces, that included an inventory of park organizations. It is ''Public Parks, Private Partners,'' not ''Public Parks, Private Spaces.''

title: Police Seek Record of Bookstore Patrons in Bid for Drug Charge
description: In the course of raiding a methamphetamine laboratory in a trailer home last March in the Denver suburb of Thornton, agents of a local drug task force found two books, ''Advanced Techniques of Clandestine Psychedelic and Amphetamine Manufacture'' by an author named Uncle Fester and ''The Construction and Operation of Clandestine Drug Laboratories'' by Jack B. Nimble.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Selling Status, And Cell Phones; Fierce Competition to Control The Wireless Market in China
description: The after school crowd was drifting into the Jegaxunlian phone store, and the staff was ready. Clad in shiny metallic windbreakers that made them look like refugees from ''Lost in Space,'' sales clerks swarmed over the young customers.

title: There's One Furry Creature Who Isn't Cute at Christmas
description: Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas

title: To Die For: Painting the Town Red, and the Capes and Nails Black
description: It's midnight, and we're in one of New York's vampire dens. The D.J. is spinning a band called Switchblade Symphony and a sexy black-clad vampiress with a bat tattooed on her belly is swaying to the music. Vampire couples are snuggling in the corners, and on the rare occasion that someone smiles we can make out the glint of white fangs.

title: Atget the Artist Adjacent to Atget the Classifier
description: ''The great thing about Eugene Atget is that we know almost nothing about him,'' John Szarkowski said in October at the International Center of Photography. We know what Atget looked like only because his distorted reflection occasionally appeared in the Paris shop windows he photographed and because Berenice Abbott took a few portraits of him as a bent old man, months before he died. The facts of his life are ''opaque'' and ''semireliable,'' Mr. Szarkowski, a former photography curator for the Museum of Modern Art, writes in ''Atget,'' his elegant new book. The photographs are left to do the talking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRMAN, EDITH K.
description: EHRMAN-Edith K. Died on November 21 after a long life and a short illness. Predeceased by her parents, Jesse and Edith G. Koshland; by her husband, Frederick L. Ehrman; by her daughters, Edith Ehrman and Anita L. Ehrman; and by her sisters, Ruth K. Hellman and Frances K. Skipsey. Survived by her nephew, F. Warren Hellman; by her niece, Nancy H. Bechtle; by six great nephews and great nieces; and by thirteen great great nephews and great great nieces. Passionately interested in and profoundly generous to a myriad of charitable organizations, including The New York University Medical Center; The Mount Sinai Medical Center; The Lincoln Center Theater; and Playwrights Horizons. There will not be a funeral service. There may be a memorial service at a time and place yet to be determined.

title: To Germans' Surprise, Koreans Look to Them as 'Role Model' : Revisiting Lessons of Reunification
description: DRESDEN  For all its lingering flaws and costs, Germany's shotgun reunification 10 years ago has found fervent admirers on the other side of the globe.

title: The Glib Critics of the Courts
description: No matter how one feels about the outcome of this election, there is reason to be concerned about some of the rhetoric we've been hearing regarding the role of courts in resolving the disputes over vote counting. Some commentators are treating the courts as if they were just one more partisan institution, staffed with political hacks who decide cases consistent with their parties' views. This kind of rhetoric threatens to undermine respect for the judicial system as a whole.

title: Pneumatic Car: Environmental Bonanza or a Lot of Hot Air?
description: WHEN considering the best power source for 21st-century vehicles, have the experts neglected the vast potential of the air around them? That is the assertion of Guy Negre, a French engineer whose previous experience was in designing high-performance Formula One racing engines for Renault and other teams.

title: Clinton in Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A Writer Is Reborn, His Halo in Place
description: Six years after his death, Harry Kondoleon is looking sharp. This brittle, theater-besotted playwright left specific instructions, it seems, for his reincarnation. So he is now on the stage of the Rattlestick Theater, in the borrowed flesh of the actor David Greenspan, wearing shiny red shoes, an impeccable suit and a manner as polished and piercing as the dialogue he wrote. He is also, for the record, wearing a halo. By the end of the evening, you are unlikely to dispute his right to it.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BEN & JERRY'S HOMEMADE INC., -- South Burlington, Vt., named Yves Couette chief executive, succeeding Perry Odak, who is resigning for personal reasons. Since 1976, Mr. Couette has been an employee of Unilever, which acquired Ben & Jerry's this summer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GALLANT, GLADYS S.
description: GALLANT-Gladys S. Remembered with love. Your family

title: Album of the Week
description: ''CHARLIE'S ANGELS: MUSIC FROM THE MOTION PICTURE'': Various artists (Columbia Records). America agreed on one truism this month: women can be heroines and still maintain great wardrobes. Part street-feminist fable, part 1970's nostalgia trip, the hit film version of ''Charlie's Angels'' offers a Hollywood version of women's liberation with comic flair. The soundtrack, supervised by the film's director, McG (who started in music videos), manages its contradictions with a similar smirk.

title: Time Is Short for U.S. to Join the International Criminal Court
description: More than 100 nations will be watching the Clinton administration over the next two weeks for an indication whether the United States will sign the treaty establishing the International Criminal Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTLEY, FREDA
description: HARTLEY-Freda. On November 20th, peacefully at home at age 88. Devoted wife of the late Joel Hartley, M.D. Beloved mother of Leslie Gise, M.D., and Sara Hartley, M.D. Adoring grandmother of Robin Gise, J.D. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Mount Sinai Alumni Association and/or The 92nd St. Y. The family will be sitting Shiva at 8 East 96th Street, Friday-Sunday, 10AM-9PM.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-35

title: Residential Real Estate; A Sky Without Limit: Prices in Hamptons Still Rising
description: Like an old tune that resonates in the mind, the news from the real estate front in the Hamptons has a familiar refrain: prices are up, up and up some more. Never mind that the stock market is considerably lower than it was last winter and that the Nasdaq has been sinking, sales figures for everything from cottages to castles are soaring from Westhampton to Montauk.

title: Telephone-Related Companies Lead Rise in European Stocks
description: European stocks rose, led by phone-equipment and phone companies like Alcatel and Vodafone as some investors bought the worst performers of the last month. Drug makers including Merck gained amid optimism they would be dependable profit generators as economic growth weakens.

title: Ad Companies Fight to Take Messages to the Streets
