description: On a dark, wet November afternoon, the twisting old street in the financial district is packed. Along with pedestrians bearing umbrellas, there are a tour bus, taxis, some dark sedans and, smack in the middle of them all, a huge white double-sided billboard mounted on the back of a truck. ''Point and Klimt,'' it reads. ''Art.com.''

title: Electing Our Leader: Room for Improvement; Machine Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Camp Asks Rejection Of Bush's Florida Appeal
description: The campaign of Vice President Al Gore told the Supreme Court tonight that the appeals filed on Wednesday on behalf of Gov. George W. Bush were ''a bald attempt to federalize a state law dispute'' over how Florida election officials should determine the will of the state's electorate.

title: Michael Rudiakov, 66, Cellist With Brooklyn Philharmonic
description: Michael Rudiakov, a cellist and teacher who performed with the Brooklyn Philharmonic and was heard regularly in recitals and chamber concerts, died on Nov. 17 in Yonkers. He was 66 and lived in Manchester, Vt.

title: Flashin' Those Dreamy Eyes Way Down Yonder
description: They have their own way of doing things in the Big Easy. They always have.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Aristide's Return: Bad News Perhaps for Him and Haiti
description: In what opponents call a tragic power grab and supporters a resounding affirmation of the will of Haiti's impoverished masses, former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide is virtually assured of returning to power in elections to be held on Sunday.

title: Sports of The Times; Top 10 List Misses a Few Key Moments
description: NO ONE'S perfect, except, perhaps, someone like Nadia Comaneci, or, as Hollywood depicted, Bo Derek, both of whom rated unprecedented 10's. Ten seems to be a kind of magic number, and the top 10 greatest moments in women's sports, as chosen in a poll of more than a thousand Americans, were recently announced. Each moment was eminently worthy. But one event was strikingly missing. Well, from a personal standpoint, I'd make it three moments.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: LSI Shares Hit Hard by Investor Reaction
description: When LSI Logic said its chief financial officer, Douglas Norby, and an executive vice president, John Daane, were leaving for other jobs, investors reacted by driving the stock sharply downward.

description: To the Editor:

title: For Gore, New Strategy Brings Some High Risks
description: For two weeks, Vice President Al Gore has portrayed himself as a man struggling to be declared the victor in an election he believes he won. Today, his lawyers portrayed him as a man prepared to legally challenge the results of an election that Florida officials are poised to declare was won by somebody else: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

title: Company Says Tracing Problem Corn May Take Weeks
description: It might take weeks to figure out how the insect-killing trait in genetically altered StarLink corn migrated into a variety of corn that was not supposed to be genetically modified, according to the Garst Seed Company, the producer of the corn.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARTER, DAVID
description: CARTER-David. Remembered every day with a smile and a kissed ring. It's time to share with me the secret, Dad, of how your children grew up with such love, respect and trust in you. I could use the help. Love forever, Donny

title: Dispersing A Private Cache
description: The name Franz Koenigs may not mean much outside the art world, but dealers, collectors and curators know Koenigs, a German-born financier, as one of the greatest art collectors of the 20th century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTLEMAN, SAMUEL T.
description: CASTLEMAN-Samuel T. On November 22, 2000. Born January 24, 1922 in Louisville, KY. Graduate of Yale University, Class of 1944. Member of the Wolf's Head Society. Decorated veteran of World War II. Executive of Wachovia and Chase Manhattan Banks. Beloved husband of Sheelagh. Devoted father of Sally, Eugenia, Sophia, Samuel III and Peter. In lieu of flowers, donations to a charity of your choice would be appreciated. Memorial service to be announced.

description: BECKENSTEIN-Al. Birthday memories. November 24. Love, Anita and Kevin

description: 'How to Reach 67 in Jewish Art: 100 Pictures'

title: Russia Hopes to Revive Sagging Power Industry
description: After years of dwindling investment and neglect, Russia's power industry is beginning to crumble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAMBOLD, LT. COL. WILLIAM HENRY
description: WAMBOLD-Lt. Col. William Henry, on November 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Princess Guity Kadjar. Devoted father of Robin Kadjar Wambold, Kristin Kadjar Wambold-Liebling and Ali Edward Wambold. Adoring grandfather of five. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Sunday from 7-9PM. Funeral Mass St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. at 84th St. on Monday 10AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Heart Association or the World Wildlife Fund would be appreciated.

title: With No More Rackets, Ivanisevic Has to Quit
description: Goran Ivanisevic banged to bits one racket after another yesterday, and then had none left to play with.

title: Short at Center, Knicks Eagerly Await Longley
description: As much as the Knicks wanted to part with Patrick Ewing this summer, they would never have made the trade if they had not received what they considered to be a quality big man in return. Scared to death to face the future without Ewing or an apt replacement, the Knicks delayed moving the disgruntled Ewing until a center of their liking came along. Eventually one emerged, and his name was Luc Longley.

title: Public Interests; Happy Friendly Skies Day
description: This Sunday marks one of the great moments in the American end-of-the-year holiday extravaganza, the much-loved busiest travel day in the history of U.S. aviation.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: As Odds Lengthen, Democrats Plan for Legal Challenge
description: A unanimous Florida Supreme Court refused today to compel Miami-Dade County to resume its manual recount of nearly 700,000 paper ballots. The ruling was a serious setback to Vice President Al Gore, whose aides promptly announced that on Monday he would formally contest the certified results of the Florida election.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUHL, BENJAMIN
description: DUHL-Benjamin. On Nov. 23, 2000, peacefully at age 91. Loving husband of Shirley Katz Duhl and the late Ethel Cohen Duhl. Devoted father of Janet Spector (Dr. Joseph) and Roger Duhl (Diane Wild). Cherished grandfather of Douglas M. Spector (Ossie), Lisa Spector Rothkrug (Adam), Dana Spector Kimmel (Scott), Alexandra Duhl and Danielle Duhl. Greatgrandfather of Daniel, Eric and Sara Spector, Rachel and Emily Rothkrug, and Jack, David and Lily Kimmel. Burial private. Shiva will be observed Sunday evening, Monday and Tuesday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Spector.

title: RWE EXPECTS FURTHER EXPANSION
description: RWE A.G., Germany's biggest electricity company, will expand further abroad after buying Thames Water P.L.C. for $9.8 billion and will raise rates at home, Dietmar Kuhnt, the company's chief executive, left, told shareholders yesterday. The company will raise power prices again in January to pass on a tax increase, Mr. Kuhnt said. RWE last raised rates in September. To make up for increased competition at home, RWE will look for companies in Europe and may also expand further afield, he said. The United States is an ''increasingly interesting market'' for RWE, he said.

title: At Duke, the Frustration Finally Ends for James
description: By now, Nate James knows the routine as well as anyone. Arrive at Duke, meet your fellow high school all-Americans and then somehow get over the frustration of not being the go-to man on your team anymore.

title: Winemakers in Spain Take Protective Steps
description: Under a soft autumn sun, migrant workers crouch beneath the low rows of vines spreading all the way to the tawny hills in the distance, snipping and gathering the heavy bunches of tempranillo grapes -- a variety native to this Rioja region of Spain and one that goes into just about every bottle of red wine fermented, aged and bottled here.

title: Eros Cruises the Museum In a Filmmaker's Dreams
description: The British artist and independent filmmaker Isaac Julien, 40, is best known in this country for his rhapsodic ''Looking for Langston,'' which made a beleaguered appearance at the New York Film Festival in 1990. Based on the figure of the African-American poet Langston Hughes (1902-1967), this was no plodding Hollywood bio-pic but a floridly seductive reverie on what it meant -- what it means -- to be black, beautiful and homosexual in America.

title: In New Era, Old Cowboys Can't Handle Digital Vikings
description: As the Dallas Cowboys continue their downward spiral you can almost see the rust accumulating on those creaky bones -- Emmitt Smith is a man who refuses to go quietly. This afternoon against the Minnesota Vikings, it seemed like old times. Big game on national television. A possible Super Bowl team knocking on his door. The load of the offense placed on his broad shoulders.

title: Le Lavandou Journal; If Villagers Die Laughing, They'll Break the Law
description: On a clear November day here, the sun glitters off the Mediterranean, dancing among the pine trees and the fuchsia bougainvillea. The village retirees gather to play petanque, a game similar to boccie, along the port.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday that described some aspects of the electoral process in Congress misstated the middle initial of the American Independent Party's candidate, for whom a Republican elector from North Carolina cast his vote in 1968. He was George C. Wallace, not A.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEGG, JAMES J. JR.
description: LEGG-James J. Jr. Of Levittown L.I. suddenly on November 20, 2000. Beloved son of Ann De Marino, Mr. and Mrs. James J. Legg. Dear brother of Vincent Legg and Kim Ciano. Loving grandson of Mary De Marino and uncle of Samantha, Dominique & Thomas Ciano Jr. Visiting Friday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Cassidy Funeral Home, 156 Willis Avenue, Mineola, New York. Prayer services 10:30 AM Saturday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY.

title: Foreign Affairs; Senseless in Israel
description: Some 20 years ago a new U.S. Middle East special envoy was making his first tour of the West Bank. At the end of the day, according to legend, he gathered with a few reporters at the King David Hotel bar for a drink. As the mood loosened, the reporters pressed him for his impression of the West Bank, which Israelis and Palestinians were contesting. ''Aw, I couldn't tell ya,'' the U.S. envoy said in his Texas drawl. This went on for a while until the envoy finally relented. ''Off the record?'' he asked the reporters. Off the record, they nodded. ''Well,'' said the U.S. envoy of the West Bank, ''I don't know why one of them would want it and why the other wouldn't just give it to them.''

title: A Faulty Colombia Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Poor Handwriting and Eligibility Mix-Ups Disqualified Many Absentee Votes
description: Jonathan Bergrab, a 27-year-old construction manager, planned to vote at his neighborhood church. Then he got a letter from the Republican Party in late October urging him to help choose the next president ''from the comfort of your own home.''

title: Actor's Paintings Found, and Man Is Arrested
description: A man who had passed himself off as a close friend of the actor Matthew Modine was in police custody yesterday, charged with possessing paintings and wedding photographs stolen from Mr. Modine years ago. He was caught after a detective with a movie career of his own peeked in the window of the suspect's Manhattan apartment and saw the stolen goods, the police said.

title: Count Undecided, Standard Unclear, Task Unholy
description: Thanksgiving Day already, two weeks and more after millions of Americans went to the polls, yet the outcome of the presidential election of 2000 remains unclear, obscured by the fog of intent.

title: Mount Saint Michael Wins With Big Plays
description: In the 58th edition of their Thanksgiving Day rivalry, Mount Saint Michael defeated Cardinal Hayes, 21-7, yesterday. Hayes controlled the action for much of the first half, but two big plays on offense and a fumble recovery on defense helped the Mount to a 21-0 halftime lead. Those were all the points Mount needed.

title: For Firefighters, Team Effort On Thanksgiving Is Dinner
description: At New York City firehouses, time spent waiting is often time spent cooking. Firefighters (those with Italian blood especially, according to one Irish-American) have been known to trade shifts to be able to work with the best chefs, and some are so well known for their meals that a 1986 cookbook from a fire station in Harlem made the New York Times best-seller list.

title: Crony Capitalists
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lonely Absentee
description: Two or three times a year a manila envelope marked with the words ''Official Election Absentee Balloting Material -- First Class Mail'' arrives at my Soviet-era apartment block here.

title: Armstrong Defaults on $50 Million Loan
description: A filing for bankruptcy court protection appeared imminent for Armstrong Holdings Inc., after the company disclosed late Wednesday that a subsidiary, Armstrong World Industries, had failed to repay $50 million of commercial paper that had matured that day.

title: In Mexico, a Man With a Badge Isn't the Good Guy
description: Ramiro Ayala Zambrano and his wife, Edith, have raised four children in a gritty barrio brimming with violence and corruption, so they know an outlaw when they see one.

title: Electing Our Leader: Room for Improvement; Confusion at the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Shuts Liaison Offices

title: Perelman's Plan: Take Profits While Public Owners Suffer
description: RONALD O. PERELMAN has a problem. Shares of Panavision, a company he controls, have plunged. Mr. Perelman could wait it out and hope business will improve. But he has a better idea. He wants to sell his stock at a profit.

title: Text of Court's Decision
description: Following is the Florida Supreme Court's denial of the Democrat's petition on the Miami-Dade County recount yesterday.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: With shocking abruptness, Marc Murphy has made a culinary U-turn, leaving the refined French cooking of La Fourchette behind and taking up a new style that might be called designer Chinese. If the concept sounds murky, it finds appropriate lighting at Chinoiserie, a gloom-wrapped, ear-splitting new restaurant in the basement of the Hotel Giraffe. Square red fold-out menus are provided. Then comes the problem. How to read them. The small white candles floating in a cut-out pool in the center of each table shed much-needed light, but it takes steady hands to illuminate the menu without setting it ablaze.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISERT, ISRAEL J.
description: EISERT-Israel J. on November 21, beloved husband of the late Bess, loving father of Cheryl Dreyfus, husband Richard, and Edward G. Eisert, cherished grandfather of Jonathan, Deborah, Carolyn and Stephen, dear brother of Otto, Yetta, Pearl & Jack. Services Friday, November 24, 11:45AM, Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 Street.

description: THE TWILIGHT YEARS

title: Protest Influenced Miami-Dade's Decision to Stop Recount
description: The Miami-Dade County Canvassing Board's decision on Wednesday to shut down its hand recount of presidential election ballots followed a rapid campaign of public pressure that at least one of the board's three members says helped persuade him to vote to stop the counting.

title: Israel Ends Army Patrols With Arabs
description: Cutting a remaining security link with the Palestinians, the Israeli Army said today that it had ordered Palestinian police officers to leave liaison offices the two sides shared after an explosion in one of the offices in the Gaza Strip killed an Israeli officer.

title: Electing Our Leader: Room for Improvement; Flaws in the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: John Keats, 79, a Writer Who Noted American Foibles and Obsessions
description: John Keats, an author and biographer with a bent for social commentary, died on Nov. 3 in Kingston, Ont. He was 79 and lived in Kingston and on Pine Island in Ontario, in the Thousand Islands region of the St. Lawrence River.

title: In Search Of Love? Just Buzz Next Door
description: The dating game hasn't gotten any easier in the 21st century. Perils abound, especially for fragile, newly divorced, 30-something New Yorkers like Dan and Lori. For one thing, you might end up on a blind date with someone like Dan or Lori.

title: Sony Won't Show Ads With Abducted Santa
description: An elaborate television campaign that showed a Santa Claus under siege, meant to introduce a Sony Web site, has been canceled before the commercials ever ran. Sony executives decided that the spots, meant to be humorous, might be misinterpreted.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Replacements

title: Sure Touch in the Halls of Justice; A Court Reporter Retires With His Poker Face Intact
description: Over the past 51 years, he has written more words than Stephen King, observed more theatrics than any critic, and recorded it all at championship speed. So on the day before he was to retire, William Cohen was asked to sit through one final drama.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARRETSON, MATILDA BLOOM
description: GARRETSON-Matilda Bloom. Remembered with love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLZ, MONICA (MONA)
description: STOLZ-Monica (Mona). The extended Stolz and Gutwirth family mourns the loss of Mona, and sends our deepest sympathy and condolences to our wonderful cousins, Danny, Alan and Phyllis, and their families. Our Aunt and Sisterin-Law will forever be remembered by us all for the countless acts of love, kindness and respect which she so generously bestowed on her family and friends. As a young adult, she faced with enormous dignity and courage the uncertainties of W.W. II and like so many others she came to America to start a new life. She and her husband, Dr. Bernard Stolz, had three young sons when he suddenly passed away in his prime leaving her to be the sole parent. She faced this enormous challenge as she faced so many others, with extraordinary grace, fortitude and an indomitable spirit. True to her wishes, she remained totally independent until the end. She deeply cherished family and friends, always remembered birthdays, and made celebrations special with her beautiful knitted clothing and delicious holiday cakes. We will always love and remember her for her warmth and kindness, for her loving and caring spirit. The Stolz & Gutwirth Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, FRANCES
description: HYMAN-Frances. The partners and staff of Milton N. Hoffman Co. regret the passing of Frances Hyman, beloved mother of our senior partner, David Levy. Our heartfelt condolences to David and his entire family.

title: Bates Will Handle Four Pfizer Brands
description: Pfizer has reassigned creative duties on four consumer brands to Bates Worldwide in New York, part of the Cordiant Communications Group. Billings for the brands -- Bonine, Desitin, Rolaids and Zantac -- were estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, CARRIE SKLOOT
description: ROSENBLATT-Carrie Skloot. On November 22, 2000. Age 94. Beloved wife of the late Jacob H. Rosenblatt. Loving mother of Emily Spiegel and her husband Jerry, and the late Eleanor Sondock. Adoring grandmother of Pamela Sanders, Lise Wilks, Clifford, Bradford and Joanne Sondock and great grandmother of Jordan, Remy, Erin, David, Andrew, Jack, Jason, Joshua and Eleanor. Dear sister of Evelyn Tobin. Interior Designer and former National Vice President and Forest Hills Chapter President of the National Women's Division, American Technion Society. Services are Friday, November 24, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Ave & 76 St. Contributions in her memory may be made to National Women's Division, ATS, 810 7th Ave., New York, NY 10019.

title: Cindy Sherman
description: Metro Pictures

title: In Land Feud, Ruling Favors Greek Royalty
description: The European Court of Human Rights ruled today that former King Constantine of Greece and members of his family are entitled to compensation for palaces and estates seized when he was dethroned three decades ago.

title: Editorials Blend Bitterness And Calls for Common Sense
description: The editorial pages of some newspapers around the country ratcheted up their rhetoric this week after the Florida Supreme Court's decision to allow hand-counted ballots to be included in the statewide tally, with some opinion pages taking a plague-on-both-their-houses view of the bitter and labyrinthine endgame of the 2000 presidential election.

title: Laurie Simmons
description: 'Tourism, 1984'

title: Effort to Cut Warming Lacks Time And Unity
description: The vise tightened sharply early this morning on negotiators seeking a treaty to curb global warming, yet many delegates, even as they headed into the final 24 hours of talks, said they remained far from consensus.

title: Another Suitor Walks Away From Quaker
description: Does anyone still want to buy Quaker Oats?

title: From Po' Boys to Mardi Gras Queens
description: New Orleans is 1,300 miles southwest of New York City. A sampling of attractions, along with travel information:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York region.

title: Circumstantial Case in Lockerbie Trial May Fail to Convict
description: Prosecutors in the Lockerbie trial closed their case this week with a theatrical flourish, calling Pierre Salinger, the former Kennedy press secretary and ABC News correspondent, to replay interviews he taped with the defendants in 1991. The defendants apparently lied to him back then because evidence introduced earlier in the trial, some of it from their own government, contradicts them.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS WEEK 13
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Need for Workers Pushes Issue to Political Fore : The Immigration Imbroglio
description: COLOGNE  As odd as it seems in a country where there are more than seven million so-called foreigners, legal immigration to Germany is all but impossible.

title: With Ties to Africa but Varied Lives All Their Own
description: Although this year has brought a few interesting American movies on the subject of race, from James Toback's ''Black and White'' to Spike Lee's ''Original Kings of Comedy'' and ''Bamboozled,'' it is still dispiritingly rare to see movies that treat the lives of black people in their full human complexity.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BALCOFF, FANNY
description: BALCOFF-Fanny. Grandma Fanny: Your good and gracious deeds, your caring and giving will be remembered, Always. The special meaning of your life remains inscribed forever in our hearts and minds, and lives on within us. Remembering you today and everyday. Bill, Robin and Sarah Faye Pollack

title: Lawyer Sabotaged Case Of a Client on Death Row
description: There have been defense lawyers in death-penalty cases who slept during trial and others who showed up drunk, but Russell Tucker's lawyer went one worse: Appointed by a North Carolina court to represent Mr. Tucker in post-conviction proceedings, he sabotaged the case by deliberately missing a deadline for filing an appeal of the sentence.

title: Odd Characters On Grand Stages
description: Over the last week, an English tramp and an American addict have taken over two of London's grandest stages, and critics and theatergoers here couldn't be happier. And if the plays' producers have their way, these two elegant undesirables -- portrayed by Michael Gambon and Jessica Lange, respectively -- may make the leap to New York, warts and all.

title: Cheney Released From Hospital
description: Dick Cheney, the Republican vice presidential candidate, left the hospital today after suffering a mild heart attack Wednesday days ago and said he would resume normal activities after a weekend of rest.

title: Luise Addiss, 101, Longtime Art Supporter
description: Luise Kraus Addiss, an art-loving New Yorker who was the first person to be a member of the Metropolitan Museum for 75 years, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 101.

title: Electing Our Leader: Room for Improvement; A G.O.P. Oddity
description: To the Editor:

title: A Path to Peace in Kashmir
description: India's announcement of a one-month cease-fire in its perennially troubled state of Kashmir is welcome. It was immediately dismissed by local Muslim rebel groups and Pakistan, but Muslim political parties in Kashmir have given a more positive response. The Kashmir conflict is a potential trigger for nuclear war. It has also led to grievous human rights violations in India's only Muslim-majority state. Several parties to the fighting have now expressed interest in a political solution. If Kashmiri rebel groups would reconsider their initial rejection, India's cease-fire could be a first step toward achieving one.

title: PROFIT UP 11% AT SAFEWAY
description: Safeway P.L.C., Britain's fourth-largest supermarket chain, said yesterday that it would expand its range of household goods and other nonfood items to build on an 11 percent increase in first-half profit. Its shares rose 3.8 percent yesterday. Net income in the six months ended Oct. 14 rose to $:119.1 million ($167.6 million), or 11.8 pence a share, compared with $:107.2 million, or 10.4 pence a share, in the period a year earlier as lower prices, in-store bakeries and a wider range of fresh foods enticed customers. Shares of Safeway rose 12 pence, to 327. The stock has risen 55 percent so far this year.

title: Natural History, the Early Version
description: DOES the name Charles R. Knight ring a bell? He's mostly forgotten now, but a century ago Knight did for Tyrannosaurus rex what N. C. Wyeth did for swashbuckling pirates. The popularity of his paintings of dinosaurs, woolly mammoths, giant sloths and other prehistoric creatures made him a celebrity through the 1920's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDS, LOUIS W.
description: FIELDS-Louis W. Beloved husband of Esther L. Fields. Devoted father of Jacqueline S. Sobel and the late Preston I. Fields. Cherished grandfather of Bonnie, Bob, Joshua and Jennifer. Adored great-grandfather of Ariel, Alexandra and Rina. Services today, 2:45PM, at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ. For information Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, Maplewood, NJ

title: Martin's Ankle Is Shaky, and So Is Nets' Play
description: The new-look Nets took the form of a sleek cruiser coming into Phoenix, powered by point guard Stephon Marbury and humming with confidence. The Nets limped out of town like a broken-down jalopy, traveling today to Salt Lake City for Friday's game against the Utah Jazz burdened by new concerns.

title: Italian Decree Could Lengthen Time That Suspects May Be Held
description: Seeking to allay public outrage over inefficiencies in a judicial system that has recently freed scores of alleged mobsters, the Italian government issued a decree today that could increase the amount of time suspects accused of serious crimes spend in detention while awaiting trial.

title: Siemens Rushes To Find Place In New e-World
description: AS THE world looks to the new economy for business models of the future, some venerable companies that helped define the Industrial Revolution have reason to envy competitors founded in California garages by geeks who barely stayed in school long enough to read about it.

title: Bassett Is Leaving DDB's Dallas Office
description: Steve Bassett, chief creative officer at the Dallas office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, is leaving to become a group creative director at the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Mr. Bassett, 51, had worked at Martin before; he was senior writer from 1989 to 1995 and associate creative director from 1997 to 1999, when he left to join DDB Dallas.

title: A Cruel Choice in New Delhi: Jobs vs. a Safer Environment
description: This teeming city of 14 million is one of the smoggiest in the world, and it is parted by a river that has been compared to a sewer. But after the Supreme Court took steps last week to compel Delhi to clean itself up, thousands of people took to the streets in violent protests, demanding that the dirty old factories stay open.

title: A Chip Plant That Is Full Of Symbolism
description: The sons of President Jiang Zemin of China and one of Taiwan's most powerful men broke ground last week on a $1.63 billion computer-chip plant that will be freighted with as much political symbolism as commercial potential.

title: Gunther Gerzo
description: Mary-Anne Martin Fine Arts

title: The Original Wily Coyotes
description: Children do their fair share of howling, but usually not for pleasure. Today and tomorrow, though, they can exercise their lungs in pure joy, taking their cues from some expert howlers in the animal kingdom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVEDISIAN, ARMEN GEORGE
description: AVEDISIAN-Armen George. Beloved husband of JoEllyn; loving father of Guy (Margot), Vann (Heidi), and Donna (Craig Chanti) Avedisian; step-father of Lisa (Darrell) Brown. Visitation 3:00-7:00 PM Sunday at BlakeLamb Funeral Home, 1035 North Dearborn St., Chicago, IL. Funeral service, 11:00 AM Monday at First St. Paul Lutheran Church, 1301 N. LaSalle Blvd., Chicago, IL. Donations may be made to The Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, Inc., 52 Vanderbilt, New York, New York 10017, or The Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago, 345 East Superior Street, Chicago, IL 60611. Funeral info: 312-944-5594.

title: A Pioneer Who Left Clues To His Enigmatic Paintings
description: The Italian painter Evaristo Baschenis (1617-1677) is not a household name. His native city of Bergamo has not the cachet of Florence or Venice. The first comprehensive exhibition of his work was held in 1996, more than 300 years after his death.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a suit over the use of Regents exams as a requirement for graduation referred incorrectly to the plaintiffs who sought to overturn a decision by Richard P. Mills, the New York State education commissioner. The suit was filed by charter schools only, and alternative schools maintain that the decision does not apply to them. A corrective article appears today, on Page B4.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Excerpts From Gore Brief
description: Following are excerpts from a brief filed yesterday with the United States Supreme Court by lawyers for Vice President Al Gore and the Democratic Party, urging the denial of two Republican petitions seeking the court's intervention in Florida:

title: The Rural Life; A Tale of Two Dogs
description: Our neighbors across the road had to put down their dog a couple of weeks ago. Her name was Molly, and the X-rays gave her no hope. For as long as we've lived here, Molly and her owners drove the half-mile from their house up the highway and onto our gravel road to feed their horses. Molly rode in the back of the pickup and barked the whole way, coming and going, which set our dogs off every afternoon. Molly was a gong sounding day after day, tipping us toward evening. Our dogs would begin to clamor for dinner -- sharp stares, deep sighs, contagious grins -- and once it was time for their dinner, it was time to feed the horses and the cats and then, eventually, ourselves.

title: A Deserted Isle For Just About Every Occasion
description: Just a few more weeks and moviegoers will see a skinny, scruffy Tom Hanks marooned on a desert island in Robert Zemekis's ''Cast Away.'' As a FedEx troubleshooter suddenly so lonely he talks to a volleyball, Mr. Hanks has to learn to experience time in new ways, now that he absolutely, positively doesn't have to be anywhere ever. Of course, the desert island experience affects every castaway differently, as these movies on video -- filled with sheltering palms, powdery sand and colorful flora and fauna -- clearly show. ANITA GATES

title: Electing Our Leader: Room for Improvement; For a Uniform Ballot
description: To the Editor:

title: Exxon Picks Zenith For Media Buying
description: The ExxonMobil Corporation has consolidated worldwide media buying for fuels and other products by naming Zenith Media to handle that assignment, with billings estimated at $100 million.

title: Bush and Gore Take Holiday Breather
description: There were still lawsuits to be resolved, dimples to be pondered and public relations salvos to be fired.

title: $200 to Own a Golf Course; Of Course, There's a Catch
description: Richard Violette owns a golf course in Augusta, Me., that he fashioned 15 years ago from a 250-head dairy farm after he retired from his job with the state. He has never been more than a hacker, but golf is a good hobby when you've got your own 18 holes.

title: Cheney's Heart Attack Renews Debate on Checking Health of Candidates
description: As Dick Cheney recuperated from a mild heart attack in a hospital here today, the misinformation provided by his doctors, and passed along by Gov. George W. Bush, raises anew serious questions regarding the public's right to know about the health of candidates and the credibility of information that their doctors and their campaigns disclose.

title: Balkan Unity May Be Closer As Talks Start For Leaders
description: The European Union, which has taken prime responsibility for reconstruction and stability in the Balkans, holds its first summit meeting with regional leaders on Friday, their task made easier by the election of a new Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica.

title: Article 2000112491631491506 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARKOWITZ, MAX, M.D.
description: MARKOWITZ-Max, M.D. Loving memories. November 16. Love, Anita and Kevi

title: A Coach's Vision Yields a Refurbished City Park
description: Eight years ago, when Geoffrey M. Croft, a freelance photographer who grew up in a mixed-income housing project between the Upper East Side and East Harlem, began coaching the local roller hockey league, he was dismayed by the condition of the neighborhood rink.

title: Ruling on Nazi Memorabilia Sparks Legal Debate
description: Aruling by a Paris judge ordering Yahoo Inc. to block French citizens from auctions of Nazi artifacts on the company's English-language Web site has sparked a passionate debate among legal experts.

title: Matthew Ritchie
description: Andrea Rosen Gallery

title: Surging Rangers Travel to Buffalo
description: One night after Theo Fleury's overtime goal gave the Rangers a hard-fought 4-3 victory over the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum, the Rangers traveled to wintry Buffalo, where tonight they will most likely face their old nemesis, Dominik Hasek, in goal.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the signing of a New Jersey law eliminating the time limit for filing some wrongful death lawsuits misstated the parole status of the convicted killer of a 7-year-old girl, whose mother lobbied for the law after learning that the deadline had expired. The killer remains in prison; he has not been paroled. The article also misstated the location of the signing ceremony. It was in the victim's hometown, Hillsdale, not Trenton.

title: His Own Breed Of Outdoorsman
description: Knee-deep in the clear, chilly waters of Cherry Creek, on the Flying D ranch, Reed Beauregard Turner expertly casts a grasshopper dry-fly tight to a grassy bank, where pugnacious brown trout lurk. He could hardly be described as a young man with the weight of the world on his shoulders.

title: Brown Sits And Waits For Chance With Cards
description: Dave Brown still spends his off-seasons in New Jersey, surrounded by Giants fans. Growing up a Giants fan himself, Brown knows the territory.

title: An Island Nation Comes of Age / 'Singapore of the North' : Isolated for Centuries in the Foggy Atlantic, Icelanders Open Up
description: REYKJAVIK  From the moment one arrives at Iceland's ultra-modern airport, through the one-hour drive across a black, volcanic landscape to Reykjavik, a visitor is challenged to define this country.

title: Inventively, Glass as Art
description: Italian glass has been prized for its magical transparency since Roman times, until the 20th century. What makes Italian glass made between 1930 and the 1970's so intriguing is how Italy's most innovative designers, working with the master glassblowers of Murano outside Venice, so often chose to deny glass its transparent properties. They were more interested in making it anything but clear and colorless.

title: Plan to Revise Zoning Laws Seems to Face An Early Death
description: Not long after Donald J. Trump's plans to build the world's tallest residential building near the United Nations ignited a well-heeled protest, the Giuliani administration responded by moving to reshape New York's byzantine zoning code and, ultimately, the city's skyline.

title: Electing Our Leader: Room for Improvement; No 'True' Winner
description: To the Editor:

title: Updating the Way We Vote
description: One very important lesson of the 2000 presidential election, regardless of its outcome, is already clear -- you get what you pay for when it comes to tabulating ballots. America's unwillingness to invest in a reliable, up-to-date system for casting and counting votes has helped produce the chaos that now clouds the outcome of the presidential election. One of the first challenges facing the new Congress will be to develop a uniform national electoral process that safeguards the sanctity of Americans' right to vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, VIOLA (BERKO)
description: BLOCK-Viola (Berko). Age 79, after an illness on November 22, 2000. Loving wife of Irving. Adoring mother of Roberta, (Frisch), and Jocelyn, mother-in-law of Charles. Cherished grandmother of Danielle, Andrew and Michael. Sister of Otto and the late Louis Berko. Dear aunt and great-aunt. Services Sunday, November 26, at 11:00 AM, Riverside Nassau-North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. 516-487-9600.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They tried to high-tech us rednecks. But they ruined us.''

title: EATING OUT
description: Truffle Season

title: Europe's Central Banker Sees Signs of Slowing
description: Wim Duisenberg, the president of the European Central Bank, said today that there were signs of slowing economic growth and inflation, indicating that interest rates might have peaked.

title: With No Hope for Economy, Many Argentines Are Leaving
description: Half a century or more ago they came here by the hundreds of thousands. They were immigrants lured from Italy, Spain and other European countries by a vast new land that symbolized hope and offered dreams of boundless pampas graced by fat grazing cattle, and of cities with bustling factories and lively tango clubs.

title: Jets' Owner Supports West Side For Dome
description: Woody Johnson today voiced his strongest preference yet for the construction of a domed stadium on the West Side of Manhattan to house the Jets after the team's lease at Giants Stadium runs out in 2008.

title: Winds Relent Just Enough to Let the Parade Balloons Float
description: It was not just pre-parade jitters. A nervous dancer might miss a step, a marching band could play off key, and a hapless clown might even fall flat on his face, but they would still have their turn at the 74th annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESSER, LILLIAN
description: TESSER-Lillian, on November 20, 2000 at the age of 94. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Sheldon, Harvey and Richard, and mother-in-law of Joan, Marion and Fran. Cherished grandmother of eight and greatgrandmother of four.

title: FLORIDA'S HIGH COURT DEALS GORE A SETBACK, DENYING BID TO FORCE A MIAMI-DADE RECOUNT
description: As Vice President Al Gore confronts a ticking clock and mounting political and mathematical obstacles, officials in his campaign and in the Democratic Party say they are increasingly doubtful that he will come up with the votes necessary in Florida to overcome Gov. George W. Bush's slim advantage and become president.

title: Tempers Flare as Broward Recount Plods On
description: If Vice President Al Gore is to win the presidency, the winning votes must now come in stacks of already disputed ballots in two counties. And if today's recount in Broward County was any indication, a contentious, bitter process could get only more tense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMELIN, DAVID B.
description: HERMELIN-David B. The Cantors Assembly expresses sorrow upon the passing of Ambassador David B. Hermelin, statesman, philanthropist, humanitarian and devoted friend of the Cantors Assembly. May his memory be a source of blessing and comfort to this wife Doreen, wonderful family and the bereaved community he leaves behind. Chaim Najman, President

title: U.S. Supreme Court to Hear Bushs Appeal of Recount
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24  The Supreme Court today unexpectedly placed itself in the middle of Florida's presidential vote-counting imbroglio, ordering arguments next Friday in Gov. George W. Bush's appeal from the Florida Supreme Court's ruling that permitted manual recounts to continue beyond the state's deadline for certifying election returns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALBAN, GLADYS
description: KALBAN-Gladys. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother passed away peacefully at home in her 85th year. Wife of Bernard, mother of Lois, Philip, Jeffrey and Sidney, nine grandchildren and a great-grandson. Stalwart of Hadassah and long-term officer of its FreeportRoosevelt Chapter. Funeral service Friday, 12:00 noon at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Longbeach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: John Levitow, 55, Airman Honored for Bravery, Dies
description: John L. Levitow, the only Air Force enlisted man to be awarded the Medal of Honor during the Vietnam War, died Nov. 8 at his home in Rocky Hill, Conn. He was 55.

title: PROFIT RISES 21% AT FORTIS
description: Fortis, the Belgian-Dutch financial services company, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 21 percent as gains from insurance offset a drop in banking income. Net income increased to 548 million euros ($463 million), or 0.45 euro a share, compared with a restated 454 million euros, or 0.38 euro a share, in the period a year earlier. The chief executive, Anton van Rossum, is expected to disclose plans for expanding outside Belgium and the Netherlands next month. Analysts had hoped the company would take more steps to cut costs after buying American Bankers Insurance Group for $2.8 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCQUAID, JOHN G.
description: McQUAID-John G. Attorney, of Ardsley on Hudson on November 21, 2000. He is survived by his wife Betty, children, Elizabeth L. McQuaid, John G. McQuaid and Catherine M. McQuaid, his grandson Matthew Paul McQuaid, daughterin-law Patricia Clay, son-in-law Robert Hirsch and his brother Paul McQuaid. Mass of the Resurrection Saturday 10AM Sacred Heart Church at Broadway and Ashford Ave, Dobbs Ferry. Visiting Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry. Memorials to Westchester Community Foundation, 740 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10607, or the Sacred Heart Church.

title: Electing Our Leader: Room for Improvement; Holiday Gift Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: Eugene M. Farber, 83, Expert On Psoriasis and Allergies
description: Eugene M. Farber, a California dermatologist who did groundbreaking research on psoriasis and allergies, died on Nov. 10 in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 83 and lived in Portola Valley.

title: Electing Our Leader: Room for Improvement; Witness to History
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Paternal Praise In Reverse

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROAS, DONALD S.
description: BROAS-Donald S. On November 22, 2000. Beloved husband of Betty Jane Langer-Broas. Devoted father of Nancy Gray, Donald Jr., Kimberley and Gregory. Cherished grandfather of Hayley Gray. Former president of Hospital for Special Surgery. Funeral arrangements to be announced.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Tracing of Modified Corn Could Take Several Weeks

title: Trying to Make the Workplace a Safer Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMAN, HELEN
description: LIPPMAN-Helen. Passed away on November 22, 2000 at the age of 83. Beloved wife of 63 years of Philip. Devoted mother of Susan Karp and Iris Boshes. Loving grandmother of Andrew Karp and wife Lauren, Melissa Karp and Isaac Boshes. Services at Temple Beth Elohim. Garfield Place & 8th Ave, Brooklyn, today at 10AM.

title: Devils, on a West Coast Roll, Win Fourth Straight
description: If first impressions matter, the Devils should be thrilled with Staples Center, the year-old home of the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Al Held
description: Robert Miller

title: Report Cards Are Due, Only This Time for Parents
description: Earlier this month, Olivia Carillo walked to her daughters' school for the autumn ritual known as report card pickup night, when Chicago parents meet teachers and discuss their children's first round of grades. But this time, Mrs. Carillo, a 41-year-old mother of three, came away with a sobering surprise: Not only her girls, but also she and her husband would be marked by their teachers.

title: A Newly Cool Newark Says, 'C'mon Over!'
description: LET'S go to Newark!

title: A Day on 2 Fronts in the Courts
description: Yesterday was Day 20 of the 2000 election. Here is a summary of the day's events.

title: As Rules Expand Competition, Irish Cabdrivers Blockade Roads
description: For the second day, thousands of taxi drivers blockaded roads in Irish cities today to protest a government decision allowing full competition in the taxi market.

title: E-Commerce Dream Proves the Undoing Of a Solid Business
description: Just before midnight, Larry K. Canoy steps into his truck to drive an hour to his father's trailer, where he will spend the night. Neither the commute nor the accommodations are ideal, but Mr. Canoy has been cutting back on expenses, like rent, since the new economy upstarts came to town and turned his world on its head.

title: A Little Country, a Big Army: Switzerland Debates Its Budget
description: With 360,000 soldiers at the ready, Switzerland has one of the larger armies in the world, and it is part of every Swiss man's life from 18 to 20. It is also one of the most expensive armies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, WILLIAM, 89
description: FUCHS-William, 89. Passed away Thursday, November 23, 2000 in Jacksonville, FL. Mr. Fuchs was predeceased by his parents, Samuel and Lena Fuchs, and his brother, Max Fuchs and is survived by his daughter, Deborah (John) DeAngelo, of Jacksonville, FL; brothers, Frank (Alice) Fuchs, Nathan Fuchs, both of Brooklyn, NY; grandchildren, David and Arielle DeAngelo of Jacksonville. Graveside services will be held at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow, Sunday, November 26, 2000 in Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. Shiva will be sat at the home of Frank and Alice Fuchs, 1580 West 4th Street in Brooklyn. Local services under the direction of WeinsteinWest End Chapel.

title: No Entourage, Just Hopes Of a Knockout; Landing Jabs to Pay Bills
description: In the boxing game, the brighter your name the dimmer your entourage.

title: Knicks Are Climbing In and Out of Sick Beds
description: Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy was already expecting a long day. He knew he had to rally his team after a miserable performance Wednesday night against the lowly Atlanta Hawks. He was also awaiting word on medical tests that would tell him how long point guard Charlie Ward and the backup center Felton Spencer would be out.

title: Shares of Suppliers Drop After AT&T Calls Halt to Purchases
description: AT&T, the nation's largest cable television company, has halted purchases of equipment that enable its cable systems to carry local telephone service -- a move that sent shares of several equipment suppliers down sharply yesterday.

title: Floridians Who Wonder: Did My Vote Count?; Miami-Dade's Deadline
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOTTISH BANK WILL INVEST $700 MILLION
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland Group said that it would invest $700 million in Banco Santander Central Hispano of Spain. The Spanish bank will use the money to help finance its $3.6 billion acquisition of Banco do Estado de Sao Paulo, or Banespa, of Brazil. Royal Bank will buy $:200 million ($280 million) of preferred shares and $:300 million ($420 million) of common shares, which will raise its stake in Santander to 2.99 percent from 2.06 percent. The move is part of an alliance, which includes cross-shareholdings, among Santander, Royal Bank and three other European banks, Societe Generale of France, Commerzbank of Germany and San Paolo-IMI of Italy. Earlier this year, Royal Bank used an investment of $:1.7 billion from Banco Santander to help pay for its $:23.6 billion purchase of National Westminster Bank. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Laughing and Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazilians Dazzled (Mostly) By Prospect of a Guggenheim
description: They came. They saw. They haven't yet conquered, but the Guggenheim Museum's top brass have singled out Brazil for their first outpost in a developing country, and starry-eyed leaders of the Brazilian elite are welcoming them with open arms and pocketbooks.

title: Latest Game: Reverse Field and Run
description: Oh, sure, it is easy enough these days to spot disputes between Al Gore and George W. Bush. But what has been particularly uplifting about the Florida standoff is how much the two candidates have agreed upon as the election returns, like a yo-yo, or perhaps a questionable meal, have kept right on returning.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: HYDRO-QUEBEC'S ELECTRICITY PROFIT TRIPLES
description: Hydro-Quebec, the exporter of electricity to the United States, said third-quarter profit more than tripled as the company, owned by the Quebec government, sold more power at higher prices. Net income rose to 114 million Canadian dollars ($74.1 million) from 35 million dollars a year earlier. Revenue for January to September rose 20 percent, to 7.44 billion Canadian dollars from 6.18 billion. Revenue from exports to the New England states, New York and neighboring Canadian provinces more than doubled, to $1.78 billion. Hydro-Quebec is based in Montreal.

title: Hayes Has His Chance In Jets' Passing Game
description: There was a time, during a preseason in which all eyes were focused on the receivers, when Windrell Hayes was the more developed rookie pass catcher. Laveranues Coles was a bit of a mystery, his senior college season obscured by off-the-field issues, and so Hayes seemed to be the choice to rely on for a team that desperately needed another dependable target for Vinny Testaverde's passes.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Book Chain And Gemstar Holding Talks
description: The bookstore giant Barnes & Noble confirmed yesterday that it was in talks with the media and technology company Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc. about a range of business deals including a possible merger.

title: Welsh and Penn State in Title Hunt
description: Christie Welsh is certainly among the next wave of players headed for the United States women's national soccer team. For now, she is riding a crest she hopes will take Penn State to its second consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association semifinals.

title: On a Student Field Trip, With the Planet at Stake
description: If it had been a normal November, Daniel Jones would have stayed at Hunter College through the Thanksgiving break instead of heading home to Kalamazoo, Mich. ''There's a lot of stuff I want to do in New York City,'' said Mr. Jones, a 19-year-old sophomore who had never been to the city before last year.

title: Snow and Penguins End Flyers' Parade
description: Garth Snow and Aleksei Kovalev gave the Pittsburgh Penguins everything they needed to end two long streaks.

title: GORE SET TO FIGHT PALM BEACH VOTE
description: Vice President Al Gore plans to contest the election results in Palm Beach County on the grounds that dimpled ballots are not being counted as votes and that voter confusion over the ''butterfly'' ballot cost him thousands of votes here, senior Democratic lawyers and strategists said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPINCOTT, WILLIAM D'OLIER
description: LIPPINCOTT-William D'Olier. On November 27 in Northeast Harbor, ME. after a short illness. Born on November 5, 1919. Alumnus of St. George's School, Newport, RI and Princeton University, Class of 1941. Former Dean of Students at Princeton University, 1954-1968, and Executive Director of the Alumni Council from 1968 to 1972. Memorial Service to be held next summer in Northeast Harbor.

title: Suit Accuses DuPont of Inflating Drug Price
description: The DuPont Company faces a lawsuit in Federal District Court here by health insurer United Wisconsin Services Inc., accusing it of seeking to monopolize the market for blood-thinning drugs.

title: AIDS Infections Rise Globally, but Sub-Saharan Cases Stabilize
description: An estimated 5.3 million people, including 600,000 children under age 15, became infected with the virus that causes AIDS this year, the World Health Organization said today.

title: Pressing On With Plans, Gore Begins Laying the Foundation for His White House
description: In a display of certainty at a time of excruciating uncertainty, Vice President Al Gore today moved ahead with plans for his transition from the limbo of this election to governing.

title: Cheney Leaves Hospital, Saying He'll Be at Work Next Week
description: Dick Cheney went home from the hospital today, two days after suffering his fourth heart attack in 22 years, saying that his doctors assured him that they had found no health reasons that would prevent him from serving as vice president or president.

title: Theodore Monod, Sahara-Loving Naturalist, Dies at 98
description: Theodore Andre Monod, a distinguished French naturalist and authority on the Sahara, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Versailles, outside Paris. He was 98.

title: An Effort to Recapture The Old Allure of Boxing
description: ''Boxing is in its most abysmal state in my lifetime,'' said Hank Kaplan, the boxing archivist who sat ringside with Frank Sinatra for the first Ali vs. Liston fight.

title: Frederick Jacobs, 78, Lawyer And Executive at Ad Agency
description: Frederick L. Jacobs, the former chief financial officer of the advertising agency Wells, Rich, Greene, died on Nov. 14 at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 78.

title: Floridians Who Wonder: Did My Vote Count?; The Dimpled Un-Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Supreme Court to Hear Florida Recount Case
description: The Supreme Court today unexpectedly placed itself in the middle of Florida's presidential vote-counting imbroglio, ordering arguments next Friday in Gov. George W. Bush's appeal from the Florida Supreme Court's ruling that permitted manual recounts to continue beyond the state's deadline for certifying election returns.

title: Giants' Backup Receivers Appear Ready and Willing
description: The bruised lungs that will sideline Ike Hilliard for at least the next two games means opportunity for the three backup wide receivers. All have limited experience, but all say they are ready.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Rangers Overpowered by Sabres
description: The Rangers' power play, the most proficient in the National Hockey League, had five chances tonight but came up empty. The Buffalo Sabres entered the game with the fourth-best power play in the league. The decisive goal of the game was scored on -- what else? -- a power play.

title: Sports of The Times; Giant Hopeful May Be Cure For Big Blues
description: YOU won't find Damon Washington's name in the Giants' media guide. His name is in small print under ''Transactions'' in your local paper during summer training camp.

title: Gore Gains in Broward; Count Reaches Midpoint
description: Heckled by hundreds of Republican demonstrators outside the Broward County Courthouse, election officials today reached the halfway point in their manual count of about 1,800 disputed ballots.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a survey of salaries paid to college presidents misstated the founding year of the University of Denver. It was 1864, not 1964.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, VIOLA (BERKO)
description: BLOCK-Viola (Berko). Age 79, after an illness on November 22, 2000. Loving wife of Irving. Adoring mother of Roberta, (Frisch), and Jocelyn, mother-in-law of Charles. Cherished grandmother of Danielle, Andrew and Michael. Sister of Otto and the late Louis Berko. Dear aunt and great-aunt. Services Sunday, November 26, at 11:00 AM, Riverside Nassau-North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. 516-487-9600.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about the groundbreaking ceremony for a semiconductor plant in Shanghai misidentified two men shown. Those present were, from the left, Chen Liangyu, a Shanghai vice mayor; Hu Qili, vice minister of information industries; Mayor Xu Kuangdi of Shanghai; Winston Wang, a Taiwan businessman who is chief executive of the company building the plant; and Jiang Yiren, another vice mayor. The company's vice chairman, who is the son of President Jiang Zemin, was not pictured, and his family name was misspelled. He is Jiang Mianheng, not Jian.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, DOLLY S.
description: MARKS-Dolly S. On November 23, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Harold Marks. Dear mother of Iris (Uzi) Sasson. Adored grandmother of Joseph, Edith Joy, Daniel & great grandmother of Melody. Service Sunday November 26th, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to the Sisterhood Congregation of Shearith Israel, New York City.

title: The New Face Of Architecture
description: You may remember the romantic hero of Ayn Rand's novel ''The Fountainhead.'' He is Howard Roark, an uncompromising Modernist who blows up his own building when he sees that someone has altered it. Chances are, though, that you have no recollection whatsoever of Roark's foil, Peter Keating. He is a compliant and pragmatic fellow who will do anything to keep developers and the public happy. He is the architect no one remembers.

title: Certification Challenge Would Transform Case
description: When lawyers for Vice President Al Gore said they would formally contest the certified votes of the Florida election, they raised the specter of moving the dispute to a new phase, one that calls for different strategies and puts added deadline pressure on the Florida courts.

title: For Mainlanders, Taiwan's Lure Proves Powerful but Often Elusive
description: When Shi Shubin stood on the Chinese coast and gazed across the Taiwan Strait, he did not brood about an unfinished civil war or China's relentless demand that Taiwan rejoin the motherland. He was not concerned by the military standoff across the 100-mile waterway, or by the political tensions that bar direct commerce.

title: Florida Legislature Plans to Enter Legal Fray, Backing Bush's Suit
description: As Florida's Republican-led Legislature announced plans today to join Gov. George W. Bush's Supreme Court challenge to hand recounts, Vice President Al Gore's campaign fought back with promises of its own lawsuits to be filed next week in the Democrats' expanding legal contest of the election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPOTTON, RHANDA ELIZABETH
description: SPOTTON-Rhanda Elizabeth at Calvary Hospital, New York, on Sunday, November 19, 2000, after a courageous battle with cancer. Born in Toronto, Canada. Beloved sister of Gloria Crouser (Carrollton, Texas), Doris Hull (Payson Arizona), Roberta Ann Burns (Port Carling, Ontario, Canada), and Ronald Spotton (Kimberly, Ontario, Canada). Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Rhanda served 25 years as Public Affairs Assistant, Air Canada, Executive Office, New York. She was active in the Light Opera of Manhattan, the Twelfth Night Club of New York and the Air Canada Pionairs. Memorial services at a later date. Remembrances may be made to the charity of your choice

title: Expansion Continues in Asia, but I.M.F. Warns of Slowdown
description: For most of the year, Asia's economies have performed a sort of levitating act, growing by double-digit rates month after month even as economists predicted that they would fall to earth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENSTEIN, HAZEL
description: ORENSTEIN-Hazel. Daughter of Sidney Orenstein and the late Mae Greiff Orenstein. Sister of Jonathan, Henry and David Orenstein. Sister-in-law of Sandra Seidlitz and aunt of Matthew, Natalie and Michael Orenstein. Died of ovarian cancer on November 23, 2000 at the age of 48 in Cambridge, MA. Her courage and fortitude in battling the five-year disease were extraordinary. A graduate in English at Brandeis University in 1974, she later obtained a Master's Degree in Special Education at Lesley College. Her life was devoted to the welfare of developmentally disabled men and women whom she helped to live self sufficent, productive lives. Her commitment to their welfare never faltered and she fought to assure that they were well treated in their housing needs, their employment and their social activities. At the center of Hazel's life were friendships of uncommon devotion. Many of these friendships lasted for decades, some for a lifetime. Hazel died peacefully among loving friends and family. She will be missed by all who knew her. A funeral service was held in Cambridge, MA on November 24, 2000. A memorial service will be held in Cambridge, MA. Call 617-661-9559 after December 14 for more information. Burial will be in the Orenstein plot at Mt. Judah Cemetery, Ridgewood, Queens on Sunday, November 26, 2000 at 2:30 PM. Donations may be made to the following charities in her memory: American Cancer Society, 30 Speen St., Framingham, MA 01701; Association for Retarded Citizens of MA, 217 South St., Waltham, MA 02453; The Wellness Community, 1320 Centre St., Suite 305, Newton Centre, MA 02459.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY
description: SERBIAN GANDHIS

title: More Reports Of Sex Crimes In Schools
description: Four days after four children were molested in a Queens elementary school, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday released data showing that while crime in the city's public schools had decreased over all, reports of sexual offenses had nearly tripled.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the Israeli Army's response to the bombing of a liaison office shared with the Palestinians misstated the army's action. It ordered Palestinian police officers to leave such offices; it did not end joint patrols with them. Because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to the patrols. Because of the violence of the last several weeks, they have ended actually, not almost.

title: With Brown And Iverson Clicking, So Are 76ers
description: In the fourth game of the Philadelphia 76ers' season, Eric Snow stole the ball in the final seconds to preserve a pulsating victory at Miami. Snow, a nimble point guard, was mobbed by his teammates. The first to embrace him was Allen Iverson.

title: Scoreless In Bruckner Territory
description: Although Lorin Maazel, who is celebrating his 70th birthday by barnstorming in New York as conductor, composer and violinist, has seen it all and done most of it, he is not particularly known as a Bruckner specialist. Yet there he was on Wednesday evening in Avery Fisher Hall conducting Bruckner's biggest symphony, No. 8 in C minor, from memory with typical flair and assurance.

title: INSIDE
description: Mideast Security Link Kept

title: New Yorkers Bike Locally, Think Globally
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and I.M.F. Welcome Salvador's Adoption of Dollar
description: El Salvador's decision to adopt the United States dollar as its currency won immediate support from the United States Treasury Department and the International Monetary Fund yesterday, reflecting a growing trend in Latin America to embrace the dollar as official tender.

title: Police Charge L.I. Woman In Poisoning
description: A Long Island woman was arrested on murder charges yesterday in the death of her longtime boyfriend, whom, the police said, she had slowly poisoned over the course of a year after discovering that he was involved with another woman.

title: A Mayor, Once Vocal for Gore, Is Silent
description: When Vice President Al Gore began his trek for the White House in the winter of 1999, he had few more fervent supporters than Alexander Penelas, the mayor of Miami-Dade County, who joined him at a fund-raiser in Bal Harbour and introduced him to the Cuban-American community here.

title: Gore Opens Drive to Keep Democrats in the Fight
description: Vice President Al Gore has begun an aggressive drive to rally prominent members of his party behind him, trying to ensure that his political support does not collapse as a smattering of uneasy Democrats express doubts about his extended drive for the White House.

title: Rethinking Negotiation With Hitler
description: Although Americans have embraced Winston Churchill as one of the great statesmen of the 20th century, he has never enjoyed unqualified adulation in his own country.

title: Beliefs; A minister turns to food's role among 'whitebread Protestants.'
description: Warning: This is a column about food -- just when you thought it was safe to open the refrigerator.

title: Russia Says Oil Companies Aren't Paying Full Taxes
description: An investigation into how much tax Russian oil companies have paid on their output of crude has found evidence of widespread evasion, Finance Minister Aleksei L. Kudrin said today.

title: Stocks Rally, But Outlook Is Still Cloudy
description: Stocks rallied yesterday in a holiday-shortened session, with the Nasdaq composite index jumping 5.4 percent while the Dow Jones industrial average climbed just 0.7 percent. But while investors appeared to jump in to pick up bargains -- especially in the technology sector -- after sharp selling recently, the concerns that have been prompting investors to sell are still there.

title: Remains Unearthed in Brooklyn Are Those of a Missing Woman
description: Human remains unearthed by workers at a sprawling Brooklyn construction site 10 days ago were positively identified yesterday as those of Eve Brown, a Long Island woman, five months pregnant, who had been missing for more than a year, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, JOAN (WEBER)
description: MARTIN-Joan (Weber). Died Thursday. Widow of William F. Martin, MD of Glen Cove, New York. Survived by her daughter, Beth Martin of Townshend, VT and son Jeffrey T. Martin of Glen Cove, NY. The Funeral Mass is Monday, Nov. 27 at 10 AM at Our Lady of the Valley Church. Visitation Sunday from 2-6 PM at White Funeral Home, Townshend, VT.

title: Education Over Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLMAN, SHEILA ALMER
description: HELLMAN-Sheila Almer. On November 24, 2000, peacefully at home. Loving wife of Hal. Devoted mother of Jill and Jennifer. No services. Shiva will be observed Saturday evening through Tuesday at home. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Sheila A. Hellman Cultural Arts Dept., at the YM-YWHA of North Jersey in Wayne, and/or The Hospice Program at the Hackensack University Medical Center.

title: Jim Wise, 81, Writer Of Show Tune Hits
description: Jim Wise, who wrote the music for the 1968 Off Broadway hit ''Dames at Sea,'' died on Nov. 13 at his home in New York. He was 81.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALITZ, CLARENCE YALE JR.
description: PALITZ-Clarence Yale Jr. Died November 23 following a brief illness at age 69. He was the Chairman of the Board of Financial Federal Corporation, a major leasing and financial services company based in New York. A graduate of Dartmouth College and New York University Business School, he served as an Officer in the United States Navy. His career was devoted to the heavy equipment leasing and financing industry. He served on numerous corporate boards in the banking industry in the tri-state area. In 1963 he founded Commercial Alliance Corporation (ASE) with his brother. In 1989, he established Financial Federal Corporation (NYSE) along with his son and brother. He has been mentor to many and his leadership will be greatly missed. He is survived by his adoring wife Anka, loving daughter Suzanne and her husband Joel Bauman, son Michael and his wife Gabrielle, stepson Gregory Kriser and his wife Sandra, brother Bernard Palitz, devoted granddaughters Elianora and Sophie, and step grandson Ryan. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on November 27 at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers donations should be made to the Central Park Conservancy or to the charity of your choice.

title: City Lines Up More Shelter For Homeless
description: Anticipating an unusually cold winter, the city's Department of Homeless Services is adding hundreds of shelter beds to be available on freezing nights to homeless single adults, Martin Oesterreich, the commissioner of homeless services, said yesterday.

title: Floridians Who Wonder: Did My Vote Count?; Why Not Do It Over?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, excerpts on Wednesday from filings by the Bush campaign in the United States Supreme Court, seeking expedited handling of an appeal, were reproduced with an erroneous surname for a petitioner. The document referred to ''Petitioners Bush and Cheney,'' not ''Chancy.'' In some copies The Times's introduction misidentified the court whose ruling was being appealed. It was the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, not the Florida Supreme Court.

title: Floridians Who Wonder: Did My Vote Count?; Election Outcomes
description: To the Editor:

title: INFINEON TECHNOLOGIES IS PLANNING EXPANSION
description: Infineon Technologies A.G. plans to earn two-thirds of its net income from memory chips this year, down from 80 percent in the last fiscal year, and increase communications semiconductor production, its chief executive, Ulrich Schumacher, said. Infineon, a German semiconductor maker, supplies memory chips to the personal computer industry and communications chips to mobile phone makers. ''I don't think we'll grow twice as fast as the market next year, because it's unclear when the D-RAM market will recover, but in all our other areas we will significantly outperform,'' Mr. Schumacher said.

title: Fire That Killed 20 Horses Is Attributed to Heater Use
description: After inspecting the scorched remains of a barn at Gaitway Farm , investigators said today that a fire that killed 20 racehorses Thursday night was caused by a portable electric water heater that someone had plugged in and probably forgotten.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALIN, MARVIN
description: MALIN-Marvin. On November 21, 2000. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Loving father of Joyce Malin and Linda Knope. Adoring grandfather of Ashlynn Knope. He will be deeply missed. Service Sunday 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROAS, DONALD S.
description: BROAS-Donald S. On November 22, 2000 at age 60. Beloved husband of Betty Jane Langer-Broas. Devoted father of Nancy Gray, Donald Jr., Kimberley and Gregory. Cherished grandfather of Hayley Gray. Former president Excelcare Health System Inc, executive vice president Interfaith Medical Center, chief executive officer Health Care Development International, Inc., president Hospital for Special Surgery, trustee Springfield College and Medic Alert Foundation. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday 6-9 PM, with service Monday 3:30 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: The Work Ahead in Bosnia
description: Nearly five years ago to the day, fueled by public outcry over the massacre at Srebrenica, American leadership, with the determined support of its allies, brought an end to the bloodiest war in Europe since World War II. It was a remarkable achievement, and since then it has been made even more remarkable by the progress in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the wider Balkan region.

title: POLES WARY OF NEW RUSSIAN PIPELINE
description: Polish fears that the Russians plan to use a 1,600-kilometer fiber-optic cable to put the country's phone companies out of business are threatening a plan by Gazprom of Russia to build a pipeline through Poland to Western Europe. ''We won't do anything against Poland's will,'' Igor Ivanov, foreign minister of Russia, said yesterday. ''The pipe can bypass Poland.''

title: Hurricanes Need Help To Reach Title Game
description: In the presidential race, all eyes are on the vote counting in Florida. In college football's national title race, partisans of two Florida schools must monitor three intrastate rivalries on this final weekend of the regular season: the battles of Oklahoma, Virginia and Georgia.

title: Police Seeking Parole Violator In Sex Attacks On Women
description: The police yesterday asked for the public's help in finding a parole violator who they said had been preying on women in Queens and Manhattan for the last four weeks, committing four sexual assaults and seven robberies.

title: Floridians Who Wonder: Did My Vote Count?; Military Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Montana Ban on Private Hunting Means an Excess of Elk
description: Jack and Myra Bridgewater looked out their dining room window at several massive, docile elk lounging in the driveway and wondered about the animals' fate.

title: Agrigento Journal; In Juno's Shadow, Temples of Illegal Construction
description: The soaring ruins of Greek temples from the fifth century B.C. recall a distant glory when the lyric poet Pindar called this part of Sicily ''the most beautiful city of mortals.'' At the perimeter of the ruins, however, a sprawl of illegally built apartment buildings, cottages and villas are temples to another, more recent historical phenomenon called abusivismo.

title: 8 Die in Armed Attack on Government Offices in Phnom Penh
description: Several dozen gunmen burst from the central railroad station before dawn today in the Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh, and attacked government offices before being repulsed by security forces.

title: Scientists Make a Bacteria-Size Machine Work
description: In the continuing march toward miniaturization, scientists have now not just built microbe-size contraptions. They have also found a way to make them move.

title: New President Of Mexico Names 4 More To Cabinet
description: The next president of Mexico, Vicente Fox Quesada, named new cabinet secretaries and aides today who will be responsible for the nation's social issues, particularly addressing the poverty gripping at least 40 million people.

title: Floridians Who Wonder: Did My Vote Count?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen fell on concern that Japan's prime minister could still lose his post and that this could defer economic reforms. In New York, the dollar settled at 111.36 yen, up from 110.25 on Wednesday.

title: Lawyers for Bush Want a Judge to Reinstate Military Ballots That Were Disqualified
description: Lawyers for Gov. George W. Bush asked a judge today to direct more than a dozen Florida counties to reinstate the absentee ballots of overseas military voters that were disqualified because they lacked postmarks, dates and proper signatures, and even some that came from unregistered voters.

title: Return Rekindles Memories
description: John Wooden left his California condominium last Wednesday for Indiana, back to the home he first knew early in the 20th century. He returned for the inaugural John Wooden Tradition, a doubleheader of college basketball games today at gleaming Conseco Fieldhouse in Indianapolis. A month after turning 90, Wooden was traveling back in time as much as cross-country.

title: $1.67 BILLION PURCHASE OF LOCKHEED UNITS IS APPROVED
description: The United States government has formally approved BAE Systems's $1.67 billion purchase of the Sanders military electronics business of the Lockheed Martin Corporation and two other units, both companies said. The Treasury Department's Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, which reviews transactions between American and foreign companies for their national security implications, yesterday informed Lockheed Martin, of Sunnyvale, Calif., and BAE Systems, which is based in Farnborough, England, that it had no objections to the deal. ''We expect to complete the transaction early next week,'' said Peter Harrigan, a Lockheed Martin spokesman.

title: Floridians Who Wonder: Did My Vote Count?; Sound-Bite Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Roger D. Malkin, 69, Leader in Agriculture
description: Roger David Malkin, a leader in the American seed industry and high-technology agriculture, died on Wednesday at his home in Scott, Miss. He was 69.

title: SHELL BIDS FOR AUSTRALIAN COMPANY
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group offered to pay as much as $3.4 billion for control of Woodside Petroleum to increase its presence in the Asia-Pacific region. Shell, a British-Dutch company, offered to pay $7.70 a share for the 66 percent of Woodside it did not already own. Shell is giving investors the option to buy back shares in the merged entity at the same price through the end of June. If all the options were exercised, Shell would hold 56 percent of the combined company, up from its current 34.3 percent. As part of the deal, Shell would transfer assets valued at $3.8 billion into Woodside in exchange for 333.3 million new shares. In June, Woodside rejected a bid offering assets worth $3 billion for 428.9 million new shares. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Maryland Village Endorses A Ban on Outdoor Smoking
