description: Smoking outdoors will soon be outlawed in a small corner of Maryland, except on private property, if the local Village Council gets its way.

title: Barak and Arafat Agree by Phone to Keep Security Link
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Yasir Arafat spoke by telephone today and agreed to maintain field-level security links that Israel had threatened to sever a day earlier.

title: Sugar Plums! Toys! Giant Mice! Encore!
description: The ''Nutcracker'' season began formally last night when the curtain went up for the first time this year on George Balanchine's standard-setting production of the holiday classic, danced by the New York City Ballet.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas last Saturday about nuclear concerns raised by the scholar Robert Jay Lifton referred incompletely to the authorship of his book ''Who Owns Death: Capital Punishment, the American Conscience and the End of Executions,'' published this month by William Morrow. Mr. Lifton wrote it with Greg Mitchell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOELL, AMY JACOB
description: GOELL-Amy Jacob. Of Scarsdale and Hartsdale, NY, died peacefully Thanksgiving evening at the age of 93 in Neptune, New Jersey. Wife of the late Milton Goell; mother of James Goell of Ocean, New Jersey, and Martha Goell Lubell of Philadelphia; grandmother of Lisa Goell Sinicki and Ric Goell and David and Sam Lubell; great-grandmother of Jake, Hayley and Maya Goell and Lindsey Sinicki; sister of Elsa Rosenwald. Private services Sunday in Bala Cynwyd, PA. A woman of social commitment and a love of nature.

title: Two Scoring Droughts Leave Nets At a Loss
description: The conditions were not in the Nets' favor tonight.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HUDSON RIVER BANCORP, Hudson, N.Y., said it had agreed to buy Cohoes Bancorp, Cohoes, N.Y., for about $158 million in cash, the second time this year the companies agreed to combine. Cohoes was the object of a bidding war in April when its original $92 million agreement with Hudson River was challenged by TrustCo Bank Corp. and Ambanc Holding Co.

title: Norman Overcomes Cramps in Victory
description: Top-seeded Magnus Norman overcame cramps late in the match and withstood a strong challenge from Sjeng Schalken to reach the semifinals of the Stockholm Open yesterday in Sweden.

title: Despite Chill in the Air, Long Lines at the Stores
description: Everything from pearls to pralines, umbrellas to undergarments was on sale yesterday. Or so it seemed in Manhattan, on the day after Thanksgiving, generally assumed to be the busiest shopping day of the year.

title: Swissair to Allow Physical Restraint of Unruly Passengers
description: Swissair has decided to crack down on unruly airplane passengers by allowing crew members to tie them down to their seats with plastic cords when they endanger a flight's safety, a plan the crew union opposes as dangerous.

title: For a Cooking Legend, the Ultimate Dinner Was Served
description: Some people might find it a bit spooky if the menu at a grand fete in their honor conformed exactly to their longstanding culinary wish list for a last meal.

title: SPORTSLINE ENDS $120 MILLION DEAL WITH MVP.COM
description: SportsLine.com Inc., the popular sports Web site, ended its $120 million agreement with MVP.com, the company known for its ties to three sports superstars, because MVP missed two payments and owes it $107 million, SportsLine said. ''Michael Jordan, Elway and Gretzky are finding out that they don't have the same mystique with people buying online as they did with die-hard sports fans,'' said John Shanley, an analyst with First Security Van Kasper, referring to the star athletes with stakes in MVP.com. Eleven months ago, SportsLine sold an e-commerce business that it said was losing at least $11 million a year to MVP.com, a closely help Internet sporting goods retailer that is owned in part by Michael Jordan, John Elway and Wayne Gretzky. In return, SportsLine received $120 million to be paid over 10 years and a 10 percent stake in MVP.com that SportsLine valued at $100 million, but now says is worth only $5 million.

title: Globalization Puts a Starbucks Into the Forbidden City in Beijing
description: Five million Chinese a year visit the ancient Forbidden City, walking across the acres of gray cobblestone, through the stately vermilion pavilions and beneath the orange glazed roof tiles of the capital's centuries-old palace complex.

title: Franco Stays With Mets for Another Run at Series
description: For John Franco, it did not come down to playing close to home or to pursuing the career saves record. When Franco, the 40-year-old Met mainstay, assessed his priorities, he decided that winning the World Series was most important. For that reason, Franco decided yesterday to return to the Mets.

title: Floridians Who Wonder: Did My Vote Count?; Trusting in Tallahassee
description: To the Editor:

title: Years of G.O.P. Animosity Toward Florida's Justices
description: Early this year, after some stinging losses before the Florida Supreme Court, Republican legislators had a few ideas about how to handle the judiciary.

title: What Is the Toll to Get to the Other Side?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chirac Exalts African Art, Legal and (Maybe) Illegal
description: Soon after President Jacques Chirac took office in 1995, he proposed that so-called primitive art from distant corners of the third world be displayed in the Louvre alongside European art and its Egyptian, Greek and Roman ancestors. Two years later he went further, announcing plans to devote a new museum to early art from Asia, Africa and Latin America.

title: Enter the Supreme Court
description: Readers of this page know we have been doubtful that, as a matter of law, the Florida election presented constitutional issues that required the United States Supreme Court to take the case after the rulings from the Florida Supreme Court. That said, we also noted that there could be a civic value in letting the nation's highest court decide the case. With its decision to hear arguments next Friday, the court has both put the Florida vote into a kind of suspended animation and perhaps also set the stage for a clarifying conclusion.

title: Lieberman's Remarks on Protesters
description: Following are remarks made yesterday in Washington by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: JUDGE IS URGED TO VOID THE SALE OF GRAND UNION
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company asked a federal judge yesterday to void the auction sale of its bankrupt supermarket rival, the Grand Union Company, asserting that the highest bidder excluded A.& P. through collusion. The dispute involves a Nov. 16 auction in which C & S Wholesale Grocers of Brattleboro, Vt., submitted a $301.8 million bid to buy 185 of the 197 stores owned by Grand Union, which is based in Wayne, N.J., and filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 last month. In court papers filed this week in Bankruptcy Court in Newark, A.& P. said that C & S chilled competition by cutting ''secret deals with numerous supermarket chains'' so that it could resell some of the stores to those chains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUHL, BENJAMIN
description: DUHL-Benjamin. On Nov. 23, 2000, peacefully at age 91. Loving husband of Shirley Katz Duhl and the late Ethel Cohen Duhl. Devoted father of Janet Spector (Dr. Joseph) and Roger Duhl (Diane Wild). Cherished grandfather of Douglas M. Spector (Ossie), Lisa Spector Rothkrug (Adam), Dana Spector Kimmel (Scott), Alexandra Duhl and Danielle Duhl. Greatgrandfather of Daniel, Eric and Sara Spector, Rachel and Emily Rothkrug, and Jack, David and Lily Kimmel. Burial private. Shiva will be observed Sunday evening, Monday and Tuesday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Spector.

title: SOFTBANK TURNS PROFIT AFTER LOSS
description: The Softbank Corporation, an Internet investment group, said yesterday that it earned 36.3 billion yen ($329 million) in the six months ended Sept. 30, after a year-earlier loss of 3.5 billion yen, but most of the profit came on the sale of shares in some of its investments, notably Yahoo. Operating income was up 28 percent, to 4.7 billion yen ($42.3 million), while sales fell 10.6 percent, to 180 billion yen ($1.62 billion). Softbank's chief executive, Masayoshi Son, said the earnings report was a poor gauge of the company's performance because of its structure as an investment vehicle. ''It would be easier to understand us by measure of our corporate value,'' Mr. Son said. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Floridians Who Wonder: Did My Vote Count?; Intentions in Broward
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: For Holidays, City Becomes Ouccupied Land
description: YESTERDAY was the unofficial start of the season when New Yorkers lose full control of their city. You probably know it better as the holidays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHLER, DAVID Q.
description: MAHLER-David Q., 77. On November 23, 2000 at home with his family. Beloved husband of Grace, devoted father of Robin, Michael, Peter, Susan, Thomas and Audrey. Adored grandfather of Emily, Rachel, Kayla, Jane, Nicholas, Alissa, Adam and Delilah. An accomplished and highly respected journalist, publisher and executive with Lebhar-Friedman for fifty years. Services Sunday, 1:30 PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Supreme Court's Order and Excerpts From Bush Brief
description: Following are excerpts from a brief filed by lawyers for Gov. George W. Bush in reply to the Democrats' opposition to a review by the United States Supreme Court of George W. Bush v. Palm Beach Canvassing Board. Also following are the Supreme Court order agreeing to hear the Bush appeal and a section of the United States Code on which the court has asked both parties to file arguments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, ROGER M.
description: GREENE-Roger M. On November 23, 2000, graduated John Adams High (NY), Vice President of Philip Morris Company, responsible for original marketing of the ''Marboro'' brand, became President of Waterock Inns, a Howard Johnson franchise, Lawrenceville, New Jersey. Husband of Dorothy, father of a loving family. Services Monday in Harford, PA.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BACHRACH CLOTHING, Decatur, Ill., named Robert C. Greening Jr. executive vice president and chief merchandising officer. He had been vice president and general manager of the Northbrook, Ill., store of Neiman Marcus. In addition, E. Julius Boasberg was named vice president and chief marketing officer. They will be based out of Bachrach's new Chicago office when it opens in January.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Mr. Cheney's Heart Attack
description: Americans should be relieved that Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, has apparently suffered no serious effects from what is now acknowledged to have been a mild heart attack Wednesday morning and was fit enough to leave the hospital yesterday. But they also have reason to be concerned by the failure of Mr. Cheney's aides and doctors to inform the public fully and promptly about his true condition.

title: Japan's Banks Pressed by Troubled Corporate Clients
description: Daiei Inc., a struggling discount store operator, won a new lease on life from its banks today, ending at least for the short term speculation that it was on the brink of bankruptcy.

title: DOCOMO CELLULAR STAKE
description: Taiwan's third-largest cellular phone company, KG Telecommunications, confirmed that it was in talks with NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest mobile phone operator. KG ended weeks of speculation about the deal, saying DoCoMo planned to put the finishing touches on a transaction next month that would give it a minority stake in KG. The Japanese company is moving fast to get its toe in the door of major mobile markets around the globe and is expected to conclude a deal next week to take as much as a 20 percent stake in AT&T Wireless.

title: XO COMMUNICATIONS MAY SLOW EUROPE EXPANSION PLANS
description: XO Communications Inc., a telephone and Internet services company, may slow plans for expansion in Europe to ease investor concerns that it will spend too much money, analysts said. XO, formerly Nextlink, will have a conference call on Tuesday to discuss plans for European expansion, the company said this week. The company could not be reached for specifics. Analysts had expected XO to spend $800 million in Europe through 2002. Nextlink, which became XO Communications in September, sells local and long-distance phone service to small businesses. XO, which is based in Reston, Va., agreed in May to buy fiber optic networks from Level 3 Communications Inc. for $306 million to sell data transmission services in Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, WILLIAM G.
description: FITZGERALD-William G., Jr. 73, of Charlottesville, VA, died November 22, 2000 at his home. For more information, contact Hill & Wood Funeral Home, 804-296-6148.

title: British Maker of Software Lowers Its Profit Forecast
description: Casting a further pall over Europe's information technology business, the Sema Group, one of Britain' s biggest software companies, lowered its profit forecast today, sending its stock into a swoon that cut its market value by 45 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHINE, SAUL
description: SHINE-Saul. Aged 89. Died in New York City on Thursday, November 23, 2000. Beloved husband of Marge. His loving family and friends will sorely miss his keen intellect and generous nature. He fought the good fight until the very end. There will be a memorial service held at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on Sunday, November 26 at 3:30 PM.

title: Bishops' Visit Shows Rift Over Episcopal Leadership
description: In another year, news that a delegation of Anglican bishops from South America, Africa and Australia was planning a pastoral visit on Sunday to the Church of the Good Shepherd here might be a subject of curiosity rather than controversy, an interesting event in the Episcopal Church's Diocese of Pennsylvania.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AT&T Shares Climb Slightly On Equipment-Buying Halt

title: Behind the Success Story, A Vulnerable Police Force
description: Murders in New York City have been cut by nearly two-thirds since their peak in 1990, and violent crime over all has fallen to levels not seen since the 1960's. Nonviolent crimes like auto theft have also shrunk by huge margins. Thousands of people who fled what they considered a dangerous and dirty city have been replaced by families who regard the city as safe and revitalized.

title: The Right Moment for Judicial Power
description: Justice Robert Jackson once famously wrote of the United States Supreme Court that ''we are not final because we are infallible, but we are infallible only because we are final.'' In this presidential election, the court's finality is a much-needed virtue. Indeed, both Al Gore and George W. Bush, not to mention the nation, have welcomed the court's announcement that it would review the Florida Supreme Court's decision to require that mandatory recounts be included in the state's certification tally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARSOTTI, EUGENE
description: BARSOTTI-Eugene. On November 24, 2000. Beloved husband of Gloria nee Abbundi. Devoted father of Claudia Musumeci and Mark. Loving grandfather of Justin and Nichole Musumeci. Father-in-law of Carmine Musumeci. Visitation, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 at Dimiceli & Sons Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Avenue, NYC. Mass of Christian Burial, on Monday, 11:00 AM, Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Justices May See Task As Calming the Storm
description: The Supreme Court's decision to hear arguments in the Florida election battle may reflect the justices' desire to calm national anxieties over the spiraling political uncertainty, and may not be an indication of how the court might rule on the narrow issues before it.

title: The Election Goes to the Supreme Court
description: Yesterday was Day 18 of the 2000 election. Here is a summary of the day's events.

title: Unions and Universities
description: The National Labor Relations Board made the correct move last month when it recognized the right of graduate students who work as teaching and research assistants at private universities to join unions. The universities are worried that the board's decision could erode student-teacher collegiality and the faculty's control over academic affairs. But their fears appear overblown. Whatever discomfort occurs will be a price worth paying for the basic right to unionize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRMAN, EDITH K.
description: EHRMAN-Edith K. Died on November 21 after a long life and a short illness. Predeceased by her parents, Jesse and Edith G. Koshland; by her husband, Frederick L. Ehrman; by her daughters, Edith Ehrman and Anita L. Ehrman; and by her sisters, Ruth K. Hellman and Frances K. Skipsey. Survived by her nephew, F. Warren Hellman; by her niece, Nancy H. Bechtle; by six great nephews and great nieces; and by thirteen great great nephews and great great nieces. Passionately interested in and profoundly generous to a myriad of charitable organizations, including The New York University Medical Center; The Mount Sinai Medical Center; The Lincoln Center Theater; and Playwrights Horizons. There will not be a funeral service. There may be a memorial service at a time and place yet to be determined.

title: Dr. Geoffrey Marshall, 62, Who Was Provost at CUNY
description: Geoffrey Marshall, the former provost of the City University of New York and the former deputy chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, died Nov. 18 at his home in Cranbury, N.J. He was 62.

title: Either Online Or in Line, Time to Shop; Amid Mixed Forecasts, Strong Sales for a Day
description: The sun was not yet up in Albuquerque on the day after Thanksgiving, but already at least 300 people were lined up waiting for the doors of Toys 'R' Us to open at 6 a.m. They had come to grab morning-only deals like scooters (this year's must-have item) for $27.99, Furbys (last year's hot item) for $5 with any purchase, and whatever else they could stuff in their shopping carts.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In terms of work, in terms of the kinds of activities I can engage in professionally, there are no restrictions.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVEDISIAN, ARMEN GEORGE
description: AVEDISIAN-Armen George. Beloved husband of JoEllyn; loving father of Guy (Margot), Vann (Heidi), and Donna (Craig Chanti) Avedisian; step-father of Lisa (Darrell) Brown. Visitation 3:00-7:00 PM Sunday at BlakeLamb Funeral Home, 1035 North Dearborn St., Chicago, IL. Funeral service, 11:00 AM Monday at First St. Paul Lutheran Church, 1301 N. LaSalle Blvd., Chicago, IL. Donations may be made to The Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, Inc., 52 Vanderbilt, New York, New York 10017, or The Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago, 345 East Superior Street, Chicago, IL 60611. Funeral info: 312-944-5594.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, CARRIE SKLOOT
description: ROSENBLATT-Carrie Skloot. On November 22, 2000. Age 94. Beloved wife of the late Jacob H. Rosenblatt. Loving mother of Emily Spiegel and her husband Jerry, and the late Eleanor Sondock. Adoring grandmother of Pamela Sanders, Lise Wilks, Clifford, Bradford and Joanne Sondock and great grandmother of Jordan, Remy, Erin, David, Andrew, Jack, Jason, Joshua and Eleanor. Dear sister of Evelyn Tobin. Interior Designer and former National Vice President and Forest Hills Chapter President of the National Women's Division, American Technion Society. Services are Friday, November 24, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Ave & 76 St. Contributions in her memory may be made to National Women's Division, ATS, 810 7th Ave., New York, NY 10019.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS RISE. Soybeans rose on speculation that soy-based animal feed would be in demand in Europe because of mad cow disease. In Chicago, soybeans for January delivery rose 9.75 cents, to $5.0075 a bushel.

title: Is a Word's Definition in the Mind of the User?
description: In England in 1857, an ambitious proposal was made to create an encyclopedic concordance of English words. Such a dictionary, it was argued, would be a ''historical monument''; it would represent ''the history of a nation'' recounted from a distinctive ''point of view.'' The result, completed 70 years later, was the first edition of the Oxford English Dictionary. In that work's 441,825 words and 1,827,306 quotations, the grandeur of the English language was displayed in all its expanse, every transformation chronicled by citations from English poetry and prose.

title: With Seles and Davenport, U.S. Leads in Fed Cup Final
description: Who needs the Williams sisters, anyway?

title: LIFFE GOES SILENT
description: After 112 years of face-to-face trading in London commodities markets, open-outcry trading of contracts in goods like coffee, cocoa and potatoes came to an end on the London International Financial and Options Futures Exchange. Open-outcry trading of financial options ended in May. The move brought to a close an era of loud traders in bright blazers made notorious by the British rogue trader Nick Leeson. As of Monday, the Liffe will be fully electronic, a spokeswoman said. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, CLAIRE
description: FRANK-Claire. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Frank. Died after a long illness on November 20. She was a caring and loving person who will be remembered by many dear friends. Memorial service Wednesday, November 29, at 1:45PM at The I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 21 East Deerfield Road, Dix Hills, Long Island.

title: Article 2000112592322179246 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Striking Domino Workers Feel Bitterness and Resolve
description: The strikers still sit huddled inside the faded trailer to escape the icy gusts whipping off the East River, just as they did last year. But now their voices, and their words, are laced with bitterness.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Sunday about Curt Siodmak, the filmmaker who developed the modern werewolf myth, misstated the given name of his brother, who directed the film ''Menschen am Sonntag'' (''People on Sunday''). The brother was Robert Siodmak, not Roger.

title: Three World-Class Teams Fall Short of Blue Ribbon Title
description: Three world-renowned partnerships were in contention for the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here Thursday night, but none of them emerged with the title. That went to Marc Jacobus of Las Vegas and Richard Coren of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., who had a slim seven-point margin of victory at the end of three days of play.

title: Talks Go Down to the Wire On a Global Warming Pact
description: Negotiators met behind guarded doors late tonight, trying to reach a consensus on a global warming treaty before their meeting breaks up on Saturday.

title: Duke Takes the Title by Doing the Little Things
description: Coaching comes in many forms, and it does not always occur on the court. When Duke was analyzing film of a practice last week, Coach Mike Krzyzewski made a firm point by emphasizing a mistake guard Jason Williams had made on a loose ball.

title: Floridians Who Wonder: Did My Vote Count?; Valid Machine Count
description: To the Editor:

title: Floridians Who Wonder: Did My Vote Count?; Cheney Has Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, PAULINE
description: FALK-Pauline. The Officers, Trustees and Members of the Ocean Beach Club regret the passing of their good friend and member and send heartfelt condolences to her family. Sandy Paskin, President Nancy Lobell, Secretary

title: China Gave Up Little in U.S. Deal on Banning Sale of Missile Parts
description: When American negotiators visited Beijing this fall to persuade the Chinese to curb their sales of missile parts, they found the going easier than usual.

title: Abroad at Home; Playing With Fire
description: However this presidential conflict ends in the Supreme Court of the United States, it has taken one dangerous turn: the excoriation of the Florida Supreme Court by George W. Bush and his lawyer, James A. Baker III.

title: In Florida, Losing Candidates Say Their Election Complaints Count at Last
description: Sore loser: That is the label Keyla Martinez resents the most.

title: May Either Man Win
description: With each twist and turn in this extraordinary election saga, commentators have marveled at the public's patience with the uncertainty and wondered when it would run out. The simple fact is that most Americans have been tolerant and temperate for the same reason that the election was so close in the first place. George W. Bush vs. Al Gore is not a compelling choice, except to the strong partisans among us. At the same time, the public is not indifferent to the outcome of the election, as TV news ratings and opinion surveys show.

title: In Brick-Attack Trial, Questions Over Identifications of an Assailant
description: As testimony nears an end in the trial of a man charged with smashing a woman's head with a brick, a Manhattan jury will have to weigh the conflicting accounts of witnesses and decide how much to rely on two jailhouse informers who said he had suggested to them that he was involved in the crime.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Candidates, Debate This: How to Fix Property Taxes
description: Your first-half property tax bill is coming due. Do you know where your local politician is?

title: Samantha Bilker, David Samuels
description: Samantha Hall Bilker, the daughter of Barrie Sachs of Sherman, Conn., and Mark Bilker of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening in Bethpage, N.Y., to David Marshall Samuels, a son of Ginny and Alan Samuels of Atlantic Beach, N.Y. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal officiated at Carlyle on the Green, a caterer in Bethpage State Park.

title: Election Day: Time for a 17th-Inning Stretch; Lawyers, Not Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shareholder Writes, And Buffett Saves the Band
description: One share of stock, like one vote, can make a difference. And it probably does not hurt when the share is Berkshire Hathaway and the company chairman is Warren E. Buffett.

title: Introduction
description: Jacob Weisberg's cover article on Daniel Patrick Moynihan prompted a storm of protest. If this was our idea of a farewell salute to a great statesman, some suggested, then thanks for nothing. But many said that we got it right, and that our writer said what had long seemed to be unspeakable.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: STATE OF THE ARTS

title: New Retail Chiefs Face Ghosts of Profits Past
description: IT'S never easy being the new kid on the block. If it is Christmas and you are a retail executive, it's worse. Every move you make is scrutinized, tallied, weighed against your future.

title: TREATY TALKS FAIL TO FIND CONSENSUS IN GLOBAL WARMING
description: High-stakes negotiations aimed at finishing a treaty to curb global warming collapsed today after a tense all-night bargaining session foundered on last-minute disputes between European and American negotiators.

title: November 19-25; Clinton in Vietnam
description: It must have been an unsettling sight for Vietnam's dour Communist leaders: President Clinton thronged and cheered wherever he went, whether to meet with officials, buy souvenirs or eat a bowl of noodle soup. The first visit to Vietnam by an American president since the end of the war 25 years ago was billed by both sides as the opening of a new chapter in relations. The United States wants Vietnam to join it in the global marketplace of trade and ideas. Vietnam's leaders aren't quite sure yet that they want to. Seth Mydans

title: In Praise of Ohnesorg
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Rights Sale Keeps the Curtain From Dropping Forever
description: Theater for the New City, a funky Off Off Broadway theater that has existed for nearly three decades, has been rescued from near death by an unlikely source: a luxury apartment building.

title: Mets' Staff Is Unsettled Because of Free Agents
description: No matter what happens with the Mets' free-agent pitchers this off-season, Steve Phillips has pledged not to shortchange the Mets or their fans next season.

title: Ruins by Day, Luxury by Night
description: A YEAR ago, visitors to the temples of Angkor bought their admission tickets at a lonely guardhouse alongside a road pocked with potholes. Today, the Cambodian Government has erected an impressive tollbooth, in faux temple style, where visitors have ID photographs taken and sealed in a laminated card that grants entry to the majestic monuments.

title: Jazzmen Who Swung
description: To the Editor:

title: Going, Going, Going Out: Bachelors Help Hospital
description: It wasn't hard to spot the eligible bachelors at a recent cocktail party at the New York Athletic Club here. Each was tethered by a string to a silver, star-shaped balloon floating above him.

title: A Place for Devotees of Sashimi and Sushi
description: AS ethnic food fads have flared brightly in the Connecticut night, then almost as quickly fizzled out, there is one foreign cuisine that has never really had its 15 minutes in the spotlight: Japanese. Yet, as Murasaki in Simsbury has been proving for 10 years, a Japanese restaurant can thrive in our state. There are a few other Japanese restaurants around, but they in no way represent a trend. This means a devotee of sashimi/ sushi and other such delights has to seek them out. For such fans, Murasaki is definitely worth the trip.

title: Let's Dance
description: Nov. 18: A Scottish country dance for 100 guests benefited the American-Scottish Foundation. The party was held in the ballroom of the New York Genealogical Society, which resembles a room in a Scottish country house, with ancestral portraits lining the walls. Many of the men came dressed in full Scottish regalia, and women wore contemporary dresses, tied with tartan sashes.

title: For the Sake Of Argument
description: Some may call Daniel Patrick Moynihan a magnificent failure, but I believe he invented himself and rose to the highest level of the political world. His retirement signals the end of the era of gentleman statesmen.

title: Sara Zimbard, Brian Haftel
description: Sara Lauren Zimbard, the daughter of Fran Zimbard and Dr. Alan Zimbard of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Brian Scott Haftel, a son of Sylvia and Seymour Haftel of Sarasota, Fla. Rabbi Richard Jacobs officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: November 19-25; A Twist of Fate
description: Queen Elizabeth II reignited a dispute with Britain's anti-blood sport movement when she was photographed on her Sandringham estate wringing the neck of a pheasant that had been shot in a royal hunt and brought to her by a hunt dog.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ROSALIE SLOCUM
description: GOLDBERG - Rosalie Slocum. Ninety-three, at Greenport, L.I. on November 23, 2000. Accomplished artist, author and public relations and development executive. Beloved wife of the late, Hon. Arthur H. Goldberg, attorney and Criminal Court Judge in New York City. Survived by her dear sister, Ruth Sander of Southold, L.I. and nephews, James and Thomas Sander and their families. There will not be a funeral service.

title: THEATER; A Drama, Religious Yet Private
description: AUGUST STRINDBERG was brought up a Christian, and then, like all the intellectuals of his day, was confronted with modern unbelief, even sharing it for a while, or thinking he did, in the form of a Darwinian materialism. He never returned to the narrow Protestantism of his childhood (he was born in 1849), but he did return to Christianity, if one can apply that term to occultist notions often classed by Christians as superstition. The important cultural fact is that his most mature creation was a new kind of religious drama.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANTZ, HOWARD M.
description: GRANTZ-Howard M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Howard M. Grantz, associated with The Times from 1992 until 1999.

title: Food; Caviar Lite
description: Jim Kahrs is working his 9-iron on the golf course he built around seven of the ponds that dot Old Sage Catfisheries, his fish farm in the Missouri Ozarks. He pauses, hits his approach shot to the second green, then climbs back into his motorized golf cart. His ponds are thick with catfish, bass, blue gill and also paddlefish, which, after three decades, are finally producing palatable roe. You could almost call it caviar. Putt. Putt. Putt.

title: Sports of The Times; When Grange Put the Pros In New York
description: PRO football is all so structured now, so financially solid. Approaching the 75th anniversary of the game that captivated New York, the National Football League has 31 teams, a billion-dollar television contract, a salary cap and a draft of college players. But in 1925 the Giants were in their infancy and in jeopardy.

title: Beth Williams, Eric Liou
description: Beth Ellen Williams, a daughter of Regina and Lloyd Williams of Morris Plains, N.J., was married yesterday to Eric Kuo Ching Liou, the son of Elaine Liou of Hazlet, N.J., and Dixon Liou of Manalapan, N.J. The Rev. Timothy Sullivan performed the ceremony at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHINE, SAUL
description: SHINE-Saul. Aged 89. Died in New York City on Thursday, November 23, 2000. Beloved husband of Marge. His loving family and friends will sorely miss his keen intellect and generous nature. He fought the good fight until the very end. There will be a memorial service held at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on Sunday, November 26 at 3:30 PM.

title: Edith Shapiro, Sol Stein
description: Dr. Edith Tennenbaum Shapiro, a psychiatrist, and Sol Stein, a writer, editor and former publishing executive, were married yesterday at the Cornell Club in New York. Robert D. Lippmann, an acting State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan, officiated.

title: And They Said Vaudeville Was Dead
description: Take an old-time vaudeville act, feed it through a Sony PlayStation, mix in a bit of black light and you'll have an idea of what's in store at Lazer Vaudeville, a family-oriented show that takes over the Community Theater in Morristown on Dec. 3.

title: Election Day: Time for a 17th-Inning Stretch
description: To the Editor:

title: The Secret Is to Mirror Public Moods
description: A SURPRISE blockbuster often has a way of unsuspectingly crystallizing a mood that makes it a must-see film, even if it isn't very good. Conversely, what is touted as a likely hit can end up an unexpected flop if it seems somehow out of touch.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LONG ISLAND CITY

title: When the Old Country Is New Jersey
description: THE neighborhood where Maria Laurino grew up is a place of white picket fences, narrow streets, and charming small colonials. It is not the wealthiest enclave in this upscale suburb, nor is it the poorest. On a Sunday afternoon in November, with millions of yellow leaves scattered on lawns and children playing boisterously in their yards, it looks like a safe, comfortable and pleasant place to have come from.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WALTER, HENRY G., JR.
description: WALTER-Henry G., Jr. A memorial service for Mr. Walter will be held on Thursday, December 7 at 4:00 PM at The River Club, 447 E. 52nd Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, NY, NY 10024, or the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, NY, NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, JAMES
description: DUFFY-James. Died November 19, 2000, after a brief illness, with loving family at his side. Will be dearly missed by all. ''The work praises the man.''

title: Pauline Baerwald Falk, 90, Philanthropist
description: Pauline Baerwald Falk, a philanthropist and a collector of Asian art who was also a former president of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.

title: Rangers' Power Play Is Showing Some Pop
description: The Rangers have lived by the power play this season. At the start of last season, they pretty much died by it.

title: Election Day: Time for a 17th-Inning Stretch; Inaugural Menu
description: To the Editor:

title: BENEFITS
description: These Truths Are Portable

title: Ruth Dyk, Champion of Women's Suffrage, Dies at 99
description: Ruth Belcher Dyk, one of the last surviving participants in the women's suffrage movement, died in her apartment in Rochester on Nov. 18. She was 99.

title: East Hampton Raises Salaries by Nearly 40%
description: WITH its employees struggling to make ends meet in one the wealthiest resort areas in the world, the Town of East Hampton has taken the novel step of voluntarily raising salaries by as much as 40 percent.

title: Glenwood Landing Eager For Revitalization
description: As civic leaders in a community that shares the eastern shore of Hempstead Harbor with Glen Cove, we applaud the revitalization effort currently under way on Glen Cove Creek [''Glen Cove Seeks Waterfront Investors,'' Nov. 5]. However, redevelopment frequently affects neighboring communities. These ramifications must be considered.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Chamique

title: For Maryknoll Sisters, Some Memories Don't Fade
description: THE years have been merciful to Sister Madeline Dorsey. As she sits in a small room at the Maryknoll Sisters Center here, her face shows only faint lines and her voice sounds much as it always has, a decibel above a whisper.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE HAPPIEST DAYS

title: Susan Tully, Nicholas Abdo
description: Susan C. Tully was married on Friday evening to Nicholas S. Abdo at the St. Sophia Greek Orthodox church in Albany. The Rev. Epiphanios Perialas, a Greek Orthodox priest, officiated, and Bishop Howard J. Hubbard of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany and the Rev. Louis Mahshie, an Eastern Orthodox priest and a cousin of the bridegroom, took part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, ELAINE F.
description: HIRSCH-Elaine F. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Elaine F. Hirsch, associated with The Times since 1951.

title: Chianti Cooking
description: To the Editor: I was excited to read Susan Allport's ''Hiking to the Kitchens of Chianti'' (Nov. 5), about her cooking school experience in Castellina.

title: Ward Out 6 to 8 Weeks; Surgery Set
description: Charlie Ward will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his chronically sore right knee tomorrow and is expected to miss six to eight weeks, the Knicks announced yesterday after losing to Toronto, 79-75, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Dividing Harry Helmsley's Empire
description: IF Harry B. Helmsley's buildings were his children, as he liked to say, dozens have found more munificent foster parents in the four years since his death.

title: Bittersweet Tasks in Cereal City
description: CARLOS M. GUTIERREZ, the chief executive of the Kellogg Company, knows something about risk.

title: Brooklyn-Based Bank Coming to Sunset Park
description: Community Capital Bank, a 10-year-old bank based in Downtown Brooklyn that specializes in providing small business loans and individual banking services in lower-income neighborhoods, is opening a branch in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, on Dec. 15. The branch, the bank's second, will occupy a building at 140 58th Street (at First Avenue) that housed a Chase Manhattan branch until it closed last spring. The closest bank to the new branch is 10 blocks away. Aaron Donovan

title: Enmity Is Not Inborn
description: After my stroke, I didn't travel much. My first big trip was to Israel last July, to dedicate two children's playgrounds that my family and I had donated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRMAN, EDITH K.
description: EHRMAN-Edith K. Died on November 21 after a long life and a short illness. Predeceased by her parents, Jesse and Edith G. Koshland; by her husband, Frederick L. Ehrman; by her daughters, Edith Ehrman and Anita L. Ehrman; and by her sisters, Ruth K. Hellman and Frances K. Skipsey. Survived by her nephew, F. Warren Hellman; by her niece, Nancy H. Bechtle; by six great nephews and great nieces; and by thirteen great great nephews and great great nieces. Passionately interested in and profoundly generous to a myriad of charitable organizations, including The New York University Medical Center; The Mount Sinai Medical Center; The Lincoln Center Theater; and Playwrights Horizons. There will not be a funeral service. There may be a memorial service at a time and place yet to be determined.

title: Beatles in London
description: Sites in London with connections to the Beatles are listed in the recently published ''Official Abbey Road Cafe Guide to the Beatles London'' (Abbey Road Cafe). The author, Richard Porter, has been leading Beatles-themed tours of London for 10 years, and his book includes the Abbey Road Studios; the Apple Building on Savile Row, which was the site of the rooftop concerts for ''Let It Be''; a train station featured in ''A Hard Day's Night''; and an apartment in Montague Square once owned by Ringo Starr. To order the book ($23.25 with shipping), contact Beatle Fest at (800) 232-8537 or at www.beatlefest.com.

title: Rough-Hewn Lives
description: The Means of Escape

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Election Day: Time for a 17th-Inning Stretch; The Fairest Way
description: To the Editor:

title: King-Riggs: Dissenting View
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Narrow Escape For the H of H-P
description: The storied life of William Hewlett took shape 61 years ago in a Silicon Valley garage. It nearly ended last week on a Silicon Valley balcony.

title: For the Sake Of Argument
description: Moynihan saw social problems and never allowed politics, or political correctness, to trump common sense in his analyses. The citizens of New York may not have been best served by his refusal (or inability) to play the political game, but perhaps the national political discourse was. And that, by my reading of history, is what the Founding Fathers envisioned for the Senate.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 26, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, DOLLY S.
description: MARKS-Dolly S. On November 23, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Harold Marks. Dear mother of Iris (Uzi) Sasson. Adored grandmother of Joseph, Edith Joy, Daniel & great grandmother of Melody. Service Sunday November 26th, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to the Sisterhood Congregation of Shearith Israel, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LELANDAIS, WILLIAM BURKE
description: LeLANDAIS-William Burke, 43. Of South Egremont, MA. Died Tuesday, Nov. 21, 2000 at St. Peter's Hospital, Albany, NY following a long illness. He was born Aug. 16, 1957. Son of the late Pierre Jean LeLandais and Patricia Burke LeLandais, brother of Michelle Esposito, grandson of Jean LeLandais. Burke is the beloved husband of Sarah (Van Wagner) LeLandais of Craryville, NY. A memorial Mass will be held at Our Lady of the Valley, Sheffield, MA on Saturday, December 2, 2000 at 11 AM.

title: His Liberal Imagination
description: At the age of 83, Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. is still hard at work. In the coming years, he plans to complete both the second volume of his memoirs and the fourth volume of his series on the age of Franklin D. Roosevelt. When asked to name his biggest regret, he said, ''I should have written more books.''

title: Texaco Grant Finances Computer Training Program
description: Texaco has given $25,000 to Pace University's School of Computer Science and Information Systems in White Plains to finance a program to help nonprofit organizations make better use of computer technology.

title: Their Own Masters
description: To the Editor:

title: An 'Unknown' Singer Releases His First CD
description: THE singer-songwriter Eddie Skuller has the kind of voice people like to label. Comparisons range from Roy Orbison (he likes that) to George Michael (he hates that) to even Cher (it's not intentional, but he hears it himself in his early music).

title: The Force Be With You
description: Despite frigid air, soil won't freeze hard for weeks, so there is still time to plant spring flowering bulbs. It is better to plant late than to store over winter.

title: After Wham! Pow! Shazam!
description: The! Greatest!

title: A Therapist Questions Use of Au Pairs
description: To the Editor:

title: A Way Around Air Rage: The Charter Flight
description: JOHN MYERS, an advertising executive from Chicago, often dreaded business trips. He had to deal with traffic gridlock on the way to the airport, frequent flight delays or cancellations, and tight space once aboard the plane.

title: INSIDE
description: Milosevic Resurfaces

title: Ideas & Trends; California Revisited: How Googie Was My Valley
description: WELCOME to the fabulous San Fernando Valley. Our tour today will take us to some of the Valley's postwar architectural gems. Notice the sweeping neon script on the front of Casa de Cadillac (1949), the same cursive used on the Cadillac name plate of the same year. Admire the original split-level Brady Bunch house, now slightly altered, where the fictional television family lived from 1969 to 1974. Don't miss the Laurelwood Apartments (1948), a moss-green complex snaking up a hill designed by the iconic modern architect R. M. Schindler. All these sites have recently hit or will soon be hitting the half-century mark. They're becoming, like, historic.

title: Beverly Whitbeck, Clint Cooper
description: Beverly Koot Whitbeck and C. Clinton Cooper were married on Friday afternoon at the Hudson River Club in New York. The Rev. Frank Gregori, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for JOHN ROTHER; Assessing New Rules for Managed Care
description: WEIGHING in on a controversy that has been stuck in Congressional gridlock for years, President Clinton issued new rules last week that promise quicker decisions for patients in disputes with managed-care companies and the right to appeal when insurance claims are denied.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Building Is Better, But Maladies Linger On

title: Snow Day Gone Bad
description: To avoid writing a school paper, 13-year-old Allie Thomson (Hallee Hirsh, above left) scoops a weather-making machine out of Santa's trash bin and covers Los Angeles in a blanket of snow on ''The Ultimate Christmas Present,'' a Disney Channel original movie that has its premiere on Friday at 7 p.m. But when flurries threaten to send the holidays into a tailspin, and a maniacal weatherman sets his sights on overtaking the world's Doppler screens, Allie finds herself in a race against time to return things to normal.

title: Irish Unions, Pay Lagging, Stage Protests
description: On Wednesday, trains across Ireland sat still in their stations. On Thursday, high school classrooms were empty. And this weekend, newsrooms are eerily quiet. After more than a decade of cordial industrial relations, Irish labor unions have returned to the picket lines with a series of intermittent one-day strikes by workers on the railroads and in hospitals, by airline pilots and journalists.

title: Kathy Pomerantz, Dave Feldman
description: Kathy Pomerantz and Dave Feldman were married last evening by Rabbi Robert Applestone at the Roslyn Claremont Hotel in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Where Westchester and Harlem Meet
description: IN the parking lot, hard by the Hudson River, S.U.V.'s with every conceivable bell and whistle jockey for space with battered gypsy cabs. In the produce section, sugar cane and green plantains are heaped beside shitake mushrooms and edible flowers. At the cash registers, one customer pays with an American Express gold card and the next with food stamps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAMBOLD, LT. COL. WILLIAM HENRY
description: WAMBOLD-Lt. Col. William Henry, on November 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Princess Guity Kadjar. Devoted father of Robin Kadjar Wambold, Kristin Kadjar Wambold-Liebling and Ali Edward Wambold. Adoring grandfather of five. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Sunday from 7-9PM. Funeral Mass St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. at 84th St. on Monday 10AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Heart Association or the World Wildlife Fund would be appreciated.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMELIN, DAVID B.
description: HERMELIN-David B. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourns the passing of our dear friend, longtime supporter, and former member of the Michigan Region Board of Directors, Ambassador David Hermelin. A constant source of inspiration and encouragement, David Hermelin believed passionately in strengthening Israel through science and technology research. He was a tireless philanthropic leader, whose efforts touched the lives of countless individuals. Amb. Hermelin was devoted to the mission of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute, furthering science for the benefit of humanity. We express our deepest sympathy to his wife Doreen, their children and the entire Hermelin family. Robert H. Asher, Chairman American Committee Albert Willner, M.D., President Martin Kraar, Exec. V.P. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THOUGH nothing can bring back the innocent hedonism and sweet excess that were the 1960's, Oliver Stone came pretty close with THE DOORS (1991). Plenty of excellent actors have proved just how hard it is to play a rock star credibly, but Val Kilmer pulls it off in grand style as Jim Morrison, the Doors' lead singer, sex symbol, poet and self-proclaimed lizard king. The film celebrates youth and beauty, and it recreates a time when drugs were seen as a search or an adventure, rather than an escape. Meg Ryan is the love of his life and Kyle MacLachlan is his bandmate Ray Manzarek, who spells out their mission early on: ''The planet is screaming for change, Morrison. We've got to make the myths'' -- Sunday at 12:30 and 6 p.m., Wednesday at 8 p.m. and Saturday at 8 p.m. on VH1.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Big-Band Theory
description: Jazz

title: Not a Sippin' Drink
description: No sooner do store windows announce that ''Le Beaujolais Nouveau est arrive'' than November's annual mini-debate begins. Traditionalists say the only Beaujolais worth drinking is vintage cask-aged wine from such top villages as Morgon, Moulin-a-Vent and Chenas. But liberal vinocrats, who adore the flirtatious gamay grape and think of nouveau as joie de vivre incarnate, can't slurp enough from Thanksgiving through Christmas.

title: Match Races Dropped From Olympic Games
description: Nipped in the bud. That's one way to describe Hannah Swett's Olympic dream.

title: Narrative Images' Alluring World
description: EVEN before anyone was writing, visual artists were telling tales. Narrative images have been a staple of art history and continue to inspire illustrators, painters and sculptors. Two exhibitions here at the Noyes Museum offer complementary responses to an artistic fascination for storytelling.

title: From Newscaster to Communications Guru
description: WHEN Mary Civiello tells her clients: ''Don't be evasive. This irritates reporters and they'll only keep digging,'' they listen. Ms. Civiello has prodded and dug into thousands of news stories during her 20-year career as a television reporter and anchor.

title: An Expanded European Union
description: The European Union can equivocate no longer. At a summit meeting early next month in Nice, France, the union's heads of state should firmly commit to enlarge the union within the next four years by taking in qualified new members from Central and Eastern Europe. A failure to do so would imperil the Continent's stability by reaffirming its division into two halves -- one united and prosperous, the other fragmented and still vulnerable to resentful national rivalries.

title: Makeover of the Month
description: Looking like a bald, wizened version of the lunar-pale alien he played in ''The Man Who Fell to Earth,'' David Bowie makes a haunting calendar boy. Mr. Bowie's self-portrait is among a dozen artworks likely to make ''Art Is Everywhere,'' a wall calendar for 2001, one of the season's most coveted collectibles.

title: Burgundy Recalls a Short, Eventful Life
description: Mary of Burgundy became one of the richest women in Europe after inheriting the Burgundian duchy in 1477, a dowry that included much of Flanders, Picardy, Luxembourg and the Franche-Comte. Although Louis XI immediately annexed portions of her territory, her wedding to the future Hapsburg emperor, Maximilian I, postponed French unification and altered the balance of power in Europe.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: ANOTHER WORLD, by Pat Barker. (Picador USA, $13.) Set in a modern-day northern English suburb, this novel explores the ways a family is haunted by old hatreds, violence and guilt, particularly the aftershocks of World War I. '' 'Another World' demonstrates the extraordinary immediacy and vigor of expression we have come to expect from Barker,'' Barry Unsworth wrote here in 1999. ''It is a powerful and moving and deeply humane study of the tyranny of the past and the quandaries of the present.''

title: Nearly Meals in Themselves
description: Mention Cartlidge & Browne to informed, thrifty wine lovers and they salivate.

title: Curse of the Wind Turns to Farmers' Blessing
description: For generations, the bittersweet question around the Schardin family table was this: What in God's name was Theodore Schardin thinking in 1884 when he stopped his wagon here, on a desolate ridge blasted by every last gust of wind that swept across the prairies?

title: Polarization of National Dialogue Mirrors Extremists of Left and Right
description: As one court case gives way to another and the presidential election of 2000 heads into yet another week, the verbal mudslinging grows ever fiercer, dealing the English language, already reeling from dismaying levels of phoniness, spin and distortion, yet another blow. In Florida and Washington, hyperbole and venomous invective have become the order of the day.

title: TEENAGE DRIVERS
description: The Department of Transportation will begin enforcing a new set of laws on Jan. 1 that adds restrictions on teenage drivers. Under the new rules, 16-year-olds will still be eligible for learner's permits after completing a driving instruction program, a written exam and vision screening, but they will be allowed to operate a vehicle only with another licensed driver over 21 at their side. Other passengers will not be allowed in the car unless they live at the same address as the permit holder. Sixteen-year-olds will be banned from driving between midnight and 5 a.m., while 17-year-olds who have passed a behind-the-wheel test will be allowed to drive after midnight. Andrew Jacobs

title: G.O.P. Help For Absentees Is Detailed In Court Suit
description: In Seminole County, where the Republican elections chief allowed Republican Party workers to correct thousands of flawed absentee ballot applications, new details of the incident have emerged.

title: Neurosis in the City: It Goes Way Back
description: DOES it mean you're on the ball or neurotic when you're the first summer renter to resurface in East Hampton?

title: Zoo Gets A White Alligator
description: THE alligator is a vision in white.

title: In Philippines, The President Could Evade An Ouster Yet
description: President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines may not be a political scientist, but as a former movie hearthtrob he knows his scripts.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the quarterly Education Life section on Nov. 12 about changes at boarding schools in the last 50 years misstated the date of the first admissions of girls to Phillips Exeter Academy. They were admitted as day students in 1970 and as boarding students in 1971, not in 1973. The article also referred incorrectly to the traditional chiming of the school's bell. It takes place on the hour and for dormitory check-in, breakfast and assemblies, not just to signal the class change.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, VIOLA (BERKO)
description: BLOCK-Viola (Berko). Age 79, after an illness on November 22, 2000. Loving wife of Irving. Adoring mother of Roberta, (Frisch), and Jocelyn, mother-in-law of Charles. Cherished grandmother of Danielle, Andrew and Michael. Sister of Otto and the late Louis Berko. Dear aunt and great-aunt. Services Sunday, November 26, at 11:00 AM, Riverside Nassau-North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. 516-487-9600.

title: Boy Who Screamed at God Finds Hope at a Gallery
description: Brookie Maxwell's preoccupation as an artist is tension and redemption on the streets of New York. Mostly tension.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, WILLIAM LAWRENCE (LARRY)
description: CLARK-William Lawrence (Larry). Died, age 68, at his Wolf Creek, MT home on November 20, 2000. Former resident of Teaneck, NJ. Son of the late Florence and William L. Clark, Sr. Survived by cousins: Louise Smith, Katharine DeLong, Anne Koester, Sidney Osborne and Peggy Huber.

title: The Time Shortage In Family Care
description: A significant number of working Americans cannot take time off when family members need care, according to a new book by Dr. Jody Heymann, associate professor of health and social behavior at the Harvard School of Public Health.

title: Uncertainty Freezes Plans for Inaugural Partying
description: To celebrate the presidential inauguration, the St. Regis Hotel, just two blocks from the White House, is offering a $100,000 package, complete with Champagne, caviar and breakfast with Larry King of CNN.

title: Kay Nagata and Blair McMillen
description: SOME people say you can judge musicians' personalities by the instruments they play. Friends of Blair Carter McMillen, a 30-year-old concert pianist, describe him as a typically relaxed keyboard player. ''The lower pitch the instrument, the more laid back the person,'' said Immanuel Davis, a flutist and a friend. ''Oboe players are often uptight people. Brass players are beer drinkers. Blair is definitely on the low-pitch, laid-back end of the spectrum.''

title: Children's Heros in Many Hues
description: AT a children's play group 10 years ago, Toni Parker and a few of her friends discussed the alarming paucity of books for young readers about famous African-American women. She has literally made it her business to find culturally diverse children's books ever since.

title: Who'll Pay the Bill for the Tax Dodgers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Church Offers Alternative for Holiday Buying
description: WITH the holiday shopping season under way, those who dread malls, hate mail-order catalogs and are wary of e-commerce may want to visit the Alternative Gift Market at Grace Episcopal Church here next Saturday and Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUBRY, LYLA
description: AUBRY-Lyla. Lewis and Marilyn Kaye and associates at Prudential MLB Kaye International mourn the loss of their longtime friend and colleague. She will be missed by all of us. Our condolences to her family and friends.

title: Lauren Rosen, Jeff Ratner
description: Lauren Michelle Rosen, the daughter of Marilyn and Alan Rosen of New City, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeff Scott Ratner, the son of Barbara and Samuel Ratner of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Clifford Kulwin officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, CARRIE SKLOOT
description: ROSENBLATT-Carrie Skloot. On November 22, 2000. Age 94. Beloved wife of the late Jacob H. Rosenblatt. Loving mother of Emily Spiegel and her husband Jerry, and the late Eleanor Sondock. Adoring grandmother of Pamela Sanders, Lise Wilks, Clifford, Bradford and Joanne Sondock and great grandmother of Jordan, Remy, Erin, David, Andrew, Jack, Jason, Joshua and Eleanor. Dear sister of Evelyn Tobin. Interior Designer and former National Vice President and Forest Hills Chapter President of the National Women's Division, American Technion Society. Services are Friday, November 24, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Ave & 76 St. Contributions in her memory may be made to National Women's Division, ATS, 810 7th Ave., New York, NY 10019.

title: Style; The Legacy
description: Throughout her grown-up life, Linda McCartney was the target of some pretty nasty press. Since her death two years ago, many of her most vitriolic critics have conceded that the criticism was unfounded. Principal among her sins seems to have been her decision to accept a marriage proposal from the most sought after Beatle and her reluctance to shave her underarm hair. Her substantial body of work as a photographer (regarded until recently as just celebrity snaps) was eclipsed by her animal activism and outspoken vegetarianism. But a 1987 show of McCartney's work at the Royal Photographic Society in England, followed later by one at the International Center of Photography in New York, helped change the critics' perceptions. And two books of her photographs -- Roadworks'' and ''Sixties: Portrait of an Era'' -- finally established her credentials as a serious photographer.

title: The Isles' Losing Streak Grows to 8
description: If only. It was another of those if-only games for the Islanders tonight, a 4-3 loss to the superior Detroit Red Wings.

title: The People's Czar
description: Midnight Diaries

title: Parents Make Toys For Disabled Children
description: THIRTY years ago, when her son Kenny was born, Joanne Consentino began making fruitless trips down the aisles of toy stores.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about the director George Cukor misidentified the writer of the song ''Farewell, Amanda,'' which was included in Cukor's movie ''Adam's Rib.'' It was Cole Porter, not Noel Coward.

title: A Christmas Extravaganza Has Neighbors Seeing Red
description: Dominick Casale said he started decorating his house in 1990 in order to express his Christmas spirit and raise money for charity. At first there were squadrons of animatronic animals and enough lights to be visible from space. Over time, the spirit moved Mr. Casale to invite choirs and other live acts onto a large stage in front of his lawn and perform on weekend evenings between late November and early January.

title: A Bad Experience With an Au Pair
description: To the Editor:

title: If You're Devout, Get Out!
description: God's Name In Vain

title: November 19-25; France Honors Julia Child
description: Julia Child, the cookbook author and television show hostess who has been popularizing haute cuisine for four decades, was awarded the Legion of Honor, France's highest award. ''I am very, very proud,'' she said after the award was pinned to her jacket at Le Meridien hotel in Boston. ''I adore France.'' Ms. Child, 88, wrote ''Mastering the Art of French Cooking'' with Simone Beck and Louisette Bertholle in 1961, and two years later started her first television show, ''The French Chef,'' the first of many in which she demonstrated Gallic culinary techniques with humor, irreverence and unique American style.

title: Ideas & Trends; Such a Deal: A Million Tons Of Animal Parts, to Go
description: IN 1988, when the British realized that feed laced with contaminated animal parts might be linked to the spread of mad cow disease, they banned British farmers from feeding animal meal to their cows. They did nothing, however, to stop British feed companies from exporting their infected wares -- often at a reduced price. Such products were sold to European nations until 1990 and to the third world until 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFER, GEORGE E.
description: SCHAEFER-George E. Of Ardsley on Hudson. On Nov. 21, 2000. Survived by his wife, daughter and grandson. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions to Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Avenue, Hawthorne, New York 10532.

title: Heading Out in Red
description: Flaming red, America's favorite pick-up-your-spirits color, began appearing in New York long before December, when it is a tradition with holiday shoppers. Last month, red clothes were seen in Paris, an unheard-of notion in Europe, where dark and neutral colors are the norm. In both cities, there was the unexpected sight of men wearing red sweater coats, suits, sports jackets and even a hooded raincoat suggesting Father Christmas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDS, LOUIS W.
description: FIELDS-Louis W. The partners of the former firm of Fields, Fischgrund & Aerenson CPAs mourn the passing of our very much loved partner and friend. Lou possessed a level of competency and technical skills rarely achieved by one in his profession. He combined this with a keen insight into the development of the best of relationships with clients, friends, employees and partners. Our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Esther, his daughter Jacqueline, his daughter-in-law Gloria and their families. He will remain forever in our hearts and thoughts. Robert and Marjorie Aerenson Daniel and Geraldine Soba Fred and Barbara Bornstein Leonard and Lois Lichter Cecile D. Fischgrund

title: November 19-25; Norma Rae at Amazon?
description: And now the aging labor movement takes on one of the superstars of the new economy, Amazon.com. The Communications Workers of America, the United Food and Commercial Workers, and the Prewitt Fund, an independent organizing group, are seeking to unionize 400 of Amazon's customer-service workers and 5,000 of its warehouse workers. With the workers' vaunted stock options nosediving in value, many Amazon workers have begun grumbling about their modest wages, causing them to look more kindly toward unions. If labor succeeds in organizing Amazon's workers -- some labor experts say it is a long shot -- it would be labor's biggest foothold in high-technology America. Steven Greenhouse

title: Soaring Bids Derail School Capital Projects
description: AFTER voters in Sag Harbor approved a $13.9 million bond referendum, the school district began preparations for an addition to the Pierson Middle School-High School. But when the first bids came in this September, almost a year and a half after the vote, the lowest bid was $5 million more than the amount budgeted.

title: Rebels Who Were More Angry Than Mad
description: WHICH actor except Jack Nicholson could have played Randle Patrick McMurphy in ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest''? Gene Hackman and Marlon Brando both passed on the role. Burt Reynolds was a candidate. But Nicholson is McMurphy, the man who put the Man into ''manic'' -- the charmer only a lobotomy could wrestle into submission. Never mind that in Ken Kesey's best-selling novel, McMurphy is a stocky redhead, with a badly stitched gash across his cheekbone and nose, which means that if the director Milos Forman had been true to the novel, Mr. Nicholson could have received Oscar nominations two years in a row for tough guys with bloody noses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, FRANCIS
description: HYMAN-Francis. Died peacefully on Thanksgiving Day. Survived by devoted son David B. Levy (Jane), cherished grandchildren James (Rosemary) and Douglas. Forever in our hearts.

title: Food Drives Find Cupboard Is Nearly Bare
description: Bread and rolls were missing from the Thanksgiving boxes given out to the needy by the Christian Life Fellowship in Orange County this year, and the church decided to hold back on giving out cheese soup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALITZ, CLARENCE YALE JR.
description: PALITZ-Clarence Yale Jr. Died November 23 following a brief illness at age 69. He was the Chairman of the Board of Financial Federal Corporation, a major leasing and financial services company based in New York. A graduate of Dartmouth College and New York University Business School, he served as an Officer in the United States Navy. His career was devoted to the heavy equipment leasing and financing industry. He served on numerous corporate boards in the banking industry in the tri-state area. In 1963 he founded Commercial Alliance Corporation (ASE) with his brother. In 1989, he established Financial Federal Corporation (NYSE) along with his son and brother. Mr. Palitz was a patron of the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic, the American Ballet Theatre and a major benefactor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He has been mentor to many and his leadership will be greatly missed. He is survived by his adoring wife Anka, loving daughter Suzanne and her husband Joel Bauman, son Michael and his wife Gabrielle, stepson Gregory Kriser and his wife Sandra, brother Bernard Palitz, devoted granddaughters Elianora and Sophie, and step grandson Ryan. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on November 27 at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers donations should be made to the Central Park Conservancy or to the charity of your choice.

title: Pastoral Pleasures At an Antiques Show
description: WHILE antiques are forever, demand for specific categories waxes and wanes. The current hot tickets are garden furniture and architectural elements.

title: The Big, Bad, Fun Gun
description: The Black Rock Desert, about 100 miles north of Reno, Nev., gets its name from lava rocks the size of soccer balls that litter the desert floor. It is a vast and mountainous region, and few people venture here without a purpose. Mine was to join three guys trying to hit a rock, from two miles away, with a .50-caliber sniper rifle, the most powerful gun you can buy.

title: November 19-25; A Grim Week in the Mideast
description: A weekend that raised hopes of a lull in the fighting introduced a grim week in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. An attack on a settlers' school bus killed two and maimed several children, and Israel responded with its most intensive bombardment of Palestinian territory to date. Egypt, one of Israel's two Arab allies, temporarily broke off diplomatic relations. Two days later, Israeli soldiers shot to death a carful of Palestinians in Gaza. That night, another terror bomb hit, this time inside Israel, killing two and wounding scores in the coastal town of Hadera. By week's end, there was a phone call between Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, engineered by Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, but hopes that the conflict could turn a corner grew ever fainter. Deborah Sontag

title: Text of Lieberman Statement
description: The following is the text of a statement made by Senator Joseph Lieberman tonight concerning the Florida vote certification, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: The State of the City: Packed Like Sardines; Many See Crowds as Progress; Others Wish Prosperity Hadn't Brought Company
description: Maybe you're thinking the city just seems more crowded but really isn't. Maybe you imagine that it's just the tourists or that you're just cranky or that it's that time of year. Maybe you figure it's just the No. 6 train or the cheese department at Fairway. Or you think New York City has always been like this.

title: Election Day: Time for a 17th-Inning Stretch; Disenfranchised in Lyon
description: To the Editor:

title: Statement by Florida Secretary of State
description: The following is the text of a statement by Florida Secretary of State Katherine Harris, Commissioner Bob Crawford and Director Clay Roberts regarding the certification of Florida votes, from the state cabinet room, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-26-00: Expert Opinion; Or Not to Vote
description: Amid all the debate about the presidential election -- how important is the graphic design of a ballot? how soon should election results be announced? -- surprisingly little has been said about whether voting itself, at least voting American style, is the best way to canvass the nation's political will. Herewith, a collection of statisticians, political scientists and economists discuss some of the leading alternatives. Phyllis Stinson

title: A Tug-of-War for the Public's Attention
description: In the media tent city outside the Emergency Operations Center here, a Bush campaign spokesman made the rounds, inviting almost every reporter he could find to spend a few minutes with Gov. Christie Whitman of New Jersey.

title: Norway to Open A 15-Mile Tunnel
description: A toll-free tunnel in Norway that will allow drivers to avoid the sometimes impassable mountainous route from Aurland to Laerdal is scheduled to open tomorrow.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Book Review last Sunday with a review of ''Frank O. Gehry: Outside In,'' by Jan Greenberg and Sandra Jordan, gave credit incompletely for the design of the building shown. Along with Frank O. Gehry, the designers were Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Steichen and His Times
description: Often criticized for sentimentality and commercialism and sometimes confused with Alfred Stieglitz, the photographer Edward Steichen has nonetheless left a far-reaching legacy to American culture. He was an early champion of photography as art and, later, of photography as the carrier of humanitarian ideals. The work of major European artists like Matisse and Cezanne were introduced to the United States through his efforts. A consummate technician, Steichen (1879-1973) developed aerial photography during World War I, while his masterly play of glamour and celebrity in commercial photography earned him record fees in the 1930's. From his 15-year tenure as head of photography at the Museum of Modern Art, Steichen wielded great influence, and in 1955 he produced the celebrated photography exhibition, ''The Family of Man.'' In STEICHEN'S LEGACY: Photographs, 1895-1973, (Knopf, $100), Joanna Steichen, the photographer's third and last wife, takes us on a chatty, sometimes catty, and altogether idiosyncratic tour of her husband's life's work. Steichen, then an 80-year-old widower who met the 26-year-old Joanna through his brother-in-law Carl Sandburg in 1959, married her the following year. In this book she has organized more than 300 of his photographs into 19 sections, each with commentary. This abundance of images gives a good picture of Steichen's breadth and artistry -- urban scenes, portraits of financiers, artists and actors, Gorham flatware, propaganda and exquisitely rendered images of plants and flowers. From Joanna Steichen we see what a life force Steichen was, even in his 80's. And from the book's elegant reproductions, we get a good sense of the times that Steichen helped create. Rosemary Ranck

title: Edward Ludlum, 80, Noted Theater Director
description: Edward Ludlum, who won praise for his stage directing on both coasts, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles, where he had helped to establish professional theater. He was 80.

title: All the Pretty Little Horses
description: LET'S not talk about the literal horse, which H&M will probably print on a tank top, but the whole dark, countryside, belle epoque lifestyle thing surrounding the horse. Is it the 80's? I don't know. I am trying to get to the horse of the matter.''

title: Corrections
description: The key on Page 6 of the Book Review today for the cover illustration of Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. and several associates, in connection with a review of the first volume of his autobiography, misidentifies the figure at the far left. It is Stewart Alsop, not Joseph Alsop.

title: The World; How to Commit the Perfect Dictatorship
description: THE Southeast Asian country formerly known as Burma may not be a perfect dictatorship, but it's as close to perfection as is humanly (or perhaps inhumanly) possible at the beginning of the 21st century.

title: Q & A
description: Patagonia Tours

title: From E-Commerce, Business Moves to Brick and Mortar
description: The owners of Steamer Trunk Merchants, a new shop on Main Street in Tarrytown, took an unusual path to retailing. They started their business two years ago with a Web site (www.steamertrunkmerchants.com) and used the profits to move from e-commerce into the more traditional kind.

title: An Immigrant's Sculptures Are Inspired by an Iconic Photo
description: Unlike many artists who sell their work on the sidewalks of SoHo every weekend, Sergio Furnari, a sculptor, does not use a folding table. His work is mounted on top of his car, a 1948 gray Dodge sedan that he parks on the corner of Spring Street and West Broadway.

title: The Black And White Album
description: London's grooviest let down their hair.

title: Palestinian Frustration
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Is Said to Harbor Unshakeable Conviction That He Has Won the Election
description: One psychological force above all others motivates Vice President Al Gore as he endures his postelection purgatory: he believes -- no, he knows -- he won the election, people who deal with him daily say.

title: Where Nostalgia and Gallic Flavors Mix
description: DINERS yearning for old-fashioned French food in an old-world country dining room will have their craving eased with a visit to Buffet de la Gare. In the 20 years since Gwenael and Annie Goulet took over the restaurant, the basic menu and preparation has changed little. No other restaurant in our area remains so fixed in time.

title: Stress Rocks Coach's World
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Shea's Send-Off Is Bright for a Time
description: Time finally ran out on Terry Shea this afternoon. But late in the game he continued to look at a manila folder of plays as if he could find something, anything, in his precise block letters that would be the inspiration for one last miracle.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARTER, DAVID
description: CARTER, DAVID I'm up before the crack of dawn still tired from the day before I sit in front of Eckford Street in my car I nap and snore I close the shop late in the dark my body so strained from the day my eyes keep closing while I drive and I fall asleep in my dinner tray Thank you for all you were to me, Love, Lcarter@carterspray.com

title: November 19-25; Peruvian Leader Makes Sudden Move, to Japan
description: Peru's president, Alberto K. Fujimori, was the longest-serving leader in South America, and the continent's most authoritarian, until he submitted his resignation to the Congress in an unsigned fax from Japan. Succeeding him was Valentin Paniagua, who had just been elected president of Congress. Mr. Fujimori's cabinet was caught by surprise.
