Even his closest backers expressed shock that he had a Japanese passport.

title: As Closets Bulge, Americans' Taste in Gifts Often Turns Toward the Taste Buds
description: Ask the holiday shoppers who are already pouring through the malls that serve prosperity-enriched America what they want for gifts, and many just groan. Their closets, drawers, attics and garages are bursting with the bounty of affluence, they say, and except for the young, they have just one locale left. That is their stomachs.

title: With Baby's First Christmas, Parents See New Holiday Magic
description: A FEW weeks before Christmas last year, Leigh Curry Young and her husband, Frank, stood at the village green here. It was the town's annual tree-lighting ceremony, and they were singing carols. When it came time to sing ''The First Noel,'' Mrs. Young's eyes filled with tears, just as they did when that song was played in church during the holiday season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVEDISIAN, ARMEN GEORGE
description: AVEDISIAN-Armen George. Beloved husband of JoEllyn; loving father of Guy (Margot), Vann (Heidi), and Donna (Craig Chanti) Avedisian; step-father of Lisa (Darrell) Brown. Visitation 3:00-7:00 PM Sunday at BlakeLamb Funeral Home, 1035 North Dearborn St., Chicago, IL. Funeral service, 11:00 AM Monday at First St. Paul Lutheran Church, 1301 N. LaSalle Blvd., Chicago, IL. Donations may be made to The Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, Inc., 52 Vanderbilt, New York, New York 10017, or The Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago, 345 East Superior Street, Chicago, IL 60611. Funeral info: 312-944-5594.

title: The Election; 2nd String Of Spin Left Idle
description: WITH the abundance of prime- time talking heads during the coverage of Indecision 2000, the market for pundits would seem to be booming. Gail Evans, an executive vice-president at CNN in charge of booking guests for its news programs and talk shows, said CNN has booked about 60 guests per day. But, she added, with 24 hours to fill, using up 60 guests ''is not difficult.''

title: Business Diary: Quality of Its Quantity Wins E-Mailer an Award
description: At a time when many e-mail users are grappling with how to reduce the amount of solicitations, commonly known as spam, that they receive over the Internet, an award has been devised for an e-mail pitch that rises above the others.

title: As Air Aruba Falters, Others Fill the Gap
description: Air Aruba, the national carrier for one of the Caribbean's most popular destinations, suspended operations indefinitely last month, leaving hundreds of tourists attracted to the island's beautiful white beaches and lively casinos temporarily stranded.

title: Chorus Girls of Harlem Challenge Father Time
description: IN the days when big bands ruled, back in the 20's, 30's and 40's, there were two New Yorks, one black, one white. The races rarely mixed in business and social gatherings. And they rarely mixed at all on the stages of Manhattan's prestigious clubs and theaters, where elaborately dressed chorus girls were an integral part of the lineup.

title: Mussina to Narrow Wide Array of Choices
description: Amid growing belief that pitcher Mike Mussina will sign with the Yankees, his agent said yesterday that he expects Mussina to reduce the leading contenders for his services to three or four early this week.

title: A Historic Cemetery Wins New Friends
description: SINCE Hartford is a city in which addressing the needs of living residents has officials running from one crisis to the next, caring for the dead ones tends to be a low priority.

title: Gore Vows to Continue Fight for Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Hours before his opponent, Governor George W. Bush of Texas, was certified as the winner of Florida's 25 electoral votes, Vice President Al Gore sat in his living room and insisted today that he had to fight on for the presidency because all of Florida's votes have not been counted yet.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about sculptures in Theodore Roosevelt Park that are bronze castings of termite mounds misstated the artist's given name. He is Steve Tobin, not Scott. The article also misstated the location of Montefiore Park, where the artist has installed similar sculptures. It is at 138th Street and Broadway in Harlem, not in the Bronx.

title: The Long Shadow Of Ailey's Great 'Cry'
description: THE audience wouldn't stop cheering when Judith Jamison danced Alvin Ailey's masterpiece ''Cry'' at its premiere on May 4, 1971, at City Center. ''They went crazy,'' Ms. Jamison says.

title: Sara Ugarte, Alfonso Aramendia
description: Sara Dorothy Ugarte, a daughter of Allyson and Jaime Ugarte of Arlington, Va., was married yesterday to Alfonso Carlos Aramendia, a son of Pilar Rodriguez de Austria and Col. Luis Aramendia of Zaragoza, Spain. The Rev. Francisco de Borja i Sirvent, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at El Paular, a monastery in Rascafria, Spain.

title: New Religious Clash on Indonesian Island
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 25  At least 10 people, most Christians, have been killed and 16 are missing in the latest fighting between Christians and Muslims in the Moluccas, the police said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANCOCK, MACK HILLIARD
description: HANCOCK-Mack Hilliard. On November 22, 2000. Beloved husband of Eline N. Brother of J.P. Hancock, S.C. David Riggs and Elizabeth Winter. Also survived by 11 nieces and nephews and several brothers and sisters-in-law. Memorial service 3 PM, Monday, at Grace Memorial Episcopal Church.

title: After Battle, Peace Seems Unlikely
description: The slender prospects of an early resolution of the nation's electoral impasse dwindled further over the long holiday weekend, and some now see it persisting into January.

title: IN BRIEF: Trends; WESTCHESTER AHEAD OF POPULATION CURVE
description: Nationally, one in every five Americans will be considered elderly by 2050; in Westchester, those numbers have already been reached. As a result, the Westchester Millennium Aging Project is collecting data and personal stories from elderly residents, those who help take care of them and family members at 20 focus groups and from 140 community surveys in Westchester communities. The data focuses on transportation, housing, long-term care services, employment, retirement and legal/financial services. Elsa Brenner

title: Going to Cuba
description: To the Editor: About ''Traveling to Cuba Is as Tricky as Ever'' (Correspondent's Report, Nov. 5): I was disappointed to see a travel agency president saying that before she'd send clients to Cuba, she'd want to sample the food and accommodations to see if they would ''live up to their expectations.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSS, SIDNEY
description: GROSS-Sidney. A beloved chapter in our family's history has closed, but a new one will open soon. In the midst of both sorrow and joy, you remain central in our hearts and memories always. Zenith, the children and grandchildren

title: Never-Fail Fascination, Courtesy of Casey Jones
description: FOR more than 50 years, the Stamford Model Railroad Club's trains and trolleys have chugged their way into children's holiday memories. The tradition continues next weekend.

title: Shelly Cornell, David Wolfe Jr.
description: Roberta Shelton Cornell, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert W. Cornell of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to David Lindsey Wolfe Jr., a son of Dr. Lisa Reynolds Wolfe and Mr. Wolfe of New York. The Rev. Gary Miller performed the ceremony at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford.

title: Safety Worries as Michigan Hunters Take Guns Up Trees
description: It is deer hunting season in Michigan, and hunters who climb trees with loaded shotguns have state officials redoubling safety education efforts.

title: A History of Himself
description: A LIFE IN THE

title: Bush Is Declared Winner in Florida, but Gore Vows to Contest Results
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 26  The State of Florida tonight declared Gov. George W. Bush of Texas the winner of its presidential election by 537 votes out of nearly 6 million cast. He promptly declared that meant he had won the White House, and vowed to "undertake the responsibility of preparing to serve as America's next president."

title: Island Idyll, For a Song
description: LAST winter, when my friend Amy and I first talked about meeting in Thailand, we pictured ourselves on a remote palm-studded island, swimming in a translucent sea. She pored over guidebooks in San Francisco, and I polled friends and fellow travelers in New York, and we beamed lists of ''undiscovered'' islands to each other across cyberspace. But even with 1,680 miles of coastline on two seas to choose from, most people pinpointed the same three or four destinations. If everyone had found the same Eden, we wondered, could it really be perfect?

title: Trying to Interpret a Ballot's Goosebumps
description: When is a dimpled ballot counted as a vote, and when is it not?

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Saturday's Child

title: MEADOWLANDS BONDS
description: The Meadowlands Racetrack in East Rutherford will have a new tote board and the parking lots at the Meadowlands sports complex will be repaved with $15 million from the sale of bonds authorized by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority as part of the latest round of capital improvements for the sports complex. Other work will include a new fire protection system and electrical cables at Giants Stadium. Debt service on the bonds of slightly more than $1 million a year will be paid by the state as part of the state's yearly contribution to the Sports Authority. Karen DeMasters

title: TROOPERS' WORK SCHEDULE
description: With State Police morale already hurt by allegations of racial profiling, the troopers union said spirits got even lower last week, when troopers were told they would work a five-day week instead of the current four-day, 10-hour-shift schedule. The state police commander, Col. Carson Dunbar, said the two-hour overlap periods resulting from the current shifts are a waste of time and will end in January. Ed Lennon, president of the State Troopers Fraternal Association of New Jersey, said Colonel Dunar ''has chosen to sink morale to its lowest depth ever.'' Steve Strunsky

title: In Fine Arts, and College Bound
description: AT the recent College Portfolio Day at the Huntington School of Fine Arts, 52 high school seniors confronted the beginning of the process they had been working toward for years. It was the first step to get into art college.

title: Habitats/Manhattan; Squirrel Hill to West 80's: A Tale of Two Cities
description: RICHARD AND KATHY MONTGOMERY have lived contentedly in Pittsburgh most of their lives, happily raising a daughter and working, he as a tax lawyer and she as an artist. But New York always appealed to them and so, with their only child away at college in New England, it seemed like a good moment to consider something new.

title: MUSIC; Rock Was Never Meant to Be in the High-Rent District
description: IN most cities in America, the welcome mat has been laid out for economic prosperity, but not here, where some residents perversely believe that the boom has been catastrophic. Because of it, San Francisco now has the highest rental rate per square foot of office space of anywhere in the country, as well as the highest rents and real estate prices. One result has been a number of evictions of nonprofit arts organizations, galleries, museums and dance spaces.

title: Behind the Smile
description: LEONARDO DA VINCI

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a store in Sleepy Hollow called Greene County misstated the surname of the family that founded it. It was Oliva, not Oliveri.

title: Chad, the Country
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-26-00: On Language; Snippy
description: 'You mean to tell me, Mr. Vice President,'' George W. Bush said incredulously to Al Gore on election night, ''you're retracting your concession?''

title: Haiti Sees A Candidate With a Pair Of Visions
description: The billboards declaring the inevitable went up even before the first vote had been cast. They boast a huge photograph of former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide with the simple and foregone declaration in Creole: ''February 7, 2001. Peace in the Head. Peace in the Belly.''

title: Luxury Tenants Yearn For Phones They Don't Have
description: ''The Ultimate in Brooklyn Heights Luxury,'' reads the brochure for 180 Montague Street, the 33-story tower now undergoing its final touches. A white-gloved concierge, a ''state of the art'' gym and dazzling views are included, says the publicity material, as are satellite television and high-speed Internet access.

title: Couples Who Aren't (or Who Shouldn't Be)
description: I HATE to say it, but ''Frasier'' just isn't the same since Niles and Daphne got together.

title: THEATER; When Ruth Draper Was Onstage, the World Was There
description: The monologist Ruth Draper was a kind of theatrical caviar that her fans could never get enough of. Born in New York in 1884, she brought her cast of characters to life -- shrewdly lampooned society wives and poignant immigrant grandmothers alike -- from the 1920's until her death in 1956. She wrote and performed nearly 40 monodramas, including probably her most famous: ''The Italian Lesson,'' a day in the life of a wealthy matron, and ''The Actress,'' an afternoon with a temperamental performer.

title: Alina Rocha Menocal, Christopher Rossbach
description: Alina Rocha Menocal and Christopher Allen Rossbach were married at the Roman Catholic Church of San Juan de Dios in Mexico City last evening. Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garcia, the retired bishop of the Chiapas Diocese in Mexico, performed the ceremony, with Rabbi Drorah O'Donnell Setel, a cousin of the bridegroom, taking part. Afterward, Judge Gabriela Izquierdo performed a civil ceremony at the Casino Espanol, a historic building in Mexico City.

title: Raptors Manage to Hold Off Ailing Knicks in a Thriller
description: Their condition kept getting downgraded as yesterday's game went on. Allan Houston inexplicably fouled out in the third quarter. A stomping and furious Jeff Van Gundy toyed with a rare ejection.

title: Help Us on Tuition
description: To the Editor:

title: At This Bar, Everything Is on the Table
description: She is a champion of social drinking, an unapologetic gossip who believes that everything, everything, should be discussed at her bar.

title: Yemen Links to bin Laden Gnaw at F.B.I. in Cole Inquiry
description: When an American guided missile destroyer sailed into Aden six weeks ago, the Pentagon, in effect, was taking a conscious risk. It was making use of the best natural harbor on the Arabian peninsula, but depending for the ship's safety on a government that relies on the uncertain loyalties of army officers, Muslim clerics and tribal leaders with long-standing links to Islamic militant groups.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: SHOW AND TELL

title: An Internal Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: A Season Full of Music, With Tons of Hallelujahs
description: FROM the busy rehearsals of October and November come the choral concerts of December.

title: The Future, if Any, of Black Theater
description: A FEW years back, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright August Wilson gave an address in which he dismissed the notion of theater as a unifying medium to bring races together, and instead called for the support of more African-American theaters and playwrights developing works culturally specific to black audiences.

title: SOAPBOX; 'Sections' Are for Grapefruit
description: IF I believed everything I read in the newspapers, I'd think I was living in some strange, befuddling place journalists in New York insist on calling a ''section.''

title: The Neediest Cases
description: This past autumn, the Census Bureau reported that the percentage of people living in poverty, nationwide, had dropped from 12.7 percent in 1998 to 11.8 in 1999, the lowest percentage in 21 years. This was good news, though it had the effect, as nationwide averages do, of obscuring local conditions. In New York City, the poverty rate remains far higher than the national average, declining from 24.2 percent in 1997-98 to 21.8 percent in 1998-99. For children, the poverty rate fell from 36.2 percent to 32.9 percent. These are promising trends, but the numbers tell us almost nothing about the meaning of poverty in this city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE HAVENON, ANDRE VICTOR
description: de HAVENON-Andre Victor. On November 20, 2000. Beloved husband of Susan and devoted father of Victor. Cherished son of Carolyn. Loving brother of Michael, David, Rebecca, Dan, Alex, Gary and Sarah. Caring uncle to nephews and nieces. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Strangers to National Stage Join Vote-Counting Drama
description: They will begin meeting on Tuesday afternoon, eight Republicans and six Democrats who were named to a select committee of the Florida Legislature on Friday. While charged with investigating voting irregularities in Florida, these 14 strangers to the stage of national politics could ultimately play an important role in determining the outcome of the presidential election.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE VISITOR

title: Football Fans To Invade Baltimore
description: Next weekend, Baltimore will be the site of a military invasion, one that the city is happy to see. On Saturday, the Army-Navy football game will come to the city for the first time since 1944. The game, one of the most famous rivalries in college football, will be played in PSINet Stadium, and even though all the tickets are sold out, festivities surrounding the event are open to everyone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUHL, BENJAMIN
description: DUHL-Benjamin. On Nov. 23, 2000, peacefully at age 91. Loving husband of Shirley Katz Duhl and the late Ethel Cohen Duhl. Devoted father of Janet Spector (Dr. Joseph) and Roger Duhl (Diane Wild). Cherished grandfather of Douglas M. Spector (Ossie), Lisa Spector Rothkrug (Adam), Dana Spector Kimmel (Scott), Alexandra Duhl and Danielle Duhl. Greatgrandfather of Daniel, Eric and Sara Spector, Rachel and Emily Rothkrug, and Jack, David and Lily Kimmel. Burial private. Shiva will be observed Sunday evening, Monday and Tuesday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Spector.

description: THE LAW OF AVERAGES

description: We've seen the cashmere cardigan with the ball gown skirt and the baby jean jacket with the silk slip dress. The incongruously casual coverup for spring 2001 is the corduroy jacket.

description: A Sort-of Leaning Tower

title: Bench Mark: Divided We Stand; If at First You Don't Secede . . .
description: SOONER or later, we are told, this will all end.

description: BALLIET-Agnes Bohrer. Your loss is overwhelming to your family and friends but the memories of your life's performance make us celebrate you with everlasting and loving memories. Cronin and Baumgartner families

description: Lifting a Balloon at a Fund-Raiser

title: The Camera as Space Explorer
description: A camera can sometimes see things the eye cannot and David Malin, one of the world's leading astronomical photographers, specializes in these types of pictures.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Nov. 5 about the sale of Resorts International in Atlantic City misstated the headquarters location of one new owner, Colony Capital LL. It is in Los Angeles, not the Bahamas.

title: Italian Film Festival Takes On Stereotypes
description: IN an effort to change the frequently negative images of Italian-Americans in movies and on television the Cinema Arts Center in Huntington opens on Friday ''Italian-American Film Festival: Other Voices.''

title: Look in the Windows, but Don't Change the Facades
description: To protect ''one of the world's premier shopping streets,'' the Landmarks Preservation Commission has approved strict design rules for boutiques along the busiest stretch of Madison Avenue.

title: Elizabeth Dover, Steven Baker
description: Elizabeth Claire Dover, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George J. Dover of Baltimore, was married last evening to Steven Douglas Baker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dewey Baker of Mount Sidney, Va. Cantor Jan Morrison officiated at the Elkridge Furnace Inn in Elkridge, Md.

title: Hitting the Deck
description: Guests on Carnival Cruises' 2,642-passenger Destiny, which departs from San Juan, can get aboard faster with a new portable check-in device. It allows embarkation agents to issue boarding passes at airports, hotels or anywhere else they meet passengers.

title: Friendly Aliens Invade Galleries
description: BUG-EYED and colorfully dressed like atomic-age samurai, Japanese tin toy robots mesmerized American children in the 1950's and 60's. The robots moved like tanks, beaming light, breathing fire and wobbling to a halt as their batteries died.

title: 'I'd Been Praying That He'd Find Me'
description: It was a pleasure to read Lorina Quigley's account of a birth mother's feelings about her son (Lives: Courtney Eldridge, Nov. 5). Too often, the news media portray us as women who want no contact with their lost children. My own son was born and relinquished in New York in 1970. We found each other in 1999. It is a joy to have him in my life now.

title: Selling Shares Now To Save on Taxes Later
description: DON'T wait too much longer to review investments if you want to trim that tax bill next April. The market's volatility this year may have left you with gains in some areas and losses in others that can be paired to cut taxes.

title: The Mavs' Maverick Owns Things His Way
description: The photo on the Dallas Morning News Web site shows a peeved man, arms folded, chest puffed out, waiting in the arena corridor for the officials to enter their dressing room.

title: Falsely Charged, Jailed, Acquitted, Jobless
description: To the Editor:

title: Accord Will Let Picket Signs Go Down and Wages Up
description: Thirteen months after workers started picketing, a lumber company and its union have signed a contract offering the employees higher wages, back pay and improved pension and health insurance plans.

title: Ideas & Trends: Old Money; Vodka and Caviar for Everyone!
description: CZARIST-ERA Russian bonds are a bit like old baseball cards. Generations of European and even a few American investors threw them away, yellowing and tattered, by the stack. They had, after all, been utterly worthless ever since the Communists came into power in 1917.

title: Gore Lawyers File Challenges to Contest Election Results
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 27 -- As promised, lawyers for Vice President Al Gore's presidential campaign went to court today to try to overturn the declaration that proclaimed George W. Bush the winner of Florida's presidential election.

title: Gruden Relates, and It Shows
description: If you coach the Oakland Raiders, you had better figure out a way to deal with Al Davis. That is like trying to pick berries without getting pricked or walking through a sprinkler without getting wet.

title: Historic Hybrid in Iowa
description: GARST FARM RESORTS looks like a classic Iowa homestead, but it occupies a unique place in history: Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union visited in 1959 in an effort to improve his country's agriculture. A hybrid, as its name suggests, the farm resort is a true agricultural operation that takes overnight guests and offers activities like riding, fishing and hiking. It's a form of agritainment, or agritourism -- a growing sideline for struggling family farmers and small rural towns.

title: Commercial Property/Long Island; Facelift for Aging Shopping Center in Stony Brook
description: A RUNDOWN 30-year-old Tudor-style shopping center in Stony Brook, whose picturesque-village concept never took off, is getting a $5 million overhaul that will provide it with a more conventional appearance.

title: BACKTALK; Dynasties Come and Go, but Fight Songs Endure
description: Even though the game of football continues to evolve, many of the college fight songs are classics that have lasted for generation after generation after generation.

title: A Hobby Becomes A Day Job
description: A FEW years ago, a survey for American Woodworker magazine concluded that more than 17 million people in the United States considered themselves amateur woodworkers.

title: A Musical Powerhouse Returns to the Stage
description: MUSICAL theater mavens know that nothing is going to harm them, not when Beth Fowler is around.

title: Post-Holiday Cheer is Not Enough
description: A snapback on Friday lifted some of the gloom hanging over the stock market, but it was not enough to pull any of the major gauges out of negative territory for the week. After the Thanksgiving holiday, investors swooped in to buy battered technology issues, prompted not only by low prices but also by hope for an end to the long presidential election stalemate. In one of its steepest surges on record, the Nasdaq composite index soared 149.04 points, or 5.4 percent, in the Friday session, which ended at 1 p.m.

title: Trumpet Ties, Mozart Pins? Must Be Right For Someone
description: A FRIEND has a theory that our five senses get one blanket allotment of talent at birth and that the size of that allotment is pretty much the same for each of us. What separates one person from another, the thinking goes, is how we divide up what we have. The ''well-rounded'' person would actually be the well-balanced one: a finite amount of ability split equally among seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting and touching. If a little of everything seems to lead us to the ideal personality, it also, I fear, identifies someone who would bore us to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARSOTTI, EUGENE
description: BARSOTTI-Eugene. On November 24, 2000. Beloved husband of Gloria nee Abbundi. Devoted father of Claudia Musumeci and Mark. Loving grandfather of Justin and Nichole Musumeci. Father-in-law of Carmine Musumeci. Visitation, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 at Dimiceli & Sons Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Avenue, NYC. Mass of Christian Burial, on Monday, 11:00 AM, Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: REFUGE CLOSED
description: The Edwin B. Forsythe National Wildlife Refuge, the state's largest bird sanctuary, was closed to human visitors last week after officials discovered nearly 200 deaths of four species of migratory waterfowl there and in Lakes Bay, a portion of the Intercoastal Waterway separating Atlantic City and Pleasantville. ''We've ruled out chemicals and pesticides as causes,'' said Steve Atzert, project leader of the 4,400-acre refuge. ''It appears to be some kind of unknown avian ailment.'' The refuge will remain closed through next week pending reports from state and national toxicology labs. Bill Kent

title: From the Beatles' Moment of Glory
description: BWWWRRRRRAAAAAAAAAANNNNG!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTIS, SADYE PEARLMAN
description: CURTIS-Sadye Pearlman. On November 22, 2000, peacefully, at age 102. Loving wife of Theodore (of blessed memory). Devoted mother of Bernard (of blessed memory) (Barbara) and David (Carole). Cherished grandmother of Marjorie (Marc) Cohen, Jeffrey (Judy) Curtis, Wendy (Chip) Uhle, Ted (Debra) Curtis and Debra Curtis. Great-grandmother of Michael, Rachel and Daniel Cohen, Jonathan and Joshua Curtis, Michael, Debbie and Bethany Uhle, Sarah and Benjamin Curtis. Shiva will be observed through Wednesday at the home of David and Carole Curtis.

title: Once Again, America Needs to Believe in Its Courts
description: At least no one will call the United States Supreme Court a banana jury. Not yet, anyway. When the country's highest court announced that it would hear the Bush campaign's appeal on the recounts in Florida, both campaigns stood up and saluted. The polite response marked the first time since Nov. 7 that any arbiter has been able to avoid harsh accusations of partisanship.

title: November 19-25; New Phase of Lockerbie Trial
description: After six months, the prosecution rested in the trial of two Libyans accused of blowing Pan Am 103 out of the skies over Lockerbie, Scotland, on Dec. 21, 1988. The trial had been expected to take more than a year, but agreement over many small pieces of evidence has probably shortened that. Legal experts point out that the prosecution showed that the defendants could have put a bomb-laden suitcase among luggage in Malta tagged to transfer to Pan Am, but it had no witness or forensic evidence saying they actually did. The defense plans to blame the bombing on Palestinians in Germany and Sweden. Donald G. McNeil Jr.

title: Voice of Reason Directs Thankless Task in Palm Beach County
description: Judge Charles E. Burton, chairman of the Palm Beach County Canvassing Board and a man swept up by the runaway train of the 2000 presidential election, somehow manages to smile over the glow of a late-night cigarette after the din of the recount has quieted and the partisan lawyers have finally stopped breathing on the back of his neck.

title: Excerpts From Interview With Gore
description: Following are excerpts from an interview today with Vice President Al Gore in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: In the Region/Westchester; After a Long Hiatus, New Condominums Appear
description: AFTER languishing in the planning stages for most of the 1990's, the Landing, a 104-unit condominium project, now rising on the banks of the Hudson River in Dobbs Ferry, is hitting the market at the best of times, when the demand for newly built condominiums in Westchester County far outstrips the supply, which has been diminishing in recent years to the point of being practically nonexistent.

title: A Maharajah's Festival for Body and Soul
description: A KING, his prince and his courtiers ride in full pomp atop richly caparisoned elephants. They, along with tens of thousands of spectator-devotees, their hands pressed together in the Hindu prayer-salute, admire and worship the gods Vishnu and Lakshmi in their incarnations as Rama and Sita. Titanic battles pit human-size gods against 50-foot-high demons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, KENNETH
description: THOMAS-Kenneth. November 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Rebecca Gale; son of Rev. Dr. Winburn Thomas and Fuji Yamanaka Thomas, both deceased. Brother of Robert Thomas. A memorial service December 2, at 3 P.M., at The Brooklyn Society of Ethical Culture, 53 Prospect Park West, Park Slope, NY, 718-768-2972.

title: A Hangout That Caters To a Crowd From Space
description: For anyone unmoved by sentiment, the Outpost Tavern might not seem worth saving. The old red building is practically falling down. A tangle of bushes growing up an outside wall seems ready to swallow the place. Outside, there is a faint smell of sewage.

title: Critics' Corner Still Tackling 'A Juggernaut'
description: Even the critics of coaches have reason to worry about varsity won-lost records. Two English professors, in particular, Tennessee's Linda Bensel-Meyers and Indiana's Murray Sperber, don't need the agony of defeat.

title: POSTINGS: Neighborhood Entrepreneurs Program; Renovating Bronx Homes
description: New York City officials and community leaders formally opened a low- and moderate-income building last week at 2001 University Avenue in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx. The building, the largest of six being rehabilitated in the immediate area, was formerly known as a haven for drug dealers. It contains 74 apartments ranging from studios to three-bedroom units.

title: Dutch Court Orders an Investigation of '82 Killings in Suriname
description: A Dutch high court has ordered prosecutors to investigate the former military dictator of Suriname, Desi Bouterse, for his role in the ''December murders'' of 1982 when 15 of the most prominent opponents of his government were tortured and killed.

title: When Artists Face Juries of Peers
description: ANNUAL or biennial art competitions dot the Connecticut landscape throughout the year. The appeal of these contests, which are usually turned into exhibitions, is not hard to understand. Viewers are treated to an array of fresh art, and there is an implicit invitation to pick one's own winners. Artists sometimes regard appearing in a contest as a first step toward getting recognized, and they can often pick up a little cash as well, perhaps enough to pay for supplies.

title: Standoff Provides Window Into the Soul of the Next President
description: The protagonists in the political drama gripping the nation have ventured into public view only sparingly since the election on Nov. 7. When they do, Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore present themselves in entirely different ways.

title: Two Literary References In Name of Clothing Stores
description: When New Yorkers hear ''Lord of the Fleas,'' they may think of William Golding's novel ''Lord of the Flies.'' But Jeremy Archer, who attended an English boarding school, initially had J. R. R. Tolkien's ''Lord of the Rings,'' in mind when he thought of the name for his clothing business.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Sorry, Wrong Number
description: To the Editor:

title: Memories Put Down on Paper; 'The Chimney Tree'
description: HELAINE HELMREICH didn't set out to be a novelist. She never had dreams of becoming a writer.

title: Sense and Nonsense
description: Children today grow up in the middle of a vast and profitable web of enterprise. Their awakening minds are at once the raw material for and the byproduct of a billion-dollar industry that churns out toys, videos, movies, cd-rom's and books microtargeted for their exact stage of development. Parents have good cause to be suspicious of any such attempts to colonize their children's imaginations, but this prodigiously inventive culture also feeds them. Its rise may be one of the great (and still largely untold) stories of the 20th century, the work not only of toy companies and media conglomerates but also of librarians, progressive educators, dedicated editors and a corps of visionary writers and artists -- to say nothing of parents themselves and the kids they once were.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-30

title: Flying Home? Take Cookies
description: I want a refund on my nonrefundable airline ticket. I have a legal theory about this, which involves live goats, but I'll get to that. Can I tell you how elated I was when I procured this ticket? My inaugural year as a college-kid parent, my 18-year-old son a six-hour drive away, and I managed in a single phone call to buy two cheap fares home: one for an October weekend, for a cousin's bar mitzvah, and one for the famously booked-up Thanksgiving break, which made me feel I had managed a great coup.

title: Preservation Campaigns, Button by Button
description: To the Editor:

title: Lives; Dog Days
description: I stole because, in my mind, I was sticking it to the Man. It was a small victory, but it was all mine. There was no way the neighborhood was going to improve, so you had better grab what you could before it all went to hell. The Man already had my parents: my father fighting for factory overtime and being passed up for promotions because his English wasn't good; my mother never getting even a box of chocolates on Christmas from her sweatshop boss, much less health insurance or job security. By the time I was 12, the Man already wanted me, telling me in so many words: You will never achieve anything. You will die in this ghetto. You will die paying rent. So I started to steal.

title: Statement by Bush
description: Following is a statement by Governor George W. Bush, about the certification of the presidential ballot by Florida, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Argentina And Canada: Two Sides of Uncertainty
description: 'STABILITY might not be everything,'' Karl Schiller, the former West German economics minister, once remarked, ''but without stability, everything is nothing.''

title: A Word of Praise
description: To the Editor: Several weeks ago we traveled to Barcelona and Bilbao. We had read so many letters about bad experiences people had with theft of passports and wallets that we went there with a lot of trepidation.

title: Imported Sparkle
description: American brides are dressing more informally, their gowns backless or strapless, sometimes pink or even black. And on the other end of the fashion curve, women are borrowing formal Indian wedding garb -- wedding skirts and shawls -- to wear to parties.

title: Quilters Labor for Love and Healing
description: WHEN Annette Ott arrived at the Stamford Government Center for an AIDS Memorial Quilt workshop two weeks ago, she said that she wanted to make a memorial quilt panel not only for her brother Darel, but for her own sake as well.

title: In Horse Country, a Fight Over Horses
description: NOT much upsets the bucolic serenity of this community, where horses graze on large farms and residents enjoy a rustic refuge just out of reach of Westchester's suburban sprawl to the south.

description: To the Editor:

title: In a Jam
description: The Best of Jackson Payne

title: INTERPRETING WITH/Jody Gill; Putting a Face on Music And Lyrics for the Deaf
description: WHAT does music look like? Jody Gill gives undulating rhythms, soulful lyrics and melodic riffs a face and body, personifying the sounds of music and language of song for hearing and deaf audiences.

title: Architectural Improv: Theaters Find Unlikely Homes
description: WHEN community theater goes looking for a home, nobody's picky. Budgets are tight and dreams are big, and besides, everyone remembers that the best performances were put on in somebody's backyard with the help of some sheets on a clothesline.

title: Buyers Need To Check Septic Tank
description: MOST prospective home buyers want to know as much as possible about the condition of the house they are buying. Few would be willing to buy a house with a leaking roof or a heating system that could fail at any time without at least getting an adjustment in the sale price to compensate for the problem.

title: Just a Housewife? No Way
description: Amy Rigby is not your ordinary rock star. She is also a middle-aged single mom, something she loves to sing about. Through ''Diary of a Mod Housewife,'' ''Middlescense'' and her new ''Sugar Tree,'' Ms. Rigby has consistently offered up a fulfilling mix of witty lyrics, strong melodies and a feminist sensibility that sways easily between pop, country and folk.

title: Jury Duty Remains Part of American Way
description: ''With Jury Duty, No Trial After All'' [Opinion, Nov. 19] reflects the fact that the American system of trial by jury is unique. No other nation relies so heavily on ordinary citizens to make its most important decisions about law, business practice, personal liberty -- even death.

title: One Battle More -- the Last? -- for Canada's Old Warrior
description: Canada's leader, Jean Chretien, used to boast that he entered Parliament when John F. Kennedy was in the White House. But that boast has faded now that he is locked in a fight for political survival with Stockwell Day, a smooth-faced opponent who looks half the age of the craggy 66-year-old prime minister.

title: Bereft Women Of Bosnia Find Solace In Graveyard
description: This month, Advija Sehomirovic, 64, bumped into the man she blames for killing her husband. She had made a rare visit to her hometown, Srebrenica, site of Europe's worst massacre since World War II, and he called out her name.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ESAU AND JACOB By Joaquim Maria Machado de Assis. Oxford University, cloth, $35; paper, $16.95.

title: Angela McCorkle, Andrew Thomas
description: Angela Leslie McCorkle, the daughter of Gay Wood-Albrecht of Naperville, Ill., and Judge Lamar McCorkle of Houston, was married yesterday to Dr. Andrew Derek Thomas, the son of Doris Thomas of Easton, Conn., and Robert Thomas of Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. Patricia Youngdahl, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Arizona Inn in Tucson.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Post Office Elves

title: A Happy Accident
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. DROPS A SUIT
description: After bludgeoning Democrats in the court of public opinion for a week with accusations that they had tried to disqualify overseas military ballots, Republicans abruptly withdrew one suit over the ballots from a court of law today before filing four new ones.

title: Two Views of a Marked-Down Market
description: THE silver lining in the market sell-off this fall is that those worrisome -- yet often ignored -- high stock valuations have come down sharply. But have they fallen enough to warrant tossing whatever cash you have back into stocks?

title: November 19-25; On Sanity and Smoking
description: You don't have to be crazy to smoke, but apparently it helps. A Harvard Medical School study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association found that the mentally ill smoke 44.3 percent of the cigarettes consumed in this country. But then a lot of Americans -- 28.3 percent of them -- fit the researchers' definition of mentally ill, since it includes a wide range of complaints, from low-grade depression to schizophrenia. The study also found that people with diagnosable mental illness were about twice as likely to smoke as other people. No firm explanation was offered, but the researchers said that mental illness may make people more vulnerable to nicotine addiction or to tobacco advertising, or that smoking may cause mental illness. Other researchers have found that people with mental illness find cigarettes especially calming. Andy Newman

title: Margaret Angevine, Robert Welch
description: Margaret Muse Angevine and Dr. Robert George Harrison Welch were married yesterday at the Royal Poinciana Chapel in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Richard M. Cromie, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: November 19-25; Burgers Are The Globe's Fast Food? Not So Fast
description: TOO bad so many people around the world spend all that energy fighting Americanization by trashing golden arches or fried chicken outlets. All along, the real Americanizer has been pizza, perhaps the one truly universal fast food.

title: Ecology Group Becomes Developer Of Hudson Site
description: THE abandoned waterfront of this old industrial town, on a grassy peninsula jutting into the Hudson, has spectacular 180-degree views of the river and the Hudson Highlands to the south. The owner of the land plans to develop it, and has drawn up an ambitious list of possible projects that includes a 150-room hotel, a restaurant, even some stores and private homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, MALVIN J.
description: MAYER-Malvin J. Age 89, of Whitefield, ME, died November 23, 2000, at home. Born in Brookline, MA, of Joseph and Ruth (Redelsheimer) Mayer, he received a BS degree from MIT in 1933. He married Eleanor (Schwarz) Mayer in 1939. They lived in New Rochelle, NY, and retired to Washington, ME. Malvin was President of Schwarz Laboratories, a company that developed early applications of DNA and was involved in brewing chemistry. A lifelong volunteer, he worked towards racial integration, presided over numerous PTA's, was on the Board of Maine General Health Associates and served as a 25 year counselor in the Service Corps of Retired Executives. His wife and his daughter, Sylvia Morrison, predeceased him. His son Donald Mayer, his daughter Barbara Mayer, nine grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren survive him. In accordance with his wishes there will be no funeral srvice. Contributions may be made to the Palliative Care Institute of Mt. Sinai Medical Center.

title: IN BRIEF: Transportation; GREENWICH ACCESS ROAD REOPENS
description: For the first time in 10 months, Gateway Lane in Greenwich, a small road near the Westchester County Airport in Harrison that was used as a shortcut to Interstate 684 and Route 120, has been reopened after it was closed to Westchester-bound drivers. The reopening comes a month after Westchester and Greenwich officials resolved their dispute over traffic in the area by agreeing to adopt restrictions to limit heavy trucks and reduce speeding on the narrow road. With the terms of the agreement fulfilled, Greenwich removed barriers on the road, allowing turns by cars in all directions from King Street onto Gateway Lane for the first time since January. Elsa Brenner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, CLAIRE
description: FRANK-Claire. With great affection we remember Claire. A wonderful, lively woman and friend to all on two and four legs. She enriched our lives with her generous love, emotional support, and humor. We miss her greatly and will always love her. Lisa Stern, David & Asher Lasday and Maggie

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Sounds Good, Feels Bad
description: In THE FISHER KING (Scribner, $23), Paule Marshall returns to Brooklyn, the site of her best-known novel, ''Brown Girl, Brownstones,'' delivering another moving tale about the complexity of family. It is 1984, and Hattie Carmichael, who now lives in Paris, grudgingly returns to her old neighborhood to attend a jazz concert in honor of the late Everett Payne, known as ''Sonny-Rett,'' a legendary jazz pianist and her former lover. With Hattie is her young charge, also named Sonny Payne, the musician's 8-year-old grandson. Hattie is the boy's ''fathermothersisterbrother,'' as he puts it, the woman who raised him after his grandfather died and his ''runaway girl-mother'' took off after he was born. Hattie is tortured about being back in the old neighborhood. It is, after all, the place that she and Sonny-Rett fled to escape the contempt Sonny-Rett's family felt for his music and the psychic toll of American racism. The visit throws Hattie back into various family rivalries, which are almost as cacophonous as Sonny-Rett's freestyle jazz, described by Hattie as ''a dazzling pyrotechnic of chords (you could almost see their colors), polyrhythms, seemingly unrelated harmonies, and ideas -- fresh, brash, outrageous ideas.'' Though Hattie's memories of the old neighborhood are ugly ones, she is forced to consider whether the solitary, squalid life she and Sonny live in Paris (she works at a seedy nightclub) is really the best life for the boy. As always, Marshall's prose is full of expert dialogue, mellifluous rhythms and sharply drawn portraits of Sonny-Rett's loved ones. Only the abrupt ending disappoints. Lori Leibovich

title: An Encounter With the Metaphorical
description: TO the non-artist, there is an assumption that artists see the world differently. Most of the time, however, when artists refer to their vision, they are speaking of an internal sight, a quick snapshot that disappears as quickly as it occurs.

title: A Diver Since 9, Erin Lashnits Reaches Higher
description: ERIN LASHNITS has spent much of her life looking down from a few meters off the ground. She has been diving since she was 9.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We cussed that wind for years and now it is turning out to be a godsend.''

title: November 19-25; Elusive Decisions on Emissions
description: Through a decade of talks aimed at generating a treaty to curb global warming, the United States has been portrayed as eco-enemy number one, the source of a fourth of the world's emissions of greenhouse gases, with each American responsible for 20 times as much of the problem as each resident of developing countries.

title: Who Let The Dogs Out? Europeans!
description: ALL over France and Germany we saw dogs. Dogs on leashes, dogs without leashes, dogs romping on the long beach at Cap d'Agde on the Mediterranean, dogs riding the U-Bahn in Munich, dogs peering out of green-shuttered windows near the cathedral in Beziers, dogs waiting patiently on the Place de la Bastille in Paris.

title: Doubt Over Election Result Spurs Plans for Change
description: Reacting to the battle for presidential votes in Florida, state lawmakers and elections officials around the country have begun proposing laws to change voting procedures to reduce the potential for legal challenges in elections with razor-thin margins of victory.

title: Making Eaves Inspection a Routine
description: THE eaves are the lower parts of a sloping roof. They extend past the walls to provide shade and divert rainwater from the roof away from the walls and foundation. The vents in the soffits (the exposed underside of the eaves) allow air to circulate under the roof. This moving air cools the attic in the summer and helps to prevent ice dams in the winter. Regular inspections of the eaves, gutters and soffits are an essential part of home maintenance because these areas are particularly susceptible to water damage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMBINO, JOSEPHINE L.
description: GAMBINO-Josephine L. On November 22, 2000 in Clearwater, FL. formerly of Albany, N.Y. Past President State Civil Service Commission appointee to commission 1977 by Hugh Carey. Awarded Honorary Doctor of Civil Law Degree from St. Johns University (1992). Member of the State Commission on Judicial Nomination, President North Queens Civic Improvement Association. Member Mayor Lindsay's Task Force South Jamaica. Bronx Director of New York City Rent and Rehabilitation. Senior Vice President of the Coalition Of The Italo American Association. Received Sister Bene Emeritus Award form Grand Lodge Sons of Italy. Formed Josephine Gambino Lodge in Brooklyn, (1980). Honored by Italian Apostate of the Archdiocese of NY Knights of Malta (Inducted 1985). Golden Lady Award of Amita (1974). Beloved wife of the late Salvatore Gambino. Loving mother of Joseph Gambino (Albany) and Mary Roche (Massapequa). Adored grandmother of Christopher (Missy) Roche-Commack and Larry Roche (Gina) Princeton. Cherished great grandmother of Kayla, Jeremy, Allie, Ethan and Renee. Devoted sister of Nancy, Joseph, Rose, Phil, Millie, and Jim. She was an intelligent and well respected woman, we're going to miss you. Reposing at the Massapequa Funeral Home, Inc. 1050 Park Boulevard (at Clark), Massapequa Park, on Sunday and Monday 2-4:30 PM 7-9:30 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday 10 AM St. Rose Of Lima Roman Catholic Church, Massapequa. Interment will be private.

title: MONTCLAIR STATE EXPANSION
description: Montclair State University is planning a $100 million expansion over the next five to six years to build dormitories for 600 to 700 students, a 500-person theater, classrooms, a 1,000-car parking garage, a children's center and a 24-hour diner. The school is undertaking the expansion because it expects total enrollment to climb by about 4,500 from its current 13,500 over the next five to six years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSH, JOSEPH
description: HIRSH-Joseph. 85, twenty year resident of Norwalk, CT, died Tuesday at home. Born Bronx, NY, January 28, 1915, son of late Irving and Yetta Haber Hirsh. He was a retired Colonel, United States Army Medical Service Corps, Dean of Students and Professor of Community Medicine at Albert Einstein Medical College, Professor, Department of Family Practice and Community Medicine at Temple University School of Medicine, Fellow New York Academy of Sciences and Fellow American Public Health Association. Survived by wife Eva Hauptmann Hirsh of Norwalk; two daughters, Lisa Hirsh of Boston, Massachusetts, and Donna Hirsh Geller of London, England; two brothers, Gene Martel of Mamaroneck, NY, and Howard Hirsh of Great Neck, NY; a sister, Ruth Emanuel of White Plains, NY, and two granddaughters. Funeral services will be private.

title: Extolling Rivalry Of Hingis vs. Kournikova
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For Pro Wrestling Fans, A New Store in Yonkers
description: Borrowing some hype from their sport, the owners of Wrestling Central are calling their store ''Westchester's first and only all-wrestling superstore.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENKIND, EVELYN
description: HENKIND-Evelyn. On November 24, 2000. Beloved wife of Sol. Loving mother of Lewis and Ellie. Dear mother-in-law of Michael. Adoring grandmother of Hilary, Steven, Chimon, Adam, Rain and Heidi. She will be profoundly missed. Service Tuesday, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Aristide in Waiting
description: Amy Wilentz's wary treatment of Jean-Bertrand Aristide (Nov. 5) contrasts sharply with her unreserved support for him during his emergence as a political force in Haiti. But Aristide's irresponsible conduct since his return to power should come as no surprise.

title: Criticism of Planetarium Brings Out Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Memories Put Down on Paper; 'Willem de Kooning'
description: BILL, Elaine and I came to dinner at this spot in 1979,'' Edvard Lieber recalled over lunch at East Hampton Point, a restaurant just down the road from Willem de Kooning's Woodbine Drive studio.

title: Election Day: Time for a 17th-Inning Stretch; Effect on Free Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BRIEF: Government; BENEFITS FOR SAME-SEX COUPLES
description: The town board of Greenburgh voted unanimously to provide health benefits for the same-sex partners of municipal enployees, becoming the second town in Westchester to do so. ''Surprisingly, there was no controversy,'' said Supervisor Paul J. Feiner. ''We had one speak up in favor, and one against.'' The new benefits plan will cost the town about $5,000 annually for each person covered. Mr. Feiner said he expected very few of the town's 475 employees to take advantage of it. Westchester County adopted a benefit plan for same-sex couples in 1998, and Eastchester adopted a similar policy in September. Robert Worth

title: Award for Brilliance, and a Title
description: Three grandmasters, Joel Benjamin of Manhattan, Alexander Shabalov of Pittsburgh and Yasser Seirawan of Seattle, tied for first place in the 2000 United States Championship held at Town Hall in Seattle Sept. 25 to Oct. 6.

title: Andrea Schmidt, Elliott Gray
description: Andrea Renate Schmidt, the daughter of Heidemarie and Josef Schmidt of Hillsdale, N.J., was married yesterday in Alpine, N.J., to Elliott Richard Gray, the son of Shirley and Thomas Gray of Longniddry, Scotland. The Rev. Robert Milsom, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Alpine Community Church.

title: BY THE WAY; A Literary Crowd
description: Fern Jaffe knows how to get people excited about reading.

title: SEAT BELT USE
description: State traffic safety officials said this week that 74.2 percent of New Jersey drivers wore seat belts this summer, compared with 63.3 percent in 1999, in response to a tougher seat belt law that went into effect on May 1. The law allows police officials to pull drivers over and issue them a $42 ticket if they or front-seat passengers are not wearing their seat belts. The old law permitted police to issue a seat belt ticket only after stopping drivers for a separate offense. Anne Ruderman

title: E-ZPasses
description: To the Editor: How do you use the pass in a taxi? E-ZPass makes a big to-do that it be mounted at just the right spot next to the mirror. Do you give it to the driver to have him just hold it up, or do you tell him to put it on the dash?

title: A Schubert Masterpiece in a Rare Package
description: MANY people listen to solo piano music. But not that many listen to piano duets, unless they happen to be pianists who play them at home.

title: This 1998 Model Is Looking More Like a Lemon
description: AS she looked out over the room of more than 400 managers at Chrysler headquarters in Auburn Hills, Mich., last Monday, Jurgen Schrempp knew that many of them viewed him as the enemy. Still, as the chairman of DaimlerChrysler A.G., and the man who orchestrated Daimler-Benz's takeover of Chrysler two years ago, he was not about to shy away. First, he apologized for recent published remarks in which he had suggested that he had duped Chrysler managers by cloaking the takeover as a ''merger of equals.'' But then he recounted a litany of complaints: that Chrysler executives had stumbled on strategy, missed their own sales forecasts, failed to communicate their problems and shocked him by running huge losses.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about horseback riding misstated the location of Hollow Brook Riding Academy and referred incompletely to its offerings. The academy is in Putnam Valley, not Pleasant Valley. Besides trail rides for experienced riders only, it offers lessons to riders of all ages and experience levels.

title: Ski Hong Kong (You Read It Right)
description: Travel agents usually describe Hong Kong as a mecca for shopping. Soon they may add skiing. Developers in Hong Kong plan to build a winter theme park, including ski runs and snowboarding, on the expectation that snow will attract visitors from neighboring subtropical countries.

title: It Takes a Lot of Elves To Properly Deck a Mall
description: DECORATING the Galleria mall here for Christmas is a project that takes three nights, some 30 people, 328,000 lights and 200 extension cords. The cost for labor alone is $75,000.

title: The D.J. Booth As Corner Office
description: Jeff Taylor, 40, is chief executive of Monster.com in Maynard, Mass. An employment Web site owned by TMP Worldwide, Monster.com was founded in 1994 and has a database of more than 6.4 million resumes.

title: A Chorus and a Historic Cemetery
description: Col. Henry Rutgers, the trustee and benefactor who gave Rutgers University its name, may or may not be buried in the tiny cemetery of the 18th-century Belleville Reformed Church in Essex County.

title: INVESTING WITH: Reed G. Bender; Bender Growth Fund
description: WHAT'S a growth manager to do when the market favors value stocks? Stick to his guns, said Reed G. Bender, lead manager of the $78.7 million Bender Growth fund.

title: SOAPBOX; Poetry in Motion
description: OFTEN on the way to a school in the morning, I look into the windows of other cars, usually SUV's nowadays, and notice the gigantic sourpusses looming behind the steering wheels. There they are, driving cars that cost more than my entire year's -- sometimes two years' -- take-home pay. I can't help noticing how so many of them look miserable, as if they were in a processional towards their own deaths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREISELMAN, JACK
description: KREISELMAN-Jack. Clarinetist and conductor, Professor Emeritus, NYU, retired Professor, Stony Brook U. Beloved husband of the late Adelaide. Cherished father of Penny (Rick) and David (Debbi). Loving grandfather of Alex and Justin, Jenny, Jamie and Michael. Memorial concerts to be announced at NYU and Stony Brook. He will be greatly missed.

title: Who Pays the Payroll Tax?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Gets Revenge and Wins Fed Cup
description: The Fed Cup final between the United States and Spain, which concluded today, was very much like a lot of boxing matches staged in this town. It was no contest.

title: Who Really Brought Down Milosevic?
description: The south of Serbia is known for plum brandy and gracious monasteries but scarcely for places like the Zulu Cafe in the small town of Vladicin Han, where the decor features African statuary and a favorite number is Lou Reed's ''Perfect Day.'' The sultry song wafts over this sleepy place, as unlikely as a rainbow, and abruptly everything does seem perfect enough: the sun is shining, the well-known police informer in the corner is showing scant interest in a stranger and Slobodan Milosevic is history, ousted in Europe's last democratic revolution. It is possible to taste freedom, just as it is possible to taste murder, and this Serbian air no longer acrid with blood is little short of intoxicating.

title: Parsing the Ethics Of a City's Culture
description: SO here we are, our waistlines thickened by Thanksgiving dinner, our heads fat with ballot counting and legal challenges. And here is Khoren Arisian, who wants New Yorkers to consider the ethics of the election process, instead of the technicalities, and how to address real issues like economic inequality.

title: The Books Within Us
description: To the Editor:

title: President at the Re-Creation
description: On Hallowed Ground

title: Quality of Its Quantity Wins E-Mailer an Award
description: At a time when many e-mail users are grappling with how to reduce the amount of solicitations, commonly known as spam, that they receive over the Internet, an award has been devised for an e-mail pitch that rises above the others.

title: For the Sake Of Argument
description: I served as a special assistant -- and sometime driver -- to Senator Moynihan for three years in the 1990's. He would often take the time to share his experiences during our rides home after long days and nights of legislating. He could easily have just sat and ignored the 25-year-old next to him in the front seat. But instead, he took the time to converse and teach.

title: Cheese Revisited: Seeing The Holes
description: WHO MOVED MY CHEESE?'' the slim little management book with the silly title, came out two years ago with the perfect message for today's corporate training departments. The book teaches that change is always for the better, that smart people will be brave enough to move ahead quickly and find a new niche, and that the inflexible will perish.

title: Are You Now or Have You Ever?
description: I'd Hate Myself

title: Hotel Revival
description: To the Editor: I just read the extensive and enjoyable article ''Grand Entrances for Big-City Visitors'' (Oct. 29). But I would like to note for the record that the accompanying article, ''Three New Hotels Are Recycling Classic Facades,'' did not list my firm, M. Castedo Architects, as the architect for the Dylan, formerly known as the Chemists Club. We were responsible for the reconstruction and new floor layouts, the addition of four penthouse floors and, more important, the restoration of the facade and the grand staircase.

title: Election Day: Time for a 17th-Inning Stretch; New Voting Machines
description: To the Editor:

title: The Store They Love and Hate
description: RICHARD BALSANO became a customer of the Home Depot long before his baseboard heating pipe picked a bad time to spring a leak. ''I had to get stuff to fix it right away,'' he said. ''Where else are you going to go on a Sunday night?''

title: Nets Lose And Leave The Coast Crestfallen
description: Thirteen games into the season and the Nets had concocted a must-win situation for themselves tonight.

title: Only a Certain Breed Appreciates Ice Fishing
description: No matter how much you may want to, not everyone is cut out to be an ice fisherman or fisherwoman. It takes a certain kind of person to get up in the predawn darkness, trek across hundreds of yards of ice, usually bucking a stiff headwind and fighting the biting cold, to find the place where last spring, you think you may have found the perch ganging up. It's even worse if you have to drive a snowmobile to get there because it can make the wind unbearable.

title: McAndrews Wins Northeast Regional
description: Seton McAndrews of upstate New York and Natasha Roetter of Massachusetts were victorious yesterday in the Foot Locker Northeast Regional High School Cross-Country Championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Finding Bach's Genius in Elasticity
description: FOR the Bach year, the 250th anniversary of the composer's death, pianists have naturally been playing the ''Goldberg'' Variations. A slew of ''Goldbergs'' arrived in town during the last few weeks, including those by William Wolfram (in the Bargemusic series under the Brooklyn Bridge), Andras Schiff (at Carnegie Hall) and Murray Perahia (at Avery Fisher Hall), Mr. Perahia's recital coinciding with the release of his new recording of the work for Sony Classical.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe on Oct. 29 for juniper-flavored gravlax misstated the amount of kosher salt. It is one-half cup, not four cups. The corrected recipe appears below.

title: Fassel's Rage Could Nudge The Giants Into Playoffs
description: The telephone was ringing at Jim Fassel's home Thanksgiving Day, and on the other end, Fassel's friends -- from Idaho to Arizona to Miami Beach -- said they had heard the news: Fassel had flipped his lid.

title: Crime
description: Is there a female college graduate alive who has read ''The Princess'' or ''Maud'' and not felt the urge to murder Alfred, Lord Tennyson? Amanda Cross does the symbolic deed with considerable relish and wit in her 13th academic mystery, HONEST DOUBT (Ballantine, $22), when she kills off a professor of Victorian literature whose Tennysonian-tinged political misogyny has stifled scholarship and poisoned the climate at his jerkwater college in New Jersey. ''I haven't seen so much infighting since we had to look into some guys who were shaving points in a basketball playoff,'' says a local cop confounded by the wealth of suspects in the embattled ranks of the English department at Clifton College.

title: The Books Within Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Season of Concerts, Heralding Holidays
description: THE 8 nights of Hanukkah and the 12 days of Christmas begin almost simultaneously this year, so what an ideal time to hear Handel's ''Judas Maccabaeus,'' the oratorio retelling the ancient legend of the warrior who led Jewish loyalists in their battle to reclaim the Temple in Jerusalem from its desecrators.

title: Four New Tenants for New Roc City
description: NEW ROC CITY, the $190 million entertainment center/hotel and apartment complex that opened in downtown New Rochelle last year, will soon have four new tenants: a bowling alley, a baseball training center, a sports memorabilia shop and locker rooms for college hockey teams.

title: With Deadline Near, Florida Recount Grinds On
description: With only hours to go before a winner is declared in Florida's presidential balloting, weary election officials in Broward County finished their manual recount of ballots late tonight, cutting Gov. George W. Bush's lead over Vice President Al Gore in half. At the same time, their counterparts in Palm Beach County prepared to spend the night checking frantically for dimples, hanging chads and daylight in hundreds of punch cards before the deadline of 5 p.m. Sunday.

title: TEMPERS FLARING UNDER PRESSURE
description: As the clock ticked, things just got meaner.

title: Evolving Partnership
description: To the Editor:

title: What Do You Call the, Uh . . . ?
description: WHEN Gabe Hakvaag was a graduate student in Boston a decade ago, he supported himself by what he called ''nannying,'' working for a couple with a 6-year-old son. It was, he acknowledged, an unorthodox job for a 25-year-old man, and the arrangement was equally unprecedented for his employers, who never quite knew what to call him.

title: Celebrating With David Amram, Free Spirit
description: LAST Saturday, with an hour until curtain time, David Amram musician, composer, conductor, world traveler, free spirit -- teetered precariously atop a stool in the Paramount Theater here to hang a banner announcing his latest achievement: turning 70.

title: Visual Feast, And Deer Cry the Blues
description: THE concept of flowering onions in ornamental borders was an oddity when I first grew them 14 years ago. Members of the Allium genus, they are related to cooking onions and garlic and are also edible. But I planted them for visual rather than nutritional nourishment.

title: OPINION; Museum Midwifery in Dicey Times
description: THE Cradle of Aviation Museum at Mitchel Field deserves credit for continuing to punch through the flak-infested skies of Nassau County politics. At a time when the county is dismantling many of its services and virtually ignoring its Parks Department, the Cradle of Aviation is on track to open its doors next October and become one of the most innovative and exciting destinations in the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ELI
description: KATZ-Eli. Age 88, passed away at home in Coconut Creek, Florida, November 18. Mr. Katz formerly of Roslyn & Great Neck, practiced law until 1994. He was a graduate of NYU and Columbia University School of Law, and was qualified to the Supreme Court of the United States in 1969. He served as Mayor of Thomaston and was active in B'nai Brith. He contributed to many Jewish philanthropies. Mr. Katz was an avid tennis player and swimmer. He enjoyed sixtythree years of married life with his wife Beulah who survives him. Also surviving, his children Lorna Lawson, and Charles Katz, and grandchildren Jason and Djahariah Katz.

title: I.B.M. Hews to Its Vision, Even as Growth Slows
description: THERE was a special guest star at I.B.M.'s annual fall meeting with analysts early this month in New York -- none other than Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the company's chairman and chief executive.

title: Burned-Out Clothing Shop In Mount Kisco Reopens
description: The Elephant's Trunk, a women's clothing and bridal shop in Mount Kisco that burned down on Aug. 17, has reopened in a new location at 383 Bedford Road. The shop, founded in 1971 and known for its collection of antique gowns, costumes, evening wear and jewelry, plans to rebuild on the site of its old home, a house on Main Street that will be demolished next week, said Robert Brache, a co-owner of the store.

title: A Free Trade Battle, by the Turnpike
description: A free trade zone is an area most associated with faraway places like the Panama Canal Zone, or at least an airport shopping concourse. But there have long been free trade zones in New Jersey, and a request for a new one along the turnpike has angered local businesses.

title: Can Design In America Avoid The Style Trap?
description: DESIGN is the art that is hidden in plain sight. In the United States, those design disciplines not prefaced by ''fashion'' have long been the neglected stepchildren of culture and commerce. But unlike fashion, which trades in distant desire, the work of product designers, graphic designers and architects is all around us: sneakers and staplers, trivets and towers, Web sites and Weber grills.

title: Traffic Is a Problem In Shopping in Millburn
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, RENA
description: YOUNG-Rena. Beloved wife of the late Isadore, devoted mother of Shirley, Melvin and Barry, adoring grandmother of Mitchell, Wendy, Lisa and Bonnie, and proud great-grandmother of Isaac. Her joyful spirit brought warmth to all who knew her. She will be greatly missed by us all. She will forever be in our hearts.

title: Nacia Pupo, Matthew Taylor
description: Nacia Gaspar Pupo, the daughter of Aldina Gaspar and Galeno Pupo, both of Sao Paulo, Brazil, was married on Friday to Matthew MacLeod Taylor, a son of Dr. Dorcas Billings Taylor and Paul D. Taylor of Newport, R.I. Dennis Revens, a justice of the peace, officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents. Later, the couple were joined by family members in an ecumenical service at the Taylors' home.

title: A Gilded Age Holiday
description: JUST before Mrs. Astor entered the ballroom of Beechwood, her Newport mansion, for Christmas dinner, she introduced me to her oldest son, John Jacob IV. As soon as he slipped beyond earshot, I framed the question that seemed so impolite but so, well, obligatory.

title: For the Sake Of Argument
description: I appreciate Weisberg's revisionist take on Patrick Moynihan. The senator's near worshipful coverage by the news media had, over these many years, almost made me forget how terrible I felt in 1976, when he eked out that 10,000-vote primary victory over the late Bella Abzug. Bella would have been even more effective as a senator than she was as a congresswoman; Moynihan was just a scold.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 12 about a series of Soviet films at the Walter Reade Theater rendered a word incorrectly in a quotation from the book ''Real Images: Soviet Cinema and the Thaw'' by Josephine Woll. She wrote that the number of full-length Soviet features increased dramatically ''between the 20th Party Congress of 1956 and the 50th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution in 1967,'' not the 15th anniversary.

title: Derring-Do of the Stay-at-Home Dad
description: I HAVE had this fantasy for a number of years, and while it is one of my few actually attainable dreams, I have never had the courage to make it happen. I suppose that's because I find the fantasy -- to quit work and stay home to raise my four children -- more attractive than what it would take to do it.

title: Tenants Rally for Landlord
description: In what looked like a combination pep rally and show trial, Joseph Barry stood on the stage of Hoboken High School and urged the crowd, made up of 500 of his tenants, to join him in fighting the ''interlopers'' who he said threatened to break up their happy, subsidized-housing family.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-26-00: Diary; Only in America
description: Out of chaos comes opportunity, and not only for the lawyers, academics and pundits who have rushed to spin the electoral confusion in Florida. The contested vote was also the big break for Mike Collins, a 26-year-old municipal water board engineer and avocational cartoonist in Elmira, N.Y. He's the one who drew the famous mock Florida ballot pictured above. Here Collins recounts those heady days of instant celebrity, Internet-style.

title: Long-Suffering Romanians To Vote for a Leader Today
description: Broken promises made in fading industrial cities like this are causing both the left and right to surge in Romanian politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, KATHERINE M.
description: BURKE-Katherine M. On Nov. 22, 2000, of Bay Ridge Brooklyn, New York. Visiting Sunday and Monday 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn, New York. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10:15 A.M., at Our Lady of Angels RC Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDEL, JUDITH ANNE
description: FRIEDEL-Judith Anne. Of Delray Beach, FL, on November 25, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother of Arleen and Sheldon Richman, Dr. Elliott J. and Dolores. Devoted grandmother of Scott and Glenn Friedel. Graveside services will be held Sunday, November 26, 3 PM, at the Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. For information contact ''Gutterman's, Inc.''

title: Ford Thinks Green for Historic River Rouge Plant
description: THE Ford Motor Company revolutionized the world of manufacturing in the early part of the 20th century at its 1,100 acre industrial complex along the River Rouge here. People came from all around the world to observe a place where iron ore went into one end and a finished automobile rolled out the other a few days later.

title: The Election; De Tocqueville Saw It Coming
description: The onslaught of legal filings in Florida would not have surprised Alexis de Tocqueville, that famous 19th-century interpreter of American behavior. In ''Democracy in America,'' he concluded that all political questions eventually become judicial ones. Excerpts follow. K. A. DILDAY

title: IN BRIEF: Government; RIVER TOWNS GRANT
description: The county has received an $18,500 state grant for the 13-community Historic River Towns of Westchester consortium to use to help towns preserve natural and historic resources. Some examples of the things the consortium hopes to accomplish include rehabilitation of distinguished old homes for inns and bed-and-breakfasts, and revitalizing Main Streets with a mix of retail, commercial and residential uses. The consortium represents municipalities from Yonkers to Cortlandt, which are finding ways to promote tourism, renew the waterfront and revitalize downtowns. Elsa Brenner

title: The Tokyo Station
description: To the Editor: Elizabeth Andoh's Choice Tables column, ''In Tokyo Station, Enticing Options'' (Nov. 5), did not mention a bit of history. The design for the station, which opened in 1914, was changed after Japan's victory over Russia in 1905. The Japanese were ecstatic, and wanted to show that Japan was not a backwater.

title: Arnott's Goal Lifts Devils To Sweep on West Coast
description: Spotting the San Jose Sharks a two-goal lead and losing their leading scorer, Alexander Mogilny, to an ejection, the Devils scored three unanswered, but not undisputed, goals for a 3-2 victory tonight.

title: He's Just an Animator in Sheep's Clothing
description: There he was, just one of the herd - fluffy, well loved and minding his own business on the family farm - when a top-secret military organization decided only he would fit the bill. Well, what's a sheep to do?

title: U.S.O.C.'s Struggles Threaten United States Olympic Movement
description: Even though Americans won the medal count at the Sydney Games, the United States Olympic Committee finds itself adrift in leadership, lacking direction to such an extent that some officials of the organization fear an impact on performance at future Games and a loss in confidence by corporate sponsors.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-26-00; What They Were Thinking
description: Arden Peters and Warren De Witt, Morgantown, W.Va., July 31, 2000

title: Red Storm's Easy Game Teaches Hard Truths
description: In Mike Jarvis's world, the messy plays are often as effective as the well-executed ones. Because he does not stomp and scream every time his players make a gaffe and because he does not forget, Jarvis's teams have earned the reputation as tenacious competitors, no matter how inferior the opponent.

title: Inquiries on Mortgage Deals Crimp Harlem's Realty Boom
description: Only a few months ago, the major residential real estate brokers in New York City were moving into Harlem, eager to capitalize on what they thought was the latest great opportunity -- a historic neighborhood abounding in beautiful turn-of-the-century brownstones that could be acquired for a fraction of what similar homes would cost on the Upper West Side.

title: Portrayer of the Black Experience Reflects on His Own
description: GORDON PARKS isn't done. Far from it. He may be turning 88 this week, but that doesn't mean that this remarkable self-taught man, a photographer, filmmaker, author and composer whose pioneering works gave white Americans a new view of the black experience, is ready to retire and retreat into his own reminiscenses.

title: More Hazards Than Pebble Beach
description: TODAY we'll begin with an entertaining activity for the whole family, one that will tell you whether you're likely to be poisoned, blown up, irradiated or otherwise disturbed while you sleep. Then we'll offer a thematically related tale from the shore, where people have concerns about a possible hazard but can't get their questions answered. So prepare to become depressed and/or paranoid.

title: Perks That Make You Turn Cartwheels
description: Can money buy happiness? Before a deafening chorus drowns out any hope of rational discourse, let it be said that there are some workplace perks and pleasures that cannot be measured in dollars and cents, that need not be set down in the lawyerly language of contracts. As the old song observed, sometimes little things mean a lot.

title: Swiss to List Bank Accounts Unclaimed Since Holocaust
