description: Swiss banks will publish the names of 26,000 dormant accounts that are likely to be linked to victims of the Holocaust, the country's banking association said this week in a new step toward returning the unclaimed wartime assets.

title: India: So Close to Home
description: THE auditorium at Vedic Heritage, a Hindu temple in Hempstead, cannot be compared with Carnegie Hall. The 700-seat theater is in the basement of a former Y.M.C.A. Upstairs, a sanctuary is dedicated to Hanuman, the monkey god. The former indoor swimming pool has been turned into a shrine where congregants slip off their shoes and take offerings to their goddesses. The temple's spiritual leader, who is known as Guru Maa Saraswati or simply as Guru Maa, has a large bedroom at the rear of the complex.

title: Criticism of Planetarium Brings Out Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: Wallflowers at Trump Marina
description: The Wallflowers jumped into the limelight in 1996 with their second album, ''Bringing Down the Horse,'' which went quadruple platinum.

title: A Street Fight in the Classroom
description: Concerned by what they see as an increase in street gangs, law enforcement officials here have asked teachers to keep their eyes open for any illegal gang activity in the schools.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Hero of the Underworld

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, MARY TURNBULL
description: ELLIOTT-Mary Turnbull. On November 18 died in her sleep after a long illness at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Robert H. E. Elliott, MD (Pat). Loving mother of Mary (Patsy), Robert, and Susan; beloved grandmother of Anne, Elizabeth, Edward, Robert Jr, Mary, Beth, and Nora; and great-grandmother of Patrick, Alexander, and Jonathan. Beloved sister of Ann (Bobby) Autorino, Stockton Graeme Turnbull, and the late Knox Turnbull. She touched all of our lives profoundly. Born in Bristol, VA, she earned her RN from Columbia University School of Nursing and later became president of its Alumni Association. At Columbia Presbyterian Hospital she worked as an operating room nurse, clinic aide, and for the Nephrosis Project. She was also a very active fund raiser. A service will be held on Wednesday, December 27 at 2 PM at the Wainscott Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Columbia University School of Nursing, Office of Development, 630 West 168th Street, New York, New York 10032.

title: November 19-25; European Military Shaping Up
description: The United States has been pressing its European allies for years to improve their military forces. Now they have decided to do just that. The 15-nation European Union plans to establish a 60,000-member force by 2003 to carry out peacekeeping and humanitarian missions. But it is not doing so on behalf of NATO, the American-led alliance that Washington insists should play the central role in safeguarding European security. Instead, it is for the union itself, an organization with no previous defense experience Michael R. Gordon

title: A Classic Tale, Best Told, Not Sung
description: MUSICALS have been a sometime thing at the Long Wharf in New Haven. In the 1980's, chamber productions of such non-mainstream works as ''Lost in the Stars'' and the operas, ''Tender Land'' and ''Regina,'' even ''Pal Joey'' took the main stage. All were large-scale works, born on Broadway. With time out for a couple of new works, Long Wharf's forays into musical theater consisted of revivals, downsized, but straight-out revivals all the same.

title: Virtues of Protea
description: IF someone were to cross an artichoke with an unopened football mum, the offspring would look like protea. This striking, tall-stemmed flower is available wherever cut flowers are sold, can be used either fresh or dried, and makes a dramatic accent in mixed bouquets.

title: The Tree Trap
description: In the end, the negotiators got lost in the trees.

title: From the Anti-Gore Right, A Battle Cry of 'Stop, Thief!'
description: The conservative message these days is simple and laced with the anger of eight long years out of the White House: the Democrats are trying to steal this election, they say. They're trying to hold on, to change the rules of the game, to thwart the will of the people.

title: So Elegant, So Intelligent
description: Words Alone

title: Skilled Foreign Workers: More to Come
description: ROBERT THOMPSON wasn't ''Bob'' until he came to Long Island. When he lived and worked in Europe, and before that in Canada, he was called Mr. Thompson.

title: Election Day: Time for a 17th-Inning Stretch; Leaders During Stress
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Versions Over the Years, Each Different
description: Walter Shenson, who produced ''A Hard Day's Night,'' had the foresight to include a clause in his contract with United Artists by which the rights to the film reverted to him in 1979. Until then, it had been a perennial favorite on campuses, in revival houses and on television, and it was always shown in its original form, albeit in increasingly battered prints. After Shenson took it over, the film had more lives than a cat, and each version either looked or sounded a bit different.

title: States See Problems With Care at Chain Of Centers for Aged
description: The nation's largest chain of assisted living facilities, including about 150 residences for people with Alzheimer's disease, has come under scrutiny in recent months by state regulators over the quality of care and safety conditions at some of its centers.

title: Footnotes
description: Resources, references and the back story behind the story.

title: Try Swiss Chard to Saute, Fill a Quiche or Toss With Pasta
description: AMONG the more versatile of cooking greens are the big bunches of Swiss chard, with either white or red stems, now readily available in the market. Not only are the generous, sturdy leaves good to saute and season as a vegetable side dish but they can also be used as a filling, like spinach, for quiche.

title: That Distinctive New-Park Odor Turns Out to Be Leaking Sewage
description: For months, a rotten egg smell at the soon-to-be-opened Riverside South Park has caused neighbors to suspect leaking sewage. This week, a city investigation found that sewage from 32 apartments in a nearby Trump building was being funneled into a pipe meant for storm water. But officials added that the sewage was apparently redirected into proper sanitation pipes before it reached the park or the Hudson River.

title: A Fishing Trip Is Its Own Reward
description: THE problem (isn't there always at least one?) was how to combine a family vacation with a dedicated fishing trip.

title: Taking to Heart The Mexican Soul
description: Graciela Iturbide

title: 'Greek Fire'
description: To the Editor:

title: Word for Word/What Really Matters; Getting Beyond the Truth, Into Appearances
description: ONE of the gravest electoral struggles in America's history is playing out in Florida. So, too, is one of the greatest public relations battles.

title: A Bank Where the Currency Is Molecules
description: In one of the many academic research buildings on the Busch Campus of Rutgers University in Piscataway is a series of powerful computers that make up part of the Protein Databank. Through the databank, at www.rcsb.org/pdb/, scientists, researchers, students at all levels and anyone else who is interested can view the latest information about the structure of molecules. The information is vital to scientists developing the latest drugs, as well as to any researchers anywhere in the world studying the properties of proteins, carbohydrates and nucleic acids -- that is any biological molecules. Dr. Helen M. Berman, a structural biologist, Rutgers University chemistry professor and director of the Protein Databank, talked recently about the bank.

title: At Crossroads, a Dramatic Pause
description: THEATER season is in full swing here the State Theater's flashing marquee lists a packed schedule of music, dance and drama. Next door, the George Street Playhouse is finishing up its season-opening drama and getting ready for a musical.

title: Underfoot, but Unobtrusive
description: THOSE who walk the city with downcast eyes may find something unexpected: 19 Con Edison manhole covers have been replaced by ones designed by Lawrence Weiner.

title: A Healthy El Corredor Justifies All the Waiting
description: Hal Earnhardt has worried about his colt ever since he bought him two years ago. There was his price tag -- at $110,000, the owner had never paid that much for a horse. Then there was the matter of his name: El Corredor. The Phoenix-based oil dealer wondered if it was too presumptuous to tag his colt with the Spanish phrase for ''the runner.''

title: U.N. Plan for a New Crisis Unit Opposed by Wary Poor Nations
description: Proposals for a new unit for gathering information and improving planning for United Nations peacekeepers, which officials see as crucial to faster and more effective responses to crises, could be blocked by developing nations in the General Assembly in the next few weeks.

title: Co-ops Fret, Tenants Sue As Corporate Renters Arrive
description: In the real estate world, Chaim Babad sits on a small gold mine.

title: November 19-25; Striking in Seattle
description: A newspaper strike has thinned out Seattle's two morning daily newspapers to as few as 24 pages each as the advertising-rich holiday shopping season begins. But despite picket lines, The Seattle Times and The Seattle Post-Intelligencer are still publishing -- as is a new union paper, The Seattle Union-Record. The strike by the Pacific Northwest Newspaper Guild, which represents more than 900 advertising, circulation and newsroom employees at the two papers, came after federally mediated bargaining failed to close the wage and benefits gap between the two sides. Management's final offer to increase wages by $3.30 an hour over six years was rejected; the guild countered by proposing a $3.25 increase over three years. Felicity Barringer

title: For the Sake Of Argument
description: Weisberg's article was hardly an unbiased or accurate answer to the question on your cover. For example, Weisberg wrote, ''After 24 years in the Senate, he leaves behind a record long on concepts and short on concrete results.'' This is false, as are other opinions expressed in the article.

title: Dreams Fade for Mexicans As Well of Credit Runs Dry
description: After seven years of cutting extravagances and building a nest egg of some $90,000, Edna Jaime and her husband thought they could finally buy their first home.

title: Streetscapes/The 1902 Cathedral of St. Nicholas, at 15 East 97th Street; Old Czarist-Soviet Battleground Enters a New Age
description: THE Russian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Nicholas, at 15 East 97th Street, was built in 1902 and soon became an American battleground for conflicts between czarist and Soviet Russians. Now, a decade after the fall of communism and the end of the officially atheistic Soviet state, a new bishop, fresh from Moscow, is planning renovations and modernization.

title: Who'll Pay the Bill for the Tax Dodgers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Diana Schlesinger, Robert Nassau
description: Diana Laurel Schlesinger, the director of education at the Museum of American Folk Art in New York, and Robert Leon Nassau, a filmmaker, are to be married today. Rabbi David Adelson is to officiate at a house owned by the bridegroom's parents, Adrienne and Stephen Nassau, in Sherwood, Md.

title: Memories Put Down on Paper; 'The Hampton Suite'
description: IN 25 years of photographing the Hamptons, Ken Robbins has focused his camera on anything that has engaged his curious mind and practised eye. Not the glamorous world of the rich and famous; rather bucolic landscapes of patterned fields, stark woods and luminous waters and simple village scenes of lighted storefronts and gas pumps are more to his liking.

title: Singing for Your Supper
description: A LINE at the bottom of 28 Oak Street's elegant, understated menu reads, ''Inspiration . . . move me brightly.'' It turns out to be the opening of a Grateful Dead song, ''Terrapin Station,'' whose second line is ''Like a song with scents and colors.''

title: Rome's Wedding Cake Is Fully Restored
description: Thirty-one years after it was declared unsafe, the Vittoriano -- the enormous national monument in the Piazza Venezia in Rome commemorating King Victor Emanuel II -- reopened to the public this month.

title: Airing Monaco's Laundry in Public
description: The spindly masts belonging to hundreds of luxury yachts still bob in the harbor. The Rolls-Royces still purr up to the front of the copper-domed Monte Carlo casino.

title: The Movies' Digital Future Is in Sight and It Works
description: GEORGE LUCAS, the creator of ''Star Wars'' and the closest thing we have to the father of digital cinema, is unsentimental about film -- the medium, not the art form. Sure, it has served us for, oh, about 100 years. But now he wishes it would go away.

title: IN BRIEF: Transportation; FREE FERRY SERVICE
description: Metro-North will offer free service on the Ossining-Haverstraw ferry for the month of December to commuters buying rail tickets from Ossining to Grand Central Terminal. The promotion, worth about $120 to daily commuters, is intended to draw more customers to the ferry service, which began on Sept. 5. ''We're pleased with how we're doing, but we want more people to take advantage of it,'' said Charlie Zabielski, Metro-North's director of marketing. About 80 people a day commute to and from work on the ferry, he said. Ultimately, Metro-North hopes to have about 300 people a day using the service, Mr. Zabielski said. Robert Worth

title: Baseball's Rich Get Richer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Milosevic Wins Re-election As Leader of Socialist Party
description: A characteristically defiant Slobodan Milosevic staged his political comeback today, winning re-election as leader of his Socialist Party of Serbia and denouncing as a coup the popular uprising that swept him from power last month.

title: E-ZPasses
description: To the Editor: Regarding Betsy Wade's ''Zapping Tolls, With Asterisks'' (Practical Traveler, Nov. 5), I am a Florida resident who spends a few months a year in Connecticut. While up North, I drive through New York State to the New Jersey Turnpike. I cross the Delaware to the Pennsylvania Turnpike to visit my daughters near Philadelphia.

title: Mandatory Stop
description: To the Editor: How wonderful to see the Hundertwasser public bathroom mentioned in ''A Mandatory Stop, Even if It's Not Necessary'' (Travel Advisory, Oct. 15).

title: The Buddha Of Detroit
description: Ford's world headquarters, in Dearborn, Mich., occupies a tall glass box of a building with a grand semicircle of international flags out front. Way up at the top of the building are the words ''Ford Motor Company'' in that familiar dark blue logo with the old-timey script so pervasive in the lives of everybody everywhere that it has become almost invisible. It's a talisman of American optimism and desire, of our romance with machines and of our belief in our own ingenuity -- that we can build our way out of the imperfect present and into an ideal future.

title: The Election; Trying to Escape the Purgatory of Parity
description: BACK in headier times when George W. Bush was first stepping onto the stage as the Republican Party's putative savior from the southwest, Karl Rove, the Texas governor's chief strategist, liked to draw grand parallels with William McKinley and prophesy that the 2000 election would be as historically significant as the election of 1896.

title: Confusing M.V.P. Criteria
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chrysler PT Cruiser; 'Le Jimmy Cagney Car' Makes a Big Bang in France
description: JUST outside the cathedral at Mont-St.-Michel on the Normandy coast, a school bus pulled up. Elementary school children rushed en masse to the windows, pressed faces to the glass and shouted enthusiastically, ''Le Pe-e-e-e Te-e-e-e! C'est magnifique!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, RAYMOND H.
description: BURNS-Raymond H. Beloved husband and father. With love always. Doris, John, David and Jane

title: CONSTRUCTION OUTLOOK
description: Construction in New Jersey should continue to boom during the next two years, according to an annual projection by the Alliance for Action released last week. The alliance predicts $20 billion in new construction during 2001 and 2002. This is a 24 percent increase over the prediction last year for the years 2000 and 2001 and the largest dollar amount predicted since the alliance began making its annual forecasts 16 years ago. The numbers are based on the plans of 25 public and private organizations involved in construction. Projected school construction of $3.1 billion over the next two years represented the largest single area. The State Transportation Trust Fund projects $975 million in construction spending over the two years. For the private sector, the New Jersey Chapter of the National Association of Industrial and Office Properties estimated $2.6 billion in new construction for the two years and New Jersey utility companies said $2.1 billion in construction work would be done. Last year the alliance predicted $16.7 billion in new construction in 2000 and 2001. Karen DeMasters

title: West's Plan For Balkans Struggles For Footing
description: The Stability Pact for Southeastern Europe, announced with great fanfare 18 months ago as the West's answer to insecurity and violence in the Balkans, is floundering with the ouster of Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Public Plazas On Private Property
description: To the Editor:

title: Mariza Caraveo, Jonathan Cohen
description: Mariza Caraveo Najera and Jonathan Goodman Cohen were married yesterday evening at the Windsor Court Hotel in New Orleans. Cantor Joel Colman perfromed the ceremony.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-26-00: Salient Facts: On the Job; A Little off the Top
description: Earlier this month, 12 toll takers on the George Washington Bridge were arrested for skimming. It's not the first time sticky-fingered toll takers have been caught, but this group is said to have taken $400,000 over five months before being detected under the Port Authority's updated security system. One is accused of taking more than $90,000. That's far more than a toll taker's $40,000 salary, but far less than any one of them handles each week. The Port Authority insists that such incidents are anomalous, but if so, surely personal restraint is as much of a factor as any security system. We asked a number of people who work in cash-oriented jobs whether they are ever tempted by the till, and if so, why they resist.

title: Capitalism, One Student At a Time, In Vietnam
description: OF all the radical free-market concepts that American teachers are pounding into their students at a small Harvard-run economics institute here, the most fundamental may be elbow grease.

title: WRONGFUL DEATH SUITS
description: Governor Whitman last week signed a bill that eliminates the two-year statue of limitations in wrongful death cases, giving families of murder or manslaughter victims the right to sue the attacker any time after the death of their relative. Abhi Raghunathan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALWEN, JACK B.
description: SALWEN-Jack B. On November 19, 2000 at age 76. Former Executive Compensation Attorney and Partner of the late V. Henry Rothschild, 2nd. Retired partner of Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith. Husband of Estelita, father of Myra Demeter, Robert, Lynda, Meyer, Miriam and Julio. Grandfather of Ron, Gil, Guy and Roy Demeter and Gregory and Emily Salwen. Brother of Cecile Feder and the late Bernard Salwen. ''Uncle'' of Kimberly de Jesus. Services were held on November 21. Donations may be made to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICKS, CHARLOTTE HALL
description: RICKS-Charlotte Hall. Of Ossining, New York died in La Crosse, Wisconsin, on November 19th while visiting her daughter Francie Ricks. The widow of James H. Ricks, Jr., she is survived by her daughter and a son, John Ryland Ricks, of Raleigh, NC. A memorial will be held at her home in Ossining on December 2nd. Gifts in her memory may be made to the Ossining Children's Center, 92 S. Highland Avenue, Ossining, NY.

title: Keith Mant Dies at 81; Pathologist Helped Convict Nazis
description: Keith Mant, a pathologist who provided evidence from exhumed corpses for the war crimes trials of Nazi doctors after World War II, died on Oct. 11 in Walton-on-Thames, Surrey, England. He was 81.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: A Price of Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Culpepper to Moss, and That's to Green's Credit in Minnesota
description: Minnesota quarterback Daunte Culpepper made the smart throw in the face of a blitz, as he has done so many times this season, this time against Dallas on Thanksgiving Day. It was the third quarter, the Vikings were in Cowboys territory and Culpepper, not wanting to take a sack, wisely threw the ball away.

title: November 19-25; Your E-Mail Has Been Ignored
description: The battle over electronic privacy has migrated to the e-mail inbox, thanks to a feature in the latest e-mail programs that enables senders to be informed when their e-mail is opened. Marketers have begun to track who opens their e-mail, and when. New services are emerging that make it easy for individual e-mail senders to monitor what was once a private act. And privacy advocates warn that Internet advertising companies could use the technology to link an e-mail address to the currently anonymous records they collect on which Web sites are frequented by individual Internet users. Amy Harmon

title: Breather Against Bears? The Jets Know It Isn't So
description: The Jets have been here before, the troubling brew of playing an underwhelming out-of-division opponent while their confidence is soaring. The Jets have seen what can happen, and the mirror in which today's game against the Chicago Bears is reflected is badly cracked.

title: Wiring in 80-Year-Old House
description: Q. I recently inherited an 80-year-old attached house in Queens. The electric wiring is original, down to the fuse box. The electric service meets our needs, and there is no problem with the wiring except for its age. Is this safe, or does the house have to be rewired? David Krieger, Ossining, N.Y.

title: Police See No Link Between 2 Deaths
description: The skeletal remains found a day after those of a missing Long Island woman who was identified Friday are of an unidentified male and appear to have no connection to the woman's death, the police said yesterday.

title: Stabilizing the Presidency
description: Thanksgiving weekend in a presidential year usually marks a turn from post-election euphoria in the winner's camp to pre-inauguration planning for office. With that ritual now deferred by the United States Supreme Court's intervention, and by the fusillade of lawsuits, charges of election-stealing and attacks on the integrity of the entire vote-counting process, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush have to start raising their sights. Since one of them will become president on Jan. 20, both need to plan for their presidencies and also look to history for lessons in how to preserve the worthy old idea that whoever is president is president of all Americans.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-26-00: The Ethicist; Open Courts for All
description: My friend and I play tennis in a neighboring town where only residents who pay a yearly fee of $50 may use the courts. The courts are unsupervised, and one or both of them are always vacant. We are not preventing any resident from playing. Are we committing an unethical act by using the courts? -- Shane Mullane, Westchester County, N.Y.

title: Montauk Point Journal; A Life Full of Solitude at Land's End
description: It is 34 degrees Fahrenheit, officially. But the wind howling through a vent atop the Montauk Point Lighthouse makes it feel more like 10 below zero.

title: Riders Say Their Buses Are the Shabbiest on the Lot
description: When the Q22 rolls up to bus stops in Arverne, some riders are dismayed by its condition.

title: Taste of Intimacy In the East 80's
description: BUTTERFIELD 81

title: Meryl Rosenblatt, Kenneth Fleisher
description: Meryl Starr Rosenblatt, a daughter of Lorraine and Howard Rosenblatt of Freeport, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Kenneth Evan Fleisher, the son of Linda Fleisher and Dr. Martin Fleisher of Glen Cove, N.Y. Rabbi Arthur Rulnick performed the ceremony at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Books Revealing Their Artistry
description: THERE is something about a book, the feel of it, the quality of the paper, the curve of the type, the binding, illustrations, size and shape, indeed, the very idea of the book: its bookness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, SR. EILEEN MARY (FORMERLY SISTER MARY GAUDENTIA)
description: TAYLOR-Sr. Eileen Mary (formerly Sister Mary Gaudentia). Died on November 24, 2000. Sister was a lifelong educator in the schools of the Archdiocese of New York as well as the New York City Public School System. She also volunteered at Jacobi Medical Center. Visiting Monday, 2-4 and 79 PM, at the Albert R. Conner-Colonial Funeral Home, 4955 Broadway (West 207 Street, NYC). Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10 AM, Good Shepherd R.C. Church. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Sisters of Mercy Retirement Fund, 150 Ridge Rd., Hartsdale, NY 10530 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOELL, AMY JACOB
description: GOELL-Amy Jacob. Of Scarsdale and Hartsdale, NY, died peacefully Thanksgiving evening at the age of 93 in Neptune, New Jersey. Wife of the late Milton Goell; mother of James Goell of Ocean, New Jersey, and Martha Goell Lubell of Philadelphia; grandmother of Lisa Goell Sinicki and Ric Goell and David and Sam Lubell; great-grandmother of Jake, Hayley and Maya Goell and Lindsey Sinicki; sister of Elsa Rosenwald. Private services Sunday in Bala Cynwyd, PA. A woman of social commitment and a love of nature.

title: Good Schools Produce Good High-Tech Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Overcoming the Tutu Factor
description: IT was probably 30 years ago that Erik Bruhn of the Royal Danish Ballet appeared on the cover of Life magazine over the headline ''The World's Most Athletic Man.''

title: Freeport Needs Overtime After Wasting a Big Lead
description: Freeport, which squandered a 13-point fourth-quarter lead, won the Long Island Class I championship yesterday by outlasting Commack, 20-19, in overtime. A Commack rally late in the fourth quarter sent the game into overtime.

title: E-ZPasses
description: To the Editor: In reference to electronic toll-taking, even using one such service presents problems.

title: How I Found This Old Thing
description: IT was a friend's 40th birthday bash. ''A vintage party,'' she explained on the phone. ''You can wear whatever you have that's vintage.'' My husband, she added, could get away with a skinny tie.

title: Paper Chase
description: AUTHOR UNKNOWN

title: SHOPPING WITH: John Epperson; What It Takes To Bring Out The Gal in a Guy
description: WRAITH-PALE and dressed in self-effacing black, John Epperson stole past the threshold of Jeffrey New York, the outpost of haute hip at 14th Street and 10th Avenue, eyeing the merchandise warily. After a moment, he pounced on a Pucci-patterned patent leather handbag that was garishly at odds with his understated look. It was perfect, however, for Lypsinka, Mr. Epperson's outsize alter ego, the lusty chanteuse now performing five nights a week at the Westbeth Theater Center in Greenwich Village.

title: Hamilton Bissell, 89, an Official at Exeter
description: Hamilton Bissell, who developed a program to recruit students who were ''long on brains and short on cash'' for Phillips Exeter Academy, died on Nov. 17 at his home in West Caldwell, N.J. He was 89.

title: A Newcomer Two Years in the Making
description: MUCH of the territory between the East End and western Suffolk is a culinary desert. Many towns have not a single noteworthy restaurant. Yet the tiny hamlet of Wading River now boasts two worth-the-trip spots. The Ponds at Wading River joins the established and well-regarded La Plage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MANDEL E., MD, FRCP
description: COHEN-Mandel E., MD, FRCP, Senior Physician at Massachussetts General Hospital, died November 19 in Boston, age 93. Beloved husband of the late Winifred Hamlen (Hunt) Cohen. Loving father of Dr. Anne Hamlen Cohen and husband, Robert E. Meggison of Belfast, ME and Rev. Dr. Katharine Cohen Black and husband Dr. Peter M. Black of Boston. Dear grandfather of Winifred Hamlen Black of Washington, DC, Elizabeth Peterson Black, Katharine Elliot Black, Peter Thomas McLaren Black and Christopher Tucker Black, Boston. Also survived by a niece, Caroline Rand Herron of Truro, MA and NY; two nephews, Rand Herron of RI and Tom Cohen of NY. Memorial services Sunday, December 17, 2PM, St. John's Chapel-Episcopal Divinity School, 99 Brattle St., Cambridge, MA. Donations may be made to Boston Atheneum, 10-1/2 Beacon Street, Boston, MA. 02108.

title: Liberties; Oyez! Oyez! Oy Vey! This Is One Nutty Election!
description: The old Don had helped the humiliated man in the black robe get justice. He had treated the judge's enemies as his own enemies.

title: When Getting to It Is Part of a Museum's Aesthetic
description: MICHAEL MALTZAN has designed a perfect museum for the work of Ed Ruscha. However, Maltzan's clients, the powers at the Museum of Modern Art, want to use it for paintings by van Gogh, Cezanne, Picasso and Matisse. Well, if they insist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, EDITH M.
description: BLOCH-Edith M. Beloved wife of the late Marc E. Bloch. Loving mother of Louise Bachman (George) and Lynne Steinberg Scheinin (Norman). Grandmother of Jaymi, Tracie, Todd, Brad and Ricki. Great-grandmother of eleven. Loving sister. Funeral at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY on Wednesday, Nov. 29, 2000 at 11AM.

title: A Very Tidy Progression
description: Most people think the nexus between soap and home furnishing is Murphy's Oil. Not so Jon Bresler and Jennifer Welte, founders of Lafco New York, a line of soaps that is less focused on hygiene than on high design. Mr. Bresler introduced the decorative soaps, some with graphic Art Deco-inspired packaging and some wrapped in handmade Japanese paper, seven years ago.

title: The World: No Time for a Change; Where Power Brokers Rule, Reform Stands Still
description: IN a country where ambiguity in politics (and much else) is often king, a rebellion in the form of a no-confidence vote in the Japanese legislature served up a choice of rare clarity last week.

title: Mayor Most Rare: Sexologist and Monied Marxist
description: In a city traditionally governed by lawyers, engineers and bankers, she is a sexologist by training. She is also an aristocrat whose strongest following is among the poor, a socialist in a financial center with the largest accumulation of wealth in Latin America, and a feminist competing in a political domain that still values bare-knuckled machismo.

title: Everything, It Seems, But Piazza's Broken Bat
description: So where is Mike Piazza's broken bat in the new Subway Series display at the Baseball Hall of Fame? Where are the jagged pieces of wood that resulted when his bat shattered from fouling off a Roger Clemens pitch in Game 2 of the 2000 World Series between the Yankees and the Mets?

title: IN BRIEF
description: Twinlab Executives To Return Bonus Pay

title: Navigating the Web For Air Fare Bargains
description: FINDING the cheapest air fare is no easy task, despite a growing list of Internet travel sites, because customers have no guarantee that what is displayed on their screen is the best.

title: Trying to Stay Cold
description: The 1969 animated version of ''Frosty the Snowman,'' narrated by Jimmy Durante, begins CBS's holiday programming on Saturday at 8 p.m.; ''Frosty Returns,'' with Jonathon Winters as the narrator, follows at 8:30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIM, ROBERT CHRISTIAN
description: HEIM-Robert Christian. Of Somers, NY. Died November 21, 2000. Husband of the late Frances. Father of Peter Heim, Abigail Vincent and Margaret Steketee. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Memorial service on Saturday, December 2 at 10:00 AM at the Briarcliff Congregational Church. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Frances M. Heim Memorial Music Fund, C/O the Briarcliff Congregational Church, 30 S. State Rd., Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510.

title: Suspect in Series of Sex Attacks Is Arrested
description: A violent parolee whom investigators have described as a criminal chameleon responsible for nearly a dozen sexual attacks and robberies was arrested minutes after he talked his way into an Upper West Side apartment Friday night, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Notable Neighbors Fight Plans to Expand Town House in Historic District
description: If Eli Zabar and Woody Allen talk to each other over the back fence, chances are they complain about the neighbors. They are angry, specifically, about plans that Michael and Laura Fisch, who live a few doors down on East 92nd Street, have to enlarge their town house.

title: G.O.P. Rethinks A Legal Strategy
description: Yesterday was Day 19 of the 2000 election. Here is a summary of the day's events.

title: Allowing the Math-Challenged To Savor the Coffee at Tip Time
description: Think fast. What's 17 percent of $45.87?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENSTEIN, HAZEL
description: ORENSTEIN-Hazel. Daughter of Sidney Orenstein and the late Mae Greiff Orenstein. Sister of Jonathan, Henry and David Orenstein. Sister-in-law of Sandra Seidlitz and aunt of Matthew, Natalie and Michael Orenstein. Died of ovarian cancer on November 23, 2000 at the age of 48 in Cambridge, MA. Her courage and fortitude in battling the five-year disease were extraordinary. A graduate in English at Brandeis University in 1974, she later obtained a Master's Degree in Special Education at Lesley College. Her life was devoted to the welfare of developmentally disabled men and women whom she helped to live self sufficent, productive lives. Her commitment to their welfare never faltered and she fought to assure that they were well treated in their housing needs, their employment and their social activities. At the center of Hazel's life were friendships of uncommon devotion. Many of these friendships lasted for decades, some for a lifetime. Hazel died peacefully among loving friends and family. She will be missed by all who knew her. A funeral service was held in Cambridge, MA on November 24, 2000. A memorial service will be held in Cambridge, MA. Call 617-661-9559 after December 14 for more information. Burial will be in the Orenstein plot at Mt. Judah Cemetery, Ridgewood, Queens on Sunday, November 26, 2000 at 2:30 PM. Donations may be made to the following charities in her memory: American Cancer Society, 30 Speen St., Framingham, MA 01701; Association for Retarded Citizens of MA, 217 South St., Waltham, MA 02453; The Wellness Community, 1320 Centre St., Suite 305, Newton Centre, MA 02459.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ITIL, ELEONORE (BRETZ)
description: ITIL-Eleonore (Bretz), 75, of Nyack, NY, on November 22, 2000 died at home, in her sleep, as peacefully and dignified as she had lived. A graduate of the University of Tubingen (Germany), Ellen had worked as a research assistant at the Universities of Tubingen, Erlangen and Missouri. She was a Vice President at HZI Research Center, Tarrytown, NY, until her retirement. Ellen was a wonderful, beloved wife of 45 years, devoted mother, generous and tolerant friend, lover of nature, animals and art. We shall all remember Ellen as a classy, dignified, warm and forgiving person. She dedicated herself to her family and was kind to everyone. Ellen possessed a unique blend of strength with tolerance. She was an exceptional person and will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Ellen is survived by her husband, Turan, children, Kurt and Yasmin, brother Kurt, daughter-inlaw, Birnur, sister-in-law Muazzez, brother-in-law Erich and niece, Esin. A memorial service will be held on December 2, 2000 at the family's home in Nyack. Donations can be made to the Eleonore Itil Parkinson's Fund.

title: Hartford Says 'No More Rats' and Means It
description: IN September 1999, Mike Peters, the mayor of Hartford, declared a state of emergency in the city for the first time since 1984, when a flood coursed through Hartford. Rats, not water, were flooding the city this time. Rats sauntering across the street in the heat of the sun. Rats popping out of cracks in building foundations. Rats teetering atop trash cans like kings of the mountain. Community groups were outraged and marched on city hall. Something, they said, had to be done.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, HULDA REES
description: FLYNN-Hulda Rees. Died peacefully November 24 at the home of her daughter Sarah Flynn in Annapolis, MD, at age 90. Born in 1910 in Dartmouth, MA, and raised in Williamstown, Dr. Flynn received her B.A. (1931) and M.A. (1933) from Smith College and her Ph.D. in psychology from Columbia University (1943). Her first husband, John W. McGarvey, died in 1939. In 1945 she married psychologist John Patrick Flynn, who died in 1980. During her career she taught at Smith and Mount Holyoke Colleges, and at Yale University, where she was instrumental in the founding of the Connecticut Mental Health Center. A lifelong champion of social justice, she was associate director of the Samuel Adams School in Boston in 1944 and 1945. Beloved by all who knew her, she is survived by her elder sister, Edith Rees, formerly of New York City, by Sarah Flynn and David Prosten of Annapolis, MD; by Kathleen Flynn Franks, also known as Apa Sunriver, and Douglas Franks of Sequim, WA; and by her grandson, Sean Patrick Greene, and Molly Burnham of Somerville, MA. In addition to both her husbands, she was predeceased by her sister Clara Rees and her daughter Barbara Flynn. Memorial contributions may be made to appropriate causes, such as American Friends Service Committee, attn. Robert Snyder, 2161 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge, MA 02140; the Rosenberg Fund for Children, c/o Robert Meeropol, 1145 Main St., Suite 408, Springfield, MA 01103; or the Hulda Rees McGarvey Flynn Scholarship Fund at Smith College, c/o Office of Development, Smith College, Northampton, MA 01063. No memorial service is planned. For further information, call Sarah Flynn at 410-268-2966.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, PAULINE B.
description: FALK-Pauline B. On Tuesday, November 21, 2000 at 90 years of age. Loving wife of the late Myron S. Falk, Jr. (Johnny). Mother of Patricia, Michael and Nancy. Grandmother of Christopher, Brooke, Melanie, Amerin, Gregory and Logan. Great grandmother of Ruby, Zoe, Jasper and Leon. Sister of the late Herman Baerwald, Jane Aron and Florence Doubilet. Also survived by devoted family and friends. Funeral service Tuesday, November 28th, 12 Noon, Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, 120 West 57 St, NY, NY 10019.

title: Daniela Bochner, Michael Rader
description: Daniela Bochner, a daughter of Tikva and Paul Bochner of New York, is to be married today to Michael Nathan Rader, the son of Barbara and Dennis Rader of Woodbridge, Conn. Rabbi Arie Strikovsky will officiate at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about investments by university endowments in venture capital and other types of private equity referred incorrectly to those of the University of California. While the university changed its policy this year to allow up to 7 percent of its endowment pool to go to such investments, from 2 percent, the change simply brought policy into line with practice. About 5 percent of the endowment's assets have been invested in private equity for several years.

title: Bench Mark; Even When Blind, Justice Feels the Political Winds
description: A NATION that worried three weeks ago about which president would pick judges now confronts the prospect of judges picking a president. For the first time in American history, the United States Supreme Court could effectively decide who the next president is -- unless, of course, the loser holds out and forces Congress to decide.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 26, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Agencies Preparing Now To Fight Rural Wildfires
description: Flush with $1.8 billion in new financing approved by Congress, five federal agencies are making efforts to better protect rural communities from wildfires like the ones that devastated Western states this summer.

title: The Election; Not Exactly Made for TV, But Think of the Ratings
description: A COURTROOM in Tallahassee drew an audience of millions last Monday afternoon, thanks to eight major broadcast and cable networks' live coverage of the Florida Supreme Court hearing on whether manual recounts could continue in the presidential race.

title: Italian Alternative to the Luxury Scene
description: NATALE PETRONE knows how to run an Italian restaurant. He proved that as the chef and owner of Il Sapore, a successful white tablecloth trattoria in Roslyn Heights for 13 years. Before that he was involved with Il Villagio in Roslyn, the Villa Parmas in Hicksville and Melville and a few other eating places, all of which offered serious alternatives to the splashy and expensive luxury dining scene.

title: Stretching For Safety Aloft
description: MEDICAL studies have produced conflicting conclusions on whether there is a link between travel, particularly in an airplane, and venous thrombosis, or blood clots in veins. But following the death of Emma Christoffersen, a 28-year-old who collapsed at Heathrow upon debarking from a 20-hour Qantas flight from Australia and died of thrombosis on her way to the hospital, the nuances of the dispute were lost.

title: IN BRIEF: Government; COUNTY'S AAA RATING
description: Westchester County has sold $46.6 million in general obligation bonds and maintained its triple-A bond rating with all three major credit rating agencies -- Moody's, Standard & Poor's and Fitch. The bonds, which were sold this month at an interest rate of 4.8 percent, will finance a variety of county projects previously approved, including roads and bridges, technology upgrades and open space. Westchester is the only county in the state with a triple-A bond rating. The bonds were bought by an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Smith Barney. Elsa Brenner

title: Alyson Hui, Paul Mellett
description: Alyson Lea Hui and Paul John Mellett were married yesterday by the Rev. Henry Fehren, a retired Roman Catholic priest, at the Hudson River Club in New York.

title: Ghosts of Portugal in Macao, Now Part of China
description: HAVE you ever been to Macao?'' I asked everyone I met in Hong Kong. The answer, nearly always, was yes. Hong Kong residents pop off to Macao for the weekend as casually as New Yorkers head for the Hudson Valley or the Hamptons. It's an easy trip that requires little advance planning. Regular ferries between the two cities, both former colonial outposts, both now Special Administrative Regions of China, zip passengers to and fro across the South China Sea in about an hour.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-26-00: Questions for Bernard Shaw; Anchor Away
description: Q: Just as you announced your retirement, the country went through that bizarre post-election moment, when everyone was obsessed with TV news. Any second thoughts?

title: Ringo's Rate of Return
description: In the middle of a Beatles' marketing blitz over the release of their autobiography and a new collection of their top hits, the Fab Four are not ignoring Wall Street. A television commercial earlier this year promoting Charles Schwab, and featuring Ringo Starr, recently resurfaced.

title: A Rock Band Parallel
description: To the Editor:

title: Back to Those Thrilling Days of Yesteryear
description: NETWORK television - once filled with cowboys, Prohibitionera gangsters, World War II heroes and the occasional do-gooder archer from the Middle Ages - now pursues a decidedly different programming philosophy, which might be summed up in one phrase: Who gives a hoot about history?

title: Standing Pat? Not Likely
description: FOR more than 35 years, Loretta Roberge and the brothers Courtland and Carlisle Fowler have been integral members of the Mohegan Indian tribe. Courtland Fowler remembers working together in the 1970's to draft the tribe's first constitution, meeting in one another's houses because the tribe had no office, no typewriter and no telephone.

title: If Only Baldrige Winners Could Be Traded as One
description: This week, the National Institute of Standards and Technology recognized a bank, a water company and two manufacturers as winners of the Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award. And to show just how adept it is at picking winners, the institute boasted that since it began presenting the awards in 1987, its choices through 1998 had outperformed the return of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by nearly 5 to 1.

title: POSTINGS: Jersey City Building's Design to Suggest a Sailboat; Newport: 32-Story Spec Tower
description: Work is scheduled to begin early next year on a 32-story, 1.1 million-square-foot office building in the Lefrak Organization's Newport development on the Jersey City waterfront. The building will be known as Newport Office Center VII and will be located at 480 Washington Boulevard.

title: To Loyal Patrons' Dismay, a Beloved Cafe Is No More
description: There is no place to sit inside Roberto Gautier's apartment on Strong Place, because it is crammed with crepe grills.

title: Spelling Trouble
description: Losing The Race

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about the death of an East Village antiques dealer, Kurt Kjellin, misspelled the name of the funeral home where a service was held for him. It is Provenzano Lanza.

title: Bookend; Fold -- No, Click -- Here
description: After the publication of one of my books, ''The Mapmakers,'' a friend enthused, ''You have told me everything I ever wanted to know about maps, except how to refold them.'' Nothing this side of a long run on the best-seller list, I suppose, pleases an author of a new book more than witty flattery. One clings to it as a consolation for not having scored big in sales. But time eventually has rewarded me with a sense of satisfaction that is deeper than consolation: the satisfaction of being the author of a book with a long life.

title: November 19-25; Milosevic Tries a Comeback
description: The former Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic is attempting a political comeback, announcing plans to lead his party, the Socialist Party of Serbia, in Serbian parliamentary elections in December. He has appeared twice on television, his first public appearances since he accepted his election defeat and resigned as president on Oct. 6. He managed to be the sole candidate for president of the party at its congress meets Saturday. His maneuvering caused several high level officials to leave the party, which with 10 percent in the polls, is likely to remain the largest opposition party. Carlotta Gall

title: For the Sake Of Argument
description: Jacob Weisberg's incisive article (Nov. 5) about the limited, even disappointing, legacy of Pat Moynihan spoke to one of the central dilemmas of elective office, especially at its highest levels: the intellect and temperament of the statesman rarely coexist with the patience and attention to mundane detail that produce effectiveness. Moynihan and Alfonse D'Amato clearly complemented each other. It may take both types to make the Senate work.

title: Honoring Those Who Sold Too Soon
description: We bought their island for practically nothing, then ran them off it, but now some New Yorkers want to give the city's first inhabitants back a patch, at least in name.

title: Franco Finds Plenty of Reasons to Stay
description: Part of his recent contract negotiations really bothered John Franco: sitting by the phone, waiting for updates from his agent. It was interrupting his workout schedule.

title: Romance Hits the Trail
description: BOONE'S LICK

title: Paris Wald, Harry Stulbach
description: Debra Paris Wald and Dr. Harry Bruce Stulbach are to be married today by Rabbi Elliot Pearlson at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RICHART, MIMI
description: RICHART-Mimi. April 2, 1927-Nov. 26, 1978. You are still the love of my life and you always will be. I miss you and love you. Lloyd

title: The Neediest Cases; A Month's Rent and a Bridge Out of Crisis
description: It was 21 degrees on the morning of Dec. 28, 1999. Pierre Blain, 26, turned on Channel 4 to check the temperature, then put on two pairs of socks and thermal boots to help stave off the cold. He thought he had the flu, but he reported to his job at a Jersey City furniture warehouse anyway because he needed the $67 that he would make that day.

title: All Parties, All the Time: New York's Bloodshot Eye
description: BY 7 p.m. on a recent chilly night, the Cerruti store on Madison Avenue had begun to fill with young socialites and wispy models. Rumors that the rapper Jay-Z and his entourage were expected at the cocktail party under way there had already sent a little thrill through the throng. But as far as the phalanx of publicists on duty was concerned, the most important guest was already there, busily sucking all the air out of the room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, GEORGE
description: JACOBSON-George. Dearly beloved brother of Bertha, and the late Sam and the late Mark. Died November 21, 2000.

title: Beaujolais, Peconic Style
description: The wine-store posters are everywhere: ''Le Beaujolais Nouveau est arrive,'' and the guzzling of the grapey treat is well under way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORREST, JILL L. (RUDES)
description: FORREST-Jill L. (Rudes). Breast cancer advocate, creator of the first rehabilatative fitness video for breast cancer survivors, founder of the www.breastfit.com website, lecturer, loved and respected reading teacher at the Smith Street School in Uniondale, Long Island, graduate of Tufts University, Cite University of Paris, Honors Graduate in the master's degree program at Hofstra University. Survived by loving husband Edward, dear son Jonathan, loving daughter Courtney, loving mother Adelaide Rudes, dear brother Alan Rudes and the many friends and colleagues who admired her warmth, kindness and courage. Chapel services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York on Monday, November 27 at 10:00 AM. The family has requested that all contributions be made to Better Than Before Fitness, Ltd., 85 Deer Run, Roslyn Heights, NY, 11577 to perpetuate Jill's rehabilitative fitness video program for breast cancer survivors. The family will be following Jill's wishes by not sitting shiva.

title: Initial Offerings: Once Hot, but Now Hot Potatoes
description: IF your holiday wish list includes shares of the hottest new stock, you are likely to be disappointed. With the way things are going in the stock market, you might find more value in a Pets.com sock puppet or a William Shatner CD.

title: QUICK BITE/Fair Lawn; Where Blood Is Thicker Than Honey Mustard
description: How does a little deli in Fair Lawn supply lunch to workers at 40 businesses? The name of A Family Affair, in Fair Lawn, tells it all. It takes only three Tisis, plus a van and driver, to handle all the orders. ''The key is organization,'' said Edward Tisi Jr., a graudate of the New York Restaurant School. ''I've been in places where 10 people don't work as fast as we do.'' Eds Jr. and Sr. arrive at 7 a.m., and Angela, Ed. Sr's wife, comes in at 8:30. ''I have to give Mom a little break,'' Ed Jr. said. In the process, the three createmore than tuna salad and B.L.T.'s. A recent menu featured as specials a tortilla wrap of pepper mill melted Harvarti dill cheese with saut-eed diced portobello mushrooms and Caesar dressing ($5.25) and cheese tortellini tossed with saut/'eed broccoli rape and Italian sausage ($5.95 a pound). Everyday fare includes a moist and tender grilled chicken cutlet with grilled eggplant, lettuce, tomato and honeymustard ($4.75); bow-tie pasta salad ($4.49 a pound); and tossed romaine salad with egg ($4.50), with tuna ($4.95) or grilled chicken ($5.25). Visitors to the sparkling white-tiled deli will find not only prepared food, but also homemade sauces and mozzarella and imported Italian products like Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese and San Marana tomatoes. A Family Affair also caters events and meetings and prepares gift baskets.

title: A Tree Grows in Queens? Too Bad, City Comptroller Says
description: Stephen Flynn says it cost him more than $1,200 to repair a sidewalk buckled by four city-owned trees in front of a house he owns on Tahoe Street in Ozone Park, Queens. But when it came to his request for reimbursement from the Office of the City Comptroller, he said, it was as if he were the proverbial tree that falls in an empty forest. There was no one to hear him.

title: Floating Flowers
description: Lots of things can be found floating in the waters around New Orleans, including crayfish and alligators. But the bathtubs of one of the city's hotels are filled with something much more pleasant. The International House Hotel in New Orleans offers a Southern Flower Bath package with a massage for two, a drawn bath with seasonal flowers floating in the water, a package of scented soaps, bath oils and bath salts to match the flower, and some refreshments. It costs $539 for two people, plus tax. The 119-room hotel is at 221 Camp Street, two blocks from the French Quarter in the Central Business District; (800) 633-5770, fax (504) 553-9560, or visit www.ihhotel.com.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Nov. 12 about the wedding of Dr. Louise Suzanne Matthews and Thomas Raymond Flickinger misstated the name of the market research company in Chicago where the bridegroom works. It is Information Resources, not Information Human Resources.

title: Hewlett Schools Head Sees Drug 'Epidemic'
description: DRUG and alcohol abuse ''by our own children'' has reached an ''almost epidemic state,'' Dr. Charles W. Fowler, the superintendent of Hewlett-Woodmere public schools, said in a letter to parents announcing a town meeting to discuss what could be done about the problem.

title: An Inspired Outsider, Even in His Own Land
description: AT 41, Habib Koite has high blood pressure. His doctors have told him that he has too much salt in his diet. Trying to juggle too many musical styles for too many audiences may not be helping either.

title: How Biotech Has Held On, And Its Prospects
description: DOT-COMS are crashing and burning. But biotechnology stocks, which in many respects are just as speculative and just as profitless, are hanging in there.

title: Indelible Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: A World of Double Outsiders: Gay as Well as Black
description: FROM the first films he made with Sankofa, a black, British film collective he co-founded in the 1980's, Isaac Julien has explored racial stereotypes and the pressures that militate against more complex racial depictions. In ''The Passion of Remembrance,'' Maggie, a levelheaded black lesbian, says: ''Every time a black face appears, we think it has to represent the whole race. We haven't got the space to get it wrong.''

title: Sydney Dancers, Fit and Radiant, Wow and Shock
description: THE choreographer Graeme Murphy is riding the wave of post-Olympic Games admiration for the immensely healthy life style of his fellow Australians. He rides it with an elan that can be a bit intimidating in its candor.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Bronxville; From Artists' Colony to Affluent Village
description: SITTING in her comfortable wood-paneled office, which features a fireplace and grandfather clock, Mayor Nancy D. Hand bubbles with enthusiasm as she tries to convey the appeal of the one-square-mile village over which she presides.

title: The Unlit Stove
description: NOT long ago, Debra Birnbaum came home to find an unusual letter tucked inside her utility bill. It was from Con Edison, wondering why she wasn't using any gas in her West Village apartment.

title: East Village Is the Canvas For a Once-Outlawed Muralist
description: One recent afternoon, Chico Garcia was standing by the restaurant Orologio, on Avenue A, about to uncap a can of spray paint. Then one of the owners stepped outside.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TROUT, ROBERT
description: TROUT-Robert. A Mass in memory of Robert Trout will be celebrated at his parish church, St. Joseph's in Greenwich Village (371 Sixth Avenue), on Saturday, December 2, 2000, at 3:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROAS, DONALD S.
description: BROAS-Donald S. On November 22, 2000 at age 60. Beloved husband of Betty Jane Langer-Broas. Devoted father of Nancy Gray, Donald Jr., Kimberley and Gregory. Cherished grandfather of Hayley Gray. Former president Excelcare Health System Inc, executive vice president Interfaith Medical Center, chief executive officer Health Care Development International, Inc., president Hospital for Special Surgery, trustee Springfield College and Medic Alert Foundation. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday 6-9 PM, with service Monday 3:30 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: What Befell the Before of Before and After
description: NOW that the leaves are off the trees for the most part, it is comforting to think forward to the delightful season of spring. That is the time of year to visit the nearby wild lands to see native flowers in full bloom.

title: Election Day: Time for a 17th-Inning Stretch; Uncertainty Principle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEUER, EMILIE (NEE BENTZ)
description: HEUER-Emilie (nee Bentz). On Wednesday, November 22. Beloved wife of the late Johannes, loving mother of Gerald R.J., Lt. Col. USAF, Ret. Sister of the late Louis Bentz (Catherine Bentz Quinn), beloved aunt of Jeannette Bentz King (Bob), great aunt of Denise King Ehrich (W. Graham), Jeannette King Burke (Robert M.), and Michele King. Great grand aunt of Dillon M. Burke and Robert M. Burke IV. Born in NYC. Cooper Union Class of '24. For information, contact A.H. Peters Funeral Home, 20705 Mack Ave., Grosse Pointe Woods, MI 48236.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-26-00; Two Nations, Undivided
description: If you take a look at that remarkable postelection map, in which all of George W. Bush's states are red, and all of Al Gore's states are blue, you would be forgiven for thinking that we live in essentially two nations. A friend recalled the map of pre-independence India: a vast, red Hindu subcontinent adorned with a Muslim necklace in the regions that would shortly become Pakistan and Bangladesh. Look at postelection America, and you see a similarly clear geographic divide: the liberal, urban coasts with a couple of Midwestern blobs nervously framing a homogeneous, conservative heartland. As the political analyst Michael Barone first noticed, cities with more than half a million people went to Gore by a 3-to-1 margin, but in small towns, Bush won about 60 percent of the vote.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Vitaly Komar and Alex Melamid; The Conceptual Spin
description: IS there a high-energy proton ring in New York City? There's at least one, centered on Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid, the Russian conceptual artists known for making international surveys of tastes and paintings to match. (For instance, Americans like trees, water, people, wildlife and George Washington.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, S. LOUIS
description: SCHWARTZ - S. Louis. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the father of its esteemed member, Mr. Morton Schwartz, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi David Yagoda, Chairman William Schwartz, President

title: Advice From 2000, to Pass On to the Children; Judges and Partisans
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, ANNA MARIA
description: MAYER-Anna Maria. On November 16, 2000, in Palm Beach, FL. Survived by her nephews Joseph Costa, Sr., and Nicholas Costa and nieces Joanne Costa and Geraldine Costa Cohen. Also survived by her grandnephew Joseph A. Costa, Jr. Funeral was Wednesday, November 22, at Our Lady of Pompei Church and interment was in Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUHL, BENJAMIN
description: DUHL-Benjamin. Working with you was a privilege. We will miss you, as will countless others. Carol Slater Director of Palm Beach Campaign for NY-UJA Federation Murray Peters Consultant Emeritus

title: Rebuilding by Boeheim at Syracuse Looks a Lot Like a Reloading
description: One month ago, the Big East men's basketball coaches picked Syracuse to finish in the middle of the pack of the West Division. Gale Catlett, the coach at West Virginia, saw the predictions and thought they were just hilarious.

title: Compressed Data; Surviving Master, Pets.com Mascot Seeks New Home
description: Pets.com has closed down, but the company, an online purveyor of pet information and supplies, still has at least one potentially valuable asset: Sock Puppet.

title: With Plot Still Sketchy, Characters Vie for Roles; The Struggles Over E-Books Abound, Though Readership Remains Elusive
description: There is something not entirely rational about the book industry's current love affair with electronic books. Few people have ever read a whole book on a screen. No one knows how many people will ever want to. And book publishers have been burned before: A decade ago, book publishers produced thousands of electronic books on computer discs with game-like interactive features, pictures and sounds, but consumers were not interested.

title: Pauline Baerwald Falk, 90, Philanthropist
description: Pauline Baerwald Falk, a philanthropist and a collector of Asian art who was also a former president of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.

title: Media; To Stay Afloat, Unlikely Ties In TV News
description: Do not be surprised if you notice Ted Koppel, the ABC ''Nightline'' anchor, being the host of an episode of ''Frontline'' on PBS this January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMELIN, DAVID B.
description: HERMELIN-David B. Thanks To Scandinavia notes with sadness the untimely passing of David B. Hermelin, dynamic U.S. Ambassador to Norway and passionate philanthropic leader. Ambassador Hermelin honored our educational foundation in 1998 with the establishment of the annual David B. Hermelin Thanks To Scandinavia Scholarship at the University of Michigan. We will be forever grateful for his friendship and his vigorous support of the moral imperatives of Thanks To Scandinavia in perpetuating appreciation for the bravery of the people, governments and churches of Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden in rescuing thousands of persons of the Jewish faith from the Holocaust. Victor Borge, National Chairman Richard Netter, President

title: Certified but Incomplete
description: By hailing the certification of Florida's ballots as the last word on the presidential election and naming a transition director and chief of staff, Gov. George W. Bush reached boldly for the mantle of president-elect. Unfortunately, he is also trying to leapfrog the nation past the important pending legal challenges to that state's incompletely counted vote. In light of the events since Nov. 7, the last word ought to be delivered by the courts that will hear Vice President Al Gore's contests of the results and, more important, by a United States Supreme Court that is hearing arguments about the election at Mr. Bush's request.

description: The Ruido Group, an agency specializing in advertising aimed at the Spanish-speaking youth market, is opening in New York.

title: Team From Italy and Illinois Leads Nationals
description: A pair from Illinois and a foursome from Italy combined to take a substantial lead in the prestigious Reisinger Team championship here on Saturday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals. George Jacobs of Burr Ridge, Ill., and Ralph Katz of Hinsdale, Ill., were supported by four of the players who won the world team title two months ago in Maastricht, the Netherlands: Alfredo Versace, Lorenzo Lauria, Norberto Bocchi and Giorgio Duboin. The scores by captain of the 10 teams qualified for today's final were:

Stone Sits Out With Rib Injury

title: With the Polls Closed, Political Sites Seek a New Focus
description: Just a few months ago, the Democracy Network, one of the first nonprofit Web sites to provide election information online, caused a stir in nonprofit political circles by selling itself to Grassroots.com, a commercial portal for news and information about political issues.

description: THE men's room that congressmen use just off the House floor is closed for now to James R. Langevin, who was elected to the House this month by voters of Rhode Island's Second Congressional District. The telephones in the cloakroom where members gather to hash out legislative strategy are inaccessible, too.

title: Change Bewilders South Africa's White Voters
description: It is election season, and the politicians are rolling through Sophiatown, a stronghold for the white opposition, where people distrust South Africa's black government and reminisce wistfully about the days of all-white rule.

title: In the Fight Against TB, Hope for an Invisible Weapon
description: The fixtures on the ceiling of the drop-in center for homeless women in Manhattan are entirely unremarkable. One year they are functioning, and the next year they are not, and only one person knows whether they are really on or off. The energy they produce is invisible, and nobody yet knows if, when they are working, they are fulfilling their intended purpose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, MAX
description: BERGER-Max. 89, of Pompano Beach, FL, passed away on November 25, 2000. He is survived by his loving children, Edward Berger and Nancy (Howard) Maybloom; cherished grandchildren, Lesley and Adam; and many nieces and nephews. Services will be held on Tuesday, November 28, 1 PM, Cedar Park Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. For information, contact Riverside-Gordon, 954-523-5801.

title: Chilling Tale Of Dutchman Has a Mythic, Modern Edge
description: The Metropolitan Opera's powerful 1989 production of Wagner's ''Fliegende Hollander'' was mounted for the bass James Morris, whose portrayal of the title role was one of the finest achievements of his great career. The production returned to the Met on Friday night with Mr. Morris again as the Flying Dutchman, the cursed sea captain condemned to roam the ocean forever, allowed only once every seven years to dock his vessel and search for a woman whose true love can release him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALITZ, CLARENCE YALE JR.
description: PALITZ-Clarence Yale Jr. Died November 23 following a brief illness at age 69. He was the Chairman of the Board of Financial Federal Corporation, a major leasing and financial services company based in New York. A graduate of Dartmouth College and New York University Business School, he served as an Officer in the United States Navy. His career was devoted to the heavy equipment leasing and financing industry. He served on numerous corporate boards in the banking industry in the tri-state area. In 1963 he founded Commercial Alliance Corporation (ASE) with his brother. In 1989, he established Financial Federal Corporation (NYSE) along with his son and brother. Mr. Palitz was a patron of the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic, the American Ballet Theatre and a major benefactor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He has been mentor to many and his leadership will be greatly missed. He is survived by his adoring wife Anka, loving daughter Suzanne and her husband Joel Bauman, son Michael and his wife Gabrielle, stepson Gregory Kriser and his wife Sandra, brother Bernard Palitz, devoted granddaughters Elianora and Sophie, and step grandson Ryan. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on November 27 at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers donations should be made to the Central Park Conservancy or to the charity of your choice.

title: A Mantle of Legitimacy
description: It was not decisive by any means, this latest chapter in the melodrama of 2000, but not meaningless, either.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, MILDRED
description: HALPERN-Mildred. Passed away on November 25, 2000, in Miami, FL. Formerly of Great Neck, NY. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Daughter of the late Joseph and Marian Lipshie. She leaves behind her brother, Norman Lipshie, her daughter, Suzy Somers, her sons, Lawrence and Robert Halpern, five grandchildren and eight nieces and nephews. For information contact Ferncliff Cemetery, Secor Rd., Hartsdale, NY.

title: E-Voting: Its Day Has Not Come Just Yet
description: After watching the mess in Florida, voters might wonder why it is not yet possible to toss out the chaos and frenzy of paper ballots or punch cards and move the process onto the Internet. After all, if you can buy a book in your pajamas, why not choose a president?

description: Ford Motor is planning this week to make major realignments among the agencies handling its European assignments and brands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, FRANCIS P.
description: CLARK-Francis P. 81, of Harwich, MA, and formerly of Briarcliff Manor, NY, in Plymouth, MA, November 24. Husband of Lenore (Riemann) Clark of Harwich; father of Peter F. Clark of Wilmington, DE, Christine Morrison of Charlottesville, VA, and Ann Clark Tucker of Pittsfield, MA; brother of William Clark of Candlewood Lake, CT, and Helen Thiemann of Westport, CT. He is also survived by four grandchildren. He was V.P. of Robert Reis & Co. in NYC, where he worked for 40 years. Memorial donations may be made to Jordan Hospital Capitol Campaign Fund, 275 Sandwich Rd., Plymouth, MA 02360. For additional information and family guest book go to www.legacy.com.

description: Running back Curtis Martin said he felt better today than he had all week, although his strained gluteus maximus remains painful. Martin was clearly hindered against the Chicago Bears, rushing 17 times for 29 yards, a 1.7-yard average. Still, his remarkable ability to block out pain is intact.

Bush as the winner of the Florida election last night, lawyers for Vice President Al Gore were finishing the drafts of what could be the most significant lawsuit of all the legal battles fought so far -- maybe more important than the issues to be heard by the United States Supreme Court on Friday.

description: Canadians vote for a new government on Monday after a five-week campaign that quickly derailed from high-minded debate over taxes and health care to sniping over topics like creationism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGHEIMER, ALAN JOSEPH
description: BURGHEIMER-Alan Joseph. A Rye resident, died on November 24, 2000, at his home, at age 87. Born in NYC on July 16, 1913, he is the son of the late Jacob and Gertrude Kahn Burgheimer. A veteran of the United States Navy, he served the nation during WWII. Mr. Burgheimer was the owner and executive of the Fisher Beer Co. in NYC. On June 20, 1939, he married Jeanne Schwarz at the Waldorf Astoria. He was a member of the City Athletic Club in Manhattan, as well as the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck. In addition to his wife Jeanne, of Rye, he is survived by his daughters Margo Burgheimer of Rye, and Joanne Robinson and her husband Jerrold of Keswick, VA. He is predeceased by a sister, Sylvia Kapp. Funeral service will be held on Monday, 11:30 AM, at Zion Memorial, followed by entombment at Maimonides Cemetery in Elmont, NY. The family requests that donations be sent to the Alzheimer's Association in his memory. For information contact Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY 10543; 914-381-1809. www.zionmemorialchapel.com

description: NOW that the Jets are 8-4, Coach Al Groh was asked if he would guarantee a playoff berth, as the Giants' Jim Fassel has.

description: The Washington Redskins negated many of Donovan McNabb's offensive options today at FedEx Field before 83,284 fans. McNabb threw for only 137 yards. He threw one touchdown pass and one interception. No Eagles running back rushed for more than 25 yards. The Eagles trailed the Redskins in first downs by 20 to 14 and in total yards by 326 to 289.

Grandmother of Christopher, Brooke, Melanie, Amerin, Gregory and Logan. Great grandmother of Ruby, Zoe, Jasper & Leon. Sister of the late Herman Baerwald, Jane Aron and Florence Doubilet. Also survived by devoted family & friends. Funeral service Tuesday, November 28th, 12 Noon, Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, 120 West 57 Street, NY, NY 10019.

title: The Human Body in Its Aesthetic Glory and Scientific Gore
description: A highlight of the carnival season in 17th-century Amsterdam was the public anatomy lesson. Sponsored by the city's Surgeons' Guild, it would draw large crowds to the guild's anatomy theater where the praelector, or public demonstrator, would illustrate his lecture by dissecting a corpse. Often, an artist -- none other than Rembrandt in 1632 and 1656 -- was on hand to paint the praelector and other guild members beside the mutilated cadaver.

title: Child Health Insurance Drive Progresses, but at Halting Pace
description: The converted motor home that pulled up to the central courtyard of the South Bronx housing project shortly before 3 p.m. was shrink-wrapped in a rainbow-colored display featuring smiling children and upbeat slogans like ''Get on Board With Kids' Health Insurance.''

description: Republicans said tonight that Florida's certification of Gov. George W. Bush as the victor there delivered them a vital political and legal argument: that no matter how slim the margin, he is the official winner in Florida and, thus, has a rightful claim on the White House.

description: Vice President Al Gore lodged his expected legal challenge today to Florida's declaration that George W. Bush had won the state, and hence the presidency, while the Bush camp forged ahead with preparations to take office.

They met at the Iguana Grill in Austin, where, five years ago, they celebrated the venture financing commitment that gave birth to their company.

title: Gerald Soffen, Chief Scientist For Mars Missions, Dies at 74
description: Gerald A. Soffen, a biologist who was chief scientist for the Viking missions that searched for signs of life on Mars in the 1970's, died on Wednesday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 74, and associates said he had a heart ailment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNILIO, VICTOR
description: CUNILIO-Victor. Age 84, died November 24, 2000. Beloved husband of Geraldine McMullen Cunilio. Dear father of Marianne Cunilio Jackson of NYC, Thomas V. of Gainesville, FL, and James of Rosemont, PA. His youngest child, Cecelia, predeceased him. Loving brother of Ann Palisi, Rose Fortunato and the late Jos. Cuniglio. Devoted father-in-law of Rick, Maria and Tricia. Treasured grandfather of Dr. Benjamin M. and Tobias M. Jackson, Christopher T., Kathleen Cecelia, Jamie G., Jessica R., and Charles J. Cunilio. Also survived by four nephews, one niece and many other relatives. Graduate of New Utrecht High School, NYU, and DePaul Law School in Chicago. In WWII served in the Pacific with U.S. Marine Corps. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held November 28, 10:30 AM, at St. Thomas of Villanova Church (PA). In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to House of Ruth, 651 10th St. NE, Washington, DC 20002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAROTTA, GIOVANNI F.
description: MAROTTA-Giovanni F. On November 25, 2000. Beloved son of the late Soave and Maria. Devoted brother of Dario and the late Jennie. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at the Basilica of Our Lady of Perpetual Help. Entombment Greenwood Cemetery. Visitation Monday, 2-5 and 79, at the McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, Third Ave. at 97th St., Brooklyn.

title: China's Rights Stand: Progress or an Irrelevance?
description: Why is this man smiling? In a picture splashed all over Chinese newspapers last week, a beaming President Jiang Zemin is shaking hands with the chief United Nations advocate for human rights, celebrating an agreement by which outside experts are supposed to help China accede to treaties on personal freedom.

title: Mr. Levitt's Leadership
description: Arthur Levitt will probably leave his post as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission next year no matter who wins the election. He is already the longest-serving chairman of the commission in its 66-year history. He is also one of its best. Upon taking office in 1993, he said his mission would be to protect small investors, even if that meant taking on the powerful accounting firms, investment banks and stock exchanges. The mission has been accomplished.
