title: One County Is Puzzling Over a Mystery Involving 218 Votes
description: It appears that one of two strange things happened here in Nassau County. Maybe 218 votes were skipped in one count, though no one involved can offer any evidence for that. Or maybe 218 phantom voters were created in another count, but there is no evidence of that, either.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKWELL, MARGARET M.
description: BLACKWELL-Margaret M. Of Old Field, LI, and New York City died peacefully at home on Saturday, November 25, after a long battle with cancer. Daughter of Ward and Dorothy Melville, she was born on April 13, 1919, in Brooklyn, NY. Her husband, James H. Blackwell, died in 1986. She is survived by her stepdaughter, Bunny Williams, of New York City, and stepson James H. Blackwell Jr., of Dover, MA, as well as his children Carter and Sarah. She is also survived by two brothers, Frank Melville of Norfolk, CT, and David B. Melville of Rum Cay, Bahamas, along with a number of nephews and nieces and their children. Mrs. Blackwell graduated from the Madeira School and attended Bryn Mawr College. She was an able horsewoman, serving as MFH of the Smithtown Hunt, and she and her husband were cofounders of the American Driving Society. She continued her parents' support of a number of causes in the Three Villages of Old Field, Setauket, and Stony Brook. Of particular interest to her was the Museums at Stony Brook, now known as The Long Island Museum of American Art, History, and Carriages. She served on the Museum board for a number of years, and has been a member of the board of Melville Charitable Trust since its inception in 1990. Funeral services will be at 11 AM, Tuesday, November 28, at Caroline Church in Setauket, LI. Interment to follow in the Caroline Churchyard Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a contribution in her memory to St. Charles Hospice, Port Jefferson, NY. For further information, contact O.B. Davis Funeral Homes, Port Jefferson, NY.

title: Patents; Tired of punch cards on Election Day? Unfortunately, there's not much help on the way.
description: DEFICIENCIES in the mechanics of voting systems in this country have never been as apparent as they have become since the vote-counting debacle in this year's presidential election. Politicians and balloting officials were not actively seeking a new system in the many counties that still rely on punch cards on Election Day, and inventors have not been particularly busy coming up with new methods for casting votes, either.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUXBAUM, JOAN
description: BUXBAUM-Joan. Former Hunter College professor. Beloved friend of Beryl, sister of Rhoda, aunt of Deborah and Jonathan, great-aunt of Maya, Isabelle, David and Omar. Services Thursday, Nov. 30 at 11AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Multipronged Strategy For Bush's Absentee Votes
description: In the end, no judge's ruling was necessary. The mere act of filing lawsuits, threatening lawsuits, lobbying officials and mounting a full-scale public relations campaign got the Republicans results: enough local elections officials in Florida reinstated overseas military and absentee ballots that they had previously rejected to add more than 100 votes to Gov. George W. Bush's wafer-thin edge over Vice President Al Gore.

title: Steam Pipe Bursts on East Side, And Tests Find Trace of Asbestos
description: A steam pipe beneath an Upper East Side street burst yesterday afternoon, spraying cars and buildings with debris containing traces of asbestos and prompting the police to close several blocks of Madison Avenue, the authorities said.

description: Lar Lubovitch's new ''Men's Stories'' is not a modern-dance version of ''The Full Monty.'' Mr. Lubovitch is after something more complicated than that in his new full-evening dance and theater piece, which opens tomorrow for a two-week run at the Orensanz Center for the Arts on the Lower East Side.

description: WOHLGEMUTH-Arthur. Of Denver, CO; formerly of NYC. Served U.S. Army World War II; Captain, Company Commander, 367th REPL Co. ETO. Was President of Century Anvil Iron Works until retirement 1982. Survived by wife, children, grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLANT, ARTHUR
description: GALLANT-Arthur. 74, of Harrison, NY, on November 25, 2000. The son of the late Earl and Essie Gallant. Beloved husband of Lois (nee Shapiro). Devoted father of Debra and Joel Binstok, Stephen and Melissa Gallant. Cherished grandfather of Danielle, Michael, Madison, Sarah and Emily. Loving brother of Elaine Roth and brothers-in-law Stanton Roth and Edward Shapiro. Arthur was an inspiration to all his friends and to those who worked with him. Services will be today, November 27, 2 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY. Interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. Donations to the Jewish Guild for the Blind.

title: Manning and Colts' Offense Continue Puzzling Decline
description: It took only a short time today for Indianapolis quarterback Peyton Manning to put his unique stamp on the backs of the Miami Dolphins. Facing a first down on the Dolphins' 27-yard line, Manning took a shot at the end zone. The ball spiraled gently, floating several inches over the outstretched fingertips of safety Brock Marion, and landed in the gut of wide receiver Marvin Harrison, who made a diving catch. Touchdown.

description: HYMAN-Frances. Died peacefully on Thanksgiving Day. Survived by devoted son David B. Levy (Jane), cherished grandchildren James (Rosemary) and Douglas. Forever in our hearts.

description: Striking across Lebanon's southern border into Israeli-held territory, Hezbollah guerrillas set off a roadside bomb near an Israeli patrol today, killing a soldier.

He promptly declared that meant he had won the White House and vowed to ''undertake the responsibility of preparing to serve as America's next president.''

title: Viola da Gamba, Sweetly To Early Music's Rescue

But threats appeared from every side, as witness an article by Hubert Le Blanc in 1740, ''Defense of the Basse de Viole Against the Encroachment of the Violin and the Pretensions of the Violoncello.''

title: Nets' West Coast Swing: Not a Trip to Nowhere
description: Like the holiday guests who never leave, the Nets stayed rooted to the Rose Garden court Saturday night, making their hosts roll their eyes. The Portland Trail Blazers, Western Conference finalists last season, were the better team by far, by their All-Stars, by their Olympians, by their bench, and by their record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROAS, DONALD S.
description: BROAS-Donald S. On November 22, 2000 at age 60. Beloved husband of Betty Jane Langer-Broas. Devoted father of Nancy Gray, Donald Jr., Kimberley and Gregory. Cherished grandfather of Hayley Gray. Former president Excelcare Health System Inc, executive vice president Interfaith Medical Center, chief executive officer Health Care Development International, Inc., president Hospital for Special Surgery, trustee Springfield College and Medic Alert Foundation. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday 6-9 PM, with service Monday 3:30 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: New Economy; Phone Mergers That May Help Competition
description: And now, a cheery holiday message for the nation's underprivileged investment bankers and takeover lawyers: the long-distance communications industry may need more consolidation.

title: Schedule of Bond Offerings for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a new two-year note being auctioned on Wednesday.

title: Devils, at Full Strength, Have Look of Champion
description: Barely more than a week ago, the Devils were in last place. Then they won back-to-back overtime games. Then they came to agreements with the restricted free agents Scott Niedermayer and Jason Arnott. Then the Devils, their roster reloaded and their psyches revived, swept through a three-game California trip to extend their winning streak to five.

title: Statements on the Certification of Florida's Votes
description: Following are excerpts from statements by Secretary of State Katherine Harris and Agriculture Commissioner Robert Crawford, two members of the Florida Election Canvassing Board, on the certification of Florida votes, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEIL, BARBARA
description: BEIL-Barbara. My beautiful and loving wife, my heart is broken and my hands are too short to touch you in heaven on our wedding anniversary. Love, Shell

title: Sprewell and Houston in Backcourt
description: Jeff Van Gundy rubbed his temple and scrunched his face into a contorted and disgusted look. Just the mention of the term ''big backcourt'' seemed enough to nearly make him sick.

title: West Nile Side Effect: A Wealth of Data on Wildlife Death
description: What's killing the mourning doves of New York?

description: Following are excerpts from a New York Times interview yesterday with Vice President Al Gore in Washington:

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Saturday listing the electoral and popular vote totals of some presidential elections since 1864 misidentified the winner for 1880. He was James A. Garfield, not Chester A. Arthur.

title: Working-Class Origins Unite Educators Group
description: When Barbara J. Peters began lecturing on sociology at the University of Wisconsin at Oshkosh eight years ago, she felt like a foreigner.

title: It Is Time for Gore to Concede
description: Four years ago, I conceded the presidential election as soon as the winner was determined. There was a lot less suspense that year than this time around. But when the outcome was clear, so was my duty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIDSON, JOHN L.
description: EIDSON-John L. 80, died on November 24, of cancer. World War II veteran, born in Toledo, OH, he moved to Detroit where he was a carrier accountant with the U.S. government. A respected actor in Detroit community theater, he made NYC his home for the past 30 years including an eight year stay in Los Angeles. While a volunteer worker at the Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center for the past 18 years, he supported AIDS Walk New York, participated from the year one, and recruited many donors as well. He also worked with the organization God's Love We Deliver for three years. He is survived by four children, two grandchildren, a sister, Mrs. Thelma Warner of Toledo, his nieces and his lifetime partner, Dai Miyazaki of NY. He is missed by his entire family. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, December 3, 3 PM, at the New York Buddhist Temple, 332 Riverside Dr., off West 105th St., 212-678-0305. Donations in his name can be made to AIDS Walk-GMHC, 119 West 24th St., NYC 10011 or Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital, 1275 York Ave., NYC 10021.

title: James Bakers Comments on Florida Certification
description: Following is the statement yesterday by James A. Baker III concerning the Florida vote certification, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Essay; Enough Nearly Enough
description: Revising Mr. Dooley's adage: The election returns follow the Supreme Court.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Sure-Handed Jets Slog Through the Mire to Beat the Bears
description: Rivulets of water streamed down Al Groh's slicker early in today's game and Vinny Testaverde had to towel off so assiduously between plays that he looked as if he had stepped out of a shower. But in their water-logged 17-10 victory over the Bears, the Jets were like children splashing in a puddle, having a last carefree moment before the treachery of the next month begins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANCOCK, MACK HILLIARD
description: HANCOCK-Mack Hilliard. On November 22, 2000. Beloved husband of Eline N. Brother of J.P. Hancock, S.C. David Riggs and Elizabeth Winter. Also survived by 11 nieces and nephews and several brothers and sisters-in-law. Memorial service 3 PM, Monday, at Grace Memorial Episcopal Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CEPPOS, JEFFREY
description: CEPPOS-Jeffrey. On November 25, 2000, at age 58 after a courageous battle with cancer. Loving husband of Sandy. Devoted father of Samantha. A highly respected licensing executive in fashion, cosmetics and sports marketing. He was most recently Vice President of International Management Group, president of Jeffrey Ceppos, Inc., also former Vice President of Estee Lauder's Aramis Division. For funeral information please call Gallagher's Funeral Home, 203-327-1313. Contributions in his memory may be made to Visiting Nurse and Hospice Care of Southwestern CT, 1029 East Main St., Stamford, CT 06902 or the Center for Hope, 590 Post Rd., Darien, CT 06820.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWID, HEINZ
description: DAWID-Heinz. Died November 25, 2000. He was a founding member of a well known noted intellectual property law firm, Weiss, Dawid, Fross, Zelnick and Lehrman, now known as Fross, Zelnick, Lehrman and Zissu. He was a world traveler. Survivors include his wife Jeanette of Oneonta, NY, his children, Anne Dawid of Portland, OR, Marcia Dawid Boshnack and her husband, Mark, of Franklin, NY, and Irvin Dawid of Palo Alto, CA, his grandchildren, Samantha, Benjamin, Isaiah and the late Michael, and several relatives in Europe. Private service will be held today and a memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEFTER, ALFRED
description: HEFTER-Alfred. Husband of Lillian, father of Robert J., Leonard R. and the late Sandford M. Beloved grandfather and greatgrandfather. Loved by all who knew him. Peacefully, Saturday, November 25, 2000, in Palm City, FL. Graveside services will be held at United Synagogue Cemetery at Route 25, Calverton, NY, on Tuesday, November 28, at 11 AM. Shiva will be observed Tuesday and Wednesday at the home of Robert J. Hefter. In lieu of flowers, donations to Temple Israel of Riverhead or the Alzheimer Foundation would be appreciated. For information contact Reginald H. Tuthill Funeral Home, Riverhead.

title: Metro Matters; A Tale Of Taillights In 2 Cities
description: YOU arrive for a week with relatives carrying a dozen bagels and planning to take home a bag of Meyer lemons (sweet as oranges). As the days pass, you delight in the sunshine, puzzle over the prevalence of bottled water, learn to distinguish between smog and fog, and worry like everyone else about traffic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHRAF, SHAHID NAJIB
description: ASHRAF-Shahid Najib. Died suddenly on Friday, November 24. He was the beloved husband of Leandra Barbieri and devoted father of Sayada Ashraf. Interment will be at 1 PM at the Washington Memorial Park, Mt. Sinai in Suffolk County on Tuesday, November 28. He is survived by his wife and daughter, a brother, Asaf Ashraf of Rhode Island, two sisters: Ashraf Jahan Varma of Bombay and Musharaff Anu Islam of Karachi. Born in Patna, India, he was the son of Najib Ashraf Nadvi and Sayyada Haq, and grandson of Moin-ul Haq. He was a long term resident of New York City and a science teacher at the Alexander Hamilton High School in Elmsford, NY. A memorial service will be announced at a future date.

description: To the Editor:

title: Austrian Airlines Raises Its Stake in Lauda
description: Austrian Airlines said today that it would buy an additional 11.1 percent stake in Lauda Air from Deutsche Lufthansa for an undisclosed price, to begin reorganizing the airline in a possible effort to take it over.

title: Eight Austrian Banks Face Charges They Fixed Fees
description: The European Commission has accused eight of Austria's largest banks of fixing foreign-exchange fees, widening an inquiry that could lead to millions of dollars of fines.

title: Florida Certifies Vote With Bush Victory
description: Yesterday was Day 20 of the 2000 election. Here is a summary of the day's events.

title: Advice From 2000, to Pass On to the Children; The Triumph of Money
description: To the Editor:

title: London Journal; 'Red Ken' Jolts Britain Again: He's a Proper Gent
description: When ''Red Ken'' Livingstone ran the city council in London in the 1980's, he practiced a brand of in-your-face politics that rattled established power so much that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher threw him out of his job and abolished the entire legislature.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A New Mexican Government
description: After waiting restlessly on the sidelines since his triumph at the polls last July, Vicente Fox Quesada will be sworn in Friday as the first president of Mexico in seven decades not to hail from the Institutional Revolutionary Party. The former governor of Guanajuato and Coca-Cola executive with a populist touch has wisely used the transition period to assemble a diverse and pluralistic cabinet. It promises to serve him well as he confronts the single greatest challenge of his presidency -- living up to Mexicans' exalted expectations of what his government can accomplish.

title: Henry Walter, 90, Head of Flavor Company
description: Henry G. Walter Jr., the former chairman and chief executive of International Flavors and Fragrances, died on Nov. 11 at New York Hospital.

title: A Paper Rises Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscellany
description: * McCann-Erickson Detroit, Troy, Mich., part of the McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising unit of the McCann-Erickson World Group, formed an alliance with Jay Advertising, Rochester, to collaborate on work for a shared client, the Buick division of General Motors. McCann-Erickson and Jay are both owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Low Changes Forward Lines and the Rangers Respond
description: Rangers Coach Ron Low gave his offense a much-needed makeover at Madison Square Garden last night, and the Rangers responded with their first victory over the Ottawa Senators in nearly two years.

title: Justices Ready to Walk A Very Fine Legal Line
description: By seizing a central role for itself in sorting out the legitimacy of Florida's presidential vote count, the Supreme Court put on the line its own legitimacy as an institution able to rise above partisan rancor and to serve as a fair and neutral arbiter, the honest broker that many people have found absent from the scene so far.

title: Gore Insists That He Must Persevere, but He Says an End Is in Sight
description: About four hours before Gov. George W. Bush of Texas was certified as the winner in Florida, Vice President Al Gore sat in his living room today and insisted that he had to fight on for the presidency but seemed to want to assure Americans, and perhaps his supporters in particular, that his effort would not be endless.

title: Preaching Gospel of Rebirth in Jamaica; Southeast Queens Residents Hope Good Economic News Spreads
description: Marc Tally has lived only a few miles from downtown Jamaica, Queens, for about 40 years. He is an entrepreneur, but Jamaica was, until recently, the last place he wanted to open a shop.

title: Long Before New Year's, a Party to End All Parties
description: The balletic baubles have been unpacked and are bright and shiny again. The New York City Ballet opened its holiday season of ''The Nutcracker'' on Friday night at the New York State Theater. All the familiar theatrical goodies were back: the enchanted tree, the toys, the mice, the snowflakes and best of all George Balanchine's choreography and Tchaikovsky's score, which was conducted by Hugo Fiorato.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend. JOE DRAPE

title: Among State Lawmakers, Bickering Along Party Lines
description: With Republicans inching closer to calling a special session of the Legislature this week to name Florida's 25 electors, legislative leaders of both parties abandoned even the slightest pretense of bipartisanship today.

title: When the Trout Arrive, the Amphibian Exodus Begins
description: The crystal mountain lakes of the Sierra Nevada, set among verdant meadows and snowy granite peaks, have become known throughout the world as a paradise for trout fishing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOR, EVA LUBETKIN
description: KANTOR-Eva Lubetkin. After 102 extraordinary years. Mother of Martin E. (Lucille), Ruth K. Shir (Sumner), and Dr. Howard L. Kantor. Beloved grandmother, great grandmother, aunt, friend. Service 10 AM Tuesday, November 28, Riverside-Nassau North Chapel. Instead of flowers, donations may be made to the Eva L. Kantor Fund at CHAI Jewish Family and Childrens Service, 31 New Chardon St, Boston, Ma. 02114

title: A Wide Open Mobile Phone Market
description: As the Russian economy posts its strongest growth since the collapse of the Soviet Union, demand for cell phones is increasing, with the number of users set to double this year to almost three million. If the economy continues to expand as quickly as it has, almost six million Russians could be using mobile phones by 2001, analysts say.

title: Negotiators Focus on 'Dirty Dozen' Pollutants
description: Industrialization and modern insect control have improved the quality of life around the globe, but they have also added some 100,000 chemical compounds that, some scientists worry, could affect the health of people and wildlife. These persistent organic pollutants, known as POP's, have gone virtually unregulated since they were developed more than 50 years ago.

title: Citizen Fujimori, Starting Over Again
description: After a decade in which he governed Peru as an authoritarian ruler, Alberto K. Fujimori now seems weary but defiant as he adjusts to a new life as a private citizen here.

title: Faster Health Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: Companies Seek Looser Rules on Labeling Genetically Altered Seed
description: In wake of the latest incident of genetic crop contamination, American seed companies are renewing a push to establish standards that would allow a small amount of genetically engineered material in bags of seeds and still have those seeds considered free of modification.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUKER, ESSIE (NEE MOLDAW)
description: DRUKER-Essie (nee Moldaw), late of Brookline, MA, entered into rest, November 25. Wife of the late Joshua Druker. Mother of Isaac Druker of Brooklyn. Sister of Tiela Kurgan of LA, CA & the late Joseph & Benjamin Moldaw. Grandmother of Ari and Jeremy. Services at Sharon (MA) Memorial Park, Tuesday, November 28 at 10:45 AM. Donations to Hebrew Immigration Aid Society, 333 7th Ave, New York, NY 10001-5004

title: ANGLOGOLD IN TALKS TO SELL SOME SOUTH AFRICAN MINES
description: AngloGold Ltd., the world's largest gold mining company, said yesterday that it was in talks to sell mines that provide at least 7 percent of its output to a number of buyers as it seeks to shed high-cost South African operations. Harmony Gold Mining said it wanted to buy the mines and other assets in the Free State province of South Africa. Durban Roodepoort Deep Ltd. expressed interest in the same two mines and an operation in Savuka. AngloGold's biggest rival, Gold Fields, said it was not involved in talks. With gold at about $268 an ounce, the Elandsrand and Deelkraal mines are unprofitable, but are still said by analysts to be worth $65 million to $116 million.

title: Realities of Breaking a Marijuana Habit
description: Within 24 hours of quitting, the subjects reported symptoms: irritability, anxiety, and physical tension, to say nothing of other changes in mood and appetite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELSHER, ROUAL
description: FELSHER-Roual. The Officers and Board of Directors of Associated Health Foundation express sincere regret on the passing of Roual Felsher a Lifetime Director. Edward Birnbaum, President

title: Strikes Disrupt The Paris Opera At Two Sites
description: Strikes at the Paris National Opera are hardly rare, with four of seven scheduled performances of Prokofiev's ''War and Peace'' canceled earlier this season. But the labor dispute that erupted here today is potentially the most serious in recent memory, with technicians at both the Palais Garnier and the Bastille Opera threatening to disrupt 41 opera and ballet performances through Jan. 21.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Leading Auto Insurer to Cut Rates For Drivers of the Biggest Vehicles
description: State Farm, the nation's biggest auto insurer, plans today to announce a shift in its pricing policies that will cut rates for drivers of the biggest cars, trucks and sport utility vehicles, based on claims data showing them to be the safest for their occupants.

title: Yanks Optimistic on Signing Mussina
description: The Yankees continued their intense and encouraging discussions with Mike Mussina's agent yesterday, and were optimistic that they could soon sign the free-agent pitcher to a six-year contract for $87 million.

title: A Plea for Patience
description: With his legal options narrowing and Gov. George W. Bush moving aggressively to claim the presidency, Vice President Al Gore last night essentially asked the American people to give him time to challenge the official vote count in Florida. As a matter of law and fairness, he deserves that right. Whether or not Mr. Gore is able to reverse the official result in Florida, the nation will be best served if all the votes that were cast in that state are counted and the winner enters the White House with as definitive a victory as is possible in these difficult circumstances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUXBAUM, JOAN
description: BUXBAUM-Joan. Former Hunter College professor. Beloved friend of Beryl, sister of Rhoda, aunt of Deborah and Jonathan, great-aunt of Maya, Isabelle, David and Omar. Services Thursday, Nov. 30 at 11AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I worked for Jerry Ford when we took over the White House as Richard Nixon resigned in 1974. That was a strange transition. There's never been anything like this, at least not in recent memory.''

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALKIN, ROGER
description: MALKIN-Roger. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art note with sorrow the passing of Roger Malkin, who, along with his companion, Barbara Jakobson, generously supported so many of the Museum's programs, from The Department of Architecture and Design and the Museum's Library and Archives to the Department of Painting and Sculpture, and our expansion and renovation project. We extend our sympathies to his family and to Barbara. His warmth and intelligence will be missed. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Excerpts From Friend-of-Court Filing by Florida Legislature
description: Following are excerpts from the filing of the Florida House and Senate as friends of the court, or amici curiae, supporting neither party in the case of George W. Bush v. Palm Beach County canvassing board before the United States Supreme Court:

title: Talk About Fuzzy Math; Numbers Abound in Florida
description: There is one number Republicans really like to talk about these days: 537, which elections officials here say is the number of votes by which Gov. George W. Bush won Florida.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Out-of-Control Elephants

title: Excoriating the Enablers, in 12 Chapters
description: SO this is how a bastion of conservative brainstorming -- the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, across the street from Grand Central Terminal and next to the Yale Club -- looks and sounds on the inside. Books doing double duty as wallpaper. Chunky furniture in that serious shade of leather, legal maroon. Murmurs from behind closed doors, even some modulated chuckling. Folks, aren't you supposed to be busy turning intellect into influence, the way your motto states? Perhaps the process is funnier than we assumed.

title: Cordiant and BSMG Make Acquisitions
description: Two agencies are making acquisitions.

title: Music Over the Net Risks Radio Fees
description: Infinity Broadcasting, Clear Channel Communications and other radio companies may face new fees for playing music over the Internet, pending a decision as early as this week by the United States Copyright Office.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: A Winner Is Proclaimed. Now, Back to Court.; Counting for History
description: To the Editor:

title: New Leader and Layoffs at ReplayTV
description: ReplayTV Inc., a pioneering maker of digital video recorders, said today that its leader of one year had resigned, that it would lay off up to half of its work force of 260 and that it would reshape its business strategy.

title: Microsoft Asks Appeals Court To Void Ruling
description: Firing the opening salvo in its appeal of a landmark antitrust case, the Microsoft Corporation said today that the trial judge who ordered its breakup had committed a host of procedural and substantive errors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, DR. JOSEPH
description: HIRSCH-Dr. Joseph. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the loss of one of the founding members of our faculty and our first assistant dean for student affairs (1955-1967). We are grateful for the notable contributions he made to the growth and development of our institution in its formative years. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Eva, and the family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Four Named as Finalists To Head Hunter College
description: A search committee for the next president of Hunter College has narrowed its field of finalists to three longtime college administrators and the chairwoman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, Jennifer J. Raab, according to people close to the committee.

title: Front Row
description: So Much for Being Cold

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Business Day yesterday in a grouping showing principal executives in the electronic book business was published in error. The top picture showed Frederick S. Harris, a vice president at Avalon Bay Communities, a real estate investment company in New York, not the literary agent Richard R. Abate.

title: For Promotional Teasers, Fox Needs a 5-Minute Warning
description: A stupid TV trick that must have enraged Giants fans: when Fox's broadcast of the Jets' 17-10 victory over the Bears concluded Sunday, the announcer Sam Rosen told viewers, ''Coming up, we're going to send you to Washington for the conclusion of Philadelphia at Washington.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, DAVID
description: ROSENTHAL - David. Beloved husband of Doris. Devoted father of Karen and Herbert Worchel and Ronnie. Cherished grandfather, uncle, cousin and friend. Service 9:45 Wednesday at ''The Riverside'' 76 & Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Winner Is Proclaimed. Now, Back to Court.; Dole's New Tune
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Medical Use of Marijuana Is Argued
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether ''medical necessity'' can justify distributing marijuana, in violation of federal law, to people who use it to relieve pain or medical symptoms that cannot be effectively treated by conventional means.

title: GAZPROM'S PIPES ARE FULL
description: The Russian gas company Gazprom does not have extra capacity in its export pipelines and thus cannot comply with an order to give rivals access to the lines, a Gazprom executive told Russian news agencies, adding that Gazprom could handle some domestic shipments. Sabrina Tavernise

title: It Will Be Difficult to Match Welch's Record
description: The years that John F. Welch Jr. ran General Electric were phenomenal in many ways: earnings soared and the stock price went up even more. The company went from being highly regarded to being viewed as perhaps the best-managed company in the world. Investors have good reason to be grateful to Mr. Welch.

title: Leader of Tamil Tiger Rebels Says He Is Ready for Peace Talks
description: Velupillai Prabhakaran, leader of the separatist Tamil Tiger rebels in Sri Lanka and one of the world's most ruthless guerrilla strategists, said today that his group was ready for unconditional peace talks with the Sri Lankan government to end the 17-year-old ethnic conflict.

title: Nursing's Value to Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Exorcists and Exorcisms Proliferate Across U.S.
description: There are demons here, some people say, the kind that torment and manifest themselves with spit-spewing and violent convulsions through the people they possess, evil spirits that can trap people inside themselves and utter foreign languages.

title: Company's Latest Move Has Ring of Familiarity
description: The decision today by the Microsoft Corporation to seek the removal of Federal District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson from any future proceedings in its antitrust case on the ground that he was prejudiced against the company had a ring of familiarity.

title: With the Cameras Rolling, Gore Tries to Send a Message
description: ''Hey, guys, how are you?''

title: Students and Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose on speculation that the European Central Bank would step back into the market to buy euros to support the currency. In New York, the euro settled at 85.14 cents, up from 83.97 cents on Friday.

title: What Else Is New? Weird Sonorities, Prickly Harmonies and a Sorceress in Trouble
description: Joel Sachs takes pride in keeping the students in the New Juilliard Ensemble up to date, and he could hardly have done that better than he did last Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall. The program in which he led his young charges included four works, and although at least two of them were started long ago, in the 1900's, all were completed this year.

title: Teachers Win Raises and Health Benefits as 5-Day Strike Ends in South Jersey
description: Classes for 450 public-school students are to resume today in Magnolia, N.J., after a 19-hour negotiating session produced a tentative agreement yesterday to end a five-day strike by teachers and custodians.

title: American in Moscow Spy Trial Claims Victory on Key Evidence
description: A lawyer for an American businessman charged with espionage said today that the judge hearing the case had admitted a crucial piece of evidence that could help to exonerate him.

title: Falling Short on Global Warming
description: The 170 countries that gathered in The Hague to address the threat of global warming have fallen short of their main objective, which was to translate the 1997 Kyoto Accord into a detailed, enforceable treaty. The British are blaming the French, the French are blaming the Germans, and nearly everyone is blaming the United States. But the inconclusive result and the post-conference recriminations should not obscure the fact that significant progress was made on important issues. Nor should it diminish the resolve of these nations to move forward when they reconvene next May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENKIND, EVELYN
description: HENKIND-Evelyn. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Evelyn Henkind, a cherished friend of the Jewish community. Mrs. Henkind and her beloved husband, Sol, shared a deep commitment to ensuring the health and welfare of Jews around the world. Together, they endowed the Henkind Eye Institute at Montefiore Medical Center, a beneficiary agency. Through their exceptional support of our Westchester campaign and other prominent philanthropic causes, they have left an indelible mark on our community. We extend our sincerest condolences to Mrs. Henkind's husband, Sol; her son, Lewis; her daughter and son-inlaw, Ellie and Michael Katz; her grandchildren; & the entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO Barry Effron, Chair, Westchester Campaign

title: A Year-End Tournament Is a New Beginning for Sampras and Agassi
description: The year-end men's championship is in transition again. New name: Tennis Masters Cup. New site: the Pavilhao Atlantico. New ownership: the ATP Tour, the International Tennis Federation and the Grand Slam tournaments are now all joint shareholders.

title: Officer Fired For Criticisms, Judge Finds
description: A federal judge in Manhattan found yesterday that the New York Police Department had violated the First Amendment rights of an officer who was fired after she sharply criticized the tactics of the department's Street Crime Unit.

title: Home Resales Declined 3.9% In October
description: Home resales declined in October to a pace that still keeps the industry on track for its second-best year on record, industry figures showed today.

title: Nuclear Testing Without a Bang
description: Since 1992, when the United States declared a moratorium on all nuclear tests, the thousands of warheads in its aging arsenal have been evaluated using computer simulations, experiments on bomb components and other methods to assess the condition of the weapons without actually exploding them.

title: Need for Nutritional Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Investor Sues DaimlerChrysler, Objecting to '98 Merger Deal
description: Kirk Kerkorian, the corporate raider who tried to buy Chrysler five years ago, sued DaimlerChrysler A.G. and three of its top officials today, accusing them of having gained control of the American automaker under false pretenses in 1998. He asked a federal court to order Daimler to pay him $8 billion in damages, and possibly to dissolve the merger.

title: Bigger Needles for Better Vaccinations
description: To a patient, few things look bigger than that needle a doctor is about to plunge who-knows-where to administer a vaccine.

title: Amaker Has a Luxury Problem: Dominant Griffin
description: The performance has become so commonplace that Seton Hall Coach Tommy Amaker fears his team will begin to rely on it. Eddie Griffin continued his startling introduction to college basketball tonight, posting a double-double and almost single-handedly outrebounding St. Peter's.

title: REFINING HALTED IN LITHUANIA
description: The only oil refinery in the Baltic states halted operations after Lukoil Holding, Russia's largest oil producer, failed to deliver 70,000 tons of crude oil it had promised. The refining company, Mazeikiu Nafta, supplies the vast majority of Lithuania's gasoline and much of that used in Estonia and Latvia.

title: Dillard's Has Operating Loss on Slow Sales
description: With clothing sales in its department stores falling and costs rising, Dillard's Inc. posted an operating loss of $9 million, or 10 cents a share, in its latest fiscal quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMCHE, MARGARITA
description: CAMCHE-Margarita. November 26, at age 66 after bravely battling cancer and a life of giving and loving. Beloved wife of Joel, mother of Leonor and Peter, grandmother of Danielle, sister of Jaime, Angel and Carmelo. Services Thursday 11:45 AM, visitation Wednesday 6-9 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Contention Continues
description: Here are the highlights of the day's events one day after George W. Bush's certification as the victor in Florida.

title: Justices Reconsider Race and Redistricting
description: For the fourth time since 1993, the Supreme Court met today to consider whether a long, skinny Congressional district in the North Carolina Piedmont is the product of an unconstitutional racial gerrymander. The justices' answer this time is likely to determine the role that race can play in the round of redistricting that is due to follow this year's census.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEASS, REUBEN, M.D.
description: LEASS-Reuben, M.D. Died peacefully at home on November 26, 2000 at age 91 after an illness. A graduate of New York University (1930), he received his M.D. (1934) from the University of Maryland, School of Medicine. He volunteered for active duty during WW II and served as a captain in the U.S. Army Medical Corps (194246). He completed his fellowship with Dr. Howard Rusk at the New York University Rusk Institute (1956). Attending Orthopedic Surgeon, St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway and Queens General Hospital. Attending and Assistant Chairman of the Dept of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at Nassau County Medical Center (1962-1977), and Emeritus. An avid swimmer, a Life Master bridge player, an expert medical legal consultant. Survived by his first wife Mae Kripke, loving children Donald (and his wife Barbara), James, Elaine (and Jon) and seven grandchildren; and by his devoted wife Shirley and step-children Jeffrey, Robin and Andrew, and one step-grandchild; brothers Ben and Sidney and sister Jean. Chapel services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, Tuesday, November 28, 2000, at 12:30 PM.

title: Yugoslav Faults West Over Attacks on Serbs
description: Warning that violence spilling over from Kosovo ''could easily set the entire region ablaze,'' President Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia said today that the United Nations and Western powers ''have failed to do their part of the job'' and stop armed Albanian attacks on the Serbian police and citizens.

title: A Winner Is Proclaimed. Now, Back to Court.; Mr. Bush, It's Not Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKE, HELEN KIRSCHNER (NEE STRAUSS)
description: BERKE-Helen Kirschner (nee Strauss). On November 8, 2000 in Belmont, MA. Born on September 11, 1914 in Brooklyn, New York. Beloved mother of Suzanne Kirschner Evenchik, grandmother of Alexander Laurence, and motherin-law of Leonard. Wife of the late Rudolph Berke, M.D. She was a warm and compassionate human being and a gifted opera singer, pianist, poet, counselor and teacher. Her life will continue to inspire us. A memorial service will be held in the spring at the New York Society for Ethical Culture. For information, please call (617) 864-4223

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, MARY ELIZABETH
description: MOSES-Mary Elizabeth. Died peacefully at home on November 19, 2000 after a long illness. 1938 Smith College graduate and member of the Knox School Board of Trustees for 25 years. Funeral November 29, 11AM, at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RAINE, SYDONIA
description: RAINE-Sydonia. December 31, 1922-November 28, 1999. In loving memory of our dear wife, mother and grandmother. You are in our hearts today and always. Murray, Caren, Bonnie, Joshua and Coli

title: State Schools Chief Nullifies Superintendent's '99 Ouster
description: The New York State education commissioner has overturned the dismissal of one of the five superintendents removed for poor performance by Rudy Crew, the former schools chancellor, in a shake-up that proved to be one of the signature acts of his four-year administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALITZ, CAL
description: PALITZ-Cal. The Wetanson family extends their deepest sympathy to Anka, Michael and the entire family. After 35 years we will miss you, Cal, our true friend, mentor and teacher. You were always there for me. Herbert Wetanson

title: An Iron Hand in Peru: Blame on All Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: Rational Software Grows
description: The Rational Software Corporation, which makes software used to create customized computer programs, said today that it would acquire the 65 percent of Catapulse Inc. it did not already own for about $405 million in stock. Catapulse, which is closely held, was begun a year ago by Rational's two founders -- Paul Levy, Rational's chairman, and Michael Devlin, its chief executive -- to lease software development tools over the Internet and to let software developers share information about projects on the Web. Rational originally invested $50 million in Catapulse in December.

title: Bassett to Cut 280 Jobs
description: Bassett Furniture Industries said today that it will eliminate 280 jobs, or 6.7 percent of its work force, to cut costs as it reorganizes. The company warned it will fall short of profit estimates in its fourth quarter and for the 2000 fiscal year. Most of the job cuts will come at its plants in Bassett, Va.

title: CARREFOUR GETS SEVERAL BIDS FOR FROZEN-FOODS UNIT
description: Carrefour S. A., Europe's largest retailer, received at least three takeover bids from private equity firms for its Picard Surgeles frozen-food unit and wants at least 1 billion euros, or $850 million, for the business, Bloomberg News reported, citing unidentified sources. The bidders named in the report were BC Partners, Apax Partners and Paribas Affaires Industrielles. Final bids for the unit, which Carrefour is selling because it no longer considers it a core business, are expected by Dec. 25. Carrefour owns 79 percent of Picard Surgeles, which has 483 stores and posted sales of 459 million euros, or $392 million, last year; family owners hold the other 21 percent.

title: DUTCH SALARIES TO BE REVEALED
description: Publicly traded companies in the Netherlands will have to begin disclosing the salaries and option awards of individual executives in annual reports under an amendment proposed by the nation's finance minister, Gerrit Zalm. The government is expected to act on the proposal, which also includes other changes to disclosure requirements, in the first quarter of 2001.

title: Athletes, Andro and Trouble in the Urine
description: Athletes who take the sports supplement androstenedione, commonly known as andro, might want to pay attention to one new finding: the substance can make them fail urine tests for the banned anabolic steroid nandrolone.

title: Light Regimen for Pregnancy Depression
description: For some pregnant women, depression does not always wait to be postpartum. Depression can come at any point in a woman's pregnancy, and if it does, she and her doctor can be in a quandary over whether to try antidepressants.

title: A Waterfront With Potential, Still Unrealized
description: For more than 15 years, the Queens West development at Hunters Point in Queens was oft-heralded as the beginning of an East River gold coast, a swirl of apartment houses, office buildings and hotels on a dilapidated industrial waterfront with a spectacular view of Manhattan.

title: A Winner Is Proclaimed. Now, Back to Court.; No Legitimacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, PAULINE B.
description: FALK-Pauline B. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Pauline B. Falk, a loyal friend and dedicated supporter of UJA-Federation and Jewish philanthropic organizations worldwide. Her legacy of community leadership and generosity have left an indelible mark. To her daughters, Patricia and Nancy; her son, Michael; and to the entire family, we extend our sincerest condolences. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: In Speech, Gore Declares That 'Ignoring Votes Means Ignoring Democracy'
description: Following is the statement last night by Vice President Al Gore on the Florida election, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Haiti's Disappearing Democracy
description: Jean-Bertrand Aristide's election as president of Haiti the first time, 10 years ago, was hailed as a triumph for democracy in a land that had known little but dictatorship. But his almost certain return to power in Sunday's elections was achieved by trampling on democratic procedures. The weeks before the voting were marred by bombings and other politically motivated violence, and all serious opposition candidates boycotted the race, citing doubts about its fairness. With nothing important to be decided on Election Day, hordes of Haitians stayed home. Mr. Aristide remains a popular figure who probably would have won under any conditions. But his indifference to legal norms and tolerance for political violence raise concerns that he might one day lead Haiti back to dictatorship.

title: A Winner Is Proclaimed. Now, Back to Court.; Disdain for Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Shoes to Fill, as Welch Picks Successor at GE
description: NEW YORK  Beginning a year-long transition, General Electric Co. announced Monday that Jeffrey Immelt had won a three-way race to succeed Jack Welch as chairman of the world's most valuable company.

title: How the Troops Were Mobilized for the Recount
description: In the predawn hours of Nov. 8, about two dozen bleary-eyed Democratic National Committee officials and Gore/Lieberman campaign staff members boarded a chartered plane in Nashville and headed to Florida. Before the plane touched down in Tallahassee, the staffers said, everyone was told to take off their campaign T-shirts, jackets and buttons.

title: Excerpts From Microsoft Brief to the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington
description: Following are excerpts from the Microsoft brief submitted yesterday to the United States Court of Appeals in Washington, seeking to overturn the District Court's antitrust ruling:

title: LAFARGE SELLS PAINT UNIT
description: Lafarge S.A. of France agreed to sell a majority stake in a unit that makes paints and mortar to three buyout firms for about 800 million euros ($672 million). The Advent International Corporation, CVC Capital Partners Ltd. and the Carlyle Group will pay 200 million euros in cash and assume 600 million euros in debt, divided equally among them. Lafarge will keep a one-third stake in the business.

title: Seminoles Set to Play For No. 1
description: The Miami Hurricanes lost ground in the Bowl Championship Series ranking released yesterday and now almost certainly need a Kansas State victory over Oklahoma in Saturday's Big 12 championship game if they want to play for the national title on Jan. 3 in the Orange Bowl.

title: Marilyn Manson, Forever Young and Miserable
description: Pity poor Marilyn Manson, who performed at Hammerstein Ballroom on Friday and Saturday nights. He is so clearly stuck, writhing in the hardening amber of his mass-marketed ghastliness, and more than a few misguided opinions are lodging between his interesting ideas and his band's solid rock 'n' roll.

title: NEXTWAVE APPEAL IS DENIED
description: The Supreme Court declined to hear an appeal yesterday from NextWave Telecom in which the company, a bankrupt wireless carrier, was seeking to overturn the forfeiture of nearly 100 licenses for potentially valuable wireless spectrum to the Federal Communications Commission. The move by the nation's highest court is expected to ease the way for an auction of the spectrum licenses to proceed next month, a necessary step in the deployment of next-generation wireless networks. Still, even as large carriers like Verizon Wireless and AT&T Wireless welcomed the court's decision, analysts warned that NextWave might succeed in persuading Congress to postpone the auction while an appeals court examines the F.C.C.'s handling of the matter. ''There is still concern over what will happen with air space that's the equivalent of untouched beachfront property,'' said Todd Harrington, an analyst with Current Analysis, a consulting firm based in Sterling, Va. Simon Romero

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS DROPS. Natural gas fell on expectations that warmer weather would reduce demand for the fuel. In New York, natural gas for December delivery fell 20.9 cents, or 3.2 percent, to $6.368 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Washington Insider and Family Loyalist Poised for Job of Bush Chief of Staff
description: The way Andrew H. Card Jr. tells it, the first time he ever set eyes on George W. Bush in Kennebunkport, Me., in 1979, the younger Bush cut a most unimpressive profile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOWITZ, MURRAY
description: LIEBOWITZ-Murray. Town and Village Synagogue-Tifereth Israel, mourns the loss of its beloved member and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Virginia and son Jacob. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Abby Sosland, Asst Rabbi Carol J. Green, President Cantor Shayna Smith

title: G.M. TO LENGTHEN HOLIDAY SHUTDOWN AT EUROPEAN PLANTS
description: General Motors said it would lengthen the Christmas holiday shutdown at factories at Russelsheim, Germany, and Luton, England, by one to three weeks in an effort to reduce bulging inventories of unsold cars, especially midsize Vectras and larger Omegas. G.M.'s sales in Western Europe slid 7 percent in the year through October, compared with the first 10 months of 1999, and the company has said it expects to post a ''significant'' fourth-quarter loss in Europe.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 18 about similarities and differences between the current Palestinian uprising and the one that began in December 1987 referred incorrectly to the event that set off the earlier one. The vehicle that swerved into a line of cars in the Gaza Strip, killing four Palestinians, was an Israeli truck, not a tank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUHL, BENJAMIN N.
description: DUHL-Benjamin N. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with deep sorrow the passing of a devoted friend of our medical school since its earliest days in the 1950's. With his wife, Laura, he was a Founder of our institution and steadfast in his support for more than four decades. We express our condolences to the entire family. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dr. Dominick P. Purpura The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Big City; IN THE SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
description: INTEREST OF THE VOTERS OF NEW YORK CITY

title: Leticia Journal; Dancing Across an Imaginary Line in the Jungle
description: No place in Colombia is farther from Bogota, and thus further from the thoughts of bureaucrats in the capital, than this sweltering Amazon jungle town. Brazil is just down the street, the border marked only by a miniature obelisk in front of a liquor store, and Peru is a mere five-minute motorboat ride across the Amazon.

title: A Winner Is Proclaimed. Now, Back to Court.; In Their Hearts
description: To the Editor:

title: Risking Safety of Fetus
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOLNICK, DR. LEO P.
description: SKOLNICK-Dr. Leo P. Beloved husband of the late Diane, devoted brother, cousin and friend. Services Wednesday 12 noon at ''Gutterman's Inc'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre.

title: Sing-Along Aerobics at Your Corner Gym
description: In the past, most health clubs with group exercise classes offered a variety ranging from about A to B. There was generally an aerobics class, another aerobics class and maybe a stretch class. But that has changed.

title: DNA Chip May Help Usher In a New Era of Product Testing
description: Of the 80,000 or so chemicals that go into the products of daily life, the vast majority have never been thoroughly tested for harmful effects. The traditional approach to such testing, exposing laboratory animals to the chemical, is slow, expensive and attacked by animal rights groups. And what happens in animals doesn't always correspond with what happens in people.

title: CAZENOVE TO OFFER 10 PERCENT OF EQUITY TO INVESTORS
description: The venerable London investment bank Cazenove & Company, a partnership since its founding in 1823, said it would float itself on the stock market within two years. Ten percent of the company's equity will be sold to institutional investors; the firm's partners will retain 70 percent, and the remaining 20 percent will be distributed to employees with restrictions on resale. Cazenove is the last of London's old guard of investment banks that is still independent; Schroders P.L.C. and Robert Fleming & Company were both acquired by American banks this year.

title: The More Things Change . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Toxicogenomics to the Test
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Winner Is Proclaimed. Now, Back to Court.
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Stands by Stadium Plan, Despite Concerns Voiced in Poll
description: A new poll shows that most New Yorkers do not support a new sports stadium for the West Side, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had a blunt reaction yesterday to the findings: most New Yorkers are wrong.

title: COVAD COMMUNICATIONS TO LAY OFF STAFF AND CUT COSTS
description: The Covad Communications Group said it would lay off one-eighth of its staff and find other economies to reduce its costs by 20 to 30 percent next year. The company, which provides Internet connections over digital subscriber lines, said it would curtail expansion of its network in 2001 to just over 2,000 telephone central offices and would cancel construction of a third operations center in Alpharetta, Ga. The cost-cutting will result in a charge in the fourth quarter; the company did not specify its size.

title: In Two Books, Glints of Musical Greatness in the Making
description: THE LIFE OF MENDELSSOHN

title: From Jungle to Space in Pursuit of New Drugs
description: Dr. Franklin Chang-Diaz, a NASA astronaut with roots in Costa Rica, and Dr. Jose Zaglul, president of a university that specializes in agricultural courses for the humid tropics, were driving onto Dr. Zaglul's campus in Mercedes, Costa Rica, one day in 1991 when they had a short conversation that has turned into a big idea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLANT, ARTHUR
description: GALLANT-Arthur. 74, of Harrison, NY, on November 25, 2000. The son of the late Earl and Essie Gallant. Beloved husband of Lois (nee Shapiro). Devoted father of Debra and Joel Binstok, Stephen and Melissa Gallant. Cherished grandfather of Danielle, Michael, Madison, Sarah and Emily. Loving brother of Elaine Roth and brothers-in-law Stanton Roth and Edward Shapiro. Arthur was an inspiration to all his friends and to those who worked with him. Services were held Monday. Donations to the Jewish Guild for the Blind. For information contact Riverside Memorial Chapel, 914-664-6800.

title: Killer Deemed Retarded Wins Review of His Death Sentence
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to review the case of a Texas death row inmate, Johnny Paul Penry, whom state authorities have classified as mentally retarded.

title: Presidential Bottleneck Jams Road Into Capitol in Austin
description: Even as the presidential campaign of Gov. George W. Bush is now openly preparing for a transition to Washington, the timetable for a similar transition in Texas remains murky, with the possibility that the process will be incomplete when the State Legislature convenes in January.

title: On Pro Football; Something's Very Wrong In Indianapolis
description: Mark Thomas is someone you have probably never heard of. He is a defensive lineman for the Indianapolis Colts. Thomas is not a star in the National Football League, but he is a key contributor. And he obviously has strong opinions, which he expressed after the Colts' embarrassing loss to Miami, which put this franchise, at one time a Super Bowl favorite, in serious jeopardy of not making the playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLMAN, SHEILA ALMER
description: HELLMAN-Sheila Almer. The Board of Directors and staff of Ballet Hispanico of New York wish to express their heartfelt sympathies and condolences to Jill and her family on the death of her mother, Sheila. Jody Gottfried Arnhold, Chairman Tina Ramirez, Artistic Director

title: Lindros Is Cleared to Play
description: Eric Lindros was officially cleared yesterday to play hockey by the Chicago-area neurologist who has been treating him, Lindros's father, Carl, said. According to a member of the Lindros family's inner circle, the Rangers have emerged as the front-runner in expressing interest in the services of Lindros, a restricted free agent.

title: Frustration in Aftermath of a Failed Recount
description: Palm Beach County's hand recount was short of the deadline for certification, short of Democrats' expectations that it might swing the election to Vice President Al Gore and short, in the end, of the highest hopes and deepest fears.

title: British Toy Store Is Offering New Holiday Sale Item: Itself
description: For the entrepreneur who has everything this holiday season, Hamleys P.L.C., whose flagship toy store on Regent Street is London's equivalent of F. A. O. Schwarz on 5th Avenue, is offering something different: the entire company is for sale.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOROWITZ, SARAH (GAYER)
description: HOROWITZ-Sarah (Gayer) November 28, 1967 Miss you, Mommy

title: Text of the Florida Statute
description: Following is an excerpt from Section 102.168 of the Florida statutes, which governs the contesting of an election:

title: Less Pain: Is It in the Magnets or the Mind?
description: Faithful readers know that I've been plagued by arthritic pain in both knees for about a decade and that I've experienced significant symptomatic improvement after daily use of a dietary supplement that combines glucosamine and chondroitin.

title: Hasbro Consolidates With Omnicom Unit
description: Hasbro Inc. said yesterday that it would consolidate brand advertising for its United States toy group by naming DDB New York, part of the DDB Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle that account. Billings for the assignment, which includes brands like G. I. Joe, Play-Doh, Tonka and Mr. Potato Head, were estimated at $80 million to $100 million.

title: READER'S DIGEST TO MARKET INSURANCE ON PETS
description: The Reader's Digest Association said it would market Pethealth Inc.'s accident and health insurance policies for dogs and cats in the United States and Canada. Financial terms of the three-year contract were not released. Pethealth, based in Oakville, Ontario, is seeking a license to begin writing policies in the United States, starting in the first half of next year, that will probably cost consumers $210 to $220 a year. Reader's Digest estimates that about 20 million of the 53 million Americans in its marketing database own dogs or cats.

title: A Reality Show That's Riveting the World
description: Enter an ordinary home anywhere in Europe, and you will probably find an American soap opera playing on the television set. Now, in living rooms from Caithness to Kosovo, Europeans are watching a new American soap opera. After ''Dallas'' and ''Dynasty'' we have . . . ''Democracy.''

title: Hall Rejects Piazza Bat Piece
description: If the baseball Hall of Fame wants to reconsider, it can still have part of Mike Piazza's broken bat for its current Subway Series exhibit. Keith Olbermann, the broadcaster for Fox Sports Net, has about 30 percent of the shattered wood and is willing to lend it.

title: James Deetz, 70, Chronicler Of America's Colonial Past
description: Dr. James Deetz, an American anthropologist who dug into the country's colonial past, died on Saturday at a hospital in Charlottesville, Va. He was 70 and lived in Charlottesville, where he had been the Harrison professor of historical archeology at the University of Virginia since 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURLANDER, JUDITH LEVEY
description: KURLANDER-Judith Levey. The members of the Board of Directors, the staff, volunteers and youth of the All Stars Project express deep sadness at the death of Judith Levey Kurlander, the mother of our dear colleague, friend and organization President, Gabrielle Kurlander. Judith generously shared her love of theater and the arts with her family, friends and community. Our sincere condolences to Gabrielle and her family. Susan Massad, M.D., Chair All Stars Project

title: Accounts
description: * Morgan Tire and Auto, Clearwater, Fla., to Kruskopf Olson, Minneapolis, as creative agency of record to handle tasks like a campaign to promote the rebranding of six tire store chains under the Tires Plus Total Car Care name. Spending was estimated at $30 million. Kruskopf Olson had handled creative duties for one chain, Tires Plus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAROTTA, GIOVANNI F.
description: MAROTTA-Giovanni F. On November 25, 2000. Beloved son of the late Soave and Maria. Devoted brother of Dario and the late Jennie. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at the Basilica of Our Lady of Perpetual Help. Entombment Greenwood Cemetery. Visitation Monday, 2-5 and 79, at the McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, Third Ave. at 97th St., Brooklyn.

title: GO ATTRACTS 25 BIDDERS
description: More than 25 potential bidders have approached British Airways about buying Go, its low-fare carrier, which British Airways hopes to sell by the end of March. ''We have a number in our heads as to how much we would like from the sale of Go,'' Rod Eddington, the company's chairman, told reporters in Tokyo. The figure, he said, was at the lower end of the reported range of $:200 million to $:400 million ($281 million to $562 million).

title: City Cannot Quiet Rally, a Judge Rules
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has ordered the city to grant an AIDS advocacy group a permit to use amplified sound at a City Hall rally on Friday, dealing the Giuliani administration another setback in its attempts to restrict protests there.

title: Nassau Leaders Are Told That Time Is Running Out
description: As Nassau County officials were unable once again to reach agreement today on a four-year fiscal rescue plan, the head of a state board monitoring the county's efforts warned that a state takeover was becoming increasingly likely.

title: Sports of The Times; New York Campaigns Heating Up
description: THE pro football season, stuck and obscured around these parts between a rock (the Subway Series) and a hard place (the political Super Bowl), may now take center stage in time for a December run by a couple of unspectacular candidates who are likely to survive their primary seasons.

title: Knicks' Ward Is Set to Miss 8 Weeks After Surgery
description: The timetable for Charlie Ward's return from arthroscopic knee surgery has been slightly extended.

title: Honors
description: * Advertising Research Foundation, New York, named winners of two awards. Erwin Ephron, a partner at Ephron, Papazian & Ephron, New York, and Stuart Gray, senior vice president and media resource director at the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, received the Richard L. Lysaker Award. And Dr. Alfred Kuehn, chairman and chief executive at Management Science Associates, Pittsburgh, received the Michael J. Naples Award.

title: Justices Stand by No-Camera Policy
description: Adhering to its policy against cameras in its courtroom, the Supreme Court today turned down a request by the cable network C-Span to cover Friday's argument in the Florida presidential election case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARAKAN, ISIDORE
description: TARAKAN-Isidore. Passed away on November 26 in Pompano Beach, FL. Loving husband of Diana. Father of Louise and Susan. Grandfather of Karen. Brother of Nathan. Beloved uncle to nieces and nephews.

title: Testing the Aging Stockpile in a Test Ban Era
description: They called it ''shaking the desert.'' For 40 years, the guardians of the nation's nuclear stockpile exploded bombs beneath the arid ground at a test site in Nevada, both to test new types of bombs and to be certain that old ones still worked as designed. Many of those tests also shook the desert from above, in the atmosphere, before a treaty banned the practice in 1963.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, ANN F.
description: AMES-Ann F. Of New York, NY. Died on November 23, 2000 at the age of 96. Mrs. Ames was the wife of the late Irving M. Ames. She is survived by her daughter Susan Ames. Mrs. Ames was awarded a Jurist Doctor degree from Cleveland-Marshall College of Law at Cleveland State University, a member of the Class of 1928. Funeral services will be private.

title: LABOR PACT AT DAEWOO
description: Workers at the Daewoo Motor Company voted to accept layoffs in a restructuring plan, clearing the way for a South Korean court to put the company into receivership rather than liquidate it. Union opposition to layoffs was cited as a main reason creditors forced the company into bankruptcy Nov. 8. The creditors hope to sell a restructured Daewoo to General Motors and Fiat. Samuel Len

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, BETTY ROSMARIN
description: EHRLICH-Betty Rosmarin. 79, of Ft. Lee, N.J. and Monroe, N.Y., died surrounded by her beloved family after a full, active life, on November 25. Predeceased by her husband Sam Ehrlich, she was the loving mother of Steven David Ehrlich (''my son the architect'') of Los Angeles and Renee Ehrlich Kalfus (''my daughter the costume designer'') of Millwood N.Y.; adoring grandmother of Onna, Rosy, Vanessa and Julia; devoted sister of Jerry Rosmarin (deceased) and Marty Rosmarin. Almost as passionate about skiing as she was about her family, Betty had planned a winter trip to Utah in early December. She was a guten neshummah, the radiant center of love and energy around which her extended family revolved. All who met her were infused by her glowing spirit and compassion. She lived life according to her credo, ''everything's good, right?''

title: The Showtime Network prepares a $10 million campaign blitz for its 'Queer as Folk' series.
description: AN extensive campaign to promote a new series on the pay-cable network Showtime is probably the most elaborate ever aimed by a mainstream marketer at gay audiences and probably the most elaborate ever with gay themes aimed at mainstream audiences.

title: G.E. Taps Successor to the Chief
description: Ending more than a year of handicapping, General Electric selected Jeffrey R. Immelt yesterday to succeed John F. Welch Jr., one of the world's most imitated business leaders, as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Welch retires at the end of next year.

title: Excerpts From Vice President's Legal Challenge to the Results in Florida
description: Following are excerpts from a complaint by the Gore campaign filed yesterday in Leon County Circuit Court contesting the results of the Florida election:

title: What's 'Unethical'?
description: To the Editor:

title: GE Names Successor to a Highly Regarded Leader
description: NEW YORK  General Electric Co. said Monday that Jeffrey Immelt, head of its medical-systems division, would replace Jack Welch as chairman of the conglomerate, ending a closely followed race to succeed one of the most admired captains of industry ever.

title: Mets Mull Their Options If They Lose Hampton
description: The free-agent market is crowded with veteran starting pitchers, and each one seems to be waiting for someone else to sign somewhere first. Mike Hampton might be the one, and the Mets might be willing to keep him.

title: Another Tunnel Offers Breathing Room for E and F Trains
description: A long-planned link connecting the E and F subway lines to the 63rd Street tunnel that runs between Manhattan and Queens will be ready for traffic in January, eventually allowing as many as 15 more trains per hour to cross the East River, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about new directions for some political Web sites misstated the plans of Voter.com. The site intends to remain a portal to political news and information; it is not leaving the portal business.

title: RACIAL PROFILING WAS THE ROUTINE, NEW JERSEY FINDS
description: At least 8 of every 10 automobile searches carried out by state troopers on the New Jersey Turnpike over most of the last decade were conducted on vehicles driven by blacks and Hispanics, state documents have revealed.

title: Those Magic Times When the Patient Makes the Doctor Feel Better
description: Doctors aren't supposed to have favorite patients. But here's a poorly kept secret: we do.

title: Dr. Louis S. Goodman, 94, Chemotherapy Pioneer, Dies
description: Dr. Louis S. Goodman, a renowned pharmacologist, a discoverer of the first effective anticancer chemotherapy and a creator of a textbook used by generations of doctors, died at his home in Salt Lake City on Nov. 19. He was 94 and had taught for many years at the University of Utah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, VIOLA
description: BLOCK-Viola. The congregaton of The Community Synagogue of Port Washington, NY notes with sorrow the passing of its member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Rabbi Jeffrey K. Salkin Jane M. Broido, President

title: Jeb Bush Is Said to Be Willing to Sign Bill Ensuring Republican Victory in Florida
description: The president of Florida's Senate said today that Gov. Jeb Bush had indicated his willingness to sign special legislation intended to award Florida's 25 Electoral College votes to his brother Gov. George W. Bush of Texas even as the election results were being contested.

title: Seidler Ready For Hall Induction
description: Maren Seidler remembers that track meet in Yonkers when she was 11 years old. Patricia Rico, the president of USA Track and Field and a meet official that day, re- members, too.

title: Guggenheim Gets Backing for New Museum
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum has won the right, and the financial backing of the city, to build a curvilinear outpost on the East River, officials at City Hall said late yesterday, calling the museum's $678 million proposal crucial to an effort to revitalize a large swath of Lower Manhattan.

title: Odd Culprits in Collapse of Climate Talks
description: Through a decade of scientific and political debate over global warming, private environmental groups were a driving force for a treaty committing industrial countries to fight the problem. The opponent always was industry, particularly oil and coal companies threatened by anything that might bring about an early end to the carbon age.

title: As Slump Deepens, Gill Shoots Even More
description: Long after the Nets' four other starters had left the court this afternoon, Kendall Gill launched majestic jump shots until perspiration beaded on his thick biceps. Every time a shot would slap off the front of the rim, he would grimace and put even more arc on his next shot.

title: Israeli Army Says Palestinians May Have Shot Gaza Boy
description: The 12-year-old Palestinian boy shot to death eight weeks ago as he crouched beside his father, in a scene that television broadcasts made well known around the world, might have been killed by Palestinian gunmen, not Israeli soldiers, the Israeli Army said today.

title: Foreign Affairs; Jekyll and Hyde
description: In a funny way, we should be thankful for this bizarre post-election campaign. Because it has actually allowed us to see George W. Bush and Al Gore so much more clearly.

title: BIG LEASING BANKRUPTCY
description: The Nippon Shinpan Company, Japan's biggest credit card company, said a subsidiary, Inter-Lease, had filed for liquidation owing 560 billion yen ($5.4 billion) to creditors, making it one of the country's largest bankruptcies of the year. The leasing unit had bad debts on its books of about 277 billion yen ($2.5 billion) as of October.

title: Joseph Hirsh, 85, Authority on Alcoholism
description: Joseph Hirsh, an authority on alcoholism who taught at medical schools, died last Tuesday at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 85.

title: The Man Who Made Jazz Hot; 60 Years After His Death, Jelly Roll Morton Gets Respect
description: When the jazz pioneer Jelly Roll Morton died penniless and alone nearly 60 years ago, his reputation was already fading. New musical styles had displaced the hot jazz he helped invent, and a younger generation of players disdained him.

title: No Time To Savor Victory For Fassel
description: Coach Jim Fassel stepped off the plane from Arizona at 6:15 this morning, and any joy over the Giants' 31-7 victory over the Cardinals on Sunday night had faded with a new dawn.

title: INSIDE
description: G.E. Selects a New Chief

title: A TV Feat by a Reeaally Cool Guy
description: To the delight of hundreds of onlookers and dozens of network executives, the magician David Blaine encapsulated himself in a block of ice yesterday, vowing to stay entombed until tomorrow night, or just in time for his exit on a prime-time television special.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Arrest Clouds Sitcom's Plot

title: Ex-Hedge Fund Manager Enters Guilty Plea in Fraud Case
description: Michael Berger, the 29-year-old hedge fund manager who rose to prominence running the Manhattan Investment Fund, pleaded guilty yesterday in New York to federal charges that he lied to investors about his fund's performance while losing $400 million on Internet-related stocks.

title: A Winner Is Proclaimed. Now, Back to Court.; Gore Must Concede
description: To the Editor:

title: 25 Blacks At Texaco Sue For Arbiters
description: A group of black employees has asked a federal judge to order Texaco to arbitrate their charges of racial discrimination, saying that the oil company is defying the terms of an earlier settlement with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: LG of Korea and Philips Set Screen-Making Venture
description: Royal Philips Electronics of the Netherlands and LG Electronics of South Korea said today that they would form a joint venture that would be the world's largest maker of television and computer screens. The companies also said that they were discussing a merger of mobile phone operations.

title: WATER FOUND FOR COPPER MINE
description: A plan by BHP Ltd. and the Rio Tinto Group to invest $1.05 billion to increase by half the output at the Escondida copper mine, the world's largest, took a step forward with a $137 million agreement to buy water rights from a nearby mine of the Placer Dome Company. The mines are in the Atacama Desert in Chile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEPPEL, RUTH S.
description: KOEPPEL-Ruth S. Age 91, died peacefully on Thanksgiving, November 23, 2000 at home with her daughter Nancy and grandsons David and Steven in Stuart, Florida. Loving wife of the late Harry Koeppel. Adored mother of Nancy S. Koeppel and the late Robert A. Koeppel. Cherished grandmother of David and Steven Koeppel and Elizabeth Lingle and William, Alexandra and Caroline Koeppel. Loving great grandmother of Benjamin and Alexander Lingle and Harrison Koeppel. She will always be remembered for her beautiful smile and her joy of living which she maintained with graciousness and charm. Most of her life she lived in NYC, which was her favorite place to be. She lived her last years with her daughter and grandsons in Florida, where hopefully she made a difference in the recent Presidential elections. She had an avid interest in politics. Funeral services will be Sunday, December 3, 1:30pm,Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Av, NYC.

title: Jamestown Wins On Leeper Runs
