description: New Rochelle held Jamestown's Aaron Leeper to 40 yards and no touchdowns for a half, but Leeper and the Raiders came back in the second half to win, 33-7, and claim the New York State Class AA title at the Carrier Dome in Syracuse on Sunday night. Leeper, who rushed for 2,276 yards this season, had 112 yards and 4 touchdowns in the second half; the four touchdowns gave him a state-record 47 this season.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TOP PRIME-TIME NEWS
description: WNBC-TV, with only three days left in the November sweeps, has again emerged as the top prime-time news station in the New York market, according to data from Nielsen Media Research. The station, Channel 4, is also ranked No. 1 in the early morning newscast, the afternoon newscast and the 11 p.m. news. The station was ranked first in its coverage of the New York City Marathon and the Thanksgiving Day Parade. In all newscast time categories, WABC-TV, Channel 7, was ranked second, followed by WCBS-TV, Channel 2. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Excerpt From Statement by Cheney on Transition
description: Following is an excerpt from a statement yesterday by Dick Cheney about the transition process, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: MetroStars Will Have New Home
description: The MetroStars will announce plans for their new stadium and the Major League Soccer expansion team they have the rights to on Monday at a news conference in Manhattan. General Manager Nick Sakiewicz declined to disclose many details yesterday except to say that the stadium would be built in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLAUT, ILSE (NEE DREIFUSS)
description: PLAUT-Ilse (nee Dreifuss). Age 88. Of New York City. At last reunited with her beloved Ernst on November 27, 2000. Dear mother, mother-in-law to Harriett and Leon Heller, Vivian and Alan Lawsky, and Michael and Stephanie Plaut. Devoted sister to Erna Rothschild and Greta Strauss. Loving Oma to Daryl Heller, Gabrielle Recht, Benjamin Lawsky, Sarah Meda, Elliot, Caleigh and Henry Plaut, and Great Oma to Hana Meda and Maxine Recht. Her warmth and kindness will be greatly missed. Service 1PM Tuesday, November 28th at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to Hebrew Home for the Aged, 5901 Palisade Ave, Riverdale, New York 10471.

title: A Winner Is Proclaimed. Now, Back to Court.; Republican Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Tunnel Vision; Man Touched By Saint, Pope And an Ex-Giant
description: New York City Transit can seem like a quasi-religious organization at times. Its officials talk in almost reverential tones about how they have kept the trains rolling every day for the last 96 years. They even have a quasi-religious phrase for this: the Miracle of Daily Service.

title: Chretien and Liberals in Canada Win 3d Straight Majority
description: Jean Chretien won a bold gamble tonight for a third term, becoming the first Canadian Prime Minister to win a third consecutive majority government since World War II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MARTIN E.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Martin E. Of New Rochelle, N.Y. died Sunday, November 26, 2000 at the age of 66. He was a partner in the intellectual property field in the law firm Darby & Darby, in New York City. He is survived by his wife Judy, daughter Sue, son Jay and four grandchildren.

title: Making a Hearty Racket Amid Trancelike Rhythms
description: ''Limp Bizkit!'' some joker shouted on Wednesday night at the Knitting Factory, evoking that rap-rock band as the new obnoxious rock concert shout-out, replacing Lynyrd Skynyrd and Freebird. Onstage the members of the Delgados looked confused.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, ENDA M. (NEE O'BRIEN)
description: RYAN-Enda M. (nee O'Brien). Of Yardley, PA. Passed peacefully into eternity while at home on Sunday, November 26, 2000. Devoted wife of John Dennis. Loved and loving mother of Dennis (Michele), Oona (Ian) Hodges, John (Stephanie), Michael (Diane), Joseph (Mary), and Christopher (Janice). Inspiring grandmother of Shannon, Michael, Leigh, John, Thomas and Kara. Sister of Deirdre Keating and the late Frances Flannery. 1947 graduate of College of Mount Saint Vincent and Fordham University in 1949. Family and friends may call Wednesday from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM at the Fitzgerald-Sommer Funeral Home, 17 South Delaware Ave., Yardley, PA. Funeral mass will be celebrated at 11:30 AM, Thursday at St. Ignatius Church, Reading Ave., Yardley, PA. Memorial contributions in Mrs. Ryan's name may be made to Covenant House, P.O. Box 731, Times Sq. Sta., NY, NY 10108.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWID, HEINZ
description: DAWID-Heinz. Fross Zelnick Lehrman & Zissu, PC, records with great sorrow the loss of one of our founding partners, Heinz Dawid, on November 25, 2000. Born and educated in Germany, he received a Doctorate of Law from the University of Berlin in 1935. In 1936 he published, illegally, a book summarizing Nazi legislation affecting the rights of German Jews entitled ''The Legal Position of Jews in Germany.'' He left Germany in 1939 and made his way to China, where he lived and practiced law for ten years. After moving to the United States, he received a law degree in 1951 from Brooklyn Law School. In June, 1969 he became a founding member of Weiss Dawid Fross Zelnick & Lehrman, an intellectual property firm now known as Fross Zelnick Lehrman & Zissu, PC. He published several works in the fields of trademark and unfair competition law. Heinz Dawid was known for his productivity, his passionate identification with his clients, his relentless pursuit of developments in the law, his endless store of experience and knowledge and his sense of decency, humor and professionalism. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire Dawid family. A memorial service is being planned by the firm.

title: Race and Redistricting
description: In considering whether a North Carolina Congressional district was gerrymandered, the Supreme Court is expected to determine the role of race in the redistricting that is due after this year's census.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, BENJAMIN S.
description: GREENBERG-Benjamin S. Died November 26 at age 78 after a courageous five year struggle with kidney disease. Beloved husband of Nancy. Loving father of Penny, DeDe, Bill and Mike. Dear fatherin-law of Dave, Craig, Susan and Roz. Loving grandfather of Bill, Elizabeth, Jake, Rachel, Eli, Daniel, Sonia and Noah. Cherished brother of Harriet and Larry. Devoted brother-in-law of Helen and beloved best friend and late brother-in-law of Arnold. Dear uncle of Sig, Joan, Ann, Betsy, Elliot, Becky, Susan, Ira and Amy. Born and raised in Brooklyn, N.Y., he received a B.A. in Journalism from New York University. During World War II he served as communications officer in the U.S. Pacific Fleet aboard the U.S.S. Caliente for 2-1/2 years. Studies at the U.S. Naval Academy Post Graduate School were followed by service as a Lieutenant in various communications posts. He co-produced the ''Armed Forces Hour'' for the National Broadcasting Corporation. He received the Peabody Award for producing the television program ''Adlai Stevenson Reports''. Aa Chief Executive Officer of motion picture production companies, he applied innovative approaches to the development of commercial and public service documentaries. Later, he served as the Director of Public Affairs for the Advertising Council and as an Editor of the Corporate newsletter for the Joint Purchasing Corporation. As a volunteer, he devoted his artistic abilities and generous spirit to the Riverside Branch of the New York Public Lirbary. A memorial service will be held at NCJW New York section, 820 2nd Avenue, between 43rd & 44th Streets, 2nd floor on Tuesday, November 28 at 5:30PM. Contributions may be made to either the Riverside Branch of the New York Public library, 127 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10023 or the National Kidney Foundation, 1250 Broadway, Suite 2001, New York, N.Y. 10001.

title: Florida Judge Is Asked to Declare Gore the Winner
description: Vice President Al Gore placed his last hope of gaining the presidency in a lawsuit filed today that contests the results of the presidential election in Florida, asking a circuit court judge to declare him the winner and award him the state's 25 electoral votes.

title: DISCOVER CARD RAISES WEB SECURITY
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter is becoming the latest credit card issuer to address consumers' fears about sending their account numbers over the Internet. Starting today, the company's Discover Card will begin a service that generates a substitute account number good for only one online transaction. The service, Discover Deskshop, an improved version of a limited test program, is similar to the Private Payments disposable-number system that American Express began earlier this fall. The Discover Deskshop will also allow a cardholder to fill out a purchase form with one click, complete with a single-use number, said Roger Hochschild of Discover. He said consumers wanted a secure but simple way to buy online. ''If it's not really, really easy,'' he said, ''it's never going to get adopted.'' Patrick McGeehan

title: Crowning the Imperial Judiciary
description: So four decades of judicial activism, at both the state and federal levels, mostly unchallenged by the other branches of government, culminates in this: Judges may now select the next president of the United States.

title: E-STAMP TO CANCEL WEB SALES
description: The E-Stamp Corporation, a provider of online postage software, said yesterday that it would phase out its Internet postage products and cut its work force by about 30 percent. Robert Ewald, president and chief executive of E-Stamp, said that ''operating in a highly regulated environment, combined with the change in valuation models of Internet companies, were key factors'' in the decision. The company, officials said, will shift its focus to Web-based shipping and logistics products: Digital Shipper and e-Warehouse.E-Stamp customers can continue to buy postage until Dec. 31. In 1998, E-Stamp became the first company to receive Postal Service approval to sell stamps online, but the market leader is Stamps.com, with more than 270,000 customers, compared with about 80,000 for E-Stamp. Stamps.com laid off about 240 employees last month to reduce costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, FLORENCE (FLORRIE)
description: ROSENTHAL-Florence (Florrie). On November 26, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Meryl Blackman and Lawrence Rosenthal. Loving mother-in-law of Kenneth Blackman and Joyce Bernstein. Adoring grandmother and great grandmother. Service Riverside Chapels, Wednesday at 12:45.

title: A Winner Is Proclaimed. Now, Back to Court.; Taking Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELMED, DAVID
description: MELMED-David. 77. Died November 25. He graduated Yeshiva University in '45, received Rabbinical ordination in '47, and M.S. of Education in '60. He served as a Rabbi and educator and was President of Ben Ari Arts NYC. He was admired for his Talmudic scholarship and honesty in business, and was loved by all. He is survived by his devoted wife of 51 years, Shoshana Balaban Melmed, children Devora and Zelig Prag, Yona and Nesanel Kasnett, Yakey and Chayella Melmed, and many loving grandchildren. Shiva will be observed at his home, 1665 54th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Filling Big Shoes? Better Tie Laces Tight
description: The toughest job in American business is to succeed a highly successful chief executive.

title: AFFILIATE NAMED BROOKLYN CYCLONES
description: And the winner is, the Brooklyn Cyclones.

title: U.N. Rights Chief Proposes West Bank and Gaza Monitors
description: The top United Nations human rights official said today that international monitors should be considered for the West Bank and Gaza, where she called the conditions of Palestinian civilian life bleak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON SCHEVEN, ELISABETH (NEE WEIDENREICH)
description: von SCHEVEN-Elisabeth (nee Weidenreich), of Foulkeways at Gwynedd and formerly of New York City. Wife of the late Walter Paul von Scheven; mother of Gisela Fort and George von Scheven; also survived by four grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Services will be private. For information, contact Helweg Funeral Service, Inc., Jenkintown, PA.

title: When Obesity Comes With a Price Tag
description: Obese people often lament the social penalties that can come with their condition, over and above the toll on their personal health. Now a new study has tried to put a price tag on the ostracism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICOLI, HENRY, JR.
description: PICOLI-Henry, Jr. formerly of Old Brookville, NY. on November 21, 2000. Member of the N.Y.S.E. since 1946. Former partner Ziebarth, Geary & Co. Beloved husband of the late Frances W. ''Billie''. Loving father of Peter, Henry III, William and Pamela Marie. Dear grandfather of Andrew, Christen, Peter, William and Lydia and stepgrandchildren Ian and Emma. Dear brother of Doris McKeon and Robert C. Picoli. A Memorial service will be held Friday, December 1, 2000 at 11 am. St. John's of Lattingtown, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in Henry's name to St. John's of Lattingtown.

title: From Welfare to Work
description: To the Editor:

title: INSWEB TO BUY A QUICKEN UNIT
description: InsWeb, which lets consumers compare insurance rates over the Internet, plans to buy Intuit's QuickenInsurance business to gain new customers. InsWeb will issue about seven million new shares for QuickenInsurance, a money-losing operation that accounted for $5.3 million in sales for Intuit in fiscal 2000. The shares, about 16.6 percent of InsWeb's stock, are valued at about $12.3 million. With the acquisition, InsWeb will operate insurance-referral functions on Intuit's Quicken.com personal-finance Web site under a five-year contract. It will share an undisclosed percentage of revenue with Intuit from the site. Despite its well-known personal-finance brand name, Intuit has struggled to profit from Web-based services for consumers. Some 75 jobs will be cut as a result of the deal. InsWeb shares fell 25 cents, to $1.75, down 95 percent from a December 1999 high of $35.69. Intuit shares rose $1.94, to $47.69.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAISEL, LILLIAN A.
description: MAISEL-Lillian A. Beloved aunt of June Alperson, Jay Norman Maisel, Jay Nathan Maisel, Howard Maisel, Helen Bohmart Pine and Rachel Guinsburg. Devoted great-aunt and great-great aunt and dear friend to many. She will be missed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Says Trial Judge Made Series of Mistakes

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the number of people infected with the virus that causes AIDS referred incorrectly in some copies to the year in which some 3.8 million people in sub-Saharan Africa became infected. It was this year, not last year.

title: An Admirable Way of Coping
description: To the Editor:

title: Rodriguez Pays Unexpected Visit to Texas
description: The Texas Rangers, an unlikely suitor, entertained Alex Rodriguez yesterday and held out hope that they could lure the premier free agent to their infield.

title: Graves Struggles On and Off the Ice
description: Adam Graves skated up and down the ice today at the Rangers' optional practice, working harder than anyone else amid questions about why he cannot get untracked this season.

title: Success Built On Selling Imaging Gear
description: Jeffrey R. Immelt, the next chief executive of General Electric, made his mark at GE Medical Systems by building up sales of imaging machines, a big-ticket, older technology.

title: Mets Are Among Hampton's Finalists
description: With Mike Hampton's contract negotiations set to escalate soon, the Mets will probably make the short list of teams that still interest the free agent left-hander.

title: Federal Agency Denies Bush Team Access to Money and Office for Transition
description: The Clinton administration and Gov. George W. Bush's transition team engaged in their first scuffles today, with administration aides declaring that they would not release $5.3 million in federal transition funds or turn over a transition office ''until a final winner'' emerges in the presidential race.

title: Aristide, Waiting for Tally, Delays Claiming Presidency
description: Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the once and all-but-future president of Haiti, acted very much the chief of state today as he emphasized the need to unite all Haitians -- including opponents who boycotted the presidential election on Sunday -- to work for his program of national peace and development.

title: 18-Rm. Roosevelt Mansion 4 Sale; Opp'ty to Alter or Demolish History for Just $599,500
description: The $10 tour of Franklin Delano Roosevelt's home lets visitors peek into the cozy room where he was born and pay their respects at his stately grave site in the rose garden. They can even try deciphering his handwriting in the presidential library.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TECHNOLOGY FUND GETS AWARD
description: Digital NYC, a city program begun this year to help technology companies break into areas outside Silicon Alley, like Harlem and Long Island City, was recognized as one of the year's best economic development initiatives by the International Development Research Council Foundation of Norcross, Ga. The foundation, which consists of corporate real estate executives, gave the program its Annual Global Innovator's Award. New York City's latest progress report on the program is set for release in early December. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Rightist, No. 2 in Romania, Is Eager for Runoff
description: Corneliu Vadim Tudor's spin doctor has his work cut out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, ZITA
description: BLOOM-Zita. Congregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member, Zita Bloom. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to her family. Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, Rabbi Alisa R. Doctoroff, President

title: Wahid Speech Said to Assail Singaporeans
description: SINGAPORE  President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia has reportedly accused Singapore and other countries in Southeast Asia of wanting to develop ties with China at the expense of relations with smaller and poorer states.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a support group for professors born into working-class families misstated the group's Web address. It is www .phoenix.liu.edu/bpeters/WCA.htm.

title: AGILENT TO AQUIRE OBJECTIVE SYSTEMS
description: Agilent Technologies, a leading maker of test and measurement equipment that was once a division of Hewlett-Packard, said yesterday that it was purchasing Objective Systems Integrators for $665 million. O.S.I. makes software that integrates and manages communications services, a fast-growing market in which Agilent already competes. Agilent, based in Palo Alto, Calif., has products in the communications, electronics, life sciences and health care markets, and last year had revenue of $10.8 billion. O.S.I. has 400 employees worldwide. Laurie J. Flynn

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB CO., New York, one of the largest drug companies in the world, said its Bristol-Myers Squibb Holdings Ltd. division would buy Amcare Ltd., a British unit of Transworld Healthcare Inc., also of New York, a provider of home health care products and services, for $14.2 million in cash.

title: Team From Illinois and Italy Wins Bridge Tournament
description: The American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals ended here on Sunday night with two players from Illinois capturing the big title with four Italians.

title: Islanders End Slide With a Torrent
description: It was a no-excuses night for the Islanders.

title: Jets Enter Crunch Time With a Lot of Company
description: Even Jets Coach Al Groh, who usually views subplots to a game as little more than annoying diversions, has thrown up his hands at any attempt to pretend that next Sunday's game against the Indianapolis Colts -- along with the three remaining games of the regular season -- will be anything other than special.

title: TRIGON HEALTHCARE JOINS BIDDING FOR CERULEAN
description: Trigon Healthcare has begun a $675 million takeover offer for the Cerulean Companies, forcing WellPoint Health Networks to raise its two-year-old bid for Cerulean to $680 million. The companies are health insurers. In July 1998, WellPoint agreed to pay $500 million in cash and stock for Cerulean, the Atlanta-based parent of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Georgia; its offer had been held up pending resolution of shareholder lawsuits against Cerulean. Trigon, based in Richmond, Va., submitted its unsolicited bid Sunday. The 1998 agreement gave WellPoint the right to match competing offers. Cerulean's board has not formally responded to WellPoint's revised bid, but it has told Wellpoint management that the bid seems no better than Trigon's.

title: Lazy Afternoon
description: Q.: Why am I so sleepy and drowsy after lunch? It makes it hard to concentrate.

title: Metro Business Briefing; AIRLINE EXPANDS FLORIDA FLIGHTS
description: A discount carrier, Spirit Airlines, said it would expand its operations at Newark International Airport to include daily round-trip service to Melbourne, Fla. Closely held Spirit Airlines, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said in a news release that it would begin the nonstop service on Feb. 8, with fares starting at $64 each way for travel between Feb. 8 and Feb. 28 if tickets are purchased by Dec. 13. The airline currently offers three daily nonstop round-trip flights between Melbourne and Fort Lauderdale to La Guardia Airport and Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLOOM, GOLDIE
description: ROSENBLOOM-Goldie. Beloved wife of Herman. Devoted mother of Sidney, Freddy and Andrew. Loving grandmother of Sarah, Henry, Noah and Cecilia. Services today, 12:00 PM at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels'', Queens Boulevard at 66th Ave., Rego Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, PAMELA POLHEMUS
description: SMITH-Pamela Polhemus. 44, died November 22, 2000. She was born in Stamford, Connecticut on April 3, 1956, the daughter of Robert B. and Patricia A. Polhemus. In addition to her mother of Darien, CT, she is survived by her beloved husband of nineteen years, Peter Smith; children, Katrina, Samuel and Duncan, and Sister, Barbar Pholhemus, all of Bass Harbor, ME; brother, Richard Polhemus of New Milford, CT. A memorial service will be held, 3:00 PM, December 2 at the Bar Harbor Congregational Church, Bar Harbor, ME.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOREN, YORAM
description: GOREN-Yoram, died peacefully in London after a short illness on November 26th. Aged 66, he is survived by his loving wife Gunilla, daughters Nicky and Leora, and stepson Leon. Donations, if desired, to the Imperial Cancer Research Fund in London or the Israel Cancer Research Fund. Private funeral service has already taken place. Memorial service in London to be held in the new year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSH, LUCILLE
description: RUSH-Lucille. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel. Devoted mother of Laurence (Doreen), Howard (Donia), and David (Ginger). Cherished grandmother, dear sister of Gladys Rosenberg. Services today 11am ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. Donations may be made to Hadassah.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLER, RICHARD
description: MILLER-Richard. 2/19/29-11/28/99. Gone from my sight but never my memories. Gone from my touch but never my heart. Bunny

title: Jury Begins Deliberations In Midtown Brick Attack
description: Combing through what the witnesses said they had seen and heard, defense and prosecution lawyers gave closing arguments and a jury began deliberations in a brick-attack trial that may turn on the credence given to passers-by on a Manhattan street corner.

title: HENRY SCHEIN SELLS BRITISH SOFTWARE BUSINESS
description: Henry Schein, a supplier of dental and medical equipment now restructuring, said it had sold its British software-development business to the closely held British unit of Software of Excellence, a New Zealand company. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. The buyer is not connected to the American company Systems of Excellence, now in liquidation, which figured in a stock manipulation scandal in 1996, but the similarity of names is not a coincidence: in 1994, the American company, then known as World Foods, changed its name in preparation for a merger that the companies discussed but never completed. Henry Schein is based in Melville, N.Y.

title: Flattery Will Win 'em Over, No Matter How Big the Star
description: There should be a sign on Howard Gotlieb's desk that reads: Flattery will get you everywhere.

title: Tracking Rogue Giant Icebergs From the Skies
description: Scientists continue to monitor the adventures of one of the biggest icebergs in modern memory, and its progeny, using weather satellites and aerial photography. The iceberg, designated B-15, launched itself off into the sea off Antarctica last March, when a slab of ice roughly the size of Connecticut broke off the Ross Ice Shelf. It has been causing trouble ever since. In the intervening months the iceberg has broken into four pieces, and one those subsequently swung back into the Ross Ice Shelf, knocking yet another new iceberg loose from the shelf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, HELENE F.
description: BROWN-Helene F. The members and staff of Pryor Cashman Sherman & Flynn mourn the loss of their dear friend and colleague, Helene Brown, loving and beloved wife of Dean, mother of Elizabeth and Samantha, daughter of Shirley Roffman and sister of Susan Hyer. Her great spirit, loving heart and professional dedication will be deeply missed by us all. The family has requested that memorial donations in Helene's name be directed to The Stephen Gottlieb Memorial Fund for Cancer Research, c/o Stuart Gottlieb, 220 Brewery Road, New City, New York, 10956.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSOCK, ADELE
description: POSOCK-Adele. On November 27, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Michael. Loving aunt of Kathy Fort and sister-in-law of Gladis Wulff. Mass Thursday 11:15 AM, St. Anne/St. George Church. Reposing at the chapel of Joseph G. Duffy Inc., 9th St. between 4th and 5th Aves., Brooklyn. Visiting Wednesday 7-9 PM only.

title: Gucci Award Of Options Is Challenged
description: LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, in an attempt to annul a stock deal that gave Pinault-Printemps-Redoute control of the Gucci Group, contended today in a court filing that Gucci secretly awarded two of its top executives hundreds of millions of dollars in stock options at the expense of minority shareholders.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: OM GRUPPEN, Stockholm, named Simon Nathanson interim chief executive of the Stockholm exchange, replacing Carl Johan Hoegbom, who is resigning in January as chief executive of the Stockholm exchange after less than two years in charge.

title: The Party Look Is Luxurious, But a Single Look It's Not
description: Patricia Herrera, whose mother is the designer Carolina Herrera, does her own thing when it comes to dressing up at night, and that might mean a cropped fur jacket with jeans, or maybe a vintage Saint Laurent tuxedo. But she's not opposed to casting a cool eye in her mother's closet. ''Oh, all the time,'' said Ms. Herrera, a magazine editor. ''I can't think of a better luxury than raiding my mother's closet. She has a lot of stuff from her predesigning days. I've been trying to get my hands on this gorgeous hand-painted Chloe dress.''

title: A Doctor With a Cause: 'What's My Prognosis?'
description: Dr. Nicholas A. Christakis, tall, animated, and impassioned, burns with a mission: to bring prognosis into what he sees as its rightful place in medicine.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Quietly but Confidently, Bush Pushes Ahead
description: As Gov. George W. Bush's aides prepared what would be the closest thing to a victory speech that he may ever get to deliver, it occurred to them that there was an important question they needed to ask him. Should they address him as governor or president-elect?

title: Art Sellers Look to Use Coupons in Settlement
description: Embroiled in a scandal over price-fixing and collusion, Sotheby's and Christie's asked a federal judge yesterday to approve a plan to offer discount certificates to auction customers as part of a $512 million settlement of a class-action civil suit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, ROSE
description: ROTH-Rose. On November 26, 2000 at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Isidor; loving mother of Jack Roth and Sheila Bogart; adoring grandmother and great-grandmother; sister of Sam and Abe Pottish. Services Tuesday 11:15AM, Parkside, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Rego Park, NY

title: GORE ASKS PUBLIC FOR PATIENCE; BUSH STARTS TRANSITION MOVES; ADMINISTRATION WITHHOLDS AID
description: As Gov. George W. Bush moved with determination to prepare his transition to the White House, Vice President Al Gore pleaded tonight for public patience while he contests Florida's decision to award its decisive 25 electoral votes to Mr. Bush.

title: A Winner Is Proclaimed. Now, Back to Court.; Hold On to That Towel
description: To the Editor:

title: Spacey Putting His Money Where His Heart Has Been
description: How many times have smitten theatergoers wished they could whip out a checkbook and bail out a struggling show or a failing theatrical company? The feeling has struck Kevin Spacey quite a bit lately, and unlike most of his fellow ticketholders he has acted on it.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY REPORTS BIG STAKE IN USG
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. reported in a regulatory filing that it holds 6.5 million common shares of the USG Corporation, or 14.98 percent of the company's outstanding common stock. The news sent USG's battered stock rocketing $4.44, or almost 30 percent, to close at $19.38. The company, based in Chicago, makes building materials, and is one of the principal manufacturers still involved in asbestos-liability litigation. Berkshire, based in Omaha and run by Warren E. Buffett, disclosed the holding on a short form used by passive and institutional investors that does not provide transaction details.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEKRETA, BARBARA ANN
description: SEKRETA-Barbara Ann, peacefully at home on November 26, beloved wife of Martin, devoted mother of Katherine, James, Carole, and Marie, loving mother-inlaw to William, Heidi, George, and Eric, adoring grandmother of Brian, Claire, Elizabeth, Ted, Owen, Claudia, and Martin, cherished sister of Frank and Paul Geissler. Devoted her life to her faith, family, and friends. All were touched by her heartfelt generosity and love of life. In lieu of flowers, Barbara requested donations be made to St. Francis Monastery, 135 West 31st Street, New York, NY 10117-0667. Family will receive friends Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, Inc., 34 Hempstead Avenue (corner Peninsula Blvd.), Lynbrook. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10:45 AM Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: Knicks Go Big, And Rice Lives Large
description: To some, it sounded pathetic. A three-time All-Star and one of the best shooters of the past decade said it was tough coming off the bench. He got cold after warm-ups.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Eating Out'' column in Weekend on Friday, about restaurants that offer white truffles, listed one dish erroneously for Barbetta, at 321 West 46th Street in Manhattan. The restaurant does not serve a veal chop stuffed with fontina cheese.

title: Office Depot Begins An Account Review
description: Office Depot, the office supply retailer, said yesterday that it was beginning a review for its account, with billings estimated at more than $50 million.

title: Mexican General to Lead Fox's War on Crime
description: Four days before his inauguration as Mexico's new president, Vicente Fox Quesada completed his cabinet tonight, selecting security and justice ministers and preparing for the nation's first democratic transfer of power to an opposition party.

title: SPANISH CELLULAR CONTRACTS
description: Telefonica Moviles of Spain selected Ericsson, Nokia and Motorola for construction of the first phase of its third-generation wireless communications network, awarding three contracts worth 120 million euros ($102.7 million). The network and related infrastructure is to be completed by Aug. 1, 2001, and is part of a total investment of almost 5.3 billion euros by the cellular phone arm of Telefonica S.A. in the wireless technology. In the initial phase of the project, 750 base stations serving 16 of Spain's biggest cities are to be built, along with a radio access network, switching structures and systems for testing interoperability among the three suppliers. Benjamin Jones (NYT)

title: A New I.R.S. Rule to Ease Paperwork for Tiny Businesses
description: A new Internal Revenue Service rule will mean much less paperwork and fewer penalties for about one million tiny businesses, but two accountants who work with such businesses warn that the rule could backfire.

title: Hewitt Wins As Sampras Rolls Over
description: His sabbatical over, Pete Sampras returned to the office today after two and a half months only to discover that somebody had changed the locks.

title: Eye for an Eye Is Human, But Is It Just?
description: LET'S begin with a brief look back to another time when someone named George Bush was running for president.

title: Liberties; Ahab vs. The Waco Whale
description: President-elect(?) Mini-Me has not yet started gnawing on his cat, as the ''Austin Powers'' Mini-Me did to the hairless Mr. Bigglesworth.

title: Guggenheim On East River Is Years Away
description: Even as officials from City Hall and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum enthusiastically described their ambitious plan yesterday for a world-class museum in Lower Manhattan, they said the project faced fund-raising hurdles, a daunting list of governmental reviews and tough scrutiny from the site's neighbors.

title: WOODSIDE REBUFFS SHELL BID
description: Woodside Petroleum rejected the Royal Dutch/Shell Group's sweetened offer of 6.5 billion Australian dollars ($3.4 billion). Woodside Petroleum's directors, excluding those appointed by Shell, which already owns 34 percent of Woodside, termed inadequate the bid of 14.8 Australian dollars ($7.80) for each of the shares Shell does not own. Woodside shares closed at 15 Australian dollars ($7.91). Shell said it was weighing its options.

title: Yes, Room for Fellowship In the Realm of Tank Tops
description: A familiar truth, proven again: Chemistry works wonders.

title: Tally in Romania Is Official: Crucial Runoff Is Due Dec. 10
description: As indicated by polls of people after they had voted on Sunday, a leftist former president and a nationalist extremist will face each other in a runoff for the presidency on Dec. 10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLKCOM, THOMAS H.
description: BOLKCOM-Thomas H. On November 27 at the age of 56. Loving husband of Donna. Extraordinary Dad of Bret & Jess. Dear brother of Gerry Ann. Memorial service at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and 5th Avenue, Tuesday, December 5 at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Bernard's School, 4 E. 98 St., NYC 10029 or Delaware River Mill Society, P.O. Box 298, Stockton, N.J. 08559.

title: On the Pond, Speed and Fury Serve Rangers
description: In the late 1990's, when the goals-per-game average in the National Hockey League dipped to 5.3 for both teams combined, the league authorities changed a few policies to encourage more scoring and increase entertainment.

title: Bipartisanship With Bite
description: Democrats have complained of the presumptuousness of George W. Bush's cabinet-making, but yesterday Al Gore indicated that he, too, was assembling a governing team. And while the two campaigns snarl ever more loudly at each other, both leaders continue to stress bipartisanship. The Gore campaign, for example, has let it be known that it would like to appoint a Republican governor as education secretary. Some Bush supporters have talked of offering a cabinet position to Joe Lieberman.

title: EXXON VENTURE MAY DELAY CASPIAN SEA PROJECT
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation and the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group may have to delay the development of a Caspian Sea oil field until facilities to separate larger-than-usual amounts of sulfur and natural gas from the oil can be built. The companies, together with BP Amoco, the BG Group, TotalFinaElf, Statoil, Eni Inpex of Japan and the Phillips Petroleum Company, are exploring the Kashagan field off Kazakhstan, which by some estimates is the largest oil deposit found in decades. ''Unless we have a robust solution for gas, we'll not be developing the oil field,'' said Keith Dallard, general manager of the venture. ''Over a half of our expenditure could be for gas and sulfur-related facilities, not just for oil.''

title: Architect Says His Design Is Just a Start
description: After the mayor and his entourage had whizzed away, after the television crews had packed up and gone, the architect Frank O. Gehry stood among his models of cardboard and tissue paper yesterday and described what he was trying to accomplish in designing a new Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum for Lower Manhattan.

title: Judge Orders Confiscation Of Papers in Terrorism Case
description: Citing ''significant security concerns,'' a federal judge in Manhattan has authorized government agents to enter the cells of five inmates awaiting trial in a terrorism case and remove documents and other materials that prosecutors say are inflammatory and could incite violence by the prisoners.

title: ASEAN Warns EU to Ease Its Burma Boycott
description: SINGAPORE  Southeast Asian countries have told the European Union they will abandon high-level talks with the EU if it continues to press for Burma's exclusion on human rights grounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, JOSEPH
description: RUBIN-Joseph. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its affiliates mourn the passing of the beloved father of our devoted member Arleen Rubin and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLER, WILLIAM
description: MULLER-William. Died peacefully November 27 in his 100th year. Beloved husband of the late Hilda. Formerly executive chef of the Louis Sherry Restaurant of the Metropolitan Opera House. Proprietor of Challet Swiss, Warrensburg, New York. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Judge Orders Morgan Stanley to Turn Over Data in Bias Cases
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has ruled that Morgan Stanley Dean Witter must turn over information about complaints of race and sex discrimination at the securities firm to the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: Three Marmalades With Star Quality
description: Frog Hollow Farm preserves have quite a pedigree.

title: Suit Alleges Major Housing Fraud Against U.S. by Brooklyn Charity
description: State investigators alleged in court documents yesterday that a Brooklyn social services group defrauded a federal homeownership program, buying 65 run-down homes in Brooklyn to qualify for mortgages and then failing to make more than minimal improvements on the properties.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on April 13 reported the failure of a civil suit by the family of Dr. Sam Sheppard, which sought to establish his innocence in connection with the 1954 murder of his wife in Cleveland. The 1954 case, involving accusations of adultery and playboy debauchery, transfixed the nation. In 1966 the Supreme Court granted Dr. Sheppard a second trial because of pretrial publicity, and he was acquitted. The article last April said an abiding mystery was why prosecutors continued to fight so hard 46 years later against reversal of the original verdict.

title: After Decades of Delay, Superfund Cleanup Site Is Ready for 'Play Ball!'
description: Over 40 years, the quality of the Little League teams and the adult slow-pitch leagues that played at Pepe Field here varied widely. But they rarely stunk as badly as the rotten-egg odor that percolated up from the field itself and permeated the northern end of this Morris County town.

title: Strong and Gentle Giants
description: BY almost all accounts, 1998 was a great vintage in the Rhone Valley, particularly in the south, the land of Chateauneuf-du-Pape. After tasting my way through more than a dozen of the 98's, which have arrived in stores over the last few months, I can say that these wines are not only rich but also enjoyable in their youth, even as many will age delightfully.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENKIND, EVELYN
description: HENKIND-Evelyn. The Solomon Schechter High School of New York is saddened by the passing of Evelyn Henkind, a cherished friend and role model, committed to Jewish education and the transmission of Jewish life values. Cochair of our benefit dinner and benefactor of our school, her love, kindness, genorosity and dignified spirit was felt by many. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to her devoted Sol, and children Lewis, Ellie, Michael and her grandchildren. Carol S. Kekst, Chairman, Board of Trustees Rabbi Judd Kruger Levingston, Principal

title: New York Approves Con Ed's Merger Proposal
description: New York State regulators yesterday approved Consolidated Edison's proposed acquisition of Northeast Utilities of New England, and also approved rate reductions and other conditions that the two utilities had for the most part already agreed to.

title: Keen Jurist Oversees Election Case
description: Faced with a case that has much of the world's attention and could decide the presidency, Judge N. Sanders Sauls of the Leon County Circuit Court surveyed the horde of lawyers before him Monday and drawled, ''This is no different from any other litigation.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MESSING, MARILYN
description: MESSING-Marilyn. November 27, 1989. In loving memory. Caren and Harvey

title: INSIDE
description: Drug Ordered Off Shelves

title: Who Is Winning the Fight for America's Heart?; Democracy Imperiled
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Bill Gates Really a Frustrated Rock Star?
description: Maybe Al Dunlap, the chief executive who earned a reputation as a hatchet man by taking over companies and cutting payrolls, wanted to be a chainsaw-wielding hard rock singer.

title: High Temperatures Shrink Ice Man's Cocoon
description: Thousands of New Yorkers, some skeptical, some spellbound, turned out yesterday to gape at the unlikely image of a man standing in a giant ice cube, as David Blaine, a 27-year-old self-described ''mystifier,'' entered his second day encased in an increasingly soggy six-ton block of ice.

title: India's Truce Over Kashmir Is Shattered As 3 More Die
description: Peace, given a chance, lasted about 14 1/2 hours.

title: From France and America, Two Bakeries That Offer A Touch of Home
description: Is your sweet tooth French or American? Two new bakeries in Manhattan give you a choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, MILTON
description: RATNER-Milton. The Officers, Directors, and Aministration of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Foundation extend their sympathy to Sheldon Ratner, fellow Board member, on the loss of his beloved father. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. S. Merrill Skeist, President Lawrence Simon, Chairman Herbert H. Friedman, Executive Vice President

title: Charge of New Irregularities On Absentee Ballot Counts
description: A second heavily Republican county in Florida allowed party officials to fix hundreds of flawed absentee ballot applications that had been submitted by voters but rejected by the elections office, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALITZ, CLARENCE YALE, JR.
description: PALITZ-Clarence Yale, Jr. It is with great sadness that the Board of Directors and staff of Career Transition For Dancers acknowledges the untimely passing of Clarence Palitz, husband of our fellow Board member and dear friend, Anka Palitz. ''Cal'' was an important and generous supporter of our work. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family, friends, and colleagues.

title: THE BOSS; I'm a Chocolate Maker's Son
description: I'm the fourth generation in my family to make chocolate. My grandfather's first building was destroyed in the California earthquake of 1906. I remember running around with my brothers in the late 40's and early 50's in the old, dingy factory on the San Francisco waterfront where my grandfather relocated. At the end of the day the aroma of chocolate permeated our clothes. You can't go into a chocolate factory and not come out smelling like chocolate.

title: Gore Is Cast as Litigant, Statesman and Cheerleader
description: He never directly asked for the nation's patience. Today, three weeks after the most inconclusive presidential election in modern times, he took note of it, saying, ''The American people have shown great patience in these extraordinary days,'' but he did not actually ask for it.

title: Comments from Gore On the Florida Election
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday by Vice President Al Gore, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Spain's Cross: Basque and Brutal
description: Mariano Sancho Collado was pulling recycling bins from a garage when he felt the shock. The blast blew the Supreme Court judge's car over the top of a nearby bus and across two lanes of traffic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HAGAN, HENRY J.
description: O'HAGAN-Henry J. (Hank). Of Manhattan and Lake Huntington, NY, on November 23. Beloved son of Marguerite and the late Harry O'Hagan. Cherished brother of Stephen, Peggy (Jeffrey) Stabile and Rosemary (Denis) Nugent. Loving uncle of Jeffrey Stabile, Elizabeth Cantwell, Michael, Kristen and Colleen O'Hagan, and Denis, Sean and Patrick Nugent. Dear friend of Judith Harlan. For information contact O.B. Davis Funeral Homes, Port Jefferson Station, LI. There will be a Memorial Mass Friday, 10 AM, at St. Andrew's R.C. Church, 20 Cardinal Hayes Place, Manhattan. Reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Nature Conservancy, 4245 North Fairfax Dr., Suite 100, Arlington, VA 22203.

title: Recipe: Pepper Pot With Shellfish and Squash
description: Adapted from Fritz Blank

title: Yanks' Talks With Mussina Hit Undisclosed Snag
description: The Yankees' determined pursuit of the free-agent pitcher Mike Mussina continued yesterday. But their effort was slowed when the negotiations hit a snag over undisclosed noneconomic issues.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHER, JOAN E
description: FISHER-Joan E. A memorial service for Joan E. Fisher of Cross River, New York, will be held on December 1, 2000, at 11:30 AM, at St. Matthews Church in Bedford, New York. Friends and family are most welcomed to attend.

title: The Giants Are Trying to Solve the Redskins' Numerical Edge
description: Forgive Giants fans if they feel as if the Washington Redskins have had the Giants' number.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMORY, ALAN S.
description: EMORY-Alan S. November 27, 2000 of pancreatic cancer at age of 78 at home in Falls Church, VA. Your sun, the glory that your words would bring. Our Winter's come. You'll be in every Spring. Eric and Linda Emory

title: Shareholders Revolt as Automaker Stumbles : Daimler Chief Under Fire
description: FRANKFURT  Juergen Schrempp, the swaggering chairman of DaimlerChrysler AG, is battling an increasingly militant shareholder revolt that threatens to toss him from his job.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a stunt in which a magician, David Blaine, has encased himself in ice in Times Square misspelled the surname of Mr. Blaine's medical consultant and in some copies misstated his given name. The consultant is Dr. Ronald Ruden, not Robert Rudin.

title: RISING POWER USE EXPECTED
description: Equipment ranging from home computers to Internet servers is now expected to soak up electricity at a faster rate than the government forecast a year ago, as a result of improvement in the outlook for the economy during the early part of the century, the Energy Department said. Electricity demand during the next two decades is now forecast to rise by 1.8 percent a year, the department said in an annual energy outlook, compared with the 1.3 percent rate forecast in last year's report. The revision came after a ''re-evaluation of the potential for growth in electricity use for a variety of residential and commercial appliances and equipment, including personal computers,'' the report said.

title: Investors Are Still Interested In Risky Start-Up Companies
description: In a sign that investor appetite for risky start-up companies remains high, wealthy individuals and institutions committed $28 billion to venture capital funds during the third quarter, up from $24 billion in the previous three months, according to an industrywide report released today.

title: Who Is Winning the Fight for America's Heart?; A Matter of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscellany
description: Townsend & O'Leary, Irvine, Calif., was renamed the T& O Group.

title: Supreme Court Bars Roadblocks Set Up To Search for Drugs
description: Police roadblocks aimed at discovering drugs violate the Constitution, the Supreme Court ruled today in an important decision reaffirming the Fourth Amendment prohibition against searches and seizures that are not based on a suspicion of individual wrongdoing.

title: A Desire to Dazzle That Didn't Know When to Stop
description: An exhibition of sumptuous jewelry, gold and silver bowls, lavishly engraved icon covers and diamond-encrusted images of saints, now on display at the Field Museum here, is a testament to the skill of Russian decorative artists over the last 10 centuries. But on closer view, the show is more than that. It traces the rise and fall of a great empire and has as much to say about history as art.

title: Who Is Winning the Fight for America's Heart?
description: To the Editor:

title: FLORIDA LAWMAKERS MOVING TO BYPASS COURTS FOR BUSH; JUDGE BARS A QUICK RECOUNT
description: Three lawyers hired by the Republican leaders of the Florida Legislature told a select committee today that the Republican-dominated body was duty-bound under the United States Constitution to promptly call a special session to name Florida's 25 electors.

title: The Sporting News Extends Its Brand
description: The Sporting News extended its brand name yesterday when its parent company acquired One-On-One Sports, a radio network with 400 affiliated stations, including 620 AM in the New York area.

title: Knowing Your Place Setting, And Some Cleanup Hints, Too
description: Oh, the problems a mere fork can present. Especially to the host of a large dinner party. Which type should one use? Where should it be placed in the table setting? How should it be cleaned?

title: Hearing Is Scheduled for Saturday Despite Demands of Gore Lawyers
description: A circuit judge this evening denied a plea from Vice President Al Gore's lawyers to accelerate his lawsuit that seeks to overturn Gov. George W. Bush's victory in Florida, refusing to recount thousands of disputed ballots at least until he holds a hearing on Saturday.

title: Johnson Re-signed to Help Kick Returns
description: Gearing up for the stretch run and trying to shore up the team's most glaring weakness, the Jets yesterday re-signed Leon Johnson, their former star kick-returner and third-down performer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, S. LOUIS
description: SCHWARTZ-S. Louis We extend heartfelt condolences to Morton Schwartz, on the loss of his beloved father. As Silver Founders of the Medical Center, Morton and Fayge Schwartz personify the highest values of Jewish tradition and ethics, which they learned from this caring and kind man. As Vice President of the National Women's Division, Fayge's deep commitment to the health care needs of the people of Jerusalem is truly exemplary. May Morton and the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr. Erica Jesselson, Chair Lee Weinbach, Pres. Nat'l Women's Div.

title: GETTING OUT/A special report.; Often, Parole Is One Stop On the Way Back to Prison
description: It seemed like the perfect solution. Build more prisons and America would be a safer place. In fact, as the nation's incarceration rate has quadrupled over the last two decades, the crime rate has fallen for eight straight years.

title: Nets Can't Hold Malone Down Long Enough
description: More than a half-hour after tonight's game, Karl Malone sat beaming in a corner of the Utah Jazz's locker room, trying to explain his uncanny ability to lift his performance near the end of a game. He quickly changed his mood when the technical foul called on him was mentioned.

title: Who Is Winning the Fight for America's Heart?; Armed for Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Hercules, a Chemical Maker, to Sell All Its Businesses
description: Hercules Inc., which spent much of this year trying to sell three of its six main businesses, said yesterday that it would sell the remaining businesses as well.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEITNER, SYLVIA (TZIPPY).
description: LEITNER-Sylvia (Tzippy). In 1940, I was blessed with a beautiful bride. Children and grandchildren made us thrive. In 1989 came the accident and you did not survive. Today only precious memories are all that remains, like an antidote for ths loss and pain. With love, Nat

title: MarchFirst To Undergo A Revamping
description: With its stock price down 98.7 percent this year to just a little above $1, MarchFirst, the new-economy consulting company, is getting out of the business it was founded to do.

title: It's a Cave? A Temple? It's a Mystery
description: The ragged caravan seems to materialize from out of a dark void. One end is overhung with what looks like gray-green Spanish moss, forming a bower that slopes down to a glowing bed of embers just inside the entrance. Look hard into the leaves and fire. Is that a man's face and bare torso or simply an illusion? Then, ''Slowlier! Slowlier! Thank you!'' a woman's voice calls out in the theater's darkness. Eiko and Koma have returned.

title: Gore Opts Not to Join Lawsuit That Could Help Him the Most
description: The crux of Vice President Al Gore's challenge to the results of the presidential election in Florida, as he said today, is that ''every vote should be counted.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MARTIN E.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Martin E. The Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee and Metro-North Railroad Commuter Council mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend our deepest sympathy to his family.

title: INTERNET COMPANY IN JAPAN VENTURE
description: A subsidiary of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone of Japan, the world's biggest communications carrier, plans to announce today that it has agreed to form a joint venture with the InterNAP Network Services Corporation, a United States company that helps stream Internet connections. InterNAP, based in Seattle, aggregates so-called backbone Internet connections from a variety of carriers and then sells high-level cyberspace connections to Web site operators and big corporate customers, among others. A deal with N.T.T. provides a beachhead for InterNAP to expand its presence in Asia in general and Japan in particular. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: Racial Pattern in Demographics of Error-Prone Ballots
description: When Florida's votes were counted on Election Day, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas had a tiny but possibly decisive edge: the majority of the state's black voters, Vice President Al Gore's most reliable voters, stalwart supporters, cast their ballots on punch cards that are more prone to voter error and miscounts.

title: 2 Exchanges Are in Talks On a Merger
description: Having failed to merge with the London Stock Exchange, Deutsche Borse acknowledged today that it had talked with OM Gruppen, which owns the Swedish stock exchange and which made its own unsuccessful bid to buy the London exchange.

title: Morgan Stanley Delays a Presentation
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, whose research analysts uncover and assess information about public companies that clients cannot readily obtain on their own, found itself having to leave the analysts that cover its own stock in the dark.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Tofu vs. Cream Cheese

title: Annan Urges End to U.N. Mission in Haiti
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan told the General Assembly today that the United Nations mission in Haiti should be terminated because of the unstable political situation there.

title: Profiling Disclosure May Prompt Dismissal of Cases and Review of Judge
description: The disclosure Monday that New Jersey's top law enforcement officials have known for years of widespread racial profiling could lead to the dismissal of dozens of pending criminal cases, increased scrutiny of Justice Peter G. Verniero of the State Supreme Court and a ratcheting up of investigations of the state's record in singling out minorities as drug and crime suspects, state officials said today.

title: Dutch Becoming First Nation to Legalize Assisted Suicide
description: The Dutch Parliament voted today to allow doctors to help end the lives of seriously ill patients who have asked to die. The bill, which is expected to become law next year, would make the Netherlands the first country to legalize mercy killing and doctor-assisted suicide, practices that are already in wide use, though technically a crime.

title: MERCK PLANS TO INVEST IN HEALTH-RELATED NET BUSINESSES
description: Merck & Company said yesterday that it had created a new venture capital subsidiary to invest up to $100 million in private Internet and other emerging businesses involved in health care services and pharmaceuticals. Merck named Per G. H. Lofberg president of the new unit. Richard Clark will replace Mr. Lofberg as head of Merck's pharmacy services unit, Merck-Medco. Merck said the unit would not invest in research-based pharmaceutical, vaccine or biotechnology companies. Merck Capital will be based in Montvale, N.J.; the parent company is based in Whitehouse Station, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about the Microsoft Corporation's appeal of the antitrust ruling against it referred incorrectly to some of the people shown. Three were lawyers for Microsoft; two were spokesmen for the company. They were not all lawyers. From the left, they were Richard J. Urowsky of Sullivan & Cromwell, the law firm representing Microsoft; James W. Cullinan, a company spokesman; William H. Neukom, the head of Microsoft's legal department; Mark Murray, a spokesman; and Steven L. Holley of Sullivan & Cromwell.

title: A Supreme Court Session We Should All See
description: If there ever was an occasion that cried out for cameras in the Supreme Court, this is it. The stakes in the case the justices will take up Friday -- the legitimacy of the office of president, not to mention its next occupant -- couldn't be higher. The traditional concerns of the justices about television coverage couldn't be weaker.

title: Are the Three R's Crowding Out P.E.?
description: OVER the nine years that Pat Oligschlaeger has taught physical education at Flynn Park Elementary School in this St. Louis suburb, he has seen a marked decline in his pupils' fitness.

title: In the Quest for Safer Seafood, One Company Follows Its Nose
description: SOME restaurants sell ambience, whether romantic or rambunctious.

title: A Rat Summit Is No Joke To Conferees; New Laws Are Proposed As the Rodents Increase
description: It is a struggle between beauty and the beast.

title: Excerpts From Court's Opinions on Roadblocks for Drug Searches
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today striking down police roadblocks for drug searches. The vote in Indianapolis v. Edmund was 6 to 3. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the majority opinion; Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the dissent.

title: Study Finds Pequot Businesses Lift Economy
description: The Mashantucket Pequot tribe and its profitable casino, hotel and pharmaceutical businesses are having a mostly positive impact on Connecticut's flourishing economy, according to a report released today by the University of Connecticut.

title: Widespread Profiling in New Jersey
description: The release this week of 91,000 pages of internal documents provides the clearest evidence yet that racial profiling has been standard operating procedure for the New Jersey State Police for years, and that high state officials were aware of it. Indeed, the use of this illegal tactic in stopping and searching vehicles was not merely the habit of a few rogue officers, but was breathtakingly widespread. The documents, released in response to lawsuits, indicate that some 80 percent of all vehicle searches conducted by state troopers on the New Jersey Turnpike over much of the past decade involved African-American and Hispanic drivers.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALKIN, ROGER D.
description: MALKIN-Roger D. On behalf of the entire Poly Prep community, the Board of Trustees of Poly Prep Country Day School wishes to express our sadness at the passing of Roger D. Malkin, a loyal and dedicated member of the Class of '48. We extend our condolences to the Malkin family and to all those who mourn their loss.

title: CALENDAR
description: The Art of Eating

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUHL, BENJAMIN N.
description: DUHL-Benjamin N. The Officers and Staff of State of Israel Bonds mourn with profound sorrow the passing of a veteran leader of its Real Estate and Construction Division. He was a long time member of the Prime Minister's Club who served with distinction as a Vice Chairman of the campaign. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Gideon Patt President and CEO Burton P. Resnick Chairman of the Board Irwin Hochberg National Campaign Chairman Howard Hirsch, Chairman Metropolitan N.Y. Region Daniel R. Tishman, Chairman, Real Estate and Construction Division

title: In Philadelphia, Gore's Plea for Patience Finds Sympathetic Ears
description: Vice President Al Gore had just finished asking that Americans be patient while he contests Florida's decision to award its decisive 25 electoral votes to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. The 10 voters who had gathered before the television in an apartment in the Chestnut Hill neighborhood of this heavily Democratic city on Monday night said they felt obligated to wait.

title: ASEAN Warns EU to Back Off Burma Boycott
description: SINGAPORE  Southeast Asian countries have told the European Union that they will abandon high-level talks with the EU if it continues to press for Burma's exclusion on human rights grounds.

title: Butterflies, Chads, And History
description: One clear victor has emerged in the Florida ballot wars: the chad has beaten the butterfly. Al Gore's strategists, challenging George W. Bush's narrow lead, chose to demand a recount, where chads would be decisive, rather than appeal for a revote of the muddled election in Palm Beach County, home of the improperly designed butterfly ballot.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Matter of Dates And Disputes
description: Here are the main events that occurred yesterday in the battle for the presidency.

title: Guggenheim to Show Video Series on Early Days of AIDS
description: It is 1987 and Stashu Kybartas has his video camera trained on Danny Sbrochi. Danny's once handsome face is covered with lesions from Kaposi's sarcoma, an AIDS-related cancer, and swollen from chemotherapy. Danny revels in the good times -- lying on the beach sunbathing, then cruising for dates, even shooting cocaine and sharing the same needle with five friends -- though the result was AIDS.

title: BARAK  DECLARES EARLY ELECTIONS, IN SURPRISE MOVE
description: Pre-empting his opponents' initiative, Prime Minister Ehud Barak told the Israeli Parliament tonight that he was ready to face new elections and to let his first term in office collapse prematurely after 17 months.

title: Recipe: Quick Gumbo
description: Time: 1 hour, 15 minutes

title: The Gumbo Variations: To Each His Own
description: GUMBO should be as straightforward and approachable as its name. But something about the spicy Creole soup seems rigid and intimidating. Whenever we mentioned gumbo in a group of food lovers we heard cryptic warnings:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: No Escaping, Even at the Opera

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMCHE, MARGARITA
description: CAMCHE-Margarita. November 26, at age 66 after bravely battling cancer and a life of giving & loving. Beloved wife of Joel, mother of Leonor and Peter, grandmother of Danielle, sister of Jaime, Angel and Carmelo. Services Thursday 11:45 AM, visitation on Wednesday 6-9 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. CAMCHE-Margarita. The Entertainment Committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York extends its deepest sympathy to its longtime member, friend and accompanist Joel Camche on the death of his wife Margarita after a long illness, who will be greatly missed.

title: New Twists, Old Rivalry For Knicks and the Heat
description: The Knicks and the Miami Heat have been downgraded significantly this season. Patrick Ewing is in Seattle, living through a basketball nightmare. Alonzo Mourning is out for the season with a kidney ailment.

title: Soft Economic Data Send Nasdaq to a 52-Week Low
description: Technology stocks plunged yesterday, as investors used additional signs of a softening economy and confirmation from Vice President Al Gore that he intends to continue his fight for the presidency as excuses to sell shares.

title: Canada's No. 1 Book Retailer Gets a Hostile Takeover Bid
description: A leading Canadian deal maker, Gerald Schwartz, is offering $41 million in a hostile takeover bid for the country's largest book retailer, Chapters Inc. He hopes to merge it with the No. 2 company, Indigo Books Music and More, which is controlled by his wife, Heather Reisman.

title: AT&T FILLS A CORNER OFFICE
description: AT&T named David Dorman as its president, filling a post that had been vacant since John Zeglis left last year to become chief executive of AT&T Wireless. Mr. Dorman, 46, was chief executive of Concert, AT&T's venture with British Telecommunications. He will oversee the company's consumer and business services units, in addition to AT&T's network services group, international ventures and AT&T Labs. C. Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chairman, will continue to oversee the company's plan to split itself into four entities. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Suspended Animation Won't End
description: EVERYBODY is just hanging, waiting for their marching orders, all these Bushes and Gores, the Mussinas and Hamptons, mentally stuffing their belongings in hypothetical cardboard boxes, wondering whether they should keep that tatty old sweater or finally chuck it, the normal things folks brood about when a move is imminent.

title: Judge Blocks Questioning of Key Witnesses in Auction House Lawsuit
description: Expressing impatience with the pace of the criminal investigation of collusion between Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses, a federal judge in Manhattan yesterday nonetheless prohibited lawyers in a civil suit from questioning key figures in the government's four-year-old case. Questioning of subordinate figures can proceed, he ruled.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Thursday about a giveaway of MetroCards to drivers using the park-and-ride lot at Shea Stadium gave a misspelled name in some copies for the president of the sponsor, NYC & Company. She is Cristyne Lategano-Nicholas, not Christyne.

title: New Classroom Recruits
description: To the Editor:

title: Malcolm Bradbury, Author, Critic and Teacher, Dies at 68
description: Sir Malcolm Bradbury, the English author, critic, biographer and teacher known for his passionate support of British and American fiction, died yesterday in Norwich, England. He was 68 and lived in Norwich.

title: Nassau Officials Say a Fiscal Agreement Is Near
description: Facing a Thursday deadline to pass a long-term fiscal rescue plan, Nassau County officials emerged today from a two-hour meeting with the state board monitoring their efforts and said they had made progress toward a final deal.

title: The Man Behind, and in Front of, the Governor
description: When Gov. George W. Bush named Dick Cheney on Sunday to prepare the transition to the White House, he fit him into the role he had always had in mind for his running mate: running things.

title: POSSIBLE TRADE SANCTIONS
description: The United States and the European Union set in motion the World Trade Organization's process that might lead to the imposition of $4 billion in trade penalties on American goods. A three-judge panel will first examine the United States' tax benefits program for exporting companies to see if changes made recently comply with free-trade rules. If its report, which is to be ready in 90 days, finds the changes inadequate, a separate panel will decide the penalty within 60 days after that.

title: An East River Guggenheim
description: Like most port cities, New York was built from the waterfront in. Over time, the inland middle of Manhattan has obscured its aquatic edges, all the more so as Manhattan's role as a port facility has dwindled. But in a sense the city has begun to go down to the sea again. The plans for Brooklyn Bridge Park and Hudson River Park will redefine the waterfronts of Brooklyn and Manhattan, making them accessible to New Yorkers in a way they have never been before. And yesterday Mayor Rudolph Giuliani endorsed a proposal for what will surely be the centerpiece of New York's future waterline -- a new Guggenheim Museum designed by Frank O. Gehry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUXBAUM, JOAN
description: BUXBAUM-Joan. Former Hunter College professor. Beloved friend of Beryl, sister of Rhoda, aunt of Deborah and Jonathan, great-aunt of Maya, Isabelle, David and Omar. Services Thursday, Nov. 30 at 11AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: District Chief Reassigns Principal of Queens School Where 4 Were Molested
description: The principal of a Queens elementary school where four children were molested last week has been reassigned to a district office while officials investigate the attacks, Board of Education officials said yesterday.

title: A Trooper's Anguished and Unanswered Complaint
description: Even in print, the voice speaks with anguish and urgency.

title: Reckonings; Sins Of Emission
description: Sam drives a huge S.U.V., Pierre drives a tiny Citroen. Both agree that for the sake of the environment they must reduce their combined fuel consumption. But who should bear the burden?

title: Even Reluctant Allies Rush to Aid Gore
description: Senator Bob Kerrey has never had much affection for Vice President Al Gore and campaigned energetically in the primaries for his opponent, former Senator Bill Bradley. But he said it was his idea to travel to Tallahassee, Fla., last week to lambaste the Republicans and make the case for Mr. Gore.

title: Presidency May Hinge On the Florida Court Case
description: The Democrats' suit to contest the vote in Florida may have become the do-or-die battle in the legal war for the presidency, turning a Florida county court case into a decisive contest of legal strategies.

title: Growers Sue Ocean Spray, Seeking Possibility of Sale
description: Faced with mounting losses from sagging cranberry prices, a group of growers sued the Ocean Spray Cranberries cooperative yesterday in an attempt to force its board to explore selling the company.

title: Briefs Reflect Yawning Gap Between Campaigns' Views
description: Lawyers for Gov. George W. Bush told the United States Supreme Court today that their client has as much, if not more, at stake now in the appeal to be argued on Friday than he did last week when he asked the justices to intervene in the Florida vote-counting dispute.

title: Washington View: Barak Can Go for Broke
description: Rather than viewing the plan for Israeli elections as another hindrance to their stalled peacemaking, the Clinton administration believes that Prime Minister Ehud Barak may be so liberated from the tangle of domestic politics that he could choose to plunge back into negotiations with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Plummets by 5% On Economy and Election

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, REV. THOMAS J.
description: PHILLIPS-Rev. Thomas J. November 28, 2000. Beloved brother of Marjorie Phillips and the late Claire Phillips Rose, devoted uncle of 7 nieces and nephews. Former pastor of St. Peter's Church in Liberty, NY and St. John's Church in Beacon, NY. Friends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday and Friday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, December 2, 2000, 11 AM Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89 Street (between Madison and Park). Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: ISLES LOSE GOALIE AT CRITICAL TIME
description: The Islanders finally won a game Monday night, but it came at a cost.

title: A Cheeky Ambassador Of the British Scene
description: CENTRAL Park South has long been one of the sleepier dining addresses in Manhattan, and initially, Atlas looked as if it would fit right in. The restaurant, in a former dentist's office, seemed rich and handsome, but the food seemed as unfocused and generic as the name. Atlas was agreeable, polite and instantly forgettable. A year after its opening, it showed every sign of being a dead duck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAYLEN, JOYCE F.
description: BAYLEN-Joyce F. On Nov. 23, 2000 suddenly after a long illness at age 77. A lifelong Community, Social Activist & Health Educator who was part of the early Civil Rights, Women's and Peace Movements. She helped organize diverse community organizations during her fifty years of residence in Hollis and Rochdale Village in Queens, N.Y., most recently the older Women's League of Greater N.Y. and N.Y. State. Mrs. Baylen is survived by her husband of 50 years, Morris (Matt); sons Harris & David, daughter-in-law Stephanie, brother Peter F. Stone of Buchanan, MI. and cousin Marilyn Blake of Needham, Ma. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday, December 9th, 2:00PM at the L.I. Ethical Humanist Society, 38 Old Country Road, Garden City, New York. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, memorial contributions be made to the following: Older Women's League GNY, Box 1242, Ansonia Station, New York 10023, Southern Poverty Law Center, www.splcenter.org, Fellowship of Reconciliation, www.forusa.org.

title: I.B.M. Executive Accused of Insider Trading
description: An executive at I.B.M., Stephen J. Cowley, has been accused of trading on inside information on the basis of tapes made by his broker at Salomon Smith Barney that are said to capture him bragging about his knowledge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATKINS, MARJORIE M.
description: WATKINS-Marjorie M. Died peacefully at home on November 28, 2000 at age 79. Loving wife of Ted J., loving mother of Pamela K. Seligman, devoted mother-inlaw of Robert J. Seligman and cherished grandmother of Tiffany D. Seligman. Funeral, November 30, 11 AM, at Lester Memorial Home, 16 West Church Street, Jamesburg, New Jersey.

title: AMBEV ACQUIRES BREWER
description: AmBev of Brazil is in the final stages of acquiring the Uruguayan brewer Cerveceria y Malteria Paysandu for $47 million, giving the company control of almost half the Uruguayan beer market. AmBev, the world's fourth-largest brewer, is buying a 95.3 percent stake in Paysandu jointly with Eufra Holding, a Swiss unit of Oetker of Germany. Paysandu makes Nortena and Prinz beers and controls Fuente Matutina, a mineral water bottler. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TABACK, MICHAEL
description: TABACK-Michael. 83, of Tamarac, FL, passed away November 28, 2000. Survived by devoted wife, Sylvia. Cherished father to David (Kathy) Taback and Cheryl (Steven) Weinberg. Beloved brother to Benjamin and Alex Taback. Loving grandfather to Anne, Daniel, Lauren and Adam. Services Thursday, 10:30 AM, at Star of David Cemetery and Funeral Home, 954-722-9000.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-20

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KNORR CAPITAL PARTNER A.G., Frankfurt, and Value Management and Research A.G., also of Germany, jointly decided to abandon a planned merger after their shares fell by half in the eight weeks since the announcement. Knorr and VMR, both venture capital companies, said they would create several joint ventures instead.

title: Metro Business Briefs
description: G.E. SUES OVER SUPERFUND LAW General Electric Company filed a lawsuit yesterday asking that provisions of the federal Superfund toxic waste cleanup law be declared invalid. G.E. is arguing that the Superfund's provisions give the Environmental Protection Agency "uncontrolled authority to order intrusive remedial projects of unlimited scope and duration in nonemergency situations." The company is battling with environmentalists and regulators over the cleanup of the upper Hudson River, where the company discharged polycholorinated biphenyls decades ago. Environmentalists and the Pataki administration want the company to dredge the river, which could cost hundreds of millions of dollars. The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to make a decision on the dredging in the next few weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, NORMAN
description: WYMAN-Norman. On November 28, 2000. Beloved husband of Edith. Loving father of June Wyman and Susan Troxel and her husband Richard. Cherished grandfather of Sarah and Benjamin.

title: When Housing Is Tight
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RISES. The euro gained after reports on consumer confidence and durable goods orders fueled concern that the United States economy was slowing. In New York, the euro settled at 85.65 cents, up from 85.14 cents.

title: After Deaths, Federal Regulators Ask Company to Halt Sale of a New Bowel Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday asked the maker of Lotronex, a treatment for irritable bowel syndrome, to take the drug off pharmacy shelves after dozens of patients suffered serious side effects and at least three died.

title: PAUL ALLEN INVESTMENT FUND BUYS SPORTS RADIO CHAIN
description: Vulcan Ventures, the company that invests for Paul Allen, the billionaire co-founder of Microsoft, said yesterday that it would acquire One-On-One Sports, a chain of sports radio stations in Boston, New York and Los Angeles. Vulcan, which acquired the Sporting News in February, said it would rename the stations the Sporting News Radio Network. Vulcan is based in Bellevue, Wash., and mainly invests in technology companies.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS
