title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAYLEN, JOYCE
description: BAYLEN-Joyce. Dear, dear Joyce, a beloved friend to each of us, the heart of GNY-OWL. Our loss is without end. Greater N.Y. Chapter Older Women's League

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Vice President Al Gore's efforts to contest the presidential election in Florida referred incorrectly to another legal action in the state. A Leon County judge will hear a lawsuit by a Democrat who says that about 15,000 absentee ballots in Seminole County should be voided because elections officials improperly let Republicans correct registration information on many of them. The suit does not involve only 5,000 military absentee ballots and does not contend that the ballots should be voided because they lacked proper identification.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEDALE, DR. GLENDA S.
description: ROSEDALE-Dr. Glenda S. On November 9, 2000 in her native New York. A Summa Cum Laude graduate of Columbia University where she earned her BA, MA and Ph.D. She taught and did research at the same university. Many, many people, both friends and acquaintances, were charmed by her warmth & her sense of humor. Her interests lay in music, art and literature. She herself possessed brilliant talent in music-she played jazz piano-and had a remarkable sensitivity to language-This was shown in her editing the work of another and in her own writing. She should also be remembered for her perceptiveness about people and life in general. For information about services, please call Frank E. Campbell at 212-288-3500.

title: Where Patlican, Ezme and Etli Bamya Are Comfort Food
description: CIGAR bars, tofu ice cream stands and other fad restaurants have come and gone in the 13 years since Uskudar opened on the Upper East Side. Thirteen years can be an eternity in the restaurant business, especially when the economic downs and ups have buffeted places bigger and more imposing than Uskudar, a sliver of a Turkish restaurant that today is the very model of a successful neighborhood institution.

title: Plan for Use of Bioengineered Corn in Food Is Disputed
description: Hoping to avoid further product recalls linked to a bioengineered corn, representatives of food, agriculture and biotechnology industries urged the Environmental Protection Agency today to approve the corn temporarily for human consumption. But critics said such a move would bail out the corn's developer and the food companies at consumers' expense.

title: MSN and 'N Sync Are Joining Forces
description: The MSN Network unit of Microsoft is teaming up with 'N Sync, the popular ''boy band'' singing group, on an elaborate marketing campaign aimed at younger consumers.

title: Developers to Buy 9.2 Acres on East Side
description: A development group signed a contract yesterday to pay up to $680 million for the largest tract of undeveloped land remaining in Manhattan: 9.2 acres of waterfront property south of the United Nations, intended for a residential and commercial complex of more than five million square feet.

title: Say, What Vintage Is That Pepper?
description: PEPPER might be called the little black dress of Western cooking, but for a long time it's been a pretty shabby outfit. These days, American cooks are beginning to realize that pepper is a spice with many other style possibilities. Like chocolate or coffee, pepper comes in different varieties with specific flavors that reflect, among other things, climate, soil and other growing conditions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICOLI, HENRY, JR.
description: PICOLI-Henry, Jr. formerly of Old Brookville, NY. on November 21, 2000. Member of the N.Y.S.E. since 1946. Former partner Ziebarth, Geary & Co. Beloved husband of the late Frances W. ''Billie''. Loving father of Peter, Henry III, William and Pamela Marie. Dear grandfather of Andrew, Christen, Peter, William and Lydia and stepgrandchildren Ian and Emma. Dear brother of Doris McKeon and Robert C. Picoli. A Memorial service will be held Friday, December 1, 2000 at 11 am. St. John's of Lattingtown, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in Henry's name to St. John's of Lattingtown.

title: Mrs. Seuss Hears a Who, and Tells About It
description: THE widow Seuss sparkles like a bright new toy, even at 79. It is easy to see why a famed illustrator and wordplay man would have fallen for her. Strikingly pretty, brightly outfitted in Prada, her face smooth in what she freely admits was a lift, and an amusing turn of phrase.

title: White House Is Set to Meet With Bush and Gore Teams
description: The White House began treating both George W. Bush and Al Gore as unofficial presidents-elect today, saying it had offered to meet with both candidates' transition directors and had arranged to provide Governor Bush the same daily intelligence briefings that Mr. Gore receives as vice president.

title: Hugh Alexander, 83, a Scout For the Next Stars of Baseball
description: Hugh Alexander, who became a baseball scout at age 20 and went on to sign dozens of future major leaguers in a career that spanned six decades and countless miles on the back roads of America, died Saturday at a hospital in Bethany, Okla. He was 83.

title: DuPont Mexico Director Is Named to Run Pemex
description: President-elect Vicente Fox Quesada has named the director of DuPont Mexico to run and reshape Mexico's state-run oil monopoly, Pemex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, EUGENE
description: NEWMAN-Eugene. The members of the East Hill Synagogue of Englewood, NJ mourn the untimely death of its esteemed member, Eugene Newman. May his family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: DOCUMENTS ON RENAULT'S ROMANIAN UNIT SEIZED IN PARIS
description: Documents relating to the management of Automobile Dacia Pitesti S.A., the Romanian subsidiary of Renault S.A., were seized in a Paris suburb in October by a French court acting on behalf of an American shareholder of Dacia, Broadhurst Investment Ltd., Renault said yesterday. Renault bought a 73 percent stake in Dacia in September 1999, and Dacia's output, earnings and stock price have fallen sharply since then. Renault attributed the troubles to a recession and to consumers holding off buying until new models are introduced. Broadhurst, which holds 8.2 percent of Dacia; in recent years it has opposed many of Renault's decisions concerning Dacia and has accused it of mismanagement and withholding information.

title: Excerpts From Legal Brief Filed by Bush Campaign With Supreme Court
description: Following are excerpts from a brief that the Bush campaign filed today with the United States Supreme Court. Italicized portions show emphasis in the original.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday tracking legal challenges over Florida's presidential ballots referred incorrectly to the Bush campaign's appeal of a decision by the Federal District Court in Miami, which refused to stop manual recounts. The case remains active in the United States Court of Appeals in Atlanta. Only a request for an immediate halt of manual recounts was rejected on Nov. 17. On Monday, at the request of Bush campaign lawyers, the appeals court decided to postpone hearings until Dec. 5.

title: Qantas Orders 12 of Planned 'Superjumbos'
description: Airbus Industrie won its first orders from Qantas Airways Ltd. today, which included plans to buy 12 of Airbus's proposed A3XX ''superjumbo'' jetliners.

title: France Steps Down As Nascar President
description: For the first time in its 52-year history, Nascar's top executive is not a member of the France stock car racing dynasty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, FLORENCE
description: PERLMAN - Florence. Beloved wife of the late Alex. Loving mother of Leslie and Ronald and mother-in-law of Judy and Bonnie. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer, Joshua and Alex. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 11:30AM Wednesday.

title: Competing Strategies: Working Out a Schedule
description: With less than two weeks remaining to choose Florida's electors, legal teams from the two campaigns are debating how to proceed.

title: Holt's Margin Over Zimmer Seems to Grow Under Recount
description: With a full recount nearly complete in New Jersey's 12th Congressional District race, the Democratic incumbent, Rush Holt, appeared yesterday to be gaining even more ground on his Republican rival, Dick Zimmer, increasing his lead to well over 700 votes.

title: The Truth About a Hero's Death
description: Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who saved thousands of Hungarian Jews from the Nazis, vanished mysteriously in January 1945 on his way to the Soviet Army's headquarters outside Budapest. Now, after decades of official Soviet denials and lies about Wallenberg's death, a Russian official investigating the case has acknowledged that the heroic Swede was probably shot in 1947 while being held by the K.G.B. Aleksandr Yakovlev, chairman of the Kremlin commission investigating the case, reported this week that ''We do not doubt that he was shot in the Lubyanka prison.'' This important pronouncement should prompt President Vladimir Putin to issue a decree at long last acknowledging that Wallenberg was a victim of Stalin's repression.

title: F.B.I. to Dig for Tapes Discarded by Scientist in Spy Case
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has moved heavy equipment into a landfill outside Los Alamos, N.M., in search of the computer tapes on which Dr. Wen Ho Lee, the former nuclear scientist, has admitted to downloading weapons secrets.

title: Article 2000112992455081801 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Who Is Winning the Fight for America's Heart?; Touch-Screen Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: Softer Outlook for a Phone Offering
description: As Europe's phone companies grapple with mountains of debt and falling stock valuations, France Telecom said today that it was scaling back expectations from a sale of shares in its mobile phone unit, Orange, planned for early next year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAXIM, LESLIE M.
description: MAXIM-Leslie M. November 29, 1917-June 23, 1996. Remembering you on Thanksigiving, Your Birthday and Every Day. Your loving wife, Pearl

title: AES Ends Bidding for Chilean Company
description: The AES Corporation cut short a bidding war today over the second-largest power company in Chile, striking an agreement with the rival bidder to split up the Chilean company's assets.

title: Mets Will Adapt if Pitching Deals Falter
description: There are two premier free-agent starting pitchers this winter, and the Mets are negotiating with both of them. The Mets still believe they can land Mike Mussina, and they are prepared to pay Mike Hampton an annual salary of $14 million to $15 million.

title: Nanporo Journal; Turning Japanese: It Takes More Than a Passport
description: Windmills are hard to find in this farm town in northern Japan, but that hasn't stopped Arudoudebito Sugawara from seeking them out and tilting at them ever since he first arrived in this country 12 years ago.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Has anybody even been able to agree on the time of day?''

title: Hollywood-Style Contest To Spread the Wealth; Stars and Studios Go Online To Give Screenwriters a Chance
description: Ben Affleck said he and Matt Damon, who shared an Oscar for writing the 1997 film ''Good Will Hunting,'' kept hearing the same thing from aspiring filmmakers.

title: Downey's Brightening Prospects Turn Cloudy Again
description: Publicly and privately, a surprisingly large number of actors, directors, studio and television executives and talent agents have battled and are still battling drug and alcohol addiction. But few celebrities have so publicly suffered the torments and humiliation of addiction as Robert Downey Jr.

title: The Holiday Spirit
description: To the Editor:

title: In St.-Emilion, New Energy and Good Value
description: ST.-EMILION is easily the most beautiful of all the wine communities in the Bordeaux region. With its rolling hills and magnificent vistas, its medieval village and dramatic ruins, it is one of the few destinations, outside of the city of Bordeaux itself, that attracts tourists not interested in wine.

title: INDONESIA TO TAKE BACK BONDS
description: Indonesia's Parliament approved a plan to take back 10 trillion rupiah ($1.06 billion) of government bonds from the country's commercial banks in exchange for commercial loans it manages. Indonesia issued at least 600 trillion rupiah ($64 billion) of recapitalization bonds after the financial crisis of 1997 to shore up bank balance sheets and stimulate lending. The bonds have proved to be difficult to trade and the interest payments on them have strained the country's budget. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Excerpts From Legal Brief Submitted by Gore Campaign to Supreme Court
description: Following are excerpts from a brief that the Gore campaign filed today with the United States Supreme Court. Italicized portions show emphasis in the original.

title: Israel Heads Toward Elections
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel, desperately short of parliamentary allies, bowed to reality yesterday and agreed to new elections, likely to be held sometime next spring. That scrambles Israeli politics and diplomacy at a time when violent confrontations with the Palestinians persist. But it can open an opportunity for peace negotiations if the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, is wise and bold enough to seize it.

title: Metro Business Briefing; G.E. SUES OVER SUPERFUND LAW
description: General Electric Company filed a lawsuit yesterday asking that provisions of the federal Superfund toxic waste cleanup law be declared invalid. G.E. is arguing that the Superfund's provisions give the Environmental Protection Agency ''uncontrolled authority to order intrusive remedial projects of unlimited scope and duration in nonemergency situations.'' The company is battling with environmentalists and regulators over the cleanup of the upper Hudson River, where the company discharged polycholorinated biphenyls decades ago. Environmentalists and the Pataki administration want the company to dredge the river, which could cost hundreds of millions of dollars. The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to make a decision on the dredging in the next few weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, BARNETT (BUD).
description: MILLER-Barnett (Bud). Passed away November 27, 2000. Beloved husband of Shirley. His family and friends will deeply miss his intellect, and being a gentle man.

title: Management: Anticipating Welch on Welch in His New Book
description: For most of his two decades at the helm of the General Electric Company, John F. Welch Jr. has thought of himself as a teacher. One of his first acts as chief executive was to rebuild Crotonville, G.E.'s management training center at Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., into the West Point of his strategic and managerial revolution.

title: Who Is Winning the Fight for America's Heart?; December Surprise?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, PAULINE
description: FALK-Pauline. The Board of Directors and Staff of the New York Association for New Americans Inc. (NYANA) mourn the passing of Pauline Falk. Mrs. Falk was a founding member of NYANA and a member of its Board of Directors from 1949-91 when she was elected as an Honorary Member of the Board. We will remember her for her work with Jewish refugees and other displaced persons before and during World War II and, for more than half a century, her commitment to NYANA and its historic core mission of serving refugees in the New York area. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Michael Loeb, President Mark Handelman, Executive V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MESSING, AVROM
description: MESSING-Avrom. November 28, 1990. In loving memory. Caren, Harvey and Meredit

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, CAROL LESSACK.
description: HOWARD-Carol Lessack. On November 28, 2000. Loving mother of William and Esther, dear sister of Arthur Lessack, adoring grandmother of Benjamin Howard. Devoted aunt, cousin, friend and co-worker. Social worker for the New York City public schools. Service on Friday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to The American Museum of Natural History and the National Audubon Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, SALA
description: SCHLESINGER - Sala. Beloved wife of the late Walter Schlesinger. Loving aunt to Bernice and Dr. Richard Altman and Maxine and Dr. Joel Hirsch and great-aunt to Michael, Russell, Kenneth, Lisa, Darren, Jeremy, Justin, Olivia and Max and cousin to the Rynderman and Blazer families. She was charitable and dedicated to the Jewish community. Her wonderful spirit, love and devotion will be missed by all. Services Wednesday, November 29, 11 AM, Sutton Place Synagogue, 51 Street, NYC SCHLESINGER-Sala (Sara): Sutton Place Synagogue mourns the loss of our treasured trustee, Patrons Society Chair and generous benefactor. Through the Walter N. Schlesinger Memorial Fund, in memory of her late husband, she provided the community with many lectures and concerts. We will sorely miss her enthusiasm, intelligence and warmth. Sincere condolences to the loving family. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President SCHLESINGER - Sala. Beloved Board member & Guest of Honor to be missed by all of us. Sympathy to nephew, Dr. Joel Hirsch, nieces, Mrs. Bernice Altman, Mrs. Helen Vogel, and Mrs. Mildred Goldblatt, and other relatives. Palisades Gardens Foundation

title: IXL SETS MORE LAYOFFS
description: IXL Enterprises Inc., an e-commerce consulting firm, said it would dismiss 850 employees, or 36 percent of its workers, and close or sell its offices in Berlin; Hamburg, Germany; Denver; Los Angeles; Madrid; Sao Paulo, Brazil; and Tokyo. A spokesman said the Atlanta company would focus on 75 customers in the financial services, travel and consumer goods industries. IXL, which cut about 350 jobs in September, will have about 1,500 employees after the current cuts.

title: Honk if It's Too Loud Where You Work
description: Blame the fax machine. Edward F. Panos does. Constantly spitting out paper and beeping like a metronome gone mad, the contraption drove him to distraction. For that matter, so did an officemate's cell phone, which belted out the opening notes to Beethoven's Fifth every time it rang. Then there was the jangle of the office telephone, the whir of the printer, the chatter of the folks around him.

title: Jets' Ward Starts to Put Pieces Together
description: They played together for a year at Washington High School in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. They went to Northern Iowa University and played together on the Division I-AA team when the receiver was a freshman and the quarterback was a senior.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOODMAN, LAWRENCE
description: GOODMAN-Lawrence. 3/11/16 TO 11/29/90. We love you, we miss you and we still tell your jokes. Love, your whole Famdamily

title: WENDY'S CLOSES BUENOS AIRES STORES AND LAYS OFF 600
description: Wendy's International said yesterday that it would close the 18 money-losing company-owned stores it has in Buenos Aires, eliminate 600 jobs there and take a pretax charge of $17 million to $22 million, or 8 cents to 11 cents a share, in the fourth quarter. After the move, Wendy's will have no presence in Argentina, and all its stores outside North America will be franchisee-owned except for four in Guam. Wendy's also said it expected per-share earnings to grow 17 to 19 percent for the year, two to three percentage points faster than previously forecast.

title: Who Is Winning the Fight for America's Heart?; The Next Election

title: Recipe: Creole Gumbo
description: Adapted from "The Dooky Chase Cookbook" (Pelican Books, 1990)

title: DANA SAYS IT WILL SELL ITS AUTO PARTS BUSINESS IN EUROPE
description: The Dana Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell its Quinton Hazell replacement auto parts business in Europe to focus on engines and drivetrain systems. Based in Nuneaton, England, Quinton has 1,100 workers and 14 plants in nine countries and posted $275 million in sales of brake discs, shock absorbers, cooling components and steering and suspension parts last year. Dana has sold businesses with about $850 million in annual sales since April 1999.

title: A New Partner For Cranberries
description: POT roast is one of the simplest main dishes to cook, but it usually involves a fair amount of chopping onions, carrots, celery and other ingredients to add flavor. When it's made with cranberries, which need no prep work and are a natural companion for beef, the result is a robust, appealing and unusual pot roast.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: CUNY Names Dean for Research

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, JAMES S.
description: JONES-James S. Architect and sportsman, died at the age of 86 near his home in Gladstone, New Jersey. Jimmy Jones had his own architectural firm in Morristown, New Jersey for over forty years.He was a graduate of Yale University and the Yale School of Architecture. And he was a member of the American Institute of Architects. Jimmy Jones was involved in the hunting of hounds in New Jersey all his life. As a young man, he hunted with the Essex Fox Hounds, the Spring Valley Hounds and the Vernon Somerset Beagles. In 1950, he and a friend started the Tewksbury FootBassets which he then hunted for 35 years. He authored many books and articles on hounds and hunting and judged at numerous hound shows. Jimmy Jones was considered by many to be ''the dean of American foot hound hunters.'' Mr. Jones served in the Navy during World War II. Mr. Jones leaves a son, F. Macy Jones of Wenham, MA, and a daughter, Elizabeth J. Dennis of Santa Fe, NM. And he leaves four grandchildren, Patrick S. Jones, Jr. of Bernardsville, New Jersey, Mrs. Walker H. Jones and Mrs. Benjamin B. Haskell, both of Boston, MA and E. Briggs Jones of Wenham, MA and three great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Friday, December 8th at 11 A.M. in the St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Tewksbury Foot Bassets, P.O. Box 312, Far Hills, NJ 07931

title: Who Is Winning the Fight for America's Heart?; Checkoff on Form 1040

title: TV Series On Science Is Planned
description: National Geographic and the television production unit of The New York Times have agreed to collaborate on a weekly science program that will be shown on National Geographic's coming cable channel beginning in June.

title: New Jersey Argues That the U.S. Wrote the Book on Race Profiling
description: Weaving its way through the 91,000 pages of documents on racial profiling released by New Jersey officials is a largely overlooked thread in the national debate on race and crime -- although states like New Jersey have been the most egregious offenders, the textbook on singling out minority drivers was written by the federal government.

title: After Election Risk, Premier of Canada Reaps Big Rewards
description: For Jean Chretien, the victory in the national election on Monday provided a critical political respite, and a resounding personal vindication.

title: Devils vs. Rangers: Just Another Game?
description: The Devils either put on a good act or they are sincerely unconcerned about the first meeting of the season against the archrival Rangers. The Devils said after today's practice that the Rangers' visit to Continental Arena Wednesday night was only another game.

title: Rangers Are Interested, but Lindros Wants to Play for the Maple Leafs
description: No matter how much Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager, is interested, if Eric Lindros has his way, he will be playing in his hometown of Toronto.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Nuance, despite falling shares, remains upbeat about speech software.
description: AMID the current carnage in technology shares, Nuance Communications is one of the last great story stocks.

title: Recipe: Duck Gumbo
description: Adapted from Bayou

title: Donations May Be Sought To Send U.S. Arts Abroad
description: The United States government now spends less than a quarter of what it spent in 1993 to spread American culture abroad. Gone are government-sponsored performances by symphony orchestras and by giant opera companies that once entranced audiences abroad.

title: NOMURA WILL ACQUIRE RECORD-KEEPING BUSINESS IN WALES
description: The Nomura Securities Company agreed yesterday to acquire Hyder Business Services Ltd., a record-keeping business owned by an American-controlled utility company in Wales, for $:100 million ($142 million). The unit's parent, Hyder P.L.C., is co-owned by the Southern Company and the PPL Corporation. Hyder Business Services handles paperwork and runs call centers for government agencies. Hyder is also selling its water company, Dwr Cymru, and analysts speculate that Nomura may bid for it as well.

title: CONTESTING THE VOTE
description: The Transition

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS PLUNGES. Natural gas dropped on expectations that milder weather will reduce demand for the fuel. In New York, natural gas for December delivery fell 35.2 cents, to $6.016 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: WEYERHAEUSER BID FOR WILLAMETTE SEEN TURNING HOSTILE
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, a forest products concern, is expected to begin a $5.4 billion hostile takeover offer today for Willamette Industries, executives close to the company said. The move comes two weeks after the board of Willamette, based in Portland, Ore., rejected a similar offer from Weyerhaeuser. According to the executives, Weyerhaeuser, based in Federal Way, Wash., will make a tender offer for Willamette's 112.5 million shares, valuing each at $48. The company would also assume $1.7 billion in debt. Weyerhaeuser's offer of $48 a share -- no different from its rejected offer -- is below Willamette's current price, which rose $1 yesterday, to $49.75. It represented a 38 percent premium over Willamette's closing stock price on Nov. 10, the last trading day before the bid was disclosed. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Two More Men Are Charged In a Mob Killing in 1988
description: One day in October 1988, the police found the body of 28-year-old Victor Filocamo stuffed inside the trunk of a white B.M.W. parked on 73rd Street in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

title: Three Olsens Make Wayne Hills Hard to Beat
description: At this time of year Chris Olsen Sr., one of New Jersey's most successful high school football coaches, can usually be found on the Wayne Hills High School sideline with a broad smile on his face.

title: A Strong Start For ECAC Teams
description: Five programs that finished last season well behind the leaders are setting the pace in the ECAC this fall.

title: Van Horn Is Progressing Well
description: Nets forward Keith Van Horn was cleared today to begin light running after having X-rays taken on his broken left leg.

title: Broadcom to Acquire An Israeli Chip Maker
description: The Broadcom Corporation, the maker of computer chips for cable modems and digital set-top boxes, announced today that it was acquiring VisionTech Ltd., an Israeli maker of chips that allow television users to personalize their own video recording. The stock transaction, valued at about $770 million, has been approved by both boards and is expected to close in 60 days.

title: Business Travel; Smile. You may be on a speed-trap camera in a long forgotten town.
description: RIGHT off the bat, let us stipulate that it is bad to drive above the speed limit, and it is very, very bad to run a red light.

title: This Just In, If Anyone Cares
description: ABC News called Florida for George W. Bush one more time on Sunday night at about the same time that NBC was deciding that it was not worth interrupting the movie ''Titanic'' for live coverage of the official certification of Mr. Bush as the winner of Florida's 25 electoral votes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULDER, JOHN E.
description: GOULDER-John E. Of Watertown, MA., November 26. Beloved son of Alice (Iseman) and the late James H. Goulder of Scarsdale, NY. Brother of James H. Jr and his wife Ingrid of St. James, NY, and Alison P. Goulder of Newton, MA. Loving uncle of Deborah and David Steingesser. Also survived by the families of Joseph Iseman and Robert Sackheim. Services are private. Contributions in his name may be made to to the Adirondack Conservancy, P.O. Box 65 Keene Valley, NY 12943, or the Longy School of Music Scholarship and Community Outreach Program, 1 Follen St. Cambridge, MA 02138 or the Chiefs Fund, Camp Lincoln, 16 Prospect Street, Mount Kisco, New York 10549.

title: Metro Business Briefing; GLOBAL REACH FROM TIMES SQUARE
description: EasyEverything.com, a British chain, opened what is believed to be the world's largest Internet cafe yesterday in Times Square. The cafe, on West 42nd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, will be open around the clock and serve food and have more than 800 personal computers that allow users to connect to the Internet for a fee. The cafe is easyEverything's first in the United States. A second cafe is scheduled to open in Union Square next year, company officials said. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Manifest Destiny
description: PBS is giving reality television another go -- in true public television style, of course.

title: Drawing the Line
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Laundering Of Money Seen as 'Easy'
description: A Congressional inquiry has found that it is ''relatively easy'' for foreigners to hide their identities and form shell companies here that can launder money through American banks.

title: Hollywood? Ho-Hum
description: For the second year in a row, a very funny show about Hollywood is struggling to find an audience.

title: Food Stuff: Dinner at Home, With a Libretto on the Side
description: Two young women have taken "singing for your supper" to new heights. Meredith Greenberg and Leora Perlman (her father is the violinist Itzhak Perlman), conservatory-trained opera singers, met in 1994 while performing in a music festival at Chautauqua, N.Y., and soon discovered that they shared an interest not only in opera but also in cooking. The result was Divas' Delite, their new catering company based on the Upper West Side.

title: A Chef Elaborates In Delicious Detail
description: THERE is a single flaw shared by most chefs' cookbooks: very few of them actually make you want to cook. The recipes and photos leave you in awe, as if you're staring at sculpture in a museum. The food is untouchable, and how to translate it into your own life is unfathomable.

title: The Radish As Big as the Ritz
description: It is the size of a tennis ball and shaped like a turnip, but is neither of those. Nor is it a fruit, though you could be fooled once you slice into it and find dazzling magenta flesh, rimmed in white.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on April 13 reported the failure of a civil suit by the family of Dr. Sam Sheppard, which sought to establish his innocence in connection with the 1954 murder of his wife in Cleveland. The 1954 case, involving accusations of adultery and playboy debauchery, transfixed the nation. In 1966 the Supreme Court granted Dr. Sheppard a second trial because of pretrial publicity, and he was acquitted. The article last April said an abiding mystery was why prosecutors continued to fight so hard 46 years later against reversal of the original verdict.

title: Jury Deadlocks In Brick Trial, Then Continues
description: A Manhattan jury deadlocked yesterday and was told by a judge to continue deliberating in the attempted-murder trial of Paris Drake, who is accused of smashing a brick into the head of a woman on a busy Manhattan street corner last year.

title: Who Is Winning the Fight for America's Heart?; Gore Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: LOSS WIDENS AT GAME MAKER
description: Eidos, Britain's leading maker of electronic games, blamed delays in the introduction of the PlayStation 2 console by Sony for widening losses that sent Eidos's battered stock down 11 percent, to 177 pence ($2.47). Net losses in the fiscal second quarter ended Sept. 30 widened to $:60.2 million ($89.1 million) from $:12.8 million ($18.2 million) in the period a year earlier.

title: HIGHER SALES AT GROCERY CHAIN
description: Tesco, the largest supermarket chain in Britain, said its sales rose 5.1 percent in the third quarter at stores open at least a year. Tesco shares, which have risen 57 percent the last year, rose 3.2 percent to close at 274.5 pence ($3.95). Alan Cowell

title: What Israel Offered
description: To the Editor:

title: Columnist Biography: Randy Kennedy
description: Randy Kennedy is a Metro reporter who has written about transportation for the past year and who began writing the Tunnel Vision column, about life in and around the subway, in November.

description: Does ABC have any regrets about saturating the airwaves with ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' and possibly diluting its impact?

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a development project called Queens West, on the East River, misspelled the surname of the chief executive of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, who has proposed a biotechnology center for the site. He is Dr. Harold Varmus, not Varmis.

title: Fifty years of Coca-Cola TV commercials will enter the halls of the Library of Congress.
description: FIFTY years of television advertising by an iconic consumer brand is being donated to the Library of Congress.

title: Patricia Yeo
description: BEFORE coming home to New York two years ago, I was working in San Francisco and missed all those local specialties New Yorkers take for granted. Bagels, pastrami and potato knishes just don't travel well.

title: Greater Role Seen for Corporations Aiding City Schools
description: If there is any doubt that Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy is serious about enlisting corporations as active partners in New York City's public schools, Fredda L. Plesser is eager to dispel it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KADIN, BRACHA
description: KADIN-Bracha. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member Esther Lewittes upon the loss of her mother. We express profound condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on April 13 reported the failure of a civil suit by the family of Dr. Sam Sheppard, which sought to establish his innocence in connection with the 1954 murder of his wife in Cleveland. The 1954 case, involving accusations of adultery and playboy debauchery, transfixed the nation. In 1966 the Supreme Court granted Dr. Sheppard a second trial because of pretrial publicity, and he was acquitted. The article last April said an abiding mystery was why prosecutors continued to fight so hard 46 years later against reversal of the original verdict.

title: Labels Shouldn't Make Quarterbacks Run-Shy
description: When Andy Reid and the Philadelphia Eagles selected Donovan McNabb with the No. 2 pick in the 1999 draft, Reid said that McNabb was chosen because he exhibited poise and leadership at Syracuse and because he had wowed him with those traits in one-on-one interviews. Reid, then in his first year as the Eagles' coach, said Philadelphia also chose McNabb because he could throw any kind of pass you wanted -- in the pocket or on the run, the deep out, the quick hitch, the fly, the post, the curl.

title: Citing Child Labor, U.S. Bans Apparel From Mongolia Plant
description: The Customs Service has banned clothing imports from a Chinese-owned factory in Mongolia after finding that the company employs underage workers and forces them to stay at their posts for marathon shifts, the government agency said today.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, EMILY LAMB TUCKERMAN.
description: ALLEN-Emily Lamb Tuckerman. 83, of Damariscotta and Round Pond, ME, formerly of Ipswich, November 23, of complications following automobile accident. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Henry Freeman Allen, formerly of Boston and Ipswich and daughter of the late Eliot Tuckerman, Esq., and Mary Ludlow Fowler Tuckerman of New York and New Jersey. Mother of, and survived by, Emily Tuckerman Allen, Jr. of Melrose, FL, Rosamond Warren Allen of Cambridge, MA., and Round Pond, ME, and Dr. Freeman Towne Allen of Centerport, NY. A memorial service will be held Saturday, December 2, at 11 AM in the Ascension Memorial Church, 31 County Rd., Ipswich, MA. For information contact the Whittier-Porter Funeral Home of Ipswich. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts in her name may be made to National Braille Press, 88 St. Stephen St., Boston, MA., and the Massachusetts Indian Assoc., 245 Rockland Rd., Carlisle, MA 01741.

title: Commercial Real Estate; New Office Building in Newark Near Completion
description: A three-story customer service center that real estate executives say is the first new office property to be built in Newark in more than a decade is nearing completion on the fringe of the city's central business district.

title: ORACLE HIRES CLINTON AIDE
description: Joe Lockhart, the former White House press secretary, joined Oracle as senior vice president. Mr. Lockhart, who resigned from the Clinton White House in October, will work on refining Oracle's business strategy and describing its work to the public, company officials said. He will report to Lawrence J. Ellison, Oracle's chairman. ''This is an incredible opportunity for me to work with one of the most exciting companies in the world,'' Mr. Lockhart said, ''and with one of the most visionary business leaders of our time.'' Mr. Lockhart became President Clinton's press secretary in October 1998, just as the House of Representatives began its impeachment proceedings of the president. Mr. Lockhart will split his time between Washington and Silicon Valley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTHUR, SAMUEL
description: ARTHUR-Samuel, 93. CPA. On November 28 in Greenwich, CT. Beloved husband of the late Edith Mones Arthur. Devoted father of Michael Arthur of Los Angeles, Calif., Jane Kramer of Rye, New York, and Stephen Arthur of Aspen, Colorado. Grandfather of Dr. Susan Danziger, Emily Kramer, Kate and Leslie Arthur. Greatgrandfather of Emma Danziger. Brother of Anne Solomon.

title: A Stephen King Online Horror Tale Turns Into a Mini-Disaster
description: Publishers one, authors nothing.

description: An article on April 13 reported the failure of a civil suit by the family of Dr. Sam Sheppard, which sought to establish his innocence in connection with the 1954 murder of his wife in Cleveland. The 1954 case, involving accusations of adultery and playboy debauchery, transfixed the nation. In 1966 the Supreme Court granted Dr. Sheppard a second trial because of pretrial publicity, and he was acquitted. The article last April said an abiding mystery was why prosecutors continued to fight so hard 46 years later against reversal of the original verdict.

description: New Zinc, Bar and All

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, ANN F.
description: AMES-Ann F. Of New York, NY. Died on November 23, 2000 at the age of 96. Mrs. Ames was the wife of the late Irving M. Ames. She is survived by her daughter Susan Ames. Mrs. Ames was awarded a Juris Doctor degree from Cleveland-Marshall College of Law at Cleveland State University, a member of the Class of 1928, where contributions in the memory of Mrs. Ames will be accepted. Funeral services will be private.

title: Board Faults Instructions for and Training of Small-Jet Pilots
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that the instructions and training given to pilots of high-flying jets, including business jets like the Learjet that lost cabin air pressure and crashed last year, killing the golfer Payne Stewart, were misleading and dangerous.

title: Student Hurt After Hanging From Noose In Classroom
description: An unusual accident involving a noose that was hanging in a Manhattan art classroom for students to draw left a 17-year-old in critical condition yesterday, the police said.

title: Slow-Cooked Rice, and Make It Snappy
description: THE question is, will risotto travel well within the steamy confines of plastic takeout containers? And the answer is, whether you travel by foot, bus, subway or car, and whether your trip takes minutes or hours, risotto travels beautifully. And that is a very good thing for Risotteria, a new restaurant in Greenwich Village.

title: Tentative Pact Would Raise Pay Of Laundry Workers About 20%
description: The union representing 4,000 workers at commercial laundries serving New York City's hotels, restaurants and hospitals reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday that provides raises of about 20 percent over three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, DAVID
description: STEINBERG-David. Of Washington, D.C. On Sunday, November 26, 2000, at his residence. The cherished son of Renita and the late Myron (Michael) Steinberg. He was a graduate of the American University. Mr. Steinberg owned a TV-production company and was co-founder and President of The State Theatre in Falls Church, VA. He is survived by many loving friends. Services will be held at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, Thurs, November 30th, 1PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, SYLVIA
description: KRAMER-Sylvia. On November 27, 2000. Beloved mother of Adrianne Crames, Rochelle Cleary, Ina Strauss, Lawrence Kramer, grandmother of eleven, great grandmother of six, dear sister of Arlene Cherney, sister-in-law of Jack Cherney, and Roslyn Leader. May her memory be for a blessing. Funeral service today 10 A.M. at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: I Stop Class for Large Spiders
description: My teaching assistant took notes today. She observed from 8:35 to 9. I spoke to 44 people -- mostly children and the teachers and parents that entered the room. I was interrupted 35 times. Teachers came in to speak with me, there were phone calls from the office, announcements on the loud speaker, kids interrupting to ask me questions. I gave 18 positive reinforcement comments: good job, great homework, thanks for sharpening the pencils, etc. No wonder I go through cough drops so quickly!

title: Amazon.com Is Using the Web to Block Unions' Effort to Organize
description: Amazon.com has come out swinging in its fight to stop a new unionization drive, telling employees that unions are a greedy, for-profit business and advising managers on ways to detect when a group of workers is trying to back a union.

title: $330 Million in Ford Grants Will Aid Foreign Students
description: In its largest grant ever, the Ford Foundation will announce today a 10-year $330 million fellowship program to support graduate education for hundreds of disadvantaged college graduates in 20 countries.

title: Khmer Rouge, In Retirement, Needn't Fear A Trial Soon
description: They are just old duffers now, sitting out the long quiet days, helping around the house a bit and complaining about their aches and pains. But there is something a little different about this group of Cambodian retirees: they never talk about the past.

title: Dinner at Home, With a Libretto on the Side
description: Two young women have taken ''singing for your supper'' to new heights. Meredith Greenberg and Leora Perlman (her father is the violinist Itzhak Perlman), conservatory-trained opera singers, met in 1994 while performing in a music festival at Chautauqua, N.Y., and soon discovered that they shared an interest not only in opera but also in cooking. The result was Divas' Delite, their new catering company based on the Upper West Side.

title: Who Is Winning the Fight for America's Heart?; A Teacher's Worry
