title: Guinness Looking To Use One Agency
description: The Guinness unit of Diageo is seeking to consolidate the advertising account for the Guinness stout brand around the world by naming one of two agencies on the Guinness roster to handle that task. The brand's worldwide spending is estimated at more than $300 million, about half in advertising and the rest in promotions, sponsorships and public relations.

title: Henry Gonzalez, 84; Served 37 Years in House
description: Former Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, a pugnacious and partisan Texas Democrat who used his perch as the chairman of the House banking committee to champion public housing and tighter controls over the savings and loan industry, died today in a San Antonio Hospital. He was 84 and lived in San Antonio.

title: An Election Puzzle, Still in Search of a Solution; Voting Rights, Violated
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; If voters could select the machines, there would be a president-elect by now.
description: FOR three weeks, the question has been nagging Americans: how can the most technologically advanced nation on earth have such antiquated, unreliable, confusing voting technology? How can the outcome of the presidential race dangle with the chads left on 1975-style punch cards?

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWAREI.B.M. APPOINTS PRIVACY CHIEF I.B.M. yesterday became the latest company to appoint a chief privacy officer to deal with the ethical, regulatory and public relations issues that have made privacy a corporate minefield. Harriet Pearson, a lawyer and engineer who led I.B.M. 's public affairs operations, was named to the newly created post; the chairman, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., wrote in a memo to employees that Ms. Pearson "has been a passionate and expert voice within our company and our industry" on the issue. Other companies, including Microsoft, have taken similar action, but the move by the industry giant I.B.M. is "an important sign to the business community," Ms. Pearson said, that "the time for corporations to have a C.P.O. is clearly now." John Schwartz (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Weyerhaeuser begins hostile tender offer for Willamette, and the opinions start rolling in.
description: THE Weyerhaeuser Company began a hostile $5.3 billion tender offer for Willamette Industries yesterday, ratcheting up the pressure on Willamette to come to the negotiating table.

title: An Election Puzzle, Still in Search of a Solution; Declare Florida a Tie
description: To the Editor:

title: For All the Tall Ships, A Single Virtual Port
description: HOW majestic. How inspiring. But how in the world do the planet's tall ships survive when they aren't having their parades-of-the-decade?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYDEN, CHARLES W., M.D.
description: HAYDEN-Charles W., M.D. Of Glen Cove, L.I. On November 29, 2000. Age 87. Beloved husband of Joan R. father of Eric W. (Tove), Brian C. (Lyn) and Carol J. Grandfather of Alex, Marielle and Jessica. Service and interment private. Inquiries Dodge-Thomas Funeral Home. Donations may be made to YMCA of Glen Cove or NSUH at Glen Cove.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RFS HOTEL INVESTORS, Memphis, said it would terminate all leases and management contracts with the Hilton Hotels Corporation, Beverly Hills, and replace them with an alliance with MeriStar Hotels and Resorts, Washington, the largest hotel management company in the United States. RFS will pay Hilton about $60 million.

title: Mainstream Sites Serve as Portals to Hate
description: EARLIER this month, in a cramped airport lounge in San Jose, Calif., two seemingly unrelated parties sat down to talk about hate.

title: With Economy Brighter, Brazil's Leader Faces Wage Demands
description: Two years after Brazil signed a $41.5 billion emergency rescue package with international lending agencies, the economy has largely returned to health. But salaries continue to lag, and President Fernando Henrique Cardoso is facing demands that the gap be closed with big increases in the minimum wage and military pay.

title: Troopers' Union Defends Stops Linked to Profiling
description: The president of the New Jersey troopers' union defended today the aggressive drug-interdiction stops the state police started making more than a decade ago -- even if, he said, race was sometimes one reason a trooper made a stop.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Vice President Al Gore's efforts to contest the election in Florida referred incorrectly to another legal action there. A Leon County judge will hear a lawsuit by a Democrat who says that about 15,000 absentee ballots in Seminole County should be voided because officials improperly let Republicans correct registration information. The suit does not involve only 5,000 military absentee ballots and does not contend that the ballots lacked proper identification.

title: Clinton, as Senator-Elect, Follows Freshman Tradition
description: Hewing to freshman tradition, Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton today ducked into the office of Senator Robert C. Byrd, the eminence grise of the Senate, for a dollop of advice on her new job and a quick lesson on Senate rules.

title: 100 Digital Cameras Give Novices a Chance to Play
description: BAJU WIJONO was once, like many people, a stranger to digital cameras. Mr. Wijono, a painter and sculptor in Brooklyn, was used to the rhythm of conventional film cameras, which make you wait a day or two or longer to see the images you've captured.

title: Verizon Abandons NorthPoint Deal
description: Less than four months after Verizon Communications agreed to acquire control of the NorthPoint Communications Group and barely a week after NorthPoint restated its latest financial results, Verizon pulled out of the deal yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARL, HAROLD
description: PEARL-Harold. Of Chicago, IL. World famous theater organist and icon of the Big Band Era, died on November 23, 2000 at age 92. Mr. Pearl is the son of the late Emil and Selma Perl. He is survived by two nephews; Gregory Pearl of Glenview, IL. and Steven Pearl, and family of Hinsdale, IL. For information Drake & Son Funeral Home, 773-561-6874.

title: Despite Fishing, Lobsters Thrive in Waters Off New England
description: BOSTON, Nov. 29  The lobster population is thriving along the ocean floor off New England, baffling scientists who point to the large numbers of lobsters that are being caught.

title: Metro Matters; Toontown Is Warning Your Town
description: FILM buffs may still remember a rueful line from ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit,'' the 1988 film set in the Los Angeles of the 1940's: ''Who needs a car in L.A.? We got the best public transportation in the world.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOROWITZ, MORRIS
description: MOROWITZ-Morris. The YIVO Institute for Jewish Research mourns the passing of Morris Morowitz, lifelong member of the Workmen's Circle, and father of Jacob Morowitz, devoted member of the YIVO National Board of Directors, Co-Chair of the National Program Committee & President of the Chicago YIVO Society. May his memory be for a blessing. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Dr. Carl J. Rheins, Exec. Dir.

title: Gore Cannot Afford to Wait For Vote Count, Lawyers Say
description: Lawyers for Vice President Al Gore said today that their only chance for victory in his contest of the Florida election would be shattered if they have to wait until Saturday to begin counting disputed ballots, and they began an appeal to the Florida Supreme Court to do the counting itself, immediately.

title: Backup's Value Rises On Field, and Online
description: How shall we measure the true value of a modern National Football League quarterback?

title: Diving to Scale a Summit
description: A scientific expedition to explore Atlantis Massif, a mountain in the mid-Atlantic range, poses some special challenges because its summit is about 3,000 feet below the surface of the ocean.

title: Flexible Displays for Electronic Ink
description: SCIENTISTS in Cambridge, Mass., have demonstrated what they say is the world's first flexible display using electronic ink, bringing engineers one step closer to creating a changeable display screen that is nearly as portable, lightweight and easy to read as paper.

title: Staten Island Man Is Charged in Death of 4-Year-Old Girl
description: A 19-year-old Staten Island man was charged yesterday with the murder of his girlfriend's 4-year-old daughter, the authorities said.

title: Survey Finds Subway Riders' Biggest Gripe Is Crowding
description: A study asking riders about conditions at some of the busiest subway stations gave the lowest rating to the station under the Citicorp building in Manhattan and the highest to the stop serving Yankee Stadium.

title: PROFITS UP AT MARCONI
description: The telecommunications equipment maker Marconi P.L.C. said its first-half operating profits rose 7 percent, to $:320 million ($448 million), mainly driven by sharp growth in its optical networking unit. Total sales rose 26 percent, to $:3.2 billion ($4.48 billion). Marconi was optimistic about its prospects for growth the rest of the fiscal year, which ends March 30, because of a heavy flow of new orders for fiber optic multiplexing and other products. It plans to spin off its British fiber optic network in February.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBROD, DOROTHY OTTO
description: WEISBROD-Dorothy Otto, 69, died Tuesday, November 28, 2000 peacefully in her home in Watchung, NJ by the side of her beloved husband and children. Many, many friends and acquaintances were both taken and charmed by Dorothy's exuberant sense of life, style and original wit. Dorothy's passion and talent were rooted in fashion and the store she ran for 36 years -the Fashion Gallery in Springfield, NJ. In 1963, she was one of the first women in the area to start her own business, which she ran successfully up until her passing. She will also be remembered for her perceptiveness about people and life in general. She is survived by her husband Ferdinand G. Weisbrod, MD, her children Wayne Otto of Watchung, N.J. and Valerie Otto of New York, N.Y., four grandsons and one brother, Fred Bohrman of Mendham, N.J. Funeral Services will be held on Saturday, December 2, 2000 at 10:00 AM at the Higgins Home for Funerals, 752 Mountain Blvd., Watchung, NJ with Rev. Ronald Miller officiating followed by interment at Hollywood Memorial Park Cemetery, Union. Visitation Friday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to the Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund, Weil Cornell Medical College, 1300 York Ave., New York, NY 10021.

title: Health Sites on the Internet Aren't Creating Amateur Doctors
description: When it comes to the Web and health, there are some habits that people just cannot break. A study by the Pew Internet and American Life Project found that 91 percent of Americans who turn to the Web for health information do so only in response to specific illnesses -- which is also the time they tend to seek information in the real world. Just 13 percent have looked for advice and information that might help them stay healthy. Similarly, women are much more likely than men to go to the Web for health information.

title: Clients Fatten Rolodex Of Giuliani's Best Friend; Private Sector Prizes Ex-Adviser's Help
description: For years, Peter J. Powers was the calm to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's storm, the shy boyhood friend who grew up to govern alongside the mayor and become, quietly, the second most powerful man in City Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKS, BLANTON S.
description: PARKS-Blanton S. Of Oyster Bay, New York, died with peace and dignity, at age 90, on November 26th, 2000. Services are private. She will be loved & remembered always by her three children: Melinda Parks Conrad of Wilton, CT., Nicholas R. Parks of Laurel Hollow, New York, and Thomas W. Parks, MD. of San Jose, CA. She had eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild. She is the wife of the late New York OB/ GYN Dr. Thomas Jefferson Parks.

title: France's Top Leaders at Odds Over Presidential Election Timing
description: For three years now, the conservative Gaullist president, Jacques Chirac, and the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, have mostly handled their relationship with a polite coolness, aware that French voters disapprove of squabbling between the two leaders.

title: Rescue Plan For Nassau Is Approved
description: After a frantic day of argument and confusion over the size of a proposed tax increase, Nassau County officials agreed tonight on a fiscal rescue plan that allows one of the nation's wealthiest counties to avert financial ruin and -- at least for now -- prevent a state takeover of its day-to-day operations.

title: Subway Etiquette
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ALTERA GROUP, San Jose, Calif., named John Daane chief executive and president, replacing Rodney Smith, who remains chairman. Mr. Daane had been executive vice president at LSI Logic Corp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARCHER, ELIZABETH
description: ARCHER-Elizabeth. On November 28, at her residence, North Greenbush, NY. Beloved daughter of Morton Archer of Green Acres, Fla., and the late Minna Archer. Sister of Lewis Archer of Teaneck, NJ. She also leaves two nephews, a niece, and many caring and devoted friends. Services 9 AM, December 3, at the Levine Memorial Chapel, 649 Washington Ave., Albany, NY. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Contributions to Funds for Animals, Inc., 200 W. 57th St., NY, NY 10019.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the beginning of the holiday shopping season misspelled the name of a mall in Illinois that reported increased foot traffic compared with the same day a year earlier. It is Gurnee Mills Mall, not Gurney.

title: Article 2000113092921757851 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: F.A.A. Plans Airline Lottery To Cut Delays At La Guardia
description: Delays at La Guardia Airport are now so bad that some airplanes spend longer waiting to take off than was scheduled for the whole flight, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: Foster Wheeler to Establish Base in Bermuda
description: Another United States company announced yesterday that it was moving its nominal headquarters to Bermuda, which does not have a corporate income tax, while keeping its operating headquarters in the United States.

title: Sales at Gap and Limited Spur Fears of Slow Season
description: Two giants of specialty retailing reported disappointing November sales yesterday. The news played to investor fears of a slowing consumer market and could set off a new round of profit-crushing price cuts during the critical holiday season.

title: Thomas Curtiss, 85, Critic for Paris Tribune
description: Thomas Quinn Curtiss, for many years a reviewer of theater and film for The International Herald Tribune, died on Monday in Poissy, France, outside of Paris. He was 85.

title: Fox and NBC May Drop Poll Group Over Fiasco
description: Officials of Fox News and NBC News announced yesterday that they would not renew membership in a service that conducts voter surveys for all the networks unless they were satisfied that the errors that led them to mistakenly project the winner of the presidential race in Florida on Nov. 7 could not happen again.

title: 'Black & Blue' Big All Over
description: Everything about the new Backstreet Boys album, ''Black & Blue,'' was poised for greatness. In what is turning into another banner year for the music business, the Backstreet Boys chose to release their album last week so it would be on record-store display racks on one of the biggest shopping weekends of the year.

title: Rangers Lose Messier and a Chance to End the Devils' Streak
description: The Devils and the Rangers were tied with a goal each early in the third period tonight when Mark Messier, who has inflicted more damage on the Devils than perhaps any other player, left the game with an injury to his left knee. It was just the kind of break the Devils needed, the opening that sparked them to a four-goal splurge and a 5-2 victory over the Rangers at Continental Arena.

title: Florida Governor Backs Lawmakers' Efforts to Bypass Courts and Select Electors
description: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida said today that it would be an ''act of courage'' for his state's Legislature to convene a special session to name Florida's 25 electors if Vice President Al Gore persisted in contesting the the state's presidential balloting.

title: Who Needs It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLER, ALEXANDER
description: COLER-Alexander. The American Technion Society (ATS) expresses its profound sorrow at the loss of Alexander Coler, a devoted supporter. As Technion Guardians, he and his wife, Tina, reached the highest level of commitment to the Technion, the ATS and Israel. He supported the Coler California Visitors Center on the campus, the Dorothy & Martin Kellner Amphitheater and numerous faculty recruitment efforts. A Life Trustee of the ATS Board of Regents, and an Honorary Life Member of the Technion International Board of Governors, Mr. Coler was honored with a fellowship from the Technion, and the Einstein Award from the ATS. As President of Coler Construction and Investment Company and C-D Investment Co., he presided over construction of the Los Angeles Airport Hilton, the Anaheim Hilton Hotel and Towers, and many other major projects. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Tina Coler and the entire Coler family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Lawrence S. Jackier, President Irving A. Shepard, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom Executive Vice President William Litvak, President, Southern California Chapter Edith Fischer, Chairman Southern California Chapter Diane Siegel, Director, Western Region

title: Article 2000113092944615629 -- No Title
description: November 30, 2000

title: Corrections
description: A front-page contents entry yesterday for an article about relative percentages of black and white Floridians in counties that use punch-card balloting, which is more prone to error than other systems, misstated the rate at which blacks live in those counties. Sixty-four percent of the state's black voters live in counties that used punch cards. But blacks do not make up 64 percent of the voters in such counties.

title: Shine the Light on Albany
description: New York's State Assembly startled even seasoned observers of Albany's strange political culture in May by staging an open revolt against Speaker Sheldon Silver. The revolt failed, but the rancorous scene left its mark, not only on Mr. Silver, the Democrat who runs the Assembly, but also on Joseph Bruno, Mr. Silver's Republican colleague who runs the State Senate. The legislators' main complaint was that Mr. Silver, along with Mr. Bruno and Gov. George Pataki, maintains a stranglehold on lawmaking in New York State. Members have little more than cheerleading rights -- a simple task for which they are rewarded by the legislative leadership with stipends, more staff, bigger offices and benefits for their district.

title: A Film Score Odyssey Down a Quirky Country Road
description: In the forthcoming movie ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?,'' by the brothers Ethan and Joel Coen, George Clooney plays Everett Ulysses McGill, one of three 1930's Mississippi chain-gang convicts. The prisoners escape their rock-breaking roadwork and embark on a picaresque journey toward a treasure whose location McGill claims to know, a journey that, the opening credits indicate, is based on ''The Odyssey'' by Homer. The movie's broad humor makes one wonder if the surname of the Homer involved might be Simpson.

title: An Election Puzzle, Still in Search of a Solution; Gore Should Give Up
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rangers Stumble, but Go Down Snarling
description: This exciting and combative hockey game unfolded last night in a series of well-defined and significant scenes, some of them brutal and some of them beautiful. Those who know and love hockey will understand.

title: Alan S. Emory, 78, Washington Journalist
description: Alan S. Emory, one of the longest-serving journalists in Washington and correspondent for one of the smallest papers to maintain its own bureau there, died on Monday at his Falls Church, Va., home. He was 78.

title: South Africa to Ask for International Gem Certification
description: South Africa plans to ask all nations on Friday to back an international certification system for gems, saying it is concerned not only that diamonds are fueling civil wars among other Africans but also that adverse publicity and calls for boycotts will hurt its own diamond-mining industry.

title: Middle-Aged Kicker Returns to the Fray
description: The call interrupted a business meeting in which Eddie Murray was making a presentation to a new customer. It was around 4 in the afternoon, on Monday, Nov. 6, in a Detroit suburb. ''Mr. Murray,'' he was informed, ''your wife is on the phone.''

title: What the House and Senate Could Do, or Not Do, in Picking the President
description: When Congress meets in early January to count the electoral votes for president, the House will be controlled by Republicans and the Senate almost certainly by Democrats, with the vice president and his running mate still in their jobs.

title: Bagging the Holidays, Street by Street
description: TECHNICALLY, I'm not a grinch. I love the holidays, but I loathe the shopping. I'd give magazine subscriptions to everyone on my list if I hadn't already done so on their birthdays. This year, I found an unlikely solution: Grand Central Terminal.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Shop Online? No, Thanks

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Police Corruption Charges Reopen Wounds in Oakland
description: On his first day as mayor here, Jerry Brown, the former California governor, swore to make reducing Oakland's notorious crime rate a top priority. To prove his point, within three months, he had forced the popular police chief to resign and was pushing an aggressive approach to policing that would brook no tolerance for even petty crimes.

title: Enough Glittering Stars to Illuminate the Night
description: The City of Light becomes the City of a Zillion Lights in winter. The French are far less obsessed about Christmas than their Anglo-Saxon neighbors across the channel, but they do put up a few creches around the city, and they do love their lights.

title: Tse & Tse Broadens Its Base With Ornaments for Christmas
description: Tse & Tse, the firm of the French designers Catherine Levy and Sigolene Prebois, is best known for porcelain tableware in distorted classic shapes. Their work is adored throughout Europe, but only slowly becoming known in the United States, where their paper-bag light garlands, below left, have sold for years. This Christmas, Tse & Tse has glass-and-iron Christmas ornaments, above ($16 each), which join their laser-cut vellum cards ($4.50) available in red, yellow and white. The perforated cards can be used as ornaments or as table decorations, below right. Both are in New York at Shi, which also stocks Tse & Tse's serving bowls, chargers, porcelain igloos and five nesting lacquer bowls. ''People pluck things out of our inventory and don't realize they are all from these same two minds,'' said Laurie McLendon, owner of Shi; 233 Elizabeth Street; (212) 334-4330.

title: Horrors Behind Rebel Lines in Sierra Leone
description: The villagers crept out of the bush on a recent morning, and although the soil here is among Africa's richest, some arrived with hollow cheeks and shrunken limbs.

title: Article 2000113091510933511 -- No Title
description: E-COMMERCE REPORT

title: Qantas Says New Jets Are Key to Growth
description: With its $4.6 billion agreement to buy new airplanes, Qantas Airways, Australia's largest airline, tried this week to lock in its position as an industry leader in a market with some of the best growth potential in the world.

title: Corporate Capital Spending Is Slowing Broadly
description: For the last decade, even as the United States economy has soared, corporate profit has paled next to the boom in companies' spending on new computers and software, industrial machinery and buildings. With the help of bank loans, bonds and most of the time, a willing stock market, companies since 1991 have bought almost $9 trillion worth of equipment, lifting productivity and sustaining the longest economic expansion in American history.

title: A Few Chips Save Many Steps for Today's Surveyors
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON, Thomas Jefferson and Abraham Lincoln all worked at one time as surveyors, helping to map thousands of uncharted acres in the land they would one day lead.

title: AT HOME WITH/Elizabeth Franklin; Decorators' Report Card: The Good, the Bad, the Dirt
description: INTERIOR design is notorious for its divas and spoiled, exacting patrons. So no surprise that an ambitious new Zagat-like guide and Web site called The Franklin Report has come along to rate more than 1,100 of New York's home-service providers. It is also no surprise, given some of the alarming egos involved, that a tsunami of response -- and a flurry of threatened lawsuits -- greeted the occasionally withering reviews of architects, decorators, upholsterers and contractors when Elizabeth Franklin, the founder of the report, sent them draft copies in September.

title: John Hancock Told to Pay Pension Fund
description: A federal judge has ordered John Hancock Financial Services to pay millions of dollars in damages to a Unisys pension plan after finding that Hancock, the big Boston insurer, used some of the retirement money for its own benefit without regard to the pension plan's rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKON, FRANCES
description: ELKON-Frances. Of Palm Beach and New York. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Spinoza of Boston and S. Max Elkon of New York. Devoted and loving mother of Marilyn Weinberg and Francine Friedlander. Loving mother-in-law of Robert Weinberg and Ralph Friedlander. Cherished grandmother of Eileen Toulouse, Debra Leberman, Vicki Reynolds, and Vivien Konsker. Fond great grandmother of Stacey and Scott Hesse, Laura and Melissa Reynolds, Joshua Konsker and Brendan and Monique Toulouse. Private family services were held.

title: After 2 Deadlocks, Brick-Attack Jury Delivers Mixed Verdict
description: After struggling for three days to reach a verdict, a Manhattan jury yesterday cleared a panhandler of attempted murder but found him guilty of first-degree assault for smashing a young Texas woman over the head with a brick last November in Midtown.

title: Appreciating Female Authors
description: An invitation to attend a benefit cocktail reception tonight honoring Edith Wharton suggested that it might be useful to examine once again whether serious female novelists were still relative strangers in the American literary canon, greeted generally with a customary frost when greatness is discussed. Or has that changed?

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about briefs in the United States Supreme Court on Florida's vote-count dispute misspelled the name of the law firm of Theodore B. Olson, who represents Gov. George W. Bush. It is Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, not Givson.

title: Greenland Is Pampered But Ponders Cutting Free
description: In this land without trees, lumber stores sell sheets of plywood stamped ''Canada.'' And although Canada lies just 200 miles to the west, the plywood comes here through Denmark, the colonial power 2,000 miles to the east.

title: A Battle Over Whether Florida Court Interpreted the Law or Wrote It
description: The Supreme Court battle between the Bush and Gore campaigns centers on a bitter dispute over whether the Florida Supreme Court overstepped its bounds when it extended recount deadlines and postponed certification of the election.

title: Give Aristide a Chance
description: Haiti had a presidential election last Sunday, and both the so-called opposition and official foreign observers, including the American delegation, stayed away. The opposition parties absented themselves because, knowing that Jean-Bertrand Aristide would win by a very large margin, they hoped to discredit his victory. The United States claimed to be disturbed by irregularities in vote counting during legislative elections last May. But disregarding the obvious paradox -- American officials scolding Haitians for irregularities in vote-counting -- this claim makes no sense.

title: INSIDE
description: Active Hunt for Looted Art

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, CAROL LESSACK
description: HOWARD-Carol Lessack. On November 28, 2000. Loving mother of William and Esther, dear sister of Arthur Lessack, adoring grandmother of Benjamin Howard. Devoted aunt, cousin, friend and co-worker. Social worker for the New York City public schools. Service on Friday, 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to The American Museum of Natural History and the National Audubon Society.

title: Shuttle to Lift Off Tonight for Space Station
description: The space shuttle Endeavour is to lift off Thursday night on a mission to add powerful new solar-power wings to the international space station.

title: Who Needs It?
description: To the Editor:

title: CADBURY TO TAKE A CHARGE FOR ABSORBING ACQUISITIONS
description: Cadbury Schweppes said yesterday that it would take a charge of $:50 million ($71 million) to $:55 million ($78 million) this year and a similar amount next year to cover the cost of integrating recent acquisitions into the company, including Snapple juices and iced teas. Cadbury said it might spend another $:3 billion ($4.3 billion) on acquisitions. The company, whose products include Dr Pepper and 7Up, said it was still negotiating to acquire the Orangina brand from Pernod Ricard. Cadbury is based in London.

title: Long Trail Awinding
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR
description: Modern Design Auction

title: Balkan Gangs Stepping Up Violence, Dutch Say
description: Balkan gangs that specialize in smuggling immigrants, drugs and weapons have chosen Amsterdam as an operations center and are becoming increasingly violent, Dutch prosecutors say.

title: Museums Accept Stronger Role in Search for Looted Art
description: Associations representing American art museums have reached an agreement with a presidential Holocaust commission that will require museums to take on broad new responsibilities in combing their collections for art that was looted by the Nazis.

title: Leaf in the Wind With Unswerving Vision
description: ''I was born dead,'' declares Gordon Parks, in an HBO documentary about his life. Then the doctor's assistant dunked the baby into a bucket of ice water. ''I began to holler, and I've been hollering every since.''

title: Better Light Bulbs, and Other Bright Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDSMAN, EDWARD, 87
description: LANDSMAN-Edward, 87. Beloved husband of the late Pearl, devoted father of Robert, Alton and fatherin-law of Patricia Tinto, adored grandfather of Perry and Andrew. Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, N.J., 11AM today. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Temple Shalom, 259 Richards Avenue, Norwalk, CT. 06850.

title: Firms in Bidding War for Midtown Space
description: The decision by the brokerage firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to move out of its headquarters in the 51-story skyscraper at 277 Park Avenue has touched off a bidding war by space-starved corporations in Midtown.

title: A Thumbs Down for Web Phones
description: IT'S probably not surprising to learn that people who use cell phones to gain access to the Web find the experience less than gratifying.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHER, JOAN E.
description: FISHER-Joan E. A memorial service for Joan E. Fisher of Cross River, New York, will be held on December 1, 2000, at 11:30 AM, at St. Matthews Church in Bedford, New York. Friends and family are most welcomed to attend

title: An Election Puzzle, Still in Search of a Solution; Already the Winner?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNTER, DAVID R.
description: HUNTER-David R. Died November 24th, 2000 after a long illness. A social worker by training and an activist by inclination, he was a lifelong partisan of freedom and democracy. Widely recognized as the leader of progressive philanthropy both in his years with the Stern Fund, The Ottinger Foundation and other individual funders and then into his non-retirement, he championed many of the social economic and philanthropic organizations that have worked to make this nation live up to its promise. He was a true democrat and a great American. Our condolences to his beloved wife Barbara, stepsons Steven and Daniel and grandchildren Alexandra and Jason. Please send contributions in his honor to your favorite charity. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Friends of David R. Hunter

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENSEN, WILLIAM CARL
description: JENSEN-William Carl. April 23, 1936 to November 23, 2000. Retired N.Y.C. Transit Police Dept. Predeceased by wife, Diane. Leaves sons: Michael David, and William Charles. Brother: Robert Kai, wife Miriam. Nephews: Kevin & Brian. Mother-in-law: Florence Wise. Sister-in-law: Valerie. Niece: Cindy, husband Tim, children, Shanna, Briane and Jesse. Nephew: Alan, wife Doris, children, Kristin, Nicole & Jessica. Niece: Karen, husband Roger, children, Stephen & Christopher. Niece: Susan, husband Eddie. Dear friend: Michael Strada. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in dad's name to: St. Judes Childrens Research Hospital, 910 Blackford Street, Chattanooga, Tenn, 37403, with return address.

title: Strangers in a Strange Workplace
description: When Procter & Gamble decided to transfer 1,000 employees here, it was the biggest such move for Geneva, which has been campaigning hard to attract companies. Many tales of hardship later, the continuing relocation has pointed up some unforeseen pitfalls of such corporate moves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, ANN F.
description: AMES-Ann F. Of New York, NY. Died on November 23, 2000 at the age of 96. Mrs. Ames was the wife of the late Irving M. Ames. She is survived by her daughter Susan Ames. Mrs. Ames was awarded a Juris Doctor degree from Cleveland-Marshall College of Law at Cleveland State University, a member of the Class of 1928, where contributions in the memory of Mrs. Ames will be accepted. Funeral services will be private.

title: CHIP-MAKING DEVICE PROMISES EFFICIENCIES
description: Applied Materials Inc. introduced its Swift ion implanter, a machine that the company said can make faster semiconductor chips that use less power. Applied Materials said the new implanter, when combined with its existing products, completes a two-system method of ion implantation, a manufacturing process that enables electrical current to flow through silicon wafers. Previously, the company said, chip manufacturers required three types of ion implant tools.

title: LEHMAN OFFERS TO BUY BACK TROUBLED BONDS
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings is offering to buy back, at prices above the market but below face value, a series of euro-denominated bonds it sold for CP Kelco, a chemical manufacturer it controls. The market value of the bonds fell by half last week when Kelco announced worse-than-expected results. Lehman sold 225 million euros ($191 million) of 10-year bonds for Kelco on Sept. 28. Lehman is now making a market in the bonds, which sold last week at around $70 per $100 of face value, by offering to buy at $80 and sell at $82 per $100, said Julian Entwistle, head of the firm's European high-yield debt business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOW, PAULINE ENGEL
description: LEBOW-Pauline Engel. Died on November 27, 2000. Beloved wife of Hy (d. 1970), mother of Barbara and Ken, grandmother and greatgrandmother.

title: Conner Wants Cup in New York
description: Dennis Conner said yesterday that if he was successful in winning the America's Cup for a record fifth time off Auckland, New Zealand, in 2003, the subsequent cup defense could be based in New York.

title: GRANADA'S PROFIT FALLS
description: As it invests in digital television and Internet sites to compete with rivals, Granada Media P.L.C., the biggest broadcaster in Britain's Independent Television network, said its earnings in fiscal 2000 slumped 45 percent despite an 8.4 percent increase in advertising sales. Granada said net income fell to $:261 million ($371 million) from $:475 million ($672.9 million) one year earlier. Alan Cowell

title: Recalling the Civilized Voice Of a Critic, Vincent Canby
description: Below a movie screen -- flickering with images from films like ''The 400 Blows'' and ''Monty Python and the Holy Grail'' -- friends and associates of Vincent Canby delivered their reviews of the life and long career of the former film and drama critic for The New York Times. Mr. Canby died of cancer on Oct. 15 at age 76.

title: Taking Holidays Into Your Own Hands
description: MY idea of party decorating is fast and loose. For this year's holiday shindig I envisioned a snow-white flokati rug under the table and on top a video monitor, showing a Yule log, rotating on a lazy susan.

title: RUSSIAN ALUMINUM SALES
description: Russian Aluminum, one of the world's largest aluminum producers, said it would begin selling directly to local buyers in Asia next year, bypassing global metals traders. The company controls most of Russia's aluminum industry. Sabrina Tavernise

title: COUNCIL APPROVES A LONG-TERM PLAN FOR CITY GARBAGE
description: After years of planning and politicking, New York City took its first formal step yesterday into a future after the Fresh Kills Landfill, when the City Council overwhelmingly approved a long-term plan to deal with the city's daily mountain of refuse through at least the opening decades of the new century.

title: An Election Puzzle, Still in Search of a Solution; Defend Your Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Luxlook Web site shows off its links to 11 top designers.
description: IN fashion, image is everything. So how does a luxury fashion start-up create a buzz for itself in the increasingly crowded field of e-commerce sites? Luxlook.com, which peddles accessories for some of the top names in fashion, like Valentino and Versace, is letting its ties to an array of megawatt designers speak for itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, JOSEPH
description: RUBIN-Joseph. The Yeshiva University family and the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary Board of Trustees are saddened by the passing of a longtime friend-a dynamic leader, generous supporter, and champion of the YU High Schools. He and his beloved wife, Rosalind, are High School Fellows (Bonim). We extend our heartfelt condolences to Rosalind; children, Arleen Rubin (and Jeffrey Klores) and Barry (and Michelle) Rubin; sister, Sylvia Zharnest; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Judah Feinerman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: Yes, Democracy Is Imperfect, Even in Those Places That Never Heard of Chads
description: In India, portable polling stations are carried into the desert on the backs of camels. Others are hauled through forests and across rivers as the world's largest democracy organizes elections for more than 600 million voters.

title: Bosnia's Rebirth
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISCIO, JOHN CARMINE FRANCIS
description: LISCIO-John Carmine Francis of Upper Montclair, NJ. On November 29, 2000. Husband of Frances (Pelzman) Liscio. Father of Laura Brooke and Gregory Luke. Son of Armand and Josephine Liscio. Brother of Jeanette Kamciyan. Uncle of Ani, Armeni and Antony. Funeral from the Hugh M. Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park Street, Montclair, NJ on Saturday at 9:00 AM. Then to St. Cassian's Church, Upper Montclair where at 10AM a mass of Christian burial will be offered. Visiting hours from 2-4 and 7-9PM on Friday. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Fordham Prep Scholarship Fund, c/o Father Joseph Parks, Fordham Prep, East Fordham Road, Bronx, NY 10458

title: Ruling That Kept Suits Apart Is Appealed
description: Lawyers for Gov. George W. Bush argued today that two lawsuits contesting the results of the presidential election in Florida should be combined because ''there is substantial risk that the two courts may enter contradictory orders concerning the winner of the statewide vote.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAIMAN, MIRIAM S. (NEE SHOLNA).
description: NAIMAN-Miriam S. (nee Sholna). ''A woman of courage''. Of Boca Raton, FL on Wednesday, Nov. 29, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Irving A. Naiman. Devoted mother of Jason Naiman and his wife Lisa of Portland, OR and Anita Yarossi & her husband Paul of Ringwood, NJ. Dear sister of the late Barry Stuart. Cherished grandmother of Mathew, Sam and Lilly. Loving aunt of Steven Stuart. Services 1:30PM Friday, December 1, 2000 at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fairlawn, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to the Ringwood Ambulance Corps or Holocaust Museum, Washington, DC.

title: No Headline
description: GOVERNOR WEIGHS IN -- Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida said he would be willing to sign legislation naming the state's 25 electors. PAGE A27

title: Raising Millions More for Separate Transitions
description: The endless election has spawned an endless thirst for soft money.

title: HOLIDAY CALENDAR
description: A Winter Walk

title: Metro Business Briefing; BANK GRANT FOR BROOKLYN
description: Fleet bank has selected Brooklyn as one of four Northeastern communities that will receive an economic development grant, officials said yesterday. The $750,000 award will be used to help attract and stabilize businesses in Fort Greene, Bedford-Stuyvesant and Clinton Hill and will provide merchants and entrepreneurs with technical assistance, said Rena DeSisto, a Fleet spokeswoman. The grant is to be administered by Fulton First, which includes the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce and three community groups. The other communities receiving grants are Buffalo, New Haven and Lowell, Mass., Ms. DeSisto said. Terry Pristin

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Adding Artichokes to Your List

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHENCK, GARRET
description: SCHENCK-Garret. Of Boston, November 13, 2000, age 68. Prominent Boston insurance executive; graduate of Deerfield Academy, Williams College and University of Virginia Law School. Survived by his wife, Sue Becket (Williams); three sons, Hilbert van Nydeck, II, Christopher Forest, and Garret, Jr.; a brother, Hilbert van Nydeck Schenck, Jr; three grandchildren. Memorial services were held yesterday. Contributions in Garret's memory may be sent to: Garret Schenck Foundation for Cancer Research, P.O. Box 1310, Boston, MA. 02205.

title: A New Judge Is Welcomed For Top Court In Albany
description: While Florida legislators met today to decide whether to undo the work of the state's highest court, New York legislators met to praise theirs and to confirm its newest member with an elaborate welcome.

title: In Flurry of TV Interviews, Gore Talks of Being Caught Between Winning and Losing
description: Until last week, giant pumpkins adorned the front stoop of the vice president's residence here. A whiff of Halloween lingered in the air. But after Thanksgiving, the pumpkins were removed, and the facade of the 19th-century Queen Anne-style home is now bare, between its seasonal decorations.

title: Essay; The Telltale Heart
description: Stipulate, as the lawyers say, that the U.S. Supreme Court hands down a decision early next week that will be accepted by most Americans as the final word about who won the presidency. Arguendo, let's assume it's George W. Bush.

title: For a Child, a Safe Haven Can Be a Picture Book
description: ''The roots of a child's ability to cope and thrive, regardless of circumstance,'' Fred Rogers, of the television program ''Mister Rogers' Neighborhood,'' once said, ''lie in that child's having had at least a small, safe place (an apartment? a room? a lap?) in which, in the companionship of a loving person, that child could discover that he or she was lovable and capable of loving in return.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, REV. THOMAS J.
description: PHILLIPS-Rev. Thomas J. November 28, 2000. Beloved brother of Marjorie Phillips and the late Claire Phillips Rose, devoted uncle of 7 nieces and nephews. Former pastor of St. Peter's Church in Liberty, NY and St. John's Church in Beacon, NY. Friends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday and Friday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, December 2, 2000, 11 AM Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89 Street (between Madison and Park). Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: VIRGIN AIRWAYS TO BEGIN TORONTO-LONDON FLIGHTS
description: Virgin Atlantic Airways will begin flying between Toronto and Gatwick Airport near London next year, the company said yesterday. The new flights will compete with Air Canada and charter carriers like Royal Aviation and Canada 3000 on a route with 1.3 million round trips a year. Virgin recently ordered 5 new 747-400 jets, increasing its fleet of jumbo jets to 24, primarily to expand service in North America. Singapore Airlines owns 49 percent of Virgin.

title: Doctor Gets 20 Years to Life For the Murder of His Wife
description: A Manhattan judge sentenced a plastic surgeon convicted of murder to 20 years to life in prison yesterday, saying that he used his elite background and medical knowledge in dismembering his wife, squeezing her body into a duffle bag and dumping it from an airplane.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about arguments to a committee of the Florida Legislature in favor of a special session to choose electors misstated the given name of a lawyer who testified. He is John Yoo, not Robert.

title: Hasbro Consolidates Another Assignment
description: For the second time in less than a week, Hasbro Inc. in Pawtucket, R.I., has consolidated brand advertising in the United States, this time for its games business, with billings estimated at $70 million to $80 million for products like Monopoly, Scrabble, Risk and Clue.

title: Strindberg, Influenced by Freudian Sleep
description: August Strindberg may not have had the snooze alarm in mind when he wrote ''A Dream Play'' in 1901, but maybe Robert Wilson did when he undertook to design and direct it. The thought was the first thing that occurred to me the morning after seeing the show at the Howard Gilman Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where it runs through Sunday.

title: Barnes & Noble and Gemstar End Talks on Possible Merger
description: Barnes & Noble and Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc. called off talks about a possible merger yesterday, ending a week of reports about the odd-couple flirtation between the giant bookstore chain and a company best known for its on-screen television guides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRAN, MORTIMER LESLIE
description: CURRAN-Mortimer Leslie. Died at his home in Palm Beach, Florida, on November 20, 2000. He is survived by his loving wife, Mary Estelle, and a son, Mortimer Finlay Curran. The family funeral service was private.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The dollar rose against the yen on expectations that growth in the United States will continue to outpace that in other major economies. In New York, the dollar settled at 111.08 yen, up from 110.16 on Tuesday.

title: An Election Puzzle, Still in Search of a Solution; Fix the System
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Who Have It All
description: To the Editor:

title: Virtual Driving With a License for Mayhem
description: I DO not have a driver's license, and if my recent performance on virtual streets tips the karmic scales in the real world, I should not have one.

title: Sprewell Delivers An Angry Message
description: It was clear on Tuesday that Latrell Sprewell did not care who was missing from the Knicks-Miami Heat rivalry. So what if Patrick Ewing and Alonzo Mourning were not playing? He expected high intensity from both teams last night, roaring, boisterous fans at Madison Square Garden. Facing Miami for the first time this season was huge, and he thought his teammates would feel the same way.

title: Bagging the Holidays, Street by Street
description: SHALL we skip the mandatory wordy intro to the journalist's shopping excursions? Move right past the jaunty-but-ironic seasonal tone? Bypass the retail sales forecasts and salient quotes from market experts? Why not cut to the secular heart of Christmas: What did you get me? Uh, sorry: What do you really want?

title: An Election Puzzle, Still in Search of a Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Breed; Games That Look Like Movies, or Movies Masquerading as Games
description: LINES too long at the local cineplex? Game developers say they are hoping that video gamers will turn to a breed of new computer games that look like movies but play like interactive adventures. Don't know where to start? Consider this list of computer games that seem as though they were dreamed up in video arcades but finished up in movie studios. Many of these games are designed to play on a variety of machines, including the handheld GameBoy Color, but only those game formats that deliver the most cinematic play are noted.

title: A Battle in Court, in the Polls and in Presidential Imagery
description: The presidential election entered its fourth week yesterday with no end in sight. Here is a summary of the day's events:

title: Woods and Finchem Begin Process to Resolve Differences
description: An amicable meeting on Monday between Tiger Woods and Tim Finchem, the commissioner of the PGA Tour, has increased the chances that their differences will be resolved.

title: Article 2000113090318469610 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Trickster's Time
description: In his remarkable new book, ''Trickster Makes This World,'' Lewis Hyde shows us that many cultures know -- by different names -- a rebellious, god-like figure that brings about fundamental change. He is called Hermes in ancient Greece, Coyote among the Indians of the American plains and Monkey in the Buddhist world.

title: An Election Puzzle, Still in Search of a Solution; Not His to Concede
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDESMAN, LUCILLE
description: FELDESMAN-Lucille, my beloved irreplaceable wife, and my best friend for 56 years. Blessed by physical and inner beauty, self effacing, giving of herself to all who touched her life, rich of character, unassuming. She and I bonded a relationship of matchless deep love, and unsurpassed mutual trust. Walter

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURZ, ALIX J.
description: KURZ-Alix J. On November 27, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Paul Helmut and loving mother of the late Josephine and Douglas. Funeral services will be held on Friday, 9:00 AM at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory can be made to the American Cancer Society. For further information contact John Krtil Funeral Home, 212-744-3084

title: SUPERCONDUCTING NAVAL MOTORS
description: American Superconductor and the ship building division of Litton Industries said yesterday that they would collaborate to develop electric motors for commercial and naval ships made from superconducting wire. The companies contend that ceramic-based superconducting materials, which lose their resistance to electric current when cooled to low temperatures, can be made into motors that are one-fifth the size and one-third the weight of today's copper-wire motors. Such designs, which could be ready for sea trials as early as 2003, also promise greater fuel efficiency. Barnaby J. Feder

title: Parisians Turn to Le Web to Put Art on Their Walls
description: Despite the city's clever stores, Parisians sometimes resort to the Internet for Christmas shopping. The London-based Internet site www.eyestorm.com sells limited editions by contemporary artists from Robert Longo to Damien Hirst (orders must be placed by Dec. 19 to reach the States by Christmas). At left is a C-print of ''Pissenlits'' (22 inches by 34 inches, $300) signed by the Belgian artist Michel Francois. The site also has prints by photographers like Alioune Ba of Mali and the Magnum agency, among others, from $20 to $16,000. For those dedicated to the full Christmas shopping experience, the first Eyestorm gallery is at n.o.m.a.d.e., 8 rue Sainte Anastase by appointment; 011-33-1-42-72-23-88.

title: I.B.M. APPOINTS PRIVACY CHIEF
description: I.B.M. yesterday became the latest company to appoint a chief privacy officer to deal with the ethical, regulatory and public relations issues that have made privacy a corporate minefield. Harriet Pearson, a lawyer and engineer who led I.B.M.'s public affairs operations, was named to the newly created post; the chairman, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., wrote in a memo to employees that Ms. Pearson ''has been a passionate and expert voice within our company and our industry'' on the issue. Other companies, including Microsoft, have taken similar action, but the move by the industry giant I.B.M. is ''an important sign to the business community,'' Ms. Pearson said, that ''the time for corporations to have a C.P.O. is clearly now.'' John Schwartz

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: FINNING TO BUY HEWDEN STUART FOR $458 MILLION AND DEBT
description: Finning International, a Canadian distributor of construction equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Hewden Stuart for $:322 million ($458 million), or $:1.15 ($1.64) a share. Finning will also assume $:68 million ($96 million) of Hewden's debt. Hewden rents cranes and other equipment in Britain. The company has struggled recently, and it replaced its chief executive last month after a sharp falloff in profits in the first half of the year.

title: Malakhov Out For the Season
description: The Rangers said today that defenseman Vladimir Malakhov would have season-ending knee surgery Thursday.

title: Cooler Ties Wont Keep Castro From Inauguration of Mexican
description: HAVANA, Nov. 29 — Days after taking a gibe at Mexico that underscored the tension in Cuba's ties with its once-strongest ally in Latin America, Fidel Castro is still set to attend Vicente Fox Quesada's inauguration as Mexico's new president.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: The Urge to Speak

title: Tonight's N.F.L. Matchup
description: Detroit (8-4) at Minnesota (10-2)

title: Using Sites to Find Shrinking Bargains
description: I AM trying to think of a neutral way to describe my husband's reaction after he learned recently that I didn't consider MP3 players appropriate holiday gifts for two of our daughters, ages 11 and 9.

title: Another Bump in a Rocky Road For Colombia and Venezuela
description: When Venezuela played host to a group of Colombian rebels last week, the overture touched off a nasty dispute between the two countries. But today they said their leaders would meet on Friday at the inauguration of Mexico's new president, and try to resolve the matter.

title: Magician Emerges From Icy Stunt
description: After nearly 62 hours trapped inside an ice cage of his own devising, a wan and weak David Blaine emerged last night in front of a live television audience and several thousand screaming fans in Times Square.

title: 20 Fingers, 1 Composer; 10 Fingers, 2 Composers
description: Opposite poles of the pianist's art occupied Carnegie Hall on Monday and Tuesday. First there were Daniel Barenboim and Radu Lupu playing a program of four-handed Schubert; second, an evening of Liszt and Albeniz with Mr. Barenboim alone. Schubert's F minor Fantasy and C major Sonata asked for, indeed required, simplicity. Liszt-Albeniz on Tuesday celebrated all things complicated.

title: Self-Destructing E-Mail Offers Additional Security
description: What would Mr. Phelps, the leader of the Mission: Impossible team from the 1960's TV series, need to guarantee that his secrets are safe today? How about self-destructing e-mail?

title: An Overtaxed Memory Makes System Sluggish
description: Q. My Windows 98 computer always gives me a message saying it is low on system resources. How should I solve this?

title: As Gore Presses His Case, Bush Camp Molds Image of Administration Building
description: Gov. George W. Bush's campaign sought to rev up the engine of inevitability today that Mr. Bush would soon occupy the White House. But Vice President Al Gore refused to budge and pressed his case anew on all the major television networks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARIS, ANN P. (NEE LIPCHUCK).
description: JARIS-Ann P. (nee Lipchuck). On Nov. 28, 2000. Beloved wife of Joseph. Devoted mother of Patricia Filip, Richard and William Jaris. Cherished grandmother of Hannah, Lisa, Maggie, Liam and Daniel. Loving sister of Lillian Lipchuck. Family will receive friends at The Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th Street), NYC, Thursday 7-9 P.M. and Friday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial is on Saturday at 10 A.M. at The Immaculate Conception Church. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Battle Over Gucci Takes a Detour Into a Paris Court
description: Pinault-Printemps-Redoute sued LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton today, accusing it of ''defamation and dissemination of false information,'' the latest twist in a long-running battle for control of the Gucci Group.

title: Balloting Battle Is a Vehicle to TV Stardom
description: RICHARD H. PILDES shuddered as a videocassette recorder and 20-inch monitor were wheeled into his office at the New York University Law School. He had agreed, with trepidation, to watch tapes of his many television appearances in recent weeks, when he went from being an academic expert on the arcane subject of election law to a talking head in such demand that NBC gave him a contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RHODES, JOHN B.
description: RHODES-John B. The employees and partners of Booz-Allen & Hamilton mourn the death of our friend and former colleague, John B. Rhodes. John's long term leadership of the firm, his vision, wise advice, unwavering support, and involvement in local and international affairs will be greatly missed. To his wife, Joan, and his children, John, Jr., Mark and Lydia, we extend our deepest condolences.

title: Daewoo Creditors to Make Loans
description: Creditor banks of the Daewoo Motor Company will offer 728 billion won ($606 million) in new loans by June of next year enabling production to resume at the main plant of the company, which has filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: Romania in Retreat
description: Most of Eastern and Central Europe is now governed by Western-oriented democrats, but Romania, which held a first round of elections on Sunday, promises to be an exception. The two remaining candidates for president are Ion Iliescu, a former president who was once a protege of the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, and Corneliu Vadim Tudor, whose erratic behavior and ardent nationalism would drive his country further into isolation.

title: Company Tries Again For Cell Phone Organizer
description: Melding two great gadgets, the cell phone and the hand-held organizer, should be a sure thing. But the road to such convergence has been anything but smooth. Qualcomm released an early version of a cell-phone-and-Palm-based-organizer hybrid, the Qualcomm pdQ, two years ago, but its bulkiness, high price and limited Palm features did not sit well with Palm fans.

title: An Election Puzzle, Still in Search of a Solution; For an Accurate Count
description: To the Editor:

title: REED ELSEVIER TO RAISE CASH
description: To finance its acquisition of Harcourt General, Reed Elsevier, the biggest publisher of scientific journals, said the two companies that control it would sell new shares valued at about $1.7 billion. Reed International, owner of roughly a half stake, will issue up to 98.9 million new shares, while Elsevier of the Netherlands will offer 57.6 million. Last month, Reed Elsevier bought Harcourt, which publishes medical textbooks and journals, for $5.65 billion in cash and assumed debt. Alan Cowell

title: Preservation Action, Then a Bigger Fight
description: As its final days tick away, the Clinton administration is proceeding with efforts to turn federally owned bits of Western America into national monuments, a strategy that many westerners regard as an intrusion into state land matters.

title: Jazz Veteran Is Most at Home When He's Away; With His Playing and His Label, Chick Corea Is Newly Influential
description: Most jazz musicians keep late hours, but Chick Corea's are even later. When he is at home in Clearwater, Fla. (lately only about three months out of the year), he wants to relax, and he gets into a ''no-schedule schedule'' -- one in which, he says, ''the light of day and the night of night just sort of roll, and I could be sleeping or awake at any time in that period.''

title: A Title Bout That's Offering Genuine Champions
description: In the weeks leading to the Felix Trinidad-Fernando Vargas fight, the animosity has increased along with the anticipation.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space yesterday referred incorrectly to the registration information in dispute. It was on ballot applications, not on the ballots themselves.

title: A New Way to Listen To Radio on the Internet
description: While everyone is waiting for the Internet to replace television, it is already transforming another popular medium: radio.

title: A Safe Place for Hate?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Fund for Wartime Slaves Set Up in Japan
description: A potentially far-reaching settlement was reached here today in a court case brought on behalf of nearly 1,000 Chinese who were forced to work in Japan in World War II.

title: NEW SALES AGENT FOR MODIFIED CROPS?
description: The Agriculture Department is considering playing a broader role in helping market genetically engineered crops and in segregating those crops from nonengineered ones, Dan Glickman, the department secretary, said yesterday. Some countries and food processors are demanding only nonmodified crops, a development that threatens American farm exports, unless the identity of varieties can be guaranteed. The Agriculture Department is seeking public comment on whether it should be involved in accrediting, reviewing or certifying the performance of programs aimed at ensuring that crops are not contaminated by other varieties. Andrew Pollack

title: Metro Business Briefing; PORT AUTHORITY AGREEMENT
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has entered into an agreement with the Port of Rotterdam, in the Netherlands, to improve cargo distribution at the agency's maritime ports. The Rotterdam port and a Dutch company, Ridderhaven B.V., will advise the agency on developing a distribution network to inland destinations using private barge and rail operators. Twenty-two percent of Rotterdam's containers are now shipped through such a system, which is intended to ease congestion on roadways by using more water and rail routes. The Port of Rotterdam, which is one of the Port Authority's biggest international trade partners, exchanges hundreds of thousands of metric tons of goods each year with the agency. Tara Bahrampour

title: Locked Up In a Place Far Beyond Redemption
description: The man's tongue seems to be growing -- filling his mouth, thwarting language, subverting thought -- and his voice expands with frustration, scraping upward into a scream. It's one word that's the roadblock. What is it anyway? Howard? Howling? Actually, it's hallowed. But by the time Angel Cruz stumbles upon it, he can't hear himself for the shouting from other cells. Reciting the Lord's Prayer is not, under the circumstances, a remotely easy thing to do.

title: A Step Beyond Palmtop: Collartop
description: CLOTHES may be about to get a lot smarter. Computers and their peripherals appear to be poised to leave desktop and palmtop for unlikely spots like shirts, neckties and bras. Soon some people won't have to bother carrying cell phones -- they'll just talk to the ones stitched neatly into the collars of their jackets.

title: Sokh Journal; Good Fences, but, Some Will Say, Bad Neighbors
description: The border guard gestured with the barrel of his Kalashnikov rifle, and the aged Soviet-built Lada pulled off the road at the checkpoint. A half-dozen people piled out of the battered car, lugging plastic bags of clothes and fruit for the guard to empty and examine.

title: The Price of Freebies
description: To the Editor:

title: Final Haitian Vote Tally Shows Aristide Winning With 91.69%
description: Former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who faced virtually no opposition in a presidential election last Sunday that was boycotted by the major opposition parties, was effectively declared the winner today, the Provisional Electoral Council announced.

title: Chase Capital Partners Is Planning a New Venture Fund
description: At a time when returns from the venture capital business are flagging, Chase Capital Partners, the long successful private equity arm of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, is inviting wealthy outside investors and institutional investors to join it in a new fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, ROSE
description: JACOBS-Rose. On November 29, 2000 in her 88th year. Beloved wife of the late Murray Jacobs. Dear mother of Howard Jacobs and the late Maxine Breslauer. Cherished grandmother of Peter, Susan, Hope and Alan. Adored sister of Frances Chasen. Services Friday, Dec. 1, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAUSIN, JOSEPH
description: CAUSIN-Joseph. Died of cancer November 27, 2000 in Baltimore at age 88. A 1933 NYU graduate and outstanding athlete, he won medals in track and field. A CPA, he taught accounting at NYU and Rutgers University. He joined the USMC Reserve in 1934, and during WWII, performed cost accounting services for the Navy. Working for a CPA firm led to a career in professional sports accounting. In 1946 he worked with the Miami Sea Hawks, the forerunner of the Baltimore Colts. 1949-1968 he worked for The New York Yankees, becoming the SecretaryTreasurer. In 1971 he joined the Baltimore Colts. He retired in 1982 as V.P. of Finance. Predeceased by loving wife Ruth and daughter Elizabeth, he is survived by daughter Ellen of Annapolis, MD., son Edward of Great Neck, N.Y., brother Daniel of Phoenix, AZ., four grandchildren and one great grandchild. Family graveside service Friday, Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, N.J. Family will receive friends Sunday, 1-6PM. Call funeral home for details, Louis Suburban Chapel, Fair Lawn, N.J. 201-791-0015. Family requests contributions to charity of your choice in lieu of flowers, please.

title: A Christmas Ornament That's Really a Birthday Present for the Metro
description: To observe the 100th anniversary of the Paris Metro this year, 20 contemporary artists were asked to come up with festive ideas.

title: David Hunter, 84, Innovator In Matching Philanthropies
description: David R. Hunter, an innovative matchmaker between progressive charities and liberal philanthropists who used a small family foundation to help bring widespread recognition to causes that had been little known, like protecting battered women and promoting environmental justice, died on Saturday in Port Washington, N.Y. He was 84.

title: Under Fire, Belgian Speech Software Maker Files for Bankruptcy
description: Facing scrutiny on accounting irregularities and lawsuits from both sides of the Atlantic, Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products N.V., a Belgian maker of speech-recognition software, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Delaware yesterday. The company's Dictaphone division, a Connecticut-based rival that it bought earlier this year, and L.& H. Holdings USA, a unit formed to own the recently purchased Dragon Systems, also filed for protection.

title: Health Costs Underestimated, Experts Say
description: Health costs will grow faster than the government now assumes, partly because of advances in medical technology, and the long-term financial outlook for Medicare is therefore less rosy than officials assume, a federal advisory panel has concluded.

title: Slowdown Shows in Revised Data
description: The economy expanded in the third quarter at the slowest pace in four years, holding down inflation and depressing corporate profits, revised government figures showed today.

title: Butler Is Comfortably Filling Carmazzi's Shoes
description: For three years, Rocky Butler practiced behind Hofstra's record-setting quarterback, Giovanni Carmazzi. If you could call it practice. Butler took about 10 percent of the snaps during workouts and got occasional mop-up duty in games.

title: A Good Turn Deserves Another: Extended Play for the Big Wheel
description: London constructed its Eye Ferris wheel as a monument. Paris, meanwhile, simply stuck the biggest wheel it could find in the heart of the city as a way to celebrate the year 2000. Nonetheless, the 197-foot wheel, above, with 50,000 blinking lights and 42 cabins, situated near the Tuileries, is such a hit that the town fathers have decided to keep it around through December 2001, giving the heart of Paris a festive look all year long. The Big Wheel of Paris, Place de la Concorde, 11 a.m. to 12:30 a.m. every day, $4 for adults, free for children under 12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAYER, RICHARD
description: BRAYER-Richard, age 65, died peacefully on November 26, 2000 at Massachusetts General Hospital. He is survived by family and friends. He is loved and will be missed by all. Services were private. Donations can be made to the New England Veterans Shelter, 20 Court St, Boston, MA 02108.

title: Tabletop Designs and More For Tenderloin Tastes
description: I AM a shopper. And what I love about shopping is the hunt for the perfect, unusual object. Maybe my love of searching comes from a mother who believed in personal style and who always said, ''You don't have to look like everyone else.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAGNALL, JUNE
description: BAGNALL-June. Died November 28, 2000 at age 74. Ms. Bagnall was the daughter of the late Jeanette and Richard Bagnall. She is survived by her nephew Rodney Stewart, his wife Anita, son Jonathan and her many friends and neighbors. Ms. Bagnall was a New York City art teacher for over 30 years. She received her MFA from Columbia University. We remember her for her many good works including working with Alzheimers patients, the 23rd Precinct Community Council and St. Ambrose Church. There will be a viewing on Friday, December 1, 910AM with a service following at St. Ambrose Church, 9 W. 130 St, NYC. The family has asked that in lieu of flowers, donations be given to the National Kidney Foundation of NY/NJ, 1250 Broadway, Suite 2001, New York, New York 10001.

title: Serb Police, Albanian Rebels and Cowering Villagers
description: Along the deserted road to this village, Serbian special police forces lie in the undergrowth, warm themselves by campfire and stand watch under the eaves of a house. Lucane marks the front line in a growing confrontation with Albanian militants who seized positions in the nearby hills last week.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: DEPARTURE AT TELSTRA
description: Paul Rizzo, the chief financial officer of Telstra, resigned unexpectedly. Mr. Rizzo, left, who was passed over for the top post at the company in early 1999 in favor of Ziggy Switkowski, will become the director of the Melbourne Business School, where he earned an M.B.A. in 1969. Mr. Rizzo was a central figure in the two-stage public offering in Telstra, the dominant phone company in Australia, half of which remains state-owned. The company's stock fell 5 percent, to 6.35 Australian dollars ($3.32).

title: When Games Go Hollywood, Do the Players Lose?
description: THE stone and steel towers of Manhattan loom large across the screen, appearing at once contemporary yet oddly quaint. Then suddenly, out of the morning mist, exotic fighter planes roar into view. They swoop and fire wing-mounted cannons in aerial dogfights set to a full orchestral score that quickens the pulse and accents the action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, IRMA S.
description: ADLER-Irma S. Of Charleston, SC, formerly of Brooklyn. Died on November 28, 2000, of post operative complications. Devoted wife of Willy for 56 years, beloved mother of Roger, Vicki, and Lauri. ''Grammy'' to Aimee, Jessica, Melissa, Matthew, and Kristin, great grandchild, Julia. A graduate of NYU Class of 1944, she devoted her life to her family's well being. She will forever be missed by those who loved her. Shiva Saturday evening and all day Sunday at 10 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Sales of PC's Down Sharply At Gateway
description: Gateway, the nation's second-largest direct seller of computers, reported yesterday that its sales over the Thanksgiving weekend had plummeted 30 percent from last year's figures and warned that it would probably miss projections for quarterly earnings and revenue by a wide margin.

title: VENTURE FUND TURNS AWAY MONEY
description: Crosspoint Venture Partners has told investors to hang on to their money for the moment. Crosspoint's managing partner, Richard Shapero, said he had telephoned investors to advise them to defer fulfilling the commitments they made to the pool the firm is now raising. The firm eventually may renounce some of the $1 billion that was committed last month.

title: Parents of 2 Killers at Columbine Offer $1.6 Million Settlement
description: The parents of the teenage gunmen at Columbine High School and the family of one of the men who supplied the killers with a gun have made a $1.6 million settlement offer to the victims' families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, ALDEN JAMES
description: SCHNEIDER-Alden James, 80. November 28. Formerly of Greenwich, CT. Husband of Mary V. Schneider, father of Anne Scanlan, William Schneider, Sue Kirby, Patricia Repik and Michael Schneider. Cherished brother, grandfather and great grandfather. Mass at Assumption Church, Westport, CT Friday 10 AM.

title: Israel's Crisis Within a War
description: As the Israeli election campaign unofficially kicked into gear today, local political experts forecast turbulence on all fronts.

title: In America; The True Believer
description: Tom DeLay spent many long months hiding in the tall grass and chuckling while George W. Bush traveled the country trying to spread the fiction of compassionate conservatism.

title: Yanks Still Know How to Play the Game Off the Field, Too
description: With the 25th anniversary of the creation of free agency only a few weeks away, the Yankees are showing once again that they can play the game as well as anyone, better than most. Their targeting of Mike Mussina, one of the top two pitchers available in this 25th free-agent class, is reminiscent of the talent George Steinbrenner acquired in the early years of the new game.

title: Rowland Forms Committee For Possible Third-Term Run
description: Taking his first official step toward a possible third term, Gov. John G. Rowland submitted a document to Connecticut's secretary of the state today establishing a re-election campaign finance committee.

title: Cheney Cleared to Resume Working
description: Dick Cheney had a medical checkup today, one week after he suffered a mild heart attack, and his doctors pronounced him fit and able to resume his work schedule, the doctors and Mr. Cheney said.

title: Transferred Principal Treated Unfairly, Union Head Says
description: The head of the New York City principals' union said yesterday that the principal of a Queens elementary school who was transferred after an intruder molested four children at her school was being made to bear the blame for inadequate security provided by the central Board of Education.

title: Bagging the Holidays, Street by Street
description: SHOP at my stores, by all means. I will give you names, addresses. Enjoy!

title: In High-Tech Home The Future Is Now
description: GADGETS here. Gadgets there. Which one to buy for the ultimate techie holiday gift? How about a fully networked home stocked with dozens of computerized goodies connected to one another like so many blinking colored bulbs on a Christmas tree?

description: Chase Offers Big Investors Chance to Join Venture Fund

description: Now Mister Rogers is attacking the neighborhood.
