title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHELAN, EUGENE F., JR.
description: WHELAN-Eugene F., Jr., 76. Of Cold Spring, New York, formerly of New York City, on November 29, 2000. Former Senior Vice President of SSC&B Advertising. Retired in 1988 as Chairman of PRI. Beloved husband of Margaret (nee Stephens). Loving father of Wendy Petrullo (John) of Sherman Oaks, CA., Jane Sullivan (James) of Briarcliff Manor, New York, Elisabeth V. Whelan of New York, and Eugene F. Whelan III of Portland, OR. Grandfather of Kathleen D. Sullivan. Dear brother of Patricia Brokaw of Iowa City, Mary Jane Woram of Dallas, and the late Charles D. Whelan (Patricia), and uncle to many nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be on Saturday, 10 AM, Our Lady Loretto Church, Cold Spring. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Philipstown Volunteer Ambulance Corps, Box 364, Cold Spring, New York 10516.

title: PRICELINE FOUNDER IS SUBJECT OF LABOR LAW INQUIRY
description: Jay Walker, founder of Priceline.com and other Internet companies, is under investigation by the State of Connecticut for possible employment law violations, the state attorney general said yesterday. The state is looking into reports that Mr. Walker failed to provide the required 60-day notice when he dismissed 100 workers, four-fifths of the staff, at his closely held company, Walker Digital, on Nov. 20. A spokesman for Walker Digital said the company had not been notified of the investigation. Preliminary conclusions from the labor investigation are expected by the end of next week, the state said, and a separate consumer complaint investigation begun in September against Priceline.com may be completed by the end of January.

title: An Election Puzzle, Still in Search of a Solution; The Old Machines
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson Savors Second Chance
description: Ernie Logan and some Jets teammates were watching television in the players lounge a few days ago when some old Jets clips came on. Leon Johnson was running back a kick.

title: President Sets Visit to His 50th State
description: KEARNEY, Neb., Nov. 29  President Clinton will complete his tour of all 50 states next week with a stop in Nebraska, the only state he has not visited in his eight years in office, the White House said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Nov. 21 about election statistics misstated the expected variation in vote counts. According to the law of large numbers, if six million ballots were counted over and over, the expected variation 68 percent of the time could be ''as large as'' 2,000 votes, not ''at least'' 2,000.

Glass decanter with tumbler, $22 at Mxyplyzyk. 8. Terry cloth puppet bath mitt, $14.95 at Laytner's Linens, 2270 Broadway; (888) 690-7260.

title: Swisscom Warning
description: Swisscom said today that operating profit in 2000 would be significantly lower as price competition hurts its fixed-line telephone business and that an unspecified charge to cover the elimination of 3,000 jobs could be expected.

title: O Tannenbaum, O Tannenbaum. Oops: O Sapin.
description: A grand palace (as the French describe their fine hotels), the newly renovated Hotel Meurice is a great address for afternoon tea

title: A Tea Party Of Small and Tony Shops
description: WHO would think that four blocks -- 68th to 72nd Streets on Lexington Avenue -- could be the shortest distance between ''I haven't started my Christmas shopping'' and ''My Christmas shopping is over''?

title: Nassau Settles Budget
description: Leaders in Nassau County have agreed on a fiscal rescue plan.

title: Alumni Fight for 'Soul' of Richest Orphanage
description: Calling itself a ''ragtag army'' of orphans, the alumni association of the Milton Hershey School is fighting with the school's administration over the future -- and, it says, the soul -- of the nation's largest, richest orphanage.

title: Netscape 6 Browser: Mixed Bag
description: THE popularity contest between Internet Explorer and Netscape Navigator is one of the most intriguing spectacles of the digital age. Each year, these two Web browsers appear in new versions, flush with features that Microsoft and Netscape have unapologetically stolen from each other. In no other industry do the two market leaders invest so much money and effort in their products and then distribute them free.

title: How Brilliant Play Helped The Winner of a Tourney
description: It was no surprise that four Italians, Giorgio Duboin, Norberto Bocchi, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace, won the big prize on Sunday at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals in Birmingham, Ala. They had won the World Teams in Maastricht, the Netherlands, in September, and joined with bronze-medal winners George Jacobs of Burr Ridge, Ill., and Ralph Katz of Hinsdale, Ill., to capture the prestigious Reisinger Teams. What was surprising, and what testified to the strength of the competition, was the failure of two top-ranked teams to reach the final. One was Nick Nickell of New York and his group of world champions, and the other was the foursome led by Rita Shugart of Pebble Beach, Calif., who had won the previous two Reisingers teamed with three European stars.

title: BANK SPLIT CONSIDERED
description: DePfa-Bank the main lender to German local governments, said it was considering splitting in two and moving its more profitable operations to Ireland to reverse a slide in earnings. Depfa-Bank's stock sank more than 11 percent, closing at 73.8 euros ($63.21).

title: Man Charged With Selling Drugs Out of Bronx Community Center
description: The director of a Bronx community center was arrested yesterday and charged with selling cocaine and heroin out of a back room, the police said.

title: The Fight in Kashmir
description: To the Editor:

title: Mussina and the Yankees Reach Agreement on Pact
description: The fierce courting of Mike Mussina was virtually complete last night as the Yankees reached an agreement in principle with the free-agent pitcher on a six-year contract for about $87 million. By yesterday afternoon the Yankees were prepared to hold a news conference, and Arn Tellem, Mussina's agent, was flying from California to New York to attend it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLISTER, JULIET G.
description: HOLLISTER-Juliet G. Died November 26 at home of cancer after a brief illness. Born October 30, 1916, Forest Hills, Long Island, daughter of James and Dorothy Garretson. Married to Dickerman Hollister, from 1939 until his death in 1983. Graduated from Ethel Walker, 1934; Frobel League, 1937; Honorary Degree, The New Seminary, New York. Founder and Chairman of the Board of The Temple of Understanding, an interfaith, educational organization that included major world political and religious leaders. Under her leadership, The Temple sponsored a number of acclaimed symposia and educational projects. Recipient: Governor Grosso Meritorious Service Award, 1979; Eleanor Roosevelt Award, Center for International Dialogue, 1994; Albert Schweitzer Prize for the Humanities, 1995. Board of Directors: Wainwright House, Center for Soviet-American Dialogue; American Teilhard Association for the Future of Man. Founding member of Green Fingers Garden Club, member of Colony Club. She is survived by three children: G. Clay Hollister, Chevy Chase, MD; Catharine H. Ecton, Cabin John, MD; Dickerman Hollister, Greenwich, CT. She had six grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Memorial Services will be at Second Congregational Church on November 30 at 11:30AM. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers contributions be made in her name to The Temple of Understanding (720 Fifth Ave, 16 floor, NY, NY 10019) or the American Cancer Society.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If we don't get some food soon in the country, we might be in a situation where we don't have any food in December.''

title: Florida's Legislative Tripwire
description: If Jeb Bush, the governor of Florida, cares to do his brother a favor, he will prevail on Republican lawmakers in Tallahassee to drop their misguided plan to meddle in the presidential election. The last thing Gov. George W. Bush needs at this fraught moment in American politics is for the Florida Legislature to try to rig the Electoral College in his favor just as Florida courts and the United States Supreme Court are preparing to rule on his election battle with Vice President Al Gore. Legislative intervention would not only further complicate the election imbroglio but would also undermine the presidency itself.

title: Japan and U.S. Group Cancel Tokyo Sowa Bank Acquisition
description: A deal by the Japanese government to sell the bankrupt Tokyo Sowa Bank to a United States investment group led by Wilbur L. Ross Jr., who is becoming one of the world's most prominent investors in distressed assets, has fallen apart after the group uncovered tens of billions of yen in bogus loans, according to people close to the negotiations.

title: Juliet Garretson Hollister, 84; Led Temple of Understanding
description: Juliet Garretson Hollister, in whose kitchen an interfaith organization called the Temple of Understanding was born 40 years ago, died on Sunday at her home in Greenwich, Conn. She was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSENICH, BEVERLY BARRY
description: KESSENICH-Beverly Barry. On November 29 after a long illness. Daughter of the late Francis J. Barry (Founder of Circle Line Sightseeing Yachtes, Inc.) and Nellie Barry. Devoted wife of Mark F. Kessenich Jr. Adoring mother of John B. Meyer, Catherine S. Warlich and Dana Debard Alvarez. Loving grandmother of Jack, Nicholas, Dylan, Kelly, Alexandra, Jaime, Cristina and Timothy Barry. Dear sister of Robert F. Barry. Friends my call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, NYC on Thursday, November 30th, 7-9PM and Friday, December 1st, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, December 2, 9:30 AM. St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84 St. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, memorial contributions be made to Little Flower Children's Services of N.Y., PO Box 9000, Wading River, NY 11792.

title: Simple Test Can Help Prevent Colon Cancer, Study Shows
description: A longtime study of more than 46,000 people has found that a simple but little-used screening test may help prevent people from getting colon cancer.

title: Palm Beach Ballots Depart for Florida Capital
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 30 -- A rental truck carrying nearly 463,000 ballots that could help decide the winner of the White House left Palm Beach County under police escort Thursday en route for a court in the state capital. The ballots, critical to Vice President Al Gore's hopes of overturning a 537-vote lead held by Texas Gov. George W. Bush in the critical state of Florida, were packed into 162 gray metal boxes and loaded onto a yellow Ryder truck for the eight-hour, 450-mile journey to Tallahassee. A state court judge in the capital ordered Miami-Dade and Palm Beach County elections officials to ship more than 1.1 million presidential election ballots to his court as he decides whether to order another recount in the two disputed counties. Democrat Al Gore had asked Leon County Court Judge N. Sanders Sauls to order that the 14,000 "undervotes" from the two counties -- the ballots on which counting machines could not read any vote for president -- be hand-tallied and included in the state's election results. Some had votes that could be detected by human eyes but which were not included in the certified tally that gave Bush, a Republican, a 537-vote lead out of 6 million cast in Florida. Gore hoped to pick up enough votes to overtake Bush and claim the presidency. But Bush's lawyers said any counting should include all the ballots cast in the two counties -- nearly 654,000 in Miami-Dade and 463,000 in Palm Beach County. Both Bush and Gore need the state's 25 electoral votes to win the presidency. Sauls will not decide until Saturday whether the ballots will be hand-counted but he ordered Wednesday that all of them be brought to Tallahassee in case they are needed. The rental truck left the Palm Beach County government offices shortly before 8 a.m. EST, led by a police cruiser and followed by an unmarked car. Palm Beach County elections supervisor Theresa LePore, who oversaw the loading, hugged the truck driver and sheriff's deputies before they left. In Miami-Dade's election office, the sorting and packing was slowed by partisan observers' complaints that election workers were manhandling the ballots, which county officials denied. The Miami-Dade Police Department's SWAT team -- the specially trained and heavily armed squad called out in gunfights and hostage battles -- will pick up that county's ballots Friday for the 10-hour drive to Tallahassee.

title: City Asks Teachers for Wage Deferral
description: The Giuliani administration took a hard-line approach yesterday in its first contract proposals to the city's 78,000 public-school teachers, making a long-anticipated demand for a merit pay system and an unanticipated demand that the teachers defer three weeks of pay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, ALEXANDER
description: SCHINDLER - Alexander. The Board of Directors and staff of the American Foundation for AIDS Research mourn the loss of our National Council member (since 1993) Rabbi Alexander Schindler, an eminent religious leader, organization executive, author/editor, and advocate for the protection of the rights of all individuals, including, very early on, the rights of those touched by the epidemic of HIV/AIDS. We honor him for his social conscience in denouncing the ban of openly gay individuals in the military. Mathilde Krim, Ph.D. Founding Co-Chair and Chairman of the Board American Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR)

title: Corrections
description: A map on Tuesday showing the location of a mansion that is for sale on the former estate of Franklin D. Roosevelt's family misidentified the town. It is Hyde Park, N.Y. (in Dutchess County), not New Hyde Park.

title: Dominican Officials Hold Man in Killing Of New York Officer
description: It was one of the darkest days in the Police Department's history, with two police officers fatally shot the same day. But this week, 12 years after the shootings, a fugitive wanted in one of the killings was captured in the Dominican Republic, officials said yesterday.

title: Cool Stuff For the Intrepid Sleuth
description: IT WAS the first day of the holiday gridlock alert, but the traffic was barely a trickle inside Mayhem, a sedate little vintage store at 441 East Ninth Street, near Tompkins Square Park. In fact, the store was populated only by Kari Auerbach, 37, one of the three owners, and two women a generation older, visiting from Cleveland. The visitors were killing time before dinner, and asked about the bar on the corner. Ms. Auerbach considered.

title: MindShare Chosen By Unilever
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products giant, said yesterday that it would consolidate media planning and broadcast television buying, effective by March 1, at one of its many media roster agencies, MindShare in New York. Unilever spends about $700 million a year on American advertising for brands like Dove, Lipton, Pond's and Wisk.

title: GILLETTE TO MAKE NEW ELECTRIC TOOTHBRUSHES
description: The Gillette Company said yesterday that it would introduce a line of three Braun Oral-B electric toothbrushes next year and would spend $100 million to market them during their first 12 months. Gillette said the line and its three-bladed Venus razor for women, which it announced earlier this month, are meant to reverse two years of sales declines. Last month, Gillette's board removed its chief executive, Michael Hawley, and named Edward DeGraan to run the company while it seeks a successor.

title: Pistons Pull Away After Nets Run Dry
description: Their shoulders sagged in resignation. Their eyes were fixated on the floor and certainly not on the basket. And the Nets staggered through the fourth quarter tonight, immersed in their own futility.

title: Arriving at Florida Voting Places, Some Blacks Found Frustration
description: Dedrana McCray, 18, turned out with her parents and her sister to cast the first vote of her life on Nov. 7, her freshly minted voter registration card in hand.

title: Zimmer Concedes to Holt in New Jersey Congressional Race
description: Dick Zimmer, the Republican candidate for New Jersey's 12th Congressional District, admitted defeat yesterday and asked for a halt to the recount he had requested. The figures had showed him losing even more ground to Representative Rush Holt, the Democrat.

description: Lukas Cervienka vividly remembers the day the giant VSZ steel mill here ran out of iron.

description: For all of Gov. George W. Bush's talk about Americans chafing over the contested election, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that they are not overwhelmingly distressed and remain deeply divided along partisan lines over who should be president.

title: MITEL TO SELL PHONE-EQUIPMENT UNIT, ANALYST SAYS
description: The Mitel Corporation plans to sell a majority stake in its struggling phone-equipment business to one or more private investment firms, according to an analyst who said he and others had been briefed on the plan by the company. The board approved the move in early November, but said publicly at that time only that it planned to ''separate'' the phone-equipment and semiconductor businesses. A Mitel spokesman declined to comment on any plans to divest itself of its phone-equipment business, which represented 57 percent of sales in the last two fiscal years, saying only that ''all options are being explored.''

title: Economics Driving an Expansion Of Hospitals Catering to Children
description: Of all the things that New York hospitals have been up to in the last decade -- research, mergers and fights with managed-care companies -- erecting new buildings has not been among them.

title: Sports of The Times; The Heat Is Missing Its Core
description: PROFESSIONAL life could not have been sweeter for Rick Brunson, the peripatetic point guard, when Pat Riley summoned him to Miami last summer and offered him not only a job, and not only a one-year guaranteed contract, but also the promise of a long run to a championship series.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose after Iraq warned of ''unspecified consequences'' if a pricing formula for its exports is rejected. In New York, crude oil for January delivery rose 41 cents, to $34.63 a barrel.

title: Sports of The Times; Testaverde Embodies The Jets' Reality
description: NORMALLY, you can't tell a lot about a team's coming performance from its locker-room decorum during the week.

title: PBOC HOLDINGS IS CONSIDERING SALE OF COMPANY
description: PBOC Holdings, the parent of People's Bank of California, said yesterday that it was considering a sale of the company and had hired Keefe, Bruyette & Woods and Sandler O'Neill & Partners to advise it. PBOC, based in Los Angeles, agreed to buy BYL Bancorp of Orange, Calif., earlier this month, increasing its assets by about 10 percent, to $3.3 billion. Also earlier this month, the trustees of the estate of Bernice Pauahi Bishop agreed to sell a 24 percent stake in PBOC to the FBOP Corporation, an affiliate of the First Bank of Oak Park in Illinois.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELLIGAN, LUKE A. SR.
description: NELLIGAN-Luke A. Sr. Of Rego Park, Queens, passed away November 26, 2000 at the age of 87. He is the former owner and operator of Lanell Inc. located in Queens. Mr. Nelligan is survived by sons Luke A. Nelligan III of Patchogue, L.I. and Mark C. Nelligan of Whitehouse Station, N.J., a granddaughter Katherine E. Nelligan and longtime friend John Wachter of Rego Park. Visitation will be Friday at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home (914) 949-7777 from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. with a mass Saturday 10 A.M. at Holy Rosary Church in Hawthorne. Interment at Gate of Heaven.

title: Appeals Court Finds Killer May Be Eligible for Parole Earlier
description: A New Jersey appellate court ruled yesterday that Samuel A. Manzie, the teenager who confessed to the 1997 murder of an 11-year-old, could become eligible for parole sooner than allowed under the sentence he received in a plea agreement.
